title: Art People
description: Bamboo, Pebbles, Ice

title: Auctions
description: Art and antiques collectors will long remember 1987 as a banner year for auctions. It saw world records toppled with the sales of two van Gogh paintings, a Bugatti automobile, a Mozart manuscript, a Stradivarius, a Gutenberg Old Testament, Charlie Chaplin's hat and cane and Babe Ruth's locker tag.

title: ALTEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $455,000 (includes writedown of $192,000) for the latest year and $482,000 for the year-ago period. The net losses from continuing operations include writedowns of $487,000 for the latest year, compared with $1,094,000 for 1986.

title: Dining Out Guide: Casseroles
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: No. 1 Just a Dream For Florida State
description: Florida State can pinpoint exactly when and why it failed to reach the Orange Bowl and a New Year's Day showdown against Oklahoma for the final No. 1 national ranking. It came nearly two months ago, when the Seminoles' 2-point conversion pass attempt was batted down by Miami defenders with 42 seconds to go in a game Miami won, 26-25, Nov. 3.

title: Restaurants
description: ZARELA MARTINEZ'S stewardship of nearly three years at the whimsical Mexican restaurant Cafe Marimba ended abruptly in September when the owner, David Keh, converted all his restaurants back to Chinese. The feisty Ms. Martinez wasted no time gathering her pots, pans and jalapenos and opening her own place, called Zarela, in the former Tastings on Two on Second Avenue.

title: Real Estate; Central Park Vista From New Tower
description: WHILE debate continues over the future of the New York Coliseum building at the west side of Columbus Circle, another tower has been rising just south of the Coliseum. It is a 55-story square residential condominium called Central Park Place, and it is replacing the cluster of low-rise buildings that represented the Circle's most tumbledown corner.

title: 48 Wild Horses Die in a Test
description: Forty-eight wild mustangs died of dehydration in the high Nevada desert last September during a University of Minnesota experiment with horse contraceptives.

title: Harry Green, Lawyer, 94
description: Harry Green, a retired New Jersey lawyer, died of heart failure Monday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 94 years old and lived in Los Angeles, where he moved in 1986.

title: Wine Makers Divided on How to Fight Curbs
description: As efforts to curb wine consumption gain momentum, American vintners are widely divided about how to combat the movement.

title: Image Problems Dog Top Teams
description: The nation's two highest-ranked college football teams will complete a trilogy of decisive bowl games involving Penn State, Oklahoma and Miami Friday night. This time, Oklahoma and Miami will meet in the 54th Orange Bowl in an attempt to provide a clear answer to an issue that has been known to involve Presidents of the United States and enrage or thrill otherwise well-adjusted college graduates.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Fell by 3% in December
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products declined 3 percent in December, from the November average, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Drug Manufacturer Recalls Cold Syrups, Citing Health Risks
description: Several brands of an over-the-counter cold medicine are being recalled because they may be mislabeled and might contain a potent tranquilizer, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: COMPUMED INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $246,000 on settlement of disputed claims. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $235,000 on settlement of disputed claims.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MINNESOTA (AL) - Agreed to terms with Juan Berenguer, pitcher, on a two-year contract for $1.125 million. BASKETBALL GOLDEN STATE (NBA) - Named Don Nelson general manager. INDIANA (NBA) - Placed Scott Skiles, guard, on injured reserve. HOCKEY DEVILS - Assigned Gordie Mark, defenseman, to Utica of the American Hockey League. ISLANDERS - Assigned Brad Dalgarno and Derek King, forwards, to Springfield of the American Hockey League. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Recalled Wilf Paiement, a right wing, from Muskegon of the International Hockey League. RANGERS - Traded Mike Donnelly, left wing, and a fifth-round pick in the 1988 entry draft to Buffalo for Paul Cyr, left wing, and a 10th-round choice in 1988. COLLEGES FLORIDA - Announced the resignation of Zaven Yaralian, defensive coordinator, and Dan Coughlin and Ty Smith, defensive assistant coaches. Dismissed Mike Heimerdinger, wide receivers coach. NORTH CAROLINA - Named Jim Cavanaugh, wide receivers coach, and Les Herrin, outside linebackers coach. OHIO STATE - Named John Cooper head football coach. ST. FRANCIS-Pa. - Announced that Eric Hammond, center, has left the basketball team for personal reasons.

title: DAVIS AND L.S.U. HALT SOUTH CAROLINA
description: Tom Hodson threw three touchdown passes to Wendell Davis, and David Browndyke added three field goals today as seventh-ranked Louisiana State beat South Carolina, 30-13, in the Gator Bowl.

title: Federal Programs Assisting New York City's Housing Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Won't Bar Return of Boy In Abuse Case to Zimbabwe
description: A New York State appeals panel ruled yesterday that state courts may not block the forcible return to Zimbabwe of a 9-year-old boy whose father, a Zimbabwean official with diplomatic immunity, is accused of brutally beating him at their Queens home.

title: Judge, Backing Blacks' Case, Orders Vote in Georgia Town
description: A Federal district judge today ordered officials to conduct Monday's scheduled election in the predominantly black town of Keysville, rejecting a state judge's ruling that the town's boundaries were too indistinct to hold a legal election.

title: The Law on 'Excludable Aliens': Stay Tuned
description: While the President's signature on a bill usually certifies the end of the legislative process, that was not the case last week when President Reagan signed a bill removing ideology as a ground for excluding foreigners from entry into the United States.

title: N.C.A.A. Mark For Long Game
description: When Clarkson defeated Colgate, 7-6, Wednesday night on a goal 9 minutes 28 seconds into the game's fourth overtime, the teams set a National Collegiate Athletic Association record for the longest hockey game.

title: Bridge; Senior Player Is Honored By New York Association
description: The American Contract Bridge League recently began to recognize that a slight majority of its membership is over the age of 55. It has therefore sanctioned events and even tournaments for these players, many of whom prefer the peace and quiet of their own age group to the hurly-burly engendered by the rising stars of the younger generation.

title: Soviet Attack Is Seen as Move in Afghan Peace Bid
description: A Soviet-backed military drive to lift the guerrilla siege of an Afghan garrison town is intended to strengthen Afghanistan's Communist Government in peace talks, Reagan Administration officials and other analysts say.

title: Bruins' Lemelin Shuts Out Sabres
description: Reggie Lemelin recorded his second shutout of the season over Buffalo as the Boston Bruins beat the Sabres, 2-0, tonight.

title: Child Abuse Cases Draw New Attention
description: The swollen eyes of a 3-year-old boy, bruised and battered repeatedly by his father despite intervention from state social workers, stare out from a snapshot that continues to haunt people in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Cordero Recovering
description: Angel Cordero Jr., the jockey who is thoroughbred racing's second-leading career money winner with more than $121 million, was transferred from the intensive-care unit to a private room at Arcadia Methodist Hospital in California yesterday.

title: Stock Markups Seen in London
description: The London Stock Exchange said that it was investigating allegations that some market makers marked up share prices on Christmas Eve to win personal bets on the closing level of a stock index.

title: Sheldon Andelson, Political Fund-Raiser, 56
description: Sheldon Andelson, a leader in the gay community and a fund-raiser for such politicians as Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Walter F. Mondale, died Tuesday of complications from AIDS. He was 56 years old. A member of the University of California Board of Regents and the founder of the Bank of Los Angeles, Mr. Andelson raised large sums for liberal politicians at parties in his Bel-Air home and at his restaurant, Trumps.

title: Economic Scene; Seeking a Course For the New Year
description: THE year 1987 ended on a downbeat. The dollar, on the last day of the year, fell to record lows of about 121 yen and 156 West German marks. In the stock market, by no coincidence, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 11.27 points. Worries about recession were rife, intensified by the sharpest fall in the leading economic indicators since 1981.

title: 2d Youth Is Arrested In Assault on Blacks
description: A 17-year-old youth was arrested yesterday in connection with what the authorities say was a racially biased incident in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn on Christmas Day in which two black men were beaten by a group of whites.

title: New Year In New Delhi
description: Why India? Why does this distant, stiflingly crowded, quarrelsome country, still ridden with wrenching poverty for hundreds of millions and still unable to free itself of murder and hatred among castes and religions, mean so much to the United States - or why should it?

title: Canada Bans Most Seal Kills After Big Protests in Europe
description: Canada has banned all offshore commercial hunting of white-coated baby harp seals and blueback hooded seals after European threats of trade reprisals and reduced demand for seal pelts.

title: Four Guilty in Plot to Free Puerto Rican Terrorist
description: Four members of the Puerto Rican independence group FALN, including its leader, were convicted of conspiracy today in a failed attempt in 1986 to free the leader from prison.

title: Taiwan Trade Surplus
description: Taiwan will record a 1987 trade surplus of at least $18.7 billion (American), the Board of Foreign Trade said today. The board's director, Vincent Siew, said that Taiwan's exports were expected to total $53.5 billion and imports $34.8 billion in 1987 compared with exports of $39.8 billion and imports of $24.2 billion in 1986.

title: INTEGRATED GENERICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the magnitude of the loss reflects the writeoff of $1,850,000 prepaid drug licensing fees acquired in November 1986; a $988,000 decrease in the carrying value of the company's investment in International Surgical and Pharmaceutical Corp. to its estimated realizable value; a $750,000 increase in the reserve against Medicare receivables; a $350,000 writeoff of goodwill and formulations acquired in connection with the purchase of the assets of Generic Blends & Chemical Corp. in May 1986; costs associated with the withdrawal of the proposed initial public offering of A.N.D.A. Development Corp. as well as the traditionally slow summer season for Generic OTC Pharmaceuticals.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman of Dyncorp Heads Buyout Group
description: LEAD: Jorge E. Carnicero, who co-founded the Dynalectron Corporation in 1946 and remains its chairman, is now leading an investment group seeking to purchase the company, which was recently renamed Dyncorp. The group has offered a package of cash and securities worth about $246 million, or $23.25 a share.

title: Retired Ad Executive Died of Strangulation
description: A 77-year-old retired advertising executive who was found slain in his Park Avenue apartment Tuesday died of strangulation and ''blunt-force trauma'' to his head, face, chest and abdomen, according to autopsy results released yesterday.

title: DOLLAR SETS LOWS IN SPITE OF BUYING BY CENTRAL BANKS
description: The dollar ended a bleak year on a bleak note yesterday, falling to new lows against the Japanese yen and the West German mark. Trading was very light.

title: A Pair of Comedies
description: Two comedy shows - featuring individual comics and the First Amendment Comedy and Improvisation Company - will be offered this weekend at 2 Bond Street, between Broadway and Lafayette Street. Tonight at 10:30, there will be appearances by four comedians - Bill Torres, Mike King, Judy Gold and Liz Wolynski. Tomorrow night, also at 10:30, it will be the First Amendment troupe. Admission each night is $10. Information: 473-1472.

title: Two in Track Honored
description: The New York Track Writers Association yesterday voted Ben Johnson of Canada and Heike Drechsler of East Germany as the outstanding athletes of the 1987 indoor season.

title: Harold Rousselot, 80, Ex-Investment Banker
description: Harold A. Rousselot, a retired investment banker and commodity trader, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: Seagram Bid Is Set Back
description: An offer by Seagram & Company of Canada to acquire a 40.1 percent stake in the French cognac producer Martell & Compagnie from the Martell family failed to follow normal procedures for takeover bids, the Paris Stock Exchange regulatory body said today.

title: Rangers' Burst Fells Nordiques
description: It is a night generally remembered for the significant seconds leading up to midnight. For the Rangers, no matter how extravagant their individual New Year's Eve celebrations, it was going to be hard to top the memorable couple of minutes they enjoyed last night slightly after 9 P.M.

title: Haig Leaves Hospital
description: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was released from a hospital early today after an overnight stay for treatment of an allergic reaction to drugs he had taken for a tooth problem. ''They gave him a clean bill of health,'' said a spokesman for Fairfax Hospital, Lon Walls. Mr. Haig, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, had been treated Wednesday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center for an abscessed tooth. He had been given penicillin and Tylenol.

title: Dow Off 11.27 to End Year at 1,938.83
description: The stock market ended a frustrating but record-filled year with the Dow Jones industrial average giving up 11.27 points yesterday to close at 1,938.83. That left the Dow down 60.84 points for the week and only 42.88 points, or 2.26 percent, above its 1986 close of 1,895.95.

title: The End Is Near
description: It seems only yesterday that America celebrated its Bicentennial. Yet it was 12 whole years ago, and by the same measure the 21st century is tomorrow - just 12 years hence. Foresighted earthlings will start now to get ready.

title: The Dance: Nikolais's 'Imago'
description: ''IMAGO'' was hailed, on its premiere in 1963, as the last word in the kind of multimedia theater-dance practiced by Alwin Nikolais. The dance started life as a full-evening work that explored ways movement, light and sound affect each other. Subtitled ''The City Curious,'' the piece also seemed to allude to the busy and mysterious pace of urban life. Now reduced to five dances, performed as before to a sound score by Mr. Nikolais and James Seawright, ''Imago'' continued to offer a clear and concise - if relatively unsophisticated -statement of the Nikolais esthetic in a revival on Wednesday by the Nikolais Dance Theater at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: Blasius in Fight For Atlas Control
description: Blasius Industries said that it intends to wage a proxy fight for control of the Atlas Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Blasius said it was beginning the process because Atlas, a gold exploration concern based in Princeton, N.J., ''has yet to make any substantive response'' to a restructuring proposal made by Blasius earlier this month.

title: MacGregor Unit Bid Is Canceled
description: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said it had been notified that Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. would not complete the acquisiiton of the assets of MacGregor's Riddell Inc. football equipment unit and the capital stock of its Equilink Licensing Corporation, a licensor of the MacGregor trademark. The fund said it had been unable to obtain satisfactory financing for the transaction, which was to have been completed by Jan. 31.

title: Company Abandons Proposal on Burning Toxic Wastes at Sea
description: The nation's biggest waste disposal company said today that it had abandoned plans to burn toxic wastes on ships off the United States coast, effectively ending the prospect of such waste disposal for the foreseeable future.

title: 300,000 Celebrators Jam Times Square
description: Despite threats of snow and sleet, more than 300,000 New Years revelers jammed Times Square last night to watch the traditional lowering of the ball on 1987.

title: SHARP OZONE DROP FOUND WORLDWIDE IN 8-YEAR PERIOD
description: The atmosphere's protective shield of ozone ebbed rapidly from 1979 through 1986, not just over Antarctica, where the depletion has been sharpest, but over nearly the whole globe, researchers said yesterday.

title: Title to Santos
description: When Jose Santos won his third race of the day aboard Jane's Dilemma yesterday in the $90,150 Display Handicap, Aqueduct's year-end feature, he earned a spot in the national money winner's circle for 1987.

title: KEY RATES
Patricia E. Roberts, Landscape Designer, 77
description: Patricia Easterbrook Roberts, a landscape designer and author, died of cancer Sunday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: 'Pinafore' Performances
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players will present ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. Tickets are $15 to $25, with a $5 discount for children and the elderly. Information: 864-5400.

title: A Brokerage Sues Drexel
description: A lawyer for a Santa Monica, Calif., brokerage firm said today that his client had filed suit against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and its ''junk bond'' expert, Michael Milken, seeking $200 million in damages and contending that 10,000 transactions had been mishandled since 1980.

title: CALNY INC reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 3
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $105,595 and $393,707 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the results of operations reported for the last year's periods include losses from the company's La Petite Boulangerie bakery operations.

title: Alexis Smith
description: The Brooklyn Museum 200 Eastern Parkway Through Jan. 11 Alexis Smith is a California artist who emerged in the mid-1970's as part of the narrative or story-art phenomenon, a more talkative, less hermetic branch of Conceptual art. Ms. Smith's metier is a collage-like installation that, using film stills, bits of printed matter, small found objects and quotations from fiction, tells tales in visual terms. In Ms. Smith's latest effort, a mural titled ''Same Old Paradise'' executed specifically for the enormous wall in the lobby of the Brooklyn Museum, she moves to the big scale of the movie screen and highway billboard.

title: A Neikrug Premiere
description: The violinist Shlomo Mintz will be guest soloist with the Cleveland Orchestra in the New York premiere of a violin concerto by Marc Neikrug, Jan. 26 at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. The piece was commissioned for Mr. Mintz by the Houston Symphony, with which he first played it in 1984. The Cleveland Orchestra will be conducted by Christoph von Dohnanyi. Also on the program are Mahler's Symphony No. 5. Tickets range from $15 to $30. Information: 247-7800.

title: Philip Weinberg, Ex-G.O.P. Aide
description: Philip H. Weinberg, a lawyer who served as appointments secretary to two governors of New York, died of leukemia Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: USX Expects Charge Tied to Oil Price Drop
description: The USX Corporation said today that it expects to take a charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect the decline in value of oil inventories at its Marathon Oil Company subsidiary.

title: Stymied Conrail Officer Resigns
description: Stuart M. Reed, Conrail's president and chief operating officer since 1979, resigned yesterday after being passed over as designated successor to the chief executive. The top job is expected to become vacant at the end of 1988 when L. Stanley Crane retires.

title: A NEW OPERATION FOR BETTY FORD
description: Betty Ford was reported doing well today after unexpected surgery to repair sutures from a heart operation last month, and she was expected to remain hospitalized for about two more days.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Kindred on Saxophone Bob Kindred Quartet, at Red Blazer Too, 349 West 46th Street (262-3112). The spirit of the great tenor-saxophonist Ben Webster is kept alive in the playing of Bob Kindred, who frequently shows his deep admiration for Webster not by copying him but by building on the emotion and intelligence that Webster brought to his performances. Soul and swing are two dominant elements in Mr. Kindred's work, but there is also a strong overlay of simple basic fun. He has been playing on Sunday afternoons at the Red Blazer Too since last fall, using a small interchangeable company of associates. This Sunday, when the group plays from 1 to 5 P.M., Al Harewood will be the drummer, Ted Rosenthal will be the pianist, and John Goldsby will be on bass. There is no cover charge and no minimum. Brunches range from $9.95 to $13.95. Braff, Moore and Alden

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance brokerage, completed sales of its two major underwriting units, Sphere Drake Insurance Group P.L.C. and Shand Morahan & Co., to separate investor groups. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bonds End Year on Familiar Note
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell as much as a point yesterday, as the dollar's decline to new lows cast a pall over the credit markets.

title: Over Somebody's Head
description: THEY were assistant coaches together a long time ago, taking vacations at the Galveston coast, talking football, relaxing and playing with the children. Mostly talking football.

title: Gifts and Good Wishes Offered for the Neediest
description: With the steadily increasing flow of gifts and good wishes, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund looks forward to a bright new year.

title: Rescue the Future, at Birth
description: ''Social dynamite'' is one way to define poor children who lack education and sound parental supervision. ''Overwhelmed'' is a way to define poor mothers who lack education and self-esteem. How to help the children and the mothers is a question that can overwhelm, too - so much that it may induce paralysis even among the most well meaning.

title: Manila Fights Rebels With Roundups
description: Jump-off, as the major called it, was at 5 A.M., and the heavily armed policemen in their fatigue uniforms clattered from a dozen jeeps and fanned out through the narrow alleyways of the sleeping slum.

title: Indoor Lacrosse Starting Up
description: They are being paid $150 a game, but they say that, for the pleasure of competition, they would play for nothing. There are 25 of them, mostly Long Islanders who learned to love the game at Sewanhaka High or Levittown or Manhasset.

title: Vietnam Children of Americans Reach Thailand on Way to U.S.
description: Sixty-five children and young adults fathered by Americans during the Vietnam War arrived here today with 91 relatives on their way to the United States under a resettlement program stalled for nearly two years.

title: Fines for 70 Players
description: Danny White and Daryle Smith of the Dallas Cowboys and Dexter Manley and Neal Olkewicz of the Washington Redskins were among 70 players from the two teams fined a total of about $30,000 by the National Football League for their part in a brawl late in their game Dec. 13. The melee started with the four players, but 30 to 35 players from each team ran onto the field and each was fined at least $400 for joining the fight.

title: Closings Today
description: Stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of New Year's Day.

title: Mugabe Now President of a One-Party Zimbabwe
description: Robert Mugabe was inaugurated today as Zimbabwe's first Executive President, marking the country's movement away from a parliamentary democracy toward a one-party state.

title: Rainier Sells Unit
description: Rainier National Bank, whose $1.2 billion acquisition by the Security Pacific Corporation became final three months ago, said it had agreed to sell its leasing operation to a unit of the First City Trust Company of Vancouver, British Columbia. Terms were not disclosed. The operation has assets of $160 million and in the first nine months of 1987 earned $2.2 million. Sale of Rainier Leasing Inc. is part of the Seattle-based bank's disposal of operations that have become redundant because of the combination of Rainier and Security Pacific businesses.

title: Vito Acconci's Art of Opposition and Provocation
description: VITO ACCONCI may be avant-garde in a rather old-fashioned sense. He has always made art that is an affront to conventional behavior (esthetic or otherwise), that is not too viable in the commercial sense and that is often all the more off-putting for the way it implicates the viewer in its machinations. An air of provocation, of confrontation, permeates much of the work in the 20-year survey of Mr. Acconci's career now on view at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y.; it is often a strength and sometimes a weakness.

title: On the Island of Cyprus There Are No Borders
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Woman Is Found Dead In Field on L.I.
description: The body of a 22-year-old woman who disappeared the night of Dec. 24 after leaving her home to take a walk was found last night in a bleak, weed-strewn field here.

title: Sheriff Reconstructs the Murders of 16
description: The man suspected of one of America's worst mass murders probably began slaughtering 16 people by stealthily strangling his sleeping children on Christmas Eve, according to the sheriff investigating the slayings.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Circle K Corp., Phoenix, an operator of convenience stores, appointed Larry J. Zine executive vice president of finance and chief financial officer. He replaces Bill J. Farmer, who resigned to pursue other interests.

title: Holly Sugar Bid Increased
description: The Holly Sugar Company, which agreed to be acquired by the Imperial Sugar Company on Christmas Eve, said today that Imperial had increased the cash portion of its offer from $105 a share to $108.

title: Political Maneuvering Intensifies In Search for Schools Chancellor
description: The political maneuvering surrounding the search for a New York City schools chancellor intensified yesterday, with both City Hall and the president of the Board of Education believing they had switched one pivotal vote in favor of their candidate.

title: Free Trade by Phone
description: For the signing of their historic free trade agreement tomorrow, President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada are planning a little telephone conversation around 4 P.M. and separate ''photo opportunities.''

title: Harlem Priest Voices Strong Convictions
description: The Harlem priest embroiled in a public dispute with Mayor Koch over remarks about racism has compiled a record of provocative commentary on a range of political and social issues since his ordination almost 30 years ago.

title: Buckeyes Meet Cooper
description: The official hiring of John Cooper as head football coach at Ohio State yesterday ended six weeks of uncertainty for the Buckeye players. Cooper was introduced to them by officials of the school as the replacement for Earle Bruce only a day after he coached Arizona State to a 33-28 victory over Air Force in the Freedom Bowl.

title: Pat Robertson Asks For Federal Money But May Return It
description: Pat Robertson's well-heeled Presidential campaign adjusted its financial course again today by agreeing to accept $4.5 million in Federal matching funds. But it pledged to put the money in escrow while Mr. Robertson decides whether to keep it or try to give it back.

title: DOUG WILSON STUDIOS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income Revenue represents net revenue.

title: COMMUNICATIONS TRANSMISION reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Texaco Financing Plan Filed
description: Texaco Inc. intends to borrow $3.4 billion and use $2.2 billion of its cash on hand to settle its dispute with the Pennzoil Company, pay off its creditors and emerge from bankruptcy, the company said yesterday in a document it filed with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains.

title: Islanders Demote 2
description: The Islanders have sent two rookies, Brad Dalgrano and Derek King, both first-round picks in the 1985 draft, to their minor-league team, the Springfield Indians. Dalgarno, a right wing, had 2 goals and 7 assists in 33 games; King, a left wing, had 2 goals and 8 assists in 20 games. King missed the team's last nine games because of a wrist fracture suffered Dec. 11 against Pittsburgh.

title: Music From A Crossroads Of Cultures
description: A FEW centuries ago, Bukhara was a Central Asian hot spot. An ancient city on the silk route between China and the West, just north of present-day Iran and Afghanistan, Bukhara developed a cosmopolitan culture of the Near and Far East. Its traditions drew from Persia, from nomadic Turkic tribes that wandered the steppes, from the bustle of trading cities and the calm of mountain villages; its music was shaped by classical Sufi poets and generations of Jewish court musicians. The Bukhara emirate was taken over by the Soviet Union in 1920, becoming a part of the republics of Uzbekistan and Tadzhikistan. But its music and dances were preserved, and tomorrow at Merkin Concert Hall, New Yorkers will have an opportunity to hear Bukhara's traditional music, or shashmaqam, along with the region's folk songs and dances.

title: The Chancellor Search Goes Haywire
description: New York City's Board of Education appears on the verge of a mistake. Acting under pressure from borough presidents and the teachers' union, it has decided to consider Dr. Bernard Gifford, a candidate rejected by the board's own search committee. Such political intervention inevitably would handicap any chancellor it produces.

title: A Free Insider Tip
description: After all the hysteria generated by stock market fluctuations during the last three months, my Super Bowl stock theory has triumphed for the 21st consecutive year, indicating that some order still exists in the financial universe.

title: Day No. 1 Of Soviet Reforms
description: LEAD: The new year marks, among other things, the beginning of a new and far more important phase of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to reform the Soviet economy. Today, enterprises accounting for 60 percent of all industrial production come under a new law that threatens unprofitable enterprises with bankruptcy and gives workers a voice in enterprise management.

title: College Basketball; Kentucky Rallies To Top Vanderbilt
description: Rex Chapman scored 13 of Kentucky's final 16 points tonight as the Wildcats rallied to beat Vanderbilt, 81-74, in the Southeastern Conference opener for both teams.

title: Wilbur Schramm; Wrote Many Works On Communications
description: Wilbur Schramm, an authority on mass communications who was the author of 30 books, died Sunday at his home in Honolulu. He was 80 years old.

title: Ramones at the Ritz
description: The Ramones are to perform tomorrow night at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Manitoba's Wild Kingdom is to open at 11 P.M., with the Ramones at 12:30 A.M. Tickets are $13.50 in advance, $14.50 tomorrow.

title: The 'Uprising' Fires Palestinian Pride
description: ''It's miserable,'' said Asmaa Khroob, summing up life in the Balata refugee district, a grim warren of dirt streets, open sewers and low concrete-block houses.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Rhodes Vice Chairman Named Chief Executive
description: LEAD: Samuel E. Hudgins, vice chairman of Rhodes Inc., became chief executive of the Atlanta-based furniture retailer yesterday.

title: Shareholders Fight Shoe-Town Plan
description: Shoe-Town Inc., a specialty retail store chain, said certain shareholders had asked Delaware's Court of Chancery to stop its $103 million tender offer to take the company private. An investment group including Shoe-Town managers began the formal offer to buy shares at $9.75 each on Dec. 21.

title: Ferry Service From Bay Ridge Coming to End
description: Ferry service between Brooklyn Heights and Wall Street, just seven months old, is scheduled to die next Friday - a victim of sharply lower ridership as temperatures have plunged.

title: Korean Trade Surplus Soars
description: South Korea's trade surplus more than doubled in 1987 to a record $6.55 billion, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in Sports Pages yesterday with the New Year's Day bowl preview misidentified the Miami player. He was Melvin Bratton.

title: Politics of Education; Chancellor Selection Process Reveals Rift on Board and Groups' Influence
description: The decision by the Board of Education to go beyond the recommendations of its own screening panel and consider additional candidates for chancellor of the New York City school system exposes a number of the political undercurrents that have been operating during the selection process.

title: A NEW YEAR'S STROLL AMONG THE SIGHTS AND DELIGHTS AT MANHATTAN'S TIP
description: IT was a cold, brisk New Year's morning, and the sun, which had started to warm lower Manhattan on the East River, had not yet surmounted the skyscraper barricade that still shadowed the West Side, where City Stroller gingerly sat on a waterside bench in Battery Park City feeling his teeth chattering like jackhammers tearing up Broadway. He was waiting for Weekend Walker, his loquacious New York booster sidekick, to show up. It was Walker's somewhat eccentric idea that New Year's morning offered the best chance for a couple of semipro sightseers to get the feel of the town without an obtruding public on foot or on wheel.

title: Parker Hannifin Renews Gull Bid
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation, which last week dropped its bid for Gull Inc., an aviation equipment maker, said that Gull had agreed to a lower price and the offer would again proceed. The Cleveland-based Parker Hannifin, which makes fluid power systems, said that under the new agreement each Gull shareholder would receive 0.55 of a Parker Hannifin share. Based on Parker Hannifin's closing price of $36.375, down $1.375, the deal values Gull, based in Smithtown, L.I., at $105.5 million. Gull's shares jumped $2 each, to $18.625.

title: Tighter AIDS Precautions Urged in Labs
description: Scientists and technicians who work with the AIDS virus have been warned in a new report to take more precautions when working with the virus to avoid the chance of infection.

title: Federal Workers Get Raises
description: President Reagan, secluded at a private estate for a New Year's celebration, signed an executive order today that grants a 2 percent pay increase to 4.3 million military and civilian Federal workers.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Watson-Lundy Quintet The Bobby Watson-Curtis Lundy Quintet featuring Slide Hampton, at the Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South at 11th Street (255-4037). This exemplary little band sparked a gleam in Max Gordon's eye the last time it played the Vanguard, and Mr. Gordon, the club's patriarch, clearly wasted no time in proposing a return engagement. The blend of Mr. Watson's Kansas City-style alto saxophone and Mr. Hampton's sumptuously rich trombone sound, exquisitely framed by John Hicks's insightful, appropriate chord voicings on the piano, is a sensuous sonic treat. The contrast in playing styles and temperaments and an unusually broad repertory that mixes original tunes with pop and jazz standards and ranges from bop to modal to Latin and beyond are additional attractions. The quintet is at the Vanguard through Sunday, playing three sets a night beginning about 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Tickets are $12 with a $6 minimum. Double Piano Bill

title: INSIDE
description: Benefit Loss as '88 Issue Elderly Iowans who say they are victims of a quirk in the Social Security law are a new political force. Page 36. Pride of the Palestinians The clashes in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip have entered the folklore of the Palestinians. Page 3. Action Against Murdoch Senator Hollings says he originated legislation aimed at barring Rupert Murdoch from owning papers and TV stations in the same cities. Page 33.

title: Subsidy to Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing Notebook; The New Year Brings Instant Birthdays
description: Happy birthday to every race horse in the Northern Hemisphere - technically, that is. Each Jan. 1, all runners age a year for official purposes, regardless of whether they were born in January or June.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 1, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-4

title: More Selfless Resolutions
description: Making resolutions for other people last New Year's had mixed results. I didn't have to worry about keeping my own, which was a relief, but not many of them lived up to the obligation. Maybe I can do better this time. Here are some suggestions:

title: Harcourt Brace Units Are Sold
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. completed the sale of its business periodicals, trade-show and school-supply distribution companies to a group of investors for $334.1 million. The sale was part of Harcourt Brace's restructuring, undertaken to fight a takeover by the British publisher Robert Maxwell.

title: North Beach Journal; The Nightclub Where It All Began Imposes an End on a Topless Era
description: Most of the topless clubs that lined Broadway Street in the North Beach section are gone, maybe because of competition from X-rated home videos, maybe just because times change and it became no big deal to watch people dance with approximately no clothes on.

title: The Supreme Court and the National Will
description: To the Editor:

title: Rio Journal; As '88 Dawns, Brazil Is Spellbound
description: As evening fell tonight, even amid tropical showers, Copacabana beach came alive with lighted candles as tens of thousands of Brazilians bedecked in white prepared to ask Iemanja, an African goddess of the sea, to guide them safely through the New Year.

title: Colombia Frees Drug Figure, Provoking American Anger
description: A Colombian reputed to be one of the world's leading cocaine smugglers has been freed from a Colombian prison, prompting angry criticism today by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the State Department.

title: Coffey Still Out
description: Paul Coffey, the speedy defenseman for the Pittsburgh Penguins, will miss at least two more games with a knee injury he suffered two days before Christmas when he collided with Don Koharski, the referee, during a Penguins-Devils game in Pittsburgh.

title: At the Movies
description: 'Aria' Coming to U.S.

title: No Decision By Robins
description: The board of the A. H. Robins Company will meet today to continue its review of three takeover offers, and a company spokesman said a decision to accept one of them was expected early in the day.

title: Monty Alexander
description: Monty Alexander, a pianist, is to lead his Ivory and Steel Jamboree, featuring Othello Molineau on steel drums, tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Smoking Ban on Jet Stirs Unruly Protest And Police Response
description: Passengers enraged by an airline's smoking ban on a cross-country flight earlier this week lit up anyway and shoved attendants who asked them to stop, and the pilot radioed for the police, the authorities said today.

title: Benefits Disparity Made Issue in Iowa
description: With single-minded persistence, elderly Iowans who describe themselves as victims of a quirk in the Social Security law have emerged as a significant force in the state's Presidential politics.

title: CRAFTMATIC-CONTOUR INDUSRIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Elaborate Creches From Italy
description: The history of European art is filled with odd but intriguing footnotes -including an 18th-century Neapolitan craze for creating and collecting extraordinarily elaborate creches. One of these sculpted tableaux, known as presepios and rarely exhibited in the United States - can be seen through Jan. 12 at the Banco di Napoli, at 277 Park Avenue (near 47th Street).

title: French and Swiss Fight About Tainted Cheese
description: Two of the world's proudest makers of cheese, the French and the Swiss, are locked in battle over allegations of contaminated cheese.

title: Variations in the Sport
description: Differences between the lacrosse played indoors and the lacrosse played outdoors include the following:

title: Leo Steiner, 48, Owner of a Deli; Known for Wit
description: Leo Steiner, co-owner of the Carnegie Deli, who was renowned for his celebrated corned beef as well as his cornball kosher humor, died of complications from a brain tumor yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Diner's Journal
description: TIME AND AGAIN, the American restaurant at 116 East 39th Street, is catering to the early-bird business client with its new breakfast club. Along with the a la carte breakfast (eggs, cereals, smoked salmon, homemade breads, from $5.50 to $15), diners get complimentary copies of The New York Times or The Wall Street Journal and the use of pads and pens, calculators and, if you ask, cassette tape recorders and cordless telephones. Breakfast is served from 7 to 10:30 A.M. Monday to Friday and 8 A.M. to noon Saturday and Sunday. All major credit cards accepted. The reservation number is 685-8887.

title: Pittance for Researchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Series to Study Black Images in Film
description: Although few black directors worked in Hollywood until the last 30 years, and histories of American movies rarely even mention such pioneering black filmmakers as Oscar Micheaux and Richard Maurice, black American cinema has a rich -albeit largely unknown - history, according to Pearl Bowser, who has organized a series of works by black directors that begins on Sunday at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: When the Campus Is the Corporation's Servant
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Junk Dances' Originators Reminisce
description: It was 23 years ago that two youngsters performed together in a new work called ''Junk Dances.'' It was a popular and critical success. The stars of the piece - Murray Louis and Phyllis Lamhut - soon went on their separate ways to become even more deft comedians and dancers, as well as modern dance choreographers with distinctive gifts. This week they have been reunited in Mr. Louis's ''Junk Dances,'' a major revival of the current, shared Murray Louis Dance Company and Nikolais Dance Theater season at the Joyce Theater. They will perform it again tomorrow night, and it promises to be a heady evening.

title: Blakey at Sweet Basil
description: The drummer Art Blakey is leading the Jazz Messengers tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
By John Gross
description: TALES OF LOVE, SEX, & DANGER. By Sudhir Kakar and John Munder Ross. 249 pages. Basil Blackwell. $16.95.

title: An Investment Bank's Big Shift
description: For years, the financial world considered Stephens Inc. something of an anomaly. The privately held brokerage firm in Little Rock, Ark., had $500 million in capital - as much as many of the big Wall Street houses - but it was neither a broker that controlled giant pools of money nor an investment banker for scores of major corporations.

title: Dance World In Dispute On Drug Use
description: The confirmation that Patrick Bissell, the 30-year old star of American Ballet Theater who was found dead Tuesday of unexplained causes, had had problems with drug abuse and alcoholism has led to a sharp exchange of views on the use of drugs by dancers, and on a therapy program established by Ballet Theater.

title: INVESTITECH reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the latest year reflects research and development expenses of $276,000.

title: 3 New Chamber Works At Symphony Space
description: Three new chamber pieces are to have their world premieres at the fourth American Music Festival on Jan. 21 at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street.

title: Hollings Says He Originated Murdoch Curb
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, an outspoken critic of consolidation within the communications industry, said yesterday that he originated legislation ''aimed directly'' at barring Rupert Murdoch's continued ownership of The New York Post and The Boston Herald while he owns television stations in those cities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is going to be a very exciting New Year for you.'' - William A. Brown, Ambassador to Thailand, to 65 Vietnamese-Americans resettling under a new accord. [ 1:1. ]

title: Tales of 1987: Strikers, Dogs And U.F.O.'s
description: The Our Towns reporter pauses to glance back at a few tales from the old year:

title: On Stage
description: Projects in the Making

title: A.T.& T. in Rate Cut Today; 3.5% Drop Exceeds Estimate
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would lower its rates for interstate long-distance calls by an average of 3.5 percent on New Year's Day, a larger reduction than expected.

title: AGING COWBOYS ON CBS
description: NO sooner is Willie Nelson released from jail after serving 20 years for trying to rob a train, than he gets together that old gang of his and goes off to try to rob a train again. He knows that an ex-Texas Ranger, Richard Widmark, who stopped him the first time, will be out to get him again, with that old gang of his.

title: Trio at Knitting Factory
description: The trio of Robert Dick on flute, Mark Dresser on bass, and Gerry Hemingway on percussion is to perform Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). At 10 P.M., the trio of Wilber Morris on bass, Claude Lawrence on saxophone, and Dennis Charles on drums is to perform. Tickets are $5.

title: 30 Reported Killed by Tamils in Sri Lanka
description: Ethnic Tamil militants killed at least 30 Moslems in eastern Sri Lanka on Wednesday in revenge for the deaths of six comrades killed by Moslem fundamentalists, two communities said today.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for 13wks Nov 25
description: The company said the share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend paid July 31, 1987.

title: BARRETT RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a writedown of $580,000 of oil and gas properties. c-Net income d-After a writedown of $2,950,000 of oil and gas properties.

title: How Goes Ozone War?
description: Friends of the Earth, a Washington-based environmental group, is at it again in its role as guardian of the earth's ozone shield.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 1, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL The dollar ended a bleak year on a bleak note, falling to new lows against the yen and the mark. Trading was very light. The drop came despite what dealers said was a fourth straight day of buying dollars by the central banks of Japan, West Germany and Switzerland. For the second consecutive year, the dollar recorded the dubious distinction of falling to its lowest levels of the year on the year's last day. The outlook for 1988 is not much better, although the Group of Seven has proclaimed again that the dollar has fallen enough. [ Page 1. ] COMPANIES American vintners are deeply concerned but widely divided about how to combat the movement to curb wine consumption. A growing interest in health and concern with alcohol abuse are fueling a drive for greater regulation of the wine industry. While wine makers say they do not see a direct connection between declining wine sales and the various advocacy groups - which they call ''neo-prohibitionists'' - some vintners nonetheless take them as a serious threat. [ 1. ] Texaco will borrow $3.4 billion and use $2.2 billion of its cash to settle its dispute with Pennzoil, pay off its creditors and emerge from bankruptcy, the company said in a document filed with a Federal Bankruptcy Court. Texaco's shareholders will vote on the proposal in a special monthlong ballot in March, with a two-thirds vote in favor required for acceptance. A Federal bankruptcy judge could approve the plan even if it is rejected by the shareholders. [ 39. ] Conrail's president and chief operating officer resigned after being passed over as designated successor to the chief executive. Stuart M. Reed, the president, had been in the shadow of L. Stanley Crane, the chairman and chief executive, during his eight years at Conrail. Mr. Reed said he was shocked to learn that the board did not intend to consider him for the company's top position. [ 39. ] USX expects to take a charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect the decline in the value of oil inventories at its Marathon Oil subsidiary. [ 41. ] Imperial increased to $108 the cash portion of its offer for Holly Sugar, from $105. Holly had previously agreed to be acquired. [ 41. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.27 points, to 1,938.83, ending a frustrating and record-smashing year. The Dow dropped 60.84 points this week to end the year 42.88 points, or 2.26 percent, above its 1986 close of 1,895.95. Some experts attributed yesterday's showing to the dollar's latest drop and to tax-related selling. [ 39. ] Treasury note and bond prices fell as much as a point, as the dollar's decline cast a pall over the credit markets. Besides lamenting the absence of demand from foreign investors, traders said prices were reduced by unconfirmed rumors that Japanese investors would be heavy sellers of bonds on Monday. [ 48. ] Precious metals futures posted moderate advances, but analysts said the gains were more subdued than they would have otherwise expected in view of the dollar's drop. ''Gold just doesn't want to rally,'' one analyst said. [ 49. ] THE ECONOMY A.T.&T. will lower rates for interstate long-distance calls by an average of 3.5 percent starting today, a larger reduction than expected. The lower rates reflect a $772 million reduction in the charges that A.T.&T. pays for connections to local systems. [ 39. ] Orders to factories edged up 0.1 percent in November, the weakest showing in three months. The report prompted concern about a possible slowdown in manufacturing in the aftermath of the October stock market collapse. [ 39. ] Prices that farmers received for raw products fell 3 percent in December from the November average. Lower prices for oranges, tomatoes, eggs and lettuce contributed most to the decline. [ 41. ] TODAY'S COLUMN The incumbent Republican Administration desperately hopes to avoid a recession in an election year by using fiscal and monetary policy to keep the economy growing. That would leave solution of the budget, trade and dollar problems to the next President. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ 40. ]

title: Football Hero Keeps Warm and Shuns Memories
description: Sunshine pours in a large picture window of the house. Outside, in a chill breeze that ruffles their gray feathers, two sandhill cranes, visitors from nearby Lake Weohyakapka, stand like frozen sentinels on the lawn. Their beady eyes beneath a tufted crown of bright red feathers dart back and forth, betraying no secrets.

title: McPherson Tired After Busy Month
description: His performance this season, much like his taste in clothes, has been virtually impeccable. Recently, however, Don McPherson has shown signs of wear: a loose thread here and there against Boston College, a wrinkled crease against West Virginia, a generally rumpled look since early December, when the Syracuse quarterback became one of the more publicized runners-up in the history of the balloting for the Heisman Trophy.

title: AT THE BAR
description: There's no way of knowing whether more clients will be fleeced by unscrupulous lawyers in 1988 than in previous years. One thing, however, seems clear: A growing percentage of them will be reimbursed for at least some of what they lost.

title: Huskies Battling For Respectability After Hard Times
description: For the last five seasons, Connecticut has been a sore spot for the image-conscious Big East. The Huskies were like a blighted part of the city tourists never see or an offbeat relative visitors never meet.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK O'Sullivan Captures Fiesta Mile: Marcus O'Sullivan of Ireland, runner-up each of the last two years, outsprinted the 1985 winner, Steve Scott of the United States, and the defending champion, Ray Flynn of Ireland, in the final 400 yards to win the third annual Fiesta Bowl Mile yesterday in Phoenix. O'Sullivan posted a winning time of 4 minutes 1.5 seconds to beat Scott by five-tenths of a second and Flynn by 1.5 seconds in the elite eight-man field. Greg Scott, who in college ran at nearby Arizona State, was fourth at 4:03.6, followed by John Walker of New Zealand in fifth at 4:04.3. (AP) HOCKEY Canada Holds Off U.S.: Canada broke a 2-2 tie with three straight second-period goals and hung on to beat the United States, 5-4, yesterday at the world junior championships in Moscow. With Canada ahead, 5-2, Kip Miller scored 16 seconds into the third period to make the score 5-3, and Ted Donato cut the deficit to one goal at 11:32. But the Canadian goalie, Jimmy Waite, made several good stops to secure the victory for the Canadians. Canada is now 3-0-1; the United States 1-3. The Soviet Union made its record 4-0-0 with a 4-2 victory over Sweden. (AP) TENNIS Kohde-Kilsch Forced to Rally: Third-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch rallied to defeat Nicole Provis of Australia, 5-7, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday in the third round of the Ariadne Classic in Brisbane, Australia. Another West German, unseeded Claudia Porwik, upset fifth-seeded Dianne Balestrat of Australia, 6-3, 6-2, in the only other third-round match completed in the warm-up tournament for the Australian Open. Kohde-Kilsch will play unseeded Manon Bollegraf of the Netherlands in the quarterfinals today; Porwik will face top-seeded Pam Shriver of the United States. (AP) Evernden and Krishnan Gain: Second-seeded Kelly Evernden of New Zealand and sixth-seeded Ramesh Krishnan of India won their matches yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the $115,000 New Zealand Open in Wellington. Evernden beat Omar Camporese of Italy, 6-3, 7-6, while Krishnan rallied to defeat Todd Witsken of the United States, 3-6, 6-4, 6-0. Menno Oosting of the Netherlands scored the only upset of the day by defeating third-seeded John Frawley of Australia, 6-3, 7-6. (AP)

title: Onset Tender Offer
description: The Onset Corporation, an acquisition company formed by the New York investment firms J. H. Whitney & Company and Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stone, raised its tender offer by 50 cents a share for the Decision Industries Corporation, to $11 a share. Under its new bid, which was accepted by Decision, Onset said it would defer the merger until April 29; the deal had been scheduled to take place immediately after its tender offer succeeded. Econocom International N.V., based in the Netherlands, said that because of the improved price, it would end its own pending tender offer for outstanding shares of Decision, a computer concern based in Horsham. Decision and Econocom also said that they had agreed to terminate all pending litigation between them and to enter into a marketing agreement under which the Dutch concern would provide lease financing for Decision.

title: Letter: On Finance; Public Power Is a State Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: More Bar Questions Are the Same But Scores Still Vary State by State
description: For decades, lawyers have been talking about the desirability of a national bar examination, but progress in that direction has been painfully slow.

title: Two Ways to Reduce Underage Drinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Being Psycholegal About the New Year
description: LEAD: Every year during the 10 years I practiced psychology, I was presented with a peculiar and seemingly untreatable illness. Typically, the patient would report moderate depression and low self-esteem along with a pervading sense of hopelessness. Of course, these symptoms are not rare; indeed, they are among the most common 20th century complaints.

title: No Tilt as Yet From New California High Court
description: When a conservative tide forced out Chief Justice Elizabeth Rose Bird and her liberal majority on the California Supreme Court in 1986, liberals feared the new court would mount an assault on defendants' rights and privacy. Conservatives expected a pronounced rightward tilt.

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,572,000 for the quarter and $2,493,000 for the year, and losses from disposal of discontinued operations of $1,588,000 and $1,666,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,044,000 for the quarter and $1,771,000 for the year, and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,050,000 for the both periods.

title: Orders Rise A Weak 0.1% At Factories
description: Orders to the nation's factories edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the weakest showing in three months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Jets for Northwest
description: Northwest Airlines Inc. has agreed to buy three more B-757 aircraft from the Boeing Company for an undisclosed amount. Northwest, a subsidiary of NWA Inc., also said it had accelerated deliveries of two B-757's ordered previously. The aircraft are to be delivered in the second half of 1988. The aircraft will seat 184 passengers each and will expand Northwest's B-757 fleet to 33.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about a dispute between the developer Sam LeFrak and Jersey City officials misidentified his development in Jersey City. The development is Newport; its shopping mall is Newport Center.

title: Raeburn Van Buren; Drew Daily Comic Strip
description: Raeburn Van Buren, a cartoonist and illustrator, died Tuesday at North Shore Community Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after suffering an injury in a fall. He was 96 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Sanofi's Bid For Robins Is Accepted
description: The board of the A. H. Robins Company last night accepted a sweetened merger bid from Sanofi, a large French drug maker, over competing offers from two American suitors.

title: Court Gives Leader's Money to Black Muslims
description: A $5.7 million bank account of Elijah Muhammad, the Black Muslim leader who died in 1975, belongs to the religious organization he founded and not to his heirs, an Illinois appeals court has decided.

title: Family Fortunes
description: SECOND SIGHT. By Mary Tannen. 259 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Why All Those People Feel They Never Have Any Time
description: Because she wanted more free time, Sue Alstedt quit her job as a manager at A.T.&T. Then, to save even more time, she bought equipment to do her banking at home. But she soon became impatient with the computer because it was not as fast as the one she had used at work. ''I couldn't stand to wait for it, even though it was coming out at the rate of speech,'' she said.

title: In Night Court: Plea Bargains and Coffee
description: Late Thursday night, while many New Yorkers in fancy dress were celebrating the new year at bright spots around the city, Judge Joel M. Goldberg took his black polyester robe and drove to Manhattan Criminal Court, where he had a job to do.

title: Autonomy in Industry To Challenge Worker
description: The Soviet Union today entered a critical phase in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempt to resuscitate the economy, in which workers will be asked to change their notion of work radically without yet having enjoyed any great rewards from two years of economic experiments and promises.

title: Waldheim Assails Racial Hatred
description: President Kurt Waldheim, who has been accused of involvement in wartime atrocities, today denounced the period of Nazi rule in Austria and urged his countrymen to avoid racial hatred and intolerance.

title: Humidifiers Aid Comfort, Not Health
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission is looking into the health risks of humidifiers.

title: COPING: WITH NEGLIGENCE CASES
description: If you slip and sprain your ankle on an icy public sidewalk or a wet floor in a department store, how do you go about getting compensation for your injury and suffering? What if your car is dented by a parking-lot attendant who won't admit fault? Or an expensive garment is damaged by a dry cleaner who accepts no liability?

title: INSIDE
description: Improving Law Enforcement

title: Specialists Saved Day
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Youths Play London
description: It rained on their parade, but five American high school bands and a drill team dazzled their audience during a New Year's Day march through one of London's main shopping districts.

title: Anti-Israeli Protests in Cairo Broken Up by Egypt's Police
description: Egyptian police with riot sticks charged and beat hundreds of anti-Israeli protesters chanting Islamic fundamentalist slogans today and besieged others at one of Cairo's most eminent mosques, witnesses said.

title: Orange Bowl; Hurricanes Overwhelm the Sooners to Claim No. 1
description: The University of Miami, with an offensive line that had to be reconstructed because of injuries and a suspension after a positive drug test, limited the most powerful offense in the nation tonight to defeat Oklahoma, 20-14, in the 54th Orange Bowl.

title: Reagan's Greetings, In Soviet Exchange, Have a Barbed Edge
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev exchanged televised New Year's greetings to the Soviet and American peoples today.

title: Depleted Auburn
description: It hasn't been the best of weeks for the front line of the Auburn (7-2) basketball team. On Monday Mike Jones, the leading scorer and rebounder averaging 21.9 points and 10.0 rebounds, was ruled academically ineligible. On Wednesday Jeff Moore, the senior center, suffered a broken hand in an 83-72 defeat to Georgia Tech in the final of the Cotton States Classic. He scored 51 points and grabbed 19 rebounds in the two games. Then Chris Morris, a senior forward and the team's second-leading scorer and rebounder (20.2, 8.9), severly bruised his right leg in the same game. He is questionable for Auburn's Southeastern Conference opener against Florida next Wednesday. ''I don't know what direction we're going to take,'' Coach Sonny Smith, said of his Tigers.

title: Cotton Bowl; Aggies Top Irish By 35-10
description: Tim Brown ended his Heisman Trophy season today looking for a towel. A crying towel would have done nicely for his Notre Dame teammates and Coach Lou Holtz.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Page 1 chart yesterday tracing the dollar's fall against the yen incorrectly indicated a recent climb by the dollar. The dollar fell on Dec. 31 to 121.05 yen, its lowest point of the year.

title: Rising Debate Over a Schools Chief Hinges on Picking Insider or Outsider
description: As was perhaps inevitable, the selection of a New York City schools chancellor has become mired in politics -personal, jurisdictional and racial.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Happy New Year. Thank you, and God bless you.''

title: Vincent Scores 33 To Lead Nuggets
description: Jay Vincent scored 33 points in his first game against his former Washington teammates, matching his season high and helping the Denver Nuggets to a 124-109 victory over the Bullets tonight.

title: Iran Seeking OPEC Talks
description: Iran wants OPEC's president, Rilwanu Lukman of Nigeria, to call an urgent meeting of the organization's monitoring committee because oil prices are falling. But a Nigerian official said Thursday that such a meeting would be premature.

title: ARCO Increases Its Stake in Britoil
description: ARCO, the United States oil group seeking to acquire a 49.9 percent stake in Britoil P.L.C., said it had raised its share in the concern to 21.2 percent. Britoil, based in Glasgow, has received a takeover bid of $:2.27 billion, or about $4.26 billion, from the British Petroleum Company and sees ARCO as a friendly suitor.

title: Forgoing Gifts to Give to the Neediest
description: It would be wrong to let the holiday season close without acknowledging some of the many people who gave to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of exchanging gifts.

title: Transcripts of New Year's Greetings From Reagan and Gorbachev on TV
description: Following are transcripts of New Year's greetings, televised today, by President Reagan to the Soviet people and by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the American people. The transcripts were supplied by the White House, with the translation from the Russian provided by an official interpreter. MR. REAGAN

title: Royalties Bill Leads To Art Black Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; Contest west down a wire For New York Player of Year
description: Rather unexpectedly, the New York Player of the Year title remained in doubt until the last day of the tournament season.

title: Bond Won't Seek Cup
description: In light of the recent decision by the defending San Diego Yacht Club not to accept any America's Cup challenges in 90-foot boats except for the one already received from Michael Fay of New Zealand, Alan Bond, the millionaire behind Australia's 1983 victory, has decided not to challenge for the trophy this year. John Longley, general manager for Bond's syndicate, which has competed in the last five America's Cup series, said work on the super-maxi Waltzing Matilda would cease immediatly, even though the Bond syndicate had spent more than $1 million on it. Fay has criticised the San Diego stance and says the challenge will almost certainly now be a one-on-one battle between New Zealand and the cup holder. ''It looks as though even pressure from Bondy can't force San Diego to change its mind,'' Fay said. ''It looks like they still have their minds on the 12-Meter challenge in 1991 and just want to get this one out of the way. They obviously think they'll have a better chance of retaining the cup if there is no challenger series.''

title: Coaching Job Swap?
description: The former Ohio State football coach, Earle Bruce, said yesterday that he would like to be considered for the coaching position at Arizona State - a job that became vacant when John Cooper accepted Bruce's old job. In an interview broadcast by NBC during halftime of the Fiesta Bowl, Bruce said: ''I'm unemployed. I'm looking for work. I would consider any job offer right now.'' Cooper, 50 years old, who coached the Sun Devils for three seasons, was named Thursday to succeed Bruce.

title: For a Hudson Greenway
description: The extraordinary cultural, historical and environmental values of the Hudson River Valley are under siege.

title: Wrestler Fails to Keep Hold on an Honorable Past
description: In the highly structured, rigidly disciplined, virtually feudal world of Japanese sumo wrestling, there had never been anything like it.

title: 2 Steel, 2 Gold Stocks Top List of Best Gainers
description: In a wildly turbulent year, the largest gains on the New York Stock Exchange were registered by two steel producers and two gold-mining companies.

title: Ship File Proves Legal Status Of a 1912 Immigrant to U.S.
description: A Federal immigration official says a 95-year-old woman facing the cutoff of state medical benefits because she could not prove legal residence status has been in the United States since 1912.

title:
Patents;
Record Year For Nation's Inventors
description: LEAD: A RECORD number of patents was issued last year, and the Patent and Trademark Office expects no letup. The total was 88,793 in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, and the brisk pace continued during the rest of 1987.

title: O-T-C Stocks Still Trail Exchange-Listed Issues
description: Like some earthquakes, the stock market debacle caused aftershocks that hit the over-the-counter market harder than the initial tremor.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Long Shot Travels by Rail: Key to the Bridge, an 11-to-1 shot, hugged the rail from start to finish and held off Avanti Sassa by a head to win the $113,480 Hialeah Breeders' Cup Handicap yesterday at Hialeah Park in Hialeah, Fla. Natania finished third, 1 1/4 lengths behind the top pair, and Way It Should Be was fourth. Home Leave and Triple Wow, the co-favorites, finished fifth and sixth, respectively. The winner, a 4-year-old daughter of Key to the Mint and Toll Booth owned by Fox Ridge Farm and trained by Pat Kelly, paid $25.20 for $2 to win. Carrying 112 pounds, one more than the runner-up, she ran the mile and an eighth in 1:50 under Mikey Solomone to earn $80,088. (AP) Spring Beauty Aqueduct Winner: With strong handling by Jose Santos, Spring Beauty closed strongly for a half-length victory in the $91,950 Interborough Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Cagey Exuberance raced on or near the lead throughout and lasted to be second in the field of 11. The victory was the ninth in 25 career starts for Spring Beauty, who raced six furlongs in 1:10 2/5 on the fast track to earn $55,170 for Glencrest Farm. She paid $5.40 for $2 to win as the favorite. Tennis Shriver Advances in Australia: Top-seeded Pam Shriver scored a pair of straight-set victories yesterday to move into the semifinals of the Ariadne Classic women's championships in Brisbane. Shriver, ranked fourth in the world, first trounced an unseeded Czechoslovak, Radka Zrubakova, 6-3, 6-2, in a third-round match held over from Thursday because of bad weather. Then she routed a West German teen-ager, Claudia Porwik, 6-2, 6-2, in her quarterfinal match an hour later. Shriver earned a semifinal meeting with third-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany. (AP) Evernden, Chesnokov Gain: In Wellington, New Zealand, second-seeded Kelly Evernden of New Zealand and fourth-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union won yesterday to move into the semifinals of the New Zealand Open. Evernden overcame an injury to his right forearm to defeat Jeremy Bates of Britain, 3-6, 1-6, 6-1, while Chesnokov powered past fifth-seeded Tim Wilkison of the United States, 6-4, 6-4. Evernden will meet sixth-seeded Ramesh Krishnan of India in today's semifinals. Chesnokov will play unseeded Chris Pridham of Canada. (AP) Road Racing New Jersey Runner First: Jim McKeon of Short Hills, N.J., who covered the five-mile course in 24 minutes 9 seconds, won the New York Road Runners Club midnight run yesterday. The race attracted a field of 3,850. McKeon, 25 years old, scored a 20-yard victory over Tom Ratcliffe, 27, of Wellesley, Mass., who was timed in 24:13. James Lauck of Pittstown, N.J., was third in 24:38. Anne Letko of Glen Gardner, N.J., was the women's winner in 27:45, followed by Gillian Beschloss of New York in 28:47.(AP) N.H.L. Capitals 5, Penguins 3: Two games after being benched, Larry Murphy scored a goal and assisted on three others as Washington defeated Pittsburgh in Landover, Md., yesterday. Murphy set up first-period goals by Dave Christian and Mike Gartner before scoring a power-play goal at 14:46 of the second period. He picked up his rebound near the right face-off circle and flipped a backhander just inside the far goal post, putting Washington ahead, 4-2. (AP)

title: Florida State Rallies
description: Danny McManus of Florida State capped a record passing performance in the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl today with a fourth-and-goal, game-winning touchdown pass from the Nebraska 15 to Ronnie Lewis with 3 minutes 7 seconds to play.

title: Spartans Stop and Smell Roses on Way to Victory
description: The theory was that Big 10 teams had lost six consecutive Rose Bowls, and 12 of the last 13, because the Midwestern kids were dazzled and distracted by Disneyland, Hollywood and the Southern California climate when they came to play the Pac-10 champion.

title: 4 Die in Burning Apartment
description: Firefighters heard faint scratching at a locked door today while they struggled to enter a burning apartment, but they were unable to save a pregnant woman and three children inside, an official said. After the firefighters sawed through the door, secured by deadbolts, they discovered a child just inside who had apparently died from heavy smoke in the apartment, a fire department spokesman said.

title: Betty Rhodes; Singer, 52
description: Betty Rhodes, a cabaret singer who played in the original production of ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris,'' died of cancer Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Johnson Is Now 'The Guy' After Beating Switzer a 3d Time
description: Jimmy Johnson stopped being ''the other guy'' tonight as his University of Miami team swarmed over Barry Switzer's Oklahoma team, 20-14, to lay claim to the unofficial national championship.

title: ENGINE DESIGN HELD A BREAKTHROUGH
description: Scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory have developed what they said today was the first electric motor based on the properties of a material that conducts electricity with minimal resistance.

title: Airbus Suffers As Dollar Falls
description: The steep fall of the dollar has created a catastrophic situation for Airbus Industrie, the European commercial aircraft consortium, the Foreign Trade Minister of France, Michel Noir, said in an interview published this week. Mr. Noir told the newspaper

title: Keycorp Buys A Utah Bank
description: Keycorp of Albany has acquired the Commercial Security Bancorpation of Salt Lake City, according to officials of both companies.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA G.O.P. IS ACCUSED OF RACISM
description: A Roman Catholic clergyman says that the South Carolina Republican Party is helping perpetuate a segregated society and that racism should be stamped out on the 125th anniversary of Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation.

title: About New York; A Composer, At 75, Gets His Big Break
description: It was cold, as all but the Sherpas know, and Ted Harris wouldn't come out of his apartment in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, on account of the angina and the stern doctor's orders, and then he thought he would take it one step further: no guests. He could visit by telephone, though, and it was important because he had a load to get off his chest. ''I mean I'm 75 years old,'' he said, ''and they're first playing me in New York. My first performance, and I'm a composer all my life.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance brokerage, completed sales of its two major underwriting units, Sphere Drake Insurance Group P.L.C. and Shand Morahan & Co., to separate investor groups. Terms were not disclosed.

title:
Patents;
Drug Abuse Detected By Using New Method
description: LEAD: A method of detecting drug abuse with the aid of a computer was patented this week for National Patent Analytical Systems Inc., a subsidiary of the National Patent Development Corporation of New York.

title: 'Elephant Repellent'
description: ''Thank heaven for nuclear weapons,'' Prime Minister

title: 13 KILLED IN BLAZE AT BANGKOK HOTEL
description: At least 13 people died and 36 were injured when a fire destroyed a tourist hotel early today. Some guests received injuries trying to jump from windows or rooftops, according to police and fire officials.

title: Britain Suppressed Details of '57 Atomic Disaster
description: A detailed account of the causes of one of the world's worst nuclear accidents - a fire at a British nuclear plant in 1957 - was suppressed by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan mainly because he feared it would threaten nuclear and defense cooperation with the United States, according to classified documents released today.

title: Chase to Close Offices in Peru
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank will close its offices in Peru, the Government said today.

title: No Aid to American Vision of South Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Bore the 'Arc'
description: To the Editor:

title: Dawn of '88 Brings Hope And Unease
description: In a shadowy section of Pennsylvania Station, Maurice Warner rocked slowly back and forth, muttering softly as he surveyed about 30 homeless people, most of them asleep on wooden benches or the bare floors.

title: Railroad Tank Car Explodes
description: A railroad tank car exploded Wednesday night, setting off a fireball seen more than 25 miles away, derailing adjacent rail cars and shattering windows of buildings up to six miles away, the authorities said. At least two people suffered minor injuries. ''The only thing left of the tank car was the wheels it was standing on,'' a police spokesman, Mike Healy, said. The blast set off a fireball seen in Gilmer, 28 miles away, Sgt. Alfred Yarbrough said.

title: NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE ISSUES
description: BIG BOARD VOLUME Total share volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the year. 1987 ............. 47,801,308,660 1986 ............ 35,680,016,341 1985 ......... 27,510,706,353 1984 ..... 23,071,031,447 1983 ... 21,589,576,997 MOST ACTIVE BIG BOARD ISSUES IN 1987 Only common stocks are listed; adjusted for stock splits (s).

title: Independent Service Contracts: Are They Worth the Money?
description: More and more consumers are being faced with a new situation when they purchase extended warranties for appliances and electronic products. Many stores sell such protection themselves, but others have decided to offer it through separate companies.

title: Moscow 1987: A Tattering of Myths
