description: Daily life is much the same in the Soviet Union. The old economic machinery creaks along. There still is no recourse against the power of the state. Yet Mikhail Gorbachev's new thinking, while short on establishing genuine reforms in economic and political machinery, has exposed some of the myths of Soviet society to public scrutiny.

title: Jackson Treated at Hospital
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson was treated at a hospital today for back pain and released after a few hours, hospital officials said. A candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Mr. Jackson went to the Franklin Medical Center here at about noon, according to a nursing supervisor at the hospital who refused to give her name. She said Mr. Jackson had routine physical therapy and was released after two hours. Mr. Jackson's campaign manager in New Hampshire, Steve Cancian, said the candidate had gone to the hospital for ''a normal checkup.''

title: Coming Soon to This Theater
description: Here is a list of the columns I shall write in the coming year unless public pleas for mercy soften my heart.

title: Warriors of Hate Find No Homeland in Idaho
description: The Rev. Richard Girnt Butler, head of the neo-Nazi sect based here in northern Idaho, believes white people in the Northwest will rally round him when he is tried on Federal sedition charges.

title: Soviet Halts Jamming of Broadcasts to Poland
description: For the first time in six years, the Soviet Union today stopped jamming broadcasts to Poland by the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe, the director of the Voice of America said.

title: NEW YORK REACHES PACT ON COLISEUM
description: The Koch administration, working to keep viable its disputed plan for developing Columbus Circle, has agreed to a new proposal that includes no reference to the height of the project, reduces its purchase price and bulk, and places a new financial constraint on the developer.

title: Erie Lackawanna Files Suit on Taxes
description: The president of Erie Lackawanna Inc. said that he hoped that the filing of a suit in Federal Claims Court this week would speed up a $42.5 million refund the company hopes to obtain from the Internal Revenue Service. Harry A. Zilli Jr., who is in charge of what is left of the former railroad concern, said company lawyers had been frustrated by a lack of progress through the I.R.S. administrative appeals process.

title: Concert: Kathleen Battle
description: Kathleen Battle has done more than any guest conductor in recent memory about teaching the New York Philharmonic to play softly -an appreciable achievement, even if her means were somewhat extreme at the New Year's Eve concert in Avery Fisher Hall. One assumes that the microphones improved matters for the telecast, but in the hall it was often hard to hear Miss Battle's singing, not because her voice is too little (when she let it out, all was well) or because the band was too loud, but because you just can't sing that quietly in a 3,000-seat hall and expect to reach the back rows.

title: Decline on Amex Paced By Battered Oil Stocks
description: Although the October stock market collapse took its toll on virtually every stock on the American Stock Exchange, those that held onto most of their gains had very little in common. The winners for the year ranged from a bedcovering importer to a cable television system, while losers ran the gamut from a poultry processor to a jewelry maker.

title: Overstaying By Patients Cuts Beds
description: Despite a critical shortage of beds in New York City's public and private hospitals, an average of 2,000 beds a day are occupied by patients who are medically ready for discharge and do not belong there, government and health-care officials acknowledge.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline yesterday with an article about ferry service in New York City incorrectly described the status of two lines. Service between Brooklyn Heights and Wall Street is to end next week. Service between the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and Wall Street is to begin in late January or early February.

title: Cold Brings California Gas Cutoff
description: The nation's largest natural gas utility will temporarily cut off shipments, starting Monday, to 800 corporate users in Southern California, hoping to avert a shortage for residential customers.

title: The Free-Falling Dollar
description: LEAD: The dollar keeps going on down. What should be done? The right answer is pretty well known by now. It was set out in a statement by 33 prominent economists issued last month by the Institute for International Economics. The first step should be convincing action to eliminate America's structural budget deficit over the next four years.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 413 money market mutual funds decreased $3.16 billion, to $258.22 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds were down $2.11 billion, to $70.99 billion. Assets of the 206 general purpose funds increased $159.8 million, to $79.36 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds decreased $1.21 billion, to $107.87 billion.

title: Comparing Apple Juice And Orange Juice
description: To the Editor:

title: China's G.N.P. Up 9%
description: China's gross national product will exceed $270 billion this year, up 9 percent from 1986, the official New China News Agency said. Zheng Jiaheng, deputy director of the State Statistical Bureau, said in an interview earlier this week that industrial output increased 14.5 percent while agricultural output was up 4 percent. China's G.N.P. - a broad measure of the value of all goods and services produced in the country - is the eighth largest in the world, although the country remains one of the world's poorest nations because of its population of more than one billion people.

title: Children's Radio Show Is Canceled
description: ''Kids America,'' an award-winning nationally syndicated children's radio program, went off the air yesterday after nearly four years of live broadcasts that combined ''Sesame Street''-style teaching with the format of talk radio.

title: Soviet Urged To Rethink Pasternak
description: Yevgeny Yevtushenko has suggested that the 1958 Nobel Prize in Literature awarded to Boris Pasternak but rejected by him under intense pressure by the Soviet Government be posthumously restored.

title: Sexual Harassment Arrest on Jet
description: An Eastern Airlines jet made an unscheduled stop here Thursday so that officials could arrest a New Jersey passenger accused of making sexual advances to two airline attendants.

title: NASDAQ NATIONAL MARKET SYSTEM

Patents;
Anti-Snoring Device Applies Electric Shock
description: LEAD: Robert B. Crossley of Austin, Tex., a retired Air Force employee, was granted a patent this week for a behavior-modification device to deal with snoring, bruxism and apnea during sleep. Bruxism is the grinding of teeth and apnea is a temporary halt in breathing.

title: Stamford Comes Alive After Dark, Finally
description: A funny thing happened as the clock at the old Town Hall here struck midnight and ushered in the New Year. There were people on hand, more than 4,000 of them, to watch.

title: RIGHTS ADVOCATES AND U.S. CONDEMN SALVADOR AMNESTY
description: The United States Embassy and human rights advocates are strongly criticizing a blanket amnesty law here that has pardoned several gunmen accused of killing Americans and Salvadorans civilians in recent years.

title: After 2 Years of Struggle, Ann Jillian's Story Is Told
description: Ann Jillian is not the first actress to play herself in a television dramatization of her life. But in preparing ''The Ann Jillian Story,'' an NBC-TV movie to be broadcast at 9 P.M. Monday, Ms. Jillian found herself embroiled in conflicts with her producers - disagreements that grew from her unusual double role as actress and as consultant on the authenticity of the script.

title: From Poles' Ferment, a Socialist Party
description: The party's founding unfolded, amid police harassment, in three acts: the first in a garden house, the second in a cafe, the third in an apartment.

title: Quick-Buck Crowd Gives Wall St. a Black Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Killed by Burning Tree
description: A Christmas tree caught fire in the elevator of a Bronx apartment building yesterday, killing one teen-ager and critically injuring two others, fire officials said. They said the youths may have been playing with matches.

title: The Rally That Was: Gone, Almost Forgotten
description: Only a year ago, the stock market was cheering the longest string of day-to-day gains on record. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 13 consecutive days before falling back on Jan. 21. Indeed, from the year's opening session on Jan. 2 through the early spring the Dow stocks were bid higher and higher.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, JANUARY 2, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8, 24 A Salvadoran amnesty law has led to the release of several gunmen accused of killing American and Salvadoran civilians, the United States embassy and human rights activists in that country say. Page 1 Israeli soldiers were on alert in Gaza, Jerusalem and the West Bank to combat Palestinian attempts to commemorate the 23d anniversary of Yasir Arafat's first military operation against Israel. 1 In Egypt, hundreds of protesters chanting Islamic fundamentalist slogans were beaten by the police. The police also besieged others at Cairo's Al-Azhar mosque, witnesses said. 8 News analysis: The Soviet economy entered a new era as Moscow initiated a program under which workers are being asked to change their notion of work without having early rewards from years of economic experiments. 1 In televised New Year's greetings by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the Soviet and American people, Mr. Reagan told millions of Soviet viewers about freedoms unavailable in their country. 1 Britain suppressed information about the causes of a major nuclear accident, a fire at a British nuclear plant in 1957. The Prime Minister feared it would threaten cooperation with the United States, documents show. 3 In Cambodia, the Prime Minister has reassumed the position of Foreign Minister. The move by Prime Minister Hun Sen may affect the tentative peace process in that country. 24 A Bangkok hotel fire killed 13 people and injured 36 others. Some guests suffered injuries trying to jump from windows or rooftops, according to police and fire officials. 3 From Poles ferment, a socialist party 3 Tokyo journal: Wrestler fails to keep hold on an honorable past 4 Soviet halts jamming of broadcasts to Poland 5 Czechoslovak president lauds Soviet goals 6 NATIONAL 9-10, 44 Nobody, it seems, has enough time, according to market researchers and poll takers. The sense that there is too much to do is especially acute at this time of year. Yet people cannot seem to resist piling on more. 1 In Idaho, laws against harassment because of religion or race have been passed in communities surrounding the headquarters of a neo-Nazi sect. ''This community has been examining its conscience,'' one legislator said. 9 Philadelphia's police are improving but have ''not yet fully escaped the powerful pressures of the past that permit misconduct and result in lower standards of policing,'' a citizen's group said. 9 A California smoking ban on planes, trains and buses took effect, but at least two airlines ignored the law, saying superseding Federal regulations allowed smoking sections. 44 Gary Hart's 1988 campaign funds cannot be claimed by two of his creditors to satisfy debts from 1984, a Federal magistrate ruled, saying that the current campaign organization was a distinct legal entity from the 1984 organization. 9 A judge shortage poses a problem that is not likely to be resolved soon because of budget pressures, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said in a year-end report on the Federal judicary. The shortage is among both trial and appellate judges. 10 A.H. Robins accepted a takeover bid from Sanofi of France. Sanofi will pay $600 million for 58 percent of Robins and will guarantee bank loans to a trust fund for women claiming injuries from the Dalkon Shield. 29 The PTL ministry's trustee will take action to recover what the Internal Revenue Service says is $9.36 million in excessive compensation paid to Jim and Tammy Bakker, an attorney for the trustee said. 9 A motor tied to superconductivity has been developed by scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory. It is the first electrical motor based on the properties of the material that conducts electricity with minimal resistance. 10 Dallas trash, from cans to bags 9 Monsignor accuses South Carolina Republicans of racism 10 REGIONAL 25-27 A Coliseum site development plan has been approved by the Koch administration. The new plan makes no reference to the height of the project, reduces its purchase price and places a new financial constraint on the developer. 1 In the schools chancellor battle, the president of the New York City Board of Education and the head of the teachers union moved closer in deciding who should hold the post. 1 News analysis: The chancellor's job is the focus in a battle over whether the person hired should be an outsider, unencumbered by existing loyalties, or an insider, someone steeped in the system's bureaucracy. 27 Chancellor candidate is perceived as teachers' ally 27 Despite a shortage of hospital beds in New York City, an average of 2,000 beds a day are occupied by patients who are medically ready for discharge and do not belong there, government and health care officials said. 25 Some defendants on New Year's Eve waited in a holding pen behind the courtroom of Judge Joel M. Goldberg, waiting to be arraigned. Judge Goldberg presides over the first and perhaps the most undesirable full court session of the year. 25 Noise and excitement in Stamford on New Year's Eve were the signs of the successful staging of a family-style, arts-oriented and alcohol-free celebration. More than 10,000 people attended. 25 Dreams and fears of the new year were expressed by New Yorkers on the first day of 1988. While some people said they had concrete plans for what they wanted to accomplish, others expressed anxiety about what the year would bring. 25 The first Democratic chief executive in Suffolk County in 16 years was inaugurated. At the hourlong ceremony, the chief executive, Patrick G. Halpin, described the county as an area ''on the edge of greatness.'' 27 About New York: Composer, at 75, gets his big break 25 Two officers find cache of guns and drugs in Queens house 26 Lawyers seek court order in Zibabwean child abuse case 27 Neediest Cases 28

title: New System For Trade
description: About 50 countries - but not the United States - began to use a new system today to track the thousands of items involved in world trade.

title:
Patents;
Modules Help Simplify Construction in Space
description: LEAD: Modules that can be connected to form a space station were patented this week for the Martin Marietta Corporation of Bethesda, Md. Patent 4,715,566 went to William O. Nobles of the company's plant in Littleton, Colo. Pyramid-shaped caps at both ends of the elongated modules are used for linkage.

title: Gains by Philadelphia Police Are Seen
description: A citizens' group overseeing attempts to improve the Philadelphia Police Department, long considered one of the worst in the country, says the department is making progress but ''has not yet fully escaped the powerful pressures of the past that permit misconduct and result in lower standards of policing.''

title: Mexico in Shift on Imports
description: Mexico has agreed to relax its restrictions on imports of steel, beer and wine, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said in a statement this week.

title: Florida Cleans House
description: Heads continue to roll at Florida after consecutive disappointing seasons, of 6-5 and 6-6 records. On the heels of the Gators' 20-16 loss to U.C.L.A. Christmas Day in the Aloha Bowl, Galen Hall, the head coch, dismissed Mike Heimerdinger, the wide receivers' coach, and three other coaches announced their resignations: Zaven Yaralian, defensive coordinator; Dan Coughlin and Ty Smith, defensive assistant coaches. All four were hired by the former Florida coach, Charley Pell.

title: Four Arrests In Taiwan
description: Four officials of a leading stock brokerage house have been arrested in connection with illegal margin loans that led to a default on payment of $750 million (Taiwan), or $26.3 million (United States) by a stock investor, police said.

title: '88 Yield Predictions Vary Widely
description: After a year of falling bond prices and volatile interest rates, the sports fans' ''wait till next year'' refrain is echoing through the credit markets.

title: Whether Swings Will Continue Is Uncertain
description: Although the stock market ended the year at about where it began, the last 12 months will go down as the most chaotic since World War II.

title: Jazz Fellowship Awarded
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced awards to three jazz musicians for contributions to ''jazz in the African-American tradition.''

title: Teachers Union, in Shift, Calls 3 Acceptable for Chancellor's Post
description: The president of the New York City Board of Education and the head of the teachers union moved closer yesterday in the political battle over who should be the next schools chancellor.

title: Time Runs Out for Peter Pan's Hospital
description: Time has caught up with Peter Pan, even in his native England.

title: Syracuse Sidesteps Criticism of Dye
description: Tim Vesling kicked the 38-yard field goal that put Syracuse ahead before Win Lyle's 30-yard field goal with 1 second remaining salvaged a 16-16 tie for Auburn in the Sugar Bowl today. But now Vesling and five of his Syracuse teammates were being asked in the Superdome's interview area for their reaction to Coach Pat Dye's decision to go for the tie instead of trying for a victory with a last-play pass from the 13-yard line.

title: A Breakthrough on Latin Debt
description: Mexico and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company have exploded the fiction that Latin America's $400 billion foreign debt can ever be fully paid off. After five dreary years of adding new debt just to pay interest on old debt, they present an alternative: partial debt forgiveness in exchange for a guarantee on the remainder. This novel deal does not end the problem; it begins to break it into manageable proportions.

title: Czechoslovak President Praises Soviet Goals
description: President Gustav Husak, who was replaced last month as Communist Party chief, praised innovation in Kremlin policies today but indicated that economic change in his country has not even begun.

title: Primaries After Conventions
description: LEAD: Let's reform our Presidential nominating process by putting primaries after - not before - the national party conventions.

title: Florida Citrus Bowl; Penn State Routed
description: Rodney Williams passed for 214 yards and Tracy Johnson scored three touchdowns today to lead Clemson to a 35-10 victory over Penn State in the Florida Citrus Bowl.

title: I.R.S. Action to Allow Spinoff of IC Rail Unit
description: IC Industries plans to spin off the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad into a separate company after it receives a favorable tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service, a company vice president, Bruce S. Chelberg, said this week.

title: Texas Star Sidelined
description: When Clarissa Davis, top-ranked Texas' all-America basketball player, came crashing down onto the court Tuesday night, badly injuring her left knee in the Orange Bowl Classic in Miami, her mother was listening to the game at a park about an hour south of San Antonio, where she and her husband had driven because that's where the reception was best. ''I was very relaxed,'' said the mother, Ann Davis Batey. ''My husband was hysterical. I felt she'd gone up like that many times before and been fine. You have to think that way when you don't know. You have to think positive until you find out otherwise.'' But Davis's junior year is already finished and her senior year, as well as an almost sure berth on the Olympic team, also are in jeopardy. She suffered ligament tears in the knee that will require an operation and 10 to 12 months of rehabilitation.

title: Santa Fe Files Plan For Rail Unit's Sale
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation filed papers with the Interstate Commerce Commission outlining its proposed sale of the Southern Pacific railroad to Rio Grande Industries, the I.C.C. said. The sale is subject to approval by the commission.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Metropolitan Report on Wednesday about the slaying of a public relations executive incorrectly referred to a merger between the Xerox Corporation and the C.I.T.

title: Ringing Out the Cans And Ringing in the Bags
description: The start of the new year means goodbye to battered curbside trash cans here, and many Dallasites are reluctant to see them go.

title: Regulators Oppose Bid By Seagram for Martell
description: The attempt by the Seagram Company of Montreal to acquire a controlling interest in the French cognac producer Martell & Compagnie has run into an obstacle from French regulators, raising the hopes of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of London, which has made a competing bid.

title: AULD LANG SYNE
description: WHILE hearing the last, fading refrain of that New Year's classic, Old Long Since (as some readers might have corrected the bonny Bobby Burns), we begin the annual look back on what has been written in this space.

title: ISRAEL PUTS ARMY ON STREET PATROL TO PREVENT RIOTS
description: The Israeli Army put hundreds of heavily armed troops onto the streets of Gaza, Jerusalem and the West Bank today, blocking Palestinian efforts to commemorate the 23d anniversary of Yasir Arafat's first military operation against Israel.

title: 2 Airlines Reject Smoking Ban On California Law's First Day
description: A law banning smoking on commercial plane, train and bus trips in California took effect today, but at least two airlines ignored the law, saying superseding Federal regulations allowed smoking sections.

title: Eagles Set to Fly in Face of Expectations
description: When someone suggested recently that Boston College's basketball program was stuck in a downward spiral, Jim O'Brien, the school's second-year coach, insisted that the Eagles' fortunes could change sooner than people thought.

title: Crystal Balls Are Murky, at Best
description: So, is the bull market over? Was that the message of last October's stock market collapse? Did the long bull market in stocks finally exhaust itself, after more than five years?

title: Your Money; The Strategy Of Overwriting
description: DR. CHARLES ALLEN, a physician in Palm Springs, Calif., has been using an options strategy called overwriting for about two years. Even following the enormous market meltdown in October, he has continued to participate in the investment program.

title: Kabul Reports Besieged City Receives 3d Supply Convoy
description: A third convoy carrying supplies arrived today in Khost, the southeastern Afghanistan city where Government troops are besieged by Moslem guerrillas, the Kabul radio said.

title: The Audience as Obstacle
description: During a recent performance of ''Tamara'' at the Seventh Regiment Armory, on Park Avenue at 66th Street, a woman in the audience could not contain her feelings. When the character Emilia, a hot-tempered housemaid, kept silent after a proposal from Dante, the good-natured valet, the spectator cried: ''Marry him! Marry him!''

title: Three Are Held In Hong Kong
description: The former chairman of Hong Kong's stock exchange and two top aides were arrested today in connection with a investigation into suspected corruption. Ronald Li, the chairman, Jeffrey Sun, the former chief executive of the stock exchange, and Donald Tsang, the former head of the stock listing department, were arrested at their homes by the Independent Commission Against Corruption, the group said.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock and commodity markets, as well as banks, government offices and most businesses, were closed yesterday in observance of New Year's Day. Most foreign stock markets, including those in Tokyo and London, were also closed.

title: Candidate for Chancellor Is Seen as Teacher Ally
description: As Dr. Bernard R. Gifford presents his case to the Board of Education today on why the board members should appoint him schools chancellor, he will be strongly perceived as a candidate allied with the teachers union. It is a perception he questions.

title: New York Should Raise Supplemental Security
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Ministry to Seek Return Of $9.3 Million From Bakkers
description: The trustee for the PTL television ministry will take action to recover what the Internal Revenue Service says is $9.36 million in excessive compensation paid to Jim and Tammy Bakker, an attorney for the trustee said today.

title: Return of Boy Stayed by Judge In Abuse Case
description: A Federal judge last night stayed the return of a 9-year-old Zimbabwean foreign service officer's son to his home country, leaving him in foster care on Long Island until at least this morning.

title: Owens-Illinois Extends Offer
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. has extended its $774 million offer for a rival glass container maker, Brockway Inc., by three days, to next Thursday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 16.

title: Cambodia Foreign Ministry Shift May Affect Talks
description: In a move that may affect the tentative peace process in Cambodia, Prime Minister Hun Sen has also reassumed the position of Foreign Minister.

title: Washington Police Arrest 11 In Protest at Israeli Embassy
description: Eleven women were arrested today at a pro-Palestinian demonstration outside the Israeli Embassy, according to the District of Columbia police.

title: Guidepost; LUGGAGE ON BOARD
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ruled that air carriers must enforce limits on carry-on luggage on domestic and international flights beginning Jan. 1.

title: Iraq Says Its Warplanes Hit 2 Tankers Off Iran
description: Iraq said today its warplanes raided two tankers off the Iranian coast, opening 1988 the way it closed out the most damaging year for shipping in the 7-year-old Persian Gulf war.

title: Japanese Becoming a Force On Exchanges in Chicago
description: Chicago's futures exchanges have long had their eyes on the large financial markets of Japan. And now the Japanese are returning that interest.

title: 2 HART CREDITORS LOSE COURT RULING
description: A Federal magistrate in Denver has rejected an effort by two major creditors of Gary Hart's 1984 Presidential campaign to lay claim to money held by his 1988 campaign.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 2, 1988
description: Companies

title: Rainier Sells Unit
description: Rainier National Bank, whose $1.2 billion acquisition by the Security Pacific Corporation became final three months ago, said it had agreed to sell its leasing operation to a unit of the First City Trust Company of Vancouver, British Columbia. Terms were not disclosed. The operation has assets of $160 million and in the first nine months of 1987 earned $2.2 million. The sale of Rainier Leasing Inc. is part of the Seattle-based bank's disposal of operations that have become redundant because of the combination of Rainier and Security Pacific businesses.

title: 14 Reported Killed by Sikhs
description: Fourteen people were killed in violence attributed to Sikh separatists over the New Year's holiday, the police said today. Sikh militants reportedly shot dead three people in Beas village today. In Amritsar the police found the bodies of two suspected extremists possibly killed by rival hardliners. And nine members of a Sikh family were killed Thursday near here.

title: Dorothy Bliss, Ex-Curator of Museum, Dies
description: Dorothy Elizabeth Bliss, a retired curator of the American Museum of Natural History, died of cancer last Saturday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. She was 71 years old and lived in Wakefield, R.I.

title: Shackles on City Prisoners, and Budgets
description: Justice Kenneth Shorter of the New York State Supreme Court rules properly that New York City's jailers don't have to shackle ailing prisoners in general population wards of city hospitals. The litigation makes clearer than ever the need to expand special hospital facilities for prisoners.

title: Bluebonnet Bowl; Longhorns Riddle Pitt's Highly-Respected Defense
description: It took Pittsburgh's defense one play, its first of the game, to know it was in for a rough evening against the Texas Longhorns in the Bluebonnet Bowl Thursday night.

title: Grown-Ups' Video Game Is a Mazelike Journey
description: In a darkened room on the third floor of the Kitchen, the experimental arts space on West 19th Street, sits a machine that resembles a futuristic piece of gymnasium equipment but is actually a video game for grown-ups. Two attached video monitors offer printed instructions to the player and an observer who stands to his left. Sitting directly in front of the smaller screen, the player, following instructions to touch the screen, sets in motion the continuing video collage known as ''The Erl King.''

title: Boy, 13, Is Dead of Rabies
description: Rabies caused the death of a 13-year-old boy, the first human in San Francisco to die of the rare disease in nearly half a century, health officials have reported. The victim, Michael Ancheta, died Dec. 15 but was not diagnosed as having the rare disease until several days later, according to the city's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control. The source of the bite that caused the rabies has not been determined.

title: October's Specter Lurks Over '88
description: The stock market opens the New Year under a shadow. The trauma of October has reintroduced the fear of losing money.

title: New Suffolk Executive Breaks With Tradition
description: Patrick G. Halpin, describing Suffolk County as an area ''on the edge of greatness,'' was inaugurated today as the county's first Democratic chief executive in 16 years.

title: KNICKS TAKE RISKS AND ROUT CLIPPERS
description: With Bill Cartwright and Patrick Ewing in foul trouble and the Knicks clinging to a 68-65 advantage with 4 minutes 40 seconds remaining in the third quarter last night, Coach Rick Pitino took a calculated risk. He played the 6-foot-9 1/2-inch Pat Cummings at center for the rest of the period.

title: Rehnquist Says Shortage of Judges Threatens to Clog Federal Courts
description: A shortage of trial and appellate judges poses a ''serious dilemma'' for the Federal courts that is not likely to be resolved soon because of budget pressures, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist says.

title: Syracuse Deprived Of Perfect Ending
description: From one cluster of reporters to another, Dick MacPherson, the Syracuse coach, moved about the basement corridors of the Superdome late this afternoon, closely guarding the Sugar Bowl championship trophy and his emotions as well. His team had left the field at the end of today's game unbeaten but unhappy, an eventuality that was simply not considered by MacPherson and his staff when they devised a game plan a month ago.

title:
Patents;
Chemical for Diagnosis Of Mental Ailments
description: LEAD: A chemical that can be injected into the body and scanned with X-rays for diagnosis of mental disease has been invented by two Georgetown University professors, Robert S. Ledley and Douglas M. Gersten. Patent 4,716,225, granted this week, is assigned to the university.

title: 2 Men Killed and 2 Wounded in Brooklyn
description: A store clerk and a bystander were killed and two other people were wounded yesterday when at least two armed robbers opened fire at a bodega in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: AMERICAN STOCK EXCHANGE ISSUES
description: AMEX VOLUME Total share volume on the American Stock Exchange for 1987. 1987 ........................ 3,505,950,000 1986 .................. 2,978,540,000 1985 ............. 2,100,860,000 1984 ....... 1,545,010,000 1983 ........... 2,081,270,000 MOST-ACTIVE AMEX ISSUES IN 1987 Only common stocks are listed; adjusted for stock splits (s).

title: 2 Officers Find Guns and Drugs In Queens Home
description: Two police officers patrolling a Queens street Thursday evening spotted a teen-ager with a gun in his hand, followed him inside a house and found a cache of automatic weapons, drugs and $5,000 that officials said appeared to belong to a major street narcotics ring.

title: To Keep Horses Alive and Wild
description: Early in this century two million wild horses roamed the American West. Human and wild predators reduced them to a mere 17,000 by 1971. Then the Federal Government stepped in with a law to protect wild horses and burros as vestiges of an older America. But like crop supports and rent control, this well-intended initiative produced unanticipated side effects.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: Who will win the playoffs? Who cares? BRIAN B. BOEHM Sea Cliff, N.Y.

title: Something New
description: FILL bird feeders daily. Put gift house plants in a cool, draft free location and keep soil moist. Move tender gesneriads, such as African violets, away from cool windows. From Catalogues

title: Olympic Challenge 'Distracts' Thompson
description: A HALF-HOUR before a recent game between Georgetown and Florida International in Miami, some fans in back of the Hoyas' bench unfurled a banner exhorting, of all things, the Syracuse University basketball team.

title: U.S. Is Asking Charitable Groups To Assist the Disabled in Vietnam
description: The United States has issued a report detailing Vietnam's need for charitable assistance and encouraging private organizations to provide the help.

title: CLAY AND GLASS: 2d CYCLE OF ARTS ANNUALS
description: ''CLAY AND GLASS,'' an exhibition now on view at the Montclair Art Museum, marks the beginning of the second cycle of ''New Jersey Arts Annuals.''

title: Doing Business, Doing Good
description: Recent insider trading scandals have again focused attention on violations of the law and of the code of business ethics. But which business leaders - and companies - are conducting themselves with the highest level of propriety? Business Forum editor Joel Kurtzman sampled the opinions of seven experts on business and ethics. ELLIOTT SCLAR; Elliott Sclar is chairman of the board of the Franklin Research and Development Corporation.

title: West Germans Are Moving to Center Stage, Reluctantly
description: THE long-dormant tectonic plates of European politics and economics have shifted again, much to the discomfort of West Germany. The changes have conspired to create pressure on the Government of Helmut Kohl to assume a role in the world commensurate with the country's economic and strategic importance - a position it has long been reluctant to accept.

title: A SURVIVAL HANDBOOK FOR THE NOVICE GRASS-ROOTS POLITICIAN
description: ELECTION Day has come and gone. And like a birthday when you are more than 40 years old, another one will be around sooner than you expect -or desire. For the intrepid, the politically committed or the just plain masochistic who are planning a grass-roots campaign this year, here is a guide to survival, based on first-hand experience.

title: La Guardia Statue: A Study in Action
description: THE question was which of two proposed statues best portrayed Fiorello H. La Guardia, New York's dynamic Mayor from 1934 to 1945:

title: Guinea-Bissau Tries to Deprogram a Popular Cult
description: From across this West African seaport, crowds converge daily on a modest tin-roofed house. Stevedores from the docks, smartly dressed office secretaries, market women with babies slung on their backs - they all come seeking medical advice from the ''Yank Yank.''

title: THE REWARDS OF A VISIT TO CHINA
description: LEAD: WHEN a group of 20 woodworkers and finishers of fine wood made arrangements nearly a year ago to spend a fortnight in the People's Republic of China in June 1987, ostensibly seeking answers to how the ancient Chinese made and finished classic Ming and Qing Dynasty furniture, they had no idea they would end up in the home of Wang

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ROOFING CEREMONY & THE SILVER LAKE. By August Strindberg. Translated by David Mel Paul and Margareta Paul. (University of Nebraska, $14.95.) In Sweden, August Strindberg's reputation is based as much on the innovative developments in his essays, voluminous experimental writings and dozen novels as on his drama.

title: SEX EDUCATION RAISES NEW CONCERN FOR SCHOOLS
description: LEAD: PUBLIC SCHOOLS in the county have thus far escaped the challenges to textbooks and reading lists brought recently by fundamentalist Christians in other parts of the country. But some local school officials say they fear a new form of censorship will surface in the county if religious groups try to control school sex-education and AI

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Week in Review on Dec. 20 about New York's Congressional delegation incorrectly traced the history of New Yorkers who have served on the Senate Finance Committee. Daniel Patrick Moynihan is the first Senator from New York to have served on that committee since the 1930's. Calvin Coolidge was from Massachusetts and never served in Congress.

title: Chicago's Grumpy Guru
description: GAZING OUT AT Chicago from the back of a cab on a rainy December night, I was stunned by the city's awesome sprawl.

title: MERYL STONE ENGAGED TO MICHAEL H. COHEN
description: Meryl Illene Stone and Michael Howard Cohen, executives at J. P. Morgan & Company in New York, plan to marry next summer.

title: DIANA L. CHANEY IS ENGAGED TO MARRY ANDREW KLAUSNER
description: The engagement of Diana Louise Chaney to Andrew Klausner has been announced by Babette Chaney of New Canaan, Conn., and William R. Chaney of New York, parents of the future bride. Mr. Klausner is a son of Dr. David Klausner of Cleveland and the late Audrey Klausner. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Trout Fisherman's New Zealand Haven
description: I RELEASED trout bigger than I had ever caught before. Then I hooked and lost trout bigger than that. And then I spooked trout still bigger.

title: U.S. and Angola: The Ties That Confound
description: UNITED STATES diplomats are expected to visit here later this month in a new attempt to break the impasse in Angola's 12-year civil war.

title: Between Palestinians and Israelis, a U.S. Role
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN, WITH ACCENT ON FRESHNESS
description: FRANCESCO'S is such an improvement over the restaurant that preceded it in its downtown Norwalk location, that one wishes it were doing better. On the nights of our visits, one of which was on a weekend, only a handful of tables were occupied.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Springfield, Mass.: Some Big Plans For Small Site
description: LEAD: A 28-STORY office condominium with some 120,000 square feet of space is being planned on a relatively small site in this city's compact downtown.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is hard to imagine a more positive or more hopeful beginning to 1988.'' - Alexander B. Trowbridge, president, National Association of Manufacturers, on U.S.-Canada trade agreement. [ 12:3. ]

title: One 'Crash' WOn't Scare Away Investors
description: LEAD: Recent forecasts by economists about near-term levels of economic activity draw heavily on psycological and sociological presuppositions. Pushed aside are economic theories of business cycles, or the stimulative effects of the declining exchange rate. Instead economists advance two propositions; first, an economic slowdown - possibly a recession - will be caused by a ''negative wealth effect.

title: STATE CRACKS DOWN ON KOSHER CHEATS
description: THE state's Division of Consumer Affairs is sending a clear message to kosher food cheaters that they face stiff penalties.

title: Missile Fire Inquiry
description: Investigators looking into an MX missile fire that killed five workers at a Morton Thiokol plant here are examining the possibility that static electricity may have ignited the blaze, a company official said. A 23-foot MX segment containing 100,000 pounds of solid propellant burst into flames Tuesday after the fuel had been poured into the rocket segment, Thiokol said. A company official declined to identify other possible causes under investigation.

title: MINNESOTAN AIMS TO BOOST FAITH OF CITY
description: Dr. Richard R. Green declared yesterday that his basic goals as the next schools chancellor of New York City would be to raise students' academic performance and to restore public confidence in the nation's largest school system.

title: Merle Evans Is Dead; Former Band Leader At Ringling Brothers
description: Merle Evans, the ''Toscanini of the Big Top'' who for 50 years thrilled crowds as he led the blaring band of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, died Thursday in Sarasota, Fla., the winter home of the circus. He was 96 years old.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE FITNESS BUSINESS
description: MILLIONS of Americans are mired this New Year's weekend in a slough of despond over the abuses to which they subjected their bodies during the holiday season. Fearing the worst, most will simply avoid bathroom scales for a week or two. But some will decide the time has finally come to get serious about physical fitness.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. We have a brick patio with a northern exposure, and there is a problem with mold and mildew forming on these bricks. We have to scrub them several times a year with bleach to remove the growth. Do you have any suggestions for preventing this growth?

title: Reagan's Search for New Year's Diplomatic Resolutions
description: PRESIDENT Reagan now has about a year left to work his will on international events, to shape his legacy. But, as he has certainly seen in the last seven years, the capacity to control world affairs from the Oval Office is sorely limited, and the prospects for dramatic accomplishments in the final period seem slim.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: Footsteps of Giants Pacific Arts Video. 46 minutes. $29.95.

title: Campo Colt Wins Flamingo
description: Johnny Campo and Jorge Velasquez, who teamed with Pleasant Colony to win the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes seven years ago, won the $250,000 Flamingo Stakes today at Hialeah Park with a son of Pleasant Colony named Cherokee Colony. The style of the colt's victory had the trainer and jockey thinking about the Derby roses again.

title: THEY UNCILIVIZED EACH OTHER
description: UNUSUAL COMPANY By Margaret Erhart. 225 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY
description: Rent Subsidies

title: Move Cardinals To Baltimore
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cutting Back
description: Rupert Murdoch, who appears to believe he cannot own too many communications companies, has been told that he does. Under temporary waivers from the Federal Communications Commission, the Australian-born publishing magnate has been allowed since 1986 to own The New York Post and The Boston Herald while simultaneously operating television stations in those cities. But, in a rider to a catchall spending bill that passed just before adjournment, Congress prohibited the F.C.C. from changing its cross-ownership rule, a move Mr. Murdoch had sought, and from extending any waivers to the rule.

title: ADVENTURE WAS WHAT SHE GOT
description: A TIME TO DANCE, NO TIME TO WEEP By Rumer Godden. Illustrated. 243 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: A NIGHT OF DANCE IN LAKEVILLE
description: CULTURE is alive and well in the Connecticut Berkshires.

title: MOLLY PARKMAN TO MARRY PRIEST
description: Mary Robinson Parkman, the director of St. Andrew's Nursery School and Kindergarten in Murray Hill, N.J., and the Rev. Alan C. French, the rector of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Murray Hill, plan to be married Feb. 13.

title: Reagan and Mulroney Sign Pact To Cut U.S.-Canada Trade Curbs
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada signed a landmark trade agreement yesterday that would eliminate tariffs and lower other barriers to trade and investment before the end of the century.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Earmuff Exalted In Maine's Chill

title: Nelson Hunt Honored
description: HE won the Hollywood Invitational with Rivlia, the San Juan Capistrano with Rosedale, the Sunset Handicap with Swink, the Laurel Futurity with Antigua, the Flamingo with Talinum, and the Santa Barbara and Santa Ana Handicaps with the 4-year-old mare Reloy. And when the victories were totaled up for the year, Nelson Bunker Hunt's horses had 323 of them, so it was no wonder that he was named the winner of the 1987 Eclipse Award as outstanding breeder. It is the third time he has received the award. He previously won in 1976 and 1985.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: AMERICAN BEAUTY. By C. J. Hribal. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) In a well-received collection of stories called ''Matty's Heart,'' C. J. Hribal introduced the people of the farming community of Augsbury, Wis. This novel, Mr. Hribal's first, is narrated by the granddaughter of that book's title character.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Things look good for TV-movie addicts early this new year, judging by the varied and well-slotted agenda that begins and ends the week.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. We have a brick patio with a northern exposure, and there is a problem with mold and mildew forming on these bricks. We have to scrub them several times a year with bleach to remove the growth. Do you have any suggestions for preventing this growth?

title:
DANCE;
HARLEM COMING TO MCCARTER
description: LEAD: THE Dance Theater of Harlem will begin its 1988 touring season with performances at the McCarter Theatre in Princeton on Friday, Saturday and next Sunday.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: WINTER CHAMBER SERIES There's nothing like good chamber music to chase away midwinter blues. At least, that's what the programmers at the Islip Arts Council suggest. So once again, the council has put together a series of free concerts for Sunday afternoons through March. This month, the musicians will make music at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale; in February and March, the activity moves to another Oakdale site, Fortunoff Hall on the Dowling College campus.

title: COCKNEY CHARISMA
description: I became hooked on Hoskins when I saw him in ''Flickers'' on Masterpiece Theater. Bob Hoskins does not have to concern himself unduly with people ''forgetting about him'' in a few years' time. He has been ''flavor-of-the-month'' with my family since 1982, and this predilection shows no sign of abating. KAY WALKER Brooklyn

title: Wearable Mandalas
description: REMEMBER the mandala? Remember the 60's? Mandala-painted beach cover-ups known as pareos may inspire good vibrations in the new year. These hand-painted five-foot squares of silk chiffon are the creations of David Picon, who lives and works on Saint-Barthelemy in the French West Indies, as well as in New York.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: BIGGEST MARKDOWNS ARE ON SOFAS Wim & Karen Scandinavian Furniture in Port Chester - and also in Manhattan - is having a nearly storewide sale of pieces for all rooms, area rugs and accessories through Jan. 16, not counting New Year's Day. The discounts on previous prices amount to 10 to 30 percent, and some of the merchandise represents samples and discontinued styles.

title: CHICAGO'S GRUMPY GURU
description: GAZING OUT AT Chicago from the back of a cab on a rainy December night, I was stunned by the city's awesome sprawl.

title: STAR WARS
description: In his article ''Star Wars Is Coming, but Where Is It Going?'' (Dec. 6), William J. Broad repeats a common fallacy: ''nuclear weapons cannot be uninvented.''

title: From the Ninth Hole To the Appeals Court
description: After a 22-year-old court battle over errant tee shots, the Quaboag Country Club in Monson has agreed to shorten its ninth hole in hopes of keeping golf balls off the property of John and Miriam Fenton.

title: Queens Theater Palace: Dark Tile and Dim Future for Boulevard
description: Seven Broadway theaters designed by Herbert J. Krapp were designated New York City landmarks in November. Another Krapp theater, the Boulevard, in Jackson Heights, Queens, was not. Altogether, eight interiors and six exteriors of Mr. Krapp's 15 Broadway palaces have been given landmark status. Meanwhile, the brick exterior of the Boulevard, at 82-28 Northern Boulevard, has been covered with brown tile. Now its owner plans to remove the seats and level the floor. An official at the Department of Buildings predicted the theater would be converted to retail space.

title: With Agnes Smedley in China
description: To the Editor:

title: LITERARY FEMINISM COMES OF AGE
description: In my years of undergraduate and graduate study of literature, I have yet to meet a student or professor who would disagree with the point made in Elizabeth Kolbert's article ''Literary Feminism Comes of Age'' (Dec. 6) that we have a legacy of neglected or forgotten female writers. However, sexual politics has less to do with who makes the course syllabus than do the practical constraints of the academic year.

title: NONFICTION
description: BELOW THE LINE. Living Poor in America. By Eugene Richards. (Consumers Union, Cloth, $32; Paper, $20.) People will be more concerned about poverty in America if they see its face up close. That appears to be the premise that inspired Eugene Richards, an award-winning photographer, to put together this book, a collection of photographs and interviews documenting the hardship endured by 21 of the nation's 32.4 million poor people. The interviews seem dull and dreary at first, but the voices of the poor ring out with piercing poignancy from some of the later pages: ''The day I sold the last of my livestock was probably the saddest day of my life,'' says an ex-farmer in Creighton, S.D. A woman in Douglas, Wyo., who supports a family by working night and day, says she is ''very ashamed of how I treated my life and my kids'' in earlier years. The photographs give a powerful impression of life in a shantytown on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, in a shack without electricity in Still House Hollow, Tenn., in a Chicago slum, or in Texas border towns. By neither romanticizing nor scorning the poor, the book breaks the stereotypes of poverty and portrays poor people as individuals. Rhoda H. Karpatkin, executive director of Consumers Union, says in an afterword that the book is ''our attempt to take the wrapping off America's most unacceptable product - poverty - and to reveal what it looks like and feels like.'' The book succeeds in achieving that difficult objective, though it does not offer much insight into the causes of poverty or means to alleviate it.

title: Quit Sabotaging The Arias Plan
description: The bankruptcy of United States policy in Nicaragua is worsened by the weakness of Congress in resisting that policy and by the trickery of the State Department in promoting it.

title: For the Retailers, A So-So Season
description: Retailers' Christmas sales were nothing to brag about, but the modest increases were enough to allay the worst fears of merchants. Gains were expected to average out to about 3 percent, which is really no gain at all when an inflation rate of more than 4 percent is factored in. But things could have been a lot worse in a year that saw a dizzying tumble in the stock market, and, in fact, the biggest sales gains came from affluent shoppers. Stores that catered to well-heeled customers had gains ranging from 8 to 12 percent, while more moderate-priced stores saw gains of less than 5 percent and some even had declines. Price-cutting was widespread, which will not help retailers' profits.

title: TRACEY SHEWMAKER WED IN MARYLAND
description: At Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Bethesda, Md., Tracey Lee Shewmaker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Shewmaker of Bethesda, was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph McCormick 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McCormick Jr. of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Buenos Aires. The Rev. H. Vernon Sattler performed the ceremony.

title: Art
description: Inadvertently, and without benefit of a major retrospective, this is an excellent time to view and review the achievement of Alexander Calder. At the Whitney Museum of American Art (945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, through Jan. 17), an exhibition of 14 works focuses on Calder's activities during the early 1930's. In these few years, after a revelatory visit to Mondrian's studio in 1930, the artist abandoned the animated wire sculpture often featuring acrobats and other circus scenes, that had earned him his initial reputation. (A prime example of this first phase, of course, is his late 20's ''Circus,'' permanently installed in the Whitney's lobby.) He moved rapidly to balancing acts of an entirely abstract nature, forging a singular alliance between the structural purity of Constructionism and the playful suggestiveness of Surrealism and making the first of his signatory ''mobiles'' and ''stabiles.''

title: Between Palestinians and Israelis, a U.S. Role; Healing in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: CALLING ALL VOICES Those who would like to become ''Messiah'' participants rather than ''Messiah'' spectators by the time Easter rolls around might get in touch with the Westchester Chorale. The community singing group directed by Daniel Paget is enlisting new members. Three evenings of auditions will be held weekly in conjuction with the first rehearsals of the new year, beginning at 7:45 P.M. Tuesday in Sacred Heart Church, at Ashford Avenue and Broadway in Dobbs Ferry. There are openings in all voice ranges.

title: Brainstorming Begins on a Cup Defender
description: Time is precious these days as planners for the San Diego Yacht Club scurry to come up with an innovative boat design for its America's Cup defense against New Zealand.

title: Islanders Triumph, Somehow
description: No one could quite describe how the goal was scored. Steve Konroyd bounced the puck into the zone, somehow it bounced back out in front of the net, and then without ceremony, Pat LaFontaine bounced it into the open goal.

title: Price Ends Maine Effort To Buy a Pristine Lake
description: The state of Maine has abandoned its effort to buy the land around Donnell Pond, one of 30 pristine north woods lakes that conservationists have been fighting to save from development, because it could not meet the developer's price.

title: U.S. Army Puts the New Foot Soldier Back on His Feet
description: ''THE strategic realities are now changing,'' said the briefing officer at the Training and Doctrine Command here, which does long-range thinking for the Army.

title: THE LOVER HAD A BROTHER
description: LIVES OF THE TWINS By Rosamond Smith. 236 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Covenant House Sells a Times Square Hotel
description: Covenant House, the shelter for runaway youths that hoped to build its endowment when it bought the Times Square Motor Hotel on West 43d Street three years ago, has sold the hotel to the New York International Hostel Corporation after operating it at a loss.

title: JANE MARIE FLYNN TO MARRY IN JULY
description: The engagement of Jane Marie Flynn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William F. X. Flynn of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Stanley Randall Silver, a son of Dr. Randall H. Silver of Auburn, Me., and Helen M. Silver of Medford, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: When Actors Beat the Odds They Face
description: I DO LIKE TO SEE A PERFORMER beat the system.

title: MARGARET HOLMES, A LAWYER, IS WED
description: Margaret Keller Holmes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Keller 3d of Ridgewood, N.J., and Donald Alan Sperling, a son of Mrs. Melville Tannenholz of New York and the late George Sperling, were married yesterday at the Anglers' Club of New York in Manhattan. Duncan A. Fraser Jr., a justice of the Garden City (L.I.) Village Court, performed the ceremony.

title: MISS MURPHY IS AFFIANCED
description: The engagement of Sheila Ann Murphy to Michael Maurice Azarian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Azarian of Andover, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Oldwick, N.J., and Groton Long Point, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: Keep Masters In New York
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: Thank you George Young and Bill Parcells for assembling a scab team that effectively turned the lights out on the Giants' season before the end of the baseball season. With their toughest adversary out of the picture, watch Washington take the whole shootin' match. PETER BLECHMAN Fishkill, N.Y.

title: GARDENING
description: The Great Plant Collections One Up Productions P.O. Box 410777 San Francisco, Calif. 94141 30 minutes. $34.95.

title: INSIDE
description: Hart Complicates Campaign Political professionals think Gary Hart will have a major influence on the Democratic Presidential race even if he does not prevail. Page 16. A Kidnapping Jolts India An abduction that forced India to release prisoners has stirred debate on dealing with extremists and focused attention on leftist radicals. Page 3.

title: WHOSE TOWN IS IT, ANYWAY?
description: I RECENTLY attended a performance of that hoary chestnut of the American theater, ''Our Town,'' at the Long Wharf in New Haven. The Thornton Wilder play had first performance a half century ago, on Jan. 22, 1938, but it remains a classic because of its timeless emphasis on the values of small-town life.

title: Soviet Sale Of Space Photos
description: WHEN the Soviet Union offered to sell to the public photos of the earth taken by its space satellites, the United States Geological Survey expressed keen interest.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Price Rises Due on Japanese Audio
description: THE SAD TRUTH THAT there is no free lunch is about to reassert itself in 1988. Looking ahead into the new year, audio fans are bracing themselves for steep and inevitable price increases.

title: Hawaiians Clean Up As Flooding Recedes
description: Flooding caused by torrential rain abated today on the eastern side of the island of Oahu, and most of the 2,800 evacuated residents returned home to clean up at least $29 million in damage.

title: Baltimore Policeman Is Held In Sales of Heroin by Phone
description: A police officer here has been charged with selling heroin over one of the department's emergency communications telephone lines, which include the 911 emergency number.

title: Next Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A New Medal Honors a Singer-Songwriter
description: LEAD: THE United States Mint is offering bronze duplicates of a gold medal honoring the late singer-songwriter Harry Chapin. The medal was presented last month to the honoree's wife, Sandy Chapin. Legislation authorizing the medal was passed by Congress in 1986. It recognized Mr. Chapin's efforts to eradicate world hunger.

title: Paris Is Still Kicking
description: LAURENCE FANON is backstage at the Lido, putting on her face. She's tall and lithe, her eyes are huge and run several depths of blue. Her father worked in the markets in the old Halles, she grew up in Montmartre, and now, lacing up her battered, steel-backed shoes, she's every inch the feisty, self-reliant Parisienne. As if born to the role, Laurence Fanon is among the very last dancers keeping alive what was once the very symbol of gay Paree, the cancan.

title: In Defense Of Brad Gilbert
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An Imaginary Office Learns to Cope
description: IT'S a brand new year here at the American Widget Works in Ludd, Tex., a ficticious company that we founded a few minutes ago (even though our motto is ''Serving Luddites Since 1982''). Widget Works is a small but growing company that designs, manufactures and distributes high-quality widgets to fine stores and airport souvenir stands.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE GLOW on the hilltop coalesced into headlights, high beams blazing. It took several seconds before the driver noticed the three dark figures lurking beside the roadside. As the car passed, we were treated to the glimpse of a startled male face.

title: State Dept. Awarded Custody Of African Boy in Abuse Case
description: A Federal judge awarded temporary custody of the 9-year-old son of a Zimbabwean diplomat to the State Department yesterday, apparently clearing the way for the child's return to Zimbabwe tomorrow.

title: MISS FRENZE WED TO J. P. DONAHUE
description: Jenifer Frenze, a lawyer in Philadelphia, and J. Philip Donahue, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University, were married yesterday at Old St. Mary's Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Edwin Sanders performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Boy Dies in Trash Compactor
description: A teen-ager was trapped inside a trash compactor and was crushed to death Friday while workers tried to rescue him. Michael Hucorne, 17 years old, was compacting trash in a large compactor behind a supermarket with another young employee when he became trapped. He was squeezed between the top of the compactor and a lower compacting level, the police said.

title: Travel Agents
description: To the Editor: Certainly, you need a travel agent. But Betsy Wade should not insult her readers. She says, ''Unless you enjoy doing jigsaw puzzles in solid colors,'' you should use a travel agent to put together an independent tour.

title: Film
description: Before the New Year and new attractions overwhelm the past, the opportunity exists in the post-holiday lull to catch up on some movies that arrived amid no great hoopla and boasted no big names but laid their claim to audiences with sheer excellence.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: The Giants! In a surprise Presidential action under the Football Powers Act, President Reagan decrees all strike games null and void. Computer programs conclude that the Giants would have won all their strike games, making them 9-6 for the year and a playoff qualifier. BRANDON DUNN New York

title: Admissions Jitters
description: A STRAIGHT-A high school senior in Connecticut's Fairfield County is caught with crib notes while taking a midyear test in history. Asked to explain himself, he responds, ''If I get a B, I won't get into Princeton.''

title:
FOOD;
HEAT WAVE
description: LEAD: THE POPULARITY of hot food in America in recent years has been phenomenal. Just a decade ago, the starred items on a Sichuan menu were avoided, and even the mention of peppery or chili-laced dishes could make one's eyes water. Today, it seems that no amount of heat is too formidable.

title: Blacks, to Jeers of Whites, Protest Racism in Brooklyn
description: Through a gantlet of residents, many of them screaming racial epithets, 450 blacks marched for three miles in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon to protest racial discrimination in the city and, in particular, the beating of two black men in the neighborhood last week.

title: AFTER SCHOOL, THEY'RE AT SCHOOL
description: LEAD: LAUREN WOLSKY, a third grader who lives in Selden, no longer feels like a piece of luggage, her father said.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: In this bizarre season, who else can win but the Saints? CHRIS LEAVEY Jamaica Estates, N.Y.

title: 'VIOLENCE IS THE ONLY WAY'
description: THE BAADER-MEINHOF GROUP The Inside Story of a Phenomenon. By Stefan Aust. Translated by Anthea Bell. Illustrated. 560 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: The Bodley Head/Salem House. $21.95.

title:
TELEVISION;
Laughs Are a Serious Business
description: LEAD: FOR A FEW LAUGHS, CALL Carroll Pratt. Literally.

title: GARDENING COPING WITH THE PROBLEMS OF WINTER
description: LEAD: ''AS the days begin to lengthen, winter, then, begins to strengthen,'' goes the old saying. Indeed, now that we have passed the shortest day of the year, we can expect the coldest, snowiest part of the winter to lie just ahead. Such weather often leads to plant problems, some of which can be prevented with minimal effort.

title: SAYING HELLO TO MY TEACHER OF THE 1940'S
description: ONE Sunday I paid a visit to my fifth-grade teacher, Sister Devota Maria, a nun I had't seen since 1945, when I graduated from St. Pascal Babylon School in St. Albans, New York City. It was the ending to a rather unplanned day.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THERE IS good news from the gypsy-moth front, and even better news for those who oppose chemical warfare.

title: Immigrants Give Thanks by Aiding Neediest
description: Growing up on Long Island during the Depression was not easy, Kjeld R. Eriksen recalls. When he was young, his father died and his mother, a Dane, had to raise her four American children.

title: WHEN A PARENT NEEDS A NURSING HOME
description: ''WE take care of our own'' was one of the family mottos I grew up with. And take care they did. My father supported his mother, my mother's parents and her two unmarried sisters. ''I married the whole damn family,'' he once said in a rare expression of feeling. Mother's sister, Bessie, submerged her life in order to care for her parents at home, through Grandma's broken hip and Grandpa's strokes. Throughout the seven years of my mother's illnesses, my father devoted himself to her care. All this was taken for granted in my family and seemed no act of special virtue.

title: MOVIES
description: Making Mr. Right Directed by Susan Seidelman. Starring Ann Magnuson and John Malkovich. 1987. HBO Video. 101 minutes. $79.95.

title: Dance
description: Martha Graham took on the gods and goddesses in her choreography, following which dance entered into a period of relative abstraction. A program this week suggests that myths and the subconscious may be becoming popular once more as a subject for dances. Marjorie Gamso, a postmodernist-era choreographer known for the resonant intensity of her dances, presents ''Her Thousand and One Nights'' at Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, Friday through next Sunday.

title: Pressure and Pride for Hebert
description: A CAJUN quarterback from a small town in Louisiana may not evoke the most flattering image in some of the more sophisticated towns around the National Football League. In New Orleans, however, the return of Bobby Hebert in 1985 was a cause for celebration, like discovering another oil field or returning from a fishing trip with the nets bulging.

title: In Historic Roslyn Village: Something New
description: In Roslyn Village, where residents stubbornly preserve what is old, 25 new homes will be built across the street from the Bryant Library, the proudest symbol of the village's past. The library, on East Broadway, contains the writings and memorabilia of William Cullen Bryant, publisher of The New York Post and the Nassau County port's most famous 19th-century resident. On an odd-shaped eight-acre site facing it, Irving Pergament, president of Prestige Properties and Development, has begun work on two four-bedroom houses that, when completed in the spring, will serve as models for 23 more build-to-order homes. The entire project is scheduled for occupancy by the early fall.

title: LATE-BREAKING NEWS ON THE WORDS WE USE
description: THE RANDOM HOUSE DICTIONARY OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE Second Edition, Unabridged. Edited by Stuart Berg Flexner with Leonore Crary Hauck. Illustrated. 2,478 pp. New York: Random House. $79.95. THIS outsize unabridged dictionary, the first in English in 20-odd years, weighs in at 12-plus pounds. It involved nine years' labor by 340 lexicographers and consultants, and its 2,500 pages contain 50,000 new words; 75,000 fresh definitions; Italian, French, Spanish and German dictionaries; prodigious, encyclopedic information; spankingly updated entries on high-tech jargon, trade names, Yiddishisms, biz-buzzwords, Valleygirlisms (''totally awesome'') and newspeak; a cornucopia of four-letter words and definitions of everything from ''boom box'' to ''rad'' and even ''glasnost.'' Aggressively priced and promoted, it is less a dictionary than a new hybrid, a blockbuster ''lexicopedia'' that records the dismayingly global conquest of American koine as written and spoken in the late 1980's.

title: Ethics Commission Pressed for Results
description: THE State Commission on Integrity in Government, barely a year old, is beginning a critical period that will very likely determine whether the New York City corruption scandals will prompt genuine reform in the business of politics or just another study to be filed and forgotten.

title: What Microwave Mania Missed
description: WHEN Barbara Boynton and John Odom cook a holiday dinner, it is no slapdash affair. There is a huge goose, sausage- and-chestnut dressing, carrots, brussels sprouts, all kinds of traditional accoutrements. Cookware of every type comes into play - except one. There is not a piece of microwave cookware in sight. They have a microwave oven, but they never cook fancy foods in it. And they laugh at the idea of special cookware to reheat leftovers. ''I have earthenware things that work just fine,'' said Ms. Boynton, a 47-year-old editorial business manager.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
STATIONS
description: LEAD: CAN Westchester get some additional mileage from four abandoned parkway service stations?

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BRUBECK AND BRUBECK Four years ago, Darius Brubeck joined the music faculty of the University of Natal in South Africa to teach jazz. Since then, Durban has become a mecca for jazz buffs.

title: He Can Do More Than Just Pitch
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Yale Law Students Aid the Homeless By Preserving Low-Income Housing
description: A new corporation, just a few months old, is poised to play a big role in the New Haven housing boom. Its legal team includes some of the nation's finest tax, finance and real-estate lawyers - a pool of talent that the largest companies in the world would covet. On paper, this is a corporation to watch.

title: The Clarinet Returns to Jazz
description: JAZZ CLARINETISTS, A RARE breed since the 1940's, are making a comeback. Two recently released albums, ''Southern Bells'' by the Clarinet Summit and Hamiet Bluiett's ''The Clarinet Family,'' both Polygram imports on the Black Saint label, document the work of no less than 12 contemporary jazz clarinetists.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: San Francisco will get it done. The 49ers are the team on a roll. But the playoff structure would be different without the three replacement games. Also, since the draft is determined by final record, the replacement games will change the draft order, in turn affecting future team quality. These unfortunate facts cloud the Niners' run at the title. CRAIG O'BRIEN Stamford, Conn.

title: RELIEF, CAUTION AND DISAPPOINTMENT GREET CHOICE FOR SCHOOLS CHANCELLOR
description: The choice of a new schools chancellor for New York City yesterday brought statements of support from politicians and educators who said they hoped Dr. Richard R. Green could soon begin to revive an ailing schools system.

title: HUNGERING FOR A CREDIBLE GODDESS
description: REINVENTING EVE Modern Woman in Search of Herself. By Kim Chernin. 191 pp. New York: Times Books. $16.95. ONCE I had a fantasy about the Virgin Mary. When the angel Gabriel announced that Mary would bear a son - a very special boy - she thought it over and said, ''No.'' Gabriel couldn't believe his ears, so Mary repeated, ''No. I'm holding out for a daughter.''

title: Prospects
description: Global Competition

title: ARTIST PUTS MEMORIES OF VIETNAM ON CANVAS
description: FOR 20 years, Richard Chamberlain did not speak of his experiences as a United States Marine during the Vietnam War. This week, he will preside at the opening of an exhibit of 40 of his paintings that deal with the year he spent in Vietnam.

title: Gephardt Jet Loses Pressure
description: A United Airlines jet carrying Representative Richard A. Gephardt suddenly lost cabin pressure today, forcing passengers to use oxygen masks and the pilot to return to O'Hare International Airport here. The Missouri Democrat and several members of his Presidential campaign staff were among the 37 passengers and five crew members on United Flight 401 from Chicago to Omaha. No one was hurt.

title: KEYNESIAN CRUSADER: Robert Eisner; Why Not a Bigger Budget Deficit?
description: AMONG economists, Robert Eisner stands out as the man who loves the Federal budget deficit.

title: About Men; Out of Depression
description: THOUGH I HAD PERENNIALLY felt anxiety during midwinter's failing light, the nadir of my depression came the spring I contemplated killing myself. That was nearly two years ago. Exhausted from insomnia and unable to function, I left my job before noon one day and went home to the suburbs.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: The 49ers appear to be headed for a Super Bowl berth. The most important factor is their defensive unit.

title: A FAVORITE OF BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: MARIO RESTAURANT on Motor Parkway in Hauppauge is at the epicenter of the fastest-growing business and industrial complex on Long Island. Restaurants have blossomed along the parkway in response to this burgeoning business community. Mario, now seven years old, was one of the first. It has retained its early popularity and tops many a businessman's list of favorite dining spots.

title: The Parents' Place: Right in the School
description: EARLY ONE brisk autumn morning, just as the school buses were beginning to roll, three members of the Parent Team, part of School District One in New York City, jumped into a four-door sedan and sped off to Public School 188. After stopping briefly to check in with the principal, they charged up five flights of stairs and burst into the computer room where they found exactly what they were looking for: parents and students learning how to run computer programs - together.

title: Two Commemoratives to Celebrate Statehood
description: THE United States Postal Service will release two statehood issues in the next six days. A Georgia statehood commemorative will be released Wednesday, to be followed Saturday by a Connecticut statehood commemorative. Both stamps are part of a series of 13. The series began last July with a Delaware issue to celebrate the bicentennial of that state's ratification of the United States Constitution.

title: Sports of The Times; The Saints Raise the Roof
description: UNTIL these New Orleans Saints emerged as a wild card, their predecessors were jokers. They once had a 1-15 season. They laughed about leading the National Football League in interim coaches. They had an astronaut as a general manager and the owner's bodyguard as a chief administrator. They had a running back who weighed less than their sideline mascot, a St. Bernard dog named Gumbo. But the quarterback who deserved better than to suffer with all those sorry teams, Archie Manning, always dreamed that someday purgatory would end.

title: EDUCATION BOARD WILL NAME GREEN AS SCHOOLS HEAD
description: The New York City Board of Education yesterday agreed, 4 to 3, to name Dr. Richard R. Green as the next schools chancellor. Dr. Green is the Superintendent of Schools in Minneapolis.

title: TV Sports; Bowl Coverage Offered Too Much of a Good Thing
description: IN the end, the winner was Overload.

title: PAMELA MARGARET DAVIS, ARTIST, MARRIES PHYSICIST
description: Pamela Margaret Davis, an artist, and Steven A. Kivelson, an associate professor and a theoretical physicist at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., were married in San Francisco yesterday. Rabbi Robert Kirschner performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. S. Marshall Kempner.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: The San Francisco 49ers will win easily. Montana and Rice are the best quarterback-receiver duet in the league. JON GELB New York

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
North Conway, N.H.: Scaling Back Rapid Growth
description: LEAD: THE turmoil in the stock market has caused some developers and would-be buyers to reconsider their plans to invest here.

title: On the High Price of Awards for Innovation
description: CHOREOGRAPHERS NEED more than ideas. They need time, dancers, rehearsal space - and money. Therefore, any attempt to help choreographers is welcome. Yet, with help may come unwelcome complications.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FAMILY FEELING. By Judith Saxton. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) ''Family Feeling'' is the kind of expansive historical novel one lives in as much as reads, absorbed in the lively narrative, rooting for its characters' reunion, tolerating the fortuitous plot twists that lead inevitably to a happy and harmonious end.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT;
ATTACKING A CENTRAL PROBLEM: PARKING
description: LEAD: THINGS change slowly on a college campus. The students come and go, but the ivy-covered halls remain pretty much the same.

title: BRIDES OF THE REICH
description: MOTHERS IN THE FATHERLAND Women, the Family, and Nazi Politics. By Claudia Koonz. Illustrated. 556 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $25.

title: AN ANTI-DRUG AD UPSETS NEW BRITAIN
description: AFTER suffering municipal corruption and a failing economy, New Britain is undergoing a rejuvenation. A highlight was President Reagan's visit to the city last July, in which he cited New Britain as an example of a remarkable economic comeback.

title: Gore Receives 2 Endorsements From Carolina
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr., who has staked his Presidential campaign on the support of the South, picked up two political prizes in North Carolina today, winning the endorsements of Senator Terry Sanford and former Gov. Jim Hunt.

title: American Oasis At Harry's Bar
description: IN the first weeks after the liberation of Paris in 1944 an odd game of hide-and-seek involved the more intellectual American G.I.'s on leave there and Jean-Paul Sartre. Highly literate soldiers made a practice of visiting the Cafe Deux Magots on the Left Bank of the Seine in search of Sartre, who was an habitue. But for the most part they never found him.
