He and his companion, Simone de Beauvoir, were over on the Right Bank at Harry's New York Bar, hoping to observe G.I. Joe in his native habitat.

title: IT STILL AIN'T BROKE
description: ONCE again this great nation of ours has avoided a major schism. The center has held. E pluribus unum and all that.

title: Where History's Been the Last 50 Years
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: A POSITIVE attitude is synonymous with the new year. The two go together like bagels and lox, corned beef and cabbage, toasts and champagne. The only difference is that unlike the other pairings, the positive attitude and the new year don't stay married for long. They separate after the first few days and there's usually a divorce within the month.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
CHICAGO TRIES CALCULATOR SOLUTION
description: LEAD: THE largest-scale use of calculators by any school system in the nation began last month when the Chicago public schools started issuing the hand-held devices to 167,000 pupils in the fourth through eighth grades.

title: JESSICA LEE STEDMAN IS WED TO ANDREW J. GUFF JR.
description: Jessica Lee Stedman and Andrew Joseph Guff Jr. were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan by Msgr. John V. Bartos, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Bending Minds as Well as Muscles
description: THE early weeks of January are golden times for the health spa industry, as thousands of flabbed-out, stressed-out Americans seek a quick fix.

title: Commercial Property: The Teleport; Moving Ahead Off the Beaten Path in Staten Island
description: Within the Teleport, a 100-acre telecommunications and office project on Staten Island that has faced many skeptics and many setbacks, workers are preparing sites for three office buildings expected to open this year.

title: Dukakis Vows Push on Health
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, stung by the refusal of Statehouse leaders to take up a universal health insurance bill in the waning days of the 1987 session, pledged Wednesday to bring the measure back next session.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Dec. 19 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village #1.1 million 17 Grove/100 Bedford Streets 4-bedroom, 3-bath, single family, 3-story, 1822, Federal frame house and 2-bedroom, 2-bath, single family, 2-story, 1833, frame house on adjoining lots, sold to same buyer; large kitchen, dining room, central chimney and 6 fireplaces on Grove Street; dining room large kitchen, on Bedford; landmark district; taxes $7,275 combined (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Greenwich Village $210,000 3 Sheridan Square 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,250-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, 9 closets, 2 exposures; maintenance $822, 59% tax-deductible (Broker: Weichert Realty) Greenwich Village $115,000 101 West 12th Street (The John Adam) 500-sq.-ft. postwar studio co-op; 24-hr. doorman, separate dressing area, renovated kitchen, c/a; maintenance $459, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Buchbinder & Warren) Upper West Side $385,000 176 West 87th Street 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, co-op in a prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, formal dining room, large kitchen, maid's room; maintenace $800, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Upper West Side $184,000 225 Central Park West (The Alden) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, large kitchen; maintenance, $650, 70% tax-deductible (Broker: Olshan Realty) BRONX Riverdale $195,000 3530 Henry Hudson Parkway (Parkway House) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,150-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, large kitchen, terrace, Hudson River view; maintenance $597, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Stephen Eldridge Realty) Wakefield $205,000 1479 Burke Avenue 2-family, brick, semiattached house; 3 bedrooms, dining area in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, large kitchens in both; basement, porch, 1-car attached garage, 25- by 100-ft, lot; taxes $1,467 (Broker: Albert R. Bryant) BROOKLYN Bedford-Stuyvesant $85,000 19 MacDonough Street 3-family, 4-story, attached, brownstone; 3 bedrooms, dining room in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in others; 1 bath in each; full cellar, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,000 (Broker: Century 21/Joseph T. King) Fort Greene $176,500 58 South Portland Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq-ft. co-op in a 5-story brownstone; dining area, marble mantels, original moldings and details, fireplace, rear garden, historic district; maintenance $364, 46% tax-deductible (Broker: Barbara D'Erasmo) QUEENS Forest Hills $74,000 110-20 71st Avenue (Majestic) 475-sq.-ft. postwar studio co-op; 24-hr. doorman, seperate dressing area, hardwood floors; maintenance $220, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Nu-Place Realty) Neponsit $685,000 195 Beach 147th Street 5-bedroom, 4-bath, single family, detached, Center Hall Colonial; formal dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, 1-car attached garage, 100- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $3,500 (Broker: Mitchnick-Kramberg) STATEN ISLAND St. George $80,000 50 Fort Place 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,033-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining area, parquet floors, optional garden plot, optional garage space; maintenance $442, includes utilities, 36% tax-deductible (Broker: J.P. Walsh) Willowbrook $152,000 28 Oakville Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2-year-old single family, attached house; formal dining room, large kitchen, utility room, attached garage, gas, hot water heat, 14- by 105-ft. lot; taxes $1,675 (Broker: Kingsley Real Estate)

title: G. C. BRINK, EXECUTIVE, IS MARRIED TO JILL RUNDLE
description: Jill Chaffee Rundle, a daughter of Joan Rundle of Southport, Conn., and Walter Clemo Rundle Jr. of Eustis, Fla., was married in Dorset, Vt., yesterday to G. Christopher Brink, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. L. Brink of Coraopolis, Pa. The Rev. Hal C. Miller 3d performed the Congregational ceremony at the United Church of Dorset.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Middlebury, Vt.: Historic House Is Resurrected
description: LEAD: WHEN Gamaliel Painter wanted a new house, he built it on a rise from which he could see the entire town of Middlebury.

title: Artists' Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tempered Skyline Strengthens a City of Steel
description: THIS IS THE ONLY CITY IN America with an entrance. You slide and slither into most downtowns, passing through gradual layers of ever-more-intensely built-up sprawl, and you do not so much enter the center as realize after you are there that it is all around you. Not Pittsburgh. Pittsburgh is entered with glory and drama. If you come to Pittsburgh from the airport, you do not see the city as you approach it. You see hills and valleys and the minutiae of suburbia, but no city. Suddenly the expressway dives into a tunnel through Mount Washington - and on the other side, revealed all at once, is a skyline of striking power.

title: Exploring Puerto Rico From the Ground Down
description: PUERTO RICO'S beaches, historic fortresses, rain forest and charming old capital have long been lures for visitors. But its newest point of interest isn't new at all. It is a prehistoric network of caves with an underground river running through it, a hidden, wondrous world in the depths of the earth.

title: POLICE TAKE SIMPLE APPROACH IN TEST FOR DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: A simple test for drunkenness while driving, introduced by the Federal Government four years ago, is being praised by police officials across the country. However, a few officers find difficulty in its simplicity, which involves checking the suspect's gaze.

title: MEDICARE BENEFITS: ERRONEOUS ASSUMPTION

IN SHORT;
FICTION

Barlow is a psychotherapist, a ''leading couples-and-family man'' with a lucrative practice in Tower Village, the Chicago high-rise where he also lives.

Ceremsak of Hamilton, Mass., to F. George Davitt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Alan Davitt of Delmar, N.Y. The Rev. John Costello performed the ceremony.

title: HILLARY SHARON ALPERT MARRIES RICHARD WOLF
description: The marriage of Hillary Sharon Alpert, the daughter of Susan Nacey and Lewis Alpert, both of New York, to Richard Hilary Wolf, the son of Margret Hirschberg of Paramus, N.J., and Dr. Robert Wolf of New York, took place last evening at the East River Yacht Club in New York. Cantor David Benedict officiated. Andrea Silverschein was the bride's matron of honor, and Jeffrey Alpert, the bride's brother, was the best man.

title:
ART;
TREASURES FROM MEXICO
description: LEAD: AS we approach the 500th anniversary of the discovery of the Americas, we can expect a number of presentations intended to celebrate the civilizations found by the late 15th- and early 16th-century explorers. The Metropolitan Museum of Art, for example, plans a 1990 exhibition, ''The Arts of Mexico,'' that will be the largest treatment of the subject ever mounted in the United

title: NONFICTION
description: THE NEW SEASON: A Spectator's Guide to the 1988 Election. By George F. Will. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) In this eclectic and engaging smorgasbord of bons mots, statistics, anecdotes and epigrams, one source crashes George F. Will's buffet line twice. ''This ain't a football game. We do this every day,'' Earl Weaver, former manager of the Baltimore Orioles, says about baseball. To this, Mr. Will, the noted conservative political columnist and commentator, adds that, ''Baseball's best teams lose about 65 times a season. It is not a game you can play with your teeth clenched.'' So it is with politics. The author says he hopes to ''defend the dignity, the gravity, the seriousness of the political vocation,'' but in analyzing the rituals of elections and forecasting how they will be played out in 1988, he calls upon wry, mordant commentators: Oliver Wendell Holmes, Max Beerbohm, John Maynard Keynes, Mark Twain and William Shakespeare. The book's three chapters cover President Reagan and the two major parties, about whom Mr. Will's biases are plain. Most Democrats, he suggests, must regard their recent Presidential nominees the way Earl Weaver regarded umpires when he shouted, ''Are you gonna get any better, or is this it?'' Not surprisingly, Mr. Will places his bets on Republicans and advises them on such issues as arms control, which he persists in opposing as ''the central drain on executive energies.'' On most other issues, Mr. Will is happier when no candidate is ''to the left of the fish fork or to the right of the soup spoon'' and when ''politics takes place between the 40-yard lines.'' He is serious about politics but makes a convincing case that, ''All American elections are entertaining. They, like baseball, are only dull to the dull.''

title: Santayana Might Have Flunked the Exam
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FALLING THROUGH SPACE: The Journals of Ellen Gilchrist. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) When Ellen Gilchrist comes on National Public Radio with anecdotes from her life as a writer and grandmother, her three-minute monologues make a nice break from geopolitical and athletic affairs. It's pleasant to hear her praise the depth of the topsoil in her native Mississippi; celebrate breakthroughs in her writing; feel melancholy about Christmas; advise us to cultivate disorder as a path to spontaneity.

title: FICTION
description: NORTH OF YESTERDAY: Or, Flowers of Waz. By Thomas McEvilley. (McPherson, Cloth, $20; Paper, $10.) Can we fault the art critic Thomas McEvilley for the preposterous ambition of ''North of Yesterday''? He flings together the quick and the dead, urban derelicts and characters dreamed up (literally) from an anecdote of Herodotus, and indulges in an orgy of mythologizing - not to mention a mythologizing of orgy. But if in this novel Quintus of Smyrna (fourth century A.D.) strolls the mean streets, if a dope addict sorts out Cheops' family tree with a centuries-dead pimp and whore, did Leopold Bloom really do less? Can't Joyce serve as a precedent for a novel inflated from a scrap of plot? For logorrhea? Couldn't we look to Lawrence as the great original of eroticism reeling with its own lyric impulse, and bugger our bourgeois decorum? (''North of Yesterday'' frequently details, for example, episodes of carnal knowledge between a drugged woman and a . . . walrus.) Didn't Djuna Barnes's ''Nightwood'' assemble a crazy cast and set them to philosophizing in brittle, opaque images and lapidary prose? Wasn't Walt Whitman, in ''The Sleepers,'' a dream journeyman, chanting his intense sojourn through the city suspended? All these and more Mr. McEvilley dares. The phantasmagoria, the quirks of style, the relentless duplication of motif - all might be accommodated if ''North of Yesterday'' were not so badly written. Fewer than a dozen sentences in the novel fail to give pain. Doggerel interlards the prose. The author's clumsy and tasteless language would hardly support a slight fictional structure; but his model is the pyramid of Cheops, and the collapse is complete.

title: 22 Are Killed in Raid on Mozambique Train
description: At least 22 people were killed last week when a group of right-wing guerrillas derailed and plundered a train packed with migrant workers returning from South Africa, the national press agency reported today.

title: Streetscapes: The West Side Improvement; On the Lower West Side, Fate Of Old Rail Line Is Undecided
description: IT was hailed in its time, but now the West Side Improvement is to some an awful blight and to others a magnificent opportunity. The elevated railroad, completed in 1934, snakes around and even through industrial buildings on the Lower West Side of Manhattan. It will either be demolished or returned to service, depending on the outcome of litigation that began in 1985.

title: WENDY SNOW IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Snow of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Sheridan Snow to J. Christopher O'Keeffe, a son of Vera Ann O'Keeffe of New Vernon, N.J., and John O'Keeffe of Sea Girt, N.J. Miss Snow, a graduate of Lynchburg College, is an administrative assistant at Executive Health Examiners in New York. Her fiance, a project manager for the Wm. Blanchard Company, a commercial builder in Springfield, N.J., graduated from Denison University.

title: Corrupt Conference
description: The Senate Ethics Committee can no longer close its eyes to the political fixes that have been infecting the closed-door Senate-House conferences.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE DUTCH LEGACY: WORTH EXAMINING
description: LEAD: NOT ALL of New Jersey's history has been plumbed by scholars or presented to schoolchildren. Some puzzling questions defy obvious answers, and sufficient intriguing sidelights remain to occupy the interest of even the idly curious.

title: How Art Springs Forth From Broken Windows
description: In the 1970's, when windows started popping out of the tall, sleek but architecturally flawed John Hancock Tower, many Bostonians laughed at the developers' dilemma.

title: THE CONTINUATION OF POLITICS BY OTHER MEANS
description: OUT OF CONTROL The Story of the Reagan Administration's Secret War in Nicaragua, the Illegal Arms Pipeline, and the Contra Drug Connection. By Leslie Cockburn. 287 pp. New York: A Morgan Entrekin Book/ Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: WAR AND DROUGHT INFLICTING FAMINE IN SUDAN
description: Mass starvation is threatening refugees in Equatoria, a southern province of the Sudan, as rebels mine roads and prevent food convoys from reaching there.

title: Record Shops
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed touring the London record shops vicariously with Mr. Haber. I spend a lot of time in the jazz specialty shops every time I'm in London.

title: Israel Keeps Its Troops On Guard for Protests
description: The Israeli Army kept a heavy guard on the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today and only minor disturbances were reported.

title: Q&A
description: Visiting Cyprus

title: WALL: A TOWNSHIP OF MANY FACES
description: THIS Monmouth County township has a rich legacy waiting to be written about, including the settlement of its westernmost village (Allenwood) and at least two Revolutionary War heroes.

title: For Botha, What Price 'Peace' in South Africa?
description: PREDICTING the course of events in South Africa has always been a dismal science. Will it end in a bloody cataclysm, or will the country's leaders, black and white, renounce violence and reach an as yet improbable accommodation?

title: Player of the Year
description: AMONG top-ranked players, not one in a hundred is as active in bridge administration as he, or she, is at the card table. When one of these rare mortals achieves a major success, it is time to cheer for dedicated enthusiasm has received a fitting reward.

title: R. S. LINCOLN, STOCKBROKER, IS MARRIED TO ANITA CHILEN
description: Anita Marie Chilen, the president and a co-owner of Charles Sumner Inc., women's clothing stores in Boston and Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married yesterday at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill to Robin S. Lincoln, a stockbroker at Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day in Boston. The Rev. James Scholz officiated.

title: Is Canned Laughter a Joke?
description: IN THE INSULAR WORLD OF television comedy, something curious is happening: On a number of new shows, no one is laughing.

title: DISABLED CITE IMPROVED VAN SERVICE
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, Danny O. Schipf, a quadriplegic, and some of his friends at the Brandywine Nursing Home in Briarcliff Manor were far from happy with the county's special transportation system for the disabled. They complained that there were not enough vans running, that people were often bumped at the last minute from pickups that had been booked and that drivers were not particularly helpful.

title: Write It Down, Please
description: LEAD: DESPITE some students' wishful thinking, writing is unlikely to become obsolete. Indeed, the prevalence of word processors in an increasingly technology-oriented society is likely to encourage writing and make it more vital and necessary.

title: Mullin Belongs With the Knicks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JOE THE DEAD SEEKS IMMORTALITY
description: THE WESTERN LANDS By William S. Burroughs. 258 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: POETRY AND WORD PROCESSING: ONE OR THE OTHER, BUT NOT BOTH
description: I WANTED to learn something about word processors. ''The Word Processing Book'' by Peter A. McWilliams was recommended to me. It has all sorts of useful information: it tells students how, when they have bought a term paper, they may alter it with a word processor to suit their own ''personal style.'' ''If you're a drama major,'' Mr. McWilliams says, ''and are forced to write a paper on medieval French tapestry to fulfill some obscure university requirement, then I can see that spending several days researching such a paper would be counterproductive and may interfere with one's education.''

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SELVAGES & BIASES: The Fabric of History in American Culture. By Michael Kammen. (Cornell University, $24.95.) The French historian Fernand Braudel wrote his classic work, ''The Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II,'' in a Nazi prison. Half a century later, suggests Michael Kammen in ''Selvages & Biases,'' historians would find it unimaginable to write history without computers and data bases and graduate research assistants.

title: Car Lynched on 10th Street
description: For residents of Manhattan's East 10th Street, Christmas this year meant turkeys, presents - and the burglar alarm on a fancy European sports car, which blasted off and wailed for four hours.

title: 5 YEARS OFF THE JOB BUT ON THE PAYROLL
description: LIEUT. FREDERIC SARGEANT of the Stamford Police Department fired one shot at a station wagon being driven by a burglary suspect as it bore down on him in the middle of a road. The bullet struck the door on the driver's side of the stationwagon, which contined on until the suspect was arrested a short while later.

title: JERSEY TAKES DRUG EFFORT INTO SCHOOLS
description: Last September, New Jersey's Attorney General received an urgent call from the Superintendent of the state police.

title: COCKNEY CHARISMA
description: I say ''bosh'' to William Boyd, and recommend that he keep his ears open while wandering around London (''Cockney Charisma,'' Dec. 6). ''Bosh'' is a Turkish colloquial interjection that has been around for years, at least since 1894, when George Bernard Shaw wrote ''Arms and the Man.'' Please see Act II, in which Maj. Paul Petkoff uses the expression to contradict his wife, Catherine.

title: Bronx Man, Thrown From Window, Dies; Teen-Agers Charged
description: A South Bronx man died after he was stabbed, beaten, handcuffed and then thrown out of an apartment window early yesterday, the police said.

title: ALLAIRE AIRPORT: BUMPY FLIGHT TO SUCCESS
description: A HALF-CENTURY ago, Edward I. Brown bought a 40-acre tract here in Monmouth County, a onetime gravel pit along the northern fringe of the Pine Barrens.

title: Rent Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Area Is Scarred By Arson and Sacrilege
description: A fire ignited by a time bomb that exploded in a Nativity scene in Cambridge is the latest in a series of arson cases at churches and religious settings in eastern Massachusetts.

title: IT'S TIME AGAIN TO REMOVE ALL THE TRAPPINGS OF CHRISTMAS
description: THE sixth of January. Call it what you will - The Feast of the Three Kings or Epiphany - but at our house it is the day to take down all the holiday trappings.

title: JENNIFER YOUNG IS WED TO PAUL D. SUNDMAN
description: The marriage of Jennifer Ann Young, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Calvin Young of Colorado Springs, to Paul Damian Sundman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sundman of West Hartford, Conn., took place yesterday at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Middleburg, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Mary Hansley, the rector. Mrs. Sundman, a graduate of Lewis and Clark College, is the membership program supervisor for the Friends of the National Zoo in Washington. Her father is an architect in Colorado Springs.

title: MOVIES
description: Losin' It With Tom Cruise, Shelley Long and Jackie Earle Haley. Directed by Curtis Hanson. 1982. Embassy/Nelson Entertainment. 100 minutes. $24.95.

title: DATA UPDATE
description: MEDIAN HOUSE PRICES

title: Guinea Frees Toure's Widow
description: Guinea's military rulers have quietly released the wife and a son of the late President, Ahmed Sekou Toure, from a detention camp here, relatives and a Government official said today. They said that Andree Toure and her son Mohamed were released Thursday. The two were sentenced to eight years' imprisonment for backing an attempted coup in 1985 against President Lansana Conte, who seized power in April 1984 after Mr. Toure died abroad.

title: TYING WELFARE TO SCHOOL ATTENDANCE
description: THE NATION'S first program that links welfare payments to students' attendance will start in Wisconsin on Feb. 1. The program, known as ''Learnfare,'' was passed at the urging of Gov. Tommy Thompson in what he described as an effort to discourage welfare dependency.

title: LITERARY FEMINISM COMES OF AGE
description: Feminist literary studies are a new thing on campuses, but they did not spring full-grown from the heads of the recent polemical feminists. For generations, well-read women have developed a chain of favorite authors, passed on by word-of-mouth. My mother was my link to the feminist literary past. She introduced me to such important and then neglected authors as Olive Schreiner, Elizabeth Gaskell and Maria Edgeworth. In turn, I brought her Etsu Sugimoto's memoir ''A Daughter of the Samurai,'' perhaps the first overtly feminist writing by a Japanese woman. It made me a feminist at age 11.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: In the A.F.C., Indianapolis and Houston lack experience. Seattle has the talent but is missing chemistry. Denver and Cleveland will play again for the title, but this time the Browns will win.

title: SARAH GILLILAND AND DANIEL P. LAWLER, AN ARCHITECT, ARE WED IN CONNECTICUT
description: Sarah Wheeler Gilliland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Gilliland of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Daniel Paul Lawler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Traugott Lawler of New Haven. The Rev. George Coxe Bland, a Congregational minister, and the Rev. Richard Russell, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

title: IRA J. SCHACTER IS WED TO JANICE LYNN LANDIS
description: At Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., Janice Lynn Landis, the daughter of Harriet Landis of Bellmore, L.I., was married last evening to Ira Jason Schacter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Schacter of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Saul Teplitz performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday about the new state law governing marine fishing licenses misstated the kind of fishermen to whom it would apply. The $100 annual license fee is required only for commercial fishermen who are state residents. Under the law, commercial fishermen are defined as those who sell one or more fish a year.

title: BITS AND PIECES INSPIRE FOLK ARTISTS
description: LEAD: GEORGE WELLS hooks detailed, intricately patterned rugs. Dick Gachot makes whimsical three-dimensional constructions with movable parts from ''found'' objects. Thomas Langan carves stately, lifelike birds of wood. Tom Malloy welds sculpture out of discarded farm implements.

title: Yanks Change Mortgage Policy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LEARNING THE RULES OF THE ROLES
description: IN these times of working marital partners and changing family roles, I find myself alienated by the machines and procedures involved in the labors that once were the responsibility of my wife.

title: The 13th Year: A Breather Before College
description: WHEN Jeanne Lorenz graduated from the Milwaukee High School for the Arts last spring, she had a scholarship to the University of Wisconsin, and she thought she was destined for college in the fall. Because she is the oldest of four children in a single-parent family, her mother was relieved that her daughter's higher education was being paid for.

title: Israeli Aircraft Attack South Lebanon Towns
description: Israeli helicopter gunships fired rockets today into two southern Lebanese villages held by guerrillas of the pro-Iranian Party of God, destroying houses, the state-run Beirut radio reported.

title: LOVE WITH A WHIFF OF THE K.G.B.
description: RED DOLL By Juan Luis Cebrian. Translated by Philip W. Silver. 162 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title: HONG KONG DETAINS 3 AT ITS EXCHANGE
description: The former chairman of Hong Kong's stock exchange and two former aides were detained and released on bail today by this British colony's anti-graft agency in connection with an investigation of suspected corruption.

title: Death Toll Climbs to 5 In a Shooting Rampage
description: A man wounded in a shooting rampage has died, bringing the death toll to five in the apparent drug-related episode that covered two cities.

title: INDIAN RESERVATION TO GET CLEAN WATER
description: FOR the 250 Indians on the Poospatuck Reservation on the Mastic-Shirley peninsula, clean water is finally on its way. With Federal money through the Clean Water Act of Suffolk County and community development funds from Brookhaven Town, the reservation will be hooked up to public water by spring - a project that will cost $170,000.

title: 100 NEW YORK FAMILIES TO GET DONATED FURNITURE
description: LEAD: One hundred homeless New York families, who are being moved into renovated city-owned apartments, will receive a gift from the Seaman's Furniture Company: bedroom and living room sets for their new homes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 3, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-15

title: TESTING GLASNOST
description: Though not an emigre, I, like Alex Goldfarb, am a biologist who has recently returned from a visit to a U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences Institute in Moscow, where I lectured and pursued a collaborative research project (financed by the United States National Science Foundation). I, too, went there to measure firsthand the consequences of glasnost.

title: Clean Air Deadline Is History
description: AFTER a series of extensions, the deadline set by Congress for cleaning up the air was to have been New Year's Eve. But more than a decade and a half after passage of the Clean Air Act, the effort is still best described by the words that were used at the beginning: long term. Just before Christmas, Congress approved legislation to extend the deadline to Aug. 31, 1988, postponing for eight months the next showdown between environmentalists and industry.

title:
ART;
COMPUTER IMAGING ON DISPLAY
description: LEAD: SINCE its Computer Imaging Center opened in September 1986, the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island in Hempstead has mounted a series of exhibitions devoted to the new and challenging art made possible by electronic technology. This year, the annual juried exhibition is devoted exclusively to computer art, with entrants' selections supplemented by a roughly equal number of works by invited artists.

title: OLD AND NOVEL
description: I believe I can aid Gary Jennings with the ancient word for getting ''bucked'' off a horse. I give him instead: equiabiciate. I recalled that reference from my high-school Latin toils with ''Caesar's Gallic Wars,'' wherein that Roman military genius sent a Gallic horseman with a message to Cicero, his general in the field. I read the original Latin to say: ''In delivering the message to Cicero, the spearbearing horseman was thrown (abiciat) from the horse (equi).

title: Phone Services Cut Back in Parts of New York
description: New technology has made the telephone more versatile. Calls can be dialed by simply pressing one button. People at three or more locations can speak at once. During a conversation, a beep signals that another call is waiting.

title: To Seacoasts, With Love
description: LEAD: HERE at the Sea Ranch hotel, on the north coast of California, a squall batters the windows and turns the Pacific vista into a diorama under antique glass, full of weird ripples and waves. Beside me, on the hearth, a fire crackles like an answering army; the air inside is crisp and consoling. In a few minutes, I will scoop up my parka from the sofa for a foray down to the wild water's edge.

title:
ART;
SOME JARRING IMAGES IN DOVER EXHIBITION
description: LEAD: PHOTOGRAPHY is counted among the fine arts, but it sometimes approaches being a craft. This has its virtues, but it also signals that different criteria have come to the fore. It means that there are ideals and standards, and that photographers attempt to meet these standards.

title: STATE BOARD TO VOTE ON SCHOOL AIDS POLICY
description: LEAD: THE State Board of Education is to vote this week whether children with AIDS should be taught in public schools with other students.

title: Mitterrand, in Survey, Outpoints All Comers
description: Two polls made public this week brought some good news for France's Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, and bad news for its conservative Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Shelly Manne Quartet Rhapsody Films. 28 minutes. $29.95.

title: End Paper; Minesweeping? Try Mindsweeping
description: ENGLISH COMP is the minesweeper of the educational fleet. There's absolutely no status in running such a class, or ship. Yet somehow the whole fleet looks very silly without it. The minesweeper clears away problems everybody else pretends are not there. It's time-consuming, hazardous duty. And if, when I'm done, there are only half as many mines - comma splices, sentence fragments and the like - have I succeeded? Well, at least I have kept the crude oil of Western thought flowing.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
NEW IMPORT: IRISH CATHOLIC TEACHERS
description: LEAD: NEARLY LOST amid the tons of electronic and automotive imports that flood into the United States each day is a commodity especially valuable to Catholic schools in the nation's urban areas: the hundreds of Irish teachers who are finding employment in American Catholic schools with a shortage of American instructors.

title: AMNESTY REQUESTS BY ALIENS DECLINE
description: The number of aliens applying for legal status under the new immigration law has dropped steadily in recent months, raising serious questions about whether the program will reach its envisioned total of two million applicants before it ends May 4.

title: Confessed Bandit From Harvard
description: ''By the way, I've done some armed robberies.''

title: HOT STUFF
description: DAVID CAMERON: AT THE END of his spring showing, the models led 26-year-old David Cameron across the stage. He had a big smile on his handsome face and for good reason: the audience was clapping, stamping and hollering approval of his highly shaded, sharply styled designs. After two years in business, Cameron is on his way to becoming a major American talent. His original designs are consistently well cut, and the finished line that he delivers to stores is very well made. His are not inexpensive designs, but he is developing a following among women who admire his way of stylish heightening of what are essentially sporty shapes. Just one Cameron jacket can put new verve and fashion into an existing wardrobe.

title: A Congressman, a Plane Ride and the Budget
description: Buried deep in the catchall spending bill passed by Congress are two pointed swipes at the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency. One virtually invites the Defense Secretary to slash the agency's personnel budget; the other takes away two aircraft used at embassies around the world to fly ambassadors, military attaches and visitors.

title: Introducing The 'Advid'
description: MAPLE SYRUP, knitting, a miniature bedroom, a novel, pottery, artwork, slides and photographs are among the supplementary materials sent by applicants these days to college admissions offices.

title: 102 Flee British Hotel Fire
description: Fire swept through the cabaret of the seafront Balmoral Hotel in Blackpool this morning, forcing 102 people from the Balmoral and a neighboring hotel, the Craigy Don, to flee. The police in this resort town on England's northwest coast said two people ill from smoke inhalation were treated at the scene. The Balmoral's cabaret was destroyed and 90 percent of the building sustained smoke damage, the spokesman said.

title: COMPUTER DELIVERED
description: There is a regular chorus of beeps and bleets emanating from one Mount Vernon home today -sounds reverberating in Bronxville and in New Rochelle.

title: NOW THE SEASON'S OVER, SETTLE FOR SOME LESS-WEIGHTY FARE
description: IS it time for the great retrenchment? The last crumbs of christmas fruitcake have been discarded, the holiday eggnog is now a memory and the bathroom scale's indicator is making the inevitable creep upward.

title: To the Victors
description: THERE'S NOT MUCH GOLD IN them, actually. According to International Olympic Committee regulations, the Olympic bronze medals shall be bronze, the silver medals silver, but each gold medal, weighing 193 grams in all, must contain just six grams of the stuff. Mostly, the golds are made of sterling silver, too.

title: THE SKY AS A TOOL FOR LEARNING
description: TO TRADITIONAL educators, the For Spacious Skies program might seem like castles in the air. But for Katie Masselam, a sixth-grader at the Pollard Middle School in Needham, Mass., the program was a new way of seeing - and speaking, writing and drawing about the world around her.

title: Limiting The Impact Of Progress
description: ONE of the delights of owning property along a back country road is the appearance of the road itself. Frequently, that road will be framed on either side by hand-built stone walls. It may be narrow and winding, allowing mature shade trees on either side to form a canopy across the middle.

title: Flying Fish
description: To the Editor: With apologies to Regina Schrambling (Fare of the Country, Nov. 15), by far the best flying fish and cou-cou in Barbados is made by Ada Lewis in Carrington Village, St. Michael. I order it ahead of time and have it waiting for me when I arrive.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: OWL MOON By Jane Yolen. Illustrated by John Schoenherr. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9) THE very best books for not-quite-reading children must be written to charm and astonish the adults who will read them aloud: thrill that reader, who will communicate those prickles at the nape of the neck, and you'll have created a desire in the young listener to learn how to read books alone. ''Owl Moon'' does this better than any new children's book I have seen in a long time. What's more, it does it simply and directly, without anthropomorphism or any other sort of cutesy-cleverness: It was late one winter night, long past my bedtime, when Pa and I went owling. There was no wind. The trees stood still as giant statues. And the moon was so bright the sky seemed to shine.

title: Alliance With Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Marimekko Changes Its Spots
description: THERE was never any doubt about what the inside label would say. The clothes and fabrics, with their striking design and splashes of bold color, were clearly Marimekko. But for people of a certain generation - those who came of age in the 1960's - they represented more than just a brand name: They conjured up an image and an era.

title: When TV Focuses On Itself
description: TELEVISION NEWS IS A RICH SUBJECT. IT IS SO big, so pervasive and, yes, so intrusive that you can't help but worry about it. A lot of people do worry about it. Academics write books and articles.

title: Harvard's Midlife Crisis Center
description: IT WAS the typical student scramble: Robert E. Vanasek pulled an all-nighter to finish his midterm in Political Management, went to class, and just half an hour before it was due, packed his knapsack and sneaked out to pick up the paper from the typist, barely making it back to class by the deadline. But after he turned it in, Mr. Vanasek boarded a plane for St. Paul to hold a news conference.

title: Hess Must Make Decisions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ART;
'CONTEMPORARY CUTOUTS' ON VIEW IN STAMFORD
description: LEAD: AT the Stamford branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art is a lively survey called ''Contemporary Cutouts,'' a phenomenon that, as its organizers point out, has its roots in Pop Art. At its most essential, the cutout boldly escapes the conventional confines of a frame and enters the viewer's space.

title: FINDING THE SECRETS OF A LONG LIFE
description: THE deed is done. Upon the doctor's insistence, we have placed my husband's stepmother in a nursing home near us.

title: MISS OUTERBRIDGE ENGAGED TO WED R. S. MCMENAMIN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Yeaton Duval Outerbridge of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Jamestown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Whipple Outerbridge, to Robert Stout McMenamin, the son of Ann Stout McMenamin of Philadelphia and the late John Francis McMenamin. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Teachers Lose at Boston University
description: Members of the faculty of Boston University have lost another round in their fight to prove they have less power than faculties at other schools.

title: Housing Bias Cited As U.S. Sues Agency In New Jersey Town
description: The Justice Department has filed suit against the Long Branch Housing Authority, charging the agency with discrimination and maintaining segregated apartment projects.

title: Meeting the Needs Of Adult Undergrads
description: ADULTS WHO decided to forgo undergraduate degrees in earlier years are now pursuing them in record numbers, and a growing number of colleges have stepped up their efforts to accommodate them.

title: HOME HEALTH-CARE REVISIONS SOUGHT
description: LEAD: THERE is an axiom on Capitol Hill that legislation cannot be too prescriptive - bills should mean what they say and say it in the most specific terms possible.

title: Kidnapping by Extremists Stirs India
description: The incident started when a group of high-level local officials was traveling in an unarmed convoy through a heavily forested area in southern India. Suddenly a gang of radicals emerged from the woods and took the travelers hostage.

title: STATE ENFORCING CHILD SUPPORT
description: STATE officials, using such methods as wage garnisheeing, property liens and the interception of Federal tax refunds, are becoming increasingly aggressive in their pursuit of child support payments.

title: CHARITABLE DONATIONS STEADY
description: ALTHOUGH charitable organizations had expected deficits in holiday fund-raising this year because of the uncertain economy, most major charities in New Jersey seem to have raised at least as much as they did last year.

title: Want Top Singers? Buy 'Em
description: EVER SINCE THE RUDOLF BING ERA ENDED and the Metropolitan Opera was gradually taken over by its board of directors, company administrators have offered a flurry of excuses about their inability to cast as many superstar singers as veteran Met audiences were used to.

title: THE NATION: The Economy; Indicators Fall, but U.S. Industry Appears Poised to Rebound
description: GOING by the numbers, things didn't look so good.

title: TENEMENTS OF 1880'S ADAPT TO 1980'S
description: IN most cities the phrase luxury apartment refers to an apartment in a new building. But in New York, increasingly, it is also being used to describe a renovated apartment in a former tenement.

title: AIDS Patients Speak Through Art
description: AIDS patients cannot always articulate what they are going through.

title: Arbitration Time Gives Clubs Something to Fear
description: STEVE CRAWFORD is a free agent, so he can't extend his record of five times filed and five times settled, but Phil Bradley can try for a third successive victory and Kevin McReynolds and Gary Pettis can try to break their two-year losing streaks. Andre Dawson can try to break the bank. It's salary arbitration time, which means clubs can start cringing because they have come to fear that procedure more than free agency. In the past three years, teams, through illegal and otherwise questionable means, have controlled the free-agent market, but they still haven't figured out how to prevent an arbitrator from awarding a salary they consider outrageous.

title: A Tale of Two Strike-Tarnished Seasons
description: I REMEMBER it vividly. The Super Bowl ring that I promised to my father as a senior in high school suddenly appeared on the finger of John Riggins.

title: Mandlikova Mix-Up
description: ALTHOUGH she became an Australian citizen on Friday, Hana Mandlikova will still play for the Czechoslovak tennis team at the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, her father said yesterday. But Mandlikova, ranked fifth in the world, told journalists in Brisbane, Australia, Friday that she ''will not play for Czechoslovakia again.''

title: Piliing Surprise Upon Surprise
description: BY defeating John Nunn in their tie-break match in Budapest, Lajos Portisch became the 14th qualifier for the elimination matches to pick the 1990 challenger for the world championship.

title: OLD AND NOVEL
description: Gary Jennings's article ''Old and Novel'' (On Language, Nov. 29) is devoted to an impassioned plea for the compilation of a dictionary of ''What People Used to Call Things.'' Such a dictionary is, in fact, being edited at the University of Glasgow - it will be called the Historical Thesaurus of English. It may also be possible to use the New Oxford English Dictionary data base (an electronic version of the O.E.D. that is being developed) as a source for the kind of information Mr. Jennings has in mind. FRED R. SHAPIRO Assistant Librarian Yale Law School New Haven

title:
DINING OUT;
DISHES FROM CHINA AND TAIWAN
description: LEAD: A TREND among newer Chinese restaurants is to pay more attention to comfort and style. The days of cheap bric-a-brac and plastic table tops seem to be passe. Now, fresh flowers, linens, taped music and even candlelight set the tone.

title: On Language; Nyet Problemy on Snow Jobs
description: BRUSH UP YOUR RUSSIAN; detente is back.

title: After 55 Years, Is It Time to Deregulate the Banks?
description: SOMETIME in February, Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, plans to have it take up the next step in bank deregulation - repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act.

title: FREE CREDIT IN BUSINESS FOR B.A.'S
description: IN A MOVE to make its liberal arts students more attractive to potential employers, the University of Rochester is spicing up its liberal arts curriculum with a series of ''practical'' business-related courses. The new program is bound to be alluring to students as well - the university is giving the courses away.

title: LITERARY FEMINISM COMES OF AGE
description: In her article, Elizabeth Kolbert refers to a ''classic'' feminist article by Sandra Gilbert, in which Ms. Gilbert attacks the image of Milton, alluding to his ''well-known misogyny'' and his ''antifeminism.''

title: Stock Plunge Chills Co-op Resale Market
description: THREE days before he expected to pocket the proceeds of the sale of a cooperative apartment on West End Avenue, Tom Carder watched the deal fall apart. Amid boxes already packed for a move to Stowe, Vt., Mr. Carder hastily began searching for a new buyer who would not back out of a sales contract.

title: Pittburgh Loses Starter but Beats Florida, 80-68
description: Charles Smith scored 30 points and Jerome Lane grabbed 21 rebounds today as Pittsburgh dominated Florida inside for an 80-68 victory.

title: U.S. Judges Extend Deadline On Louisiana Desegregation
description: A Federal court order to improve Louisiana's mostly black universities has been extended to allow more time to decide whether the state has fulfilled its terms.

title: WQXR WILL MAKE MAJOR ADJUSTMENTS IN ITS PROGRAMMING
description: Radio station WQXR AM-FM, responding to competition for the New York region's classical music audience, will make major adjustments in its programming this month, reducing the amount of discussion and adding more music on its FM signal, according to station officials.

title: CAN KEAN DEACTIVATE PARKWAY-TOLL BOMB?
description: GOVERNOR KEAN declared a misdeal last week in the New Jersey Highway Authority's game plan that calls for raising tolls on the Garden State Parkway by April.

title: Intellectual Seduction
description: LISTENING TO MIKHAIL S. Gorbachev's impassioned address in the rococo white-and-gold ballroom of the Soviet Embassy on 16th Street in Washington, on the late afternoon of Dec. 8, in a heterogeneous gathering of some 50 fellow American ''intellectuals'' and ''artists,'' I recalled these cryptic words of Nietzsche's; but wondered if my habitual skepticism, particularly regarding politics in its most public, theatrical mode, might be irrelevant here, unjustified. Simply because one of the world's most powerful men, indeed the world's supreme Communist leader, the General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was speaking to us in warmly seductive tones, employing words reminiscent of the social optimism of the 1960's - ''interrelatedness, integral, global peace, democratization'' - and assuring us of matters that sounded almost literally too good to be true, as if our deepest, most desperate wishes were being uttered in an exotically foreign language and translated into our own, did it mean that these matters could not be true? - or even probable? Though the grim lessons of history suggest otherwise, and idealism's trajectory usually falls off rapidly, man is, of all creatures, the hopeful animal; and it is a hard task to resist believing in the very things (above all, an end to the fanatic arms race of past decades) that we have been talking about for so long.

title: Hirohito Makes a 'Banzai' Showing
description: In a brief ceremony made significant by its ordinariness, Emperor Hirohito appeared before thousands of his subjects today to wish them well and to be heartily cheered in turn.

title: Dad's Bad Mood
description: To the Editor:

title: Embattled Teamsters Fight Government on Several Fronts
description: FEW labor leaders were surprised last month by a spate of reports that Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, had resigned. The rumors weren't true, but the fact that they were so widely believed showed how troubled is Mr. Presser's reign over the 1.7 million-member union, the nation's largest.

title: PHYSICIAN IS WED TO MISS MURDOCH
description: Elizabeth Patterson Murdoch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Murdoch Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Henry Clinton Maguire 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Maguire Jr. of Merion Station, Pa. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, the Episcopal chaplain of Princeton University, performed the ceremony at the university chapel.

title: 12 Acres of Garbage Bits Are an Artistic Attraction in India
description: After years of collecting bits of discarded junk like old toilet bowls, broken bangles and shards of rock, Nek Chand has finally found success and renown - not as a scrap merchant, but as a sculptor.

title: Correction
description: The Week in Business column last week misidentified the company from which Steve S. Chen recently resigned. It was Cray Research Inc.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: The Bishops; An Unseemly Battle
description: ON the surface, it was a fight about condoms, an unsightly brawl on an unseemly topic for the Princes of the Roman Catholic Church. But at the heart of the matter of last week's debate over the new AIDS policy of the American bishops was a long-simmering struggle between conservative and liberal forces in the American church.

title: Boitano's Big Attempt
description: ALTHOUGH a quadruple jump has never been completed in competition, Brian Boitano, who goes after his fourth straight United States Figure Skating championship this week in Denver, has come close and he says he will be trying to come even closer. ''Whether the jump is successful or not on a particular night will not make that much of a difference in the results,'' said Boitano, who won the 1986 world championships then finished second to Brian Orser of Canada last year. ''But succeed or miss, I will have tried and that is what is most important to me.'' Debi Thomas, who lost her crown to Jill Trenary last year, is favored to recapture the United States women's title.

title: CONTEMPORARY SILVER IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: LEAD: TEAPOTS and liqueur cups, cappuccino steamers and candlesticks, caviar spoons, a honey swirler and a pickle fork. These are a sampling of the diverse range of contemporary silver objects for the tabletop that are on display in ''Silver in Service'' at the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle through next

title: Captain Vinegar's Ancestors
description: To the Editor:

title: New Act, Old Tragedy
description: The general strike by almost 750,000 Israeli Arabs was not only an impressive tour de force but a remarkable display of solidarity with their compatriots in the occupied territories of Gaza and the West Bank. It was also the culmination of a slow, painful process of community building, carried out during 40 years of living in the Jewish state.

title:
INVESTING;
No More Trains for IC Industries
description: LEAD: IN the next few months, IC Industries hopes to change its corporate identity by getting rid of the business most closely associated with its past: the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad, a system that links Chicago and New Orleans.

title: THE DISTURBING ALLURE OF A GIACOMETTI 'WOMAN'
description: WHAT MAKES A WORK OF art ''great''? What makes a painting or sculpture more than the sum of its parts, more than a document of a person, period, position or style? What is it about a work that makes people from other periods and places keep returning to it?

title: Warsaw Pact and Comecon: Formal Ties
description: The Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (Comecon) and the Warsaw Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation and Mutual Assistance (the Warsaw Pact) were established to improve economic and military cooperation among the Soviet Union and its allies.

title:
MUSIC;
A Many-Sided Maverick
description: LEAD: LUKAS FOSS, COMPOSER, PIANIST, conductor of music of the past and the present, is asked what he would like his entry to be in the history book of 20th-century music. ''I'm not very good at epitaphs,'' he demurs with a grin, but then says, ''In terms of my salvation, I hope that composing is going to be of greatest significance, that my music will be heard and be found of continuing freshness and interest.

title: HEADING WEST
description: THERE IS A FELLOW who drives around San Francisco with a bumper sticker that says, Il faut boire du pinot noir: ''Drink pinot noir.'' Who would argue with that? To paraphrase Will Rogers, I've never met a man who didn't like pinot noir.

title: LAUTENBERG EMERGING FROM BRADLEY'S SHADOW
description: HE'S THE man with no name, the other Senator from New Jersey.

title: TESTING GLASNOST
description: I was impressed by Alexander Goldfarb's article ''Testing Glasnost: An Exile Visits His Homeland'' (Dec. 6), and congratulate The New York Times Magazine on having selected him to give us a picture of what is happening now in the U.S.S.R.

title: Kodo Drummers Hone Bodies as Well as Skills
description: A decade ago, the drummers of Sado Island in the Japan Sea whipped their bodies into shape for the Boston Marathon by making predawn runs along the island's snowbound roads.

title: LAURA JEANNE DUTZEK MARRIED TO JONATHAN LICHTER
description: The marriage of Laura Jeanne Dutzek, the daughter of Henry Dutzek of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Barbara Mae Dutzek, to Jonathan Simons Lichter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lichter of Larchmont, N.Y., and New York, took place yesterday at Singer's Caterers in Spring Valley, N.Y. Kenneth Rones, a town justice in Clarkstown, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: For Vatican, Gorbachev's 'Openness' Is A Solid Wall
description: ''THE church fights the enemies of yesterday and the friends of tomorrow.'' That enigmatic slogan, a senior Vatican diplomat said, explains how the Roman Catholic Church dealt with the Huns and the French Revolution - and how it now deals with the Soviet Union.

title: SUSAN ANN CROTTY IS WED
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., Susan Ann Crotty, a vice president of Hamilton & Company, financial consultants in New York, was married yesterday to David William Lohuis, a vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. The Rev. William Donovan officiated. Their parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Crotty of Darien and Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Lohuis of Barrington, Ill. The bride, a graduate of Boston College, received a master's degree in finance from the University of Connecticut. Mr. Lohuis graduated from the University of Illinois.

title: RICHARD FOREMAN: 'I WANT PEOPLE TO HAVE FUN'
description: LEAD: PERHAPS THE QUESTION least appealing to Richard Foreman, the experimental theater-maker, is the one he is most often asked: What is your work about?

title: SOVIET BLOC FEELS THE REINS LOOSENING
description: A few days after Rumanian workers rioted in November in the city of Brasov, a senior Soviet official in Moscow was asked how the Kremlin would respond if the unrest 120 miles from the Soviet Union's western border got out of control.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
For New Brunswick, a Surge in Housing
description: LEAD: THE focus of revitalization in New Brunswick, which has risen from a derelict city to a commercial hub in the last 12 years, has shifted to housing, re-establishing it as a place to live as well as work.

title: ERIC D. CARLSON IS TO BE MARRIED TO MISS ANSPACH
description: Elizabeth Bodne Anspach and Eric David Carlson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. David Carlson of Munster, Ind., plan to marry in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Anspach of New York and Edgartown, Mass., have announced.

title: Comings & Goings
description: THE Olympic 100-meter champion, Evelyn Ashford, who holds the world record of 10.75 seconds in the event as well as indoor bests of 5.74 for 50 yards and 6.54 for 60 yards, will compete in the United States Olympic Invitational meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Feb. 13. The 30-year-old Ashford, who won the United States Olympic Invitational in 1986 after the birth of her daughter but missed most of last year because of an injury, will run in the 55-meter dash against the defending champion, Gwen Torrence, and Merlene Ottey, the bronze medalist in the 100 meters at the 1984 Olympics. . . . Clarissa Davis, the all-America University of Texas basketball player injured in the Burger King-Orange Bowl Classic last Tuesday night, underwent reconstructive surgery for ligament damage to her left knee in Nix Hospital in San Antonio, and Dr. Jesse DeLee said the rehabilitation process would take 10-12 months. That means she will definitely miss the Olympics next summer and it could also put her senior year in jeopardy. Davis was averaging 24.8 points and 9.7 rebounds. . . . The two Most Improved Players in golf, as rated by Golf Digest magazine, are Paul Azinger and Colleen Walker. While winning four events in 1987, Azinger tripled his 1987 earnings to more than $820,000 and reduced his scoring average from 70.76 to 70.21. Walker more than doubled her 1986 earnings last year winning 190,815 and won her first tournament, the Mayflower Classic.

description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, an evil wizard and a mouse. 2 8 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 3 9 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in four previously pupublished novels. 4 5 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $4.95.) These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The Chicago market is a made-for-speculation market, but it leads New York around by the nose.''

title: Iran-Contra Aside, Webster Asks for Trust
description: WHEN William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, announced his long-awaited response to the Iran-contra affair, most of the public attention focused on the disciplinary action he took against several agency officials. But Mr. Webster's carefully crafted statement went well beyond personnel issues: It outlined his agenda for the upcoming year, and it proposed answers to several of the major criticisms leveled at the Central Intelligence Agency over the year just past.

title: Miami Coach Prevails
description: Of all the labels that could have been attached to Jimmy Johnson as the football coach at the University of Miami for the past four seasons, the notions of champion and educator have never seemed to stick.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: Pro football is no longer a sport but a business; the game has been structurally altered. Society's values are reflected in this uniquely American game. This game is violence, greed and absolutely dull.

title: AMANDA C. ALLEN IS WED TO JAMES BOARDMAN BLAIR
description: Amanda Clark Allen and James Boardman Blair were married yesterday at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Conn., by the Rev. Kirk Steven Smith.

title: Shades of Sputnik: Who's Ahead in Space?
description: ECHOES of 1957 reverberated from the Soviet Union last week to a snow-coated rocket test site in Utah. The space age is now 30 years old, moon landings have come and gone and a whole generation has grown up with the reality of space travel. Yet there was something about the triumphant return of a record-setting Soviet astronaut, and another setback to the grounded space shuttle, that was reminiscent of the grim time following the first Sputnik launching in October 1957.

title: In the Office: See How They Run
description: WHEN Toyota and General Motors opened their joint-venture auto plant in Fremont, Calif., in 1984, workers began each shift with several minutes of calisthenics accompanied by piped-in music. Today the music remains, but nobody bothers with the calisthenics.

title: MORRISTOWN DRUMMER, DEAD A YEAR, EULOGIZED
description: LEAD: THE 1960's has had few parallels in modern pop-music history. The decade saw the birth of the Beatles and Rolling Stones, the British rock invasion, the California surf sounds of the Beach Boys and Bob Dylan's music of social protest.

title: The Moment of Truth for Big Blue
description: SIXTY years ago, Thomas J. Watson Sr. paced the maple floors in the International Business Machines Corporation's giant plant here in the center of New York State, presiding over the production of time clocks and meat slicers. Now, on those same floors, I.B.M. has spent hundreds of millions of dollars building a state-of-the-art production line that can snap together in minutes its newest, smallest and most price-competitive mini-mainframe computer. In the industry, the machine is called the ''Vax killer'' because it is supposed to do to the Digital Equipment Corporation's popular Vax line what I.B.M. meat slicers did to meat.

title: 1988: PREVIEWS FROM 36 ARTISTS
description: WHEN WE CONTEMPLATE A WORK OF art, the experience most of us share is of seeing or hearing something with a beginning, a middle and an end. Or, in the case of paintings and sculpture, it's the discovery of a point of view. We also conveniently like to think of artistic careers as orderly sequences of completed works. And perhaps, if we look hard enough, clear connecting threads will be revealed. However, conversations with creative artists about the way they work show that the creative process is an ongoing process of exploration, often into unknown territory. By the time a work of art reaches the public, its creators are often already immersed in future projects that will redefine our perception of the sensibilities we are just coming to know. They remain one step ahead of us.

title: Helping Customer Relations
description: I'LL bet they still exist, somewhere under the gray paint. They are my New Year's resolutions, circa 1953.

title: AN ARTISTIC ALLIANCE AT HARTFORD STAGE
description: WHILE it may not be unusual for directors of regional theaters to call upon the same performers with regularity, it is a rare thing for an actress and a director to establish a working relationship that has the earmarks of a sustained artistic alliance.

title: GREAT EXHORTATIONS: BOOKS WITH RESOLVE
description: The start of every year invites new resolve about how we will improve ourselves. The start of every fourth year invites new resolve about how we will improve the nation. Soon many of us will go on diets, and many of us will begin listening in earnest to what the Presidential candidates have to say. Both recurring urges - toward self-improvement and public improvement -require persistent enthusiasm and unending hope.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Top Dogs WHEN Tony Bullock, the incoming East Hampton Town Supervisor, was still in the Suffolk County Legislature and gave out his Thanksgiving ''Stuffed Turkey Awards'' for waste in county government, he included in the list $125,000 that had been allocated for ''a police dog academy.'' The Suffolk County Police had requested a new building and kennel in which to house and train police dogs during their rookie training period.

title: Photos That Capture the Sculptor's Spirit
description: THE PHOTOGRAPHS IN the recently published book ''Alberto Giacometti'' do something rare: they convey a measure of what we feel when we encounter the sculptor's work in the flesh. The pictures may be missing the sculpture's scale, texture and command of space, but they elicit its essential spirit through the pictorial equivalent of metaphor. The result is perhaps the best introduction we might have to Giacometti's sculpture short of seeing it in the flesh.

title: PLANNED BRIDGE IS LOWER AND CHEAPER, BUT FOES FIGHT ON
description: EVERYONE agrees that something has to be done about the bridge between Waterford and East Lyme. Just what is to be done is the question.

title: LYOVA'S DEATH WAS TEMPORARY
description: PUSHKIN HOUSE By Andrei Bitov. Translated by Susan Brownsberger. 371 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: 'Make Mine Sarsaparilly!'
description: CALAMITY JANE With Doris Day (in photo), Howard Keel, Allyn McLerie, Philip Carey, Dick Wesson. 1953. Warner Home Video. 101 minutes. $24.98

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: When Shopping For Videos, Beware 87's Dogs
description: THE DECENT THING TO DO about the year's bad films used to be to let them go quietly. But that was in the days when a movie of no merit could be counted on to disappear into the oblivion from whence it came. Those days are gone, as anyone who regularly visits video stores must surely realize. It is now possible for a terrible film to resurface in a nice package that bears no memory-jogging information, just an indistinct title and the name of a star or two. With more new releases than ever, it takes a great barking dog of a bad film - an ''Angel Heart,'' a ''Who's That Girl?'' - to stand out from the crowd.

title: O'ROURKE TO PURSUE I-287 CHOICE WITH STATE
description: LEAD: THE State Transportation Commissioner, Franklin E. White, will meet Jan. 11 in Albany with the county's 13 State Senators and Assemblymen to explain why he advocates rebuilding the current six lanes of Route 287 and adding a seventh high-occupancy-vehicle lane reserved for buses and car and van pools.

title:
DINING OUT;
BRIEF BUT BROAD MENU IN GARRISON
description: LEAD: WHILE the food and service has always been decent at Xaviar's in Garrison, in the past the overwhelming appeal of this restaurant has been its unique, dramatic setting - in the lofty game room that once was part of an extensive estate. But now the Garrison establishment appears to be benefiting from the newly honed and considerable culinary skills of Peter Xaviar Kelly, who, although spending most of his time these days in Piermont at the sister restaurant of the same name, brings his winning expertise to Garrison, where he continues to advise the kitchen staff.

title: MICHIGAN RALLIES TO TOP ALABAMA
description: John Kolesar caught a 20-yard touchdown pass from Demetrius Brown with 50 seconds to play today, and Jamie Morris carried for a career-high 234 yards and three touchdowns, leading Michigan over Alabama, 28-24, in the Hall of Fame Bowl.

title: Dutchess Development: Harmony Reigns
description: Joshua Schulman, project manager for Twin Creeks Village, said the architecture of the East Fishkill, N.Y., development would reflect ''the essence of a New England farmhouse and a more formal colonial home.'' He meant not only the 424 town houses planned for the 110-acre project, but also the 54 condominiums for older people and a 24,000-square-foot office and retail building. ''We don't want one glass building sticking out like a sore thumb,'' he said of the two-story commercial structure. The architects are Albert Moore and John Sullivan.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
SPRING LAKE
description: LEAD: FROM the boardwalk, Spring Lake presents an idyllic setting. On one side are two miles of uncrowded beachfront and the Atlantic Ocean; on the other are elegant Victorian homes set around the spring-fed lakes that gave the community its name.

title: Fairness of Case Reviews for Cubans Is Challenged
description: Cuban detainees who rioted at two Federal penitentiaries in November may not be properly represented as a new round of individual case reviews opens Monday, an attorney for the detainees says.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
LET'S RING IN THE OLD YEAR
description: LEAD: IT can't be 1988. I haven't even gotten a handle on 1972 yet. I am a 78 R.P.M. record in a compact-disk world.

title: BENEFITS FOR WINTER NIGHTS
description: Savoyard Sing-Along Jan. 6 -- An opportunity to join in the musical shenanigans of Gilbert and Sullivan will come after a performance of ''the Yeoman of the Guard,'' the spoof of English manners and morals, at symphony space, 2587 Broadway (95th Street). After the 8 P.M. performance there will be a sing-along with the 30-member cast. Hors d'oeuvres and a cash bar will be available, all to benefit the New Hork Gilbert and Sullivan Players. Tickets, $25, $20 and $15 for the performance; $25 for the party; from 212-769-1000. Oceanic Nostalgia Jan. 7 -- Memories of the Trans-Atlantic ocean liner, whose heyday began in the 1880's and ended in the mid-1950's, are being preserved by a group called the Ocean Liner Museum, which is trying to find a permanent home for its memorabilia. A benefit for the group will be held from 6 P.M. To midnight at Christie's, with cocktails, a buffet, dancing and an auction of vacations and trips around the world. Tickets, $160 ($90 for guests under 40), from 212-249-4949. Theater Party Jan. 9 -- The Helen Keller Manhattan League for the Blind, which was founded 20 years ago, supports programs for visually impaired and deaf children. An 8 P.M. benefit performance of Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera'' at the Majestic Theater will be followed by a dinner-dance at Regine's Crystal Room. Tickets, $100 or $150 for the perfromance alone; $125 for just the party; from 212-285-7029. Swedish Kickoff

title: Oiler Fans Can't Believe They've Got a Gusher
description: DON'T worry. You're not the only one who's surprised the Houston Oilers are in the National Football League playoffs.

title: Police Say Robbery Was Racially Motivated
description: A 28-year-old white woman was forced into a van in Brooklyn by two black men and robbed on Thursday in what the police yesterday called a racially motivated incident.

title: Tar Heels Defeat U.C.L.A. By 80-73
description: J. R. Reid scored 25 points today to lead North Carolina to an 80-73 victory over U.C.L.A.

title: Ballet: 2 Role Debuts In Joffrey 'Nutcracker'
description: THE Joffrey Ballet's new Victorian production of ''The Nutcracker'' is so pretty a spectacle and is performed with such liveliness that it seems almost like splitting hairs to talk of mundane things like role debuts. On Friday at City Center, however, Leslie Carothers and Ashley Wheater danced the Sugar Plum Fairy and the Nutcracker Prince for the first time in New York. They are two of the Joffrey's purest classicists and brightest, most stylish stars. But both have been seen to better - and more secure - effect.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
KEEPING THE ARTS ALIVE AS AUDIENCE APPLAUDS
description: LEAD: THE recent chapter in the history of Long Island Stage, an innovative theater group whose poor economic health has threatened to bring the theater's curtain down for good, reflects an even larger problem regarding the cultural development of Long Island.

title: How Education Came to Be a Campaign Issue
description: CONGRESS created the national Office of Education in 1867 and then, not quite sure of what it was supposed to do, ordered its Commissioner to keep an eye on the Federal reindeer herds in Alaska. Commissioners have since been relieved of their reindeer-watching duties, but the tradition of turning to education to deal with everything from driver safety to drug abuse lives on. Witness the current national obsession with economic competitiveness.

title: PROPHECIES FOR THE FAR, FAR FUTURE FROM A SEER OF THE FAR, FAR PAST
description: I AM Amen-Ra, the king of the Egyptian gods, and I'm speaking through the scoundrel whose name is on this article in order to describe the future of that fair and formidable land mass, Long Island.

title: WHERE THE OUTRAGEOUS GO IN SPRINGTIME
description: TWO WEEKS IN THE MIDDAY SUN A Cannes Notebook. By Roger Ebert. Illustrated by the author. 182 pp. Kansas City, Mo.: Andrews & McMeel. Paper, $8.95. THERE'S something outlandish about the very notion of the Cannes Film Festival, which lures thousands to a Mediterranean town during the second two weeks of May so that they can spend most of their time in the dark. Though less selective than New York and not as esteemed as Venice, Cannes surpasses its rival festivals in sheer flamboyance. Here are the biggest stars, the most prestigious jurors, the most sought-after new films and - since it's first and foremost an industry trade fair - the most outrageous hucksters and richest pate de foie gras.

title: Death at 80 Parts Twins Who Never Grew Old
description: Until Buell Fuller died last week at the age of 80, he and his identical twin, John, were separated only twice in their lives: once when John preceded Buell at birth by two minutes, and a second time two decades later when Buell joined the Air Force for two years.

title: UNION CITY ANGERED BY CUBA PACT
description: LEADERS of the Cuban community here say they have been sold out by the Federal Government in its deportation agreement with Fidel Castro.

title: MAGGIE FERDON WED TO JOHN W. COOLEY
description: At the Roman Catholic Old Mission Dolores in San Francisco, Maggie Ferdon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jay Ferdon of San Francisco, was married yesterday to John Withrow Cooley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Cooley of West Hartford, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass. Msgr. Edward M. Dullea and the Rev. Janet Griffin, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title:
ART;
A 'LIVING VERSION' OF HERESIES MAGAZINE
description: LEAD: HERESIES, the title of a feisty feminist publication of art and politics, also encompasses one of the more resonant puns going: in it the feminine pronoun is allied with iconoclasm. At the Bronx River Gallery, at 1087 East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx through Saturday, is something like a living version of this often wave-making magazine.

title: Syria Tries to Dissuade Iran From New Attack
description: Syria is seeking to persuade Iran not to launch a new ground offensive against Iraq so as to avoid expanding the Persian Gulf war into an all-out Arab-Persian confrontation.

title: Increasingly, Court Has Last Word on City Hall's Rulings
description: IF you can't fight City Hall, take it to court. Increasingly, that is the tack being taken by groups frustrated by the normal political process in New York City. And in resorting to litigation, they are winning some victories.

title: Mauritius Seeks to Regain Island With U.S. Base
description: This island state still wishes it could regain sovereignty over the faraway island of Diego Garcia, which the United States has turned into a military base in the Indian Ocean.

title: TIMOTHY SCHIFTER AND HELEN E. LEE PLANNING TO WED
description: The engagement of Helen Elizabeth Lee to Timothy Ware Schifter, the son of Melvin Schifter of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Margaret Hoyt Schifter, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Chun-Chao Lee of Arlington, Tex., and Destin, Fla.

title: The New Wave of Body Sculptors
description: DICK ROBERTSON, a senior executive with Lorimar Telepictures in Los Angeles, is the quintessential bicoastal fitness fanatic. Whether at home in Malibu or on his frequent trips to New York, the 6-foot-3, 186-pound executive works out six days a week with trainers. In 1987, Mr. Robertson estimates he spent upwards of $20,000 on instructors, equipment and club memberships.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Will Win the Pro Football Playoffs?
description: A great summation to this crazy football season would be a Colts and Saints matchup in the Super Bowl. GARY M. LEON East Brunswick, N.J.

title: LATEST CAREER STOP: YIDDISH STAGE
description: LEAD: IF Robert Paul Abelson had to sum up his philosophy, it would probably go something like this, he said: ''Life is like a top; you don't know where you'll end up.''

title: AT THE SAATCHI COLLECTION, A THIN SHOW OF 'NY ART'
description: ONE OF THE WORLD'S MOST beautiful exhibition spaces is the one that was confected not so long ago by the English architect Max Gordon for the Saatchi Collection here. It is a mysterious space, in which level is played against level and shape against shape. It is, in fact, something of a thinking man's maze. It has a beginning and an end, but along the way between the two we never know quite where we are, and there may even be moments when we don't quite know who we are. In other words, Mr. Gordon takes away our everyday identity and leaves us wide open to new experience. The Saatchi Gallery fine-tunes the art, but it also fine-tunes the visitor.

title:
FILM;
The Task of Turning Joyce's Prose to Film Poetry
description: LEAD: JOHN HUSTON'S FINAL MOVIE - A very moving one, and just now in theaters - is an adaptation of James Joyce's short story ''The Dead.'' This is not the first time that it has been converted into drama. The BBC put on a television version some years ago, and I remember one of my Princeton students turning ''The Dead'' into a lively verse play.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. We have a brick patio with a northern exposure, and there is a problem with mold and mildew forming on these bricks. We have to scrub them several times a year with bleach to remove the growth. Do you have any suggestions for preventing this growth?

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: JUST when help is needed to understand the Tax Reform Act of 1986, here comes the ''1988 New Jersey Tax Handbook'' (Prentice Hall, New York, $17.50), a guide tailored specifically to the state's needs.

title: Bulls Run Away From Nets
description: Dave Corzine and John Paxson came off the bench to combine for 22 points during a 25-6 second-quarter spurt tonight as the Chicago Bulls ended a five-game losing streak with a 116-93 victory over the Nets.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Livingston $280,000 6 Rale Terrace 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 34-year-old split level; C/A, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $3,354. Millburn $235,000 750 Ridgewood Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,141. Ridgewood $255,000 434 Bogert Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; 1-car attached garage, new siding, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,028. Ringwood $312,500 17 Custer Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old contemporary; cathedral ceiling, 4-zone heating, fireplace, circular driveway; taxes $5,499. West Orange $150,000 71 Rollinson Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 52-year-old Tudor; sun porch, fireplace, full basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,529. Wyckoff $315,000 600 Fairview Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; deck, circular driveway; taxes $2,724.
