OTHER AREAS Pleasantville, N.Y. $250,000 260 Lake Shore Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old frame raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, fenced yard, overlooks Bear Ridge Lake; taxes $3,722. Wilton, Conn. $450,000 23 Telva Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; near train and parking, good condition, 1 acre; taxes, $3,225. Smithtown, L.I. $158,000 90 Howell Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, new roof; taxes $3,000.

title: SHERRI LONDON ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl London of Bulls Head, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sherri Sue London, to Michael Edward Pastolove, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Pastolove of Brookville, L.I. Ms. London, an account representative for the Arts and Entertainment Cable Network in New York, graduated from the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. Her fiance, a graduate of the Syracuse University School of Management, is the vice president of the Asco Sprinkler Company in New York.

title: The Spinoff Puzzle for Shareholders
description: WHEN a corporate management decides that a subsidiary no longer fits into its grand design for the future, one solution is to spin off the unit to the company's shareholders. For the company, one advantage of such a transaction is that unlike an outright sale, it would probably not be subject to Federal income taxes. But a spinoff can be perplexing for investors. If management wants to unload the operation, should shareholders want to own it?

title: A Place to Show One's Pedigree
description: THERE are several daily fashion parades on the gilded shopping stretch of Madison Avenue between 60th and 96th Streets.

title:
MUSIC;
WINTER POPS HAS P.D.Q.
description: LEAD: THE new Winter Pops Series of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra will open in Pomona Friday night with P.D.Q. Bach's ''Desecration of the House'' Overture, ''Hindenburg'' Concerto, Canine Cantata (''Wachet Arf!'') and Concerto for Bassoon vs. Orchestra. Amy Kaiser, the guest conductor, will lead the full orchestra in the concert, assisted by the only known P.D.Q.

title: Between Palestinians and Israelis, a U.S. Role; Nonviolence Is the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Slides vs. Prints
description: ONE of the reasons that color-print films outsell color-slide films is their reproducibility. Take a picture on slide film of the family gathered together round the Yule log and you get back a slide, period. Take the same picture on print film and you get back a print and a negative. With the negative, you can order as many duplicates of the picture as there are family members.

title: Rediscovering A Great Jazz Guitarist
description: THE GUITAR WAS PRIMARILY A rhythm instrument in jazz until Charlie Christian brought the electric guitar into the jazz mainstream in 1939 when he came out of Oklahoma to join Benny Goodman. In the big bands that dominated the 1920's and 30's, it was difficult for an acoustic guitar to be heard as a solo instrument, which was one reason the banjo was favored over the guitar until electrical recording arrived in the mid-1920's.

title: GARDENING COPING WITH THE PROBLEMS OF WINTER
description: LEAD: ''AS the days begin to lengthen, winter, then, begins to strengthen,'' goes the old saying. Indeed, now that we have passed the shortest day of the year, we can expect the coldest, snowiest part of the winter to lie just ahead. Such weather often leads to plant problems, some of which can be prevented with minimal effort.

title: MYSTIC SHIP ON STATEHOOD STAMP
description: IN her 80-year career, the whale ship Charles W. Morgan made 37 voyages, visiting every ocean. Soon, small pictures of the historic vessel will be visiting many mailboxes.

title: THE APPROACH
description: ONE OF THE very important attractions of the game of golf,'' wrote Bobby Jones, one of the sport's immortals, ''is that it provides a varied assortment of topics for conversation.'' Not least, it seems, the golfer's zany wardrobe, which over the years has encompassed such classical oddities as screaming argyle hose and peaked tartan caps. More recently, that repertory has stretched to include shirts and sweaters emblazoned with country club logos and jaunty golf bags in searing shades of pink.

title: A City of the Future Grapples With A Troubled Present
description: IN WHAT SEEMED LIKE A timely tribute to the main architect of this modernistic capital, just a week before Oscar Niemeyer's 80th birthday on Dec. 15, Brasilia was added to Unesco's list of sites that form part of the cultural patrimony of mankind.

title: 'EDWIN DROOD' PROVIDES CHALLENGE IN METUCHEN
description: ''THE Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' a very loose musical version of Charles Dickens's unfinished thriller, has a clever gimmick going for it: The ''surprise final denouement,'' as the show's master of ceremonies-chairman puts it, is up to the audience.

title: The Scholastic Empire
description: LAST AUTUMN Junior Scholastic magazine celebrated its 50th year in print - a life that began with reports about a new Supreme Court Justice named Hugo Black and a war between Japan and China. But for the magazine's parent, Scholastic Inc., the anniversary was no time for nostalgia.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOK PUT ON STAGE
description: WEARY, forgetful and slow-moving, Penelope, a fairy godmother, is up for retirement. All she needs to reach it is to grant one more wish. But by the time she remembers just who is wishing what - and gets to them - ''they've already gotten what they want.''

title: MARY D. SHAFTER, ENGINEER, TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Shafter of New Canaan, Conn., and Peru, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Dunn Shafter to James Thomas Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Sullivan of Bristol and Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ANNA DELANEY'S CHILD, by John Thorndike. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Anna Delaney is grief-stricken by the loss of her son in a car crash; her father, Alex, is depressed over the death of his wife. This ''lyrically powerful'' first novel ''deftly explores the ethics of memory, dramatizing how Anna and Alex learn to forge bonds with the living without betraying their loving memories of the dead,'' Sherie Posesorski said in The Book Review in 1986. THE CYCLES OF AMERICAN HISTORY, by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $11.95.) Liberalism may be on the wane, but as the wheels of history turn, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. believes, its day will come again. In this book of essays, Benjamin R. Barber said here in 1986, ''Mr. Schlesinger both describes and, as an intellectual engage, embodies liberalism's powerful virtues: its intellectual circumspection, its political vigor, its antipathy to extremism, its championing of the unpopular sides of liberty and tolerance and its devotion to social justice. And, without quite meaning to, he exemplifies some of the defects that have contributed to its recent decline.'' AT PLAY IN THE FIELDS OF THE LORD, by Peter Matthiessen. (Vintage, $6.95.) When Peter Matthiessen's novel about the foibles of fundamentalist missionaries in the Amazon jungle was published in 1965, our reviewer, Emile Capouya, liked the author's ''detailed picture of Indian customs, his insight into character and his physical descriptions. [ The book ] is never less than a very superior adventure story, and often a good deal more than that.'' The same publisher has reissued two more of Mr. Matthiessen's early novels. RADITZER ($5.95) is about a strange friendship between two sailors during World War II, one a derelict ne'er-do-well, the other a young aspiring artist. ''This novel is a complex moral parable,'' David Boroff said here in 1961, which reminds us ''that the links that connect us are strangely intricate.'' The hero of PARTISANS ($5.95) is a young American journalist who becomes enmeshed in a search for a disgraced Communist leader. In 1955, William Goyen complained in The Book Review that the author's characters were ''only mouthpieces,'' but he was impressed with the ''thoughtful attempt to find answers to ancient and serious questions.'' A SEASON ON THE BRINK: A Year With Bobby Knight and the Indiana Hoosiers, by John Feinstein. (Fireside/ Pocket Books, $4.50.) Bob Knight, the sometimes overbearing basketball coach at Indiana University, is known to despise the press. So it is remarkable that he allowed John Feinstein, a Washington Post sportswriter, to spend the 1985-86 season chronicling his tempestuous relationship with his team. ''It's the best book on sports that I have read in some time,'' one reviewer said in 1986, ''and one of the most troubling.'' SAINTS AND STRANGERS, by Angela Carter. (King Penguin, $5.95.) The characters in Angela Carter's collection of eight stories include Edgar Allan Poe, Lizzie Borden and Jeanne Duval, the alienated mistress of Charles Baudelaire who ''was like a piano in a country where everyone has had their hands cut off.'' ''Ms. Carter's is an absolutely unique voice,'' Charles Newman said in The Book Review in 1986, ''intensely literary without being precious, deep without being difficult, indifferent to formulas without being 'experimental,' and funny without being superficial or cruel.'' A MISSING PLANE, by Susan Sheehan. (Berkley, $3.50.) After the wreckage of a World War II transport plane was found in the New Guinea jungle in 1982, Susan Sheehan recorded the efforts of the United States Army's Central Identification Laboratory to excavate the decades-old remains. And, through interviews with friends and relatives, she unearthed the histories of the 22 men who had been on board. In 1986, our reviewer, Eric Lax, called the book ''a superbly reported reconstruction of a quirk of fate and its aftermath.'' CITY OF WOMEN: Sex and Class in New York, 1789-1860, by Christine Stansell. (University of Illinois, $9.95.) During the 19th century, Christine Stansell believes, New York City's working women developed into a socially aware class that challenged the status quo. While Martha Saxton had quibbles with the neo-Marxian analysis, she said here in 1986 that the author had written ''an immensely important book for historians.'' SHERMAN'S MARCH AND VIETNAM, by James Reston Jr. (Macmillan, $10.95.) The My Lai massacre and other Vietnam war crimes have roots in General Sherman's historic march to the sea, James Reston Jr. argues. Stephen W. Sears said here in 1985 that he found the analogy strained, but he admired the author's ''ambitious effort both to understand and to resolve what was for many the central dilemma'' of the United States' role in Southeast Asia. A TOUGH ACT TO FOLLOW, by Max Wilk. (PaperJacks, $4.50.) This roman a clef about the early days of television revolves around a Hollywood film executive's attempt to document the rise and fall of an obnoxiously ambitious comedian. Max Wilk ''handles nostalgia well,'' our reviewer, Carole Klein, said in 1986. He is ''a stylish and skillful storyteller.'' THE POLITICAL LIFE OF CHILDREN, by Robert Coles. (Houghton Mifflin, $10.95.) By interviewing children in trouble spots around the world, the author tries to learn how they develop their political and moral consciousness. ''There is no one who is more interested in what children say, sing, don't say or don't sing - and why - than Robert Coles,'' Neil Postman said in The Book Review in 1986. ''He is to the stories that children have to tell what Homer was to the tale of the Trojan War.'' Mr. Coles's companion volume, THE MORAL LIFE OF CHILDREN ($10.95), is available from the same publisher.

title: Lunchroom Etiquette: It Improves With Age
description: FROM THE AGE of 4, most children can recite the litany of good table manners: I won't talk with my mouth full. I won't play with my food. I won't put my elbows - or feet - on the table.

title: 'IT'S LIKE BEING LOST IN A DESERT'
description: MORE than 144,000 women in Connecticut's cities, suburbs and rural areas have lost their main source of income, state officials say. Five years ago, there were roughly 70,000 of these women, termed displaced homemakers.

title: 'Beware the Ides of March'
description: CLEOPATRA Directed by Cecil B. DeMille. With Claudette Colbert (in photo), Warren William (in photo) and Henry Wilcoxon. Goodtimes Home Video. 100 minutes. $9.95.

title: Anthony V. Barber, Educator, Is Dead; Led 2 Prep Schools
description: Anthony V. Barber, a former headmaster of preparatory schools in the New York metropolitan region, died of bronchial pneumonia Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Barber, who had been ill with cancer, was 83 years old and also lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: Making A Difference
description: After the Helsinki Conference of 1975 reached its accords on human rights, a handful of brave Russians formed a group to report on Soviet compliance. They paid dearly for their courage. The organizers of the Moscow Helsinki Watch, as they called it, were all eventually imprisoned.

title: A LA CARTE
description: IT'S the season for bulging waistlines, the aftermath of holiday parties. Eggnog, plum pudding and fruitcake have taken up permanent residence on the hips. Big eating leads to big promises in the form of New Year's resolutions. But there will be restaurant dining and socializing even after the resolutions.

title: 1988 RECITALS BEGIN IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: IT will be well into the middle of the month before the concert calendar builds up to anything resembling its usual midseason pace, but music at the New Rochelle Public Library hardly misses a beat. Having last Sunday sponsored one of the final county concerts of 1987, the library this afternoon ushers in the '88 recitals roster.

title: What's Doing in Cleveland
description: An old-world open-air grocery marketplace within blocks of an upscale nightclub; a restaurant with a la carte menus priced to match New York establishments around the corner from a family-owned diner serving more than you can eat for less than half as much and, braving the cold winds off Lake Erie, 80,000 Browns fans regularly packing Cleveland's Municipal Stadium during football season - and loving it - while officials discuss the possibility of a new, enclosed sports arena.

title: A New Year's Resolution That Counts
description: For most New York children, Christmas and New Year's are dramatic holidays that may entail days of feasting, gift giving and family celebration. But for thousands of homeless children, the holidays mean only slight variation in a grim routine - a token gift from some charity's Santa Claus, glimpses of New Year's revelry on television.

title: Sunday Observer; Coming Home To Roost
description: IT WAS FUN BEING a yuppie until the stock market ran out of gas. Since then, it's been pain and suffering. I have it firsthand from my friend Duffy. In Wall Street they used to call him ''Duffy the Yuppie.'' That was to distinguish him from Duffy the pushcart pretzel vendor of the arbitrage district, who was known as ''Duffy the Scruffy.''

title: Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: THE REGION: Pro & Con: Tactics of Transit Officers; Police Decoys, Temptation and Crime
description: SINCE the days when burly, bewigged policemen masqueraded as women to catch molesters, police departments around the country have used decoy officers to trap suspected muggers, rapists and other criminals. The technique works, but it has sometimes been abused. Officers have been accused of entrapping suspects by dangling money, flaunting jewelry, planting evidence - a practice sometimes called ''flaking,'' though the origin of the term is uncertain - or tricking a target into picking up a valuable item an officer has purposely dropped.

title: Possessions of Dead Stolen, Ex-Coroner's Employee Says
description: A former coroner's investigator has accused some of his former colleagues of stealing money, jewelry and other property from the dead, and a grand jury is investigating the allegations, a newspaper reported Friday.

title: For Expert Skiers in Austria
description: ZURS is an expert skier's jewel in the crown of the Arlberg, the spectacular range of chalk-stone mountains in western Austria. For skiers whose mission is to find challenging slopes in an intimate European village high above the tree line, it is close to perfection. The main street, which you can walk in 10 minutes, is bordered by chalet-style hotels and a few shops. The tiny wooden church, next to a cow barn, is just up the hill, and there are cozy small hotels off the main road, each on its own plot of snow. There are very few cars and no noise. Snowy peaks, which reach as high as 8,450 feet, are linked by 35 lifts and provide a dizzying variety of trails, some suited to intermediate schussers, a few geared to beginners. But it's the experts who find Zurs heaven.

title: TOWNS IDEALIZED IN 19TH-CENTURY PRINTS
description: LEAD: PRIDE of place, in 19th-century America, found ultimate expression in idealized vistas of cities and towns known as ''bird's-eye views.'' From the 1840's to the turn of the century, thousands of communities, large and small, were depicted in minutely detailed drawings executed from an imagined aerial perspective - as might be glimpsed by a bird in flight.

title: THE NOBEL PRIZE-WINNER NOBODY KNOWS
description: THE announcement that Joseph Brodsky, an exiled Russian poet now an American citizen, won the Nobel Prize for Literature coincided with the course ''Inside Gorbachev's Russia'' that my husband and I were teaching at the Scarsdale Adult School this fall. I had already planned to lecture on this greatest living Russian poet and had been interested in him for a long time. Actually, I had met Joseph Brodsky a number of years ago when he was in Ann Arbor teaching at the University of Michigan, my alma mater. Because I speak Russian, we conversed in his native language, although his English was already quite good by then. We met again when he was reading his poetry at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, and since then I have continued to follow his career with great interest.

title: SIGN LANGUAGE GETS RECOGNITION
description: AS HIGH SCHOOL students in California start selecting classes next fall, some will be able to get credit for an unusual language course -American Sign Language. The addition of the language of the deaf as an acceptable alternative to the state's requirement that students complete a course in either a foreign language or visual or performing arts will take effect July 1. It will make California the third state in the nation to accept sign language as a graduation credit.

title:
Focus: San Diego;
City Makes Strides in Downtown Growth
description: LEAD: THE last 10 years in the development of San Diego's downtown can be characterized as a ''series of catalytic projects that have reversed, or are helping to reverse, a pattern of physical decline,'' according to a report completed early in 1987 by the Urban Land Institute, an independent research center.

title: Whalers Tie Devils With Help of Liut
description: Mike Liut, playing in his 500th National Hockey League game, made 11 saves in the third period and two more in overtime tonight as the Hartford Whalers hung on for a 1-1 tie with the New Jersey Devils.

title: PATRICIA A. GALLAGHER TO WED GREGORY RYAN
description: The engagement of Patricia A. Gallagher to Gregory A. Ryan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Ryan of Morristown, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mr. Edward F. X. Gallagher of Newburgh, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: The New Math for Joining a 401(k) Plan
description: NOW that the stock market has recovered somewhat from its recent rout, shaken investors are reassessing their long-term finances. Those who are counting on investment earnings to fund their retirement may find new appeal in 401(k) employee retirement plans, especially because the new tax law now prevents many people from making tax-deductible contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Trips and Tours To Catch the Solar Eclipse

title: General Is Ordered Tried in Brazilian Killing
description: A Brazilian judge has ordered that a retired four-star general be tried for the 1982 murder of a journalist in what could become the first prosecution of a senior army officer since civilian rule returned here almost three years ago.

title: GROUP TO BATTLE ARMY DAM PROJECT
description: A State Assemblyman, joined by environmentalists, has announced the formation of an organization to stop a $48 million Army Corps of Engineers project because it would flood part of Letchworth State Park.

title: Japan's Lethal Whale 'Science'
description: Japan's whaling fleet, reconfigured as a ''research expedition,'' steams toward the Antarctic. In defiance of the International Whaling Commission, Japan plans to kill 300 minke whales in the name of science. The meat would be sold, as usual, for profit. The U.S., traditionally the conscience of the treaty that protects whales, can have only one reaction to this brazenness: sanctions.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. We have a brick patio with a northern exposure, and there is a problem with mold and mildew forming on these bricks. We have to scrub them several times a year with bleach to remove the growth. Do you have any suggestions for preventing this growth?

title: BEST SELLERS: JANUARY 3, 1988
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week$ YList Fiction 1 1 6 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates havoc. 2 2 11 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 3 3 9 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) An investment banker in the jungles of New York. 4 4 14 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' 5 6 11 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride. 6 5 23 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 7 7 28 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 8 9 5 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Continuing the space saga begun in ''2001'' and ''2010.'' 9 8 14 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 10 11 16 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 11 10 20 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $19.95.) Ten thousand years of English history, seen through the experiences of five families. 12 12 2 WINTERS' TALES, by Jonathan Winters. (Random House, $13.95.) Unusual short stories by the comedian and television personality. 13 13 17 LEGACY, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $16.95.) The ordeal of a military officer charged with high crimes. 14 29 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 15 15 10 BLUEBEARD, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A painter's life in the artists-and-writers world of Long Island's Hamptons. 16 * 1 WINTER, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $19.95.) The experiences of a Berlin family, from Kaiser Wilhelm to Adolf Hitler. Nonfiction 1 1 14 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $15.95.) Counting his blessings and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50. 2 4 3 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 3 5 6 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 4 2 17 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 5 3 6 SEVEN STORIES OF CHRISTMAS LOVE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack, $12.95.) The advocate of caring and love recalls experiences during holidays past. 6 10 50 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 7 7 17 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (Random House, $19.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells his story. 8 9 8 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF THE SOVIET UNION. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The vast country on May 15, 1987, as recorded in pictures by 100 of the world's leading photojournalists. 9 13 5 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) Profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. 10 6 7 FREE TO BE . . . A FAMILY, edited by Marlo Thomas with Christopher Cerf and Letty Cottin Pogrebin. (Bantam, $19.95.) Stories, poems and drawings about family relationships. 11 11 23 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former senior member of the British secret service. 12 15 2 PERESTROIKA, by Mikhail Gorbachev. (Bessie/ Harper & Row, $19.95.) The Soviet leader's views on changing his country and the world. 13 14 2 THE NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC SOCIETY, by C. D. B. Bryan. (Abrams, $45.) The 100-year history of an American institution in pictures and words. 14 8 3 I THINK I DON'T REMEMBER, by Art Buchwald. (Putnam, $16.95.) Humorous columns about the late afternoon of the Reagan era. 15 9 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 6 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. 2 5 7 BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS NEW COOK BOOK. (Meredith, $16.95.) The ring-bound edition. 3 2 121 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 4 26 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 5 1 MICROWAVE GOURMET, by Barbara Kafka. (Morrow, $19.95.) More than 500 recipes for microwave cooking. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE NATURE OF LOVE. Volume Three: The Modern World, by Irving Singer. (University of Chicago, $24.95.) In the final volume of his history of love as a history of ideas, Mr. Singer follows the decline and collapse of the romantic ideal through such writers as Kierkegaard, Freud, Proust and Sartre. ROMANTIC COMEDY: In Hollywood, From Lubitsch to Sturges, by James Harvey. (Knopf, $35.) A vast (716 pages), unsystematic and frequently brilliant critical romp through the film comedies of the 1930's and 40's and the absurd joy they brought us. VOYAGER, by Jeana Yeager and Dick Rutan with Phil Patton. (Knopf, $19.95.) The nuts, bolts and agony of the authors' preposterous, glorious nine-day nonstop flight around the world. THE FRANCO REGIME: 1936-1975, by Stanley G. Payne. (University of Wisconsin, $30.) A judicious, thorough and empathetic account of the durable, enigmatic Spanish dictator. CONGREGATION: Contemporary Writers Read the Jewish Bible, edited by David Rosenberg. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $29.95.) Various, vocal and intelligent, 37 writers approach the books of the Bible through their own sensibilities; the resulting testimonies run from irreverent to devout, from quixotic to profoundly serious. EDDY DECO'S LAST CAPER: An Illustrated Mystery, by Gahan Wilson. (Times Books, $14.95.) Power-mad extraterrestrials assault Mr. Wilson's private detective in a thriller whose wonderful cartoons are the best part of the narration. LOVERS OF THE AFRICAN NIGHT, by William Duggan. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Mr. Duggan's second novel uses the devices of oral storytelling to render the pragmatic, tenacious BaNare, holding fast to their tribal past through cataclysmic change.

title: TOWN AND GOWN: HOW NEIGHBORLY I THE RELATIONSHIP?
description: LEAD: IN 1926, William Van Duzer Lawrence, a prominent Bronxville businessman and real-estate developer, had a vision for a college based in his village. It would bear the name of his late wife, Sarah, and be ''restricted and confined to the education and finish of the best American girls.''

title: JANET A. SCHIERLOH, A TEACHER, TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Schierloh of Oradell, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Janet Appleton Schierloh to Reese Evans Howard Jr., the son of Mrs. Alger Howard of Far Hills, N.J., and Mr. Howard of New York and Southport, Conn. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Correction
description: Because of mechanical errors, a review of William Duggan's ''Lovers of the African Night'' on Dec. 20 included two incorrect phrases. They should have read: ''Ata Four is a woman of courage; when a vicious Boer sets his dogs loose and three innocent Africans are killed, Ata pays the Boer back with honey-and-mustard goat meat pies laced with rat poison''; and, ''She has a son, Kanye -which means 'enough' - and lives to see him become a hero: In a student demonstration against abuses in education he is shot by the police.''

title: Machaut and Chaucer
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Credit For Life's Experiences
description: AS A COLLEGE student in the late 1960's, Elliott J. Murphy was a classic flop. ''I hated it,'' said Mr. Murphy, who has since become a successful rock musician and songwriter. The two years he spent at a local community college, he said, were ''basically a way to keep out of the draft.'' Today, Mr. Murphy, who is 38 years old, is about to get his bachelor's degree from Empire State College, a school that caters to adults returning to education - often after a long hiatus. He has only positive words for his most recent encounter with higher education, and for this he credits Empire State's unusual approach to learning.

title: Giving New Life to Old Fabrics
description: JENNY BELL WHYTE TRANSFORMS tattered textiles into pedigreed finery. Not just any old tatters, but worn antique textiles of museum quality. The finery is contemporary clothing fashioned from the restored pieces, which are available at her homey brownstone ''shop'' on the Upper East Side, indistinguishable from the living quarters Mrs. Whyte shares with her husband and daughter.

title: INCREASE IN TUBERCULOSIS TIED TO SPREAD OF AIDS
description: Federal researchers have reported a substantial increase in tuberculosis in the United States for 1986, the first in more than three decades of record-keeping. They said AIDS was partly to blame. The nation recorded 22,768 cases of tuberculosis in 1986, up 2.6 percent from 22,201 in 1985, the Federal Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday.

title: MOVIES
description: Come Back, Africa Written, directed and produced by Lionel Rogosin. Mystic Fire Video. 83 minutes. $60.

title: GARDENING COPING WITH THE PROBLEMS OF WINTER
description: LEAD: ''AS the days begin to lengthen, winter, then, begins to strengthen,'' goes the old saying. Indeed, now that we have passed the shortest day of the year, we can expect the coldest, snowiest part of the winter to lie just ahead. Such weather often leads to plant problems, some of which can be prevented with minimal effort.

title: Young Fenians In Love and History
description: THE TENANTS OF TIME By Thomas Flanagan. 824 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/E. P. Dutton. $21.95.

title: MISS GRUBER PLANS TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Gary R. Gruber of Bryn Mawr, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Martha Gruber, to Richard William Wagner, the son of the Rev. and Mrs. William O. Wagner of Southbury, Conn.

title: A Patch for Rose
description: WHEN workers ripped up the nine-year-old artificial turf at Riverfront Stadium two weeks ago to clear the way for the installation of a new surface, they were instructed by Cincinnati Reds officials to save one piece of the carpet - and of baseball history. That was the patch where Pete Rose's 4,192d hit landed on Sept. 11th, 1985, the hit that broke the longstanding record of Ty Cobb for most hits in a major-league career.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A NARROW TIME. By Michael Downing. (Vintage, Paper, $6.95.) When first encountered, Anne Fossicker, the Connecticut woman who narrates this remarkable novel, seems to have achieved the best of all possible worlds. Married to a capable and affectionate man, mother of three intelligent children, she is about to begin a promising full-time job.

title: Only Memories For Giants Fan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CHRISTMAS PARTY
description: LEAD: As E. Bruce Ross recalls it now, the idea was born four holiday seasons ago after he and some friends had spent a relaxed time in the warmer climate of the Caribbean, talking about boats and shopping for expensive presents for families and friends.

title: Plane Crash in Turkey Kills 16
description: A West German charter plane carrying 16 people crashed in mountainous countryside near the western coast tonight. Everyone aboard was believed to have been killed, the Anatolia news agency reported.

title: What Would Hippocrates Have Said About AIDS?
description: ALMOST as difficult as the scientific riddle of AIDS is the ethical question of whether doctors are obliged to care for patients infected with the deadly virus.

title: INQUIRY INTO BUSH SEEN ON IRAN SALES
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair is expected to submit questions to Vice President Bush about his role in the sale of American weapons to Iran and is considering requesting an interview with Mr. Bush, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: GULOTTA FACING A FULL AGENDA OF CHALLENGES
description: WHEN Thomas S. Gulotta was appointed Nassau County Executive a year ago, he inherited thorny problems ranging from solid-waste disposal to a dwindling water supply.

title: New Jersey Guide
description: 'BILOXI BLUES' IN MILLBURN Neil Simon's ''Biloxi Blues,'' which won a Tony award for best play in 1985, opens Wednesday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn. It is the middle work in Mr. Simon's semi-autobiographical trilogy, which begins with ''Brighton Beach Memoirs'' and ends with ''Broadway Bound.''

title: Italy's Aged Balsamic Vinegar
description: IN Modena, until not long ago, a girl could hope to find a husband only if she could make pasta and if her dowry included a little barrel of balsamic vinegar. Eating well is very important in Modena, hometown of Luciano Pavarotti and Ferrari cars, as it is in next-door Bologna and throughout the region of Emilia-Romagna, the gastronomic heartland of Italy.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Word-Killer In an encyclopedic novel that was a recent best seller in France, Georges Perec describes an unusual occupation. This is from ''Life: A User's Manual'' (Godine).

title: AID GROUPS RATED ON PUERTO RICANS
description: Puerto Rican organizations receive negligible philanthropic support from some leading foundations, according to a study conducted for the National Puerto Rican Coalition, a seven-year-old association based in Washington.

title: TEACHER WHO STARTED IN ONE-ROOM SCHOOL MARKS 50TH YEAR
description: LEAD: THE widely discussed problem of teacher burnout has never been an issue for Emily Lent, who recently marked her 50th year as a teacher in the Hendrick Hudson School District. For Mrs. Lent, who started her teaching career at the age of 19 in the last one-room schoolhouse in the county, the constant stimulus in her work has been, and continues to be, the children.

title: Ultraconsumers
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDENING COPING WITH THE PROBLEMS OF WINTER
description: LEAD: ''AS the days begin to lengthen, winter, then, begins to strengthen,'' goes the old saying. Indeed, now that we have passed the shortest day of the year, we can expect the coldest, snowiest part of the winter to lie just ahead. Such weather often leads to plant problems, some of which can be prevented with minimal effort.

title: CELEBRATING 80 YEARS OF LITHOGRAPHY
description: WHEN a major exhibition of the work of Georgia O'Keeffe, marking the centennial of the artist's birth, opened at Washington's National Gallery of Art two months ago, a big, lavish book entitled ''Georgia O'Keeffe Arts and Letters,'' containing 120 color plates of all the exhibited work, accompanied the exhibition.

title: STAR WARS
description: As many studies have shown, most notably the recent one by the American Physical Society, there is no way either now or in the foreseeable future to build a Star Wars defense that would shift the balance from offensive to defensive weapons. Given the dim military prospects, given the risks in deployment, given that the Russians seem eager to negotiate limits on research, why would anyone want to spend $4 billion a year on Star Wars research? (Never mind the $100 billion to $1,000 billion that William Broad estimates will be required as an ''initial cost.'') JOHN BECHHOEFER Chicago

title: BOARD MAY LIMIT SALES AT GAS STATIONS
description: LEAD: THE Brookhaven Town Board is considering a ban on conversions of service stations into convenience stores that would sell anything other than automobile-related articles.

title: What's Behind Cheap-Fare Ads
description: THE questions asked most insistently of this column concern the small ads in newspapers, including this one, that simply list cities in Europe and Asia and then prices. At the bottom of the ad is the name of an organization, a phone number and sometimes an address.

title: DR. YEOMANS TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic H. Yeomans of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Susan Mary Yeomans, to Dr. Thomas Francis Breen Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Breen of Burlington, Vt. Dr. Yeomans, who graduated from Princeton University and the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, is a chief resident in ophthalmology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Her fiance, a Harvard fellow in orthopedics and hand surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, graduated from Williams College and the University of Vermont Medical School.

title: Court Blocks Use of Illicit Assets for Legal Fees
description: A sharply divided Federal appeals court has ruled that the Government may in effect prevent defendants from hiring the lawyers of their choice by freezing defendants' assets in racketeering and drug cases.

title: COCKNEY CHARISMA
description: I encourage William Boyd to refamiliarize himself with Evelyn Waugh's masterpiece ''Brideshead Revisited,'' Chapter 6, in which Cordelia, one of the Flyte family members, says to Charles, the narrator: ''Charles . . . modern art is all great bosh, isn't it?''

title: A Nominee by Spring? Hart Makes It Tougher
description: Gary Hart's sudden decision to re-enter the 1988 Presidential campaign has provoked, at least in public, more wringing of hands than careful calculation, more denunciation than analysis of its impact on the Democratic race.

title: Special Today: Education Life/Section 12
description: Special reports in this issue include:

title: IS WALL STREET AS BAD AS IT'S PAINTED?
description: BEFORE THE STOCK MARKET collapse of all too recent memory, the fashion designers got it wrong: hemlines kept climbing, allegedly a sign of good times to come. But the creative artists of stage, screen and literature got it right: They saw the boom, the big bull market, the age of the yuppies coming to an end, to be brought down by pride, lust, greed and other deadly sins.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DIMINISHING RETURNS
description: LEAD: BLOOMINGDALE'S last weekend was a time warp.

title: The Shape of a Rodin Tour
description: THE obvious Rodinophile's rendezvous in Paris is the Musee Rodin, one of the most popular museums in France. For decades - at least until Picasso got his museum in the Marais - it had no rival among one-man galleries anywhere in the world. A young Parisian friend and I used the museum, on Rue de Varenne, as the starting point for a Rodin tour of Paris, a tour on foot, Metro and train that led to churches, tenement and mansion, to both banks of the Seine and to a suburban vantage point.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: Suleyman the Magnificent Produced and directed by Suzanne Bauman. Home Vision. 57 minutes. $39.95.

title: A Year of Shame
description: As one scandal after another unfolds, it is clear that President Reagan presides over one of the most corrupt administrations ever. Whether measured by the rank or the sheer numbers of officials who have come under ethical suspicion and criminal investigation, the amount of sleaze is awesome. Precise comparisons to the Grant, Harding and Nixon Administrations aren't possible or necessary. The Reagan Administration rivals them all for official lawlessness, contempt for law, and playing loose with the truth.

title: Dye's Tie Still Ugly In Syracuse's View
description: It was apparent that there had not been any overnight revelations for Dick MacPherson. The Syracuse coach came to a team breakfast this morning, lacking sleep and a satisfactory explanation for why Auburn chose to play for a tie in the Sugar Bowl game the day before. He tried to mask his feelings, engaging in long goodbyes with players heading home for the remainder of the semester break, hugging and kissing members of their families. But inside, he stewed.

title: THE NEW GREED TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: SUDDENLY EVERYBODY IS TALKING about greed. It may not be a brand-new topic, but after the chastening experience of the stock market fall in October it seems an all too appropriate one. We virtuously distance ourselves from yesterday's excesses (without necessarily discarding today's); and three works in particular have shown up at just the right time to highlight our concerns - Oliver Stone's movie ''Wall Street,'' Caryl Churchill's play ''Serious Money'' and Tom Wolfe's novel ''The Bonfire of the Vanities.''

title: NONFICTION
description: RED HORIZONS: Chronicles of a Communist Spy Chief. By Lieut. Gen. Ion Mihai Pacepa. (Regnery Gateway/ Kampmann, $19.95.) In 1945, Rumanian intelligence officers provided the nascent United States intelligence organization with copious secret files on the Soviet Union - of value in part because they covered Soviet territory occupied by Rumanian forces during World War II. In 1978, Ion Pacepa, chief of the Rumanian foreign intelligence service, defected to the United States, one of the highest-ranking East European espionage chiefs to change sides since Communist rule was established in Eastern Europe. On the face of it, he seemed to be the biggest catch from Rumania since the 1945 files. But since his defection, Mr. Pacepa, who in Rumania attained the rank of lieutenant general and was a personal adviser to President Nicolae Ceausescu, has several times changed his stories. The changes, according to the State Department and counterintelligence officers who have debriefed him, have cast doubt on his veracity. Now, with ''Red Horizons,'' he offers a version of his life and experiences that increases one's doubts about whether his defection was much of a coup. Mr. Pacepa is the Happy Hooker of the spy trade, relating utterly sordid tales of a drunken Ceausescu son tearing the clothes off women at parties and urinating on a plate of oysters, of the deviant sexual tastes of a Palestinian leader and vile acts by Rumanian politicians. These squalid anecdotes about the private lives of the Communist elite make up a good part of the memoir; I can confirm his picture of the debauchery of the Ceausescu son Nicu, who heads the Communist youth movement. But when Mr. Pacepa describes the poor, rundown Athenee Palace Hotel as a grand nest of spies, or boasts that Rumania maintained powerful ''agents of influence'' in this country, or profited from the theft of American advanced technology one can only chuckle. Besides, his stories are all at least a decade old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Rutgers 77, Arizona 54: Sue Wicks scored 17 points and grabbed 11 rebounds and Rutgers reeled off 14 straight first-half points last night on the way to a victory over Arizona in Piscataway, N.J. The victory was the 35th straight at home for the Lady Knights and raised their record to 6-2. Rutgers held Arizona scoreless for more than seven minutes during the 14-point outburst in the first half that gave it a 25-13 edge. Rutgers held a 38-18 lead at halftime and led by as many as 30 points in the second half. Missy Lender and Janet Malouf added 14 points apiece for Rutgers. Dana Patterson scored 19 points and had 8 rebounds for Arizona, which is coached by June Olkowski, a former all-American at Rutgers. Olkowski, who played at Rutgers from 1978-82, was honored before the game and her No. 45 jersey was retired. (AP) Tennis Shriver Moves to Final: Top-seeded Pam Shriver routed Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, 6-4, 6-0, yesterday to reach the final of the Ariadne Classic tournament in Brisbane, Australia. Shriver will be looking for her second title in the event when she faces Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia in the final today. Novotna downed Patty Fendick of the United States, 7-5, 6-1, in the other semifinal. (AP) Masur Crushes Fitzgerald: The defender, Wally Masur, crushed a fellow Australian, John Fitzgerald, 6-1, 6-1, last night to move into the final of the South Australian Open at Adelaide. Masur, ranked 35th in the world, will face a countryman, Mark Woodforde, in the final today. Woodforde, seeded third, eased to a 6-1, 6-4 victory over Johan Anderson of Australia in the other semifinal. (AP) Chesnokov Beats Pridham: In Wellington, New Zealand, fourth-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union fought off a match point and went on to beat Chris Pridham of Canada, 4-6, 6-3, 9-7, yesterday to advance to the final of the New Zealand Open. Chesnokov will meet sixth-seeded Ramesh Krishnan of India, who took only 58 minutes to defeat second-seeded Kelly Evernden of New Zealand, the defending champion, 6-3, 6-1.(AP) Horse Racing Clever Secret Wins on Foul: Clever Secret was placed first in the $91,350 Aqueduct Handicap for 3-year-olds and up yesterday after King's Swan, the favorite and the first to finish, was disqualified and placed fourth for causing interference. Proud Debonair was placed second in the revised order of finish with Native Wizard awarded the third spot. King's Swan, the odds-on favorite, bore in, impeding Native Wizard nearing the finish. He reached the wire a half-length ahead of Clever Secret, but was disqualified following an inquiry. Clever Secret carried 112 pounds and E. T. Baird over the mile-and-a-sixteenth route in 1:45 1/5 on a fast track. The 4-year-old colt by Secretariat-Small Loaf earned $54,180 for Eugene V. Klein and returned $30.60 for $2 to win in the field of nine. Bowling A First for Jasnau: Mike Jasnau of Wichita, Kan., threw a strike in the final frame to capture his first Professional Bowlers Association title in the ARC Alameda Open in California. He beat Wayne Webb of Waco, Tex., 259-246, to earn $18,000. (AP) Track and Field Pascuzzo Qualifies for Games Trials: Mike Pascuzzo of Mount Laurel, N.J., a former University of Maryland high jumper now competing for the New York Athletic Club, made the qualifying height for the 1988 Olympic trials yesterday when he cleared 7 feet 5 inches during the Reebok New Year's Indoor Festival at the fieldhouse of the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y. Bill Krone won the two-mile run in 8 minutes 53.38 seconds. Jim Flynn was second in 8:56.98, and Pat Petersen was third in 9:01.37. In high-school events, Rod Greenidge of Boys and Girls upset Sam Rice of Cardinal Hayes in the 300-meter dash in 35.88 seconds. Sharon Moore, also from Boys and Girls, won the girl's 1,000-meter run in 3:00.72. Boxing Nunn Keeps His Title: Michael Nunn of Van Nuys, Calif., the North American Boxing Federation middleweight champion, defended his title against Kevin Watts of Pleasantville, N.J., yesterday by taking a unanimous 12-round decision in Los Angeles. The champion, who weighed 160 pounds, used superior hand and foot speed to negate Watts's punching power. Watts, who also weighed 160, moved in steadily and kept pressuring. The 23-year-old Nunn, who won his 28th consecutive bout, is ranked No. 2 by both the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association. Watts appeared to make Nunn back off in the 11th round, hitting him with a powerful left-right combination. But Nunn regained his composure and finished the round in command. Nunn improved to 28-0; Watts fell to 17-4-1.(AP)

title: Staying Out
description: Armand Therrien, a murderer who escaped from a Massachusetts prison three weeks ago, has apologized for his early departure. But he also said he would not be coming back. The state Correction Commissioner, Michael V. Fair, disclosed last week that he had received the apology in a letter from Mr. Therrien, a former state trooper who in 1975 was sentenced to serve two consecutive life terms for killing his business partner and a Westwood police officer. Mr. Fair, who two years ago overruled other prison officials in approving Mr. Therrien's petition to transfer to the minimum-security facility from which he subsequently escaped, said he felt ''burned and betrayed.'' He said it was the first time in 19 years that ''a prisoner went back on his word to me.''

title: Rochambeau Camped Here: Homes on Hill
description: On July 2, 1781, General Comte de Rochambeau chose a 60-acre hillside in Ridgefield, Conn., to encamp his French Army troops aiding the American colonists because it afforded a strategic view of the British camp in New York. John W. Ryan looked over the same border 206 years later, saw the corporate headquarters of Westchester County, and decided that a 17-home development on the same hillside would have a market. Work has begun on three houses since the project was approved in the summer, with the first to be completed in March. The entire project should take three years to complete. The four-bedroom, colonial-style homes, priced from $700,000 to $750,000, will sit on three-acre lots, as mandated by Ridgefield zoning laws. The town also required that the project, near several stables, have a riding trail across it. ''Ridgefield is equestrian country, and so they wanted to get from one area to another,'' said Daniel R. Pisani, Mr. Ryan's partner. ''It's sort of like a right of way.''

title: Village Rich in History Is Now Just Plain Rich
description: A history of Weston's role in the Revolutionary War notes that the farming town was half a day's carriage ride to Boston and a favorite overnight spot for weary travelers headed for the state capital.

title: Record Shops
description: To the Editor: Re ''Shopping in London for Record Bargains'' by Leo Haber (Travel, Nov. 29): We are frequent travelers to London and recognized most of the shops mentioned. We would, however, like to bring to your readers' attention another.

title: RANDY S. CAPLAN TO WED PHYSICIAN
description: Randy Sue Caplan, a third-year student at the Fordham University school of Law, and Dr. Michael Hunter Perskin, a resident in internal medicine at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York, plan to be married on Jan. 31.

title: DEIRDRE CONNOLLY PLANS TO MARRY OLAF SPORNS
description: Deirdre Connolly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Connolly of Locust Valley, L.I., and Olaf Sporns, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl L. Sporns of Kiel, West Germany, plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents have announced.

title: A BLOSSOMING OF CREATIVITY
description: THE Christmas tree has been hurled out in the back of the property, where it will gradually turn brown and become a haven for birds and other animals braving the blasts of winter. The children have just left amid hugs and honks of the car horns. My husband beats a hasty path to the television set to catch the last seconds of the football game, and I slip away to my long-awaited rendezvous with the amaryllis.

title: PREVENTING PIPES FROM FREEZING
description: FROZEN plumbing is easily one of winter's worst household disasters.

title: Vermont Town to Keep Cross Despite Adverse Court Ruling
description: Town officials here say that an adverse court ruling will not keep them from leaving a cross atop a Christmas tree on the courthouse lawn until holiday decorations are dismantled next week.

title:
GARDENING;
Bark Enlivens a Landscape
description: LEAD: FEW gardeners choose plants because they have beautiful bark. But where there are cold winters and the plants are leafless more than half of the year, ornamental qualities of tree bark are important.

title: The Baby-Boomers Change Courses
description: ANN HOROWITZ, 27 years old, traveled across the nation and abroad for several years after college, trying her hand at being a chef but finally deciding she would never be as good as she wanted to be. Instead she turned to graduate school at New York University and discovered that she greatly enjoyed the field of public policy. ''I was very ambivalent about going back to school, because I had not been happy at all in college,'' she said. ''But graduate school was the opposite. It wiped away all the fears that I wasn't cut out for academic work. I actually excelled, despite my initial doubts.''

title: A Needed Rest
description: 'The French have a saying that the cemeteries are full of indispensable people. . . . If I come back and function better, it is better for the university.'

title: ANTI-MISSILE LASER GIVEN FIRST TESTS FOR USE IN SPACE
description: The military has begun top-secret ground tests of a compact, powerful laser that the Reagan Administration wants launched into space in the early 1990's as part of the effort to build a defense against nuclear missiles.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: TRADING CARD MANIA

title: U.S. Applauds (Softly) at Changes in Eastern Europe
description: As Eastern Europe enters a period of political and economic fluidity, the United States faces a quandary. If it does nothing, it forfeits an opportunity. If it does too much, it risks fostering an instability that could deliver a severe setback to Soviet-American relations.

title: How 'The Chosen' Became a Musical
description: ''THIS HAS COST ME A novel,'' says Chaim Potok. ''I should be working on it right now. I really should. And I will never write it. You have a finite life to live, so that the price I've paid is a novel, and I don't know whether it is or is not worth it. Because I don't have that novel and I will never have that novel. What I want to do now, as soon as this enterprise is on the boards, is go back to my work - and I would like to do that as quickly as possible.''

title: Executive Is Appointed Yonkers City Manager
description: The Yonkers City Council today appointed Neil J. DeLuca, a former Yonkers youth services director, as city manager. He is to serve until a nationwide search for a permanent manager is completed.

title: EXPENSIVE SQUABBLES
description: LEAD: GUCCI A House Divided. By Gerald McKnight. Illustrated. 362 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $18.95.

title: The Housing Crunch Moves on Campus
description: AMID THE burst of question marks that traditionally rain down on the freshman heading off to college, the dorm room often emerges as the one certainty - reassuringly available, universally inhospitable. Parents in tow, the car trunk a tangle of quilts, extension cords and Impressionist posters, the fresh college student arrives on campus, greeted by an overly cheerful junior who motions toward the new home. It is a barren space, generally measuring about 12 by 14 feet, with an invisible line down the middle flanked by two twin beds, two desks and two wastebaskets. But it - and, with any luck, the roommate - still has terrific potential.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
AT HOME WHERE NOBODY IS
description: LEAD: In the 19th century, Americans could barely stomach the look and feel of the drylands. Today, they seem to have an insatiable appetite for every bare rock, spiny plant and empty salt-flat. DRYLANDS: The Deserts of North America (Yolla Bolly/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $75) appeals to this hunger for dry ground empty of every human artifact (no power lines, no roads, no people, no machines, no smog, no houses, no livestock) save the graffiti of American Indians, stuff we call petroglyphs.

title: OFFICE RENTAL BOOM IN MELVILLE SLACKENS A BIT
description: LEAD: WHEN Reckson Associates opened its new four-story, 190,000-square foot 495 Expressway Corporate Center on New Year's Day, there was something missing: tenants.

title: Travel Agents
description: To The Editor: With reference to the Practical Traveler (Nov. 29) concerning travel agents: I am an agent who happily books leisure travel, and I would like to point out a few additional services a good travel agent can offer.

title: Sick Thinking
description: WAKING AT night, I made my way in the dark to the bathroom without trouble, but when I switched on the light, I was stunned: it wasn't my bathroom at home - or, in fact, any bathroom I'd ever seen. I supposed I must be in a hotel on a business trip - but what trip? What hotel? I had no idea. Panic such as one feels in certain nightmares swept over me, but this was no nightmare; I was definitely awake. I wondered whether some tiny fragile blood vessel in my brain had burst, wrecking the intricate machinery of the mind.

title: DAZZLING THE KILLJOYS
description: THE LIFE OF KENNETH TYNAN By Kathleen Tynan. Illustrated. 597 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: RABBI'S SON WINS PROSECUTOR'S AWARD
description: LEAD: SITTING behind a large desk stacked with legal papers, Michael Chertoff hardly looks the type who could put some of the nation's most hardened criminals behind bars.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: AMERICA ON SIX RUBLES A DAY: Or, How to Become a Capitalist Pig. By Yakov Smirnoff. (Vintage, Paper, $5.95.) Yakov Smirnoff is a Soviet emigre amusenik who has become popular in America via stand-up comedy, light beer commercials and a syndicated television series. In the decade he has been here, he has made the quantum leap from the Volga to Vegas by using a combination of traditional mainstream Catskills shtick and comparisons of the wild, crazy and ecstatically confusing United States of America with the dour, paranoiac police state of Mother Russia.

title: Stunning Playing of a Wonderful Period Piece
description: THE COMPACT DISK REVOLUTION reminds many old-timers of the early days of the LP. Starting around 1950, dozens, then scores, then hundreds of small companies started putting out a kind of product, especially in classical music, that the major companies would not touch. Suddenly we had a plethora of Baroque music. We had a mania for complete sets - the complete Haydn symphonies, the complete Mozart quartets, the complete Bach organ music, the complete everything. American companies made deals with European radio stations for tapes and other materials, and out came Verdi and Donizetti operas nobody had ever heard. Young, unknown artists came cheap, and they were signed up left and right. Some, like Alfred Brendel and Paul Badura-Skoda, went on to big things. Conductors: whoever heard of Hermann Scherchen and Ernest Ansermet before LP? Those were wild, happy, adventurous days. A new world had opened.

title: Moving In
description: Never one to duck trouble, Ariel Sharon has now set up housekeeping in the middle of it. Recently, in what was criticized by many as a provocative gesture, the pugnacious former general, now Israel's Minister of Industry and Trade, took an apartment in the Moslem quarter of Jerusalem. After Mr. Sharon spent his first night in the apartment last week, insisting he was promoting ''integration'' of Arabs and Jews, Mayor Teddy Kollek said the move was ''counterproductive.'' One Islamic religious authority recalled that Jews had lived peaceably in the neighborhood in the 1920's, but said, ''No one wants to live next to Sharon,'' whom he accused of wanting Jerusalem to be ''only for the Jews.'' Mr. Sharon said he was acting out of his long-held belief that ''Jews and Arabs should live together and will live together in the land of Israel.''

title: Another Low For Dollar
description: The dollar rebounded after opening at a record low against the Japanese yen today, while stocks declined sharply in an abbreviated post-holiday session.

title: Villanova Gets Tough To Establish Credibility
description: An hour before his team was scheduled to face Virginia on Saturday night, Rollie Massimino sat in a deserted locker room at the John E. duPont Pavilion contemplating the Big East season.

title: Energy: Forecast for Prices Is Weak, At Best
description: Ask a Texas oilman about the outlook for oil prices in 1988 and the answer typically is about $18 a barrel, or a little more than $1 above the spot price last week for American crude.

title: Cairo Journal; Of Cars and Drivers (and the Body Shop Boom)
description: Business - the Lord be praised - is good thanks to human ineptitude, Said Ead remarked.

title: Hundreds of Youths Mourn Loss of a Friend, 57
description: Many people in Manhasset, L.I., have compared Gus Potter to George Bailey, the character in the classic Frank Capra film ''It's a Wonderful Life.''

title: FILM CRITICS' GROUP HONORS 'THE DEAD'
description: ''The Dead,'' the work that marked the extraordinary synthesis of a great literary talent with a great cinematic one, was voted the best film of 1987 by the National Society of Film Critics yesterday.

title: Green Must Hurdle a Wall of Skepticism
description: Despite expressions of good will from top politicans and educators, Dr. Richard R. Green must contend with a widespread sense of skepticism that an outsider can master the intricacies of the job of New York City Schools Chancellor.

title: Gay Catholics Resume Protest At St. Patrick's
description: A group of gay Roman Catholics resumed their protests during Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, one month after 11 of them were arrested at the Cathedral when they refused to be seated during the sermon.

title: Market Place; Potential Gains In Foreign Stocks
description: A FURTHER decline in the value of the dollar against major foreign currencies would be, on balance, bullish for foreign stocks. However, one risk of investing abroad is that a drop in foreign stock markets could offset the advantage of the currency play. With that caveat in mind, what are some foreign stocks that appear attractive for 1988?

title: African Nation Turns to Song To Warn of AIDS Infection
description: Gripping a microphone, Buca Pussick charmed the crowd with the ballad of Maria, a girl with a ''honey-sweet mouth'' and a ''beautiful body.''

title: Don't Mock New Yorkers Who Want Air and Light in Their City
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Investing More Complex as Markets End Wild Year
description: What a year.

title: Let Those Menorahs, Crosses and Creches Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen Schaffer Weds A Professor of Physics
description: The marriage of Ellen G. Schaffer, the international and foreign law librarian at the Georgetown University Law Center, to Sidney A. Bludman, a professor of physics at the University of Pennsylvania, took place yesterday at the Thomas Law House in Washington. Rabbi Mindy Portnoy performed the ceremony.

title: Chinese Crime Groups Rising To Prominence in New York
description: Chinese organized crime's involvement in extortion, prostitution, loan sharking, gun smuggling and murder is sharply on the rise in the New York area, law-enforcement officials say.

title: Fletcher F. Acord, Postal Official, Dies at 56
description: Fletcher F. Acord, the third-ranking official in the United States Postal Service, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage, a Postal Service spokesman said. He was 56 years old.

title: Comedy: A. Whitney Brown
description: A. WHITNEY BROWN, whose sardonic political commentaries inject a note of ferocious cynicism into the ''Weekend Update'' segments of ''Saturday Night Live,'' brings an air of offended gentility to his analyses of world affairs and governmental mismanagement. An apple-cheeked smoothie, whose deep-set eyes glint with inscrutable comic cool, Mr. Brown epitomizes the attitude of civilized disgust that has replaced moral outrage as the stance of many 80's liberals. This stance assumes knowingness and compassion to be synonymous.

title: Steel: Domestic Producers Seeking 2d Good Year
description: The steel industry has made one of the great comebacks in American corporate history. The question now is whether it can continue to hold its own against foreign competition.

title: Shearson's Chief Cohen Built a Brokerage Army
description: Reminiscing about the growing pains of Shearson Lehman Brothers, Peter A. Cohen, who at 41 is possibly the youngest investment chief on Wall Street, recalls what his daughter, Lauren, told him when she was a little girl.

title: The Year of the Brave
description: On the human rights calendar, 1987 belonged to the brave, especially those who risked their skins monitoring governments. These are freedom's foot soldiers, volunteers who courageously record the names of political prisoners and report on torture and star-chamber justice.

title: Semiconductors: Recovery Is Expected To Continue in 1988
description: After two years of heavy losses that turned the plight of the nation's semiconductor industry into an international political issue, chip makers returned to profitability in 1987. Industry officials and analysts generally expect a continuation of the recovery in 1988.

title: Advertising; JWT's Saga Topped 1987's High Points
description: IN a year that was crowded with major advertising developments, the ongoing saga of the J. Walter Thompson Company was clearly the dominant news story.

title: VIKINGS' 'DIFFERENT' WEAPON
description: IN preparing for the Super Bowl playoffs, coaches often talk about how it's just another football game. ''We haven't approached this game,'' Jim Mora of the Saints said before yesterday's wild-card game, ''any differently than any other game.'' But a playoff game is different. And the Minnesota Vikings approached it differently. Jerry Burns, the Viking coach, added another weapon by using Anthony Carter, his Pro Bowl wide receiver, to return punts. That's the primary reason why the Vikings will oppose the 49ers in San Francisco on Saturday.

title: Strong '88 Profit Rise Doubted
description: The profits of American corporations are likely to rise again this year, aided by growing exports that have been made more competitive by the weak dollar. But, at this point, it looks like consumers will not buy enough in 1988 to give corporations a year of strong income growth.

title: Oilers Win in Overtime
description: The Houston Oilers, the team their fans and the rest of the National Football League forgot, produced a rare but spectacular playoff victory today - their first since 1979.

title: The Chicago Lyric Opera Savors Its Most Successful Season
description: The 10 inches of snow that fell on Chicago this week snarled the city's airports and roads. But down at the Civic Opera House, where the Lyric Opera is halfway through its most successful season, the big winter storm seemed barely a flurry.

title: Washington Talk: The Pentagon and the Press; Gathering News in the Persian Gulf: Suntans and Simmering Frustration
description: The six American journalists, members of a Pentagon-sponsored news pool covering military operations by the Navy in the Persian Gulf, were fed up. They had languished in the sun at their harborside hotel for nearly a week without setting foot aboard a ship.

title: COACH OF CHAMPIONS GOES FOR MORE GOLD
description: THE building was erected in 1928 as a grand equestrian stable. Ten years later, it was converted to its present form, a skating rink, when the owner felt like watching some hockey. For his horses, he built another stable across the street.

title: Panama Strongman Fights Back Against U.S.
description: American servicemen and government civilians arriving in Panama are given a printed ''fact sheet'' by the United States Embassy warning them of civil unrest and providing a radio frequency to tune to for information and instructions in case of trouble.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 4, 1988
description: International A2-11

title: Purchasers Cite Gains for December
description: The nation's industrial economy expanded briskly in December, significantly outshining November in new orders and production, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report scheduled to be released today.

title: Vikings Smash Saints
description: Somehow, a page from the past must have been planted in the New Orleans Saints' playbook last week without the Saints' knowledge. How else can anyone explain what happened today to a team that thought it had put 20 years of football follies behind it, stirring the imagination of its fans, who proudly painted their faces when just a few years ago they covered their heads with paper bags?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Shriver Overcomes Novotna: Top-seeded Pam Shriver of Lutherville, Md., had to struggle for almost two hours yesterday, but she defeated Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 7-6, in the championship of the Ariadne Classic at the Milton Courts in Brisbane, Australia. Shriver won $25,000. Novotna, the 11th-seeded player, held 4 set points when she led, 6-2, in the first-set tiebreaker, but Shriver came back by winning 6 straight points. Novotna also led, 4-1, with two breaks in the second set, but Shriver forced a second tiebreaker. (AP) Final to Krishnan: Ramesh Krishnan of India beat Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-7, 6-0, 6-4, 6-3, to win the New Zealand Open. Krishnan, who was seeded sixth, needed 2 hours 45 minutes to win. Chesnokov, 21, tried to pressure Krishnan by coming to the net, but the 26-year-old Indian countered with well-placed groundstrokes and passing shots. In the doubles final, Rick Leach and Dan Goldie of the United States defeated Brod Dyke of Australia and Glen Michibata of Canadia, 6-2, 6-3. (AP) Soviet Player Wins: Andrei Cherkasov of the Soviet Union, the top-seeded player, overtook another Soviet player, Vladimir Petrushenko, 4-6, 6-1, 6-0, to win the Boys' 18 singles title in the Port Washington international junior championships yesterday at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy. Cherkasov was runner-up in the Orange Bowl last week and finished second in the United States Open junior championships in September. In the Girls' 18 finals, unseeded Nana Mujagi of Japan routed third-seeded Elena Brukovets of the Soviet Union, 6-1, 6-3. College Basketball Hofstra 94, St. Joseph's 55: Carlos DiCenta, who connected on seven of eight 3-point shots, scored 24 points yesterday to lead Hofstra to a rout of St. Joseph's of Patchogue, L.I., in the Hofstra Classic at Hempstead, L.I. The Flying Dutchmen (2-5) moved into tonight's title game against Westmont of Santa Barbara, Calif., which beat Brown, 71-64, in the other first-round game.(AP) Horse Racing Second Choice Wins: Joe's Tammie raced in front wire-to-wire to score a 3 3/4-length victory in the $81,300 Montauk Stakes for New York-bred 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Whodam was second with Fourstardave, the favorite, another 1 3/4 lengths back in third. Cannondawn and Nashua's Secret completed the order of finish. The victory was the fifth in 10 career starts for the 3-year-old daughter of Zoning-Funny Tammy, and the fourth in stakes company. She covered the mile and one-sixteenth on the fast track in 1:46 2/5 to earn $48,780 for David S. Milch and paid $5.20 for $2 to win as the second choice. Boxing On the Comeback Trail: Donald Curry, a former welterweight champion, continued his comeback by scoring a unanimous 12-round decision over 25-year-old Lupe Aquino of Mexico in a super welterweight bout yesterday. On the same card, Gianfranco Rosi of Italy, the World Boxing Council super welterweight champion, defended his title by knocking out Duane Thomas of Detroit. Rosi will now defend on April 8 against Curry. Curry piled up a wide advantage by landing fast left hooks and precise combinations to the body and head of Aquino. Curry, of Fort Worth, lost his welterweight title in September 1986 to Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain. Last year, Curry was stopped by Mike McCallum in six rounds for the vacant World Boxing Association junior middleweight title. With his victory over Aquino, Curry has a 29-2 record, with 20 knockouts. Aquino's record fell to 31-1-4. Aquino, who fights out of Las Vegas, Nev., was the former world super welterweight champion. The match was somewhat dull and drew some whistles from the crowd. Both fighters weighed 156.86 pounds.(AP) Road Racing Trott Wins Run: Paul Trott of Super Runners took the lead after three miles and went on to win a 5-mile run in 24 minutes 42 seconds yesterday in Central Park. Michele Bush of the Warren Street Athletic Club won the women's race in 27:43. Jorge Fernandez of the West Side Y.M.C.A. finished second among the men in 24:56. Scott Elliott of Boulder, Colo., was third in 24:57. The race was sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club.(AP) Ice Hockey Canadian Juniors Win: In Moscow, Canada remained unbeaten in the world junior championships with an 8-1 victory over West Germany yesterday. A victory over Poland today would give Canada the gold medal. The Soviet Union (5-1-0) scored a 7-2 victory over Poland (1-5-0). The Russians play West Germany (1-5-0) today. (AP)

title: 28 Chilean Exiles Occupy U.N. Offices in Brazil
description: For the last four weeks, 28 Chilean exiles, including 10 children, have been occupying the local offices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees as part of a campaign to obtain political asylum in a country other than Brazil.

title: Banking: Regional Powers Gain As Giants Struggle
description: The shake-up in the nation's banking industry will accelerate this year. Regional banks will continue to consolidate into bigger and bigger institutions, while the traditional behemoths - based in New York, Chicago and California - will remain locked in their struggle to deal with huge loans to deeply troubled third-world countries.

title: Byzantine Coins in Egypt
description: Archeologists have unearthed a trove of ancient gold coins while restoring a 1,500-year-old Coptic monastery, the head of Egypt's Antiquities Organization said today. Ahmed Kadri said at a news conference that the 820 Byzantine coins, dating to the fifth and sixth centuries, were found last month in two clay jars. They bear portraits of the Eastern Roman Emperors Heraclius and Justinian I. The treasure was found at the White Monastery in Sohag, 370 miles south of Cairo. It was built by the Copts, the Christians of Egypt who now make up about 10 percent of the population of 52 million.

title: Europe Is a Desert for U.S. Issues
description: For American companies seeking to sell debt or equity, Europe is looking barren and forbidding.

title: CANADA
description: The story of the Toronto Stock Exchange in 1987 was the story of the commodities markets. Creeping inflation and increased economic activity helped raise the prices of such important commodities as gold and copper. That proved a boon for many companies on Canada's resource-oriented exchange.

title: Brooklyn Man Held in Killing Of Boy at Door of Apartment
description: A 41-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with the slaying of a 12-year-old Coney Island boy who was shot in the head Dec. 30 as he looked through the peephole of his family's apartment door.

title: UNITED STATES
description: Only three weeks into 1987, the year was already shaping up as an historic one on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had closed out 1986 at 1,895.95, promptly waltzed past 2,000 on Jan. 8 and then 2,100 on Jan. 19.

title: Wagner's Call to Teachers' Leader Cleared Way to Schools Decision
description: Toward the end of the withering four-and-a-half-month process of choosing a New York City schools chancellor, a critical moment came when the president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., telephoned Sandra Feldman, the head of the teachers' union, on Thursday morning.

title: Israeli Army Decides To Deport 9 Arabs In Wake of Rioting
description: The Israeli Army announced today that it would permanently expel nine Palestinian nationalists arrested during the riots of the last three weeks.

title: Boom in U.S. for Latin Writers
description: A half-dozen years ago, so many American publishers were issuing fiction by Latin American authors that critics dubbed the period the ''Latin boom.'' The boom inevitably subsided, but now it is returning stronger than ever - not just with more titles, but also with books that are already major critical or commercial successes in Latin America and Europe.

title: UNSELD IS NAMED BULLETS' NEW COACH
description: Kevin Loughery, who coached the Washington Bullets to an 8-19 start this season, was dismissed today and replaced by Wes Unseld, a Bullets assistant coach.

title: Buyout Artist Kravis Had a High-Ticket Year
description: For Henry R. Kravis, the man who perfected the art of the leveraged buyout, it is hard to imagine a better year than 1987.

title: Pope Dines With Homeless
description: Pope John Paul II had dinner with about 130 poor and homeless people today, becoming the first Pope in modern history to sit down and eat with the poor inside the Vatican. Vatican sources said the Pope was greeted with applause as he entered a refectory near St. Peter's Basilica to share a meal of pasta, meat, fruit and wine with the homeless men and women, many of whom sleep in the streets of Rome throughout the year.

title: Package of Problems for a Player and His Coach
description: LEAD: AGILE, polished and powerful, at 7 feet and 270 pounds, Stanley Roberts is the sort of center around whom winning basketball teams are built. During his first two seasons playing for Lower Richland High School on the outskirts of Columbia, S.C., he led the Diamonds to a 48-8 record and a 1987 state championship.

title: Metro Matters; Rhetoric, Rage And Discussing Volatile Issues
description: Mayor Koch declared his own ''Day of Outrage'' last week, but almost nobody came.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 4, 1988
description: Companies

title: Ph.D. Candidates Need Faculties That Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
