description: QUESTION: How many players have hit home runs in their first time at bat in the major leagues and which one of the group wound up with the most homers for a career? Have any made it to the Hall of Fame?

title: France Moves to Curb Campaign Funds
description: Officials in the administration of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac said today that they would formally propose legislation later this month that would set limits for the first time on campaign spending and donations.

title: Call It Sleep
description: LEAD: In 1970, Sheik Mohammed Ali Jaabari, the Mayor of Hebron, had a few of us American journalists to his home for tea.

title: Greenspan's Fast Action Reassured the Skeptics
description: When Alan Greenspan was sworn in as Federal Reserve chairman in August, few doubted his powers as an economic analyst, but whether this lifelong adviser could adequately set policy as head of the nation's central bank remained to be seen.

title: Indoor Lacrosse; N.J. Saints Win In Season Opener
description: Lacrosse at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, an ancient game in a modern setting, mixed marketing and mild mayhem tonight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's a shame we had to pick this week to be terrible.'' - Tony Elliott of the New Orleans Saints. [ C4:1. ]

title: Autos: Detroit's Rosy View Has Some Support
description: America's passion for new transportaton vehicles remains nearly as ardent as ever. Most industry forecasts call for sales of about 10 million cars and 5 million light trucks - roughly the same as last year but down from 1986, when 16.3 million vehicles were sold.

title: GERMANY
description: The West German stock market got off to a bad start in 1987. Foreign investors, who had accounted for 60 percent of the turnover, began to pull out amid concern that the market's bull run was ending. The relative stability of the dollar in the spring led to some improvement, but the summer would prove a calm before the storm.

title: Queens Man, 59, Held In Slaying of Woman
description: A 59-year-old Queens man was arrested early yesterday in the shooting death of a woman who was described as his girlfriend, the police said.

title: At Tully Hall, Ushers Gain a Spot in the Lights
description: The only problem at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night will be finding someone to show you your seat, because all but a few of the ushers will be performing.

title: Sabres Prevail, 2-1
description: Tom Barrasso made 27 saves tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Quebec Nordiques, 2-1.

title: Dog Survives Arrow Attack
description: Hundreds of people have offered to adopt a dog that was found wandering in the desert with razor-tipped hunting arrows dangling from its head and body, the police say. The dog, a male shepherd mix under a year old, was found by two women on horseback near Sunset Park. Clark County animal control officers took the dog to an animal hospital, where a veterinarian removed the arrows, disinfected the wounds and kept him under observation. The dog was in good condition.

title: A Long Scouting Trip
description: The New York Mets will go to any lengths to try to return to their championship form of 1986. Even to Australia.

title: E.P.A. REASSESSES THE CANCER RISKS OF MANY CHEMICALS
description: New evidence of the way chemicals cause cancer is leading the Environmental Protection Agency to reassess the risks of many of the substances it regulates. It is finding some of them less dangerous than it previously believed.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MY FIRST LOVES by Ivan Klima. Translated by Ewald Osers. 164 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: In Poland: Lines, Lines, Lines, Especially for Vodka
description: Krystyna's office opens for business at 7 A.M., but the stores open at 6. So the Polish housewife from the edge of Warsaw starts her day early, standing in line ''maybe for 10 or 15 minutes'' for staples like bread, butter and cheese.

title: Less Style, More TV News, Please
description: LEAD: Three household names make the major difference in the evening news broadcasts of the Big Three television networks: Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings and Dan Rather. But there are three other people whose services have been enlisted to add a touch of class, or at least a distinctive sound, to the broadcasts, and it is unlikely that most viewers have ever heard of John Williams (the successor to Arthur Fiedler of the Boston Pops), Bob Israel and John Trivers.

title: Outdoors: A Risky Profession
description: ANY young man thinking of a career as a professional black-bass fisherman would do well to read Nick Taylor's just-published ''Bass Wars,'' (McGraw-Hill) which describes the fierce struggle either to remain in the big money or to get a small bite of it. So forewarned, he might decide to buy a mule and prospect for gold.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Press Corps Index
description: The Black Book, proclaimed by its sponsors to be the most comprehensive and useful index to the Washington press corps ever produced, is scheduled to appear this month.

title: FRANCE
description: Even before Oct. 19, traders on the Paris Bourse were suffering through a tough year. The leading French stock index, the index of the Compagnie des Agents de Change, started the year at 397.80 and peaked on March 26 at 460.40.

title: Light Activity For Bond Sales
description: Treasury financings this week consist of today's regular weekly sale of new three-month and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by an auction of seven-year notes.

title: New Albany Session: Hard Issues and Delicate Politics
description: The beleaguered New York State Legislature returns to Albany on Wednesday for what promises to be a rocky 211th legislative session, filled with tough issues and shadowed by pending corruption trials.

title: Most of Police Force Off Job In a Poor Suburb of Chicago
description: A majority of the police officers in this Chicago suburb, one of the poorest in the country, walked off the job this weekend because they have not been paid in more than two weeks.

title: Is Moscow Vanguard Of Kitsch?
description: Boris Baryshnikov saw on television that an entrepreneur in Finland was getting rich peddling Mikhail S. Gorbachev souvenirs. Suddenly a light went on over his head - possibly the word ''glasnost'' in marquee lights.

title: Soviet Letting Trade Partners
description: In the Polish city of Cracow recently, Soviet and Polish businessmen drank Crimean champagne to celebrate their countries' first joint venture.

title: Retail: Consumer Caution Likely to Persist
description: For retailers still reeling from one of the most difficult Christmas seasons in years, 1988 offers little hope for improvement - at least in the early months.

title: Joseph Sittler, 83, Dies; Was Lutheran Scholar
description: Joseph Sittler, a Lutheran theologian known for his work on religion and ecology, died of cancer Dec. 28 at his home in Chicago. He was 83 years old.

title: 20 Are Reported Hurt At a Bangladesh Rally
description: At least 20 people were hurt today when policemen charged demonstrators who were demanding that President H. M. Ershad step down, opposition party leaders and witnesses said.

title: JAPAN
description: The October collpase ended what had been an astounding bull market here. This was the year that the Tokyo stock market's capitalization exceeded New York's - at the end of October, the New York Stock Exchange was capitalized at $2.254 trillion, while Tokyo was worth $2.677 trillion, according to Morgan Stanley.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; An L-word Acronym
description: There is such a thing as official lust in the Federal Government. Among the many little-known provisions tucked deep within the $17.6 billion deficit-reduction bill adopted by Congress just before Christmas is a Senate amendment covering the excise taxes that are levied on diesel and certain other motor fuels sold wholesale to dealers. It requires that a part of these taxes, once collected, be transferred to the Highway Trust Fund or the Leaking Underground Storage Tank (LUST) Trust Fund. This prompted Brian Doherty, legislative director for Representative Gerald D. Kleczka, Democrat of Wisconsin, to assert that the arcane paragraph in the gigantic bill demonstrated there was ''lust, not only in people's hearts, but in the Government itself.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; That Mars Venture
description: The Resident Associate Program of the Smithsonian Institution has for years been enriching the Washington scene with a variety of offerings for people who hold membership in the institution - from lectures, concerts and film programs to courses and seminars on architecture, religion and the arts.

title: A Man Is Shot and Killed At a Restaurant in Queens
description: One man was fatally shot and another was critically wounded in a sudden burst of gunfire yesterday afternoon as the two men were leaving a restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said.

title: A Jersey Town Searches For Vanishing Volunteers
description: The drastic remaking of this old farm town has changed what it means to be a volunteer.

title: Hart Seeks to Demonstrate Character and Integrity
description: Gary Hart said today that his resurrected Presidential campaign would be directed at the task of convincing voters that he really can govern the country despite the scandal that drove him from the race for seven months.

title: MEXICO
description: For the Mexican stock market, 1987 has been a year straight out of Charles Dickens: the best of times, the worst of times. For the first nine months of the year, the Bolsa de Valores in Mexico City performed more impressively than any other market in the world, rising eightfold in local currency terms.

title: BRITAIN
description: It was also a year of extremes in London. The Financial Times 100-share index closed the year at 1,712.14, up 2 percent from its opening for 1987 at 1,679. But in between, the market soared to new heights.

title: In Tennessee, a Grand New Opry
description: Every Friday night in an old school auditorium tucked back in the southeast Tennessee mountains, a brand of bluegrass music in the tradition of the early days of the Grand Ole Opry takes center stage.

title: Soviet Plans to Explore Mars And to Expand Space Station
description: The Soviet Union will add extensions to its manned orbiting station Mir this year, a senior space official said today. Other projects call for conducting space research with France and Poland, and sending a probe to one of the moons of Mars.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Nation Building in Argentina
description: Everyone hears this is a difficult time in Argentina, but it's also a promising one. Fashionable Buenos Aires fills its conversation with the troubles. To discern the positive requires poking beneath the surface of the capital's complex and Italianate political life and venturing into the million-square-mile interior.

title: PTL Ministry's Cost For Hahn's Silence Is Put at $363,700
description: Payments by the PTL ministry to Jessica Hahn in exchange for her silence about a tryst with Jim Bakker totaled $363,700, nearly $100,000 more than previously reported, according to an Internal Revenue Service report.

title: Less Growth Expected in '88
description: Previous forecasts for the agency business might have been too optimistic, according to Greg M. Ostroff, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, who is reducing his own domestic growth forecast for 1988 to the 6.5 to 7.5 percent range, from 8-plus, and to 4 percent in a worst-case scenerio.

title: The Basic Speech: Michael S. Dukakis; A Call to Meet the Challenges of 'the Next American Frontier' Stump Speech: Roots Were Planted in '96
description: The following speech, by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, is the first in a series of basic, or stump, speeches that will be published over the coming months in The New York Times.

title: HONG KONG
description: In Hong Kong, the stock market underwent a devastating collapse in October that seriously harmed confidence. The market's Hang Seng index started the year at 2,568.30 and finished at 2,302.75, down about 10 percent. Its high for the year was 3,944.24 on Oct. 1.

title: Airlines: Labor Agreements Are Key For Carriers
description: Lower fuel prices, fewer discounts, more modest additions of new planes, continuing good traffic. All portend a good year for the airlines. The wild card is labor settlements.

title: U.S. Warns Dairy Farmers of Drop in Income
description: Dairy farmers can expect the price processors pay them for their milk to slide to a 10-year low in 1988 as a result of a reduction in Federal price supports that went into effect Friday, an Agriculture Department economist says.

title: Takeovers Revert to the Old Mode
description: The fall of the stock market is rewriting the rules of corporate takeovers. Gone are the swashbuckling raiders who used junk bonds to plunder the business landscape. Instead, Wall Street is expecting a return to normalcy: back to the days when corporations merged for strategic business reasons and not for quick financial gain.

title: 21 REPORTED DEAD IN ISRAEL AIR RAIDS IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Twenty-one people were killed and 14 wounded in overnight Israeli air strikes on Palestinian districts and Lebanese militia positions in southern Lebanon, the Lebanese police said today.

title: Tipper Gore Widens War on Rock
description: Two years after beginning a campaign against sexually explicit and violent lyrics on record albums, Tipper Gore has moderated her tone but expanded her scope to include music videos, television programming and video cassettes.

title: Huge Projects For Britain
description: Costain Group P.L.C., a construction and mining company, is seeking support from investors to build a privately owned, high-speed rail network across southeast England, The Financial Times reported.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Developer vs. Himself Over Coliseum Project
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman is at odds with himself.

title: Helping Novices to Survive the Bumpy Beginning
description: SKI instructors call them never-evers. These are people who have never been on skis and usually arrive at a ski school with visions of dashing down racecourses, jumping off cliffs or gliding through waist-deep snow.

title: In 45th Street Apartments, Time of Change for Actors
description: A French singer with a pet pigeon lives there. So do a former vaudeville female impersonator, a saxophonist who played with Benny Goodman and a woman who began her theater career as a cat.

title: Health Care and Drugs: Squeeze Tightening For Medical Providers
description: The vise tightens on the $450 billion health-care industry, which runs the gamut from drug and medical-supply houses to hospital chains and nursing homes. Many costs are soaring, and skilled workers are scarce in the labor-intensive hospitals, where revenues have been cut by insurer-imposed restrictions.

title: Going After the Press in the Panhandle
description: To the Editor:

title: Telephones: Winners and Losers Might Change Places
description: In the telephone industry the winners of recent years seem likely to lose their momentum in 1988, while losers of the recent past could be the companies to watch.

title: Collapse of Diesel Tank Pollutes Drinking Water Near Pittsburgh
description: The collapse of a new storage tank poured an estimated one million gallons of diesel oil into the Monongahela River over the weekend, threatening drinking water for 750,000 residents of suburban Pittsburgh.

title: Giuliani Led Crusade Against Wall St. Crime
description: When Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, requested that insider trading indictments be dropped against three Wall Street professionals, he promised reporters that a new round of broader indictments against the three would be handed up ''in record-breaking time.''

title: A CHANGING OF THE GUARD, AND A RECKONING IN INSIDER CASE
description: The flow of economic and financial news in 1987 - which seemed dominated by insider trading investigations, questions about international economic cooperation and the stock market plunge - thrust many people into the spotlight.

title: Redmen, and Coach, Are Going With Quicker Flow
description: Sooner or later, all things must change. Winners become losers, the weak become strong, the young become old.

title: Protection for Runners
description: What runner hasn't had to contend with yapping dogs, a car that swerves too close, or a dimly lit route? A dentist in Rockville, Md., who is an avid runner, has come up with a device meant to thwart those annoyances.

title: Horse Racing; An Old Combination Starts to Click Again
description: When Cherokee Colony rallied to a promising victory in the Flamingo Stakes here Saturday, it marked the emergence of a new Kentucky Derby contender but the return of a familiar team.

title: Entertainment: Bright Prospects At the Box Office
description: Hollywood not only shrugs off economic uncertainty but thrives on it, according to legend. Despite the ripple effects of the stock market collapse, customers keep pouring into movie theaters, even as ticket prices reached $7 in some areas.

title: Philharmonic Radiothon
description: The 11th New York Philharmonic Radiothon, a three-day broadcast of music, interviews and pledges, will take place in February on WQXR (1560 AM and 96.3 FM). The broadcast, an annual fund-raising event for the orchestra, will begin at noon on Feb. 5 and last until midnight Feb. 7. Included in the 60-hour broadcast will be taped excerpts of performances. Hosts include station staff members and Henry Fogel, executive director of the Chicago Symphony and former manager of the New York Philharmonic. A catalogue of premium items, which are available with donations, can be received by calling (800) 247-3030.

title: Broadcasting: Best Performer Could Be Cable
description: This year the performance of various segments of the media industry could vary widely. Cable television, for example, is expected to have a very strong year. But the growth of cable is among the key factors that may make it a relatively lackluster year for broadcasters.

title: Ph.D. Candidates Need Faculties That Care; Learning to Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A report on Dec. 25 about charities in the Soviet Union misidentified the chairman of a fund to help Soviet orphans. He is Albert A. Likhanov.

title: Distribution of AIDS Resembles That of TB
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 3, 1988: MONDAY Carolina Freight Nevada Power TUESDAY Centerior Energy Puget Sound Pwr & Lt Orange & Rockland Util WEDNESDAY American Water Works Rite Aid Corp Houston Industries THURSDAY General Pub Utilities Pillsbury Co WR GraceSun Co FRIDAY First Chicago Corp US West Inc LeaRonal Inc United Water Resources

title: Fitness Regimen for Eyes May Help Coordination
description: GLENN SEIFERT, a Long Island optometrist, tells the story of a top amateur tennis player with a blistering serve who sometimes had difficulty holding up his end on the volley. Someone suggested that a vision problem might be a factor.

title: Coming to Terms With the Latin Debt
description: LEAD: As 1987 comes to a close, the only uncertainty about the Latin American debt problem is when the last of the diehard optimists will have to concede. The strategy of muddling through, cobbled in 1982 and subsequently modestly revised, has finally run its course. What 1988 holds in store is debt relief in one form or another.

title: Phelan Kept His Cool Amid Stock 'Meltdown'
description: It seemed nothing more than a colorful bit of hyperbole from a passionate reader of mystery novels when John J. Phelan Jr., the chairman of New York Stock Exchange, began to talk a year ago about the prospect of a stock market ''meltdown.''

title: Sports World Specials; Still No Pardon
description: George Steinbrenner has just about everything money can buy, but the one holiday present he has wanted for years still eludes him: a Presidential pardon.

title: Bridge: A Taiwanese Could Qualify For 1987 Apology of the Year
description: The game of bridge surely generates more apologies than any other activity, unless one counts late arrival as an activity. Millions of them cross the world's card tables every year, and as many again fail to materialize through stubbornness, lack of courtesy or lack of understanding.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Unemployment... Dec. Consumer Borrowing... Nov.

title: Colombia Denies Vow To U.S. on Drug Figure
description: Colombia said today it had never promised the United States it would hold Jorge Luis Ochoa, a reputed major figure in the drug traffic, in jail, and called the attitude of the United States Government offensive.

title: 1973 Georgia Murders Back in Courts
description: Fourteen years after six members of a south Georgia family were murdered, the case, which has caused many Georgians to debate the justice of the legal system, is before the courts again.

title: Japanese Fight Invading Sea For Priceless Speck of Land
description: Japan, always a bit self-conscious about its limited size, has taken a giant step to keep itself from shrinking.

title: 'ANN JILLIAN STORY,' ON NBC
description: ANN JILLIAN has kept a tight rein on ''The Ann Jillian Story,'' the television movie on NBC at 9 this evening. A year or more of skirmishing took place before Ms. Jillian settled on a teleplay by Audrey Davis Levin. Corey Allen is the director. And Ms. Jillian plays herself. The result is admirable in some ways, puzzling in others.

title: Computers: A Potential Boom Faces Uncertainties
description: Rarely has the computer industry entered a new year so uncertain whether it would soar or stagnate.

title: American Irks Bonn as an Agent for Surrogate Births
description: Franklin Torch says he was reading the latest West German census, which shows a declining birth rate, when ''it clicked in my mind that they could use surrogate mothers.''

title: Expatriate Americans Keep Giving to Neediest Cases Fund
description: Two Americans living in Toronto, Alda and Robert Bell, are often homesick and they try to return to the United States, specifically New York City, several times a year.

title: Coliseum Pact Criticized By Goldin as a Bad Deal
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, and an attorney for the Municipal Art Society yesterday sharply criticized a new agreement by the Koch administration to keep alive a controversial Columbus Circle development.

title: Trial Opening For Chambers In Park Killing
description: In the 16 months since Jennifer Levin was killed in Central Park, the story of her last hours, and how she spent them with Robert E. Chambers Jr., has emerged in patchwork form. Today, in a 13th-floor courtroom in lower Manhattan, where Mr. Chambers stands charged with her murder, a jury is expected to begin hearing the full fabric of the tale - and prosecutors and defense lawyers say many widely held assumptions about the case may fall.

title: G.M. SETS TRADE SHOW TO AID IMAGE
description: The General Motors Corporation, in an obvious effort to divert attention from its recent market-share losses and other woes, is opening a three-day exposition of its advanced technology in New York City beginning Tuesday.

title: Miami No. 1 in All Three Rankings
description: Miami was voted the No. 1 college football team in the nation yesterday in both The Associated Press and United Press International polls and also finished on top in The New York Times's computer rankings. Florida State and Oklahoma were second and third, respectively, in all three rankings.

title: New Name Is Sought For Babbitt Airport
description: Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt may have poor name recognition in Iowa and New Hampshire, but some residents of his home state think his name is too prominent.

title: Rules on Debt Recast By Reed and Preston
description: The world of big banking acknowledged reality last year, largely as the result of moves by two men: John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, and Lewis T. Preston, chairman of J.P. Morgan & Company. In a one-two punch of sorts, the two bankers smashed the myth that such big third-world debtors as Mexico and Brazil would ever fully repay their hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign debt.

title: Running It Up
description: Three teams in the country average more points a game than the University of Oklahoma basketball team, and they all play in the National Basketball Association.

title: Workshops in Theater Look at Writing Lyrics
description: Martin Charnin, a Broadway lyricist, is to lead a workshop in lyric writing and directing for the musical theater, during two-hour sessions, Jan. 7, 11, 14 and 21 at 7:30 P.M., at the 92d Street Y School of Music, at 1395 Lexington Avenue.

title: Business and the Law; Prospects of Action On Bank Legislation
description: SINCE September, when Senator William Proxmire announced his intention to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act, the prevailing view has been that any bill to deregulate banking that got through the Senate would hit a brick wall in the House.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Treasury Speculation
description: Inauguration Day is more than a year away, but speculation has already begun on candidates for the new President's Cabinet, in particular the person who might become Secretary of the Treasury.

title: Anchorage Journal; Perilous Driving in Land of the Moose
description: Few things grab the attention of drivers speeding along the icy, six-lane Glenn Highway here quite so quickly as the sight of a 1,000-pound moose with a vast array of antlers, galloping into the beam of their headlights.

title: An Empty Weapon
description: A growing international determination to stop a regional war that actually endangers world peace is reflected in the Soviet Union's abandonment of its opposition to sanctions against Iran.

title: Fighting AIDS in Song
description: A song contest is one method used by Guinea-Bissau to fight AIDS, which has spread in that nation without many visible signs. Page A2. Higher Profits Are Seen Corporate profits will rise a modest 5 to 7 percent this year, economists say. Page D1. The outlook for 11 industries, pages D6. The Agenda in Albany Tough issues and the pending corruption trial of three lawmakers face the New York State Legislature when it reconvenes this week. Page B1. Dukakis on the Stump Each Presidential candidate conveys his campaign's soul in a basic speech.

title: Robins Merger Plan Stirs Some Skeptical Responses
description: Opposition by the A. H. Robins Company's shareholders and claimants to a merger between Robins and a French drug maker appeared to be mounting yesterday. The $600 million deal was announced this weekend.

title: U.S. Presses Colombia on Drug Suspect
description: The State Department stepped up its protests today over the release from a Colombian prison of a man described as one of the world's leading cocaine smugglers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the coming session of the New York State Legislature misidentified State Senator John R. Dunne. He is the deputy majority leader.

title: Despair Prompts Gifts to the Neediest Cases
description: Euphemia M. Bruenner of Manhattan does not dare open her purse on the street to respond to pleas of those in need. Instead, she sent $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: The Basic Speech: Paul Simon; An Appeal to Seek Out 'a Better, Brighter Future'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a basic speech. It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: The Planes in Spain
description: Washington is unhappy about Spain's insistence on pulling out American warplanes when an existing base agreement runs its course about three years hence. True enough, the Socialist Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, promised in 1986 to cut back U.S. forces if Spain voted to remain in NATO, which it did. What's causing the agony is the nature of the reduction - three squadrons of F-16's to be removed from Torrejon, near Madrid.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the proposal to develop Columbus Circle misstated the role of Richard I. Beattie, an attorney. He was an unpaid adviser to Salomon Brothers, the company that has withdrawn as a partner in the project.

title: Arthur Lumsden, 68, Publishing Chairman
description: Arthur J. Lumsden, a former head of the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce and chairman of the publishing house of Dodd, Mead & Company, died of lung cancer Sunday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 68 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla., and West Hartford, Conn.

title: Concert: Harris's 'James Robert Sonata'
description: IT took three-quarters of a century but finally, on Sunday afternoon in Merkin Concert Hall, Theodore Harris got the break he had been waiting for all his life. The performance by Malle Magi of Mr. Harris's ''James Robert Sonata,'' a work for piano, dedicated to the composer's grandson, marked the first time a serious piece by the 75-year-old composer from Queens had ever been played in public.

title: Traces of Muscle Drug Are Found In Body in Nurse Inquiry on L.I.
description: Traces of a muscle-paralyzing drug have been found in the body of one patient suspected of dying from unauthorized injections given by a West Islip nurse, a Suffolk County prosecutor said today.

title: German Diplomat Slain in Paris; Hint of Kurdish Role Is Disputed
description: A West German diplomat was shot and killed here early today, and there were hints and denials that a Kurdish group was responsible.

title: Loosening Up: A New Look in Men's Wear for Fall
description: When retailers went to Ronaldus Shamask's showroom to look over his spring fashions for men, the designer was sure his sports jackets and pants in bright red or purple wouldn't sell.

title: Gulotta Is Given Oath in Nassau As County Chief
description: Pledging to protect suburban values threatened by continued growth, Thomas S. Gulotta was inaugurated today as Nassau County Executive.

title: Advertising; Hearst Gives Its Magazine Deals a Push
description: TEN years ago Hearst Magazines, which then had eight magazines, began offering a ''corporate buy'' that gave advertisers discounts for running ads in at least three of the magazines at least three times each.

title: Cold Snap Aids Olympic Skiing
description: The recent cold snap in Alberta has put snowmaking on Mount Allan back on schedule.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE DROWNED AND THE SAVED. By Primo Levi. Translated from the Italian by Raymond Rosenthal. 203 pages.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Among the people as a whole, as long as she can deliver bread and circuses, as long as the prosperity is there, she can go on and it will be hard to stop her.'' - Robert D. Waller, Conservative Party polltaker, describing Margaret Thatcher. [ A6:4. ]

title: Natural Gas Prices Reach 2-Year High
description: Natural gas prices climbed to their highest levels in two years on the spot market today amid what experts said was a combination of bitter cold weather and a fresh dispute between pipelines and gas producers over a Government ruling that went into effect last Friday.

title: Two Mayors Begin Their Second Terms With Visions of Jobs and Integrity; A Call for Honesty in Philadelphia
description: With a call for public integrity and a pledge of governmental unity that even this city's boosters acknowledge have often eluded it, Philadelphia's top officials today embarked hopefully on a new four-year term of office.

title: Clark Won't Re-sign
description: Jack Clark, who led St. Louis to two division titles in the last three seasons but was injured for parts of all three years, will not re-sign with the Cardinals, his agent said yesterday.

title: Cordero Out 3 Weeks
description: Angel Cordero Jr., thoroughbred racing's No. 2 career money-winning jockey behind Bill Shoemaker, with more than $121 million in purses earned, will be sidelined for at least three weeks because of injuries he sustained in a spill last Wednesday at Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After the loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $294,000,000. The company said a new method of accounting for income taxes was implemented in the fourth quarter of 1987; for 1987 the accounting change lowered income taxes and increased earnings by $47 million, or 30 cents a share. The previous three quarters have been restated to increase net earnings $12 million, or 8 cents a share, $14 million, or 9 cents a share and $9 million, or 6 cents a share for the first, second and third quarters, respectively. The 1986 information has been restated to reflect the consolidation of Sea-Land Corp. from the date of acquisition, May 30, 1986.

title: PATTERNS
description: Bargain Time for Furs

title: Holtzman's 6 Years: Innovations and Antagonism
description: In six years as District Attorney of Brooklyn, Elizabeth Holtzman says, she has raised the professional standards of her office, introduced new strategies to deter crime and forged closer ties with the black and Hispanic communities by aggressively investigating complaints of police brutality.

title: CRAVING FOR PAINKILLERS IS RECALLED BY JACKSON
description: Jesse Jackson told patients at a drug-rehabilitation center he was briefly dependent on a painkiller more than 25 years ago, but he said in an interview today that the episode lasted less than a day.

title: Sikhs Are Blamed for Killing 10 Over 24 Hours in Punjab
description: Sikh militants in Punjab state killed 10 people, one a senior member of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, in attacks over a 24-hour period Sunday and today, the police and news organizations said.

title: N.B.A. Notebook; Once Again, Bullets Call Upon Unseld
description: On June 7, 1978, the Washington Bullets' dressing room was filled with the laughter and shouting that go with winning the National Basketball Association championship. But, off to the side, away from the din and the flowing champagne, there were tears.

title: No Medal for Mr. Meese
description: Not content with the usual year-end self-congratulations, the Justice Department makes an extravagant prediction about Attorney General Edwin Meese, a frequent grand jury witness and subject of special prosecutor interest.

title: A Thatcher Milestone Spurs Debate on Her Forceful Style
description: Margaret Thatcher has become Britain's longest-serving Prime Minister of the century, and the main effect of her new historical status seems to be a broadening of the debate about authoritarianism and the concentration of power in her third term.

title: The Power Of Tenzin Gyatso
description: The man in the maroon robes took a ballpoint pen, carefully put his name and calling on a scroll and read aloud what he had written.

title: Drug Cases Top Others In Prisons
description: For the first time in New York State, the number of inmates serving time for drug-related offenses has surpassed those imprisoned for any other type of crime, officials of the overcrowded prison system said yesterday.

title: A Visa for Walters
description: Rumors during the superpower summit last month had it that Raisa Gorbachev, wife of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had agreed to be interviewed by Barbara Walters. Yesterday a large pile of visa papers was spotted at the Soviet consular office in the capital, apparently to permit Ms. Walters and a television entourage to travel to Moscow next week. Whether Mrs. Gorbachev is waiting for them remains unknown. Meanwhile, a spokeswoman for Nancy Reagan said she knew of no plans for Ms. Walters to interview the First Lady.

title: Korean Trade Outlook
description: South Korea's trade surplus in 1988 is expected to exceed $4 billion, down from last year's $6.55 billion, the Trade and Industry Ministry said today. It predicted that exports would grow by 8 to 13 percent, to about $52 billion, despite the rise of the won against the dollar.

title: Differing Roles of Cancer Agents Are Studied
description: Deepening knowledge of the differing ways that chemicals can turn normal cells into runaway masses of malignancy may add new complexity to the effort to regulate cancer-causing substances, many experts say.

title: Picking Over the Pork in the 1988 Spending Bill
description: As usual, the behemoth spending bill that Congress passed just before adjourning in December contains tucked-away provisions serving special interests of individual legislators. But, surprisingly, some Capitol Hill analysts suggest that, in a reflection of general budget constraint, the bill may have fewer pork-barrel items than in the past.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Attributable primarily to $2.6 million in strike-related costs, $1.8 million in costs related to decreased production volume due primarily to crop shortages and a $700,000 loss on the disposal of underutilized assets. c-Net income The results for Mushroom King Inc. from its acquisition on Oct. 1 are included in the results for the latest quarter and 9 months.

title: OLD FASHION FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
A's Sign Hubbard
description: The Oakland Athletics have signed the free-agent veteran second baseman, Glenn Hubbard, to a contract for the 1988 season, plus an option year, the club announced yesterday. The Athletics did not reveal other terms of the pact.

title: Why Is This Man Yawning?
description: THE yawn is something of a biological mystery.

title: OHIO MATTRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Strike Left Mark on Network Ratings
description: DESPITE a strong finish, the three major networks were not able to erase the effects of the players' strike from their National Football League broadcasts.

title: 130 Seized in Argentina At Tina Turner Concert
description: About 130 people were arrested in disturbances during and after a concert by the pop singer Tina Turner in an Argentine soccer stadium, the police said.

title: VW's Price Rise
description: Volkswagen United States, a subsidiary of Volkswagen A.G., said it had raised suggested retail base prices by an average of 5.6 percent, or $377, on its Fox models, effective immediately. The base price of Volkswagen's Fox two-door model will increase to $6,290, from $5,990; its four-door GL model to $7,280, from $6,890, and its wagon to $7,380, from $6,990.

title: Our Towns; I Live for Art, But Getting Paid Is Great, Too
description: It was Sunday night, so Bill had his ARTS Anonymous meeting in Hicksville.

title: Pritzker Has Union Talks
description: Representatives of Jay A. Pritzker met with union leaders of Pan American World Airways Inc. in an effort to revive his attempt to take over the airline, sources close to the talks said yesterday.

title: East Bloc's Wind of Change Now Blows in From Moscow
description: In Eastern Europe, where for four decades the Soviet leader has represented to millions the main source of their discontent, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has wrought an astonishing transformation.

title: Shamir Defends Expulsion Move, Terming the 9 Arabs 'Incorrigible'
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today defended the army's decision to order nine Palestinian nationalists deported, saying the Gaza Strip and West Bank residents being thrown out were ''incorrigible.''

title: BankAmerica's Settlements
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had reached settlements involving a number of lawsuits against its employees and others that will net the company about $28 million in payments from its insurance company, the Employers Insurance of Wausau Mutual Company.

title: Coalition Defends Cuban Mothers Facing Separation From Children
description: A coalition of legal and church groups here is trying to prevent the deportation of a handful of Cuban women, detained around the country, so they will not be separated from the children to whom they gave birth in this country.

title: KEY RATES
Stock Index Inquiry Report
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had found no evidence of price manipulation in the Major Market Index, a stock index futures contract traded on the Chicago Board of Trade, during the October market collapse.

title: Dee Might Cut Ties With Citibank
description: The Dee Corporation, parent of Herman's Sporting Goods Inc., said it might cut its ties with Citibank, its investment banker, because the bank is also helping to finance a hostile takeover bid for the British retailer. Alec Monc, chairman of Dee, said in a statement to shareholders that Britain's Monopolies Commission should investigate the $:2.04 billion bid, or about $3.8 billion, it received from Barker & Dobson P.L.C., a small British food retailer.

title: Koch, at the Movies, Gives $7 Tickets Thumbs Down
description: It could have been a scene from a made-for-television movie.

title: Dollar Up After Tokyo Fall; Gold and Silver Prices Drop
description: The dollar rallied yesterday after touching new lows during overnight trading in Tokyo, bolstered by signs that several central banks, including the Federal Reserve, had bought dollars.

title: Questions Swirl Around a Fatal Shooting by Police
description: In a matter of seconds last Tuesday evening, 11 shots from two police revolvers rang out on a Queens street. Moments later a man who the police say had lunged at an officer with a five-inch knife lay dying, struck by at least six bullets.

title: BRIDGFORD FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Albert Nipon In Chapter 11
description: Albert Nipon Inc., a producer of women's designer clothing, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, after an unfavorable assessment from the Internal Revenue Service on its 1986 taxes. In its petition, filed on New

title: Tourists in London
description: Foreign visitors spent a record $5.7 billion in London in 1987, the London Tourist Board estimated today. There were 8.9 million visitors, and 23 percent of them were Americans.

title: Conquering Christmas
description: On Jan. 1 a person who has never before made a New Year's resolution made one. She resolved to get Dec. 25, 1988, over with this month.

title: Reader's Digest to Acquire Magazine
description: For 60 years, the Reader's Digest Company's sole magazine was the highly successful Reader's Digest. Now George V. Grune, the company's chairman since 1984, is seeking to expand the company's publishing empire.

title: Iceboat Racers Set Sail to Broaden Their Sport's Horizons
description: LEAD: On a wall in Henry Bossett's loft in Point Pleasant, N.J., there is a black sail. On a long, mahogany floor of the workshop, there are several white sails in various stages of completion. Bossett does not normally make black sails; he used this one while racing an iceboat in a Chap Stick commercial.

title: A.M.I. Investor Plans A More Active Role
description: M. Lee Pearce, a doctor and lawyer who is president of a Miami health-care consulting company, wrote out a sobering prescription yesterday for one his clients, American Medical International Inc.

title: Reagan With Scissor
description: President Reagan will cut the ribbon Friday morning when the Army-Navy Club, a 102-year-old institution, rededicates its clubhouse on Farragut Square after almost four years of remodeling and reconstruction. The light-yellow brick building was dedicated by President Taft in 1912 after a move from a building across the street that President Harrison had dedicated in 1892. Both of them were members; Mr. Reagan is not.

title: Go Slow on Ratifying the I.N.F. Pact
description: The treaty limiting intermediate-range nuclear forces has been welcomed in the West as a small step that may have constructive results, depending upon the next step in the nuclear arms-control negotiations.

title: Troubled Waters: The Concern Grows
description: On the beaches of southern New Jersey, children hunting for seashells came upon broken hypodermic needles and other hospital debris. Off the craggy coast of Connecticut, lobstermen found their catch already dead because of the paucity of oxygen in the water. Biologists in New York, performing autopsies on sea turtles that had washed ashore, discovered plastic shopping bags in their stomachs.

title: Nora Kaye Honored In Memorial Tribute By Artist Colleagues
description: Members of the dance and theater worlds gathered yesterday afternoon at the City Center to honor Nora Kaye, the American ballerina who died last year. Known for her dramatic power, Ms. Kaye, who was born in New York City in 1920, was a member of American Ballet Theater from its inception in 1940 until 1951, and again from 1954 to 1959. In between, she appeared with the New York City Ballet. Celebrated for her interpretations of the psychological ballets of Antony Tudor, she also danced in works by Agnes de Mille and Jerome Robbins.

title: French Singer at Wallman's
description: Yvonne Constant, a French singer and actress, will offer cabaret songs in French and English at Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street, tonight, Saturday and Jan. 16. Miss Constant first performed in New York in the revue ''La Plume de Ma Tante,'' and later was featured in ''No Strings.'' She has appeared on television on ''Tonight'' and recently in the CBS miniseries ''Sins.'' There will be two shows nightly at Jan Wallman's, at 9 and 11 P.M., with a $10 cover charge and an $8 minimum. For information and reservations: 764-8930.

title: FILIPINO TESTIFIES ON AQUINO'S KILLER
description: After four years of silence, an airport worker testified today that he saw a soldier shoot and kill Benigno S. Aquino Jr. as the opposition leader stepped off a plane to end years of exile.

title: Building Outlays Up
description: Construction spending shot up 2.2 percent in November, the biggest increase in nine months, as the building industry benefited from widespread gains in both residential and nonresidential construction, the Government reported today.

title: 76.42 Jump Sends Dow To 2,015.25
description: Stock prices staged a powerful year-opening rally yesterday, and traders said a strengthening dollar and program trading were behind the surge.

title: The Goose Factor
description: In the early 1950's, a flock of migrating geese made an alarming appearance on the nation's Distant Early Warning radar screens. Steadily advancing across the DEW line, their formation resembled that of an enemy bomber squadron. Fortunately, the error was discovered and nuclear scenarists lived to think again.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Donnelley Marketing, Stamford, Conn., a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corp., to Marquardt & Roche, Stamford, for Carol Wright's couponing promotion package.

title: W. J. Cagney, Producer For His Brother James
description: William J. Cagney, a brother of James Cagney and the producer of such films as ''The Time of Your Life'' and ''Kiss Tomorrow Goodbye,'' died of a heart attack Sunday at Hoag Memorial Hospital here. He was 82 years old.

title: U.S. and Florida Split Over Fruit Ban
description: New outbreaks of citrus canker in Florida have split Federal and state disease experts over the success of efforts to prevent the disease from establishing a permanent foothold in the continental United States.

title: Atomic View of Insect Virus
description: APPLYING advanced X-ray techniques, scientists have for the first time determined the three-dimensional structure of an insect virus in atomic detail.

title: HEALTHCARE COMPARE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $60,000.

title: SUBSTANTIAL RISE SOUGHT NEXT YEAR IN OUTLAY ON AIDS
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has requested a substantial increase in funds to fight AIDS next year. Budget officials have urged President Reagan to approve most of the request, saying that significant cuts ''would embarrass the Administration.''

title: Boitano's Coach Rules Out Risky Figure
description: For something that has never been performed successfully in competition, the quadruple toe loop gets a lot of attention. It came up again when Brian Boitano, the only American skater with a realistic chance of landing it, said he did not intend to try it during the United States figure-skating championships, which began here today.

title: Market Place; Buying Laggards Of Previous Year
description: THE worst performers in the Dow Jones industrial average sometimes turn into winners the following year. This laggard approach to investing is of more than passing interest on Wall Street, where any theory that pans out even once in a while - dart-throwing comes to mind - engenders a certain respect.

title: Cheap, Clean Needles
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal for Lincoln Bank Pleases Unicorp Chief
description: Wayne J. Stemmer was snowed in yesterday at his home in Westport, Conn., and he had a cold to boot. But he also had a deal wrapped up to give him some cheer - the $150 million acquisition of the Lincoln Savings Bank.

title: E-II Seeking Key Role At American Brands
description: E-II Holdings Inc., a publicly traded spinoff of the Beatrice Company, said today that it plans to nominate six candidates for election to the board of American Brands Inc., the diversified giant whose businesses includes tobacco and numerous consumer products.

title: Shevardnadze in Kabul Amid Efforts to End War
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze flew to Kabul today and met with the Afghan leader, Najibullah, as speculation grew that the Soviet Union has increased its efforts to find a way out of the eight-year-old war in Afghanistan.

title: 5-Year Term in Check Fraud
description: A man who was convicted of stealing more than $428,000 from his employer was sentenced today by Judge Gerard Goettel of Federal District Court to five years in prison and ordered to return the money. The man, Charles Bates, 41 years old, had pleaded guilty to defrauding the company, Equitable Relocation Management Corporation, during a 10-month period in 1986.

title: Salah Hindawy, Egyptian Diplomat, 48
description: Salah Hindawy, a senior Egyptian diplomat who took part in efforts to resolve a border dispute with Israel, died of a heart attack Sunday in Kuwait. He was 48 years old.

title: The Past Of a Town Is at Stake
description: When California was known to people in southern China as ''the Golden Mountain'' a century and more ago, Chinese immigrant settlements dotted the rural regions of the state. Chinese communities, born in the Gold Rush of 1849, thrived in the countryside until job opportunities began swelling the Chinatowns of big cities like San Francisco.

title: 'Carmen' From Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Lyric Opera's professional workshop, the Opera Stage, is to perform Bizet's ''Carmen'' on Thursday at 8 P.M., Sunday at 3 P.M., Jan. 14 at 8 P.M. and Jan. 17 at 3 P.M. in Hirsch Hall at Temple Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th Street. Tickets are $7.50. Information: (718) 837-1176.

title: AMERICAN NURSERY PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Electrical Gremlins
description: SURGE suppressors are devices that stand between a computer and its power source, guarding the machine's delicate circuitry against surges and other electrical fluctuations that are normal along AC power lines but potentially disastrous in a computer. I like to think of them as gremlin guards.

title: No Five-Story Bunkers for the Village, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 5, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL The U.S. and other governments bought an estimated $2 billion to $3 billion in dollars, helping the currency recover from a sharp decline in Asian trading, dealers said. To some market analysts, the purchases indicated that Washington and other governments feared another uncontrolled fall in the dollar. On Wall Street, stock prices staged a strong rally. [ Page A1. ] The dollar rallied on the signs of buying by the central banks. Gold fell $7.05 an ounce in New York, to $479.20. [ D16. ] Saudi Arabia is taxing foreign businesses and workers on their incomes and increasing import duties on many goods. It also issued its first public debt in a quarter-century and drew money from its foreign currency reserves. The taxes will affect the profitability of hundreds of foreign companies and will fall heavily on the one million foreign workers, including 35,000 to 40,000 Americans. [ A1. ] Iranian and Turkish officials discussed a new pipeline. Iran's desire for a pipeline through Turkey reflects the toll that Iraqi raids are taking on Iranian shipments, experts say. [ A10. ] Price Waterhouse won't require clients to write down the value of their Mexican loans if they participate in a plan to exchange part of those loans, at a loss, for new Mexican bonds, the accounting firm is expected to announce. [ D4. ] COMPANIES Hoffmann-La Roche offered $4.2 billion for Sterling Drug, makers of Bayer aspirin, Phillips Milk of Magnesia and dozens of other pharmaceutical items. The $72-a-share cash offer, which is being presented directly to shareholders, drew no immediate response from Sterling, which is expected to resist. [ D1. ] Reader's Digest will buy Family Handyman, the home-improvement magazine, its second acquisition in a little more than a year. The price was thought to be about $30 million - a relatively high 12 times cash flow. [ D1. ] Continental's first-class seats and service will be sold for coach fares, and other airlines are expected to follow suit. Continental, Eastern and Northwest also announced cuts of as much as 20 percent in discount fares. [ D1. ] Dow Jones sold its Richard D. Irwin textbook publishing unit to Times Mirror for $135 million. [ D3. ] E-II Holdings will put up six candidates for American Brands' board. [ D3. ] MARKETS Stock prices staged a powerful year-opening rally and traders said a strengthening dollar and program trading were behind the surge. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 76.42 points, or 3.94 percent, to 2,015.25. That was its fourth-best point gain ever and its highest close since Oct. 21. [ D1. ] Treasury bond prices retained moderate gains after soaring earlier in the session. While relatively light, the trading was described by some dealers as somewhat unnerving. [ D15. ] Oil prices climbed after an OPEC official said output quotas were being observed, even though few people believed him. [ D16. ] THE ECONOMY Natural gas prices climbed to their highest levels in two years amid the combination of cold weather and a fresh dispute between pipeline companies and gas producers over a Government ruling on prices. Executives at several large users of natural gas said supplies appeared to be plentiful. [ D1. ] A proposal in Delaware to restrict takeovers advanced when a group of lawyers approved it. If the plan enters the Legislature, its fate is unclear amid opposition from S.E.C. officials and large stockholders. Twenty-seven states already have such a law. [ D4. ] Construction spending jumped 2.2 percent in November, the biggest increase in nine months. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Accountants are failing to keep up with the sweeping changes of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and have failed to give their clients important advice on critical matters. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] The Dow's worst performers sometimes turn into winners the following year. The laggard approach to investing produced some interesting results: In 1987, the Dow's five weakest performers of 1986 turned in a banner performance. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: China Is Reported to Execute 17
description: At a mass rally, 17 people were tried and convicted last month of crimes including murder, rape and robbery, then immediately shot in one of the largest reported group executions in recent years, according to a radio report.

title: HOUSING AND WELFARE: A LOGICAL LINK
description: The first housing bill in seven years is on its way to the Oval Office.

title: Robins Bids May Go Up
description: Bidding for the A. H. Robins Company appeared to be headed higher yesterday - only three days after France's big drug producer, Sanofi S.A., announced that Robins had accepted its $3.1 billion takeover offer. Other bidders contended that Sanofi's offer was difficult to evaluate.

title: 'A Bulging Cabinet'
description: Few issues have so riled old-fashioned Reagan supporters as the plan that Mr. Reagan has endorsed for elevating the Veterans Administration and its 250,000 employees to the status of a department of the Federal Government and its chief to membership in the Cabinet.

title: Saudis Impose An Income Tax On Foreigners
description: Ending an era in which it seemed to be a fountain of untaxed wealth, Saudi Arabia has introduced income taxes on all foreign businesses and foreign workers, increased import duties on many goods, issued its first public debt in a quarter-century and drawn from its foreign currency reserves.

title: Unmet Aspirations
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Space Age, the Old Wind Tunnel Is Being Left Behind
description: AEROSPACE engineers have hit a dead end in conventional efforts to test designs for the next generation of spaceships, planetary probes and other futuristic flying machines, prompting a rush of new proposals and projects for exotic techniques to help develop 21st-century spacecraft.

title: Day 1: Minnesota Educator Meets New York
description: On his first day in New York City as Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, displayed confidence, flashes of humor and a certain no-nonsense attitude toward what he clearly thought were fringe issues. And at his baptismal City Hall news conference yesterday he suggested, ever so gently, that he, not Mayor Koch, was the star.

title: By Design: Wet Wear
description: If you are lucky enough to be heading south you are now confronting the bathing suit problem. The scenario is all too familiar. First comes the debacle of the dressing room. There are few fashion moments as depressing as this one. The bare facts about your body are facing you in the mirror. How to find a suit that will enhance what's all right but also disguise what isn't?

title: Bell & Howell Breakup Likely
description: The investment group that has agreed to acquire the Bell & Howell Company for $64 a share said today that it was considering selling certain ''non-core'' Bell & Howell assets in order to finance the transaction.

title: Iranians Reported in Turkey for Talks About a New Pipeline
description: An Iranian delegation has arrived in Turkey to begin negotiations on a new oil pipeline, Turkish Government and oil industry officials said today.

title: Advertising; New Yorker's New Publisher
description: Steven T. Florio, the president of The New Yorker, announced yesterday that Rebecca Wesson Darwin, a long-time associate, had been promoted to publisher of the magazine, a title that he had previously held.

title: Fast Start for Bioengineered Drug
description: At Williamsport Hospital and Medical Center in Pennsylvania, a special committee is supposed to decide whether the hospital's pharmacy will carry a particular drug, and the process can take several weeks. But when Genentech Inc.'s heart attack drug came out in November, hospital officials eager to get their hands on it bypassed the committee and placed an order immediately.

title: O'Neill on 'Playhouse'
description: ''American Playhouse,'' public television's weekly drama anthology series, will open its seventh season on Jan. 18 with a three-part adaptation of Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude.''

title: INSIDE
description: Biotech: A Sales Challenge

title: Charges Sought For a Principal Reagan Praised
description: At a tumultuous public meeting, the Board of Education voted tonight to draw up insubordination charges against the principal of Eastside High School, Joe Clark, because of his suspension of 60 students last month.

title: South Korea Tests Blind U.S. Anti-Communism
description: To the Editor:

title: Power in a Pocket
description: MANY people keep their distance from personal computers, even those who could find a use for one, because of an impression that only the mathematically inclined can truly understand them.

title: 'Doublespeak' Crusade
description: ABOUT a year ago, in a small airport in Kentucky, I was alarmed by a sign that read:

title: Moscow Journal; For Russian Shoppers, a Touch of Rodeo Drive
description: Murat T. Gadginsky wants to change the way Russians shop.

title: Primerica-De Luxe
description: The Primerica Corporation said the sale of its direct marketing subsidiary, Looart Press Inc., to De Luxe Check Printers Inc. had been completed, resulting in an after-tax gain of about $35 million for the fourth quarter of 1987. The proceeds from the previously announced sale of Looart and its operating subsidiary, Current Inc., totaled about $180 million, or about $150 million after taxes, Primerica said. It said the net proceeds of the sale, which was completed Thursday, would be used to reduce its debt.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 5, 1988
description: International A3-12

title: Currency Traders Kept On Edge by Fed's Moves
description: In the instantaneous world of foreign exchange trading, no bit of market gossip spreads faster than reports that the Federal Reserve or some other central bank is intervening to buy a particular currency.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $47,059,000.

title: Devils Pay Penalty For Shoddy Play
description: Having never finished with a winning record in 13 years as a National Hockey League franchise, the Devils are not accustomed to playing in games they are supposed to win.

title: Lily Laskin, Harpist, 94
description: Lily Laskin, a French musician who helped make the harp a featured solo instrument in concert halls, died today in a Paris nursing home. She was 94 years old.

title: FIRST FEDL SAVINGS-ARK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $132,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and after extraordinary charges of $917,000 and $367,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said there were no common share earnings for the fiscal 1986 year because the bank converted from mutual to stock ownership in April 1986.

title: Japan Gains In Chip Market
description: Japan increased its share of the worldwide semiconductor market in 1987 despite United States trade sanctions, a survey by the research concern Dataquest Inc. showed today.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year results of operations include a writeoff of intangibles of $494,490 for which no tax benefit can be realized.

title: Court Finds Gandhi Opponent Guilty of Nepotism
description: An Indian court has dealt a severe blow to one of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's sharpest political foes, saying that he had misused his office to benefit his relatives.

title: FOOTBALL COMES CLEAN
description: FOR a while last Friday night I rooted for the University of Miami to be No. 2 because I thought it was a dirtier team than Oklahoma. Why else were so many of its players wearing towels on their belts?

title: Dow's Textbook Unit Sold to Times Mirror
description: Dow Jones & Company, publishers of The Wall Street Journal, yesterday announced the $135 million sale of Richard D. Irwin Inc., its textbook-publishing subsidiary, to the Times Mirror Company, publishers of The Los Angeles Times.

title: Bridge: A Computer Takes 5 Weeks To Digest a 10-Day Tourney
description: At the end of a decathlon the track-and-field computer can normally digest the results of 10 events and produce final standings within five minutes or so. The American Contract Bridge League's computer in Memphis, however, took more than five weeks to digest the results of 10 days of national play, admittedly involving much more data.

title: Advertising; Lois Pitts Gershon Pon Wins Playboy Account
description: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK, the Swiss-owned agency long favored by media accounts and currently serving USA Today and MTV, has now been chosen to promote Playboy magazine.

title: Court Keeps Envoy's Son in Custody
description: A Federal appeals court decided yesterday that the 9-year-old son of a diplomat from Zimbabwe should remain in foster care on Long Island pending a full hearing later this week in a case involving accusations that the boy had been beaten by his father.

title: Careers; Some Advice On Securing Business Jobs
description: LIKE advice to the lovelorn, helpful words for job losers and job seekers are widely available. Now an economist and a forecaster offer some advice for middle managers who have lost their jobs and for people with new M.B.A. degrees who are looking for their first jobs.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp., Milwaukee, a developer of specialized technology for process control equipment, said it had completed the sale of its mining equipment unit to Boliden A.B. of Sweden for $97.9 million.

title: Viking Problems Left Behind
description: Now, it is on to San Francisco, where the Minnesota Vikings fully expect to be regarded as an appetizer on the 49ers' playoff menu. Their one-sided victory Sunday against New Orleans probably will end the talk that they did not deserve to be in the playoffs, but ultimately, the Vikings figure the National Conference wild-card game will be remembered as the day the Saints reverted to their losing ways.

title: Defense in Chambers Trial Raises Question of Motive
description: The defense attorney in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. stood before the jurors yesterday and urged them to ask a single question: Why would Mr. Chambers kill Jennifer Levin in Central Park in August 1986?

title: Tyson's Big Deal
description: Mike Tyson's big deal was sealed yesterday.

title: Monongahela Oil Spill Threatens Water Supplies in Pittsburgh Area
description: Faucets dried up for tens of thousands of people in suburban Pittsburgh yesterday as emergency crews battled to contain a huge fuel-oil spill oozing more than 50 miles downstream from a collapsed storage tank on the Monongahela River.

title: Nevada's Radioactive Jackpot
description: Just before Christmas, Congress gave Nevada an expensive present - the Federal repository for highly radioactive waste, now to be tunneled out of Nevada's Yucca Mountain. The gift comes with a special evergreen greeting: $20 million, every year. Yet the Governor of Nevada, Richard Bryan, does not sound grateful. He calls it a ''legislative atrocity.'' It is something of an atrocity, but at least it's a solution of sorts to a festering problem.

title: Long Views In Poland
description: Mieczyslaw Rakowski has been at the leading edge for reform among Polish Communists for over a generation. He never quit the party, as so many did, and his fortunes waxed and waned according to the climate. Along the way he accumulated enemies among party officials who thought him too soft and critics of the party who thought he lacked the courage of his conclusions.

title: Cyclosporine and Kidneys
description: About one in 10 people receiving cyclosporine to prevent rejection of transplanted organs develops kidney problems, including fatal kidney failure. Now a group at the Albany Medical Center has found experimental evidence that the reason those people develop kidney trouble is that the drug breaks down into poisonous fragments in their bodies.

title: Julius S. Impellizzeri, Lawyer and Executive
description: Julius S. Impellizzeri, a lawyer and business executive who helped investigate police corruption in New York City, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan and Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Article 741588 -- No Title
description: Hoffmann-La Roche & Company, the big Swiss drug producer, said last night that it was offering $4.2 billion in cash for Sterling Drug Inc., makers of Bayer aspirin, Phillips Milk of Magnesia and dozens of other pharmaceutical products.

title: Town Election Is First Since '33
description: Emma Gresham, a retired schoolteacher, was chosen mayor and four other blacks were named to the five-member City Council today in the election of the first municipal government in this town of 300 people since 1933.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 12
Special Prosecutor Is Sought
description: A civil-rights association and a federation of block associations in Queens said yesterday that they had formally asked Governor Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the fatal shooting by white police officers of a black man on a residential street in Laurelton, Queens.

title: After an All-Day Siege, Actor Commits Suicide
description: A 53-year-old unemployed actor shot himself to death last night after having held his former girlfriend hostage for seven hours earlier in the day in her West Side apartment, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Oilers 2, Bruins 2: Charlie Huddy scored an unassisted goal on a long shot apparently deflected by a Bruin player with 2 minutes 17 seconds left in the third period, giving Edmonton a tie last night. Huddy's 60-foot shot apparently hit Boston's Ken Linseman and spun past the goalie. Edmonton played without the injured Wayne Gretzky. (AP) Maple Leafs 7, Canucks 7: Russ Courtnall's goal with 2:16 remaining in the third period gave the Maple Leafs the tie in Toronto as the teams combined for nine goals in the third period. Courtnall beat the Vancouver goalie, Kirk McLean, with a slap shot from the right face-off circle for his 19th goal of the season.(AP) N.B.A. 76ers 122, Suns 114: Cliff Robinson scored 31 points and Charles Barkley added 28 at the Spectrum as the 76ers snapped a five-game losing streak last night. Robinson scored 18 in the first half as Philadelphia overcame a 10-point deficit to take a 61-55 lead at halftime. Eddie Johnson led Phoenix with 27 points.(AP) Rockets 117, Mavericks 107: Akeem Olajuwon scored 31 points and pulled down 11 rebounds to lead Houston at home. He hit 13 of 19 shots as Houston won its fourth straight game.(AP) Celtics 107, Jazz 99: Larry Bird scored 28 points and Danny Ainge added 20, including six 3-point goals, to lead Boston at Salt Lake City. Kevin McHale had 24 points for the Celtics, who had to come from behind in the fourth quarter, with a 19-5 run. Karl Malone led Utah with 25 points. (AP) HORSE RACING Raja's Shark Wins: Despite being forced to alter course in midstretch, Raja's Shark was up in time for a three-quarters of a length victory yesterday in the $50,000 Swelegant Handicap for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Sir Smokem was easily second best in the field of six. For Raja's Shark, who carried highweight of 122 pounds and Jack Kaenel, the victory was the 13th in 35 career starts. He covered six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 2/5 and returned $4 for $2 as the favorite. TENNIS Van Rensburg Advances: Top-seeded Christo van Rensburg of South Africa recovered from a slow start yesterday to defeat Johan Anderson of Australia in the first round of the men's singles of the New South Wales Open at White City, Australia. Van Rensburg, ranked 29th in the world, trailed the Swedish-born Anderson, 4-2, in the first set before downing the 16-year-old by 7-5, 6-3. In the Virginia Slims women's event, ninth-seeded Rosalyn Fairbank of San Diego and 10th-seeded Anne Minter of Australia advanced to the second round.(AP) Svensson Gains: Third-seeded Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden romped to a 6-2, 6-0 triumph over Tim Wilkison of Asheville, N.C., yesterday in the first round of the Benson & Hedges Open in Auckland, New Zealand. David Lewis defeated Christian Saceanu of West Germany, 1-6, 6-4, 7-5. The fourth-seeded player, Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, was the first seeded loser, dropping a 6-2, 7-6 decision to Jim Grabb.(AP)

title: Success of Oilers Points to Zendejas
description: THE way the Oilers' exuberant coach, Jerry Glanville, was talking yesterday, Sunday's sudden-death victory over the Seahawks was merely a diversion on the way to Super Bowl XXII.

title: New Headache on Roads: Drunken Bicycling
description: Paul Lynch had been drinking beer at a party a few hours before he decided to ride his bicycle to the neighborhood market for cigarettes one foggy night last January in Lebanon, Pa.

title: OFF BROADWAY'S BIGGEST GAMBLE
description: ''The Chosen,'' which opens Thursday at the Second Avenue Theater, is the biggest gamble in Off Broadway history. Its $2.5 million capitalization is more than the combined cost of all Off Broadway productions last season, according to Paul Libin, head of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, a trade group.

title: Plum Resumes Bidding for Holly
description: The New York investor group Plum Associates, which appeared to have lost a takeover bid for the Holly Sugar Corporation to the Imperial Sugar Company, re-emerged as a suitor. In its third proposal in two weeks, Plum Associates, a group headed by Peter R. Harvey of Illinois, is now offering to acquire 60 percent of the company's stock at $92.50 a share, or $61.5 million, instead of the previous cash price of $85 a share, or $56.5 million.

title: KAYPRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $515,000.

title: For Israeli Soldiers, 'War of Eyes' in West Bank
description: Leading an Israeli patrol through the streets of the Balata refugee center, Lieut. Col. Yisrael explained that on most days the confrontation here is not a war of bottles, stones or bullets.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE
description: The United States and other leading governments reportedly bought $2 billion to $3 billion in American currency today, helping the dollar to recover from a sharp decline in Asian trading.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TRANSFORMING A BROOKLYN THEATER
description: Armed with pickaxes and jackhammers, a contingent of 40 stagehands worked furiously yesterday to tear apart the set of ''The Mahabharata'' at the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn, barely 10 hours after the last performance of Peter Brook's epic production. Looking more like a muddy contruction site than the scene for this season's most-talked-about theatrical work, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's controversial new performance space was rapidly being transformed. The spartan setting of dirt and water that served to frame ''The Mahabharata'' was to become a turn-of-the-century Russian parlor for Mr. Brook's production of Chekhov's ''Cherry Orchard.''

title: Vietnam Acts On Investing
description: A Vietnamese investment code governing business and trade with foreigners has been passed by the country's National Assembly.

title: Houston Journal; The Drive-Through, A City's Love Affair
description: Once thought of as a a cow town, this city has long been one of the ultimate car towns. There are drive-through florists, drive-through dry cleaners, drive-through liquor stores and drive-through pharmacies. There is even a drive-through pawn shop for those who do not want to leave their cars and expose their hard luck to the world.

title: Chicago Provides Free Calculators to Students
description: In an effort to take some of the misery out of mathematics, the Chicago public schools began providing free pocket calculators to students today, but some critics warned that the program could cause learning problems.

title: New York's 2 Senators Seek To Alter Rule on Murdoch
description: Both United States Senators from New York, Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said yesterday that they would seek to reverse legislation passed by Congress that would likely require Rupert Murdoch to sell The New York Post.

title: Soviet Computer Push
description: A Soviet crash program to catch up with the West in designing powerful new computers is beginning to pay off, but the Russians still lag far behind, according to industry reports.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Philadelphia 76ers suspended Andrew Toney yesterday after the guard failed to complete the team's West Coast tour while complaining of chronic foot problems. Toney, who has appeared in only nine games this season, started and played 29 minutes at Portland Friday, tying his season-high of 13 points and handing out a season-high nine assists. After the game, he complained about his feet and declined to accompany the team to Seattle for their game Saturday. . . . Clint Malarchuk, the goalie, whose 2.45 goals-against average in four games helped the Washington Capitals to three victories and a tie in four games, was the player of the week in the National Hockey League. On Saturday night he turned in his first shutout of the season, a 2-0 victory over the Edmonton Oilers, the defending Stanley Cup champions.

title: Soviet Path Is Cleared
description: Marat Gramov, the chairman of the Soviet Union's sports committee, said today that his country intended to participate in the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, and that an official announcement was expected next week.

title: Notable Pensioners
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Watch; Intricate Changes Frustrate C.P.A.'s
description: AT a professional training course for accountants in the Bay Area, there were signs that tax practitioners have not kept up with the sweeping changes of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and thus have failed to give their clients important advice on critical matters.

title: Dock Union Organizer Is Found Slain in Auto
description: A 61-year-old union organizer, reputed to be an organized-crime figure, was found shot dead yesterday afternoon in his automobile parked in front of his home in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: List Submitted on Babbitt Delegates
description: Supporters of Bruce Babbitt yesterday submitted to the New York State Democratic Committee the names of 140 prospective candidates for delegate to the party's national convention. It was the first day such filings were permitted under state party rules.

title: For 'Silver Hair'
description: Senator John Melcher of Montana, chairman of the Senate's Special Committee on Aging, is working to convene a ''Silver-Haired Congress'' alongside the regular Congress sometime next year.

title: SLAVAGING OF AIRPLANE IN ANTARCTICA IS ON SCHEDULE
description: Plans by the National Science Foundation to recover a airplane used for polar exploration that crashed in 1971 are still on schedule despite the crash last month of a second plane carrying spare parts for the first, officials here say.

title: Music: New Setting of 3 Lorca Poems
