description: A NEW song cycle by David MacBride was the main feature of Sunday evening's concert by the Prism Chamber Orchestra at Merkin Concert Hall. ''Nocturnos de la Ventana'' is a setting, in Spanish, of three Garcia Lorca poems for tenor, string quintet, keyboards, percussion and a small wind complement. The themes are moon, water and death: even after George Crumb has set so many of these haunted reflections to music for American listeners, they remain more, clean and memorable in their imagery and filled with motion, for a younger composer to draw on.

title: Advertising; Johnstown, Pa., to Mark Centennial of Big Flood
description: Johnstown, Pa., has had a number of tragic floods, the worst one being almost 100 years ago. Indeed, the Johnstown flood is almost a part of the language.

title: Oil Rig Count Declines
description: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States fell by 24 last week, to 1,121, Baker Hughes said today. A year ago the total was 962.

title: Rolf Presthus, Norwegian Party Chief, 51
description: Rolf Presthus, chairman of the Conservative Party and a former Finance Minister, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Friday, his family said. He was 51 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What flesh-and-blood person would be the source of the genetic material used to map, or ''sequence,'' the entire human genetic code? A. Each person has 23 pairs of chromosomes, which together contain about 3 billion bits of DNA. Only one in a thousand differ from person to person, said Dr. Eric Lander, a researcher at the Whitehead Institute at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. For much research, it is the differences that are illuminating, so scientists use genetic material from a variety of people.

title: 10 Salieri Scores Are Found
description: A Czechoslovak museum has unearthed 10 manuscript scores by the Italian composer Antonio Salieri, the press agency C.T.K. reported today.

title: E.I.L. INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $189,900 for the quarter and $214,300 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $48,700 and $113,100 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: U.S. Matching Aid Is Being Disbursed To 12 Candidates
description: The Treasury began disbursing $28.7 million today in Federal matching funds to 12 Presidential candidates.

title: Continental's First Class Offered for Full Coach Fare
description: Continental Airlines struck a blow at the concept of first-class service yesterday, announcing that passengers who belong to its frequent-flier program and pay the full coach fare could get first-class seats on most flights by making reservations on a first-come, first-serve basis.

title: No End to Streak By Vanbiesbrouck
description: In the first 34 games, Michel Bergeron used at least three goaltending schemes and produced zero solutions. Six games ago, his imagination nearly exhausted and his intentions unclear, Bergeron threw up his hands and told John Vanbiesbrouck to start.

title: Books: Iraq's Jews
description: OPERATION BABYLON. By Shlomo Hillel. Translated from the Hebrew by Ina Friedman. Illustrated. 301 pages. Doubleday. $19.95.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Rise Moderately
description: Treasury bond prices retained moderate gains late yesterday after soaring earlier in the session. While relatively light, trading was described by dealers as somewhat unnerving, as illustrated by the behavior of the key long-term Treasury bond.

title: SAFETY EXPERTS QUESTION PROGRESS BY NASA
description: An internal report by safety experts concludes that two years after the Challenger disaster the space agency still lacks the engineers, guidelines or leadership to ensure the safety of manned spaceflight.

title: Many in Congress Feel Urge to Write
description: Along with writing the nation's laws, members of Congress have shown a 200-year passion for pen and paper by writing everything from college textbooks to boastful biographies to spy novels.

title: Dr. Max Siegel, Psychotherapist, 69
description: Dr. Max Siegel, a New York psychotherapist for many years, died of a heart attack Friday at Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: Westinghouse Growth Projection
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said that sales for the industrial and broadcasting company are expected to grow 8.5 percent this year. John C. Marous, the company's new chairman and chief executive officer, and Paul E. Lego, president and chief operating officer, who both took office today, said acquisitions and new business generated internally would account for three percentage points of the revenue growth.

title: Two Mayors Begin Their Second Terms With Visions of Jobs and Integrity; Flynn Vows Anew To Aid Youth
description: Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, building on a theme he has often sounded in his first four years in office, today pledged his administration to providing jobs for the city's young people.

title: Temple (8-0) Routs Rutgers by 86-60
description: Tim Perry, a senior forward, scored 16 points, including the 1,000th of his career, as Temple defeated Rutgers, 86-60, tonight in an Atlantic 10 game.

title: Mugabe Picks New Cabinet, Giving a Key Post to Nkomo
description: President Robert Mugabe appointed a new 27-member Cabinet on Saturday, dropping several longtime supporters and giving key posts to former foes, including Joshua Nkomo.

title: California Leads States In Money From Filming
description: California remained the favorite location for motion picture and television filming in 1987, taking in some $6 billion, slightly more than last year, according to early figures made public today by The Hollywood Reporter newspaper.

title: REBUKES TO ISRAEL ARE MUTED BY U.S.
description: The State Department has decided to refrain from further strong public criticism of Israel's handling of Palestinian protesters, a well-placed Administration official said today.

title: Anti-Takeover Move Advances in Delaware
description: Delaware, which is home to more major corporations than any other state, moved a step closer yesterday to adopting a law that would make unfriendly takeovers more difficult.

title: TV Review; Date Rape on 'Cagney and Lacey'
description: WHY does CBS keep conveying the distinct impression that, all things being equal, it would prefer not to have ''Cagney and Lacey'' on its schedule? You may remember that the series was officially canceled a few years ago and then brought back, thanks largely to viewer protests. Since then the show had been doing reasonably well in the ratings on Monday nights, although rumors of its permanent cancellation continued to circulate each year at renewal time. But the thing keeps on winning Emmy Awards, most notably for its two stars, Tyne Daly and Sharon Gless.

title: Apartheid Takes a New Year Break
description: Tyson Kobus sat under an oak tree here the other day and vented his disgust. Mr. Kobus is black and works as a $65-a-week driver for a local engineering company. But what troubled him as he relaxed on a garden chair was nothing to do with apartheid.

title: New Treatments May Aid Women Who Have Repeated Miscarriages
description: FOR some scientists, the question is not: Why does a woman's body sometimes reject a developing fetus? Instead, they ask: Why does any fetus survive all the way to term?

title: Wildcats Pound Redmen On Inside
description: The Villanova Wildcats invaded Alumni Hall last night and, despite a lapse late in the second half, dominated St. John's with a pulverizing inside attack that gave them a 69-62 victory.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Price Waterhouse Plan to Aid Banks
description: Price Waterhouse & Company, the accounting firm, is expected to announce today, according to accounting industry sources, that it will not require its clients to write down the value of all their Mexican loans if they participate in a recently announced plan to exchange part of those loans at a loss for new Mexican bonds.

title: MENTAL PATIENTS IN SOVIET TO GET NEW LEGAL RIGHTS
description: The Soviet Union has adopted a new set of legal rights for mental patients, the official press agency Tass reported tonight. It was the first fundamental revision of the Soviet regulations governing psychiatry in 27 years.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., elected as a director Harry Winters Jr., president of the Winters Co., Tucson, Ariz., a mining industry consulting concern.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Gary C. Robert has joined Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising, Melville, L.I., as executive vice president in charge of client services.

title: MAFIOSO'S ART EXHIBITED
description: Luciano Liggio, the real-life ''Godfather'' of Corleone, is spending his long hours in prison painting.

title: Gaston Eyskens Dies at Age 82; Led Six Governments in Belgium
description: Gaston Eyskens, a former Prime Minister of Belgium, who led six Governments during a period that spanned 24 years, died at his home in Louvain on Sunday. He was 82 years old.

title: Constitution Allows Pardons Before Conviction
description: To The Editor:

title: Van Hits Boy, 7, on L.I.
description: A 7-year-old East Meadow, L.I., boy, Anthony Accetta, was critically injured yesterday afternoon when he was hit by a Cablevision van in the road in front of his home on Maurice Avenue, according to the police. The driver of the vehicle, James Terry, 34, of West Babylon, L.I., was issued a summons for driving a vehicle with a suspended license. The injured boy was admitted to the intensive care unit at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow with a fractured skull.

title: Decision to Pay Fees to Econocom
description: The Decision Industries Corporation has agreed to pay Econocom International N.V. $1.85 million for certain expenses relating to Econocom's failed takeover offer for the computer concern based in Horsham, Pa.

title: Ski-Lift Death in Italy
description: A cable car loaded with about 50 skiers here started up accidentally with its door open and without its conductor today, and one teen-age skier fell 50 feet to his death, the police said. Two other teen-agers were injured when they also fell to the parking lot below the valley station.

title: Chess: American Open Tournament Is Won by Yasser Seirawan
description: Yasser Seirawan won the $10,000 first prize in the 23d annual American Open Tournament at the Los Angeles International Airport Marriott Hotel. The 27-year-old Seattle grandmaster scored the winning, 7-1, in the eight-round Swiss-System competition sponsored by Software Toolworks and organized by the Santa Monica Bay Chess Club.

title: Give Them Milk, Cookies and Vitamins
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Research On New Drugs Bypasses Addicts And Women
description: AIDS experts are growing more concerned that results from many trials of experimental drugs against the disease may not be valid for key segments of the population that the epidemic is increasingly hitting: drug users, nonwhites and women.

title: Ruins Yield Tales of Ancient Wars and Spies
description: WRITTEN in the clay, a sunbaked tablet from the 18th century B.C., was a message from one ruler of a city-state of upper Mesopotamia to another. We have released your spies, the ruler said, so where is the money you promised as ransom?

title: Oil Contracts Rise Modestly After 'Squeeze' In London
description: Crude oil futures posted modest gains yesterday on carry-over buying from Monday, when prices of all energy contracts soared on reports of a ''squeeze'' in London's cash market for North Sea Brent grade oil.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 6, 1988
description: International

title: The Pop Life
description: Gene Lees's 'Singers'

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: TV Review; 'Politics of Food,' on Channel 13
description: ''THE Politics of Food'' examines worldwide hunger and finds it's the fault of the West. Western creditors and governments, particularly the United States, have joined to choke off world food supplies. The two-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, is provocative, but it doesn't have much breadth.

title: Film: 'The Horse Thief'
description: THE Chinese film ''The Horse Thief'' is best watched as pure spectacle, since it unfolds almost entirely without benefit of dialogue. What little talk there is tends to be plain and to the point (''If only we had stew''). However, from the scenic and ethnographic standpoints the film is often quite arresting. Like the more dramatically compelling ''Wild Mountains,'' another product of the Xian Film Studio in China, ''The Horse Thief'' concentrates on a primitive way of life, and captures it with a surprising degree of sophistication.

title: Washington State's Young Wine Industry Seeks Recognition
description: THE horizon seems boundless as scanned from many vineyards in eastern Washington, with the snowy Cascade Mountains rising far away across semi-arid deserts. For Simon Siegl, executive director of the Washington Wine Institute, the economic horizon of the state's steadily rising wine industry seems equally expansive.

title: Waxing and Waning at Mme. Tussaud's
description: Once a month, eight people meet to decide which world figures will remain immortal and which will be smashed and melted down.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about the appointment of New York City's new Schools Chancellor misidentified Peter F. Vallone. He is the majority leader of the City Council, not its president.

title: Jon Miles Kurtis, Sales Executive, 32
description: Jon Miles Kurtis, foreign sales executive with Manley Productions Inc., New York film producers, died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Woodstock, Vt. An autopsy is planned to determine the cause of death. He was 32 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Capital Reading; Rehnquist Taking Stock of the Federal Judiciary
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist last week issued his year-end report on the Supreme Court and the Federal judiciary. Following are excerpts:

title: How to Welcome Chancellor Green
description: In introducing himself to New York, Richard Green revealed a confident, adroit public figure and passionately concerned educator. To rescue the failing school system, he will need those qualities and more. He will need substantive help from the central Board of Education, which will formally choose him as Chancellor today, and from City Hall and Albany. They'd all do well to start now.

title: Death of Black In Jail Beating Stuns 2 Towns
description: Early Christmas night Loyal Garner Jr. said goodbye to his wife and six children in nearby Florien, La., hopped in his pickup truck and headed with two companions to retrieve a friend's automobile just across the border in Texas.

title: Israeli Troops Kill Arab In a Fresh Riot in Gaza
description: Israeli troops shot and killed at least one stone-throwing Palestinian youth today and wounded seven others while trying to quell another outbreak of rioting in the Gaza Strip. Five Israeli soldiers were slightly wounded by rocks and bottles.

title: Navy Awards Pact
description: The Navy has awarded a $644 million contract to the General Dynamics Corporation to build the 15th Trident missile submarine. The submarine will be built by General Dynamics' Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn., and is scheduled to be completed in July 1994, the Navy said. The submarines will each carry 24 of the Navy's updated Trident 2 missiles, or D-5, which is undergoing flight tests.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Advance
description: Bond prices rose modestly yesterday for the second consecutive day, following the lead set by the foreign exchange market, where the dollar continued to strengthen.

title: Study of Drinking Water Assails E.P.A. as Derelict in Monitoring
description: Nearly one out of five public water sys-tems tested in the United States has been found to be contaminated by chemicals, a group affiliated with the consumer advocate Ralph Nader said today.

title: Reinforcements Reach Iowa For Final Push on Caucuses
description: Presidential contenders in both parties are bringing in reinforcements for their final political offensives before Iowa's important caucuses on Feb. 8.

title: Fellini Asks Court to Ban French Version of Film
description: Federico Fellini, whose latest film, ''Intervista,'' opened two weeks ago in France to rave reviews, asked a Paris court today to ban further showings, complaining that the French dubbing was vulgar.

title: Nominees Announced For 1988 Golden Globes
description: ''Broadcast News,'' ''The Last Emperor'' and ''Moonstruck'' each received five 1988 Golden Globe nominations today from the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

title: TOP CONTENDERS IN HAITI DECLARE BOYCOTT OF VOTE
description: Less than two weeks before the presidential election scheduled by Haiti's army-dominated Government, the four leading candidates have carried out their threat to call a boycott and the field is dominated by seven former associates of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship.

title: New President Named By Pacific Exchange
description: Herbert G. Kawahara, a longtime executive of E. F. Hutton & Company, has been named president of the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: How Can U.S. Continue Indefinite Detention?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hirshhorn Given 8 Major Works
description: The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden has been given eight major works of modern art from the estates of Gustave Ring, a leading builder in the Washington area, and his wife, Marion.

title: F.C.C. to Revive Minority-Help Policies
description: The Federal Communications Commission plans to reinstate policies designed to increase ownership of radio and television stations by members of minority groups and by women, according to a commission spokesman.

title: Caribbean Cooking
description: RIGHT now, it's tempting enough just to gaze at the cover of ''Tropic Cooking'' by Joyce LaFray Young (Ten Speed Press, $12.95), with its photograph of a turquoise sea lapping at white sand and a grove of palm trees set against an azure sky.

title: KEY RATES
Alysheba Is Top 3-Year-Old
description: Alysheba lost to Java Gold the only time they met on the race track last year, but scored a resounding victory yesterday in the Eclipse Award balloting for the champion 3-year-old of 1987.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Credit Card Deficit
description: Calculating that each American taxpayer, in theory, could be responsible for $18,569.10 of the debt now on the Federal books, a Republican Congressman from New York is trying to force the Internal Revenue Service to make that more widely known.

title: Lotus and Rossin Suits Settled Out of Court
description: The suit and countersuit involving the Lotus Development Corporation and the Rossin Greenberg Sereonick & Hill agency and the question of the security of company secrets have been settled out of court, with the agency promising not to solicit business from any Lotus competitor for 10 months, as well as promising in writing not to release any confidental information of Lotus's.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FRIENDS are often surprised when I tell them that one of the favorite foods of my childhood in Burgundy was macaroni and cheese taken bubbling from the oven of the wood-burning stove. Their response is conditioned by the thought that macaroni and cheese is as solidly American as Boston baked beans and clam chowder.

title: Washington Talk: Campaign Press Secretaries; A Buckley Who Doesn't Exactly Fit the Mold
description: In the nation's capital nearly everybody who is anybody has a press secretary. Their lot in life is to quash unpleasant rumors, write press releases, schedule interviews with sometimes hostile journalists, fend off attacks from many quarters and, for the most part, entrust their futures to the boss.

title: 'Chess': On, Off, and On Again
description: The Broadway production of ''Chess,'' which for the last year has been scheduled, threatened with cancellation and, only last week, postponed indefinitely, is now scheduled to open in April, the producers announced yesterday.

title: Dow Gains 16.25 More, To 2,031.50
description: LEAD: Bolstered by a strengthening dollar and by takeover speculation in the drug sector, the stock market moved higher again yesterday, although its sharp early gains were eaten away by late-afternoon profit taking.

title: Hold the Salt at the Food Factories
description: To the Editor:

title: Gluttony Kills 10 Yugoslavs
description: Too much New Year's food and drink killed 10 people in Belgrade, the newspaper Vecernje Novosti reported today. It quoted doctors as saying the deaths were caused by heart attacks or strokes resulting from overeating or drinking too much alcohol.

title: Grand Auto's Sale To Paccar Is Set
description: Grand Auto Inc., the struggling chain of automobile parts stores based in Oakland, Calif., has agreed to be acquired by Paccar Inc., a manufacturer of trucks and oilfield equipment based in Bellevue, Wash., for $16 a share, or about $49.2 million.

title: G.M. Fills Key Post
description: The General Motors Corporation said that J. T. Battenberg 3d had been promoted to vice president. Mr. Battenberg, who is 44 years old, heads the design and manufacturing of cars for the Flint Automotive division of the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alliant Computer Systems Corp., Littleton, Mass., said it was restructuring to add 50 new jobs in its international organization and to eliminate 40 positions at its headquarters.

title: Salvador Leader Says Rebels Killed Head of Rights Group
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte asserted today that Salvadoran leftist guerrillas were responsible for killing a leading human rights official here three months ago.

title: Jackson Obtains Matching Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission today declared the Rev. Jesse Jackson eligible to receive Federal matching funds for his 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: All's Well at Manhattan
description: Jack Powers, the Manhattan College athletic director, announced yesterday that school officials had met with the basketball coach, Bob Delle Bovi, and would not take any disciplinary action against him for pulling his team off the court and forfeiting a game against Drexel in a Texas tournament two weeks ago.

title: H.C.A. Completes Repurchase Plan
description: The Hospital Corporation of America has completed a $564 million stock repurchase plan. The offer for 12 million of common shares at $47 a share expired at midnight Monday.

title: G.M.'s High-Tech Visions of Sales
description: The General Motors Corporation showed off its technological visions of the future yesterday, even though some of its high-tech efforts have been less than wildly popular with consumers.

title: New Call to Conserve Water Is Made in Wake of Oil Spill
description: Saying a crisis still existed, Gov. Robert P. Casey called today for renewed efforts to conserve water in suburban areas in the aftermath of the huge oil spill in the Monongahela River.

title: Life in the 30's
description: I HAVE been married almost 10 years to the same person. Sometimes it's hard for me to believe. Neither of us was sure that any human being could be expected to live over the long haul with anyone as stubborn, opinionated and difficult as the other. Somehow it has worked, and it is not a gross exaggeration to say that this is partly because I am a much better cook than he is, and he tells much better jokes than I do.

title: Northrop Delays Test Of Stealth Bomber
description: The top-secret Stealth bomber being built by the Northrop Corporation, which is already believed to be hampered by problems that have brought more than $200 million in write-offs, is now experiencing new delays and management problems.

title: LESSONS
description: Here in Texas by the Colorado River is a man from Oregon whose story begins in Chicago. He is a mountain man, a lover of Douglas firs, the self-appointed watchman who keeps a summer vigil high on a Pacific peak. It seems strange to encounter him on a cold, leaden day among cinder block and steel. And yet, this is an apt place. The unknowing are here and he, again, is a teacher.

title: NEW FLAW IS FOUND AFTER TEST FIRING OF SHUTTLE ROCKET
description: A second flaw in the redesigned shuttle booster rocket has been discovered by engineers from the space agency and Morton Thiokol Inc. Their further examination of last month's test firing showed that hot gases reached an O ring seal in a critical rocket joint.

title: Threat by Wagner to Resign Resolved Schools Stalemate
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr., his authority as president of New York City's Board of Education imperiled, resolved a sensitive political stalemate over the choice of a new schools chancellor last week with a threat to resign, city and education officials said yesterday.

title: Cuomo Years: The Words vs. the Deeds
description: From Maine to California, from Detroit to New Orleans, Governor Cuomo traveled the country 27 times last year, mostly to sound the impassioned theme that has become his trademark: Ronald Reagan is wrong. More money and programs are needed to help the poor and others who do not share in the American dream.

title: Seton Hall Beats Connecticut, 71-58
description: There was no need for inspirational speeches by Coach P. J. Carlesimo when his Seton Hall team played Connecticut tonight. All the Pirates had to do for motivation was recall last season, when Connecticut, the last-place team in the Big East Conference, defeated them twice.

title: Marblehead Journal; Jarring Footnote To Historic District
description: Every year thousands of visitors flock to Marblehead, to its historic harbor, its art and craft galleries and antique shops, its purposely quaint Colonial streets and its six yacht clubs. This winter, a new group of guests are staying unseasonably late: 15 homeless families.

title: Capitals Top Flyers To Extend Streak
description: Dave Christian and Mike Gartner scored first-period goals tonight as the Washington Capitals defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 3-1, and extended their unbeaten streak to five games.

title: Dr. Denton Cooley Petitions For Bankruptcy Protection
description: Dr. Denton A. Cooley, one of the nation's foremost heart surgeons, filed for protection Monday under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, an apparent victim of the foundering real estate market here.

title: U.S.-Mexico Export Pact
description: Textile and apparel exports from Mexico to the United States would grow by 6 percent annually in the next four years, compared with a 50 percent increase in 1987 imports, under a pact between the two countries announced today by the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter.

title: A Closer Look at Drugs in Animals
description: Manufacturers of drugs given to animals that are used for food will be required to develop new tests for residues, in order to meet a stricter safety standard proposed by the Food and Drug Administration, officials announced Monday.

title: Stage: 'Song of Refuge,' Environmentalist Show
description: THE most vivid images in ''Song of Refuge,'' a kind of environmentalist Punch and Judy show, suggest a high-minded, low-budget theatrical offshoot of the movie ''Robocop.'' Following scenes in which the unpolluted natural environment is depicted in shadow puppetry underscored by ethereal chanting, actors clad in outfits made entirely from metal cans battle one another clumsily in a sequence of clanking duels. The armor worn by these ''garbage gladiators,'' as they are called, includes buckets for helmets and garbage-can lids as shields. Their blind, lurching encounters, fatal to all combatants, offer an apt if obvious metaphor for technological doomsday.

title: Food Notes
description: Chefs on the Slopes

title: The Versatile Sweet Potato (Or Is It Actually a Yam?)
description: ASK a few friends whether they prefer yams or sweet potatoes and you'll get quite an earful. Of course yams are better, they'll tell you. They're richer, moister, smoother and sweeter. It's a fact, they'll say, that the paler sweet potatoes just can't compare. They know, because they've tried them both in a variety of ways: mashed, souffled, candied and just plain roasted.

title: Knicks Stumble Against Suns
description: Don't assume anything with the Knicks. Just when it seemed they had taken two major steps forward, they found a way to take a big step back last night.

title: New Hunt for Ideal Energy Storage System
description: ENGINEERS have long dreamed of a near-perfect energy storage system in which a huge current of electricity would circulate indefinitely without resistance, always ready for use. The basis for such power storage would be a superconducting coil, but the cost of the device has prevented its development by utility companies. Now, an infusion of money from the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program may be bringing the superconducting storage coil nearer to reality.

title: Inquiry on Nestle Unit
description: Peru has started an investigation of a subsidiary of Nestle S.A. here, accusing it of stockpiling three million cans of evaporated milk. ''This is serious because it involves a foreign company and we have to intervene to safeguard the economy,'' Peru's President, Alan Garcia, told reporters Monday as he announced the investigation into the company, called Perulac. Mr. Garcia began a campaign against stockpiling last weekend, sending officials to uncover goods he said were hidden in expectation of higher prices.

title: Topics of The Times; Bagging the Tree
description: This being Twelfth Night and the end of the Christmas season, it's safe to say that millions of American homes will sport a trail of needles from tree stand to front door tomorrow. But not where the homeowners had the foresight to invest in a tree removal bag.

title: ASPIN DENOUNCES REPORT BY REAGAN
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin, issued a blistering criticism today of a year-old report from President Reagan on his strategy for achieving national security.

title: McGwire Leaving Iowa
description: Saying he didn't get a fair shake at Iowa, Dan McGwire, who dropped from starting quarterback for the Hawkeyes in the preseason to No. 3 by the end of the year, said he plans to transfer to San Diego State. ''Very unhappy. Very unhappy. You can underline that,'' McGwire said. ''They built me up to be real big and they didn't give me a chance.'' McGwire, a 6-foot-8-inch, 218-pound sophomore, whose brother Mark hit 49 home runs for the Oakland A's last season, started in Iowa's 23-22 loss to Tennessee in the Kickoff Classic and in the Hawkeyes' 19-14 loss to the eventual Big Ten and Rose Bowl champion, Michigan State. Then he was replaced by Chuck Hartlieb, who guided Iowa to six consecutive victories and will return next season. Coach Hayden Fry was in Atlanta and could not be reached for comment.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: NOTHING is better for you or shows off a microwave oven to better advantage than vegetables, particularly winter vegetables.

title: Oil Experts Call Tank Typical But Question Dike's Capacity
description: The collapse of an oil storage tank near Pittsburgh on Saturday was highly unusual, according to experts in the field, but they said it was also surprising that surrounding dikes did not keep a million gallons of diesel fuel out of the Monongahela River.

title: John Millis, College Chancellor
description: John S. Millis, chancellor emeritus of Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, died of cancer Friday at his home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. He was 84 years old.

title: Takeover Bar In Delaware
description: The executive committee of the Delaware Bar Association, as expected, yesterday endorsed a measure that would limit certain unfriendly corporate takeovers.

title: Stuart Perlman, 60, Co-Founder Of Caesars World With Brother
description: Stuart Z. Perlman, who with his brother founded Caesars World Inc., a chain of opulent gambling casinos and hotels, and then severed ties with it amid charges of ties to suspected organized-crime figures, died of a heart attack Monday at the North Miami Medical Center in North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 60 years old.

title: The Masses: Still Huddled
description: LEAD: A union official recently overheard a Haitian-born worker listening to a radio station broadcasting in Creole. Every word was in the man's native tongue, with one glaring exception: The Immigration and Naturalization Service's announcement about the amnesty program for undocumented workers was in English!

title: Icahn Gives Court Plan On Texaco
description: Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street financier who is the largest Texaco shareholder, has made good his promise to offer an alternative to the company's plan to emerge from Federal bankruptcy protection.

title: What Americans Really Eat; How Do Your Habits Compare?
description: TO discover what Americans eat, 1,870 people nationwide were asked a battery of questions, including the following. To find out how you measure up, compare your responses with those of the survey respondents.

title: Congress Acts to Ease Plight of Black Colleges
description: Congress, attaching special significance to the financial plight of black colleges and universities, has increased the amount of Federal aid for those schools by about 50 percent this year, to $73.1 million.

title: CSX Corporation Joins Hawaii Plan
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said that the CSX Corporation had agreed to become a partner in a $200 million project to develop two hotels and 150 homes on the Hawaiian island of Lanai.

title: British Reserves Surge
description: Britain's foreign currency reserves rose by $3.74 billion in December, which was more than expected, the Government said today. Analysts attributed this to actions by the Bank of England to limit the rise of the pound and to support the dollar.

title: Postmaster General Plans to Step Down by Spring
description: Postmaster General Preston R. Tisch announced today that he would leave office to return to private business in the next few months.

title: Real Estate; Flushing's Main Street Is Thriving
description: MAIN STREET, the downtown of Flushing, was weakened but never felt the sharp decline that hit other Queens commercial centers when regional shopping malls began opening in the borough in the 1960's. Since the early 1980's Main Street has evolved from a struggling retail street into a thriving shopping center where retailers have squeezed into almost every square inch of space and where the vacancy rate is less than 1 percent.

title: 3 More Will Go to Seoul
description: Three more Eastern European countries - Poland, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia - have said they will compete in the Seoul Olympics, increasing to 133 the number of nations who have accepted invitations.

title: A.T.&T. Case To Continue
description: The General Services Administration's board of contract appeals said yesterday that it would resume considering a protest by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, ruling in the process that the Government had not provided enough information to justify a continued delay.

title: Bell & Howell Sued
description: The Bell & Howell Company faces seven shareholder lawsuits, contending that the company failed to negotiate fairly with all parties during the bidding that developed between the British publisher Robert Maxwell, the New York publishing company Macmillan Inc. and the Bass family of Texas. Bell & Howell, based in Skokie, Ill., accepted an offer of $64 a share, or $647 million, from the Bass group, which also included several Bell & Howell executives. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the company said it ''believes that the actions are without merit.''

title: New York Shelters Step Up Work Programs
description: New York City officials said yesterday that more than 2,700 residents of city shelters had been placed in jobs through work programs since they began in 1982, with almost half the placements since last fall.

title: Muller Jordan Adds Blair Entertainment
description: John Blair Communications is made up of Blair Television, a national advertising representative for a number of stations, and Blair Entertainment, which produces and syndicates TV programming.

title: Allen Ginsberg's 'Howl' In a New Controversy
description: Thirty-two years ago, Allen Ginsberg sent shock waves through the seemingly placid cultural landscape of mid-1950's America with a poem that proclaimed ''the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness.''

title: Saday Courville, Fiddler, 82
description: Saday Courville, who played second fiddle on the first known Cajun record in 1928 and was one of the last links with the ''pure'' sounds of the Acadian heritage, died of heart failure Sunday. He was 82 years old.

title: The Vice President's Advice
description: It's always been hard to accept that George Bush could, at the same time, be the most ''completely involved'' Vice President of modern times, as he and President Reagan assert, and still have been disengaged from the Iran-contra affair, as he asserts. And it's getting harder as Mr. Bush still refuses to say more about his role in that disaster. That he is engaged in a Presidential campaign is no excuse; a campaign is an occasion for coming clean with the voters, not for ducking.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Saturday listing Nasdaq stocks with the biggest gains and losses for 1987 misstated the percentage decline for National Bancshares of Texas. The stock fell 81.6 percent. In addition, a chart of the leading underwriters misidentified a top-ranking firm. It was Credit Suisse First Boston, which shared the top spot with First Boston.

title: Vote Puts Small-Town Blacks on Top
description: The small, impoverished town of Keysville, 120 miles east of here, on Monday re-established a local government that had been dormant for 54 years. The election, seen by many as a symbol of efforts by rural blacks to gain political power, marked a victory for blacks seeking more municipal services over whites who fear higher taxes.

title: Montand to Be Honored In Film Society Tribute
description: The French singer and actor Yves Montand will be the recipient of the 1988 tribute by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, April 25 at Avery Fisher Hall. As it has done annually since the first tribute in 1972, the society will show excerpts from several of the honoree's films, including his latest, ''Jean de Florette'' and ''Manon of the Spring.'' Several actors who have worked with Mr. Montand will take part in the event, which is to begin at 7 P.M.

title: Prison Revolt Ends in Brazil As Police Wound Ringleader
description: Police sharpshooters wounded the leader of a prison revolt today, ending a 30-hour uprising that left four inmates and guards dead and eight wounded, officials said.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Chairman Would Go In Pan Am-Union Deal
description: C. Edward Acker's days as chairman and chief executive of the Pan Am Corporation appear numbered.

title: Marmie Named Coach
description: Arizona State named defensive coordinator Larry Marmie as its new head football coach last night, just five days after John Cooper resigned to take the job at Ohio State. Although Marmie, who is 45 years old, has no previous head-coaching experience, he had Cooper's support as his successor plus the unanimous approval of the Sun Angel Foundation - the school's main booster group. Marmie, a quarterback at Eastern Kentucky from 1961-65, previously was an assistant at Morehead State (1968-71), Eastern Kentucky (1972-76), Tulsa (1977-78), North Carolina (1979-82) and Tennessee (1983-84).

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Nothing Like Bogus Guidance on Japanese Intent
description: Last spring, Representative Tom McMillen, a freshman Democrat from Maryland, took the floor of the House of Representatives to describe an ''internal, high-level Japanese Government memo'' that he said had recently been brought to his attention.

title: Trading Plan for N.A.S.D.
description: Still smarting from criticism that some of its market makers failed to cope with the crush of customer orders in the Oct. 19 stock trading rout, the National Association of Securities Dealers plans further improvements in executing transactions electronically.

title: 13,000 Deaths a Year Indicated By Science Academy Radon Study
description: Exposure to radon, the odorless radioactive gas that seeps into buildings from underground rocks, appears to be responsible for about 13,000 lung cancer deaths annually, according to new data compiled by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Ex-Senator Enters Plea In Fraud Case in Jersey
description: David J. Friedland, the former New Jersey state senator who was captured on an island in the Indian Ocean last month, pleaded not guilty today in Federal court to charges of conspiracy to defraud a teamsters union pension fund.

title: Advertising; Spreading The Word of Cable Guide
description: WHINING chief executives of agencies and magazines, in search of publicity, are fond of saying, ''We are the best-kept secret in the business.'' Few, however, back up that cliche with proof.

title: Guests Coming to 'Evening News'
description: The ''CBS Evening News,'' hoping to capitalize on the allure of its star journalists, will begin next week to schedule regular guest appearances on the newscast by the correspondents from the CBS prime-time program, ''60 Minutes.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Gun Lobby Protests
description: Pro-gun forces in the capital, who have long perceived Senator Edward M. Kennedy and other gun control advocates in Congress as their chief adversaries, are now viewing with alarm a purported threat from an entirely different quarter - the Reagan Administration.

title: U.S. Literature: Canon Under Siege
description: Many college professors around the country are rethinking the very notion of what is literature.

title: VNU Sets Acquisition Of Media Records
description: VNU, the United States subsidiary of a Dutch publishing company, has acquired Media Records, a company that keeps track of the advertising content of newspapers, and will add it to its Marketing Services division. Since the division already operates Leading National Advertisers, a major media-measuring service, it means a more complete service for the industry.

title: Citicorp Rates Off
description: Interest rates fell for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's regular commercial paper auctions yesterday. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.908 percent, down from 7.3946 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.0184 percent, down from 7.2978 percent.

title: Optical Sets $13 Payment
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -

title: Islanders Alone in First After They Salvage Tie
description: Nobody was gratified by the 3-3 tie that followed three plodding periods and the blizzard of offense both clubs appeared to save for the five-minute overtime. Still, the Islanders and the Minnesota North Stars admitted to feeling a sense of relief about at least being able to emerge unbeaten from a lengthy game whose difficulty grew as it neared its conclusion.

title: U.S. Crude Output Off
description: United States crude oil production declined 4.1 percent, to 3.03 billion barrels, in 1987, a year when the oil industry was thought to be showing signs of recovery from its nose dive in the early 1980's, Petroleum Information reported on Monday. Meanwhile, natural gas production, bolstered by increased production from the Gulf of Mexico, increased by 1.7 percent above 1986 to an estimated total of 18.2 trillion cubic feet, according to the Denver-based reporting service for the oil industry.

title: Gadgets From the Attic Are Put Back to Work
description: FOUR years ago, De Gustibus discussed useless kitchen gadgets that were collecting dust in the attic: things that were broken, like electric mixers and electric frying pans, and things that were in good working order but served no useful purpose at the time.

title: G.M.A.C. Offering Noncallable Notes
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $250 million of 8 3/4 percent noncallable notes, due in 1991, at a price of 99.95 to yield 8.767 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: 'Three Men and a Baby' Top Film at Box Office
description: ''Three Men and a Baby'' remained the top film at the box office for the first weekend of 1988, earning nearly twice as much as the second-place movie.

title: Sinking-Fund Issue by Berkshire
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. is offering $150 million of 10 percent sinking-fund debentures, due in 2018, at a price of 99.25 to yield 10.079 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; '88 Predictions
description: Among dozens of political tout sheets that give the morning line on Presidential and Congressional campaigns, the Cook Political Report is one of the most respected. In its latest edition, Charles E. Cook Jr., editor, finds that ''with every week, the Republican nomination becomes more of a two-way contest'' between Vice President Bush and Senator Bob Dole. For the Democrats, he says that ''the re-entry of Gary Hart is a very serious matter, witty jokes notwithstanding.'' It is splitting the vote of all the other Democratic hopefuls except Jesse Jackson, the report says, and has increased the difficulty of relatively unknown candidates in gaining attention.

title: A Computer's Penmanship Problem
description: Computers are dumb beasts that do exactly what they are told. When told to do something perfectly, they do it perfectly. Inscribe, a Cambridge, Mass., company marketing computerized calligraphy , is finding that the computer is . . . well, not human enough. It doesn't make mistakes.

title: A Vital Shadow Society: East Bloc Breadwinner
description: Across Eastern Europe a shadow society has sprung up outside of the control of the ruling Communist parties, tolerated because the authorities have neither the money nor the ability to fulfill Marxism-Leninism's promise to build a better life for working people.

title: Soviet Bloc Proposes Talks Toward Battlefield Nuclear Missile Ban
description: The Warsaw Pact has proposed negotiations that could lead to the elimination of the battlefield nuclear missiles deployed in Central Europe and along the border between the Germanys.

title: Boxing Notebook; Hagler's Future: No Decision
description: By now it seems as if Marvelous Marvin Hagler would have made up his mind about his boxing future.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KRAZY KAT. A Novel in Five Panels. By Jay Cantor. 250 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Chip Designers Seek Haste Without Waste
description: WHEN the Intel Corporation developed the 80286 microprocessor a few years ago, the chip was jammed with 120,000 transistors and took about three and a half years to create. Its successor, the 80386, was more than twice as complex - 275,000 transistors - and was finished in a little under three years.

title: U.S. Rules on Documentaries Challenged
description: Independent film makers have challenged new rules by the United States Information Agency that allow the Government to label documentary films as propaganda when certifying them for duty-free distribution abroad.

title: BRAZIL NAMES NEW FINANCE MINISTER
description: President Jose Sarney today named an economist and longtime Government official, Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega, as Brazil's new Finance Minister, succeeding Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira, who resigned last month in a clash over economic policy.

title: Solomon Telushkin, Accountant, 81
description: Solomon Telushkin, an accountant, died of a stroke Dec. 24 in his home in Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

title: Let Us Not Praise Any Famous Womanizers; A Complicitous Press
description: To the Editor:

title: The Main Challenge Facing South Korea
description: LEAD: A new political era is dawning in South Korea. While significant tensions linger from the presidential vote last month, the election may be the nation's most dramatic progress in political development since its formation in 1948.

title: Sale in West by Soviet Bank Is Called the First of Its Kind
description: Soviet bank said today that it was issuing 100 million Swiss francs ($75 million) of 5 percent bonds, a move bankers said was apparently the first of its kind by an enterprise incorporated in the Soviet Union.

title: Let Us Not Praise Any Famous Womanizers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gorbachev Ally Calls Latest Changes 'Fiction'
description: A member of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic brain trust today published an unusually strong critique of the country's latest economic innovations, saying the measures introduced throughout most of Soviet industry just four days ago were ''a fiction.''

title: Jazz: Rashied Ali Quartet
description: RASHIED ALI became John Coltrane's drummer in the late 1960's, when the saxophonist had broken into free jazz. But for its first set Monday at the Knitting Factory, Mr. Ali's quartet harked back to the late 1950's, when Coltrane was on the cusp of hard-bop and modal jazz. With Arthur Rhames on alto saxophone, Antoine Roney on tenor saxophone and Greg Murphy on a rather soupy-sounding electric piano, the quartet played a modal blues, a hard-bop tune and a breakneck version of ''Cherokee'' - staying, for the most part, within the boundaries of tonal harmony.

title: GLADLY, THE JAPANESE IMPORT AN AMERICAN CAMPUS
description: Shinya Watanabe was amused at the unlikely sight of his fellow students panicking over a term paper that was almost due. Nearby, students sitting in study carrels with their heads bent over Western classics occasionally looked longingly out the window.

title: Behind New York City Policy on Restraining Prisoner Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo to Ask Rise in Jobless Aid
description: Governor Cuomo, in his State of the State message on Wednesday, will propose raising the maximum weekly benefit for unemployed workers in New York by almost 30 percent, aides to the Governor said today.

title: Koch Discloses Cuts in Hiring Police Officers
description: Mayor Koch, seeking to dissuade the State Legislature from approving increases in municipal pensions, said yesterday that New York City would hire 1,548 fewer police officers and sanitation workers over the next two months than had been anticipated.

title: Fox Sneakers In Agency Shift
description: Travel Fox sneakers, which created quite a stir last year by running an ad featuring a male and female clad only in sweat socks and the product, have been switched to another agency.

title: Sutton Returns
description: Don Sutton, a 300-game winner who spent the first 15 years of his major-league career pitching for the Dodgers, has signed a one-year contract with his old team. ''We are extremely happy to have Don Sutton return to the Dodgers' organization,'' Fred Claire, the team's executive vice president, said. ''We know he will make an outstanding contribution to the Dodgers in 1988.'' Sutton, 42 years old, became a free agent when the California Angels did not re-sign him. The right-hander's career record is 321-250, with 3,530 strikeouts. He was 11-11 with a 4.70 earned run average in 34 starts with the Angels last year. He holds Dodger team records in eight pitching categories, including victories (230), shutouts (52) and strikeouts (2,652). . . . Danny Cox has re-signed with the St. Louis Cardinals for undisclosed terms. Cox, 28, compiled an 11-9 record and a 3.88 e.r.a. in 31 starts spanning a staff-leading 199Y innings last season. . . . Thad Bosley, a free agent who led the American League in pinch hits with 12 last season, agreed to a two-year contract with the Kansas City Royals, the first year of which is guaranteed.

title: op That Drop
description: Here's an acronym you should know: MEGO. It stands for ''My Eyes Glaze Over.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rolando Blackman, whose 18.5- point scoring average is second highest on the team, will miss the Dallas Mavericks' next five games after spraining his knee in a 117-107 loss to Houston Monday. The 6-foot-6-inch Blackman was injured when Allen Leavell of the Houston Rockets fell on him after fouling Blackman on a drive to the basket. . . . Danny White, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, said he will not have off-season surgery on his right wrist, which was broken during a game against the Giants on Nov. 2, 1986. White said he made his decision after having the wrist X-rayed Monday by Dr. Peter Carter in Dallas. ''He thinks it's improved and doesn't think there's any surgery that they could do that would give me the strength and the flexibility that I would need to play,'' White said. . . . Trevor Berbick, former World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, pleaded not guilty in Halifax, Nova Scotia, yesterday, to a charge of sexual assault. Berbick, 35, chose to be tried by a county court judge without a jury on a charge that he sexually assaulted a teen-age girl in Halifax in August 1985. The charge was filed last Nov. 26. . . . John Holt, the general secretary of the International Amateur Athletic Association, said yesterday that an appeal by the Swiss runner, Sandra Gasser, against a two-year international suspension for drug abuse, will be heard on Jan. 18 in London. Until then, Holt said, any athlete competing against Gasser also would become immediately liable for suspension.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For the past two days the central banks have been like a basketball team that uses fast breaks to keep the opposition off balance. For the past two days they have been buying dollars as the currency has risen in value, an action that has pushed the dollar even higher. For the last year or so they always bought dollars as the currency was sinking.'' - John Prout, a London currency trader. [ D2:3. ]

title: Ward Calls for Increased Training To Reduce Use of Guns by Police
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that New York City officers needed more training in subduing violent people without using guns and in ''overcoming a mindset'' that makes them reluctant to retreat.

title: Savings Deposits Grow
description: Net new deposits at savings and loan institutions rose by $2.7 billion in November, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today. It was the second consecutive monthly gain: Deposits rose by $6.1 billion in October as stock market investors shifted money to savings accounts.

title: Manhattan Weekly Reduces News Staff by 25%
description: The New York Observer, a four-month-old weekly serving Manhattan, cut its news staff by 25 percent yesterday to try to reduce costs, said Arthur L. Carter, the owner and publisher.

title: About New York; A Father and Son And a Shop On Lafayette St.
description: You know how it is in these parts: you step into a shop and all of a sudden the shopkeeper is your newest best friend. Everybody has a story like that. Everybody has at least one warm song for every three tunes of rudeness, or should. In any event, Pasquale Ursitti answered the door.

title: Syracuse Tops Boston College
description: Rony Seikaly and Derrick Coleman scored 19 points each, and Steve Thompson added 15 tonight as Syracuse scored an 80-67 Big East victory over Boston College.

title: BULLETS DEFEAT NETS
description: Bernard King scored 15 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter, and Moses Malone scored 26 points as Washington snapped a five-game losing streak by defeating the Nets, 101-97, tonight. It was Wes Unseld's debut as the Bullets' head coach.

title: 2 Soviet Families Defect
description: Two Soviet families asked for political asylum in Turkey last week, a Foreign Ministry official said today. The spokesman, Inal Batu, said the Government was reviewing the requests and had not made a decision.

title: Bush Retaliates for Dole's Criticisms
description: Vice President Bush, who has been repeatedly attacked by his leading Republican rival, Senator Bob Dole, struck back today, scoffing at Mr. Dole's Senate career and his expertise in foreign policy.

title: Man and Woman Rob Malcolm X's Daughter
description: The 23-year-old daughter of Malcolm X was forced into a car on West 60th Street yesterday afternoon and robbed at gunpoint, the police said.

title: Judge Upsets U.S. Rule on Transit Aid for Disabled
description: A Federal district judge in Philadelphia has overturned regulations set by the United States Department of Transportation that he said deprived disabled people of the right to have access to mass transportation.

title: In North Africa, Feminists on Diverging Paths
description: Hinde Taarji and Assia Belghiti consider themselves in the vanguard of change for women's rights in North Africa.

title: SAUDIS CANCEL TAX AFTER COMPLAINTS
description: Saudi Arabia rescinded a sweeping package of income taxes on foreigners today following protests from foreign workers and Saudi businessmen. The taxes had been instituted by royal decree only a few days ago.

title: 8 1/2%-9% Rates By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering today four-year and seven-year debentures totaling $1.35 billion through various securities dealers.

title: THEY CALLED HIM PISTOL
description: THE first thing you noticed were the eyes, sad eyes, moist eyes, unfulfilled eyes. Bil Keane has made a career of painting sad-eyed clowns, waifs who have seen too much, but Pete Maravich was not merely a Keane painting, he was a man trying to go straight.

title: Death of L.I. Nurse's Patient Ruled Homicide, Aide Says
description: The Suffolk County Medical Examiner has issued a ruling of homicide in the death of a patient at Good Samaritan Hospital who was treated by a nurse suspected of injecting lethal drugs into patients, a law-enforcement official said today.

title: Henrique de Souza, 43, A Brazilian Cartoonist
description: Henrique de Souza Filho, a prominent Brazilian cartoonist better known locally as Henfil, died here from pneumonia and other AIDS-related complications Monday. He was 43 years old.

title: Paris Landmark Bought by Chain
description: After more than 60 years as a Left Bank landmark, the restaurant La Coupole has been sold to a French restaurant chain for about $10 million, the buyer said today.

title: John Hancock Unit Hires Ex-Prescott, Ball Chief
description: John H. Goldsmith, who lost his job as chief executive of a Midwestern brokerage firm in a dispute with the firm's parent, has landed on his feet with a new post in the regional brokerage industry.

title: DOLLAR RISES AGAIN AS CENTRAL BANKS CONTINUE SUPPORT
description: The dollar's value rose dramatically in heavy trading yesterday, bolstered by a growing belief that, for now, Washington and other governments are committed to preventing its further decline.

title: EVEN AT $7, FANS WANT THE HIT FILMS
description: In 1912, when Adolph Zukor, founder of Paramount Pictures, exhibited the first full-length feature film in the United States at the Lyceum Theater in New York, he charged $1 for admission.

title: Business Growth Is Slowing in New York
description: Business expansion in the New York metropolitan region slowed last year, with its economy showing strain even before the stock market collapse on Oct. 19, according to a Government report released yesterday.

title: Alan Sweetser, Executive, 59
description: Alan Sweetser, founder and president of Compass Inc., which helped corporate managers who lost their jobs find new ones, died of a heart attack Nov. 16 at St. Mary's Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 59 years old and lived in Minneapolis.

title: Eating Right? Not In America
description: Sugary snacks, soft drinks and french fries are still high on the list of America's favored foods, a nationwide New York Times telephone survey has found. Despite recommendations to decrease sodium, sugar and cholesterol in the diet, and despite greater consumer awareness, the diets of Americans of all age groups are not significantly more nutritious.

title: INSIDE
description: Ending a Schools Stalemate The president of the New York City Board of Education ended a stalemate over a new schools chancellor by threatening to quit, city and education officials said. Page B1. East Bloc's Shadow Society Across Eastern Europe, a shadow society has sprung up outside the control of the ruling Communist parties.

title: Topics of The Times; Unicef's Shooting War
description: The world's most benign weapons systems are the salts and shots in the arsenal of the United Nations Children's Fund. For a pittance, Unicef confounds common and deadly foes of children: diarrheal diseases, measles, tetanus, whooping cough and polio. A decade ago only 5 percent of the third world's children were vaccinated. Even fewer had access to oral rehydration therapy, the solution of salt and sugar that combats dehydration caused by diarrhea, the largest single killer.

title: Bilzerian, Investor End Their Talks
description: The Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian said he had ended negotiations with an unidentified investor who he said had previously given an oral commitment to purchase $150 million in stock to help Mr. Bilzerian complete his $1 billion bid for the Singer Company. Mr. Bilzerian has already raised $895 million for the bid, but the loans are contingent upon his obtaining the remaining $150 million, now being offered as high-yield bonds.

title: Ex-Illinois Governor in Prison
description: Daniel Walker, a former Democratic Governor of Illinois, began a seven-year sentence Monday for bank fraud and perjury at a minimum-security Federal prison.

title: Darmstadt Journal; Still Free and Proud: The G.I.'s Hometown Paper
description: With the stacks of unruly paper on his desk, the faded cardigan, the gruff talk and the nostalgia for good old-fashioned reporting, Mert Proctor is the image of the hometown editor.

title: Best Sellers From 1987's Book Crop
description: Stephen King's ''Tommyknockers,'' a nightmarish tale set in a Maine village, was the best-selling hard-cover book in the United States in 1987, according to a survey by The New York Times. Even though it went on sale only in October, there are already 1,345,000 copies in print.

title: Palestinians Admit Terror Guilt in Pakistan
description: Five Palestinians today admitted involvement in the hijacking of a New York-bound Pan Am jumbo jet in 1986. But they blamed Pakistani commandos for the deaths of 21 hostages killed by gunfire and grenades.

title: With a Gallic Touch: 3 French Chefs At Epcot
description: THERE aren't many French restaurants in the United States where a couple wearing Bermuda shorts, T-shirts and Mickey Mouse ears would be tolerated, much less welcomed. But Chefs de France is no ordinary French restaurant. In this extravaganza at the futuristic Epcot Center at Disney World in Orlando, Fla., adult protocol surrenders to childlike glee, and the mouse is indisputably king.

title: Study of Plunge Due in a Month
description: By early February, the Securities and Exchange Commission staff is expected to complete its study of the October stock market collapse, the commission's chairman, David S. Ruder, said today. S.E.C. officials had hoped to have the report ready in early January.

title: Optimistic Rangers Are Starting to Jell After a Slow Start
description: Michel Bergeron removed his glasses and smiled determinedly before he answered. John Vanbiesbrouck, as he is predisposed to do, spoke quickly and earnestly when the question was put to him. Everyone, it seemed, prefaced their remarks differently, but almost all of the Rangers arrived at the same response. Asked how they would grade the team's performance over the first half of the season, they concluded with approximate unanimity - incomplete.

title: Israel Says Arabs Duped Key British Envoy
description: Israel said today that a top British diplomat had been taken in by Arab propaganda when he criticized as ''an affront to civilized values'' conditions at a Palestinian district that he toured in Gaza.

title: Pope to Visit Austria in June and Meet Jews
description: Pope John Paul II will make a second visit to Austria in June, the Vatican radio said today. During the visit he is to meet Jews who protested against his meeting at the Vatican with President Kurt Waldheim last year.

title: GRETZKY SIDELINED
description: The sprained right knee that originally was expected to keep Wayne Gretzky out of action for a game or two will sideline him for at least three weeks. ''He's undergoing daily treatment but he's definitely not ready to skate,'' Dr. Gordon Cameron, the Edmonton Oilers' team physician, said. Cameron said Gretzky suffered a ''substantial wrench to the knee, and nature dictates that it'll take time to heal.'' If Gretzky is out for three weeks he would miss about 12 games, more than he has missed in his previous eight seasons.

title: Economic Scene; Changes in Labor By the Year 2000
description: WITH the United States losing share of the world market in manufacturing, mining and agriculture, what is the job outlook for the labor force through the end of the century?

title: REDSKINS' ENDS ARE AT FOREFRONT
description: At one end of the Washington Redskins' defensive line, there is the sometimes ebullient, sometimes troubled Dexter Manley, one of the better known players in the National Football League.

title: Investigators Seek a Motive In Diplomat's Death in Paris
description: Investigators are considering the possibility that the shooting death of a West German Embassy employee was related to a private matter and not terrorism, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Tools' Mismatch to Task Hampering Oil Cleanup
description: Despite advances in the last two decades, most of the mechanical and chemical tools for cleaning up large oil spills were designed for use in the open ocean or on and near coastlines, and not for spills in rivers.

title: Monopoly By Shuberts Is Charged
description: Three ticket agents charged yesterday that Broadway's largest theater owner has a monopoly on theater-party sales of tickets to the musical ''Phantom of the Opera,'' in violation of antitrust law.

title: Newsletter Offers Pupils Lessons for Real World
description: Do students actually use what they learn in school? Some educators say no, and one of them has started a publicaton, called Think, Inc., aimed at helping children bring what they learn in the classroom to the outside world.

title: Green Urged to Oppose School Board Plan
description: A group of opponents to the appointment of the new Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, urged Dr. Green yesterday to oppose proposals to give Mayor Koch more control of nominations to the city's Board of Education.

title: Murder Trial in Bungled Extortion Case Enters Final Stages
description: Closing arguments began here today in the murder trial of two members of a former business and social group that called itself the Billionaire Boys Club.

title: Yeutter Files Complaint
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, decided today to file a formal complaint against the European Community, charging that its subsidies for soybean and other oilseed producers unfairly damages American soybean exports to Europe, an aide said. The complaint will be filed with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The American Soybean Association, which represents soybean growers, has pressed the Administration to take this step.

title: Skaters Have No More Time to Dream
description: They sometimes talk about skating in the Olympics as if it were a hazy dream from childhood, a goal once conjured up that seems, even now, so unrealistic, unreachable and presumptuous.

title: Jersey Schools Join With Police To Fight Drugs
description: Despite a potential for conflict because of their differing missions, educators and law-enforcement officials said today that they had found a basis for working cooperatively to try to drive drugs out of New Jersey's schools.

title: Rights Group Tells of Oppression Of Children, Citing 18 Countries
description: Amnesty International issued a survey today on children who are victims of political repression around the world, citing 18 countries in which ''the most basic rights'' of children were violated.

title: Swimmer Dies After Sting
description: A swimmer has died after being stung by a Portuguese man-of-war, a bubble-like relative of the jellyfish. Emily H. Small, 67 years old, screamed and lost consciousness when she was bitten about 30 feet from shore, friends who were with her said. She was in a coma for five days before she died Friday. The Palm Beach County Medical Examiner's report cited a Portuguese man-of-war sting as the chief cause of death.

title: What Americans Really Eat: Nutrition Can Wait
description: THE dramatic nutrition revolution that was going to change the way Americans eat is not happening, judging by a recent nationwide telephone survey conducted by The New York Times.

title: Vile as Smoke
description: There was another one of those smoke fights on an airplane the other day. It's always the same: a smoker so desperate for a cigarette he's ready to start screaming in pain. Somebody willing to die rather than be subjected to cigarette smoke. Pandemonium in the sky, police meeting the plane at the gate. Much assertion of human rights vis a vis tobacco smoke.

title: The Economic Development Agency Must Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico Swap Endorsed
description: The accounting firm Price Waterhouse & Company said yesterday, as expected, that its clients would not be required to write off the value of their loans to Mexico if they participated in the recently announced exchange of Mexican loans for Mexican bonds. The firm gave its position in a ''generic accounting letter'' to clients.

title: Bridge: A Player Declined to Double And Also Avoided a Disaster
description: If you and your partner have ample values for a game contract, and you allow an opponent to play undoubled at the level of one, the result is almost always a disaster. But not invariably, as the diagramed deal from the Blue Ribbon Pairs at the recent Fall Nationals in Anaheim, Calif., demonstrates.

title: Contra Demand on Peace Talks Is Rejected
description: Guatemala has rejected a request by Nicaraguan rebels that they meet there with the chief mediator before continuing talks on a cease-fire, United States officials said today.

title: 25 Charged In Bribes Tied To Asbestos
description: The officials of 23 companies - the majority of all the concerns involved in the removal and disposal of asbestos materials in the New York metropolitan region - were arrested yesterday and charged with bribing a Federal environmental protection inspector to overlook violations of Federal rules and regulations.

title: Bear, Stearns Acquiring Asiel
description: Bear, Stearns & Company announced Monday that it was acquiring the specialist operations of Asiel & Company, a small brokerage house.

title: Harold Matson, Literary Agent for Major Authors
description: Harold Matson, a literary agent who represented Evelyn Waugh, C. S. Forester, Arthur Koestler, Malcolm Lowry and William Saroyan, died yesterday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Let Us Not Praise Any Famous Womanizers; Willkie and Wallace
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 6, 1988
description: International A2-12

title: Market Place; Drug Stocks Gain On Sterling Offer
description: DRUG stocks took off yesterday in the wake of Hoffmann-La Roche & Company's $72-a-share, or $4.2 billion, hostile takeover bid for Sterling Drug Inc., which makes Bayer aspirin and other products.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Schneider Wins Giant Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland won a women's World Cup giant slalom yesterday at Tignes, France, holding off challenges from Catherine Quittet and Carole Merle, both of France. Schneider was timed in 2 minutes 33.68 seconds for the two runs. Quittet, who led after the first heat, came in second at 2:33.83. Merle had the fastest time in the second heat and placed third in 2:34.82. Michela Figini of Switzerland, who was fourth with a total time of 2:35.12, retained the overall World Cup lead with 104 points.(AP) Tennis Flur Upsets Masur: Marc Flur, an unseeded American, pulled off the first upset of the New South Wales Open in Sydney, Australia, yesterday when he eliminated second-seeded Wally Masur, an Australian Davis Cup player. Flur, ranked 134th in the world, held the edge over 36th-ranked Masur almost from the start of their match. Masur was broken early in the first set and never recovered as Flur won, 6-4, 6-4. John Fitzgerald of Australia, seeded fifth in the $123,400 event, beat Richard Schmidt of the United States, 3-6, 7-5, 6-3. In women's play second-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia beat Rachel McQuillan of Australia, 7-5, 6-2, and third-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany eliminated Sandra Wasserman of Belgium, 6-3, 6-2.(AP) Lundgren Advances: Top-seeded Peter Lundgren of Sweden defeated Dan Cassidy of the United States, 6-3, 6-4, in the first round of the $93,400 Benson and Hedges tournament in Auckland, New Zealand, yesterday. Ramesh Krishnan of India beat Tarik Benhabiles of France, 6-0, 6-4, and eighth-seeded Dan Goldie of the United States posted a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Amos Mronz of West Germany. In other first-round matches, Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, beat Claudio Pistolesi of Italy, 6-3, 6-2, and second-seeded Amos Mansdorf of Israel eliminated Shuzo Matsuoka of Japan, 6-3, 6-4.(AP)

title: Patricia Powers, Writer, 62
description: Patricia Powers, a short-story writer and the wife of Bertram A. Powers, president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, died of a heart attack Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: George Grayson Tyler, a Lawyer And Expert on Taxes, Dies at 81
description: George Grayson Tyler, a former head of the tax department of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore and a former president of the University Club, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan and in West Redding, Conn.

title: Myerson & Kuhn Arises From Finley, Kumble
description: Myerson & Kuhn is making its debut in New York City this week, arising from what was recently the nation's fourth-largest law firm.

title: A Weather Emergency Is Declared in Capital
description: The District of Columbia Council declared an emergency today because of sub-freezing temperatures and ordered the Mayor to open government buildings to the homeless.

title: Gifts to Fund Seek to Help The Homeless
description: Chris Columbus says that it is a privilege to live in New York City and that he ''wanted to give something back to the city I love so much.''

title: MUBARAK TO TOUR GULF ARAB LANDS
description: Amid reports of a deepening Egyptian military involvement in the Persian Gulf, President Hosni Mubarak is to embark this week on a tour of gulf Arab nations, sealing Cairo's emergence from ostracism because of its peace with Israel.

title: Pete Maravich, a Hall of Famer Who Set Basketball Marks, Dies
description: Pete Maravich, the leading career and single-season scorer in major college basketball history, died yesterday in Pasadena, Calif., after suffering an apparent heart attack while playing in a pickup game. He was 40 years old.

title: New Center to Review The Rochester Schools
description: The public schools here will be the focus of a national research center on education being established with the goal of restructuring American education and making the country's work force more competitive with foreign workers.

title: U.S. Joins U.N. in Vote Against Plans by Israelis
description: The United States joined with the rest of the Security Council tonight in unanimously adopting a resolution calling on Israel to drop plans to deport nine Palestinians involved in disturbances in the occupied territories. The Council said such expulsions would violate the Palestinians' human rights.

title: Where How You Eat Matters, Not What
description: THE main course was braised beef, the wine a hearty Beaujolais and the occasion a drill in table manners.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Germans Open Terror Trial Against Lebanese
description: Abbas Ali Hamadei, a dual Lebanese-West German citizen, went on trial here today on kidnapping and other charges.

title: Wrong Even When Right
description: It is bad enough that Congress openly stuffs favors into appropriations bills - a project here for a Congressman's home district, a grant there to soothe a senator. But doing it in the dark subverts honest government. That's just what Congress has done with its secret stuffing of the new omnibus spending bill.

title: Eating Well
description: MILLIONS of adults brought up on breakfast grains that were colored, sugared, flavored and shaped like little O's or chocolate-chip cookies are continuing their lifelong cereal habit. But as they have grown older their tastes have changed. Today, they want something a little less sweet, a lot more sophisticated, with emphasis on nutrition.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHAT wine with what food? Insofar as it's possible to predict anything, it's a pretty safe bet to say that this will be the hot topic in wine books for some time to come. And why not? It would be a food book, too. Two for the price of one, you might say.

title: Officer Is Shot and Robbery Suspect Is Killed
description: A New York City police officer who interrupted a robbery at a house in Brooklyn early yesterday was shot in the stomach and seriously wounded in an exchange of gunfire that left one of the suspected thieves dead, the police said.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: House & Garden magazine to Della Femina, Udell, a division of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
COSTCO WHOLESALE reports earnings for 12wks to Nov 22
description: b-Includes a $1,160,000 gain on retirement of debentures, a tax credit of $771,000, and a pre-tax capital loss of $1,540,000 related to the sale of marketable securities. c-Net loss

title: Man Says He Killed Friend's Mother
description: In a matter-of-fact voice, a 19-year-old from Glastonbury described today how he had strangled the mother of his 16-year-old girlfriend after the girl had repeatedly begged him to commit the murder.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday, about the Presidential campaigns in Iowa misstated the margin of sampling error in a poll conducted by the Gallup Organization. It was plus or minus five percentage points, not three.

title: PARENT & CHILD
