description: THE first few times you hear your child say that he doesn't want you, but wants his other parent, it can be crushing. What have you done so wrong that he has rejected you many years before you can blame it on the churning hormones of puberty? Where are the adoring looks, the tiny arms flung around your leg as you return home? Is this the thanks you get for your years of changing soiled diapers and soothing the pains of colic and teething?

title: Bathtub for a General
description: To the Editor:

title: Gaza City-State Could Be Singapore of Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Sterling Chairman Reprimands Bank
description: The chairman of Sterling Drug Inc. wrote an angry letter to the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company because the bank, of which Sterling is a client, is acting as financial adviser for a company that is trying to take it over. ''I am shocked and dismayed by what I consider to be Morgan bank's unethical conduct in aiding and abetting a surprise raid on one of its longtime clients,'' John M. Pietruski, chairman and chief executive of Sterling, wrote to Lewis T. Preston chairman and chief executive of Morgan Guaranty. Sterling made the letter public. A spokesman for Morgan Guaranty, John M. Morris, said that although Mr. Preston intends to respond to Mr. Pietruski directly, ''I can say that we are acting properly in this transaction.'' Morgan Guaranty is acting as adviser to F. Hoffman-LaRoche & Company in its hostile $4.2 billion tender offer for Sterling. Mr. Pietruski said that, as a result, Sterling was reviewing its dealings with Morgan Guaranty.

title: Mexico City Journal; Forget the Alamo! Look at the Sins of the Yankees
description: At the entrance stands Uncle Sam, his ax raised triumphantly over a prostrate Mexico. But inside the National Museum of Intervention, the tables are turned, and it is the United States that comes under unrelenting attack.

title: Schwab to Market Lotus Service
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the nation's largest discount stock brokerage, said that it would market a Lotus Development Corporation service that provides real-time stock quotes to investors.

title: Subpoenas Said to Aim At Drexel
description: The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan has sent out a new series of subpoenas focusing on several takeover transactions involving Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., according to several people with knowledge of the Government's investigation.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; One in 100,000?
description: As James F. Smith, a Texas economist tells it, little did he know that he would lose his own job as a result of his candor when he predicted that more than 100,000 Texans could lose their jobs if the trade bill now before Congress was enacted.

title: 3 Divers Cling to Overturned Boat For 16 Hours in Frigid L.I.
description: Three divers from Connecticut spent 16 hours clinging to the keel of a small capsized boat in Long Island Sound Monday night as 8-foot-high seas washed over them and 40-mile-an-hour winds left their bodies coated with ice.

title: Can Milken Sell Bonds For Moscow?
description: Is there a market for ruble-denominated junk bonds? Is the Soviet Union ready for Michael Milken, the head of the junk-bond department at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.?

title: Robeson and Gilpin
description: To the Editor:

title: Pistons Repay Hawks, 90-87
description: Isiah Thomas scored 6 of his 18 points in the final 4 minutes 32 seconds tonight as the Detroit Pistons snapped Atlanta's six-game winning streak with a 90-87 victory over the Hawks.

title: ARCHITECTS BOOKSTORE FINDS A NEW HOME
description: THOUGH now twice as big, it remains small, because it was really, really tiny before.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Buddy Biancalana, shortstop, to a one-year contract with Richmond of the International League. DETROIT (AL) - Named Joe Klein special assignment scout. METS (NL) - Named Greg Pavlick bullpen coach and Vern Hoscheit minor-league catching instructor. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Reached agreement with Paul Molitor, designated hitter, on a two-year contract. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Agreed to terms with Phil Bradley, outfielder, on a one-year contract. YANKEES (AL) - Signed Jack Clark, first baseman, to a two-year contract. COLLEGES IDAHO STATE - Named Neal Richardson defensive line coach and Kyle Whittingham linebacker coach. ILLINOIS STATE - Named Steve Wigton assistant football coach. MICHIGAN - Declared Sean Higgins and Demetrius Calip academically ineligible for the remainder of the basketball season. PURDUE - Dropped field hockey as a varsity sport, effective immediately. FOOTBALL MIAMI (AFC) - Signed Charles Bennett, Chris Scott and Derek Wimberly, defensive ends; Marvel Burgess, safety; Steve Holloway, tight end; Scott Schankweiler and Kenneth Jordan, linebackers, and Vincent Warren and Michel James, wide receivers. HOCKEY ISLANDERS (NHL) - Sent Todd McLellan, center, to Springfield of the American Hockey League. PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Sent Chris Kontos, center, and Mark Kachowski and Scott Gruhl, left wings, to Muskegon of the International Hockey League. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Recalled Jocelyn Lemieux, left wing, from Peoria of the I.H.L. Sent Shane MacEachern, center, to Peoria. TRACK AND FIELD THE ATHLETICS CONGRESS - Suspended Lynn Valley, distance runner, from national and international competition for two years for refusing to submit to a drug test. TUESDAY BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Signed Dennis Lamp, pitcher, to a one-year contract. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Ron Roenicke, outfielder, to a minor-league contract with Nashville of the American Association and invited him to training camp as a nonroster player. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Agreed to terms with Thad Bosley, outfielder, on a one-year contract. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Signed Don Sutton, pitcher, to a one-year contract. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed Danny Cox, pitcher, to a one-year contract.

title: College Basketball; Rams Give Tar Heels a Scare
description: J. R. Reid had 23 points, and Scott Williams scored the first 5 points in overtime tonight as North Carolina defeated Fordham, 76-67.

title: Hunts Hail Silver Ruling
description: The Hunt brothers announced a major victory after a recent order by a Federal judge reduced their potential liability against a Peruvian company's contentions that the Hunts had manipulated the silver market in 1980.

title: Advertising; A Doubling of Issues For On the Avenue
description: Judith Price, who presides over the publishing success story known as Avenue magazine, has now made a major decision affecting another of her publications, On the Avenue, which is more of a slick tabloid.

title: Hunger Strike by Iran Dissidents Entangles Chirac Over Expulsions
description: The deteriorating medical condition of several Iranian dissidents on a nearly month-old hunger strike to protest France's dealings with Iran is presenting Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's Government with new political difficulties.

title: Letting The Service Come to You. . . At Home
description: IT is the stuff of fantasy. A woman is delayed at work and arrives home with only an hour to dress for a party. Her daughter needs help with her homework; so much for bath time. She jumps in and out of the shower and wraps her hair in a towel. Thirty minutes to go. Is she frantic? No. A personal shopper has made sure she has the right earrings, stockings and shoes to go with her dress. The doorbell rings. The hairdresser has arrived.

title: CVN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a pre-tax charge of $8 million relating to the restructuring of retail operations, and included an equity loss of $1.8 million from Cable Value Network, which was, at that time, a joint venture of the company. Year-ago results are restated to its new fiscal reporting period, which was changed to a fiscal year ending Aug. 31 from a Dec. 31 calendar year. The company said Cable Value Network became a wholly owned unit on Aug. 31, 1987.

title: Ex-Mayor of Syracuse Pleads Guilty in $1.2 Million Extortion
description: Lee Alexander, the longtime Mayor of Syracuse and former president of the United States Conference of Mayors, pleaded guilty today to Federal charges that he turned the Syracuse City Hall into a racketeering enterprise that extorted at least $1.2 million over 16 years from city contractors.

title: Dollar's Fall Seems About Over, Experts Say
description: The fits-and-starts decline of the dollar that began last fall appears about over, growing numbers of economists and financial market experts say. Few see the dollar keeping all of its new-found strength, but few see it going down much either, although there are caveats.

title: Nimby and the Horror Hotels
description: The word of the year in 1987 was probably Nimby, biting shorthand for Not In My Back Yard. It may be the word of 1988, too. The New York City Board of Estimate has rejected Mayor Koch's plan for transitional housing at Lexington Avenue and 106th Street. That condemns 48 homeless families to lives of continued squalor in the Mayfair Hotel.

title: Debt
description: Columbus Southern Power Co. filed a shelf offering of up to $200 million of first mortgage bonds. First Executive Corp. announced a private placement of $235 milllion in short-term notes, with proceeds to be mainly invested in its Executive Life Insurance Company. Merrill Lynch Realty signed a $330 million credit agreement with 12 international banks led by the New York branch of Algemene Bank Nederland. National Realty L.P. received a $100 million, seven-year revolving line of credit from an affiliate, Heller Financial Inc., to be secured by first and second mortgages on apartment complexes, shopping centers and office buildings. Phoenix Civic Improvement Corp. is offering $23 million of airport terminal excise tax revenue bonds, yielding 8 percent for those due in 2002, 8.10 percent in 2003 and 8.476 percent in 2009, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham. The issue is rated Aa/AA+ and for certain individuals is subject to the alternative minimum tax. Weyerhaeuser Co. is offering $150 million of 9 3/8 percent notes, rated A-1/A+ and due in 1998, at 99.25 to yield 9.412 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley. Noncallable for seven years, the issue yields about 3/4 of a percentage point more than Treasury securities of similar maturity. Ratings Sterling Drug Inc.'s triple-A senior debt rating and A-1+ commercial paper rating are under review by S.&P. for possible downgrading.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 7, 1988
description: International A3-13

title: Talking Deals; Alaska a Test Site For Bank Rescues
description: THE number of bank failures in the United States reached a record 184 last year, and it is expected that there will be about as many in 1988. As a result, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is under pressure to find creative ways of rescuing failing banks and keeping depositors whole at the least possible cost to itself.

title: LIVE ON STAGE AT BATTERY PARK CITY
description: SINCE the beginning of December, on Tuesdays and Wednesdays people going down the elevators or across the pedestrian bridge to the north buildings of the World Financial Center at Battery Park City have chanced onto Bobby Short at the piano, the Boys Choir of Harlem, the Danny Buraczeski Dance Company and others performing in the cavernous new Winter Garden.

title: Citicorp Unit to Cut 400 Jobs
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it would eliminate 400 of the 2,500 jobs at its North American investment bank within two months. The decision follows an announcement in November that about 1,000 jobs would be cut by the end of 1988 in its retail banking operations because of a centralization process.

title: David C. Sutherland, Shipping Executive, 63
description: David C. Sutherland, vice president of Home Line Cruises Inc., died of pneumonia Saturday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 63 years old and lived in West Orange, N.J.

title: Chile's Inflation Rate
description: Chile's cost of living rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in December, bringing the increase for the year to 21.5 percent, the Government reported on Tuesday.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $11.6 million associated with a restructuring program.

title: Murdoch Laughs
description: The New Year has started with a welcome bit of hilarity in our national life. Rupert Murdoch is solemnly complaining that Congress did not play by the rules in passing legislation that may crimp his style as a press tycoon.

title: CITY BALLET: 'ALLEGRO BRILLANTE'
description: REPERTORY has made a glorious comeback at the New York State Theater.

title: Advertising; Philadelphia Agency Publishes Its Prices
description: In an unusual move, a small Philadelphia agency has announced that it has published a price list of its services. Harris-Edward Communications is 12 years old, bills about $11.5 million and serves both business-to-business and consumer accounts.

title: VLSI Names A President
description: VLSI Technology Inc., a semiconductor manufacturer based in San Jose, Calif., said today that James R. Fiebiger had been named president and chief operating officer, effective Feb. 1. He succeeds Henri Jarrat, who announced his resignation last month. Experienced in the semiconductor industry, Mr. Fiebiger was most recently president and chief executive of Dallas-based Thomson Components-Mostek Corporation.

title: DOLLAR UP 3D DAY, EVEN WITHOUT AID OF CENTRAL BANKS
description: The dollar's value rose for a third straight day in hectic trading yesterday, reaching levels not seen in a month or more against the West German mark and the yen.

title: Nofziger Trial to Hear Meese
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d will be called as a prosecution witness in the conflict of interest trial of Lyn C. Nofziger that begins next week, the prosecutor disclosed today.

title: Gas Leak Delays the L.I.R.R. at Hicksville
description: Service on the main line of the Long Island Rail Road was halted for about an hour last night because of a leak in an 8-inch gas main near the railroad station in Hicksville, L.I., officials said.

title: KEEPING FINE WOOD PANELING LUSTROUS
description: LEAD: The best-maintained paneling I ever set eyes on was in a pub in the west country of England. Its appearance was superb even when the sun was shining in on it, always a demanding test. Surprisingly, in the 17th century a great deal of old English oak paneling was ''antiqued'' with some sort of finish or fumed with ammonia to give it an aged look.

title: Korean Opposition Chief Gets Party Backing
description: Kim Young Sam, the South Korean opposition leader, won an overwhelming vote of confidence from his party today after saying he would step down to take responsibility for his defeat in last month's presidential election.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am using a veneered hardwood plywood to panel a wall. My problem is covering up the nail holes after I nail the panels in place. No matter what kind of filler or putty I use, the holes are still noticeable. Can you suggest an easy solution? A. An old cabinetmaker's trick should work. Wherever you drive in a nail, first use a very sharp chisel to raise up a sliver of the veneer. Do this without splintering the wood, and without completely shaving it off. Prop the sliver up with a toothpick; then use a nail set to drive the finishing nail through the plywood or paneling under the sliver. After the nail has been countersunk, use some white glue to secure the sliver. Q. My concrete basement floor is covered with vinyl asbestos tile. Mild water pressure under the floor has puckered the tile, especially at the edges. Because I am concerned that walking on the flooring may release asbestos fibers into the air, I had planned to carpet the area. But carpet dealers tell me that the moisture will cause a mildew problem. Can I solve the asbestos problem while also containing the moisture? A. There is probably little need to worry about the asbestos unless you scrape up the tiles or sand them. You can cover them with an outdoor carpet that will withstand dampness, but this will not contain the moisture, which could lead to mildew. The overall solution is to cure the moisture problem first. Call in a waterproofing contractor, who might install a drain system with a sump pump to carry water away. Then you can lay outdoor carpeting, or any other floor covering, over the existing tiles. Q. The supply valves on all my hot-water radiators are rusted in the open position. Most of the heat goes to the upper floor, leaving the lower floor much cooler. I have considered replacing the valves, but am afraid this might jar the old pipes and cause leaks. What should be done? A. In a hot-water system, the valves on all radiators should be open all the way, or shut all the way - never partly open. You might increase heat downstairs by shutting off some upstairs radiators, but this usually doesn't work. The best solution is converting to a two-zone system, with a thermostat for each floor. An experienced mechanic should be able to repair or change the valves without damaging the pipes. Q. We recently moved into a 1939 house and had the bedrooms repainted, not realizing that the walls had been covered with wallpaper that was painted over. The paint job looks only passable, so I am thinking of repainting or putting up new wallpaper. I know I will have to remove the old wallpaper to paint. What is the best way to do this? A. Removing wallpaper that has been painted is a tough job. It might be close to impossible on dry wall, but is easier on plaster. In a 1939 house, the walls must be plaster. Start with a long-handled scraper (the kind for stripping off wallpaper). This has razor-sharp blades and a head that holds the blade almost flat on the paper for efficient scraping. Starting is the hardest part; after that you can usually shave the paper and paint from the wall in strips. After scraping off as much as you can, you might rent a steamer to get the rest of the paper off.

title: Washington Talk: Endowment for Humanities; Another Historian Is Up in Arms
description: The Reagan Administration is being accused of exercising conservative bias on historical projects through the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Tenneco Arranges Credit Agreement
description: Tenneco Inc. announced yesterday that it had arranged a $3.6 billion three-year bank credit agreement with a group of 48 American and foreign banks. Morgan Guaranty administer the loan for the bank group.

title: Korean Car Output Up
description: The South Korean automobile industry produced 957,394 vehicles in 1987, up 63.3 percent from the previous year, according to a report issued today. Nearly a third of the vehicles were exported. Yonhap, the South Korean press agency, quoted unidentified industry sources as saying that auto exports totaled 304,471 vehicles, up 78.3 percent from 1986 levels.

title: Man Accused in Death Retains Child Custody
description: A Manhattan man charged with murdering his wife was allowed to retain temporary custody of the couple's two children yesterday, after a third day of hearings failed to resolve a custody dispute.

title: For Gardeners, Snow Is Welcome News
description: January brings on the snow. But gardeners can take heart. Snow is nature's blanket, the best thing that can happen to plants, at least when it is light and fluffy. Plants snuggle underneath, bulbs and shrubs push their roots down deeply and grass is safe from harm.

title: GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said all of the per share results reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective May 13, 1987.

title: Digital, Wang Halt Bids
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that they had withdrawn from the bidding for a $4.5 billion contract to supply the Air Force with more than 20,000 minicomputers.

title: G.&W. Net Up by 24.8%
description: The Gulf and Western Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year ended Oct. 31 climbed 24.8 percent on a 43.6 percent jump in revenues.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: HAITI'S NEIGHBORS OPPOSE SANCTIONS
description: Leaders of seven Caribbean nations accused Haiti's military-led junta today of violating democratic principles, but after a day of talks they refused to impose diplomatic or economic sanctions.

title: Patrick Dolan Is Dead; Retired Ad Executive
description: Patrick Dolan, a retired international advertising executive, died Dec. 31 as a result of a stroke at St. Joseph's Hospital in Baltimore, Md. He was 76 years old and had residences in Manhattan and Much Hadham, England.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The Phoenix Suns said they would activate Armon Gilliam from the injured list and make him available to play tonight in a home game against the Dallas Mavericks. The 6-foot-9-inch, 248-pound rookie forward from Nevada-Las Vegas, who was the second choice in the college draft after David Robinson of Navy, suffered a broken bone in his left big toe in the season-opener at Portland. . . . Greg Pavlick, a coach with the Mets in 1985 and 1986, will return this year to replace Vern Hoscheit, who will instruct catchers in the Mets' minor league system. Pavlick, as he did in his previous stint with the Mets, will assist the pitching staff and oversee the bullpen. . . . Sean Higgins, a freshman forward who was the University of Michigan's fourth leading scorer, and Demetrius Calip, a reserve guard, have been declared academically ineligible for the rest of the season . . . The Islanders have assigned Todd McLellan, a rookie center, to their Springfield farm club.

title: Washington Talk: Capital Reading; A Judge's View of Society's 'Losers'
description: David L. Bazelon, who retired in 1986 after serving 35 years on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, including 16 years as Chief Judge, has written a book, ''Questioning Authority - Justice and Criminal Law,'' in which he deals with what he calls ''the losers'' of contemporary American society. Following are excerpts from the book, published by Alfred A. Knopf:

title: Human Service Workers Deserve a Living Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Crisis Easing in Pittsburgh Area
description: As diesel fuel from last week's spill flowed down the Ohio River, the water crisis here eased somewhat today and attention turned to why a storage tank burst.

title: Baby Dropped; Charge Is Murder
description: A Staten Island man has been charged with killing his infant son by twice dropping the child onto the floor while playing with him after drinking, the police reported yesterday.

title: HUNTER-MELNOR INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 1
description: The results are on a pro-forma basis.

title: The Jordan Option
description: To the Editor:

title: Nestle Unit Under Watch
description: The Peruvian Government today took over supervision of a local milk processing operation owned by the Swiss-based food company Nestle S.A., which has been accused of speculative hoarding of evaporated milk.

title: Reagan Says Diplomat's Son Would Be Safe in Zimbabwe
description: After investigating the matter, President Reagan has determined that the 9-year-old son of a Zimbabwean diplomat would be adequately protected if he were sent home, despite accusations that the boy was beaten by his father, White House officials said today.

title: On Call To Fight Oppression
description: ON a recent afternoon, Colleen Harrison, 8 years old, tottered downstairs in aqua spike heels and one of her grandmother's old cocktail dresses, and entered the United States headquarters of Amnesty International's urgent-action network.

title: A.T.&T. to Buy Stake IN Sun Microsystems
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would acquire up to 20 percent of Sun Microsystems Inc., a fast-growing manufacturer of computer work stations for engineers and scientists.

title: In Japan, Jazz Resurges As a National Passion
description: Motohiko Hino began his musical career when he was 8 years old, tap-dancing in his father's shows at United States military bases. That was when he first heard jazz and, like many Japanese, fell in love with it.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS. Economic Change and Military Conflict from 1500 to 2000. By Paul Kennedy. Illustrated with maps, tables and charts. 677 pages. Random House. $24.95.

title: Cabaret: Helen Schneider
description: HELEN SCHNEIDER'S appearances in New York cabarets, which have been widely spaced over the past dozen years, have shown her in constantly changing lights. She has been a blues singer drawing on Muddy Waters and Willie Dixon, a jazz singer leaning on Billie Holiday and Ella Fitzgerald, a singer of rock nostalgia and - after an absence of nine years during which she became a rock star in West Germany and an actress in films and theater - she returned to New York almost two years ago singing pop songs of the 20's in a one-woman revue, ''A Flapper's Folly,'' at the Ballroom.

title: Jail Term in Mummy Case
description: An amateur archaeologist has been sentenced to 60 days in jail and three years' probation for trying to sell a 1,350-year-old mummy of an Indian infant to an undercover Federal agent for $35,000. The 54-year-old archaeologist, Ralph L. Cortiana, was sentenced Monday in Maricopa County Superior Court after being convicted by a jury on felony charges of trafficking in archeological resources and possession of stolen property taken from Federal land.

title: A New Voice Of the Young Bursts Forth
description: Governor Cuomo's Decade of the Child began today with what seemed to be the Hour of Terence Zaleski. While Mr. Cuomo was delivering his State of the State Message, the 2-year-old son of an Assemblyman was crawling across his father's desk in the Assembly Chamber.

title: Concert: 4 Composers' New Works
description: ALL music lovers know how often and radically one's impression of a piece can change between a first and subsequent hearings; this is true for almost any kind of music, but most of all for difficult, dense contemporary works, which sometimes yield up little at first and much later. The most one can ask of a new piece is some enticement to probe further - to play the record again, or look out for a repeat performance.

title: U.S. Said to Set Korea Deadline
description: The United States has given South Korea three weeks to open its markets to more than 100 American agricultural products, according to a Korean news report.

title: Stocks Climb for Third Straight Day
description: LEAD: Stock prices advanced yesterday for the third straight session and the Dow Jones industrial average moved 6.30 points higher to close at 2,037.80.

title: Sports People; Champions Saluted
description: The first national indoor track and field championships were held in 1888 in an early Madison Square Garden. This year, the nationals, now known as the USA/Mobil championships, will be held Feb. 26 at the current Garden. To celebrate the 100th anniversary of the meet, seven former champions who won a combined 68 individual national titles were honored yesterday at the Garden. One of them - 95-year-old Abel Kiviat, a middle-distance runner - was a national champion 75 years ago. Also hon-ored: Glenn Cunningham, the miler; Jimmy Herbert, 600 yards and 600 meters; Joe McCluskey, a distance runner, and Ben Johnson, a sprinter. The champions honored from 25 years ago were Gary Gubner, shot-put, and Willye B. White, women's long jump.

title: Appeal Funds Sought In Howard Beach Case
description: Friends of the three white teen-agers convicted of manslaughter in the Howard Beach trial are discussing ways to raise funds for the teen-agers' appeals, their lawyers say.

title: Georgetown Sends Pitt to First Defeat
description: Charles Smith scored 13 of his 20 points in the second half tonight as Georgetown beat previously unbeaten Pittsburgh, 62-57, in a fight-marred Big East Conference basketball game.

title: Carlucci, in Gulf, Reaffirms U.S. Role
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that he was reviewing how many Navy ships were needed in the Persian Gulf region, but reaffirmed the American intention to continue escorting commercial vessels.

title: German Court Shuts Center For Surrogate Motherhood
description: A West German court today ordered the immediate closing of a Frankfurt surrogate motherhood center, declaring that it was contrary to the country's adoption laws and to basic moral principles.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. to Increase Inspections Of Travelers From Colombia
description: The State Department, retaliating for Colombia's release of a reputed cocaine smuggler. said today that all travelers from Colombia are now subject to closer inspection on arrival in the United States.

title: Nelson Has Surgery
description: Karl Nelson, the Giants' offensive tackle who missed the 1987 season while being treated for cancer, underwent surgery today to strengthen his left shoulder.

title: Metro Matters; Bleak Outlook For a Lost Block Of 59th Street
description: The continuing debate over the Columbus Circle project has centered on such weighty matters as price, process, tax abatements and the prospective marring of Central Park by architecturally produced shadows.

title: 5 Anti-Apartheid Journals Are Warned by Pretoria
description: Four months after adopting emergency powers enabling it to censor or close publications it deems subversive, the South African Government has warned that it may use the powers against five of the country's most forthright anti-apartheid journals.

title: Reporting Matters of the Heart in Nigeria
description: ''MERCHANT Bank Lawyer Orders Wife Out.''

title: SUMMAGRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After tax credits of $299,706 for the quarter and $489,884 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $105,000 for the quarter and $141,592 for the 6 months.

title: Judge Blocks Owens's Acquisition of Brockway
description: A Federal judge in Washington yesterday temporarily blocked the $750 million proposed acquisition of Brockway Inc. by Owens-Illinois Inc., as the Federal Trade Commission had requested.

title: Newark Moves to Test for AIDS Virus
description: Prostitutes and their customers who are arrested and convicted in Newark would have to submit to tests for the AIDS antibody, under an ordinance passed today by the City Council.

title: Bruce J. Bergman, Librarian, 55
description: Bruce J. Bergman, a former library director at Pace University, died last Sunday at the Yale-New Haven Medical Center. He was 55 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Accord on New Ferry Service
description: New York City officials announced yesterday an agreement with a company to replace canceled commuter ferry service between Brooklyn and Manhattan. The company, Manhattan Express, will offer three runs between Fulton Landing and Wall Street each rush hour, starting Monday, and will expand service later this month to include the 69th Street pier in Bay Ridge. Direct Line provided a Fulton Street ferry service but is suspending it because of dwindling winter ridership.

title: SUDBURY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Sabres Overtake Montreal
description: The Buffalo Sabres scored two goals in the final 58 seconds tonight to stun the Montreal Canadiens, 6-5.

title: Fourth-Best Year for Vehicle Sales
description: Sales of new cars and trucks in the United States totaled about 15.1 million units in 1987, well below 1986's record of 16.3 million but enough to rank as the fourth-best year ever.

title: The Making of a 'Literary' Film
description: A few years ago, James L. Brooks, the writer and director of ''Broadcast News'' - a critical favorite that opened last month and is now making a surprisingly strong showing at the box office - attended a screenwriting seminar in San Francisco. In a discussion with several other screenwriters and members of the audience, Mr. Brooks found himself alone when he began to defend the importance of dialogue of literary quality in films.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 29
description: b-After a tax credit of $2,089,000. c-Net income

title: ORACLE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WOR to Start Program Changes Next Week
description: WOR-AM, caught between its long tradition as the leading talk-radio station in the New York market and the desire to attract a younger audience, next week begins a new program schedule that has already prompted loud cries of protest from some in the station's audience.

title: B.P.'s American Subsidiary Offers $250 Million of Notes
description: BP America Inc., a unit of the British Petroleum Company, offered $250 million of 9 1/2 percent notes yesterday. Due in 1998, they were priced at 99.30 to yield 9.61 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Rangers Extend Unbeaten Streak to 7
description: The Rangers, initially taken aback by the fiesty, forechecking Vancouver Canucks, scored three rapid goals in the second period and held on for a 4-2 decision before 16,814 fans at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Texas City Picked by Chip Group
description: A consortium of 14 companies at the forefront of the nation's computer chip industry said today that it would locate an ambitious, cooperative research effort here in the capital of Texas.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 20
CUOMO ISSUES CALL TO HELP CHILDREN
description: Calling for a Decade of the Child, Governor Cuomo opened the 1988 session of the New York State Legislature today with a plan for increased health and education programs for children.

title: Advertising; Wide Range Of Efforts by Geer, DuBois
description: DIVERSITY of interests is a quality that generally sets advertising people's workday apart from that of run-of-the-mill business types.

title: BREZHNEV'S NAME DROPPED FROM CITY
description: The Soviet authorities dropped the name of Leonid I. Brezhnev from a city, town squares and a Moscow neighborhood today, reflecting their low regard for the late leader, who is now blamed for bureaucracy and stagnation.

title: New York's School Chief: The View in Minneapolis
description: In his eight years as schools superintendent, Dr. Richard R. Green gained a national reputation as an innovator by dismembering his district, planning in the minutest detail for its future and then putting it back together in an entirely new configuration.

title: Harold M. Lane, Executive, 96
description: Harold M. Lane, former chairman of the Lerner Stores Corporation, died of a stroke Friday at his country home in Byram, Conn. He was 96 years and lived in Manhattan.

Why Cardinal Bars Condom Instruction
description: To the Editor:

title: College Hockey Notebook; Holidays Highlighted by Longest Game
description: Holiday highlights in college hockey included the longest game in the sport's intercollegiate history, a sold-out tournament in Detroit that attracted almost 40,000 spectators, one on Long Island that was a well-kept secret, and Maine's winning a tournament in Alaska but then losing the final of its own event in Orono.

title: Human Gene in Mice Producing Blood Substance
description: Scientists have transplanted a human gene into mice so that the animals produced a key human blood substance, an advance that may hasten the day when gene transplantation can be used to cure serious human blood diseases.

title: Learning a New Career: Paperhanging
description: DALE C. EPPEL has worked in accounting for 14 years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We would like the year 1988 to be the last year of the presence of Soviet troops in your country.'' - Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, interviewed by an Afghan press agency. [ A1:6. ]

title: Valley Federal In Merger Talks
description: Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association, a 47-office thrift institution with assets of $3.1 billion, said it was holding merger talks with an unspecified California-based thrift unit. Gerald Haims, an analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles, said that Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of San Diego is the probable suitor. He estimated a sale price of $22 a share, or $125 million.

title: Nets Collapse in Second Half
description: The Nets held the Denver Nuggets, the league's highest-scoring team, below 100 points tonight. They made all 22 of their foul shots in the first half. They even led by as many as 19 points. But somehow the Nets lost again, 98-93.

title: New X-Ray Machines Minimize Radiation
description: To the Editor:

title: THAI-LAOS CLASHES ON BORDER GROW
description: A border dispute between Laos and Thailand is growing into a wider diplomatic controversy while both Vietnam and the Soviet Union are trying to improve relations with non-Communist Southeast Asian nations.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The latest quarter and 9-month results include the combined operations of Univar and McKesson Chemical Co., which was purchased by Univar on Nov. 1, 1986; comparable year-ago periods reflect only one month of McKesson Chemical's operations. The company said the latest third quarter was adversely affected by increased charges to build LIFO reserves, by costs associated with the absorption of the McKesson computer system and by the consolidation of various functions.

title: For Newest Candy Striper, Hospital Stocks Up on Batteries
description: In about six months a three-foot-tall prototype robot named Roscoe is scheduled to begin taking over some of the drudge work from nurses at Danbury Hospital, hauling meal trays and handling similar chores.

title: Taking Out The Trash In Style
description: WHILE most people may think taking out the trash has to be a dirty job, the founder of Good Taste Waste says that's rubbish.

title: E-Z-EM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about hazards of radon gas in houses gave an incorrect telephone number for New York State residents desiring information about radon. They can call the state health department at (800) 458-1158 or the state energy office at (800) 342-3722.

title: INSIDER CHIC: 'WALL STREET' INTERIORS
description: THE offices and houses in the film ''Wall Street'' are conspicuously hung with the best contemporary art money can buy. With the sets of Stephen Hendrickson, the production designer, the movie makes a point of illustrating how the stock market fuels the New York art market. A Rosenquist and a block of airline stock are each treated as commodities.

title: '89 REAGAN BUDGET SEEKS $1.1 TRILLION
description: President Reagan's budget director said today that Mr. Reagan had tentatively approved a $1.1 trillion budget request for the next fiscal year, including a substantial increase in spending for space programs.

title: Sports People; Toney's Problems
description: The Philadelphia 76ers announced yesterday that the suspension of Andrew Toney would be lifted Saturday and that the would not be paid for three games he missed during the five-day penalty. Bob Wright, Toney's agent, responded by threatening to file suit for the lost pay and said he would seek damages for what he called ''embarrassment and all the things that go with a wrongful suspension.'' Toney, troubled by chronic foot problems for two years, has played in only nine games this season. He made his first start last Friday in Portland, Ore., scoring 13 points in 29 minutes before reinjuring a foot. He then returned to Philadelphia rather than accompanying the team to Seattle. The suspension was imposed by the 76ers on Monday. Toney, who earns $710,000 a season, would lose $8,658 a game. He said that after the game in Portland he called Dr. Ray Moyer, the team orthopedist in Philadelphia, who told him either not to play in Seattle the next night or to come back to Philadelphia.

title: Chico Journal; If It's Exile, at Least It's Not Siberia
description: ''Welcome to Chico-slovakia,'' the man with the full gray, Old Testament beard says to a visitor arriving in this Northern California town, famed as the almond capital of the world.

title: Boitano Leads in U.S. Skating
description: It all looks so silly, skaters making large circles on the ice with one foot, then retracing them with the other. These are the actual figures in figure skating, even though the general public is more familiar with the graceful dancing and tricky jumps of the short program and freestyle elements in a competition.

title: James Walker, 80, Former Steel Executive
description: James H. Walker, a former vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, died of cancer Dec. 31 in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Hawley, Pa.

title: S.E.C. Sets Canada Pact
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and Canadian securities regulators plan to sign a joint agreement Thursday that will expand the cooperation between the two countries in securities fraud cases, the S.E.C. announced today.

title: Kennedy and Paper Battle in Boston
description: A high-stakes feud has erupted here between The Boston Herald, a scrappy tabloid owned by Rupert Murdoch, and the state's senior United States Senator, Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Calendar: Gardens Around the World
description: Horticultural Talks

title: The Significance Of Becoming 50
description: When I was in my 30's, a 50-year-old friend told me that you don't know anything until you are 50. I reach 50, and what does he tell me? ''You really don't know anything until you are 60.''

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 1
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $223,000 and a tax credit of $525,000. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $4,737,000. The results for fiscal 1987 include Action Drug Co., which was acquired on Aug. 29, 1986.

title: On-Time Performance of Airlines Fell in November
description: The on-time performance of domestic airlines in the United States declined markedly in November, the Department of Transportation said today, and the airline industry attributed the poor showing to unexpectedly bad weather.

title: Green Is Approved Unanimously by School Board
description: In a switch from its original 4-to-3 vote, the New York City Board of Education yesterday formally and unanimously named Dr. Richard R. Green Schools Chancellor.

title: First Bond Rally of 1988 Fizzles
description: The first bond market rally of 1988 fizzled yesterday as long-term Treasury issues fell as much as 1 1/2 points, completely erasing the gains of the previous two days.

title: Worry Chic
description: Don't relax. There's always something to worry about. Herpes, crack and nuclear holocaust have not gone away but have become passe worries. A trendy era obeys fashion even in its fretting. Here are some worries that have already infected 1988.

title: Yields Are Mixed Again
description: Yields of certificates of deposit, money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts remained mixed in the week ended yesterday.

title: Advertising; A Shuffle at the Top Of McCaffrey & McCall
description: Robert H. Cherins, the 47-year-old chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi's McCaffrey & McCall, is stepping up to chairman, as the founder, David B. McCall, shifts to chairman of the executive committee. That leaves the president's title void but only for a trice, for into it leaps the former vice chairman, Gary D. Landis, also 47, who additionally takes on the unused title of chief operating officer.

title: AUTOSPA CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a $467,750, or 4 cents a share, extraordinary tax credit.

title: MOSCOW DECLARES ITS AIM IS TO LEAVE AFGHANISTAN IN '88
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said today in Afghanistan that the Soviet Union hoped to remove its troops from Afghanistan by the end of the year, and indicated that the withdrawal would not depend on creation of an acceptable transition government.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., said its board had rejected the recapitalization plan proposed in December by Blasius Industries. BankAmerica Corporation, said it had reached an agreement under which mutual funds, life insurance and annuitites would be sold in its California branches. Dee Corporation, the London-based parent of Herman's Sporting Goods, has dismissed Citicorp and its units as its investment banker and financial adviser. Prime Motor Inns Inc., Fairfield, N.J., has agreed to sell 28 Howard Johnson Motor Lodges it owns or operates to Northeast Hotel Associates for about $30 million. Emhart Corp., Farmington, Conn., a maker of shoe and glass-container-making machinery, completed its acquisition of Advanced Technology Inc. for about $140 million.

title: Koch, in Washington, Criticizes Civil Libertarians Over Homeless
description: Mayor Koch sharply attacked civil libertarians and some advocates for the homeless today, asserting that their actions were doing more harm than good.

title: A Law That's Failed
description: During Ronald Reagan's Presidency, U.S. military forces have been engaged, without a declaration of war but sometimes with heavy loss of life, in Lebanon, Grenada, Libya and the Persian Gulf. Congress has not used the so-called War Powers Resolution to prevent or terminate any of these exercises in Presidential muscle-flexing - or, in the 1970's, President Ford's use of the military in retaking the Mayaguez, or President Carter's in the Iranian hostage rescue effort.

title: Ford's Theater to Offer 'Elmer Gantry' Musical
description: Ford's Theater said today that it would start its 20th season since its reopening with a new musical based on the Sinclair Lewis novel ''Elmer Gantry.''

title: Elf Extends Bid For Tricentrol
description: France's state-controlled oil group, Elf Aquitaine, extended its hostile offer of $:134.7 million, or about $245.2 million, for the British oil exploration company Tricentrol P.L.C. until Jan. 26, after securing only three-tenths of a percent of Tricentrol's capital in the first round, the closing date of which was Tuesday.

title: Bird Leads Celtics Past Knicks, 117-108
description: Johnny Newman, in his second pro season, drew a tough assignment for the Knicks tonight: guarding Larry Bird. Kenny Walker, Gerald Wilkins, Louis Orr and Pat Cummings also tried. But Bird was not be stopped in the first half, when he scored 32 of his 41 points. As it turned out, the Celtics needed every one of them.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the 1987's results benefited from a pickup in worldwide drilling activity during the last half of the year, the continuation of internal programs to enhance productivity, non-recurring gains of $88.9 million following the settlements of certain pension liabilities. The 1986 results included non-recurring gains of $61.7 million related to settlements of certain pension liabilities as well as special charges of $25.3 million for a writedown of excess oilfield assets.

title: Sports of The Times; Clark a Big Deal, for Mets
description: IN signing Jack Clark, the Yankees might or might not have helped themselves but, most of all, the Yankees helped the Mets.

title: Good Deeds on the Ski Slopes
description: AMERICANS have been called the world's most generous people, but few charitable events enable people to combine a favorite sport with a donation to a worthy cause. Skiing for charity, a growing phenomenon over the past few years, has changed that.

title: Search Resumes for Heiress Missing for 10 Years
description: The state police say a newly cooperative convict has led them to resume the search for the body of Helen Vorhees Brach, a wealthy widow who disappeared in 1977.

title: BIG BEAR CO reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 28
Rorer Backed In Robins Bid
description: Michael H. Steinhardt, the New York investor who is the largest outside shareholder in the A. H. Robins Company, said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he favored the Rorer Group Inc. over two rivals that submitted takeover plans to Robins last week.

title: Market Place; Brighter Outlook For Natural Gas
description: COLD weather, increased demand and a subtle shift in buying habits are shaping a better outlook for natural gas companies, according to Wall Street analysts.

title: The State of Children
description: Governor Cuomo, whose eloquent advocacy of the family of New York has won national attention, now focuses on the children. In his State of the State Message yesterday, he characterized the next 10 years as the Decade of the Child and outlined an ambitious program intended particularly to help the one child in four who grows up in poverty.

title: Dell'Olio's Swimsuits: No Camouflage
description: WINTER, particularly when snow is on the ground, is the best time to appreciate swimsuits. They conjure memories of warm pools and sunny beaches, and are a sign that benign temperatures will eventually return. So there was a disposition, earlier this week in numbing weather, to applaud Louis Dell'Olio's showing of his first collection of swimsuit fashions. The styles deserved the applause.

title: REAGAN SIGNS A BILL TO RESCUE TROUBLED FARM CREDIT SYSTEM
description: President Reagan signed legislation today rescuing the indebted Farm Credit System, saying the bill should help alleviate farmers' financial troubles.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Prosecutor No Quitter
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, Lawrence E. Walsh, is in for the long haul.

title: Midseason Report; Improved Devils Not Content
description: Moderation, which he had lost along with his composure two days before, returned to Doug Carpenter's voice. Perspective, too, was slowly replacing the angry tunnel vision that had overtaken the coach of the Devils. After watching his team's sorry 6-3 surrender Monday night to the Los Angeles Kings, Carpenter had issued a painstakingly brutal review of the performance.

title: Implanted Fetal Tissue Aids Parkinson's Patients
description: Doctors here have transplanted tissue from a spontaneously aborted fetus into the brains of two patients suffering from Parkinson's disease, the leader of the group that performed the operations said today.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 12
ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ease Up on Babies
description: To The Home Section:

title: BIO-LOGIC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions of Business Day yesterday about the new law firm of Myerson & Kuhn incorrectly described the financial status of Booth, Marcus & Pierce, a law firm whose partners joined the new firm. Booth, Marcus & Pierce specialized in bankruptcy law; it was not bankrupt.

title: Jazz: Tom McKinley Group
description: TONIGHT at Carnegie Hall, the American Symphony Orchestra will perform music by William Thomas McKinley, who teaches at the New England Conservatory. On Tuesday, however, Mr. McKinley was at the piano leading the Tom McKinley Group, a quartet with Richard Stoltzman on clarinet, opening a two-night stand playing jazz at Fat Tuesday's.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $444,000 and $711,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also includes a gain of $1,198,000 from partial insurance settlement. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective in September 1987.

title: Neoax Makes An Offer for IU
description: Neoax Inc., a company that grew from the ashes of the old White Motor Corporation, has initiated a surprise tender offer of $17.50 a share, or about $480 million, for the IU International Corporation, a bid that IU is expected to fight.

title: Messiaen Hears Himself, Though Long Ago
description: When it was new in 1947, the ''Turangalila-Symphonie'' of Olivier Messiaen divided opinion immediately, and it still does. In this enormous, lush, orgiastic 10-movement symphony, which Zubin Mehta is to conduct tonight in the first of four performances with the New York Philharmonic, some heard the final excess of overloaded symphonic post-Romanticism.

title: Bilzerian's Singer Bid Aided by Pickens Loan
description: A $1 billion hostile takeover of the Singer Company seemed assured yesterday as Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor who has offered to buy it for $50 a share, announced that T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, had agreed to provide the last $150 million needed to finance the deal.

title: Alan Sweetser, Executive, 59
description: Alan Sweetser, founder and president of Compass Inc., which helped corporate managers who lost their jobs find new ones, died of a heart attack Nov. 16 at St. Mary's Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 59 years old and lived in Minneapolis.

title: No. 1 Supporter Is Key to Hart's Bid
description: Her husband calls her ''babe'' and often puts his arm around her. At a drugstore here he helped her put some batteries in the small travel alarm clock he bought her for Christmas. They are always side by side, tall and smiling, framed in the dozens of camera lenses that follow everywhere.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $38,700,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said the extraordinary gain includes a gain of $58.9 million, net of applicable taxes of $30.6 million, resulting from the sale of real estate, and a loss of $20.2 million, net of income tax benefits of $17.2 million, on certain debt refinancing transactions.

title: NONPROFIT ARTS ACTIVITY HELPS BOSTON ECONOMY
description: Nonprofit cultural activities contributed $500 million to the Boston economy in 1986, and the arts industry was the third-largest private employer in the city, according to a study.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday about a speech by Vice President Bush at the National Press Club in Washington misidentified the club president. He is Andy Mollison.

title: Cabaret: Margaret Whiting
description: WHEN Margaret Whiting appeared for the first time last year at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street), the centerpiece of her show was a medley of songs inspired by the hotel and its famous occupants over the years. On Tuesday, Miss Whiting, accompanied by her regular pianist, Tex Arnold, returned to the room for a six-week engagement with a new program that is much less historically slanted.

title: Cab Calloway, at 80, Is Still Doing the Old Hi-De-Ho
description: Cab Calloway, age 80, leaned back in his chair, smiled broadly and held out his hands as if he were a priest signaling the congregation to rise.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: Homeless Plight Protested in 3 Cities
description: Not far from a public housing complex here that has hundreds of vacant units, 50-year-old Joe Thomas wanders the streets in the sub-zero wind. ''This weather could kill a man,'' Mr. Thomas, wearing a dirty, tattered scarf, said as he rummaged through a garbage can. ''But where's a guy gonna go?''

title: Farm Credit Unit Cancels Offering
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation has canceled an offering of intermediate-term bonds that was expected later this month, it announced yesterday.

title: Ingenuity Counts If 500 Square Feet Is The Space
description: WILLIAM KOPELK and Olga Hirshhorn both live alone in triplexes that measure about 500 square feet. ''To live in a space this small,'' Mrs. Hirshhorn said, ''you have to think as you would on a boat.''

title: Intervention: Simple but Secret
description: The process by which governments intervene in the currency markets - these days in vigorous support of the dollar - is procedurally straightforward but typically veiled in secrecy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Best Foods Affiliates Group, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., a unit of CPC International Inc., appointed Raymond B. Rudy president.

title: Sports People; Molitor Signs
description: Paul Molitor, who had a 39-game hitting streak last season before becoming a free agent, signed a two-year contract with the Milwaukee Brewers yesterday. Molitor, who is 31 years old, will earn a guaranteed $1.4 million each year and could earn an additional $450,000 each year in bonuses based on the number of games played and plate appearances. The Brewers and Molitor reached agreement two days before the deadline for teams to sign their current free agents or lose the rights to negotiate with them until May 1. Molitor, who completed a five-year contract worth $5 million last season, had career highs in 1987 in batting (.353) and stolen bases (45). Despite missing 43 games because of early-season injuries, he led the American League in doubles (41) and runs scored (114). . . . The Philadelphia Phillies gave Phil Bradley a one-year contract. The Phillies acquired Bradley, an outfielder, from the Seattle Mariners in a trade last month.

title: ROMAN MONUMENTS REBUILT
description: Tourists and Romans today got a glimpse of five well-known monuments from ancient Rome, most of them restored for the first time since they were erected in the first centuries after the birth of Christ.

title: Mark J. Rozance, Transit Official
description: Mark J. Rozance, deputy director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, died of leukemia Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HEALTHPersonal Health
description: The holidays are finally over. You're exhausted, relieved and wondering whether it was worth all the time, energy and money you put into the event, which each year seems to be longer, more complicated, more stressful and less satisfying.

title: Senator Defends Plan to Aid Jews in France
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye has defended his role in persuading Congress to approve $8 million to build schools in France for Jews who emigrated from North Africa.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The ITT Financial Corporation is offering $100 million of 9 1/2 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.75 to yield 9.55 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Fixing Antique Clocks
description: WHEN he was a child in Pittsburgh, Joe Fanelli had no intention of going into the clock-repair business. But to keep him out of trouble, his father made him work after school twice a week with a local clockmaker. As he got older, he repaired friends' clocks for fun.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about regulations on mass transit for the disabled misstated the provision turned down by a Federal judge. The provision was that a mass transit agency could comply with the regulations by spending 3 percent of its budget on transportation for the disabled, but it did not prohibit an agency from spending more.

title: Bush to Answer Queries on Iran-Contra Affair
description: Vice President Bush said today that he would answer any questions put to him by the independent prosecutor investigating the Iran-contra affair.

title: TOLL BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: All the share earnings reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in February 1987 and the 2-for-1 stock split in April 1987.

title: Sanofi Head Optimistic on Robins Bid
description: The A. H. Robins Company may not fall quietly into Sanofi of France's arms, but Jean-Francois Dehecq, the chief executive of the large French drug company, was in New York this week talking confidently about the ultimate outcome of his company's campaign to outbid two American rivals for the Richmond-based pharmaceuticals maker.

title: Britain's Woman of the Century
description: Cliches flock around Margaret Thatcher as thickly as sparrows in London's East End. She is indeed forceful, divisive, gritty, a quick study, thinks fast on her feet. So are other politicians, yet none in modern Britain have equaled Mrs. Thatcher's longevity. She has served longer than any previous Prime Minister in this century - 3,167 days as of last weekend - and has a fair chance of winning a fourth straight election. She may still be Prime Minister in the year 2000, when she will be 74.

title: Henri Filion Rebuts Race-Fix Charge
description: Henri Filion, the harness driver accused by a colleague of trying to fix a November race at Yonkers Raceway, denied the charge yesterday and said he had never exchanged more than casual greetings with his accuser.

title: MATRIX SCIENCE CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The share earnings for 1986 reflect the 2-for-1 stock split declared in April 1987. The year-ago results have been restated.

title: DOLE, IN HOSPITAL VISIT, RETURNS TO PAST
description: For Bob Dole, it was a return to the past.

title: For New Food Products, Entry Fee Is High
description: With the ever-growing number of new food products, supermarkets are finding their shelf space increasingly valuable - so valuable that they are charging food companies hundreds of millions of dollars a year for the chance to have their products displayed.

title: Medical Groups Reach Compromise On Frequency of Giving Pap Tests
description: After years of conflicting advice on when women should have a Pap smear to test for cervical cancer, the American Cancer Society and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists have reached a compromise recommendation on how often women should have the test for cervical cancer.

title: Illinois Imposes a Tax on Illegal Drug Dealers
description: Illinois has imposed a tax on marijuana, cocaine and other illegal drugs but expects most of the revenue from the new law to come from stamp collectors.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax loss of $1 million from the sale of a health care facility. c-After a $2,396,000 charge from debt redemption.

title: Critic's Notebook; Can Background Music Move Up Front?
description: I HAVE been reading Parents magazine, and report the following exchange from an advice column in December's issue.

title: INSIDE
description: Daring Medical Technique

title: Advertising; Heineken to Go To Warwick
description: After April 1 Heineken Beer, as well as Amstel Light Bier and Grizzly Canadian Lager, will have their advertising done by Warwick Advertising.

title: Rebuilding Techniques Promise Broad Gains In Periodontal Fight
description: New technologies and procedures are beginning to dramatically alter the treatment of periodontal diseases, the chief cause of tooth loss in Americans over the age of 35.

title: THE STATE OF THE STATE ON DISPLAY
description: THE two architectural figures may seem safely captive within the large atrium of the Great Hall at the University of the Arts in Philadelphia, at Broad and Pine Streets, where they will stand through Jan. 14. But if you walk down the stairs to the bottom level, the 27-foot-tall structures take on a menacing aspect. The looming, four-legged figures stir thoughts of guard towers, electronic surveillance and police states.

title: ISRAELIS UNHAPPY AT U.S. VOTE IN U.N.
description: Israel expressed ''regret and disappointment'' today that the United States had voted for a United Nations Security Council resolution urging Israel not to deport Palestinians from the occupied territories.

title: Copters in Ulster Receiving Anti-Missile Gear
description: In response to warnings of stepped-up violence by the Irish Republican Army, British military helicopters in Northern Ireland are being equipped with machine guns and with infrared systems designed to protect aircraft against surface-to-air missiles, military authorities say.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: EVEN among professionals, rollers replaced brushes long ago for painting the major portions of interior walls and ceilings. But a brush is still necessary to reach areas where a roller will not fit. Knowing how to use a paintbrush skillfully makes working with one much easier and less messy, and it gives better-looking results. If you feel clumsy using a brush, here are a few tips.

title: Theater: 'The Chosen,' as a Musical
description: ELEMENTS that made the Chaim Potok novel ''The Chosen'' popular help to turn the new musical adaptation into a ponderous evening. ''The Chosen'' - the movie as well as the book - is a dense, atmospheric study of a rigorous religious and generational conflict among Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn in the 1940's. Talmudic disputation is not the likeliest source for show tunes, and the discussion of whether Israel should be founded by men or by the Messiah is not a subject that easily lends itself to musicalization. The result is a wordy, unmusical musical.

title: A LITTLE SHOP OF CRAFTS
description: FOUR months ago the American Craft Museum quietly opened a small shop on the upper level of its galleries at 40 West 53d Street. And for a very small store, it has a surprisingly high concentration of things you didn't know you needed.

title: Doctors' Faustian Deal
description: LEAD: Proposals for Federal spending cuts in medical funding, as well as their potential effects on medical economics, are adding to the anxiety of physicians who already are beleaguered by ongoing changes in their formerly well ordered profession. The key word is ''profession,'' and it may no longer apply, certainly not to private practice.

title: Boy Accidentally Kills His Brother With Gun
description: A 9-year-old boy accidentally shot to death his infant brother today with a pistol he found in the house, the police said.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
Cuomo Agenda Greeted With Cheers and Jeers
description: To lawmakers, lobbyists and state commissioners, listening to Governor Cuomo's State of the State Message is like reading the cut list for the high school basketball team.

title: Plan to Help Youngsters: Health Care and Schools
description: In declaring the next 10 years the Decade of the Child, Governor Cuomo asked lawmakers today to approve new programs ranging from improved prenatal care to broader health insurance to increased financial aid for college students from low-income families.

title: Garry Shandling Show Moving to Fox Network
description: The Fox Broadcasting Company has said that the comedy series ''It's Garry Shandling's Show'' will make its debut on the network in March.

title: Advertising; MONY Financial Unit Chooses Korey, Kay
description: MONY Financial Services, which began an agency search last summer, ended it yesterday with the announcement that it had selected Korey, Kay & Partners. The former agency was Lowe Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Ohio Pays Off Bank Bonds
description: Gov. Richard F. Celeste said the state had completed the early payoff of its obligation on bonds issued after the collapse of the Home State Savings Bank.

title: U.S. Charges 9 In Mexico Death Of a Drug Agent
description: Nine men, including three former Mexican police officials, were indicted today in connection with the torture and murder of a Drug Enforcement Administration agent in Mexico in 1985, the Justice Department announced.

title: Excerpts From Cuomo Address: Preparing for the 21st Century
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's State of the State Address to the Legislature yesterday, as transcribed by The New York Times through the facilities of Channel 13.

title: Masada Mentality
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: Alain Zutter and Charles Rutman named senior vice presidents, group media director, at Backer Spielvogel Bates. Joseph L. Pedone has been named senior vice president at Saatchi & Saachi DFS Compton. Sheffield Halsy has joined North Castle Partners, Greenwich, Conn., as a senior vice president and management supervisor and Robert Pallotta has been promoted to senior vice president there. Alan Wurtzel has been promoted to the newly created position of senior vice president, marketing and research services, at ABC-TV Network Group.

title: Bethlehem Steel's Debt Rating Lifted
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's senior debt rating was raised to B from CCC+, Standard & Poor's announced yesterday. The steelmaker's subordinated debt was raised to CCC+ from CCC-.

title: Despite Bitter Cold, Many of Homeless Shun Shelters
description: As temperatures plunged to 8 degrees yesterday morning, New York City officials proclaimed that there was shelter for all. But hundreds of homeless people preferred to brave the bitter weather on their own, saying they were safer, and in some cases more welcome, on the streets and in subway and bus stations.

title: Clever Approach Is Browns' Style
description: The gray-haired gentleman in the middle of the Cleveland Browns' huddle at practice the other day was not an aging quarterback. It was Art Modell, the owner.

title: CBS News Employees Give to Neediest
description: A group of CBS News employees has joined forces and sent a donation of more than $1,200 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The contribution came from more than 200 employees, including maintenance workers, security guards and mailroom employees, as well as newsroom personnel.

title: '87 Spending Law Contained Benefit for Sugar Producers
description: Buried in the 1,000-page catch-all spending bill signed into law late last year is a $100 million favor from Congress to sugar producers in the Caribbean and the Philippines and sugar refiners in the United States.

title: Air Controllers Blamed For a Midair Collision
description: Errors by air traffic controllers were to blame for the collision of a skywriting plane and another small aircraft near Orlando, Fla., last May in which all four people aboard the planes were killed, Federal investigators said Tuesday.

title: Renault Executive Quits
description: Jose Dedeurwaerder, a top Renault executive who once headed the American Motors Corporation, has resigned after 30 years with the French auto maker, officials said. Renault refused to comment about his departure, but industry sources said this week that Mr. Dedeurwaerder had differences over the direction of the company.

title: Washington Talk; Look, No U.S. Funds!
description: Demonstrating what historians can do - without Federal financing - on a subject as profound as the country's basic law, the American Historical Association devoted much of its annual convention to aspects of the Constitution.

title: Ahold Purchase
description: Ahold N.V., a leading Dutch food retailer, said it had bought an 80 percent stake in First National Supermarkets, a chain of 122 supermarkets across the United States, for an undisclosed amount of cash. The Dutch company, which also owns the BI-LO and Giant Food Store chains in the United States, said the present management would continue to direct First National, which is based in Cleveland. Ahold said that an agreement had been reached with the shareholders of FNS Holding Inc., holding company for the chain.

title: New Chief Is Chosen At Burson-Marsteller
description: Burson-Marsteller, whose revenues make it the largest public relations firm in the world, announced a top management change yesterday. James H. Dowling became the second chief executive in the company's 35-year history, succeeding Harold Burson, a co-founder.

title: SIMON OUTLINING PLANS ON REVENUE
description: Marching ever more proudly as his party's traditional Democrat, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois has begun the final stretch of his Iowa campaign by promising to tax the affluent, if new taxes are necessary, while reaffirming his commitment to more Federal aid for education, the elderly and the unemployed.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Nominee to Federal Bench in Colorado Withdraws
description: The United States Attorney in Colorado has asked President Reagan to withdraw his nomination to the Federal bench after a dispute over the accuracy of the prosecutor's disclosure statements.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bridge: 1930 Article Gives a Writer A Good Claim to Seniority
description: It seems improbable that anyone now alive wrote about bridge in any newspaper in the 1920's. Seniority in this area probably belongs to George Copeland, who wrote about the game in The New York Times in 1930. He received varying answers when he asked the experts, for a Times article, whether married couples who played bridge as partners were excessively likely to have fights and, consequently, divorces.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Concern for Farmers
description: Is W. Allen Wallis, the No. 3 man at the State Department intruding on the Agriculture Department's turf? Directories around the State Department have added to Mr. Wallis's title, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, the phrase ''and Agriculture.''

title: Article 247788 -- No Title
description: The World Food Program said today that it would provide food worth $36.6 million for drought victims and refugees in seven countries, the bulk of it to Ethiopia and Mozambique. The Rome-based agency said about a million people in Ethiopia and Mozambique would receive emergency supplies worth more than $24 million.

title: HERS
description: ''SEE that squirrel?'' my friend said, pointing. To me the squirrel looked like any other, except for its tail, which was not a curve but a right angle. ''So?'' I said. ''If your farm were any closer to this park,'' my friend continued, ''that squirrel would have found you.''

title: New York Judges Feel Pressure To Forge Out-of-Court Accords
description: Acting Justice Harold Tompkins of State Supreme Court in the Bronx is a settler and proud of it. He thinks judges in civil cases should try to avoid jury trials because justice is better served by out-of-court settlements that leave ''both parties a little happy and a little unhappy.''

title: Yanks Sign Clark, Shaking Up Free-Agent Market
description: The Yankees shattered the two-year calm in baseball's free-agent market yesterday when they signed Jack Clark, the power-hitting first baseman for the St. Louis Cardinals and one of the premier sluggers in the big leagues.

title: Europe Alters Steel Quotas
description: The European Community formally approved a change in steel output quotas today. Less than 50 percent of the trade bloc's steel will be produced under the quotas, compared with almost 85 percent at the end of 1985.

title: Suit Challenges Auditing Plan
description: A group of small and mid-sized accounting firms filed suit jointly in New York State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to block the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants from counting the votes on a member referendum that would introduce sweeping changes in the accounting profession. The judge postponed a ruling until Jan. 14. The plaintiffs, which include

title: Prosecutors in Myerson Case Accused of Delaying Trial
description: A Federal judge has accused prosecutors of ''a ploy to put off the eventual trial'' of Bess Myerson on charges that she improperly tried to influence a state judge.

title: TV Review; 'Singing Detective,' BBC Series
description: THESE are not the best of times for those of us who are convinced that television has the potential to be something more than a receptacle for slick formula entertainments. But then, every so often, a production comes along to demonstrate conclusively that the medium can indeed be every bit as challenging and compelling as the very best of film and theater to be found on the contemporary scene. The latest conspicuous example is ''The Singing Detective,'' a six-part BBC series that, beginning at 11 o'clock tonight, will be shown in three installments on Channel 13's weekly ''Channel Crossings'' series. Don't miss it.

title: GROUP LIVING FOR THE ELDERLY
description: THEY were once alone: elderly people who had retired from jobs or housekeeping. Their children were busy, and sometimes far away. Perhaps they had trouble seeing, or were just frail. The old neighborhood was changing and it was hard to find an affordable apartment. They were a little fearful, anyway, of being on their own.

title: Martell Bid Raised By Grand Met
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. raised its offer for the French concern Martell & Compagnie to $508 a share, from its previous offer of $481. Grand Metropolitan, the British drinks and hotel concern, is involved in a takeover battle with the Seagram Company of Canada, which has offered $449.60 a share for Martell.

title: ICH to Raise Stake In First Executive
description: The ICH Corporation, already a leading shareholder in the First Executive Corporation, said it intended to make a cash tender offer of $12 a share, or $134.4 million, for 11.2 million more shares of the Los Angeles-based life insurer. ICH, an insurance holding concern based in Louisville, Ky., must seek regulatory approval and the consent of certain lenders before making the purchase.

title: Farm Accord With Tokyo
description: Japan and the United States have struck a deal over Japanese import quotas on 10 minor farm products but remain deadlocked in their dispute over trade in computer chips, Tokyo officials said today.

title: Sports People; McCracken Honored
description: Herb McCracken, the former coach at Allegheny and Lafayette, received the American Football Coaches Association's Amos Alonzo Stagg Award yesterday for his contributions to college football. McCracken, 88 years old, compiled a record of 75-48-7 in 3 years at Allegheny (1921-23) and 12 at Lafayette (1924-35). He is credited with inventing the huddle in 1924 and was elected to the National Football Foundation's Hall of Fame in 1973. He retired from coaching in 1935. . . Joe Restic of Harvard took over yesterday as president of the coaches association, succeeding LaVell Edwards of Brigham Young.

title: HART SEEKS RULING ON PAYING '84 DEBT
description: The Presidential campaign of Gary Hart, facing continued pressure from angry creditors, took steps today to resolve its debt problems from 1984.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 7, 1988
description: The Dollar

title: Gaetti Signs
description: Yesterday, less than 24 hours after Gary Gaetti had said that there was ''a real good chance'' he would reject a contract offer from Minnesota and seek a better deal, and slightly more than 24 hours before he would lose the chance to return to the Twins until May 1, the free-agent third baseman signed a three-year Twins contract worth $4.3 million.
