Gaetti, a Gold Glove selection at third base who was voted the most valuable player in the Twins' seven-game World Series victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, had been unhappy with Minnesota's second contract offer, $3.6 million for three years. Jim Bronner, Gaetti's agent, had spoken with representatives of the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Cardinals before reaching agreement with the Twins. Gaetti batted .257 and had 31 home runs and 109 runs batted in last season. . . . Another free agent who returned to the fold yesterday was Charlie Leibrandt, the Kansas City Royals' left-handed pitcher, who agreed to a two-year contract worth $2.5 million. Leibrandt, who was 16-11 with a 3.41 earned run average last season, had been asking for $1.3 million a year and had been talking with the Yankees, the California Angels and the Cleveland Indians. . . . Doug Sisk, the relief pitcher traded by the Mets after the season, signed a one-year contract with the Baltimore Orioles for $410,000. . . . Andre Dawson has rejected the Chicago Cubs' latest contract offer, according to General Manager Jim Frey, who did not reveal the terms.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: New Sculpture Garden

title: Bout for Duran
description: Roberto Duran, the 36-year-old former champion, will challenge the Continental Americas middleweight champion, Ricky Stackhouse, Feb. 5 as part of a pay-per-view cable-television tripleheader in Atlantic City. The other bouts, previously announced, include a title defense by Marlon Starling, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, against Fujio Ozaki, and a welterwieght fight matching Mark Breland and Juan Alonzo Villa.

title: Clark's Signing: Impact Assessed
description: Baseball and union officials yesterday debated the impact the Yankees had made on the game by signing Jack Clark, the free-agent slugger from the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Bond Prices Post a Moderate Rise
description: Treasury bond prices rose modestly yesterday, as many market participants waited for the dollar to stop gyrating and for more economic data to provide clues on interest rates.

title: BOOKS: Recalling Papa
description: THE TRUE GEN: An Intimate Portrait of Hemingway by Those Who Knew Him. By Denis Brian. 356 pages. Illustrated. Grove Press. $19.95.

title: Bridge: The Right Defensive Signals Can Thwart Declarer's Plan
description: Facing a partner who is knowledgeable and skillful is just as important in defensive signaling as it is in bidding. It is frustrating to send signals that your partner does not read, or look for signals that are not sent.

title: Moscow Speeds Plans for Afghan Pullout Even if it Risks Collapse of Kabul Regime
description: Having failed to find a safe exit from Afghanistan, the Soviet Union may now be bracing itself to settle for a quick exit - even one that leaves the possibility of continued civil warfare on this country's southern border.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Raised Eyebrows Over Dole Request
description: It is not only what you say that counts in Washington, it is where and when you say it.

title: TEXACO HOLDERS SEEK TO STOP 'POISON PILL'
description: A committee of shareholders of Texaco Inc. pressed the company's chairman yesterday to change the board's proposed bankruptcy reorganization to remove bylaws that make unfriendly takeovers difficult.

title: Courtroom Sketches
description: More than 15 courtroom sketches of those involved in recent trials will be on view through January at the library of the New York Law School, Queens College, Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard. Subjects of the sketches, done by a variety of artists, include David Berkowitz, Mary Beth Whitehead, Cheryl Pierson, Marla Hanson and Eddie Murphy. Weekend hours are today, 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.; tomorrow, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. Information: (718) 575-4240.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Old Masters

title: 90 Jobs Cut By C.B.O.E.
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it would cut 90 jobs, or nearly 10 percent of its work force, in response to the steep decline in trading volume since the October market collapse.

title: Syria Is Seeking to Mediate in Iran-Arab Tension
description: Syria has begun a diplomatic offensive, proposing to be host for a meeting of the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf and Iran, with which they are at odds.

title: Let's Stop Deporting Haitians Who Flee
description: To the Editor:

title: Jamaican Says Election In Haiti Is 'on Course'
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga of Jamaica said today that the pledge by the army-dominated Government of Haiti to hand over power after a presidential election scheduled for Jan. 17 ''seems to be on course.''

title: Wedtech Prosecutor Said to Scan Some Meese Stock Dealing
description: The Justice Department has sent additional information about investments by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to the independent prosecutor investigating Mr. Meese in connection with the financially troubled Wedtech Corporation.

title: Emancipation Proclamation on Display
description: The original manuscript of the Emancipation Proclamation, in the handwriting of President Abraham Lincoln, will go on exhibit tomorrow and Sunday at the State Museum in the Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller Empire State Plaza in Albany.

title: Views of U.S Public Sought Over Relations With Moscow WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -
description: Americans in four cities will have a chance to voice their concerns on the future of American-Soviet relations this month as part of a project designed to let Presidential candidates know how Americans feel about the Russians.

title: Moynihan Says He'll Offer Law To Help Murdoch Keep The Post
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that he would propose legislation that might allow Rupert Murdoch to continue to own both The New York Post and a New York City television station, at least temporarily.

title: Not Computer's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Contra Looks Back, Finding Much to Regret
description: The seaside condominium where Arturo Cruz now lives in exile is set in a gentle landscape of marinas and country clubs quite unlike his native Nicaragua. But the comfort that surrounds him has done nothing to ease his regrets.

title: William C. Brennan, Advertising Executive, 75
description: William C. Brennan, a former advertising executive, died of cancer of the colon and liver Tuesday at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 75 years old and lived in Great Barrington.

title: McFarlane Lawyers Dispute Iran Allegations
description: Lawyers for Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, have sharply disputed allegations of wrongdoing leveled against their client in the Congressional Iran-contra report.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Saints and Presidents
description: The renewed Presidential campaign of Gary Hart has received thousands of small contributions from adiring supporters. Some checks were accompanied by notes to Mr. Hart's wife, Lee, praising her for standing by her husband after disclosures about the weekend he spent with a Miami model.

title: Washington Talk: Army and Navy Club; Quiet Place for Cards And Shaping History
description: War strategies were plotted and top secrets discussed in its rooms; journalists gathered scoops here and Presidents lost at bridge.

title: General Is Named to Head Arms Control Agency
description: President Reagan has chosen Maj. Gen. William F. Burns as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the White House announced today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Musical Chairs
description: After three months on the job, Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. is preparing to make some major changes in the hierarchy of his department.

title: Washington Talk: Labor Union Consultants; Big Winner in Teamsters' Return
description: The high-ceilinged corridor of the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach was crowded with labor leaders, most of whom had suddenly become publicity shy.

title: U.S. Is Suing Con Edison Over Asbestos
description: The Federal Government filed a lawsuit yesterday charging that the Consolidated Edison Company had removed asbestos from its plants without properly protecting its workers or the public. Asbestos, when dispersed in the air, can cause cancer or other diseases.

title: A Fair December for Retailers
description: A late Christmas shopping surge and strong after-Christmas buying helped lift December sales for some big retailers. Page D1.

title: Boitano Near-Perfect in Short Program
description: With a stunning performance in his short skating program, earning perfect marks of 6.0 for composition and style from eight of the nine judges, Brian Boitano tonight virtually assured himself of his fourth consecutive national title.

title: A Jumbo Pick-Six for the Price of Five at Hialeah
description: A betting frenzy surrounding the largest Pick-Six pool in Florida racing history made for a memorable closing afternoon at Hialeah Park today.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: In these days of fierce competition for legal talent, a law firm in Grand Rapids, Mich., recently came up with a proposal that would have pleased the satirist Jonathan Swift.

title: Our Towns; An Ex-Senator Finds a Welcome On the Airwaves
description: Ex-State Senator Joseph R. Pisani has been out of prison less than a year and he already has his own radio talk show. ''My name is Joe Pisani and welcome to 'Let's Talk with Joe Pisani,' '' he said yesterday as he signed on at WVOX, New Rochelle, for the first time.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: LE REGENCE, the opulent, Old World French restaurant in the Hotel Plaza Athenee, has in a sense been a victim of its own success.

title: FRANCE YIELDS ART LINKED TO MARCOS
description: Nine paintings found in France in the custody of Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi arms dealer, may actually belong to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and have been turned over to the Justice Department by the French Government, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Sihanouk 'Determined' to Gain Cambodia Accord
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk intends to negotiate a political settlement with the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia with or without the backing of his coalition partners or foreign allies, the Prince's son and spokesman said today.

title: The Law; A Tenure Dispute at CUNY
description: The law school of the City University of New York, a much-lauded experiment in devising a nontraditional curriculum and in preparing law graduates for public service careers, is embroiled in a dispute over tenure.

title: Bern Dibner Dies at 90; Historian and Engineer
description: Dr. Bern Dibner, a science historian and founder of the Burndy Corporation, manufacturer of electrical and electronic equipment, died in his sleep Tuesday night at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 90 years old.

title: Beacon Theater Organ
description: A program of show tunes, soul, jazz and gospel music is to be played on Sunday on the vintage organ at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street. James Paulin, who was the organist at Radio City Music Hall during the early 1970's, is to play the theater's 1928 Wurlitzer. The concert is sponsored by the New York Theater Organ Society. Tickets are $6 ($5 for students and the elderly.) Information: (914) 457-5393 or (718) 225-1643.

title: Bob Eddy, Ex-Editor Of Hartford Courant
description: Bob Eddy, a former editor and publisher of The Hartford Courant, died Monday at his home in Glastonbury, Conn. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S. Aide Urged Panama General To Yield Control, Diplomats Say
description: A senior Defense Department official made a secret trip to Panama last week to urge the country's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to withdraw from politics and allow an elected civilian government to take power, State Department and senior Latin American diplomats said Thursday night.

title: Demand Rising for Insurance That Covers Long-Term Care
description: Thousands of Americans have begun buying a new form of health insurance that pays for nursing homes or care in their own homes for chronic illnesses.

title: U.S. Accuses Airline in Buffalo Of Operating After Losing License
description: A Buffalo charter airline formed by a Continental Airlines pilot was charged by Federal authorities yesterday with operating illegally for seven months after its airline license had been revoked.

title: Will TV's and Stereos Cost More?
description: Consumers long accustomed to a deluge of sophisticated electronic products that have continually declined in price might be in for a rude awakening this year. For the first time in years, prices of televisions, stereos, compact disk players and video cassette recorders appear to be going up.

title: Sledding Accident Kills Boy
description: A 12-year-old boy was fatally injured Tuesday when he hit a tree while sledding at a park near his home here. The boy, Maximillian Schuberthan, of 447 Park Hill Avenue, died Wednesday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, the county medical examiner's office said. He was sledding at Pelton Field at about 5 P.M. when he apparently sped off the side of a hill and slammed into a tree, the authorities said. He was a seventh grader at the Hawthorne School in Yonkers.

title: Topics of The Times; Mixed Message for Whistle Blowers
description: The Koch administration says it's serious about protecting New York City workers who blow the whistle on waste, fraud and corruption. But consider the case of Samuel Adams, formerly a $263-a-week Health Department janitor. After a month on the job, Mr. Adams reported to the department's Inspector General that his supervisor was turning back the time clock to protect tardy co-workers. Two months later he was dismissed for ''poor job performance.'' That was nearly three years ago.

title: Toscanini Documentary and a British Soap Opera
description: ARTURO TOSCANINI. More than 30 years after his death, at the age of 89, the maestro's name remains synonymous with excellence and uncompromising dedication. The reasons are made clear in the documentary ''Toscanini: The Maestro,'' a ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13 at 9 this evening.

title:
About Real Estate;
7 Housing Projects Rise in Great Neck
description: LEAD: Development opportunities are hard to find in Great Neck, a densely populated area of Long Island noted for its expensive real estate.

title: Dance: City Ballet in 'Piano Pieces'
description: ONE of the pleasures of frequent ballet-going is the chance it gives to see dancers step into new roles. On Wednesday, the New York City Ballet offered such an opportunity in a performance at the New York State Theater that boasted four role debuts in Jerome Robbins's ''Piano Pieces.''

title: POPE LIKELY TO SEE WALDHEIM 3 TIMES
description: Pope John Paul II is likely to meet President Kurt Waldheim as many as three times during a papal visit to Austria this June in keeping with protocol, Roman Catholic officials said today.

title: Jersey Passes Bill Banning Sale of Irradiated Foods
description: A bill banning the sale and distribution of irradiated foods was passed by the Assembly today by a 62-to-3 vote and sent to Governor Kean.

title: HITTING GURU INSTRUCTS HIS DISCIPLES
description: LEAD: Walter Hriniak's hitting school was in session this week at Tufts University, north of Boston. In a setting where baseball was rubbing shoulders with such prestigious campus centers as the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Hriniak's curriculum included his own set of laws, along with an amplitude of diplomatic skills, to expound theories of hitting that are followed throughout the major leagues.

title: Surprise Teams Hope to Take Another Super Step
description: Three largely unheralded teams remain alive in the National Football League playoffs this weekend. But if the Minnesota Vikings, the Indianapolis Colts and the Houston Oilers are the underdogs, the Chicago Bears, the San Francisco 49ers, the Washington Redskins, the Denver Broncos and the Cleveland Browns are recognizable big names.

title: Poll Shows Discontent on Reagan Helps Dole Outpace Bush in Iowa
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas has capitalized on disaffection with President Reagan among Iowa Republicans to build a substantial lead there over Vice President Bush, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll has found.

title: Life Magazine to Lift Circulation Base Again
description: Life magazine, which raised its circulation rate base by 100,000, to 1.6 million, with its November issue, is now going to increase it another 100,000 with the March issue, Elizabeth P. Valk, its publisher for the last year, has announced.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 8, 1988
description: Markets

title: FMC Turkish Deal
description: The FMC Corporation's Defense Systems Group and a Turkish partner, Nurol Defense Industry, will receive a $1 billion contract from the Turkish Government to build armored combat vehicles, it was announced today. A spokesman for the FMC Defense Systems Group, which is based here and has a manufacturing plant in nearby San Jose, said the deal called for about 1,700 armored vehicles to be made over the next eight years. The final agreement is expected to be signed in a month.

title: Cooper Stake Up
description: A New York family that increased its stake to 7.6 percent of the Cooper Companies' 23 million shares outstanding said it might seek representation on the board of the eye-care concern, based in Palo Alto, Calif. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bruce, Howard and Wayne Sturman of Mount Vernon said they might present a restructuring proposal to Cooper management that ''could include the sale or disposition of one or more of the company's principal business segments and a restructuring or liquidation of the company.'' A spokesman for Cooper said the company would have no immediate comment. Cooper's shares closed today at $11.50, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange, after jumping $1.50 on Wednesday.

title: A Nonwhite Gets a Finger on the Levers of Power
description: Of all the South African political figures likely to pose serious problems for President P. W. Botha, the Rev. Allan Hendrickse has never figured very prominently.

title: ON STAGE
description: Errol and Beverly in Love

title: JULES-FRANCOIS CRAHAY, DESIGNER
description: Jules-Francois Crahay, a Belgian designer who began working as a couturier in Paris in the early 1950's, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Monte Carlo. He was 70 years old. Mr. Crahay retired in 1984 from the House of Lanvin, where he had worked for 20 years. Before that, he worked for Nina Ricci from 1952 to 1963.

title: Second Graders Jump Rope To Raise Money for Neediest
description: A group of second graders at Public School 54 on Staten Island held a Jump-a-Thon the other day to raise money for the homeless of New York City.

title: Chiat/Day Terminates Its Rockport Business
description: Chiat/Day, New York, announced yesterday that by mutual agreement with its client, the Rockport Company, the two are splitting.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Islanders have assigned the 27-year-old defenseman Ken Leiter to Springfield of the American Hockey League for conditioning. Leiter, who has played in only 18 of the team's 38 games because of chronic abdominal and groin strain, had missed seven of the team's last eight games. 26. . . . Dick MacPherson of Syracuse was honored last night in Atlanta by the 5,500 members of the American Football Coaches Association as this season's major-college coach of the year. Also honored were coach-of-the-year winners in three other divisions: Mark Duffner of Holy Cross in Division I-AA; Rick Rhoades of Troy State of Alabama in Division II, and Walt Hameline of Wagner College in Division III.

title: Juilliard School to Hold 2 Free String Concerts
description: Eight string quartets that are now taking part in the Juilliard String Quartet Seminar Week are to give two free concerts at the school's Michael C. Paul Recital Hall today at 4 and 8 P.M.

title: NATIONS' WARNINGS LIFT DOLLAR MORE
description: Central bankers, who acted dramatically to bolster the dollar's value earlier this week, backed up those deeds with strong words yesterday, and nervous currency traders responded by pushing the dollar higher for the fourth straight day.

title: L.I. Housing Problem Forces SUNY at Stony Brook to Create New Program
description: The housing problems of Long Island came home to Jeff Casey last summer when the 29-year-old assistant business professor moved his family from Boston to take a job at the State University of New York management school.

title: Gunnar Engellau, Headed Volvo
description: Gunnar Engellau, the Swedish industrialist who built the Volvo company into a major international automobile maker, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Goteborg, where he lived. He was 80 years old.

title: Woman Killed By Gunman In IRT Station
description: A woman was shot and killed, and her sister was seriously wounded, when the dead woman's ex-boyfriend approached them on a crowded platform at the Grand Central subway station in the rush hour last night and fired a shotgun before disappearing into the crowd, the police said.

title: Advertising; A Travel Weekly to Hit Newsstands
description: WITH support from one TV commercial for men, one TV commercial for women and one radio commercial that is sexually ambiguous, Fairchild Publications on Monday will be offering its new weekly consumer publication Travel Today to the East Coast reading public.

title: Will Soviet 'Psychiatry' Go Straight?
description: Under Stalin, much as in czarist times, a dissenter in the Soviet Union might have been shot in the back of the neck. Under Yuri Andropov's tenure at the K.G.B., the dissenter might instead have been confined to a psychiatric hospital and tortured with psychotropic drugs.

title: Stage: 'Searching Satyrs,' Sophocles at Nat Horne
description: SOPHOCLES' comedy ''The Searching Satyrs,'' we are notified in the program at the Nat Horne Theater, was ''performed once in 440 B.C. and lost for 2,500 years.'' That should give us a reprieve until 2060, but here it is, as if early confirmation were required that Aristophanes was Greece's great comic poet.

title: You Can'tGet to Mars Without a Space Station; The Human Touch
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Serious About Plastic Pollution
description: By halting the purchase of plastic foam cups, plates and other products by New York City agencies, Mayor Koch sets a welcome example.

title: 49ers Fined
description: The San Francisco 49ers will not appeal the National Football League's $50,000 fine for offering playoff bonuses to their players, Coach Bill Walsh said yesterday. Commissioner Pete Rozelle notified the team yesterday that, although he would not rescind the bonuses promised by the 49ers' owner, Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., he was fining the 49ers for ''violations of league rules regarding the form and timing of the bonuses and for failing to follow proper procedures in the filing of player contracts which contained these bonuses.'' After the N.F.L. Players Association strike, DeBartolo announced that he would double the playoff money for each player this season.

title: The Eyes Speak for Her
description: IN her latest film, Emmanuelle Beart goes a very long way on very short speeches.

title: Blame for All in Gaza
description: Sanctimony and hypocrisy attend the great tragedy being played out now over the Palestinians of the Gaza Strip. Any fair look at Gaza, and the West Bank, shows guilt on all sides - Israel, Arab leaders, the United States and the United Nations. They have all stood by while Palestinians have been stripped of any legitimate political voice, and few have worked to rekindle hope through renewed Arab-Israeli negotiations.

title: New Hunt Set For Fed Choice
description: The White House is casting about for a new candidate to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board because of a powerful Senator's opposition to the front-runner, Leif H. Olsen, according to officials.

title: Comedy: Dennis Miller
description: DENNIS MILLER is one of the youngest and brightest standup comedians to belong to the tradition of urbane scattershot commentary that extends from Bob Hope to Johnny Carson to Chevy Chase. Mr. Miller, who maintains an air of sarcastic deadpan geniality in his role of anchorman for the ''Weekend Update'' segments on ''Saturday Night Live,'' is more vivacious and irreverent in his club act than on television. His show at Caroline's at the Seaport (89 South Street), where he is appearing through Sunday, is a viciously funny barrage of nasty observations on American philistinism.

title: Islanders Caught In Crowded Race To Gain First Place
description: The Islanders, the unanticipated proprietors of first place in their division for the bulk of the season, aren't sure whether they ought to be pleased with themselves or worried.

title: Cold, Fat City
description: When the wind howls and the Hudson freezes and the clouds hang heavy in the sky, a funny thing happens to New York. It turns into Fat City.

title: Fledgling Plays Take First Flight, Ready or Not
description: WHEN most theater-, concert- or museumgoers come in contact with a creative work, they expect the play, composition or painting to be a finished, polished product. They may pause to reflect on the arduous and perhaps mysterious process that led from the first spark of an idea, through many creative twists and turns, to a completed work with which the artist presumably was more or less satisfied. Yet rarely does that average arts consumer get the chance to see a rough cut of a movie, read a draft of a novel or attend a not-quite-ready-for-production version of a play.

title: Lehman Joins Paine Webber
description: Paine Webber Inc. announced yesterday that John F. Lehman Jr., the former Secretary of the Navy, had joined its investment banking division as a managing director.

title: Hanover Bank Sells Investment Unit
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that it would withdraw from the institutional money management business, making it one of the few large banks to abandon that field.

title: Corrections
description: Articles about the publisher Rupert Murdoch yesterday and on Jan. 1 misstated the circulation of The Boston Herald. It had an average daily circulation of 355,000 and Sunday circulation of 265,000 in the six-month period ended Sept. 30, 1987.

title: A Path to Modernism: Mondrian at the Janis
description: FOR those deeply attracted to modern and contemporary art, the greatest story ever told remains the invention, early in this century, of abstraction. A heroic epic played out on many fronts, both esthetic and geographic, its countless chapters seem to sustain endless scrutiny. As with much of the past, these chapters are in perpetual motion, being continually revised and elaborated upon by succeeding generations of art historians, critics, curators and, in their own way, artists.

title: Mack Lobell Horse of Year
description: Mack Lobell, winner of 13 of 16 starts last year, was a landslide choice for Horse of the Year and top trotter of 1987 in balloting conducted by the United States Trotting Association and the United States Harness Writers Association.

title: Article 785588 -- No Title
description: Damages of more than $1.5 million have been awarded to New York City in a civil suit against the contractor who demolished four unoccupied residential buildings off Times Square three years ago in an illegal night raid by a wrecking crew and crane.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Harold Matson on Wednesday gave an incorrect date for his death. Mr. Matson, a literary agent, died Monday.

title: British Car Sales Record
description: New-car sales in Britain last year exceeded two million for the first time, the industry said today. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said that December sales of 91,000 vehicles, the best since 1971, raised the year's total to 2,013,693. The group's provisional figures show that British plants made just under 1.2 million cars last year, up from about a million in 1986.

title: What Banks Want . . . And Don't Want
description: LEAD: ''History shows that banking leadership and economic leadership go hand-in-hand.''

title: INSIDE
description: Trevor Howard Dies at 71

title: Foster Care Can Be Found for AIDS Infants
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The argument that this is going to encourage drug abuse is ridiculous. We're one of only 11 states restricting needles, yet we have the highest rate of drug abuse in the world anyway. And we're not giving needles to anyone who doesn't already have them.'' - Yolanda Serrano, head of a private drug-abuse agency in New York City. [ B6:5. ]

title: Koch Agrees to a Cut in Limit On Spending for Campaigns
description: The Koch administration and the City Council leadership have reached agreement on a key provision that had threatened the Mayor's proposal for public financing of election campaigns, city officials said yesterday.

title: Israel's Survival Issue
description: Survival has always been the first issue for Israel, but it has changed dimension over several periods. In the aftermath of the Holocaust, the goal was creation of the state.

title: Arizona Gets Rolling Again
description: Sean Elliott scored 23 points, and Tom Tolbert had 20 as third-ranked Arizona, which held California to 12 first-half points, cruised to an 80-51 Pacific-10 Conference victory tonight.

title: 2 Fish Dissected in Hunt For Evolutionary Clues
description: Scientists wielding million-dollar medical instruments completed a weeklong operation yesterday, the main feature of which was the carefully choreographed dissection of two dead fish.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Robertson Battles Image of TV Minister
description: Pat Robertson, seeking to broaden his support, stumped through western New Hampshire earlier this week, urging voters to judge him on the issues and not on his personal religious beliefs.

title: Chrysler's Sales Fell 8.1% in 1987
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had sold 2,012,950 cars and light trucks in the United States in 1987, down 8.1 percent from its own 1986 sales plus those of the American Motors Corporation, which it acquired last year. Its car sales were down 20.9 percent, to 1,096,385, and its truck sales were up 14.1 percent, to 916,565.

title: Brooklyn Man Seized in Attempted Robbery
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged in an attempted robbery Wednesday that left a police officer wounded and another suspect dead outside a Brooklyn house, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Flyers 6, Blues 4: Rich Tocchet and Brian Propp each scored two goals last night as Philadelphia defeated visiting St. Louis, extending its unbeaten streak against the Blues to 34 games at the Spectrum. The Flyers are 31-0-3 at the Spectrum since Jan. 6, 1972, when the Blues won, 3-2, for their last victory in Philadelphia. The line of Tocchet, Propp and Pelle Eklund accounted for five goals and seven assists.(AP) Bruins 3, Penguins 2: Gord Kluzak and Randy Burridge scored short-handed goals 23 seconds apart late in the first period and Boston extended its unbeaten streak to five games with a victory over the Penguins in Pittsburgh. The Bruins are 3-0-2 in their last five games and pulled into a tie with the idle Montreal Canadiens for the Adams Division lead with 53 points. The Penguins are 0-3-3, their longest streak without a victory of the season.(AP) N.B.A. Bulls 100, Nuggets 96: Michael Jordan, held to 15 points in the first three quarters, hit a fadeaway jumper to break a 96-96 tie with 56 seconds remaining to lead Chicago at home. Jordan, who finished with 28 points, had 4 blocked shots and 6 steals as the Bulls posted their third straight victory. Lafayette Lever led Denver with 31 points and Alex English had 26. (AP) Tennis Lundgren Holds Off Witsken: Top-seeded Peter Lundgren of Sweden outlasted Todd Witsken of the United States, 6-3, 6-7, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the Benson and Hedges Open in Auckland, New Zealand. The victory moved Lundgren into the quarterfinals tomorrow against Ramesh Krishnan of India. Witsken, a former United States Junior Davis Cup team member, twice held break points in the third set before Lundgren recovered with a vital service break. Krishnan beat the seventh-seeded Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 7-5, 6-3. Second-seeded Amos Mansdorf of Israel overcame Jeremy Bates of Britain, 4-6, 7-6, 6-1, and Dan Goldie of the United States defeated another American, Marty Davis, 5-7, 6-4, 6-1. (AP) Horse Racing Royal Discovery Edges Nasherrico: Royal Discovery stalked Nasherrico, the pace-setting favorite, into the stretch, took over and edged away to a 1 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $42,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Nasherrico finished second in the field of six. Royal Discovery, ridden by Carlos Correa, earned the winner's share of the purse, $25,200, after carrying 117 pounds over six furlongs in 1:12 1/5 on a fast track. She returned $5.60 for $2 to win.

title: Early-Music Ensemble
description: Vineyardmusik, an early music ensemble, is to present ''Gulliver's Travels'' set to music by Telemann and performed on 18th-century instruments tomorrow at 10 A.M. and noon at the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street. The performances are intended for children. Tickets are $6. Information: 683-0696.

title: What Banks Want . . .
description: LEAD: Securities industry protectionists are citing the market meltdown of 1987 as proof that banks have no business in the securities business. In fact, the case for expanded bank powers, far from being invalidated by the market collapse, has been strengthened.

title: Art: The Silver of San Gennaro, From Naples
description: WITH the Nancy Graves sculpture retrospective and the display of Rodin bronzes, the third installation on the fifth floor of the Brooklyn Museum is easy to overlook. It doesn't help that its title, ''The Treasure of San Gennaro: Baroque Silver From Naples,'' suggests luxury items, religious relics and little else.

title: Art: 'Realism Today,' At National Academy
description: ''REALISM TODAY,'' an exhibition at the National Academy of Design, pulls together drawings that can be grouped only in the loosest way under the same artistic banner. American artists whose pictures incorporate recognizable images of the world, whether or not these were generated by observations of nature, have been allowed to share the academy's walls. So one of William Bailey's handsome, cool still lifes and a mysterious seascape by April Gornik entitled ''Islands'' hang with one of Neil Welliver's banal depictions of an autumnal meadow and an insipid Edith Neff pastel of smiling figures.

title: Hit or Miss to Mullen
description: Hit or Miss Shops of Stoughton, Mass., a division of the Zayre Corporation, has assigned its advertising account to Mullen Advertising of Wenham, Mass. The budget is $4 million. Hit or Miss operates more than 450 off-price women's apparel shops.

title: French Music Series Turning to Debussy
description: The Year of French Music, a series of performances sponsored by the New York University Chamber Music Society, continues today at 8 P.M. with a concert of piano music by Debussy at the New York University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street. Gregory Haimovsky is the pianist for the concert, which is a benefit for the society.

title: Economic Scene; Policy on Dollar: A Puzzle to Solve
description: WITH the financial markets pursuing the dollar down, up and sideways, the big question remains: What is United States policy on the dollar?

title: PILLSBURY RESTAURANT CUTBACKS SET
description: The Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it planned to sell or close about 103 of its fast-food and full-service restaurants to improve sagging corporate profits.

title: On Campuses, Too, Prohibition Fails
description: To the Editor:

title: Evidence to Be Retested In Chicago Rape Case
description: A judge today approved an agreement that will allow new tests of evidence that helped convict Gary Dotson of rape and send him to prison for six years.

title: Israelis Wound 7 in Gaza; Peres to See U.N. Envoy
description: Israeli troops wounded at least seven Palestinians today as violent demonstrations broke out again in the occupied Gaza Strip, and there were reports that a 15-year-old youth died of his injuries.

title: Top S.E.C. Accountant Chosen From Ranks
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that after a nationwide search, it had selected a new chief accountant from its own ranks, naming Edmund Coulson to the important financial post.

title: DiFranza Williamson Acquired by Ketchum
description: DiFranza Williamson Inc., a 32-year-old New York sales promotion agency, has been acquired by Ketchum Communications, a Pittsburgh-based advertising and public relations company.

title: Driver Denies Charge
description: One of the seven drivers charged with trying to fix a race at Yonkers Raceway in November said yesterday that he did all he could to win the race but that his horse was outclassed.

title: Retail Sales Higher for December
description: December sales at the nation's top retailers were generally, in some cases surprisingly, improved over the figures from December 1986.

title: Study of AIDS And Insects
description: A study of the rapid spread of AIDS in a small Florida town found no evidence that the AIDS virus can be transmitted by mosquitoes, as had been feared by local officials, a research team reported today.

title: Trio to Perform
description: As part of the Washington Square Contemporary Music Series, a trio -Rolf Schulte, violinist, William Purvis, french hornist and Alan Feinberg, pianist - is to perform works by George Edwards, Robert Helps, Babbitt and Stockhausen on Sunday at 3 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street). Tickets are $8. Information: 362-8719.

title: Devils Lose Again As Slump Goes On
description: There was slightly less than seven minutes left in the third period when Aaron Broten, having been assessed a misconduct penalty, was done for the night.

title: Robins Seeks Support for Merger
description: The A. H. Robins Company, which has operated under a bankruptcy court's protection since August 1985, yesterday began an uphill battle to win support for a plan to clear its debts and reorganize itself as a subsidiary of Sanofi, a big French drug company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 8, 1988
description: International A3-11

title: TASK FORCE URGES A MAJOR OVERHAUL OF STOCK TRADING
description: A task force appointed by President Reagan to study the stock market crash will call for radical changes in the way stocks, bonds and other financial instruments are traded.

title: Cards Contact Horner
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, starting an immediate search for power after the loss of Jack Clark, have held preliminary discussions with Bob Horner. ''At this point, we're talking,'' Horner said last night from his home near Dallas. ''Obviously, there's a fit there.'' Clark signed a free-agent contract with the Yankees Wednesday, leaving the Cardinals without their only proven power hitter. Clark hit 35 of the club's 94 home runs last season. The Cardinals' general manager, Dal Maxvill, said the Cardinals would consider dipping into the free-agent pool, a practice they have avoided in the past. Horner, 30 years old, is the only home-run hitter remaining among free agents. He played last season in Japan and batted .327 with 31 homers and 73 runs batted in for Yakult. The first baseman said he wants to return to the United States. Horner made $1.8 million in 1986, his last year with the Braves. Yakult signed Horner for about $2 million, including benefits and incentives. Atlanta and the Texas Rangers have expressed interest in Horner, although neither has offered more than $1 million.

title: Trevor Howard, Actor in Over 70 Films, Dies at 71
description: Trevor Howard, the gravelly-voiced actor who made a career of playing English officers and gentlemen in his more than 70 motion pictures, died yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: Dining Out Guide: Sunday Night
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE GRECO, 1390 Second Avenue, near 71st Street (737-4300) -

title: S.E.C. Details Canada Accord
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and its Canadian counterparts today set up a framework for close cooperation in an effort to stem a broad range of cross-border violations of securities laws.

title: After Storms, Help Pours Into Town
description: In a modest frame cottage built on a concrete slab, Willie Mae Porter and Marlin Gingerich looked down at her carpet, ruined by water. ''Tear it out,'' Ms. Porter said. Mr. Gingerich bent to do so.

title: Guarneri Strings
description: The Guarneri String Quartet is to perform an all-Beethoven program tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Grace Rainey Rodgers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $16. Information: 570-3949.

title: 81% Found to Support U.S. On Backing AIDS Research
description: Three of four adult Americans now know that the AIDS virus can be transmitted through sexual contact, and 81 percent support federally financed research to find a cure for the deadly disease, a new poll shows. In 1986 this fact about transmission of the disease was known by 61 percent.

title: Odetta To Speak At Forum on Dr. King
description: The folk singer Odetta will be among the speakers tomorrow during a three-day forum for educators and community leaders on the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Talking of Eloquence
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., traveling in Europe, has conferred this week with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and President Francois Mitterand of France. He is scheduled to meet Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in London next week. His main subject: The United States-Soviet treaty banning intermediate missiles in Europe. But, next Tuesday in the House of Commons, he is also scheduled to meet Neil Kinnock, head of the British Labor Party, whose autobiographical eloquence so entranced the Delaware Democrat that he borrowed some Kinnock phrases last year for his Presidential campaign. When the similarity was discovered, Mr. Biden was persuaded to withdraw from the race.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adelphia Communications Corp., Coudersport, Pa., said it had entered into an agreement with Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. to acquire Ultracom Inc. for $78 million.

title: Selling Out Tibet
description: Traveling about India, or suddenly during conversations here in the capital, I find my mind wandering off to a street in a distant town in the Himalayas.

title: Hart's Rivals Soften Attacks on Him
description: At first they excoriated him, but now the other contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination have stifled their attacks on Gary Hart because they found they were only hurting themselves and helping his resurrected campaign.

title: You Can't Get to Mars Without a Space Station
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Flashcards and Cuomo-Watching
description: State Senator James H. Donovan, a powerful Republican from Chadwicks and chairman of the Senate Education Committee, uses flashcards.

title: For Melodies From Weill To Webb, Come To the Cabaret
description: Cabaret, an ever-fragile world perpetually on the verge of flickering out, seems to thrive at the coldest time of the year, its intimacy a buffer against the blast of winter.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A WOMAN RUN MAD. By John L'Heureux. 258 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: DOW IS UP BY 14.09, TO 2,051.89
description: As the dollar strengthened and bond prices recovered, stock prices rose yesterday for the fourth session in a row.

title: Jordan Is Wary of P.L.O.'s Influence
description: Jordan is watching the events in the Israeli-occupied West Bank to see if they might lead to a reopening of Middle East peace talks, but it is wary of a possible resurgence of the Palestine Liberation Organization's influence.

title: Former Shell Engineer To Head Sonat Division
description: Donald G. Russell, who has spent much of his career bouncing sound waves beneath the ground as a petroleum engineer for the Shell Oil Company, was named this week to head a small exploration and production company trying to rebuild.

title: Texas Burglar Who Shot a Woman to Death for Her $1 Is Executed
description: Robert Streetman, a high school dropout who murdered a woman in a $1 burglary, was put to death by injection early today. The execution was delayed three hours by confused state officials.

title: A Witness Tells Of Finding Body In Park Slaying
description: The first witness in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. described yesterday finding the body of Jennifer Levin, almost nude and sprawled with her arms and legs askew in Central Park, and seeing a tall man in khaki pants lingering under the trees in the background.

title: CANDIDATES FACING SERIES OF DEBATES
description: While political specialists continue discussing how many debates are too many debates, the second round of the prolonged 1988 Presidential debating competition will start Friday in Des Moines.

title: New York City Needs A Volunteers Exchange
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Philly Connection

title: SHULTZ URGES END OF SOVIET ARMS AID IN AFGHAN PULLOUT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that an agreement on Afghanistan should include not only a withdrawal of Soviet troops and a halt in American arms to Afghan rebels, but also an end to Soviet military aid to the Afghan Army.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: GAGE & TOLLNER, the 99-year-old Brooklyn landmark restaurant, may be sold soon, and its future as a business is uncertain, the owners say.

title: Court Permits Effort to Send Boy, 49, Back to Zimbabwe
description: A Federal appeals court issued a brief order yesterday allowing the State Department to resume efforts to return a diplomat's 9-year-old son to Zimbabwe in a dispute growing out of accusations that the boy had been beaten by his father.

title: Consumer Credit Increase Slowed to 4.4% in November
description: Americans took out about $2.22 billion more in installment credit than they paid off in November, as the growth in consumer borrowing slowed in the first full month after the October stock market plunge, the Government said today.

title: New Try to Get Pacific Railroad
description: Kansas City Southern Industries said today that it would continue to press its bid for the Southern Pacific Transportation Company despite an agreement by the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation to sell the railroad to another line. Santa Fe said last week that it would sell Southern Pacific to Rio Grande Industries for $1.8 billion, including the assumption of $800 million in Southern Pacific debt.

title: South African Reports 4 More Blacks Killed
description: The police said today that four blacks had been killed in separate incidents in Pietermaritzburg, where fighting between black political groups has killed 31 people this year.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: British 'American Way'

title: Some Satisfactions For the Palestinians
description: LEAD: In early 1971, Gaza was ''pacified'' by the Israeli Army. Several thousand Palestinians were moved from their homes, neighborhoods were eradicated, scores were arrested and killed and most of the residents were crowded into more easily surveyable districts, where living conditions remain deplorable.

title: Rent Control Is Target of Reagan Budget
description: President Reagan's draft budget for the next fiscal year calls for a new policy that would prevent cities with rent control laws from receiving Federal grants for the repair of rental housing, according to confidential budget documents.

title: People
description: * Hans Hansberg and Ann T. O'Hara have been promoted to senior vice presidents at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

title: The Law; The Rise and Fall of the Class-Action Lawsuit
description: The class-action lawsuit, which has its roots in medieval English law, achieved what many consider its finest hour in 1954 when Brown v. Topeka Board of Education desegregated the nation's schools. Then, in the 1970's, class actions became the rage of the legal profession. Now they appear to be dying. The surge of class actions, which allow a large group of ''similarly situated'' plaintiffs to combine similar claims in a single suit, related to the loosening of rules governing them in 1966. Fees in class actions were high and there seemed no end to what they might accomplish.

title: Investors Keep B.P. Shares
description: A Government offer to buy back stock in the British Petroleum Company closed this week with most investors apparently hanging on to their shares, according to official figures released today.

title: KEY RATES
New U.S. Investigation Looks at Esposito
description: Meade H. Esposito, the 81-year-old former Brooklyn Democratic leader who was convicted last September of giving an illegal gratuity to Representative Mario Biaggi, is under investigation again by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Dec. 31 with an article about Sam LeFrak's Newport development in Jersey City was published in error. The photo - showing waterfront strollers - was made at Pier 17 of the South Street Seaport in Manhattan.

title: Soviet Bonds Are Success
description: The Soviet Union's first venture into Western bond markets was a resounding success and other issues could follow, according to the West German bank that arranged the trail-blazing deal.

title: Cold Sends Oil Contracts Up Despite Late Profit Taking
description: Severe winter weather over much of the nation bolstered heating and crude oil futures yesterday. Despite a late burst of profit taking, the spot February heating oil contract closed up 0.31 cent a gallon, at 53.79 cents, after soaring to an intraday high of 54.40 cents.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Refugee Report Burned Over Data on Germany
description: All 138,000 copies of a United Nations report on refugees were ordered burned by the United Nations High Commissioner because he thought it unfairly represented West Germany's policy toward asylum-seekers.

title: Merc Exchange Is Withdrawing From a Project
description: Citing an uncertain investment climate and a soft market for office space in the financial district, the New York Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from a project that would have created the world's largest commodity exchange. The withdrawal appeared to doom the project.

title: Frankenmuth Journal; Christmas Shopping, All Year Round
description: For many Americans who are just now storing their holiday decorations, plastic angels and stocking stuffers may not be at the top of their shopping list. But on a 45-acre site in this community of 3,000 some 80 miles north of Detroit, the selling of seasonal cheer is a year-round business.

title: Reagan Picks a Moderate to Lead National Labor Relations Board
description: President Reagan today named James M. Stephens to succeed Donald L. Dotson as chairman of the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Oil Slick From Tank Collapse Reaches City in West Virginia
description: A 20-mile oil slick caused by the collapse of a huge oil tank in Pennsylvania on Saturday reached this city on the Ohio River at midnight, prompting officials to start the process of closing the city's water treatment plant.

title: Salvadoran, in Jail Talk, Tells of Assassination
description: Sitting alone in a bare prison cell, a man accused of being a guerrilla gunman spent an hour this morning quietly recounting how, he says, he helped kill a human rights official here 10 weeks ago.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY FOCUS ON A PRODUCER

title: Spacecraft Flaw Seen as Less Serious
description: An investigation of the nozzle failure on the space shuttle booster rocket has determined that a key component probably did not fall off in the test firing but immediately after, and so the problem is not considered to be as serious as first thought, industry and space agency officials said yesterday.

title: Bernard Krauss, Publisher, 58
description: Bernard Krauss, former president of Esquire Inc., an educational and music publisher, died of cancer Jan. 4 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 413 money market mutual funds increased $5.64 billion, to $263.88 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds increased $4.32 billion, to $75.31 billion. Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were down $117.0 million, to $79.27 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased $1.43 billion, to $109.31 billion.

title: The Stage: 'Man and Superman'
description: George Bernard Shaw subtitled ''Man and Superman'' ''a comedy and a philosophy.'' Shorn of its third act, ''Don Juan in Hell,'' and without the appended ''Revolutionist's Handbook,'' the play accents the comedy rather than the philosophy - a cascade, sometimes a surfeit, of wit and impertinence at the expense of marriage, morality, wealth and social position. One of the lingering pleasures of the play, as demonstrated in William Woodman's revival (opening last night at the Roundabout Theater Company), is to watch Shaw's archetypal new women merrily slip rings through the noses of the men of their choice.

title: The Big East Race Begins in Earnest
description: While the Big East season began a month ago, the bitter battles that distinguish conference play began when Georgetown and Pittsburgh squared off Wednesday night in the season's first true heavyweight bout.

title: FCB/Leber Establishes A Specialized Division
description: FCB/Leber Katz Partners has set up the Targeted Communications Group at 101 Park Avenue with Jon Adams as its president, a staff of 80, and $60 million in billings.

title: Anti-Smoking Rules Get Koch's Signature
description: Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday a bill that will greatly restrict smoking in public places in New York City.

title: Indian Group Founder Retires
description: Russell C. Means, a co-founder of the American Indian Movement, announced his retirement from the group today, proclaiming the organization ''has worked itself out of a job.''

title: Market Place; Funds Outpace S.&P. in Quarter
description: THE stock market's October tumble dealt a harsh blow to general equity mutual funds, but an odd thing happened along the way. In the final quarter, these funds managed to outperform the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the first time since the second quarter of 1983.

title: Bush Queried on Role in Iran Scandal
description: Vice President Bush said today that he knew ''a lot'' about the President Reagan's secret initiative to ship arms to Iran.

title: Suria Saint-Denis, Theater Teacher, 85
description: Suria Saint-Denis, consultant director of the drama division of the Juilliard School, died Dec. 29 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ford Talks Ended by Bank Board
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had ended its efforts to arrange a sale of the troubled Financial Corporation of America to the Ford Motor Company.

title: A 'Dido and Aeneas' Precursor
description: To most concertgoers, the early English Baroque and the music of Henry Purcell are synonymous, and it is Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' of 1689 that remains the best-known example of English opera from this period. That piece makes its way onto New York stages every so often, but the work from which it may have drawn inspiration has so far not been staged in New York City.

title: Drug Group to Offer Free Needles To Combat AIDS in New York City
description: In an attempt to force the issue of giving addicts clean needles to help prevent AIDS infection, a private drug abuse agency has decided to defy New York State law by distributing free needles and syringes in New York City.

title: Taiwan Trade Record
description: Taiwan had a record trade surplus of $19 billion in 1987, up 22 percent from 1986, the Government reported today. Exports were $53.5 billion; imports were $34.5 billion. Taiwan's surplus in trade with the United States grew 18.5 percent, to $16 billion.

title: 143 Nations Sign To Go to Seoul
description: The International Olympic Committee said today that a record 143 countries have signed for the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Dyncorp Approves $246 Million Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -

title: BIG-CHILL PERILS, HOT-HOUSE TEAMS
description: WHEN thrust into the cold, hot-house plants quickly wither.

title: Topics of The Times; Ticket Buyer's Line
description: New Yorkers, however outraged they may be by $7 movie tickets, like to think they are beyond street shock. Nothing is so unusual or outrageous, they imagine, that they haven't seen or heard it already. But a New Yorker visiting Chicago recently found something about which to be surprised.

title: Jackson Says No
description: Bo Jackson, already a professional baseball and football player, has rejected an opportunity from pro basketball. Offered a chance to sign a contract with the Orange County (Calif.) Crush of the new International Basketball Association for players 6 feet 4 inches or shorter, the former Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn said no thanks yesterday and went home to Bessemer, Ala., to pursue hunting, a sport for which he receives no pay. Jackson, having finished his first season with the Los Angeles Raiders, had explained to Crush representatives after being drafted that he didn't know how to play basketball and that from May to September, when the new league will be in operation, he would probably be playing outfield for the Kansas City Royals. The Crush offered to send Meadowlark Lemon, the former Harlem Globetrotter, to teach Jackson the fundamentals of basketball, and the team assured Richard Woods, Jackson's agent, that his client would not have to play basketball, just sign a contrac

title: Rates Drop on Mortgages
description: Interest rates on fixed- and adjustable-rate home mortgages fell for the second consecutive month, and although rates on fixed-rate mortgages declined at a faster pace, the share of adjustables continued to rise, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: Top Specialist Gives Up Role in Morgan Stock
description: In the first of what is expected to be a series of sanctions resulting from the stock market crash, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the largest specialist firm on the exchange was giving up its right to make a market in an important stock, that of J.P. Morgan & Company.

title: A. Hawley Peterson, Stockbroker, 83
description: A. Hawley Peterson, a retired New York investment counselor and stockbroker, died Monday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 83 years old.

title: Singer Advisers In Bilzerian Talks
description: The Singer Company said its advisers, Goldman, Sachs & Company and the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, had entered into talks with representatives of Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, about his $50-a-share bid for Singer.

title: Bush May Give Sworn Testimony On Iran-Contra Affair on Monday
description: Vice President Bush is expected to be placed under oath Monday during an interview with representatives of the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: French Film Noir
description: ''Le Doulous'' (''The Informer''), a 1962 French film noir written and directed by Jean-Pierre Melville, is being shown through Thursday at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. The film, based on a detective novel, features Jean-Paul Belmondo in the leading role. Screenings this weekend are at 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 P.M. today and tomorrow. Admission is $5. Information: 431-1590.

title:
PATENTS;
Testing Spacecraft Materials
description: LEAD: THE National Aeronautics and Space Administration will receive a patent next week for a testing system that is to be used on aircraft and spacecraft materials. John R. Crews Jr., a staff member at the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., will receive patent 4,718,281.

title: Correction
description: Thursday's editorial on Margaret Thatcher erred in asserting that the Prime Minister's Conservatives failed in the June 1987 election to capture any Scottish seats. Her party holds 10 of 72 seats from Scotland.

title:
WHAT NEW YORK'S NEW SCHOOL CHIEF IS UP AGAINST;
Put a Stop To Violence
description: LEAD: If there was one thing I'd like to tell the newly appointed schools chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, it would be that the extent of violence, disruption and anarchy in the city's high schools has long been deliberately underreported.

title: TANDEM PLUNGES ON SALES NEWS
description: Tandem Computer Inc.'s shares lost a quarter of their value yesterday after the company, which makes business computer systems, said revenues for the quarter just ended would not meet its expectations.

title: Kuwait-B.P. Link
description: Kuwait has told Britain that it does not plan to use its big stake in the British Petroleum Company to control the oil giant. In a short statement, the British Treasury said, ''The Kuwaiti authorities have assured us that they have no ambitions to control British Petroleum, nor any interest in any management role, and that the Kuwait Investment Office holding in the company is intended as a long-term investment.'' Since the stock market plunge in October, the Kuwait Investment Office, an arm of the Kuwait Government, has built its holding in B.P. to 18.35 percent. Oil analysts said that there had been some concern within British Petroleum and the Government about the size of the stake.

title: Making a Christmas Eve Visit to Rikers Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Warrant for Ciccarelli
description: The police have issued a warrant for the arrest of Dino Ciccarelli, the Minnesota North Star right wing, on a charge of assault from a stick-swinging incident during a game here last Wednesday, officials said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 9, 1988
description: Markets

title: Single-Premium Policies a Target
description: ONE of the fastest-growing ''investment'' products available is single-premium whole life insurance. Its appeal comes primarily from the tax advantages it retained after the Tax Reform Act of 1986 took effect last Jan. 1.

title: Commercial Rents
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Gloom on Haiti Washington now appears powerless as its efforts to lead the military Government away from dictatorship seem to be exhausted. Page 2. Bush and Iran Affair Vice President Bush, in a campaign debate, was on the defensive over the Iran-contra affair. He is expected to be interviewed under oath about the affair on Monday. Pages 3 and 9. Texas Ballot Irregularities Texas Republicans are upset over flaws in petitions to qualify Bob Dole and Alexander M. Haig Jr. for the Presidential primary. Page 8. New Rent Rules Favored Governor Cuomo will seek changes in housing rules, including doing away with the need to renew leases in rent-stabilized apartments. Page 29.

title: Jazz: John Campbell, Pianist, In Solo Appearance at Zinno
description: The confident, polished jazz piano playing of John Campbell, who winds up a brief engagement tonight at Zinno, 126 West 13th Street, with Michael Moore on bass, suggests that he is an experienced, well-established musician. Mr. Campbell is experienced: He

title: Hart Finds Strength In Woes
description: Gary Hart says he lost his confidence for a while after ''the business last May,'' as he calls the episode with a Miami model that detoured his Presidential campaign. But now he says he may be stronger personally and politically because of it.

title: Escaped Rapist Is Captured
description: An inmate who escaped last April from a Virginia state prison where he was serving a 135-year term for rape and sodomy was captured here Thursday night, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. The inmate, Rafael Rogel Acosta, was four years into his sentence when he walked out of the prison dressed as a corrections officer. He was charged with unlawful flight to escape and is to appear in Federal District Court in Bridgeport next week.

title: Bridge Open and Women's Teams To Be Picked the Same Way
description: For the first time, the American Contract Bridge League will this year use the same formula for selecting the two United States squads.

title: Chinese Accord on Toshiba
description: China agreed today to accept substitutes for some products of the Toshiba Machine Company, partly resolving an eight-month dispute over Japan's decision to bar Toshiba from exporting to Communist states.

title: New Method to Detect AIDS May Be Tool to Test Drugs
description: A new biological method that can detect tiny amounts of the AIDS virus may be a powerful tool for testing the effectiveness of experimental drugs against the disease, researchers say.

title: Interview at S.M.U.
description: Doug Single, the athletic director at Southern Methodist University, is continuing to interview candidates for the job of head football coach, and the latest one is Bill McCartney, the coach at the University of Colorado. ''I visited with the proper authorities at S.M.U. and was able to get an idea of the direction their program will take and the facilities that are available there,'' McCartney told The Dallas Times Herald. Since the resignation of Coach Bobby Collins during a recruiting scandal in 1986, the S.M.U. football program was suspended by the National Collegiate Athletic Association during 1987 and will be voluntarily kept inactive in 1988.

title: BOITANO PEAKS AT RIGHT TIME
description: Long after Suzanne Semanick and Scott Gregory had won the dance title at the United States figure skating championships late Thursday night, the afterglow of Brian Boitano's remarkable effort in the men's short program was still illuminating McNichols Sports Arena.

title: Dan J. Bradley, 47, Dies of AIDS; Ex-Head of Legal Services Agency
description: Dan J. Bradley, a former president of the Legal Services Corporation who later became a leading advocate for gay rights, died of AIDS today at Doctors Hospital in Coral Gables, Fla., He was 47 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Yonkers Said to Propose An Accord on Bias Suit
description: Yonkers officials were reported today to have offered to settle at least part of the city's seven-year-old desegregation suit by proposing to build 10 units of public housing on each of 20 sites in white neighborhoods.

title: A Bit Late, Town Approves Constitution
description: The stoic Yankees who live in the small towns nestled in the Litchfield Hills are renowned for their sense of tradition and their resistance to new ideas.

title: David Puttnam to Get 1988 Eastman Award
description: David Puttnam, the film producer whose credits include the Oscar winners ''Midnight Express,'' ''Chariots of Fire,'' ''The Killing Fields'' and ''The Mission,'' will receive the 1988 Eastman Second Century Award.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Filipino Town, Local Politics Kills
description: When a bullet hit Ceferino Lumanlan in the forehead Wednesday night, it looked as if a sudden gust of wind was blowing back his hair.

title: Hijacker Kills Himself
description: A man arrested for hijacking an Aeromexico jet with 119 people aboard hanged himself today, the federal Attorney General's office said. The man, Marcos Ganem, a 37-year-old Mexican, committed suicide in the hospital of the Monterrey federal prison, a spokeswoman said. He was arrested Tuesday in Monterrey, where the DC-9 had landed for refueling.

title: BITTERSWEET HOLIDAY JOURNEY PROMPTS GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: ''Sorry I am late,'' Sophie Gluck of Brooklyn wrote in a note, along with her gift of $15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She requested that her contribution go to a needy older person.

title: Virginia Haviland Author, 76
description: Virginia Haviland, an author and retired director of the Children's Literature Center at the Library of Congress, died of a stroke at her home in Washington on Wednesday. She was 76 years old.

title: SOARING METAL PRICES' RIPPLE EFFECT
description: While economists debate whether another bout of inflation is on the way, Louis R. Cooper, the manager and part owner of Cooper Plumbing and Heating in Ottsville, Pa., thinks it has already arrived.

title: ISRAEL JAILS ARABS WITHOUT A TRIAL
description: Israeli officials said today that dozens of Palestinians had been jailed in the last few days under a procedure allowing them to be held without trial for up to six months.

title: Commissions for Composers
description: The Library of Congress has announced the award of commissions totaling $91,500 to 10 composers to write works under auspices of the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation.

title: Tandon in Pact On Holders' Suits
description: The Tandon Corporation, a disk drive maker in Chatsworth, Calif., said it had agreed in principle to the settlement of class action suits filed last July by shareholders charging Tandon had violated Federal securities and state laws in statements and public reports made in 1983 and 1984.

title: Power Agency To Seek Ruling
description: The Bonneville Power Administration said this week that it intended to file a lawsuit in Federal District Court to determine whether it can terminate two partly constructed nuclear power plants without defaulting on the plants' $3.7 billion in bonds.

title: TEXACO PLANS TO TAKE $4.9 BILLION IN CHARGES
description: Texaco Inc. will take charges of $4.9 billion against its fourth-quarter after-tax earnings in order to finance its bankruptcy reorganization, the company said yesterday. The charges are among the largest ever taken by an American company.

title: France Criticizes East German Chief on Arms
description: On his first visit to a Western country responsible for the security of Berlin, Erich Honecker, the East German leader, met polite but firm disagreement here today on human rights and arms control.

title: Nissan Recalls 75,000 Cars
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation is recalling 75,000 four-wheel-drive vehicles for repairs to pollution-control devices and fuel lines. The fuel line problem, involving the potential for leaks, is limited to 1987 and 1988 Pulsar NX models. Nissan said in a statement that it had received no reports of engine fires.

title: Unemployment in New York Area Falls to Lowest Level Since 70's
description: Unemployment in the New York region fell last year to its lowest level since the early 1970's, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday, attributing the decline to an economy that expanded through most of the year.

title: HISTORY CONVENTION REFLECTS CHANGE FROM TRADITIONAL TO 'GENDER' STUDIES
description: These are the spiritual descendants of Gibbon and Michelet, two of the world's greatest historians, one chronicling the end of the Roman Empire and the other the history of France.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Is this the equivalent of Oct. 16? Are we going to be down 500 points on Monday? I don't think we're into that. But they did some major damage today.'' - Edward Collins, a securities executive in New York. [ 1:5. ]

title: 'The Chosen' to Close
description: ''The Chosen,'' a musical adaptation by Chaim Potok of his novel, with music by Phillip Springer and lyrics by Mitchell Bernard, will close after the evening performance on Sunday at the Second Avenue Theater. The play, directed by Mitchell Maxwell and starring George Hearn, will have run for six regular performances and 52 previews.

title: Washington Is Losing Hope For a Fair Election in Haiti
description: After successfully nurturing movements toward democracy in the Philippines and South Korea, the Reagan Administration now appears to have been overcome with a sense of powerlessness as it faces the prospect of failure in Haiti.

title: The Gentle Tasaday Are Merely a Persistent Hoax
description: To the Editor:

title: MAIL SWEEPSTAKES: CHANCES TO WIN ARE SLIM TO NONE
description: January usually brings a post-holiday lull and, without fail, post-holiday bills. Just when there seems to be no escape, the mailbox swells with sweepstakes letters. The timing is no coincidence, according to direct-mail marketers, who say they get the best response at this time of year.

title: Sun, Not Clouds, Above the U.S.-Japan Trade Summit
description: LEAD: ''Japan is now a highly educated and fairly intelligent society, much more so than America on the average. In America, there are quite a few black people, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans.''

title: PANEL'S CONCERN: POWER, NOT PANIC
description: The idea that less than 10 large financial institutions could bring the financial system to its knees through their unrelenting selling of stocks and financial instruments that set off the selling of stocks is a terrifying prospect. But that in essence is what the Presidential commission on the stock collapse concluded.

title: One for Mother
description: Diego Maradona, the Argentine soccer star who has played in Naples since 1984, said yesterday in an television interview in Milan that when his contract with Napoli (which he recently extended by four years) expires in 1993, he will return to Argentina. ''After nine years in Naples, I will return home and join Boca Juniors to fulfill my mother's dream that I and my brothers, Hugo and Lalo, would play together for at least one year,'' he said.

title: Opera: 'Macbeth,' at the Metropolitan
description: The Metropolitan Opera's revival of ''Macbeth,'' which opened Thursday evening, has already been in the news as an example of the problems an opera house faces when star singers cancel. The baritone Renato Bruson pulled out without giving a reason (the falling value of the dollar, Met insiders say); the scheduled participation of the conductor Giuseppe Sinopoli and the soprano Eva Marton then fell like dominoes in response, and the performance was headed instead by Frederick Burchinal and Elizabeth Connell on stage and Kazimierz Kord in the pit.

title: Cardinals Near Move?
description: Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri and local leaders met with the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday in a last-ditch attempt to keep him from moving the National Football League franchise out of town. William Bidwill, the team's owner, reportedly was ''leaning heavily'' toward moving his team to the Phoenix-Tempe area in Arizona. The Boston Globe, describing its sources as ''solid,'' said yesterday that Bidwill will announce the intention to move at a news conference next Thursday. The Globe said if the team wins approval from the league, it will play in Arizona State University's Sun Devil Stadium next fall, with the option of moving into a proposed domed stadium in downtown Phoenix. Bidwill has said he is dissatisfied with Busch Stadium because it is too small - with seating for 54,392 spectators - and lacks the number of luxury boxes to generate the level of revenue needed to keep the team competitive in the N.F.L.

title: U.S. May Back Private Venture For Space Base
description: A senior White House policy group has agreed in principle that the Government should back a private plan for construction of a small, inexpensive space station that would fly into orbit years ahead of NASA's multibillion-dollar space outpost, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 5.7%, LOWEST SINCE 1979
description: The economy continued to create jobs at a rapid pace last month, the Labor Department reported today. The unemployment rate fell one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.7 percent, the lowest level since mid-1979.

title: 2-Week Hiatus for 'Tamara'
description: ''Tamara,'' a play by John Krizanc at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street, will suspend performances for two weeks, beginning Jan. 18, to make room for the Winter Antique Show. The play will resume on Feb. 2.

title: For Whom the Bill Tolls
description: The onset of the $7 movie ticket seems to have aroused some anger in New York, if not much resistance at the box office. This may puzzle an out-of-towner buying tickets for a Broadway show.

title: BOAT SHOW POINTS WAY OUT OF WINTER
description: A display of more than 1,000 new boats and marine accessories has turned the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan into a winter monument to summer days.

title: Foreign Cars Gain in Japan
description: The cash-rich Japanese bought a record number of foreign cars last year, particularly luxury models from West Germany.

title: Texas A&M Head Resigning
description: Frank E. Vandiver, the president of Texas A&M University, said Thursday that he would resign his post to establish a national defense research organization at the university. Mr. Vandiver, a military historian, said he hoped to relinquish the presidency Sept. 1 but would stay until his successor was named.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Options Exchange Weighs Changes in Operation
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it was studying a wide range of changes in its operations and regulatory role in response to the October market collapse.

title: Eagle Cripples Ethiopian Jet
description: An eagle crashed into the cockpit of an Ethiopian Airlines jetliner Tuesday, breaking the co-pilot's leg and forcing the plane to make an emergency landing in Khartoum, an airline spokesman said Thursday.

title: Computervision Bars A Takeover Proposal
description: The Computervision Corporation said yesterday that its board had rejected a $390 million takeover proposal from one of its leading rivals, Prime Computer Inc.

title: Cold Comfort From Siberia
description: Literature celebrates the equalizing aspect of the weather: John Huston's film of ''The Dead'' ends with James Joyce's mesmerizing report that snow ''was general all over Ireland''; it was ''falling upon all the living and the dead.''

title: Ministers Won't Invite Koch To Observance for Dr. King
description: A group of black Baptist ministers voted this week not to invite Mayor Koch to its annual memorial service for the Rev.
