Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Leaders of the group, the Baptist Ministers Conference of Greater New York and Vicinity, voted 16 to 13 against asking Mr. Koch to attend its Jan. 18 service at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem.

title: Frederick H. Kelley Jr. Accountant, 69
description: Frederick Hammond Kelley Jr., a retired partner in the accounting firm of Peat Marwick Main & Company, died of emphysema Wednesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Savannah, Ga. He was 69 years old and lived in Hilton Head, S.C.

title: ARIZONA GOVERNOR INDICTED BY STATE ON CAMPAIGN LOAN
description: Gov. Evan Mecham, already facing a possible recall from office, was indicted today by a state grand jury on six felony counts including perjury and concealing a $350,000 campaign loan.

title:
PATENTS;
Cigarette Substitute And a New Toothbrush
description: LEAD: Patent approval for a new cigarette substitute and a toothbrush design has been received by Michael J. Vieten of Brooklyn. He expects the patents to be issued soon.

title: Excerpt From Summary Of Brady Stock Report
description: Following is an excerpt from a summary prepared by the President's Task Force on Market Mechanisms of its report on the October stock market collapse, as released today by the White House: THE MARKET BREAK

title: Reagan Asks Increase for Education in '89 Budget
description: President Reagan proposes increases for the Education Department, the air traffic control system and the Federal crackdown on drug trafficking and white-collar crime as part of his $1.1 trillion budget for 1989, according to confidential budget documents.

title: Duties Ended On Potash
description: The Commerce Department has withdrawn temporary duties on Canadian potash after Canada agreed to stop selling the fertilizer in the United States for less than cost, the Canadian Embassy said today.

title: With Cut Flowers
description: Spring is just a few steps away, as close as the cut flowers at the nearest greengrocer or neighborhood florist.

title: Salvador Judge Refuses Amnesty To Killers of 4 U.S. Churchwomen
description: A judge refused today to grant amnesty to five national guardsmen convicted of murdering four American churchwomen in 1980, a court official said.

title: Japan to Pay More of U.S. Bases' Cost
description: Government and ruling party leaders agreed today to seek legal changes that would enable Japan to absorb a larger share of the costs of stationing United States troops here.

title: Los Angeles Gets $2 Billion Plan To Provide Housing for Homeless
description: Mayor Tom Bradley today proposed a plan to spend more than $2 billion over the next 20 years to build more low-income housing and provide more services for the city's fast-growing homeless population.

title: General Mills Resignation
description: David R. Waters, president of the specialty store operations of General Mills Inc., resigned yesterday after the company announced on Thursday that it would seek to sell its Talbots and Eddie Bauer retail chains.

title: Snow Shuts Race Tracks
description: The snowfall that hit New York yesterday wiped out thoroughbred and harness-racing programs at three tracks in the region and postponed basketball and hockey games in West Point, N.Y.

title: AIDS Testing Without Consent Reported
description: Almost half the tests for the AIDS virus given at a major United States medical center over a 15-month period were administered without a sound medical reason or the patients' consent, researchers reported today.

title: Correction
description: An obituary of Jascha Heifetz on Dec. 12 confused him at one point with another person similarly named.

title: Brown Tops East In Japan Bowl
description: Tim Brown of Notre Dame, the Heisman Trophy winner, and Don McPherson of Syracuse, the runner-up, will be teamed on the East squad Sunday for the Japan Bowl, an annual college All-Star game to be played at Yokohama.

title: Mexico's Inflation Rate
description: Consumer prices in Mexico soared by a record 159.2 percent last year, the Bank of Mexico announced. The bank said on Thursday that consumer prices rose by 14.8 percent in December alone, the highest one-month increase since the Government began collecting such statistics in 1968. Consumer prices rose 105.7 percent in 1986, which had been the previous record level.

title: BOY'S CASE IN SUPREME COURT
description: A United States Supreme Court Justice was asked today to block the State Department's planned return to Zimbabwe of a 9-year-old diplomat's son who was said to have been beaten by his father.

title: NETS HANDED ONE AS KNICKS COLLAPSE
description: For the Nets, tonight's game began to resemble the temperature: cold, dropping fast, looking as if it would get worse before it got better.

title: Geese, Sheep and Chemists Vie to Keep Us Warm
description: Is there warmth without down? After years as the unrivaled cold weather insulator, down is facing growing competition from dozens of new synthetic insulators.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Fifth-Ranked Wyoming Loses: In El Paso last night, Tim Hardaway scored 18 points and Chris Sandle added 16 as Texas-El Paso (12-2) rallied for a 68-62 victory over fifth-ranked Wyoming (11-1) in the Western Athletic Conference opener for both teams. Sandle, who covered Fennis Dembo for much of the night, held the Wyoming star to 9 points. Eric Leckner led the Cowboys with 22 points. (AP) N.B.A. 76ers 117, Clippers 103: Charles Barkley scored 17 of his 27 points in the decisive third quarter last night in Philadelphia as the 76ers handed Los Angeles its ninth straight loss. The Clippers have lost 11 of their last 12 games and 8 in a row on the road. Norris Coleman of the Clippers tied the score, 73-73, with 4 minutes 2 seconds left in the third quarter, but Barkley scored 10 points in a 12-0 surge.(AP) Celtics 125, Bullets 109: Larry Bird scored 35 points and Kevin McHale 31, and the Celtics outscored Washington, 30-11, in the final eight and a half minutes for the victory in Boston. The Celtics withstood a 43-point second quarter by the Bullets, fought back from a 10-point deficit and then rode the big rally to their 10th victory in 11 games.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 3, Whalers 1: Ray Sheppard and Christian Ruuttu scored third-period goals to lift Buffalo to its fourth straight victory. Sheppard broke a 1-1 tie 25 seconds into the third period when Mike Ramsey's shot from the blue line deflected off him and past Mike Liut. (AP) Oilers 4, Jets 4: In Winnipeg, Dave Hanna's goal with 3:09 left in the second period gave Edmonton a tie. The Oilers scored three times in the second period and then battled the Jets to a scoreless third period. (AP) Tennis Navratilova Tops Evert: Martina Navratilova defeated Chris Evert, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday in their last warm-up for the Australian Open next week in Melbourne. Evert and Navratilova face $20,000 fines by the Women's International Tennis Association for playing the exhibition, but accepted the invitation in Gold Coast, Australia, because the court and the balls were identical to those that will be used at the Open. Association rules provide for a fine for any player playing an exhibition on the same continent as an event it endorses. The New South Wales Open is being played on grass in Sydney.(AP) Shriver Advances: Top-seeded Pam Shriver overcame a groin injury to reach the semifinals of the New South Wales Open championships yesterday. Shriver defeated fifth-seeded Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden, 6-4, 6-1, but with the match only three games old, and leading by 3-0, Shriver left the court for treatment. In the semifinals, Shriver will meet Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, who beat Etsuko Inoue of Japan, 6-2, 6-3. (AP)

title: Reality of Hell's Kitchen Is Playwright's Material
description: Robert Moresco sits in Jimmy Armstrong's, one of those old Irish saloons on the West Side of Manhattan, and talks about a play he has written, and the reality on which it might or might not be based.

title: Nichols Is Convicted On Drug Charges
description: A man described as one of the city's major drug dealers was convicted yesterday on charges that will put him in jail at least 15 years, officials said. A jury that deliberated more than A jury that deliberated more than two days found Lorenzo (Fat Cat) Nichols, 29 years old, guilty of three counts of criminal possession of a controlled substance, criminal possession of marijuana, criminal use of drug paraphernalia and six counts of criminal possession of a weapon.

title: Reaction to Needles-for-Addicts Plan
description: A drug counseling group's proposal to give addicts clean needles to help prevent the spread of AIDS drew strong reactions yesterday from Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch, and the group itself moderated its position.

title: Early Black Dolls
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Quips, Not Literature
description: DOROTHY PARKER: What Fresh Hell Is This? By Marion Meade. Illustrated. 459 pages. Villard Books. $22.50.

title: O'NEILL DOES NOT HAVE CANCER, DOCTORS SAY AFTER REMOVING POLYP
description: One of three polyps removed from Gov. William A. O'Neill's colon this week contained a cluster of cancer cells, his doctors said today. But because the polyp has been taken out, he faces no risk of recurrence, they said.

title: With the Tide
description: Homer Smith, an outstanding running back for Princeton in the early 1950's and head football coach at Army from 1974 through 1978, was named offensive coordinator yesterday for the University of Alabama football team by Coach Bill Curry. Smith, 56, spent 28 years coaching at the college level before serving with the Kansas City Chiefs as offensive coordinator last season. He replaces Rip Scherer, who will become Alabama's assistant athletic director for player development. The Crimson Tide failed to score a touchdown in its last two regular season games, and that is one of the reasons for the hiring of Smith, who spent seven years as offensive coordinator and quarterback coach at U.C.L.A. ''The word 'Alabama' has the right ring for me,'' Smith said. ''Coach Curry wants a balanced offense and I am from a background that attempts to achieve a balanced offense.''

title: Lawyers' Feud Over Bar Association Endorsements Leads to a Suit
description: A feud within the City Bar Association in New York over who has the authority to speak for it on the qualifications of United States Supreme Court nominees has spilled over into the courts.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Bank Loan Given Rating
description: Duff & Phelps Inc., a Chicago-based credit-rating agency, said this week that it had released the first public long-term credit rating of a commercial bank loan.

title: VIKINGS' WILSON TO START AGAINST 49ERS
description: All week, Coach Jerry Burns of the Minnesota Vikings had declined to say whether Tommy Kramer or Wade Wilson would be his starting quarterback in the National Football League playoff game here Saturday against the 49ers. Most people close to the Vikings thought it would be Kramer, but today Burns named Wilson.

title: Taiwan Investment Up
description: Foreign investment in Taiwan soared 84.4 percent, to a record $1.42 billion in 1987, from $770 million in 1986, the Investment Commission said today. Investment in other countries by Taiwan businesses surged 80.8 percent, to a record $103 million, from $57 million. Investment in Taiwan from the United States totaled $414 million in 1987; from Japan, $399 million; from Europe, $224 million, and from Hong Kong, $181 million.

title: Oral Roberts to Cut Back TV Outlets
description: Oral Roberts, the evangelist, has decided to remove ministry programs from scores of television stations across the country because of sagging donations and a decision by many stations to drop religious programming.

title: Trevi Fountain in Rome Is Due for Refurbishing
description: The Trevi Fountain, one of Rome's most famous landmarks, is to receive a waterproof basin as part of an $830,000 restoration scheduled to begin next spring.

title: Australian Seedings
description: Pat Cash of Australia, who last year defeated Ivan Lendl in the semifinal round of the Australian Open and in the final at Wimbledon, has been seeded fourth in the draw for this year's Australian championships and would meet top-seeded Lendl in the semifinal round again, if both players get that far. Seeded second is Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the defending champion, and third is Mats Willander of Sweden, a two-time champion of the tournament that begins Monday in Melbourne.

title: Norway Names Head of Statoil
description: Harald Norvik, an economist in private industry since 1981 and a Socialist Government official for 10 years before that, will be the next managing director of Statoil, the state-owned company announced Thursday.

title: 9 Palestinians Who Face Deportation by the Israelis
description: On Sunday, Israel ordered nine Palestinians expelled from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, saying they had incited anti-Israeli violence in the occupied territories. These are the nine Palestinians and the charges against them:

title: Cooper Lasersonics
description: Cooper Lasersonics Inc. said that because of the difficulty it had encountered in turning around its laser business, it was no longer considering a spinoff of the business. Cooper had said in June that it would spin off the business as a separate public company by this month. The company said it was considering other divestitures to maximize shareholder values. The company, whose shares are trading for less than $1 each, makes high-technology devices for surgical markets.

title: G.M. Job Cuts May Be Eased
description: Slow sales of Pontiac Firebirds and Chevrolet Camaros have prompted the General Motors Corporation to elminate 1,900 jobs at a California assembly plant, but a new plan may save workers from permanent layoff, the nation's largest auto maker said today.

title: How to Insure Fairness on the Air
description: The Fairness Doctrine is dead but won't stay buried. President Reagan vetoed an attempt to make it statutory law in June and the Federal Communications Commission struck it from its regulations in August.

title: Dance: Works by Anna Sokolow
description: Anna Sokolow's Players' Project offered two suites of choreographic images and a little sketch of a dance on Thursday night in Buttenwieser Hall of the 92d Street Y. Because of the fragmentary nature of the proceedings, watching Ms. Sokolow's choreography was like browsing through someone's scrapbook.

title: Shareholder Unit Delays Decision on Robins Plan
description: A committee representing the outside shareholders of the A.H. Robins Company yesterday put off a decision on whether to oppose Robins's plan to become a subsidiary of Sanofi, the French drug company.

title: About New York; How Ms. Mastri Opens Minds With Blue Skies
description: Middle of an arctic January morning in second grade in Barbara Mastri's class in Public School 97 on Houston Street at the East River:

title: Letter: On Yachting; Cut America's Cup Rules to Waterline
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
A Semiconductor Laser
description: LEAD: A laser made of semiconductor material that generates light was patented this week for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The light is reflected from a focusing mirror built into the semiconductor. Patent No. 4,718,070 was granted to Zong-Long Liau and James N. Walpole, staff members at the M.I.T.

title: TOKYO'S PRICE LIMITATIONS
description: Prices fell less on the Tokyo Stock Exchange than in other major markets of the world when stocks collapsed in October. Some analysts, trying to explain why, have cited Tokyo's curbs on price movements.

title: ONCE AGAIN, PAYTON ADJUSTS
description: Two days from the possible end of his 13th and final season with the Chicago Bears - or three weeks from the completion he would prefer, in Super Bowl XXII -the football career of Walter Payton has room for one last fantasy.

title: Trustee Is Urged For Sharon Steel
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation's creditors have asked a Federal bankruptcy judge to appoint a trustee to run the company since the chairman, Victor Posner, has failed to agree on restructuring the board of directors. The creditors on Thursday asked United States Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz to appoint a trustee to supplant the directors now controlled by Mr. Posner.

title: Adaline Frelinghuysen Is Married to Sculptor
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York Adaline Havemeyer Frelinghuysen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Gerald Ogilvie-Laing, the son of the late Maj. and Mrs. Gerald Ogilvie-Laing of Newcastle-on-Tyne, England. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. IS DENOUNCED ON ACID RAIN STUDY
description: The Canadian Government has denounced a major United States report that concluded acid rain caused little if any damage to American crops, forests and lakes and was unlikely to do so.

title: THE BASIC SPEECH: Albert Gore Jr.; Southerner Stresses Strong Military
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: Celtics Sign Gilmore
description: The Boston Celtics answered their need for a backup center yesterday by signing the 7-foot-2-inch Artis Gilmore, a 17-year veteran who was released by the Chicago Bulls last month at the age of 38. Gilmore, who averaged at least 11 points and seven rebounds a game in each of his pro seasons, averaged 15.5 minutes, 4.2 points and 2.6 rebounds with the Bulls this season. Gilmore, who began his pro career in 1971 with Kentucky of the American Basketball Association, is the National Basketball Association's career leader with a .600 field-goal percentage. Boston has been using Greg Kite, Mark Acres and Brad Lohaus at center when Robert Parish, the starter, leaves the game. But Kite was placed on the injured list with a recurrence of back problems two days after coming off it. . . . The Celtics also announced that Jerry Sichting, a guard, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee yesterday and will be sidelined three to five weeks.

title: 40-1 Winner At Gulfstream
description: Cook's Brown Rice, the longest shot in a field of eight at 40-1, just lasted to nose out Evening Kris and win the $59,135 Spectacular Bid Stakes today as Gulfstream Park opened its winter meeting.

title: Jews for Jesus Ad Poses Painful Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Light in the Khyber Pass?
description: Logic and interest argue powerfully for a Soviet withdrawal in 1988 of its 115,000 troops in Afghanistan. But it can't be done without military and political cost. Is Mikhail Gorbachev wise and strong enough to pull out anyway?

title: Bush Is Target of Foes at Iowa Debate
description: Vice President Bush, on the defensive over his role in the Iran-contra affair, insisted in a debate here tonight that he had answered every question, save one, about his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: DOLLAR FALLS AS STOCKS PLUMMET
description: The dollar fell yesterday, ending a tumultuous week on an uncertain note.

title: Dharmsala Journal; In Tibet's Dark Hour, Dalai Lama Is Their Refuge
description: Hours after the first anti-Chinese riots broke out last fall in Lhasa, the distant capital of Tibet, this normally quiet community of Tibetan refugees in the Himalayan foothills of India came to life.

title: The Ice Hockey Follies, With Qaddafi Starring
description: Striding languidly into the large, brightly colored Bedouin tent with his flowing brown cape swept over his arm, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi declared to the two dozen West German sportswriters that he had watched an ice hockey game on videotape and approved of it. It is not a violent game, he declared, but a mass sport that people like.

title: New York State's Presidential Primary Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: BONDS DROP SHARPLY ON JOBLESS DIP
description: Prices of Government securities fell sharply yesterday after the release of a better-than-expected report on the nationwide unemployment rate.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Rodgers, the 40-year-old world-class marathoner who had earlier announced he would not compete in the Phoenix City Marathon today because of a mild Achilles' tendon injury to his right foot, has changed his mind and plans to attempt to break Barry Brown's American Masters marathon record of 2 hours 15 minutes 15 seconds. . . . Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe have entered the Italian Indoor Tennis championships Feb. 15-21 in Milan.

title: Jazz: Clifford Jordan, On the Tenor Saxophone
description: For the last decade, Clifford Jordan has quietly and consistently been making brilliant music with his tenor saxophone. At 56, with 30-odd years of professional experience behind him, Mr. Jordan's profound mastery allows him to wrap each note of his solos in its own texture. In the midst of his unhurried improvisations, he'll convert a low note into a crying moan, slide it up through a silky blue haze to a new pitch and end the phrase with a gently swaying vibrato.

title: GULLICKSON LEAVES YANKS TO PLAY IN JAPAN
description: Two days after they signed a major hitter, the Yankees lost a major pitcher last night when Bill Gullickson said no to their final offer and headed for Japan, where he is expected to sign a two-year contract Monday for $3.3 million with the Tokyo Giants.

title: KEY RATES
Tale of Two Presidents And One Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: Executives Shifted at William Morrow and Little, Brown
description: James D. Landis, who heads his own imprint at William Morrow & Company, was named publisher and editor in chief of Morrow yesterday. He replaces Sherry W. Arden, who was named head of a new Morrow imprint, Silver Arrow Books.

title: Former Banker Gets Jail Term
description: A former banking executive found guilty of defrauding one of his company's subsidiary banks was sentenced today to three years in prison and fined $5,000. United States District Judge

title: The New Way to Get to Broadway
description: It was a Monday night, when most Broadway theaters are dark, but Bill Mernit sat at a piano on a stage playing the songs he has been working on for three years.

title:
WHAT NEW YORK'S NEW SCHOOL CHIEF IS UP AGAINST;
A PROPOSED AGENDA
description: LEAD: Here are a few suggestions for Dr. Richard R. Green, the superintendent of public schools in Minneapolis, who has been appointed the next chancellor of the New York City public school system.

title: Buyout Rejected By Holly Sugar
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation rejected a last-ditch, $92.50-a-share buyout proposal from Plum Associates and paid the New York-based investor group a $900,000 fee for calling off the deal in favor of an offer from the Imperial Sugar Company.

title: Officer Cites Wounds on Levin's Neck
description: A police sergeant testified yesterday that sometime near or after her death in Central Park, Jennifer Levin's clothing was pushed up until it completely covered her neck, which was found to have ''multiple horizontal red wounds'' across it.

title: Japan Curbs On Insiders
description: Japan's Finance Ministry is seeking tighter controls on insider trading in securities and hopes to present a draft to amend the current law before Parliament next month, a senior ministry official said today.

title: Conductors' Conference To Honor Max Rudolf
description: This year's National Conference for Conductors will interrupt classes and meetings at Columbia University today to give its Theodore Thomas Award to Max Rudolf, a man whose Central European training and professionalism has had a strong influence on American symphonic life over the last half-century.

title: Michael N. Taylor Educator, 47
description: Michael N. Taylor, director of Indian education programs for the Association of American Indian Affairs, died of pnuemonia Tuesday at the Washington Adventist Hospital in Tacoma, Md. He was 47 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: South Africa Helps U.S. Film Makers In Namibia With Troops and Trucks
description: South Africa provided tanks, trucks, troops, jeeps and mortars for the filming of an American adventure movie scheduled for release next summer, South-West African publications have reported.

title: Mullin Due Back Soon
description: Chris Mullin is expected to be released as early as Monday from the California hospital where he is undergoing treatment for alcohol dependency, a source close to the Mullin family said yesterday. The source said that after his release, Mullin plans to continue therapy and will rejoin the Warriors when he thinks he is ready to play again.

title: Y.M.C.A. Resident Is Slain in Dispute
description: A dispute between roommates at a midtown Y.M.C.A. ended yesterday with a fatal stabbing, the police said.

title: German Jobless Rate Up
description: West Germany's unemployment rate rose to 9.2 percent in December from 8.5 percent in November as the number of jobless grew by 175,200, to more than 2 million, the Government reported today.

title: Auto Sales Climb in Italy
description: Sales of new cars in Italy rose 8.3 percent last year, to a a record 1,976,541, the Italian Association of Auto Makers reported today. Fiat accounted for 43.7 percent of the total.

title:
WHAT NEW YORK'S NEW SCHOOL CHIEF IS UP AGAINST;
The Big Need For Research
description: LEAD: If the troubles in New York City schools stemmed from an outbreak of cancer, we would know what to do. Teams of doctors would sweep through the schools to cure the cancers that were curable; a cadre of the world's finest scientists would search for the cause and prevention of the cancers.

title: CUOMO TO SEEK KEY CHANGES IN RENT RULES
description: The Cuomo administration plans to propose major changes in housing regulations, including making leases permanent in rent-stabilized apartments and ending the need for their renewals. It would also eliminate rent surcharges for fuel costs and stiffen some penalties against landlords who do not properly maintain apartments.

title: Investigation Of Index Data
description: Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who plays a powerful role in overseeing the securities industry, said today that he had begun an investigation into charges that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission used unreliable data in its study of possible manipulative trading involving the Major Market Index.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arnox Corp., Greenwich, Conn., said TXL Acquisition Corp., a subsidiary of TXL Corp., had agreed to withdraw its $10-a-share offer for Arnox.

title: RANGERS' STREAK ENDED BY CAPITALS
description: Painful as it is to experience, there is something cathartic about being humbled. Somehow, the vulnerability it exposes leaves its victims more easily introspective, certainly more engagingly candid.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JANUARY 9, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-5

title: 3,000 Boneless Hams Recalled by Processor
description: A Pennsylvania meat processor has has expanded a voluntary recall of products to include about 3,000 boneless prosciutto hams suspected of being contaminated by salmonella, the Agriculture Department has reported.

title: Taxi Panel Member Assails Agency and Quits
description: A member of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission has resigned, calling the agency's efforts to register the city's nonmedallion vehicles ineffective.

title: Devils Recall Forwards
description: The Devils called up three forwards, Anders Carlsson, Chris Cichocki and Al Stewart from Utica of the American Hockey League yesterday. They are expected to be in the lineup when the Devils play the North Stars in Minnesota tonight. Carlsson, 27 years old, is being recalled for the third time this season. He has appeared in four games with the Devils and scored one goal. He has 3 goals and 18 assists in 52 National Hockey League games. Cichocki, 24, was acquired from the Detroit Red Wings last March along with a third-round 1987 draft choice in exchange for Mel Bridgeman. He has yet to play for the Devils. In 61 games with the Red Wings, he scored 10 goals and had 11 assists. Stewart, 23, was slowed by injuries earlier this year and has not played for the Devils this season. He has played in 11 career games for New Jersey and 1 one goal.

title: Variations on a Theme
description: IN Chicago years ago, there was a coach from my high school named Ralph Margolis, a barrel-chested fellow and a storyteller of wide repute. He once told of playing baseball for the University of Illinois, where, he said, he beat out Red Grange for right field.

title: Storm Hits East Coast After Burying South in Snow
description: Winter raided the East Coast yesterday with heavy snow and freezing winds that disrupted transportation, government, business and education and recast the landscape into snowbound shapes from the Carolinas to the New York metropolitan area.

title: Music: Mehta Conducts Messiaen's 'Turangalila'
description: Olivier Messiaen's ''Turangalila'' Symphony is only 40 years old, but it belongs to an age other than ours. Its vastness contradicts modern science's assertions that man is small and the universe infinite. Extravagance such as this bespeaks a confidence in our powers ultimately to control the world around us.

title: 263 Movies From 1987 Are in Race for Oscars
description: A near-record number of feature-length films from 1987 qualified for Academy Awards consideration, missing the 1974 mark by a single entry, academy officials said today.

title: Choosing Batteries
description: If you're thinking about winter travel, it's time to check batteries for the appliances you may need. Manufacturers usually specify the size, from AAA to D, but there are different types to choose from. Zinc carbon batteries: Least expensive; most cost effective when used in gadgets that require little power. Alkaline: More expensive than zinc carbon, but last longer. Zinc air and lithium: Popular because of their longevity; harder to find; more expensive than zinc carbon and alkaline batteries. Rechargeable (nickel cadmium): Limited capacity but may be recharged dozens of times; most expensive. All are produced by major battery manufacturers and are available at appliance and hardware stores. Here is a list of some appliances and the batteries recommended for them, starting with the ones that require the least power: EQUIPMENT BATTERY CHOICE RECOMMENDED Travel clocks Zinc carbon Alkaline Alkaline Small radios and electric toys Zinc carbon Zinc Carbon Alkaline Rechargeable Remote-control pagers Zinc carbon Zinc air Alkaline Rechargeable Zinc air Flashlights Zinc carbon Depends on size Alkaline Rechargeable Cameras Alkaline Lithium Rechargeable or Alkaline Lithium Portable radios, cassette Zinc Carbon Akaline players, motorized toys Alkaline Rechargeable (National Electrical Manufacturers Association, George Consulting International Inc. (consultants to the battery industry))

title: Terminal: Home for Hundreds
description: When the temperature drops outside, Charlene Turner, a resident of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, south wing lower level, wraps a matted blanket around her thin shoulders, and turns up the latest episode of her favorite soap opera on her five-inch television set.

title: WNYC Plans Tribute To Simone de Beauvoir
description: Simone de Beauvoir, the French writer and scholar, is being honored today with a daylong program of readings and interviews on WNYC radio, 830 AM and 93.9 FM. The tribute, beginning at 10 A.M., falls on the 80th anniversary of her birth; Miss de Beauvoir, author her birth; Miss de Beauvoir, author of ''The Second Sex,'' among other works, died in 1986.

title: Yale Offers Workers 15% Three-Year Pact
description: Yale University today proposed 15 percent pay increases in a three-year contract for 3,600 employees and said that the proposal was its sole economic offering.

title: Head of Federal Agency Says Age Bias Cases Were Ignored
description: A Federal employment rights commission ignored 900 grievances concerning age discrimination for more than two years, preventing most people who filed the complaints from taking legal action, the agency's chief said Thursday.

title: Wynn Halts Sale
description: Wynn's International Inc., an automotive products supplier, said that it was abandoning a two-month effort to find a buyer. The company had received an unsolicited $27.25-a-share, $109 million buyout proposal from a unit of the Security Pacific Corporation in September. That offer was dropped on Oct. 30 and a plan by a management-led group, intending to take the company private through a leveraged buyout, was unable to obtain financing. Wesley E. Bellwood, chairman of Wynn's, based in Fullerton, Calif., said that the company had failed to attract any other offers in part because of forecasts predicting a 20 percent decline in car sales in 1988, he said. Wynn, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange fell today by $3, to $16.75.

title: Ruth Wright Theater Owner, 75
description: Ruth Wright, a retired theater owner, died of cancer Dec. 31 at her home in Great Neck, L.I. She was 75 years old.

title: STOCKS FALL 140.58 IN A LATE SELLOFF
description: LEAD: Stock prices plunged wildly yesterday, wiping out a week of strong gains.

title: Alfred J. Barabas, Star Halfback In Columbia's Rose Bowl Victory
description: Al Barabas, the Columbia halfback who scored the game's only touchdown in the famous 7-0 upset of Stanford in the 1934 Rose Bowl, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 77 years old. He made other runs, he scored other touchdowns, and he later became one of Columbia's most successful fund-raisers, but nothing could match the acclaim he received for the single play in the second quarter of the Stanford game.

title:
PATENTS;
Barrier Holds In Heat
description: LEAD: Wallace G. Hanson of Dodge Center, Minn., will receive a patent next week for a barrier that will prevent the passage of heat from a warm area to a cold area. Mr. Hanson said that patent 4,718,249 might have various applications, including the production of energy in space.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: Luciano Pavarotti is the recipient of this year's Crystal Star Award given by Il Teatro dell'Opera, a Brooklyn-based opera company, for his ''invaluable contribution to opera.'' Mirella Freni, who received the award last year, is to present the award to Mr. Pavarotti at a dinner on Jan. 16 in Manhattan.

title:
PATENTS;
Rule Changes Reprinted
description: LEAD: This week's Official Gazette of the Patent and Trademark Office contains more than 400 pages of republished notices and rule changes issued since July 1, 1964. Notes are added for items no longer in effect.

title: Girl Will Stand Trial In Mother's Slaying
description: A 16-year-old girl whose former boyfriend admitted strangling her mother will stand trial as an accessory to the killing, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Off
description: Canada's unemployment rate fell to 8.1 percent in December, the lowest level in more than six years, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The November rate had been 8.2 percent. The average unemployment rate for 1987 was 8.9 percent, down from 9.4 percent in the previous year.

title: Mentally Disabled May Gain Thousands in Back Benefits
description: Mental health and social workers are looking for thousands of mentally disabled people in New York City, many of them homeless, who may be due Social Security benefits that were cut off several years ago in what the courts said was an illegal policy. Some people may get tens of thousands of dollars.

title: Task Force Ties Market Collapse To Big Investors' Program Trades
description: A handful of the nation's largest money management firms, using two types of computerized trading, were mostly responsible for the October stock market collapse, a Presidential task force said in a report today.

title: Robert U. Redpath Jr. Executive, 81
description: Robert U. Redpath Jr., an advisor to corporations for pension and estate planning, died Dec. 28 at his home in South Orange, N.J., after a long illness. He was 81 years old. Mr. Redpath graduated from Yale College and was associated with several life-insurance companies.

title: Petitions of Dole and Haig In Texas Reported Faulty
description: Republican officials in Texas asked Federal agencies today to investigate charges that petitions filed for the state's Presidential primary by two Republican candidates, Senator Bob Dole and Alexander M. Haig Jr., contained numerous forgeries.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 53.

title: Landlord Is Arrested For Heatless Building
description: A West Orange surgeon, called a slumlord by Mayor Sharpe James, has been charged with 11 counts of contempt of court for leaving 62 tenants without heat, hot water and other services, the police said yesterday.

title: ISLANDERS FALL TO THE FLAMES
description: Brett Hull scored twice and assisted on two other goals tonight as the Calgary Flames defeated the Islanders, 7-4.

title: Economist Installed as Princeton's 18th President
description: Harold T. Shapiro took office as Princeton University's 18th president today and appealed to American higher education to be more mindful of the moral and spiritual needs of college students.

title: Suspect Seized In IRT Shooting That Killed One
description: A 38-year-old man wanted in the shotgun killing of his former companion Thursday on a crowded platform in the Grand Central subway station was arrested yesterday outside his brother's home in New Jersey, the police said.

title: Robert Barrios Editor, 33
description: Robert Barrios, a copy editor for The New York Times and former Foreign Service officer, died Thursday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 33 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Studies New Curbs On General in Panama
description: The Reagan Administration is considering whether to impose new punitive measures against Panama if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega moves to consolidate his position as the power behind the scenes, senior Administration officials said today.

title: LONG HOURS, FAST PACE FOR PANEL'S STAFF 42
description: The report issued today by the Presidential Task Force on Market Mechanisms was largely the product of a 42-member staff drawn from universities and Wall Street.

title: Robertson Is Rejected in Bid To Delay Libel Case He Filed
description: Pat Robertson has lost a bid to postpone the trial of his libel suit against a former Congressman who questioned the Republican Presidential candidate's Korean War record.

title: 'EDUCATION FOR WHAT?'
description: Dr. Vartan Gregorian, president of the New York Public Library, will give a talk on ''Education for What?'' on Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall as part of the ''Lincoln Center Off Stage'' lecture series. The program is to begin with a reception at 5:30 P.M.; wine and cheese will be served and guests will have a chance to talk with Dr. Gregorian. The lecture, with a question-and-answer period, will start at 6 P.M. Tickets, at $12, are available at the box office or through Center Charge, 874-6770.

title: Future Is Now on Trial for Colts
description: On Saturday, the country will get a peek at what might be the National Football League's new era.

title: Concert: McKinley Pieces By American Symphony
description: While William Thomas McKinley cannot strictly be called a Minimalist, the four concertos by the composer that the American Symphony Orchestra performed Thursday evening in Carnegie Hall showed him to rival certain members of that school in his capacity to write seemingly endless stretches of unvaried, uninteresting music.

title: STACEY CHAPMAN ENGAGED TO WED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Mark L. Chapman of Norwood, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Stacey Ann Chapman to Adam Saravay, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Saravay of Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: IMPASSE PORTENDS TROUBLE FOR HALPIN
description: LEAD: A VOTING deadlock in the Suffolk County Legislature last week portended difficulties for County Executive Patrick G. Halpin in dealing with the 18 legislators.

title: Toxic Cleanup Plan Moves Slowly Amid Criticism From Two Fronts
description: A year after Congress toughened a 1980 law for cleaning up toxic waste sites, the Environmental Protection Agency is struggling to do the job Congress intended, caught between critics who say its efforts are not adequate and those who question whether the cleanup is the best use of the agency's resources.

title: BEVERLY BELEW TO WED A FELLOW ARMY OFFICER
description: Lieut. Col. Beverly Ann Belew of the Army Nurse Corps and Col. Michael Richard Antopol, commander of the Brooke Army Medical Center at Fort Sam Houston in Texas, plan to be married Feb. 14, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Jerry B. Belew of Andrews, Tex., have announced.

title: SAUDI PLAYS DOWN MARCOS PAINTINGS
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi businessman, said today that at least a third of 31 paintings he bought from former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, were reproductions of masterworks and that several ''cheap ones'' were among those turned over to the United States by France.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Nothing fundamentally has changed, but you don't find as many bears in the woods as you used to.''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WEDDING. By Yann Queffelec. Translated by Linda Coverdale. (Macmillan, $17.95.) This novel begins with one of the most brutally depicted rapes in fiction, in which a 13-year-old French girl is sadistically violated by three American soldiers who are quartered near her seaside village in the closing days of World War II.

title: An Actor Gives New Direction to China's Stage
description: YING RUOCHENG IS FAMILIAR to American audiences as the prison warden in Bernardo Bertolucci's new film ''The Last Emperor.'' However, in China, he is now primarily known not for his acting ability, but as the nation's Vice Minister of Culture. In this powerful post he is presently at work on a broad reform of the performing arts.

title: S.M.U. Job Rejected
description: BILL McCARTNEY, the head football coach at Colorado, changed his mind at the last minute last night about taking the Southern Methodist coaching job after consulting with his family, Colorado's athletic director, Bill Marolt, and the Colorado president, Gordon Gee, according to Doug Single, the S.M.U. athletic director.

title: About the Show
description: Where and When: The New York National Boat Show is located at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, at 11th and 12th avenues between 34th and 39th streets. The show is open today through next Sunday. The show will be open today and next Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Monday through Friday, noon to 10 P.M.; Saturday, 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. Admission is $7 for adults and $3 for children age 12 and under.

title: Fuel Spill Clogs Wheeling, W.Va.
description: Shops closed and firefighters worried about a water shortage today as the city stopped pumping water from the Ohio River because of a diesel oil spill that has traveled 100 miles in a week.

title: New Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: Ortega: Can He Be Trusted?
description: EARLY ON A HUMID MORNING in November, Daniel Ortega Saavedra boarded a jet in Managua and flew off to fight contras. He was headed not for Nicaragua's rugged mountains or lush tropical rain forests, where combatants stalk one another, but for Washington, where he believes the contra war will ultimately be won or lost. Aboard his plane, President Ortega succinctly explained the purpose of his lobbying trip. ''Whether Reagan wants to send $3 million or $30 million or $270 million to the contras, he always needs Congress.''

title: PREMISES AS PRETENSE
description: MONSIEUR TESTE IN AMERICA & Other Instances of Realism. By Andrei Codrescu. 138 pp. Minneapolis: Coffee House Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: Racism Protest Leaders Assailed by N.A.A.C.P.
description: Leaders of the N.A.A.C.P. in New York yesterday criticized the lawyer Alton H. Maddox Jr. and other black lawyers and clergymen for ''whooping and hollering'' rather than working methodically to fight discrimination and violence against blacks.

title: CHAMBERS JURY TO TEST THE MEANING OF MOTIVE
description: SINCE at least the 14th century, when English common law called it ''malice a prepense,'' judges and juries have struggled with the concept and the consequences of trying to gauge a killer's state of mind at the moment of killing.

title: JILL L. JELENKO, STUDENT, WEDS ROBERT N. ANGEN
description: Jill Leslie Jelenko and Robert Neal Angen were married yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Pacific Palisades, Calif. The Rev. Peter Kreitler performed the ceremony.

title: A Different Way To Sell a House
description: DISENCHANTED with realty brokers, Linda and Carl Mattson tried a more challenging approach to sell their house in Buxton, Me.: a dog-naming contest with the house as the prize.

title: Spielberg at 40: The Man and the Child
description: IN THE FIRST PART OF STEVEN Spielberg's sprawling new epic, ''Empire of the Sun,'' a boy dressed in a party costume discovers a derelict fighter plane in a field near Shanghai. The adventurer, resembling Aladdin, instantly climbs into the rusted cockpit and gleefully imagines he is stalking enemy aircraft.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I don't have to comply with George Bush. Why doesn't he release what we're all trying to find out about, the Iran-contra thing?'' - Senator Bob Dole. [ 22:1. ]

title: Multiple Reviews
description: To the Editor:

title: James V. Siena, Former Pentagon Official
description: James V. Siena, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense and an executive at the American Institute of Architects, died of cancer last Sunday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 55 years old and lived in Washington.

title: CHRONICLES OF THE PUMPHOUSE GANG
description: ALMOST HUMAN A Journey into the World of Baboons. By Shirley C. Strum. Drawings by Deborah Ross. Photographs. 294 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

title: CHOICES BOTH GREAT AND SMALL
description: THE rract of making a choice and all its implications have begun to take on a new meaning for me. Most people, whether they make the right or wrong choice, usually have that option. The degree varies, of course; should I remain at this job or look for another, should I stay with my husband or leave him, will I eat steak or pasta for dinner?

title:
MUSIC;
The Night When Carnegie Hall Swung
description: LEAD: WE WERE YOUNG.We were like the

title: WOMEN IN SCHOOLS: ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT
description: Women indeed have cracked the glass ceiling in leadership positions in Long Island school districts [ ''The Best Man for the Job,'' Opinion Page, Dec. 13 ] .

title: NOW PLAYING: THE NEW HOLLYWOOD
description: THINGS CHANGE ALL THE time in Hollywood. Stars come and stars go. Raunchy teen-age comedies clogged the theaters like cholesterol in aging arteries for six years, then disappeared overnight, to be replaced in the fall of 1987 by courtroom melodramas and steamy love stories. Three months ago, the stock market crash put upstart companies at risk, those fragile new movie makers dependent on stock sales and one hit movie.

title: The Big-Stakes Battleground of Shareholder Suits
description: FOUR days after Black Monday, CJI Industries, a maker of coin and currency handling products, announced plans to merge with Triangle Industries, the nation's biggest packaging manufacturer and a company whose stock had been battered in the Oct. 19 market plunge.

title: Appearance By Solo Sailor
description: Tania Aebi, the 21-year-old sailor who recently circumnavigated the globe alone on a 26-foot sailboat, is scheduled to appear at the New York National Boat Show today and next Saturday and Sunday from noon to 4 P.M. Her boat, the sailing sloop Varuna, will be on display throughout the show, along with a pictorial display of Aebi's 27,000-mile voyage.

title: The Letters of Tell Leilan
description: It's hard not to envy Harvey Weiss, an archeologist at Yale who is hot on the trail of an intriguing correspondence. It's between the king of Shubat Enlil and his son, the governor of Mari. Those were two once-great cities on the plains of Mesopotamia, where urban civilization began some 5,000 years ago. Mari was excavated in 1933, providing clay tablets that are half the correspondence. Dr. Weiss seems close to unearthing the other half.

title: In Gaza, Confrontation at Crossroads of History; Finding a Sponsor
description: To the Editor:

title: WENDY SCHACK IS ENGAGED TO MARRY ALAN M. FORREST
description: Dr. and Mrs. Julius B. Schack of Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Gail Schack to Alan Michael Forrest, a son of Joyce Forrest of New York and the late Milton Forrest. A May wedding is planned.

title: Philadelphia Asks, Is It Art Or Politics?
description: The history of the world is littered with the debris of collisions between art and politics. And so, to Philadelphians who like to call their city the birthplace of both American art and American politics, a current uproar over art exhibits in City Hall comes as no surprise.

title: NOVICE FINDS A SPOT ON THE Varsity
description: MITCH BUONAGURO, the men's varsity basketball coach at Fairfield University, did a double-take when he spotted 6-foot-10-inch Alex Forbes shooting baskets last September at the school's recreational complex during the freshmen orientation weekend.

title: THE EARLY EMPIRE
description: THE BINGHAMS OF LOUISVILLE The Dark History Behind One of America's Great Fortunes. By David Leon Chandler with Mary Voelz Chandler. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $17.95.

title: Haiti Vote Panel Bars Duvalier Allies
description: In a move that was could bring new violence in Haiti, the electoral council appointed by the military-led Government announced tonight that it had rejected 10 of 11 former associates of the deposed Duvalier dicatorship as candidates for president in an election Jan. 17.

title: More Good Things About the Midwest
description: To the Editor:

title: Local Foes Hamper New York's Bid for Collider
description: When New York was selected last month as one of eight finalists in the national competition to become home state for the superconducting supercollider - the biggest and costliest tool for science research ever built - state officials expressed satisfaction.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ANIMATION IN NORWALK Eighteen prize-winning animated films are featured in the 20th Tourney of Animation to be shown at 7:30 P.M. Friday through Jan. 18 at the SoNo Cinema, 15 Washington Street, South Norwalk. A 5 P.M. matinee is scheduled on Saturday.

title: SPECIAL UNITS AIMING TO HASTEN DRUG CASES
description: FIVE special prosecuting units for drug cases are being created in Connecticut this month, working with local police departments to insure that investigations withstand court tests and to target cases for speedy prosecution. The units will be part of what state officials call Connecticut's most ambitious effort to step up drug enforcement.

title: CHARLESTON'S INSIDE AGITATOR
description: LEAD: A PASSION FOR JUSTICE J. Waties Waring and Civil Rights. By Tinsley E. Yarbrough. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $32.50.

title: A CONVENTION OF GROUSERS
description: DETERMINING the difference between a children's book and a book for adults is often tricky business. After all, many people once considered ''Huckleberry Finn'' - that bible of individualism, perhaps the most delightfully subversive, antiauthoritarian work in American literature - to be a charming children's story. Later generations may be just as surprised to discover that we once classified the mature work of Arthur Yorinks and Richard Egielski as picture books - ''read-alouds'' for young children.

title: SCHOOL RESTRAINS JOURNAL ON AIDS
description: LEAD: ADMINISTRATORS at Longwood High School have held up publication of a student journal that uses the often blunt vernacular of teen-agers to describe methods of AIDS prevention.

title: A Hong Kong Satellite Looks Ahead to 1997
description: TEN years ago Shatin was a quiet patch of farmland in Hong Kong's New Territories, with water buffalo pulling plows through geometric acres of rice paddies and fishermen's cottages along the Shing Mun River. It was an evocation of rural China, even though it was only 10 miles north of the teeming city of Kowloon, separated from Hong Kong's busiest district by the steep Lion Rock Hills.

title: INDUSTRY WEATHERING THE FINANCIAL STORM
description: THE New York National Boat Show, coming at the onset of a new year, is viewed by the marine industry as the bellwether for its coming season. In 1988, eyes are peeled for a glitch in the boating market that might be traced to the stock market's Black Monday in October. But few really expect such a ripple.

title:
IN SHORT;
A SHORT COURSE IN AMERICAN LEISURE
description: LEAD: In retrospect, the miniature golf craze of the 1920's made as much sense as anything else at the time. If college students were swallowing goldfish while their elders sat on the tops of flagpoles, why not try to push a golf ball through a smallish copy of a Dutch windmill? The people who put together MINIATURE GOLF (Abbeville, $19.95) have done some very intelligent things.

title: CYNTHIA GOODWIN TO WED
description: Cynthia Ann Goodwin, the travel and finance advertising sales manager for Vanity Fair magazine, and Timothy Francis Byrnes, a senior sales representative for the Harris Corporation, a computer company in New York, plan to be married March 19. Mr. and Mrs. Alton Bent Goodwin of Wellesley, Mass., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Byrnes of Westport, Conn. Miss Goodwin and her fiance are 1979 graduates of Stonehill College in North Easton, Mass.

title: POSTINGS: Warehouses to Condos; Ugly Duckling
description: Though Waterfront Invest once won an award for historic preservation, the group's current Jersey City project certainly does not fit that category. ''We have taken an extremely ugly, black-looking building and turned it into something quite nice,'' said Robert Fioretti, Waterfront's managing partner for Riverview Terrace. Formerly four adjacent warehouses at 44 Sherman Avenue, the 54-unit condominium will be completed in March after a year-long, $3.5 million gut rehab. The buildings, once filled with office furniture and archives, were of different heights and additions had to be made to bring the entire structure to its present six floors. Meanwhile, floors did not always meet from one warehouse to another, and the basement, which will be used to park 22 cars, needed 19 tons of steel girders to compensate for nine support columns that had to be removed. The result, Mr. Fioretti said, is solidity, even though the oldest of the warehouses dates from 1890. ''This thing will stand when everything else around it dies,'' he said.

title: New Snow, Old Ice - and Old Excuses
description: The big weekend snow that covered the Northeast would have caused mighty traffic problems all by itself. But in many residential sections of New York City, it came on top of the thick ice still left from last Sunday night's fall. With cars now swathed in snow and cemented in ice, some streets may not be cleared till the forsythia blossoms.

title: About Men; Shoveling
description: THE MEN WHO LIVE ON MY ONE-BLOCK street are a banker, a lawyer, a television ad writer, an obstetrician, a librarian, a retired ophthalmologist and another college prof like me. On mornings after a big snow, three or four of us will be out there at more or less the same time, shoveling the stuff out of our driveways and off our walks. Now and then, one of us will wave or call out a remark to another:

title: In Gaza, Confrontation at Crossroads of History; The Old Ideologies
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; DINING LIGHT
description: WHEN I SEE CALORIE counts listed on a menu, I cringe. Although the threat of extra pounds is constant, the idea of being reminded of this when I'm out to enjoy myself is no fun at all. Paying dearly for diet food is only further insult.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: DIZZY AND McKEE

title: A Transient Art Form With Staying Power
description: WITH THE SPEED AND glitz of the art world, the need for the installation as a self-contained work of art, in which visitors can be totally immersed, is not likely to diminish. Installations are made for a particular place and time. After their run, they are dismantled. Most are never reassembled. At best, they are at the same time immediate and slow.

title: 'LIMITS' AT 30: THE TRIP IS WORTH IT
description: In ''Learning Limits as 30 Looms'' [ Opinion Page, Dec. 6 ] , Lisa James offers more of her own depressed view of life than any insight into universal truths.

title: Chef at White House Quits After 4 Months
description: John Hill, executive chef at the White House, resigned Friday, just four months after taking the job.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: Having Chris Mullin back in New York would be great. But if he accepts his alcoholism (and only he can say whether or not he is an alcoholic), then he and people around him must understand that moving back to New York doesn't mean he's cured of the disease. JOEL SCHWARTZ Jamaica, Queens

title: INCEST VICTIMS GET SYMPATHY BUT LITTLE HELP
description: IN sentencing Cheryl Pierson to six months in jail, the judge at her manslaughter hearing said that the 18-year-old Selden girl had had alternatives short of arranging her father's killing. But many professionals who deal with such incest cases warn that had the teen-age victim turned to Suffolk County for help, she might have been frustrated and might even have ended up dead herself.

title: PREDICTING THE PULSE OF THE ECONOMY
description: WHAT everyone in business needs is a good crystal ball. But to be of value, forecasts must be accurate, and a Chappaqua consulting group, Levy Economic Forecasts, has compiled one of the best records in the country for predicting turning points of the business cycle in the United States for the last 40 years.

title: THE ROAD TO SELF-RELIANCE
description: Ralph Waldo Emerson warns us, in his essay ''Self-Reliance,'' not to drag about ''the corpse of memory.'' But Michael Norman drags his memory of childhood loneliness through all the phases of his maturation, calling it the road to self-reliance. Romanticizing is dangerous. All the current psychobabble -being your own person, not needing anyone, doing your own thing - boils down to being lonely. PEG FISK Port Chester, N.Y.

Bluepoint $180,000 10 Arthur Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200. Floral Park $300,000 7 Fuller Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-family, 45-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, finished basement, aluminum siding; taxes $3,000. Levittown $142,000 25 Peony Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, aluminum siding; taxes $2,000. Smithtown $158,000 90 Howell Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, new roof; taxes $3,000.
