title: Real Runaway
description: To the Editor:

title: The Smoky Soup Of Scotland
description: FISH chowder, soupe de poisson, zuppa di pesce, cullen skink. Cullen skink?

title: FICTION
description: THAI HORSE. By William Diehl. (Villard, $18.95.) Christian Hatcher is the kind of guy you wouldn't mind having at your side when trouble lurks around the corner. This ex-naval officer, amateur boxer, cat burglar, linguist, expert lover and former operative for some shadowy government agency is your perfect adventure hero. In fact, his only imperfections are the occasional physical scar and his raspy voice, which produces a growl that resembles the Cookie Monster's. Hatcher, now living on an island somewhere off Florida, is making ends meet by heisting art and ransoming it back to insurance companies when he is recruited to find an old pal, Murphy Cody, who was presumed killed in action 15 years earlier in Vietnam. The ensuing worldwide search leads the reader through familiar thriller territory in quest not only of Cody but also the mysterious identity of the person known as Thai Horse. William Diehl, the author of the novels ''Chameleon'' and ''Sharky's Machine,'' throws everything into this suspense thriller: drugs, the Mafia, Vietnam, Latin American politics, Chinese gangs, Arab terrorist bombings -even a tiger hunt partly seen through the eyes of the tiger. Along the way, we learn much about the Far East. Too much, in fact. Nevertheless, Mr. Diehl knows how to tell a story, and his novel moves along at a good pace. Unfortunately, too many ''colorful'' characters get in the way of the narrative as he scrambles to tie up all the loose ends.

title: STATE TAKING LEAD IN COURT TRANSLATION
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY has taken the national lead in attempting to provide qualified interpreters for non-English-speaking people in court, a response to a 1985 State Supreme Court task force that found that language services in state and municipal courts did not meet minimum levels of competence.

title: Q and A
description: Closing Without a Lawyer

title: U.P.I. News Service to Cut Its Local Coverage
description: United Press International is planning to reduce its coverage of local news and instead concentrate on major news events in an effort to put the company back on a solid financial footing, a U.P.I. spokesman said today.

title: Early Early Music: Still a Fight
description: A FEW DECADES AGO, THE term ''early music'' carried the implication of quaintness, oddity and distance, and described a vast literature that ran from medieval troubador songs to the dawn of the Classical symphony. As musicologists supplied theories about ancient performing practices, established a hierarchy among medieval, Renaissance and Baroque composers, and fleshed out the lists of those composers' works, ensembles specializing in subdivisions within the genre flourished. Yet, until the late 1970's, a distinct boundary separated this literature from the ''modern'' symphonic, operatic and chamber music mainstream - a repertory that begins with the Classicists, gets into full gear for the Romantics, and makes its way somewhat more fitfully through the 20th century.

title: WINGED KEEL HITS THE MARKET
description: THE winged-keel concept that in 1983 helped Alan Bond's marauding Australians lift the America's Cup from its longtime resting place at the New York Yacht Club did more than set the world of sailboat racing on its ear. Once the Australian yacht designer Ben Lexcen had proved the concept on the race course, manufacturers of production sailboats could see the benefits for family cruisers. This week at the New York National Boat Show, boat buyers can shop among a variety of resulting designs for cruising.

title: LEMON LAW BEARS FRUIT FOR CAR OWNER
description: I would like to urge every car owner who qualifies to seek redress under the New York State Lemon Law and not through Autocap or the Better Business Bureau [ ''Car Buyers Get a Referee in Disputes With Dealers,'' Dec. 13 ] .

title: Estate Planning for Disabled Children
description: WHEN parents of a disabled child draw up an estate plan, they face a concern that other parents do not. While other adult children may be fully independent and in no need of a legacy, a disabled child may be left more vulnerable than ever by a parent's death.

title: Wall Hangings From Oaxaca
description: THE cacti, dwarf trees and small farm plots that dot the vast plateau of the Mexican state of Oaxaca create subtle harmonies of green and ocher right up to the jagged gray profile of the Sierra Madre. As the Pan American Highway traces an unswerving black line across this alto plano, or high plane, a blue signpost overhead indicates, by a pattern of white lines symbolizing interwoven threads, the turnoff for Teotitlan del Valle. The name means ''God-place of the Valley,'' but it is locally known as the town of 5,000 weavers.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: At the Haunted End of the Day: A Profile of Sir William Walton With Julian Bream, Yehudi Menuhin, Laurence Olivier, others. Directed by Tony Palmer. 1981. Kultur. 100 minutes. $59.95.

title: THE ROAD TO SELF-RELIANCE
description: I hope the irony of the Nyack Boys School is not lost on Michael Norman. The place where boys learned that the fundamental lesson of manhood is the ''lesson of separation'' and where ''the road to independence and self-reliance . . . insured forever the loneliness'' - that place became a therapeutic center for children with behavioral and emotional problems. GALEN J. GUENGERICH Chicago

title: BROWNS STOP COLTS: Kosar's Passing Leads 38-21 Triumph
description: On their painted, icy field, the Cleveland Browns disposed of one bad memory and one real obstacle today by beating the Indianapolis Colts in their American Conference semifinal playoff game.

title: Steps Urged in Report on Market Are Likely Never to Be Acted On
description: The key recommendations for reordering the regulation of the nation's financial markets included in the report of a Presidential commission are likely to be tied up in Congressional debate and may never be acted on, lawmakers and regulatory experts said today.

title: ST. PETER'S TOPS IONA IN 2 OVERTIMES
description: Alex Roberts scored a career-high 33 points and Chuck Veterano had all 6 of his points in the second overtime today as St. Peter's beat Iona, 81-76, in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game.

title: Randolph K. Byers; Pediatrician and Neurologist, 91
description: Dr. Randolph K. Byers, a Milton, Mass., pediatrician and child neurologist, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday. He was 91 years old.

title: NONFICTION
description: THUMBS UP: The Life and Courageous Comeback of White House Press Secretary Jim Brady. By Mollie Dickenson. (Morrow, $19.95.) Most of us are familiar with the tragic and heroic story of Jim Brady, the White House press secretary; now, Mollie Dickenson, a journalist, has given us a more complete portrait of the man. Leading with the events of March 30, 1981, when Mr. Brady was critically wounded in John Hinckley's failed attempt to assassinate President Reagan, the author goes into absorbing clinical detail about Mr. Brady's injury and the surreal scene at George Washington University Hospital (including Uzi-toting Secret Service agents clad in surgical greens). She deftly intercuts the account of Mr. Brady's recovery with the story of his life and political greening, from Illinois ward politics to the Pentagon and finally to the Reagan campaign. Threaded throughout are anecdotes, most of them garnered from journalists, Washington cronies and Mr. Brady himself, that add up to an informal social history of Republican politics since the mid-1970's. Ms. Dickenson's most important point is that a stronger role for Mr. Brady might have made the Reagan White House a more ideologically temperate place. Mr. Brady is a dyed-in-the-wool moderate and Ms. Dickenson maintains that White House staff, not John Hinckley's bullet, have kept his presence from being more strongly felt. Ms. Dickenson was faced with the task of writing about a genuinely nice guy overcoming extraordinary odds - and she succeeds without being excessively partisan or maudlin.

title: Safety Pins Flap
description: IT was Sigrid Wolf of Austria who had the fastest run in the season's third World Cup super-giant slalom in Lech Am Arlberg, Austria, yesterday, but after investigating complaints from rival coaches the official jury decided there was something a bit too fast about the run - the starting number on Wolf's ski suit.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Lakefront Projects on a Saltwater Island
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Long Island has more than 1,000 linear miles of shoreline, its sandy soil is not conducive to freshwater lakes, and the few that exist are for the most part in parks or nature preserves.

title: MARIA SICURELLI WEDS
description: Maria Adriana Sicurelli, a daughter of Dr. Robert J. Sicurelli of North Salem, N.Y., and Marie DiCapua of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Andrew Scott Wist, the son of Reba Psaty Wist of Brooklyn and the late Milton Wist. Justice Martin Schneier of New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated at the St. Regis-Sheraton in Manhattan. The bride is a dental hygenist and the bridegroom is the president of the Standard Waterproofing Corporation and the Wist Development Corporation, both in Manhattan.

title: A STEADY GIRL WITH A BREAD KNIFE
description: LOVING ROGER By Tim Parks. 151 pp. New York: Grove Press. $15.95.

title: ECLECTIC FOOD, DRAMATIC SETTING
description: YOUR PLACE . . . OR MINE, in Williston Park, is not a yuppie watering hole where the gang can go for buffalo wings. Nor is it a dark roadhouse rendezvous with dewy-eyed couples holding hands in the corners. It's a startlingly attractive restaurant serving well-prepared, eclectic food.

title: PROPOSED RATE RISE FOR HOSPITALS CRITICIZED
description: The New Jersey Hospital Association has moved to increase all hospital rates as if it were opening a sales campaign for a new soap product.

title: Afghan Hints at a Soviet Reconciliation Policy
description: Afghanistan's party leader, Najibullah, has suggested in recent speeches in Hanoi and Phnom Penh that the Soviet Union may be moving toward a broad policy for trying to end conflicts bleeding some of its allies in the developing world.

title: 2 Die in Plane Crash
description: A jet carrying 1,500 pounds of packages for Federal Express crashed before dawn Friday on its approach to an airport here, apparently killing both pilots. One pilot's body was found, and divers searched the Ouachita River for the other, a spokesman for the local sheriff said. The names of the pilots were not immediately released.

title: In Gaza, Confrontation at Crossroads of History; How Much Force?
description: To the Editor:

title: AS AUSTERITY NEARS, WARSAW RELAXES RULES FOR AN ELITE
description: POLISH sociologists, taking advantage of less restrictive travel rules, recently renewed academic links with the West that were severed under martial law six years ago.

title: What to Do With Worthless Options
description: STOCK options took a bath in the October stock plunge, forcing corporate boards to wrestle with two problems: First, should they make up the losses for executives whose profits from options were wiped out by the collapse? Second, given the market's volatility, how could options be tailored to provide a buffer against a repeat performance?

title: Q&A
description: East Berlin Question: To make the most of a day visiting East Berlin, do you recommend a guided tour or going on my own? What costs are involved? -B. B. R., Cleveland Heights, Ohio Answer: Travelers who feel they will be satisfied by a four-hour excursion to East Berlin should consider taking a bus tour arranged by a West Berlin travel agency. Like strangers in any foreign city, they will almost certainly see more on a first visit by taking a tour than by trying to find their way around on their own. Joining a tour is the only way to get a guided visit in English.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SIEG HEIL! War Letters of Tank Gunner Karl Fuchs, 1937-1941. Edited and translated by Horst Fuchs Richardson. Historical commentary by Dennis E. Showalter. (Archon/Shoe String, $25.) When Adolf Hitler came to power, many of Germany's young men were ready for his fanaticism and his visions. Gone were the dark clouds of despair that followed the Great War and the capitulation of the Kaiser; now it was to be Sieg Heil!

title: WHALERS' HISTORY IN WORDS AND PICTURES
description: LEAD: PROFESSIONAL ice hockey thrives in Connecticut as Jack V. Lautier describes it in his recent book entitled ''The First Fifteen Years of Whalers' Hockey,'' about the rise of the Hartford franchise.

title: Refugee Family Facing Ouster
description: AS Dr. Tomas Koppany and his wife, Kornelia Nagy, tell it, they gave up prosperous jobs as lawyers in Hungary, a desirable apartment in Budapest, a summer cottage in a lake resort and a sizable bank account -not because they prefer poverty.

title: SAVED BY HIS PROLETARIANISM
description: IN THE NAME OF THE WORKING CLASS The Inside Story of the Hungarian Revolution. By Sandor Kopacsi. Translated by Daniel Stoffman and Judy Stoffman. 304 pp. New York: Grove Press. $17.95.

title: EAST AMWELL WRESTLES WITH ITS FUTURE
description: LEAD: IN 1968, when Richard Ginman moved here, he considered this Hunterdon County area rural and remote - although convenient to his job in Trenton - and likely to remain so.

title:
GARDENING;
THE DIVERSITY AND USEFULNESS OF CONIFERS
description: LEAD: CONIFERS, or cone-bearing evergreens, are just as popular in the garden as they are for holiday decorations. While the most interesting landscapes use both deciduous and evergreen plants, the conifers are so diverse it is entirely possible to develop a garden with year-round interest using only them.

title: Clones and Grafts As Ballet Traits
description: BUILDING A BALLET COMPANY demands more than the training of dancers. It also requires assembling a repertory. But that is no easy task. Repertory-building is a challenge shared by the artistic directors of ballet companies everywhere.

title: Restricting Farming to Farmers
description: Initiative 300 critics is that by strict enforcement of the tough constitutional language, the electorate's support of the constitutional amendment will weaken.

title:
BUYING AND SELLING IN A WEAKENED MARKET;
In Huntington, the Attanasios May Lose a $20,000 Deposit
description: LEAD: ON Oct. 19, Joseph Attanasio, a floor broker on the New York Stock Exchange, was on the front lines as the market crashed. While his business has continued to prosper, his prospects of finding a buyer for his Huntington, L.I., house have worsened.

title: FICTION
description: THE PIOUS DANCE: The Adventure Story of a Young Man. By Klaus Mann. Translated by Laurence Senelick. (PAJ Publications, $15.95.) In this 1925 novel, written when its author (Thomas Mann's son) was 19 years old, everything - carnivals, despair, erotic love, bug bites - is experienced with the solemn rhapsodic intensity of romantic youth, a mood reminiscent of Rimbaud that is skillfully captured in Laurence Senelick's translation. Leaving behind his cultured provincial family, young Andreas Magnus comes to Berlin in search of reality and suffering and becomes embroiled in the labyrinthine homosexual underworld of the city. He performs in cabarets with an aging transvestite and a pitiful former prostitute, both of whom fall in love with him; he in turn falls in love with a beautiful hedonist, Niels, who torments and rejects him. While the shrill, sad revels of his doomed circle grow more and more frenzied, Andreas's quest for meaning leads him into mysticism. Haunted by dreams of the Virgin Mary, he purchases a rosary and drapes it reverently over his only photograph of Niels. At last, after Niels disappears, Andreas is finally released from his pain by the revelation that to love another being and suffer for him is to become acceptable to God. The reader of ''The Pious Dance'' may hunger at times for more causality and human interaction, conversations and personalities rather than gratuitous acts and poetic talk of essences. But compared to the psychopathic cool of the characters depicted by fashionable young writers today, Andreas's feverish sorrow, his religious yearnings, his anguished meditations seem not only touchingly innocent but even morally admirable.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
For a Little Falls Mill, a Bright New Life
description: LEAD: FOR more than a century Little Falls has lived with the Beattie Carpet Mill, which covers 13 acres along the Passaic River and overlooks the falls that gave the township its name.

title: Creatures Great and Small Split Rural Town
description: LOUIS CRECHETTI is not your average pig farmer. He spends his day teaching engineering at the University of Hartford. But, come dusk, you'll find him in his Granby barn, tending his pigs and sheep.

title: BYRNE ARENA: IS IT PRIVATE OR PUBLIC?
description: LEAD: THE North Jersey chapter of a national Irish-American unity group has sued the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, contending it prohibits demonstrations at a ''public'' site, the Brendan T. Byrne Arena in East Rutherford.

title: HAVE AN URGE FOR A GOOD BOWL OF SOUP?
description: IN winter I could eat soup every day. For lunch, I like nothing better than a bowl of hot soup and a sandwich. I also like seasonal winter soups for dinner, thick vegetable soups that are almost like stews, with additions of lentils, beans, pasta, rice or potatoes. I like to serve them in large deep bowls, along with some fresh French bread, with cheese and salad to follow.

title: MOVIES
description: That's Life! Starring Julie Andrews, Jack Lemmon, Robert Loggia and Sally Kellerman. Directed by Blake Edwards. 1987. Vestron Video 102 minutes. $79.98.

title: MOVIES
description: Street Smart Starring Christopher Reeve, Morgan Freeman. Directed by Jerry Schatzberg. 1987. Media Home Entertainment. 97 minutes. $79.95.

title: Special Gift Of Concerto Conducting
description: LAST FALL, JORGE BOLET PLAYED A lovely run of performances of the Grieg Piano Concerto with the New York Philharmonic. But what made them lovely was not just the pianist's own brand of commanding, diffident elegance. It was also the orchestral accompaniment - forthright on its own; properly subservient yet never self-effacing in partnership with the pianist.

title: New Delhi Struggles With Haze of Pollution
description: Most days of this sharp, cool winter - as in previous winters - a thick, dirty blue haze settles across much of the Indian capital, causing an increase in sore throats, colds and other respiratory ailments.

title: THE PRIVATE PAIN OF INFERTILITY
description: In reading Gwen Davis's article ''The Private Pain of Infertility'' (Dec. 6), I was struck by the many similarities to my own situation, and a few major differences.

title: Murder Charges Dismissed In Death of Deformed Baby
description: A judge has dismissed murder charges against a father awaiting a third trial for flinging his deformed newborn son to the delivery room floor.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Rye Weighs Plan to Preserve Waterfront
description: ''IT doesn't take Bernard Baruch to figure it out,'' said Peter Fischbein, part owner of the Nichols Yacht Yards in Rye, which is being sold for development.

title: FOES AND SUPPORTERS URGING ARIZONA GOVENOR TO RESIGN
description: Opponents and some supporters of Gov. Evan Mecham are urging that he consider stepping down while he responds to his indictment on charges of fraud, perjury and filing a false campaign financial report.

title: THE ISRAELIS: RIOTS UNIFY THE UNITY GOVERNMENT - FOR NOW By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN
description: NOW, the 64,000-shekel question: What is the impact on Israeli party politics of the recent Palestinian protests in the occupied territories? Answer: Virtually none - so far.

title: Knicks Stun Celtics As Jackson Stars
description: Mark Jackson, the Knicks' rookie playmaker, has had so many outstanding games, it is difficult to pinpoint his best one.

title: The Accuracy Keeps Improving
description: IT is no secret that forecasts of the economy are fallible. As a nonexperimental social science, economics cannot achieve the degree of precision that physicists attain in measuring the speed of light or even the lower degree achieved by meteorologists in predicting tomorrow's precipitation. It is less widely understood that, despite several notable mistakes, economic forecasters have been able to predict some, though not all, important economic variables better than simple rules of thumb and that their accuracy seems to have increased over time.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: NIGHT SIEGE: THE HUDSON VALLEY U.F.O. SIGHTINGS by Dr. J. Allen Hynek and Philip J. Imbrogno, with Bob Pratt. Ballantine. 208 pages. $6.95.

title: WORLDWIDE ODYSSEY LEADS TO PGA TOUR
description: HE used to joke when he talked about the difficulty of getting into professional golf events without a tour card.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: Chris Mullin is Bill Bradley reincarnate: a team player in constant motion who has a very good shot when he is open. Just like Trent Tucker. Based on Pitino's pitiful progress in getting his players to set picks and screens for Tucker, Mullin would fare no better. KEN ROSENBERG New York

title: A JUNE WEDDING FOR TRACY JACOBY
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Jacoby of Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement of Mr. Jacoby's daughter, Tracy Lynne Jacoby, to John Wells Stevens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Stevens of New Canaan, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt.

title: Headliners; Ousting the Boss
description: It was propelled flight of a sort that was being arranged last week for C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive of the Pan Am Corporation, but it was unlikely he was looking forward to the trip. According to sources who described a private meeting in New York City attended by ranking representatives of various contending parties, a representative of Pan Am's board offered to dismiss Mr. Acker and Martin R. Shugrue Jr., the vice chairman; the price was $180 million a year in pay cuts and other concessions from the five unions that represent the company's Pan American World Airways subsidiary. The unions, accusing Mr. Acker of mismanagement during the six years he has been trying to turn the ailing airline around, have been trying for a year to get rid of him. As of last week at least one union had agreed to the concessions.

title: 'The Health of Nations'
description: To the Editor:

title: India Replaces a Top General in Sri Lanka
description: India has replaced a senior military commander in northern Sri Lanka after months of speculation that New Delhi had been dissatified about his handling of the Indian peacekeeping force there.

title: RADIO STATIONS AND SHOREHAM ISSUE
description: More than one ''knowledgeable'' person has asked me why WGLI-AM agreed to continue to be member station of the Lilco emergency broadcast system [ ''Emergency Broadcast Plan Decided,'' Dec. 13 ] .

title: Zaire Mission's Debts in New York Prompt Concern at U.N.
description: Zaire's Permanent Mission to the United Nations owes landlords and companies in the New York region more than $150,000 in rent and other bills, with many of those debts outstanding for more than half a year, according to complaints filed with various official United States bodies by Zaire's creditors.

title: Verbatim: Britain's 'Cure'
description: 'They used, when I first came in, to talk about us in terms of the British disease. Now they talk about us and say, ''Look, Britain has got the cure. Come to Britain to see how Britain has done it.'' That is an enormous turn-round. And it has brought hope to others as well.' Margaret Thatcher in an interview last week on the occasion of her becoming Britain's longest-serving Prime Minister of the 20th century.

title: KATHERINE H. HELLER, DOCTORAL STUDENT, PLANS TO WED JOHN R. HEWITT, LAWYER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Blanchfield Heller of Bedford, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Holland Heller, to John Robert Hewitt, the son of Donald Birch Hewitt of San Diego and the late Edith Marie Hewitt.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: There is no one in the N.B.A. that can make more of an impact for the Knicks than Chris Mullin. He has the intellect that can help solidify the defense and a jump shot that would rock the Garden. BOB LEE Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title:
ANTIQUES;
LEARNING TO CARE FOR TEXTILE COLLECTIONS
description: LEAD: THE 1,500 or so items comprising the extensive costume collection at the Drake House Museum here will be aired, selectively repaired and properly stored under the provisions of a grant recently awarded by the New Jersey Historical Commission.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
COMEDY
description: LEAD: Chevy Chase Lorimar Home Video. 60 minutes. $19.95.

Marlboro, N.J. $280,000 71 School Road East 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; new roof, deck, Franklin stove; taxes $2,405.

title: YANKEE AFFAIR WINS APPLETON AT GULFSTREAM
description: Yankee Affair benefited from an inside start in a field of 14 but proved clearly best while scoring a three-length victory over Performing Pappy and King's River today in the $100,000 Appleton Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: NEW YORK IS WORTH A NOVEL - ARE YOU?
description: THE reviewers agree that Tom Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' is the New York City novel -but not much has been said about what kind of New York City Mr. Wolfe offers us. He is generally considered to be a brilliant reporter - yet no one seems to be reading past his headlines, past the scandal. It's almost as if we were afraid to look more closely, to be burned in the bonfire.

title: Bernie Kosar's Climate
description: AS sharp and as cold as a knife blade that had been left overnight on the ice along the Lake Erie shore, the wind sliced through the 78,586 customers pounding their mittens together on the slopes of Cleveland Stadium's tundra. This was pro football the way it always is here during the Super Bowl playoffs. The way it oughta be. The way it must be. Snow on the sideline. The frozen field painted green to try to fool the television viewers into thinking that it's grass instead of dirt.

title:
INVESTING;
Analysts Warm to Kysor
description: LEAD: THE Kysor Industrial Corporation, based in Cadillac, Mich., plies a fairly mundane trade: manufacturing refrigeration displays for supermarkets and component parts for trucks. But the company's progress - and its conservative financial management - have caught the eye of a handful of analysts and money managers.

title: Swallowing Hutton in 1,200 Bites
description: THEY were taking turns at the microphone a few weeks ago in the auditorium of Shearson Lehman Brothers' data-processing center in downtown Manhattan. About 225 managers entrusted with carrying out the firm's merger with E. F. Hutton & Company lined up to give their weekly progress reports to Leonard V. Haynes, Shearson's 51-year-old, cigar-chomping operations chief.

title: STREETSCAPES: West-Park Presbyterian; An 1890 West Side Church Fighting Landmark Status
description: DESIGNATING religious properties as landmarks is a sensitive subject. Churches have opposed such designation, fearing a loss of not only religious freedom but the flexibility to deal with property that often is difficult to maintain.

title: IN DEFENSE OF LIBERTY PARK'S MARINA
description: ''CROWN jewel,'' ''treasure,''

title: ROSENTHAL APPOINTED EDITOR AT G.P. PUTNAM
description: A. M. Rosenthal, a columnist and former executive editor of The New York Times, has been named editor at large at G. P. Putnam, the publishing house announced yesterday.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SPARTANBURG, S.C.;
Golf and Lakes Spur Project
description: LEAD: BUILDERS are transforming 11,000 acres of farm and timberland here into a huge development with an 18-hole golf course as its centerpiece.

title: Arias: Whom Can He Trust?
description: IT WAS MIDDAY AND THE President of Costa Rica was hungry. Pausing just long enough to invite a visitor along, he hopped in his blue Honda Accord and drove to a nearby corner restaurant. The President brought along his sunglasses but left his bodyguards behind.

title: ROUGH AND TOUGH
description: THE PROFESSIONALS Starring Burt Lancaster (in photo), Lee Marvin, Robert Ryan, Ralph Bellamy, Jack palance, Woody Strode, Claudia Cardinale. 1966.

title: TOTS ON THE FAST TRACK
description: MISEDUCATION Preschoolers at Risk. By David Elkind. 221 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: UBIQUITOUS PESTS
description: CATALOGUES are arriving; before tossing out the old ones, check them to be sure garden notes and plans are not discarded. Use calcium chloride on icy steps and walks; keep it dry so it does not cake. Start petunias, snapdragons and other long-season seed indoors. Mealybugs

title: POSTINGS: Roosevelt Island Tour; 25th Anniversary
description: Howard Goldberg remembers the first tour he led of Roosevelt Island in 1963. Student firemen leaped from buildings set ablaze as part of their graduation ceremony. The training center is no longer on the East River island; neither are the almshouse, the prison and the New York City Lunatic Asylum. Today, Roosevelt Island - renamed from Welfare Island in 1973 - is a community for 6,800 residents. ''The island is changing every time you visit it,'' Mr. Goldberg said.

title: ARTS AND CRAFTS FOR THE COLLECTORS
description: RECENT stamp issues can be used to form a collection within a collection. Pottery, fine jewelry and native crafts can be gathered for an international arts and crafts fair within the confines of a stamp album.

title: BRIDGE PLAYERS HAVE NO KNUCKLES
description: AS a kid, I ate corn mush for breakfast and tomato-soup gravy for dinner, but I learned tough from hard-nosed card games like euchre and pinochle. These were Midwestern card games that set brother against brother, parent against child.

title: 'BRIGHT LIGHTS, BIG CITY' -- BIG TROUBLE
description: MICHAEL J. FOX HAS BEEN dragged by the collar, thrashing and yelling, down the length of a fashion-show runway and tossed out the door several times. Now, resting between takes on the set of ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' he's sitting in the second-floor foyer of the Parsons School of Design in Manhattan, joking with his real-life bodyguard, who plays the fashion-show bouncer on screen, and talking to Jay McInerney. Suddenly Fox and McInerney look at each other and sing out, as if on cue, ''Spo-o-o-ky!''

title: HART'S 1984 DEBTS MAKE THE 1988 CAMPAIGNS NERVOUS
description: ON a national television program last week, a caller from Connecticut told Gary Hart that she was ''sick of hearing about your sleeping habits.''

title: English and Other Languages
description: To the Editor:

title: MARTHA COX IS MARRIED TO THOMAS FARRELL JR.
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, Martha Bancroft Cox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Cox of London and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Vail Farrell Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Farrell of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Dr. Hays H. Rockwell, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: NEW COUNCIL TAKES ITS FIRST STEPS
description: A NEW Yonkers government began work on an uncertain note last week, appointing an interim city manager while beginning the search for a full-time administrator and seeking a unified stand on the divisive housing desegregation issue.

title: THE UTTER SADNESS OF THE SURVIVOR
description: THE DROWNED AND THE SAVED By Primo Levi. Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. 203 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: FAIRFIELD 2000 SHOWS PROBLEMS ARE SIMILAR
description: The recently released Fairfield 2000 Report now takes its place alongside Westchester 2000. With it comes the recognition of just how many problems in the two counties are intertwined.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I am finishing my attic to add a workroom, so I want to add insulation to the roof (it is now on the attic floor). I have been told to allow for ventilation above the insulation - between the insulation and the roof sheathing - but am not sure how to do this. Can you tell me if this is really necessary, and if so where vents should be located?

title: ONE-YEAR PACTS MAY BE MAKING A COMEBACK
description: AT the rate the length of player contracts is shrinking, the players and the owners will soon be back to the days before free agents - the time of the one-year contract - or they will be immersed in a labor dispute that could severely intrude on the 1990 season.

title: MISS THOMPSON TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Announcement of the engagement of Claudia Rose Thompson to William Jay Iselin has been made by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Thompson of Winchester, Hampshire, England. Mr. Iselin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Jay Iselin of New York, and Vinalhaven, Me. A June wedding is planned.

title: WHEN FILM IS LOST...
description: THE holidays are over, you've just finished your semiannual roll of film, and you're waiting for the prints to come back from the processor. You wait and wait. Weeks pass. Could it be that your most treasured memories have vanished without a trace?

title: U.S. Olympic Team Is Finally Set
description: The figure-skating team that will represent the United States next month in the Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, emerged today, after a hectic 24-hour period in which 12 of the 16 team members were determined and several judging decisions were questioned.

title: ROBIN EISENBERG WEDS
description: At the Woodmere (L.I.) Club, Robin Sue Eisenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Eisenberg of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., was married last evening to Daniel B. Kula, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Kula of Jericho, L.I. Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz and Cantor Lazar Wax officiated. Mrs. Kula, a graduate of George Washington University, is an account executive for Parfums Stern in Miami. Mr. Kula, a sales representative for Owens & Minor, a distributor of medical supplies in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., graduated from the University of Maryland.

title: ROBIN STARR IS ENGAGED TO WED NEAL J. BERMAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Starr of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Starr to Neal Jason Berman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Berman of Needham, Mass.

title: A Top Machine Carries a Top Price
description: THE Compaq Deskpro 386-20 personal computer is the most powerful PC an executive can buy. It is certainly the fastest one I've ever used - and the most expensive, too. Both its speed and price are likely to take your breath away.

title: Unbidden, Confessions In a Dining Car
description: IN my life, the two points between which I must routinely travel are Union Station in Washington, D.C., and Penn Station in Manhattan. If I am feeling rushed, I pay a bit more for the Metroliner, which gets me back and forth a little faster. Otherwise I take the regular train that stops for more pilgrims in its progress along the way. But whatever train I take, I always head for the dining car, where I can spread my books, papers and coffee cups around and pretend that I am sitting at my own kitchen table and not on a trip at all. Usually, somebody else will take the seat across from me. Depending upon my mood, I do or don't look up.

title: The Weather
description: To the Editor: The Nov. 1 Q & A column provided information about weather conditions for travelers. Since March of last year, American Express has provided Accu-Weather forecasts to card members through our Global Assist Hotline. The forecasts, updated twice daily, are available for 220 cities in the United States and throughout the world. SUSAN CLARK New York, N.Y.

title: NEW INVENTIONS FROM THE CORNFIELD
description: OF all the Christmas gifts exchanged on Capitol Hill last month, few attracted more interest than the biodegradable plastic bags Senator Tom Harkin included in the baskets of Iowa farm products that he delivered to colleagues. The bags, which are designed to decompose after a year or two, are at the head of a growing list of industrial products made with corn, the nation's largest and most important crop.

title: U.S. IS DEVELOPING SURVEILLANCE JET THAT ELUDES RADAR
description: The Air Force is secretly developing a long-range reconnaissance aircraft that will incorporate technology designed to permit the plane to evade detection by radar, Defense Department officials say.

title: Broadcast TV
description: A varied batch of worthy films from works by well-known authors dots the week's agenda. Topping the list, because it's so rarely shown, is ''The Beachcomber'' (1938), a wonderfully pungent version of Somerset Maugham's ''Vessel of Wrath,'' with Charles Laughton and Elsa Lanchester - Saturday at 11:30 P.M. on Channel 21. Mr. and Mrs. Laughton are simply superb in this wise, wry South Seas tale of an island rake and a prim missionary. The last scene, in a sedate English pub, caps the movie like a bottletop.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: Yes. The Knicks need a scoring forward like a viper needs fangs. Without one, their offense is severely limited. If Mullin can play basketball the way he did with an alcohol problem, imagine what he can do with the problem under control. TROY WEXLER Warren, N.J.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: Robert Vickrey: Lyrical Realist Nauset Light Productions. artsAmerica. 203-869-4693. 28 minutes. $39.95.

title: Death Turns Attention to the New York Moose
description: One of New York State's rare moose has died, the victim of either a gunshot wound or a collision with a car, according to state wildlife experts.

title: SRI LANKA: A NATION DISINTEGRATES
description: The picture of Tamil fighters looking over the bodies of Indian soldiers vividly portrays the tragedy of conflicts inspired by mistaken ethnic pride (''Sri Lanka: A Nation Disintegrates,'' by Steven R. Weisman, Dec. 13). The young Tamils stare in disbelief at what they have done. There is neither joy nor celebration of victory; just plain shock and a pall of gloom descending on the blood bath.

title: U.F.T. USES ITS POWER TO PULL A PUNCH
description: AFTER Robert F. Wagner Jr. disclosed last week that he had threatened to resign as president of New York City's Board of Education unless Sandra Feldman relaxed her grip on the process of selecting the next schools chancellor, she said, ''It was my pleasure to be able to save Bobby Wagner's job and get an excellent chancellor in the process.''

title: ON POWER AND HISTORY: WHAT MARGUERITE YOURCENAR KNEW
description: WHEN I was seated by Marguerite Yourcenar at a dinner given in her honor last February in New York - the occasion of her receiving the medal of the Commander of the French Legion of Honor and the National Arts Club's Medal of Honor for Literature - I placed before her my copy of ''Memoirs of Hadrian,'' which she had previously agreed to autograph. She had evidently already considered what she would write in it, for she rapidly inscribed her approval of this ''good'' first edition, the only one not marred by misprints. She then appended in solid capitals the words ''LIBERTAS, HUMANITAS, FELICITAS,'' the motto engraved on Hadrian's coins. Thus moving from the exactly rendered particular to the broader universal, she put me in mind, however irreverently, of the lady with the squint in the Edward Lear limerick who ''Could scan the whole sky / With her uppermost eye / While the other was reading small print.''

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I am finishing my attic to add a workroom, so I want to add insulation to the roof (it is now on the attic floor). I have been told to allow for ventilation above the insulation - between the insulation and the roof sheathing - but am not sure how to do this. Can you tell me if this is really necessary, and if so where vents should be located?

title: Community Seeks End To Redevelopment Ban
description: The Clinton community board has unanimously approved a zoning change to end a ban on redevelopment of local apartment buildings in which tenants have been harassed by landlords.

title: The Portman Formula in Miniature
description: JOHN PORTMAN is perhaps the best-known hotel architect in the world. His Hyatt Regency in Atlanta, completed in 1967, was the first postwar hotel with a central atrium, and it changed the nature of hotels everywhere, replacing the banal boxes of the Hiltons and Sheratons with the Portman trademarks of vast atrium spaces, fountains and glass-enclosed elevators. Mr. Portman spent the 1970's designing one hotel after another - each one, it seemed, bigger and showier than the one before. But his real dream, he had said for a long time, was to design a different kind of hotel, a hotel that would free him from the stereotype of the architect as producer of extravaganzas; it would also prove that he could design a small luxury hotel, a building that would rank as a serious work of architecture as well as set new standards for hotelkeeping.

title: MELISSA ROSSE TO WED COLM DOBBYN IN JUNE
description: Melissa Thompson Rosse and Colm James Dobbyn, the son of Mrs. Oliver Dobbyn of Cliffside Park, N.J., and the late Mr. Dobbyn, plan to marry in June, the future bride's mother, June P. Rosse of Brooklyn, has announced.

title: lONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: WALTER A. GREEN; GETTING MEETINGS ON RIGHT TRACK
description: ALTHOUGH American executives spend close to half their time in meetings, Walter A. Green believes that most are not meeting well.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: Mullin can be had cheap, can blend well with the team and will make his outside shots. If the Knicks don't try to get Mullin, perhaps they should try to rehire Hubie Brown. JONATHAN GLICK New York

title: Mountains
description: To the Editor: Not to diminish Lesley Hazelton's fine endorsement of mountain ascents, ''Because It's There'' (Travel, Nov. 29), a slight correction is in order. Mount Monadnock is such an approachable and adoptable peak precisely because it is not above the tree line. Its summit is artificially bare, devastated by fire. KATHLEEN INGOLDSBY Floyd, Va.

title: MS. PLATT TO WED HARLAN H. SIMON
description: The engagement of Eden Michele Platt to Harlan H. Simon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Simon of Pomona, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon N. Platt of Scarsdale, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: THRILL OF THE SNOWMOBILE POSES PROBLEMS FOR FARMERS
description: THE roar of snowmobiles is being heard across fields and forests, but farm and conservation officials say the recreational vehicles are crushing crops and seedlings under the snow.

title: Texas
description: To the Editor: In his interesting article about Austin, Tex. (Travel, Nov. 8), Peter H. Lewis says that often in the morning the Hill Country is covered with a purple haze. Those two words, like magic, immediately called to mind pleasant but hitherto long-dormant memories from my teen-age years when I first read one of the many exciting Western novels by Zane Grey, namely, ''Riders of the Purple Sage,'' with the cowboy mystery man, Lassiter, dressed in black. Thus, from now on, when I have memories of that thrilling tale of Grey's, I can fantasize in Technicolor and envision Lassiter, dressed in black, riding his horse amid the purple sage and disappearing into the morning's purple haze. WILLIAM OLEKSAK New York, N.Y.

title:
ART;
CUTOUTS: IMAGES ESCAPE THE PAINTING
description: LEAD: AT the branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art in nearby Stamford, Conn., is a lively survey called ''Contemporary Cutouts,'' a phenomenon that, as its organizers point out, has its roots in Pop Art. At its most essential, the cutout boldly escapes the conventional confines of a frame and enters the viewer's space.

title: For Dukakis at Home, Hard Legislative Year Special to The New York Times
description: LEAD: Just before the Massachusetts legislative year ended three days ago, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis sat slumped in a receptionist's chair in his executive suite, surrounded by aides who briefed him on the night's bad news.

title:
CRITIC'S CHOICES;
Art
description: LEAD: Christopher James's garden photographs are part of a curious collection of sculptures, paintings, drawings, old engravings, modern installations and photographs both old and new that goes under the title ''Classical Concerns'' at the Twining Gallery (586 Broadway, through Jan. 20). With ghostly statues from Muriel Castanis's ''Toga Series'' and enigmatic monuments like Christopher Hewat's ''Musee Ruse N314,'' the concerns are classical more in the post-modern way of Charles Jencks than in the traditional way of Henry Hope Reed.

title: VIEWS ON THE ROLE OF TRANSLATOR VARY
description: LEAD: ABOUT 15 years ago, Maurice Gilbert of Bloomfield, then a Spanish teacher for the Berlitz School, was asked by a relative to translate for him in Municipal Court.

title: WHAT SHE DID FOR LOVE
description: ALL IN A LIFETIME An Autobiography. By Ruth K. Westheimer with Ben Yagoda. Illustrated. 225 pp. New York: Warner Books. $17.95.

title: Vermont's Top Court Rejects Plea to Dismiss Zaccaro Case
description: The Vermont Supreme Court has rejected a request by lawyers for John A. Zaccaro Jr. to dismiss cocaine charges against him.

title: A MASTER OF THE MINI-SERIES
description: AMERICAN ACTORS ARE AS good as ours. American technicians are as good as ours. American executives are much more cowardly and will not risk their jobs. Ours will.''

title: Lola Beltran: Mariachi's Queen Ignites Hope, Soothes Hardship For Multitudes
description: THROUGHOUT MEXICO, across much of the rest of Latin America and among more than 12 million Mexican-Americans in the United States, she is known simply as La Reina - The Queen.

title: FANS HAVE LITTLE SYMPATHY FOR SYRACUSE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Denounce Those Who Engage in Racism and Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracking Down Lead Poisoning
description: MYSTERIOUSLY, one in every five children was being poisoned by lead in the poorest section of the town of Thompson in northeastern Connecticut.

title: LIBRARY USE AND L.I. GEOGRAPHY
description: In response to your article of Dec. 6 [ ''Library Access Prompts Feud'' ] , I would like to make it clear that there is no ''feud'' between the Smithtown Library and the Commack Public Library.

title: A BOATER'S CATALOGUE
description: IF there's anything boat owners love more than their boats, it's the gear and the accessories that they bring aboard. Sailors, fishermen and powerboat operators are all inveterate tinkerers and gadgeteers. The more space, time and energy that an instrument saves, the likelier that it will find a home aboard a well-found vessel. And that's why boats are only part of the attraction of the New York National Boat Show. Here is some of the latest and best marine gear for 1988:

title: Hike! uh, Ahoy!
description: WITH the America's Cup competition returning to its big-boat format, Dennis Conner, who won the cup for the San Diego Yacht Club with his 12-meter Stars & Stripes last winter, must have been wondering if there was any future for the little boats. Now Conner has come up with a way to keep a couple of 12-Meter craft in the public eye during Super Bowl week in San Diego.

title: Salving Market-Battered Managers
description: WHEN the stock market falls, the flight to safety begins. ''Companies are looking at different vehicles that give people an equity position, but protect them from volatility,'' said Ms. Meyer of Handy Associates.

title: HOMELESS SHOULD LIVE SUCH A DOG'S LIFE
description: If I were a homeless person in Westchester, I would immediately sign up to be a resident of the proposed Central Westchester Humane Society Shelter, where dogs and cats will live in a brand-new architect-designed $4 million edifice [ Westchester Journal, Dec. 6 ] . It's wonderful to know where our priorities are in Westchester County and that many corporations will be solicited and surely donate to the needy animals in our area. I am trying to recall when such a well-planned effort was made for the needy women and children who make up the greatest proportion of our homeless population.

title: STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES ACT TO SLOW EROSION OF FARM SOIL
description: SOME farm land in the state is losing topsoil at a rate of 40 tons per acre per year, about 10 times as fast as it replaces itself, according to state conservation officials.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: The Knicks don't need a slow, and possibly chemically dependent shooting guard. The Knicks should continue to build through the draft. BRITT BURR New York

title: BIG EAST LIGHTS UP, WARMING THE NORTHEAST
description: LONG before Tyson and Holmes could get at each other, the Big East provided the first punches of the new year. The couple of quick rights were thrown by - surprise, surprise - a Georgetown player who did not like the possessive way a Pitt player snatched away a held ball, and so, tried to punch a few heads.

title: HOME, HOME ON THE PUBLIC RANGE
description: THE KINGDOM IN THE COUNTRY By James Conaway. 293 pp. Boston: A Richard Todd Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: HORSE CARRIAGE, ANYONE? PRICELESS COLLECTION IS UP FOR SALE
description: ONE OF the state's most varied and valuable horse-carriage collections is about to be broken up.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CORPORATE STREAMLINING;
The Right Way to Shrink a Company
description: LEAD: LAST year's holiday season was a time of mixed blessings for many middle managers and staff professionals. The holidays coincided with the end of many corporate fiscal years, the time when the pressure is often greatest to increase results by cutting costs. Unfortunately this meant that for thousands the festive spirit was dampened by the news that they were losing their jobs.

title: THE PRIVATE PAIN OF INFERTILITY
description: My recollections as an obstetrics-gynecology practitioner in the early 1970's, at the time the Dalkon Shield was marketed, may be of interest. Patients who had been on the pill were so persuaded by articles in feminist magazines extolling the virtues of the shield that they would demand the shield and threaten to leave my practice if I did not oblige them. (You are poisoning my body, they would tell me.) Fortunately, I never liked the look of the shield, and so put in only one or two. ROBERT H. TICHELL, M.D. Rochester

title: Correction
description: A Sunday television highlight listing and a front-page picture caption today in The Guide, section 2A, misstate Mike Nichols's connection with the ABC comedy series ''The Thorns.'' He is the executive producer.

title: CATHERINE WICK ENGAGED TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Wick of Watertown, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Lee Wick, to Robert Michael McLean, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin B. McLean of Potomac, Md., and Rehoboth Beach, Del. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: The World of Mothers and Daughters
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping the Farms Just for the Farmers
description: LEAD: A NEW assault on Nebraska's constitutional ban against nonfamily corporate investment in the state's 44.9 million acres of farm real estate is under way here. It began obliquely a couple of months ago when the state's Department of Justice was prodded into trying, for the first time, to enforce the law .

title: Don't Make Bets on the Predictions
description: THE recent upheaval in the stock market proves once again how unpredictable the world is. Few forecasters had spotted the timing and extent of the fall; fewer still had foreseen the prolonged rise.

title: FEARS ON GROWTH DIVIDE RESIDENTS OF WATER MILL
description: IN what is likely to be the first test of a newly elected Southampton Town Supervisor's campaign pledge to give government back to the people, Mardythe DiPirro said recently she will pursue a six-month moratorium on commercial development in the hamlet of Water Mill.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Allendale $385,000 11 Berkshire Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, slate roof, deck; taxes $4,500. Lakewood $154,000 125 Mountainview Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; wall-to-wall carpeting, fireplace, 2-car attached garage; taxes $2,500. Marlboro $280,000 71 School Road East 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; new roof, deck, Franklin stove in living room; taxes $2,405. Short Hills $350,000 90 Wellington Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old Tudor; family room, eat-in kitchen, deck, finished basement; taxes $4,670. Springfield $241,250 77 Spring Brook Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; screened porch, den, fireplace, formal dining room; taxes $2,742. South Orange $495,000 35 Hart Drive North 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, C/A, deck, above-ground pool; taxes $7,860. OTHER AREAS Bay Shore, L.I. $650,000 55 Gardner Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fireplace, boat slip, 2 waterfront acres; taxes $10,000. Kent, Conn. $227,000 Bull's Bridge 5-bedrooms, 2-bath, 150-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, barn, .75 acre; taxes $1,294. Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. $272,000 7 Marianna Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, den, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $4,648.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MAKERS OF THE NEW: The Revolution in Literature, 1912-1939. By Julian Symons. (Random House, $19.95.) This lively history traces the development of British and American literary modernism in the years between the founding of Poetry magazine in Chicago in 1912 and the publication of ''Finnegans Wake'' in 1939.

title: Gore Is Openly Challenging Jackson For Black Voters in Southern States
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. is openly challenging the Rev. Jesse Jackson for a share of the black vote in the 14 Southern and border states that on March 8 will choose delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: A Ukrainian Troupe That Carries a Legacy
description: ONCE UPON A TIME IN THE Ukraine, there were Cossacks and Tartars, tambourines and magic boots, and the kind of impromptu dance competitions that Miroslav Vantukh watched years ago on summer evenings in the villages around Lvov.

title: SRI LANKA: A NATION DISINTEGRATES
description: It was surprising that Steven Weisman's article made no mention of an interesting and important personality in the recent history of Ceylon/Sri Lanka, Sirimavo Bandaranaike, who became the world's first female prime minister, in 1960. Her husband, Solomon West Ridgeway Dias Bandaranaike, had been assassinated the year before, and she was persuaded to take over the reins of his party, which won the general election the following year. This was six years before Indira Gandhi became Prime Minister of India, nine years before Golda Meir became Prime Minister of Israel and, of course, long before Margaret Thatcher became the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

title: FANS HAVE LITTLE SYMPATHY FOR SYRACUSE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Italy Taking Steps Against an Increase in Anti-Semitic Vandalism
description: Police protection of Jewish communities in Italy has been stepped up after an upsurge of anti-Semitic vandalism that coincides with the recent unrest in Israeli-occupied territories.

title: JUST GIVE ME A CHIP OFF THE OLD BACH
description: KICKED A MACHINE lately? Among music lovers, you're not alone.

title: Street Fashion; In Mink, Longer Is Better
description: SKIRT lengths may be all over the lot these days, but coat lengths - especially fur-coat lengths - remain decidedly long. And who can argue the logic? Furs are supposed to keep one warm (in much of the nation recently one has needed all the warmth one can get), and fur coats can't serve that function adequately if they're cut off at the knees. So it's hardly surprising that we're seeing a good many stretch mink coats right now: ankle-length coats with an emphasis on function rather than trendy design. Witness these in New York City.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: YOU may well ask - her family certainly did - what Joan Hamburg was doing in her kitchen last week, in the middle of the night, cooking and baking. Particularly as this occurred after the holidays, when she was not expecting company and there was absolutely no need for all that chopping and stirring.

title: ART
description: POPULAR ART OF 2 PERIODS, IN BRIDGEPORT

title: DECISION AWAITED IN SOMERS DISPUTE
description: LEAD: THE final battle of last year's often acrimonious supervisor's race in Somers may be settled this week.

title: WHALING MUSEUM SEEKS AID FOR ITS HISTORIC HOME
description: LEAD: THE Sag Harbor Whaling Museum, one of two Long Island museums devoted to the region's whaling history, is searching for money to maintain the building that houses it, which was built in 1845 and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: How Far Will the New Travel Magazines Go?
description: ITS publisher, Ronald A. Galotti, contends that Conde Nast's Traveler, which made its debut in September, is unique among travel magazines. Several advertisers agree - which is why they withdrew their ads.

title: Group to Profile New York's History
description: Nearly all New Yorkers know the Empire State Building as a towering symbol of their city, La Guardia Airport as a bustling memory of a legendary Mayor and Bryant Park as a place to avoid. But they probably do not know that the Empire State Building replaced the original Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, that Fiorello La Guardia wanted to be a World War II general, or that Bryant Park was a reservoir.

title: 'PUBLIC OPINION IS QUITE VOLATILE'
description: SHELDON R. GAWISER, 38 years old, owns a consulting concern in Westport that specializes in helping businesses collect and manage information. He is also a recognized expert on polls, which the public will be seeing a lot of in the coming months of the Presidential campaign.

title: Pelham Parkway
description: WHEN the New York Police Department wanted to build a new precinct house directly on Pelham Parkway, the residents of the quiet Bronx neighborhood that takes its name from that thoroughfare were outraged at what they saw as a desecration of their tree-lined sense of identity. They rallied to protest the plan, the new 49th Precinct stationhouse was built on Eastchester Road and the parkway remains residential.

title: A PLACE FOR MOTHERS TO MEET
description: LEAD: WHEN Anne Garncarz moved from Riverdale to New Rochelle with her husband and two small daughters six years ago, she felt as if her carefully arranged life was crumbling in front of her eyes.

title: YANKEES LOSERS IN FREE-AGENT PITCHING PICTURE
description: The Houston Astros' pitching staff is intact, Charlie Leibrandt has completed Kansas City's starting rotation, Detroit has Jack Morris and Frank Tanana back and California held onto Mike Witt. Then there are the Yankees.

title: Police End Search for Heiress
description: Law-enforcement officials from two states have called off a search for a missing heiress after concluding that a prison inmate had led them on a wild goose chase.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of ''Mexican Churches'' Dec. 20 inadvertently omitted the name of the translator. The review, by Octavio Paz, was translated by Robert Pegada.

title: Terrorism Stalks A Drama
description: AIR FORCE COMMANDOS SNATCH A TERRORIST in Lebanon and bring him to the United States for trial. The Justice Department is involved; the American Civil Liberties Union is involved. Sy Resnik (played by Ron Liebman), the well-known defense attorney who also teaches law at the University of Pennsylvania, becomes involved, although not because he really wants to. As he says, the terrorist is ''scum, lowlife,'' a fanatic who murders civilians. Besides, he has other things on his plate. On the other hand, duty does call. ''It's not about him, sir,'' a first-year law student says earnestly to Resnik, ''it's about due process.'' Well, maybe it is; maybe it isn't. Either way, though, ''Terrorist on Trial: The United States vs. Salim Ajami'' is a pretty good television movie.

title: FANS HAVE LITTLE SYMPATHY FOR SYRACUSE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CENTER AIDS YOUNG ON PROPER DIET
description: TEEN-AGERS, too often linked with alcohol and drugs through the devastation of family life, are seldom thought of in the same category as the compulsive under- or over-eater, whose pattern on examination is remarkably similar.

title: IN QUEENS, A DESIGN CENTER THAT LIVES UP TO ITS NAME
description: There has been so extraordinary a flurry of publicity in the last couple of years surrounding the transformation of a group of old factory buildings in Long Island City into something called the International Design Center, New York - a set of showrooms for the design industry - that the whole project has seemed to take on an air of manifest destiny. That is precisely the point of all this hype, of course: to convince us that there is something akin to a force of nature about this huge complex. For several years elegant newsletters with graphics by Massimo Vignelli have touted the center, valiantly trying to counteract the impression that this place was a struggling venture in the old Chiclets factory on the far side of the East River from most of its customers, and hoping to make us believe instead that these old factories constituted the classiest and most established operation going.

title: For Hair, A Look That's Sleek
description: IN two fashion collections presented last week, models wore their hair pulled back severely from the face, the better to show off earrings and sunglassses. ''The clothes are frilly and feminine, the earrings are elaborate, so the hair must be smooth,'' said Charles Nicholas, who was responsible for the coiffures at the Adolfo spring and summer show. His solution: variations on the French twist, which made the heads look sleek but sophisticated above the fluff of the clothes. Models showing the Sirena swimsuit collection by Louis Dell'Olio of Anne Klein sometimes had their hair tied back and covered with black scarves. Most of the suits were also black. The rather severe head treatment carried out the urbane, slick look the designer recommends for the beach or pool.

title: With Hope, Money Goes To Neediest
description: ''Sorry I am late,'' Sophie Gluck of Brooklyn wrote in a note, along with her gift of $15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She requested that her contribution go to a needy older person.

title: DATA BANK: January 10, 1988
Bush and Dole Attack Each Other As Iowa Race Takes Negative Turn
description: The front-runners for the Republican Presidential nomination, Vice President Bush and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, attacked each other sharply today, each accusing the other of having something to hide.

title: COOKING FOR ONE IS A DULL SITUATION
description: With regard to the article by R. C. Casey, ''Cooking for One, Forever'' [ Opinion page, Nov. 15 ] , I, too, live alone and am a survivor. My husband also needed a special diet and special enticements while he underwent chemotherapy.

title: Maybe the Party Will Thank Hart
description: Contrary to some speculation, Gary Hart's latest caper may turn out to be a valuable gift to the Democratic Party. He may turn out to be his party's deliverer in the coming electoral season.

title: THE RIGHT GIFTS TO TAKE ABROAD
description: A DELFT TILE of a blue sailing ship, a gift from a Dutch friend, hangs over our kitchen sink filling the blank space with sea voyages and adventure. A miniature Puerto Rican ''coqui,'' decorates a shelf in my office, reminding me how the little green frog sings through the tropic nights. It accompanied a birthday gift of local rum from a Puerto Rican friend. A colorful cascade of a thousand paper-folded cranes, symbol of good health and long life, hangs from a bedroom doorknob and brings back days and nights in the Orient. The gifts are inexpensive and personal, yet represent the country of origin.

title: Marion B. Reith Dead; Taught Aliens English
description: Marion B. Reith, who founded the English in Action program, died of pneumonia Dec. 21 at Pomona (Calif.) Valley Community Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Claremont, Calif.

title: Iranian and Iraqi Vessels Clash in Gulf
description: Iran resumed artillery attacks on Iraq's second-largest city and the two sides fought a naval battle in the northern Persian Gulf, reports from Baghdad and Teheran said today.

title: Fat Bear, Thin Bear and the U.S.; Is Soviet Growth Worth Betting On? Yes, a Little.
description: The Soviet economy stagnates and it's clear that Mikhail Gorbachev is willing to undo a half-century of Stalinist central planning to get it moving again. What's not clear is whether a successful fix would serve American interests.

title: THE PRIVATE PAIN OF INFERTILITY
description: Gwen Davis's article brought back all of the grievous memories of my five years of infertility treatments. Her depiction of an in vitro fertilization cycle - in which couples gamble $5,000 and all of their hopes on a 10 percent long shot - is accurate.

title: Bush Raising Questions On Blind Trust for Doles
description: A day after Vice President Bush challenged Senator Bob Dole to make his tax returns public, the Bush campaign began sending reporters copies of an article in a small Kansas newspaper that raised questions about a real estate transaction by a blind trust belonging to the Senator's wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title:
MUSIC;
HARPIST TO BE SOLOIST WITH THE WESTFIELD
description: LEAD: The harpist Heidi Lehwalder will be soloist in three works with the Westfield Symphony Saturday night.

title: 2 Hurt in Shootings by Police
description: Two men were shot by the police in Brooklyn and the South Bronx - 20 minutes apart - early yesterday, and one of them remained in critical condition last night, the police reported.

title: MADNESS OF WAR
description: ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT Directed by Lewis Milestone, wiith Lew Ayres (in photo), Louis Wolheim and Yola D'Avril (in photo). 1930.

title: IN A BARN, BIRTH OF PAST AND FUTURE
description: THERE is a barn behind my great-grandfather's house in Stony Brook. I suppose now I should say my grandfather's, for it is he who inherited the house and lives there now, but to me it will always be Poppy's house. Even after all the new paint, soft carpets and beautiful unfamiliar furniture, I still like it better the old way, the way it used to be.

title: LAURI KIEN TO MARRY ERIC KOTCHER IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Julian M. Kien of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauri Allison Kien, to Eric Kotcher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Kotcher of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Worrisome Glut in Offices
description: REAL ESTATE brokers are warning that this city, the financial center of the Pacific Northwest, is about to experience a jump in office vacancy rates because the pace of downtown construction shows no signs of slowing.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: Sure . . . and while they're at it why don't they pick up Bill Wennington, Walter Berry, Shelton Jones, Willie Glass. . . . F. C. GALLAGHER Princeton, N.J.

title: A PRIVATE OWNER FOR PUBLIC HOUSING
description: A 40-YEAR-OLD public housing project in New Rochelle, still solid but now shabby, graffiti-marked and in need of major repairs, is being sold to a private corporation that will renovate it at a cost of $7 million and continue renting it to 180 low-income families.

title: BEST SELLERS: JANUARY 10, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 2 2 12 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 3 4 15 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' 4 3 10 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) An investment banker caught in the jungles of New York. 5 6 24 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 6 7 29 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 7 5 12 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride to the North Pole and the magical events that follow. 8 9 15 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 9 8 6 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Continuing the space saga begun in ''2001'' and ''2010.'' 10 10 17 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 11 11 21 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $19.95.) Ten thousand years of English history, seen through the experiences of five families. 12 13 18 LEGACY, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $16.95.) The ordeal of a military officer, charged with high crimes, whose family heritage covers 200 years of constitutional history. 13 14 30 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 14 9 RUBBER LEGS AND WHITE TAIL-HAIRS, by Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $14.95.) Humorous tales about an outdoorsman's life. 15 16 2 WINTER, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $19.95.) The experiences of a Berlin family, from Kaiser Wilhelm to Adolf Hitler. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 15 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $15.95.) Counting his blessings and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50. 2 4 18 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 3 2 4 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 4 3 7 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 5 6 51 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 6 7 18 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (Random House, $19.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells his story. 7 8 9 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF THE SOVIET UNION. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The vast country on May 15, 1987, as recorded in pictures by 100 of the world's leading photojournalists. 8 11 24 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former senior member of the British secret service. 9 13 3 THE NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC SOCIETY, by C. D. B. Bryan. (Abrams, $45.) The 100-year history of an American institution in pictures and words. 10 9 6 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) Profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. 11 11 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 12 5 7 SEVEN STORIES OF CHRISTMAS LOVE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack, $12.95.) The advocate of caring and love recalls experiences during holidays past. 13 12 3 PERESTROIKA, by Mikhail Gorbachev. (Bessie/ Harper & Row, $19.95.) The Soviet leader's views on changing his country and the world. 14 10 THE DISCOVERY OF THE TITANIC, by Robert D. Ballard with Rick Archbold. (Madison Press/ Warner, $29.95.) Recent findings about the sinking of the legendary ship 75 years ago. 15 14 4 I THINK I DON'T REMEMBER, by Art Buchwald. (Putnam, $16.95.) Humorous columns about the late afternoon of the Reagan era. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 7 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. 2 2 8 BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS NEW COOK BOOK. (Meredith, $16.95.) The ring-bound edition. 3 3 122 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 29 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. 5 4 27 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $21.95.) This long and lovely novel by the author of ''The Year of the French'' recalls the turmoil of Ireland in the 19th century to handle with love and clarity the making of history, the construction of memory, the fluidity of time. OUT OF CONTROL: The Story of the Reagan Administration's Secret War in Nicaragua, the Illegal Arms Pipeline, and the Contra Drug Connection, by Leslie Cockburn. (Morgan Entrekin/ Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) A sometimes awkward and hasty but on the whole persuasive job by a former television news producer. LIVES OF THE TWINS, by Rosamond Smith. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Ms. Smith (really Joyce Carol Oates) offers a resonant, paradoxical metaphysical novel that concerns identity, freedom and people's deepest needs (or the illusions of all these). THE LIFE OF KENNETH TYNAN, by Kathleen Tynan. (Morrow, $22.95.) An observant and thoughtful biography, by his widow, of the brilliant, narcissistic, sexually obsessed theater critic. PUSHKIN HOUSE, by Andrei Bitov. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.50.) Wonderfully - perhaps fiendishly - clever and elaborate, this performance by a Soviet novelist is both a lament about Russia's dullness and a theoretical treatise on fiction. A TIME TO DANCE, NO TIME TO WEEP, by Rumer Godden. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) The British novelist's account of her first 40 years, mostly in India, amply justifies her own self-description: ''always . . . intransigent and farouche.'' THE NATURE OF LOVE. Volume Three: The Modern World, by Irving Singer. (University of Chicago, $24.95.) In the final volume of his history of love as a history of ideas, Mr. Singer follows the decline of the romantic ideal through selected modern writers.

title: HAZARD: ALL TOO FAMILIAR: In Coal Mining, A Call for Strict Standards
description: In fulfillment of President Reagan's campaign pledges, the Mine Safety and Health Administration, known to coal men by the awkward acronym ''EM-sha,'' joined many other regulatory agencies in emphasizing cooperation with industry, rather than being its adversary. Republicans and Democrats in Congress, the United Mine Workers union and now a number of the agency's top career safety engineers have accused it of going too far - of calculated laxity in enforcing safety standards in what has long been the most hazardous of all industrial workplaces.

title: NONFICTION
description: OVERTIME: A Twentieth Century Sports Odyssey. By Peter Schwed. (Beaufort, $15.95.) Many young sports fans know the joy of settling onto a grandfatherly lap and listening to colorful tales from someone who professes to have seen Babe Ruth swing a bat or experienced the patriotic euphoria created by Jesse Owens in 1936. In this collection of childhood memories and homespun stories, Peter Schwed - the author of several books, a former editor at Simon & Schuster and a self-proclaimed ''sports freak'' who grew up in the 1920's - tries to be everyone's grandfather. A native of Long Island and a passionate club-level tennis player, he writes mainly of such personal passions as his family's devotion to Princeton sports, his father's penchant for horses, his brother's sense of humor and his own quest for a tennis haven. Mr. Schwed's sports knowledge, his admiration for athletic achievements and compassion for perhaps the most maligned of athletes, the defeated, are evident. But his meandering accounts of the intricacies of such sports as badminton and carom billiards, combined with his sometimes overly romantic style, dampen the impact of his reflections. The author also missed several opportunities to break new ground. Any tidbit concerning perhaps the most profound enigma in tennis history, Bill Tilden, would have been welcomed. But Mr. Schwed, who edited a book written by Mr. Tilden while the former player was serving a prison term for homosexually molesting a minor, dismisses the incident in one paragraph. Sports books of this nature can often provide useful reminders of some glorious past feats. Unfortunately, ''Overtime'' deteriorates rather quickly into a family album.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: PERU, by Gordon Lish. (Scribners, $8.95.) A violent television newscast from Peru and a bump on the head jar a 50-year-old man into a remorseless recollection of a murder he committed as a child. Told in an obsessively circular manner, the novel ''increases speed to a kind of frenzy,'' Stephen Dobyns said in The Book Review in 1986. ''It is an amazing book - not attractive or likable but amazingly built, almost like a corkscrew.'' GOD'S FOOL: The Life and Times of Francis of Assisi, by Julien Green. Translated by Peter Heinegg. (Peren-nial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) With little more than hagiography and dubious legends to draw on, compiling an objective biography of a medieval ascetic is a daunting task. ''For every one statement of fact in the book there are two questions,'' Rachel Billington said here in 1985. Ultimately, though, the novelist and diarist Julien Green ''has persevered, building up the probabilities of Francis' life through the nearer certainties of historical background.'' The book is, she said, ''a labor of love.'' PARADISE, by Donald Barthelme. (Penguin, $6.95.) Three homeless lingerie models, who have given all their money to fight starvation in Africa, move in with Simon, a 53-year-old architect. Our reviewer, Elizabeth Jolley, said that although Donald Barthelme has written some of the most innovative contemporary fiction, ''Paradise'' still comes as ''a shock and a revelation.''
