The novel is made up of a ''collision of brilliant moments [ that ] cannot be summed up,'' she said in 1986. THE BLIND WATCHMAKER: Why the Evidence of Evolution Reveals a Universe Without Design, by Richard Dawkins. (Norton, $7.95.) In his effort to show that God is not a necessary ingredient in the creation of life, the biologist Richard Dawkins programmed a personal computer to demonstrate a crude but visually spectacular form of evolution. ''Readers who are not outraged will be delighted,'' Michael T. Ghiselin said here in 1986. ANYWHERE BUT HERE, by Mona Simpson. (Vintage, $6.95.) Adele August flees her husband and a boring life in Wisconsin to drive her daughter to California while she's still young enough to become a child star. The two main characters are ''the most exasperating, insupportable and credible mother-daughter duo to make their presence felt in recent fiction,'' Le Anne Schreiber said here last year. She found the novel brilliant and funny as well as ''trying and unique.'' THE USES OF LITERATURE, by Italo Calvino. Translated by Patrick Creagh. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6.95.) The subjects of these essays include Homer, Ovid, Balzac and Stendhal, but the book is as much about Italo Calvino's own inventive prose. ''One comes away from this collection of intellectually playful essays . . . inspired to go back and reread the body of his fiction,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times in 1986. SPHINX, by D. M. Thomas. (Washington Square/ Pocket Books, $4.95.) Toward the end of D. M. Thomas's third novel about poets and spies in modern Russia, a Welsh journalist reads (and disparages) a book called ''Ararat,'' which, in reality, was the first installment in Mr. Thomas's planned literary quartet. Last year, The Times's Walter Goodman called this self-referential effort ''a virtuoso performance.'' THE THIRD ROSE: Gertrude Stein and Her World, by John Malcolm Brinnin. (Merloyd Lawrence/Addison-Wesley, $14.95.) ''Civilization began with a rose,'' according to Gertrude Stein's inscrutable, much-parodied aphorism. ''Rose is a rose is a rose is a rose.'' When this biography of the avant-garde writer was first published in 1959, our reviewer, Lloyd Frankenberg, stretched the floral metaphor even further. ''Without disturbing the separate roses,'' he wrote, ''the book gathers them into a handsome, wittily gallant bouquet.'' ANAGRAMS, by Lorrie Moore. (Penguin, $6.95.) Benna Carpenter, a solitary woman who is at various times a poet, a singer, an aerobics instructor and other things, has an imaginary friend, Eleanor, and an imaginary daughter, Georgianne. ''Benna loves Georgianne intensely,'' Carol Hill said here in 1986, ''and in this love, which is sustained only by words, we discover how much this novel is about language, about the power of sounds to slice through the darkness, and through meaning to join us.'' IF YOU WANT TO WRITE, by Brenda Ueland. (Graywolf Press, $6.50.) ''Everybody is talented, original and has something important to say,'' the writer and teacher Brenda Ueland writes in this book, which was first published in 1938. When it was reissued last year, one reviewer said its ''advice rings contemporary in its emphasis on centering or locating a self [ that ] can be relied upon to provide'' the voice necessary to create effective prose. ENTERING FIRE, by Rikki Ducornet. (City Lights, $6.95.) An amateur botanist who is a descendant of Cyrano de Bergerac develops new varieties of orchids in the Amazon, while his son becomes a Nazi sympathizer in France. ''Though the satirical ambitions of the novel are not fully realized,'' Oliver Conant said here last year, it ''displays a cheerfully gruesome audacity and an imagination both lively and bizarre.'' THE MORNING AFTER: American Successes and Excesses 1981-1986, by George F. Will. (Collier/Macmillan, $9.95.) When this collection of columns by the conservative pundit was published in 1986, our reviewer, Randall Rothenberg, found most of them too mechanical. But in the essays on his teen-age son, who was born with Down's syndrome, George F. Will's ''quiet anger can be affecting. . . . The columnist's assertion of his son's dignity and happiness, even in the face of governmental, judicial and journalistic arrogance, is nothing less than powerful.''

title: Correction
description: The TV View column in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday, about the public TV series ''Inside Television'' misidentified an NBC News vice president. He is Joseph Angotti.

title: FOR JAPANESE, POWER IN U.S. MARKETS IS HARD TO EXERCISE
description: IN the high-stakes game of trade war, Japan's strong hand does not insure victory.

title: WHAT CRITICS HAVE DONE, AND HOW WELL
description: LITERATURE AND ITS THEORISTS A Personal View of Twentieth-Century Criticism. By Tzvetan Todorov. Translated by Catherine Porter. 203 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $24.95.

title: Books From The Times
description: RITA REIF'S THE NEW YORK TIMES WORLD GUIDE TO ANTIQUES SHOPPING. By Rita Reif. (Times Books, Paper, $14.95.) Rita Reif, the author of the New York Times antiques and auctions columns, ranges from African art and agateware to wood carvings and Zuni jewelry in this Baedeker to the four corners of the antiques world. More than 200 shops in 22 cities in the United States, Europe, the Middle East and the Far East are included in this 363-page guide, some whose contents have appeared in the author's columns in The Times.

title: The New American Truck Stop
description: WHEN Larry Puckridge began driving a rig in 1973, ''dirty old truck stops that sold greasy food and fuel'' gave him little incentive to stop while he crisscrossed the country, he said.

title: OILERS TROUNCE ISLANDERS
description: Craig Simpson scored twice as the Oilers routed the Islanders, 5-1, tonight, giving Simpson 16 goals in 22 games since being acquired from Pittsburgh in the trade that sent Paul Coffey to the Penguins on Nov. 24.

title: HOW TO INSTALL A LOCK ON A DOOR
description: THE term ''lockset'' is used to describe collectively all door hardware (except hinges) that permit the door to be opened, closed and locked. Usually a lockset consists of a lock with keys, a latch bolt, doorknobs and a strike plate, which is installed in the door jamb to receive the end of the latch bolt and hold the door shut.

title: Honors for Excellence
description: THE RECOGNITION OF excellence is not a sure thing. The maker of the better mousetrap may be in real trouble if the other fellow has the bigger ad budget. They didn't know this back in the days when proverbs were coined.

title: A Look Beyond Stravinsky's Style
description: MUSICAL FASHION IDENTI-fies itself primarily with style, and only when time has sepaand only when time has separated the two (so that the style in which a work was composed merely becomes one of several attributes by which it can be judged, rather than the test of its timeliness) is it possible to attempt accurate comparative assessments of contemporaneous works.

title: SYRACUSE HOLDS OFF SETON HALL, 84-82
description: Sherman Douglas scored 11 of his 15 points in the second half tonight and Derrick Coleman had 17 points and 16 rebounds as Syracuse edged Seton Hall, 84-82.

title: Opera: By John Blow, 'Venus and Adonis'
description: ''VENUS AND ADONIS,'' a ''masque for the entertainment of the King'' by John Blow, is an endearing trifle, but the beginnings of English opera were so sparse and tentative that it can plausibly be called a landmark among them. The king was Charles II; we do not know precisely when he was entertained by this brief retelling, with dance and diversions, of the Greek tale. The king's mistress Moll Davies played Venus, their daughter Mary was a child Cupid, and a troupe of little cupids, taking lessons in cupidry and playing games in Act II, gave the children of the court a chance to frolic adorably.

title: LATIN PEACE HOPES SEEM TO BE BLEAK BEFORE KEY TALKS
description: The prospects for peace in Central America appear bleak as the region's leaders prepare to meet next week to judge the results of the peace plan they signed five months ago.

title: Boy's Return to Africa Barred
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court barred the State Department yesterday from returning a 9-year-old Zimbawean boy to his country until the court reviews the Government's arguments against legal attempts to block the boy's return.

title: LONG ISLAND NEEDS A SENSE OF COMMUNITY
description: Dispersed and fragmented Long Island needs more than leaders who take a hand in community affairs, as John Racanelli urged recently [ ''Countering the Hysteria on Economic Growth,'' Opinion Page ] . Gaining ground on Long Island's future requires a mixture of public leadership with wider vision.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ANIMAL NUMBERS By Bert Kitchen. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books. $11.95. (All ages) CROWS An Old Rhyme. Illustrated by Heidi Holder. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. (All ages)

title: DATA UPDATE: January 10, 1987
DEMOCRACY GOES TO THE MOVIES
description: REEL POLITICS American Political Movies From ''Birth of a Nation'' to ''Platoon.'' By Terry Christensen. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $24.95.

title: Wider Testing For Radiation Urged in Study
description: A major study of the monitoring of radiation at nuclear power plants has concluded that better equipment and procedures are needed in the plants and in nearby areas to achieve safe operations and inspire public confidence.

title: INVENTORY OF HISTORY
description: OVER the years, the county has compiled lists of its wildlife, itemized its big trees and catalogued its open spaces. Now it is starting an Inventory of Historic Places, and it is looking for local nominations of historically significant buildings, structures and sites. Anything - a barn, a bridge, a house, a monument, a cemetery - might be eligible.

title: WANTAGH EXTENSION IS DESIRABLE
description: The letter to the editor from the Long Island Association [ Dec. 13 ] concerning the projected work on the interchange between the Meadowbrook and Northern State Parkways and the widening of the Northern State between the Wantagh and the Meadowbrook requires an answer.

title: POSTINGS: Putnam Project; Northward Ho!
description: Most builders in New York City's northern suburbs are making two mistakes, according to Anthony J. Amicucci. Either they overestimate how many people can afford high-priced, Westchester County houses, or they underestimate what customers will pay for homes farther north.

title: PRISON PLAN ADVANCING DESPITE OPPOSITION
description: DESPITE opposition in some communities, Connecticut is pushing ahead with a record $300 million construction program to add 3,000 new prison beds in the next five years to keep pace with a steadily rising inmate population.

title:
ART;
TRENTON: CONTINUATION OF A RETROSPECTIVE
description: LEAD: MARGUERITE DOERNBACH, a 70-year-old painter who lives in Trenton, has been awarded a two-part retrospective.

title: Miami-Florida St. May Go to Sept. 3
description: Next season's game between the national champion, Miami, and second-ranked Florida State may be moved to Sept. 3 for prime-time national television, according to Wayne Hogan, a Florida State spokesman.

title: Oilers Eager To Face Broncos
description: It is a tricky business figuring just what message the Houston Oilers' coach, Jerry Glanville, is sending to the Rocky Mountains.

title: MISS LONGOBARDO TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Guy Longobardo of Bronxville, N.Y., and Amagansett, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alicia Anahid Longobardo, to Lance David Langston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Langston of Pittsburgh. A May wedding is planned.

title: ACTIONS AND WORDS AT PURCHASE CAMPUS
description: The article about the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York at Purchase [ ''Performing Arts Center: Reviewing a Decade,'' Nov. 29 ] speaks not only to local usage of a quasi-public facility and to programming but to larger issues of interaction between public institutions and private-sector giving.

title: Carnegie Hall Names A Music Administrator
description: Carnegie Hall has appointed Catherine Gevers to the newly created post of music administrator, Judith Arron, general manager of the hall, announced. Miss Gevers, who will assume her responsibilities Feb. 15, will be in charge of engaging artists and developing programs for the main hall. Summer programming is to be expanded and planning begun for the hall's centennial celebrations in the 1990-91 season.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Basement Grapes

title: A Revival By the River
description: TRAIN passengers to Wilmington used to arrive at a rundown railroad station in an equally shabby neighborhood.

title: HAVING FUN, AIDING OTHERS
description: Preservation Concert Jan. 10 - Pete Seeger will be the lead performer at a 4 P.M. benefit concert for Save the Village, a preservation group that is seeking to establish a historic waterfront district adjacent to Greenwich Village. The concert, with refreshments at intermission, will be held at the chapel of St. Luke in the Fields Church at 487 Hudson Street, south of Christopher Street. Tickets, $20, or $12 for the elderly, from 212-255-1185. For Young Thespians

title: Salaries Inch Up - Sometimes
description: JOHN H. GUTFREUND, the chief executive of Salomon, Inc., took a $2 million voluntary pay cut in 1987. Merrill Lynch & Company is cutting brokers' compensation by 6 percent, and analysts say other brokerages mayfollow that lead.

title: Big Talents vs. the Big Screen
description: FOR ONE REASON AND AN-other, some great performers don't fit easily onto the motion picture screen. The camera wasn't kind to the Lunts in ''The Guardsman'' (1931), their first (and last) co-starring screen appearance. Somewhere between the movie set and the movie theater, the grace and elegant humor that were evident in all of their theatrical performances evaporated.

title: Miami Schools: Laboratory for Major Changes
description: In an experiment intended to cut through red tape and create a new management model for large urban school districts, the Dade County Public Schools have turned the running of 32 schools over to teams that include teachers and parents.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ASPEN
description: The Dec. 27 snowstorm that closed Denver's Stapleton Airport for the first time in four years and dumped several feet of snow in the Colorado Rockies came as a great relief to Aspen residents, who had grown anxious about the season's persistent dryness and its effect on skiers.

title: SARAH E. THORNTON, FINANCIAL ANALYST, AND JOSEPH D. J. DOWNING ARE MARRIED
description: The Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Sarah Elizabeth Thornton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Thornton of Bronxville, N.Y., to Joseph Dominic John Downing, a son of Gertrude Martin Downing of Pittsfield, Mass., and the late John F. Downing. The Rev. Michael Donahue performed the ceremony.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: Chris Mullin may not be the missing link to make the Knicks a contender, but his unselfish style and excellent passing and shooting will contribute greatly. ROGER L. GILDE New York

title: 200 Protest Beating Death Of Black Man in a Texas Jail
description: About 200 people gathered outside a church here today to protest the death of a black truck driver investigators say was killed in a beating by the police.

title: LEGISLATORS PREDICT A SESSION OF POLITICAL DRAMA
description: LEAD: ON the surface, there was nothing new in last week's 55-minute reorganization meeting of the County Board of Legislators. Edward J. Brady, a Thornwood Republican, and Diane A. Keane, a Rye Republican, were re-elected as the respective chairman and vice chairwoman of the legislative body, 16 of whose 17 members were returned to office in last November's election.

title: By Freighter
description: To the Editor: I read and reread Joseph Disponzio's account of nine days at sea on a freighter. Since I plan a similar voyage, I should thank Mr. Disponzio for alerting me to the potential of isolation aboard when no one else speaks English. He surely learned the hard way about the language barrier. I shall take along both a dictionary and a phrase book of the crew's nationality.

title: THE ARABS: A COLLISION OF CRISES UPSETS THE NEW AGENDA
description: THE protest in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip has forced the issue of Israel and the Palestinians back to the top of the Arab world's agenda. It has done so, however, at a time when the Arabs, increasingly focused on the hazards in the Persian Gulf war and the rivalries among themselves because of it, seem least prepared - or willing - to respond to the unrest.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: RAMPAL, FLUTE AND BATON Jean-Pierre Rampal, the virtuoso flutist, will perform with, as well as conduct, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra next weekend in Englewood, Red Bank, Trenton and Elizabeth. On the program will be Weber's Overture to Oberon, Mozart's Flute Concerto No. 2 in D, K. 314, and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 3 in D, Op. 29, (''Polish'').

title: MARAVICH IS EULOGIZED
description: Hundreds of mourners heard Pete Maravich eulogized today as a man whose evangelical Christian zeal surpassed his love for the sport that made him a star.

title: Honor for McPherson
description: HE was edged out for the Heisman Trophy, but Don McPherson has been doing just fine in the awards department since then. After losing to Tim Brown of Notre Dame in the Heisman balloting, McPherson, the quarterback who led Syracuse to an undefeated season and a tie with Auburn in the Sugar Bowl, has won the Maxwell Trophy and the Sugar Bowl's most valuable player award.

title: MEASURING SUCCESS WITH A SCALE OF IMPS
description: A small demon has long appeared in this column in enlarged form: the ''international match point,'' which will in future be described as an ''Imp'' and so conform to the practice of most bridge books and magazines.

title: BRUCE G. ECKERSON IS WED TO ALICE COLEMAN ELSBREE
description: Alice Coleman Elsbree, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Elsbree of Kensington, Md., was married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Bethesda, Md., to Bruce Godwin Eckerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer W. Eckerson of Fair Haven, N.J., and Raymond, Me. The Rev. David S. Stanton officiated.

title: 'The Health of Nations'
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Police Challenged on Palestinian Death
description: An Israeli magazine asserts that the police investigating the sudden death of a Palestinian prisoner have rewritten their opinion ''to make it possible to close the file.''

title: NEW RESEARCH ON BOTTOM PAINTS
description: EVER since primitive man discovered that his dugout canoe quickly became a garden of organisms if left in the water, mariners have fought the battle against bottom-fouling.

title: U.S. SEES QADDAFI AS BEING WEAKER
description: The Reagan Administration believes the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya has been so weakened by a series of setbacks over the last year that it no longer poses a serious threat to its neighbors in the Mediterranean region, according to White House and State Department officials.

title: PANTHERS FINALLY DEFEAT REDMEN
description: Pittsburgh, a team that hopes to finally realize its potential this season, cleared an early hurdle this evening by defeating St. John's, 81-70, in front of a sellout crowd at Fitzgerald Field House.

title: VICTORIA ROCKEFELLER ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Victoria Stillman Rockefeller to Peter Sandys Philip has been announced by Mrs. John Philip Fisher of Toronto and Andrew Carnegie Rockefeller of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Ness Philip of Bedford, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: CONDUCTOR IN DEBUT WITH CHOIR
description: THE last Christmas concert of this season is coming up next Sunday, when the Ossining Choral Society begins its 51st year with Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio.'' The 3 P.M. performance at the high school also serves to introduce the choir's new maestro, Thomas Filo.

title: GRETCHEN RICHTER PLANNING TO WED PAUL J. MASSEY JR.
description: Announcement of the engagement of Gretchen Van Lear Richter to Paul J. Massey Jr. has been made by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Stewart A. Richter of Short Hills, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Albany Notes; Cuomo Plan for Prison Barge Appears Dead
description: A plan to use a decommissioned British troop barge to house 700 New York State prison inmates, announced with fanfare by the Cuomo administration last June, has run into trouble and now appears unlikely to be carried out.

title: ASTRTAL BODIES AND TANTRIC SEX
description: FORBIDDEN JOURNEY The Life of Alexandra David-Neel. By Barbara M. Foster and Michael Foster. Illustrated. 363 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $21.95.

title: Karachi Chooses Mayor, 28
description: Farooq Sattar, a 28-year-old, was chosen here as Mayor, the youngest in the city's history. Mr. Sattar, who graduated from medical school last year, is a member of the Mohajir movement.

title: PLANETS OF THEIR IMAGININGS
description: THE SILVER DESOTO By Patty Lou Floyd. 257 pp. Austin: Council Oak Books/ Texas Monthly Press. $14.95.

title: Behind the Oil Tank Failure, Changes in the Use of Fuel
description: THE public safety authorities in Pennsylvania are investigating why a storage tank failed last weekend, contaminating water supplies with enough oil to heat almost 1,000 single-family houses for a year. If the accident prompts officials elsewhere to check the soundness of tanks in their jurisdictions, however, they are likely to find that knocking on the cold steel shell produces an unexpected sound - a hollow ring.

title: DR. PATRICIA L. ROBERTS PLANS TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Roberts of Old Bethpage, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Patricia Lynne Roberts, to Dr. Michael Stuart Rosenblatt, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Rosenblatt of Margate, N.J. A summer wedding is planned.

title: NECESSITY IS THE MOTHER OF INVENTORS CLUB
description: LEAD: STANLEY I. MASON demonstrated the better-shaped pinless baby diaper. Robert Krauser showed an attempt to cure the common cold. And Nathaniel Silver presented the Euphorotron, which he described as ''a noninvasive instrument for relieving stress by inducing a state of relaxation.''

title: 100TH YEAR FOR BANK IN YONKERS
description: UNDERHILL, Belknap, Stillwell and Elliott are all names of Yonkers streets today, but 100 years ago they belonged to a far-sighted group of Yonkers families who organized the Yonkers Building and Loan Association, the first savings and loan association in the county.

title: Headliners; Borrowing Trouble
description: ''I have deep regrets and no excuses,'' said former Gov.

title: SCHOOL SPACE URGED FOR DAY CARE
description: LEAD: DAY CARE centers use space where they can find it, in buildings ranging from former funeral homes to old fire houses. Efforts are now being made to encourage the use of space in buildings that have traditionally been associated with children: public schools.

title: OLYMPIC PROFILE: Ingemar Stenmark; STENMARK, AT 31, IS PROVING HE STILL CAN TACKLE SLALOM
description: THREE gates into the morning run Ingemar Stenmark had fallen, catching his outside shoulder on the top of a flag and skidding ingloriously down the icy slope.

title: The Dollar's Up, With Some Help
description: The dollar got strong support from central bankers in both words and deeds. When the week's trading began in Tokyo the dollar resumed its slide to record lows, but central banks of several countries, including the United States, moved vigorously to prop it up, buying billions of dollars in the currency markets. In addition, several monetary officials gave currency traders unusually blunt warnings that betting against the dollar could prove quite costly to them. The rebound took the dollar over 130 yen, from the week's early low near 120. Against the mark, the dollar rose as high as 1.6575, from a low of 1.5630.

title: 'THEY WANTED TO TERRIFY ME'
description: CHILE Death in the South. By Jacobo Timerman. Translated by Robert Cox. 134 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Hauling the Nothingness What does a congregation of poets remind you of? This is Lyubomir Nikolov, a Bulgarian writer, describing ''The Poets of Iowa'' in ''The World Comes to Iowa: Iowa International Anthology'' (Iowa State University), edited by Paul Engle, Rowena Torrevillas and Hualing Nieh Engle.

title: HOW A CHILD ABUSE CASE TOOK ON INTERNATIONAL DIMENSION
description: WHEN school teachers in Queens reported last month that the 9-year-old son of a Zimbabwean diplomat had come to class with suspicious scars and injuries, a complaint of child abuse escalated into an international incident.

title: Body and Mind; The Drink-a-Day Lore
description: MY FATHER, A soft-spoken, hard-working, heavy-smoking, meat-and-potatoes alcoholic, died the classic death of the mid-1950's. Shortly after his 48th birthday, complaining of pain in his stomach, he spent a day in bed. By afternoon, his heart, not his stomach, had stopped working. The doctor explained that his coronary arteries had become ''filled with crud'' and so he had a fatal heart attack. At the time, I and others close to him assumed the villain was alcohol. Since then, however, medical journals have become filled with papers suggesting that alcohol was the one thing he had in his coronary favor. The notion that a drink a day is good for the heart has taken hold in medical folklore.

title: Excerpt of G.O.P. Debate Involving Bush on Iran Arms
description: Following is an excerpt of the Republican Presidential debate Friday night, as recorded by The New York Times. It involves questions by the moderator, James Gannon, editor of The Des Moines Register, and responses by Vice President Bush.

title: KEAN SEEKS TO COUNTER AIDES' LACK OF CANDOR
description: THE state's Department of Education has a growing scandal on its hands in its awarding of $1 million in vocational education contracts, and Governor Kean, for one, found the department's communication skills lacking last week when it came to keeping the public informed about what was going on.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Zurbriggen Takes First of Season: Pirmin Zurbriggen, after two second-place finishes, won his first World Cup downhill race of the season yesterday at Val d'Isere, France. Zurbriggen, the Swiss skier who was the overall World Cup winner last year, posted the fastest time ever on the Oreiller-Killy course: 1 minute 57.10 seconds. Austria's 29-year-old veteran, Anton Steiner, took advantage of a late-breaking sun to come in second with 1:57.64, edging Marc Girardelli, the Austrian who skis for Luxembourg and was clocked in 1:57.67. The highest American finisher was Tom Moe of Palmer, Alaska, who was 57th. Doug Lewis and Mike Brown were injured in practice runs earlier in the week. Lewis, of Salisbury, Vt., suffered a broken collarbone, and Brown, of Vail, Colo., suffered a broken wrist.(AP) Tennis Shriver and Sukova in Final: The two top-seeded women, Pam Shriver of the United States and Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, will meet today in the final of the New South Wales Open at Sydney, Australia. Shriver overcame a groin injury to beat third-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, 7-5, 6-2, yesterday. Sukova beat Patty Fendick of the United States, 7-6, 6-1. In the men's competition, third-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union beat top-seeded Christo Van Rensburg, 6-3, 7-6, in the semifinals. Chesnokov will meet John Fitzgerald of Australia in the final. The fifth-seeded Fitzgerald defeated Joey Rive of the United States, 6-4, 3-6, 6-1.(AP) Horse Racing Vinnie the Viper Rallies to Win: Vinnie the Viper raced along the rail and saved ground to the stretch then swung wide to rally from the rear of a seven-horse field and post a 2 1/4-length victory in the $85,200 Paumonok Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. Raja's Shark was runner-up, three-quarters of a length ahead of Best by Test, the favorite. Vinnie the Viper covered six furlongs on a fast track in 1:10 1/5 under Julie Krone. The victory was his third straight in a stakes race. He earned $51,120 for Lazer Two Stable and paid $5.80 for $2 to win as the second choice. Track and Field Relay Victory for DeWitt Clinton: At the Dartmouth Interscholastic Indoor meet yesterday in Hanover, N.H., DeWitt Clinton High School of the Bronx won the boys' mile relay in 3 minutes 28.6 seconds. Ridgewood (N.J.) High School's girls team won three events: Virginia Figlar was first in the 400-meter dash in 59.83 seconds, and ran lead leg on the winning two-mile relay (9 minutes 41.7 seconds). The other Ridgewood victory was in the triple jump, where Jen McDermott won with a jump of 37 feet 5 inches. Dennis Webster of Clarence, N.Y., took the boys' mile run in 4 minutes 18.8 seconds, and earned an invitation to the Millrose Schoolboy Mile at Madison Square Garden next month. Luge Lake Placid Man Wins First Trial: Duncan Kennedy of Lake Placid, N.Y., won the men's division of a United States Olympic team trial on the Olympic track in Lake Placid yesterday. It was the first of three trials. Frank Masley, the 1987 national luge champion from Newark, Del., finished second, and Tim Nardiello of Lake Placid finished third. In the women's division, Cammy Myler of Lake Placid finished first, followed by the 1987 women's national champion, Bonny Warner of Mount Baldy, Calif. Erica Terwillegar of Lake Placid finished third. Joe Barile of Spring Valley, N.Y., and his partner, Steve Maher of Chicago, finished first in men's doubles. Jason Mully and Lance Karley, both of Leverett, Mass., were second. The second trial will be held Tuesday and Wednesday, and the third will be Saturday and Sunday. (AP) College Basketball Auburn 71, Tennessee 68: Vickie Orr scored 26 points and rallied Auburn in the final 33 seconds yesterday to lead the second-ranked Lady Tigers past No. 4 Tennessee in a Southeastern Conference game in Knoxville, Tenn. Auburn improved to 12-1 over all; the Lady Volunteers fell to 9-2 in the conference opener for both teams. (AP) Rutgers 108, Duquesne 33: Rutgers jumped out to a 37-4 lead in the Atlantic 10 Conference game and cruised to victory yesterday in Piscataway, N.J. Sue Wicks led the winners with 26 points. The 75-point margin of victory was 5 points short of the Lady Knights' school record set in 1980 against William Paterson College. Rutgers (8-2, 4-0) led by 59-14 at halftime. Duquesne (5-7, 1-3) hit just 13 of 61 shots in the game, or 21 percent. The victory was the 37th straight for Rutgers at home.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 113, Nuggets 105: Dominique Wilkins scored 33 points and Jon Koncak added a career-high 25 to lead Atlanta to a victory at home. It was the eighth victory in the last nine games for the Hawks. Alex English led the Nuggets with 27 points; Jay Vincent scored 25 and Lafayette Lever had 20.(AP) Lakers 101, Pacers 98: Magic Johnson and James Worthy scored 21 points apiece last night as Los Angeles won their 14th consecutive game by rallying in the fourth quarter in Indianapolis. Byron Scott added 20 points for the Lakers, including a pair of free throws with seven seconds remaining. Steve Stipanovich led Indiana with 26 points.(AP) Bullets 108, Clippers 76: Bernard King scored 24 points as Washington handed the Los Angeles Clippers their 10th straight loss. The victory was the Bullets' second in three games since Wes Unseld replaced Kevin Loughery as coach last Sunday. They had lost five straight games before the change. Mike Woodson scored 15 to lead the Clippers, who last won on Dec. 17.(AP) N.H.L. Canucks 3, Nordiques 2: Steve Tambellini scored two goals last night to lead Vancouver to a victory in Quebec. Tambellini, who had opened the scoring in the second period with his ninth goal of the season, scored at the 13:15 mark of the final period to give the Canucks a 3-0 lead.(AP) Whalers 5, Penguins 4: Kevin Dineen scored 55 seconds into overtime to give Hartford the victory in Hartford. Dineen scored the winning goal on a 10-foot shot off a pass from Joel Quenneville. The loss made Pittsburgh's record 0-4-3 since Dec. 26.(AP)
