Wonica) Great Kills $212,000 43 Country Woods Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, raised-ranch; dining area, large kitchen, family room in finished basement, c/a.

title: INSIDE
description: Panama General on Visit Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military strongman who has been criticized by Washington, is in the Dominican Republic on what he called a private visit. Page 12. Vikings and Browns Win In the N.F.L. playoffs, the Vikings stunned the 49ers, who had the season's best record, 36-24. The Browns defeated the Colts, 38-21. Section 5.

title: Egypt Says It Arrested Iranian in Terror Plot
description: Egypt said today that it had arrested an Iranian agent who was setting up a sabotage group and attempting to recruit adherents from among Moslem fundamentalists. The announcement came a few days after Bahrain reported the arrests of members of what it called a terrorist network directed by Iran.

title: A TRICKSTER IN TIANJIN
description: GRIEVER An American Monkey King in China. By Gerald Vizenor. 238 pp. Normal: Illinois State University/ Fiction Collective/Sun & Moon Press. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: NAN T. KENNELLY ENGAGED TO WED
description: The engagement of Nan Terese Kennelly, a Foreign Service officer in Lahore, Pakistan, to Gregg Easterbrook, a journalist and novelist, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Kennelly of Short Hills, N.J. Mr. Easterbrook is a son of Dr. George E. Easterbrook of Tallahassee, Fla., and the late Vimy Easterbrook.

title: JILL E. BUZZI WEDS M. A. TANENBAUM
description: The marriage of Jill Elizabeth Buzzi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Buzzi of Colonia, N.J., to Michael Alan Tanenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Tanenbaum of Short Hills, N.J., took place last evening at the Essex County Country Club in West Orange, N.J. Judge John E. Keefe, presiding judge in the chancery division of the Superior Court of New Jersey, Middlesex County, officiated.

title: On Language; Dam That Tinker
description: WHEN GENERAL Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev brushed off charges of human-rights violations in the Soviet Union with the question, ''What about the wetbacks?'', Americans cringed - not at the crude attempt of moral equivalency, but at the use of a term now regarded as a slur. A wetback - from the condition of a Mexican swimming across the Rio Grande to enter the United States - later become known as an illegal alien, and when that became onerous, the name was changed to undocumented person, now applied to persons of any nationality who enter the country without a visa. But nobody told the Soviet propagandists.

title: In Gaza, Confrontation at Crossroads of History; Ominous Arrests
description: To the Editor:

title: Hart Declines to Answer Query on Drug Use
description: When asked today on a campaign stop here whether he had ever used drugs, Gary Hart told reporters, ''None of your business.''

title: By Freighter
description: To the Editor: It was delightful to read ''Marquesas by Freighter'' by Robert Gordon (Travel, Dec. 6). My friend and I took that trip last March and the best part of it was that there are no age limitations on the passengers. She and I are both 80, and while it's true that one must be in good health since there's no doctor on board, we found no difficulty in making all the shore excursions and being tossed by muscular sailors into and out of the whaleboats on to the shore or back at the ship for the ascent up the ladder. DOROTHEA BARBONE Flushing, Queens

title: B.P. AMERICA'S 'HATCHET GENTLEMAN': Robert B. Horton; Cost-Cutter With a Soft Touch
description: JUST about the minute Bob Horton arrived in town two years ago as the new chairman of the Standard Oil Company, he slashed the budget for the big bash the company was planning to celebrate the opening of its new headquarters on Public Square here. They still had the party, but it was not nearly as much fun.

title: FRESHENING THE SKILLS OF OLDER DRIVERS
description: DRIVER'S education classes are often filled with young adults eager to hit the road.

title: TEMPERED TAN
description: BY NOW, EVERYONE KNOWS THAT A HEALTHY TAN IS A contradiction in terms. The gap between knowledge and behavior, however, is big enough to hold all the cocoa butter in Florida. People like the all-over toasted look. Accordingly, tanning parlors, born in the early 1970's, now dot street corners across the country, holding out the promise of the impossible: a safe tan. Even those machines that screen out ultraviolet B light (the rays that cause sunburn and skin cancer) aren't innocuous. Ultraviolet A radiation, which shines from most tanning lamps, may accelerate skin aging.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Books Are Bargains At Bryn Mawr Sale Donations to the Bryn Mawr Book Shop in White Plains provide tax deductions in addition to recycling favorite books, or sets of books, first editions and rare or out-of-print collectibles to eager new owners.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPENSATION
description: IN January, corporations traditionally add the final sweetening to employee compensation packages, signing off on year-end bonuses and incentive awards. At the same time, personnel administrators re-examine compensation policies, reshaping them to meet changing company needs.

title: New Indian Educator
description: The Education Department said Thursday that John L. Sam had been named director of its $66 million Indian education programs. Mr. Sam, a 43-year-old member of the Cherokee Tribe, has been a Federal education official for the past decade and formerly taught in the Sand Springs, Okla., public schools.

title: IDENTITY RECLAIMED, CONFUSION RAMPANT
description: ''ORDERED, adjudged and resume the use of her maiden name, to wit: Kennedy.''

title: Evoking the Amazon
description: BLOWGUNS, FEATHER ORNAMENTS, shrunken heads: artifacts from past and present cultures of Amazonia, the tropical rain forest area of northern South America, are being assembled in the Hall of South American Peoples, which New York's Museum of Natural History is to open in October. Complementing an exhibit of Andean archeology, the hall's ethnographic display includes 1,000 Amazonian artifacts that were selected, over two years, from more than 15,000 in the museum's collection by Robert L. Carneiro, curator of South American ethnology, and Laila Williamson, a staff anthropologist. ''We went through four storerooms of stuff,'' Carneiro says. ''You look at every artifact with a fresh eye.''

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: ALBANY RETURNS TO THE USUAL WARFARE
description: DURING last year's tumultuous legislative session, traditional party alliances often seemed to break down into personality conflicts, with the new Speaker of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly, Mel Miller, more at odds with the state's Democratic Governor than with the majority leader of the Republican-controlled State Senate. When the state leaders came together again last week for the start of the new session, their remarks seemed intended to signal a return to the relative peace of partisan politics.

title:
DINING OUT;
PUZZLES THAT A MENU CAN PRESENT
description: LEAD: MENU language in Chinese restaurants is often as delicious as the dishes described. Imagine, for instance, the dish that would be served if the following description were exact:

title: Music: Brooklyn Philharmonic Plays Corigliano Piece
description: LISTENING to Friday night's concert by the Brooklyn Philharmonic made one wonder whether music is American by virtue of a special identity or by the lack of same. Two pieces on the program at the Academy of Music seemed to argue the question in different directions.

title: Melvin H. Worth Sr.; Executive, 84
description: Melvin H. Worth Sr., retired president and chairman of Cosmopolitan Mutual Insurance Company, died of cancer of the colon Thursday in Staten Island Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: PISTOL PETE AND BIRD: DREAM TEAMMATES
description: I WAS standing at the head of the players' ramp just before game time, having small talk with Dennis D'Agostino, one of the Knicks' publicists. The tipoff against the Phoenix Suns last Tuesday night was just a few minutes away and the Garden was about two-thirds full. D'Agostino suddenly looked at his watch and then peered up at the game clock, which had counted down to zero.

title: PACKS OF WOLVES? THIS IS RIDICULOUS
description: Martin Brech wrote in the Dec. 13 Westchester letters section that wolves and coyotes might be a solution to the deer problem in Westchester. This is ridiculous. Whereas I have never heard of a wolf attack on human, the coyotes have been noted in California for taking a small child in a suburban neighborhood encroaching in the Sierras.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Mexico's Debt Plan, Will It Work?

title: WHAT DID WOMEN WANT?
description: THE GROUNDING OF MODERN FEMINISM By Nancy F. Cott. Illustrated. 372 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: Gorbachev and Hart on List of Admired Men
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Gary Hart are two of the 10 men most admired by Americans, the latest Gallup Poll says.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MINK ARE BACK
description: LEAD: Mink tracks - possibly the first to be seen along the Hudson in Westchester in 38 years - were recently spotted at Croton Point Park. Christopher Letts, ''river educator'' for the nonprofit Hudson River Foundation, recognized the paw prints in the sand along the river. They might indicate a return of the mink to the area, and are, according to Mr.

title:
INVESTING;
The Case Against Index Funds
description: LEAD: IN 1987, for the fifth consecutive year, two-thirds of the professional money managers failed to match the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500 index. Such results explain in part why individuals and institutional investors in recent years have poured billions of dollars into index funds, unmanaged diversified portfolios of large common stocks designed to mimic the performance of a particular index.

title: A JULY WEDDING FOR AMY SCALERA
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Scalera of Beaver, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Marie Scalera, to Donald Cameron Findlay 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Findlay Jr. of Elkhart, Ind. A July wedding is planned.

title: Dubcek Sees a Link With Gorbachev Effort
description: Alexander Dubcek, the Czechoslovak leader ousted by Soviet-led troops in 1968, sees a ''profound connection'' between the changes he tried to initiate 20 years ago and those now being undertaken by the Soviet leader, according to a rare interview to be published here Sunday.

title: Moira Shearer: Still Chased by 'Red Shoes'
description: MENTION THE NAME Moira Shearer and movie buffs will instantly smile and say:

title: SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE IN STORRS
description: JACK COHAN, the director of the Jorgensen Auditorium at the University of Connecticut, faces the challenge each season of assembling a schedule that ''contains something for everyone.'' This time, he said, ''I think we've succeeded.''

title: A STAY-HOME MOTHER WITHOUT CHILDREN
description: AFTER 16 years, I am at last a stay-home mother. The only thing is, the children are no longer there. I timed my transition from corporate executive to budding author to coincide (was it coincidental?) with the high school graduation and departure for college of my younger daughter, Sarah.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LINDBERGH'S SON. By John Vernon. (Viking, $17.95.) Two women accost Charles Cooper as he plays basketball with his stepson. One tells him he is the son of the aviator Charles Lindbergh. Ensuing events pull Cooper's memories into daylight, turn them inside out and repack them roughly into his brain.

title:
DINING OUT;
THAI CUISINE IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: LEAD: TO our mind Thai (or Siamese) cuisine ranks as one of the most tantalizing in the world. As in Chinese cooking, most Thai dishes are stir-fried, and successful variations on the classics are considered praiseworthy achievements. The cuisine is, in addition, a hospitable one; dishes are meant to be shared.

title: RITUAL OF RENEWAL IN CLOTHES AND SELVES
description: RECENTLY I read two articles whose juxtaposition had an impact on me. The first was entitled ''Is Fashion Destiny? Ask Cinderella,'' by Janice Gordon [ Opinion Page ] .

title: The Power Of Boards Challenged
description: AS the elected directors of a co-op corporation, board members have long had the right to make management decisions without disclosing their reasons to the shareholders.

title: Comings and Goings
description: PENN STATE'S leading rusher, Blair Thomas, who missed the Citrus Bowl after hurting his knee, will undergo surgery tomorrow. If he has not fully recovered by the fall, Thomas has said he might sit out a year. . . . Cris Carter, the Philadelphia Eagles' wide receiver, underwent surgery on his right foot and will be in a cast for six weeks. . . . Doug Padilla, who has won five distance titles at Millrose Games, will be trying for a sixth against an outstanding field in the 3,000 meters at the 1988 event in Madison Square Garden Feb. 5.

title: INCINERATOR FOES FIGH GLEN COVE DAY CARE SITE
description: LEAD: AN environmental wrangle is building up in Glen Cove, where a group of out-of-towners have denounced plans to put a day care center beside the city's incinerator.

title:
GARDENING;
THE DIVERSITY AND USEFULNESS OF CONIFERS
description: LEAD: CONIFERS, or cone-bearing evergreens, are just as popular in the garden as they are for holiday decorations. While the most interesting landscapes use both deciduous and evergreen plants, the conifers are so diverse it is entirely possible to develop a garden with year-round interest using only them.

title: ALICE J. LIPTROT IS WED TO DONALD W. BEATON
description: At the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Georgetown, Conn., Alice Jeanne Liptrot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Atherton Liptrot of Wilton, Conn., and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Donald Wilson Beaton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Beaton of Burlingame, Calif. The Rev. Luke McCann performed the ceremony.

title: 'UNCLE FLOYD' TAKES NEW TACK
description: FOR Floyd Vivino, laughter makes the world go round, and although he has not taken the career leaps that other New Jersey comedians have, his followers have kept his zany humor alive.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
IN THE BEGINNING, RITA
description: LEAD: BEFORE aerobics classes became a more popular social activity than having lunch, before Jane Fonda cashed in on exercise, before leopard print leotards and purple legwarmers appeared in chic stores, there was Rita. Exercise had not yet become trendy when Rita started. Workouts were what one's weight-lifting son indulged in around the time Rita came on the scene.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 10, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-16

title: Sunday Observer; High-Flying Confusion
description: AMERICANS ARE cruel to their journalists. They say we would rather take cyanide than confess error. Nonsense. I am no different from the next journalist, and I am always eager to retract and apologize if I make an error.

title: 4 Former and Suspended Officers Are Accused in 2d Stun Gun Trial
description: Two former New York City police officers and two suspended officers went on trial last week in the latest case stemming from accusations that suspects were tortured with an electronic stun gun at a Queens station house.

title: Mopeds
description: To the Editor: In the article on the hazards of Bermuda's mopeds (Practical Traveler, Nov. 15) no mention was made of the fact that these auxiliary cycles apparently are not required to have rear-view mirrors on their handlebars. Last summer, I was on both Block Island (where all mopeds seem to have such mirrors) and Bermuda (where only scooters seem to have them). Since I rented mopeds in both places, I can attest to the difference in safety I felt where there were mirrors.

title:
GARDENING;
THE DIVERSITY AND USEFULNESS OF CONIFERS
description: LEAD: CONIFERS, or cone-bearing evergreens, are just as popular in the garden as they are for holiday decorations. While the most interesting landscapes use both deciduous and evergreen plants, the conifers are so diverse it is entirely possible to develop a garden with year-round interest using only them.

title: HAZARD UNKOWN: In Spanking-New Industry, A Search for Answers
description: A COMPUTER chip factory appears to be the epitome of cleanliness and safety. Workers don white ''bunny'' suits, gloves and goggles and pass through an air shower before entering the production area, known as a ''clean room.''

title: Wearing James Baldwin's Crown
description: To the Editor:

title: STEPHEN BURNHAM PLANS TO BE WED TO KRYSIA BEREDAY
description: The engagement of Cornelia Krystyna Bereday, the daughter of Mary Hale Bereday of New York and the late George Z. F. Bereday, to Stephen Tyler Burnham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Campbell Burnham of Providence, R.I., and Fishers Island, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's mother. A June wedding is planned.

title: OFF BROADWAY'S UNLIKELY HITS
description: QUIETLY, WITHOUT FAN-fare, there has been a resurgence of Off Broadway, with plays as well as musicals developing into long-run successes. This theatrical arena has once again become a healthy commercial territory at the same time that it is providing the theater with new and rewarding work. The plays include Alfred Uhry's ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' Terrence McNally's ''Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune,'' Robert Harling's ''Steel Magnolias,'' Barbara Lebow's ''Shayna Maidel'' and Tom Griffin's ''Boys Next Door.'' In addition, there have been several successful musicals - ''Oil City Symphony,'' Graciela Daniele's ''Tango Apasionado'' (which recently completed its engagement) and ''Sarafina'' (which is about to move from Lincoln Center to Broadway). Variety recently summarized this renewal of activity under the headline, ''Off Broadway Showbiz Darling,'' noting that many of those shows had been sold to the movies or that movie sales were imminent.

title: REMEMBERING A CAT CALLED JENKINS
description: I SPOTTED the cat at the other side of the road poised to bolt. I slammed on the brakes but my front wheel caught it, and a pleasant day in the suburbs was plunged into confusion and gloom.

title: A. R. Gurney Spins a Darker Tale
description: IN 1971 A. R. GURNEY JR. WROTE ''The Old One-Two,'' a play about a classics professor whose beloved Euripides and Seneca are about to be displaced by timelier courses taught by young teachers yearning to be relevant.

title: THE ODYSSEY OF A SUBMARINE (SANDWICH, THAT IS)
description: MY DAUGHTER, aside from being a connoisseur of feminine attire, also knows a great deal about submarine sandwiches. You have to admit that this is an unusual duo of interests.

title: REPUBLICAN PARTY FLOATS ITS CAMPAIGN HOPES ON THE DOLLAR
description: AS the 140-point plunge of the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday reminded Republican optimists, it would hardly be prudent to be smug. What with the unknowable courses of things like the stock market, oil prices and the trade and budget deficits, a sour economy could rout the party from the White House just as the combination of inflation and recession helped put them in eight years ago.

title: RAPPERS KEEP THEIR MUSIC'S CONTENT FRESH
description: RAP IS HEALTHIER THAN IT'S ever been, although its death has been repeatedly forecast since it was born in the Bronx in the late 1970's. In a typical week, half a dozen rap albums sit securely in the Top 40 of Billboard's black-albums chart, while the 12-inch single market flourishes with the diversity of an Arab bazaar.

title: China Claims Nuclear Counterattack Power
description: China said today that its strategic missile force has developed a nuclear counterattack capability.

title: The Dance: Program By Louis
description: THE Murray Louis Dance Company and the Nikolais Dance Theater of Alwin Nikolais have been sharing a season at the Joyce Theater. Usually, the two troupes have been sharing the programs, as well. But on Friday night the program consisted entirely of works by Mr. Louis for his eight-member company. They showed Mr. Louis being choreographically sprightly and somber.

title: Condo Doldrums
description: To the Editor:

title: YONKERS PLAN ON CAR THIEVES
description: A NEW Yonkers police program scheduled to take effect this month will give the police the right to stop any car between the hours of 1 A.M. and 5 A.M. that displays a special decal. The decal allows the police to operate under the ''reasonable suspicion'' that the car is being stolen.

title: THE U.S.: A FAILED BID FOR SAFE PASSAGE IN THE GULF
description: EVER since the Government said it would allow Kuwait to fly the American flag on 11 Kuwaiti tankers and protect them with American warships in the Persian Gulf, American shipowners have petitioned the Defense Department for the same protection. Even though their ships fly foreign ''flags of convenience'' to cut costs, the owners argued, their tankers carry more than 50 percent of American oil imports to United States ports and can be requisitioned by the President in national emergencies.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: AFTER spending almost a year winnowing a list of potential locations for an incinerator and disposal facility, the state's Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission is putting its own siting process on hold while it considers the merits of three other proposals from private industry.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
WOMEN'S GOALS: PLUS CA CHANGE...
description: LEAD: AN ARCHEOLOGIST once described Europeans of 12,000 years ago as changing just enough so that they didn't have to change. Much later, the French naturally turned it into an adage: Plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose.

title: Statues of Caligula Clan On Display in Florence
description: Several life-size statues, thought to have been smashed nearly 2,000 years ago to eradicate traces of the Roman Emperor Caligula's family, have been restored and put on display.

title: PROGRAM TO AID TROUBLED YOUTHS
description: A wide range of social services will soon be available in 29 New Jersey school districts in what state officials say is the first program in the country intended to deal comprehensively with crippling problems faced by teen-agers.

title: JILL WING TO WED HAROLD HECK JR., A LAWYER, IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rodney G. Aller of Lakeville, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Aller's daughter Anne Jaquett Wing to Harold Daniel Heck Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Heck of Easton, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: BROWNS STOP COLTS: Carter Sets a Record In Easy 36-24 Victory
description: The Minnesota Vikings had the poorest record (8-7) of the 10 teams that started the National Football League playoffs last Sunday. Now they are one game away from reaching the Super Bowl.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AUCTION WILL FEATURE RARE COINS
description: LEAD: STACK'S of New York will conduct its 400th public auction this week. It will take place Wednesday and Thursday evenings in two sessions starting at 6:30 o'clock at the Omni Park Central Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street. The sale will encompass more than 2,000 lots and will feature United States gold, silver and copper coins from four collections.

title: IN AIDS RESEARCH, MONEY IS JUST THE START
description: SEVEN years into an epidemic that is expected to kill more than 179,000 Americans by the end of 1991, Federal financing to fight AIDS is approaching the amount spent in the war on cancer. Budget documents show that President Reagan plans to ask Congress for $1.3 billion in the next fiscal year to help the Public Health Service combat the epidemic, an increase of 37 percent over appropriations for the current year. By way of comparison, the National Cancer Institute's 1988 budget is $1.5 billion.

title: WHEN THE ID COMES KNOCKING AT YOUR DOOR
description: HOW OLD WAS LOLITA? By Alan Saperstein. 275 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: PHOTOJOURNALISM: A BLEND OF ARTIFICE AND ACTUALITY
description: THE CURRENT ISSUE OF LIFE Magazine, devoted to ''The Year in Pictures'' for 1987, features a remarkable portrait of Lt. Col. Oliver L. North. Taken by the photojournalist Harry Benson, it shows the star of the summer's Iran-contra hearings in full-dress uniform, standing at attention next to an American flag. The camera's position, roughly waist-high, causes him to loom larger than life. A polished marble background adds to the heroic, even mythic effect of the pose. One could say that Colonel North apppears to be impersonating Charleton Heston impersonating Moses on the mountain.

title: South Korean Leader Seeks Talks With Rival
description: President Chun Doo Hwan has proposed talks with the opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, ''for national reconciliation,'' a presidential aide said today.

title: Royal Cousin Weds Scholar
description: The Earl of St. Andrews married a Canadian scholar, Sylvana Tomaselli, today and became the first member of the royal family to wed in a civil ceremony in Britain. Lord St. Andrews, 25 years old, is the son of the Duke of Kent, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II. The bride, 30, a Roman Catholic and divorced, is a history research fellow at Cambridge University, where she met the Earl. By marrying her, he excluded himself from succession to the British throne, to which he had been 17th in line. Successors may not be married to Roman Catholics. The Earl is eligible to become the Duke of Kent, and his wife is now the Countess of St. Andrews.

title: MISS WEBB PLANS TO MARRY IN JULY
description: The engagement of Heidi-Rachel Webb to Dr. Andrew Millard Singer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Singer of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. Gertrude Mikels Webb and J. Chester Webb of Waltham, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I am finishing my attic to add a workroom, so I want to add insulation to the roof (it is now on the attic floor). I have been told to allow for ventilation above the insulation - between the insulation and the roof sheathing - but am not sure how to do this. Can you tell me if this is really necessary, and if so where vents should be located?

title: Taking On Mount Kilimanjaro
description: IT is two and a half hours after midnight, Tanzanian time. In the light of the full moon lighting our climb, we can look down on the lofty peaks of Kenya's mountains poking up through layered clouds in the far distance. We are more than three miles into the sky, almost as high as jet liners cruise, and higher at that moment than any of the millions of people on the African continent. Perhaps somewhere in Switzerland a mountaineer is climbing Mont Blanc or the Matterhorn. But even he or she will be no higher than we, working our way up the 19,324-foot Mount Kilimanjaro. It is Africa's highest peak, and we have never climbed a mountain before.

title: Harold Brayman, 87; Author and Executive
description: Harold Brayman, an author and retired director of public relations at the Du Pont Company, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in Wilmington, Del. He was 87 years old.

title: PURSUING POWDER ON SLOPE AND TRAIL
description: FOR AVID skiers, downhill or cross-country, there is no such thing as a bad snowstorm. Oblivious to wind and cold, they pursue their ideal: fresh powder.

title: British Government Seeking to Censor 2d Spy Book
description: In a fresh move to guard the increasingly shopworn secrets of its intelligence services, the British Government is trying to suppress yet another book describing the services as riddled with would-be traitors and homosexuals.

title: STATE DEPT. GIVEN A BUDGET REPRIEVE
description: Congress has forestalled the State Department budget crisis for at least a year by quietly appropriating additional funding in the final days of its last session.

title: POSTINGS: Leasing a Suite; Boesky's Space
description: Last year, Ivan F. Boesky paid a record $100 million civil penalty for insider trading. In March, he will begin serving a three-year prison sentence for conspiracy. Clearly, he needs less office space.

title: Venezuela
description: To the Editor: How disappointing that ''Venezuela's Island in the Caribbean'' (Travel, Nov. 15) focused on overpriced, overcrowded Margarita Island when Puerto La Cruz lies only 40 minutes from Caracas. Five minutes after we arrived the Doral Beach Hotel staff had us happily in our rooms. We were surrounded by tennis, volleyball and basketball courts, a long private beach and free shuttles to the shops and sights of Puerto La Cruz. Three restaurants and a sunny cafeteria overlooked the pool; guides were available for tours to Angel Falls, Cumana and Caracas. Couples loved the privacy; families relished bargains in the well-stocked mini-supermarche. LORRAINE MURPHY North Bergen, N.J.

title: MONITORING DRUGS FOR THE AGED
description: In his article ''Monitoring Drugs for the Aged'' (Body and Mind, Dec. 13), William Ira Bennett describes problems associated with drug side-effects, particularly in the elderly.

title: THE MEANING OF GLASNOST
description: Alex Goldfarb's moving account of his return to the Soviet Union is also an interesting testimonial to the confusion caused by the Communist Party's opening the door to public expression just a crack (''Testing Glasnost: An Exile Visits His Homeland,'' Dec. 6). Mr. Goldfarb and other dissidents know they are hoodwinking themselves about the meaning of glasnost. Any Russian dictionary confirms that it means only ''publicity,'' and their hoped-for meaning of ''openness'' is derived from three Russian nouns - otkrovennost, pryamota and yavnost (''Smirnitsky and Muller,'' 1985). Furthermore, the common usage of glasnost is ''propaganda.''

title: FICTION
description: BROWNSTONE FACADE. By Catherine M. Rae. (Joan Kahn/St. Martin's, $13.95.) Catherine M. Rae has concocted a leisurely mystery-romance in her first novel that fairly cries out for a long train ride during which to read it. She presents New York City in the winter of 1920 through a frame of more recent years: In 1981, a middle-aged man comes upon a disturbing memoir purportedly penned by his late aunt two decades before. ''I have decided,'' the nephew declares in a foreword, ''now that everyone directly concerned with the events of that winter has died, to make public what she wrote.'' Readers in whom such words produce a frisson of anticipatory pleasure will find the story that follows as civilized, as restrained yet as modestly bracing as a cup of Earl Grey tea. Early in this century, the Upper East Side brownstone of the title was the home of the Millerton family: Papa, Mamma, Carrie, Alfred, Tom, Will, our narrator Grace and her younger sister Rose. The winter of 1920 finds Rose absent and unmentionable within the family, Grace still mourning the fiance she lost in the Great War, Alfred at last pulling out from under his mysterious bankruptcy, and Mamma starting to ail. Unaccountable noises in the house lead to a story of blackmail, madness and death - which sounds lurid enough but is presented in an extremely sedate style. In fact, the mood it conveys is more like that of a mild, enjoyable stroll around old New York. The plot's suspenseful turns occasionally strain credulity, but one willingly forgives such lapses and concentrates on the appealing romance. In the end, ''Brownstone Facade'' remains a cozy, intelligent diversion.

title: FANS HAVE LITTLE SYMPATHY FOR SYRACUSE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Panama Strongman on Visit
description: Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, arrived here unexpectedly today and said he was on a private visit.

title: Hogmanay
description: To the Editor: In his piece on the Scots' hogmanay (Travel, Nov. 29), Israel Shenker has resurrected an impressive list of folklore and folk customs about welcoming the New Year in Scotland. Much of that applied, if it ever did, only to previous generations.

title: THE HIGH PRICE OF GARBAGE
description: The sooner we face the undeniable fact that disposing of garbage costs a lot of money, the quicker we'll be able to solve our environmental difficulties. I had hoped that the plight of the garbage barge would have raised our waste consciousness. After all, it probably cost over $1,000 per ton to transport, inspect, incinerate and finally dispose of the garbage back on Long Island.

title: Rival Guerrillas in Lebanon Seeking Unity Against Israel
description: Palestinian and Lebanese guerrilla groups, which have been fighting among themselves for years, are showing new solidarity in their common war against Israel.

title: Is There Life After Dr. Feelgood?
description: LEAD: As the Presidential campaign has intensified, I've been affected by a strange gnawing fear.

title: THE KING OF KISS AND TELL
description: CASANOVA A New Perspective. By J. Rives Childs. Illustrated. 346 pp. New York: A Giniger Book/Paragon House. $24.95.

title: SRI LANKA: A NATION DISINTEGRATES
description: Steven Weisman's article is a balanced analysis of a complex problem. In the article, Sri Lankan President Junius Richard Jayewardene was quoted as saying: ''I don't mind giving in to India, I could not give in to Prabakaran [ the Tamil guerrilla leader ] .'' Interestingly, this reflects the crux of the problem. A lasting peaceful soluton will be found only through an agreement between the Sri Lankan Government and Tamil guerrillas. Failure to do so will only strengthen the Tamils' resolve to create a separate Tamil nation and will increase the agony of an already bleeding nation. The only beneficiary of the Indo-Sri Lankan agreement is India, which gained a strong foothold in Sri Lanka. EVA S. ANTON Chicago

title: JODIE JUDD, A HORTICULTURIST, IS WEDD TO JEFF MORGAN
description: Jodie Judd and Jeff Morgan were married yesterday on Great Camanoe Island, V.I., at the winter home of the bride's father, Eugene C. Judd of New York and Amagansett, L.I.. Sidney Jacobs, the Registrar for the British Virgin Islands, performed the ceremony.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
JACK CLARK AND THE YANKEES' RORSHACH TEST
description: LEAD: EVERYTHING flows from this fact: I am a Yankee fan. I have been a Yankee fan my entire life. I learned right from left by standing at home plate and pointing to Hank Bauer's position, or Irv Noren's. I have been a Yankee fan from Mickey Mantle through Dooley Womack to Don Mattingly. I am a Yankee fan.

title: A Lottery (and Other) Affordability Deals
description: UNTIL last year, Janet M. Bondeson could not afford to live in Wilton, Conn., where she is an assistant to the Superintendent of Schools.

title: DIAMOND PITTAS IS WED TO CONSTANCE S. SBILIS
description: At St. Paul Greek Orthodox Church in Hempstead, L.I., Constance Stavroula Sbilis and Diamond Pittas were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Demetrios Katerlis, the Dean of St. George Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Philadelphia and an uncle of the bride, and the Rev. Nicholas Magoulias, the Dean of St. Paul.

title: Stuart Feld Brings Zest to Americana
description: STUART P. FELD'S stepped-up pursuit of American decorative arts over the past five years has made him the most discussed merchant in the field of Americana. A relative newcomer as a dealer in the three areas he now handles at Hirschl & Adler Galleries - folk art, 20th-century architect-designed furnishings and 19th-century revival styles - Mr. Feld is criticized for his brusque manner but praised for his sure eye, scholarship and aggressive presentation of folk-art exhibitions and catalogues.

title: YOUNG HOMELESS READERS
description: It was just about a year ago when Elaine Mittelgluck, the young people's librarian of the Hastings-on-Hudson Public Library, decided that she had read just a bit too much about Westchester's burgeoning homeless population.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 21 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: OUT OF CHAOS AND ORDER COMES JUDICIOUS MARRIAGE
description: WE live in one of those 1930's not-quite-gracious Colonial houses that with imagination, money, time and hard work could be almost lovely. When we bought it four years ago, my husband, Charlie, zealously and single-handedly began restructuring the neglected and overgrown two acres of land the house occupies. His first formal venture into the world of nature, he approached this challenge as he does all projects: without restraint.

title: After Chernobyl, Africans Ask if Food Is Hot
description: ''Chernobyl in Banjul?'' read a recent headline in an African magazine.

title: New York Is to Buy Acreage on Hudson For Recreation Use
description: New York State has announced an agreement in which it is to pay $13.3 million to buy a scenic peninsula in the Hudson River for conversion to a recreational area.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Knicks Trade for Mullin?
description: No way! Coach Pitino is doing a great job with the pressure defense and he doesn't need any changes. Mullin is a guard and we already have Jackson, Wilkins and Donovan. DANNY PORITZKY Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Dance
description: New dances by five choreographers with live music and commissioned scores are featured on the programs offered by Moving Sound Concert, Thursday through next Sunday nights at St. Mark's Church (Second Avenue at 10th Street). ''Elliot's Wave,'' choreographed by Michele Elliman to music by Dalton Portella, concerns greed and the stock market. Michael Fulwiler's ''Marceline,'' with a score by Sandy Jacobs, is based on Andre Gide's novel, ''The Immoralist.'' In ''One,'' for which Beatriz Roman contributed the music, Jan Gero choreographically depicts how, as a man grows older, the spirit of adulthood conflicts with and tries to extinguish the spirit of boyhood. ''Safe: An Alternative for the Post-Nuclear Family'' is a dance-play with choreography by Eric Larson, music by Jim Farmer and photographic projections by Don Chiappinelli. Libby Flynt, Virginia Tate and David Licht provide the music for Chris Nieder's ''Thrown,'' in which three lighted spaces give the illusion of being areas from which there is no escape.

title: THE LURE OF WARM SUNSHINE
description: THIS is the time of year when northern grandmasters peruse travel folders of balmier climes in the effort to align comfort with a reasonable competition to play in. Since sponsors pick up air tickets and, indeed, the entire stay, it does not matter how long the journey may be.

title: Imperial Cycles: Bucks, Bullets and Bust
description: THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS

title: NONFICTION
description: SEARCH FOR A SUPERTHEORY: From Atoms to Superstrings. By Barry Parker. (Plenum Press, $21.95.) On the way to the Grand Unified Theory (GUT) charted in this book, we confront hoards of electrons, protons, neutrons, mesons and their discoverers, rushing by like billiard players burdened with eight-balls, positively and negatively charged. Using a peculiar mix of scientific and lay terminology, Barry Parker, the author of two books on science and a professor of physics and astronomy at Idaho State University, has produced a dandy particle-theoretical physics guidebook describing the quest to understand the universe and all its parts. The story ranges from dullish John Dalton surmising the atom in 1808 to physicists rewriting the Big Bang theory right now. The book should be consumed quickly, before it ages. Dates would have been useful, but never mind, because finally, here we have clear explanations of the action in particle accelerators (CERN, SLAC, FERMILAB), and reasons for the clamor for more powerful versions. And what interesting questions the GUT quest raises. Is there really a shadow world? Why do fundamental particles collect in threes? Are those really cosmic superstrings glowing near the center of our galaxy? From between the lines emerge some illuminating views of physicists struggling (and battling) toward truth, glory and first publication honors. A caveat: The subject matter is sometimes arcane. Yet the book creates a strange anticipation. Perhaps this science and this story is, indeed, physics for poets. IRIS POLISKI

title: Shopping for Study Programs
description: IT'S the time of year when teen-age students and their families discuss summer school, summer travel or a semester overseas.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Influx of Foreign Retailers; Europeans Signing Leases Despite the Weak Dollar
description: EUROPEAN makers of everything from eyeglass frames to kitchen cabinets are continuing to sign leases for new retail outlets in American cities and suburban malls, despite the sagging fortunes of the dollar.

title: LAURIE K. NOVAK, BANK EXECUTIVE, BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Laurie Kay Novak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Novak of Houston, to Thomas Stewart Glanville, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Glanville of Darien, Conn., took place yesterday at the Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Houston. The Rev. John Brown officiated, assisted by the Rev. Edward R. Danks, pastor of the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien.

title: Pro Slow Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GUN AND KNIFE SHOW One of two Winchester model 21 three barrel shotguns known to be in existence will be for sale at $50,000 in the Great Westchester Gun and Knife Show, in progress from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. today at the County Center in White Plains. The weapon is owned by Dave Bichrest, a collector from Gray, Me. Mr. Bichrest will also have on display a 1924 engraved Colt Peacemaker for $12,500 and a silver-plated Winchester rifle.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BEFORE THE DARKNESS FALLS. By Eugenia Price. (Doubleday, $17.95.) It's only been two years since the second volume of Eugenia Price's Savannah Quartet appeared, and already we have a third installment. Set in antebellum Georgia, the novel continues the romantic story of the Browning-Mackay-Stiles families.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I am finishing my attic to add a workroom, so I want to add insulation to the roof (it is now on the attic floor). I have been told to allow for ventilation above the insulation - between the insulation and the roof sheathing - but am not sure how to do this. Can you tell me if this is really necessary, and if so where vents should be located?

title: The Case for Kemp
description: A recent prediction in this space (with the wish admittedly father to the thought) that Representative Jack Kemp would upset conventional wisdom and emerge as the Republican nominee has drawn the expected hoots of derision.

title: OVER THEIR HEADS IN HISTORY
description: WINTER A Novel of a Berlin Family. By Len Deighton. 571 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: U.S. Unsure Pakistan Seeks 2d A-Fuel Plant
description: Pakistan may be building a second plant to enrich uranium to be used for nuclear weapons, in the view of some American officials.

title: Anthony Lewis State Of Violence
description: For all that Americans have learned about South Africa in recent years, we remain largely unfamiliar with the mechanisms of white control. How does a government representing a small minority of the population actually exercise totalitarian dominion over the vast majority?

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'MEET THE COMPOSER'

title: MISS PENNINGTON ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Juliet Jean Pennington to James Jude Matte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Matte of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Gloria Pennington of Hastings-on-Hudson and Bruce Pennington of New York. Miss Pennington, a reporter for The Sun Chronicle in Attleboro, Mass., and her fiance, a copy editor at The Boston Herald, plan to marry in May.

title: Russell O. Blosser; Executive, 63
description: Russell O. Blosser, senior vice president of the National Council of the Paper Industry for Air and Stream Improvement, died of a heart attack Dec. 29 in Denver. He was 63 years old and lived in Norwalk, Conn.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: LIMITS STUDIED FOR PAC DONATIONS
description: LEAD: CONCERN over the rising influence of political action committees, or PAC's, is prompting state election officials to look at restrictions on the amount of money candidates can receive from such groups.

title: SARA GREER IS ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Sara Temple Greer to Magruder Harrison Dent has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. William Hershey Greer Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Back to School: Combining Travel With Learning
description: FOR youthful travelers, vacation can mean a welcome hiatus from classrooms, books and study; for another, often older group it means the opposite, an opportunity to spend two or three weeks rediscovering the pleasures of learning, in many cases through seminars, lectures or research projects. A wide array of programs sponsored by academic institutions, museums and nonprofit organizations offers the opportunity to combine travel and education. In many cases, such trips afford travelers experiences and contacts they might not obtain on their own - whether it be tracking dolphins as part of a research team in Hawaii with the University of California's University Research Expeditions Program or meeting garden owners in Ireland with a New York Botanical Garden group.

title: Headliners; Following the Rules
description: ''It's hard to argue with success,'' Dr. Frank Napier Jr., superintendent of schools in Paterson, N.J., said in 1983, speaking of Joe Clark's first year as principal of Paterson's Eastside High School. Hard, maybe, but last week the Paterson Board of Education started an argument that could result in Mr. Clark's dismissal. Mr. Clark has been praised by President Reagan, among others, for bringing discipline to a student body once characterized by the local prosecutor's office as ''a caldron of terror and violence.'' His methods have ranged from ordering mass expulsions to patrolling the hallways with bullhorn and baseball bat, and last month he tried to remove about 60 students who he said had little chance of graduating. The board said he had ignored due process and voted to charge him with insubordination. Said the board's attorney: ''Even Mr. Clark has to follow the rules.''

title:
GARDENING;
TRY HOUSE PLANTS FOR BONSAI
description: LEAD: BONSAI sales have been increasing dramatically recently. According to nurserymen and florists, more and more house plant shoppers are succumbing to the appeal of these dwarf potted trees.

title: A+ FOR ATTENDANCE
description: In the first session of the 100th Congress, most members took part in an overwhelming percentage of House and Senate votes. Some who were running for President, however, participated in fewer than half the votes. Here are the 5 northeastern senators and 10 northeastern representatives who had that best voting attendance records in 1987.

title: Salomon Brothers' John Gutfreund
description: LAST MONTH, JOHN H. GUTFREUND, the chairman and chief executive of Salomon Brothers, Wall Street's largest investment banking house, completed the grueling task of fixing the annual bonuses for his senior managers. There was a lot of bad news to be passed around, including that of his own compensation. He told his executives he would take a $2 million pay cut.

title: SMALL TALK AND BIG STAKES IN BEARS-REDSKINS MATCHUP
description: The coach of the Chicago Bears, before his team's most significant game of the season, suggested that the defensive end of the Washington Redskins has ''the I.Q. of a grapefruit.'' Oh, yeah? Well, Dexter Manley had a snappy answer for Mike Ditka. Manley maintained that the coach has an ''ugly face.'' So there.

title: WATSON AIMS AT '88 RETURN TO TOP OF LEADERS' PACK
description: Two shots in 1987 will go down among the most memorable in golf history -Larry Mize's chip into the second extra hole to beat Greg Norman for the Masters title and Lee Trevino's hole-in-one at the Skins Game in November. Those who saw them on television or in person should remember them - they probably won't be repeated any time soon.

title: Does Clark Make the Yanks the Favorites?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: ARIELLE BIENENSTOCK WEDS A PHYSICIAN
description: >The marriage of Arielle Nadine Bienenstock, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Bienenstock of Belle Harbor, Queens, to Dr. David Kauver, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham J. Kauver of Denver, took place yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbis Jacob Reiner and Bennett Rackman performed the ceremony.

title: Frank Pace Jr., Former Secretary Of the Army and Executive, Dies
description: Frank Pace Jr., a former Secretary of the Army and the first chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, died of a heart attack Friday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: NEW HOMES FOR YOUNG MOTHERS
description: LEAD: THE 18-year-old mother had the baby dressed in pink leggings and a pink-and-white ruffled top when she brought her down to meet the visitors in the living room.

title: TAKING PHILOSOPHY TO GRADE SCHOOLS
description: LEAD: IS PHILOSOPHY an activity only for the intellectual elite -professors at Princeton or Rutgers, perhaps? Or is it the domain of the layman as well?

title: THE ROAD TO SELF-RELIANCE
description: Michael Norman makes some interesting observations in his article ''The Road to Self-Reliance'' (About Men, Dec. 13). It's true that ''society forces [ isolation ] on men.'' But it strikes me as misguided to put aside or deny the anger and pain this causes and to speak of how ''the loneliness . . . served me well.'' It's a little like saying, ''My father used to hit me regularly, and I turned out O.K., so it can't be that bad.'' On the contrary, self-reliance, the ability to function well on one's own, is not taught by hurtful separation and imposed isolation, but by closeness and love. BYRON LEONARD Oak Park, Ill.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Air Travelers In Los Angeles Face New Delays

title: PROSPERO'S ISLAND FORTRESS EUROPE
description: LEAD: PERFECT GALLOWS A Novel of Suspense. By Peter Dickinson. 234 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: Texas
description: To the Editor: I was interested in the feature on Austin, Tex., and the lack of any mention of the Austin Symphony Orchestra under the ''Music'' heading. Mr. Lewis should be aware of the symphony. Symphony Square, which is owned by the symphony, is a fascinating center for music activities, concerts and galas and has a fine restaurant. LOIS H. ALLEN Columbus, Ohio

title: In Stamford, Sweetening The Deals Makes a Difference
description: FROM the time Stonegate opened in the summer of 1986 until last Oct. 19, 53 houses were sold. But from the day the market crashed until the beginning of December, buyers and even lookers at the single-family subdivision in Stamford, Conn., virtually disappeared.

title: If You Can't Fight City Hall, Here's a Different Idea: Sell It
description: While Boston's City Hall is certainly bigger than a breadbox, many municipal employees say that it is far less watertight and useful. And at least one worker there, David Scondras, a City Council member, would like to see the building sold.

title: INSTANTLY NOTORIOUS
description: CVJ Nicknames of Maitre D's & Other Excerpts From Life. By Julian Schnabel. Illustrated. 222 pp. New York: Random House. $75.

title: Central Albania Earthquake Causes Damage to Buildings
description: A strong earthquake struck central Albania early today, rocking and damaging buildings in and near Tirana, the capital. Thousands of residents who had been asleep when the earthquake struck at about 2 A.M. fled into the streets in the rain.

title: IN THE MIDDLE: For OSHA, Balance Is Hard to Find
description: FOR most of the Reagan years, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration has been a punching bag. It was hammered not only by labor unions and other groups seeking safer workplaces, who accused it of internal disarray and lax enforcement, but also by conservatives demanding that it stop stifling American industry with petty rules. But in recent months the agency has made a comeback of sorts.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston; Condos to Rise On Pier Site
description: A FORKED pier on the edge of downtown Boston will soon be the site of a condominium complex to be known as Burroughs Wharf.

title:
BUYING AND SELLING IN A WEAKENED MARKET;
In Fairlawn, the Lynches Cut Their Price to Get a Deal
description: LEAD: AFTER six months of house-hunting, Richard and Geraldine Lynch contracted to buy a colonial in Ridgewood in the $300,000 range last October, before selling their Cape Cod in the Radburn section of Fairlawn and just before the stock market plunged.

title: Judges and Lawyers Honor a 'Pioneer'
description: Helen L. Buttenwieser, a legendary figure in New York legal circles, felt a bit of trepidation about what lay ahead Friday night.

title: CRAFT FOR WATER-SKIING: DESIGN GLIDES BEYOND BASICS
description: UNTIL 20 years ago, water-skiers were content to use a standard powerboat with outboard engine to tow them across a lake or a bay. The only requirement was that the boat have sufficient horsepower.

title: BRUBECK ODE TAPS SPIRITUAL ROOTS
description: LEAD: LOOKING back on it now, after almost 20 years, Dave Brubeck, the jazz musician-composer, recalls that as a white Christian he was more than just a bit ''nervous'' about writing a cantata that would draw historic and spiritual parallels between Jews and American blacks.

title: THIS WAY THE LABYRINTH, THAT WAY THE ABYSS
description: JOHN CALVIN A Sixteenth Century Portrait. By William J. Bouwsma. 310 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Girl Scouts Gorge In Mechanicsburg IT'S time to sell Girl Scout cookies and so, to honor the tradition and work up some enthusiasm, the scouts of Mechanicsburg, Pa., held a cookie eating contest.

title: A Crack Addict, 17, Is Held in the Killings Of Five Since Jan. 1
description: A 17-year-old, described by the police as a crack addict, was charged yesterday with killing five people and wounding six others in a series of robberies in East Harlem that began on New Year's Day.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Tamiment, Pa.;
Pocono Resort Redevelopment
description: LEAD: THE new owner of the Pocono Mountains Tamiment resort is continuing the ambitious residential development started under the former owners, a Nevada investment group in which the entertainer Wayne Newton had a substantial interest.

title: Job for Radical Reflects Role of Brooklyn Group
description: Within months of his acquittal on Federal charges of conspiring to organize a prisoner escape and rob armored cars, Roger Wareham, one of a group of black revolutionaries known as the New York Eight, landed a job at the Center for Law and Social Justice, where he helped establish a 24-hour hot line to monitor reports of police brutality.

title: THE MYTHS OF HUNTING
description: In explaining why he chooses not to hunt, gentle Hervie Haufler [ ''Three-Generation Perspective of Hunting and Killing,'' Opinion page, Dec. 13 ] shows he has bought two of the most powerful myths, both promoted by game agencies, that perpetuate the notions that hunting is necessary to reduce deer overpopulation and that the legendary conservationist John James Audubon is the prototype for combining kindness and killing No data support the overpopulation contention. In fact, Connecticut's deer herd has multiplied sixfold since it began being ''managed'' in 1975, hardly a help to motorists and farmers. Experts, some of whom have no ethical objections to sports hunting, reported succinctly on this dearth at a recent forum at Yale University.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; A Revival By the River
description: TRAIN passengers to Wilmington used to arrive at a rundown railroad station in an equally shabby neighborhood. Now the station has changed and so has the neighborhood.

title: WHY SHOULD NOBEL LAUREATES FORFEIT THE MONEY?
description: ALTHOUGH the American Nobel Committee has no official connection with the Nobel Institutes in Norway and Sweden, we reflect the interests of some 100 American Nobel Laureates. There are more Nobelists in the United States than the rest of the world combined.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: IT'S ALL IN THE PLAYING. By Shirley MacLaine. Bantam, $18.95.) This fifth installment of Shirley MacLaine's memoirs and forays into the metaphysical world recounts the filming for television of her previous book on reincarnation, ''Out on a Limb.'' Before going in front of the cameras, Ms. MacLaine voiced concern that television critics might be inclined to pan the production because they hadn't had ''otherworldly'' experiences themselves.

title: BRIDGEPORT TO PREMIERE BRITISH MUSICAL
description: WHAT to call ''Blood Brothers''? Is it a musical melodrama, a musical tragedy or, more singularly, a ''modern ballad opera brushed with legend,'' as one London reviewer described it.

title: Theater
description: If you remember high school - or even if you have forgotten high school - you should enjoy ''Oil City Symphony'' (at Circle-in-the-Square Downtown, 159 Bleecker Street), a grand spoof of old times, good times and those who compulsively return for reunions. Four musically inclined graduates of Oil City High come together in concert to honor a former teacher, toasting her with a garland of nostalgic and amusing tunes. Some of the songs are as familiar as John Phillips Sousa, many of them are new hewn by the cast, including ''Ohio Afternoon,'' which takes off on all lazy, moonlight-bay ballads.

title: DENNY'S TO REPLACE NATHAN HALE'S ON I-95
description: LEAD: DENNY'S RESTAURANTS is to become the third chain in less than three years to provide sit-down food service on Interstate 95 in Fairfield and Milford, according to the State Department of Transportation.

title:
GARDENING;
THE DIVERSITY AND USEFULNESS OF CONIFERS
description: LEAD: CONIFERS, or cone-bearing evergreens, are just as popular in the garden as they are for holiday decorations. While the most interesting landscapes use both deciduous and evergreen plants, the conifers are so diverse it is entirely possible to develop a garden with year-round interest using only them.

title: The Kingdom And the Power At Cambridge
description: ''I'M a fellow in English here at Cambridge,'' the young man presiding over our class told us, ''and I shall be the literature half of your course on Tudor kingship. My history colleague will handle the historical material and we hope our different approaches, intellectual prejudices and convictions will crossfertilize the subject and give you the chance to explore it in considerable depth.''

title: 3 ARTISTIC DIRECTORS MOVE INTO SPOTLIGHT
description: ALTHOUGH the state's professional theaters reflect a repertory of extraordinary variety - from the new year's first opening (a Shakespearean tragedy, as interpreted by a leading and much-lauded experimental troupe) to the season's windup (the reworking of a failed, but, for many, a favorite Jerry Herman musical) - it appears that the current attention-getters are three artistic directors.

title: AFFORDABLE THAI FARE IN Westport
description: THE Thai restaurant wave that seems to be flowing throughout the United States is rippling into Fairfield County. First there was Bangkok in Danbury. Now we have a new entry, Siam-o-cha, in Westport. Tucked away in the largely unchanged upstairs premises formerly occupied by Chez Bach, Siam-o-cha (whose name means delicious Siam), is a happy addition to Westport's expanding ethnic dining scene.

title: In Gaza, Confrontation at Crossroads of History
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ODD COUPLE - POUND AND YEATS TOGETHER
description: EZRA POUND began publishing ''The Cantos'' in 1917, and when he left the poem unfinished at his death, he had included material ranging from ancient Homeric hymns to Chinese dynastic history. At the center of the 800-page poem, surrounded by esoterica, occur these lines: I recalled the noise in the chimney as it were the wind in the chimney but was in reality Uncle William downstairs composing . . . at Stone Cottage in Sussex by the waste moor.

title: Plan to Protect Bluefish Is Nearly Complete
description: BLUEFISH have been abundant along the Atlantic coast for more than 10 years, so abundant that they have become the backbone of a multimillion-dollar marine sport fishing industry from Cape Cod to Cape May, N.J. And now a Federal-state plan, aimed at insuring that the species is not overharvested by recreational or commercial interests, is nearing completion.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Nov. 29 article from Concord, Mass., about efforts to ban swimming in Walden Pond in Concord, Mass., misstated the status of a concrete pier. The pier was removed in 1983.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Sunday about the new immigration law incorrectly described the number of aliens whose applications have been approved for lawful status. About 1.2 million aliens have applied so far, and fewer than a quarter of their applications have been fully reviewed. Of those that have been reviewed, 92 percent, or 249,000, have been approved.

title: Eisner Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: PAMELA REYNOLDS, PHYSICIAN, IS WED
description: At the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C., Dr. Pamela Preston Reynolds, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Reynolds of Akron, Ohio, was married yesterday to Dr. John Robert Ball, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Ball Jr. of Auburn, Ala. The Rev. Noel Calhoun, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: KENTUKY, AT HOME, UPSET BY AUBURN
description: John Caylor sank a 3-point basket with 10 seconds left tonight as unranked Auburn stunned top-ranked Kentucky, 53-52.

title: A Cautious U.S. Response To Plan on Afghanistan
description: AFGHANISTAN has become the world's leading hypothetical question. If the Soviet Union truly plans to withdraw its 115,000 troops in 1988, as Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said last week, if it abandons its clients in Afghanistan's Communist Government, if it surrenders that country to the civil strife and rebel takeover that seem likely to follow a pullout, then the Russians will have suffered a rare reversal in the expansion of the empire that they began building under the czars.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 9 of the Travel section today about the Portman hotel in San Francisco identifies the hotel management incorrectly. The property is managed by the Portman Hotel Company of Atlanta, which has affiliated with the Peninsula Group of Hong Kong for marketing purposes only.

title: Princeton Alters Plan For Jewish Center
description: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY has revised its plans for a Center for Jewish Life, which were put on hold at the end of 1986 because the major contributor, Ivan Boesky, had run into trouble with the Securities and Exchange Commission and withdrawn his $750,000 pledge.

title: BRONX IS THE SUBJECT THROUGH EYE OF A RESIDENT REALIST
description: IT is not easy being a Realist these days. Something - the massive art-education program of the last 30 years, the long shadow that Abstract Expressionism still casts, end-of-the-century blues - has made it very difficult for artists to tackle observable reality without a game plan or without seeming to put their efforts in quotes. Sylvia Plimack Mangold is an example, with her beautiful Corot-like landscapes that she renders Conceptual by bordering them with masking tape.

title: Sports World Specials; Decoding Baseball
description: Baseball has long been known as the national pastime. But in recent years satellite transmissions have given the sport true national scope, at least for the 2 million or so Americans with satellite dishes connected to their television sets.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 10, 1988: MONDAY La-Z-Boy Chair Co...Phillips Petroleum Oxford Indus TUESDAY Diversified Energies...TECO Energy Procter & Gamble WEDNESDAY Bard (CR)...Walgreen Co Pacificorp...Wisconsin Pwr & Lt Transco Energy...Woolworth (FW) Co USLIFE Inc Fd THURSDAY Hartmarx Corp...NERCO Inc Idaho Power...Texas Industries L & N Housing FRIDAY CP National...Twin Disc NY State El & Gas

title: Nofziger's Trial Is Opening With Jury Selection Today
description: Jury selection is scheduled to begin Monday in the trial of Lyn Nofziger, the former top political adviser to President Reagan who is accused of capitalizing on his relationship with the President in violation of Federal ethics law.

title: Off Season for Baseball Isn't What It Used to Be
description: IN the old days, Casey Stengel used to drive a taxicab in Kansas City to pay the bills, Walter Johnson dug postholes for the Idaho Telephone Company, Smoky Joe Wood and countless other baseball players spent their winters working the family farm and Rube Marquard passed three winters hoofing round the vaudeville circuit on stage with his wife, Blossom Seeley.

title: Disqualified Haitian Candidates Expected to Fight Panel's Action
description: Many Haitians and Western diplomats said today that they expected former associates of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship to appeal the rejection of their candidacies for the presidential election scheduled for Jan. 17.

title: Cabaret: Jimmy Webb Sings Webb at Wallman's
description: THE songs of Jimmy Webb, whose hits for Glen Campbell, the Fifth Dimension and Richard Harris made him the ranking wunderkind of West Coast songwriters in late 1960's, are defined by an unblushingly effulgent romanticism. From early hits like ''Up Up and Away'' and ''MacArthur Park'' to recent songs like the lovely ballad ''Skywriter,'' which he performed at Jan Wallman's on Friday, his music strains against the conventional boundaries of pop form toward an operatic breadth and expressiveness. Many of his lyrics employ a homegrown lyric surrealism to capture the evanescent passion of the moment. At the same time, Mr. Webb's songs are driven by a country-flavored melodic directness.

title: It Takes Single-Minded Zeal to Protect New York's Landmarks
description: To the Editor:

title: Move to Require Recycling Gains In City Council
description: Frustrated by the slow pace of the fledgling recycling efforts in New York City, 16 City Council members are backing legislation that would make recycling mandatory citywide and set a four-year goal of reusing a fourth of the city's garbage.

title: STICKS AND STONES ARE FLYING AS BUSH-DOLE RIVALRY HEATS
description: Democrats have always relished political brawling. The Republicans say they prefer campaigns run according to the rules of engagement laid down by Emily Post.

title: College Basketball; St. John's Can't Get Started
description: Lou Carnesecca's postgame comments notwithstanding, St. John's hasn't been through this before - at least, not recently.

title: False Picture Given Of Highway Fatalities
description: To the Editor:

title: Business and the Law; Tactic on Witness Draws Judge's Ire
description: WHEN a lawyer for a major financial underwriter refused last month to produce a company executive at a trial in San Diego, the Federal District Court judge supervising the case decided he had heard enough.

title: Grand Jury Isn't Finished With Arizona Governor
description: The state grand jury that has indicted Gov. Evan Mecham on six felony counts will take a few weeks off but has not concluded its investigation of him, Attorney General Bob Corbin said today.

title: Oil Discounts By Saudis Are Reported
description: Losing patience with price discounting by other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Saudi Arabia has introduced a discount plan to insure it will hold on to its major American customers, a respected trade journal and industry experts said.

title: A Brazilian Parable of Furniture and Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Is to Hold Talks With Theater Council
description: The city's relationship with Broadway theater is to be the subject of talks this morning between Mayor Koch and a panel that has accused him in the past of ignoring its suggestions: his Theater Advisory Council.

title: Olympic Notebook; U.S. Committee Sets Sights on Raising Budget
description: With rising costs and increasing demands for new and better facilities and athletic development programs, the United States Olympic Committee has projected an operating budget for the next four years of about $200 million.

title: Emhart Offers to Acquire Stanadyne
description: The Emhart Corporation announced yesterday that it would make a $577 million unsolicited bid for Stanadyne Inc., which makes precision metal parts.

title: India's Birth-Rate Burden: One Northern Village Tells the Story
description: Looking drawn and tired, Ram Kumari all but admitted that she was unlikely to become pregnant again. In the last 20 years, she had given birth to six children, only four of whom survived, and now her husband was weak and ailing, unable to farm or harvest this year's rice.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1988
description: International A2-11 A Moscow-Beijing summit proposal was made by Mikhail S. Gorbachev in an interview with a Chinese magazine. The proposal underscored Mr. Gorbachev's desire for more normal relations between the two largest Communist societies. Page A1

title: Sports of The Times; Walter Payton's Last Time
description: WHEN the game ended and the Bears had lost, when he knew he would never play football again, Walter Payton sat on the Bears bench with his head in his hands for perhaps five minutes. In the chill - it felt as if it was 23 degrees below zero - his teammates had hurried off Soldier Field to the warmth of their locker room. But in his ''34'' jersey, the best running back in National Football League history was out there all by himself on the Bears' bench, his face smeared with tears.

title: Study Says Inspectors Overlooked Violations
description: Environmental inspectors are overlooking more than half the serious violations at facilities handling and storing hazardous waste, a Congressional study says.

title: The Brady Report: Looking for Flaws; Market Makers Receive Criticism and Sympathy
description: The Presidential panel that evaluated the performance of market makers in October's stock plunge criticized the New York Stock Exchange specialists, although it acknowledged that they were faced with unprecedented conditions.

title: PLAN URGES NEW LOOK AT TERMINAL By RICHARD LEVINE
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad would like to make Grand Central Terminal a destination in its own right and not just a place to catch a train.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1988
description: Markets

title: Memphis Journal; Where Barbecue Lovers Go Simply Hog Wild
description: A whole lot of people, including some Kansas Citians, many North Carolinians and most Texans, claim distinction when it comes to cooking and enjoying barbecue.

title: The Right Choice
description: For Phil Sellers, choosing a college to attend some 16 years ago was not an easy process. It never is for high school basketball players who rank among the best in the country.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMR Corp., Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, and its American Airlines subsidiary announced that John C. Pope had resigned as senior vice president of finance and chief financial officer to become executive vice president of finance at United Airlines

title: Knicks Top Celtics on 'Charm'
description: Rick Pitino is noted for his ability to movitate his players. He did it last year when his Providence College team went to the Final Four. And he is trying to use some of that same psychology in his rookie season as the Knick coach.

title: Hong Kong Market Shift
description: Hong Kong's stock exchange, stunned a week ago by the arrests of three top officials, announced a management shake-up on Saturday.

title: Redskins Knock Out Bears; Broncos Crush Oilers; Elway Leads Onslaught
description: The Denver Broncos moved a step closer to a second consecutive appearance in the Super Bowl by ending the ambitious hopes of the Houston Oilers in the last of the weekend's four playoff games.

title: Mr. Bush's Skeleton
description: The questions Vice President Bush's campaign is raising about Senator Bob Dole's finances seem too contrived and nit-picking - even in this year of The Skeleton in the Closet - to divert inquiry from Mr. Bush's own involvement in the Reagan Administration's Iran-contra scandal.

title: Israeli Army Reinforces Troops in Gaza
description: The Israeli Army poured reinforcements into the Gaza Strip today but failed to quell continued violence as two more Palestinians died of army gunshot wounds.

title: Colorado Avalanche Leaves 2 Dead and 1 Missing
description: An avalanche roared down a mountain pass near this resort, killing two skiers today, the authorities said. A third skier was missing.

title: Opera: 'Sir John in Love,' at Lehman College
description: RALPH Vaughan Williams's ''Sir John in Love'' is probably the closest approach before Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' to a satisfactory Shakespeare opera in English. The Bronx Opera Company opened its 20th-anniversary season with a new production of the piece (which it first revived in 1978) Saturday evening at the Lehman College Theater, in the Bronx. There will be Manhattan performances Friday and Saturday at the Hunter College Playhouse, 695 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, and a visit should be worthwhile for anyone interested in this ambitious opera.

title: A.F.C. Playoffs; Browns Get a Second Chance
description: The Cleveland Browns won't play in the American Conference championship game until next Sunday, but along with their fans they've been playing the game for the past year.

title: GORBACHEV OFFERS A SUMMIT MEETING WITH THE CHINESE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed a summit meeting with China's leadership in an interview published today in a Chinese magazine.

title: Edward V. Hickey Jr., Federal Maritime Commissioner, 52
description: Edward V. Hickey Jr., chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission since 1985, died unexpectedly of heart failure on Saturday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 52 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: HE GOT HUNGRY AND FORGOT HIS MANNERS. A Fable. By Jimmy Breslin. 275 pages. Ticknor & Fields/Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

title: Jazz: Philly Connection
description: THE Philly Connection, a group consisting of the vibraphonist Khan Jamal, the bassist Jamaaladeen Tacuma, and the drummer Dennis Alston came to Jazztrack on Saturday night to have fun. All three are virtuosos, and listening to their intense first set was like overhearing a conversation by friends who haven't seen each o erern n ara And with all their risk taking and informal good humor, they invited the audience to share their joy.

title: Ballet: The Kirov's 'Giselle' in Paris
description: Yekaterina Maksimova and Vladimir Vasiliev, two of the greatest dancers the Bolshoi Ballet has ever produced, are now in their late 40's - nearly three decades away from their 1959 New York debut with the company from Moscow. It was an unforgettable beginning that made them international favorites.

title: Kennedy vs. Murdoch: Test of Motives
description: In a city with a distinguished political tradition of grudges and vendettas, some people are asking what is really behind Senator Edward M. Kennedy's hot battle with the publisher Rupert Murdoch.

title: Jersey's Anti-Takeover Law
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean has signed legislation that makes permanent a law that protects New Jersey companies from hostile takeover bids.

title: Why New Delhi's Plans Just Don't Work
description: Declaring population growth to be India's most serious problem, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi doubled expenditures for health and family planning services in the last two years. But the country's own experts say they have been disappointed by the results so far.

title: Adirondack TV: Low-Power Gamble
description: LEAD: In the foothills of the Adirondacks, where mountains often obstruct television signals and satellite dishes are as common in backyards as clotheslines, Jim Grich has taken the gamble of starting his own low-power television station.

title: N.F.C. Playoffs; Vikings Peaking At the Perfect Time
description: Obviously, the Minnesota Vikings are doing many things right in the National Football League playoffs, and their timing could not be better.

title: Team of 100 Will Battle Building Industry Graft
description: In a combined drive against corruption and racketeering in New York City's construction industry, state and city officials say they are assembling a unit of more than 100 prosecutors, investigators, auditors and other personnel.

title: KARYN SUSAN STIEFEL WED TO ASHER A. BLASS ON L.I.
description: At Temple Ohr Torah in North Woodmere, L.I., Karyn Susan Stiefel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Stiefel of West Hempstead, L.I., was married yesterday to Asher Ansel Blass, a son of Lorell Blass of Herzliya, Israel, and the late Dr. Judd Blass. Rabbi Jonathan Blass, the brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Warsaw Journal; A Dream House? The Poles Just Keep Dreaming
description: The white clapboard bungalow, four rooms, kitchen, bath and carport, seems better suited to Levittown than to Lublin.

title: Burmese Train Bomb Kills 8; Tie to Anti-Rebel Drive Seen
description: A bomb exploded on a Burmese passenger train arriving in Rangoon from Mandalay today, killing at least eight people and wounding 38, the official Burmese radio reported tonight.

title: Jet Passenger Discharged
description: A USAir jetliner made an unscheduled stop in Kansas City early Saturday to discharge an intoxicated passenger who tried unsuccessfully to open the cockpit door and an outer door during the flight, officials said. Federal agents arrested the man, who was identified only as a 24-year-old San Diego resident. The plane was en route from San Diego to Pittsburgh when the incident occurred.

title: Outdoors: Sonar, Radar and Loran
description: TRYING to chart a sensible course through the enticing maze of sonar, radar and Loran units displayed at New York City's 78th National Boat Show reminded me of the time when, with pocket watch and compass, I learned to pilot my father's open launch between the north shore of Martha's Vineyard and the Elizabeth Islands in fog so thick one couldn't see three boat-lengths ahead.

title:
Market Place;
Merrill Sees Volatility For 1988
