description: LEAD: ACCORDING to Robert J. Farrell, the Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at 1,911.31 on Friday, could end the year at 2,100. That is not to say that Mr. Farrell, the chief market analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, thinks Wall Street will have an uneventful year. After all, the Dow closed out last year at 1,938.83, for a gain of 42.88 points for all of 1987 - and nobody would call 1987 uneventful.

title: ERIC M. BREINDEL WEDS MS. JACOBY
description: Tamar Jacoby, a senior writer at Newsweek, and Eric M. Breindel, the editorial page editor and a columnist for The New York Post, were married yesterday in Manhattan at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Breindel. Rabbis Judah Nadich and Arthur Hertzberg officiated.

title: Two Youths Are Shot Outside Skating Rink
description: Two youths were wounded, one of them critically, in a shooting yesterday afternoon outside a popular roller skating rink in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Chevron-Rhone Deal
description: The Chevron Corporation said its subsidiary, the Chevron Chemical Company, would assume management responsibility for Orogil S.A., which it owns jointly with Rhone-Poulenc, a French chemical company. Chevron said it might also acquire Rhone-Poulenc's 50 percent interest in the European manufacturer of petroleum additives in the future. Chevron also said it had acquired Rhone-Poulenc's 30 percent interest in an affiliate, Petrosynthese S.A., increasing Chevron's share in that concern to 65 percent. It did not disclose the terms of the transaction.

title: After 17 Years Buried in Ice, Airplane Flies in Antarctica
description: Seventeen years after it crashed on takeoff at a remote site in the Antarctic, a ski-equipped Hercules aircraft Sunday flew over the ice and snow that had once buried all but three feet of its tail.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A political dialogue is established. We believe a Soviet-Chinese summit could be its logical extension.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A1:6. ]

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic And 'Meet the Moderns'
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic under the direction of Lukas Foss will give four concerts this season in its ''Meet the Moderns'' series, with programs including seven world premieres, three United States premieres and five New York City premieres.

title: JUDITH TROSSMAN IS WED
description: Judith L. Trossman, an editor in the communications department at the accounting firm of Peat Marwick Main & Company in Montvale, N.J., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Dr. Alvin Ruthenberg, a dentist in Brooklyn. Rabbi Andre Unger officiated at the Village Green. The bride is the daughter of Shirley Newman of Schenectady, N.Y., and Sanford Lindy of West Hartford, Conn. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of the bridegroom. He is a son of Miriam Ruthenberg of Long Beach, L.I., and Hollywood, Fla., and the late Edward Ruthenberg.

title: Retailers Seek to Use Scanners More
description: For a dozen years, general retailers and apparel and textile manufacturers have envied the supermarket industry's black-and-white bar code, which has helped speed customers through checkouts. But the vast number of general merchandise items -in many different sizes and shapes -had seemed to be an obstacle to wider use of bar-code scanners.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Actuary Fulfills Dream By Buyout of Reinsurer
description: LEAD: Steven H. Newman started business in his native Brooklyn. He sold used comic books and recycled newspapers to finance his studies at Brooklyn College, where a part-time job as an actuary's assistant set him on a 20-year path to the pinnacle of that profession.

title: Not a Luxury Item
description: To the Editor:

title: Back on Road, Nets Lose to the Bucks
description: Desperate for a victory after four losses in their previous five games, the Milwaukee Bucks found the perfect solution today: the Nets.

title: 3 SLAIN AND 2 HURT IN BRONX SHOOTING
description: Three gunmen entered an apartment in the Bronx early yesterday, forced the occupants to remove their clothes and then shot them repeatedly, killing three men and wounding two others, the police said.

title: Fitness; Exercising Carries Risks With Rewards
description: THE death last week of the retired professional basketball player Pete Maravich offers a sober lesson for anyone who exercises or is thinking of exercising. Maravich, who was 40 years old, collapsed and died of sudden cardiac arrest while playing basketball with friends in a church gymnasium in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Punish the Mother, Not the Daughter
description: Judith Clark, a former member of the Weather Underground, has spent the last six years behind bars for her part in a 1981 robbery that resulted in the death of two policemen and an armored truck guard. Last month, she was suddenly transferred from New York State's penitentiary for women in Westchester County to a Federal facility in Tucson, Ariz. The state had reasonable grounds for the transfer. Still, there's reason to give complaints from Ms. Clark's family and friends a hearing. The transfer not only affects the prisoner but her young daughter, who bears no responsibility for her mother's criminality.

title: The Brady Report: Dissecting the Trading; 'Unsettling Signs,' Then a Sweeping Selloff, in October Stock Plunge
description: Following is an excerpt from the report of the Presidential Task Force on Market Mechanisms, which spent two months studying the October stock market collapse: A Ripple Effect

title: Dole Assails Bush Staff
description: Bob Dole said today that the distribution of a negative article about him by the staff of Vice President Bush was similar to the derailment of Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s Presidential campaign by Michael S. Dukakis's campaign staff.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Did Paul (Bear) Bryant coach the most Heisman Trophy winners? In a head-coaching career that spanned 38 years at four colleges from 1945 to 1982 and resulted in 323 victories, Bryant saw only one of his players voted the Heisman Trophy, and it wasn't even a player at Alabama, where Bryant coached for 25 years. In 1957, Bryant's fourth and last season at Texas A&M, John David Crow, his star running back, won the Heisman.

title: Inside the 'Tank': Bowls of Candy and Big Brass
description: When Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, Chief of the Soviet General Staff, called on the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff during the Washington summit meeting last month, he was invited into their sanctum sanctorum, a place rarely visited by any outsiders, much less Communist military men.

title: Remark on Maimed Official Brings Demand for Apology
description: The District Attorney here has demanded an apology from a City Councilman who said the prosecutor won his election only because he lost a leg fighting in Vietnam.

title: Short-Term Bill Auctions Highlight Sales This Week
description: Treasury auctions this week are confined to the bill market, where today's regular sale of new three-month and six-month issues will be followed by a one-year issue on Thursday.

title: Brazil to Hold Talks on Debt
description: Brazil will resume debt talks on Monday, and Goverment officials said the success or failure of the talks will determine whether the country definitively lifts its moratorium on paying interest on its $70 billion bank debt.

title: Redskins Knock Out Bears; Broncos Crush Oilers; Washington Rallies, 21-17
description: Jim McMahon had said he would return. The posters all over this city - the solemn leader in his general's uniform and corncob pipe - had reinforced the promise. McMahon was back, and everything would be all right. Too cold, but all right.

title: Reaching for Cognac, Seagram Is Blocked
description: The Seagram Company has learned that it is not easy to wed a sexy French company like Martell & Compagnie, the renowned cognac house.

title: Thatcher's Top Deputy and Consensus Builder Resigns in Ill Health
description: Deputy Prime Minister Lord Whitelaw, one of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's closest aides, resigned today because of ill health after suffering a slight stroke last month.

title: U.S. JOB OFFER FOR TOUGH PRINCIPAL
description: Joe Clark, the Paterson, N.J., high school principal whose tough actions have led to conflict with the local school board, has been offered a post in the Reagan Administration, a White House official said yesterday.

title: Rangers Fall to Sabres
description: Appalled at how little the play of his team in the first period resembled its performances of the last three weeks, Coach Michel Bergeron proceeded to tinker with its cast tonight. Thus reorganized, the Rangers for two periods struggled to act in concert. They wound up, however, producing only an old and disturbingly familiar encore.

title: U.S. Still Needs To Buy Grain
description: The United States, the world's leading grower of grain, also is a major importer. The reason, according to farmers and policy makers, lies in the conflicting goals of the Federal farm program, and in global competition.

title: Advertising; Merger Goes Smoothly for Saatchi Unit
description: THE much-talked-about merger by Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi of its Ted Bates Worldwide and Backer & Spielvogel, forming Backer Spielvogel Bates, was completed Oct. 1. Now, three months later, G. Robert Holmen, who is chairman and chief executive domestically, is on the verge of calling the merger a success.

title: Dollar Up; Tokyo Stocks Fall
description: The dollar was trading in mid-afternoon at 128.50 yen, slightly above its closing price of 128.30 yen Friday in New York. But Tokyo stocks fell 1.3 percent today in thin trading as Wall Street's 140-point plunge on Friday reminded traders of the October stock market collapse.

title: Philippines' Delay Is Causing $1 Billion in Aid to Languish
description: Some $1.5 billion in international aid available to the Philippines is stuck in the pipeline awaiting decisions on how it should be spent, according to officials of the State Department, Pentagon and Agency for International Development.

title: A 1988 Wish List
description: LEAD: Here, for the new year, are 10 not inconceivable changes that would help fix up the world. 1. The Soviet Union lives up to its declared intent and pulls out of Afghanistan, we end aid to the freedom fighters and a United Nations peacekeeping force certifies Afghan neutrality. 2. The Soviet Union and Cubans end military aid to Nicaragua, and the contras participate in an election conducted by the Organization of American States.

title: On Your Own: Running; As Women Run More, Relationships Run Better
description: IN the beginning, men ran and women didn't, and running came between them. Seduced by the many health benefits of running and its combination of play and competition, the born-again athletes of the 1970's became obsessed, to the detriment of relationships. Men even took perverse pride in their addictive behavior, flaunting their excesses as a kind of emancipation from the traditional needs of work, family and romance.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Executive in Demand - In Bankruptcy Court
description: Philip B. Schwab's formal job description could be, and often is, president of any one of several construction, demolition or heavy equipment companies based in the New York City area. But to hear his creditors tell it, sometimes in court testimony, he is in the bamboozle business - has been for years.

title: If Arms Were Cut 50%
description: LEAD: So great are the excesses of the era of nuclear overkill that the American and Soviet strategic nuclear arsenals can be reduced by 50 percent - and more -without risking security. Political, military and psychological reasons strongly point toward the wisdom of reductions; the time appears propitious on both sides.

title: Advertising; 2 Executives Leaving J. Walter Thompson
description: With an exceedingly flowery memo, Burton Manning, chairman and chief executive of the British-owned J. Walter Thompson Company, notified his people that two members of Don Johnston's management team would be leaving the agency - as Mr. Johnston, the former chief executive, quietly did himself late last year.

title: Dukakis, Shunning Manager Label, Incorporates Oratory of Compassion
description: It was a classic Democratic tableau: rich with ethnicity, populated by children and senior citizens, presided over by a candidate voicing compassion and concern.

title: Memo to Schools Chief: A System Adrift
description: At the Bronx High School of Science, one of New York City's premier public schools, more than 300 windows have been shattered since last summer. But because of a union contract, only half have been fixed, leaving the school with the aura of an abandoned building rather than a place of achievement.

title: Jersey Legislators Face Old Issues in New Session
description: Environmental concerns and other problems that have defied legislative remedies will be the most pressing issues when the New Jersey Legislature convenes on Tuesday to close the book on its 202d session and open its 203d.

title: John Cade, Political Strategist, 59
description: John Cade, the political strategist who masterminded the 1979 campaign that made Dave Treen Louisiana's first Republican Governor since Reconstruction, died Friday at the age of 59.

title: BOY KILLS MOTHER AND HIMSELF
description: A 14-year-old Milton, N.J., boy interested in the occult killed his mother with his Boy Scout knife, set a fire in the family's house as his father and brother slept, then committed suicide with the same knife, the authorities said.

title: Cabaret: Judith Cohen Returns to the Ballroom
description: THE return to the Ballroom, at 253 West 28th Street, of Judith Cohen, one of the most popular figures in the 1970's cabaret revival, is a reminder of how, even in a milieu that treasures nostalgia, styles come and go.

title: Clear for Take-Off
description: Last year Tom Webster may have been willing to sell his soul to the doctor just to hear him say it was O.K. to fly. The former Ranger coach suffered from a disorder that grounded him from flying and forced him to step down from a job he waited a lifetime to receive.

title: It's Only Snow
description: An eight-inch snowstorm that caused an official closing of the Federal Government on Friday was no match for the two main participants in one of Washington's longest-running public forums. It was the 101st monthly appearance by Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress to explain the latest employment figures. Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, has presided on 70 of these occasions.

title: Colombia's Diversification Into Flowers Pays Off
description: They are still tiny but, by the time they are chosen to bolster some message of love on St. Valentine's Day, they will have traveled several thousand miles and matured into beautiful long-stemmed red roses.

title: Panel Says MX Guidance Problems Continue
description: The guidance systems used for aiming MX missiles are continuing to fail in tests at an alarming rate, the House Armed Services Committee reported today.

title: Recital: Lin and Schub
description: FOR their recital at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, Andre-Michel Schub and Cho-Liang Lin chose a program fitting to their talents but never really matching their youth and energy. There was an air of safety to the proceedings - the requisite Beethoven piano-violin sonata (the E flat from Opus 12), the requisite Romantic piece (Brahms's D minor Sonata from the late years), Prokofiev's F minor Sonata to add a touch of easily digestible modernity, and novelties that were few and brief (two Stravinsky-Dushkin transcriptions called ''Pastorale'' and ''Tango'').

title: WHEN JUSTICE ISN'T BLINDFOLDED
description: LEAD: Government's most intimidating power is the power to indict: to accuse a citizen of a crime and place him at risk of imprisonment. Confronted with an indictment, a citizen has two sources of strength - the constitutional presumption that he is innocent and the constitutional right to have a lawyer represent him.

title: System's Surprising Breakdowns
description: A startling features of the report by the Presidential panel on the stock market collapse is its conclusion that several major systems that had been expected to protect the market or keep it in balance instead contributed to its near disintegration last October.

title: Hopes Dim for Further Rate Cuts
description: Hopes for lower interest rates were dealt a blow Friday when the Government announced stronger-than-expected employment data for December.

title: U.S. and Mexico: Trade Barriers Fall
description: Mars chocolate bars, Miller Lite beer, Avon products and WestPoint Pepperell towels are among American products that will become available in Mexico for the first time after a spate of unusual agreements between the two countries.

title: New York City to Reassess Zoning Trade-Offs
description: Amid a heightened sensitivity about development in New York City, a range of officials - from Mayor Koch to some of his sharpest critics - are calling for a reassessment of the widespread practice of trading zoning variances for promises of public amenities.

title: On the Supply Side
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Reviews; 'Evil in Clear River,' With Lindsay Wagner
description: CONFRONTING the disease of anti-Semitism, ''Evil in Clear River'' gets the symptoms right but is curiously vague about the root causes. On Channel 7 at 9 this evening, the television movie is, according to a press release, ''a fictionalized drama suggested by real events.'' The fictionalizing seems to have left reality decidedly fudged.

title: STOCK TRADERS WARY ABOUT TODAY; SOME PARALLELS WITH OCTOBER SEEN
description: LEAD: Investors and traders are facing today's opening of the stock market with a high degree of uncertainty.

title: Intimidated Colombia Courts Yield to Drug Barons
description: Demoralized by corruption and virtually paralyzed by fear, Colombia's courts have signaled their unwillingness to continue fighting this country's powerful drug barons.

title: Figure Skating; Boitano, Thomas In Good Shape
description: In figure skating, reputation is everything.

title: Music: Emigres at Merkin
description: ''THE MUSIC OF MIRACLES'' at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night was part celebration, part plea and partly music as well. Its subject (and object) was Chamah, an organization dedicated to the health and growth of Judaism in the Soviet Union. A good part of the evening was taken up by speeches and awards, but there was also music by Russian-Jewish musicians who have emigrated to the West in recent years.

title: IN THE BATTLEGROUND OF GAZA, PARENTS JOIN IN YOUTHS' ZEAL
description: A battered white Peugeot pulled up to the roadblock the Palestinians had thrown across the main highway through the Gaza Strip, and the driver opened the trunk to reveal his cargo: eggplant, tomatoes, scallions and potatoes.

title: U.S. Urged to Cut Reliance on Nuclear Arms
description: A bipartisan Pentagon commission will recommend to President Reagan on Tuesday that the United States play down its reliance on nuclear weapons and shift toward a strategy of deterrence that gives greater emphasis to more advanced and accurate non-nuclear weapons.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, page C26 of The Home Section last week, opposite the television listings, bore an incorrect date. The page, carrying articles about music, radio and television, should have been headed ''Thursday, Jan. 7.''

title: Rise Predicted In Oil Demand
description: The International Energy Agency has raised its estimates of world oil consumption to more than 50 million barrels a day for most of this year, about a million barrels a day more than previously forecast, according to a report to be released Monday.

title: To Stay Alive at 65 M.P.H.
description: Do states have a right to set their own speed limits? Of course. The national 55-mile-an-hour limit was imposed by the need to conserve oil. That's no longer so urgent a national concern. Last April's highway bill properly relaxed the Federal rule; the continuing resolution just passed relaxes it a bit more. But states that raise limits incur a moral obligation to toughen enforcement. Too many have simply sacrificed safety to speed.

title: Couple Held in 2 Murders and Taking of Baby
description: A husband and wife have been arrested in the killing of another couple and the kidnapping of the couple's newborn son. The police say the suspects pretended for months that they were expecting a child of their own.

title: 'Conserving America,' Documentary on PBS
description: ''CONSERVING AMERICA'' is refreshing; it's about ordinary people as much as it's about the environment. Ordinary people may fight to protect marshes, swamps and prairie potholes not so much because wetlands are consecrated as because people like them. Documentaries about the environmental movement sometimes forget people; ''Conserving America,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, does not.

title: Olympic Games; Cubans Facing a Dilemma Over Sending Team to Seoul
description: The unresolved issue of North Korea's participation in the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, could place Cuba in the uncomfortable position of either supporting an ally or satisfying its own considerable sports appetite, according to senior Olympic officials in the United States and elsewhere.

title: Horse Racing; Funistrada Wins First Lady
description: Funistrada, purchased two months ago for $810,000, earned back only a fraction of that price today, but she proved her class by rallying to beat a stellar field in the First Lady Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: Noriega Is Home After Trip
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega returned today from an unexpected weekend visit to the Dominican Republic, ending speculation that his trip might be a flight into exile.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Shriver Wins in New South Wales Open: Top-seeded Pam Shriver scored an impressive 6-2, 6-3 victory over second-seeded Helena Sukova in the New South Wales Open at White City outside Sydney, Australia, yesterday. In the men's final, John Fitzgerald of Australia, seeded fifth, posted a 6-3, 6-4 victory over third-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union. Sukova had not dropped a set on her way to the final. (AP) Australians Advance: The Australian juniors, Jason Stoltenberg and Todd Woodbridge scored first-round victories early today in the Australian Open Championships at Melbourne. Stoltenberg, 17, the world's top junior in 1987, advanced with a 6-1, 6-3, 6-1 triumph over Jon Levine of the United States. Woodbridge, also 17 and the world's fourth-ranked junior, crushed John Letts of the United States, 6-2, 6-0, 6-1. Also advancing was Matt Anger of the United States, who beat Britain's Andrew Castle, 6-3, 6-1, 6-4. (AP) Skiing Markus Wasmeier First in Super-G: Markus Wasmeier of West Germany, who spent more than six weeks in a cast recovering from a serious back injury last year, won the first men's World Cup Super-G race of the season yesterday in Val d'Isere, France. He scored his seventh World Cup victory and the fifth Super-G triumph of his career in 1 minute 29.16 seconds. Switzerland's Pirmin Zurbriggen was in 1:29.62 and Alberto Tomba of Italy fifth in 1:29.99. Tomba raised his World Cup total to 136 points, with Zurbriggen at 131. (AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 7, Penguins 5: Steve Yzerman and Bob Probert scored two goals each last night as Detroit extended its unbeaten streak to six. Probert returned to the lineup after sitting out a two-game suspension. Yzerman capped the four-goal second period by knocking his own rebound past the Penguins' goalie, Gilles Meloche, while Detroit held a man advantage. Mario Lemieux had four goals, raising his season point total to 86, tying him with the injured Wayne Gretzky for the league lead. (AP) Jets 4, Maple Leafs 3: Dale Hawerchuk scored a with just 22 seconds left for Winnipeg's winning goal. In the game's final seconds, with the game tied at 3-3, a Winnipeg defenseman, Randy Carlyle, stripped the wing Al Secord of the puck at center ice. Iain Duncan flipped the puck ahead to Hawerchuk at the blue line, and Hawerchuk skated in alone and beat the Toronto goaltender, Jeff Reese. (AP) Flames 8, Capitals 2:Joe Nieuwendyk and Hakan Loob each had two goals to lead Calgary. Nieuwendyk continued to lead the league's rookie scoring race with 32 goals and 20 assists. The victory improved the Flames' record to 27-12-4. (AP) Blackhawks 5, Kings 2: Dirk Graham, a recently-acquired right wing, had two goals and an assist to lead Chicago. Graham, obtained from Minnesota on Jan. 2, gave the Blackhawks a two-goal lead when he made a 10-foot power-play goal early in the final period. Bob McGill had made a five-footer late in the second period to break a 2-2 tie. (AP) N.B.A. Kings 109, SuperSonics 108: Harold Pressley's 20-foot jumper with 1:14 left in the game put Sacramento ahead and the Kings held on for a victory last night. Xavier McDaniel's 14-foot baseline jumper at the buzzer bounced off the backboard to assure the Kings of the win. Reggie Theus topped Sacramento with 25 points, Pressley added 17 and Kenny Smith 16. Dale Ellis paced Seattle with 30 points, Tom Chambers added 27 and McDaniel 20. (AP) Speed Skating Soviet Breaks 1,000-Meter Record: Nikolai Gulyayev of the Soviet Union bettered the track record of Igor Vidyatin to win the 1,000-meter race at a World Cup event in Innsbruck for his second record-breaking performance in two days. Gulyayev won in 1 minute 15.76 seconds. (AP) East German Sets 4-Race Record: Karin Kania of East Germay improved the world record for a four-race combination at a single meet by winning the 1,000 meters and finishing second over 3,000 meters at a World Cup competition in Davos, Switzerland, yesterday. She won at 500 and 1,500 meters Saturday at the event. Her combined timings in the four distances gave her a world record of 163.446 points under international rules. Kania ripped through the 1,000 in 1 minute 18.11 seconds, only a quarter of a second slower than her world record. (AP)

title: Verbeek's 3 Goals Do Trick for Devils
description: Ron Hextall, the temperamental Flyer goaltender, was thrown out of tonight's game against the Devils with his team trailing by two goals midway through the first period.

title: Bid for IU Is a Key Part Of Neoax Leader's Plan
description: Louis A. Guzzetti Jr. is president and chief executive of Neoax Inc., which had a more recognizable name when it was known as the White Motor Corporation.

title: Takeshita Ready for U.S. Visit
description: As Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita departs for his first state meeting with President Reagan, Japan may be in its strongest position in years to turn aside American criticism.

title: PUERTO RICO GAINS AS TOURIST HAVEN
description: One year after a fire at the Dupont Plaza hotel killed 97 people, Puerto Rican tourism is thriving and leaders of the industry are painting a bright future for travel to the island.

title: Metro Matters; In Land of 'Oz,' A State Senator Breaks the Rules
description: Sometimes State Senator Nancy Larraine Hoffmann likens the State Legislature to a soap opera. ''It's like 'General Hospital,' '' she says, ''except it's called, 'State Capitol.' ''

title: Opera: Hans Sotin as Wotan In Wagner's 'Rheingold'
description: WITH its new production of ''Das Rheingold,'' the Metropolitan Opera has created a series of visual effects befitting the grandeur of Wagner's mythic tale. At the same time, it has fashioned, through the sheer richness of imagery, a backdrop against which only the most heroic of singers can hope to compete for attention. If the vocalists who took over four principal roles in the opera on Saturday evening did not seem entirely equal to this challenge, they nonetheless provided performances strong enough to move the proceedings along efficiently and effectively through the work's two-and-a-half hours.

title: Presidential Birthday Call
description: President Reagan telephoned former President Richard M. Nixon on Saturday to wish him a happy 75th birthday, the White House said. No details of the conversation were released.

title: GIULIANI SAYS HE IS AVAILABLE FOR SENATE SEAT
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani said last night that he would be available to run for the United States Senate if an acceptable candidate could be chosen quickly to succeed him as United States Attorney in Manhattan.

title: The Brady Report: Looking for Flaws; Study Cites Portfolio Insurers' Role as a Key to the Market Meltdown
description: The report by a Presidential panel agreed with what some stock market participants have suspected for months: portfolio insurance managers were among the major villains in the frenetic five-day stock market drama of October 1987.

title: Pittsburgh Star Faces Charges
description: Craig Heyward, the star running back for the University of Pittsburgh, was charged today with fighting with police officers who were investigating a campus shooting.

title: Western Union Picks Chief and a Chairman
description: The Western Union Corporation which has just completed a major financial restructuring directed by Bennett S. LeBow, its controlling stockholder, has announced its new management lineup.

title: Groups Are Bracing to Help More Refugees on Slim Funds
description: Private American aid organizations, bracing for a substantial increase in foreign refugees seeking new homes in the United States, are being advised by the State Department that they cannot expect more money to cover rising costs.

title: Gasoline Tax Would Hurt Rural America
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Handle on Third World Debt
description: Major banks are reported to be unenthusiastic about the novel debt-relief scheme cooked up by Mexico and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. The reluctance of other big players may limit the scheme's effectiveness. But the Mexican arrangement still could open a promising new chapter in the third world's crisis of overborrowing.

title: Learning Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS WALLACH, ACCOUNTANT, MARRIES ERIC MATZA ON L.I.
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Robin Gay Wallach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Wallach of Malverne, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric Matza, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Matza of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Theodore Steinberg officiated.

title: GAINS ARE PROVING ELUSIVE FOR HAIG
description: In his hotel suite overlooking this snow-draped city, Alexander M. Haig Jr. finishes his morning coffee and prepares, once more, to bundle up and shake hands at a factory gate.

title: Congress Faces New Battle on Media Ownership
description: Congress seems poised for a new and rancorous debate over whether there should be a ban on ownership of a daily newspaper and a television station in the same city.

title: U.S. FARM EXPORTS UP, WITH DEMAND GREATEST SINCE'84
description: Influenced by political, economic and meteorological trends that have converged in recent weeks, the global demand for American farm products is stronger than at any time since 1984, and exports are climbing, according to the Department of Agriculture.

title: Spender Novel Emerges After 6 Decades
description: ''Virginia Woolf read it, was fascinated by it, and told me to scrap it. So I did. She said that nobody should publish before the age of 30.''

title: Computerized Honors
description: Ever since baseball got things started in Cooperstown, athletic halls of fame have proliferated. In addition to such obvious sports as football, basketball, tennis and golf, there are now halls for just about every athletic endeavor from rodeo to roller skating.

title: Diplomacy to Rescue
description: According to diplomatic sources here, orders have gone out from Tokyo to a Japanese whaling ship in Antarctica that it not harpoon any whales, at least until the end of Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita's visit to Washington this week.

title: INSIDE
description: Saudis Said to Cut Oil Price

title: 2 Homeless Men Found Dead After Cold Night
description: Two homeless men were found dead in Manhattan yesterday morning, the police said, and both appeared to have died of natural causes.

title: DR. LEONORE BETH MAX WED TO J. S. SILVERBERG
description: The marriage of Dr. Leonore Beth Max to Jonathan Seth Silverberg took place yesterday at the Faculty House at Columbia University. Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Legislators And Aid Group Going to Hanoi
description: Although Vietnam and the United States have no diplomatic relations, three Congressional delegations are visiting Hanoi over the next two weeks. So are an American humanitarian aid mission and a technical team looking for missing servicemen.

title: BUSINESSES HELP THE NEEDIEST
description: This season the New York Graphic Society, fine art publishers based in Greenwich, Conn., adopted a new theme for its annual holiday art sale: ''Help the Homeless.''

title: Mirth Control
description: Four new sitcoms do not rely on laugh tracks: TV writers will now explore new forms of timing and content. Such lofty talk betrays the art of television comedy. What better typifies it than the sound of raucous laughter at dumb jokes?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption Saturday with an article about the play ''Half Deserted Streets'' misidentified the actor at right. He was Michael Imperioli.

title: Father Wins Custody of Son
description: A boy abducted from his California home seven years ago and found living with his father in a secluded shack near here has been returned to his father.

title: Peace Monitors Criticize Sandinistas
description: With less than a week until Central American Presidents meet to assess five months of progress toward regional peace, three of the four Nicaraguans appointed to monitor the compliance of the Sandinista Government with the new peace accord say it has not met its obligations.

title: 'Poor' Billionaire Is Returning Home
description: This is one of the few cities in the world where Preston Robert Tisch could feel poor. Not that Mr. Tisch lacks money. He can't tell you exactly how much he has, but he estimates his fortune as just under $1 billion.

title: In Era of AIDS, 'Safe Sex' Becomes the Latest Campus Crusade
description: ''he talk was turning reflective at Phi Kappa Psi, a white-columned fraternity house on the campus of Syracuse University. Sitting around the big brick fireplace recently, the brothers considered the rituals of dating.

title: Skiing, New York City-Style
description: A man ventured to Vermont on a recent weekend seeking the tranquillity of mountain vistas. It turned out to be one of the busiest weekends of the season and skiing was more of an urban experience: brief periods of skiing and long periods of standing in line.

title: Schultz Wants a Curb
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association must stop trying to legislate integrity, its executive director, Dick Schultz, said today in remarks opening the 82d annual convention.

title: West Berlin Links Woman Sought In Disco Bombing to Palestinians
description: The police suspect that a West Berlin woman working for Palestinian terrorists planted the bomb that killed two American soldiers and a Turkish woman and wounded 229 people in a West Berlin discotheque in April 1986, the authorities said today.

title: For Bissell, All Was Too Much
description: When he was 8 years old, Patrick Bissell jumped off a 30-foot-high diving board, even though he did not know how to swim.

title: Georgetown Halts DePaul Rally, 74-64
description: Perry McDonald scored 16 points and Charles Smith, a reserve guard, added 15 today as Georgetown fought off a late rally by DePaul to defeat the Blue Demons, 74-64.

title: Gore's Youth
description: There are some minor disadvantages to becoming a Presidential candidate at 39. When Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, who was born in 1948, was asked at a recent news conference in Tallahassee whether he was interested in becoming the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee this year, he offered a low opinion of the post and its historic significance. ''Who in this room,'' he inquired rhetorically, ''remembers the name of Herbert Hoover's Vice President?

title: Itel Offers Notes
description: The Itel Corporation is offering $125 million of 12 5/8 percent senior subordinated notes, due in 1993, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Rated B-3 by Moody's Investors Service and B- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the issue is noncallable for life.

title: Massachusetts Housing Bonds
description: The Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency is tentatively offering $55.1 million of tax-exempt multifamily residential housing revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 8.89 percent for an issue due in 2021, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: U.S. and Canada Close Extradition Gap
description: Officials of Canada and the United States signed an amendment to an extradition treaty today in an effort to close loopholes that allowed some people wanted for crimes in one country to find haven in the other.

title: New Registry Is Raising Hope For Those in Need Of Bone Marrow
description: THE recently established National Bone Marrow Donor Registry has given new hope to thousands of people whose lives depend on finding genetically compatible strangers willing to donate some of the tissue that produces life-sustaining blood cells.

title: Koch Meets With Theater Council
description: A panel that has accused Mayor Koch in the past of ignoring its suggestions - his Theater Advisory Council - met with the Mayor yesterday morning to discuss the city's relationship with Broadway theater, and then said little had been accomplished.

title: Kean, in Annual Message, to Urge Aid for Exporters
description: A wide range of new programs to help New Jersey businesses sell their goods overseas will be proposed by Governor Kean in his State of the State Message to the Legislature on Tuesday.

title: Our Towns
description: Where does all the time go? David Roth knows.

title: LILLIAN VERNON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: The net income for the latest 9 months and year-ago period are on a pro-forma basis. The company terminated its Subchapter ''S'' tax status on Aug. 20, 1987. Accordingly, no provision for income taxes was made for the first 6 months of the fiscal year; a pro-forma tax provision is being shown for comparative purposes only.

title: RANGERS LET 2-GOAL LEAD SLIP TO A TIE WITH HAWKS
description: Lucien DeBlois emerged from the shower, quietly made his way to his locker and picked up the sheet of statistics that showed how the Rangers and Blackhawks had played to a 2-2 tie last night. He had fully anticipated that the numbers would anger him, but he had no idea a name on the sheet would leave him infuriated.

title: EARTH TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
ASSOCIATES CORP OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
'Teddy and Alice' to Close
description: ''Teddy and Alice,'' a musical with a book by Jerome Alden and music by John Philip Sousa, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Minskoff Theater. Directed by John Driver and starring Len Cariou, it will have run for 77 regular performances and 11 previews.

title: Books of The Times
description: FOOL'S SANCTUARY. By Jennifer Johnston. 132 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: Debate Double-Talk
description: The wonder of it, given the length of this Endless Campaign, is that there haven't been more bobbles by the Presidential candidates. They've already endured debates by the dozen. But as demonstrated in the Republican debate Friday in Iowa, the demon of mystification has suddenly struck.

title: Contributors Say LaRouche Misled Them on Donations
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. is using money for his Presidential campaign that some contributors say they thought was going into an anti-AIDS program.

title: Superconductivity Moves From the Laboratory to the Classroom
description: THE discovery in 1986 of a new class of substances called high-temperature superconductors has galvanized research in chemistry and physics, spurred a global race for industrial and military applications and led two scientists to a Nobel Prize. Now, less than two years after the landmark discovery, even high school students can demonstrate high-temperature superconductivity for less than $50.

title: Banks' Mexican Debt View Mixed
description: The negative accounting effects of a proposal to exchange United States-backed Mexican bonds for some of Mexico's bank debt will apparently limit the role of big banks in the plan.

title: Apple Unit's New Products
description: The Claris Corporation, a software subsidiary formed last spring by Apple Computer Inc., yesterday announced new software programs for the Macintosh computer.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $228,000 and $550,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $48,000 for the quarter and $138,000 for the 9 months.

title: CUOMO SEEKS QUICK LEGISLATIVE ACTION
description: Hoping to end the legislative session as soon as possible, Governor Cuomo filed an unusually large number of bills today -61 measures, including his plan to give Mayor Koch control of the New York City Board of Education.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net loss

title: D'AMATO DECIDES TO SUPPORT DOLE
description: After weeks of public fence-sitting,Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday endorsed his Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, for President.

title: An Instant Musician
description: OKAY, it's fantasy time.

title: New Bid Made For Dyncorp
description: Dyncorp, which had agreed to be acquired for $216 million by a group led by its chairman, Jorge E. Carnicero, said today that a separate management group had made a new takeover offer. Anaylsts said the new offer, from DME Holdings Inc., was worth $1 a share more than the Carnicero bid, or about $226 million in all.

title: REDICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represents patient revenue.

title: Ex-Officials to Hold A Party to Aid Biaggi
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, a former Bronx and New York State Democratic chairman who served more than a year in prison for income tax evasion, is sponsoring a cocktail party tomorrow evening to help defray Representative Mario Biaggi's legal expenses.

title: Redskins Counting On Fans' Craziness
description: The Washington Redskins, fresh from their playoff victory over the Chicago Bears on Sunday, prepared for the National Conference championship game next Sunday with a light workout today, and their coach, Joe Gibbs, said the Redskins' fanatical fans should provide an extra lift against the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Boy, 13, Saves 4 Neighbors
description: Matt Snyder, a 13-year-old boy who stayed up late doing homework, has been credited with saving four neighbors when their home caught fire. He was translating Latin sentences about 12:30 A.M. Sunday when he heard a crackling noise. After alerting his parents to call the fire department, he ran next door and banged on the front door until Mike Oklevitch answered and got his family out. John Keane, a Public Safety Department spokesman, said, ''His quick actions saved the family.''

title: B.B.D.O. Is Beginning Its First Pizza Hut Ads
description: The first Pizza Hut advertising from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn will begin to run on the three commercial TV networks tomorrow. You will certainly get familiar with it since the national budget is $70 million and additional millions will be spent on the same advertising by the franchisee advertising groups.

title: People
description: * Michael Feuer has resigned as senior vice president, marketing, advertising and financial communications, from Fabri-Centers of America, Cleveland.

title: The Speech: Jack F. Kemp; 'The Dollar Should Be So Trustworthy, So Good, That It's as Good as Gold'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: Plea in Concealing of Death
description: The father of a boy whose body was found in a ditch two years ago pleaded guilty today to misdemeanor charges of abandoning a body and concealing a death. The man, Eli Stutzman, was sentenced to 18 months in prison after he entered the pleas in Thayer County Court. Mr. Stutzman testified that he and his 9-year-old son, Danny, were driving from Wyoming to Ohio on Route 81 in December 1985 when the boy died. Mr. Stutzman said he was shocked and tried desperately to revive his son but finally left the body in a ditch near Chester. Danny's body was found on Dec. 24, 1985, but his identity was discovered only last month.

title: Owners May Face Fines if Cabs Refuse Service
description: Mayor Koch, asserting that New York City cabdrivers frequently refuse to accept black passengers, proposed yesterday that cab owners be punished if their drivers refuse service to potential passengers.

title: Mattingly Signs for 3 Years
description: The deal was essentially done last month, but yesterday the Yankees finally announced the signing of Don Mattingly, their most valuable first baseman, to a guaranteed three-year contract after finding an insurance company to write a policy covering the player's back.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Honda Lifts Prices
description: The American Honda Motor Company said it had raised its prices to reflect the falling value of the dollar against the yen. The Honda division, which sells Civic, Accord and Prelude cars, raised prices by an average of 2.2 percent, or $274 a car.

title: Bantering Nofziger Goes on Trial in Case Involving Ethics Law
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political director, on charges of illegal lobbying after he left Government service.

title: Irving Bank's Adviser
description: The Irving Bank Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had hired J. P. Morgan & Company as a special adviser in Irving's efforts to ward off a hostile takeover bid by the Bank of New York Company. Goldman, Sachs & Company remains Irving's principal investment banker, but Morgan, a commercial banking company, is providing advice specifically about commercial-banking matters. Morgan was retained last month, an Irving spokesman said.

title: Austria Glances Back
description: Austria is preparing nervously for the 50th anniversary of its absorption into Hitler's Third Reich, on March 11. As Chancellor Franz Vranitzky says, it wiped the country off the map in 1938, but also led to ''its rebirth as a nation'' after the war.

title: TV Review; 'Into the Homeland'
description: HOW do you make a serious subject ridiculous? One way is to concoct a movie script that seems determined to make believability a hazard that must be studiously avoided. Witness ''Into the Homeland,'' a made-for-pay-cable movie currently on the Home Box Office schedule. It can be seen at 10 o'clock this evening.

title: N. Korea Won't Go . . . Unless
description: North Korea said today it would not attend the Seoul Olympics unless its demands to be a co-host of the Games were met by the International Olympic Committee and the Seoul organizing committee.

title: Dance Teacher Facing Loss of Studio
description: Mary Anthony, a teacher and choreographer of modern dance, is facing imminent eviction from the lower Manhattan studio where she has worked for 20 years, and she says she is the victim of a vindictive landlord and an unfair city ruling.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday offered $250 million of short-term floating-rate notes, due on July 14, at a price of 100 through various securities dealers.

title: Campaign Trail; Running Mate Efforts
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has named Francis O'Brien, a man of some renown in press and political circles, to the position of senior press adviser.

title: Vice Chairman Named At Continental Illinois
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said yesterday that S. Waite Rawls 3d, a managing director of Chemical Bank, would join it on Feb. 1 as vice chairman.

title: Florence Eiseman, 88, a Designer And Leader in Children's Fashion
description: Florence Eiseman, a designer of children's clothes who was known for excellent workmanship, top quality fabrics and simple but elegant styles, died of emphysema Friday at Columbia Hospital in Milwaukee, Wis. She was 88 years old and lived in Milwaukee.

title: SONY, IN A SHIFT, TO MAKE VHS UNITS
description: The Sony Corporation, which popularized the home video cassette recorder with its Betamax in 1975, announced today that it would sell the rival VHS system that has come to dominate the market.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Nevada A-Test Plaintiffs Lose Appeal
description: The Supreme Court today let die the last appeal by civilians suing the Government for deaths, cancers and other illnesses that they say were caused by open-air atomic bomb tests in Nevada from 1951 to 1962.

title: QMAX TECHNOLOGY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Detective Says Marks on Levin Drew Speculation
description: Detectives examining the body of Jennifer Levin in Central Park on Aug. 26, 1986, discussed the possibility that morning that the red marks found on her neck might have been caused by a metal watchband, a police sergeant at the scene testified yesterday.

title: DAMON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $35,000. The company said the three months ended Nov. 30, 1986, include sales of $1,100,000 and net income of $560,000 associated with the favorable settlement of litigation regarding the licensing of certain technology by the company's medical and electronic products business.

title: 100 Years of National Geographic
description: ''How do you understand 'A Tale of Two Cities,' '' asked Gilbert M. Grosvenor, ''unless you understand the English Channel and London and Paris?''

title: WISCONSIN TOY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $567,000. The company went public in May 1987.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes $3.8 million gain from the sale of property.

title: No Shelter Funds Cut For Homeless Families
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHULMAN, A INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bishop Sees No Moral Issue If Feeding Ends in Coma Case
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of Providence, R.I., Louis E. Gelineau, said yesterday that a diocesan official's opinion approving the removal of a feeding tube from a comatose patient ''does not contradict Catholic moral theology.''

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss of $6,678,347 from discontinuance of the Catalog-Showroom Stores division. The year-ago first quarter's loss from continuing operations included a provision for inventory valuation allowance of $15 million, pretax.

title: Toronto's New Force In Theater
description: Sometime after Ed Mirvish bought the Old Vic Theater in London in 1982, he was invited to a reception at Clarence House, the residence of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother. An aide took him around to meet the royals and the other prestigious guests.

title: Winning Hole-in-One
description: Dan Pohl posted a hole-in-one yesterday, although his ace on the 181-yard third hole at LaCosta Country Club in Carlsbad, Calif., won't go into the official record book. The eagle 1 proved to be the margin of victory as Pohl won the annual nine-hole Epson shootout by two strokes over Ben Crenshaw, Paul Azinger and John McComish. This competition is one of the many high-priced sideshows on the PGA Tour. The 10-man field was made up of the golfers who led each of the 10 statistical categories that Epson, a computer company, compiled during the 1987 Tour. Pohl, who used a 5-iron for his ace, won $10,000 for the hole-in-one and $75,000 for the nine-hole victory with a five-under-par 31 on the front nine. Pohl did not win a tournament on the PGA Tour in 1987 so he will not play in the MONY Tournament of Champions, which starts at LaCosta on Thursday. That event is the year's first official PGA Tour competition.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,620,000 on capital restructuring.

title: Bond Prices Regain Part Of Losses
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, recovering part of Friday's steep losses.

title: COOPER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $700,000 and an extraordinary loss of $17,200,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; litigation settlement of $13.2 million for the quarter and $6 million for the year, and the year also includes a net pretax gain of $194.8 million primarily on the sale of the ophthalmic pharmaceutical business. c-Net income d-Includes a net gain primarily on the sale of Richards Medical Co. of $47.8 million for both the quarter and year; losses from discontinued operations of $10,479,000 and $13,650,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and costs associated with restructuring operations of $8.1 million for the quarter and $8.9 million for the year. The Cooper Companies' results for fiscal 1987 include those of Cooper Technicon Inc. beginning on July 1, 1987, the date on which the Cooper Companies acquired majority ownership of Cooper Technicon; from July 1, 1987, Cooper Technicon reported $167.5 million in net sales, $16.9 million in operating income and $4.5 million in net income.

title: 2 Water Mains Burst on Upper East Side
description: Two aging water mains burst early yesterday morning on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, flooding basements, knocking out utilities and making the rush hour treacherous for commuters as water turned to ice in the subfreezing weather.

title: Pollution Is Blamed for Killing Whales in St. Lawrence
description: Pollution from industrial activity along the St. Lawrence River and its tributaries, including the Great Lakes, is causing disease, premature death and a declining birth rate among the white beluga whales in the river, according to Canadian researchers.

title: Blair Thomas's Surgery
description: Blair Thomas, Penn State's star running back, underwent arthroscopic surgery for ligament damage in his right knee yesterday at Hershey Medical Center. Dr. Alexander Kalenak, the Penn State orthopedic surgeon who performed the operation, said the procedure was successful. Kalenak said a return to full activity from such an operation can require from nine months to a year but a swifter return is possible. Thomas, a junior, was injured in an informal workout on Dec. 9.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the installation of Harold T. Shapiro as president of Princeton University misidentified the man at the center, in light-color robes. He was John V. Fleming, a professor of English, who acted as mace bearer.

title: SEQUEL CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $59,743 for the latest year and $326,708 for 1986.

title: KN Energy Rejects Mesa Buyout Offer
description: KN Energy Inc. said it had rejected as inadequate an $18-a-share buyout offer from Mesa Limited Partnership. J. Robert Wilson, KN Energy's chairman and chief executive, said in a letter to Mesa, of Amarillo, Tex., that the KN board believed the company's continued independence was in its shareholders' best interests.

title: CONTINENTAL HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Retail Sales Gain of 5.8% Seen for 1988
description: The chief economist for Sears, Roebuck & Company predicted yesterday that sales of general merchandise would increase 5.8 percent in 1988, compared with a 5.2 percent rise last year.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company noted that the Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated investment tax credits retroactively to Jan. 1, 1986; it also said this action resulted in a charge to earnings equal to 4 cents a share for the prior year's first quarter, as required by the accounting rules. This represents the investment tax credits previously recognized and reported as a reduction of the company's income tax provisions from Jan. 1, 1986, to Aug. 31, 1986.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1988
description: International A3-10

title: Dance: 'Einszweidrei'
description: JODY OBERFELDER-RIEHM'S ''Einszweidrei'' ought to be bottled and sold as instant good cheer. It is that rare genuinely funny dance that manages both to make its points wittily and to give its dancers a chance to let loose and yet be themselves on stage. There was a good deal more to their performances on Friday evening, in a program of four dances presented by the Jody Oberfelder-Riehm Dance Company at the Dia Art Foundation theater. Ms. Oberfelder-Riehm, who has performed with Meredith Monk, Phyllis Lamhut and Pooh Kaye, has assembled a company of deft, charmingly personable dancers with a good deal of the choreographer's impressive physical control. But in ''Einszweidrei'' everything comes together with an inspired sense of rightness.

title: Little Space Station Demands a Hard Look
description: FIVE years ago, a young Texas company said it wanted to open the heavens to American industry, creating a cheap, private, no-frills space station where the marvels of weightlessness could be used to purify metals, grow rare crystals, fashion new semiconductors, make scarce drugs, form exotic compounds and invent altogether new types of materials.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a $178,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: Waldbaum's Agency
description: The Waldbaum's chain of 100 or so supermarkets in the New York area is taking its advertising to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. The budget is $5 million. The chain formerly handled its own advertising.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American President Co., Oakland, Calif., appointed Robert K. Dahl senior vice president and chief financial officer, replacing John Flynn, who left earlier this year to pursue his own interests.

title: Kirin Buys Bottler
description: Japan's leading brewer said its United States subsidiary had acquired the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Northern New England. KW Inc., a Bedford, N.H., subsidiary of the Kirin Brewery Company, bought the remaining 75 percent of the bottling company's stock for $46.5 million earlier this month, Kirin said. KW had purchased 25 percent of the company's stock last January, it said.

title: Seoul Opposition Leader Accepts Outcome of Vote
description: The opposition leader Kim Young Sam said today that he had decided to stop fighting the presidential election victory of Roh Tae Woo and would meet with him Wednesday.

title: ANALYZE EX-ATHLETE ANALYSTS
description: THE sports divisions at the major television networks are huge operations, making and spending hundreds of millions of dollars each year. They pay their broadcasters astronomical salaries, and provide them with excellent working conditions and a national audience that religious leaders might covet. In short, the networks are the masters of the televised sports universe.

title: China Rejects Gorbachev Summit Offer
description: China today rejected a proposal by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to hold a summit meeting with Chinese leaders.

title: Trade Record In Germany
description: West Germany, under international pressure to buy more foreign goods and sell fewer abroad, reported a record trade surplus last year, according to early official figures published today.

title: Children Find Ways to Make Donations to Neediest Cases
description: Elizabeth Koster of Manhattan, who is 8 1/2 years old, and her friend Alizah Allen have been collecting money for the poor by selling books and toys they no longer want.

title: L.I. Husband Seized as Strangler Of Young Bride on Christmas Eve
description: A Huntington Station man was arrested today and charged with strangling his bride of two months on Christmas Eve and dumping her body in a garbage bag in a field.

title: ONCOGENE SCIENCE reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Parking Rules
description: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended today in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: CHERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Children's-Book Award To Lincoln Biography
description: Russell Freedman won the annual Newbery Medal yesterday as the author of the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children, for ''Lincoln: A Photobiography'' (Clarion Books/Ticknor & Fields).

title: GERMAN IS SEIZED IN DISCO BOMBING
description: The police announced today that they had arrested a West German woman suspected of planting the bomb in a West Berlin disco that killed two American servicemen and a Turkish woman, wounded 229 and prompted the American air attack on Libya in April 1986.

title: Stage: From Foreman, 'Symphony of Rats'
description: THE central character in Richard Foreman's ''Symphony of Rats'' (at the Performing Garage) is the President of the United States, but his residence is more a labyrinthine fun house than anything remotely resembling the White House. As is customary with Mr. Foreman, the evening's author, director and designer, the scenery and properties are animated. Figuratively, the walls have eyes, ears and arms. Chairs are at such a severe tilt that a sitter automatically slides to the floor, and there are long Foreman strings that intersect the room like some cosmic clothesline.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $450,000. c-Includes net of $144,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in May. The company said the latest quarter includes a one-time $400,000 expense provision to reflect the costs of closing the Enerpac European headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, and offset by a gain from the final revaluation of its obligation under a stock appreciation rights program for management, which was replaced by a stock option program at the end of the quarter.

title: Prize Reporting
description: The Gerald R. Ford Foundation has established two $5,000 journalism prizes, one for coverage of the Presidency and the other for national defense. The 1988 awards, to be presented in Washington in June, will recognize ''lifetime journalistic achievement'' in the field; subsequent prizes will honor ''consistent, judicious, sensitive and noteworthy coverage'' during the previous calendar year.

title: 'Cabaret' to Switch Theaters
description: The revival of ''Cabaret,'' starring Joel Grey, is to move from the Imperial Theater to the Minskoff to make way for the musical ''Chess,'' Fred Nathan, a spokesman for the show, said yesterday. The show, which must move no later than March 20, may move earlier, he said. ''Chess'' is to begin performances at the Imperial on April 4.

title: Mexico City Journal; Economists' Day Dawns; Twilight for Lawyers?
description: An old Mexican saying has it that every student who enrolls at the law school of the National Autonomous University of Mexico here does so ''dreaming of someday wearing the presidential sash across his chest.''

title: INTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 4
description: b-Net income Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in July 1987.

title: Milt Jackson's Classical Jazz
description: Last week Milt Jackson, the vibraharpist and one of America's most recorded musicians, flew to California to play ''Save the Bones for Henry Jones,'' one track of a record with Lou Rawls and Ray Charles.

title: Furs: Now It's a Buyer's Market
description: The deep freeze of the last week has set many cloth-coat wearers to thinking about furs. And now is the time to buy. Between fears about the economy and concern over hemlines, fewer coats were sold earlier in the season than furriers had anticipated. As a result, fur salons, stores and manufacturers are marking down furs anywhere from 20 to 50 percent.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $76.7 million and $108.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and also includes a tax credit of $4.2 million and $16.2 million related to pension expense for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $4.3 million and $17.2 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The fiscal 1987 loss is comprised of a $20.5 million pre-tax provision for restructuring of the company and an $11.4 million pre-tax loss from operations.

title: INTERACTIVE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DECOY UNIT ON BIAS CASES IS READIED
description: Moving to deter the rising number of bias-related crimes reported in New York City, the Police Department announced yesterday that beginning today it would deploy at least six decoy teams ''to identify and arrest those who victimize others because of race, religion or ethnicity.''

title: Dance: John Carrafa
description: JOHN CARRAFA, Donald Fleming and Vicky Shick are all very good dancers. They move interestingly and have strong techniques. They also have intelligent, clearly defined stage presences. And the dances they presented on Saturday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, in a program produced by Dance Chance, were as sophisticated and well-crafted as one might have expected. What was missing, depressingly, was the spark of individuality that makes each of the three dancers so worth watching.

title: Rockwell-SOMA
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it had acquired the assets of SOMA Europe Transmissions S.A., a French automotive-equipment supplier with sales of $80 million in 1987. Terms were not disclosed. Rockwell said SOMA, which has a plant in St. Etienne, complements its own automotive-equipment plants in Europe and Troy, Mich.

title: N.C.A.A. Told to Review Aid
description: The elimination of athletic scholarships would help return college sports to ''the amateur student-athlete model'' that most college presidents desire, the head of the American Council on Education told the National Collegiate Athletic Association today.

title: S.M.U. Wooing Gregg
description: Forrest Gregg of the Green Bay Packers said last night he has received permission to talk with Southern Methodist University officials about the vacant coach's job at his alma mater. ''We will talk,'' Gregg said. ''I'm sure they are interested in what I have to say and I'm interested in what they have to say.'' The post has been vacant since Bobby Collins resigned in December 1986. The football program was shut down by the N.C.A.A. for the 1987 season because of repeated rules violation, and the school decided not to play football in 1988. S.M.U. was punished because its athletes were receiving money and other benefits from alumni.

title: Oil Prices Off - Saudi Discount Seen
description: The prices of crude oil and oil-related futures crumbled further yesterday as more traders questioned OPEC's ability to maintain the production and pricing levels to which its members agreed at a meeting last month.

title: Scherer Purchase
description: The R. P. Scherer Corporation, a Troy, Mich., manufacturer of pharmaceutical products, said it had agreed to pay $15.25 a share in cash, or about $59 million, for the Paco Pharmaceutical Services Inc. of Lakewood, N.J. A Scherer subsidiary is to be merged into Paco as soon as Scherer obtains a majority of Paco's 39 million shares outstanding.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Include pre-tax charges of $45 million for the quarter and $100 million for the year from special loan loss provisions related to National City's less-developed country exposure.

title: 12 Make All-Pro Again
description: Mark Bavaro, the Giants' tight end, and Jerry Rice, the San Francisco 49ers' wide receiver, were among 12 players named yesterday to the Pro Football Writers of America All-Pro team for the second consecutive year. Ron Meyer of the Indianapolis Colts was named the American Conference Coach of the Year and Jim Mora of the New Orleans Saints was selected National Conference Coach of the Year.

title: Seagram Raises Its Bid For Martell Cognac
description: Faced with objections from the French Government over its earlier offer, the Seagram Company said today that it would raise its bid for the cognac maker Martell & Compagnie to 2,975 francs a share, thus topping a bid made by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.

title: Mecham Seems Contrite in a Speech
description: The troubled Governor of Arizona, Evan Mecham, opened the state's legislative session today by acknowledging ''I have made mistakes'' and extending a conciliatory hand to legislators he had largely ignored in his first year in office.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
U.S. Services Agency to Hire An Outside Firm on Auditing
description: The General Services Administration said today that for the first time it would hire an outside accounting firm to audit its books.

title: Campaign Trail; Robertson's Resume
description: ''Here's the total picture of Pat Robertson.''

title: HOVNANIAN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes equity in net income of $10,000 for the quarter and equity in net loss of $473,000 for the 9 months in unconsolidated subsidiaries and affiliate. c-Includes equity in net income in unconsolidated subsidiaries and affiliate of $77,000 for the quarter and $167,000 for the 9 months.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International, Pittsburgh, said it had called a meeting of the holders of its $11.25 cumulative preferred stock for March 2 in Pittsburgh to elect two additional directors to the company's board as requested by a shareholder, Spear, Leeds & Kellogg.

title: Arab Marked for Exile: Still a Militant?
description: Just two months before he was ordered deported by the Israeli authorities, Jibril Rajub, 34 years old, promised his wife that he was giving up militancy.

title: A Solitary Dissenter Disputes Cause of AIDS
description: A provocative argument that the wrong culprit has been cited as the cause of AIDS is almost universally rejected by AIDS scientists, but it is gaining attention in the gay press and other publications and has even piqued the interest of a White House official.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Big Three Get a Tax Break
description: New language inserted in last month's omnibus Federal spending bill appears to have insured that a tax benefit originally intended for a farm-equipment manufacturer will also apply to the Big Three auto makers, Congressional and industry sources said today.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,361,000 and $7,146,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a $58,255,000 charge from writedowns in the carrying values of certain of the company's assets, $18,786,000 of interest expense and discount amortization related to Anglo's 15 percent secured income notes. c-Net income and after a gain of $64,986,000 from the settlement of Chapter 11 obligations and a $780,000 gain from the termination of a pension plan, both for the quarter and year; the quarter also includes a charge of $2,164,000 from the writedown of carrying value of certain of the company's assets and a tax benefit of $620,000, and the year also includes a tax benefit of $186,000 and interest expense and discount amortization of $3,889,000.

title: Roth and Rhodes Books Get Critics Circle Awards
description: ''The Counterlife'' by Philip Roth was named the best novel of 1987 by the National Book Critics Circle yesterday, beating out ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' by Tom Wolfe after what a participant described as a ''passionate and heated discussion.''

title: Sterling Sues Hoffmann-La Roche
description: Sterling Drug Inc., the object of a $4.2 billion takeover offer from F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Company, filed suit yesterday against the big Swiss drug producer, accusing it of falsifying dealings to hide profits and avoid income taxes, buying stock on inside information and failing to disclose details about who owns the company.

title: Protein Fights Cat Allergy
description: Injections of protein extract from cats can help reduce suffering for those allergic to cats, a researcher says.

title: Autopsy of Maravich Discloses Heart Defect
description: Pete Maravich's death last week resulted from an enlarged and weakened heart with a continuous lack of oxygen into the heart muscle, the Los Angeles County Coroner's Office said today.

title: INSURANCE RATES FOR HEALTH CARE INCREASE SHARPLY
description: A surge in health insurance premiums, reflecting an unexpected failure to bring rising medical costs under control, is stunning thousands of employers and millions of workers nationwide.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1.2 million and $1.4 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also includes a non-recurring charge of $3,975,000 to terminate a distribution agreement.

title: Game Ends, Scoreless Tie
description: AFTER taking turns swatting each other with the powerless forms of their finest athletes, the Soviet Union and the United States are calling it even. We got them. They got us. On your mark, get set, go.

title: Savings Bond Sales Up 16%
description: Sales of United States savings bonds climbed 16 percent in December, the Treasury Department said today. Sales rose to $630 million in

title: Syracuse Surprised by Villanova, 80-78
description: Tom Greis talked himself into a perfect scoring game tonight, helping Villanova to a 80-78 Big East upset over Syracuse.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a net gain of $1,256,000, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of Baird Corp. common stock. Year-ago figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 30.

title: Excerpts From Message by Kean
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Kean's State of the State Message, which will be given Tuesday to the 203d New Jersey Legislature.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid June 2, 1987. The company said the latest periods' results include CMI Corp., which was acquired in August 1987.

title: Soviet Union Will Join Olympics But North Korea May Stay Home
description: The Soviet Union said today it would participate in the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, later this year, clearing the way for the first Soviet-American Summer Olympic showdown in 12 years.

title: Reagan Assails Economic Doomsayers
description: In his first public appearance of 1988, President Reagan stepped into the political campaign today by extolling his own economic record and raising money for the prospective Republican nominee for Senator from Ohio, Mayor George V. Voinovich of Cleveland.

title: Paine Webber to Sell C.D.'s Tied to Rise in College Costs
description: Paine Webber Inc. and the College Savings Bank in Princeton, N.J., have agreed on plan whereby the bank's certificates of deposits can be sold through the brokerage firm's 285 offices around the nation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article from Washington yesterday about a commission on American military strategy misstated Zbigniew Brzezinski's former title. He was national security adviser, not Secretary of State.

title: Former Agent Indicted
description: A grand jury in Opelika, Ala., yesterday indicted Jim Abernethy, a former Atlanta sports agent who has said he paid performance bonuses to the Auburn defensive back, Kevin Porter. Don Siegelman, the Alabama attorney general, said that the panel returned misdemeanor counts of tampering with a sports event, violating the deceptive practices act and commercial bribery. Siegelman said that prosecuting the case could be difficult because Abernethy lives in Georgia. Porter, who prosecutors have said is not a target of the investigation, did not attend the grand jury session. But the attorney general said that the state was seeking Porter's assistance in prosecuting the case. Abernethy could not be reached for comment. He said previously that the grand jury investigation ''sounds like sour grapes from Auburn fans who wanted Porter in the Sugar Bowl.'' Porter was declared ineligible for the Sugar Bowl game against Syracuse because of the rule that prohibits college athletes from dealing with agents. Abernethy said he believed he paid Porter about $1,000 a month, plus bonuses.

title: Our New China Traders Must Learn Patience; Managers of Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Air Their Mistakes
description: After a lengthy practice in Pittsburgh yesterday, Coach Terry Simpson of the Islanders transformed his hotel room into a counseling session as player after player on his slumping team filed in and recited their mistakes.

title: A Cultural Trailblazer To Seek New Path at 77
description: For 16 years they have been an inseparable pair: Roger L. Stevens and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and now they are about to go their separate ways.

title: NELLCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
For Soviet Alternative Press, Used Computer Is New Tool
description: In the living room of his southwest Moscow apartment, Lev M. Timofeyev has a Toshiba 1000 personal computer and a Kodak Diconix printer.

title: Publishing: At Warner, More Public Affairs Titles
description: For 16 years Ida Nudel was denied permission to leave the Soviet Union, and she was banished to Siberia for four years after she hung a banner from her apartment balcony that read: ''K.G.B., give me my visa to Israel.''

title: WALL TO WALL SOUND & VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
