description: The company said second quarter and first-half results include November operations for Electro-Biology Inc., reflecting Biomet's purchase of a 72 percent controlling interest in EBI in October 1987.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A.T.&T. to Raise Stake in Venture
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would put more money and technological expertise into its European joint venture with Philips N.V. of the Netherlands. It also said it was seeking additional partners.

title: Rise of 33.82 in Dow Average Allays Fears of New Plunge
description: LEAD: Wall Street's worst fears went unrealized yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 33.82 points, or 1.77 percent, to 1,945.13, in moderate trading.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Net income

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1988
description: The Economy

title: MORE TEAMS SCORE BY A LONG SHOT
description: The Boston Celtics race downcourt, then swing the ball around the free-throw circle waiting for Larry Bird or Danny Ainge to get into position to take a shot from beyond the 3-point line.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
True Love Revealed
description: To the Editor:

title: Drawing; FASHION: BY DESIGN Pants Update
description: Stylish wearing of any kind of clothing has little to do with common sense but everything to do with the fashion of the moment. Right now, of course, the short skirt has surpassed every other silhouette. Even recently, with the temperature in the teens, it has prevailed at see-and-be-seen restaurants.

title: Campaign Trail; Just Cool It
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa said today that he understood why Senator Bob Dole and Vice President Bush are scrapping so fiercely, given the closeness of their race and the importance of the voting in the Feb. 8 caucuses.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $350,000 from the reversal of previously recorded investment tax credits. c-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Executives Changes column of Business Day on Dec. 31 misidentified the new positions of Kazuo Ishikure and Norihiro Takeuchi of the Bridgestone Corporation. Mr. Ishikure is returning to Tokyo as a director and assistant to the executive vice president in charge of corporate planning and tire sales. Mr. Takeuchi has been appointed to the additional post of president of Bridgestone U.S.A. and will remain president of its tire sales group.

title: FASHION: PATTERNS
description: Cameron Line Crashes

title: Leading Candidates
description: Representative Jim Bunning, the Kentucky Republican who won 224 games in his career as a major-league pitcher, and Willie Stargell, whose name appears on the ballot for the first time, are considered the leading candidates to gain admittance to the baseball Hall of Fame when the results are announced tonight. Bunning missed election to the hall by 21 votes last year when Jim (Catfish) Hunter and Billy Williams were chosen by voting members of the Baseball Writers Association of America. A player must be named on 75 percent of the returned ballots to gain admission. This year, 450 ballots were sent out. Stargell hit 475 home runs in 21 seasons and was the clubhouse leader of the 1979 Pittsburgh Pirates that won the World Series.

title: Reagan Seeks Increase In World Bank Money
description: The Reagan Administration is hoping to negotiate an increase in payments for the World Bank that would necessitate annual Congressional appropriations of less than $100 million, Administration officials said today.

title: Our New China Traders Must Learn Patience
description: To the Editor:

title: New Antibiotics Offer Freedom From Hospitals
description: WORKING with a drug tried unsuccessfully against malaria in the 1960's, scientists have developed a new class of antibiotics that promises to have a profound effect on the treatment of important infectious diseases. Many patients who in the past have been hospitalized for weeks in order to receive intravenous antibiotics can now be discharged to take the new drugs orally at home.

title: Music: Chamber Society
description: THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center came hearteningly close Saturday afternoon to solving the basic contradiction of its chosen medium - trying to provide a sense of intimacy in a ''chamber'' (Alice Tully Hall) that holds over a thousand people.

title: COOPER DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $59,721,000 on the sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year, an extraordinary credit of $4,189,000 and an extraordinary loss of $522,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes income from discontinued operations of $7,775,000. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $51,101,000 and $49,878,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said it did not report revenue or sales in fiscal 1987 or 1986 because its principal operating business, Cooper Laboratories, is a non- revenue generating research and development subsidiary. The company also said it restated its results for fiscal 1986 and for the first 9 months of 1987 to separately reflect the results of Cooper Technicon Inc., its former affiliate, as a discontinued operation.

title: Napa Journal; Custom Caves for Vintners' Tastes
description: Give Alf Burtleson a mountain, and he'll give you a cave. In California's Napa Valley, about 45 miles north of San Francisco, no one is more in demand these days than Mr. Burtleson, who calls himself a cave man. He digs caves. But not ordinary caves. Burrowing into hillsides, he creates spacious and elegant caverns in the earth that wine makers fill with barrels and bottles of aging wine.

title: Supreme Court Refuses to Revive Hurricane Carter's Murder Case
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to consider reinstating the triple-murder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis. It was the latest and perhaps the last chapter in a tangled 21-year legal struggle.

title: Worse Than Himalayas?
description: Last Friday, the Washington headquarters and museum of the National Geographic Society, whose explorers have braved blizzards to reach Himalayan peaks and the North and South Poles, were closed on account of an eight-inch accumulation of snow. Intrepidity returned Saturday as officials mushed their way in to work on downtown M Street.

title: Pinch Scotch Goes to Grey
description: Grey Advertising has got the Pinch Scotch assignment back. It had lost it a year ago after Schenley Industries acquired Renfield Importers. At that time the brand, billing about $1.2 million, was reassigned to Chester Gore Advertising.

title: Tears for Kelly: An Elderly Man Freezes to Death
description: Last Thursday, on the day workers from a cleaning service arrived, along with a city social worker carrying a bag full of shirts, Joseph Stiletto was found frozen to death in his second-floor apartment at 16 Abingdon Square in Greenwich Village. He was 79 years old.

title: Isidor Isaac Rabi, a Pioneer In Atomic Physics, Dies at 89
description: Isidor Isaac Rabi, a pioneer in exploring the atom and a major force in 20th-century physics, died yesterday at his home on Riverside Drive after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: A Better Way to Tame Bikers
description: New York City still seeks to limit the dangerous excesses of bicycle messengers by banning all bikes from congested midtown blocks. A comment period on the ban proposal expires today. The ban does not make nearly as much sense as another city proposal to license the messenger business.

title: Short Shifts at Porsche
description: Porsche put 6,100 workers on short shifts today as the luxury sports car maker tries to make up for a sharp decline in United States sales. A Porsche spokesman said the move affects 4,300 workers at Porsche's main plant in Stuttgart-Zuffenhausen and 1,800 at Volkswagen A.G.'s Audi unit in Neckarsulm, where Porsche's four-cylinder cars are built.

title: Pan Am Board Faces Tough Choices Today
description: A showdown between the Pan Am Corporation's board and the company's chairman, C. Edward Acker, grew nearer yesterday.

title: Campaign Finance Folly
description: The New York City Council is considering legislation to use tax money to finance political campaigns. Under it, candidates who choose to participate must accept a spending cap and limit the private contributions they accept to certain maximums. Each contribution would be matched by city tax dollars. Most political analysts estimate that this would cost about $30 million. I am not against campaign financing reform, but the Council proposal would not keep its promise to clean up corruption and does not reflect economic realities.

title: L.S.U. Stuns Oklahoma
description: Jose Vargas scored 30 points and led a defense that held Oklahoma 40 points below its average tonight as Louisiana State University handed the Sooners their first defeat of the season, 83-71.

title: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 11 (AP) -
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia scored a 6-3, 7-6, 6-2 first-round victory over Bryan Roe tonight in the Australian Open.

title: Why So Diffident on Haiti?
description: Make no mistake about the decision of Haiti's electoral council to bar Duvalier collaborators from the presidential election. This minimal concession to constitutional procedure won't salvage the impending travesty: the election of a regime-approved puppet under rules requiring voters to hand unsealed ballots to armed soldiers.

title: Bush Questioned by Iran-Contra Investigators
description: Vice President Bush was interviewed under oath today by investigators working for the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair and was assured that he was not under investigation in the case, Mr. Bush's office said today.

title: Settlers in West Bank Kill a Palestinian
description: A Jewish settlement leader and his bodyguard fired at Palestinian demonstrators today, killing a teen-ager in the first significant involvement by militant settlers in the unrest that began a month ago.

title: No Headline
description: A teen-ager who resisted a robbery was shot in the thigh, and the same bullet seriously wounded a woman who was seated near him on a subway train in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said. The gunman escaped. The victims were shot on a southbound A train as it approached the Kingston-Throop Avenue station in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section about 1 P.M., the police said. They said another teen-ager tried to steal a gold chain from the youth, Phillip DeSilva, 16 years old, and shot him once with a .45-caliber pistol when he resisted.

title: Bridge: Book Offers Post-Mortems From Husband-Wife Teams
description: If complete statistics were available on the millions of post-mortems conducted around the world each year by bridge partnerships, it might well be found that more than half the post-mortem time is consumed by married couples. Husbands and wives often dissect the details of bidding and play while on their way home after a session of play, and the discussion, or battle, may resume at breakfast the next day.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Vikings Looking Great In the Role of Pretender
description: In this National Football League season of the unexpected, the unusual prevails even in the playoffs.

title: Global Climate Project Is Summit Bonus
description: To the Editor:

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Driver Denies Charge
description: Michel LaChance, one of seven harness drivers suspended by the State Racing and Wagering Board in connection with a Nov. 14 race at Yonkers Raceway, told the board yesterday that ''I tried everything I knew to win.''

title: Portraits on a Wall
description: In the end, what will count most about Rajiv Gandhi is whether he rules India in the tradition of his grandfather or of his mother.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $149,000 for the quarter and $489,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $132,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Prison Riots Provoke Debate Among Cuban Exiles
description: The consequences of the recent prison riots by Cuban alien inmates in Atlanta and Oakdale, La., are still reverberating here in a divisive debate about the image of the Cuban-American community, After the riots late last year there was a consensus here that the image of Miami Cubans, who account for more than 700,000 of the area's population of l.9 million, had been tarnished. But many Cuban exiles thought the memory of the riots would quickly fade.

title:
Market Place;
Calls for Changes In Option Trading
description: LEAD: IN evaluating the performance of various financial markets during the October stock collapse, the Presidential Task Force on Market Mechanisms singled out the options market for its sharpest criticism. In particular, it focused on activity in the Standard & Poor's 100 index options contract, charging that small investors were at a severe disadvantage on Oct.

title: Recital: Marilyn Horne
description: FOR her recital at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday afternoon, Marilyn Horne presented a program of German songs, sung with characteristic security and precision, though without much heart.

title: SILICON VALLEY BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $230,000 and $246,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Meier & Frank Officer Is Back
description: Judith Hofer is returning to a former post - president and chief executive officer of Meier & Frank, the eight-store chain of department stores in Oregon - from her present position as president and chief executive of Famous-Barr, the St. Louis-based department store group.

title: UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $45,515. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $72,792.

title: 'Slippery Water': Mystery Seems Finally Solved
description: A VISION of long, silken molecules coiling and uncoiling like millions of invisible yo-yos appears to have explained one of the most perplexing phenomena of fluid flow.

title: Latins Fighting U.S. Bid for Veto Power at Bank
description: Eight Latin American countries are threatening to block the appointment of a new president of an international lending agency unless the United States backs off from a demand for virtual veto power over new loans.

title: Careers; Motivation After Layoffs Is Stressed
description: PRODUCTIVITY on the assembly line has been stressed in recent years, with some success. Now many companies are seeking to insure that their middle managers and the workers those managers supervise are also motivated.

title: Stage: 'By Sondheim'
description: THERE'S entertainment tonight at the Equity Library Theater - more than two dozen songs from about a dozen shows by Stephen Sondheim. The occasion is the return of ''Side by Side by Sondheim,'' the revue or concert or party that was brought to Broadway by the British in 1977. Drawn from shows for which Mr. Sondheim wrote the lyrics (''West Side Story,'' ''Gypsy'') as well as those for which he did the music too (''Company'' ''Follies''), these witty, romantic, perceptive songs confirm, if confirmation were needed, his unrivaled place in today's musical theater.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Sunday about a concert by the Brooklyn Philharmonic gave an incorrect title, taken from the printed program, for a composition by John Corigliano. It was the ''Promenade'' Overture.

title: KING WORLD PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
INTERVOICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Airbus Gives U.S. Warning
description: The president of Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, today threatened to bring trade actions against America's leading aircraft makers if they file trade suits against his company.

title: SCIMED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $51,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Advertising; Bulova Olympic Campaign
description: TIME is of the essence, as they say in clock and watch circles, and there are probably few companies that have such a lock on the very word as Bulova has.

title: Article 784188 -- No Title
description: After nearly a decade of international legal wrangling, a Federal district judge today ordered the Amoco Corporation to pay $85.2 million in damages for the 1978 oil spill of the Amoco Cadiz.

title: Shuttle to Be Delayed At Least Until July 15
description: Problems with the space shuttle's booster rockets will delay the resumption of flights at least until July 15, space agency officials said today. But they said they would launch the craft as soon as it was ready, countering speculation that they might delay the flight until after November's Presidential election for political reasons.

title: BRAJDAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $234,100 and $684,800 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $109,750 for the quarter and $339,250 for the 9 months.

title: Chess: Tal Parries Gambit to Defeat Romanishin in Soviet Event
description: Four grandmasters tied for first place in the Jurmala International Tournament in the Soviet Latvian Republic: Aivar Gipslis, who has given himself mainly to training top women in recent years; Lev Psakhis, a two-time Soviet champion; Mikhail Tal, a former world champion, and Yuri Razuvayev, a tournament regular.

title: Three Theater Events Out of Festival
description: Two key theater events planned for the First New York International Festival of the Arts, including a show that would have had its premiere on one of the festival's three opening nights, have been postponed until after the festival, and a third has been canceled, the chairman of the festival board, Martin E. Segal, said yesterday.

title: Science Watch; Test Tube Chickens
description: THE question of which came first, the chicken or the egg, may be losing some of its meaning. A scientist has learned how to produce the chick without its own egg shell.

title: 'Pappy' Boyington Is Dead at 75; Hero of the Black Sheep Squadron
description: Gregory (Pappy) Boyington, the Marine flying ace of World War II who commanded the famous Black Sheep Squadron, shot down 28 Japanese planes and won the Medal of Honor, died here this morning at a hospice for cancer patients. He was 75 years old.

title: Privatizing N.I.H. Is an 'Idiotic Idea'
description: LEAD: If the Office of Management and Budget's threatening suggestion to privatize the research arm of the National Institutes of Health was meant to intimidate, demoralize and destabilize one of the Government's most effective enterprises, it has probably been moderately successful. If O.M.B. was searching for a cheap, unthinking way of addressing delicate management issues at N.I.H., it has found the perfect instrument.

title: Dialing QuantumLink
description: IF you own a Commodore 64 or 128 and a modem, QuantumLink is definitely worth a trial flight.

title: Q&A
description: Q.How do people who have been deaf from birth articulate their thoughts internally?

title: The Crash, Backward and Forward
description: The Brady task force deserves high marks for its detailed, sophisticated analysis of the October stock market catastrophe. The report does better at pinpointing Wall Street's weaknesses, however, than providing credible remedies.

title: 5 Die, 17 Hurt In Building Fire On the East Side
description: Five residents of an apartment building on the East Side of Manhattan died in a fire last night that began in a ground-floor office and spread up an elevator shaft to the top floor, where most of the victims were found, fire officials said.

title: AIDS Researchers Frustrated in Hunt For Genetic Factors
description: THE search for genetic factors in susceptibility to AIDS has suffered a setback with the failure to confirm preliminary findings of a main candidate.

title: Arms Pact: Next Hurdle Is Senate 'Graveyard'
description: When the Senate returns to Capitol Hill Jan. 25, the main order of business will be its consideration of the arms reduction treaty signed last month by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to eliminate land-based, shorter- and intermediate-range nuclear weapons.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $76,000 and $277,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $80,000 and $305,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: SPEX GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Genetic Testing Limits Rejected in New Jersey
description: A bill that sought to establish the nation's first state commission to review and regulate products of genetic engineering was defeated here tonight by the state Assembly. With 41 votes needed for passage, the bill attracted only 26 votes.

title: U.N. Lowers '88 Estimates
description: The United Nations said today that it had revised downward its forecast for worldwide economic growth in 1988. The United Nations is now predicting growth of 3 percent, instead of the 3.5 percent rate reported two weeks before the Oct. 19 stock market plunge.

title: Seaport in a Storm
description: The historic vessels and unusual older buildings at New York City's South Street Seaport Museum were saved with funds generated by selling unused air rights over the old buildings to a consortium of banks. The banks hoped to resell the rights for transfer to new buildings nearby.

title: BENGUET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results for the latest net income and net loss are based on Benguet's current equity in its Engineering Equipment Inc. unit. The year-ago results are restated to reflect the previously reported adjustments to the results of Engineering Equipment.

title: Wall Street: The Inquiry
description: Wall Streeters, inside traders and corporate raiders beware: Representative John D. Dingell, one of the toughest questioners on Capitol Hill, is preparing to hold hearings on the operations of the stock market. The hearings, to be held by the investigations subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee, are expected to last six to eight days and focus on leveraged buyouts, corporate takeovers and insider trading. The panel insists that all its witnesses be sworn before they testify.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 24 about Hob Broun, a writer, included an incorrect account from his publisher, Alfred A. Knopf, about his illness and death.

title: Business and Health; Behind Troubles Of Empire Plan
description: WHEN the government of the nation's second-largest state and three highly respected health insurers are burned as New York State and Metropolitan Life, Blue Cross and Equitable have been in recent months by losses in the state's Empire health insurance plan, a lot of people start asking questions.

title: INSIDE
description: Settlers Kill Palestinian A Jewish settlement leader and his bodyguard opened fire on Palestinian demonstrators in the West Bank, leaving a teen-ager dead. Page A8. Afghan Guerrilla Infighting Rivalries among Afghan rebel groups have worsened and led to new fighting among them, guerrilla spokesmen and diplomats say. Page A6. Terror Suspect Arrested A West German woman suspected in the 1986 bombing of a West Berlin disco that killed two American servicemen was arrested. Page A3. Budget Cutbacks Assailed Dr. Otis R. Bowen denounced cutbacks in President Reagan's draft budget for the Department of Health and Human Services. Page A12. Cuomo Pushes Bills Early Governor Cuomo filed 61 bills in an unusual attempt to get the Legislature in Albany to move faster and adjourn earlier. Page B3.

title: Babes in Law Land
description: You are checking your notes in preparation for cross-examining the star witness in a sensational murder trial. The telephone rings. It's your baby-sitter. She has the measles!

title: Court Allows Natwest's Broker Link
description: Further breaking down the barriers between the banking and securities businesses, the Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal of a decision that allowed bank affiliates to offer investment advice and brokerage services to institutional or wealthy clients.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Are Said to Clash
description: At a time when Moscow has increasingly talked of an early withdrawal of its troops from Afghanistan, differences among the Afghan insurgent groups have worsened and led to new fighting among them on Afghan soil, according to guerrilla spokesmen and diplomats.

title: Keep Ice Hockey
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $858,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Chief Financial Officer Is Chosen by Citicorp
description: Nancy S. Newcomb has been named chief financial officer of Citicorp, the nation's biggest banking company announced late yesterday, Ms. Newcomb, who is 42 years old, has been with Citicorp and its primary subsidiary, Citibank, for 20 years.

title: Big Bank's Loss Reserve
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said today that it had set aside a reserve to cover more than half of its $1.8 billion portfolio of loans to developing countries, making it the largest bank to declare more than half of the portfolio in jeopardy.

title: Foreign Edge in Takeovers
description: Companies in Britain, West Germany and Japan have an advantage in acquiring American companies because of how laws regarding good will payments are handled by their countries, a Congressional report says.

title: Sikorsky Contract
description: The Sikorsky Aircraft division of the United Technologies Corporation. has been awarded a $983.2 million contract to build 252 UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters, the Army said. The contract is for four years. The Army said Sikorsky had been given $243.5 million as a first-year increment toward work on the helicopters, which will be built in Stratford, Conn. The work is scheduled to be completed by the end of August 1991.

title: Justice Dept. Plans Anti-Racketeering Drive Against Pornographers
description: In a move to close down several major distributors of pornography, the Justice Department plans to seek a series of racketeering indictments this year designed to seize tens of millions of dollars from the distribution and sale of sexually explicit material.

title: ZYTEC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $82,000 and $203,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively.

title: SOUTHERN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year includes a gain equal to 8 cents a share from the sale of the mortgage servicing rights. The figures for 1987 and 1986 were restated to include those of the Union National Bank of Oxford, N.C., which was merged into Southern National on Oct. 30, 1987, in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Emhart's Plans For Stanadyne
description: The Emhart Corporation said it would consider selling all of Stanadyne Inc.'s non-plumbing businesses if its $40-a-share hostile tender offer is successful. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Emhart also said that it had received a commitment for $600 million to complete the takeover from a syndicate of banks led by the Bankers Trust Company. Emhart estimated that it needed $585 million to complete the takeover.

title: U.S. Considers Broadcasting A TV Version of Radio Marti
description: Congress has taken the first step toward creating a television version of Radio Marti, the Government's news service beamed to Cuba.

title: Plan for Atom Smasher Riles a Town
description: At this time of year, when the winds sweep off Lake Ontario, bringing an unending supply of snow, this is a community of stark beauty and natural calm, of gnarled apple orchards and old farm homes clustered in ice-covered fields.

title: FITZGERALD, DEARMAN & ROBRTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. The company said the share earnings do not take into account the 982,545 shares issued on Dec. 31, 1987.

title: A PLEA FOR MARKET COORDINATION
description: The Presidential panel's report on the stock market crash has run into a cool reception from some in the White House and heavy criticism from some in Congress and on Wall Street for its proposed reforms of the financial system. Already there have been predictions that the proposals will never be enacted.

title: Fashion's Stars Gather at Met To Fete the Best of Their Own
description: ''It's quite different from Dallas,'' said Victor Costa, the designer from Texas. ''I'm like a kid in a candy store.''

title: Jackson Isn't Afraid to Beg for Funds
description: ''I've got to look Presidential,'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson told a group of supporters at a house party here. ''Don't you all make me beg.''

title: Computer Unit Discloses Talks
description: The Computervision Corporation, which last week rejected a $380 million takeover bid from Prime Computer Inc., has indicated that it talked with other potential suitors.

title: Dollar Steady In Tokyo
description: The dollar remained steady today, while stocks declined after an initial rally in early trading in Tokyo.

title: Thanks, Travis McGee
description: Travis McGee, the hard-drinking, free-wenching hero of John D. MacDonald's adventure novels, has come to the aid of the Library of Congress and its continuing campaign to promote reading.

title: Cocktail Party to Aid Biaggi
description: Patrick J. Cunningham, a former Bronx and state Democratic chairman who served more than a year in prison for income tax evasion, is sponsoring a cocktail party tomorrow evening at the New York Athletic Club to help defray Representative Mario Biaggi's legal expenses. It is one of at least five fund-raisers being held for Mr. Biaggi, who was convicted of accepting an illegal gratuity from Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader.

title: SANTA MONICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A State Department Official Meets President of Paname Special to The New York Times
description: William G. Walker, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Central America, made an un-announced trip to New York today to meet with Panama's civillian Presi-dent, Eric Arturo Delvalle, State De-partment officials and senior Latin American diplomats said.

title: KEY RATES
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am exhilarated by the Court's decision and relieved that this nightmare seems finally to be ending.'' - Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, on the Supreme Court's refusal to reinstate a murder conviction. [ B8:1. ]

title: Life in New York's Lock-and-Buzzer Boutiques
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Secretary Assails Proposed Cuts
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today denounced personnel and budget cutbacks proposed in President Reagan's draft budget for the next year, saying they would cripple management of his department.

title: Vote Spurs Exodus From Haiti Capital
description: The old coastal steamer was packed with hundreds of people, bundles of clothing, sacks of food and even a few pigs.

title: Mets' Tribute to Seaver
description: The Mets announced yesterday that they would retire Tom Seaver's uniform next July 24 in a tribute to ''the best player to perform for the Mets in their 27-year history.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pacers 111, Clippers 90: John Long scored 9 of his 19 points in the decisive third quarter last night as the Indiana Pacers handed the Los Angeles Clippers their 11th straight loss. It was their 12th loss in 13 games and the last game of a disastrous seven-game road trip against Eastern Conference teams. Wayman Tisdale led the Pacers with 22 points.(AP) Suns 127, Nuggets 115: Larry Nance scored 29 points, Eddie Johnson added 24 and both together shut down Denver's Alex English. English, the N.B.A.'s seventh-leading scorer with a 25.3 average, was held to two free throws by halftime and finished with 13 points before fouling out with 1:38 remaining. Jay Vincent scored a career-high 42 points for the Nuggets, who lost their third straight.(AP) N.H.L. Whalers 4, Bruins 3: Dave Tippett and John Anderson scored goals 26 seconds apart early in the third period as the Hartford Whalers defeated Boston, ending the Bruins' six-game unbeaten streak. The Whalers, beating Boston for the first time in five games this season, rebounded after Keith Crowder gave the Bruins a 2-2 tie with his 13th goal of the season. (AP) Kings 5, North Stars 4: Bernie Nicholls scored a league-leading sixth short-handed goal in the second period to help the Kings beat the North Stars. A Kings defenseman, Ken Hammond, got credit for the tying goal at 1:16 of the second period and Mark Hardy's power-play goal just over four minutes later gave the Kings a 3-2 lead. Nicholls's short-handed goal came when the center converted Hardy's pass, and Luc Robitaille's 25th goal at 15:02 increased the Kings' lead to 5-2. (AP) Oilers 3, Capitals 2: Charlie Huddy and Mark Messier scored power-play goals to lead Edmonton to victory at home. The outcome was influenced by three decisions by Referee Ron Hoggarth, and all the calls went against the Capitals. Washington had two goals disallowed on quick whistles. But the call that hurt Washington the most was allowing Messier's power-play goal at 4:17 of the final period. The Capitals argued that Messier kicked the puck into the net and television replays seemed to support their stand.(AP)

title: Laura Chapman, Educator, 78
description: Laura Chapman, a former dean of the School of Nursing at Rutgers University, died of leukemia Jan. 1, at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. She was 78 years old and lived in Piscataway, N.J.

title: Waite Case Fraud Denied
description: One of two men the Church of England said it paid for information about Terry Waite, the kidnapped church envoy, denies that the deal was a fraud. A church spokesman said Sunday that the $21,000 payment was made to Charles Armstrong and John Entwhistle after they said they would meet with Lebanese contacts who knew Mr. Waite's captors. The church said the meeting never took place. But Mr. Armstrong said Sunday that he had supplied the church with information about Mr. Waite.

title: Lindsay, in Rare Move, Backs Historic District
description: Making a rare public statement before a city agency, former Mayor John V. Lindsay yesterday urged the Landmarks Preservation Commission to protect a huge swath of the Upper West Side of Manhattan from ''unrestrained, unplanned, unthinking, rampant development.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CONSOLATION OF NATURE AND OTHER STORIES. By Valerie Martin. 147 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95.

title: Resorts Bid Withdrawn By Trump
description: The developer Donald J. Trump withdrew his offer to buy control of Resorts International Inc. today and said he would probably be forced to halt construction of the huge Taj Mahal casino hotel.

title: Con O'Neill, Diplomat, 75
description: Sir Con O'Neill, who led the intricate negotiations that took Britain into the European Economic Community, died Monday, his family said. He was 75 years old.

title: Korean Oil Imports
description: South Korea's crude oil imports this year are expected to drop 6.6 percent from last year, to 215 million barrels, the Energy and Resources Ministry said today.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: Driver Disputes Charge
description: Rene Poulin, one of six drivers suspended by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board Dec. 2 for what the board termed ''lack of effort'' in a race Nov. 14, testified yesterday that his pacer could have won, instead of finishing third, if the horse, Handy Yankee, had not stretched his left hobble early in the fourth race at Yonkers Raceway.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Lakers Win 15th Straight: Byron Scott had 30 points for Los Angeles, which scored 10 of its last 14 points on free throws last night in a 117-113 victory against the Golden State Warriors that extended the Lakers' winning streak to 15 games.

title: Advances; A Device To Assist The Heart
description: EVERY year, cardiologists estimate, tens of thousands of Americans with heart disease are potential candidates for a heart transplant or an artificial device to assist the heart. According to some estimates, at least half of them have a defect of the left ventricle, the part of the heart that often wears out first.

title: Taiwan Plan For Investing
description: Taiwan is planning ''large scale'' investments in hotels, theaters and other cultural establishments in Hong Kong, according to a Cabinet statement issued Monday.

title: Aged Twins Slain in Illinois
description: Elderly twin brothers who lived as recluses in a house filled with trash were beaten to death and the house set afire, the authorities said today. ''The fire was used to cover the crime,'' said Fire Chief Tom Anderson. ''The motive at this time is unknown.'' The bodies of the victims, Roy and Irl McNutt, 79 years old, were found Saturday in their living room. Firefighters had difficulty getting to them because of the trash. ''The house had about two feet of trash in every room - cans and garbage, not just paper,'' Chief Anderson said.

title: U.S. Ready to Tell Japan It Will Back Nuclear Cooperation Pact
description: The Reagan Administration is prepared to tell Japan during its Prime Minister's visit here this week that the United States intends to proceed with a nuclear cooperation agreement despite Congressional objections, Administration officials said today.

title: Hanover Staff Cuts
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation will begin cutting its staff this week to reduce its payroll by 9 percent, the company's chairman, John F. McGillicuddy, said. Mr. McGillicuddy said the reductions among the New York-based banking group's 30,134 employees would affect some units more than others. He declined to be specific.

title: Australian With U.N. Force Is Killed by Mine in Lebanon
description: An Australian Army captain serving with a United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon was killed today when his car ran over a land mine, a United Nations spokesman said.

title: Gullickson Signs
description: Bill Gullickson, who spurned a Yankee offer last week, signed a one-year contract today with the Yomiuri Giants. Gullickson will receive $1.1 million for 1988 plus a contract signing bonus of $400,000 and at least $150,000 in expenses. ''I will try my best for the Giants as I did in the major leagues,'' Gullickson said at a news conference in Tokyo. Gullickson, his wife, Sandra, and his agent, Doug Baldwin, arrived in Tokyo last Saturday amid reports that Gullickson would accept a two-year, $3.3 million offer from the Giants, the 1987 champions of the Central League, one of Japan's two pro leagues. Gullickson, a 28-year-old right-hander who pitched in the majors for nine seasons, compiling a 101-86 record, turned down New York's $1.8 million, two-year offer last Friday.

title: At Adolfo, the Antic Mood Moderates
description: BETWEEN periods of turbulence, fashion often simmers down. Despite the prevalence of lace boleros, fluffy skirts paved in ruched ruffles and the glitter of gold-colored metal, the Adolfo collection for spring and summer actually reflects a moderate mood. It contrasts with the boisterousness of his last collection, giving women as well as the designer a chance to catch a breath.

title: U.S. Prosecutor Is Resigning
description: The head of the nation's largest Federal prosecutor's office announced his resignation today after leading investigations ranging from espionage to corruption in the administration of Mayor Marion Barry Jr. of Washington.

title: What New Tiles?
description: Senators returning from recess later this month might not notice the new tile floor that is being installed in one of the main lobbies on the first floor of the Senate wing of the Capitol. Their oversight would be understandable, because the new floor looks exactly like the old tile floor that has been in place since it was installed in the 1850's.

title: PAKISTANI LEADERS BACK COMPROMISE FOR AFGHAN PEACE
description: Pakistan's two senior leaders have concluded that some members of the pro-Moscow Government in Afghanistan must be allowed to take part in a successor government as a condition for the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

title: Jane S. Nickerson, 87, Writer and Historian
description: Jane Soames Nickerson, a writer and historian, died Sunday at her home in Locust Valley, L.I. She was 87 years old.

title: Is Austin the Next Silicon Valley?
description: IF it were simply a matter of 800 new jobs by 1990, the arrival here of a much sought after experimental research consortium, Sematech, probably would not mean that much for Austin and its growth-conscious city fathers. After all, the state government payroll alone grew by 2,000 in the Texas capital last year.

title: CONSOLIDATED PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 23
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $190,000.

title: Bridge: First Big Regional Tourney For 1988 Is Opening Today
description: The first major tournament of 1988 for players in the New York metropolitan area, the Tri-State Regional, begins today at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y. This is the schedule: Today - Men's pairs and women's pairs, 1:30 and 8 P.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1988
description: International

title: State Dept. Adviser Says Shutting P.L.O. Mission Would Break Law
description: Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department legal adviser, says that closing the Palestine Liberation Organization observer mission to the United Nations, as Congress has mandated, would violate international law.

title: Harried Lawmakers Find Congress 'Too Chaotic'
description: A study of 114 members of Congress has found that nearly 95 percent complained that the legislative process was ''too chaotic.'' Among other criticisms, most lawmakers said that an ineffectual budget process was increasingly dominating policy considerations.

title: U.S. Would Put Off Sending Child Home Pending Counseling
description: The Reagan Administration, while urging the Supreme Court to lift an interim order barring the return of a 9-year-old boy to Zimbabwe, indicated today that it might allow a brief wait for psychological reasons before returning the boy, who the Administration says was badly abused by his diplomat father.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Vikings-Redskins Gives No. 2 Passers Another Chance
description: You don't have to look at the depth chart to find out who the backup quarterbacks are in the National Conference title game Sunday - they'll be starting.

title: Judge Orders Readjustment Of Allowances for Housing
description: A New York State judge yesterday ordered a temporary halt to the eviction of all New York City families on welfare whose monthly rent is higher than the shelter allowance provided by the state.

title: TV and Politics: 2 Cities Give Hint of the Impact
description: Iowans besieged by politicians and their electronic messages since before 1988 began, are growing weary of the prolonged Presidential campaign. In Texas, voters are still trying to sort out just who is running for the White House.

title: Hart's Campaign Igniting Emotions
description: When Gilbert Fuchsberg, a Harvard student, asked Gary Hart whether he had ever used marijuana or any other illegal drug, he expected that the Democratic Presidential candidate would not like the question.

title: 4 LATIN PRESIDENTS CAUTIONED BY U.S. ON CONTRAS' FATE
description: The President's national security adviser has warned the leaders of four Central American countries that they could face serious economic and political consequences if Congress lets the contras collapse, according to senior Administration officials and diplomats familiar with the discussions.

title: WESTWOOD ONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Rights Group Reports Iraqis Used Rat Poison on Kurds
description: Amnesty International said yesterday that it had received reliable reports that Iraqi security forces had used rat poison to try to kill at least 40 Kurds opposed to the Government.

title: A Coming Filipino Vote Divides Aquino Family
description: Trucks stacked high with newly harvested sugar cane on the plantation of President Corazon C. Aquino have been flying tiny banners supporting the gubernatorial candidacy of her family's choice, Candido Guiam.

title: Jones Leads St. John's by Rutgers, 73-55
description: Taking a brief respite from the Big East Conference, St. John's defeated overmatched Rutgers handily, 73-55, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Singer Board To Meet on Bid
description: The Singer Company said yesterday that its directors had called a special meeting today to consider a $1 billion takeover bid from Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor.

title: BARRY'S JEWELERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
USX and Bethlehem Lift Sheet Steel Prices
description: Two leading steel companies said yesterday that they had raised prices by 4 percent to 8 percent on their sheet steel products, which are used heavily in the automobile and appliance industries.

title: MGM/UA COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of about $3 million from the sale of the company's corporate headquarters building in September 1987.

title: Boy, 6, Handling Gun, Kills Brother, Who Is 7
description: A 7-year-old boy was accidentaly shot to death by his 6-year-old brother, who was playing with a loaded revolver last night in their apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: Gerald Peter Plano, Record Producer, 49
description: Gerald Peter Plano, a record producer for 25 years, died of lung cancer Saturday at his home in Pacheco, Calif. He was 49 years old. Mr. Plano, a native of Los Angeles, was director of arts and repertoire services for RCA/Ariola Records in New York City. He produced 6,000 special record collections, including more than 30 for Reader's Digest, during his years with the company.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Lemieux Forces A Tie
description: For too long, neither the Islanders nor the Penguins have felt the comfort that comes with victory, so they have been playing without confidence and with uninspiring results. Nothing changed tonight and the division rivals emerged with a 5-5 tie.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Tops Last Year's Record
description: Contributions to the 76th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have set a record, passing the $3 million mark for the second year in a row.

title: Simon Sees Tax Rise as Likely
description: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois said today that the ''most probable'' way to finance his plan to bolster long-term health care would be to increase Social Security taxes.

title: WESTERN FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Orleans Symphony Cancels Rest of Season
description: Struggling with a large debt and low attendance, the New Orleans Symphony has decided to cancel the rest of its season.

title: American Express Bank Write-Off
description: The American Express Bank said yesterday that it had written off all its loans to Latin America's private sector and added $350 million to its reserves for loan losses.

title: Wings' Yzerman Flourishes On Graceful Scoring Touch
description: When he discusses the notable contributions of Steve Yzerman to the Detroit Red Wings this season, Jacques Demers, the coach, acknowledges them in the context of the split personality of professional hockey.

title: In Reversal, Black Clergy Group Votes to Invite Koch to Memorial
description: In an unexpected reversal, a group of black Baptist clergy members voted to invite Mayor Koch to attend its annual memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the president of the group said yesterday.

title: Advertising; New Magazine Caters To the Performing Arts
description: A new magazine for the visual and performing arts called Contemporanea, with a publishing frequency of six a year, will make its debut here and in Italy in May.

title: Lush Life: Investor, 23, Named in Huge Fraud
description: David P. Bloom, a 23-year-old New Yorker with an unregistered investment business, collected $10 million in the last two years from 100 friends and associates to play the stock market. Instead, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission, he bought himself an art collection, a beach house on Long Island and a reputation as a philanthropist.

title: U.S. Study of Airline Accidents Finds Sharp Increase in 1987
description: The major airlines in the United States had their highest number of accidents in 13 years last year and the most deaths in five years, the National Transportation Safety Board reported today.

title: Debt
description: Florida Department of Natural Resources is tentatively offering $25 million of tax-exempt ''Save Our Coast'' revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. The bonds, insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, yield from 5.60 percent for an issue due in 1989 to 8 percent in 2012; they are rated triple A. Preferred Stock

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sky-High Crop Prices

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Net income

title: The Greed of the Notch Babies
description: The Notch Babies: They are not babies at all but an angry special interest group of Social Security recipients in their late 60's. Timothy Noah, writing in The New Republic, called them ''a parody of a special interest group.'' But as the Presidential candidates are learning on the campaign trail, the seven million Notch Babies are righteous, well organized and powerful.

title: E-II to Talk With Brands
description: Donald P. Kelly, chairman of E-II Holdings Inc., a Chicago-based offshoot of the Beatrice Companies, will meet today with William J. Alley, chairman of American Brands Inc., to discuss ideas to improve American Brands' stock price, both companies said yesterday.

title: Rise Sought In Cocoa Prices
description: Emergency talks between cocoa-producing and consuming nations will open here on Wednesday in hopes of establishing mechanisms to support prices in a glutted market.

title: First Titan 4 Is at Canaveral
description: The first Air Force Titan 4, the United States' most powerful unmanned space rocket, arrived here today to be prepared for a launching with a military payload in October. The 204-foot booster was brought here by a C5A cargo plane from a plant near Denver. In addition to the Air Force's plans to launch two of the rockets annually from here, the space agency is considering using the Titan 4 for scientific payloads, and its manufacturer, Martin Marietta, wants to market it for commercial customers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Real Estate; Vertical Plan Cuts Costs of Retail Space
description: SHUNNED by retailers and office tenants, the cheapest space in most commercial buildings is to be found in the basement or on the second floor.

title: Santa Fe Plans Staff Cutbacks
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said today that it would reduce its corporate staff to about 125 positions, from 371 positions, as part of a restructuring plan to sell its non-core businesses. Separately, Olympia & York

title: Democracy's Fair Weather Friend
description: The new year has started with democracy in retreat in several countries, yet the Reagan Administration, quick to claim credit when there's good news, now prefers to ignore, or disguise, the bad.

title: Confusion In the Cockpit
description: PATRICK EWING has a problem with aerodynamics, primarily and most deleteriously on defense. He is often seen flying through the air when his wheels should be firmly on the floor.

title: Macchiarola Assails Board of Education
description: Frank J. Macchiarola, the former New York City Schools Chancellor, excoriated the city's Board of Education yesterday, accusing its members of being ''more concerned with political influence'' than with education.

title: Dyncorp Board Sets Bid Deadline
description: The board of Dyncorp said that it would terminate an agreement to be acquired by an investor group led by its chairman, Jorge E. Carnicero, unless the group increases its $216 million takeover offer within five days. Dyncorp has received a second takeover offer from DME Holdings Inc., a group that includes several Dyncorp managers. Analysts valued the new offer at $1 more per share than the Carnicero bid, or about $226 million.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Wonderful Belgrade
description: For a number of years, Belgrade has been considered one of the prize ambassadorial posts for those in the United States Foreign Service and when it opens up there is hot competition for it.

title: PSA Official Takes Job At McDonnell Douglas
description: Russell L. Ray, an aviation executive, crossed into hostile territory on Monday.

title: Remy Martin Bid
description: The French brandy distiller Remy Martin said it would bid for a 60 percent stake in the venerable liqueur maker Benedictine. Terms were not dis-closed, but based on its recent market price, Benedictine is valued at 854 million francs, or about $155 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the articles on daily trading in the stock market yesterday and on Saturday incorrectly ranked Friday's 140.58-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. The decline was No. 13 in percentage terms and No. 3 in points.

title: Legislators Seek a Panel to Study New York City Board of Education
description: In a move that some New York City officials fear could delay proposed changes in the city's Board of Education, some legislators are pressing for a state commission to examine the structure of the board.

title: MARYLAND FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: There are no per share earnings for the year-ago periods because the association converted to public ownership in June 1987.

title: Dollar and Gold Down a Bit As Cautious Mood Prevails
description: The dollar dipped in light trading yesterday as currency dealers warily awaited Friday's report on the American trade deficit.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American President Cos., Oakland, Calif., appointed Robert K. Dahl senior vice president and chief financial officer, replacing John Flynn, who left to pursue other interests.

title: Soviet Is Losing Rights To Fish Off West Africa
description: The waters off West Africa -long the Soviet Union's largest overseas source of fish - are increasingly off limits to Soviet fishing boats.

title: Thriving on Currency Tumult
description: For months, betting against the dollar seemed a sure thing to the global army of traders who ply the $200 billion-a-day currency market. Going into the new year, most foreign-exchange traders expected the United States currency to fall even more.

title: 2 Killed in Zimbabwe Blast
description: Two people were killed and three were wounded when a car bomb wrecked a suburban villa used by the African National Congress, the outlawed South African rebel group, a Zimbabwe official said today. The official said those killed may have been planting the bomb outside the house in Trenance, a suburb of Bulawayo.

title: Tax-Exempt Market Active With Three Large Offerings
description: Activity in the tax-exempt market rebounded yesterday with three new issues of more than $120 million each.

title: Colombia Says U.S. Reprisals Weaken Support for Drug Fight
description: Colombia has warned that the United States is indirectly aiding powerful cocaine traffickers by carrying out reprisals against Colombians over the release from prison of a reputed cocaine smuggler here in late December.

title: Bradley Back on Track As Hawkins Leads Way
description: There were rumblings in these parts as early as 1986 after a quiet but devastating sophomore guard led Bradley to a 32-3 record.

title: Tripoli Journal; Face to Face With Square Jaws of Billboard Fame
description: As personality cults go, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's is up there with the most visible.

title: U.S. Legislators Warn Sandinistas on Peace Talks
description: Members of a Congressional delegation visiting Nicaragua said today that they warned the Government here that Congress may approve more aid for rebels if the Sandinistas do not reverse their position and agree to begin direct cease-fire talks with the contras.

title: Curb on News Copters Urged
description: The National Transportation Safety Board is calling for tighter curbs on the use of helicopters by the news media at accident scenes, saying that they often interfere with rescue or cleanup operations.

title: REALTY SOUTH INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Korea Export Rise Seen
description: South Korea's merchandise exports in the first quarter are expected to reach $12.1 billion, up 28.8 percent from the corresponding period last year, the Korea Foreign Trade Association said today. The association also forecast that the nation's imports in the January-March period would remain at $10.4 billion, creating a trade surplus of $1.7 billion.

title: Accidental Shootings of Children Raising Concern
description: Sensational shootings often draw more attention, but to many people here there is something deeply troubling in the numbing frequency of incidents like the one Monday that left 14-year-old Aaron Fultz critically wounded.

title: Mafia Trial Discloses Inquiry Into Jury Tampering
description: The Federal trial of a reputed Mafia ''capo'' and nine other defendants took an unusual turn yesterday when the judge disclosed that he had privately questioned one or more jurors. The disclosure came amid indications that he was inquiring into possible tampering.

title: New TV System Offers Descriptions for Blind
description: When public television broadcasts a three-part performance of Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude'' next week, blind and vision-impaired people in nine areas may be able to enjoy the show more than in the past, since an oral description of the visual portions will be broadcast at the same time.

title: Advertising; WCRS Deal Expands Hong Kong Operation
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners' sister agency in Hong Kong has just gotten much bigger.

title: The Pointless Minuet
description: After the stock market's October blowout Wall Street said it was Washington's fault. What caused it, said Wall Street, was President Reagan's famous voodoo economics: spend and spend, and tax not, tax not, tax not.

title: Mark Saxton, A Book Editor, Is Dead at 73
description: Mark Saxton, an author and editor, died, apparently of a heart attack, last Thursday in his home in New York City. He was 73 years old.

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,989,000 on the sale of the company's New York City office building. c-Net income

title: A Civilian President Named in Suriname To End Army Rule
description: The National Assembly elected a civilian President today, paving the way for a return to democracy after seven years of military rule.

title: U.S. Says Iran Received More Chinese Missiles
description: An Administration official said today that Iran had received a new shipment of Chinese-built Silkworm missiles by way of North Korea.

title: N.C.A.A. Rejects I-A Football Playoffs
description: A proposed national championship football playoff was overwhelmingly rejected today by the nation's major football schools.

title: Perils of Gulf Can Be Yours With a Cruise
description: This is the plan: they will sail into the Persian Gulf aboard a vessel offering what the publicity calls ''delicious food, parties, festive activities,'' and offer a vision of peace.

title: Katherine Fenimore Cooper, Horticulturist, 92
description: Katherine Guy Fenimore Cooper, a horticulturist and member of the boards of many charitable groups, died Friday at her home in Cooperstown, N.Y. She was 92 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday about pedestrians walking on a plank bridge over a Manhattan street flooded by a water main break misidentified the location. It was Park Avenue at 73d Street.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: Highlights for Children magazine to McCaffrey & McCall Direct Marketing.

title: Chase Appoints Citicorp Official
description: Richard L. Huber, formerly an executive in Citicorp's investment bank, has joined the Chase Manhattan Corporation as sector executive for capital markets and foreign exchange.

title: What's the Hot Item in Town? Depends on the Town
description: GRANTED, some local favorites make sense: grits in New Orleans, rice in Charleston, S.C., and cranberry juice in Boston. But why do people in Dallas eat more canned spinach than anyone else in the United States? And why is New York City, supposedly a center of sophisticated tastes, the Wonder bread capital of the country?

title: U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD ON SCIENCE SIGNED
description: The broadest Soviet-American accord on scientific cooperation in almost a decade was signed here today by the heads of the two countries' top scientific academies, paving the way for greater joint efforts in fields ranging from AIDS research to nuclear reactor safety.

title: Ray Bauduc, Drummer, 81
description: Ray Bauduc, a jazz drummer and composer in the era of the big bands, died Jan. 8. He was 81 years old.

title: Donald S. Curtis, Investment Analyst, 78
description: Donald S. Curtis, a financial analyst who retired as vice president in the investment research department of Marine Midland Bank in 1974, died Jan. 3 at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Old Greenwich.

title: Dow Falls By 16.58 in Wide Drop
description: LEAD: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, although closing prices were well above their lowest levels of the day.

title: Lendl, Navratilova Advance
description: Ivan Lendl, seeking his first Australian Open singles title, and Martina Navratilova, going after her fourth, made quick work of second-round foes today.

title: Sihanouk Will Meet A Coalition Partner Before Peace Talks
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann, the leaders of the two non-Communist forces battling the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia, are planning to meet in Paris on Monday, Mr. Son Sann said today.

title: THEATER: ''MIDSUMMER NIGHT''
description: AS festively staged by A. J. Antoon, ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' is the perfect show to inaugurate Joseph Papp's marathon presentation of the entire Shakespeare canon -not by any means because it's perfect Shakespeare, but because it's quintessential Joseph Papp. The cast is an urban populist's utopian ideal, as diverse in show-biz experience (and inexperience) as it is in ethnic mix. The play's setting has been moved from Athens to funkier Brazilian climes (turn-of-the-century Bahia), with the bossa nova beat of an offstage band often overriding the poetry. And there's a harmless, old-time liberal political agenda. By transforming the young lovers into starchy European colonials and the fairies into jungle spiritualists, this ''Dream'' is less a vision of romantic emancipation than an outsider's gaga celebration of the liberating culture of the third world.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1988
description: International A2-13

title: Concert by Andre Watts Celebrates 25-Year Career
description: Andre Watts, who has been playing a big, rare Romantic piano concerto with the Brooklyn Philharmonic, has three big familiar ones waiting for him tonight at Avery Fisher Hall, the scene of his spectacular television debut under Leonard Bernstein 25 years ago. As his anniversary celebration approached, Mr. Watts was relaxed, witty and articulate, discussing details of the repertory and speculative program-building in his suite at an East Side hotel on the morning of his Brooklyn performance.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ON a recent evening Zeus Goldberg, an executive with Restaurant Associates, left the Grand Tier Restaurant at the Metropolitan Opera House. At the Lincoln Center station he boarded a downtown IRT train. Some stops later a well-dressed woman laden with shopping bags and assorted parcels got on board. As she headed for a seat one of the bags she was juggling broke, sending a bottle of wine smashing all over the floor of the car. Startled passengers looked up, then stared helplessly at the puddle.

title: Educated Guesses About '87 Vintages
description: THERE is a tale about a brash fellow who stopped J. P. Morgan as he left his club and asked, ''Will the market go up or down?'' To which old J. P. is said to have replied, ''Yes.''

title: Little Change in Treasury Prices
description: Treasury note and bond prices were unchanged to slightly lower yesterday in aimless trading that reflected a widespread lack of conviction about the future course of interest rates.

title: FIRST EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago fourth quarter and year results are restated to reflect First Eastern's merger with Liberty Bancorp Inc., accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TELECRAFTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
States With 55 M.P.H. Limit Face Millions in U.S. Penalties
description: Twelve states that have retained the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, could lose millions of dollars in highway funds under a new quirk in Federal laws and regulations.

title: HELEN OF TROY (CO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $256,000 and $782,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: A Scholar Guides China's Food Policy
description: WANG QING was 17 years old in 1967, when Red Guards surrounded her home here and placed her entire family under house arrest.

title: Campaign Finance Thaw
description: New York's Mayor Koch and the City Council majority leader, Peter Vallone, deserve praise for a compromise on public financing of city election campaigns. It should make possible Council approval of a landmark campaign finance law.

title: The Little King
description: Who is to blame for the loss of more than a score of Palestinian Arab lives in the past month?

title: State Colleges' Appeal To Nonresidents Grows
description: When the tuition at your favorite ivy-covered private college is simply out of the question and you would not be caught dead at your local state university, what to do?

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GORBACHEV SEES CRUCIAL PERIOD FOR HIS CHANGES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in an interview made public today that his domestic initiatives offer the current generation of Russians the last chance to reshape their country.

title: Concert: From Babbitt, 'Joy of More Sextets'
description: THE title of ''The Joy of More Sextets'' - a recent violin and piano work by Milton Babbitt that had its first local performance Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall - refers to a work of 20 years ago entitled simply ''Sextets.'' Neither involves a sextet in the conventional sense of six instruments; the term refers to numerical groupings that govern the pitches and other events in the 20-minute work.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Net loss

title: ALLWASTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Confections With Taste and Spectacle, From Two Bakers
description: SOME artists work with oils, some in watercolors. But Sylvia Weinstock and Colette Peters prefer butter cream, a moist, tender cake and icing. Although the two women work independently they share the same idea of what a cake should be: an edible extravaganza.

title: Morris Giloni, Stockbroker, 80
description: Morris Giloni, a stockbroker and a member of the board of the Jewish National Fund of America, a group that represents the Herut Zionists, died on Jan. 4 at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mr. Giloni, who had suffered a massive stroke five days earlier at his home in Manhattan, was 80 years old.

title: Robert F. Kennon, 85; A Louisiana Governor
description: Robert F. Kennon, who was Governor of Louisiana from 1952 to 1956, died Monday. He was 85 years old.

title: Savings Mergers Assailed
description: House Speaker Jim Wright said in an interview published today that he was opposed to steps taken by regulators to merge small, ailing savings and loan institutions into larger institutions.

title: Chicago Journal; Poverty Kills a Church That Disaster Couldn't
description: More than a century ago, struggling immigrant families, mostly from Ireland and Italy, pulled together to erect a church that matched their own gritty determination and soaring hopes.

title: About New York; Presto, It's Open! Wizard Is on Call And Expensive
description: Leslie Koerner was having his cheeseburger with a slice of onion and a Dr. Brown's black cherry soda at Big Nick's on Broadway when his beeper went off and he leaped out the door to find a pay phone. He was just saying, ''a lot of times people are antagonistic because of the price - they feel they're being ripped off even if they're not,'' when he was summoned.

title: Ron and Nobu
description: Soon after Noboru Takeshita's selection as Japan's leader last October, he received a congratulatory telephone call from President Reagan.

title: Triangle Package Unit Hires Chip Executive
description: William N. Sick, executive vice president of Texas Instruments Inc., switched yesterday to packaging from electronics, announcing that he had been named chief executive of the American National Can Company.

title: Back Behind the Wheel
description: Roberto Guerrero, who suffered critical head injuries in September, will climb back into the cockpit of a race car for the first time tomorrow at Firebird International Raceway in Phoenix. The 29-year-old Colombian driver was injured in a crash during tire testing at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. He remained in a coma for more than two weeks. A spokesman for the Granatelli-STP team said yesterday that Guerrero will drive a 1987 March-Cosworth in tomorrow's test session. ''This is more a test of the driver than the car,'' explained the spokesman, Harvey Duck. ''Roberto wants to see where he stands and so does the the team. They'll go on from there.''

title: Rate Is Tied To Price Index
description: Morgan Stanley & Company is offering a new type of debt security on which the interest rate will be adjusted according to changes in the Government's Consumer Price Index.

title: MUSIC: 55TH ANNIVERSARY OF COMPOSERS GROUP
description: TO mark the 55th anniversary of its founding, the National Association of Composers, U.S.A., sponsored a program of six works at Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening. Three of the pieces were given their local premieres and, as it happened, they were the program's least memorable selections.

title: Biden Gives Kinnock Copy of His Speeches
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., meeting Neil Kinnock for the first time, today presented the Labor Party leader with a bound copy of the Senator's speeches and told reporters: ''I told him he was welcome to use them whenever he liked, with or without attribution.''

title: Another U.S. Study Down the Drain?
description: It is too early to tell if the $1.6 million study on future American military strategy delivered to the President today by a distinguished group of former Government officials and retired military men will suffer the fate of most other such studies. But it is highly likely.

title: COMPUTERVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $7.5 million, or 26 cents a share, from the sale of minority interest in a subsidiary and sale of stock and warrants. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain of $1.5 million, or 5 cents a share, from the sale of stock warrants.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we take fright and stop the processes we have begun, it would have the most serious consequences, because we simply could not raise our people to such a massive task a second time.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on revitalizing the Soviet Union. [ A1:5. ]

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Business People column yesterday characterized the Continental Illinois Corporation's business strategy incorrectly. The bank is emphasizing investment banking and leaving retail banking, but it will continue other aspects of commercial banking, including trust services, lending and providing personal banking services for wealthy customers.

title: Cecil Cooper Waived
description: Cecil Cooper, the Milwaukee Brewers' career leader in batting and runs batted in who did not play after the All-Star break last season, was waived yesterday for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Cooper, 38 years old, played 11 of his 14 major-league seasons with the Brewers. The five-time All-Star had one year remaining on a contract that called for a reported $700,000 in 1988, not including a deferred payment of $840,000. Any team can claim Cooper for $1 during the next three days, but he has the right of refusal. If he clears waivers, Cooper will be free to deal with any team he chooses. In 63 games last season as the team's designated hitter, Cooper batted a career-low .248 with 36 r.b.i.'s and 6 homers. A career .298-hitter, Cooper played in 1,896 games during his 14 years with 241 homers, 1,125 r.b.i.'s and 2,192 hits.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARCO, Los Angeles, has raised its holdings in British-based Britoil P.L.C. to 23.04 percent from 21.91 percent.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $612,000 for the quarter and $2,188,000 for the year, and tax credits of $527,000 and $7,051,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $37,043,000 and $54,728,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $100,000 for the quarter and a tax loss carryforward of $1,500,000 for the year.

title: Quintuplets Artificially Conceived Are Born
description: The first birth of quintuplets conceived outside the womb in the United States occurred Monday, officials of the William Beaumont Hospital said today.

title: CONSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Jersey Firms Searched in Drexel Case
description: Expanding their investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., Federal authorities confiscated records from a securities firm in Princeton, N.J., last month to gather evidence of possible securities and tax fraud.

title: East Side Dries Off After Day of Flooding
description: When Helen Costantino Fioratti lifted a soaked antique chair in her Upper East Side shop yesterday, the leg, weakened by moisture, plopped to the floor.

title: Guggenheim Names a New Director
description: The director of the Williams College Museum of Art in Williamstown, Mass., who is known as aggressive museum administrator and an innovator in the field of art museum management, has been appointed the new director of the Guggenheim Museum of Art, museum officials announced yesterday.

title: Market Place; 2 Analysts Assail Retailer Inertia
description: TWO Wall Street analysts took on hundreds of retailers yesterday and showed them no mercy.

title: Jaguar in Pursuit of Porsche
description: The British are coming.

title: Agatha Singer, Physician, 76
description: Agatha Singer, a retired New York City physician who for many years worked in child-health care in the city's Health Department, died Sunday at New York Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: European Jobless Up
description: The number of unemployed in the 12-nation European Community rose to 15.9 million in November from 15.8 million in the previous month, Eurostat, the statistical service, reported today. Eurostat said the unemployment rate was unchanged at 10.8 percent in nine community nations, excluding Greece, Spain and Portugal.

title: COATED SALES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Advertising; Over All, '88 Forecasts Are Bullish
description: AMONG the upper echelons of Madison Avenue there is more optimism about the immediate future than you're likely to find among the mighty of Wall Street.

title: JAPAN MAY YIELD ON PUBLIC WORKS
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita of Japan will tell President Reagan this week that he is ready for negotiations to open some public works projects to foreign construction companies, Japanese officials said today.

title: Dublin Backs Disputed Road
description: The City Council has agreed to build a four-lane highway that will pass within yards of the Irish capital's Anglican St. Patrick's Cathedral, despite furious protests from environmentalists. The council voted on Monday to go ahead with a $3 million highway through the Liberties, the city's most ancient part. Dublin is celebrating its 1,000th birthday and the city authorities are using the occasion to begin several improvement plans like new pedestrian precincts, fountains and sculptures.

title: G.O.P. Battling Over Giuliani's Future
description: The selection of a new Federal prosecutor in Manhattan has touched off a major behind-the-scenes confrontation between Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, according to Republicans close to both men.

title: Beyond New Jersey's Boom
description: With an unemployment rate down to 3.6 percent and jobs increasing by 100,000 a year, New Jersey appears on an economic upswing. But Governor Kean, in his State of the State Message yesterday, wisely spent less time crowing about the boom than assessing how to prolong it. He's concerned with those it leaves behind, particularly the homeless.

title: Estimate Board May Face Limit In Making Deals
description: Mayor Koch called yesterday for a curb on the deal-making powers of the Board of Estimate, of which he is a member, by limiting the board to a simple yes or no vote on land-use issues before it.

title: Report Criticizes 2 Relatives In Child's Fall in Texas Well
description: Jessica McClure fell into an abandoned well as a result of inadequate supervision by her mother and an aunt, a state official says in a letter.

title: Martin Griffin Jr., Yale Dean and Historian
