description: Martin I. J. Griffin Jr., a historian and, for the last dozen years, dean of undergraduate studies at Yale University, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his campus residence in Saybrook College. He was 54 years old.

title: Harvard Leads Tight Race
description: Colgate and Harvard each won twice on their home rinks; Maine captured two games in Colorado, and Plattsburgh State upset Providence.

title: Israel Moves to Impose Curfew on Palestinians
description: The Israeli Army, stunned by more than a month of protests in the occupied territories, is sealing off refugee districts and ordering Palestinians to stay in their houses, sometimes for days at a time.

title: FIRST AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,091,000 from the call of debentures for both the quarter and year, and the quarter also includes a pre-tax charge of $10 million from a special provision for loan losses.

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 12
description: b-Net loss and after a $1.3 million writedown of surplus inventory and a charge of $700,000 for plant consolidation.

title: Ashton-Tate Seen In Microsoft Pact
description: The Ashton-Tate Company, a leading producer of software for personal computers, is expected to announce a major agreement with the Microsoft Corporation, industry officials said. The terms of the agreement were not available. Ashton-Tate, based in Torrance, Calif., and Microsoft, of Redmond, Wash., declined to comment.

title: Apply U.S. Pressure To Delay Haiti's Vote
description: It is not too late to help Haiti. Washington should use what influence it still has there to persuade Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy's ruling junta to postpone the presidential elections scheduled for Sunday. By gaining more time, the Reagan Administration could help assure that all candidates could take part in a fair election.

title: World Military Spending Up By $50 Billion, Study Finds
description: The nations of the world spent about $930 billion on their military forces last year, an increase of $50 billion over 1986, and the United States ranked first in such spending, a military and social researcher reported nan annual study made public this week.

title: MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $14,000. c-Net loss

title: Price's Extra Effort Paces Cavaliers
description: Mark Price scored 9 of his career-high 29 points in the final four minutes tonight to help the Cleveland Cavaliers defeat the Knicks, 119-111.

title: 3 N.B.A. Stars In Dunk Contest
description: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls will defend his title in the slam-dunk competition during the National Basketball Association All-Star weekend against two former winners, Dominique Wilkins and Spud Webb of the Atlanta Hawks.

title: New Job for Williams
description: The Chicago Cubs announced yesterday that Billy Williams, a former star outfielder for the team, would join the front office as a special player consultant for the 1988 season. Williams, 49 years old and a member of the Hall of Fame, will be primarily involved with scouting and evaluating players in the major and minor league. He will report directly to General Manager Jim Frey.

title: BEEBA'S CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes the effect of the company's $580,000 loss realized on the sale of marketable securities as a result of the Oct. 19 stock market crash. c-Net income

title: Commuter Train Kills a Man
description: A 79-year-old man was struck and killed by a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train early today, the police said. The victim, Eleuterio Giacovelli of Harrison, was hit by the New York-bound train at about 6:30 A.M. just south of the Harrison station, the police said.The train involved was the 6 A.M. from Stamford, due in Grand Central Terminal at 7 A.M. The man was removed from under the train by Harrison emergency workers and was taken to United Hospital in Port Chester, where he died at 8:39 A.M. There was no word on why the man was on the tracks. Mr. Giacovelli lived about a quarter-mile from the scene of the accident.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-After a charge of $13.6 million from costs associated with the closing of certain facilities, termination of a financing agreement, and a change in third party administrative service used for the company's private label credit card. c-Net income

title: SUNTRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest and prior-year periods have been restated to comply with the Financial Accounting Standards Board statement concerning accrual of fees and costs associated with loans and leases; the company said the restatement reduced per share earnings by two cents in 1987 and three cents in 1986.

title: Supreme Court Rules State Judges May Be Sued for Discrimination
description: The Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 today that state court judges may be sued on allegations of discrimination or other illegality in the demotion or dismissal of court employees.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates were mixed at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.8845 percent, down from 6.908 percent last week. Another $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 7.073 percent, up from 7.0184 percent.

title: Testing 5-Year-Olds: Helpful or Hard on the Ego?
description: In Minneapolis, children can flunk kindergarten.

title: The Pop Life
description: Versatile Swayze

title: Governor Offers Vermont a Plan on Controlled Growth
description: In a state where growth has been one of the most divisive issues, Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin today outlined a set of sweeping proposals that could shape Vermont for years to come.

title: Icahn Objecting to Part Of Texaco-Pennzoil Plan
description: Carl C. Icahn, the financier who holds a 12.3 percent stake in Texaco Inc., filed a motion in Federal Bankruptcy Court yesterday to overturn an accord between Texaco and the Pennzoil Company in which they promise to support Texaco's $5.5 billion reorganization plan.

title: Dorsett to Be Traded
description: Coach Tom Landry ruled out getting a first-round draft pick for Tony Dorsett but said yesterday he hopes the Dallas Cowboys can get a solid, journeyman player when they put their 33-year-old running back on the trading block soon. Landry told Dorsett on Monday he will try to work out a trade for the 11-year veteran who lost his starting tailback job to Herschel Walker this season. Landry said Dorsett's age ''will be a very critical thing. It eliminates so many teams because they are rebuilding. However, there are some teams that just missed the playoffs that might need help. Tony could go a couple of years. He is in remarkable shape.'' Dorsett has a two-year contract for $500,000 a year and a $2.4 million annuity. Club President Tex Schramm said any club getting Dorsett would have to pick up the base salary and fund the annuity.

title: Brazil Pays Creditor Banks
description: Brazil's creditor banks said yesterday that they had received a $360 million payment of overdue 1987 interest. With another interest payment on Dec. 31, the latest remittance brings to $1.46 billion the amount of 1987 interest that Brazil has paid so far.

title: SOUTHINGTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted to stock ownership in July 1986.

title: Air Force Pact Set Special to The New York Times
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation said that it had received a five-year, $278 million contract to help conduct flight tests at two Air Force ranges, includ-ing Edwards Air Force Base in the Mojave Desert in California.

title: Gallup Poll Sees Rise in Support for Kemp in New Hampshire
description: A poll taken by the Gallup Organization in New Hampshire shows growing support for Representative Jack F. Kemp's bid for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: TV STATION FACES PENALTY IN F.C.C. INDECENCY CASE
description: The Federal Communications Commission moved today to penalize a television station in Kansas City, Mo., saying it appeared to have violated rules against broadcasting indecent programming at a time when children were likely to be in the viewing audience.

title: Pan Am Board's Deal With Unions Hits Snag
description: The deal between the board of the Pan Am Corporation and its airline's unions, which would lead to the ouster of the company's top two officers, ran into major snags yesterday.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: ONE of the first terms of art you learn in the newspaper business is that there is something called the silly season, which used to occur around August. That was the time of the year when news had ground to a dead halt, when the Mayor was at the beach, the kids were out of school and public relations people called up promoting things like the Madonna look-alike contest. After Labor Day the pace was expected to quicken again: legislation, Supreme Court decisions, heating complaints and the press of daily business.

title: Reagan Battle to Reshape Courts Is in New Arena
description: Message to anyone who might think there are no more battles left to fight over the Reagan Administration's judicial nominees: stay tuned.

title: Study Finds Antibodies for AIDS In 1 in 61 Babies in New York City
description: One of every 61 babies born in New York City last month carried antibodies to the AIDS virus, indicating that their mothers were infected and that many of the babies were carriers of the deadly virus.

title: REISTERSTOWN FEDERAL SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings were unavailable; the company went public in February 1987.

title: MAYFAIR SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1987.

title: N.H.L. All-Stars
description: Mario Lemieux, a center, and Paul Coffey, a defenseman for the Pittsburgh Penguins, were chosen yesterday as starters on the Wales Conference All-Star Team. The 39th National Hockey League All-Star Game will be played Feb. 9 in St. Louis. Lemieux, with 315,699 votes, was the leading vote-getter in the conference and outdistanced his nearest rival, Peter Stastny of the Quebec Nordiques, by nearly 200,000 votes. Coffey will join Ray Bourque of the Boston Bruins on defense. Bourque led the balloting among defensemen with 275,806 votes. Other starters selected by the fans were Michel Goulet of Quebec at left wing, Kevin Dineen of the Hartford Whalers at right wing and Ron Hextall of the Philadelphia Flyers in goal.

title: Pluto Reported to Share Atmosphere With Moon
description: Observations of Pluto and its moon Charon, which can now be seen eclipsing each other every few days, are providing astronomers evidence that the two may be the oddest couple in the solar system: a double planet apparently enveloped in a single atmosphere.

title: Portfolio Insurers Reject Blame
description: Facing renewed criticism that they were to blame for the October market collapse, money managers offering portfolio insurance are instead pointing the finger at other market players.

title: Insurance Companies Also Need Some Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Gladys Vaughan, 64, A Theatrical Director
description: Gladys Vaughan, the first woman to direct a New York Shakespeare Festival production, died Dec. 30 in her home in Manhattan. She was 64 years old.

title: I.B.M. to Add Sales Agents
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, seeking to revitalize sluggish sales of mid-sized computers, said today that it would recruit more independent companies to sell those machines. The program is aimed at reaching the 4.5 million businesses that have fewer than 5,000 employees. Even I.B.M.'s direct sales force of 28,000 cannot penetrate all those accounts.

title: A Day of Pledges, Praise and Skepticism
description: The start of a new legislative session is the day that flowers bloom in plastic pots around the Capitol and Democrats and Republicans acquire a clear-eyed view of what lies ahead for the state. The Governor delivers his

title: New Sprint Service
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company is offering digital, private-line service for large business customers. Private lines are used for intracompany communications where high volumes of voice traffic or data are transmitted between sites. U S Sprint, the third-largest long-distance telephone company, said that the new service, to be called Clearline 1-dot-5, was intended for such large telecommunication users as stockbrokers, airline reservation centers and hotel chains. The company, based in Kansas City, Mo., said the new service was priced about 44 percent lower than those offered by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the MCI Communications Corporation.

title: BUSH RETREATING FROM DOLE BATTLE
description: Vice President Bush retreated today from the recent verbal barbs at Senator Bob Dole, saying the sharp public sparring had been a ''mistake.''

title: INSIDE
description: Stargell Makes Hall of Fame

title: Moore to Seek Fourth Term
description: Gov. Arch Moore, the silver-haired patriarch of West Virginia's Republican Party, has announced that he will seek a fourth four-year term. The announcement Monday by the 74-year-old Governor ended months of speculation that he would run for the United States Senate.Mr. Moore won his first of two consecutive terms in 1968, then stepped down. He lost a comeback bid in 1980 to then-Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th, then won again in 1984.

title: F.B.I. Study Hints Some Lied To Hide Ginsburg Drug Use
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation will forward information to the Justice Department indicating that associates of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg lied to investigators when they denied knowledge of the judge's past marijuana use, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Grand Union Plan
description: The Grand Union Company, a unit of Generale Occidentale of Paris, said that a management group, led by its chairman, Floyd Hall, had organized a leveraged buyout for all the assets of the supermarket company, based in Elmwood Park, N.J. Terms were not disclosed. The transaction is scheduled to close March 1. Grand Union, founded in 1872, operates 360 food stores under the Grand Union and Big Star names in 11 Eastern states.

title: Plain Old Vanilla Isn't All That Plain Anymore
description: DINNER included salad with vanilla vinaigrette, vanilla-glazed beef kebabs and vanilla cream seltzer. For professional reasons, the diners dutifully consumed eight vanilla custards, or at least took a thoughtful taste; each was made with a different vanilla extract or bean. Organizers of this unusual vanilla dinner, a gathering of the San Francisco Professional Food Society, had hoped to decide which vanilla was best. By evening's end they had a consensus of sorts: everything was delicious, even the kebabs.

title: The Coatroom Question: How Big a Tip?
description: THE only time most of us give a second thought to coat checking is when the coat checker can't find our coats. And that is part of the reason many people don't leave tips and others tip far too little, according to some coat checkers and their employers.

title: John Williams, Ex-Senator, Dies; Represented Delaware for 4 Terms
description: John J. Williams, a Republican Senator from Delaware for 24 years, died of heart and respiratory failure Monday night in a hospital in Lewes, Del. He was 83 years old and had been in poor health for some time.

title: What Texans Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Robins Gets New Offer From American Home
description: With the support of a committee representing shareholders in the A. H. Robins Company's bankruptcy proceedings, the American Home Products Corporation yesterday sweetened its takeover bid for the Richmond-based drug company.

title: Trustee Plan At Sharon Steel
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has ordered that a trustee be appointed to run the Sharon Steel Corporation. Such a move is likely to reduce control of the nation's 12th-largest steel maker by its chairman, Victor Posner, the Miami financier.

title: Energy Contracts Decline In Rumor-Driven Session
description: Energy futures prices closed moderately lower yesterday after being whipsawed by rumors throughout the trading session.

title: Home Loan Banks
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks offered one-year and three-year bonds totaling $1.8 billion through various securities dealers yesterday. For $690 million of bonds due on Jan. 25, 1989, the yield is 7.40 percent, while a $1.12 billion issue due on Jan. 25, 1991, yields 8.30 percent. Both issues were offered at a price of 100.

title: Grass-Roots Reform In Miami Experiment
description: Jim Griffin's sixth-grade classroom at the North Miami Elementary School is home to 36 children, a boa constrictor named Clyde, a cockateel named Keiko, Columbus the turtle, salamanders and a colony of gerbels whose population depends on when you last counted. Along the back wall is a ''mini-lab'' where students peer into a microscope to examine amoebas or use a computer to calculate wind velocities.

title: History Has Become Retrospective Sociology
description: To the Editor:

title: Xerox Credit
description: The Xerox Credit Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.93 to yield 8.65 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P., the three-year notes yield about 67-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The notes are not callable for two years.

title: Kicking About Discrimination
description: Managers of the Radio City Rockettes may pat themselves on the back for finally hiring a black dancer to perform with their world famous New York City chorus line. Others wonder what took them so long.

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-Includes a loss of $229,000 and net of $1,486,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations; and the quarter also includes an extraordinary charge of $171,000 for reversal of an income tax credit. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,308,000 for the quarter and $4,266,000 for the year. Results for fiscal 1987 include Action Drug Co. acquired on Aug. 2, 1986 by Technodyne Inc., which is controlled by Electro Audio Dynamics.

title: North Korea Threat May Be on Wane
description: The United States' two members of the International Olympic Committee and a senior State Department official said yesterday that the presence of many allies of North Korea, including the Soviet Union, would serve as a deterrent to the possibility of disruptive actions by North Korea during the Seoul Olympic Games.

title: Gerry Letourneau, Executive, 52
description: Gerry Letourneau, president of Airstream Inc., a leading manufacturer of motor homes, died in a snowmobile accident Saturday. He was 52 years old.

title: White Columbia Student Ia Ruled Bias Victim
description: A jury in Federal District Court in Manhattan found yesterday that Columbia University had discriminated against a white student by disciplining him after a racial brawl last spring, and awarded the student a nominal $1 in damages.

title: Waiting for Christmas
description: Perhaps it had something to do with the uncertainty of United States funding for the anti-Sandinista rebels known as contras: Christmas cards sent to Washington from Miami by the contras' political umbrella group, the Nicaraguan Resistence, were postmarked Jan. 8.

title: Mrs. Dole to Seek More Meaningful Role in Race
description: It was shortly before 8 o'clock this morning, and Elizabeth Hanford Dole was speaking to a Rotary breakfast in a rising voice while her husband sat silently behind her.

title: One Agency Clears Scientist Of Breaking Genetics Rules
description: The National Institutes of Health concluded today that a scientist at Montana State University did not violate the agency's guidelines for research when he injected genetically modified bacteria into 14 young elm trees last spring.

title: Economic Scene; Learning Caution The Hard Way
description: ALTHOUGH the London stock market remains ''jittery and skittish,'' as one highly placed Government economist put it yesterday, there is a growing belief on London's Wall Street that the danger of another market crash is receding. That belief was strengthened by the ability of equity markets here and around the world to withstand the shock of last Friday's plunge in the New York stock market, when the Dow industrials fell 140 points.

title: Return New York City Transit Police to the Transit Authority
description: To the Editor:

title: 122 New Yorkers Are Chosen In a Science Talent Search
description: In an improved performance over last year, students at New York City public high schools have won more than one-third of the semifinal places in the national Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

title: 2 Fire Doors Were Wedged Open In Building Where Smoke Killed 4
description: The smoke that killed four residents of an apartment building on the East Side of Manhattan Monday night spread through the structure because two lobby-level fire doors had been wedged open in violation of the fire code, the authorities said yesterday.

title: EDUCATION: Lessons
description: In auditoriums and conference rooms across the country, local school boards are preparing their budgets. Yet it is unlikely that the process, which involves billions of dollars, is monitored by more than a handful of citizens. And this lack of interest is perplexing.

title: EATING WELL
description: IN the New York Times survey of American eating habits published last week, 25 percent of the respondents said they watched their cholesterol intake at every meal. But when these people were asked what they had eaten the day before, they described meals high in fat and cholesterol. Like so many of us, the respondents probably were not really sure what to look for when watching the cholesterol in their meals. Nor did they seem to understand that to reduce the cholesterol level in the blood, it is essential to reduce not only dietary cholesterol but also fat, especially saturated fat.

title: UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $741,000, or 8 cents a share, from the sale of the wiper business, and also includes the results of the Texas Industrial Services unit, acquired in December 1986.

title: 6-Month-Old Drowns In Bathtub in Brooklyn
description: A 6-month-old Brooklyn girl drowned in the bathtub of her parent's Cobble Hill apartment last night while being bathed by a baby sitter, the police said.

title: Feeding the Soul: A Lunch With a Religious Fervor
description: Every Wednesday at lunch time - the dead center of the workweek - hundreds of office workers in lower Manhattan file into Mariners' Temple Baptist Church for a rollicking service aimed at lifting people's spirits at a time of the week when those spirits are most likely to be flagging.

title: Yankees Still Hope To Bolster Pitching
description: The Yankees' search for pitching help remains at a standstill, just five weeks before pitchers and catchers have to report for spring training. Lou Piniella, the team's general manager, said yesterday that he was conducting talks with several teams, but that there was little chance a deal would be made soon.

title: Florence Knapp, Former Teacher, 114
description: Florence Knapp, a retired teacher who was recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records as the world's oldest person, died Monday at the Dock Terrace nursing home here. She was 114 years old.

title: Dance: Ukrainian State Company
description: IF one had to name the two great pioneering folk dance ensembles from the Soviet Union that became the model for all other professional folk companies in the world, they would have to be the companies founded separately by two choreographers, Igor Moiseyev and Pavel Virsky.

title: American's Filing
description: American Airlines has filed a com-plaint with the Department of Trans-portation seeking sanction against British Airways P.L.C. for maintain-ing ''a virtual monopoly'' on its flight schedule system in Great Britian. The complaints has asked the Govern-ment to ''eliminate several unfair air-line computerized reservation sys-tem practices of British Airways.'' Since 1984, British Airways has bene-fited from fliht displays in United States terminals that do not favor one airline over another, American said.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT is amusing to think that when French chefs were passing out names for dishes in the days of Escoffier, they often named the simplest of dishes ''a l'anglaise,'' meaning in the English style. The term was used for foods that were simply boiled in water or stock, like mutton or chicken or potatoes. It was also applied to foods that were breaded and cooked in a little oil until golden brown.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $10,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,534,000 for the year, both on sales of securities; the year also includes an extraordinary charge of $3,165,000 from the redemption of debentures. c-Net loss and includes a gain of $330,000 and $3,148,000 on sales of securities for the quarter and year, respectively. Volt said that in connection with a change in the methods of operations in Europe, pre-tax foreign currency translation losses of $1,070,000 were charged to operations in the fiscal 1987 full year. The company also said that other income in the latest fiscal year included a pre-tax profit of $2,734,000 on the settlement of an insurance claim arising from a fire loss in a foreign branch in the fiscal 1987 first quarter. In fiscal 1986, foreign currency translation losses were recorded as a direct charge to stockholder equity. The company said the fiscal 1986 results include pre-tax provisions for losses on contracts and writedowns of inventory and other assets of $13,400,000 for the full year and $11 million for the fourth quarter. Also included in the fiscal 1986 fourth quarter and year is a $4.5 million foreign currency translation pre- tax loss that has been reclassified from a direct charge to stockholder equity and an $8.7 million tax benefit, both of which arose from the termination of subsidiary company arrangements in Europe in connection with the establishment of independent distributorships and branch operations there. The tax benefit resulted from losses that were recognized through the third quarter of fiscal 1986 and prior years for financial reporting purposes, but could not be accorded U.S. tax benefit at that time.

title: Stargell to Cooperstown In First Year of Eligibility
description: Willie Stargell, the longtime Pittsburgh Pirate slugger who struck a formidable pose at the plate and in the clubhouse, gained admission to the Baseball Hall of Fame last night in his first year of eligibility.

title: 'SWORD OF ISLAM,' ON 13
description: ''SWORD OF ISLAM'' explores the world of Moslem fundamentalists. The view is not always attractive. Many of the fundamentalists seem to be in love with death. Political fanatacism and sexual repression join. The 90-minute documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, is compelling.

title: Texas G.O.P. Ballot Will List All 6 Presidential Candidates
description: Texas Republican officials say the names of all six of their party's Presidential contenders will remain on the March 8 primary ballot despite questions about the validity of some signatures on petitions submitted by four of the candidates.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Includes a gain of $230,000 reflecting an accounting adjustment for income taxes.

title: Advertising; Franchising World Now Available to Public
description: Franchising World, the year-old publication of the Washington-based International Franchise Association, is making itself available to the public on a limited number of newsstands and bookstores beginning with its January-February issue.

title: G.M. Weighing Venezuela Sale
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was negotiating the possible sale of a stake in its Venezuelian operations to the Mendoza Group, a local conglomerate.

title: Iowa Caucuses: Clear as Mud
description: One of the largest concentrations of reporters ever will descend on Iowa Feb. 8 to record the purported success or failure of a baker's dozen of Presidential candidates. History suggests that relatively narrow margins at the state's Republican and Democratic caucuses could decide which candidates are launched, which are humbled and which are eliminated from the Presidential contest.

title: Canadian Jet Lands After Bomb Warning
description: A Canadian jumbo jet bound from Amsterdam to Vancouver with 263 people aboard landed safely here today after a note was found in a washroom saying explosives were on the plane, the police reported, No explosives were found, the police and Federal officials said.

title: PREMIER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
The Open-Pit Barbecue: A Texas Tradition in Good Hands
description: THE owner is a 74-year-old Hawaiian-born woman of Japanese descent, the manager is a classically trained British chef, the cooks are originally from Mexico and the waitress is a hillbilly from southern Missouri. They keep the secret of one of Texas' dearest and most fragile treasures: the traditional open-pit barbecue.

title: Freedom of the Press in Frontier Days
description: To the Editor:

title: DIGITAL MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $403,000 for the quarter and $955,000 for the 9 months.

title: CAREERCOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
John H. Johnson Dies; Executive in Baseball
description: John H. Johnson, who presided over the nation's 176 minor-league teams as president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, died of chest cancer yesterday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 66 years old.

title: GENERAL COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Reagan Said to Ignore Data on Downing of Jet
description: Three days before President Reagan declared that there was ''no way'' a Soviet pilot could have shot down a Korean Air Lines jet in 1983 by mistake, American intelligence had concluded that a mistake was the likely explanation, according to declassified documents released today.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring income of $5.4 million from the sale of Instant Teller, City National's automated teller machine business; its payroll processing service and two leveraged leases. The company said earnings per share include non-recurring gains of 27 cents for the latest year and 10 cents for the year-earlier period. The per share earnings have been restated to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend payable Jan. 15, 1988.

title: Judge Rules for Bush's Side In Michigan G.O.P. Dispute
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed a constitutional challenge to seven state laws, giving supporters of Vice President Bush a new legal victory over a coalition that controls the Michigan Republican Party.

title: Citicorp Unit Cuts 85 Jobs in London
description: Citicorp Investment Bank Ltd. said it would cut 85 jobs in its London securities division, or just under 4 percent of its staff. The investment bank has 2,200 employees. Citicorp, based in New York, has a total work force of 4,500 in Britain.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart with the Eating Well column in The Living Section last Wednesday referred incorrectly to Nabisco Spoon Size Shredded Wheat.

title: Getting Good Value For Research Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: WARNER COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Toyota's Exports
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation expects its exports will be down for the third con-secutive year, its president, Shoichiro Toyoda, said. A higher Japanese yen and changes in the American tax sys-tem can be blamed for sluggish ex-ports, he said. Toyota's exports num-bered 1.77 million cars in 1987, down 6 percent from 1.88 million in 1986. Its exports are expected to drop to 1.75 million cars this year, he said.

title: Washington Talk: Arms Control and the Bureaucracy; Treaty Spurs Turf Struggles in U.S.
description: Officials of the Reagan Administration have hailed the new accord on eliminating two classes of nuclear missiles as a precedent-setting agreement that provides for extensive on-site inspection to verify that its provisions are being observed.

title: Big Navy Contract
description: The Navy awarded a $4.38 billion contract to the General Dynamics Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to develop its new Advanced Tactical Aircraft for delivery in the 1990's. The joint program, one of the largest ever undertaken by the Navy, is expected to produce 450 attack aircraft, at an eventual cost of $45 billion, to replace the service's current A-6 attack planes. Few details have been released about the top-secret program, but the craft is expected to include radar-evading ''stealth'' features.

title: Richland Journal; Little Sentiment Here To Ban the Bomb
description: Here in the desert of southeastern Washington, in a city built virtually overnight in the rush to create the atomic bomb, the question of the year is what to do with the mushroom cloud.

title: KEY RATES
Sam Raphling Dies; Composer and Pianist
description: Sam Raphling, a composer and pianist, died Friday of heart failure. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Theater: 'The River'
description: PETER LINK'S new musical, ''The River,'' is a collage of rock, rap and pop gospel, extolling water in spiritual and metaphorical terms. In Mr. Link's lyrics water falls, tumbles, rains and rushes in streams, rivers and oceans. By the end of the show, which opened last night at the Promenade Theater, one has been inundated by images of liquidity.

title: Japan Tourism Abroad
description: The number of Japanese tourists going overseas rose by 23.3 percent, to 6.8 million, in 1987, mainly because of the strength of the yen, Japan Travel Bureau Inc., a leading Japanese travel agency, said today.

title: COURT, 5-3, WIDENS POWER OF SCHOOLS TO ACT AS CENSORS
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 3 today that public school officials have broad power to censor school newspapers, plays and other ''school-sponsored expressive activities.''

title: Murdoch to Petition F.C.C. on Property Rule
description: Rupert Murdoch, trying to keep his media properties in the face of Federal legislation that might require him to give some of them up, is to file a petition today with the Federal Communications Commission, arguing that the legislation is unconstitutional, his lawyers said yesterday.

title: Navy Chief Suggests Forces in Europe Be Cut
description: The Secretary of the Navy, James H. Webb Jr., called today for a thorough review of United States commitments to foreign nations and a re-examination of the deployment of American forces around the world, especially in Europe.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 14, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL Japan will work to reduce its interest rates, as the U.S. has wanted, Prime Minister Takeshita told President Reagan. Both countries also agreed to intensify efforts to halt the dollar's decline. The Japanese leader also made several conciliatory gestures on the trade disputes that have marred bilateral relations. [ Page A1. ] The dollar's value swung sharply, apparently influenced by central bank intervention and a variety of rumors. In New York, gold prices fell slightly. [ D20. ] West Germany's G.N.P. grew only 1.7 percent last year, compared with 2.5 percent in 1986, Bonn confirmed. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Texaco said the U.S. might seek $6.5 billion in back taxes as part of the company's bankruptcy proceedings. Tax lawyers said that would represent the largest corporate tax case ever. [ A1. ] Batus offered $4.2 billion for the Farmers Group, the nation's seventh-largest property and casualty insurer. Farmers Group said it would consider the $60-a-share proposal. [ D1. ] Apple is expected to team up with Digital Equipment to develop products that will allow the two companies' machines to connect, helping them compete with I.B.M.'s. Apple is also revamping its line of laser printers. [ D1. ] Ashton-Tate and Microsoft plan a joint software product that manages data bases on computer networks. Again, the goal is to compete more potently with I.B.M. [ D1. ] One of the nation's hottest ad agencies has lost an account billing about $10 million, as a direct result of its flippant responses to a complaint from a feminist. [ D1. ] A.T.& T. formally accused Government officials of leaking sensitive bid information to its competitors, enabling them to win telephone contracts. [ D1. ] Donald J. Trump wants a stake in Federated Stores and has asked for U.S. clearance to buy at least $15 million of shares. [ D4. ] Digital's earnings rose 22 percent in its fiscal second quarter, while Intel said that it earned $95.5 million in contrast to a loss of $16.4 million a year ago. [ D22. ] Primark's board wants to spin off its Michigan utility, which provided $1.4 billion of its $1.5 billion revenues in 1986. [ D4. ] Prime Computer sweetened its offer for Computervision, to $15 a share, or a total of $433.5 million. [ D4. ] ECONOMY U.S. oil production dropped 4.5 percent last year to the lowest level since 1977, and demand rose 1.8 percent. As a result, the U.S. had to raise its imports to 6.5 million barrels a day. [ D1. ] Rule changes to improve accounting practices were adopted by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. [ D2. ] Sales of cars and light trucks climbed 21.8 percent early this month from the year-ago period. [ D9. ] MARKETS A seesaw session in the stock market ended with the Dow Jones industrial average down 3.82 points, at 1,924.73. The Dow had been down 20 early in the day, and up 20 in mid-afternoon. [ D8. ] Bond prices rose modestly after the dollar improved and oil prices fell. Traders were unnerved when the Treasury delayed its announcement of an auction of two-year notes. [ D19. ] Comex's chairman will give up the post in March. Alan J. Brody, will remain as president and chief executive. Separately, the New York Merc's board cleared its chairman, William R. Bradt, of accusations of improper business relationships, but dismissed Kevin Conway, its vice president of compliance. [ D2. ] Yields were flat on C.D.'s and bank money market accounts in the week ended yesterday, while those of money market mutual funds slipped. [ D17. ] Copper futures prices plunged to their lowest levels in more than a month on profit taking and computerized selling. [ D20. ] Illinois is offering an innovative issue to finance education that raised more than $90 million for the state. [ D19. ] TODAY'S COLUMN Japan expects to establish a new futures market, possibly by the end of the year, that will offer trading in such financial instruments as currencies and deposits. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: The Politician Shifts In Drive for Change
description: The imperative of political accommodation has begun to reshape the policies and public posture of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, moving him increasingly toward the center of the Soviet political spectrum.

title: Koch Skips Chance to Side With Angels
description: ''Mayor'' (the musical) has come to City Hall, three years after its debut, two years after its closing, and in a version not likely to please its creator, Mayor Koch.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $96,000 and $205,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a loss of $21,109,000 from discontinued operations which contains a reserve of $13,750,000 for loss on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Includes a loss of $3,612,000 and $7,242,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. The quarter also includes a charge of $99,000 from reversal of a tax credit, and the year includes a tax credit of $350,000.

title: Excerpts From Opinions in Ruling on Censoring High School Newspaper
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion in the Supreme Court's decision today upholding censorship of a high school newspaper in Hazlewood, Mo.

title: New York's Schools Move to Curb Power Of Custodian Union
description: Amid new allegations that New York City's school custodians are guilty of waste and job abuse, officials of the Board of Education say they will try to use current contract talks to weaken the grip of the custodians' powerful union.

title: 4 Palestinians Linked to Protests Are Expelled to Lebanon by Israel
description: Israel expelled four West Bank Palestinians today, taking them by helicopter to a lonely mountain road in southern Lebanon.

title: BAHAMAS LEADER TIED TO DRUG BRIBE
description: A Government witness in the drug trial of a reputed leader in Colombian cocaine trafficking testified Tuesday that he had been told the defendant paid $88,000 a month in protection money to Bahamian Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling.

title: Critic of the Caucuses Is an Unpopular Iowan
description: There are times, Hugh Winebrenner says, when he has been made to feel like a traitor to the state of Iowa.

title: Michigan G.O.P. Is Split on Eve of Vote
description: Michigan Republicans are preparing to cast the first ballots of the 1988 Presidential campaign on Thursday, but the party's precinct caucuses could be disrupted by angry walkouts and snarled in a tangle of litigation.

title: Carefree Landscape
description: WHEN the landscaping is finished George Walter will have plenty to see, hear, sniff and harvest. Otherwise, he won't have a lot to do. No pruning, weeding, spraying, mowing or fertilizing, and very little watering.

title: Beth Campbell Short, Truman White House Aide, 79
description: Beth Campbell Short, who covered Eleanor Roosevelt for The Associated Press and held a top White House job in Harry S. Truman's Presidency, died of cancer Monday. She was 79 years old.

title:
THE SPEECH: Pat Robertson;
A Strong Warning That Moral Decay Is Basic Trouble Facing the Nation
description: LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: School Basks In Spotlight Of Contest
description: For Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Bayside, Queens, the celebrations yesterday had a familiar ring: 11 students were named as semifinalists in the prestigious Westinghouse science awards.

title: Music: Woodwind Quintet
description: THE opening number on the New York Woodwind Quintet's program Tuesday at Merkin Concert Hall predicted an evening of tense music-making. Variety and richness emerged instead; perhaps the Mozart quintet (K. 452) simply found the guest pianist, Gilbert Kalish, out of his element. He lacked the singing legato tone it wants, and there was some rhythmic unevenness in the ensemble.

title: Bush Recalls No Strong Dissent on Arms to Iran
description: Vice President Bush said tonight that he had not heard strong objections voiced in meetings on the shipment of arms to Iran, even though he attended at least one session in early 1986 where such concerns might have been aired.

title: TV Review; Creator of 'Detective' Interviewed
description: THE man is just about immobilized in a London hospital ward, his skin covered with psoriasis sores, his joints crippled by arthritis. He feverishly drifts between present and past, jumbling the facts of his life with the cheap fiction of his detective novels. He and the other characters periodically break into song, bizarrely miming the words from old 1940's recordings featuring everybody from Bing Crosby to Dick Haynes.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Growing Older: A Call for Self-Determination for Women
description: Although women today are living longer and more vigorously than their mothers did, growing older in America can still be a series of blows to self-esteem.

title: Jacuzzi Whirlpool Creator To Oversee Hanson Unit
description: Roy Jacuzzi, who developed the self-contained whirlpool bath, was named the president and chief executive yesterday of Jacuzzi Inc. The company was among 100 businesses acquired on Dec. 31 by Hanson P.L.C. in its $1.7 billion buyout of Kidde Inc.

title: School Officials Acclaim Decision as Appropriate Strengthening of Authority
description: Administrators of public high schools greeted yesterday's Supreme Court decision allowing them to censor student newspapers as an appropriate strengthening of their authority.

title: Comex Chief Will Give Up Chairman Post
description: Alan J. Brody, the chairman of the Commodity Exchange, the nation's largest precious metals futures exchange, will give up the post on March 16, the Comex announced last night.

title: New Compound Is Hailed as Boon to Ozone Shield
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and a small company, Petroferm Inc., announced today that they had developed a compound that would permit reduced use of one of the most widely used chemicals blamed for depleting the earth's ozone shield.

title: Oilers and Interlopers
description: The National Hockey League calls it an All-Star team, but the Campbell Conference starters who will face a group of Wales Conference stars in St. Louis on Feb. 9 could just as well be called the Edmonton Oilers and a couple of friends. Four of the six Campbell starters selected in balloting by fans are Oiler regulars. They are Grant Fuhr, goaltender; Wayne Gretzky, center; Jari Kurri, right wing, and Kevin Lowe, defenseman. The two interlopers are Doug Wilson, a St. Louis Blues defensemen, and Luc Robitaille, a right wing for the Los Angeles Kings. Actually, the Campbell starting lineup could end up with as many as five Edmonton players. That's because Wilson, who had shoulder surgery last week, will miss the All-Star game. His replacement as a starter will be among the balance of the squad to be selected next week by the Campbell coach, Glen Sather, who also coaches the Oilers.

title: Vindication, Fearfulness On Decision
description: Robert E. Reynolds, the principal at Hazelwood East High School, the suburban St. Louis school where the student censorship case began, said today that he felt great about the Supreme Court ruling because it proved his judgment correct.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Simon Mellor, corporate development director at Saatchi & Saatchi, has been named to the additional post of deputy chief executive of the communications group.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago fourth quarter and full year nets included pre-tax gains of $41 million on the sale of the company's New York City headquarters building and $32 million on an offering of class A depositary units of IP Timberlands Ltd., as well as a pre-tax charge of $31 million covering principally a reserve for relocation of staff to new quarters and in part shutdown expenses mainly associated with plant closings.

title: To What End?
description: In 20 years of occupation there have been waves of Palestinian protest, but none nearly so intense or extended. Gaza has been in turmoil for more than a month now. The shops in the West Bank and East Jerusalem have been closed for days. And the protest goes on despite successive Israeli measures: deportations, arrests, detentions, at least 35 Palestinians killed.

title: Reagan to Speak on Jan. 25
description: President Reagan will deliver his State of the Union Message before a joint session of Congress on Jan. 25, the White House announced today. The nationally broadcast address will begin at 9 P.M., Eastern standard time.

title: Objects Detected in Universe May Be the Most Distant Ever Sighted
description: Astronomers, applying new technologies for looking deeper into time and space, have detected what they believe may be the oldest and most distant objects ever seen in the universe.

title: Steel Shelves Go Home
description: HEAVY-DUTY industrial steel shelving is selling well at the New York Store Fixture Company. William Cherkin, the store's president, said the shelves adapt easily to home use.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about increases in steel prices incorrectly described the types of steel affected.

title: This Heroin Fix Ought to Be the Law
description: Heroin, a scourge of America's inner cities, is also an extremely effective painkiller that many physicians believe could help desperately ill cancer patients. That's why Senator Daniel Inouye and Representative Henry Waxman are leading an uphill fight to allow treatment of terminal cancer victims with the drug.

title: To Freshmen, a Big Goal Is Wealth
description: A record proportion of more than three-quarters of college freshmen surveyed around the country feel that being financially well off is an ''essential'' or ''very important'' goal. At the same time, the lowest proportion of freshmen in 20 years, only 39 percent, put great emphasis on developing a meaningful philosophy of life.

title: No More Temporary Solutions to Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: August T. Baden, Toothpick Producer, 93
description: August T. Baden, a drugstore owner who founded cinnamon-flavored Baden's Hot Toothpicks almost 40 years ago, died Sunday. He was 93 years old.

title: Samuel LeFrak: A Donald Trump For Middle Class
description: There is something very different about the view of lower Manhattan from New Jersey, at least from Samuel J. LeFrak's vantage point.

title: 2 Hard-to-Quit Habits Sustain Trade Deficit
description: Two deeply ingrained practices of American business are likely to prevent the nation's trade deficit from declining sharply in the 1980's and perhaps beyond, according to a number of economists and executives.

title: Currents; The Cans and Caps of Furniture Art
description: CREATING furniture and decorative objects from recycled materials has been an American tradition since the 1870's, when itinerant artists used discarded cigar, fruit and vegetable boxes to make things like lamps, picture frames and tables. These carved pieces, known as tramp art, are widely sought today, and are often found at country fairs and flea markets.

title: New Families Are Barred From Hotel
description: New York City officials have been barred from placing new people in a Chelsea welfare hotel. State officials said the hotel failed to meet minimum living conditions.

title: WESTPOINT PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $5,065,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,339,000.

title: Refund Is Sought for Owners Of 3-Wheel Off-Road Vehicles
description: A public interest law firm filed a lawsuit in Federal court here today seeking refunds for owners of three-wheel all-terrain vehicles.

title: Recalling the Blizzard of 1888
description: New Yorkers who are up to a slushy slog to Central Park West and 77th Street may sneer at the current messiness when they encounter an exhibition on the legendary Blizzard of '88 - 1888, that is.

title: Donors to Neediest Honor Fatally Beaten Girl
description: The tragic story of Elizabeth Steinberg, the 6-year old child who died of a fatal beating in Manhattan last November, has been remembered by a number of contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases.

title: In Salvador, They Are Still Fleeing the Violence; A Nicaragua Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loan-loss provision of $3.3 million for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a gain of $900,000 from the settlement of a tax issue for both the quarter and year.

title: Battle Looming Over a Nominee For U.S. Court
description: In what may be another bitter fight over the Reagan Administration's judicial appointments, civil rights groups say they will vigorously oppose the nomination of a prominent San Francisco lawyer to the Federal District Court there.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.T. & E. Corp., San Francisco, said Dr. Ronald F. Foerster had joined the company as president of its A.T. & E. Laboratories Inc. subsidiary.

title: Reagan Checkup on Friday
description: President Reagan said he felt ''pretty good'' today after being up much of the night with an upset stomach and nausea. In what was called a coincidence, he will enter the hospital Friday for a six-month checkup to guard against a recurrence of colon cancer.

title: Primark Plans Spinoff Of Its Michigan Utility
description: The Primark Corporation of McLean, Va., said today that its board had recommended that its Michigan utility, which provided $1.4 billion of its $1.5 billion revenues in 1986, be spun off to shareholders.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $257,000 for the quarter and $344,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: More Music for the Money
description: Long-playing recordings are getting longer.

title: Cornelius P. Mulder, Pretoria Aide Ousted in '78 Scandal, Dies at 62
description: Cornelius P. Mulder, who was forced to resign as South Africa's Information Minister in 1978 amid revelations about his role in a scheme to buy influence in the United States and other Western countries, died Tuesday at the age of 62, his family announced. He had been taken to hospital in Johannesburg on Sunday, and the cause of death was given as kidney and liver failure.

title: ZIEGLER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 143, Pistons 105: Kevin McHale, Larry Bird and Danny Ainge keyed a 43-point third period last night as Boston broke open a seesaw game and rolled to victory over Detroit. It was the Celtics' 20th consecutive home-court victory over the Pistons. (AP) Mavericks 110, Pacers 108: Mark Aguirre scored 35 points and Roy Tarpley grabbed a club-record 23 rebounds as the Mavericks defeated Indiana at Dallas and gave Coach John MacLeod his 600th N.B.A victory. Tarpley's rebound total broke the team record of 22 reached twice by James Donaldson. (AP) Hawks 120, Spurs 110: Dominique Wilkins scored a season-high 48 points to pace the Atlanta Hawks over the Spurs at San Antonio. Wilkins was perfect from the free throw line, 18 for 18. Walter Berry led the Spurs with 28 points. (AP) N.H.L. Canadiens 5, Bruins 4: Claude Lemieux and Mats Naslund each had a goal and two assists at Montreal last night as the Canadiens took the Adams Division lead from Boston. The Canadiens never trailed after a defenseman, Mike Lalor, made the score 2-1 with 1:04 left in the first period. (AP) Maple Leafs 3, North Stars 3: Mark Osborne had a goal and two assists and Jeff Reese made 30 saves in his second game for Toronto. All of Osborne's points came in the second period at Minneapolis. (AP) Oilers 5, Flames 3: The Oilers scored three power-play goals, including the winner by Steve Smith, to take over first place in the Smythe Division. The victory, at Edmonton, gave the Oilers a 3-1-1 record against Calgary and moved them past the Flames with 59 points. The Flames led, 3-0, after only four minutes. But the Oilers got a power-play goal late in the period and then scored three in the second. (AP) Skating Record for Perfect Scores: Katarina Witt of East Germany earned five perfect scores in her short program, and the Soviet world pairs champions, Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov, won the first gold medal yesterday at the European skating championships in Prague. Witt, the 1984 Olympic champion and current world champion, earned one perfect mark of 6.0 for technical merit and four for presentation in her program, which included seven required free-skating moves.

title: Advertising; Environment Specialty Is Booming
description: HAVING worked as a chemical and pharmaceutical company public relations man for the last seven years, Arthur C. (Buck) Benedict is now prepared to offer his services to other corporations facing problems with an environmentally aware public.

title: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Edberg Advances; Mandlikova Romps
description: Stefan Edberg and Hana Mandlikova, the defending champions, easily moved into the third round of the Australian Open tennis championships today.

title: Providence Upsets Georgetown, 78-74
description: Delray Brooks scored a season-high 28 points, including an important seventh 3-point field goal with 1 minute 17 seconds left, as Providence upset a Big East rival, Georgetown, 78-74, tonight.

title: Durban Journal; Apartheid's Guardians Yield Beachhead t0 Change
description: As Mayor of Durban, Henry Klotz faces problems that are in many ways a microcosm of those confronting the country.

title: Advertising; Some Changes At Diamandis
description: Roman Beyer has left Diamandis Communications and has been replaced by Winston Anthony (Tony) Johnson as vice president and publisher of Stereo Review, Car Stereo Review and Stereo Review Buyers' Guide.

title: Weekend Wood Squad Delivers
description: DURING the week they wear suits, and the heaviest thing they carry is a briefcase.

title: Dance: 2 Ballets by Jerome Robbins
description: SWEET and sour ballets by Jerome Robbins were offered by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Music: Juilliard Quartet
description: AS if to test the mettle of its audience at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, the Juilliard String Quartet programmed not two but three hefty works by Brahms from the 1870's -pieces in which the composer went out of his way to declare himself a creator of serious, large-scale music. The concert wedged the huge B flat major Quartet (Op. 67, No. 3) between the C minor and A minor quartets from Opus 51. These are moody works, full of thickly textured, stirring music but also rambling in parts and tough to swallow in a single gulp.

title: String Sinfonia Concert
description: The New York String Sinfonia is to present a concert at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street, tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. The program is to feature Grieg's ''Holberg Suite'', Marcello's Oboe Concerto in C minor, Turina's ''La Oracion del Torero'' and Tchaikovsky's Serenade for Strings in C. Daniel Kaly is to conduct and Vicki Bodner is to be oboe soloist for the Marcello concerto. Admission is $7.

title: Redskins Stick With Rogers
description: George Rogers, despite an uneven season, will start at running back for the Washington Redskins in the National Football Conference championship game Sunday against the Minnesota Vikings. Today he said he was looking forward to the game without any loss of confidence.

title: Innovative Illinois Bonds Benefit Savers for College
description: To encourage saving for college education, officials in Illinois have turned to the tax-exempt bond market, where they attracted individual investors to an innovative issue that raised more than $90 million for the state.

title: Market Place; Japan to Widen Futures Trading
description: JAPAN expects to establish a separate futures market, possibly by the end of the year, that will offer trading in such financial instruments as currencies and deposits.

title: Oil Spill Boosts Interest in Liability Bill
description: The diesel fuel spill in the Ohio River has given new impetus to legislation that would set liability for oil spills, a proposal that has languished through six previous sessions of Congress.

title: DATA TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $438,000 and $818,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest results include the performance of Compac Microelectronics Inc., which merged with Data Technology in December, on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Home Improvement
description: WALLBOARD, prefabricated panels of gypsum sheathed in heavy paper, was first marketed in the United States after World War I. But it was not until the housing boom following World War II that wallboard really began to replace lath and plaster walls.

title: GEODYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $5,108,000 from the repurchase of subordinated debt. c-Net income

title: Critic's Notebook; 'Fashion and Surrealism,' And Influences on Ballet
description: BECAUSE fashion design can be outrageous and Surrealism is a flamboyant art style, it is not surprising that Surrealist artists and trend-setting fashion designers often share a similar love of extravagance. The relationship between the fields is examined in ''Fashion and Surrealism,'' the exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology through Jan. 23.

title: Grand Union's Chief In Key Buyout Role
description: When Floyd Hall became the chairman and chief executive of the Grand Union Company in 1984, it was his first job as a supermarket executive. He had sold sewing machines and had run the B. Dalton bookstore chain and the Target discount store chain for the Dayton Hudson Company.

title: Pakistan Tied to Atom Shipping Plot
description: The State Department was reported today to have sent a memorandum to President Reagan concluding that the Pakistani Government was probably involved in a plot by a Pakistani-born businessman to smuggle material for nuclear weapons out of the United States.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes special provisions of $90 million and $197 million for the quarter and year, respectively, for loans to refinancing countries.

title: Reagan and Takeshita's Joint Statement
description: Following is the transcript of the joint statement issued today by President Reagan and Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita of Japan on economic issues:

title: Chiang Ching-kuo Dies at 77, Ending a Dynasty on Taiwan
description: President Chiang Ching-kuo of Taiwan died of a heart attack yesterday, ending a four-decade era in which Chinese who fled the mainland in 1949 were the prime leaders of the island nation.

title: Jazz: Modern Quartet
description: JOHN LEWIS opened the Modern Jazz Quartet's six-night stand at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street) with a dancing fragment of near-stride piano. The vibraphonist Milt Jackson wove a wreath of a blues melody for counterpoint, and by the time the piece ended, the group had wandered through two of Mr. Lewis's compositions, ''The Golden Striker,'' and ''Three Windows,'' tempo changes, duets, blues and fugues. It was a lesson not only in the formal possibilities available to a quartet, but also, in its easy blend of jazz and European classical elements, in the endless cultural possibilities open to Americans willing to embrace the spectrum of modern experience.

title: Copiers by Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, in a move to enter the growing color copier market, introduced two models. The company said its Coloredge copier duplicator would produce color copies from color originals at speeds of 23 copies a minute, about four times as fast as any copier on the market. The company said its Coloredge AC copier duplicator would make color copies from black and white originals at speeds of 23 to 70 copies a minute. The market for color copiers is expected to reach about $2 billion within two years.

title: American Students to Travel In Vietnam on a Study Tour
description: Fifteen young Americans from Colby College in Maine, the first group of American students to visit Vietnam on a study tour, are planning to leave for Hanoi from here on Friday.

title: Calendar: A Look At History And Crafts
description: Discovering The Upper West Side

title: US TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Arts Festival Gives Preview at U.N.
description: Still five months away from opening night, the First New York International Festival of the Arts is already a full-time behind-the-scenes production as the final scheduling details are ironed out for the monthlong presentation of the performing arts. And on Tuesday night at the United Nations, representatives of more than 50 delegations as well as several hundred artists and business leaders got a first preview of the festival, which its chairman, Martin E. Segal, characterized as an overview of the best music, theater, dance and film of the 20th century.

title: Domestic Vehicle Sales Up by 21.8% for Jan. 1-10
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks climbed 21.8 percent early this month from the sales in the comparable period a year earlier, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times on Tuesday misstated the telephone number for Broderbund, the maker of Jam Session software. Its correct number is (800) 527-6263.

title: Bridge: Sometimes the Vital Card Is Hard to See in Advance
description: A great many crucial contracts hinge on possession of some apparently trivial spot card that played no role whatever in the auction. It would be hard to guess in advance which of South's cards is vital on the diagramed deal from the North American Swiss Team Championship in the Fall Nationals in Anaheim, Calif.

title: Assault With a Tree
description: This is shaping up as a season of troubles for Rod Strickland, the high-scoring DePaul guard. Academic problems kept the 22-year-old junior out of action for the first three games of the sesason, and since then he has been held out of the starting lineup several times for missing practices and team meetings. Now Strickland has another problem. He has been charged with assaulting a campus guard with a Christmas tree. According to a police report filed Jan. 6, Strickland pushed the unidentified guard in the face and shoved a small Christmas tree at him after the guard refused to give him a dormitory passkey early on New Year's Day. Strickland has denied that any punches were thrown, but has declined further comment pending a court appearance next week on a charge of battery. Meanwhile, Strickland, who has been averaging 18.5 points a game, is expected to play against Dayton tonight, but he won't be starting. It seems that he was so upset with his 9-point, 4-turnover performance against Georgetown on Sunday that he skipped practice on Monday.

title: Laker Streak Ends at 15
description: Quintin Dailey scored the tying basket and set up the game-winner by Larry Drew in the final 41 seconds of overtime tonight as the Los Angeles Clippers snapped the Los Angeles Lakers' 15-game winning streak and also ended the Clippers' 11-game losing streak with a 110-109 victory.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about a United Nations official's attempt to visit Palestinian refugee districts in the occupied Gaza Strip misstated the circumstances of his departure from one. He was turned away from one district by Israeli troops, but decided on his own against entering a second, where violence was occurring between residents and soldiers.

title: Pan Am Plan Gains As Teamsters Shift
description: William F. Genoese, the leader of the teamsters' union at Pan American World Airways Inc., who only Tuesday had threatened to strike the carrier, notified the National Mediation Board yesterday that his union was willing to submit to arbitration. The about-face by the teamsters improved the chances that Pan Am management will be able to reach its goal of having its unions accept about $180 million in concessions to help the carrier ride out the next two months when its traffic is low and its cash flow slows considerably.

title: Katherine Fenimore Cooper, Horticulturist, 92
description: Katherine Guy Fenimore Cooper, a horticulturist and member of the boards of many charitable groups, died Friday at her home in Cooperstown, N.Y. She was 92 years old.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Blank Ballots By Writers Burn Bunning
description: IN slamming the doors of Cooperstown on Jim Bunning's fingers, nine Baseball Hall of Fame voters each signed and mailed a blank ballot in this year's election. Had those voters chosen simply not to return a ballot, Bunning would be in the Hall of Fame with the slugger Willie Stargell. But the 224-game winner, one of the few pitchers with more than 100 victories in each league, remains on the outside looking in. Once again the Hall of Fame emerges as a philosophy as much as a museum.

title: C.P.A. Group Votes to Alter Membership Criteria
description: In a development that will affect hundreds of thousands of accountants nationwide, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants said yesterday that its membership had approved a series of rule changes aimed at improving the quality of accounting practice.

title: Super Bowl Loss Still Haunts Broncos
description: The Browns have the memory of John Elway's magnificent 98-yard drive in the American Conference title game last year against the Broncos, but Denver has its own bit of history that refuses to fade, at least for its general manager, John Beake. That is the loss in the Super Bowl to the Giants.

title: 'Three Men and a Baby' Is Top Box-Office Film
description: ''Three Men and a Baby,'' a comedy, was the top film at the box office last week, earning $8.1 million, nearly twice as much as the second-place movie.

title: Surplus Goods Aid Social Agencies
description: The Strycker's Bay Neighborhood Council, a housing and social service organization in New York, took two filing cabinets, a cart and three chairs from the warehouse. Coney Island USA, a theater-museum group, picked up a desk, a filing cabinet and four walkie-talkies. Neither organization paid for the items, but got them under a New York City program that gives away surplus office furniture and supplies to nonprofit community groups.

title: 9-Year-Old Driver Is Injured In Fatal Crash During Chase
description: The police chased a car driven by a 9-year-old boy at speeds of nearly 90 miles an hour today until it careened past a red light and struck another car, killing its adult driver, police officers said.

title: No Peace for Central America
description: A double-barreled reality leaps out of the Central American peace process: the Reagan Administration doesn't want peace, and the Sandinistas say they do but are unwilling to pay the necessary price for it.

title: Slowing German Economy During 1987 Is Confirmed
description: The West German economy slowed in 1987 to its lowest growth rate in five years, with almost no expansion in the last three months, official figures released today confirmed.

title: Parent & Child
description: THE picture of adult life parents paint for their children is filled with false colors.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $23,512,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and $72,512,000 for the year. c-Net loss and the year includes a gain on debt repayment of $10,119,000. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 28.

title: China's Money Supply
description: China's central bank announced plans today to reduce the money supply to help curb inflation, which rose above 7 percent last year.

title: Petroleum and Plastics
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Juror Tells of Car Offer If He Discussed Mob Trial
description: A former juror testified yesterday that a man he knew at work had offered him a new car if he would reveal the jury's thoughts about the current racketeering and drug trial of Gene Gotti and other defendants.

title: Court Nominee Clarifies How He Differs From Bork
description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's nominee to the Supreme Court, submitted written testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee this week that further underscored the differences in his outlook and that of the Administration's first choice for the vacancy, Judge Robert H. Bork.

title: ORION PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Rebirth of 1866 Manhattan Frame House
description: FIFTEEN years ago, on her first day in New York, Karen Marcus - then 21 years old and fresh from West Virginia - explored her new East 50's neighborhood with a friend and spotted a narrow, four-story, clapboard town house. With its wood frame, plain facade and simple mansard roof, it was as modest as it was rare.

title: Garvey Retires After 17 Years
description: Steve Garvey, the 17-year veteran first baseman who finished out his fifth season with the San Diego Padres on the disabled list, announced his retirement from major league baseball today.

title: A.T.&T. Says U.S. Agency Aided Rivals
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday formally accused officials of the General Services Administration of leaking sensitive bid information to its competitors, enabling them to win Government telephone contracts at A.T.&T.'s expense.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Salute to Reaganism
description: The dollar is down, Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination has been defeated and the Iran-contra affair lingers on. But it might as well have been 1981 Tuesday night when the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, the research organization at Stanford that laid out many of the grand themes of Reaganism, brought together 300 of the faithful from the theological center of California and the power center of Washington.

title: Advertising; Drake Bakeries Account Is Awarded to Wyse
description: Drake Bakeries of Wayne, N.J., which began an agency search in August, yesterday announced that Wyse Advertising of New York was its choice.

title: Rangers Beaten By Red Wings
description: When last at the Garden, Jacques Demers, coach of the Red Wings, exited without the benefit of his eyeglasses, having hurled them across the ice in a fit of pique after a 4-3 loss to the Rangers.

title: INSIDE
description: Fewer Youths Use Cocaine The use of cocaine among high school seniors in the United States dropped last year for the first time in 13 years, an annual survey found. Page A24. Collegians Prefer Wealth Record numbers of freshmen say being well off is important, a survey has found. Far fewer stress a meaningful philosophy of life. Page A14. Unlocking Contra Aid The Reagan Administration is appealing to four Central American Presidents to help persuade Congress to renew contra aid. Page A8. U.S. Troop Shifts Advised The Secretary of the Navy, James H. Webb Jr., called for a review of the deployment of American forces, especially in Europe. Page A13. Far Out in the Universe Astronomers have detected what may be the oldest and most distant objects in the universe. Page A24.

title: Homes for the Homeless Are Resisted in Illinois
description: A real-estate entrepreneur wants to provide work, neighbors and another chance to some of the nation's homeless people, using 19 houses he owns in this southern Illinois town of 5,400.

title: Dow, in a Seesaw Session, Falls 3.82
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, in relatively light trading.

title: One More (0-14) for the Road for Nets
description: The Philadelphia 76ers showed the Nets tonight how to play just hard enough to win. But it was something New Jersey could not relate to. On nights like tonight, the Nets play their hardest and still can't win.

title: Tricky Task of Replacing Woven Splint
description: LEAD: When cane or rush seats show signs of wear they can be rewoven so they look as good as the original. Not so seats woven with hand-cut splint, the inner bark of trees (often the bark came from the same tree, typically hickory, whose wood was used in the chair). One often sees these old chairs in the corner of a room, seats sagging, the odd strand broken or missing.

title: Advertising Account Is Lost Over Responses to Feminist
description: As a direct result of its flippant responses to a complaint from a feminist, one of the nation's hottest advertising agencies has lost an account billing about $10 million annually.

title: Totem Poles for Traffic
description: It's hard enough to find a parking space in New York City; often it's harder still to figure out if the space is legal. The confusion encourages parking violations. The city's Transportation Department, aware of the problem, has responded, though slowly, on some cross streets. But it remains mystifyingly paralyzed about Manhattan avenues.

title: Cuomo Criticizes SUNY for Failing to Limit Budget
description: Using unusually strong language, Governor Cuomo criticized the State University of New York today, calling its leaders irresponsible for not coming up with ways to limit budget growth.

title: Oil Output In U.S. Fell 4.5% in '87
description: The nation's oil production dropped 4.5 percent last year to the lowest level since 1977, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

title: Q&A
description: Q.In my windowless bathroom the wallpaper has some spots of mildew. How can I get rid of the mildew permanently?

title: Young Adults Show Drop in Cocaine Use
description: The use of cocaine has declined substantially among high school seniors for the first time in more than a decade, according to an annual survey released today.

title: Prime Raises Bid for Its Rival
description: Prime Computer Inc. sweetened its offer yesterday to acquire its rival the Computervision Corporation, to $15 a share, or a total of $433.5 million. The company, which previously offered $13.50 a share for Computervision, said that it would not increase its offer again.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Remembering Iran, 1981
description: About a dozen former American hostages in Iran who live in the Washington area will celebrate the seventh anniversary of their freedom next Wednesday at an annual reunion lunch at the Army-Navy Club.

title: Scientist Identifies Ancestor to All Life Forms
description: An analysis of genetic material from many species has indicated that all of today's living things may have evolved from single-cell organisms that consumed sulfur and lived in near-boiling water, perhaps in hot sulfur springs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cerus, Paris, a holding company controlled by the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti, agreed to sell to News International, the British subsidiary of the News Corp., Rupert Murdoch's holding company, its 4.9 percent share in Pearson Group, owner of The Financial Times newspaper.

title: INTEREST RATE CUT PLEDGED BY JAPAN
