description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita told President Reagan today that Japan would work to reduce its interest rates, and both countries agreed to intensify efforts to halt the dollar's decline.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 14, 1988
description: International A3-13, B7

title: Officer's Catch Is a Life Saver
description: A police officer caught a five-month-old boy dropped by a screaming woman from the third-floor window of a burning row house Tuesday, although he said all he could see was ''a big white Pamper.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ogden Phipps resigned as an active member of the New York Racing Association's board of trustees and was named a director emeritus. Phipps, 79 years old, had served on the board since its inception in 1959. Arthur F. Long, a member of the Jockey Club since 1981 and an owner of thoroughbreds for 23 years, has been nominated to replace Phipps on the board. The nomination is subject to approval by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board. . . . Paul A. Stiehl, a business consultant who has been serving as treasurer of the United States Soccer Federation, has been named to the new post of director of World Cup USA and charged with leading the effort to hold the 1994 World Cup in the United States. . . . Ralph Sampson left the Golden State Warriors yesterday for his home in Houston, where his wife, Aleize, was expected to deliver the couple's first child.

title: Vikings Stay Warm and Busy
description: Welcome to the big time. Within 12 hours of their arrival here, the Minnesota Vikings checked into two hotels, waited for a Mack Truck convention to leave their primary hotel and then, after team meetings and lunch, the offense walked through some plays on a dirt lot near several parked cars, a pickup truck and a bulldozer clearing debris.

title: Ex-Nurse Indicted in Death
description: A grand jury has indicted a former nurse, Richard J. Angelo, on murder charges, District Attorney Patrick Henry said today. Mr. Angelo, 25 years old, is charged with injecting a patient at Good Samaritan Hospital with a muscle-paralyzing drug, killing him.

title: S.E.C. Charges 2 as Insiders
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged two employees of a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., the giant oil services concern, with illegally purchasing the stock of the Texas International Company, while in the possession of confidential information about the discovery of a major oil field by Texas International in western Egypt in early 1985.

title: More Contra Aid, More Suffering
description: The Government and people of Nicaragua want peace. There have already been more than 50,000 Nicaraguan casualties in the war financed by the United States. This includes 25,527 dead, the majority of whom are women, children and poor farmers. For a small country with 3.5 million people, this is a staggering figure. The harm to our economy exceeds $3.5 billion. More United States aid to the contras can only mean more war, more death and destruction - more totally unnecessary and unjustifiable suffering.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN THE NEW WORLD. Growing Up With America 1960-1984. By Lawrence Wright. 322 pages. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Hugh A. Robertson, Film Maker, 55
description: Hugh A. Roberston, a film maker who won an Academy Award nomination for editing ''Midnight Cowboy,'' died Sunday of cancer in the Wadsworth Memorial Center in Los Angeles. He was 55 years old. Mr. Robertson also edited ''Shaft'' and was associate editor of ''The Miracle Worker'' and ''Lilith.'' He directed ''Melinda,'' a 1972 melodrama, and produced and directed ''Bim,'' a 1976 film on colonial Trinidad. His final film, ''Obeah,'' is to be released this year.

title: New Alliances Seen in Computers; Apple-Digital Deal Said to Be Close
description: Apple Computer Inc. is expected to announce Friday that it will enter into a joint development agreement with the Digital Equipment Corporation.

title: A Renaissance in American Manufacturing Shops Is Coming
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Ruling on Death Opens Way for Transplants
description: After years of painstaking study, the Japan Medical Association has decided to accept brain death as a valid definition of death, clearing the way for heart and other organ transplants that are now effectively banned.

title: United Unit Sales
description: The United Technologies Corporation said it had entered into separate preliminary agreements to sell two of its financial subsidiaries. The company, with headquarters in Hartford, would sell the UT Credit Corporation and certain of its subsidiaries to Jet Florida Inc., Miami, and the MGC Leasing Corporation for an aggregate cash price of about $200 million. The UT Financial Services Corporation and its unit, the UT Leasing Corporation, would be purchased by the Zapata Corporation of Houston for an aggregate cash price of about $134 million.

title: U.S. Says It Will Stay Firm in Arms Talks With Soviet
description: The United States will stick to key elements of its position on reducing long-range nuclear arms when American and Soviet negotiators begin a new round of talks in Geneva on Thursday, Administration officials said today.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax extraordinary gain of $40,280,000 on the sale of a United Kingdom affiliate.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Digital Net Up by 22%
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported late yesterday that earnings in its second fiscal quarter, which ended Dec. 26, rose 22 percent and revenues increased 22.5 percent.

title: Split in N.C.A.A. On Grade Standard
description: Just a few hours after approving legislation that demands better grades from college athletes, Division I schools reversed themselves today and decided not to impose uniform standards.

title: Psychiatric Test Is Ordered for Homeless Woman
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered an independent psychiatric examination of Joyce Brown, the 40-year-old woman whose involuntary hospitalization has become a test of New York City's powers to remove disturbed homeless people from the streets.

title: Rolling Stone Magazine Begins a French Edition
description: The first French edition of the rock magazine Rolling Stone went on sale today, with a cover story looking back at the last 20 years - ''From the Summer of Love to the Purple Decade.''

title: Ralph H. Cutler Jr., Commodity Executive, 69
description: Ralph H. Cutler Jr., a commodity executive, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Morristown, N.J. He was 69 years old.

title: Financial Reform? Not in This Life
description: LEAD: The Brady Commission has delivered to President Reagan its findings on the causes of Black Monday and instability in the financial markets, and we now await further reports by numerous institutions, both public and private. While we don't know what those later studies will add to the Brady Commission's recommendations, we can be sure of one thing: Few, if any, concrete suggestions will be translated into regulatory law.

title: Labor Groups Assail E.P.A.'s Proposed Rules on Pesticide Use
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to revise its rules governing the exposure of farm workers to pesticides, but its draft proposal is already under fire from labor groups.

title: What We Need Is a Gold Standard Time; Resetting the Dog
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Gore Advantage
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. has a peculiar advantage in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. His state, Tennessee, borders on eight other states, all of which hold their primaries on March 8, the day politicians call Super Tuesday. Day after day, Senator Gore has told neighboring state audiences how happy he was to be in a state that borders on his own and remarked on how much the neighboring states have in common.

title: Quebec Defeats Devils
description: First place in the Patrick Division eluded the Devils again tonight as they suffered their third consecutive loss at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, this time to the Quebec Nordiques.

title: Barge Knocks Out Causeway Linking Miami Beach to City
description: A barge ferrying a construction crane rammed a heavily traveled causeway to Miami Beach, knocking the drawbridge out of commission for at least a week, officials said today.

title: Robertson Set for Texas Vote
description: Texas Republican Party officials today approved primary petitions filed by Pat Robertson for the state's Presidential primary but continued to check signatures on qualifying petitions filed by other candidates. Federal agents are investigating reports that some of the people whose names are on the petitions said they did not sign them.

title: Currents; Unseasonable Dressing For an Empty Room
description: THERE still may be snow outside, but the decor in one of the rooms at the cavernous Seventh Regiment Armory will resemble an Italian garden. The armory's Tiffany Room is being prepared for preview parties that will herald the opening of the Winter Antiques Show on Jan. 22.

title: What We Need Is a Gold Standard Time
description: To the Editor:

title: A.M.A. Proposal On Malpractice
description: The American Medical Association has proposed a new system to expedite malpractice claims and to insure that incompetent doctors are weeded out of the system.

title: NORTHEAST SAVINGS FEDERAL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $6,164,000 and $7,693,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $4,086,000 and $10,634,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Gearing Up To Stay Home
description: The couch potatoes are going to be cocooning in their families' personal oases this year.

title: Yanks Pursuing Boddicker
description: Neither side is talking publicly, but it appears the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles are involved in some serious discussions about a trade that could involve as many as seven players.

title: Veterinarian Backs Filion's Testimony
description: Henri Filion's contention that he was driving a sick horse in the fourth race at Yonkers Raceway on Nov. 14 was supported yesterday in testimony before the State Racing and Wagering Board by a track veterinarian and the horse's present owner.

title: Bond Prices Moderately Higher
description: Bond prices rose modestly yesterday, with all the gains coming after the dollar improved and oil prices fell from their morning highs.

title: France Agrees to Take Ousted Iranians Back
description: France will allow seven Iranians expelled to Gabon last month to return ''for humanitarian reasons,'' and has arranged for the remainder of the 15 people expelled -five Iranians and three Turkish Kurds - to move to Spain, the Interior Ministry said tonight.

title: Comedy: Colin Quinn
description: COLIN QUINN, a comedian whose reputation for New York Irish streetwise humor has been described as Joycean, is a performer who relies more heavily than most comics on electrical communication with individual members of the audience.

title: Lighthearted Classics Evoke Epochs Ancient and Archetypal
description: LAST week, a visitor to Jerrystyle, a newly expanded East Village emporium that specializes in verdigris and well-patinated copper home furnishings, seemed disappointed. ''I must have that really old look,'' she said to Jeff Brown, who works there. He responded: ''If you don't see anything here, bring in something and we'll oxidize it for you.''

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday with a London dispatch about currency trading reversed the figures for the pretax foreign-exchange income of Chase Manhattan and Chemical Bank. The correct figures for Chemical were $55.5 million in 1982, $103.2 million in 1986 and $104 million in the first three quarters of 1987. The figures for Chase Manhattan were $130.5 million, $223.2 million and $169.7 million.

title: HEALTHVEST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $268,000 for the writeoff of certain financing costs. The company went public on May 29, 1986; for the seven months ended Dec. 31, 1986, Healthvest earned $6,260,000, or $1.05 a share, on revenue of $8,610,000 and average shares were 5,978,000.

title: Forecast: Bad Trade Data
description: Financial markets are braced for tomorrow's report on the November foreign trade deficit - and it's sure to be misleading, once again. Whatever it shows, the dollar figure will be wrong. The Administration's failure to make the trade figures more accurate is irresponsible.

title: Chambers Jury Hears of Flaws In Key Evidence
description: A New York City detective conceded yesterday that an area in Central Park where several key pieces of evidence about Jennifer Levin's death were discovered was initially ignored by investigators and used as a parking lot on the morning of her death.

title: New York City Welcomes Proposed Rise in State Aid
description: New York City is to receive an 8.1 percent increase in state assistance under Governor Cuomo's proposed 1988-89 budget, administration officials said today.

title: Jewish Women, Careers and Religion
description: While many women still find themselves having to choose among marriage, career and childbearing, a significant number of Jewish career women seem to be juggling all three successfully, according to a recent study by a sociologist at Gratz College in Philadelphia.

title: 'Type A' Men Fare Better in Heart Attack Study
description: In the continuing controversy about how much hard-driving ''Type A'' behavior may affect the risk of developing and dying of heart disease, a new study has found that men who were considered Type A were less likely to die after a heart attack than their more placid Type B counterparts.

title: Suffolk Officers Testify They Wiretapped Illegally
description: Suffolk County narcotics officers conducted illegal wiretaps with the approval of their supervisor and the chief of the District Attorney's narcotics bureau, two former officers testified today as a state hearing on the Police Department began.

title: Singer Backs Bid
description: The Singer Company's board of directors approved a once-hostile $1.06 billion takeover bid by a group led by the Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian, and it recommended shareholders tender their stock. The Montvale, N.J., military electronics company said in a statement that its board considered the $50-a-share offer ''fair and in the best interests of the company.'' In November, the board had rejected the offer and challenged it in court. Later, Singer put its challenge on hold and said it would acquiesce if Mr. Bilzerian could come up with the financing. The Tampa, Fla., financier has said he has the commitments.

title: At P.S. 132, Members of a Comedy Club Learn as They Laugh
description: IT'S show time at the Kids' Comedy Club in Washington

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The year-ago periods' share earnings are restated to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend in October.

title: Dr. Adam Munz, 60, Hospital Psychologist
description: Dr. Adam Munz, chief psychologist at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center since 1962, died of cancer Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Leonia, N.J.

title: Currents; He's Got Designs on These Plates
description: DINERS at the newly restored Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center musn't be so dazzled by the views or the beautiful 1930's-style architecture that they ignore what's on their plates or, for that matter, the plates themselves.

title: For George, A House That Expands Vistas
description: LEAD: ''THIS is George's house,'' his mother said. The house is an elegant pink villa designed by Herschel Parnes, a Seattle architect. George is 14 years old and has cerebral palsy.

title: How Television Saw News of 1968
description: Twenty years later, the images retain their searing power: beefy Chicago policemen clubbing the inert bodies of long-haired demonstrators outside the Democratic National Convention, Country Joe and the Fish singing ''One, two, three, what are we fighting for? Don't ask me, I don't give a damn; next stop is Vietnam,'' President Johnson cradling his beagle, Richard M. Nixon lifting his arms in a victory salute, stunned faces all around the country crumpling into tears at the news that first the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., then Senator Robert F. Kennedy had been shot.

title: TOWN & COUNTRY JEWELRY MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a net charge of about $200,000 resulting from the change in the market value of its investment portfolio stemming from the mid-October stock market decline.

title: In Salvador, They Are Still Fleeing the Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet and Swedes Sparring Over Submarines
description: The Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, finished a three-day round of fence-mending in Sweden today with an agreement on fishing rights in the Baltic Sea, an accord on sharing information about nuclear accidents and a pledge to step up trade.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Capital's Bumper Crop
description: With diplomatic representations from 152 countries quartered in the capital, the presence of exotica is part of the scene. Still, there are occasional surprises, such as the ultimate in bumper stickers on a car with diplomatic license plates parked outside an Arab embassy on Massachusetts Avenue: In green and red it announces: ''I [ love ] Oman.''

title: Cat Out of the Bag
description: Elliott Abrams and Lieut. Gen.

title: Paterson Principal: A Man of Extremes
description: Getting a measure of Eastside High School, the inner-city school whose principal, Joe Clark, patrols hallways with bullhorn and baseball bat in hand, isn't easy. Last year a state monitoring team tried, and barely got in the door.

title: U.S. and Soviet, in Gulf, Show Rare Cooperation
description: In a rare display of Soviet-American cooperation in the Persian Gulf, the United States responded to a Soviet request last week to find a mine in gulf waters, according to an official with the Central Command in Tampa, Fla.

title: European Farm Income
description: The average income of European farmers dropped by 5 percent last year and by 25 percent since the mid-1970's, the European Farmers Organization said today. By comparison, the income in all other sectors of the European economy had increased by 1.5 percent, the group said. The figures are based on early estimates from the statistical office of the European Community, the organization said.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AIRCOA HOSPITALITY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yields Flat Or Down
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were flat in the week ended yesterday, while those of money market mutual funds slipped.

title: HEALTH: Personal Health
description: A decade ago a 9-year-old girl I loved like a daughter developed rapidly progressive leukemia. When potent drugs and radiation failed to control the cancer, there was only one possibility: a bone marrow transplant to replace her diseased blood-forming cells. Unfortunately, no one in her immediate family was a good enough ''match'' to be a donor, and she died.

title: Shakespeare Troupe Eyes Weak Dollar
description: Britain's financially troubled Royal Shakespeare Company is feeling the pinch of the weaker dollar and could face a fresh crisis as American theatergoers stay away, its artistic director warned today.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Farrar, Straus & Giroux Has New Editor in Chief
description: Roger W. Straus, president of Farrar, Straus and Giroux, has named Jonathan Galassi editor in chief and Pat Strachan associate publisher, effective immediately. Both were formerly executive editors.

title: A Variety of Plants to Suit Any Climate
description: COMPLAINT plays an important part in almost every gardener's life. We complain about problems we can solve with a little work, like chickweed or crabgrass in the flower beds. We also complain about matters beyond our control, mainly the weather. Chief among these meteorological complaints are those concerning the plants we cannot grow because we live in a climate they find too taxing or unfriendly.

title: New York Officers Lose Bias Settlement Appeal
description: An equally divided Supreme Court today turned aside, on procedural grounds, a challenge by white police officers to an affirmative action settlement intended to increase promotions of black and Hispanic officers in the New York City Police Department.

title: Hers
description: LEAD: I'VE never lived in a house with a television, except for one year. That was in 1967. I was in my mid-20's. Every evening I watched the war on the news. Vietnamese refugees, their faces contorted, their voices anguished, streamed across that flickering blue screen into my living room. Their cries haunted me during the day and stayed with me deep into the night.

title: Katia Ricciarelli, Ill, Cancels Monday Recital
description: A recital by Katia Ricciarelli scheduled for Monday at Alice Tully Hall has been canceled because the soprano is ill and cannot come to New York City, the concert hall has announced.

title: Beatrix Potter Illustrations on Display
description: Generations of children have been brought up on the tales of Peter Rabbit, but few know that his creator, Beatrix Potter, was a watercolorist and naturalist as well as a storyteller.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings for the year-ago fourth quarter and all of 1986 were reduced by an extraordinary charge of $4.5 million related to a merger.

title: Price Limits On Futures
description: The Chicago Board of Trade set permanent daily price limits on its stock index futures today, becoming the first futures market to attempt to reduce the trading volatility that some experts have blamed for worsening the October market collapse.

title: Advertising; President for Midwest Is Chosen by Bozell
description: Ric Cooper, 41, has been named president of the Midwest division of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. He replaces Ron Anderson, who was recently appointed associate chief creative officer.

title: First China Stock Firm
description: China has set up its first domestic securities firm, the official China News Service said. It is in the Shenzhen special economic zone. The agency, monitored in Hong Kong today, said the firm, in the Shenzhen special economic zone, would trade stocks and bonds and help underwrite shares issued by Chinese companies.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-After pre-tax charges for increase in reserve for losses associated with investment activity of $252,000 and $333,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, the 6 months also includes a pre-tax gain of $1,371,000 from the sale of a unit. The company said revenue figures have been restated to exclude investment activity and gains on the sale of assets.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: WORKING PROFILE: Theodore S. Greenberg; Prosecutor Who Knows How to Keep a Secret
description: Last month, to the surprise of some Justice Department officials, a Manila businessman pleaded guilty to the charges of defrauding the Pentagon on a Philippine military contract. Before a Federal judge in Alexandria, Va., he paid the United States $1 million in fines.

title: Hoffman-La Roche Gets Bank Backing
description: F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Compagnie, a Swiss drug producer offering $4.2 billion for Sterling Drug Inc., said yesterday that it had received a $4.2 billion commitment from a bank group headed by the Swiss Bank Corporation. Swiss Bank will provide $1 billion while the rest will come from the Union Bank, Credit Suisse, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, Banque Nationale de Paris and Deutsche Bank.

title: School to Give Up Art Tied to Stock Scheme
description: Duke University said yesterday it would turn over to a court-appointed receiver two paintings and $20,000 in cash donated to the school last year by David P. Bloom, a 23-year alumnus who was charged Tuesday with operating a fraudulent investment advisory scheme in New York.

title: Texaco Facing Back Tax Claim For $6.5 Billion
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, disclosed yesterday that the Federal Government might seek $6.5 billion in back taxes as part of Texaco's bankruptcy proceedings.

title: William Duff, Theater Investor, 58
description: William Duff, a theater investor and actor, died of heart failure Tuesday at Danbury Hospital in Danbury, Conn. He was 58 years old and lived in Redding, Conn.

title: Britons' U.S. Takeovers Up
description: British spending on takeovers of United States companies more than doubled last year, according to a study published today.

title: Top Player Dismissed
description: Angie McClellan, leading scorer and rebounder for the University of Illinois's women's basketball team, said she has nobody to blame but herself for being bounced off the team. She was dismissed Tuesday for altering the date on a school medical form so she would have an excuse for missing a class on a day when an absence could have lowered her grade. ''There's been lots of drugs and steroids,'' she said. ''It's part of college life. But what I did wasn't right and it was a violation, too.''

title: General Fund: How It's Grown Under Cuomo
description: The size of the state's General Fund, as Governor Cuomo outlined in his budget presentation, will mean that in his first six years as Governor, state spending will have increased more than 50 percent.

title: E-II Has Loss On Stock Fall
description: E-II Holdings Inc., a publicly traded spinoff of the Beatrice Company, reported a $131.9 million loss in its third quarter today.

title: PENTAGON CALLED LAX ON CLEARANCES
description: The Pentagon is ignoring its own rules by granting thousands of military security clearances to people born in nations of the Soviet bloc and other countries designated as ''adverse'' to United States interests, a Congressional report says.

title: CHAMPION ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Net income The company said in the latest periods it made an additional provision for income taxes of $1,295,000 for the quarter due to the writeoff of prepaid taxes which began in the second quarter, and due to the writeoff of prepaid taxes which reduced year-to-date, or for the 9 months, net income by $2,144,000. The company was formerly Champion Home Builders Co.

title: Bush, in a Shift of Strategy, Appeals to the Unregistered
description: When Vice President Bush was bruised by a third-place finish in an Iowa straw poll last September, two aftershocks ensued.

title: 'Zhivago' Appears in Russia
description: A Soviet monthly has begun publishing installments of Boris Pasternak's ''Doctor Zhivago,'' which had been banned since Mr. Pasternak won the 1958 Nobel Prize for literature.

title: Costa Rica in Ultimatum to Contras
description: In a surprise move, President Oscar Arias Sanchez has ordered Nicaraguan contra leaders living here to either resign from the rebel movement or leave Costa Rica.

title: Currents; Nothing Folksy About Folk Art Market
description: FOLK art, a major ingredient of the American country look, is more popular than ever, according to museum curators, auction-house experts and gallery owners.

title: TAIWAN AT A GLANCE
description: People

title: New Alliances Seen in Computers; Ashton in Project With Microsoft
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation, two leading producers of personal computer software, said yesterday that they plan to jointly offer a new software product that manages data bases on computer networks.

title: Job Offer from S.M.U.
description: Forrest Gregg, coach of the Green Bay Packers, was offered the head coaching job at Southern Methodist University yesterday and said that the decision ''is not an easy thing.'' Doug Single, the S.M.U. athletic director, said that the offer was made in the afternoon and that Gregg said he would have an answer soon. Single said he wanted to give Gregg an opportunity to talk over the offer with his family and the Packers. Gregg, 54 years old, has completed four years of a five-year contract with the Packers. Green Bay was 5-9-1 in 1987, giving Gregg a 25-37-1 record with the Packers. Gregg earned N.F.L. Hall of Fame honors with Green Bay during the Packers' glory years in the 1960s. He played collegiate ball at S.M.U., where both of his children also went to college. S.M.U. will start playing football again in 1989. The N.C.A.A. shut down the program in 1987 and placed limitations on its 1988 season after determining that players received money and other incentives from boosters. S.M.U. then canceled its 1988 season as well.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We hold that educators do not offend the First Amendment by exercising editorial control over the style and content of student speech in school-sponsored expressive activities so long as their actions are reasonably related to legitimate pedagogical concerns.'' - Justice Byron White, for a Supreme Court majority in upholding censorship of a school newspaper. [ A26:4. ]

title: HEALTH: Medical Insurance; Fate of the Newest Treatments Is Often Determined by Medicare
description: Almost every month brings word of new miracles of medical technology that help diagnose illness, prolong life or overcome crippling disability.

title: Winners Open Golf Tour
description: The 1988 PGA Tour and the 1988 Senior PGA Tour will begin here Thursday with the MONY Tournaments of Champions over the La Costa Country Club.

title: Excerpts From Governor's Budget Message to the Legislature
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's budget message to the Legislature: EDUCATION

title: Law Firm's Moscow Unit
description: Seeking to expand its practice again, a Manhattan law firm, Coudert Brothers, announced yesterday that it would establish an office in Moscow.

title: Paul A. Cohen, Stockbroker, 79
description: Paul A. Cohen, the former senior partner of Herzfeld & Stern, a New York stock brokerage firm now owned by Gruntal & Company, died of Alzheimer's disease yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES 8.3% SPENDING RISE AND CUTS IN TAXES
description: Governor Cuomo proposed a budget today that would begin a four-year tax cut while increasing spending for health care, housing and education.

title: Unlocking Contra Aid: 4 Men Called Key
description: After six years of firm commitment to the Nicaraguan rebels, the Reagan Administration is now in the position of saying that, in the end, their fate rests in the hands of four Central American Presidents who have all said the contra program is a bad idea.

title: FEARS FOR TAIWAN: A NEW INSTABILITY
description: Chinese and American specialists on Taiwan expressed concern yesterday about the future of the island after the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo, in their view the most significant political event there since 1949.

title: NATIONAL WESTMINSTER BANK USA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods included gains on sales of investment securities of $814,000 for the quarter and $4,926,000 for the year, compared with the year- ago periods of $3,702,000 and $7,890,000, respectively. The latest periods' net losses were because of an $75 million addition to the reserve against loans to a number of countries with severe debt servicing problems for the quarter and special provisions against cross border exposures of $295 million for the year.

title: Redford to Take Films To Moscow for Festival
description: Robert Redford has accepted an invitation from the Soviet Film Makers Union to be the host of a festival of his movies in the Soviet Union.

title: Trump Hints at Federated Stake
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, is seeking clearance to buy at least $15 million worth of Federated Department Stores Inc., the company said yesterday.

title: Public Halts A Ballet By Bejart
description: Maurice Bejart's second ballet presentation in his new home was marred on Tuesday night when spectators booed and complained they could not see.

title: Batus Bids $4.2 Billion For Insurer
description: Batus Inc., the American subsidiary of the British conglomerate B.A.T. Industries, said today that it had offered $60 a share, or $4.2 billion, for the Farmers Group Inc., the nation's seventh-largest property and casualty insurer.

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV Review; On 'Currents,' 'Women in Prison'
description: ''CURRENTS,'' Channel 13's weekly series, examines tonight a new problem in United States penology. Women are incarcerated in growing numbers; more than 26,000 are now in prison. ''Currents'' does not say they shouldn't be there, but it does worry about some of the effects. The program, ''Women in Prison,'' will be seen at 8:30 P.M.

title: Piano: Angela Cheng
description: THE opening phrases of Mozart's D major sonata, K. 576, are not especially difficult, but the poise and clarity with which Angela Cheng played them at the beginning of her Alice Tully Hall recital Monday evening immediately left the impression that nothing was going to be especially difficult for her. The remainder of the program (fantasies by Schumann and John Corigliano and a group of Chopin pieces) did not test the limits of bravura technical accomplishment, but as far as they went, Miss Cheng lived up to the suggestion at the outset.

title: Honda Expansion
description: Honda of Canada Manufacturing Inc. said it would spend about $62 million to expand its Alliston, Ontario, plant, and add the three-door hatchback version of the Civic car to the Accord cars it has manufactured since late 1986. . Honda said the expansion would add 100 jobs by 1989.

title: Retail Sales Climbed 0.7% In December
description: The nation's retail sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December over the November level, the best performance in four months, spurred in great part by higher auto sales, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: Treasury Prices Increase Slightly
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose slightly yesterday, after trading in a relatively narrow range before the barrage of economic statistics to be announced today.

title: A Different East-West Rivalry?
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has openly admitted that his system failed to deliver on its promises and no longer appeals as a model. Scarcely news in the West, but it is a signal of great importance in the East. The search for self-renewal requires an attempt to divert human as well as material resources away from the only field in which the Russians proved adept at competition -the military.

title: Group Sets Plan For Stop and Shop
description: The Stop and Shop Companies said that a partnership controlled by Herbert Haft, the chairman of Dart Group, planned to buy more than $15 million of Stop and Shop stock. Stop and Shop, which operates 171 Bradlees discount stores in addition to 114 Stop and Shop supermarkets, said it had received a letter from Mr. Haft stating that Jefferson Partnership was seeking antitrust clearance in relation to the purchase. The Haft family has made sizable profits from its stock holdings of companies it has attempted to acquire. Its most recent attempt was a $6.62 billion bid for the Dayton Hudson Corporation.

title: Is Quality of Federal Work Force Deteriorating?
description: Paul A. Volcker is concerned about the decline in the quality of the Federal bureaucracy, and he plans to do something about it.

title: Late Rally in Oil Contracts Gives Lift to Precious Metals
description: A late, heavy flood of buy orders bolstered futures prices for crude oil and oil-related products yesterday, despite reports of widespread price cutting by Middle East producers.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Tribute for Montand

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after non-cash, pretax charges of $957,092,000 for the writedown of oil and gas properties and a writeoff of surplus railroad assets.

title: Harold Kennedy, Producer, Dies
description: Harold J. Kennedy, a jack-of-all-theatrical-trades and for nearly half a century a champion of the summer theater circuit, died of cardiac arrest on Sunday at Doctors Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times; Purple Uniform, Green Bucks
description: RON DAUGHERTY is planning a party for Sunday afternoon -his ''football cronies'' crowding into his Chicago apartment, and purple pompons everywhere.

title: Regan Supports Bush Assertion on Concern Over Iran Arms Sales
description: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, said through a spokesman today that Vice President Bush had voiced reservations on ''several occasions'' about aspects of the arms shipment to Iran. The concerns were raised in the presence of President Reagan, the spokesman said.

title: Art: Fom Robert Morris, Images of Sex and Death
description: FEW contemporary artists bite off more than Robert Morris.

title: Memorials to Dr. King In an Array of Activities
description: Unlike America's nine other designated national holidays, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday is less a day for celebration than one for reflection on both the achievements and the goals yet to be realized in this country's generations-long struggle for social justice.

title: Sports People; Guerrero Back at Wheel
description: Only four months after a crash nearly ended his life, Roberto Guerrero was back in a race car yesterday, feeling ''100 percent.'' The 29-year-old driver from Colombia suffered critical head injuries in a crash last Sept. 10 during a test of tires at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. He spent more than two weeks in a coma after the accident. ''I felt more nervous getting back in the car today than I ever did,'' Guerrero told The Associated Press in a telephone interview from Firebird International Raceway in Phoenix. ''I started out easy. After a few laps, I felt like I was 100 percent, like I had never been out of the car. I've taken a big load off my shoulders.'' Last season, Guerrero won two races and finished second in the Indy 500.

title: Ex-New York Official Is Convicted of Perjury
description: A former New York State official and a real-estate developer have been convicted of lying to a state panel about their business relationship in connection with the relocation of state offices from the World Trade Center in the early 1980's.

title: Pakistan's Afghan Moves Perplex U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration appears to have been thrown off balance by Pakistan's recent statements that members of the pro-Moscow Government in Afghanistan should be retained as part of a government that would take office as a condition of a Soviet troop withdrawal.

title: Beijing Extols Taiwan's Chief On His Death
description: Zhao Ziyang, the head of the Chinese Communist Party, delivered a remarkable tribute today to Chiang Ching-kuo, the President of Taiwan and a fervent anti-Communist, who died Wednesday in Taipei.

title: Editors' Note
description: A brief article on Sunday reported that A. M. Rosenthal, columnist and former executive editor of The New York Times, would serve as an editor at large for G. P. Putnam, book publishers.

title: Levin's Last Night Recalled by a Friend
description: Jennifer Levin spent the last night of her life in a crowded bar filled with her friends, mostly recent high school graduates enjoying a final, emotional late-summer night together before starting college. But her mind was on Robert E. Chambers Jr., a witness testified yesterday.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: DAVID KEH'S idea of a fine French dinner, those who know him attest, might be navarin of lamb or a hearty bouillabaisse, with a stop on the way home for some ''real food'' - a plate of spicy pork dumplings, steamed fish or crispy orange beef at a Chinese restaurant. Mr. Keh, the indefatigable Manhattan restaurateur, has apparently never felt comfortable with Western food, which is why it came as no surprise when he pulled the plug on his two experiments in Occidental cuisine - the California-style Safari Grill and the Mexican restaurant Cafe Marimba - and turned them back into Chinese establishments.

title: FIRST WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges from provision for losses on loans to developing nations of $18.2 million for the quarter and $38.2 million for the year, net of an $8.9 million equity security gain. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $12.1 million on the sale of a subsidiary and equity securities, and a $12.1 million charge from a provision for loan losses.

title: Woman Says She Put Bomb On a Korean Jet, Killing 115
description: A woman suspected by South Korea of destroying a South Korean airliner with 115 people aboard in November said on television today that she was a North Korean agent and that she and an accomplice had planted a bomb on the plane.

title: City Ballet: 'Chaconne' With Maria Calegari
description: MUSIC was the controlling impulse behind George Balanchine's choreography and two of his works at the New York City Ballet Wednesday night typified how wide-ranging that specific focus could be.

title: Man Held in Jet Crash Hoax
description: A man was arraigned Wednesday on charges that he falsely reported a plane crash that led to a search by 100 people in a snowstorm. The 28-year-old Laconia man, Mark Blair, pleaded not guilty in Laconia District Court on a misdemeanor charge of false public alarm. He was ordered held on $1,000 bail, and a hearing was set for Feb. 3. The report Friday of a downed jet with four people aboard prompted a weekend search that produced no results.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
KEY RATES
SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $3.6 million of expenses in connection with its pending merger with Hartford National Corp.

title: Art: 'Media Post Media,' A Show of 19 Women
description: ''MEDIA POST MEDIA'' is the latest exhibition organized by the independent curators Tricia Collins and Richard Milazzo. Their exhibitions, of which this is at least the eighth in a New York gallery, are well known in the art world as barometers of a sort, or of several sorts. The duo's shows usually manage to indicate important directions in new art while remaining somewhat inconsistent and presenting a number of artists whose prominence will probably not exceed the proverbial 15 minutes. Their current effort, at the Scott Hanson Gallery, is no exception. ''Media Post Media'' is a timely yet mixed bag of the good, the bad and the indifferent.

title: Diner's Journal
description: PARRILLADA is the Spanish term for mixed grill, which in the Argentine tradition ususally means a mini-charcoal barbecue presented at the table and heaped with T-bone steak, marinated skirt steak, morcilla (blood sausage), sweetbreads, kidneys, calf's liver and sausage. At La Fusta, a popular neighborhood Argentine restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, the lusty and well-cooked parrillada (sans kidneys and liver) comes with a jar of chimichurri, a piquant sauce made with garlic, parsley and olive oil. The parrillada is $12.50 a person.

title: Urban League Says Blacks Suffered Loss Over Decade
description: The economic and social status of most black Americans did not significantly improve in the last decade and may actually have worsened, the president of the National Urban League said today.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Reggie Jackson said yesterday that he was considering an offer to play baseball in Japan. Jackson, currently on the Oakland Athletics roster, indicated last season that he was playing for the last time, but never formally announced his retirement. . . . Jerry Rice of the San Francisco 49ers, the wide receiver who set National Football League records of 22 touchdown receptions and at least one in 13 straight games this season, has been voted the Maxwell Football Club's Bert Bell Award as pro player of the year. . . . The Devils have recalled Anders Carlsson and Doug Brown, forwards, from Utica and have sent three other forwards, Andy Brickley, Al Stewart and Chris Cichocki, to that American Hockey League farm team.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Consider Demilitarized Palestinian Democracies; The State of Gaza
description: To the Editor:

title: Randolph S. Brown, Executive, 35
description: Randolph S. Brown, a former vice president and sales director of A.G.B. Television Research, died of histoplasmosis last Dec. 30, according to the executor of his estate, Edward J. Kissko. Mr. Brown was 35 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Consider Demilitarized Palestinian Democracies; Homeland and Home
description: To the Editor:

title: TALMAN HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $5,067,000 and $7,915,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary loss of $2,738,000 and $3,474,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company went public in December 1986.

title: Cuomo, Under Fire, Drops Bid for Supercollider Near Rochester
description: Governor Cuomo has withdrawn a proposal to make Wayne County near Rochester the home of a $4.4 billion atom smasher.

title: Money Funds' 2d-Biggest Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 414 money market mutual funds increased $7.62 billion, to $271.51 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Tar Heels Stop Terrapins
description: Coach Bob Wade and the Maryland Terrapins were reintroduced to the realities of the Atlantic Coast Conference tonight. Riding high after two conference victories and a noticeable recovery from a disastrous 1986-87 season, the Terrapins were brought back to earth by North Carolina.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: Picasso Repainted

title: Steps a la Carte: A Dancegoer's Menu Has Something to Suit Every Taste
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM has frequently compared the art of choreography with the art of cooking. George Balanchine did, too. And if dance-making could be compared to the perfect steaming of a parsnip or the celestial balancing of elements in a blini, then this dance weekend in New York City would be a rugged winter stew with enough meat, vegetables, spices and sauce to fill a kitchen.

title: Stocks Mixed as Caution Persists
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday in a desultory session, as investors again showed caution before today's release of the nation's trade-deficit figures.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Saturday about an award presentation and dinner to honor Luciano Pavarotti omitted the event's location and purpose. It will take place tomorrow at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street, as a benefit for Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera. The ticket information telephone is (212) 722-3207.

title: Judge Quits Myerson Case In a Dispute
description: A Federal judge withdrew yesterday from the pending trial of Bess Myerson because of a bitter dispute with the United States Attorney in Manhattan, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Strike and Boycott Are Urged in Haiti
description: Four leading Haitian politicians called today for a national strike on Saturday and repeated their appeal for a boycott of the election that the army-dominated Government has scheduled for Sunday.

title: Holiday for Dr. King Gaining Wider Observance
description: When Congress approved a Federal holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., many who had fought for passage of the bill privately feared it might produce no more than another three-day weekend. Backers of the holiday also believed it would take years to become widely accepted.

title: Sports People; Tests for Bergeron
description: Michel Bergeron, the coach of the Rangers, will remain at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y., at least until today, the team said yesterday. Bergeron entered the hospital Tuesday night complaining of abdominal pains. A statement said Bergeron had undergone extensive testing in the last two days but the results were inconclusive. Preliminary indications, though, hinted that the problem might be with Bergeron's gall bladder. Phil Esposito, the team's general manager, said that if Bergeron could not return for weekend games against the Canadiens on the road and at home against the Flyers, the Rangers would continue to be run by Wayne Cashman and Charles Thiffault, Bergeron's assistants. Cashman and Thiffault shared coaching duties Wednesday night. ''He sounds like he's not sick,'' Esposito said of Bergeron. ''But we really don't know. We won't until Friday. They have one more test to run.'' Esposito left open the possibility that he would assume the coaching role if Bergeron's illness proved to be lengthy.

title: AIDS Spurs Gifts to Help The Neediest
description: Concern for people suffering from AIDS has inspired many donors to the 76th appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ADVO-SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $515,000. The company said the average shares outstanding as of Dec. 26, 1987, includes 5,347,435 common equivalent shares, which include the assumed conversion of preferred stock and the assumed exercise of options, Advo warrants and Blair warrants.

title: Suspect Is Sought as Molester of 14 Girls in Queens
description: A man with a mustache and a pock-marked face is being sought as a suspect in the molestation of 14 young schoolgirls in separate incidents over the last nine months in Queens, the police said yesterday.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Kenny Barron Quintet

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After pre-tax gains of $126.4 million from the purchase of an annuity contract in settlement of a portion of the company's pension obligations and $25.6 million from the sale of the company's factoring business; results also reflect increases in net interest income, fees for other services and foreign exchange and bond trading activities and a lower provision for loan losses. These factors were partially offset by higher noninterest expenses and lower gains from the sale of investment securities. c-Reflects a $1.1 billion special addition to the allowance for loan losses made in June for loans to countries engaged in debt rescheduling and the $135 million restructuring charge recorded in the third quarter. d-Net income The company said Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc., which merged with the company in May, incurred a fourth quarter loss of $28.8 million. For the 8 months since the merger date, the unit's loss amounted to $122 million, primarily reflecting the $80 million special addition to its allowance for loan losses related to loans to countries engaged in debt rescheduling, higher expenses on foreclosed properties and litigation settlements.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $9.4 million for the quarter and $17.9 million for the 6 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $9.5 million for both the quarter and 6 months. In the year-ago quarter and 6-month periods share earnings were less than 1 cent a share.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Japanese Are Targets Of Arizona Governor
description: Gov. Evan Mecham, who in the past has upset blacks and homosexuals, says Japanese get ''round eyes'' over Arizona's golf courses.

title: Israelis Detain 10 Palestinians Termed Moderates
description: The Israeli authorities detained 10 Palestinians, most regarded as members of the moderate Arab establishment, in a continuing crackdown today as scattered disturbances continued in the occupied territories.

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-cash writedown of about $4.8 million of the carrying value of oil and gas properties in compliance with SEC guidelines.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Sports Pages on Jan. 13 with an article about the N.F.L. playoffs misidentified the Denver Broncos' backup quarterback. He is Gary Kubiak.

title: New Polish Voting Laws Bar Candidates From Opposition
description: The Polish Communist Party today categorically ruled out a role for opposition candidates under new voting laws that the party has vaunted as part of its design for broader democratization of Polish political life.

title: Horner Signs With Cardinals
description: Bob Horner, the former Atlanta Braves infielder who spent last season playing in Japan, reached agreement with the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday on a one-year contract for a base salary of $950,000. He is expected to fill the void created by the Cardinals' loss of Jack Clark as a free agent to the Yankees.

title: Paul E. McKeever, Theologian, 64
description: The Rev. Paul E. McKeever, professor of moral theology at St. John's University and a former editor of The Long Island Catholic, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at the Seminary of the Immaculate Conception in Huntington, L.I., where he lived. He was 64 years old.

title: Film: 'Return Of Living Dead Part II'
description: YOU can't keep a gooey ghoul down. That's the message of ''Return of the Living Dead Part II,'' which revives the creatures who enlivened (that may not be the right word) ''Return of the Living Dead'' but which has nothing to do with George Romero's 1968 cult favorite ''Night of the Living Dead.''

title: U.S. Seeks to Link Gotti Worker To Effort to Tamper With Jurors
description: A Federal prosecutor yesterday tried to tie an investigator who worked for John Gotti and the investigator's attorney to an effort to tamper with a Federal jury in the current racketeering and drug trial of Mr. Gotti's brother Gene and other defendants.

title: Hospitals Lack Beds for Acute Patients, Aide Says
description: The head of New York City's municipal hospitals said yesterday that the overcrowding crisis is so severe that she cannot guarantee there will be enough beds to take in all patients who need medical care.

title: Miller Brewing Fills Position of President
description: Leonard J. Goldstein, senior vice president for sales at the Miller Brewing Company, has been named president and chief executive, succeeding William K. Howell, who took early retirement effective yesterday.

title: A Dry Martini and Double-Nut Mocha
description: LEAD: Ten years ago, if you were told in India that an American was about to visit you and you didn't know what he looked like, you would probably conjure up an image of a large man - ''beefy'' is the word - who wore a baseball cap and ate most of the time. When he was not eating hamburgers, he would chew sugar-coated gum.

title: Results Plus; N.B.A.
description: Bullets 136, Bucks 107: Moses Malone scored a season-high 36 points and grabbed 14 rebounds last night in Landover, Md., leading Washington to a lopsided victory. The Bullets have won all three of their home games since Wes Unseld took over as head coach 12 days ago. Washington broke the game open midway through the third quarter. Over a span of 5 minutes 22 seconds, the Bullets outscored the Bucks, 20-5, opening a 93-74 lead. Malone, who made his first 10 shots in the game, scored 7 points in the burst. Malone's first basket of the game gave him 20,709 points in his 12 seasons in the N.B.A., and moved him past George Gervin into 11th place on the league's career scoring list. He finished the evening at 20,743, 137 behind Bob Pettit in 10th place. Malone is 13th on the combined National Basketball Association-American Basketball Association scoring list with 22,914, trailing Elgin Baylor, No. 12, by 235. The Bullets got 25 points from Bernard King. (AP) Cleveland 91, Chicago 88: Craig Ehlo scored 4 points in overtime and Brad Daugherty added 3 as Cleveland defeated Chicago in Richfield, Ohio. Ehlo sank two foul shots with five seconds remaining to give the Cavaliers the final margin before Michael Jordan's 3-point attempt bounced off the rim with two seconds left. A foul shot by Jordan, who scored 28 points, tied the game, 82-82, with 18 seconds left in regulation time. (AP) N.H.L. Flyers 3, Sabres 1: Dave Brown scored two goals last night in Philadelphia as the Flyers ended Buffalo's six-game winning streak. The Flyers returned to first place in the Patrick Division, 1 point ahead of Washington and the Islanders. Brown's first goal gave the Flyers a 2-1 lead with 1:55 remaining in the first period. He skated the length of the ice and pushed the puck past the fallen goalie, Jacques Cloutier. After a scoreless second period, Brown followed his own shot and beat Cloutier over his gloved hand for a 3-1 lead 56 seconds into the final period. Kjell Samuelsson gave Philadelphia a 1-0 lead at 13:35 of the first period on a slap shot from the right face-off circle. Buffalo tied the game 61 seconds later when Christian Ruuttu knocked a rebound past Ron Hextall. (AP) Figure Skating Witt Captures Title: Katarina Witt of East Germany, skating to ''Carmen,'' won the European women's figure skating championship yesterday in Prague for the sixth consecutive time. Witt tied Sonja Henie's mark of six straight titles by easily winning the long program, worth 50 percent of the total score. Her two top challengers, Kira Ivanova and Anna Kondrashova of the Soviet Union, both fell during their long programs and were second and third for the second consecutive year. Witt landed four triples - two in combinations - in a four-minute program. She earned two perfect marks of 6.0 for artistic impression, and mostly 5.8's and 5.9's, for the routine she hopes will carry her to a second Olympic title next month at Calgary. In other events, Soviet defending champions were leading. Aleksandr Fadeyev led in the men's event after the compulsories, while Natalya Bestemianova and Andrei Bukin led in ice dancing. (AP) Skiing Swiss Wins Downhill: Michela Figini of Switzerland dominated the field to win a World Cup downhill event yesterday in Zinal, Switzerland, leaving Karen Percy of Canada nearly one second behind. Figini, the 1984 Olympic downhill champion, was timed in 1:55.16 minutes for her third victory this season. Percy, who fractured a thumb two weeks ago, finished in 1:56.10 as she turned in her best finish in four World Cup seasons. Petra Kronberger, a 19-year-old Austrian, came in a surprise third in 1:56.39 over the 9,707-foot course. Starting 37th, she edged the defending World Cup champion, Maria Walliser, by 13 one-hundredths of a second. The next nine women finished within one second in a tight battle for World Cup points. Figini pushed her total to 146 points after 15 events. Walliser moved into second with 102 points. Blanca Fernandez-Ochoa of Spain slipped to third with 101. (AP)

title: To Recognize and Treat Dance's Drug Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: VMX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Preston Grover, War Correspondent, 87
description: Preston Grover, who covered World War II in Germany, the Mediterranean and North Africa as a correspondent for The Associated Press, died Monday. He was 87 years old. In a 38-year-career with The A.P., he headed bureaus in New Delhi, Moscow and Paris.

title: Beethoven Society
description: The Beethoven Society will present a program of familiar Beethoven sonatas performed by five pianists -Jacob Lateiner, Ursula Oppens, Seymour Lipkin, Ralph Votapek and Lee Luvisi - tomorrow at 3 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $17.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: Market Place; Why Hoffmann Wants Sterling
description: SOME analysts say there was a lot of ego behind the decision of F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Company to offer $72 a share, or $4.2 billion, to buy Sterling Drug Inc.

title: U.N. Council Again Asks Israelis To Stop Deporting Palestinians
description: With the United States abstaining, the Security Council adopted a second resolution today calling on Israel to cancel plans to deport Palestinians from the occupied territories and allow those already deported to return home. All 14 other Council members voted in favor of the resolution.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Refugees of Nixon Years
description: In a capital in constant flux, the White House staff is one of the least permanent institutions of all, shifting kaleidoscopically with elections, Presidential whims, Government scandals and intramural political coups.

title: Eastern Air to Cut 600 From Its Staff
description: Eastern Airlines said it was eliminating 600 jobs, most of which will affect airport workers, like skycaps, represented by the machinists' union. Eastern's management has been putting pressure on Charles E. Bryan, the leader of the International Brotherhood of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, to accept wage and benefit cuts in a new contract.

title: STOCK EXCHANGE SETS TEST TO CURB PROGRAM TRADING
description: Reacting to criticism that computerized program trading was a major factor behind October's stock market collapse, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday announced a six-day experiment to curb the practice.

title: Gregg Takes S.M.U. Job
description: Forrest Gregg left his head coaching job with the Green Bay Packers today, returned to Southern Methodist University with a $200,000 cut in pay and vowed to rebuild his alma mater's scandal-rocked football program.

title: San Francisco Journal; The Rush These Days Is Hardly for Gold
description: San Francisco can boast of beautiful scenery, crusty sourdough bread and flaky white Dungeness crab, which is now bountiful and in season. But when San Franciscans get together these days, the prime topic of discussion is the difficulty of simply finding a parking space.

title: Judge Says 13 at Newspaper Cannot Be Paid for Overtime
description: A Federal district judge ruled Wednesday that 13 editors and reporters at The Washington Post were artistic professionals and could not invoke the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act.

title: From Ping Chong, a Human Multimedia Bouquet
description: Ping Chong, who has been creating multimedia theater works since the early 70's, has discovered that he returns to certain ideas again and again. ''I remain always interested in the idiosyncrasies of the human race and the themes of time and mortality,'' he said in a recent interview. ''So I keep doing variations on those themes.''

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 13
description: Share earnings for all periods reflect a 4 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 4, 1988.

title: Jes Grew Orchestra
description: Jemeel Moondoc, a saxophonist, is to lead his Jes Grew Orchestra tonight at 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street, at Mulberry Street (219-3055). Admission is $6.

title: Chip Industry Enjoys Surge
description: The United States semiconductor industry closed out the year with a surge as product orders for December reached the highest level in more than three years, industry officials said.

title: A Waldbaum Trader Fined
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Joseph Sierchio, a 36-year-old lawyer from Sea Cliff, L.I., with illegally buying shares of Waldbaum Inc., while possessing non-public information about an impending takeover of the food chain by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in November 1986.

title: Chemical Net Climbs in Quarter
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, the corporate parent of the Chemical Bank, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income more than doubled. Much of the increase, however, resulted from special, one-time factors rather than the company's main operations.

title: No Straight A's for the Law Schools
description: Sometime before the turn of the century, a million lawyers will be practicing in this country. ''To some, that is an awesome thought,'' said Haywood Burns, dean of the City University of New York Law School at Queens College. ''To some, that is an awful thought.''

title: Bid for USG Stalls
description: Two wealthy Texas oilmen, Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, said they had been unable to obtain financing for a hostile takeover of the USG Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the men's investor group, called Desert Partners, said that it had been advised by an unidentified investment banking firm that subordinated debt financing for a hostile bid of USG was impossible ''under current market conditions.''

title: Investor, 23, Charged in $10 Million Fraud
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan yesterday charged a 23-year-old, self-styled money manager with mail fraud, saying he took $10 million from 100 friends and associates to invest in stocks and instead bought himself an art collection, two homes and expensive cars.

title: As Arab Workers Stay Home, The Israeli Economy Suffers
description: The past month of rioting in the occupied territories, which has kept thousands of Palestinians away from jobs in Israel, has been a bitter reminder to Israelis that the country's economy is largely dependent on its political foes.

title: John D. Robilotto, 85, Real Estate Executive
description: John D. Robilotto, a vice president of Helmsley-Spear and a life member of the Real Estate Board of New York, died of heart failure Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 85 years old and a lifelong resident of Manhattan.

title: E.P.A. Critic Enters the Lion's Den And Is Showered by Wild Applause
description: It was as if the Christians led into the Colosseum for slaughter had suddenly turned on the Roman mob, or like Daniel's attacking the lions in the den.

title: STONERIDGE RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: G.S.A. Shifts Employee Tied to Leak
description: The General Services Administration said yesterday that it had reassigned an official suspected of disclosing, in exchange for gratuities, secret bid information about a Government telephone contract.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 15, 1988
description: MARKETS The New York Stock Exchange will curb program trading in a six-day experiment. Reacting to criticism that the enormous computerized trades were a major factor in October's stock market collapse, the exchange asked the firms that engage in it to refrain from using the exchange's computer system on any day when the Dow Jones industrial average climbs or falls by 75 points or more. The firms agreed to the experiment, which starts today. [ Page A1. ] The squall at the New York Merc has begun to subside. The nation's fastest-growing futures exchange dismissed its compliance-division vice president Wednesday, but cleared its chairman of accusations of improper business relationships. [ D1. ] Stock prices were mixed, as investors again showed caution before the release today of the nation's trade-deficit figures. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.62 points, to 1,916.11, but broader market gauges edged higher. [ D4. ] The dollar weakened late in the day, after advancing in Asia and Europe, as dealers awaited the trade figures. Gold rose $6.55 in New York, to $486.35 an ounce. [ D12. ] A late flood of buy orders bolstered crude oil futures and oil-related products, despite reports of widespread price cutting by Middle East producers. [ D12. ] Treasury note and bond prices rose slightly, after trading in a relatively narrow range before the barrage of economic statistics to be announced today. [ D11. ] INTERNATIONAL Higher U.S. interest rates are needed ''to make the dollar an attractive currency,'' a high-level I.M.F. representative said. Japanese-American progress in steadying the dollar will not offset the need to raise rates, said H. Onno Ruding, chairman of the policy-making committee of the 151-nation I.M.F. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Texaco's president wrote a letter to shareholders, urging them to approve an ''anti-greenmail'' provision in the company's charter. [ D1. ] The I.R.S.'s pending $6.5 billion claim against Texaco appears to be similar to those it filed in recent years against Toyota, Nissan and other companies. [ D4. ] Manufacturers Hanover said its net would fall 70 percent in its fourth quarter as a result of costs related to a contraction of its business, aimed at increasing future earnings. The bank also began to lay off 2,500 employees, most of them in New York. [ D1. ] Chemical New York's net income more than doubled in the fourth quarter. But much of the increase resulted from special one-time factors. [ D3. ] Xavier Moreau has disappeared, and is being sought by his partner as well as artists and photographers he represented. Many of them say he made off with their money. [ D1. ] The General Services Administration reassigned an official accused of disclosing secret bid information in exchange for gratuities. A.T.& T. has said the official provided its competitors with information about its bids for Government contracts. [ D1. ] British Petroleum offered $4.13 billion in cash for Britoil, which quickly rejected the bid. Britoil has reached an agreement that allows Arco to buy a partial stake. [ D3. ] Merger talks resumed between United Cable and United Artists Communications. [ D3. ] THE ECONOMY Retail sales rose 0.7 percent in December over the November level, the best performance in four months. But the results were 0.6 percent below those of December 1986. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The British are feeling good about their economy. Growth is high, and inflation is expected to remain low. But there is one big worry beneath the cheer. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Analysts say there was lots of ego behind Hoffmann-La Roche's decision to offer $72 a share, or $4.2 billion, for Sterling Drug. And there were also some solid business reasons. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Administration Calls Law on Aliens Effective
description: The Reagan Administration says the new immigration law is working, as shown by a drop in apprehensions of aliens at the border, by a steady rise in applications for legal status and in broad employer compliance.

title: MNC FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Plastic Tree Bags Are Ecologically Gauche
description: To the Editor:

title: Film: Liza Minnelli in 'Rent-a-Cop'
description: THE cop for rent in ''Rent-a-Cop,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is Burt Reynolds. He is reduced to taking a job as a security guard in a Chicago department store after a $2 million drug bust ends with everybody except him being blown away. It is during the busted bust, which starts things in brisk fashion, that he falls into the arms of Liza Minnelli, a rent-a-girl who was just doing business as usual in a nearby apartment when the bullets started to fly.

title: New York City Doesn't Develop Its Career Managers Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Nissan Official Sees Quota Cut
description: The import quota on Japanese cars will probably be reduced in 1988 as a means of easing trade frictions with the United States, a top official of the Nissan Motor Corporation said today.

title: On Eve of the Peace Parley, Costa Rican Is Pessimistic
description: Looking and sounding extremely somber, President Oscar Arias Sanchez said today that the meeting of Central American leaders here Friday will be a ''very difficult'' negotiating session with no guarantee of success.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain from accounting for leveraged leases brought about by the Tax Reform Act of 1986 of $3,572,000, or 10 cents per primary share outstanding. The bank said provision for loan losses charged to income in the fourth quarter was $5.8 million, up $4.9 million a year ago. Total net charge-offs during the quarter were $9.5 million and included $5.6 million of Latin American loan charge-offs.

title: West End Jazz
description: Harold Ousley, a saxophonist, is to lead a group tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (570-7037). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight, plus a 1:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: Our Towns; Getting the Truth About the Ways Of Streetwalkers
description: How much to believe of what you hear on Broad Street? Police Sgt. Charles Whitner can't say. The prostitutes tell him they make $300 a night on the street, but he always sees them in the same clothes, with the same holes in the same jackets - jackets too thin for the winter's cold.

title: To Foil Haiti's Election Charade
description: LEAD: This Sunday, the army-dominated provisional Government of Haiti will attempt to herd voters to the polls to elect a president under the threat of a $200 fine and imprisonment. The election, assuming it actually takes place, is in violation of the Haitian Constitution passed only last March.

title: Dole Sees Spending Freeze As Centerpiece of Campaign
description: Senator Bob Dole said today that if he was elected President he would propose a one-year spending freeze that would save $150 billion over three years and slash the Federal budget deficit.

title: Judge Bork Is Stepping Down To Answer Critics and Reflect
description: Judge Robert H. Bork will resign from the Federal appeals court here next month, freeing himself to respond to what he says was ''an essentially unanswered campaign of misinformation and political slogans'' that led the Senate to reject his nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: Film: 'Couch Trip,' With Aykroyd and Matthau
description: IN ''The Couch Trip,'' Michael Ritchie's new farce about radio sex therapists and assorted southern California con artists, Walter Matthau plays a comparatively small role, but in the way he looks and behaves he defines the movie's laid-back, ramshackle charm.

title: Plastic Tree Bags Are Ecologically Gauche
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Troubled School Seeks Reassignment
description: The principal of Park West High School, a school in the Clinton section of Manhattan where there has been an unusual amount of violence among students, has asked to be reassigned, according to the Board of Education.

title: Music Before 1800
description: Music Before 1800 will present a concert of viol music on Sunday at 4 P.M. at Corpus Christi Church (121st Street, east of Broadway). Tickets are $9, $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 666-0675.

title: Film: Testing Poses in 'Patti Rocks'
description: BILLY REGIS (Chris Mulkey) is a ladies' man who likes to boast about his exploits, and Eddie (John Jenkins) is the friend who has heard it all. So when the two of them embark on an all-night drive to visit a girlfriend of Billy's in ''Patti Rocks,'' it's a very long journey indeed. Billy describes his sexual adventures in rude, graphic detail; meanwhile, the more sensitive Eddie laments the breakup of his marriage. ''Did your going out on June have anything to do with your splitting up?'' Billy innocently wants to know.

title: Word May Be 'Fraud' For Man Seen on TV
description: A man described as the biggest winner in the history of televison's ''Password'' game show was arrested on fraud charges today by Federal agents when he arrived to pick up his $58,000 prize check, the authorities said.

title: PAPERBOARD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said its latest quarter net includes the operations of recently acquired Belkin Inc.

title: Ford Rebate Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had extended its buyer incentive program, which it began in late October, for another month. It has added the Aerostar van with a $500 rebate, and certain Mustang car models, with a $400 rebate, to an enhanced program that runs through March 8.

title: Sports People; Hall List Gets Shorter
description: Mike Ditka, Al Davis and Bob Griese were among the survivors yesterday when the list of 1988 Pro Football Hall of Fame candidates was cut to 15. Davis, the Los Angeles Raiders' managing general partner, was nominated as a contributor. Other former players nominated were Fred Biletnikoff, Buck Buchanan, Jack Ham, Lee Roy Jordan, Leroy Kelly, Tom Mack, Alan Page, Lou Rymkus, Art Shell and Lynn Swann. George Allen and Bud Grant were nominated as coaches. Seven candidates will be chosen on Jan. 30 and the final results will be announced two days later.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; That Presidential Bug
description: Representative Thomas S. Foley, the House majority leader, insists he is not likely to come down with a case of Presidential fever, even if Democrats try to recruit him for the Presidency.

title: Citadel Makes Bid
description: The Citadel Holding Corporation said it had made a $18.50-a-share, or $107.3 million, offer to buy Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association, the first hostile takeover attempt in California's thrift industry. Valley Federal, based in Van Nuys, Calif., has $3.1 billion in assets and 47 offices. Valley Federal, trying to avert a takeover by Citadel, is talking with other potential merger partners. Analysts believe Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of San Diego, is a likely suitor. Citadel, based in Glendale, Calif., is the parent of Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: United Cable Talks Resume
description: United Artists Communications Inc. and the United Cable Television Corporation said today that they had resumed merger talks.

title: Film: 'El Sur,' From Spain
description: ''EL SUR'' (''The South''), opening today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, is the second feature by Victor Erice, the Spanish director whose first film, ''The Spirit of the Beehive,'' was one of the critical hits of 1976.

title: Plastic Tree Bags Are Ecologically Gauche
description: To the Editor:

title: College Basketball; Late Temple Rally Overcomes La Salle by 59-56
description: Mark Macon, a freshman guard, scored a field goal with 18 seconds remaining tonight to put Temple ahead to stay as the fourth-ranked Owls used a 12-2 rally in the final four minutes to beat La Salle, 59-56.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a special pretax addition of $135 million to the allowance for loan losses. The company said the provision for loan losses in the latest fourth quarter and year were $35 million and $300.8 million, respectively, and $40.5 million for the year-ago fourth quarter and $142 million for the year. The company also said included in the latest year provision for loan losses of $300.8 million is the fourth quarter special addition of $135 million.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Merrill/Norstar Bank, Portland, Me., to Arnold & Company Advertising/Marketing, Boston.
