title: Recruit, Born in a Radio Car, Meets the Midwife (His Boss)
description: Scanning the roster, Lieut. Robert McLaughlin thought there was something familiar about the name of the new recruit from the Police Academy, but he could not quite put his finger on it.

title: Drug Term for an Ex-Mayor
description: Former Mayor Mike Roark, who admitted last year that he had possessed cocaine six times, was sentenced today to 179 days in prison, fined $5,000 and given a three-year suspended sentence.

title: ON STAGE
description: Is It the Last of 'Tango'?

title: SHL SYSTEMHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Advertising; Pen Account For Waring
description: Waring & LaRosa, of the Omnicom Group, is the new ad agency for the Montblanc line of premium writing instruments from West Germany.

title: European Urges U.S. Rate Rise
description: Despite Japanese-American progress in steadying the dollar, higher United States interest rates are needed ''to make the dollar an attractive currency,'' a high-level representative of the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Paine Webber Is Charged
description: The E. F. Hutton Group Inc. and Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. have begun criminal proceedings in Switzerland against Paine Webber Inc. and four of its employees on charges that include stealing client records and brokerage business from Hutton, the investment firms said yesterday.

title: Oreo Thief Gets 3-Year Term
description: A transient has been sentenced to three years in prison after pleading guilty to breaking into a church nursery school and eating Oreo cookies and drinking Kool-Aid, officials said. David Deskin, 25 years old, drew the sentence Tuesday because he was already on probation for another burglary. The Rev. Mike Sutton of the Pearsall Road Baptist Church, angered by repeated break-ins, told prosecutors he was unable to turn the other cheek any longer.

title: Race Is Said to Be a Motive In 2 Incidents Under Inquiry
description: Two incidents in the Bronx in which race is said to be a motive are under investigation, the police said yesterday.

title: Bridge: 2 World Champions Capture Another Title at Tournament
description: Two reigning world champions added to their large collection of titles when the tournament year began Wednesday in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Raphael L. Elias, Lawyer, 82
description: Raphael L. Elias, a lawyer who specialized in probate cases and estate planning, died of cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: Supercollider Plan Dropped Bowing to local opposition, Governor Cuomo has withdrawn a proposal to have Wayne County, N.Y., chosen as the site of a $4.4 billion superconducting supercollider. Page B1. Republican Caucus Protest Michigan's Presidential caucuses were disrupted by walkouts. Aides to Vice President Bush, who did well in the caucuses, blamed Pat Robert-son's followers. Page B4. Where Is Xavier Moreau? Xavier Moreau, a successful fashion photographers' agent, is being sought by photographers and makeup stylists seeking their fees. Page D1.

title: Texaco Case Called Part Of Growing Crackdown
description: The Internal Revenue Service's pending claim against Texaco appears to be similar to those it filed in recent years against other multinational companies, including the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, former Government tax officials said today.

title: Folk Music Trio
description: Huxtable, Christensen and Hood, a folk trio, is to perform tonight at 8 P.M. at Greenwich House, 46 Barrow Street near Bleecker Street, in a concert sponsored by the Pinewoods Folk Club (718-426-8555). Tickets are $8.

title: U.S. Condemns Haiti on Its Plan For Election, Terming It Flawed
description: The Reagan Administration today described the election scheduled for Sunday in Haiti as ''flawed,'' and called on Haiti's Government to prevent violence.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec. 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,400,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $71,411,000. In the latest quarter, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Hanover Bank Sets Big Charge
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would drop by almost 70 percent because of costs related to efforts to make itself a more efficient competitor.

title: Miller Fires Eagle
description: Johnny Miller scored the first eagle of the 1988 PGA Tour today with a shot that brought back memories of his deadly iron play during his winning days in the 1970's. His 8-iron effort of 140 yards at the par-4 13th hole took one short bounce into the hole for a deuce.

title: Town Accepts Plan to Shelter The Homeless
description: The Town of Greenburgh, which embraces several villages in central Westchester County, agreed today to the construction of 108 units of housing for the homeless in a wooded area between a country club and a community college.

title: Mullin Works Out and Then Speaks Out
description: In the early stages of the rest of his life as a recovering alcoholic, Chris Mullin today discussed what he had learned about himself in the past month.

title: Clara Mae Taylor-Olson, Professor, 89
description: Dr. Clara Mae Taylor-Olson, professor emeritus of nutrition at Teachers College, Columbia University, and a leading figure in the field of nutrition education, died after a long illness Jan. 6 in a Pittsburgh hospital. Dr. Taylor-Olson was 89 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 15, 1988
description: International A2-9

title: In Bullish Britain, One Big Worry
description: THE British are feeling good about their economy. The latest official forecast of the Treasury, prepared soon after the October stock market collapse, put the growth rate for the national economy in 1988 at 2.5 percent. Inflation is expected to remain low. And unemployment, still at the high level of 9.4 percent, has come down from 13 percent and is still declining.

title: AT THE BAR
description: It's no longer a big deal when a key partner at a mojor New York law firm changes jobs. But as the fate of Kenneth J. Bialkin unfolded this week, a profession that has almost entirely lost its capacity for suprise or indignation was jolted to attention.

title: About Real Estate; New Life for Jersey Garden Apartments
description: In the center of Teaneck, N.J, stands a cluster of rundown three-story brick apartment buildings optimistically called Teaneck Gardens. It is typical of hundreds of similar garden apartment developments that went up in a hurry in New Jersey shortly after World War II and by now are on the verge of decay.

title: Islanders Beat Nordiques, 8-5
description: For Denis Potvin, his goal meant history. For Randy Wood, his meant the promise of at least a brighter future. In the locker room after the Islanders had outlasted the Quebec Nordiques 8-5, the two stood separated by a handful of stalls and more than a dozen years of National Hockey League experience. It was hard to tell who was enjoying it all more.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly CONVENTION ON ELIMINATION OF RACIAL DISCRIMINATION - 10:30 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.

title: Fund Rise Barred For Use of TPA
description: A Government advisory panel has decided not to recommend a special increase in Medicare reimbursements to hospitals that treat heart attack victims with tissue plasminogen activator, the new drug from Genentech Inc. The decision could discourage some hospitals from using TPA. Under Medicare rules, hospitals receive a set payment for a particular disease. TPA, which dissolves blood clots that can cause heart attacks, costs $2,200 per treatment so that hospitals are bound to lose money if they use it for Medicare patients.

title: Met Menagerie Tour With Steve Martin
description: IF you've seen the comedian Steve Martin as a modern-day Cyrano de Bergerac in the film ''Roxanne'' or the bedeviled traveler in ''Planes, Trains and Automobiles,'' you might want to catch his more serious side at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Steve Martin, at the Met, you say? Correct. Mr. Martin is narrator of an audio tour of ''Animals at the Met,'' which, in a sense, is a special exhibition of permanent works from the museum's collection that runs through Feb. 21.

title: Bonn Inquiry Hints Pakistan And Libya Got Atom Material
description: The West German Environment Minister said today that a widening investigation into illegal cross-border transportation of nuclear wastes by a West German company has raised the possibility that nuclear materials may have found their way to Pakistan and Libya.

title: Texaco Is Urging Approval Of an 'Anti-Greenmail' Plan
description: Apparently fearing a takeover threat, Texaco's president and chief executive is recommending that shareholders approve an ''anti-greenmail'' provision in the company's charter.

title: Australian Open; Lendl Gains Easily
description: Ivan Lendl overwhelmed Mark Woodforde of Australia, 6-4, 6-3, 6-1, today to advance to the fourth round of the $1.9 million Australian Open Tennis Championships.

title: U.P.I. Accuses 3 Ex-Top Editors Of Defamation
description: United Press International filed a lawsuit charging defamation and breach of contract Wednesday against three former top editors who left the news agency last November after saying they could not assure its ''quality and integrity.''

title: Emergency Rooms: The New Wards
description: On a recent evening at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, a woman who had undergone heart bypass surgery and had been readmitted with chest pain asked her doctor how long she must remain in the hospital's emergency room. ''Awhile,'' he answered. ''What you call awhile?'' she shot back. ''Awhile,'' it turned out, might mean five days, depending on how quickly beds became available in the hospital's intensive care or cardiac units.

title: Consider Demilitarized Palestinian Democracies; Sharon's Move
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TO WITHDRAW 72 JET FIGHTERS FROM SPANISH BASE
description: The United States, after months of negotiations with Spain, has decided to accede to Spanish demands and withdraw 72 F-16 jet fighters based there, Defense and State Department officials said today.

title: The New Afghan Struggle
description: The Afghan resistance movement has achieved one historic victory and is fighting hard for another.

title: Kidder, Peabody Is V.A.'s Adviser
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company has been named financial adviser to the Veterans Administration, which plans to sell an undisclosed amount of home mortgage loans from its portfolio this year.

title: Rock Songwriters
description: Richard Lloyd and Elliot Murphy, two rock songwriters, are playing a double bill Saturday at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M. at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street at Mercer Street. Tickets are $12.50.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Sweets Edison and Trio

title: Canadians Rally Over Team USA
description: The United States Olympic hockey team's 11-game unbeaten streak, cultivated in weeks of confrontation with lesser opponents, ended tonight at the Met Center with a 6-4 loss to the Americans' rugged Canadian counterparts.

title: Sports People; Floyd Fined, Suspended
description: Eric (Sleepy) Floyd of the Houston Rockets was suspended for one game and fined $5,000 for his part in a fight Wednesday night with Jeff Hornacek of the Phoenix Suns, the league announced last night. Floyd sat out Houston's 103-98 victory over Portland as part of his punishment. Floyd's suspension and fine was issued by Rod Thorn, the leauge's vice president of operations. Floyd was cited for ''instigating the initial confrontation and then, after the players had been separated, twice renewing the altercation.'' Hornacek was fined $1,500 for throwing a punch and chasing after Floyd, actions that prolonged the incident. Walter Davis and James Bailey of the Suns were fined $500 each for leaving the bench area during the incident.

title: 2 Events at Met Museum
description: Elaborate historical analogies that elucidate the past while referring to the present have been a popular pastime of historians and pundits for centuries. One of the best-loved epochs for such scholarly musings has been that of the Roman Empire, from the time of its greatest grandeur 2,000 years ago to its subsequent decline. Marlene Barasch, an art historian, will discuss ''Life Styles of the Rich and Famous in Ancient Rome'' in a slide lecture, Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Ms. Barasch's talk will explore everything from architecture and statuary to the prominent personalities, foods, hair styles and other aspects of everyday life in the generations before Vesuvius erupted in A.D. 79.

title: Mob Trial Witness Who Recanted Gets Suspended Sentence
description: A former mob hit man who recanted his testimony in a key Mafia trial and then said he was coerced into doing so was spared a prison sentence yesterday for obstruction of justice.

title: Nets Put Distractions Aside
description: The Nets came up with one of their rare victories tonight, defeating the Sacramento Kings, 90-87, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The victory was their seventh in 36 games this season.

title: Consider Demilitarized Palestinian Democracies
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out Guide: With Fireplaces
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARIZONA 206, 206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - **(Nov. 15, 1985) The ultimate winter fantasy is to dine near a fireplace, and finding such a setting in the city is a search worthy of any explorer. The glowing hearth at this narrow East Side restaurant is only one reason to stop by. Virtually all the recipes demonstrate how appealing California- and Southwestern-style cooking can be. Appetizers include flour tortilla with crab meat and salsa verde and goat cheese ravioli with Anaheim and ancho chili sauces. Main-course options are chili-rubbed chicken with sauteed broccoli rabe; chile relleno with sauteed pork adobado, and grilled swordfish with chayote tomatillo. Dinner entrees $19 to $23. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays, 6 to 11 P.M. BLACK SHEEP, 344 West 11th Street (242-1010) - *(April 22, 1983) The pleasantly romantic atmosphere of this convivial bistro is enhanced by the lace curtains and fireplace. The kitchen style can be best described as country cooking from France. To start, you might choose the country pate made of chicken, pork and liver, or a seasonal soup. Entree options include duckling cooked two ways: the leg is braised with Armagnac and the boneless breast is grilled; marinated and grilled leg of lamb with herbs, and Norwegian salmon fillet steamed and served over noodles with smoked salmon, dill and cream sauce. Five-course prix-fixe dinner $23 to $31, depending on entree. Fridays through Sundays, 6 P.M. to midnight. DEVON HOUSE, 1316 Madison Avenue, at 93d Street (860-8294) - **(May 24, 1985) A century-old fireplace graces one of the formal dining rooms at this patrician East Side restaurant. The food is essentially Continental with a dash of West Indian salsa sprinkled in. You might start with escargot in garlic-tinged cream sauce or a soup of leeks, lettuce and spinach in chicken broth. For a main dish, options include broiled fillet of salmon, marinated and braised in stock, white wine and Jamaican peppers; roasted baby pheasant with red wine sauce and sage, and filet of beef in a zippy Pickapeppa sauce with green peppercorns. Entrees $24.50 to $29.50. Fridays through Sundays, 6 to 11 P.M. JANE STREET SEAFOOD CAFE, 31 Eighth Avenue, at Jane Street (243-9237) - *(May 8, 1987) A working fireplace and brick and natural wood walls provide the backdrop at this sleeves-up fish house. Better appetizers are the brittle fried zucchini sticks and succulent steamed littleneck clams. For a main dish, you can usually rely on the crispy golden-brown fried fillet of sole and the poached fillet of king salmon with a mild dill sauce. Also recommended is a frequent special called sole Portuguese, which is a fillet served atop a crest of garlic-loaded tomatoes and mushrooms. Entrees $11.95 to $20. Fridays and Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 4 to 10 P.M. RENE PUJOL, 321 West 51st Street (246-3023) - *(Sept. 26, 1986) One of the few surviving family-run French restaurants in the theater district is this one with its stucco and timber dining rooms and working fireplace. For starters, the duck terrine is rustic and tasty; and you can't go wrong with the intense old-fashioned onion soup. For an entree, you might choose rack of lamb with pan juices and assorted tiny vegetables; pink sauteed veal kidneys in red wine sauce, or Dover sole meuniere. Five-course prix-fixe dinner $26 to $30, depending on entree. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. What the stars mean, page C2O.

title: The Monthly Announcement That Makes Wall St. Sweat
description: At 8:30 A.M. Friday, or a split second later, a number representing the deficit in the nation's trade for November will flash across news-service terminals from Wall Street to Tokyo. While other Government statistics have had their heyday, the trade figure is clearly the number to watch these days.

title: Stage: By A. R. Gurney, 'Another Antigone'
description: SOMEWHERE - even if it's only Hollywood - there must be a school where all the teachers are as inspiring as Mr. Chips, Miss Brooks, Miss Jean Brodie, Professor Kingsley and those other lovable fictional educators who lecture so often on screen or stage but somehow always seem to be on sabbatical in real life. If so, that institution should offer a tenured post to Henry Harper, the classics professor who is the hero of ''Another Antigone,'' the new play by A. R. Gurney Jr. at Playwrights Horizons. In the delightful performance of George Grizzard, Harper is crusty yet passionate about learning, a determined foe of academic fads and inflated grades, a mesmerizing lecturer who can make throwaway jokes about the Bacchae. In the age of word processors and punk rock, Harper is a true defender of Western civilization - and he wears bow ties, too.

title: Music: An Andre Watts Celebration
description: CAN it really be a quarter of a century since a 16-year-old pianist named Andre Watts made his spectacular debut with the New York Philharmonic as the substitute for an ailing Glenn Gould? Evidently so, for there was Mr. Watts striding onto the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night to mark the silver anniversary of that celebrated event. This time the conductor happened to be Zubin Mehta, not Leonard Bernstein, but the music on the orchestra stands was the same: Liszt's Concerto No. 1 in B flat, by now virtually a signature tune for Mr. Watts.

title: First Amendment Lessons
description: The Supreme Court has upheld in broadest terms the power of public school authorities to control the content of high school newspapers. Now just about any educational reason will justify heavy editing and outright exclusion of student articles. The Court reaffirms its 1969 decision that students may not be punished for non-disruptive political expression, like wearing black armbands in school to protest the Vietnam War. But it holds that those First Amendment rights do not require a school to publish whatever a student journalist writes.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Corrections
description: A chart on the Education page on Wednesday carried incorrect tuition figures provided by the State University of New York at Binghamton. The figures shown were for a semester; yearly tuition is $1,350 for state residents and $3,200 for nonresidents.

title: China Is Going To the Olympics
description: Three days before the deadline, China announced today that it would send a team to the Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea.

title: An Artists' Agent Who Left by Night
description: Most of the photographers and fashion stylists whom Xavier Moreau represented had already quit his agency. There had been lawsuits against his company, with more threatened. And months ago, he had suddenly moved out of his Sutton Place town house.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Cellular Communications Inc. said it would begin a tender offer for up to 4.5 milion shares of common stock of American Cellular Network Corp. at a price of $15.50 a share, representing about 51 percent of the outstanding shares on a fully diluted basis.

title: Film: 'For Keeps,' on Teen-Age Pregnancy
description: THERE was a time when unwanted teen-age pregnancy meant missing the senior prom, to say the very least. It was more of an inconvenience than it is in the thoroughly modern ''For Keeps,'' which stars Molly Ringwald as a bright young mother-to-be. The problems created by adolescent pregnancy and early marriage are indeed set forth here, sometimes with the appearance of great candor. But in the final analysis, they are handled with all too remarkable ease. Its subject is nominally daring, but in spite of that, ''For Keeps'' proceeds with an amazing degree of caution.

title: Walkouts Disrupt Republican Caucuses in Michigan
description: Michigan's Republican caucuses, the first of the 1988 Presidential campaign, were disrupted tonight by delegate walkouts, and the campaign of Vice President Bush charged that followers of Pat Robertson tried to confuse the process to deny Mr. Bush a victory.

title: NATO May Meet Before Reagan Soviet Trip
description: Western officials are considering plans for a rare meeting of NATO leaders to review Western policy toward the Soviet Union and to demonstrate the alliance's solidarity before President Reagan visits Moscow this spring.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PSEUDO-SCIENCE AND SOCIETY IN 19TH-CENTURY AMERICA. Edited by Arthur Wrobel. 245 pages. The University Press of Kentucky. $24.

title: Guggenheim Expansion Plan Upheld
description: After a lively, standing-room-only hearing at City Hall, the Board of Estimate yesterday voted 8 to 3 to uphold a lower city agency's decision to approve a plan by the Guggenheim Museum to build a 10-story addition to its building at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Old Masters Sale Produces Mixed Results at Sotheby's
description: The Old Master paintings owned by Linda and Gerald Guterman, described as the most valuable such selection ever auctioned in New York, brought mixed results in a record-breaking sale yesterday morning at Sotheby's.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $33.9 million, a gain of $50.7 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change, restructuring charges of $23.3 million, and a $48 million loss provision for sale of Pacific Appliance operations.

title: SYNCOR INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Corrections
description: The headline yesterday on an article about Governor Cuomo's proposed budget misstated the plan for tax cuts. The budget would put into effect tax cuts agreed to last year. It does not include further cuts.

title: A Rival for the Space Palace
description: The space station NASA wants to build is a luxury sky hotel with a sky-high price tag, now at $32 billion. Congress has at last decreed that the agency should also consider supporting a much smaller, privately operated space station that costs a mere $700 million and can do many of the same things. NASA seems petrified that Congress may next wonder why it needs a palace in space if a mobile home would do nearly as well.

title:
THE BASIC SPEECH: Alexander M. Haig Jr.;
'We Must Become an America of Excellence, an America That Does Well'
description: LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: Holiday Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only; offices are open in Manhattan at 25 Broadway, 90 Church St., 909 3d Ave., Grand Central Terminal, 33d St. and 8th Ave., 73 Pine St., 1384 Broadway, and 610 5th Ave. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular collections. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. Libraries: New York Public Library, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule; minor adjustments during rush hour. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven Line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Army Sergeant Is Arrested on Espionage Charges
description: An Army instructor at a major weapon-testing center was arrested today on espionage charges and accused of attempting to sell military documents to the Soviet Union, Federal law-enforcement officials said.

title: Then Turned Into Now But 60's Music Lives On
description: TWO decades after the fact, the 1960's really have a hold on us. We're surrounded by its images and echoes, in a wash of revisionism and nostalgia. Historians and film makers try to sort out the Vietnam War; academics defend or disparage 60's ideas. Television characters sling 60's references to prove they're fun-loving folks; fashion plates wear tie-dye and mini-skirts.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Odds Shift for Florida Tracks
description: From all the fuss here Tuesday, one would think that the Fountain of Youth had been rediscovered, or at least that an extraterrestrial had arrived.

title: TODD-AG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
C.P.A. Lawsuit Is Ruled Moot
description: A judge in New York State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a lawsuit by a group of accountants to block a tally of votes on proposed rules changes by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants was moot since the institute had already counted the votes. But the judge, Irma Vidal

title: 2 Students in New York Wounded by Gunfire
description: Two New York City students were injured, one critically, by gunfire yesterday in incidents at the schools, the police said.

title: A Pen Breathes Revenge; Stalin Is Steeped in Evil
description: Less than two months after Mikhail S. Gorbachev delivered his official verdict on Stalin, Mikhail F. Shatrov made it clear the Soviet leader would not have the last word on the subject.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Lee Teng-hui; Taiwan's Leader and Son of the Soil
description: There is little dispute here that Taiwan's new President, Lee Teng-hui, is a man of sincerity and scholarship, a soft-edged man who associates say virtually exudes moral rectitude. But there is a question about whether those exemplary attributes will be enough to keep him in office for long.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Key Salomon Officer Retires to Join Lazard
description: LEAD: In the latest of a series of setbacks for Salomon Brothers, J. Ira Harris said yesterday that he would retire as senior executive managing director to join the rival Lazard Freres & Company as a general partner.

title: University Given $20 Million By Perot for Medical Studies
description: The University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas, one of the most respected medical schools in the nation, said today that it was receiving a $20 million gift from H. Ross Perot, the Texas businessman, to support its Nobel Prize-winning cholesterol research and to train medical scientists.

title: Irving A. Greene, Securities Executive, 89
description: Irving A. Greene, a Wall Street executive who worked in the securities industry for 75 years, died Tuesday in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Tunesmith's '50 Years' Of Music
description: ANYONE who has seen the movie ''Broadcast News'' is not likely to forget a nutty cameo featuring a pair of eager-beaver jingle writers auditioning their John Williams-ish ''evening news'' theme for a major network news department. Amid office chaos, the unflappable duo, waving their arms and la-la-la-ing, present their theme song like the set piece from a comic operetta.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Job for Bullhorn and Bat
description: If the Board of Education in Paterson, N.J., is unhappy with Joe Clark, the school principal who maintains order with a bullhorn and a baseball bat, there could be a place for him in the Reagan White House. Gary Bauer, Assistant to the President for Policy Development, has invited him to Washington to see if he wants a job. ''Maybe we could take him with us up to the Hill,'' a White House official quipped. The New Jersey school board is not happy with Mr. Clark's tendency to expel students he has described as ''leeches, miscreants and hoodlums.'' Whether he'll find any miscreants or hoodlums during a White House assign-ment is probably a function of political interpretatin, and timing.

title: Advertising; Enhancing A Bank's L.I. Image
description: THE European American Bank, which was doing its own advertising, felt that its name didn't go with the image it wanted. It doesn't really sound like Long Island's leading bank.

title: AUCTIONS
description: The Americana auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's every January are traditionally the largest and most important such sales of the year, and 1988 looks like it will be no exception, with Christie's presenting more than 400 works and Sotheby's about 2,000.

title: Playoff Matchups; Strike Didn't Destroy Harmony
description: If good intentions helped, the Giants would be defending their National Football Conference championship Sunday and not watching the Washington Redskins and the Minnesota Vikings play for it.

title: Some Details Emerge On Squall at the Merc
description: As the storm at the New York Mercantile Exchange began to subside yesterday, details emerged about the charges leveled against two of its highest officials.

title: STATE-O-MAINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Two Paul Taylor Works on 'Dance in America'
description: IT'S difficult to tell who is getting better, Paul Taylor or the people in charge of ''Dance in America.'' Probably both. In any event, Mr. Taylor is returning to the public-television showcase for the fifth time since 1978, and his choreography has never been seen to better advantage on a television screen. ''Paul Taylor: 'Roses' and 'Last Look' '' is being broadcast tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13 as a ''Great Performances'' presentation.

title: 2 Witnesses Challenge Henri Filion Testimony
description: Henri Filion's claims of innocence about having any knowledge about tampering involving a race at Yonkers Raceway last Nov. 14 were challenged yesterday in the final day of hearings before the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: Jose Zacarias Arza, Ex-Paraguay Official, 93
description: Jose Zacarias Arza, former president of Paraguay's ruling Colorado Party, died Tuesday. He was 93 years old.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Chamber Music Society
description: The Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society will perform the premiere of Peter Lieberson's ''Ziji'' tomorrow at 6 P.M. at the Paula Cooper Gallery (155 Wooster Street) and Sunday at 5 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. The program also includes works by Mozart and Brahms. Tickets are $8 for tomorrow's performance, $18 for the Sunday concert. Information: 874-6770.

title: Consider Demilitarized Palestinian Democracies; Holy Places
description: To the Editor:

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
B.P. Bids for Britoil, But Offer Is Rejected
description: Despite major obstacles, the British Petroleum Company formally offered $:2.27 billion in cash today for Britoil P.L.C., which quickly rejected the bid.

title: Japanese Scientist Will Head World Health Organization
description: A Japanese specialist in psychopharmacology, Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, was elected today to be Director General of the World Health Organization.

title: G.M. Ratings Cut
description: Long-term debt ratings of the General Motors Corporation were reduced by Moody's Investors Service yesterday. For senior debt issues of G.M. and its financing unit, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the new Moody's rating is Aa-3, down from Aa-1. The lower rating also applies to various securities backed by pools of automobile loans, for which G.M. provides a limited guarantee. The subordinated debt of G.M.A.C. is reduced to A-1, from Aa-2.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Suffolk Man Indicted In Slaying of His Wife
description: A grand jury indicted Matthew Solomon today on a murder charge in connection with the strangling of his bride of two months, the District Attorney said.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY A PLAGUE ON OUR HOUSE

title: Malcolm Reybold, 77, Writer and Executive
description: Malcolm Reybold, an author and retired advertising executive, died Jan. 7 in Glen Cove Community Hospital on Long Island. He was 77 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As a sitting judge on a very busy court, I cannot devote the time and energy I wish to public discourse.'' - Judge Robert H. Bork, resigning from the bench. [ A1:4. ]

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Sniffing Out Terrorists
description: The State Department has found a new tool to combat terrorists: a dishwasher-size explosives detector called the EGIS Mark II that will be installed in all United States embassies next fall.

title: Film: Lahti in 'Stacking'
description: ''STACKING,'' opening today at the Public Theater, is somewhat better than its title, which evokes nothing before one has seen the movie and not much more after. It refers to the operation by which bales of hay are collected and stacked together in one part of the field with the use of a large, tractorlike vehicle equipped with a forked scoop.

title: Riding the Black Market to Development
description: The black market, long thought the enemy of third world economies, may instead indicate their surest path to development. So argues Hernando de Soto, an iconoclastic Peruvian economist whose ideas have begun to attract interest in Latin America and beyond.

title: Key Dole Aide Leaves to Calm Queries on Fund
description: The national finance chairman of Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign stepped aside today as Mr. Dole sought to distance himself from the growing political controversy over the aide's financial dealings with his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title: On Legal Call to Meet Medical Emergencies
description: The emergency room is a familiar place in any hospital: doctors, nurses, patients in acute need, medical crises competing for attention. But medical emergencies can easily become legal emergencies, and then it is lawyers and a judge, along with the medical experts, who rush to another kind of emergency room.

title: How About Verification?
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Saturday about the annual Ascap Musical Theater Workshop identified the sponsoring organization incompletely. It is the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, the musical licensing organization.

title: INSIDE
description: Cuba Says No to Olympics

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about observances for the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. misattributed a quotation about the level of participation by white Americans. The statement was by Lloyd Davis, executive director of the King Federal Holiday Commission, not by Alan Jackson, its deputy director.

title: RADIANT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $40,000. c-Net loss and includes income from discontinued operations of $175,000.

title: O'Sullivan Won't Retire
description: One week after a lopsided defeat for the vacant North American Boxing Federation welterweight title, Shawn O'Sullivan ended speculation that he might end his boxing career by announcing yesterday that he would continue with a new sense of commitment. ''There's no debate in my mind, I will not retire,'' O'Sullivan said at a news conference in Toronto. ''I take full responsibility for what I guess would be classified as a very poor performance in Las Vegas one week ago. I think my ability to concentrate and remain hungry possibly have dwindled. It's my job to find that again.'' O'Sullivan, 25 years old, was stopped in the 11th round by Luis Santana, only the second loss in 19 professional bouts for the Toronto fighter.

title: 'Crazy Horse' Author Is Upheld in Libel Case
description: A Federal District Court in Minnesota has dismissed a four-year-old libel suit brought against Peter Matthiessen, author of ''In the Spirit of Crazy Horse,'' and his publisher, Viking Penguin. The ruling, which is subject to appeal, upholds the right of an author ''to publish an entirely one-sided view of people and events.''

title: Political Marketing; Cable TV Is Becoming an Integral Player in Advertising Strategies for 1988
description: Political operatives are making cable television an integral part of their advertising strategy for the first time in a Presidential race. They are buying spots on cable for their candidates and exploring other ways of using the nation's 5,000 cable television systems.

title: Frederic Karoly, 95, Abstract Painter, Dies
description: Frederic Karoly, a painter whose abstract oils are in the collection of the Metropolitan, the Guggenheim and the Whitney museums, died on Dec. 15 at the Inter-Continental Hotel in Manhattan, where he had made his home for many years. He was 95 years old.

title: Concert: Philharmonic Plays Reich
description: Commissioned by the San Francisco Symphony, Steve Reich's latest orchestral score, ''The Four Sections,'' was first performed by that orchestra in October. Kent Nagano led the New York premiere with the Brooklyn Philharmonic the following month, and now Zubin Mehta is conducting the score for the current round of New York Philharmonic subscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall. This reviewer heard it yesterday afternoon, and repeat performances are scheduled for tonight and Tuesday night.

title: Abercrombie Chain Bought
description: The Limited Inc., the diversified chain of women's apparel stores, and Oshman's Sporting Goods said yesterday that the Limited had agreed to buy the Abercrombie & Fitch division of Oshman's for $47 million in cash.

title: TV: 'Pulaski,' on A&E, New Detective Series
description: Pay attention. This gets complicated. ''Pulaski: The TV Detective'' is an eight-episode BBC series that starts tonight at 10 o'clock on the Arts & Entertainment Network. It is about a character named Larry Summers, an American actor who plays the title role in a British action series called ''Pulaski.''

title: Strike Disrupts Ports in Northwest
description: A 38-hour work stoppage by 3,800 longshoremen that shut down docks in all ports of the Pacific Northwest ended today, but labor leaders hinted of further disruptions in the coming weeks.

title: ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said its 1987 results reflect a $946,188 writedown of an investment and loans to a subsidiary which are now deemed unrecoverable.

title: Let The New York Post Survive...
description: LEAD: It will be unfortunate if the dispute over Rupert Murdoch's efforts to hold on to both his television stations and his newspapers in New York and Boston is seen as a battle of titans: Mr. Murdoch, the media mogul, vs. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who is out to settle old scores with Mr. Murdoch.

title: Leader of Army Revolt Escapes in Argentina
description: The leader of an army revolt last April that threatened Argentina's democratic Government escaped from house arrest today, shortly before he was to be taken to jail, officials said.

title: STATE O' MAINE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Bridge; Four Groups Capture Titles In Tri-State Regional Event
description: Four championships were decided Thursday, on the second day of play in the Tri-State Regional Championships in Port Chester, N.Y. The winners of titles were: Men's teams - Miles Storfer of Jamaica, Queens, Irving Ingwer of Brooklyn, Dave Greenwald of Manhattan, and Gene Prosnitz of Brooklyn.

title: Soviet Pressing Limits on 'Star Wars' Tests
description: Soviet officials presented a formal proposal today underscoring Moscow's refusal to reduce long-range nuclear arms unless the United States agrees to strict limits on the scope of ''Star Wars'' tests.

title: Agent Surrenders
description: Jim Abernethy, a former Atlanta sports agent, turned himself in to Alabama authorities Thursday on misdemeanor charges stemming from his admitted payments to an Auburn defensive back, Kevin Porter. Abernethy was released on a $1,000 cash bond after he was booked at the Lee County Jail in Opelika, Ala. State Attorney General Don Siegelman said that Abernethy was indicted by a Lee County grand jury on misdemeanor counts of tampering with a sports event, violating the deceptive practices act and commercial bribery. Each count carries a maximum sentence of one year in jail. Annette Hardy, a clerk with the Lee County Circuit Court, said Abernethy would be arraigned Friday, with a trial set for Feb. 29. Abernethy disclosed in December that he made monthly payments to Porter, a senior who was declared ineligible for the Sugar Bowl for violating the rules against dealings with agents. Abernethy, who says he is no longer an agent, is believed to be the first person indicted for dealing with a college athlete as a professional agent.

title: DATA MED CLINICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago 9-month loss reflects results after the company's inception Feb. 6, 1986, and the revenue reflects only sales recorded after the May 22, 1986, acquisition of assets of a predecessor company.

title: Novel Promotion Idea: Letting a Movie Sell Itself
description: How do you sell a movie with no major stars, no car chases, a bland title, articulate characters who can't stop talking and a heroine who won't sleep with the leading man because she doesn't like his ethics?

title: Luck Runs Out for a Winner As TV Publicity Boomerangs
description: Kerry Ketchem may have won the biggest one-game prize in the history of television's ''Super Password,'' but it paled in comparison with a string of illegal jackpots he has scored in recent years, authorities across the country said today.

title: GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an accounting change credit of $7,212,000.

title: Your Money; Franchises Offer Profits and Risks
description: JAMES Goodman, executive vice president of the Morehouse School of Medicine in Atlanta, recently decided to leave his position and go into franchising. So he bought the Seattle-area rights to open franchises of Jiffy Lube International Inc., a fast oil-change and lubrication system for automobiles.

title: SUNSTAR FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Includes a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $295,000 for the latest quarter and includes for the year-ago period a loss from discontinued operations of $28,000.

title: Inventories Jumped 0.8% In November
description: Business inventories jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the second big monthly increase, while total sales fell, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Producer Prices Post 0.3% Drop
description: Prices at the producer level declined three-tenths of 1 percent in December, reflecting new rounds of automobile rebates and lower oil prices, the Labor Department said today.

title: PRIVATE BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company changed its fiscal year from Sept. 30 to a calendar year.

title: Broncos Lose Johnson
description: Vance Johnson, the Broncos' leading wide receiver and an extraordinary playoff performer, will miss the American Conference championship game on Sunday against the Browns.

title: U.S. and Spain Announce a Limited Military Accord
description: The United States and Spain announced new military arrangements today that would sharply curtail the American presence here and terminate American aid to Spain under the existing 35-year-old treaty between the two countries.

title: Newark Bill on Testing Of Prostitutes Is Vetoed
description: Mayor Sharpe James today vetoed a city ordinance that would have required convicted prostitutes and their customers to be tested for AIDS, saying it was unconstitutional.

title: Gooden Files for Arbitration
description: Dwight Gooden of the Mets, Eric Davis of Cincinnati and George Bell of Toronto, the American League's most valuable player, were among 104 players who submitted their names for arbitration yesterday and could have their 1988 salaries determined by an arbitrator.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, the ''Moscow Journal'' article yesterday about the Soviet political playwright Mikhail F. Shatrov omitted a paragraph in some editions. The paragraph, 12th from the end, at the top of the last column, should have read:

title: Coping: With Self-Help Books
description: For every New Year's resolution, there now seems to be a companion book. Feeling blue? ''Letting Go'' promises, on its jacket, to help readers ''erase painful memories'' within three months. Shy? ''Stand Up! Speak Out! Talk Back!'' has, the jacket states, ''liberated thousands from anger, guilt and self-denial.'' Forgetful? ''Optimum Brain Power'' says it provides ''a total program for increasing your intelligence.'' Sexual problems? ''Supermarital Sex'' promises to help readers ''achieve the ultimate intimacy with your mate.''

title: FIRST TEAM SPORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
About New York; A Man's Career: Opening the Door At 1125 Park Ave.
description: Sixty years ago today, Paul Wallahora, then a 16-year-old high school dropout, was prowling the Upper East Side looking for a job. He found one and never let it go. He has spent his life opening and shutting the door at 1125 Park Avenue.

title: Wells Fargo to Buy Barclays in California
description: Wells Fargo & Company said today that it had agreed to acquire Barclays Bank of California for about $125 million in cash. A subsidiary of the London-based Barclays Bank P.L.C., Barclays Bank of California is the 17th-largest bank in the state, with 1987 year-end assets of about $1.3 billion.

title: Bergeron Released
description: Three days after he checked himself into a New York hospital complaining of stomach pains, Coach Michel Bergeron of the Rangers was released yesterday after undergoing a final examination. Bergeron promptly flew to join the team in Montreal and planned on coaching when the Rangers play the Canadiens at the Forum tonight. ''I had wanted to go behind the bench for the game with Detroit,'' said Bergeron, referring to the 7-4 loss to the Red Wings Wednesday. ''The doctors weren't too happy with that idea. But this morning, they all had a meeting and said I could go. I figured I'd better get back to work.'' Bergeron said he was diagnosed as suffering from problems with his gallbladder. He said doctors at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y., informed him that it was likely his gallbladder would have to be removed. ''It could be one week, it could be two,'' Bergeron said. ''It could be 10 years.'' He said he was ordered to give up cigarettes and coffee. . . . The Rangers will take on the Canadiens without either the injured Marcel Dionne or Ron Duguay, but will have the services of David Shaw, a defenseman who missed the last two periods against the Red Wings with a bruised foot.

title: Dollar Posts Big Rise; Gold Slumps
description: Bolstered by a stronger-than-expected trade report, the dollar's value surged yesterday to its highest level in about two months.

title: ROSS, A.J., LOGISTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Stage: Ping Chong's View Of History in 'Maraya'
description: In theater, Ping Chong discovers the same kind of freedom of abstraction that others utilize in dance, music and the visual arts, all of which are inextricably intertwined in his innovative work. His new performance piece, ''Maraya - Acts of Nature in Geological Time'' (at the Apple Corp Theater), is a mysterious investigation of world history, as studied on Mr. Chong's private timeline. The play is also, one might add, an exercise in theatrical archeology, revealing layers beneath layers.

title: Knicks Fall to 1-15 on Road
description: The Knicks suffered a second-half collapse tonight on the way to their 10th consecutive loss on the road, a 119-104 decision against the Philadelphia 76ers. New York had played an outstanding first half at the Spectrum, leading by as many as 13 points, and holding a 58-50 lead at the half. Then came the third period.

title: Muller Scores 3 Goals Again
description: Kirk Muller drew the penalties and capitalized during the manpower advantages tonight in leading the Devils with three goals to a 7-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Raimondo Manzini, Editor, 86
description: Raimondo Manzini, editor of the Vatican daily L'Osservatore Romano for 18 years and a former member of parliament, died Thursday. He was 86 years old.

title: STATUS GAME reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,746,101 and $3,096,909 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Pop: Culture, Rockers Reggae Band
description: The raw-edged lead vocals of Joseph Hill, melodies like pop hymns and lyrics that meld current observations with biblical prophecies made Culture one of the most important Jamaican reggae bands of the late 1970's. Its first LP, ''Two Sevens Clash'' from 1976, is a landmark reggae album that helped shape steadfast, mid-tempo ''rockers'' reggae. The original vocal trio disbanded in 1981, but reunited in 1986; its current United States tour brought it to Sounds of Brazil on Tuesday and Wednesday. After 12 years, Culture is still a definitive rockers reggae band.

title: Joyce Brown Obtains a Ban On Medicine
description: A judge yesterday blocked the Koch administration's efforts to force medication on Joyce Brown, a homeless woman whose involutary hospitalization is testing the city's policy to removed disturbed homeless people from the street.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT NARROWS SHARPLY AS EXPORTS SURGE
description: In a surprisingly favorable development, the United States trade deficit tumbled by 25 percent in November, to $13.2 billion, as exports surged to a record for any month.

title: NBC Rules Out TBS Stake As Talks With Turner Fail
description: NBC and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. have halted negotiations that would have given NBC a minority interest in Ted Turner's cash-hungry television enterprise, officials of the two companies said yesterday.

title: Moves to End Digital Tape Dispute
description: Record companies and consumer electronics manufacturers have begun moving toward resolving a dispute that has kept a new tape recording technology - digital audio tape - out of the hands of American consumers, industry and Government officials say.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 122, Kings 86: Kevin McHale and Larry Bird led Boston in a 14-0 surge to take a 34-11 lead after one quarter and rolled to a victory last night over visiting Sacramento. The Kings were never in the game after the midpoint of the opening period. The closest they came in the last three quarters was 63-44 with 10 minutes 3 seconds left in the third quarter. The Celtics led, 5-4, before scoring the next 14 points, 8 by Bird, to take a 19-4 lead with 5:55 left in the quarter.(AP) Pistons 97, Cavaliers 93: Adrian Dantley scored 14 of his 38 points in the fourth quarter and the Pistons rallied from a 12-point deficit in Pontiac, Mich. Cleveland took its biggest lead, 79-67, on a 3-point play by Mark West with 40 seconds left in the third quarter. But Dantley's 3-point play later highlighted a 12-0 run as the Pistons took an 83-81 lead with 6:30 left in the game. Dantley scored 6 points in the final 3:36, including a running hook shot to give Detroit a 95-91 lead with a minute to go. (AP) Pacers 112, Spurs 108: Indiana erased a 16-point deficit behind a season-high 32 points by John Long at San Antonio. Layups by Alvin Robertson, who led San Antonio with 25 points, and Leon Wood put San Antonio ahead, 108-107, with 1:34 left before Long hit a 15-foot jumper and added two free throws with 15 seconds to go, putting Indiana up for good, 111-108. Chuck Person scored the final points of the game with a free throw.(AP) N.H.L. Flyers 5, Penguins 4: Derrick Smith and Mark Howe scored third-period goals in Pittsburgh and Philadelphia held on for a victory last night that extended the Penguins' streak without a victory to 10 games. Smith, alone on the left side, converted Howe's pass at 7 minutes 41 seconds for his eighth goal of the season. Howe fired in a shot from the left point during a power play at 11:00 for his ninth, giving the Flyers a 5-3 lead. The Penguins fell to 0-6-4 since beating Detroit on Dec. 26.(AP) Figure Skating Soviet Duos Dance to 1-2 Sweep: Natalya Bestemianova and Andrei Bukin skated to their fourth straight ice dance title, leading a 1-2 Soviet sweep, and Aleksandr Fadeyev retained his lead in the men's event yesterday at the European figure skating championships in Prague. Behind Bestemianova and Bukin were Natalya Annenko and Genrikh Retenski. Isabelle and Paul Duchesnay of France moved from fifth to third. After the short program in the men's event, Fadeyev, the defending champion from the Soviet Union, led his teammates Vladimir Kotin and Viktor Petrenko.(AP) Skiing American Has Longest Jump: Reed Zuehlke of the United States had the day's longest jump of 90 meters in his first attempt but finished in 20th place yesterday, and Nika Kojonkoski of Finland made steady jumps and won the 70-meter jump in the Sapporo Olympic Memorial in Japan. Kojonkoski leaped 87.5 meters on his first attempt and 84.5 meters on his second at Miyanomori Hill for 204.7 points. After jumping 90 meters, Zuehlke leaped only 64.5 meters for 170.2 points.(AP)

title: Democrats Gentle as Hart Joins Debate
description: The seven Democratic Presidential hopefuls tonight attacked large corporations, Republicans and President Reagan in a nationally televised debate here tonight. But they were far gentler with each other, and spoke not an ill word of Gary Hart, who joined them in a face-to-face exchange for the first time since he re-entered the campaign last month. Mr. Hart confronted the single question that hung in the air in the days preceding the debate, not from his op ponents, but from the debate's moderator, James P. Gannon, editor of The Des Moines Register, the newspaper sponsoring the debate. When Mr. Gannon asked Mr. Hart, the former Colorado Senator, if he thought voters should consider a candidate's character in deciding how to cast their votes, Mr. Hart chose at once to be penitent and aggressive.

title: U.S. May Return Boy, 9, To Africa, Court Rules
description: The United States Supreme Court today cleared the way for the State Department to return to Zimbabwe a 9-year-old boy who was taken from his father, a diplomat, last month amid accusations that he beat the boy.

title: KEY RATES
Let The New York Post Survive ... Sell The Post or Channel 5
description: LEAD: The First Amendment has been ''mugged'' and ''assaulted,'' cry the advocates of Rupert Murdoch's continued ownership of The New York Post and WNYW-TV, Channel 5, which has been permitted for the last two years under a waiver of the Federal Communications Commission's ban on cross-ownership in the same media market.

title: Guidepost
description: Borrowing Costs After months of see-sawing interest rates, American consumers enter the new year facing moderately higher borrowing costs than in January 1987. The uncertainty has led people to postpone purchases, and indeed the outlook remains clouded as the Federal Reserve adjusts for changing economic conditions. Generally speaking, an economic slowdown would translate into lower interest rates, while a widening of the trade deficit would destabilize the dollar and force the central bank to push interest rates higher. But analysts say that for consumers, at least, the rates now in effect should prevail for several months; a good time, in other words, to make plans. Here are average percentage rates for basic consumer loans, and some benchmarks of the cost of funds: $ Jan. 1988 Jan. 1987 Mortgage rate (30-year fixed for owneroccupied single-family) 10.69% 9.63% Automobile (48-month new car fixed- rate loan, 20% down) 11.19 10.78 Unsecured personal loan (For a $3,000 loan with a 24-month fixed rate) 15.78 15.47 Prime rate 8.75 7.50 30-year Treasury bond 8.92 7.43 Source: Bank Rate Monitor of North Palm Beach, Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: RAI RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: 39.96 Rise Puts Dow At 1,956.07
description: LEAD: Stock prices surged broadly yesterday after the Government reported that the trade deficit in November fell substantially, driven by record exports.

title: NAKED IGNORANCE
description: Happy 100th birthday to the National Geographic Society.

title: Battling the Radar Busters
description: When Geico decided to deny automobile insurance to drivers who said they owned radar detectors, it expected no controversy. ''It made sense,'' said August P. Alegi, vice president and deputy general counsel for the company. ''People own detectors for one reason only: to avoid speed limits. That makes them unacceptable risks.''

title: Down and Out
description: GREYHOUND FOR BREAKFAST. By James Kelman. 230 pages. Farrar, Straus, Giroux. $15.95.

title: CAPITAL ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the increased revenue for the quarter was due to an accounting change.

title: Joe Albany, 63, Dies; Master of Jazz Piano
description: Joe Albany, a jazz pianist who first emerged in the be-bop era, died of upper respiratory failure and cardiac arrest on Tuesday in the Roosevelt Hospital Division of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Show Producer Kills His Wife And Is a Suicide
description: The producer of the long-running Broadway show ''Oh! Calcutta!'' stabbed his wife to death and then jumped to his death from the roof of his Riverside Drive apartment yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JANUARY 16, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 28 Tardiness on an Iran arms embargo by Moscow was charged by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He said that despite public statements in support of sanctions, the Soviet Union was moving too slowly. Page 1 Israeli police fought Palestinians around the Dome of the Rock mosque, among Islam's holiest sites. The clash began at prayers crowded with thousands of worshipers. At least 70 Palestinians and several policemen were reported injured. 1 A plot to smuggle Bolivian cocaine into the United States involved three men identified as senior officers in the Mexican Army and nine others, Federal law enforcement officials announced. The 12 were indicted in San Diego. 1 A Gorbachev-Sakharov meeting was held. Dr. Sakharov, freed from internal exile by Mr. Gorbachev 13 months ago, used the opportunity to renew his calls for the release of imprisoned Soviet dissidents. 1 The final stage of Latin peace talks was opened and the leaders of the five principal Central American states were locked in what appeared to be difficult negotiations over the peace accord they signed five months ago. 4 For Sandinista, a strong literary escort 4 Soviet efforts to compromise guards in American embassies around the world are believed to have been uncovered by counterintelligence officials who administered polygraph exams to marines, officials said. 3 U.S.-Spanish military arrangements that would sharply curtail the American military presence in Spain and terminate American aid to that country under the existing 35-year-old treaty were announced. 3 Death of Chiang will be no bar to democratic changes, aide says 2 Seoul threatens North Korea after confession on jet bomb 2 Mexico City journal: New alarm over pollution 4 Thatcher uses muscle to retain secrets law 28 NATIONAL 6-10 The U.S. trade deficit tumbled by 25 percent in November to $13.2 billion as exports surged to a record for any month. The surprisingly favorable development helped spur strong gains in the dollar's value. 1 Stock prices surged broadly higher in what traders said was a relieved reaction to the better-than-expected trade figures. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 39.96 points, to close at 1,956.07. 35 The financial dealings of a Dole aide concerned other people working on Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign. The aide, David Owen, quit after questions arose about his handling of a blind trust. 9 Arizona's Governor violated laws, a special counsel retained by the Arizona House of Representatives to investigate Gov. Evan Mecham asserted. The counsel suggested the violations were grounds for impeachment. 6 An increased space program budget will be requested for next year by the Reagan Administration. The new requests include more money for the space station and space shuttle improvements, according to an aviation industry magazine. 9 A tag sale at Michael Deaver's office was held to raise money for Mr. Deaver's reportedly million-dollar legal and medical bills. The asking price for Mr. Deaver's desk was $20,000; a desktop stapler went for $2. 6 The Michigan caucuses degenerated into a melee on Thursday as dele gates for Republican Presidential candidates battled each other. ''It's a disgrace, all of this,'' one delegate said. ''It puts us all to shame.'' 8 A work stoppage by longshoremen in the Pacific Northwest ended, but labor leaders hinted at further disruptions in the coming weeks. The stoppage by 3,800 longshoremen shut down shipping activity in all 12 ports in the Northwest. 7 Postal Service plans interruptions 1 E.P.A. considers sanctions against oil company 6 Luck runs out for TV game show winner 6 California and Connecticut seek funds for AIDS tests 7 No cancer is found in test on Reagan 7 Three laboratories selected to test the shroud of Turin 7 Congress embroiled in fight for Mormon worship facilites 7 Bush seeks to end questions about role on Iran 8 Candidates clear Illinois hurdle 8 Cable TV playing key role in 1988 8 Democrats gentle as Hart joins debate 8 REGIONAL 29-32 Demand for electricity has soared to record levels following extreme cold across the Northeast this winter as businesses, industries and residential users have turned up thermostats and plugged in space heaters. 1 A decrease in Manhattan traffic, specifically in mid- and downtown, was reported for the first time since the 1970's. 30 At least six people froze to death in New York City during the recent winter cold, officials said. Three of the people were homeless. The other victims included a Bronx man, a Greenwich Village man and a newborn baby. 29 The Schools Chancellor's education in the intricacies of New York City's schools and politics started this week. Dr. Richard R. Green is learning about the bureaucracy, the custodians and the value of being a new face in town. 29 Efforts to medicate Joyce Brown by force were blocked by a state judge. The homeless woman's involutary hospitalization has become a test of the New York City policy to removed disturbed homeless people from the street. 29 Racist attitudes had been tolerated in the police department and government of Rocky Hill, Conn., a state investigation concluded. The five-month investigation was conducted by the State Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities. 29 Two of the 12 jurors in a Mafia trial said that they they could no longer be objective about the case. Their disclosures in the racketeering and drug trial of Gene Gotti and nine co-defendants raised the possibility of a mistrial. 31 Water main bursts on West Side 30 New judge picked in Myerson case 30 Coalition calls boycott as protest of racism 30 Taxable value of property in New York rises by $6.4 billion 31 The Supreme Court rejects ban on returning a boy to Africa 31 ''Oh! Calcutta!'' producer stabs wife and kills himself 31 Neediest Cases 32

title: XSCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOLITEC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $47,000 and $124,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a pretax writeoff of $900,000 and $5,005,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, for intangible assets.

title: Germany Finds No Illegal Nuclear Shipment
description: The West German Environment Minister said today that no hard evidence had surfaced to support an informant's assertion that nuclear materials might have been illegally shipped to Pakistan or Libya. Officials of international regulatory agencies also said they had found no such illegal diversions.

title: Stopping Car Alarms
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Is Reported to Seek Budget Increase for NASA
description: The Reagan Administration, seeking a budget increase for space programs, plans to ask for more money for the space station, space shuttle improvements and research into new technologies useful for missions to the Moon and Mars, according to an aviation industry magazine.

title: POP: HOT CLUB RE-CREATES REINHARDT-GRAPPELLI SOUND
description: Few sounds in modern pop are more archetypally jazzy than the lilting string-band music of Django Reinhardt, the Belgian gypsy guitarist, and his Hot Club of France. Led by the guitarist, who died in 1953, and Stephane Grappelli, the violinist, who will turn 80 this year, the group refined a propulsive, accelerated dance music that, savored in the context of today's electronic jazz-fusion, seems quintessentially pure and simple. And at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, for three weeks beginning last Tuesday, that sound is being lovingly re-created by a group also calling itself ''The Hot Club of France.'' Joining the group for several vocal numbers is Michele Bautier, a gifted pop-jazz singer.

title: Sakharov Meets With Gorbachev And Hands Leader a Prisoner List
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the most powerful symbol of authority in the Soviet Union, met in the Kremlin today with Andrei D. Sakharov, the Nobel laureate once made an outcast here for defending the rights of the individual.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BALLISTIC RECOVERY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
MIDWEST COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ADAMS EXPRESS reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The company said net asset value per share is after a capital gain distribution of $2.66 paid in 1987 and $3.74 paid in 1986.

title: At Latin Parley, Charges of Bad Faith
description: The leaders of five Central American countries opened a final stage of peace negotiations here today amid accusations of bad faith and strongly differing interpretations of the regional treaty they signed five months ago.

title: Apple in Pact With Digital
description: Apple Computer Inc. and the Digital Equipment Corporation, as expected, formally announced a joint development effort aimed at developing products to connect Apple Macintosh machines and Digital VAX computers.

title: AMERICAN BIONETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $597,000. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $259,672. The year-ago revenue is restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chronology from The Associated Press on Dec. 30 about recent mass killings in the United States misstated the number of people slain by a gunman July 18, 1984, at a McDonald's restaurant in San Ysidro, Calif.

title: Town in Georgia Has A Government Again
description: In a jubilant ceremony, this small eastern Georgia town swore in its first government in 55 years today.

title: Deaver on the Block: Auction Helps Pay Legal Fee
description: Shortly after the doors opened, the hand-painted Chinese screen from Michael K. Deaver's lucrative lobbying business was sold this morning for the asking price of $3,500.

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN CHOCOLATE FACTORY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Hyundai Price Rise
description: Hyundai Motor America said it had raised the base prices of Excel car models by $200, with the exception of the three-door hatchback, whose price rises $100, to $5,395. The company attributed the increase to the depreciation of the dollar against other currencies and to other business costs.

title: Amid Cold Winds, Many Do Remember the Neediest Cases
description: Recent cutting winds and merciless cold have stirred increased concern for the plight of the homeless among many donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Divestment's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: TCBY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CUBANS TURN THEIR BACK ON THE SEOUL OLYMPICS
description: Cuba said yesterday that it would not participate in the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, this summer unless North Korea, one of its allies, could be co-host of the Games, and the safety of its athletes could be guaranteed.

title: 3 Seminars on Dance
description: Movement Research Inc. will present seminars on aspects of dance on Feb. 14 and March 5 and 20 at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street. The seminars are part of the organization's series, ''The Studies Projects.'' Kei Takei, Kumiko Kimoto and Yoshiko Chuma will take part in ''From Japan to New York: Three Japanese Choreographers,'' moderated by Wendy Perron, on Feb. 14 at 3 P.M. Stephanie Woodard, Simone Forti and Steve Paxton will discuss dancers writing on dance on March 5 at 8 P.M. And Stephanie Skura, Joe Melillo, Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane will discuss dancers' marketing concerns on March 20 at 3 P.M. Admission is $7; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Reservations: 691-5788.

title: Post Office Hours to Be Cut in Austerity Move
description: The United States Postal Service said tonight that post offices around the country would begin to close a half-day a week to absorb budget cuts.

title: Bush Seeks to End Iran Questions
description: Vice President Bush said today that he had answered all questions on his role in the Iran-contra affair and that he believed the issue was closed.

title: ISC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Mr. Cuomo Promotes Housing Crisis
description: New York needs desperately to encourage housing production, especially housing for rent. What a disappointment, therefore, that Governor Cuomo's first 1988 bill will discourage any sane builder from creating it.

title: 2 Mob-Trial Jurors Say They Can't Be Objective
description: Two of the 12 jurors in the Federal racketeering and drug trial of Gene Gotti and nine co-defendants told a judge yesterday that they they could no longer be objective about the case.

title: LACANA MINING reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a $1,019,000 tax credit. The year-ago figures are not comparable because the company has changed its fiscal year-end from Dec. 31 to Sept. 30. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CENTURY COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said in the year-ago quarter preferred dividends exceeded net income.

title: Conner Is Still Fuming
description: Dennis Conner took an opportunity yesterday to lash out at Michael Fay, the New Zealand merchant banker and yachtsman, charging that Fay's unorthodox challenge for the America's Cup amounts to a ''legalized ambush'' of the 137-year-old trophy.

title: Jerusalem Police, Firing Tear Gas, Fight With Palestinians at Mosque
description: The Israeli police, firing tear gas and wielding night sticks, fought today with stone-throwing Palestinians around the Dome of the Rock mosque, one of Islam's holiest sites.

title: CONERT: GUARNERI QUARTET
description: Erich Wolfgang Korngold was the center of interest when the Guarneri String Quartet played at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. Korngold, who began as a Viennese child prodigy and ended his days in Hollywood, endured the first half of the 20th century without ever finding a comfortable place in it.

title: Ron and Noboru: A Good Start
description: The first meeting of President Reagan and Prime Minister Takeshita of Japan showed promise - a friendly spirit at the top of what is otherwise a difficult economic relationship. With Japan's power swelling steadily, and American supremacy no longer unchallenged, relations still will be poisoned by stand-offs over trade and finance. The leaders on both sides need to demonstrate the will and disposition to counteract the poison.

title: L&N HOUSING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Decision for Sears in Sex Bias Suit is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court in Chicago this week upheld a ruling against the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in its nine-year-old sex discrimination suit against Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
New York Area Store Sales Up
description: Sales at several of New York City's largest department stores rose by an average of 8.8 percent in December from the period a year ago, according to a monthly spot-check. The stores posted average sales gains of 7.3 percent in the metropolitan area.

title: Seoul Threatens North Korea After Confession on Jet Bomb
description: South Korean officials threatened today to retaliate against North Korea for the bombing of a Korean Air Lines plane in which 115 people died in November.

title: ADVANCED MARKETING SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nofziger Jury Chosen
description: A jury of seven men and five women was selected today for the conflict-of-interest trial of Lyn C. Nofziger, a former aide to President Reagan. The jury was selected from a panel of 60 prospective jurors that had been screened in questioning that began Monday. Mr. Nofziger, 63 years old, is charged with improperly lobbying former White House colleagues after he resigned from the President's staff in early 1982.

title: In the Rite Spirit
description: LEAD: ''I was absent because my grandfather pasted away,'' my student wrote. ''This is college,'' I said. ''You don't have to bring a note.''

title: DOLE AIDE CAUSED CONCERN IN CAMP
description: Aides to Senator Bob Dole now say they expressed concern among themselves about the financial dealings of David Owen, the national finance chairman of Mr. Dole's Presidential campaign who stepped aside Thursday after questions arose about his handling of investments for Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: ENTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said last year's second quarter and first half results included major shipments to Southland Corp. and Circle K Corp.

title: Group Plans Boycott as Protest Over Racism
description: A coalition of labor leaders, ministers and heads of professional organizations have called for an economic boycott Feb. 19 against racism in New York City.

title:
Patents;
Invent America! Project Starts Its Second Year
description: LEAD: The Invent America! program, which encourages student creativity, is beginning its second year, under the sponsorship of the United States Patent Model Foundation. A conference of educators is being held this weekend at the Hilton Hotel in Washington.

title: Three Laboratories Are Chosen to Determine Age of Shroud of Turin
description: Three laboratories have been chosen by the Roman Catholic Cardinal of Turin to test fragments of the shroud of Turin in an effort to determine its age.

title: Another Judge Selected to Preside In Federal Case Against Myerson
description: A new Federal judge was selected yesterday to conduct the trial of Bess Myerson, the former New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner, on charges that include obstruction of justice.

title: Reagan Waiver for Pakistan
description: President Reagan invoked a waiver today to assure continued aid to Pakistan despite American concerns that Pakistan may have been involved in smuggling nuclear-weapons materials from the United States. The waiver was invoked on a law that requires a cutoff of aid to any nation believed to be exporting restricted materials from the United States that can be used to make nuclear weapons.

title: Chorus to Give Free Programs of Spirituals
description: A performance of spirituals, many sung a cappella by a 16-member chorus with soloists, will be offered tomorrow night in a most appropriate setting: a church. The concert will take place at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street, at 7:30.

description: b-Includes an accounting loss of $110,000 incurred when the company transferred proceeds from the sale of a GNMA mutual fund into a GNMA security. c-Net income
