title: N.H.L. Suspends Two
description: Calling one incident ''potentially very dangerous'' and another ''totally irresponsible,'' Brian O'Neil, the executive vice president of the National Hockey League, issued suspensions yesterday totaling 12 games to Steve Konroyd, the Islanders' steadiest defenseman this season, and Randy Cunneyworth, the Pittsburgh Penguins' free-swinging left wing. Konroyd will sit out the Islanders' next four games, starting this evening against the Devils, for his part in a stick-swinging scuffle with Cunneyworth last Tuesday night. Cunneyworth drew a three-game suspension, a lighter sentence, according to O'Neil, because Konroyd swung first and acted more severely. But there was nothing light about the penalty Cunneyworth drew for striking Michael Thelven of Boston on the helmet and knocking down the Bruin defenseman during an altercation last Dec. 29. That stunning blow brought a five-game suspension, meaning that the Penguins will lose Cunneyworth for eight straight games.

title: DATATRAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Broad Soviet Effort Seen to Use Marines as Spies
description: After administering polygraph exams to 259 marines stationed in American embassies around the world, counterintelligence officials believe they have uncovered extensive attempts by Soviet intelligence to compromise the guards, Administration offficials said today.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST-HOTEL INVESTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $520,000 on the sale of land. The company said the increased revenue and net income were a result of the expansion of the trust and corporation, including the acquisition by the trust of Hotel Properties Inc. and 9 other hotels, and the acquisition by the corporation of Western Host Inc. The company's year-end will be changed from Aug. 31 to Dec. 31.

title: Student Discipline, Principal Discipline
description: Can Joe Clark, the two-fisted school principal in Paterson, N.J., survive the conflict with his Board of Education? The White House says it wants him for a full-time position, but he has agreed only to an unpaid consultancy. Whatever games are being played on that front, Mr. Clark need not lose his job as principal unless he forces the board to dismiss him.

title: 6 Freeze to Death in New York
description: At least six people, three of them homeless, have frozen to death in New York City in the last week and a half of bitter winter cold, city officials said yesterday.

title: Death of Chiang Will Be No Bar To Democratic Change, Aide Says
description: A senior ruling party official said today that planned democratic changes would be carried out on schedule over the next few months despite the death this week of President Chiang Ching-kuo.

title: Better Ways to Clean New York's Dirty Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: The Homeless Drive Teen-Age Athletes Into the Cold
description: LEAD: A little-known territorial dispute with far-reaching ramifications for New York City high school students has left thousands of teen-age athletes with no place to practice their sport. Ironically, it was a population of homeless men that put them out on the street.

title: David Bromberg, 61; Served on Judicial Unit
description: David Bromberg, a lawyer who was a member of the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct, an agency that investigates complaints against judges, died of a heart attack Thursday in Grand Central Terminal after a day of hearings at the commission. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
Patents;
Computer Network
description: LEAD: An electronic neural network for signal processing in telecommunications and computers was patented this week for AT&T; Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., and the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. Patent 4,719,591 was granted to Prof. John J. Hopfield of Caltech and David W. Tank of A.T.&T.;

title: For Dr. Green, an Education On a Complex New Domain
description: Dr. Richard R. Green started on the path of self-education in the intricacies of New York City's public schools and politics this week, learning along the way about the bureaucracy, the custodians and the value of being a new face in town.

title: Thatcher Uses Muscle to Retain Secrets Law
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher used personal lobbying and parliamentary tactics today to defeat the latest effort to rewrite Britain's Official Secrets Act.

title: DEKALB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $600,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday omitted identities for five of the nine members of the Baseball Writers Association of America who returned blank ballots in the Hall of Fame election. They were Michael Martinez of The New York Times, Fred Down and Fred Lief of United Press International, Bob Oates of The Los Angeles Times and Ken Nigro, a former baseball writer who works for the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Politics at the Grass Roots On Icy Michigan Night
description: Rich Bond, Vice President Bush's deputy national campaign manager, stood in the street outside Elmer's Steak Pit Thursday night, bundled against the arctic cold in a blue loden coat, his face creased in anger, and shouted at the bolted door in front of him, ''Let our people in!''

title: Ida Betzak, Painter, 78
description: Ida Betzak, a painter, died Sunday of a cerebral hemorrhage at her home in Manhattan. She was 78 years old.

title: Some Doubts About New Cosmetics for Tanning
description: Tan accelerators, the newest cosmetics for sunning, are intended to provide the maximum tan with minimum exposure. For winter travelers who are planning short vacations in the sun, the products sound ideal. But some dermatologists are dubious.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TECTONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Reflects an accounting change which reduced earnings by $40,874 for the quarter and increased earnings by $57,676 for the 9 months.

title: SHULTZ IS CHIDING RUSSIANS OVER IRAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz complained today that the Soviet Union was not moving quickly enough toward a Security Council resolution imposing an arms embargo on Iran.

3 LINKED TO ARMY IN MEXICO INDICTED IN U.S. DRUG PLOT
description: Three men identified as senior officers in the Mexican Army and nine others have been charged in San Diego in connection with a plot to smuggle tons of Bolivian cocaine into the United States, Federal law enforcement officials announced today.

title: CONCEPT 90 MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Hong Kong Charges May Grow
description: Ronald Li, the former chairman of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange who was charged Thursday with accepting $352,000 from a Japanese company in return for listing it on the exchange, could face further charges as the colony's Government continues its investigation, a prosecutor said today.

title: Congress and Critics Eye Army-Mormon Rift
description: Congress says the Army is not providing adequate religious facilities for workers at a remote weapon-testing facility in Utah where Mormon Church officials were denied land to build a church.

title: Hutton Announces Big Loss
description: The E. F. Hutton Group yesterday reported an after-tax loss of $112.7 million for October and November.

SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Frigid Northeast Setting Records In Power Levels
description: Extreme cold across the Northeast has sent demand for electricity soaring to record levels this winter as businesses, industries and millions of residential users have turned up thermostats, plugged in space heaters and switched on lights in the late afternoon twilight.

title: TRANSTECTOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Pyongyang as Outlaw
description: North Korea, a political and economic failure, hates and envies successful South Korea. Recently that envy has grown as Seoul reaches for new prestige by playing host to the 1988 Summer Olympics. Now it appears that despite the new and positive foreign policy signals Pyongyang has been emitting in recent months, its policy still comes down to nastiness, terror and murder.

title: Australia Marks Settlement
description: A fleet of tall ships re-enacting the 1788 settlement voyage by convicts from England made landfall today, and celebrations went ahead despite fears of a huge protest by aborigines. The police said that they had expected about 2,000 aborigines to protest what militants call a celebration of invasion but that only a handful had turned up.

title: MEDITRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Treasury Prices Advance Sharply
description: Treasury bond and note prices rose sharply yesterday after the Government reported an unexpectedly sharp drop in the nation's trade deficit for November. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose by more than two and a half points, its biggest one-day increase since October.

title: Yes, Traffic in Midtown Is a Little Less Crowded
description: For the first time since the gas lines of the 1970's - and one of the few times since motorists had steering wheels to slide behind - the number of cars, taxis and trucks entering mid- and downtown Manhattan has declined.

title: F.C.C. Reinstates Rule On Minority Ownership
description: The Federal Communications Commission has reinstated policies meant to increase the opportunities for women and minorities to own radio and television stations.

title: Texaco to Ease Takeover Defenses
description: Concerned that their bankruptcy reorganization plan might be rejected by shareholders, executives of Texaco Inc. agreed in principle yesterday to demands by a shareholders' committee to ease restrictions on an unfriendly takeover.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH REALTY INOME TR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: No comparative figures are available because the company became publicly owned in December 1986.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only; offices are open in Manhattan at 25 Broadway, 90 Church St., 909 3d Ave., Grand Central Terminal, 33d St. and 8th Ave., 73 Pine St., 1384 Broadway, and 610 5th Ave. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular collections. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. Libraries: New York Public Library, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule; minor adjustments during rush hour. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Little Federal Office Has Big Role in Art Tours
description: Last year, an art exhibition in the United States commemorating the 750th anniversary of the City of Berlin was postponed, not because of the usual artistic or political problems but because Federal officials declined to provide a form of insurance to protect the lenders against possible loss.

title: Sean MacBride of Ireland Is Dead at 83
description: Sean MacBride, an Irish revolutionary who went on to win the Nobel and Lenin peace prizes, died after a short illness yesterday at his home in Dublin. He was 83 years old. In a 70-year career that took him from street battles with the British in Dublin to the international award-ceremony podium in Oslo, Mr. MacBride's name was linked, often controversially, with such causes as Irish nationalism, a united Europe, nuclear disarmament and human rights.

title: Racial Remarks Cause Furor
description: Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, the longtime CBS Sports commentator, provoked a controversy yesterday when he told a local television interviewer in Washington that blacks make better athletes than whites because they were ''bred to be that way.''

title: Alfred Easton Poor, Architect, 88
description: Alfred Easton Poor, a New York architect who designed many government buildings, banks and institutional headquarters, and who was part of a group that designed the restoration and extension of the East Front of the United States Capitol in the early 1960's, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $18,000 from equity in earnings of a 50 percent-owned affiliate. c-Includes a pretax gain of $22,000 from equity in the affiliate.

title: Levin Friend Testifies Of Drinks and Diet Pills
description: Jennifer Levin was not intoxicated when she left an Upper East Side bar with Robert E. Chambers Jr. just after 4 o'clock on the morning of her death, a witness at Mr. Chambers's murder trial testified yesterday.

title: INTEGRATED DEVICE TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid in November.

title: AVAir Halts
description: AVAir Inc., which operates the American Eagle commuter airline service, has suspended operations indefinitely, officials said. American Eagle, which serves airports in North Carolina, Virginia and Washington, D.C., is owned by Dallas-based American Airlines. AVAir is a franchisee, with headquarters in Raleigh, N.C. Other companies also operate American Eagle flights, but those flights have not been suspended. AVAir officials were not available for comment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The figures are unambiguous on the improvement in exports.

title: Collegiate Swan Song
description: For many of the college stars in the East-Shrine game today in Palo Alto, Calif., their next football game will be in the National Football League. For Lorenzo White, that's a long way off. ''I've been on the road for the last month,'' said White, the running back who starred for Michigan State in the Rose Bowl victory over Southern California and then went to Japan for an all-star game. ''I'm going home after this game to see my mother, then going back to school.'' White's mother became sick while in California for the Rose Bowl and recently underwent surgery in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: E.P.A. Considers Sanctions Against Oil Company in River Spill
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, after inspecting the site of a huge oil spill from an Ashland Oil Company storage facility in Pennsylvania, is considering legal action against the company for violations of the Clean Water Act, agency officials said today.

title: New York City Has Record Rise In Assessments
description: The taxable value of property in New York City is now $65.7 billion, reflecting a $6.4 billion increase that is the largest annual rise in the city's history, tentative city figures showed yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; The Heart of Pistol Pete
description: TOO many times, said Atlanta Hawks Coach Richie Guerin in 1970, Pete Maravich gets himself ''stuck up there in the air.'' It's a great trait for a moon, but not necessarily for a basketball player.

title:
Patents;
Reducing The Cost of Solar Power
description: LEAD: A POWER converter described as a way to produce electricity from sunlight at greatly reduced cost will be patented next week for Phototherm Inc. of Amherst, N.H. Alvin M. Marks, chief scientist for the company, will be granted patent 4,720,642, his 116th.

title: Bank Board Plan Near On Texas Savings Units
description: Federal regulators are expected to adopt soon a plan to close or merge by year-end 104 savings institutions in Texas and 42 in neighboring states, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, M. Danny Wall, said today.

title: Output in 1987 Up 5.2%, Biggest Gain Since 1984
description: The nation's industrial output climbed 5.2 percent in 1987, almost five times the previous year's gain and the best showing for American industry since 1984, the Government reported today.

title: Met Opera: Debussy's 'Pelleas,' With Von Stade
description: Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande'' is less an opera than an anti-opera. His setting of the Maeterlinck play rarely raises its voice above a somber hush but can draw the susceptible listener deep into a world of gauze and shadow where hazily defined characters move as if in a trance and where almost everything important is left unsaid. The spell that Debussy's music works can be so powerful that in spite of the work's five-act length, the intermissions are felt as unfortunate intrusions. That alone would set ''Pelleas'' apart from most operas.

title: NO CANCER IS FOUND IN TEST ON REAGAN
description: Doctors who examined President Reagan today found ''no recurrence of cancer'' in his colon and none of the nonmalignant growths that have been discovered on the four other checkups he has had over the past two years, the White House said.

title: BROKEN WATER MAIN FLOODS BUILDINGS AND KNOCKS OUT UTILITIES ON UPPER WEST SIDE
description: A 90-year-old water main broke underneath Broadway between West 84th and 85th Streets in Manhattan early yesterday, sending a cascade of water flowing westward in the frigid darkness into basements of apartment houses and stores.

title: Mexico City Journal; Season of Smog in 'Makesicko City'
description: To a large extent, the 20 million people in the world's largest metropolis have reluctantly adapted to living with the pollution that fouls the air here.

description: Pam Shriver and Lori McNeil of the United States scored straight-set victories today to advance to the fourth round of the Australian Open tennis championships.

description: Gardner Cox, an artist known for his portraits of prominent Americans, died of heart failure on Thursday in a hospital in Cambridge, Mass., his city of residence. He was 81 years old.

Accelerating Projectiles Along Parallel Rails

Patent 4,718,321, granted to Emanuel M. Honig, a staff member at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, and William C. Nunnally, a former member, covers use of a pair of parallel rails for guiding a projectile, and a capacitor for storing the energy.

title: Concert: Marc-Andre Hamelin Plays Ives
description: The ''Concord'' Sonata by Charles Ives is one of those pieces that rarely makes its way onto piano recital programs but invariably steals the show when it does. It appeared as the welcome entry on the first half of Marc-Andre Hamelin's concert in Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening. Mr. Hamelin won first prize in the Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition in 1985.

title: Faldo Shoots 7 Birdies In a Row
description: Nick Faldo of England, winner of last year's British Open, posted seven consecutive birdies today to fall just one short of the American PGA Tour record of eight birdies in a row.

description: A special counsel retained by the Arizona House of Representatives to investigate Gov. Evan Mecham asserted today that the Governor had violated numerous state laws and suggested that there were grounds for impeachment.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Monday about Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, and his views on political corruption included an incomplete quotation. Asked whether political corruption was pervasive, he said, '' No, I don't think so,'' and then added: ''I think that where political power remains in somebody's hands for a very long period of time, it's the rare individual who doesn't become personally corrupt.''

description: Office vacancy rates in Manhattan rose in the fourth quarter of 1987, to 11.5 percent in the downtown area and 10.2 percent in midtown, according to a study by a leading real estate concern.

title: ARCO's Britoil Stake
description: Los Angeles-based ARCO, competing with the British Petroleum Company for shares in Britoil P.L.C., said today that it had increased its stake in the North Sea producer to 23.83 percent, from 23.73 percent. ARCO has said it was seeking to acquire a 49.9 percent holding in Britoil. On Thursday, Britoil rejected B.P.'s formal bid worth $:2.27 billion, or more than $4 billion, discarding it as ''inadequate and unwelcome.'' Both companies want to obtain Britoil's valuable North Sea oil and natural gas fields.

title: A New Way to Shed Bad Loans
description: A growing number of banks are utilizing a novel approach to shed their bad loans: They are putting them into a separate unit and then spinning the unit off to shareholders.

title: MEDCHEM PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Leon Seltzer, 69, Dies; Led a University Press
description: Leon E. Seltzer, a national figure in university press publishing and a lawyer, died of cardio-respiratory arrest Monday at Stanford University Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived on the Stanford University campus in Stanford, Calif.

title: A New System for Nasdaq
description: The Nasdaq over-the-counter market began using a new automatic trading system today for large stock orders. The change is intended to reduce reliance on telephone lines, which became clogged during the October market turbulence.

title:
Patents;
Cloning a Polio Virus For Vaccine Research
description: LEAD: A method of cloning a polio virus by using genetic engineering techniques was patented this week for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. The process is described as useful in developing vaccines as well as diagnosing the presence of the virus in samples.

title: CLAYTON HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in April 1987.

description: The nation may have to spend an estimated $22.7 billion cleaning up hazardous waste sites that were supposedly operating under strict environmental regulation, a Congressional study says.

title: James Marcus, Ex-Water Chief
description: James Lewis Marcus, a former New York City Water Commissioner who pleaded guilty to Federal charges in a kickback conspiracy involving a city reservoir contract, died of leukemia yesterday at Maricopa County Medical Center in Phoenix. He was 57 years old and had moved to Arizona from Manhattan last year.

title: Grand Met Makes Final Martell Bid
description: The British liquor and hotels giant Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. today made what it said was its last raise in the bidding against the Seagram Company for the cognac house Martell.

title: Correction
description: An art review in the Critics' Choices column of The Guide last Sunday misidentified a photographer in the show at the Twining Gallery.

title: 'Wall Street': The Banality of Greed
description: HOLLYWOOD has at last made what it considers a serious movie about business and we bray appreciatively at its verisimilitude. ''Wall Street'' the movie does get the technicalities right. The jargon is dead on, the brokers dress in their conformist code, the geography of the trading room is, well, picture perfect. But if ''Wall Street'' gets the small matters right, it misses the big issues by at least a few hundred points on the Dow - especially that most important one, character. What is wrong with Wall Street still needs telling.

title: Paris
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from a week in Paris, we have been telling friends about our tour of the catacombs, which was not unlike that described in Frederick Turner's article ''The Worlds Beneath Paris'' (Travel, Oct. 25).

title: O'Rourke and Board to Submit Joint Package of Requests in Albany
description: LEAD: AFTER two years of going their separate ways, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and the Board of Legislators will submit a joint list of measures that they want enacted during the current legislative session in Albany. The package, now being put in final form, is expected to be approved by the Board at its Feb.

title: Needed: A Protocol - or at Least a Truce - About Gift-Giving
description: OUR friend Alan gets the shakes every time he thinks of how close he and Ellen came to a divorce after 38 years of marriage.

title: An Aids Nightmare
description: LATE ON AN UNUSUALLY WARM June 1 afternoon last year in East Baltimore, Jewel Foster Lyles, 25 years old, was walking down East Federal Street, which was littered with empty liquor bottles and food wrappers. Mrs. Lyles, a dark, statuesque woman with a broad forehead and a vibrant smile, was two weeks past term with her second child. Her cheerful demeanor belied a difficult life. She had dropped out of school when she was 16 and had had a daughter the next year by Jerra Lyles. She had married Lyles five years later, but the marriage didn't last. Now, pregnant with a child from a new boyfriend, she lived with her parents on East Oliver Street, one block from East Federal. She was on maternity leave from a job as a housekeeper at Johns Hopkins Hospital. As she walked down the street, she saw Andre Williams and Lamont Jones fighting.

title: The Weed That Won't Go Away
description: DOUGLAS GINSBURG (the Supreme Court candidate who withdrew from consideration after an admission that he had smoked marijuana) was the topic of conversation. The occasion was a large family party that followed a traditional christening.

title: WHEN PLAYERS ARE METHODICALLY GROUND DOWN
description: WHAT is the right moment to terminate a game, whether by resigning or by offering a draw?

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MYRNA LOY: Being and Becoming. By James Kotsilibas-Davis and Myrna Loy. (Knopf, $22.95.) With 124 feature films spanning a 60-year career, Myrna Loy should be a wellspring of stories about the golden age of Hollywood, the studio system where she was one of its foremost players, and the political arena she embraced when her acting career slowed.

title: LATE NIGHTS WITH THE KAMA SUTRA
description: DR. GRUBER'S DAUGHTER By Janice Elliott. 159 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Hodder & Stoughton/ David & Charles. $18.95.

title: Survey Rates West Virginia the Heftiest State
description: Nearly a quarter of West Virginians are overweight, fewer Tennesseans are, and Hawaiians and Utahans are the slimmest of all, according to a 25-state study by Federal health researchers that found Americans' weight seems to vary by state.

title: Teheran Reported Planning Chemical Arms
description: Iran has set aside funds in this year's budget for the production of chemical weapons, according to a summary of the budget published here.

title: ROMANCE COMES TO UP CALLOW
description: CIVIL TO STRANGERS And Other Writings. By Barbara Pym. Edited by Hazel Holt. 388 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: 'Pajama Tops' Chases for Laughs
description: WHEN the maid, Claudine L'Amour, and the police inspector, LeGrand, confide to each other that their respective careers would be enhanced by a ''notorious scandal,'' the audience knows that a crime of passion is lurking somewhere offstage. However, in ''Pajama Tops,'' the sex farce by Mawby Green and Ed Feilbert now at the Arena Players Repertory Company, the fast-paced staging is the only rousing element in this flaccidly plotted play.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: FALL RIVER, MASS.;
Condos Liven Waterfront
description: LEAD: NEW condominiums are transforming a blighted waterfront parcel in this working-class city of 100,000.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: The Mashantucket Pequot Indian Reservation;
Descendants Regain Tribe's Lost Land and Diminished Pride
description: LEAD: WHEN Ruth Thomas decided in 1986 to move her family from Providence, R.I., to the Mashantucket Pequot Indian Reservation in Ledyard, she joined her mother and four siblings, who were already living and working on the reservation.

title: Orpheus to Make Two Appearances
description: BY next weekend, the concert calendar will have returned to its busy preholiday pace, and choices will have to be made from among orchestral concerts, chamber recitals or folk music.

title: MARY SHELLEY TO WED DR. JOHN MORRISSEY JR.
description: The engagement of Mary Eileen Shelley to Dr. John Daniel Morrissey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morrissey of Pelham Manor, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Shelley Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: DATA BANK: January 17, 1988
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Bruins 5, Sabres 1: Cam Neely scored three goals for the third time in his career as the Bruins won yesterday in Boston. Buffalo, beaten by 9-0 and 2-0 in two games with Boston in late December, ended a scoreless string of 186 minutes 22 seconds against the Bruins on Phil Housley's 18th goal at 12:45 of the second period. But the Sabres managed few other scoring chances.(AP) Blues 3, Capitals 1: In St. Louis, Cliff Ronning, playing in his first game since returning from the Canadian Olympic team, scored the go-ahead goal for St. Louis. Brian Sutter and Perry Turnbull also scored for St. Louis, while Bengt Gustafsson got the Capitals' only goal. Rick Wamsley stopped 30 shots for St. Louis.(AP) Penguins 4, Maple Leafs 3: Mario Lemieux scored his league-leading 45th goal and set up two others as Pittsburgh broke a 10-game streak without a victory. The Maple Leafs, playing at home, are now 0-7-4 in their last 11 games and are two short of tying the team record of 13 games without a victory, set in 1985.(AP) College Football West Squad Wins Shrine Game: Tom Whelihan of Missouri kicked three field goals to lead the West to a 16-13 victory yesterday in the 63d East-West Shrine Game in Stanford, Calif. San Jose State's Kenny Jackson ran for 65 yards and was named offensive player of the game. His teammate, Mike Perez, threw for the West's only touchdown in the defense-dominated all-star game. Ken Harvey, a California linebacker, was the top defensive player, as the West held the East to 89 yards passing. (AP) Burnett of Wyoming Excels: Craig Burnett of Wyoming passed for one touchdown and led the drive for another as the West defeated the East, 20-18, in the Hula Bowl game yesterday in Honolulu. Burnett completed 8 of 14 passes for 109 yards. Aaron Cox of Arizona State, who had six receptions for 101 yards, was named the game's outstanding offensive player. Dennis Price, a U.C.L.A. cornerback who had three key interceptions, was the outstanding defensive player.(AP) Skiing Swiss Men First and Second: Peter Mueller and Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland finished 1-2 yesterday in a men's World Cup downhill event in Bad Kleinkirchheim, Austria. Mueller mastered the slippery course in 1 minute 53.31 seconds. Zurbriggen had the best time in the first stage of the course, but lost time and wound up only 27 one-hundredths of a second behind his Swiss teammate in 1:53.58.(AP) Swiss Women in a Sweep: The Swiss female downhill skiers proved again that they are the ones to beat at the Olympics next month as Maria Walliser, the world champion, led Michela Figini, the 1984 gold medalist, in a sweep of a World Cup race yesterday in Zinal, Switzerland. Walliser trailed Figini, the World Cup leader, on the steep first half of the course but picked up speed to finish seven-hundredths of a second ahead. The winning time was 1 minute 52.17 seconds. Figini was clocked in 1:52.24. Brigitte Oertli took third place in 1:52.87.(AP) Speed Skating Italians Set World Records: Christina Sciolla and Orazio Fagone, both of Italy, set world records in 500-meter events at the European Cup speed-skating finals yesterday in Budapest, the official MTI press agency said. Sciolla covered the 500-meter course in 47.77 seconds, bettering the previous women's record of 48.11, held by Bonnie Blair of the United States. Fagone, with a time of 44.46, eclipsed the 500-meter men's record of 45.08, set by Louis Gremier of Canada.(AP) Figure Skating Fadeyev Misses Quad, but Wins Event: Aleksandr Fadeyev failed to make skating history yesterday by abandoning his attempt to land the first quadruple jump ever in competition, but still won the men's event at the European championships in Prague. The 24-year-old Soviet skater won his third European title with his teammates, Vladimir Kotin and Viktor Petrenko, in second and third, the same places they finished last year.(AP) Squash Talbott in Final: Top-seeded Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., reached the final of the Rolex Greenwich Open Squash Racquets Championship yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., with a 15-8, 13-15, 15-10, 15-8 victory over David Boyum of Brooklyn. In the other semifinal, second-seeded Ned Edwards of New York ousted Greg Zaff of Boston, 15-10, 10-15, 17-16, 13-15, 15-9, in a seesaw match. Edwards won the third game with a rare nick off the back wall. Talbott reached the semifinals earlier yesterday with an 11-15, 15-12, 15-6, 15-11 victory over Juan Mendez of Mexico City, while Edwards beat Alex Doucas of Montreal, 6-15, 15-9, 15-13, 15-10. Horse Racing Three Straight for Tricky Squaw: Tricky Squaw, ridden by Jose Santos and carrying the highweight of 123 pounds, raced to her third straight victory and her 12th triumph in 37 career starts in taking the $87,900 Affectionately Handicap for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-year-old daughter of Clever Trick-Black Apache, who conceded from 9 to 17 pounds to her eight rivals, covered a mile and a sixteenth in 1:45 1/5 to reach the wire five lengths ahead of With a Twist. Tricky Squaw earned $52,740 for Eugene V. Klein and returned $3.80 for $2 to win.

title: ALEXANDRA MEREDITH TO MARRY IN MARCH
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Meredith of Pennington, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Meigs Meredith to Ward Shaffer Taggart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Taggart of Dallas. A March 26 wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CONCERT FOR DR. KING

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Les McCann Trio Les McCann, Jimmy Rowser, Donald Dean. Rhapsody Films. 28 minutes. $29.95.

title: A Student Verdict On Legal Issues
description: LEAD: IN some New York City-area classrooms, fifth and sixth graders are asked to voice their opinions only when it is time to pick a volleyball team captain or the place for a picnic on the last day of school.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: Jack Clark makes the St. Louis Cardinals the favorites. The Cardinals have given up a spoiled, injury-prone and unfaithful player who will not be able to handle New York, Billy Martin, George Steinbrenner, or the expectations of the New York fans and the news media. THOMAS HELLER Summit, N.J.

title: A Final Round?
description: The last round in the tangled 21-year legal battle of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter may have ended last week when the United States Supreme Court refused to reinstate triple-murder charges against the onetime contender for the middleweight boxing championship. Mr. Carter, now 50, and John Artis, 41, were convicted in two trials, in 1967 and in 1976, of the fatal shootings of two men and a woman at a bar in Paterson, N.J., in 1966. Both verdicts were reversed by appeals courts because the prosecution suppressed critical evidence. Mr. Carter's cause was championed in the mid-1970's by civil rights leaders, politicians and entertainers, and Bob Dylan recorded ''Hurricane,'' a popular ballad depicting Mr. Carter as a man unjustly accused. Legal experts said a new trial would be unlikely; Mr. Carter, who served 19 years in prison, said he was ''relieved that this nightmare seems finally to be ending.''

title: 2 Are Slain in Belfast
description: Two men were shot dead in separate attacks in Belfast, becoming the first casualties in 1988 of Northern Ireland's political violence, the police said today.

title: IN THE NATURE STATE
description: LEAD: ALL OF a sudden, there was a muzzle on my thigh and two brown eyes trying to catch mine. The eyes said, ''I want attention,'' and the tail that thumped and the whine that reached deep into the well where my guilt is stored said, ''I want attention now.''

title: Bringing the Office Home
description: IF there was one hot catch-phrase at this year's show, it was the ''home office.'' By one estimate, there are 13 million proprietors running businesses from their homes, and many of these people have high incomes, making them attractive targets for vendors.

title: BUICK PUTS STAMP ON REATTA
description: IT happens, I guess. The older you get, the less certain you are about anything.

title: Nets Send Gminski, Coleman to 76ers
description: While Mike Gminski chugged up and down the court in the fourth quarter of the Nets' 103-96 loss to the Boston Celtics tonight, the team's front office traded him to the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: The Yankees signed the wrong Jack. What they need is pitching, and Steinbrenner should have signed Jack Morris. Besides, as a right-handed power hitter, Clark will not have an easy time hitting homers in Yankee Stadium. JOSEPH A. LEVY Rego Park, Queens

title: HIGH COURT GIVES A CIVICS LESSON
description: IN 1969, the Supreme Court ruled that students ''do not shed their constitutional rights to freedom of speech or expression at the schoolhouse gate.''

title:
GARDENING;
The Long and Short of Dwarf Conifers
description: LEAD: CONIFERS are among the more highly valued landscape plants. Their evergreen foliage is attractive regardless of season, they vary greatly in color and texture and are available in a variety of forms.

title: JOYCE WOLF IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. George A. Wolf of Bellerose, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Joyce Carol Wolf to Phillip Anthony Ortiz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar A. Ortiz of Port Jefferson Station, L.I. Miss Wolf, a purchasing agent for the Thomas Publishing Company in New York, graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton, N.Y., as did Mr. Ortiz, who is studying for a Ph.D. degree in physiology and biophysics at the School of Medicine of SUNY at Stony Brook.

title: A '31 ANSCHLUSS MIGHT HAVE FOILED HITLER
description: To the Editor:

title: Ordeal of Son's Auto Injury Spurs Father to Seek a Recall
description: Larry Garrett is mild-mannered and friendly, traits reflected in his son Jimmy, who is paralyzed from the waist down because of a 1985 car accident.

title: EMPLOYERS OFFER AID ON CHILD CARE
description: More than 10 percent of the nation's employers provide specific benefits or services to help their workers arrange for child care, the Labor Department said Friday.

title: T. J. JULIAN IS WED TO MARY R. RAHO
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., Mary Rachel Raho, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Raho of Rye and Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Joseph Julian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Julian of Boca Raton, Fla., and Utica, N.Y. Msgr. Donald Pryor performed the ceremony.

title: Cuba's Decision to Stay Home Could Be Costly
description: Cuba's decision not to attend the 1988 Seoul Olympics could result in its loss of the 1991 Pan American Games, which were awarded to Havana two years ago.

title: 'Greek' Loses an Out Bet
description: IN the tinkle of Las Vegas slot machines nearly two decades ago, Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder was hurrying out of the Stardust lobby toward double glass doors. But instead of moving through the door that opened outward, he found himself stumbling against the door that opened inward.

title: Correction
description: A picture on page 26 on Dec. 27 with an article about Chinese writers and artists carried an incorrect caption. The playwright pictured was Wu Zuguang, not Liu Jinyuan.

title: A CASE OF COLIC
description: It was a thrill to see our son's article on the About Men page. It was also a source of perverse satisfaction to me, as I well remember that he, too, was a colicky baby who drove us to distraction for a time, as we paced the floor with that same feeling of helplessness. There is some justice in the world. ARNOLD BERMAN, Coconut Creek, Fla.

title: The Co-op 'Chill'
description: To the Editor:

title: Aboard the Andalusian Express
description: AS the Andalusian Express wends its way through the southern Spanish province for which it is named, the beauty and splendor of the region unfold as if the pages of a photo album of the American South and West were being slowly turned.

title: Jazz and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Plays A Factor In N.F.C.
description: Between them, the Washington Redskins and the surprising Minnesota Vikings have four starting quarterbacks, two big-play receivers who have emerged from the shadows, two strong defensive lines and one cornerback with a pain in the ribs.

title: MY SIX YEARS ON THE COUCH
description: It is worth noting that Dan Wakefield was strongly advised by his analyst not to marry a woman he thought he loved. I can testify that a very similar episode took place in my own analysis. When, years later, the analyst began to have second thoughts about his earlier judgment, he brushed the matter off. ''You know what they say about analysts,'' he said, ''always certain, frequently wrong.'' LOU LIPSITZ Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: PRAISING HIS NAME IN THE FIRE
description: KIDDUSH HASHEM Jewish Religious and Cultural Life in Poland During the Holocaust. By Shimon Huberband. Translated by David E. Fishman. Edited by Jeffrey S. Gurock and Robert S. Hirt. 474 pp. New Jersey/New York: KTAV Publishing House/ Yeshiva University Press. $35.

title: Ballet: 'Square Dance'
description: LIKE a well-oiled machine, the New York City Ballet nowadays can be counted upon to produce reliably smooth performances. Friday night's program at the New York State Theater was no exception, even when some previously scheduled dancers were replaced by others.

title: A Crew Leader
description: WHILE Horace Davenport was growing up in not very prosperous circumstances in Brooklyn in the 1920's, he went to Columbia, where he went out for sports teams - football, swimming and crew -so he could eat. In that era, the training table for the athletes featured steaks and was a standard accoutrement of intercollegiate athletics.

title: 117 Secret U.S. Atomic Tests Are Indicated in Seismic Data
description: The United States has concealed at least 117 nuclear explosions at its underground test site in the Nevada desert over the past quarter-century, a group of private scientists reported yesterday.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: With Henderson and Randolph in front and Winfield and Pags following, the Yankee lineup will be devastating. With Clark hitting behind him, Mattingly will have an unbelievable season. As for pitching, the American League East is a weak division anyway with no team able to count on more than two reliable starters. The Yankees will be there in October. NORMAN KRASNE Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: ANIMAL-RIGHTS GROUP ASSAILS EGG FARM
description: NEW JERSEY'S largest egg farm has put this Warren County community on the map by just having produced its billionth egg. Poultrymen are impressed, but not everyone is crowing about it.

title: CONNECTICUT Q&A: Frank D. Gawle; 'Teaching Is Something You Live'
description: THIS month, Frank D. Gawle begins his official duties as the Connecticut Teacher of the Year. He is also marking his 30th year as a teacher, 28 of which he has spent teaching social studies at Enfield High School.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SONS AND DAUGHTERS. By Stephen Longstreet. (Putnam, $18.95.) Though this is the concluding volume of the novelist Stephen Longstreet's trilogy tracing the rise of a fictional banking family, it hardly closes the book on them. In fact, the Fiore clan has produced enough offspring to make it seem likely they will ride the tide of fortune far into the future.

title: FIRST, ALBANY HAS TO COUNT ITS MONEY
description: THE 1988 battle over the New York State budget, which began formally last week with Governor Cuomo's presentation of his spending plan, will probably be not so much about how to spend the money as about how much money there is to spend.

title: Early Salvo: Moynihan Begins TV Campaign Ads
description: In what political analysts view as a pre-emptive strike, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan is taking his 1988 re-election campaign public with a series of television advertisements that begin in New York City on Monday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE National Football League has named Shane Conlan of the Buffalo Bills rookie of the year. Conlan was a first-round draft pick from Penn State, where he helped the Nittany Lions win the 1986 national championship. . . . Tamara McKinney, the United States' best hope for an Olympic medal in skiing, has progressed to gate training in her comeback from a fractured ankle. McKinney, whose injury in November caused her to miss the World Cup season, is expected to compete in her first race of the season later this month or in early February. . . . Six years after his last appearance at the United States Olympic Invitational Track and Field meet, Renaldo Nehemiah, who took some time off to play football for the San Francisco 49ers, has entered the 55-meter hurdles at the event set for the Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Feb. 13. . . . Evelyn Ashford, the world-record holder in the 100-meter dash, has entered the 55-meter dash at the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5. . . . Bruce Murray, a senior forward who led the Clemson soccer team to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship last month, has won the Hermann Award as the top college soccer player in the country.

title: LOUISE M. PURCELL TO WED GLENN EDWARD HEMMERLE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Purcell of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Louise Mary Purcell to Glenn Edward Hemmerle, the son of Mrs. John Hemmerle of Rocky Mount, N.C., and the late Mr. Hemmerle. An April wedding is planned.

title: L.I.U. Is to Shift Its Emphasis To Work-Study Curriculum
description: Trustees of Long Island University approved a plan last week to shift its academic emphasis to a work-study program.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A WORLD DESTROYED: Hiroshima and the Origins of the Arms Race, by Martin J. Sherwin. (Vintage, $9.95.) Examining decisions made by Franklin Roosevelt, Winston Churchill and Harry Truman, the historian Martin J. Sherwin attempts to show how the world lost its chance to avoid the arms race by bringing nuclear weapons under international control. In 1975, Gaddis Smith said here that the book ''presents a comprehensible and disturbing picture of the continuities between World War II and the cold war.'' THE COUNTERLIFE, by Philip Roth. (Penguin, $4.95.) Nathan Zuckerman, the hero of Philip Roth's novels ''The Ghost Writer,'' ''Zuckerman Unbound'' and

title: A Wellspring From Poulenc's Song Legacy
description: FOR A DECADE NOW, THE GREAT point of reference for the songs of Francis Poulenc has been the rich edition integrale, lovingly and carefully produced for EMI with Dalton Baldwin (who early in his career was close to Poulenc's artistic circle) at the piano. The singers are Elly Ameling, Nicolai Gedda, Michel Senechal, William Parker and Gerard Souzay: important talents all. The five-disk imported set (French EMI 165 16231) remains essential for any song lover's library.

title: AUGUST WEDDING FOR CAROLE BALIN
description: The engagement of Carole Beth Balin to Michael Eric Gertzman, a son of Dr. Gloria B. Gertzman and Arthur A. Gertzman of Bridgewater, N.J., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore G. Balin of Andover, Mass. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Balin is a second-year rabbinical student at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in New York. She graduated cum laude from Wellesley College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Her mother, Marcia Balin, is a telemarketing sales trainer at the Compugraphic Corporation in Andover. Her father is a senior engineer for Textron Defense Systems in Andover.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Restoration Project Saves a 1785 Saltbox
description: A SALTBOX Colonial on two-thirds of an acre at 79 Hollow Tree Ridge Road in Darien is on sale for $400,000. Built in 1785 by Benjamin Weed, a soldier in the Revolutionary War, the 33- by 35-foot dwelling is listed on the State Register of Historic Places and has been undergoing extensive structural restoration since last July by the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: FOREIGN MONEY, U.S. FEARS
description: Isn't progress wonderful (''Foreign Money, U.S. Fears,'' by Martin and Susan Tolchin, Dec. 13)? In just a little over 200 years we have progressed from being a colony whose economic and political life was governed from across the ocean, to an expanding free nation, to the world's greatest political and economic power and the world's largest creditor nation, and, in the last six Reagan years, to being the world's largest debtor nation, with an economy increasingly owned and controlled by foreign investors from across two oceans. BERNARD LEIBMAN Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: CONSPIRACY TO ADVOCATE
description: LEAD: FIGHTING FAITHS The Abrams Case, the Supreme Court, and Free Speech. By Richard Polenberg. Illustrated. 431 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
EXERCIZE
description: LEAD: Martina: Fitness and Conditioning RKO Pictures Home Video 55 minutes. $29.95.

title: LOOKING BACK AT 'LOOKING BACKWARD': WE HAVE SEEN THE FUTURE AND IT DIDN'T WORK
description: NEAR the end of the last century Edward Bellamy wrote ''Looking Backward'' - a ''fanciful romance,'' as he called it - in which he risked daring predictions about life at the end of our own century. We are still reading his durable classic, but time has revealed to us what it hid from him: the appalling implications of his prophecies.

title: INSIDE
description: CBS Drops Commentator Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, a television commentator for 12 years with the CBS Sports show ''N.F.L. Today,'' was dismissed a day after making controversial comments about blacks in sports. Section 5. Unifying Force in Cambodia Many of the 61,000 Cambodians in border refugee camps controlled by the Communist Khmer Rouge look to Prince Sihanouk, the non-Communist opposition leader, as a sort of liberator. Page 14. Ikle Leaving Pentagon Fred C. Ikle is quitting as Under Secretary of Defense, completing a realignment of senior officials. Page 13.

title: Does Pro Golf Need A New Star To Succeed?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: MOVIES
description: My Name Is Nobody Starring Henry Fonda, Terence Hill. Directed by Tonino Valerii, 1974. Kartes Video Communications. 115 minutes. $19.95.

title: Retelling Blizzard of '88 in Pictures, Prose and Poetry
description: THE mood on Wall Street was glum; only 2,000 shares changed hands that Tuesday. Retail sales took a beating; a B. Altman's store saw only one costumer all day. Food prices soared; milk went from 2 cents to more than 10 cents a quart within three days.

title: A Tax Worry Adds To Texaco's Burdens
description: Texaco might face a $6.5 billion bill for back taxes relating to the pricing of Saudi Arabian oil from 1979 to 1981. The Internal Revenue Service would not comment, but Texaco said it was possible such a claim would be filed in the company's bankruptcy proceedings. Texaco's effort to get out of bankruptcy was already facing enormous expenses, principally a $3 billion payment to Pennzoil to settle their celebrated legal dispute. Texaco's three partners in the Arabian American Oil Company - Exxon, Chevron and Mobil - all said that they had received no indication that additional taxes would be sought from them.

title: 'Mystery of Edwin Drood' in Elmsford
description: ''PREPARE yourself for unexpected twists and turns,'' the audience is forewarned. It is the audience that determines some of those surprises - by applauding, by hissing, by a show of hands - in the second act of ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood.''

title: Cambodians in Pol Pot's Camps Await a Liberator
description: Of all the Cambodians whose future will be discussed in coming talks on a political compromise, perhaps none have so much to gain or lose as the tens of thousands of civilians still living under the control of Communists who run several refugee camps along the Thai-Cambodian border.

title: Ikle Leaving Pentagon as Carlucci Realigns Aides
description: Fred C. Ikle, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, said today that he was resigning from the top-level Pentagon post, essentially completing a realignment of senior military officials under the new Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci.

title: Trends in Art History
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Doing in Rio de Janeiro
description: THERE is much more to celebrate in busy and sensuous Rio de Janeiro than generous beaches, exotic night life and the string of luminous baccanalia that climax with Carnival.

title: JERI BITTERMAN TO WED MICHAEL ALAN KARPEN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Bitterman of Parsippany, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jeri S. Bitterman to Michael Alan Karpen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Karpen of Passaic, N.J.

title: Clipper Sinks at Boston Pier
description: A 144-foot clipper believed to the nation's last working square rigger of her size sank Thursday night while docked for maintenance work, officials said Friday. The 80-year-old Regina Maris was undergoing routine maintenance at the Boston Marine Works when she sank in about 30 feet of water, said Dusty Rhodes, a spokeswoman for Quincy's Marina Bay, where the vessel was usually docked. She said officials did not know what caused the ship to sink.

title: Jazz
description: Compatible improvisers who stick together, year after year, develop camaraderie and quick reflexes that can't be built any other way. A long-running band doesn't need conventions or formulas; like family members who can finish one another's sentences, they can skip the basics and get down to deeper communications. Two long-running jazz groups are in the clubs this week.

title: Jazz and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace. Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room. We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out. Is there any other kind of stripping you can suggest to fill in these gaps?

title: Des Moines Downtown Changes Its Face
description: LEAD: IN a few months, when the ground is no longer frozen, executives of the Principal Financial Group, the largest employer in Des Moines, plan to break ground for Iowa's tallest building. It is a speculative rental that is to rise 44 stories in the city's downtown.

title: Are You an American? Show Us Your Papers
description: IT'S always been an early harbinger of spring around our house: the first mail of the new year brings a letter from a Connecticut university congratulating me for once again having been appointed an adjunct professor for the spring semester. It's a little extra cash, but that's not why I do it; call it teaching for the joy of it.

title: 200 Workers Vote to Strike At a Connecticut Steel Plant
description: Two hundred workers at Thames Valley Steel Corporation, one of the city's largest businesses, voted Friday to strike after the current contract expires at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They're interested only in famous brand names like Brooks Brothers, Ralph Lauren, Tiffany; they aren't interested in American souvenirs.'' - Katsuhiko Narisada, of the Japan National Tourist Organization, on foreign shoppers in the U.S. [ 22:2. ]

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: On-Time Data For Flights Draw Interest

title: PANAMA'S CHIEF DEFIES U.S. POWERS OF PERSUASION
description: WHEN RICHARD L. ARMITAGE, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, embarked on a secret mission to Panama two weeks ago, he carried a harsh message. In a lengthy meeting, he told Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega, the de facto leader of the military-controlled regime, to get out of politics within three months so that the country could have a cushion of civilian rule before elections next year.

title: ITALY DEBATES ITS 45 YEARS OF AVERSION TO FASCISM
description: SINCE Mussolini's fall in 1943, anti-Fascism has been a national creed in Italy, extolled, institutionalized and politically manipulated. Only recently has anyone argued that it is obsolete. The debate has raged since Italy's most prominent historian of the Fascist period, Prof. Renzo De Felice, said in a newspaper interview last month that ''the great alternative'' between Fascism and anti-Fascism ''no longer makes any sense either in the public conscience or in the reality of everyday political struggles.''

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
DONGAN HILLS
description: LEAD: SAL PENNACCHIO remembers the day five years ago when he and his wife moved to Dongan Hills. A storm had left a mountain of snow between him and his new front door.

title: THE MAKE-OVER AT ESTEE LAUDER
description: How weary I am of having the marketing world tell me I am old and worthless (''The Make-Over at Estee Lauder,'' by Lisa Belkin, Nov. 29)! Movies are made for yuppies. Clothes are designed for people in their 20's and early 30's with the figures of nymphs. And now, even Leonard Lauder has decided that the future of his Estee Lauder empire rests primarily with the young.

title: STORMING PRETORIA'S CASTLE - TO WRITE OR FIGHT?
description: LEAD: ARTHUR NORTJE, one of South Africa's finest young writers, died in Oxford in 1970 at the age of 29. He was a poet and black. He was also intensely lonely. Some say he committed suicide because he dared not return to his native land to oppose apartheid. Others say he had died well before his death.

title: Ski Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Filipino Leftists Take a Half Step Above Ground
description: Simply stating his party affiliation is considered to be an act of courage for Amado Santos, a candidate for mayor of this town 50 miles north of Manila.

title: Mayor of Newark Proposing 12% Increase in Property Tax
description: Residents face an average property-tax increase of 12 percent this year, most of it attributable to sharply higher costs for garbage disposal, Mayor Sharpe James announced this week.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Mahopac, N.Y. $272,500 21 Florence Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 17-year-old frame/brick raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, cul de sac, .96 acre; taxes $3,420. Rye, N.Y. $257,500 8 Glen Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 61-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman; new eat-in kitchen with quarry-tiled floor, study; taxes $2,500. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $253,000 341 Hunterbrook Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 19-year-old frame colonial; den, deck, 1.8 acre; taxes $3,888. Farmington, Conn. $178,000 47 Red Coat Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; excellent condition, screened porch, 100- by 200 foot lot; taxes $1,355. Glastonbury, Conn. $230,000 216 Carriage Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; gas heat and hot water, 2-car garage; taxes $2,280. Bridgeport, Conn. $139,000 Vincellette Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 19-year-old town house condominium; community pool, landscaping; taxes $2,072, monthly charges: $167. OTHER AREAS Milburn, N.J. $215,000 172 Myrtle Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 34-year-old colonial; screened porch, 1-car garage, fireplace; taxes $3,200. New Providence, N.J. $225,000 1596 Springfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, 33-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, newly remodeled kitchen, fireplace; taxes $2,508. Bay Shore, L.I. $650,000 55 Gardner Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fireplace, boat slip, 2 acres; taxes $10,000.

title: Correction
description: A front-page caption on Jan. 3 in The Guide, about the Boar's Head and Yule Log Festival at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, gave an incorrect identification provided by the event's publicity agent for the actor at the right. He was Rob Elk.

title: Mondrian on the Path to the Abstract
description: IT IS UNUSUAL FOR A DEALER TO put together an exhibition on a modern master that seems indispensable. Yet Sidney Janis has done just that. The 44 paintings, drawings and gouaches at the Sidney Janis gallery through Feb. 13 focus on the early figurative work and the ideas and feelings that Piet Mondrian wanted to distill and synthesize in his abstraction. The result is a timely statement about Mondrian and about abstract art.

title: PUT LIFE IN DEAD-CAR COLLECTION
description: American cities are awash in a tidal wave of hulks - abandoned cars. They could be reducing the tide and making money in the process. Instead, notably in New York, they are sinking.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HUMOR AND THE PRESIDENCY. By Gerald R. Ford. (Arbor House, $15.95.) At the opening of the Gerald R. Ford Library and Museum in Grand Rapids, Mich., in 1981, President Ford found himself reminiscing with a bunch of old political cronies about the good times they had had when Mr. Ford was in the White House.

title: Goodbye Daisy Wheel, Hello Laser
description: JAMES BOB stomped into the employee lounge, slammed his quarters into the cold drink machine and pounded on it. ''I hate that printer!'' he said. ''The noise is driving me crazy and I hate getting ribbon ink all over my hands.'' He's fussy that way.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Fare Offered in Irvington
description: LEAD: HISTORY does repeat itself, but usually at a higher price. Certainly the menu at Peregrine's is a perfect case in point.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Colonial Atmosphere in Bergen
description: LEAD: ON A BLUSTERY winter's evening, the setting could not be more inviting: Wing chairs spotted around the spacious dining room, grandfather clocks quietly ticking and a fire aglow in the hearth.

title: WOULD YOU CHOSE TO PLAY OR DEFEND?
description: THE interests of bridge players reflect, in microcosm, a 20th-century tendency to move away from intellectual challenges. Many voters who once studied editorials and argued about socialism are now content with a 30-second television view of a politician. Many schoolchildren do not study grammar, history and foreign languages. Those who might once have sampled Henry James now watch a soap opera. And bridge players have abandoned the double-dummy problem.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 17, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-15

title: IN TV AT THE MOMENT, 'DIGITAL' MAY NOT ADD UP
description: WHAT SNAKE OIL was to folk medicine in the last century, the word ''digital'' is to home electronics in our era. Like the reptilian elixir, or traditional incantations of ''abracadabra,'' that word is deemed to possess miraculous powers. Anything to which the term digital can be attached is supposed to be either perfect already or getting there fast.

title: DIANE MCFERRIN TO WED
description: Lieut. Col. Ralph W. McFerrin, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. McFerrin of Kansas City, Mo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Diane Elizabeth McFerrin to Gerald Harlan Peters, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Peters of Manhasset, L.I. Miss McFerrin, a graduate of the University of Missouri, is a marketing manager for the Rosenbluth Travel Agency in Philadelphia, where her fiance is an associate with the Susquehanna Investment Group. Mr. Peters graduated from Lafayette College. His father is a stockbroker in New York.

title: First Town Houses: Strangers In Town
description: The first town-house development in Palisades Park, N.J., is under construction at the corner of Grand Avenue and Roosevelt Place. Upon completion next fall, the six buildings of the 26-unit complex will join the area's mostly one-family homes and garden apartments. The $4 million project's first building, with three units, will be ready for occupancy next month, said the developer, Alfred Haber. A second building with five units will be completed in March. Since sales of the two- and three-bedroom town houses, priced from $259,000 to $289,000, began in November, nine have been sold.

title: THE WORLD: The Stinger Missile; HELPING TO CHANGE THE COURSE OF A WAR
description: WHAT the longbow was to English yeomen and the V-2 rocket was to the Germans in World War II, the Stinger antiaircraft missile is to today's American-backed guerrilla fighters.

title: DR. KATHERINE MIRIAM HESS WEDS KENNETH M. TALLERING
description: The marriage of Dr. Katherine Miriam Hess, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hess of New York, to Kenneth Marc Tallering, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Tallering of Great Neck, L.I., took place last evening at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck and Bolton Landing, N.Y. Rabbis Robert Widom and Gunther Hirschberg officiated.

title: HEIDI DINA CHEVEN WEDS MICHAEL D. JAFFE, LAWYER
description: Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., was the setting last evening for the wedding of Heidi Dina Cheven, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Cheven of Sands Point, L.I., to Michael David Jaffe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Jaffe of Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal officiated. The bride, a graduate of Adelphi University and the St. John's University Law School, is an officer and a director of the Country-Wide Insurance Company in Manhattan. Her father is the president and chairman of the company, and her mother, Barbara Cheven, is its attorney of record.

title: Tactics and Technology on Farmers' Agenda
description: WHILE household gardeners, with spring in mind, have begun poring over seed catalogues, farmers and others for whom the land provides a livelihood have been preparing to gather in Atlantic City Tuesday for the annual New Jersey Vegetable Meeting, a three-day conference said to be the largest of its kind on the East Coast.

title: The Winter Kitchen Offers Fish Staples
description: FISH cookery in winter turns to the skillet and the oven, rather than the grill. As a result, thick steaks of swordfish and tuna are low on the shopping list.

title: Dismissed Officer Held in Attack on Captain
description: An officer who was dismissed for running a British container ship aground stabbed his captain and threw him overboard today, the Coast Guard reported.

title: PILOT FATIGUE ENDANGERS PASSENGERS ON INTERNATIONAL FLIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKE PARALYZES THE HAITI CAPITAL ON EVE OF ELECTION
description: On the eve of Haiti's second attempt at presidential elections in seven weeks, a general strike brought the usually teeming capital to a virtual standstill today.

title: LONGINGS, SWOONINGS AND POSTURINGS
description: LEAD: RILKE AND BENVENUTA An Intimate Correspondence. Edited by Magda von Hattingberg. Translated by Joel Agee. 148 pp. New York: Fromm International. $16.95. THE PRETTIEST LOVE LETTERS IN THE WORLD Letters Between Lucrezia Borgia & Pietro Bembo 1503 to 1519. Translated by Hugh Shankland. Illustrated by Richard Shirley Smith.

title: Corrections
description: A Travel Advisory report on Dec. 27 about Hertz rental cars omitted mention of some national car-rental companies that hold renters responsible not only for collision damage but also for vandalism, theft and other loss of the car. Besides Value Rent-a-Car and Hertz, they are Alamo and Thrifty. In some copies, the headline characterized Hertz's new policy inaccurately. Purchase of the company's revised damage waiver now covers the customer for loss of the car and other damage cited above.

title: Classics Won't Just Disappear
description: OUT OF FRUSTRATION WITH A HISTORICAL clock that insists on moving at its own measured pace, some dedicated propagandists for new music come to sound like the generals who insisted that the only way to save Vietnamese villages was to bomb them out of existence. Only by ruthlessly dismantling the repertory built up over previous centuries, it is suggested, can room be made for the 20th century's own candidates for survival. Few, even among the fiercest ideologues, actually call for the extermination of Mozart, Beethoven or Schubert, but drastic solutions short of that are sometimes proposed.

title: Fire at Russian Palace
description: A fire broke out in the 18th century Yekaterinsky Palace on Friday night, slightly damaging its gilded throne hall, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today. The palace in the town of Pushkin, near Leningrad, is considered one of the finest examples of Russian Baroque architecture.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: If Jack Clark is healthy, he provides the Yankees the right-handed power they have missed since Thurman Munson. But to win the pennant, the Yankees still need a right-handed starting pitcher. STAN BARBER Bronx

title: Leading a New Effort To Support Channel 13
description: LEAD: ELAINE WINGATE CONWAY makes the concession: she loves organizing. People, parties, even the clutter on her own desk. Mrs. Conway, who lives in Bronxville, gets a kick out of making order out of chaos, festivities out of simple gatherings and volunteer activists out of merely interested individuals.

title: In White Plains, a Growing Disenchantment With Development
description: THE city of White Plains has 47,000 occupants at night and close to 250,000 in the daytime, when shoppers and office workers arrive - and that's enough for the time being, according to city officials.

title: LUCINDA J. ALPERT TO WED D. H. GRANDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm C. Green of Boston and East Hebron, N.H., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Green's daughter Lucinda Jean Alpert to Dodd Harrison Grande, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Grande of Des Moines, Wash. The couple plan to marry March 5.

title: BORK IS BACK IN OLD ROLE OF INTELLECTUAL CRUSADER
description: IN choosing to end his career as a Federal judge with a blast at his critics and a vow to seek vindication off the bench, Robert H. Bork validated both the admiration of his supporters and the worst fears of those who succeeded in blocking his elevation to the Supreme Court four months ago.

title: Economics in 4 Million Words
description: LEAD: SUMMING UP modern economics is no easy matter. But a new four-volume ''dictionary'' of economics, published this month by Stockton Press and Macmillan U.K., attempts to do just that. ''The New Palgrave: A Dictionary of Economics'' presents leading economists surveying their fields: Milton Friedman on monetary theory, Wassily Leontief on input-output analysis, Thomas Sargent on rational expectations, Paul Samuelson on neoclassical economics, Paul MacAvoy on regulation.

title: Defenses Face Test In Denver
description: The two most dangerous quarterbacks remaining in the National Football League playoffs perform here Sunday in the American Conference championship game.

title: A CRASH PROGRAM
description: What can be done right now to bring back a semblance of stability to the stock market?

title:
Body and Mind;
Caffeine High
description: LEAD: ABOUT TWO-THIRDS of the way through one of those 36-hour shifts in medical school, I went to the coffee urn - that ubiquitous trough nestled somewhere in or near every known nurses' station - to draw perhaps my 10th cup of the shift. One of the surgical residents - true exemplar of a sarcastic breed - said, ''If you sign up now, I'll do your Whipple for you at today's prices.

title: CELEBRATING BY DONATING TO NEEDIEST
description: Engagements, weddings, the birth of a child or grandchild and enduring friendship are reasons for celebration, and many people share their joy with The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 'Frosty' Increases Streak
description: Frosty the Snowman joined an increasingly interesting lineup of Florida Derby prospects by winning his third start without a defeat at Gulfstream Park today.

title: MARY ANN DORE IS ENGAGED
description: Mrs. Edward James Dore Jr. of Bloomfield Hills and Glen Arbor, Mich., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Ann Dore, to David James O'Connell of Bronxville, N.Y., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence O'Connell. Ms. Dore, the daughter also of the late Mr. Dore, is an institutional equities saleswoman with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. Her fiance is a principal of Morgan Stanley Asset Management. They plan to marry Feb. 27.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Derry, N.H.: Hometown Retirement
description: LEAD: ACTING on a hunch that older retirees want to live in their hometowns, a nursing-home owner has turned to building small retirement villages in New Hampshire.

title: Army Is Trying to Save Half Of Plan for New Helicopters
description: The Army has asked Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci to authorize continued development of a new tactical helicopter in exchange for delaying similar work on a model for transporting troops, Pentagon sources say.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW BELGIAN COINS IN GOLD AND SILVER
description: LEAD: TWO bullion coins from Belgium intertwine history and modern economics. The coins bear a traditional design dating from the 16th century and are the first legal-tender coins denominated in present-day European Currency Units, or ECU's.

title: CBS Dismisses Snyder
description: CBS Sports dismissed Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder yesterday, a day after the veteran commentator made derogatory racial comments about athletes.

title: CANDIDATES TAKE TO THE STUMP, THEN AND NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Going to Pieces
description: FINDING SOLUTIONS TO PROBLEMS may be difficult enough these days without someone like Steve Richardson, whose active trade is obfuscation. He's the owner of Stave Puzzles in Norwich, Vt., an enterprise dedicated to state-of-the-art vexatiousness. Stave's hand-painted and custom-cut wooden jigsaw puzzles go beyond the ruses that other puzzlemakers have long employed as tools of confusion - monochromatic designs, say, or pieces painted back and front. ''One dastardly thing we do,'' says Richardson, gleefully, ''is paint the puzzle so that a piece in the wrong place looks more correct there than it does in the right place. We intentionally mislead the puzzler.''

title: Mitsuko Shirai in Recital
description: Mitsuko Shirai, a mezzo-soprano, will sing songs by Mendelssohn, Liszt and Wolf, and Karol Szymanowski's settings of James Joyce poems, tonight at 8 in Alice Tully Hall. Her accompanist will be Harmut Holl. Tickets are $10. Information: 874-6770.

title: The Real Revelation In Pollock's Floor
description: I fail to see how the uncovering of Jackson Pollock's studio floor reveals evidence of his working process [ ''Studio Floor Yields a New Look at Polock's Art,'' Dec. 20 ] . The real revelation coming from Pollock's studio floor is the fact that he was a very messy painter who liked to walk around in wet paint.

title:
MUSIC;
Music Is Reward Enough
description: LEAD: AT THE AGE OF 75, ERICH Leinsdorf has little use for honors, anniversaries and the like. ''I don't believe in jubilees, and I don't believe in awards - in all this piffle - because we have been rewarded already, we people who live with Haydn and Mozart and Bach, and we don't need any more medals.'' Yet even Mr.

title: WHO PAYS FOR MEXICO
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSAN ROBINSON, A LAWYER, WEDS
description: Susan Dana Robinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin S. Robinson of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there last evening to Lincoln W. Briggs, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald K. Briggs of New York. Rabbi Charles Lippman and the Rev. Raynar W. Hesse, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Fenway Country Club.

title: Water-Fund Plan Gives Town Hope
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN proposed a $60 million loan fund last week to help provide alternative sources of water for people whose private wells are contaminated.

title: Free Trade Pact Spurs Debate in Canada
description: Canada's free trade agreement with the United States is provoking a spirited debate unusual for this normally placid nation.

title: Jackson Campaigns on an Iowa Farm
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson holding 8-year old Nick Aldrich on his lap on a visit yesterday to the farm of Terry Hoy, right, in Adel, about 20 miles west of Des Moines. The Democratic Presidential candidate was there to talk with a group of local farmers about his farm policy proposals. (NYT/Jim Wilson)

title: New Attack on Arizona Governor
description: Four Republican members of Arizona's Congressional delegation called for Gov. Evan Mecham to resign today, saying the legal and political turmoil surrounding him had virtually paralyzed the state.

title: Mets Unveil New Team
description: A SCARECROW stood guard on the snowy field, orange work clothes and a bucket for a head. A few footprints led toward the pitching mound, where Dave Johnson often trudged last summer. The scoreboard was being dismantled, more radically than the team itself.

title: COORDINATE, DON'T STRANGLE, MARKETS
description: While the New York Stock Exchange scrambles to tame the exaggerations of computerized program trading, President Reagan's task force report looks elsewhere for the causes of the October crash. Traditional markets for stocks, and the newer markets for stock futures and options, the commission argues, are now inextricably linked. But regulation of the markets remains separate. The uncoordinated response to plunging securities prices on Oct. 19 and 20 deepened the crisis and even threatened to destabilize the banking system.

title: TV
description: Look to the stars in choosing films on both cable and broadcast TV this week. Bravura performances highlight a cross-section of offerings. On cable, women have the edge. Elisabeth Bergner, the German-born actress, makes a memorable Empress of Russia in the British biographical drama, ''Catherine the Great'' (1934) - Monday at 9 P.M. and 1 A.M. on Arts & Entertainment. Deborah Kerr, as a prep-school teacher's wife dominates ''Tea and Sympathy'' (1956) with a luminous performance, sharing the focus with John Kerr, as the tormented student. This adaptation of Robert Anderson's play has a soggy, tacked-on apologia but also two powerful new scenes, one being the wife's inspection of a girl at a cash register. Watch Miss Kerr's expression here -Thursday at 4:30 P.M. on Cinemax.

title:
GARDENING;
The Long and Short of Dwarf Conifers
description: LEAD: CONIFERS are among the more highly valued landscape plants. Their evergreen foliage is attractive regardless of season, they vary greatly in color and texture and are available in a variety of forms.

title: AMERICA STILL HAUNTED BY PROBLEMS OF BLACK POOR
description: NOT long before he was gunned down on the balcony of a motel in Memphis, the Rev.
