Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. observed that it did no good to be allowed to eat in a restaurant if you had no money to pay for a hamburger. Dr. King, whose birthday will be commemorated tomorrow, died 20 years ago this year, an anniversary that is provoking deep reflection. His remark about race and poverty reflects both his achievements and the tragedy of inner city poverty that neither he nor anyone else has been able to remedy.

title: Computers: A Necessary Insidiousness
description: COMPUTERS are insidious things. You may have read how easy it is to use one.

title: Harvesting Drama in Hardy Country
description: IN PROSPECT, VISITING THE NA-tional Theater to see ''Entertaining Strangers'' seemed rather like going to the Ritz for bran and apple juice. According to pre-opening publicity, it was a ''community play,'' a history of 19th-century Dorchester painstakingly researched by the townspeople themselves and originally presented in a local church. Everything suggested the sort of piece critics receive respectfully and their readers are canny enough to avoid. It sounded worthy, earnest and paralyzingly dull; the equivalent of a working breakfast in a rural vicarage.

title: New Mafia Drive Seen in Sicily Ex-Mayor's Death
description: A former Mayor of Palermo was shot to death on a crowded city street this week in what officials say is a signal that the Mafia has taken the offensive again, less than a month after a mass trial convicted 338 defendants of Mafia crimes.

title: Taiwan Imprisons 2 Backing Independence
description: A Taiwanese court today imposed long prison terms on two dissidents who were convicted of sedition for advocating Taiwan's independence from China.

title: IN COLOMBIA, DRUG MONEY TALKS AT THE HIGHEST LEVELS
description: SHORTLY after Jorge Luis Ochoa Vasquez was detained on minor traffic violations near Cali on Nov. 21, Yolanda Rico, a lawyer from Colombia's Attorney General's Office, arrived at the police precinct where he was being held, embraced him warmly, and then, with a flurry of legal arguments, began demanding his release.

title: WORKERS, IMMIGRANTS, SLAVES
description: POWER & CULTURE Essays on the American Working Class. By Herbert G. Gutman. Edited by Ira Berlin. 452 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $29.95.

title: Bigger Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed tomorrow. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only; offices are open in Manhattan at 25 Broadway, 90 Church St., 909 3d Ave., Grand Central Terminal, 33d St. and 8th Ave., 73 Pine St., 1384 Broadway, and 610 5th Ave. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: Regular collections. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on regular schedule. Libraries: New York Public Library, Brooklyn and Queens libraries closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule; minor adjustments during rush hour. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line of Metro-North on regular weekday schedule.

title: 'School for Wives' At the Whole Theatre
description: ''EACH man has his own design for wedded bliss.'' So says Arnolphe, a would-be husband determined not to be duped, in ''The School for Wives'' at the Whole Theatre.

title: MY SIX YEARS ON THE COUCH
description: With regard to Dan Wakefield's article, I am enclosing a poem I wrote some time ago, which I think you will find appropriate. I told him my anxieties, Confessed some improprieties, Revealed a dozen vices too (Well, at these prices, wouldn't you?) I thought that he'd have prodded me, He didn't even nod at me, He never showed a mild concern, Yet meekly, weekly, I'd return. MARILYN SHAPIRO New York, N.Y.

title: THE CALL WAS LATE: THE PRISONER DIED
description: LEAD: At 3:19 A.M., Central Standard Time, on Jan. 7, Texas began to execute Robert Streetman, who was strapped down at the state prison in Huntsville, by pumping lethal drugs into his veins. Before he was pronounced dead seven minutes later, the telephone rang in the death chamber. The Governor's office had word that the United States Supreme Court was prepared to consider a new motion for appeal, and, in the words of a prison spokesman, wanted to know ''where we were in the process.

title: College Offers Free Program to Help Those Over 50 Find Jobs
description: LEAD: PROGRAMS at Brookdale Community College in Lincroft and Middlesex County College in Edison are helping to ease the path to employment for older workers.

title: Towns That Want Radioactive Waste
description: MENTION plans for a radioactive waste dump, and most communities recoil in horror. Not Needles, Baker and Trona, three small towns in the Mojave Desert of California.

title: Zero-Coupon Bonds and the 'Kiddie' Tax
description: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

title: THE LAST MASSACRE
description: SHOSHONE MIKE By Frank Bergon. 290 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: NOVICE REGULATOR: David S. Ruder; Seeking Tighter Control Over the Financial Markets
description: DAVID S. RUDER was tapped to be a good caretaker.

title: The Many Visions of Shakespeare's 'Dream'
description: More than most Shakespearean plays, ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' freely lends itself to reinterpretation and transplantation, or - to use the word applied to Bottom - to ''translation.'' Although the play takes place in Athens and the forest beyond, it is an Athens of the mind, and the fairies can be relocated to almost any fictive environment - in contrast to the histories, which, by definition, are so rooted in specificity. The tragedies and many of the other comedies also happen in clearly defined courts, battlefields and forests. Although they certainly can be relocated, they are more indigenous than ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' which, with its extraordinary mythic qualities, can assume an even greater universality. A director can, in other words, imagine his own ''Dream'' - or nightmare - while the heart of the play remains immutable.

title: END OF AN ILLUSION
description: Palestinian protests over the last five weeks have brought about at least one profound change in Israeli thinking. People no longer believe that it will be easy to go on occupying the West Bank and Gaza.

title: L.I.R.R. Main Line to Enter Electric Age
description: LEAD: BEGINNING tomorrow, riders on the main line of the Long Island Rail Road will get faster, smoother, quieter and more direct service to Manhattan with the opening of full electric train service from Ronkonkoma.

title: MISS BRIGGS WED TO J. G. BROOKS JR.
description: The marriage of Margaret Mary Briggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Briggs of Williamsville, N.Y., to James G. Brooks Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooks of Naples, Fla., and Dorset, Vt., took place yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Robert A. Nunn performed the ceremony.

title: Finger Exercise
description: THEY look like overgrown calculators, but they do much more than math. A variety of handheld electronic devices can now do everything from keeping track of appointments to choosing lottery numbers.

title: HIGH-POWERED HOT DOGS AND OTHER MONUMENTS
description: Norval White has already done much to elevate popular appreciation of New York's physical history, as the co-author with Elliot Willensky of ''The AIA Guide to New York City,'' the standard architectural reference work for almost two decades. His new book, NEW YORK: A Physical History (Atheneum, $29.95), is as opinionated as that earlier volume, more of a commentary than a history, although it has dates and names in abundance (including such tidbits as crediting the high-powered firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill with the design of a small building in Times Square that now houses Nathan's Famous Hot Dogs). The book is organized by categories - water supply, transportation, immigration, monuments and so on - and thus tends to jump around chronologically. In his criticism, Mr. White hews to fairly conventional esthetic orthodoxy but serves up some surprises, such as his opinion that 240 Central Park South ''ranks as one of the great apartment houses.'' He views the city's development through phenomena that might at first seem remote or arcane. For example, he links the Irish potato famine of the 1840's to the enlargement of private residences from Federal-style intimacy to Renaissance Revival grandeur, fueled by the ''vast labor pool for domestic service.'' He sees the change in the skyline after World War II occurring largely because ''air conditioning made possible interior offices far from a window, and great fat boxes were plunked down among the finials.'' This book is an appropriate accompaniment to a period in which physical development is a hot topic and a subject of major importance.

title: Christmas
description: To the Editor: It's nice to be remembered. Especially at Christmastime. And that's what Virginia Van der Veer Hamilton did in her article ''Leaving Home for Christmas'' (Travel, Dec. 13).

title: NONFICTION
description: TRAGIC WAYS OF KILLING A WOMAN. By Nicole Loraux. Translated by Anthony

title: NOW IT'S NOFZIGER'S TURN
description: THE scene was familiar: a former senior Reagan Administration aide on trial, accused of trying to capitalize illegally on political contacts and a friendship with the President.

title: MY SIX YEARS ON THE COUCH
description: It would be unfortunate if Dan Wakefield's experience of ''strict Freudian psychoanalysis'' in the 1950's were considered representative of psychoanalysis today (''My Six Years on the Couch,'' Dec. 20). That he was not helped despite considerable expenditure of time and money, and that he felt traumatized is obvious from his bitter account.

title: MISS DICKERMAN TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen F. Dickerman of Lexington, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Tracey Beth Dickerman to Mark Albert Bilski, the son of Berthold Bilski of New York and the late Esther Alix Bilski, and the stepson of Victoria V. Bilski. A June wedding is planned.

title: PAMELA EVAN ROLLINGS WEDS NEAL R. BRENDEL
description: At the Heinz Memorial Chapel in Pittsburgh, Pamela Evan Rollings and Neal Robert Brendel, lawyers in Pittsburgh, were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert L. English, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Tornado Toll at 59 in 1987
description: Tornado deaths rose to 59 in the United States last year, nearly quadruple the toll of a year earlier, the National Weather Service says. While tornado-related deaths rebounded from the record low of 15 posted in 1986, last year's total still fell short of the long-term average of 90 fatalities, the agency said Thursday. Texas suffered the most from tornadoes last year, with 42 fatalities.

title: Inquiry on House Chairman and Lobbies Is Slowed
description: The former chief investigator for the Justice Department recommended last month against prosecuting Representative Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Banking Committee, because of insufficient evidence that he had accepted meals and entertainment from Washington lobbyists, lawyers close to the case say.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: COURTING EMMA HOWE. By Margaret A. Robinson. (Adler & Adler, $16.95.) The sweet, old-fashioned title is just right for this tale of personal trial in pioneer times. Arthur Smollett is a young man settling his own homestead in the new state of Washington in 1904. He is courting Emma Howe, a plain but spirited young woman who lives with her family in Warwick, Vt.

title: Violin: Sylvia Rosenberg
description: GEORGE PERLE'S Second Sonata for Solo Violin is, at its best, a work of expressive vigor, overlong by just a bit maybe, but calling for a performer who can project dissonant lines of urgent, nervous energy. The 20-minute piece from 1963 found a worthy exponent in the person of Sylvia Rosenberg, who gave the belated local premiere of Mr. Perle's sonata to start the second half of her recital at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday evening.

title: SUSAN R. SOLOW PLANS TO WED MARVIN DUBIN
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Solow of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Renee Solow, to Marvin Dubin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Dubin of Howard Beach, Queens.

title: Wiretap Inquiry Irks Suffolk Police
description: LEAD: SHARPLY differing views on law enforcement in Suffolk County were offered last week as a New York State watchdog agency convened hearings to make new accusations against the county police and prosecutors.

title: Roadside Diner In the Limelight
description: A BOARDED-UP stainless steel diner, resting forlornly amid weeds off a highway in Robbinsville, N.J., was destined for fame in Washington last spring. The Smithsonian Institution said it would acquire it as a classic example of the roadside eating places that flourished in the 1930's and '40's, the Golden Age of Diners.

title: Country Life Is Just A Matter of Adjustment
description: PETER constantly reminds me that I'm the first line of defense against the forest. It's been that way since we moved here.

title: Iroquois Drops Spur To Hartford Area
description: OPPONENTS of a proposed natural gas pipeline are hailing the elimination of a 42-mile east-west spur that would have cut through 10 towns in Connecticut. But they remain staunch in their opposition to the major part of the project, the route from Sherman to Milford.

title: Hamden Engraver Creates Artwork On Cycles and Cars
description: THOMAS LETIS'S candy apple-red motorcycle is often the subject of intense stares as he drives along streets and highways. It isn't the machine's color that attracts attention - it's the scores of scrolls and hand-engraved dragons and flowers.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Nobody wants to play now. I've been a player all my life, and I don't want to play. We have no control over our destiny.''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: INTIMATE ENEMIES. By Caryl Rivers. (Dutton. $17.95.) As a soap opera, ''Intimate Enemies'' might find an audience. Its two central characters, the liberal, attractive college provost Jessie McGrath and the handsome but disabled Mark Claymore, a Vietnam vet whom she has hired to head the R.O.T.C.

title: NAOMI R. HABER IS MARRIED TO JOEL BARRY RUDEN
description: The marriage of Naomi R. Haber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Haber of New York, to Joel Barry Rudin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Rudin of Bayside, Queens, took place last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Lavey Derby officiated.

title: Plotting Against U.S. Brings a 7-Year Term
description: A man who pleaded guilty to conspiring to overthrow the United States Government as a member of a radical group accused of nearly 20 bombings has been sentenced to seven years in prison and fined $20,000.

title: Martha's Vineyard Land Pact Leaves Some Indians Bitter
description: A bitter legal dispute between Indian tribal leaders and the Martha's Vineyard town of Gay Head ended this week with the signing of a final piece of legislation needed under a settlement that allows the tribe to buy some of the land it has long wanted. But few of the Indians are rejoicing.

title: NICARAGUA AGREES TO TALK DIRECTLY WITH THE CONTRAS
description: In a last-minute concession after two days of difficult bargaining, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua agreed today to open direct talks with rebel leaders and to suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua.

title: Music: 'Verein Revisited,' By Chamber Ensemble
description: THE New York Chamber Ensemble has undertaken an appealing four-concert series this season at Alice Tully Hall. Entitled ''Music of the Verein Revisited,'' it offers music once heard on the programs of Arnold Schoenberg's Society for Private Musical Performances in Vienna between 1917 and 1921.

title: Dole Investment Fund Shows a 30% Increase
description: Documents released today by Senator Bob Dole show that an investment fund established as a blind trust by his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, increased in value by 30 percent in the last three years, according to a review of the financial records.

title: Pop-Up Books: The Magical Art Of Making Movable Pictures Over the Years
description: WORDS, WORDS, words, said Hamlet, when Polonius asked him what was in the book he was reading. But sometimes books contain pictures, too; and sometimes, just sometimes, the pictures revolve or jiggle around or spring to attention.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER: The Art World
description: LEAD: THE Young Artists 88 show at the Katonah Gallery, five of its young artists agreed, was nifty.

title: As Catholic Rolls Rise, Priests Diversify
description: LEAD: THOUGH the Island's Roman Catholic population has increased considerably during the last 20 years, the ratio of diocesan priests to the Catholic population has steadily declined.

title: What Is a Wife? A Mix of Peccadilloes and Passions
description: JUST beyond the senior prom and the soft-spoken words ''I will'' is a wonderful creature called a wife. Joke all you want about them, wives are the best things that happen to men. They come in all heights and weights, with straight or wavy hair, with green or blue or brown eyes, with freckles and without, but somehow the one you have is the nicest combination of all.

title: Rangers Fail in Rally
description: Michel Bergeron had gotten out of a hospital bed and brought himself, weary and medicated, back to his team. To his dismay tonight, he found them where he had left them. The Rangers, often within reach of victory, are still in last place in their division.

title: Practical Traveler; Coping With New Baggage Rules
description: IF your Christmas gifts did not include carry-on luggage, perhaps your New Year's self-improvement project should be measuring your suitcases and practicing how to pack everything into two bags.

title: Young Love
description: EVERY TIME WE SAY GOODBYE Starring Tom Hanks and Cristina Marsillach (both in photo). Directed by Moshe Mizrahi. 1987. Lightning Video. 97 minutes. $79.98.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Bamboo Utensils Crafted in Kyoto
description: LEAD: IT is not only the arts of textiles, ceramics, lacquer and painting for which Kyoto is justly famous. Kyoto is also the original home of classical Japanese cuisine (nihon ryori), the more narrowly defined kaiseki ryori (the cuisine that developed with the tea ceremony) and Zen vegetarian cuisine (shojin ryori), which developed in the great

title: A Lake Placid Landmark, in Ashes, to Rise Anew
description: As smoke from a fire in the historic Mirror Lake Inn hung above this village Monday morning, the inn's owners, Edwin and Lisa Weibrecht, arranged an unusual shopping expedition.

title: Lake Champlain Cleanup Plan Nears Completion
description: Looking westward on a frigid January afternoon across the icy shore of Lake Champlain, it is hard to imagine balmy midsummer days when hundreds of people make their way here to North Beach for a refreshing dip.

title: 80's Movies Take the Easy Route
description: LIKE SO MANY FILMS OF THE 1980'S, THE GOLDIE Hawn comedy ''Overboard'' offers something for everyone. To begin with, it presents the amusing spectacle of Miss Hawn impersonating a viciously bad-tempered heiress, striking terror into everyone she meets. After this satirical high-life phase, the film moves into its low-rent period, with an amnesiac Miss Hawn trapped in the squalid home of a carpenter (played by Kurt Russell), who intends to teach her a lesson. But it's an 80's-style lesson that the film has in mind.

title: CYNTHIA AIDA HACINLI WEDS WILLIAM CONNOR
description: Cynthia Aida Hacinli, a freelance journalist, and William Steel Durward Connor, a reporter for WCSH-TV in Portland, Me., were married yesterday at St. Vartan Armenian Orthodox Cathedral in Manhattan. The Rev. Arten Ashjian performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Arnak Kasparian and the Rev. Gerald G. Alexander, an Episcopal priest.

title: Donald Healey; Sports Car Designer, 89
description: Donald Healey, designer of Austin-Healey sports cars in Britain, died last Wednesday after a short illness, his family said today. He was 89 years old.

title: Remembering the Big One of 1888
description: THE mood on Wall Street was glum. Just 2,000 shares changed hands that Tuesday. Retail sales took a beating. The B. Altman store had only one customer all day. Food prices soared. Milk went from 2 cents to more than 10 cents a quart within three days.

title: Lawsuit by City Against Boy, 7
description: RYAN McDONNELL, 7 years old, got the bad news nearly a year after he collided with a municipal truck while riding his bicycle and was hurt slightly in San Carlos, Calif. The city was suing him for $13,000.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: East Brunswick $182,000 11 Thompson Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old contemporary; deck, hardwood floors, fireplace, above-ground pool; taxes $3,024. Hackettstown $145,000 18 Laurel Terrace 3-bedroom, 1 bath, 26-year-old contemporary; family room, newly renovated kitchen, fireplace; taxes $2,110. Livingston $185,000 206 Passaic Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 bath, 45-year-old ranch; fireplace, full basement, enclosed porch; taxes $2,212. Milburn $215,000 172 Myrtle Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 34-year-old colonial; screened porch, 1-car garage, fireplace; taxes $3,200. New Providence $225,000 1596 Springfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, 33-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, newly remodeled kitchen, fireplace; taxes $2,508. West Orange $175,000 7 Holmes Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; den, patio, screened porch, 1-car attached garage; taxes $2,603. OTHER AREAS Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $253,000 341 Hunterbrook Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 19-year-old frame colonial; den, deck, 1.8 acre; taxes $3,888. Farmington, Conn. $178,000 47 Red Coat Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; excellent condition, screened porch, 100- by 200 foot lot; taxes $1,355. Williston Park, L.I. $240,000 69 Dartmouth Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; finished basement, den, attic, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,100.

title: Legislators Plan Limits On Off-Road Vehicles
description: The chairmen of the Transportation Committees of the New York State Senate and Assembly plan to propose stringent laws to regulate the sale and use of all-terrain vehicles, a legislative commission report said yesterday.

title: Perspectives: Land Auctions; Buying City Parcels on Must-Build Terms
description: THE public auction - that tried and true method of getting city-owned tax-foreclosed land back into private ownership - is alive and well in New York City, but it has acquired a new wrinkle.

title: U. S. Aide Sees 'Important Step' By Nicaraguans >
description: A senior Reagan Administration official said today that Nicaragua's reported agreement to open direct talks with the contra rebels ''would be an important step'' if it led to serious negotiations.

title: Priest Looks Ahead to His Vocation
description: LEAD: NINE Long Islanders will be ordained as Roman Catholic priests in the Diocese of Rockville Centre on June 4. Twenty-six-year-old Jim Vlaun of West Babylon will be one of them.

title: TOWARD BETTER DEALS AND BETTER DEALMAKING, IN ZONING
description: SHOULD developers be allowed extra stories on their high-priced buildings if they promise, in exchange, to construct day care centers or esplanades as well? And in any case, who should have the power to make such a concession and what role should the local community board play?

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: HONORS FOR DR. KING

title: BROKER ENGAGED TO MISS WINGATE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Wingate of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Joy Wingate, to Joel M. Hausman, the son of Mrs. Irving Hausman of San Francisco and the late Rabbi Hausman. An April wedding is planned.

title: Trends in Art History
description: To the Editor:

title: 848 Hunters Bag Just 4 Turkeys
description: WHILE the number of hunters reached a record high during the fall wild turkey season, the success rate dropped to a record low, the State Department of Environmental Protection reported last week.

title: Jazz and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Aide in Middle as Israelis Shoot
description: A senior United Nations official, sent to investigate conditions in Palestinian refugee districts, was caught up in a hail of rubber bullets and tear gas today as the Israeli Army chased youthful protesters.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A Bridgewater Complex Spares the Land
description: LEAD: IN the last 15 years development has not been a stranger to Bridgewater, whose 32 square miles of once-rural countryside have sprouted many new homes. More than 5,000 dwelling units were proposed in the township, placing it third among Somerset County's 21 municipalities in residential building activity, figures from the county planning board show.

title: MOVIE
description: Bombay Talkie Starring Jennifer Kendal, Shashi Kapoor and Zia Mohyeddi. Directed by James Ivory. 1970. Embassy Home Entertainment. 115 minutes. $39.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace. Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room. We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out. Is there any other kind of stripping you can suggest to fill in these gaps?

title: THE COURSE OF TRUE LOVE IN VANCOUVER
description: LOVE IN THE TEMPERATE ZONE By L. R. Wright. 280 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Don't Call Me, I'll Call You - on My Car Phone
description: LEAD: IF your telephone rings this year and a strange man says hello, it's probably my neighbor Norman. Not to worry. Norman is calling everyone in the Nassau and Suffolk County phone books on his new car telephone. Why? How else would you know he has one?

title: NEWLYWED MURDER STRIKES A CHORD
description: LEAD: MATTHEW SOLOMON'S name became a household word on Long Island during the last three weeks, even before the 23-year-old resident of Huntington Station was arrested in the strangulation death of his 22-year-old wife, Lisa.

title: ONE LIFE WAS NOT ENOUGH
description: CHATTERTON By Peter Ackroyd. 234 pp. New York: Grove Press. $17.95.

title: CRIME
description: For a first novel, PUSH, MEET SHOVE by Peter Barthelme (St. Martin's, $14.95) moves with unusual confidence. The writing is assured and relaxed, with snappy, sophisticated dialogue and convincing characterizations. Mr. Barthelme is also on secure ground, in that he is an advertising man in Texas writing about an advertising man in Texas.

title: Missing the Point On a Folk Artist
description: Helen Harrison's discussion on Dec. 6 of the Temperance Hall Gallery show in Bellport was thorough and balanced, as one would expect from a Times reviewer. Her appreciation of Long Island artists is commendable, but she missed the point on Stuart Taylor Rabb.

title: Dancing to the Beat, Counted Out in Sign Language
description: THE dancers relaxed during their break and chatted about the performance they would give at the New Rochelle Public Library that evening. There was laughing and teasing about what hair styles to wear, and the only thing unusual about the group was that the conversation was in sign language.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Global View
description: LEAD: Spanishtown, Jamaica, is a long way from here, but the Y.M.C.A. of Central and Northern Westchester is raising money to assist people in that island community.

title: More Than Ever, Gershwin Songs Are Here to Stay
description: IT WOULDN'T BE SURPRISING if future pop historians, looking back on 1987, expressed more interest in the accelerating popularity of George Gershwin than in Michael Jackson's changing physiognomy or Bruce Springsteen's romantic maturation.

title: NEW LAW PROTECTS RIGHTS OF PATIENTS IN NURSING HOMES
description: A new Federal law dramatically strengthens the protection of patients' rights by imposing dozens of new requirements on nursing homes and home health agencies.

title: Death Brings Texas Town Together
description: The preacher's words sounded like something from the Book of Revelation as they thundered through the old pine pews of the Macedonia Baptist Church.

title: Artists Present Other Artists
description: THE show now at Art/Place, the co-operative at the Southport railroad station, is ''Gallery Artists Choose Other Artists.'' Twenty guests are present - presumably one per member - although the observer has no way of knowing who chose whom.

title: Dance: Ann Law Company
description: IT is not the easiest thing in the world to balance words and movement in a dance character study. But Janice Bourdage did so impressively in the first performance of ''Joanna Burden,'' presented Thursday in a program of new and recent dances by Ann Elizabeth Law, performed by the Ann Law Dance Company at the Dia Foundation theater, 155 Mercer Street. Ms. Bourdage, who is possessed of a clear and resonant voice and way of moving, caught both the poignant yearning and feverish destructiveness of the title character, the antiheroine of William Faulkner's ''Light in August.'' She also managed to suggest the lethal effect of religion on the characters who people that Faulkner world.

title: Schools Assess Role in AIDS Education
description: LEAD: THE legal, medical and educational issues that affect how schools respond to AIDS are as complex as the disease, several panels of experts told a Westchester audience last weekend.

title: Alysheba Heads San Fernando
description: Alysheba, winner of the Eclipse Award as the top 3-year-old last year, will head a field of eight entered in the $200,000-added San Fernando Stakes Sunday at Santa Anita.

title:
GARDENING;
The Long and Short of Dwarf Conifers
description: LEAD: CONIFERS are among the more highly valued landscape plants. Their evergreen foliage is attractive regardless of season, they vary greatly in color and texture and are available in a variety of forms.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Reductions on Furs In New Rochelle

title: New York Area Agencies Pressed To Study Shift From Sea Dumping
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency is pressing New York City and several sewage authorities in New Jersey to find alternatives to dumping sewage sludge in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Retracing Jewish History In Austria
description: ALMOST three centuries ago, Emperor Leopold I called a money expert, Samson Wertheimer, from Worms on the Rhine to Vienna to help him replenish his treasury, which had been exhausted by the Emperor's Turkish wars.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: Jack Clark's departure from St. Louis heralds the arrival of a subway series in New York. JENNIFER CLIFT Lake Hiawatha, N.J.

title: East Europe's Links to Foreign Creditors Strained
description: Throughout Eastern Europe, an economic crisis is placing increasingly heavy strains on the region's already difficult relations with foreign creditors.

title: Karan Takes A Long View
description: Donna Karan said she did not show longer skirts in her summer collection Friday just to provide the customer with options. She said she did so because ''I think they look great, and they look new.''

title: O.A.S. Adopts Rule to Battle Trafficking in Drugs
description: The Organization of American States unanimously adopted a compromise resolution late Friday in which the member countries reaffirmed their commitment to wage a vigorous war against drug traffickers.

title: Talking: Rentals; Knowing The Laws That Apply
description: EVEN though the rents of well over a million apartments in New York City are governed by rent control or rent stabilization, hundreds of apartments do not have to abide by those regulations.

title: RENEE GREENSPAN, C.P.A., IS TO WED
description: The engagement of Dawn Renee Greenspan to Charles Heller Brownman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Brownman of Watchung, N.J., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Greenspan of Beaumont, Tex. A September wedding is planned.

title: SHAWN MAHIEU WEDS CAPT. CARLOS FRANCISCO ORTIZ
description: Shawn Mahieu, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Julien Mahieu of North Haledon, N.J., and Lake George, N.Y., was married at the First Presbyterian Church in North Haledon yesterday to Capt. Carlos Francisco Ortiz, U.S.A., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andres A. Ortiz of Mahwah, N.J., and New Paltz, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Robert Lee George performed the ceremony.

title: On Language; Beware the W-Word
description: THE WASHINGTON Post was bewailing the reluctance of candidates to mention the dread word taxes. ''They've been Mondaled,'' the editorialist wrote, making a verb out of the name of the last candidate to suggest that a rise in taxes was inevitable, ''you say the T-word and you die.''

title: Student Nurses to Work at Shelters
description: LEAD: STUDENT nurses will provide health care and education at eight Hartford shelters for the homeless beginning this week.

title: U.S. Ends Evidence Presentation in Westies Trial
description: Federal prosecutors have finished presenting their evidence in a long racketeering trial involving several grisly murders attributed to a gang known as the Westies.

title: Reagan to Wind Down Mostly by Summing Up
description: As the Reagan Administration starts its final year Wednesday, senior White House officials say President Reagan is planning no major initiatives and instead will spend his last months in office cleaning up unfinished matters, large and small.

title: AMY R. BERMAN, LAWYER, TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Berman of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Robin Berman to Crain Alan Sukin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Sukin of Billings, Mont. A June wedding is planned. Miss Berman, an associate in the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College and received a J.D. degree from the New York University School of Law. Her father is a senior partner in the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae.

title: Baseball Notebook; Some Clubs Need More Power Against Left-Handers
description: THE Toronto Blue Jays failed to win the American League East championship last year because they failed to win any of their last seven games of the season. That disaster, however, could have been less disastrous if, during the season, they had won a few more games in which left-handed pitchers started against them.

title: A Horovitz Comedy Traces the Rosens
description: LAST season Studio Theater in Lindenhurst presented ''Today I Am a Fountain Pen,'' the first of a trilogy by Israel Horovitz based on stories by Morley Torgov about the Jewish community of Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, Canada, before, during and after World War II. In ''Fountain Pen'' we were introduced to the Yanover family, whose 10-year-old son, Irving Yanover, has a passion for eating bacon. We also hear a great deal about the Rosens, who are the Yanovers' best friends.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'MACBETH'' IN STAMFORD

title: ISRAEL'S HEAVIER HAND
description: ISRAEL struck back with a variety of strong measures last week in new efforts to quell Palestinian demonstrations in the occupied territories. But the violence continued and more deaths and injuries were reported.

title: Teams Find It's Better to Receive
description: FOR three seasons, Anthony Carter felt more like a status symbol than an integral part of the Minnesota Vikings' offense. He was the family heirloom that the Vikings were reluctant to remove from its display case. Whether a wide receiver relies on speed or moves, or both, he must be elusive. And here was Carter, sensing constraints, as if he were running his pass patterns in a ball and chain.

title: New England
description: To the Editor: One does not expect Marian Burros to traverse the length and breadth of New England in order to write an article on great New England restaurants (''Nouvelle New England,'' Travel, Nov. 8), but not to include a few of New Hampshire's elegant eating places - in fact not to include New Hampshire at all! How did Ms. Burros get from Maine to Vermont? MARIE HARRIS Barrington, N.H.

title: Rail Car Plant In Yonkers Seeks $1 Billion Contract
description: IT was just a year ago that Yonkers officials were saying they hoped the city's new Kawasaki rail car plant, which was making subway cars for New York and New Jersey, would someday be manufacturing them for railroad and subway systems around the world.

title: Jarrell's Death, Jarrell's Poems
description: To the Editor:

title: Lakshmi Jha, Indian Economist And Former Envoy, Is Dead at 74
description: Lakshmi Kant Jha, one of India's most distinguished economists and an architect of the country's recent economic liberalization, died of kidney failure today. He was 74 years old.

title: Showplaces of Art in Barcelona
description: LEAD: MIES VAN DER ROHE'S Barcelona Pavilion, recently rebuilt, is just one reason for art lovers to visit Montjuic, the park-covered hill that rises from the city's Mediterranean harbor. A day spent on Montjuic (pronounced MONT-zhoo-eek) is a day of contrasts between modern and traditional art and architecture.

title: Borderline 'Village': Condos
description: The Federal-style apartment building fills the sharply angled southeast corner of Hudson Street and Ninth Avenue. It is in the West Village, but just barely: Chelsea is across the street. Still, the building's developer, Alan B. Friedberg, chose to emphasize the geographic distinction and named the 49-unit condominium Village Pointe. ''I feel the West Village has a charm that Chelsea does not have,'' he said. ''By that I mean tree-lined streets. It doesn't have the commercialism that Chelsea has.''

title: Sherlock and Stress
description: LEAD: ''Stress will bury you if don't manage it properly,'' Raymond Shelton, a therapist, warns his patients, who are emergency medical workers.

title: From 3-D to Baking Bread
description: A NUMBER of other eye-popping items were displayed at the show. Toshiba showed a three-dimensional video camera. Available in early summer for $2,850, it will require viewers to wear special glasses attached by a cable to an electronic adapter. . . Panasonic showed off its automatic bread baker, already a hot item in Japan. Pour in the ingredients and the machine takes over - going through different cycles like a washing machine, and coming up with a loaf in about four hours . . . Pioneer Electronics showed its Bodysonic surround-sound chair. Stereo speakers are attached to the headrest, and bass vibrations come from the bowels of the seat cushion. At $2,000, however, can one rest easy? . . . Casio, which has made a big business of electronic keyboards, now has an electronic horn. It produce any of six different sounds and is sensitive to how hard the musician blows. However, since the sound is really produced by electronic chip, the synthetic sax can also be played by just fingering the keys, without blowing into it at all . . . Off-The-Wall Products of La Jolla, Calif., has alarm clocks in the shape of balls. To turn off the alarm, just throw the clock against the wall.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Help on the Way
description: LEAD: ALMOST every morning, Matt McGuy of New City in Rockland County experiences breakdowns on Interstate 287, the Cross Westchester Expressway. But they never make him late for his job. In fact, they are his job. Mr. McGuy is a professional Good Samaritan. Monday through Friday during the morning and evening rush hours, he drives a customized Ford van along the busy Westchester artery, looking to assist motorists in need.

title: Crash Comparison
description: To the Editor: I have followed with interest the graph you printed each week comparing the crashes of 1929 and 1989. But to put the post-crash periods in proper perspective, I think it mandatory that you graph the 50 or so trading days before the crashes. Doing that will allow readers to see longer-term similarities and differences between the two events, and thus help us to evaluate the post-crash period. THOMAS F. HIRSCH Brooklyn, Dec. 27

title:
INVESTING;
Spectramed's Dubious Distinction
description: LEAD: AMONG companies selling their first stock to the public in 1987, Spectramed Inc., a maker of medical products based in California, earned a distinction of sorts. Of the year's 15 worst-performing deals, according to Going Public, Spectramed ranked first in terms of money raised, at $40 million. By last week, the 3.64 million shares that were sold at $11 each had sunk to $2.625, a loss to investors of $30.5 million, or 76 percent, in seven months.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: The Red Sox are the team to beat. Unless the Yankees can find a starting pitcher or two, all acquiring Jack Clark can do is help them build on the new Yankee tradition: finishing in second place. J. D. GALLAGHER Essex Junction, Vt.

title: ResidentialResales
description: Closings in the week ending Jan. 2 MANHATTAN Morningside Heights $186,000 320 Riverside Drive (104th St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft., prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, large kitchen; maintenance, $542, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: A.J. Clark) Murray Hill $$70,000 140 East 40th Street 300-sq.-ft. studio co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; manned elevator, south exposure; maintenance $497, includes gas heat, 56% tax-deductible (Broker: Penthouse Properties) TriBeCa $$245,000 261 Broadway 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 885-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar loft building; nemodeled kitchen and bath, City Hall Park view; maintenance $496, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Upper East Side $$2.13 Million 550 Park Avenue (60th St.) 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 3,500-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, formal dining room, maid's room and bath; library; maintenance $2,000, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Sotheby's International Realty) Upper West Side $$532,000 321 West 78th Street 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, maid's room, high-ceilings; maintenace $1,040, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Hahn & Mann Realty) Washington Heights $$155,000 360 Cabrini Boulevard 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; Part-time doorman, dining foyer, sunken-living room; maintenance $456, 39% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) BRONX Baychester $$150,000 4356 Edson Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached, frame house; dining room, large kitchen, full basement, 2-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Gold Circle Realty) Riverdale $$81,760 3235 Cambridge Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; dining area, remodeled kitchen and bath; maintenance $399, 62% deductible (Broker: Susan E.
