title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline on Dec. 20 with a Travel Advisory report misstated the scope of the Hertz Euraildrive Escape. The program covers 16 countries, not France alone.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: Jack Clark should prove to be the Yankees' best designated hitter since Don Baylor. If they do not get overconfident, the Yankees, with Clark and company, should be strong contenders for third PETER MOUNT Secaucus, N.J.

title: DOES THE PATIENT MATTER?
description: LEAD: THE WEARY SONS OF FREUD By Catherine Clement. Translated by Nicole Ball. 115 pp. New York: Verso/Methuen. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $11.95.

title: Witsken Makes Quarterfinals
description: Todd Witsken, the only American remaining in the men's competition of the Australian Open, advanced today to the quarterfinals of the Grand Slam event.

title: Lawyers Argue Over Key Count In Assault Case
description: Prosecutors last week disputed defense arguments that the verdict in the Howard Beach trial of four white teen-agers requires the dismissal of a key charge pending against seven other youths.

title: MOVIES
description: Through a Glass Darkly Directed by Ingmar Bergman. With Harriet Andersson, Gunnar Bjornstrand, Max Von Sydow. 1961. International Collection/ Nelson Entertainment Group 90 minutes. $29.95.

title: Oysters From Northern California
description: PREHISTORIC garbage heaps testify that humans have enjoyed oysters for hundreds of thousands of years. In modern times, Californians had little chance, until relatively recently, to consume local oysters because the Olympia oyster - the only one native to the West Coast - didn't grow large enough to be commercially viable. During the past 30 years, however, development of oyster farming technology has made possible the establishment of a small industry on the Pacific coast. Today one can find locally grown oysters in many California restaurants.

title: Cambodian Is Said to Offer To Return American Remains
description: A high-ranking Cambodian official told three Congressmen touring Southeast Asia that his country has the remains of 80 American servicemen killed during the Vietnam War and is prepared to release them to the United States, the lawmakers said today.

title: CITY RULES ON TRUCKS FAULTED
description: FEDERAL transportation officials have declared New York City's restrictions on the size of fuel tanker-trucks a violation of Federal law and an indirect threat to environmental safety in some New Jersey and Westchester County communities.

title: BUSINESS FORUM: Factories, Services and Speed; Just-in-Time, Right for Retail
description: ALTHOUGH just-in-time systems were once used exclusively by large manufacturers, a wide range of non-manufacturing companies are beginning to use such systems successfully to increase their competitiveness and extend their geographic reach. In my judgment, just-in-time techniques applied to retailing and services offer benefits for small and large companies as dramatic as those they offer manufacturing.

title: PLANTING CARROTS AMONG THE STICKS
description: SOVIET AGRICULTURE By Zhores A. Medvedev. Tables. 464 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $27.50

title: Hiram Bingham; Diplomat, 84
description: Hiram Bingham, a former diplomat and head of the Sportatron Company of America, died Wednesday at his home in Salem, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: Are They Statistics or Guesswork?
description: I DON'T know about anyone else, but I'm very impressed with all the information we get from the Government in Washington. I'm especially impressed with statistics about the Gross National Product, the percentage of unemployment, the trade deficit, personal income and the like. Just think about the amount of work it takes to compile those figures and the number of people who must be involved. No wonder they can't reduce the Federal payroll.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: If, by April, Jack Clark can learn to throw a curveball as well as he has been able to hit one, then the Yankees will have a shot. FRANK J. CARROLL River Edge, N.J.

title: MISS BROWN TO MARRY NICHOLAS DEVLIN
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Sage Brown to Nicholas Kirk Devlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Devlin of Mountainside, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. R. Brown of Leesburg, Va., parents of the bride-to-be. A May wedding is planned.

title: A FEW OF THE SEASONAL PROJECTS
description: STUDY seed and nursery catalogues and place orders promptly to be sure of getting first choices. Stock bird feeders daily. Bring in a pot of hardy bulbs from the coldframe, water gradually and place in sunlight to force flowers. Study pruning manuals to brush up on methods for trimming back grapevines, fruit trees and other dormant plants, weather permitting. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS BONSAI

title: Rutgers Honors Urban Policy Expert
description: LEAD: THE founder of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University has been named a university professor, a title that Rutgers reserves for distinguished senior faculty members.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: Jack Clark's acquisition doesn't improve the Yankees' chances as much as it does the Mets'. The Cardinals have been stripped of their lone power hitter. Unless Jack Clark can give the Yankees a few good innings on the mound (rotating, perhaps, in the fifth spot with such distinguished hurlers as Rick Cerone and Dave Winfield), the Yankees can look forward to another summer of 10-9 scores. JON RIZZI Brooklyn

title: RUTGERS SUFFERS 7TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: Tom Garrick and Carlton Owens combined for 40 of 58 second-half points for Rhode Island today as the Rams defeated Rutgers, 84-71. The loss was the seventh straight for Rutgers.

title:
ART;
GALLERY RETAINS GROUP SPIRIT
description: LEAD: NEW ventures usually generate enthusiasm among the participants, and so it is with the B. J. Spoke Gallery's move to Sea Cliff. What started as a loss of lease in the former quarters in Port Washington may become an asset because of substantial pedestrian traffic on the new block.

title: THE 'BLACK HOLE' OF MONEY
description: The foreign trade deficit may have shrunk by more than $4 billion in November, as the Commerce Department reported, but statisticians know that raw monthly totals can be off by as much as $2 billion. They will eventually refine the figures. For overall world trade statistics, however, a much larger error defies refinement.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE HOUSE WITH THE BLIND GLASS WINDOWS. By Herbjorg Wassmo. Translated by Roseann Lloyd and Allen Simpson. (Seal Press, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $9.95.) Coming of age in the 1950's in a nation still deeply wounded from more than four years of German occupation has been an important theme for Norway's postwar writers.

title:
MUSIC;
Theater's Revival Is Planned
description: LEAD: REPRESENTATIVES of arts organizations met here last week to discuss proposed restoration of the Rivoli Theater at the Williams Center and state their groups' specific needs and requirements.

title: Verbatim; Reductions
description: ' We must, perhaps for the first time since the late 1940's, seriously debate the posture of U.S. military forces around the world. ' James H. Webb Jr. Secretary of the Navy, suggesting that American forces, especially in Europe, could be cut.

title: Irving Hochstadter; Chemical Engineer, 100
description: Irving Hochstadter, a chemical engineer who founded Hochstadter Laboratories Inc., died Jan. 8 at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N.J., where he lived. He was 100 years old.

title: About Men; The Pastor's Problem
description: WALKING THROUGH MILFORD, A NEW England town turned small city turned New York suburb, I think of my parishioners and can't help but feel a little envy. It's not that I am jealous of their cars (which are nice) or their boats (beautiful) or their homes (expensive). Rather, I am envious of the ways that their careers reward them.

title:
ART;
Baskin's Tragic View of Mankind
description: LEAD: ''I HOLD the cracked mirror up to man.'' In these few eloquent words, Leonard Baskin encapsulates the essence of his preoccupation as an artist. His vision, centered on the grandeur and frailty of the human condition, explores both the tragic and noble aspects of mortality, establishing a spiritual linkage to forebears as diverse as William Blake and Francisco Goya.

title: How One Company Clamped Down on Doctor Bills
description: FOR Jeanne Kardos, director of employee benefits at the Southern New England Telecommunications Company, the numbers were alarming. Last year, she estimated, her company spent almost $40 million on medical expenses for its employees, up 14 percent in one year and more than double its spending five years ago. ''The costs are just getting crazier,'' she said.

title: The Lessons Of a Hospital Stay Abroad
description: NO ONE, I thought at the time, could prepare adequately for the kind of terror that grabbed me when I awoke abruptly at 5 A.M. in the Tel Aviv Sheraton to find that I was hemorrhaging internally. Today, I realize that with careful planning for a possible medical emergency, I might have avoided the panic.

title: Surgery for Stanley
description: THE pitcher who has saved more Boston Red Sox games than anyone else, Bob Stanley, was hoping that doctors at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester had saved the day for him after four hours of surgery on his pitching hand Friday. Stanley, a right-hander with 123 saves in his 11 years with the Red Sox, was listed in good condition yesterday following the surgery on his hand to repair tendons and digital nerves that were cut when he fell while taking out the trash at his home Friday.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: Norman Rockwell's World . . . An American Dream Directed by Robert Deubel. Narrated by Norman Rockwell. Home Vision. 1-800-262-8600. 30 minutes. $24.95.

title: MY SIX YEARS ON THE COUCH
description: Dan Wakefield's article leaves readers with the impression that his hallucinatory psychotic illness resulted from the analysis and his doctor's mismanagement. There is no question in my mind that Mr. Wakefield was suffering from alcohol-induced hallucinations. The explanation offered by his analyst that they had entered the ''heartland'' of analysis is pure nonsense.

title: Brady's Market Plan
description: The Brady report called for changes in the financial markets. Among other things, the commission recommended unified margin requirements, better clearing mechanisms, a coordination of existing ''circuit breakers'' and the establishment of a market coordination agency. But what kind of future does the Brady Plan have, and can it really fix the market? EDWARD MARKEY Democratof Massachussetts and chairman of the House Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance.

title: HIP GRAPHICS
description: Your essay on ''Hip Graphics'' (Works in Progress, Dec. 13), with the images in sequential rotation of the human hip, recalls a similar revolutionary image of the human body 76 years ago -Marcel Duchamp's ''Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2.'' The painting caused quite a stir at the Armory Show of 1913 in New York, owing to the liberties it took with the human form. The artist's adaptation of Cubist and Futurist ideas served to represent three-dimensional form in movement upon a two-dimensional surface. The work foreshadowed these CAT-scan-derived images in the sense that Duchamp freed the artist from having to mentally integrate numerous separate images of the body. It is as if an artistic representation evolved into a therapeutic tool. CHARLES D. COLLINS Rochester

title: NONFICTION
description: A DESIGN FOR LIVING. By Lillian Langseth-Christensen. (Viking, $18.95.) Today, Josef Hoffmann is revered by design enthusiasts the world over. But at the beginning of this century the Viennese architect, one of the founders of the Wiener Werkstatte movement, had only a coterie of avant-garde admirers. One of these was a 10-year-old girl who was introduced to his spare designs in a German magazine, Deutsche Kunst und Dekoration (German Art and Decoration), that came to her parents' home in New York, where their wood-paneled library boasted ''a fringed moose-hide hassock, on a grizzly bear skin.'' Over 70 years later, Lillian Langseth-Christensen, now a decorator and a food writer, has written an engaging memoir, illustrated with personal snapshots, of her acquaintance with the man whose rooms and objects were to have such a revolutionary effect on future generations. ''Nothing ever lay about,'' the writer recalls. ''J. Hoffmann, whom I began to think of as a man, did not hold with clutter.'' In the annals of interior design, that may be one of the most memorable of understatements. At 14, Ms. Langseth-Christensen convinced her parents that she should study with Hoffmann. Her meeting with the painter Gustav Klimt and his cat continues the chronicle of a privileged and cultured life in Vienna. The author's perceptive visual and esthetic memory - she describes Hoffmann as ''a three-piece mountain of pepper and salt homespun. . . . Black and white were his two colors. They were all he needed'' -reminds us that there isn't any substitute for being there, and for being able to remember and write it all down so well.

title: The Grand Canyon's Winter Face
description: I FIRST saw the Grand Canyon by the light of a winter moon. A handful of the canyon's snow-topped buttes shimmered under its gaze; ethereal and serene, they seemed to float above the darkened canyon floor. Under a blanket of snow, the Grand Canyon lay mysteriously, almost terrifyingly, still.

title: Venturing Back Alone To a City Once Shared
description: I want to love you As long as the world is a world, Oh, Fiorenza, Until the stones go flying away.

title: Secrets of the Rain Forest
description: ''BUTTERFLY heaven,'' exults Donald Perry from his mobile perch above the jungle roof. The first sunny morning all week and the butterflies are out; a dozen varieties, a dozen different color swatches, flit by within half an hour.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 37 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: 2 BRITISH PARTIES TRY MERGER ANEW
description: To the delight of Labor and Conservative leaders, the attempt by the Liberal and Social Democratic parties to merge into a new party has veered toward becoming a ritual of self destruction.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $275,000 13 Victoria Way 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new condominium town house; den with fireplace, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $5,200, monthly charges $450. Bay Shore $650,000 55 Gardner Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 65-year-old colonial; fireplace, boat slip, 2 acres; taxes $10,000. Mastic $119,900 35 Pawnee Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; dining room, sunken living room, family room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Mineola $240,000 462 Foch Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old center-hall colonial; den, fireplace; taxes $2,000. Sayville $190,000 11 Bowery Court 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, skylights, cul-de-sac, pool, 2-car garage; taxes $3,600. Williston Park $240,000 69 Dartmouth Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; finished basement, den, attic, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,100. OTHER AREAS New Providence, N.J. $225,000 1596 Springfield Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, newly remodeled kitchen, fireplace; taxes $2,508. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $253,000 341 Hunterbrook Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 19-year-old frame colonial; den, deck, 1.8 acre; taxes $3,888. Farmington, Conn. $178,000 47 Red Coat Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; excellent condition, screened porch, 100- by 200 foot lot; taxes $1,355.

title: Show of Folk Art In Scarsdale
description: THOUGH its clapboard facade has changed a few times, the Cudner-Hyatt House has stood near the corner of the White Plains Post Road and Boulevard for 254 years. The Quaker Meeting House next door, another wood building, is a comparative newcomer, having been removed from its original site on Griffen Road in 1977.

title: SERENA REED TO MARRY PAUL KUSSEROW
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Verner Reed Jr. of New York and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Serena Reed to Paul B. K. Kusserow, a son of Suzanne Kusserow of Underhill Center, Vt., and the late Dr. Berthold Kusserow. A May wedding is planned.

title: Work Begun to Protect Bombers From Birds
description: Two B-1B bombers assigned to Dyess Air Force Base here are the first to undergo modification in a $40 million program intended to make the aircraft less vulnerable to birds, officials said.

title: Brunswick, Me.: College Town Graduating
description: TWO office complexes are under construction here and a third is planned, adding a new dimension to this town of about 19,000 people on the Androscoggin River.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: You just betcha. Who needs more pitchers? These bats will take care of those arms. MINNI WALKER New York

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: ONE certain thing about the reflection in the mirror - it's sort of a shock, a picture that would surprise, maybe even stun, an awful lot of your friends. Is it really you - you, who only a few hours ago, were an example of good grooming and put-togetherness, the epitome of big city chic?

title: The Buck Stops
description: Over the last two years a 23-year-old New York investor named David Bloom collected $10 million from 100 friends and associates to play the stock market. But last week authorities charged that Mr. Bloom's favorite investment was himself. They said he spent most of the money on such things as an art collection, a beach house, a condo, an Aston Martin and contributions to Duke University, his alma mater. Without conceding any wrongdoing, Mr. Bloom agreed to turn over most of his assets to a court-appointed receiver who will determine their value and make recommendations as to their disposal. He also was charged with mail fraud, and, if convicted, could face up to five years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000.

title: BUSINESS FORUM: Factories, Services and Speed; Simplify the Shop Floor
description: RECOGNIZING that they were losing their ability to compete in domestic and world markets, many American manufacturers have been engaged in years of globe-trotting, seeking cheap offshore labor to bring their manufacturing costs down. Now, a handful of companies, including I.B.M., Emerson Electric and Swank, are returning production to our home shores. They have realized that lower wage scales alone will not enable them to regain a competitive edge. Rather, if American companies are to return to their position as a driving market force, they must make serious changes that include their approach to manufacturing.

title: Thai Food: Flavors in Harmony
description: LONG ISLAND offers adventurous eaters food choices that didn't exist here a decade ago. Some are quite sophisticated, even exotic. Not the least of them is Thai food. And one of the best of the new Thai restaurants is the Thai House in Huntington.

title: High Costs in Massachusetts Thin Ranks of Obstetricians
description: Nearly one-fifth of the obstetricians in Massachusetts who responded to a survey have quit their practices since 1984, a result of increasing malpractice insurance rates and a rising number of lawsuits.

title: Stocking Up for the Winter War
description: WHEN I was a little girl, my mother used to tell me about the ration cards she jealously guarded during World War II. She always stressed how difficult it was to obtain items like nylon stockings and gasoline; that even keeping your larder stocked with butter and sugar presented a formidable challenge.

title: MAYBE A FENCE IS NEEDED
description: ALTHOUGH deer are beautiful to watch as they bound across open fields with their white tails raised, many homeowners, nurserymen, farmers and orchardists are changing their views about them. Once supportive, they are now part of the so-called anti-Bambi lobby.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: I LIKE THE MUSIC By Leah Komaiko. Illustrated by Barbara Westman. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Food; FEASTS AGAINST FROST
description: IT IS A BROMIDE, of course, to say that fresh air - particularly fresh snowy air - fires the flames of hunger. At mealtime on the slopes, the skiers I have observed over the years have been discriminating but unpretentious eaters.

title: Two Goaltenders Are Better Than One
description: THERE is tension on Canada's medal-conscious Olympic hockey team as the calendar draws closer to that time Coach Dave King calls ''the point of no return.'' But the anxieties don't extend to the team's impromptu goaltending duo. The coincidence of King's ending up with a pair of first-string goalies could provide the edge his club of modest scorers will need against more talented Olympic opponents.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SHIKSA. By Barbara Bartlett. (Morrow, $18.95.) Risky business, intoning Alexander Portnoy in the first paragraph of your first novel. Yet that is what Barbara Bartlett does in her story of Katherine Winterhaus, a gorgeous blond shiksa (Yiddish for a Christian, or in this case Catholic, female) who, though raised in anti-Semitic surroundings, finds herself wildly attracted to Jewish men.

title: Excerpts From Communique of 5 Presidents
description: Following are excerpts from the communique issued by the Presidents of Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, Guatemala and Costa Rica after their meeting on the regional peace treaty, which is officially called the Esquipulas II Treaty:

title: Double Vision for Just $280
description: UNTIL now P.I.P. has hardly made a squeak. But that could change soon.

title: Canadian Team Wins
description: The United States Olympic hockey team, testing itself against tougher competition after an idyllic schedule in which it routed collegiate squads, today lost its second consecutive game to Canada's Olympic team. Sean Burke of Canada made 50 saves in a 5-1 Canadian victory at the Joe Louis Arena.

title: LONG-TERM WITNESS
description: In 1935, a 62-year-old Philadelphia schoolteacher named Florence Knapp retired - but for a period that extended beyond all expectation.

title: A PHILATELIC SALUTE FOR THE WINTER OLYMPICS
description: THE United States Postal Service salutes the winter Olympics with a single 22-cent commemorative that was released earlier this month. It is the 15th Olympics issue. The first was released in 1932, for the Olympic Games in Lake Placid, N.Y. Subsequent United States stamps for winter Olympics were issued in 1960, when Squaw Valley, Calif. hosted the event.

title: HOW CIVIL RIGHTS CAME TO BE A 'SPECIAL INTEREST'
description: IN his crusade for the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said the evil of race discrimination was ''so great that the Negro cannot fight it alone.''

title: Q&A
description: Stefan Batory Question: I understand the Polish Ocean Lines' Stefan Batory is to be retired. Is there to be a replacement for this wonderful ship, which my family has enjoyed the past three summers? - W. B. R., New Paltz, N.Y. Answer: Polish Ocean Lines is seeking a more modern ship to replace the Stefan Batory, which is to be taken out of service in March. An official of the lines' agents in Montreal said she hoped to have news soon of another vessel that would take over the Batory's route between Montreal and London, Rotterdam and Gdynia, Poland. The Batory, formerly the Maasdam of the Holland America Line, was acquired by Polish Ocean, and rebuilt, in 1969; since then it has provided trans-Atlantic service for up to 770 passengers from April to November and cruises in winter.

title: N.F.L. Cardinals Get Stadium Lease
description: The Arizona Board of Regents unanimously approved a 10-year lease today that would permit the St. Louis Cardinals to play their National Football League games next season in 70,491-seat Sun Devil Stadium.

title: ABC vs. Neighbors: Stand-Off on West 67th St.
description: THIS IS A STORY OF A GOOD piece of architecture that some people think is in the wrong place - or perhaps it is better described as the story of how, in New York, you can never win. The building is the new headquarters of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., the communications conglomerate, and the place is the neighborhood of West 66th and West 67th Streets off Central Park West, just north of Lincoln Center. It is not a typical part of town by any means. Although West 66th Street contains a fairly uneven mix of industrial architecture (much of it housing other facilities of the ABC television network) and new high-rise apartment buildings, West 67th Street is a remarkable enclave of exceptionally gracious early-20th-century apartment buildings, many of which contain double-height studios originally constructed to house artists. This is a place like no other, a self-contained village as much as it is a New York City block. It is not the sort of site on which one would expect to find the skyscraper headquarters of a major television network.

title: In Tokyo, States Compete for Plants and Jobs
description: Like a general marking his victories, Francis T. Vaughan pointed to the map of New York State hanging on the wall of his office in downtown Tokyo. It was covered with red dots - several clustered on Long Island, two near Elmira, others scattered throughout the state.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BURY THE DEAD By Peter Carter. 374 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. (Ages 12 to 16)

title: ON THE EDGE OF A PERILOUS FOREST
description: A HOUSE OF TREES By Joan Colebrook. 256 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Drunken Driver Imprisoned
description: An insurance agent who drove his car into a neighbor's house while drunk and killed a 4-year-old girl was sentenced Friday to 15 years to life imprisonment. The driver, James Masoner, 47, was convicted on four counts, including one of second-degree murder, after he crashed his car into the home of Timothy and Barbara Shaner and killed their daughter Jessica while she was sleeping on a couch.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: DICHTER OUT EAST

title: ROSCOE MITHCELL'S MUSIC KNOWS NO CATEGORY
description: ROSCOE MITCHELL'S ''FLOW of Things'' (Black Saint, LP and cassette) and ''Four Compositions'' (Lovely Music Ltd., compact disk only) present contrasting views of a complex and frequently misunderstood musical sensibility. On ''The Flow of Things,'' Mr. Mitchell, a saxophonist and founder of the Art Ensemble of Chicago, is backed by a trio of piano, bass and drums; the album is a probing exploration of musical processes pioneered by the late John Coltrane.

title: DOES CLARK MAKE THE YANKS THE FAVORITES?
description: Steinbrenner has betrayed Yankee fans, once again. He's merely seeking to increase his turnstile profits. Clark would only help the Yankees if he revealed a latent ability to pitch a 15-victory season, or if he accidently mistook Steinbrenner's head for a screwball in batting practice. H. M. BRAVER Brooklyn

title:
DANCE;
LIMON TROUPE TO DANCE AT 'Y'
description: LEAD: IN ADDITION to the usual layers of tights and leg warmers, four members of the Limon Dance Company added kneepads for a recent rehearsal of Jiri Kylian's ''Cathedrale Engloutie'' (''The Sunken Cathedral''), which they will perform next Sunday at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey, 760 Northfield Avenue, West

title: Outdoors; Books on Fly Fishing Are Flourishing
description: BOOKS dealing with fly fishing have long outnumbered those devoted to any other angling technique. This tradition shows no sign of weakening even though fly fishermen represent only a small fraction of the angling public.

title: Men's Style; UNDER COVER
description: EVEN THEIR WIVES DON'T ALWAYS KNOW for sure. So while some men talk breezily about coloring their hair, most stop short of candor. One case in point concerns an investment banker, who asked not to be identified. A man in his 30's, he admits he touched up his gray just before his marriage because, as he put it, ''I didn't want to look like an old fogy in my wedding pictures.'' Another man, similarly reticent, is a television-industry executive in his 40's. He recalled darkening his temples after a friend suggested it might take years off his face.

title: After Flood, The West Side Is Recovering
description: A crowd stood on a corner at West 84th Street and Broadway yesterday, gawking at the enormous hole left by an aged water main that broke and spewed thousands of gallons of water onto the streets early Friday morning.

title: Ice Dancers Who Spin Tales of Romance skates.
description: YOU DIDN'T NEED TO KNOW A time step from a soft shoe when you watched Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire. And you won't need to tell a death spiral from a flying camel or any other picturesquely named skating move when the British skaters Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean arrive in town Wednesday with the Ice Capades.

title: A CASE THAT CHANGED THE RULES
description: CHADHA The Story of an Epic Constitutional Struggle. By Barbara Hinkson Craig. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Special Tax District Proposed for Lake
description: LEAD: WHEN Gerald L. Agliata goes fishing at Lake Innisfree, a 65-acre private body of water near his New Rochelle home, he always comes back with a plentiful catch. That, he says, dismays him. It's not that Mr. Agliata minds reeling in a nice, large bass. But the fact that the fish are plentiful means that so, too, are the weeds, which are threatening the lake.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CONSUMER ELECTRONICS
description: IN the annals of consumer electronics, 1987 will go down as the year in which sales of video cassette recorders stopped growing. Now, beset by the falling dollar and shrinking profit margins, the industry is looking for its next blockbuster product.

title: How They Tore Hutton to Pieces
description: ON a windy, bitterly cold day last week, Robert P. Rittereiser sat in his eerily still office on the 28th floor of E. F. Hutton & Company's year-old headquarters. In the plush offices all around him, the telephones were silent. Sunlight poured in on dozens of empty, tufted-leather chairs. Everything was clean, orderly, an office seemingly poised for an important meeting of Wall Street dealmakers. But E. F. Hutton had cut its last deal. Slate gray and set in a haggard face, Mr. Rittereiser's eyes flashed with anger and bitterness as the 49-year-old chief executive recounted his version of one of the most tangled tales of intrigue to hit Wall Street in years: the messy, ultimately destructive, battle for control of the company that had once been one of America's proudest and most profitable brokerage houses. In the end, Hutton was forced into an embarrassing auction just weeks before its executives thought it might collapse.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES

title: DOLE POLISHES HIS 'POOR BOY' ROLE AGAINST 'PREPPIE' BUSH
description: STANDING before a rally the other night in an airport hangar in Ottumwa, Iowa, Senator Bob Dole began speaking at length about the differences between himself and Vice President Bush. ''I don't want to get into class, but all of us have different backgrounds,'' he said. ''I didn't start at the top and stay at the top. I started at the bottom.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Fall River, Mass.: Condos Liven Waterfront
description: LEAD: NEW condominiums are transforming a blighted waterfront parcel in this working-class city of 100,000.

title: Cabaret: Murray Grand In Satirical Retrospective
description: MURRAY GRAND is a singer, pianist and songwriter whose songs and performances reflect a past era of nightclub life. He has gathered almost a score of his songs, written over the last three or four decades, in an intimate revue, ''Grand Slam,'' in which he is joined by Claiborne Cary and Nancy Timpanaro, both singers, at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, on Thursdays and Fridays this month.

title: Examining King's Nonviolent Resistance
description: AS we remember Dr. Martin Luther King's achievements, we readily focus upon his courageous crusades that attained extensive desegregation and contributed to the passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act and the 1965 Voting Rights Act. But what were the sources of the philosophy of nonviolence that directed his crusades? Who were the thinkers who inspired him to oppose several forms of collective violence - including economic exploitation and militarism -and to remain so consistently nonviolent in his opposition?

title: Correction
description: An article by The Associated Press last Sunday about United Press International misstated the number of people dismissed from U.P.I. in the last two months. Christopher Smith, a U.P.I. spokesman, said that while as many as 100 employees had left the news agency in the period, only 33 were laid off. The rest were temporary employees whose terms expired, probationary employees who were not retained or employees who resigned or left for other reasons.

title: Woman Killed in Fire At a Manhattan Hotel
description: A 69-year-old woman was killed yesterday evening when fire broke out in her room at the Martha Washington Hotel on the East Side of Manhattan, fire officials said.

title: Along the Dalmatian Coast
description: LEAD: THE route along the 600-mile Adriatic coastline of Yugoslavia abounds in secluded coves and sandy beaches, bristles with islands and islets and is, for almost its entire length, flanked by dramatic mountains. Everyone who visits comes back with a favorite old town, a favorite excursion or just a favorite patch of clear, blue water.

title: 429 THOUGHTS ON WHAT CAN FILL THE SPACE OF WESTWAY
description: THE New York real estate market, perhaps even more than nature, abhors a vacuum, and one of the biggest vacuums in the city is the 4.2-mile stretch of Hudson River waterfront between 44th Street and Battery Park City. Though last August Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch announced their support of a roadway and esplanade, which will succeed the Westway proposal defeated in 1985, no comprehensive plan exists for the adjoining ragged edge of water, piers and land amassed during the Westway years. The future of the area is a politically charged issue, and planners, after the failure of Westway, are gun-shy.

title: A Manuscript Recounts Drake's Explorations
description: TWO major exhibitions that span centuries of European and American exploration and history - ''Sir Francis Drake and the Age of Discovery'' and ''Edward Curtis and 'The North American Indian' '' - have just opened at the Pierpont Morgan Library and will continue into the early spring.

title: Correction
description: An article on the film page of the Arts and Leisure section today about the movie ''The Family'' gives an incorrect opening date. The film opens Friday at the Cinema Studio. A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about a Benny Goodman concert at Carnegie Hall 50 years ago misidentified the photographer. He was Lawrence Marx Jr.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: JANUARY 17, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, an evil wizard and a mouse. 2 10 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 3 7 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $4.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 4 11 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: PATRICIA AYCOCK TO WED
description: The engagement of Patricia Ann Aycock to Christopher Stephen Baker, a son of Linda Baker of Point Lookout, L.I., and the late James E. Baker, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. William G. Aycock of Mebane, N.C.

title: He Furnishes Objects To Fit a World Gone Awry
description: RICHARD ARTSCHWAGER'S IS A strange sculptural world, like an ordinary home whose furnishings - the tables and chairs, the windows, the floorboards, the medicine chest, everything - have all gone slightly mad. His work called ''Handle,'' for instance, is a handsomely crafted piece of polished oak that resembles a length of bannister, but it hangs on the wall and is not a handle to anything. Then there is his ''Sliding Door'' that doesn't slide, his ''Piano'' that doesn't play, and his ''Cradle,'' which is so enormous that even Rambo couldn't rock it.

title: JUST A COTTAGE SMALL
description: LEAD: O COME YE BACK TO IRELAND Our First Year in County Clare. By Niall Williams and Christine Breen. 233 pp. New York: Soho Press. $16.95.

title: CONTENTIOUS BUT CATALYTIC
description: HITCHCOCK AND SELZNICK The Rich and Strange Collaboration of Alfred Hitchcock and David O. Selznick in Hollywood. By Leonard J. Leff. Illustrated. 383 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.50.

title: CARLEY A. MILLER PLANNING TO WED ARTHUR SULLIVAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lindley G. Miller of Upper Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carley Anne Miller to Arthur Gary Sullivan, a son of Mrs. Sidney Blakemore Sullivan of Fredericksburg, Va., and the late Mr. Sullivan. They plan to marry in the spring.

title: MY SIX YEARS ON THE COUCH
description: The article by Dan Wakefield suggests to me a modestly successful analysis as opposed to a failed analysis. Mr. Wakefield's analysts withstood his self-destructive attempts to get them to intervene and become the involved parents he lacked (or felt he lacked). Because the analysts resisted his attempts at emotional blackmail, Mr. Wakefield learned to assume responsibility for his behavior. JEREMIAH M. GELLES, M.D. Brooklyn

title: Hauler's Fee Stirs a Dispute
description: NOTHING could take away from the success of East Hampton's innovative recycling project last fall - except perhaps a partisan squabble over a garbage bill.

title: Why New Issues Usually Disappoint
description: FEW investors who bought new stock offerings from companies in 1987 will look back with pleasure. The frothy pre-October market enabled Wall Street's underwriters to sell a record volume of initial public offerings - $24.2 billion worth, up 8 percent from a year earlier, according to Going Public, a service that tracks the new-issue market. But by the time the books closed last month, the average new issue had fallen 24.6 percent from the price the initial buyers paid.

title: Executive Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques Preview; WINTER'S GLITTER
description: NO GATHERING OF ANTIQUES is more eagerly anticipated in New York than the Winter Antiques Show, which opens with a series of preview parties on Friday and runs through Jan. 31 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street. Now in its 34th year, it is one of the city's smartest social charities (proceeds benefit the East Side House Settlement in the South Bronx) as well as a showcase for many of this country's top dealers.

title: Clint Eastwood's Riff on Charlie 'Bird' Parker
description: WEARING NIKE RUNNING shoes and an expression of casual glee, Clint Eastwood stepped into 1943.

title: Leveraged Buyouts: On the Level?
description: FOR MOST OF MY LIFE, I trusted the system, especially the economic system, to serve as an engine not only of prosperity but of equality and freedom and individual rights under the law. I fully believed that once principles of law were at stake, all Americans were equal.

title: Bonn Pledges Aid to Poland in Stability Drive
description: West Germany has pledged to explore new economic aid to Poland, a move that evidently reflects growing concern in Bonn that economic turmoil could produce social instability in Eastern Europe.

title: Trends in Art History
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance
description: The poetic and the rowdy will be celebrated at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) this week when Jazzdance: The Danny Buraczeski Dance Company performs in a program of new and recent work. Over the past decade, Mr. Buraczeski has set himself the task of exploring and mining jazz dance, and he has stretched the boundaries of that seemingly limited form of dance with contagious wonder and good cheer. ''Soulo,'' danced by the choreographer before a night sky backdrop by Susan Weil, is a solo, set to Negro spirituals, arranged for French horn and played at each performance by Willie Ruff. ''Out of the Blues,'' the program's other world premiere, is set to a funky Dixieland score by Amy Duncan that will be played by Brass Brass Tacks, Ms. Duncan's 10-piece band. And ''Night Vision,'' set to three tangos by Astor Piazzolla, is a dance inspired by ''Imagining Argentina,'' a novel by Lawrence Thorton.

title: JEANNE MININALL, LAWYER, IS WED
description: Jeanne Miller Mininall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Franklin Mininall of Birmingham, Mich., was married last evening to Arthur Edwin Bass, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herman Michael Bass of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Burt Segal and the Rev. Lazarus Sequeira, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Meadowlands estate in Darien, Conn.

title: The Theory Gap on the Trade Gap
description: THE persistent failure of the cheaper dollar to significantly improve the United States trade balance not only signals problems for Administration economic policy. It is a puzzle - and increasingly an embarrassment - for an economics profession that predicted almost unanimously that a cheap dollar would bring dramatic trade improvement.

title: THE WORLD: With India and Pakistan; U.S. INTEREST IN SOUTH ASIA IS DEEPENING, CAUTIOUSLY
description: A NEW wariness has crept into the relationship between the United States and each of the two South Asian rivals, India and Pakistan, but there is also opportunity for Washington to extend its authority. Both the wariness and the opportunity are a result of deepening American involvement in an area that often receives less attention than the neighboring Persian Gulf but may be no less critical to Washington's interests. And the prospect that the Russians might pull their troops out of Afghanistan soon has forced the recalculation of the diplomatic equations in this part of the world.

title: Thousands of Executives Seeking Wall Street Jobs in Bleak Market
description: Three months after the stock market collapse, an army of highly educated, highly paid executives, people used to sitting at the center of corporate power, are scrambling to salvage their careers, professional reputations and affluent styles of life.

title: MICHELLE CRUZ IS ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Michelle Marie Cruz to Mark Bingham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bingham of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. David Cruz of Great Neck, L.I. Miss Cruz, a graduate of the University of Colorado and the Fordham University School of Law, is an associate in the New York law firm of Shea & Gould. Mr. Bingham, a graduate of Harvard University, is a vice president of Adler Communications, a New York sports-marketing firm.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace. Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room. We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out. Is there any other kind of stripping you can suggest to fill in these gaps?

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Social Events
description: Achievers and Royal Gala Honoring Role Models Jan. 19 - Arthur Ashe and Marilyn Horne are among well-known achievers who came up the hard way and who will be honored as role models at the ninth annual Sidewalks of New York fund-raising dinner of Big Brothers of New York City in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Adult volunteers at Big Brothers provide friendship and guidance for children in single-parent homes. Other distinguished role models to be honored are Dr. R. Bruce Merrifield of Rockefeller University, who received the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1984, and Delbert Staley, chairman and chief executive officer of Nynex. Cocktails at 6:30, dinner at 7:30. Black tie is optional. Tickets $300, from 212-580-5511. A Theater Gala Jan. 21 - The Duchess of York, the former Sarah Ferguson, is scheduled to be the guest of honor at a royal gala preview performance of Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' which will open Jan. 26 at the Majestic Theater, 245 West 44th Street, near Eighth Avenue. The gala will benefit three organizations: the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., the Royal College of Music in London and the Sick Children's Trust in London. Tickets are $200, $500 and $1,000. The $200 ticket includes a Champagne reception during intermission. The $500 ticket provides admission to the Champagne intermission and also to a pretheater Champagne party in the Hilton Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The $1,000 ticket holders are invited to attend a dinner in the Waldorf's Grand Ballroom after the performance. All ticket holders will receive a personal gift. Black tie. Tickets, 212-302-7077 or toll free, from 800-223-4446. To Advance Learning Jan. 21 - Continuing development of the Research and Learning Center at Manhattan College will benefit from the college's $400-a-plate De La Salle Medal dinner in the Waldorf's Grand Ballroom. The De La Salle Medal, awarded each year by the college to a person who exemplifies ''service to the moral, cultural and educational life of the nation,'' will be presented to Maurice R. Greenberg, president and chief executive officer of the American International Group. Reception at 6, dinner at 7. Tickets from 212-920-4011. Winter Antiques Show Jan. 22 - Several parties will precede the official opening on Jan. 23 of the Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street. For 34 years the show has benefited the East Side House Settlement. Tickets are $500 for the benefactors' tea in the main exhibition hall at 4 P.M. and may be used for daily admission to the show until it closes Jan. 31. The tea is to be followed by a patrons' cocktail party, tickets $250, at 6 in the Tiffany Room at the armory; the ticket is also good for three additional admissions to the show. There will be a preview party buffet in the exhibition hall at 7:30, for which tickets are $150, entitling holders to an additional admission to the show. Tickets from 212-655-5250. To Cool La MaMa Jan. 23 - A 9 P.M. benefit performance of Dave Hunsacker's play ''The Summer Face Woman'' at the annex of La MaMa Theater at 66 East Fourth Street, between Second Avenue and the Bowery, will help pay for the installation of a new air-conditioning system at the theater. A party with dancing will follow the performance in Club Tundra downstairs at the annex, and there will be a raffle of prizes. Tickets $100, from 212-254-6468. Biomedical Research Jan. 23 - A dinner-dance at 7:30 P.M. at the Pierre, with entertainment by the magician Kreskin and a raffle of jewelry, furs and vacations in Florida, Utah and the Caribbean, will benefit biomedical research at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University. Black tie. Tickets, $250, $375, $500 and $750, from 212-430-4242. Fund-Raiser for Crafts Jan. 26 - To raise money for the American Craft Museum at 40 West 53d Street, the American Craft Council will sponsor a week of festivities to herald the opening Jan. 27 of three exhibitions of contemporary crafts. To start things, at 7 P.M. on Jan. 26 there will be a black-tie buffet at the swanky new McDonald's designed by Charles Morris Mount on the concourse level of the Time-Life Building in Rockefeller Center. In addition to a McDonald's bill of fare, E.A.T. on Madison Avenue will provide delicacies. Tickets for the buffet are $250 and include a party at 9 P.M. at the museum, at which dessert will be served and Julienne Scanlon, the singer, will entertain. Tickets for the party only are $100. All ticket holders will receive a year's membership in the council. 212-956-3535.

title:
Focus: Des Moines;
Downtown Changing Its Face
description: LEAD: IN a few months, when the ground here is no longer frozen, executives of the Principal Financial Group, Des Moines' largest employer, plan to break ground for Iowa's tallest building. It is a speculative rental that is to rise 44 stories in the city's downtown.

title: Case Closed
description: ''This is the continuing saga of McDuff and Tucker, two members of the species 'canis familiaris,' popularly known as 'man's best friend,' who had an altercation on the streets of Pleasantville in January 1986.''

title: Of Men and Mice: Witty Toys on View
description: THE MOST COMPREHEN-sive collection of comic-character toys ever exhibited - Mickey Mouse, Popeye, Donald Duck, Little Orphan Annie, Felix the Cat and Betty Boop - will be on view through Saturday at the Alexander Gallery, 996 Madison Avenue (at 77th Street). The 400 outrageously colorful and boldly graphic windup, push-pull, squeezeable and noisemaking toys were produced mostly between 1920 and 1940. Acquired by Robert Lesser over two decades, the collection has never been exhibited until now.

title: Trends in Art History
description: To the Editor:

title: A Real Sign of a Bargain Says, 'Made in America'
description: Akami Ueno, who lives near Tokyo, flew across the Pacific and bought a camera with a familiar label: Made in Japan.

title: G.O.P. CANDIDATES CLASH IN DEBATE
description: The six Republican candidates for President clashed sharply in a debate here today over economic policy, taxes and each other's records.

title: HOURS TO BE CUT FOR POST OFFICES
description: The United States Postal Service said Friday night that post offices around the country would shorten their lobby hours by an average of half a day a week to absorb budget cuts required by Congress.

title: WING SOMMERS, A BANKER, IS MARRIED IN CAPITAL TO R. O. BLAKE JR., A DIPLOMAT
description: The marriage of Anne Wing Sommers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Feldher Sommers of Chevy Chase, Md., to Robert Orris Blake Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Blake of Washington, took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington. The Rev. George L. Peabody performed the ceremony.

title: Journeys in a Spanish Landscape
description: LEAD: EVERYWHERE one goes in today's Spain there is work in progress: clouds of dust in the streets, machines chugging and churning, new highways and buildings and communications. But the immemorial face of Spain has hardly changed yet, perhaps will never change much. The Spanish temperament comes out of the Spanish landscape, and out of the long struggle - partly armed resistance and partly assimilation - with the Arabian invaders who occupied some or all of the country for 600 years.

title: Knicks Roll Past Sixers
description: Rick Pitino, searching for a new way to win, revived an old concept last night: starting Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright together on the front line. It was only the second time this season that the Knick coach had started his two 7-footers together in hopes of controlling the boards and the tempo of the game.

title: ST. JOHN'S SURVIVES BY 71-70
description: In an evening of Big East Conference upsets, Seton Hall came close to doing what it had not managed in many years: beating St. John's on its home court.

title: Political Notes; A Successor For Giuliani: A List Grows
description: The list of possible successors to Rudolph W. Giuliani as United States Attorney in Manhattan is like an accordion - for a variety of reasons, it expands and contracts in the hands of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and his aides.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Maryland Tops Duke; Oklahoma Is Upset
description: A slam-follow by Derrick Lewis with 24 seconds left broke a tie, and Rudy Archer added a free throw as Maryland upset Duke, 72-69, in an Atlantic Coast Conference game tonight.

title: Self Discipline
description: To The Editor:

title: ON CHOOSING FILM
description: IT'S a scene I see almost every time I go into a camera store. Harry, the hapless customer, walks up to the counter and asks for a roll of film. ''What kind?'' the clerk queries. ''I dunno, the kind that makes color prints,'' Harry replies, acting as if he's on an errand for his wife.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A DEATH IN NOVEMBER: America in Vietnam, 1963. By Ellen J. Hammer. (Dutton, $22.50.) The title of this carefully researched book refers to the death of Ngo Dinh Diem, president of South Vietnam from 1955 to 1963, and that of his brother and adviser, Ngo Dinh Nhu. They were assassinated in a military coup encouraged by the Administration of John F.

title: Nurse and Teacher Licensing Under Fire
description: THE rush to fill vacant nursing and teaching positions is resulting in what critics contend are policies and proposals that will lower the licensing standards for people entering the fields.

title: Q and A
description: 2-Family House Tenant

title: A VCR In Every Pocket
description: THE Sony Walkman helped usher in a new category known as ''personal audio'' products, which allow people to take high quality music with them anywhere. Now, electronics companies hope to repeat their success with ''personal video.'' They are combining tiny television sets and video cassette recorders into miniature units that would allow people to take their favorite movies with them anywhere.

title: Census Count: 42 Eagles
description: The annual census of bald and golden eagles has counted 36 birds in the Quabbin Reservoir so far and at least six others elsewhere in the state, according to Massachusetts wildlife officials. Bird counters said this week that this year's total was slightly below those of the past two winters, when more than 50 birds were counted.

title: CARTING OFF THEIR FAITH
description: TIME WITHOUT BELLS By Horst Bienek. Translated by Ralph R. Read. 338 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: Gorillas and Dian Fossey
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right Against Reagan
description: ONE MORNING just before Congress took its Christmas recess, President Reagan and eight key Senate Republicans gathered around the polished table in the Cabinet Room. The President's goal was to recruit them for his campaign to win quick approval of the arms-control treaty he had just signed with the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: AWARD-WINNING CD PLAYERS
description: THERE ARE FEW PATHS to glory for audio engineers.

description: Former Gov. Pete du Pont of Delaware asked today that his name be pulled off the ballot for the Republican Presidential primary in Texas, saying his campaign was a victim of ''a nasty fraud'' involving forged signatures on petitions.

title: Dole, Pressed About His Finances, Releases Data on Taxes and Trust
description: After a week of controversy about his financial affairs, Senator Bob Dole today made public 21 years of Federal tax returns along with the details of a blind trust belonging to his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title: A CASE OF COLIC
description: Joel C. Berman's description of his daughter's colic and his reactions to her distress has an important message for all of us (About Men: ''A Case of Colic,'' Nov. 29). Patients will hear a sensitive physician admitting his frailties and will admire his expressions of camaraderie with those who turn to health-care providers for help. Physicians would do well to listen to the essential message: that the effect of an illness is determined not so much by the symptoms it causes as by the significance those symptoms have to the patient (or her father!). WENDY GLADSTONE Exeter, N.H.

title: 3 Officials Named for Democratic Convention
description: The Democratic high command today chose the convention officials who will referee the opening rounds of competition between the party's Presidential candidates who survive the primaries and caucuses.

title: Packaging an Estate: Seacroft For Sale
description: W. James Oelsner, the mayor of Centre Island from 1975 to 1977, is selling Harbour Point, the Oelsner family's Centre Island estate since 1946. The 25.4-acre tract, which faces Cold Spring Harbor on the north shore of Long Island, is composed of 12 land parcels assembled over the years around Seacroft, the family's Mediterranean-style mansion. The site also has eight other houses.

title: Newark Must Provide For Its Homeless
description: ''Shelter means out of the terrain, out of the inclement weather.'' BISHOP JAMES W. PARROTT

title: Walking Made Easy With Snowshoes
description: THEY are not numerous, but they are out there, traveling along woodland trails, across meadows and beaches, up and down hillsides and around backyards. They are the people who fasten frames of ash or aluminum to their feet and go snowshoeing.

title: NOT THE SAME OLD SHEARLING
description: Shearling coats, which have seen their wearers through some cold times, are getting the chance to do so again this frigid winter. Simple, honest, rugged - these are the words that come to mind in describing the sturdy and functional shearling. They still apply to this hardy perrennial, but now some new descriptions can be added to the shearling coat lexicon, such as sophisticated and fashionable.

title: 'Sandwich' Adults: Doing Double Duty
description: I AM a member of the ''sandwich'' generation. I am a parent who has suddenly found herself caring for own parent. Sometimes I feel as if I am trapped in the middle, like the cream of the Oreo cookie, with no way out of a situation for which I was totally unprepared.

description: The Yanks will be favorites when they have a starting rotation to match the Blue Jays. Adding John Candelaria (still a big 'if') still leaves them a quality pitcher short. JEFF MARINER New Hyde Park, L.I.

description: The next round of United Nations-sponsored peace talks on Afghanistan will open in Geneva in February and appear likely to produce agreement on a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet forces, according to United Nations officials and diplomats here.

description: Parents cannot be held liable for all their children's actions, a magistrate said Tuesday in rejecting a misdemeanor charge against a woman whose teen-age son was charged with allowing minors to drink at a party at their house while she was away.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A New Perspective on 'Eloquent Objects'
description: OCCASIONALLY, a book causes one to step back and, with a widened vision, see everything with a new perspective. That was this writer's experience on opening ''The Eloquent Object,'' published in conjunction with a recent exhibition of the same name at the Philbrook Museum of Art in Tulsa, Okla.

title: Jersey Casino Revenues Grew 9.4% Last Year
description: The revenues of the Atlantic City casino industry continued to grow about 10 percent last year, despite the addition of a 12th casino to a market limited by a lack of scheduled air service.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE TECHNOLOGY WAR: A Case for Competitiveness. By David H. Brandin and Michael A. Harrison. (Wiley-Interscience, $24.95.) Information may be to the age of technology as oil was to the industrial era: the fuel running the world's economies. David H. Brandin, president of Strategic Technologies Inc., and Michael A. Harrison, professor of computer science at the University of California, Berkeley, demonstrate forcefully that those who control information will be the new world leaders. The Western defense system, the stock market, telecommunications, air traffic control and even competitive manufacturing are now highly dependent on rapid, computerized information and more dependents are being added yearly. Information technology is worth at least $100 billion a year and is growing ''beyond our ability to measure it.'' Not surprisingly, the United States and Japan are the two major players in this competitive field, with a balkanized Europe lagging and Korea closing in fast. Less well known is the rise of Malaysia as a producer of integrated circuits and the Soviet Union's lag in digital communications because the K.G.B. eliminated direct distance dialing in 1982 to facilitate monitoring of telephone calls. One of the book's oft-repeated refrains is that the United States is in serious trouble, with 10 percent of its population functionally illiterate, and the lack of a coordinated Government and industrial policy. The authors virtually omit some players, such as Israel. Nonetheless, the book identifies many important issues, including the need for better software to make different computers compatible and the need for a Cabinet-level technology department in the United States. Over all, it is a worthwhile introduction to the field of ''knowledge capital.''

title: CONNECTICUT STUNS SYRACUSE IN DOME
description: Cliff Robinson made a foul shot with two seconds remaining tonight and Connecticut upset Syracuse, 51-50, in a Big East Conference game.

description: Sure . . . just as much as Andre Dawson, the National League's most valuable player in 1987, made the Chicago Cubs the favorites. KARL HAMILTON West Point, N.Y.

description: Let no reader of Dan Wakefield's troubling article be misled into thinking that the decline of ''orthodox'' Freudian analysis has made the couch a safer place.

description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, under investigation for his stock holdings in the telephone industry, apparently met with top executives of two regional Bell companies while his financial manager held $10,000 worth of his telephone stock.

title:
TELEVISION;
Glenda Jackson Brings an O'Neill Heroine to TV
description: LEAD: THE THOROUGHLY ENGLISH Glenda Jackson is no stranger to America's only Nobel Prize-winning dramatist. About three years ago, to heated plaudits, she graced this side of the Atlantic with a British production of Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude.'' That nine-act, five-hour production, featuring O'Neill's infamous ''thoughts'' - streams of consciousness spoken aloud and alternating with dialogue - had not been significantly performed on the American stage since its premiere in 1928.

description: BEFORE the Democratic candidates for President gathered in debate here last week, people figured they knew what would be said about the deficit and arms control and welfare reform. What people were wondering was, would any one in the pack go after Gary Hart on the character issue?

title: Streetscapes: 1451 Lexington Avenue; Sad Brownstone Monument To an Aborted Plan for a Sliver
description: IT was to be the narrowest - and perhaps most notorious - of the sliver buildings, 33 stories on an 18-foot-wide lot at 1451 Lexington Avenue, between East 94th and 95th Streets.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace. Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room. We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out. Is there any other kind of stripping you can suggest to fill in these gaps?

title: Fire Volunteers Get Help on Stress
description: LEAD: ''WHAT I couldn't deal with that day,'' recalled Joseph Amato, a Plainview volunteer fireman, ''was when we were bringing the children out in body bags and the media was homing in with those cameras. A bunch of us had opened our coats so they couldn't get a picture of the bodies when one of the cameramen yelled out to me, 'Lieutenant, don't be childish.

description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing Units)

description: LEAD: ''I SAW the deer to my right about 30 to 40 feet away. I slowed down and he ran right into me - headed right for the car. I could't believe it. It was like he was out to get me.''

title: Photography
description: It sometimes seems that there are two competing schools of contemporary photography. One, usually called street photography, aspires to capture the textures of life itself. The other, generally known as art photography, is less literal and more experimental, emphasizing the expressive potentials of the medium. But as antipodal as these two approaches seem, they are not necessarily mutually exclusive - witness the work of Michael Spano.

title: Hoyt to Allenwood
description: THINGS might have taken a turn for the better for LaMarr Hoyt, the former Cy Young Award winner whose pitching career came to a sad end last January when he was released by the San Diego Padres after a succession of drug arrests in 1986.

Famous for offering designer women's clothing - sans label - at discount prices and infamous for provoking fights among aggressive bargain hunters, the 80-store chain, a division of May Department Store Companies, plans to open a new outlet in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx in March. The chain's current Bronx store on West Fordham Road may then be closed, but no final decision has been made, a company official said.

If the protests and Israel's harsh countermeasures, like this week's deportation of Palestinian leaders, continue, the United States also will face hard questions about its posture in the Middle

title: Jazz and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: NIGHTS AT THE ALEXANDRA. By William Trevor. Illustrated by Paul Hogarth. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) ''I am a 58-year-old provincial,'' writes the narrator of William Trevor's slim novella, the latest in the Harper Short Novel series. ''I have no children. I have never married.'' The person responsible for this state of affairs is Frau Messinger, an Englishwoman who finds refuge from World War II with her elderly German husband near the Irish town of Cloverhill. The great events of the far-off war and Cloverhill's distance from Dublin make the town a backwater twice over, its tedium double-dyed. Soon the glamorous new arrival begins to rely on young Harry, the narrator, to run errands for her and, just as important, to listen, spellbound, as she relates the story of her life. For a teen-age boy in oppressively dull circumstances, destined to toil in his father's lumberyard, Frau Messinger is a dangerous dose of romance, almost a screen goddess in her perfection and unattainability. The cinematic suggestions become explicit when Herr Messinger builds Cloverhill's first movie house, names it the Alexandra after his wife, and finds Harry a job there. Some 40 years later, we learn, Harry has taken possession of it - or vice versa. Like Miss Havisham's wedding cake, the boarded-up theater has succumbed to rodents and rot. Its proprietor has become the curator of a fantasy or, as he describes himself, ''the ghost of an interlude.'' Elusive and elliptical, ''Nights at the Alexandra'' seems a touch perfunctory, a sketch rather than a fully realized drama. But the noted Irish novelist and short-story writer's prose - austere, distanced and precise - casts the familiar spell.

title: 3 Indictments Strain U.S.-Mexican Links
description: Drug trafficking is again emerging as a source of tension between the United States and Mexico, after an interlude of nearly a year in which both sides played down their differences on what each should be doing to combat it.

description: THE OYSTER CLUB, a new restaurant in Cos Cob, doesn't just look familiar, it is familiar. We failed to identify the locale driving into the Palmer Point office-condominium complex where it is situated, but the view of the Mianus River rang a faint bell.

title: LONGINGS, SWOONINGS AND POSTURINGS
description: A LITERATE PASSION Letters of Anais Nin and Henry Miller, 1932-1953. Edited, and with an introduction, by Gunther Stuhlmann. 422 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Corrosion of Bridge's Cable Is Called Limited
description: Engineers and transportation officials, seeking to determine the future of the aging Williamsburg Bridge, uncovered the bridge's most corroded cable yesterday and pronounced it not as badly damaged as they had feared.

title: T.A. Pappas, 89, Dies; Was Envoy to Greece
description: Thomas A. Pappas, a prominent Republican who was Ambassador to Greece during the Eisenhower Administration, died at his home here after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title:
GARDENING;
The Long and Short of Dwarf Conifers
description: LEAD: CONIFERS are among the more highly valued landscape plants. Their evergreen foliage is attractive regardless of season, they vary greatly in color and texture and are available in a variety of forms.

title: TAMARA AND TAMARA AND TAMARA . . .
description: In ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,'' Tom Stoppard gave audiences a chance to see the tragedy of ''Hamlet'' through the eyes of its bewildered bit players. In ''Tamara,'' the playwright John Krizanc makes bit players of the members of the audience, who trail after 10 characters through action set in the sprawling estate of the Italian poet Gabriele d'Annunzio. The title refers to Tamara de Lempicka, the Polish artist whom d'Annunzio pursues.

title: CHIRAC, TRAILING IN POLLS, DECLARES CANDIDACY
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, the conservative who has headed France's Government since March 1986, today announced his candidacy in the presidential elections this spring.

title: Taxes and Outlays: Scenario in Works
description: GOVERNOR KEAN touched nearly all the bases in his State of the State address last week, but omitted tax and spending reforms, probably because the working script for those items is being written by others.

title: Adrift on the Rocky Seas of Adaptation
description: THE MAJOR NOVELS OF OLIVIA Manning, written in the 1960's and 1970's and collected in two volumes called ''The Balkan Trilogy'' and ''The Levant Trilogy,'' have at long last made it to television. They are dramatized in a BBC production entitled ''Fortunes of War,'' a mini-series that begins on WNET at 9 this evening as a ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation.

title: WHAT SNOOLS THESE MORTALS BE
description: WEBSTERS' FIRST NEW INTERGALACTIC WICKEDARY OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE By Mary Daly with Jane Caputi. Illustrated. 310 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $35.
