description: Eliza Ordway Webb and Craig Robert Faulks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Faulks of Rocky River, Ohio, plan to marry in May, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gaynor Webb of New Canaan, Conn., have announced.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DANCE
description: LEAD: Manon Starring Jennifer Penney and Anthony Dowell. The Royal Ballet. Choreography by Kenneth MacMillan. HBO Video. 126 minutes. $39.95.

title: U.S. TRADE: TAKING THE LONG VIEW
description: WAS Friday's report of a 25 percent drop in the United States trade deficit, to $13.2 billion for November, the sign of a long-awaited turning point? The stock and bond markets certainly thought so. The Dow Jones industrial average added nearly 40 points, even as delighted Administration officials cautioned against overreliance on any one month's figure. Nevertheless, economists called the improvement remarkable, for its breadth across geographical and product lines, and for the roughly similar gains made in both exports and imports.

title: FOR FIGHT GAME, A SOLUTION TO AN AGE-OLD PROBLEM
description: WITH two leviathans from the past (Larry Holmes and George Foreman) once again rumbling round a boxing ring, I've been keeping a good idea on the back burner. However, if Mike Tyson readily dispatches ex-champion Holmes in Atlantic City Friday night, things will be put into proper perspective and we can go ahead as planned.

title: Tax Credits Produce Housing for Poor
description: EVEN though Maurice Callender has never been to the boardrooms of J.C. Penney or The Equitable, he expects the small neighborhood organization he heads - the West Harlem Group Assistance Corporation - to become a partner with those companies and several other corporate giants later this year to rebuild, of all things, 180 apartments for low-income families in Harlem.

title: Building Rules for Casinos Tightened
description: NEW JERSEY has closed a loophole in its 1977 Casino Control Act that had allowed companies operated by reputed organized-crime figures to reap more than $800,000 from casino construction projects in Atlantic City.

title: Police Are Monitoring a New Drug
description: LAW-ENFORCEMENT officials are trying to combat a new form of cocaine that they say is deadlier, more addictive and cheaper than crack.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: VIRGINIA BEACH, VA.;
Growth Pangs On the Atlantic
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION is to start next month on a 14-story office building, Two Columbus Center, that has come to symbolize the attempt by this sprawling Atlantic shore resort city to establish a true downtown.

title: Installing a Drywall Ceiling
description: INSTALLING panels of drywall, also known as plasterboard, gypsum wallboard or Sheetrock, overhead to create a ceiling is seldom a cinch. However, the job can be made much easier by employing some of the strategies and tools used by professionals.

title: WHAT WE DON'T KNOW ABOUT NUCLEAR POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: SARAH BERNSTEIN TO WED IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bernstein of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Rachel Bernstein to Ian O. Lesser, the son of Mortimer Lesser of New York and the stepson of Henrietta Lesser. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Islanders' Hrudey Stops Devils, 4-2
description: The Islanders' Kelly Hrudey put a goaltending tip to good use this evening. But he was not ready to divulge the key to his success.

title: Bagpipes In Spotlight In Hartford
description: BAGPIPES, ballads and poetry will be in the spotlight Thursday as the South Congregational Church in Hartford celebrates Robert Burns Night.

title: Creating a Climate for Growth
description: THE debate rages clear out to Montauk. Where is Long Island going and what will it look like when it gets there? The economy, our government, education, transportation and taxation are just a handful of the issues that keep popping up like targets on a pistol range.

title: Fashion; SUIT SEARCHING
description: IT'S THE JACKET THAT MAKES THE SALE. THE moment a woman slips into the top half of a suit, she sees herself taking on a new shape. This season, her shoulders are still jaunty, though more rounded than squared. The seaming makes her look at once thinner and curvier. The elongated lapels or lower openings suggest that her neck is admirably longer. And, of course, she looks taller and certainly more chic and perhaps even prettier. It's all in the magic of the cut of the jacket. But a suit is, after all, an assemblage of compatible separates. This spring, there are other pluses to the new suits, besides the flattering jackets.

title: IT'S THE ONLY FED WE'VE GOT
description: SECRETS OF THE TEMPLE How the Federal Reserve Runs the Country. By William Greider. 798 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Opera: An Adaptation Of Massenet's 'Cendrillon'
description: ADVERTISEMENTS for the Music-Theater Group's ''Cinderella/ Cendrillon'' at St. Clement's Church on Thursday night were enough to chill the opera lover's spine. A ''retelling'' of the Cinderella story with ''a modern sensibility,'' they promised. (''Retelling'' plus ''modern'' in small American opera companies usually means ''vulgarization.'') Selective editing, adaptation and additions to Massenet's little-known opera were also announced (for these three processes, read in most cases ''perversion and destruction.'') The production - shared by Anne Bogart, Jeff Halpern and Eve Ensler -began with yet another scarcely tenable position: dialogue in English, singing in the original French.

title: Sunday Observer; Polls Apart
description: THOUSANDS OF POLL fans, learning of my retirement, beg me to publish my memoirs of the early days of polling.

title: OOH OOH. AND THEN AGAIN, AH AH
description: LITERAL MADNESS Three Novels: Kathy Goes to Haiti. My Death My Life by Pier Paolo Pasolini. Florida. By Kathy Acker. 410 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

title: SUSAN ELIZABETH TELLIER, AN EXECUTIVE, MARRIED TO JOSEPH JAMES PERTICONE JR.
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in Scarsdale, N.Y., Susan Elizabeth Tellier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Tellier of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph James Perticone Jr., a son of Mary C. Perticone of Baltimore and the late Mr. Perticone. Msgr. James F. McCarthy, assisted by the Rev. William E. Warren, performed the ceremony.

title: A Widow Reflects on Her Difficult Adjustment to a New Life
description: TWO years have gone by since my husband died, and I have just realized that I no longer wince when I refer to myself as a widow. Looking back now, I see there have been other changes in my feelings during my difficult adjustment to a new life. I've experienced shock, anger, grief, depression, guilt, doubt, pain, regrets and loneliness. But I'm now feeling something else -a strength I never knew I had and an awareness of an emerging new self.

title: Bogeys Haunt Pate, But He Holds Lead
description: After playing 42 holes over three days with 15 birdies, 27 pars and no bogeys, Steve Pate took a double bogey on his 43d hole, his seventh hole in today's round. He then took three bogeys on the back nine of LaCosta Country Club's course. But he also had seven birdies for the round, and that helped him keep the lead he has held from the first day of the 36th annual MONY Tournament of Champions.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Earning the (Ice) Blue Belt ''Eee-yaah,'' the barefooted Long Islander gasped as his toes sank into the snow. ''Eeeeeee-yoooowwwww'' came the collective roar as 62 more bare feet hit the icy whiteness.

title: A CORRECTION
description: In a Posting on Dec. 27 on the Cutter Financial Center in Hartford, a reference to another office project, 180 Allyn Street, failed to mention that the Tishman Realty & Construction Company is its codeveloper.

title: The Guggenheim's Man
description: The Guggenheim Museum of Art has appointed a man described as ''the Clint Eastwood of the art museum director's world'' to direct its expansionist fortunes.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection is trying to get rid of 9,500 barrels of radium-contaminated soil in Kearny the same way it got rid of 5,000 barrels in Montclair.

title: ETTORE SCOLA SCANS HISTORY THROUGH 'THE FAMILY'
description: IN ''THE FAMILY,'' WHICH opened on Friday at the Cinema Studio, Ettore Scola offers up a two-hour crash course in 80 years of European history, without ever leaving the rambling apartment which is both haven and prison for five generations of a comfortable Roman clan. Just outside the family's field of vision - and the audience's - World War I rages, Mussolini waxes and wanes, threadbare liberation is followed by a burgeoning postwar boom, post-'68 malaise segues into the uneasy reconciliations of the 1980's. Some sign of this tumult penetrates these sturdy walls from time to time, but it's always upstaged by the ceaseless tremors of family life -squabbles in the dining room, flirtations in the study, births and demises in some bedroom off the hallway where the kids are thumping each other with wooden swords. In the end, the family seems intact but everything has changed, and nobody concerned can explain just how it all happened.

title: Appeals Court Says Judge Erred In Not Discharging Biased Juror
description: A trial judge should have discharged a juror who said after deliberations began that she could not ignore her own prejudice against Hispanic people in a case with a Hispanic defendant, the state's highest court has ruled.

title: Abe Waters; Textile Executive, 77
description: Abe Waters, a textile executive, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Lauderhill, Fla. He was 77 years old.

title: Learning How to Run a Small Business
description: GEORGIA ROELOF was there. So was Risa Bell, Carolyn Davis and Paulette Ensign. All of them had paid $100 to attend a conference at which they hoped to learn how to manage better their own small businesses. The daylong conference, sponsored by the Entrepreneurial Center of Manhattanville College in Purchase last November, attracted 160 people.

title: Creating a New Career at Age 52
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, after Virginia Gilbert moved to this Monmouth County community from South Orange, she quickly tired of the 80-mile round trip to and from her job as manager of an art gallery and began what turned into a fruitless two-year odyssey in search of a position nearer her home that would pay more than $300 a week, including benefits.

That was just six days after a group of black Baptist ministers had delivered a calculated snub by refusing him an invitation to their Martin Luther King Day celebration tomorrow. Then, three days after he was received by the Methodists, the

title: ELIZABETH C. O'HERRON PLANS TO MARRY IN APRIL

description: HOW far can a rubber band stretch before it snaps?

title: AIDS ANTIBODIES IN NEW YORK INFANTS
description: EVEN in an epidemic in which grim statistics have become numbingly commonplace, a New York state study on AIDS and newborn infants was shocking: one of every 61 babies born in New York City last month carried antibodies to the virus, indicating that their mothers were infected and that many of the babies were also carriers.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Giving Patchwork Quilts the Right Care
description: LEAD: GENERATIONS that have come to treasure time as a commodity understand that there is nothing humble about hand work. Or permanent.

title: Adult Zone Is Sought By Town
description: LEAD: THE Town of Brookhaven is considering the creation of a ''pink-light'' zone, which would put adult-entertainment businesses such as topless bars, massage parlors, adult movie theaters and bookstores in areas zoned for industry and remove them from residential and business areas.

title: BEST SELLERS: JANUARY 17, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 8 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 2 4 11 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 3 2 13 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 4 6 30 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 5 5 25 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 6 3 16 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' 7 9 7 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Continuing the space saga begun in ''2001'' and ''2010.'' 8 10 18 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 9 8 16 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families, the Mains of South Carolina and the Hazards of Pennsylvania, in the aftermath of the Civil War. 10 7 13 THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) A small boy's Christmas Eve train ride to the North Pole and the magical events that follow. 11 * 15 3 WINTER, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $19.95.) The experiences of a Berlin family, from Kaiser Wilhelm to Adolf Hitler. 12 11 22 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $19.95.) Ten thousand years of English history, seen through the experiences of five families. 13 * 3 WINTERS' TALES, by Jonathan Winters. (Random House, $13.95.) Unusual short stories by the comedian and television personality. 14 11 BLUEBEARD, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A painter's life in the artists-and-writers world of Long Island's Hamptons. 15 3 A MAN RIDES THROUGH, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) Second and concluding novel about Mordant, a strange land where reality is intertwined with fantasy. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 3 5 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 2 1 16 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $15.95.) Counting his blessings and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50. 3 4 8 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 4 2 19 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 5 8 25 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 6 25 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 7 10 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 8 5 52 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 9 * 7 10 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF THE SOVIET UNION. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The vast country on May 15, 1987, as recorded in pictures by 100 of the world's leading photojournalists. 10 6 19 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (Random House, $19.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells his story. 11 13 4 PERESTROIKA, by Mikhail Gorbachev. (Bessie/ Harper & Row, $19.95.) The Soviet leader's views on changing his country and the world. 12 11 12 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 13 10 7 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) Profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. 14 8 FREE TO BE . . . A FAMILY, edited by Marlo Thomas with Christopher Cerf and Letty Cottin Pogrebin. (Bantam, $19.95.) Stories, poems and drawings about family relationships. 15 32 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education and American undergraduates during the past 25 years. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 8 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. 2 7 SUPER MARITAL SEX, by Paul Pearsall. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Counsel derived from interviews with 1,000 couples. 3 5 28 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 4 3 123 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 4 30 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS: Economic Change and Military Conflict From 1500 to 2000, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) The author, a Yale historian, argues cogently that the modern empires declined when their military commitments outran their economic strength; guess who is next. THE DROWNED AND THE SAVED, by Primo Levi. (Summit, $17.95.) The last effort of this great writer to understand his experience in the Holocaust; humane, disciplined and very sad. THE SILVER DESOTO, by Patty Lou Floyd. (Council Oak/Texas Monthly, $14.95.) Strong and memorable short stories set in Oklahoma during the dust bowl years, all narrated by a girl coming to terms with her family secrets and her growing up. PERFECT GALLOWS, by Peter Dickinson. (Pantheon, $16.95.) This suspense novel, set in England just before the invasion of Normandy in 1944, juxtaposes an eccentric English family, a pack of boorish Americans and an amateur Shakespeare production. CHILE: Death in the South, by Jacobo Timerman. (Knopf, $15.95.) Mr. Timerman, an Argentine, reassesses the sufferings of his neighbor state and finds its best plausible prospect for freedom in a reconciliation of the center with the democratic right. FORBIDDEN JOURNEY: The Life of Alexandra David-Neel, by Barbara M. Foster and Michael Foster. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) A wonderful biography of a Parisian woman, five feet tall but far larger than life, who became a Tantric lama in Tibet at the age of 52, hobnobbed with princes and gurus, and died in 1969 at 100. JOHN CALVIN: A Sixteenth Century Portrait, by William J. Bouwsma. (Oxford University, $22.95.) An insightful study of the brilliant, anxiety-ridden Renaissance humanist and reformer.

title: Group Homes for Retarded Gaining Success and Goodwill
description: EVERY evening after dinner, George Papineau goes to a nearby Friendly Ice Cream Shop for a snack. When he gets his check, he fishes a small card from his wallet and scans the numerical tables to find the correct amount for the 15 percent tip.

title: Vermont Citizen Legislature Gets Used to the Fast Lane
description: As a chill settled over the Vermont capital a couple of weeks ago 180 farmers, lawyers, homemakers, insurance salesmen, car dealers and teachers settled down to what is certain to be the most trying 15 weeks of their year.

title: Commercial Property: Submetering; A Carrot for Landlords Who Limit Profits on Power
description: AFTER a decade of failed efforts to restrain New York City landlords who generate profits off electricity, the Koch administration hopes to cajole them into trimming their revenues as middlemen between Con Edison and commercial tenants.

title: A Pianist's Encore: Son's Compositions
description: LEAD: ''MUSIC is music,'' Morton Estrin, the pianist with an international reputation as an interpreter of the Romantic repertory, said. ''And how one choses to exercise one's knowledge and talent is irrelevant. The only differences are in style.''

title: From Usher to Rozelle
description: Dear Pete:

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Artistic Titan
description: LEAD: THE MYSTERY OF HENRY MOORE Home Vision. 84 minutes. $39.95.

title: Director Revives 'Lost Art Form'
description: IMAGINE casting Jack Gilford, Jack Weston, Ellie Greenwich and David Essex in ''We Bombed in New Haven.''

title: Tinkering With Way Parties Choose Nominees Hasn't Worked Very Well
description: Since the Democratic National Convention of 1968, when tensions within the Democratic Party exploded into riots on the streets of Chicago, American political parties have been tinkering with the methods by which they choose their Presidential nominees, attempting to make the process more responsive to the views of the average voter.

title: ZZZZ Best Indictment
description: A young entrepreneur who started a carpet-cleaning business in his parents' garage and turned it into a million-dollar enterprise was charged Friday along with 11 other people in a 54-count Federal indictment that includes accusations of securities fraud and embezzlement.

title: Mixed View of G.M. Sales
description: Officials of the General Motors Corporation's Pontiac, Buick and Oldsmobile divisions gave a mixed view Friday of auto sales for 1988.

title: BALANCING WORKOUT WITH FUN ON SKATES
description: It is cold, very cold and the pond is frozen solid. The neighborhood children push aside the snow, someone builds a fire and soon the ice is covered with skaters gliding to and fro, their faces reddened from the cold and exertion.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; A 'Fighting Marine' Battles Japan on Trade . . .
description: Jack Brooks is a Congressman who loves a good fight, and sometimes he goes looking for one. Such is the case now as he takes the lead in bashing Japan on its trade policy with the United States.

title: Trump Developing Ringside Interests
description: IN his office, 26 floors above Fifth Avenue, there are models of buildings that Donald Trump has in the works or on his mind.

title: More Gains Foreseen for Bonds
description: Long-simmering hopes that interest rates will decline boiled over Friday after Government statistics showed a large drop in the nation's trade deficit and lower-than-expected inflation.

title: Papers in PTL Inquiry Are Reported Missing
description: Missing financial documents that may have been shredded or removed have hampered a Federal investigation of Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL ministry, and his top aides, a newspaper reported today.

title: Katherine Brod Weds
description: Katherine S. Brod and Milton H. Lehrer were married yesterday in New York by Rabbi David M. Posner, who performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El. The bride, the widow of Melvin D. Brod, an architect and engineer, is a painter in oils and acrylics. The bridegroom is an administrative law judge and arbitrator. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Companies Match Worker Donations to Give Lift to Neediest
description: Donald G. Fiordelisi of Princeton, N.J., contributed $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in honor of his father, Peter, who died on Thanksgiving Day.

title: Nets and 76ers Analyze Trade
description: With 4 minutes 17 seconds remaining in Saturday night's game against the Boston Celtics at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Mike Gminski hit a 13-foot jumper over Dennis Johnson that tied the score at 91-91 - it was to be the 6-foot-11-inch center's last basket as a Net.

title: Koch, O'Connor And Moynihan Back The Post
description: Mayor Koch, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and John Cardinal O'Connor were among 1,500 people who attended a ''Save The Post'' rally yesterday outside The New York Post building in lower Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you like a man but you can't stand his wife, that tempers your judgment about whether you invite him to dinner.'' - Linda Denning, an Iowa voter, explaining how disillusionment with President Reagan hurts George Bush. [ A13:4. ]

title: The Lie That Wasn't Shot Down
description: On Aug. 31, 1983, the Soviet Union shot down a Boeing 747 with the loss of 269 lives, having failed to identify it as a civilian airliner. Moscow deserved the universal obloquy it incurred. But the Reagan Administration added a savage twist, sometimes implying and sometimes saying outright that the Soviet Union knew it was attacking a civilian plane. Now, in an intelligence analysis released last week by Representative Lee Hamilton, the Administration in effect acknowledges, grudgingly, that it misled the American people and the world. Though diplomacy may at times require stretching the truth, the Administration had no need to paint the Soviet action blacker than it already was.

title: Jazz: Big Band Revival at Carnegie
description: FIFTY years to the day after Benny Goodman's orchestra played the first complete jazz concert ever held in Carnegie Hall, on Jan. 16, 1938, the program was repeated on Saturday evening by an orchestra led by the clarinetist Bob Wilber.

title: SURPRISES FOR GEORGETOWN AND SYRACUSE
description: A series of upsets and close finishes last week might lead to questions whether the talent pool in the Big East is half full or half empty.

title: How to Handle Long-Term Health Care
description: LEAD: With great fanfare, Congress soon will pass a bill establishing a new Medicare program. It will be represented as protecting the elderly from the costs of catastrophic illness. President Reagan is expected to sign it.

title: Venezuela's Oil Dealings Abroad
description: After Venezuela nationalized 14 American and other foreign oil companies in 1976, it came to recognize that much of the industry - the business of refining and marketing oil abroad - was in fact still in foreign hands.

title: Bank of America Fined
description: The Commerce Department said Friday that it had fined the Bank of America $220,000 for 22 purported violations of blacklist laws. The Commerce Department said the bank had paid an American beneficiary based on a letter of credit that required him to refuse to do business with certain blacklisted nations. United States law forbids Americans to agree to blacklists. The Commerce Department said the bank had neither admitted nor denied the purported violations.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a sen-tence in an article by Kosta Tsipis on Jan. 11 implied that canceling further production of the MX missile and the Trident submarine would save $2 bil-lion. It should have said ''as much as $2 billion per submarine.''

title: Rock: Big Dipper, Dumptruck and Subtle Plague
description: BIG DIPPER and Dumptruck, two big attactions on the college rock circuit, brought a near-overdose level of earnestness to CBGB Saturday night. Both groups are from the Boston area, and they both present rock as anti-spectacle. Band members wear the same T-shirts and jeans offstage as they do on, both groups stand there, calmly delivering their songs with the idea that the words take priority over entertainment - rock as literature.

title: Irving Hochstadter, Chemical Engineer, 100
description: Irving Hochstadter, a chemical engineer who founded Hochstadter Laboratories Inc., died Jan. 8 at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N.J., where he lived. He was 100 years old.

title: Williams Makes His Point
description: THERE are moments when the elements of time and place and improbable coincidence converge to make for dramatic events. This afternoon was one of those moments.

title: What About King?
description: LEAD: What shall we do with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.?

title: 'St. Elsewhere,' on NBC, to Cease Production
description: ''St. Elsewhere,'' NBC's award-winning medical drama, is to cease production in March and its crew is to move to a new series, although NBC is still discussing ways to keep the show alive, officials said today.

title: Business and the Law; Expectations In Cigarette Case
description: HALFWAY through a trial in Lexington, Miss., lawyers representing the survivors of a cigarette smoker are convinced that they have made the strongest case yet against the tobacco industry.

title: Hanoi Seeks New Image, U.S. Lawmakers Report
description: A Congressional delegation has returned from Vietnam convinced that Hanoi is embarking on a campaign to regain some of the international understanding it lost by invading and occupying Cambodia nine years ago.

title: Rock: The Music of the 60's From the Dinosaurs
description: PSYCHEDELIC-ERA nostalgia arrived Friday when the Dinosaurs, a group of San Francisco rockers with a 1960's pedigree, headlined an evening of music, lights and reminiscences. It was the first Psychedelic Daze Revue at the Saint, the discotheque that replaced the Fillmore East Auditorium at 105 Second Avenue, at Sixth Street; the next revue, with the Chambers Brothers, is scheduled for Jan. 29. At the initial concert, which marked the 15th anniversary of Relix, a 1960's-rock fan magazine, anachronisms and hippie prodigality were both abundantly represented. The audience set students in new tie-dyed shirts alongside original 1960's rock fans.

title: Quiet Farewell for Snyder
description: The subjects that had bedeviled CBS Sports for two days - Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder and his racial comments - were reduced to a mere oblique mention on the network's pre-game show yesterday.

title: Ms. Grossbard, Medical Student, Weds
description: Caren Lisa Grossbard, a fourth-year student at the Harvard Medical School, was married yesterday to Dr. Scott David Solomon, a resident in medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Rabbi Hyman Krantz performed the ceremony at the Terrace Restaurant Atop Butler Hall in New York.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Diplomatic Gaffe
description: A playbill issued by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts contains a passage that conflicts with the frequently-declared policy toward Yugoslavia of the center's sponsor, the United States Government.

title: Seeking the Gold Wins at Gulfstream
description: Can a son of Mr. Prospector win the Kentucky Derby?

title: At Pan Am, Tensions Beneath a Surface Calm
description: On the surface, the daily routine at the Manhattan headquarters of the Pan Am Corporation looks like business as usual.

title: Painting Brings $6.6 Million
description: Jan Davidsz de Heem's depiction of a banquet table from 1642 - the largest and most lavish still life ever painted by this artist - brought $6.6 million Friday in a sale at Christie's. The price was the highest ever paid at auction in the United States for an Old Master painting. The previous record was set Thursday at Sotheby's, with the sale of another Heem still life for $2.5 million.

title: Martha Graham, 93, Is Hospitalized for Tests
description: Martha Graham, the 93-year-old modern-dance choreographer, is in the hospital to undergo tests, according to Ron Protas, associate director of the Martha Graham Dance Company. Mr. Protas said last night that Miss Graham had experienced dizziness in the afternoon and that they had made the decision together for her to enter the hospital. He added that Miss Graham's condition was stable.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a Reuters picture in some copies on Thursday about a hockey game between the Winnipeg Jets and Vancouver Canucks misidentified the Winnipeg player. He was Ray Neufeld.

title: U.S. Studied Halting Iran-Bound Missiles
description: Reagan Administration officials considered and rejected a military option to intercept ships carrying Silkworm missiles to Iran in recent weeks, deciding the idea was probably illegal and diplomatically unwise, according to several officials.

title: Paris Journal; Scandal, Sex, Big Money; That's TV, Off-Screen
description: As if there were not enough uncertainties in this presidential election year, French television is in a state of upheaval.

title: News Analysis; Takeshita Visit: Warmth, Skepticism
description: A new Japanese Prime Minister, Noboru Takeshita, has just visited Washington talking of his country's greater willingness to shoulder global economic responsibilities.

title: Frank V. Schwinn, 67, Bicycle Company Chief
description: Frank V. Schwinn, who developed the independent dealership network for his family's bicycle company, died unexpectedly at home last Tuesday. He was 67 years old.

title: High Stakes In Nicaragua
description: The Nicaraguan Government's last-minute offer Saturday to suspend its state of emergency and begin direct talks with the rebels opens a volatile period of political maneuvering, with high stakes that could determine the future course of not only the Sandinista revolution but also of Central America.

title: VIKINGS LOSE BY 17-10 AS DRIVE STALLS
description: The Redskins won the National Conference championship and a berth in the Super Bowl today, though they made it harder than it should have been. But in the last quarter, they stopped the Minnesota Vikings once on the 1-foot line and, with 52 seconds to go, stopped them near the end zone again to save a 17-10 victory.

title: Church Attack Leads to a Dissident's House
description: An explosion ripped through a Mormon church Saturday. Hours later law-enforcement officers surrounded the house of a woman whose husband had feuded with the Mormon leadership before he was shot to death by the police nine years ago.

title: Flyers Edge Rangers in Scrappy Match
description: A sellout crowd at Madison Square Garden last night prepared to jeer the return of Dave Brown of the Flyers but got a double disappoinment.

title: COACHES COVERED IN DRUG PROPOSAL
description: If an athlete tests positive for use of a banned substance, and it is his first offense, should he alone bear the responsibility of sanction?

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1988   ; International A2-9
description: New military aid for the contras will be sought by the Reagan Administration despite a pledge by the Nicaraguan President to hold direct talks with rebel leaders and suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua, officials said. Page A1

title: Subtle Steps to a Better Grip on the Game
description: THE names of the basic tennis strokes, forehand and backhand, should tell you something about the role of your hands in shot-making. The adage is that the racquet should feel like an extension of your hand. You should meet the ball on the forehand side as if you were striking it with your open palm, and on the backhand side as if you were hitting it with the back of your hand. That's why instructors spend so much time teaching beginners about grips - how to place the hand on the handle to make the racquet meet the ball squarely.

title: Shifting Tactics, New York Plans Closer Supervision of Mentally Ill
description: In a major change of strategy, the Cuomo administration plans to create a new category of highly trained workers to manage the lives - from psychiatric care to welfare benefits - of the 25,000 people who are most difficult to treat among the state's mentally ill.

title: Acting Mayor to Run in '89
description: Eugene Sawyer, the Acting Mayor, announced today that he would run in a 1989 election to complete the last two years of the four-year term vacated by the death of Mayor Harold Washington. ''I'm the Mayor, the man in the chair,'' Mr. Sawyer said in an interview on the radio station WBMX. ''I'm going to remain the Mayor. I'm going to run in 1989.'' Mr. Sawyer was an alderman when he was chosen Acting Mayor by the City Council on Dec. 2, a week after Mr. Washington suffered a massive heart attack and died. Mr. Washington had been re-elected in April.

title: Games Banks Play With Home Equity Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Effort In Securities Fraud Cases
description: Concerned that insider trading and other crimes are going unpunished, the Justice Department and several regulatory agencies are planning a task force that will seek out securities fraud cases across the country, concentrating on several large cities outside New York.

title: Sheik Reported to Link Reagan and Hostages
description: The Sunday Express quoted a Moslem cleric as saying in an interview that kidnappers holding foreign hostages in Lebanon will not consider terms for their release until President Reagan leaves office, but the cleric said in Beirut today that the report was ''fabricated.''

title: The Way Up
description: With George Foreman's boxing comeback, Don King has come down with a mild case of nostalgia, remembering Foreman's part in what amounted to something of a role reversal between the two men: Foreman losing his crown and King gaining a new career.

title: Shevardnadze in Bonn; He Hails 'New Era'
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arrived in Bonn today for a three-day visit, the first by a senior Soviet official under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Dukakis Is Hard at Work Next Door
description: It was not the schedule of a complacent candidate, confident of the affections of his neighbors.

title: Lull in Weekly Note and Bond Sales
description: The only Treasury auctions scheduled this week are today's regular sales of three- and six-month bills.

title: Islanders Lose, 5-2
description: Scott Arniel scored twice in the third period tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Islanders, 5-2.

title: REAGAN WILL SEEK MORE CONTRA AID DESPITE NEW MOVE
description: The Reagan Administration will push plans to ask Congress for new military aid for Nicaraguan rebels despite a pledge by the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, to hold direct talks with rebel leaders and suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua, senior White House and State Department officials said today.

title: OUTRDOORS: A GOOD TIME TO WORK ON FISHING GEAR
description: MOST northeastern anglers will be casting for nothing but memories until spring, and one way to enliven this winter-imposed idleness is to begin putting gear into shape for the coming season.

title: In Iowa, Tarnish on Reagan Rubs Off on Bush
description: Bill Southwick is George Bush's nightmare.

title: Dance: Middle Eastern Panorama
description: THE Ramzi El-Edlibi Dance Company offered a panorama of Middle Eastern dances on Saturday night at the Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University.

title: 20% of Reliance Unit Sold
description: The General Accident Corporation of America said Friday that it had bought 20 percent of the United Fire and Casualty Company for $20.2 million from the Reliance Insurance Company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, General Accident said the purchase was for investment. General Accident, a unit of the Scottish Insurance Corporation of Perth, Scotland, also said it might seek seats on the board of the insurance company, based in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

title: 'Midsummer Night' Comeback
description: Fifteen years ago, when A. J. Antoon directed ''Much Ado About Nothing'' to the accompaniment of ragtime music, an oompah band, and the antics of Keystone Kops, President Nixon saw the play and said wonderingly, ''I didn't know they could do it that way.''

title: Joseph May Serve Egypt Once Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Poor Young Farmer
description: Senator David Karnes, Republican of Nebraska, is calling on the Federal Department of Agriculture to change the way it interprets the definition of a ''person.''

title: Harvey Herman Gains 2 Health Care Clients
description: After a particularly bad 1987, Harvey Herman Associates is seeking to improve its economic health with a pair of new health care clients.

title: Excruciating End for Vikings
description: A highlight film of the Vikings' season will not be necessary. All that splicing and editing would not capture the year in review any better than today's National Conference championship game against the Redskins. Steve Jordan, the tight end, called it a bumpy road, much like the one the Vikings have traveled since September.

title: Pretoria's Frozen Debt
description: South Africa said Friday that foreign creditors who were owed $13 billion in frozen debt could use the money to buy equity or property in the country. Pretoria froze repayments of the debt in 1985 after foreign banks, worried by anti-Government actions, cut credit lines.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES. By I. F. Stone. 282 pages. Little, Brown. $18.95.

title: Mexican Candidate Ties Repayment Of Foreign Debt to Economic Growth
description: In an interview here today, the man almost certain to become Mexico's President later this year said repayment of his country's $105 billion foreign debt must be linked to the achievement of ''sustainable economic growth'' and urged the United States to seek a more ''dignified'' and realistic relationship with Mexico.

title: Percy Qoboza, 50, A Black Journalist From South Africa
description: Percy Qoboza, an award-winning black journalist who was editor of several leading anti-apartheid publications, died today. He was 50 years old.

title: Babbitt Takes On an Iowa Meat Plant
description: Bruce Babbitt was the first, accusing IBP Inc., the giant meatpacking company that operates four plants in Iowa, of being a ''corporate outlaw'' because of recurrent labor problems and a history of unsafe working conditions.

title: Rising Use of Donated Eggs For Pregnancy Stirs Concern
description: One woman goes to the Women's Medical Pavilion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., because she is determined to have no more children. Another is there because she has been unable to conceive. If all goes well, the second woman will become pregnant with an egg contributed by the first, who is then to be sterilized.

title: Chambers Case Turning On Truth of Confession
description: A police sergeant who had investigated the death of Jennifer Levin in Central Park was testifying in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. Mr. Chambers's lead defense lawyer, Jack T. Litman, was doing exactly what most defense lawyers avoid - putting his client at the scene of the crime.

title: Judge Edward Weinfeld, 86, Dies; On U.S. Bench Nearly 4 Decades
description: Judge Edward Weinfeld, one of the nation's most respected Federal judges, died of cancer at his home in Manhattan yesterday at the age of 86.

title: Verity Sees Stable Dollar
description: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said today that he believed the American economy was strong enough to stabilize the dollar at about its current level.

title: Jessica Wolfe Weds Jonathan Bernstein
description: The marriage of Jessica Wolfe, a public affairs specialist at the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation in Washington, to Jonathan Bernstein, the assistant press secretary and a legislative assistant to Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, took place yesterday in New York. Rabbi Marshall Hurwitz performed the ceremony at 24 Fifth Avenue, a restaurant.

title: Advertising; Supplement Reaches Goal In New York
description: WHEN The Daily News announced Friday that it would include Vista, the Hispanic Magazine, in its Sunday issue once a month beginning March 6, it concluded a three-year effort by Arturo Villar, Vista's publisher, to crack the country's second-biggest Spanish-speaking market.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Young Name Dropper Wins Riches, and a Date in Court
description: David P. Bloom has finally stopped telling everyone he meets about how much money he has. Instead, the 23-year-old Duke University graduate with an eye for American art and, according to the Government, a knack for selling bogus investment services stood before Federal Magistrate James C. Francis 4th in Manhattan last week and asked to be released on his word.

title: The Misadventures of 2 Best-Selling Books
description: One disgruntled author got so angry in 1979 at his publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, because he thought his book had been mishandled that he rented an airplane and buzzed the house's mid-Manhattan headquarters.

title: Blending Event and Invention
description: In fiction rooted in history, a novelist uses but transcends fact. This is what happens in a hefty new novel (size: 824 pages; number of real and fictional characters: 107) that has already arrived in the bookstores, ahead of its Jan. 29 publication date, preceded by trumpets of critical acclaim.

title: Memorial Set for Leo Steiner
description: A memorial service for Leo Steiner, co-owner of the Carnegie Deli, will be held 12:30 P.M. Feb. 1 at the Sutton Place Synagogue at 225 East 51st Street. Mr. Steiner died of complications of a brain tumor Dec. 31 at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 48 years old.

title: Metro Matters; Shutting the Door On the P.L.O. In New York
description: It was one day after Andrew Young resigned under fire as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, and Zehdi Labib Terzi was worried.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Mel Allen, among many others, has called Don Mattingly the best Yankee first baseman since Lou Gehrig? How about it?

title: 3 Die in 3-Car Crash on L.I.; Drunken Driving Is Charged
description: Three people died, including two Canadians, in a three-car accident early this morning.

title: Building on a Legacy in Taiwan
description: A dynasty ended in Taiwan when President Chiang Ching-kuo died last week, but change had already begun. While faithful to the myths of Chiang Kai-shek's rule, the generalissimo's son was a realist who had recently set course toward liberalization and democracy. The challenge to Taiwan's new president is to keep that course, tackle economic problems and yet not upset the delicate balance that maintains calm in the Formosa Strait.

title: Group Meets On Multifoods
description: Bregman Partners, an investment group led by the Bregman and Belzberg families of Canada, has met with the International Multifoods Corporation to discuss buying ''certain operating divisions'' of the food processing company, based in Minneapolis. In a Securities and Exchange

title: Ms. Goldberg, Writer, Is Wed to Stuart Lewis
description: The marriage of Judith Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Goldberg of New York, to Stuart Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lewis of Blauvelt, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New York. Rabbi Martin Zion officiated.

title: Conflict Over Tradition Ends A West Point Cadet's Dream
description: From the age of 12, John Edwards had wanted to go to the United States Military Academy, and he made it the hard way, first enlisting in the Army and then distinguishing himself in military intelligence and language studies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about troubles at the New York Mercantile Exchange misstated the employment record of Kevin Conway, most recently the exchange's vice president of compliance. He has never worked for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Ski Boot: A Softer Approach
description: The rigid plastic ski boot became an institution in downhill skiing after its introduction in the mid-1960's. Along with it have come improvements in the way bindings anchor the boot to the ski.

title: Cello: Karine Georgian
description: THE latest installment in the Town Hall series of ''Russian Nights'' was an estimable and sometimes exciting recital by the cellist Karine Georgian. ''Russian Nights'' is a misnomer, though doubtless more salable than ''Soviet Nights'' would be, since both Miss Georgian and her accompanist, Sahan Arzruni, are Armenian. One cannot thank the cellist's heritage alone for her avoidance of the hyper-muscular, sometimes harsh style of string playing associated with Russian players in recent decades, for one of her teachers was Mstislav Rostropovich, Russian to the core, who transcends any such limitations himself. And it was Mr. Rostropovich's best playing of intricate 20th-century music that came to mind as Miss Georgian sailed through the treacherous, encyclopedic solo sonata of Zoltan Kodaly Friday evening.

title: Music: Alan Mandel Plays Ives
description: LISTENING to Alan Mandel play piano music by Charles Ives and Elie Siegmeister Friday night was to reverse the usual musical practice of tension and release. Mr. Siegmeister was in attendance at Weill Recital Hall, and surrounded by colleagues, he spent the first half of the evening listening to Ives's cheerful iconoclasm - ''Five Takeoffs,'' eight Studies and five other pieces including ''Baseball Takeoff'' and a march on ''Here's to Good Old Yale.''

title: New Hopes at Space Companies
description: Maxime A. Faget, a leading figure in the development of NASA's manned space program, now runs a six-year-old company called Space Industries. He and his colleagues at the Houston-based concern think they can build and operate a small, low-cost space station that would be rented to commercial and Government researchers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Tomba Wins Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy scored his fourth victory of the season yesterday in a slalom race at Bad Kleinkirchheim, Austria, increasing his overall lead in the World Cup standing. Two Austrians, Thomas Stangassinger and Bernhard Gstrein, finished second and third. In two runs, Tomba maneuvered the Strohsack course in 56.40 seconds and 1 minute 2.06 seconds for a combined time of 1:58.46, beating Stangassinger by more than two seconds. The victory put Tomba 80 points ahead of Gstrein in the slalom standing with a total of 120 points.(AP) Road Racing Miers Takes Frostbite: Charles Miers of the New York Athletic Club led from the start in winning the New York Road Runners Club's Frostbite 10-mile run in 51 minutes 32 seconds yesterday at Central Park. Paul Trott of Super Runners was second in 53:38. Michele Bush of the Warren Street Athletic Club had the second-fastest time ever on the course by a woman, 57:38, in earning the women's gold medal. The Central Park Track Club won the men's title with 57 points; the Atalanta Track Club the women's with 12. %Squash Racquets Edwards Upsets Talbott: Ned Edwards of New York dropped the first two games, but rallied to upset top-seeded Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., yesterday to capture the $15,000 Rolex Greenwich Open in Greenwich, Conn., 11-15, 10-15, 15-5, 15-12, 15-13. Horse Racing Anniron Captures Broadway: Anniron continued her consistent ways yesterday by winning her 14th race in 18 starts with a 1 1/2-length victory in the Broadway Handicap for New York-bred fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. Oh How We Danced was second in the field of 10. Anniron, ridden by Robbie Davis, covered one mile and 70 yards on the fast track in 1:44 3/5. Anniron, a 5-year-old daughter of Iron Constitution and Leap Year Miss, earned $52,140 for William A. Martusewicz, and returned $3 for $2 to win. On the Line Wins: With favorites Alysheba and Temperate Sil scratched because of bad weather, On the Line won the San Fernando Stakes, the second leg of the Strub series for 4-year-olds, at Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif., yesterday. Ridden by Jose Santos, On the Line withstood a final bid by Candi's Gold, with Gary Stevens riding, for a half-length victory.(AP) N.B.A. Bullets 130, Kings 113: Bernard King scored 28 points as Washington beat Sacramento, 130-113, yesterday for its third straight victory. The loss was the third straight for Sacramento. Otis Thorpe led Sacramento with 33 points. Jeff Malone added 23 points for the Bullets.(AP) Bucks 111, Cavaliers 93: Terry Cummings scored 25 points and Paul Pressey added 23 as Milwaukee won yesterday at home. The Bucks also got 22 points, and a career-high 17 rebounds, from the center Randy Breuer. Brad Daugherty led Cleveland with 19 points.(AP) School Basketball High schools from New York City defeated schools from Long Island in three games yesterday at the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Basketball Classic at the Nassau Coliseum. A fourth game was halted when fighting broke out in the stands. Boys and Girls High School of Brooklyn defeated Freeport, 70-61; Andrew Jackson of Queens scored a 67-65 victory over John Glenn High School, and Springfield Gardens of Queens, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, beat North Babylon, 76-50. The game between Hempstead and Hillcrest High School of Queens was stopped with the teams tied at 37-37 and 5 minutes 20 seconds left in the third quarter when fights among some of the 12,700 fans resulted in some spectators running onto the court. Officials reported no injuries or arrests inside the arena.

title: Rail System Plan Backed by Houston Voters
description: Voters here approved a $2.57 billion transit improvement program Saturday that includes a 20-mile rail system to connect downtown with other business areas.

title: City Ballet's 'Matinee'
description: The New York City Ballet will present its annual ''Family Matinee'' on Jan. 31 at 1 P.M. at the New York State Theater. The company will perform ''Symphony in C'' and ''The Four Temperaments,'' both by George Balanchine, and ''Brahms/ Handel,'' a collaboration by Jerome Robbins and Twyla Tharp. During intermissions, company members will be on hand to answer questions and demonstrate such activities as the preparation of toe shoes, pre-performance warm-ups and applying stage makeup. Ticket prices range from $5 to $42. Information: 870-5570.

title: Business People; Fluor Official Poised To Succeed Chairman
description: Leslie G. McCraw has been named president of the Fluor Corporation, putting him in line to head the international construction and engineering company based in Irvine, Calif.

title: 'Preach-Off': Keeping the Flocks Awake
description: The choir finishes the hymn and the minister ascends the pulpit. Across the congregation, even before the preacher has opened his mouth, eyelids begin to feel heavy.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Choice for Ambassador
description: The next American Ambassador to East Germany will be Richard C. Barkley, according to State Department insiders.

title: E.P.A. Will Allow Use of a Chemical That It Had Banned
description: The Environmental Protection Agency says it will permit dinoseb, one of only three pesticides ever subjected to an emergency ban, to be used in the Pacific Northwest for the next two years as long as inventories last.

title: Stop and Shop's Control Mostly All in the Family
description: Management at the Stop and Shop Companies is a family affair. Avram J. Goldberg is chairman and chief executive; his wife, Carol R. Goldberg, is president and chief operating officer.

title: Neoax Raises Offer for IU
description: Neoax Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its tender offer for the IU Corporation by $1.50 a share, to $19, or about $589 million.

title: VOTE APPEARS LOW
description: Haiti's army-dominated Government held its presidential elections today, but voting appeared to be light, and irregularities, from multiple voting to voting by youths under the minimum age of 18, appeared widespread.

title: TV Reviews; DRAMA OF COLLEGE FOOTBALL, ON ABC
description: ''WHAT PRICE VICTORY'' has no question mark; it has no story, either. Mostly it has cliches: big-time college football has no soul; it chews up and spits out good old country boys. Actually, this makes the two-hour movie, on ABC at 9 o'clock tonight, sound more interesting than it is. Cliches can work fine, but in this movie they are particularly barren.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Met Opera: The Final 'Fledermaus'
description: THE season's final ''Fledermaus'' at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night brought together several cast members who had gone into the show at one time or another since the return of the production last month. Thomas Allen was an excellent Eisenstein; he delivered the spoken dialogue with more verve and class than anyone else, and his ringing, juicy baritone was a pleasure to hear.

title: Independent Taiwan: Risky Idea May Be Gaining
description: As Tsai Yo-chuan and Hsu Tsao-teh saw it, all they had done was to exercise free speech when they organized a political group with a charter calling for Taiwan's independence from China. But to the Government, what they did constituted an act of sedition, and this weekend Mr. Tsai and Mr. Hsu were sentenced to up to 11 years in prison.

title: Council Leaders Draft a Compromise Bill on Campaign Financing
description: After weeks of negotiations, the leadership of the New York City Council has crafted a compromise bill on the Koch administration's proposal for public financing of municipal election campaigns and says it has the votes to pass the measure.

title: City Ballet to Honor American Composers
description: The New York City Ballet will celebrate the music of American composers with its American Music Festival at the New York State Theater. The festival, which features such guest artists as Ray Charles, begins April 26 with a gala opening of the company's spring season, and continues through May 15. Over 35 ballets are scheduled, 19 of them world premieres.

title: The U.N. Today; Security Council
description: Meets on southern Lebanon at 11:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council COMMISSION ON INTERGOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE AND FUNCTIONS IN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL FIELDS - 10 A.M.

title: The Wrong Lesson
description: The Supreme Court, as Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote in dissent, taught ''young men and women'' the wrong civics lesson when it upheld the right of a principal to impose prior restraint on a student newspaper. So it did, and that damaging lesson may well be absorbed far beyond the corridors of high school.

title: Denver Defense Rewrites the Script
description: The Cleveland Browns were going to score. The orange-clad fans stacked to the top of Mile High Stadium were going to have to endure an overtime period with a spot in the Super Bowl resting on the outcome. The script said so, and the Denver Broncos thought so.

title: Slowdown In Housing Expected
description: After four years of robust demand that kept construction of new homes at annual levels of more than 1.7 million units, the housing industry has entered a slower period that is likely to extend into the mid-1990's.

title: Redskins' Defense Answers a Prayer
description: As the Minnesota Vikings lined up with a minute to go, just 6 yards from a touchdown that could have tied the game, and even less than that for a first down that could have given them another chance, Coach Joe Gibbs of the Washington Redskins dropped to his knees on the sideline.

title: Few Voters in Evidence at Provincial Polling Place
description: At the Douglass Memorial Children's School, four elections officials sat on the front terrace grimly surveying the courtyard from behind large gray ballot boxes as they waited in the rising midmorning heat for voters to appear.

title: Artificial Heart Patient, 60
description: Walton Jones, the oldest person ever given a temporary artificial heart, died today of an infection, doctors said. He was 60 years old. Mr. Jones' heart was replaced by the Jarvik-7 pump on Dec. 4 by Dr. William DeVries, the surgeon who has done four of the five permanent mechanical heart operations. Mr. Jones was given a human heart transplant Dec. 19 but never reganined consciousness.

title: Taiwan Democracy's Next Step
description: LEAD: When Taiwan's President, Chiang Ching-kuo, died last week, the regime reacted by instinct: It banned demonstrations for 30 days, and in so doing illustrated the fragility of the country's nascent democratization. Ruling party leaders later issued assurances that the democratic reforms started by Mr.

title: Panel Hearings Will Examine 'Hate Crimes'
description: A House panel is planning to investigate the phenomenon of ''hate crimes,'' including the racial incident in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: The Dance: Laurie De Vito's She-Bops and Scats
description: MODESTY and lack of assumption are virtues that seem increasingly rare in the theater these days. But they were refreshingly present in a program by Laurie De Vito's She-Bops and Scats company on Friday at Marymount Manhattan Theater, at 221 East 71st Street. Ms. De Vito, a noted Manhattan jazz-dance teacher, seemed to be aiming for simplicity, freshness and an entertaining and even inventive evening of jazz dance performed by a well-rehearsed company of strong and personable dancers. And the program, which included work by Ms. De Vito, Alfredo Gonzales and Cynthia Pratt, was all that.

title: Argentine Troops Move on Rebel Soldiers at Base
description: Troops loyal to the civilian Government encircled a northern army compound today after a rebel officer and about 100 sympathizers had seized control of the compound's regimental headquarters.

title: Coliseum as Shelter
description: To the Editor:

title: Concessions Insufficient, Nicaragua Cleric Says
description: Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, who has been serving as a mediator in Nicaragua's civil conflict, said today that political concessions made by the Sandinista Government this weekend were encouraging but insufficient.

title: Renegade Officer Seeks Philippine Governorship
description: Col. Rodolfo Aguinaldo, jungle fighter, mutineer and now candidate for governor of Cagayan Province, sat over a breakfast of rice, eggs and marinated beef the other day discussing his campaign strategy.

title: Biotechnology Lags Despite Success
description: Amid the national uproar over whether to release living, genetically altered bacteria into the environment, one vital development seems to have gone virtually unnoticed: a biotechnology experiment that began last year in California seems to have worked.

title: When a Tie Vote Means Death
description: While the Supreme Court awaits a ninth justice,tie votes of 4-to-4 have blocked decisions in some instances. But not when the Court grinds out orders that send condemned prisoners to the executioner. An anomaly in the Court's rules, coupled with the determination of four justices to get on with executions, is producing death decrees from a deadlocked tribunal.

title: India's Clandestine Market in Gold
description: It is the wedding season in this wealthy and powerful city - as in many other parts of India -and ballrooms and community centers are booked for months.

title: Usual Party Politics At R.F.K. Stadium
description: Today was a normal wintertime Sunday in Washington for Jack Kent Cooke. He gave a party and invited a few dozen of his closest friends, including the nation's No. 1 military leader, a former White House chief of staff, three men who might have been President (and a couple who may yet be) and the Governor of Virginia.

title: Dance: Carol Fonda's 'Pieces of Glass'
description: THE scenery dances along with the human performers in Carol Fonda's ''Pieces of Glass,'' thereby creating much of the magic of the two-act work that Carol Fonda and Company presented Friday night at the Triplex Theater of Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Barbara Zinn, President Of Travel Agency, Weds
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York, Barbara Zinn, the daughter of Eve Zinn of New York and the late Victor Zinn, was married yesterday to Stephen Stout-Kerr, a son of the late Cantor and Mrs. Aron Stoutzker of London. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler officiated.

title: City Ballet: 'Petits Riens,' by Martins
description: EVEN Mozart wrote a ballet score, and last year Peter Martins became the latest choreographer to be attracted by it, creating one of his best works in the process.

title: Glenda Jackson in 'Strange Interlude'
description: YESTERDAY'S experiment is today's curiosity. That's one easy conclusion, certainly, to be drawn from Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude,'' an award-winning sensation when it was unveiled in 1928 and now a decidedly odd but still powerful period piece in a four-and-one-half-hour production made for television. Beginning this evening at 9 on Channel 13, it will be unfolding in 90-minute segments on public television's ''American Playhouse'' over three consecutive nights.

title: Master Scout
description: As a baseball scout for more than 25 years, Pete Smith, who started with Houston and has been with the Mets since 1971, has seen his share of high school and college players with major-league potential.

title: Dole Data Yield No Surprises
description: The stack of income tax returns and other financial documents released by Senator Bob Dole this weekend contained no major surprises, according to those familiar with the matter.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 17, 1988: MONDAY Central & SW Corp Midwest Energy Eastern Util Assoc PS Group Jorgensen Co Southern Co Kennametal Inc WICOR Inc TUESDAY Crompton & Knowles Jostens Inc Equitable Resources K Mart Corp Honeywell Inc Scott Paper ICM Property Invstrs Inc JM Smucker Co WEDNESDAY Alberto-Culver Pilgrim Regional Bk Shs CalFed Inc Pinacle West Cap Corp Columbia Gas Sys St Joseph Lt & Pwr Hillenbrand Indus Shaw Industries Lone Star Indus Triangle Industries Mortgage & Realty Tr Zero Corp THURSDAY Bearings Inc Niagara Share Corp Cincinnati Gas & Elec Outboard Marine Corp First Wisconsin Corp PPG Industries Grumman Corp Parker-Hannifin Handy & Harman Ralston Purina Hexcel Corp Trinova Corp MAPCO Inc Universal Foods FRIDAY BRE Properties Inc Florida Steel Corp Baker Hughes Inc John H Harland Co Ferro Corp Health Care Prpty Invstrs First Wachovia Corp Kaufman & Broad Hm Corp

title: Hart Finds You Can Go Home Again
description: Some of Gary Hart's old friends did not turn out to see him this weekend when he came back to his hometown.

title: Governor of Arizona to Face Impeachment Hearings Soon
description: The Arizona House will begin impeachment hearings this week against Gov. Evan Mecham, the House Speaker said today.

title: Promotions At Times Co.
description: Arthur M. Hettich, editor in chief of Family Circle magazine, has been named senior vice president, magazine development, of The New York Times Company Magazine Group.

title: In Philosophy's Turf Wars, They Hurl Syllogisms; Journey of the Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions on Jan. 7 about a hockey game between the Rangers and the Canucks misidentified the Rangers' defenseman. He was David Shaw.

title: College Basketball; Maryland Bounces Back Under Wade
description: THE large oak desk that seemed so formidable 15 months ago has been moved from the south wall to the west wall, where it supports stacks of papers and an engraved nameplate that reads: Robert P. Wade.

title: BROWNS FALL, 38-33, AFTER LATE FUMBLE
description: A year later, the Browns fell nine feet short of creating their own heroics in the American Conference championship game. The Broncos again toppled them and once more will go to the Super Bowl.

title: U.S. Drops a Warrant In '85 Ship Hijacking
description: The Justice Department has withdrawn the arrest warrant it issued two years ago for Mohammed Abbas, who also uses the name Abul Abbas, in connection with the hijacking in 1985 of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro and the murder of an American passenger, a department spokesman said today.

title: Thief Must Pay Aged Victim
description: A circuit judge has ordered a 17-year-old robber to pay $100 a month for the next five years to a 102-year-old man he attacked outside a grocery store. Judge Frank Eppes issued the order to Darrel Burrel in sentencing him to 10 years in prison, suspended to probation for five years.

title: Central Bank Is Urged for Europe
description: Despite widespread skepticism and strong opposition from West Germany, the Finance Minister of France, Edouard Balladur, has been talking up the idea of forming a European central bank, in the hope of putting the matter on Western Europe's economic and political agenda.

title: GOVERNMENT LAGS ON PHONE CHANGES
description: A $25 billion plan to overhaul the Government's outdated telephone system has fallen almost a year behind schedule and could experience substantial additional delays because of a bidding dispute that has led to several criminal investigations.

title: AN 'ANGEL' SAVES ROCKET DEVELOPER
description: The American Rocket Company has always been a fun kind of place. In one of his previous professional incarnations, George Koopman, Amroc's president, designed the spectacular stunt and car-chase scenes in the movie ''The Blues Brothers.'' And when it came to naming Amroc's first two test engines, they naturally became Jake and Elwood, after the movie's title characters.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Morris Giloni, a stockbroker and board member of the Jewish National Fund of America, described the fund incorrectly. It represents not only the Herut Zionists but other Jewish groups as well.

title: In Philosophy's Turf Wars, They Hurl Syllogisms
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane Aaron Wed to Skip Blumberg, a TV Producer
description: The marriage of Jane Aaron to Skip Blumberg took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sam Aaron of New York. Justice Betty Weinberg Ellerin of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: Greta Bernard Is Married To R.S. Brown in Michigan
description: Greta Bernard, a rabbinical student at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York, and Robert S. Brown, a student at the New York University School of Law, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Shalom in Southfield, Mich. Rabbis Robert Abramson and Robert Nelson officiated.

title: Executives
description: * Air Midwest Inc., Wichita, Kan., elected as chairman Gary M. Adamson. Robert L. Priddy was named to succeed Mr. Adamson as president and chief executive.

title: Big Shootout at the Bronco Corral
description: HIGH atop the scoreboard at Mile High Stadium a big white fiberglass bronco is rearing on his hind legs, his front legs pawing the rarefied Rocky Mountain air. It's as if the bronco had been startled yesterday by all the points that kept going up beneath him like bursts from six-shooters when John Elway and Bernie Kosar had a shootout on the dusty main street of the Bronco corral.

title: Who Wears Dr. King's Mantle?
description: In life, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. fought to put an end to segregation, discrimination and, hardest to root out, bigotry. On the anniversary of his birth, many now claim to wear his mantle, to walk in his footsteps.

title: Dollar Jumps In Tokyo
description: The dollar rose sharply in trading in Tokyo this morning, on the heels of an improvement in United States trade figures announced Friday. Stock prices also rallied, traders said.

title: Israeli Inflation Eases
description: Israel's consumer price index rose 16.1 percent in 1987, the lowest annual inflation rate in 15 years, the Central Bureau of Statistics announced Friday. The improvement reflected a sweeping austerity program begun in July 1985. It included a freeze on prices and wages and helped to reduce inflation from a record 444.9 percent in 1984 to 19.7 percent in 1986.

title: Pate Wins Shortened Event
description: Steve Pate became the winner of the 36th MONY Tournament of Champions today when a Pacific storm with 40-mile-an-hour winds and heavy rains washed out the final round of the year's first PGA Tour event.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Getting the Last Laugh on a Budget Gap
description: By and large, an executive budget briefing is about as funny as a tax form.

title: Bridge: Imp Scoring With Computer Has Impact on a Pairs Event
description: Computers have long been used for generating tournament deals, and more recently for scoring. They now have an impact on the type of event being played.

title: Chicago Journal; Whites Lead a Revival of the Blues
description: Like the roar of an El train, thunderous and urgent and get-out-of-my-way powerful, the sound bursts out through the walls of the Checkerboard Lounge and escapes down the streets of the South Side.

title: Allen Churchill, 76, Writer on New York Nostalgia
description: Allen Churchill, a social historian who wrote sprightly books on subjects ranging from the bohemian culture of Greenwich Village to the unsolved disappearances of several famous missing persons, died of pancreatic cancer on Saturday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DEALS PROPEL SPACE STATION MAKER
description: If any company has positioned itself well for the commercialization of space, it is Space Industries.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business Digest on Friday about the reassignment of a General Services Administration official misstated A.T.&T.'s allegations on the Government bidding process.

title: Bias Lawsuit May Have Wide Impact
description: When Clara Watson dropped by Fort Worth Bank and Trust in 1973 to pick up an application for a job as a teller, she said, the chilly reception almost ended her dream of working at the bank.

title: ISRAELIS MAINTAIN WIDE ARAB CURFEW
description: The Israeli Army kept more than 250,000 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip sealed up in their refugee centers today in what is emerging as the Government's major tactic against the rioting in which at least 38 Palestinians have been shot dead.

title: Music: Waverly Consort Plays Medieval Program
description: ELEANOR OF AQUITAINE - celebrated Saturday night by the Waverly Consort at Alice Tully Hall - watched over a century of remarkable change in Medieval Europe. Music was one of them. Wife to two great kings, mother of Richard the Lionhearted, possessor of enormous political and cultural influence in both France and England, she accompanied the French King Louis on the 12th century's Second Crusade and survived 16 years of imprisonment to become the power behind the throne of her legendary son and English king.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; . . . as Tiny U.S. Agency Takes on Japan Bashers
description: While some legislators and others in the Government vilify Japan over economic issues, one tiny Federal agency struggles on to bring the two countries closer together.

title: Ballet Stars Join in Brussels AIDS Benefit
description: Twenty-five international ballet stars, including current Soviet dancers and an expatriate, joined here today in an AIDS gala benefit.

title: Market Place; The Strategies Of Top Managers
description: THE nation's top-ranking investment advisers of 1987 began raising cash well before the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19. But, unlike many other money managers, they also had the fortitude to jump back into the market on the heels of the record 508-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Cross-Ownership Rule Driving Newspapers Out of Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Being There
description: For some firefighters in Engine Company No. 45 on Tremont Avenue in the Bronx, the daily routine provides enough excitement. The firehouse has been among the busiest in the city for years.

title: 1988: The Process
description: Efforts to improve how America elects a President have had unexpected side effects such as Michigan's confusing caucus process. First article of a series, page A12. Mexican Debt Condition The man almost certain to be Mexico's next President said foreign debt repayments must be linked to ''sustainable economic growth.'' Page A7. Entrepreneurs in Space Spirits are running high at small private companies hoping to play a major role in space transportation and research. Page D1. Tending the Water Mains For its chief planner, New York City's water supply system is a thing of beauty - even when it fractures twice within a week. Page B1.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Just an 'Intimate' Party
description: Several weeks ago, the finance chairmen of the Democratic National Committee sent out invitations to a $500-per-person ''intimate birthday dinner'' honoring Paul G. Kirk Jr., the national chairman, on Jan. 20, two days after his official 50th birthday.

title: Pacific Gas Ends Offer
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said it was withdrawing its proposal to consolidate its gas service in the Sacramento, Calif., area with the electricity operations of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District. P.G.&E., which had proposed in September to take over the struggling utility and scrap its nonfunctioning nuclear power plant, said it was dropping the offer because of the Sacramento utility's failure to give it serious consideration. ''We remain convinced that consolidation would provide Sacramento the best permanent assurance of reliable energy service at stable prices,'' Richard A. Clarke, P.G.&E.'s chairman, wrote in a letter to Clifford Wilcox, president of the Sacramento utility.

title: Bank Officer To Join Mellon
description: David L. Eyles, chief credit officer for the Chemical Bank, is leaving to become a vice chairman of the Mellon Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, Mellon announced Friday. Mr. Eyles, 48 years old, will also be chairman of Mellon's credit policy committee and the senior credit committee. Chemical, a subsidiary of the

title: Australian Open; Shriver Is Upset; Mandlikova Gains
description: Anne Minter, cheered by a hometown crowd, stunned fourth-seeded Pam Shriver, 6-2, 6-4, today to advance to the quarterfinals of the Australian Open.

title: James Macandrew, Leader in New York In Educational TV
description: James F. Macandrew, a pioneer in educational broadcasting who helped build New York City's public radio and television systems, died of a heart attack Friday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Water System: The Marvelous Monster
description: It is a vast subterranean network, a whooshing, gurgling 6,000-mile iron snake under the streets of New York City, and it is unseen and largely ignored until it erupts like a monster, flooding basements, streets, subways and utility lines as it did twice last week.

title: 3 Children and Adult Die in 2 Newark Fires
description: Four people, including three children, died in two fires here over the weekend and 27 other people were left homeless, fire officials reported today.

title: DECOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28

title: Retirement Set At Federated
description: Donald J. Stone will retire Jan. 31 as a vice chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc. and will be succeeded by Allen I. Questrom, chairman of the company's Bullock's division in Los Angeles and a corporate executive vice president, Federated announced.
