description: b-Includes $286 million, or $3.53 a share, resulting from additional income recorded when FAS 91 was implemented. Year-ago results are restated for adoption of a new accounting standard. Share earnings are fully diluted. The company said during the latest fourth quarter management elected to adopt retroactively a new accounting standard for loan fees (FAS 91) and also took other actions that affected earnings. The 1987 earnings include an additional $290 million, or $3.57 a share, resulting from the retroactive adoption of the new accounting standard.

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Another Phone Concern Held Talks With Meese
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d met with executives of Pacific Telesis, a regional Bell telephone company, while his financial manager held about $10,000 in telephone stock for him, a company spokeswoman said today.

title: A Powder For Testing Conductivity
description: ONE of high tech's current buzzwords is ''superconductivity,'' the capacity for a material to conduct electricity without friction if the material is cooled to low enough temperatures. The discovery that some substances become superconducting at much higher temperatures than previously thought electrified scientists last year, leading to speculation about superconductivity uses ranging from high-speed trains to superfast electronic components. Engineers were quick to warn, however, that taking advantage of the discovery could be years away in terms of new high-tech products.

title: 'Long March' Ends for One Reagan Chief as Short One Begins for Another  One of the Last of the Old Guard Looks Back
description: In the beginning there was ''the team,'' whose members had been recruited in the 1970's for ''the Cause, with a capital C,'' at the start of ''the Long March'' to the Presidency of Ronald Reagan. As the second term draws to an end, the tone has changed, because the natural process of departures and deaths has stripped the original phalanx of almost all of its centurions.

title: The Work and the Apple: Squawks; Christmas Memories, and Mulch
description: January brings snow, ice, post-holiday letdown - and a sudden profusion of used Christmas trees that block Manhattan sidewalks. This year's abundant crop reflects softness in the local mulch market.

title: Wine Talk
description: THERE being no rule of thumb on this sort of thing, let's make one up: A bottle of wine to go with dinner at home should not cost more than the rest of the meal.

title: BALTIMORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,990,000 from extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary charge of $10,971,000 from deferred income tax related to loan reserve recapture for the quarter and year. The latest quarter and year nets also included a credit of $2.6 million, or 20 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Ortega Vs. The U.S.
description: The Communist dictator of Nicaragua has issued a fairly simple and understandable ultimatum to the U.S.

title: At the Nation's Table; Baltimore
description: DRESSED in a black dinner jacket, Ronald W. Scott spends his days hawking jars of his homemade-style Morgan Pierce jellies and preserves for nonprofit groups like the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington and the Central Maryland Committee on Sickle Cell Anemia in Baltimore. He even has gift shops at hospitals and at the Maryland Historical Society selling his preserves.

title: Justices Refuse to Hear North's Plea to Block Walsh Inquiry
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear a petition by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to block the independent prosecutor's investigation of the Iran-contra affair.

title: Mitel-G.E. Deal
description: Mitel Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Mitel Corporation of Canada, said it had agreed to acquire the General Electric Company's RCA Telephone Systems Business. RCA Telephone Systems Business sells private branch exchange systems to small and medium-sized businesses.

title: F.C.C. Refuses Waiver for Murdoch on TV Station and Newspaper
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday dismissed Rupert Murdoch's petition for an extension of waivers that allowed him to retain ownership of a newspaper and television station in both New York City and Boston.

title: Liz Taylor at 55: Thin Again, and Wiser
description: Elizabeth Taylor swirled a carrot stick in a gray-colored dip made of yogurt, Roquefort cheese and spices. In ''Elizabeth Takes Off,'' the diet book just published by G. P. Putnam's Sons, the actress recounts her five-year battle with fried chicken and fancy desserts, observing, rather wistfully, that her life has been perceived as black or white. At the age of 55, she said she is now trying to cultivate gray. ''My life has always been lived at the extremes,'' she explained, ''but it's fairly moderate at the moment.''

title: Will Riot Role Blunt Israelis' Warrior Spirit?
description: Since early December, the Israel Defense Force, envied among armies of the world for courage and performance, has been playing an unaccustomed role as policemen in trying to put down Palestinian riots in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. It is hardly a role that the combat-oriented army relishes.

title: Brendan Sexton, 77, Ex-U.A.W. Dept. Head
description: Brendan Sexton, a former director of the education department of the United Auto Workers union, died of lung disease Sunday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will not allow any support from the outside by commodities, not by countries, not by organizations. There are commodities and once all the shops will be open there will be no shortage of any commodity.'' - Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, of Israel. [ A1:6. ]

title: CRESTMONT FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects after-tax gains on the sale of mortgage loans and securities of $793,000 for the quarter and $1,802,000 for the 9 months. c-Reflects after-tax gains of $3,243,000 and $10,020,000, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, on the sale of mortgage loans and securities. Year-earlier share earnings aren't available; the thrift converted to stock ownership in January 1987.

title: Opera: 'Mefistofele,' By Boito, in Philadelphia
description: As the third installment in its cycle of operas devoted to the Faust theme - the first was Gounod's ''Faust'' in 1984 and the second, Berlioz's scenic cantata ''The Damnation of Faust'' in 1985 - the Opera Company of Philadelphia presented a new staging of Boito's ''Mefistofele'' on Monday night at the Academy of Music.

title: Shevardnadze Leaves West Germany, Chiding West on Arms Issues
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union left Bonn today after a three-day visit in which he assured the West Germans that Moscow was in favor of eliminating short-range nuclear arms and chemical weapons, and of a ''radical reduction'' in conventional forces.

title: Panel Vote Set for Nominee
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has scheduled a vote for Jan. 27 on Judge Anthony Kennedy's nomination to the Supreme Court, a committee spokesman said today. The nomination of Judge Kennedy, a 51-year-old Federal appellate court judge from California, is expected to be approved by the committee and sent to the full Senate for final confirmation.

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included $444,000 resulting from a change in accounting for refinery material and supply inventory. c-Included a pre-tax gain of about $3.9 million from the sale of undeveloped land at the company's Via Verde residential community in eastern Los Angeles county.

title: 7 States on Final List for U.S. Atom Smasher
description: The Government announced today that seven states were finalists in the competition for a $4.4 billion atom smasher.

title: Rock: Tom Russell Band
description: SUNDAY'S double bill at the Lone Star, featuring two Rounder Record acts, the Tom Russell Band and Bar-rence Whitfield and the Savages, was a study in the way music functions. Both bands, neither especially dis-tinctive, pump out American dance music. But they fill basic social needs, and by attacking different gen-res - Mr. Russell takes on country, country rock, Tex-Mex, New Orleans rhythm-and-blues; Mr. Whitfield acts as an encyclopedia of black music, roving from jump and blues to soul and rock - they produce, the same way a record player or a classical musician might, music of different eras and styles. And to their credit, they have an unpretentious, fun time doing it.

title: Cheryl Pierson Leaves L.I. Jail
description: After serving 3 1/2 months in jail for arranging her father's murder, 18-year-old Cheryl Pierson was released today and celebrated by riding in a limousine and feasting on a diner breakfast and later on a belated Christmas dinner.

title: Devils Still Winless At Captial Centre
description: Capital Centre continues to be the only arena in the National Hockey League where the Devils have never won.

title: DAMON BIOTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Snyder Defended
description: Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, who was dismissed by CBS over racial remarks he made last week, ''spoke the truth'' and was repeating statements made by black leaders, according to Roy Innis, the chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality. Among the remarks Snyder made during a televised interview on Friday was a comment that blacks are better athletes than whites because of breeding techniques that go back to the Civil War. ''During the slave period, the slave owner would breed his big black with his big woman so that he could have a big black kid - that's where it all started,'' Snyder said during the interview. Innis defended the statement as accurate during an awards dinner Monday honoring the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., and said black leaders, including Malcolm X, had made similar statements in the past.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MAHINES CORP (IBM)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represents gross income.

title: Ward Blames Reagan For Poor Racial Climate
description: New York City Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that he believed race relations in New York had deteriorated significantly in recent weeks. But he insisted that much of the blame lay not with Mayor Koch and the police, but with President Reagan, whose policies ''have built up the kind of tension that we're seeing in this city today.'

title: DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORESTATES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $24,526,000 for early redemption of debt for the quarter and year.

title: Advertising; Gains Seen In Drive On Drugs
description: THE members of the advertising community, who have been involved in the public-service advertising war on drugs, are taking as proof of the effectiveness of their efforts the Government's report last week that substantially fewer high school seniors were trying cocaine.

title: DE LAURENTIIS ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the loss in the latest third quarter and 9-month resulted from revenues not being sufficient to cover costs relating to revenues, selling, general and administrative expenses and interest expense incurred by the company.

title: MICROCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $462,000. c-After tax credits of $426,000 for the quarter and $990,000 for the 9 months.

title: Offer Accepted By Dyncorp
description: The board of Dyncorp announced today that it had accepted an offer from an investment group led by its president and chief executive, Dan R. Bannister, to take the company private. The offer valued the company at about $226 million.

title: Components Expected For I.B.M. PS/2 Clones
description: A group of small computer companies will announce Wednesday that they have succeeded in making chips and software that will allow computers to be built that are compatible with the new PS/2 line of personal computers from the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DIONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Medium Goes Elite
description: Glued to Sunday's televised football, I was astonished by the high volume of commercials for goods and services which are of little or no use to most football fans.

title: Sweden to See Vikings
description: The National Football League, which has played preseason games in England, Japan, Mexico and Canada, will make its debut this summer in Sweden. The Chicago Bears and the Minnesota Vikings have agreed to play a preseason game in Goteborg. The game will be sponsored by Volvo North America. The Jets and the Cleveland Browns will meet in a preseason game in Montreal, and Joe Browne, an N.F.L. spokesman, said negotiations were continuing to play a preseason game in London for the third straight year.

title: Nylon and Teflon, 50, Take On New Roles
description: IT might seem too soon, according to the memories of some people, but 1988 marks the 50th anniversary of the introduction of two synthetic materials that ushered in the golden age of polymer chemistry: nylon and Teflon. A half-century later, both materials are still widely used staples in the industrial world and continue to generate innovative new uses. They have earned their inventor, E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, untold millions of dollars.

title: The Stage: 'Vinegar Tree'
description: ''THE VINEGAR TREE'' was a Broadway hit in 1930. For visitors to Paul Osborn's comedy now at the York Theater, that information invites two interpretations - either that the present production is missing something or that the audience of 58 years ago was happily undemanding.

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Humidifiers Are Good For Dry Skin in Winter
description: To the Editor:

title: Withdrawal of Nominee
description: Kenneth Bergquist, a Justice Department official who had been nominated to become the Pentagon's top civilian aide in charge of special forces and unconventional warfare, has withdrawn his name from consideration, according to a military industry newsletter.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $13.9 million, or 55 cents a share, on the sale of GenCorp securities. c-Includes a gain of $19 million, or 79 cents a share, on securities sales. Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 50 percent stock distribution of April 23, 1987.

title: Madonna's Stage Debut Is Planned for March
description: Madonna is to make her stage debut at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center this spring, in David Mamet's ''Speed-the-Plow.'' The play is scheduled to begin an 8- to 10-week run March 29.

title:
At the Nation's Table;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: BAGELS are about as Southern as sushi, but Burger King is undaunted and, as part of a nationwide campaign, has introduced the bagel to the region where biscuits are king.

title: Afghan Siege Over, Troops Still Duck
description: Three weeks after Soviet and Afghan forces broke the prolonged siege of this dusty garrison town near the Pakistani border, Government control seems precarious.

title: A Visiting Dissident
description: Milovan Djilas, the venerable Yugoslav Communist dissident, is due to visit Washington next month on his first trip to the United States in almost 20 years.

title: Gertrude Waldeyer, Educator, 79
description: Gertrude Waldeyer, an educator and conservationist, died Sunday at the Hilaire Nursing Home in Huntington, L.I. She was 79 years old and had lived in Queens.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANCHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings for 1986 have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split approved on Sept. 8.

title: EAGLE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $78,000. The company went public in February 1987.

title: Coke Unit Faces Layoffs
description: Citing fewer soft-drink bottlers in the United States, the Coca-Cola Company said today that it would lay off about 8 percent of the management workers in its domestic bottling operations. About 200 of the 2,500 employees of the Coca-Cola U.S.A. division will be laid off ''over the next several weeks,'' said Randy Donaldson, a company spokesman. Mr. Donaldson said he could not recall such a large layoff of Coca-Cola personnel. ''Ten years ago, the domestic-bottling business had 365 bottler owners,'' he said. Today, there are 185.''

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter net included a net gain of $39 million from the sale of real estate in Japan. The year-ago quarter's net was favorably affected by $9 million, after taxes, because of the cumulative impact of a federal income tax rate reduction applicable to Chase's leveraged lease financing portfolio. The loss for 1987 is after a special addition of $1.6 billion made to the reserve for possible credit losses in the second quarter. The provision for possible credit losses for the latest periods were $130 million for the quarter and $2,150,000,000, including the special addition, for the year, compared with $140 million for the year-ago quarter and $595 million for 1986.

title: Israel Kills 3 Guerrillas Near Lebanese Border
description: Israeli soldiers killed three Arab guerrillas infiltrating from Lebanon into Israel early today, the military command said.

title: Viola Re-signs
description: Frank Viola, the Minnesota Twins' ace left-hander who was voted the most valuable player in the World Series, will remain with the Twins at least through 1989. He signed a two-year contract Monday worth $2.9 million.

title: Sterling Drug Obtains $2 Billion to Fight Bid
description: Sterling Drug Inc. disclosed today that a leading New York bank had agreed to arrange a $2 billion line of credit to help the company ward off a hostile takeover offer of nearly $4.4 billion from Hoffmann-La Roche & Company of Switzerland. Sterling did not identify the bank. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sterling said the $2 billion could be used for ''acquisitions, stock repurchases and extraordinary dividends.''

title: ACTION STAFFING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Hanoi Rejects U.S. Plan on Private Aid
description: Hanoi rejected as inadequate today the Reagan Administration's plan to make it easier for private organizations to give humanitarian aid to Vietnam.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods had provisions for possible credit losses of $23,972,000 for the quarter and $72,858,000 for the year, compared with $24,493,000 for the year-ago quarter and $77,088,000 for 1986. The latest year also included a special provision of $15 million for loans to Latin American countries and a $27.6 million settlement of a class action lawsuit.

title: Chemical Bank
description: The Chemical Bank said it had sold its Chicago-based merchant processing business to the Electro Data Corporation of Denver. Terms were not disclosed. Chemical announced in November that it would discontinue the service as part of its program to streamline its operations.

title: Tennessee Democrat Elected To Vacant Seat in Congress
description: Bob Clement, a Democrat and the son of a former Governor, defeated his Republican opponent today in a special election to fill Tennesse's vacant Congressional seat.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank said its provisions for loan and lease losses was $67.4 million for 1987, compared with $52.3 million a year ago. Net chargeoffs were $34,266,000, compared with $35,571,000 for a year ago.

title: Panel Says Presidents Should Plan for Temporary Succession
description: When the next President is inaugurated a year from Wednesday, his staff, doctor and wife must be better informed about the disability provisions of the 25th Amendment to the Constitution than his precedessors have been, a private commission said today.

title: PENNBANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Central American Agreement: Nicaragua as Target
description: The Central American peace treaty is in danger of being converted into a series of demands directed only at Nicaragua, rather than retaining the broad force of an accord binding on all major countries in the region, according to diplomats and Government officials here.

title: President's Door Open For Spelman Students
description: Amid the bustle of registration last week for the new semester at Spelman College, several students sat in the high-ceilinged reception area of the president's office.

title: Books of The Times
description: CAPTIVITY CAPTIVE. By Rodney Hall. 214 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: California Women Receiving Millions To Settle Bias Case
description: In a multimillion dollar settlement, the State Farm Insurance Company has agreed to pay damages and back pay to women who were refused jobs as insurance sales agents in California over a 13-year period.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $4,579,000 for the quarter and $19,135,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $3,905,000 for the quarter and $15,099,000 for the year. d-Net income The latest year loss resulted from the second quarter's $100 million special addition to its reserve for possible loan losses.

title: PEOPLES SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago fourth quarter included a non-recurring distribution from the Mutual Savings Central Fund equal to 49 cents per share.

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter includes a charge of $2,100,000 related to the shutdown of a plant.

title: AUTOINFO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
End of a Tradition
description: Most people think of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist as a rather traditional sort, but he is about to break a tradition established 18 years ago by his predecessor, Warren E. Burger.

title: The Other Ben Johnson
description: WHEN people call him ''the first Ben Johnson'' or ''the real Ben Johnson,'' he smiles and asks, ''What about the original Ben Jonson?'' A Columbia education comes in handy sometimes.

title: Key Unilever Executive Plays Down New Role
description: If the past is any precedent, Morris Tabaksblat's promotion to become Unilever's regional director for North America bodes well for his career.

title: N.B.A. Union Hints at Strike
description: The pro basketball union's player representatives will meet two days before the Feb. 7 All-Star Game in Chicago to discuss whether to recommend a boycott of the game, a strike or other actions to break their impasse with the owners.

title: U.S. Calls Haiti Voting 'Clouded' but Vows to Work With Winner
description: The State Department issued a carefully understated rejection today of the legitimacy of the elections Sunday in Haiti, but said that the United States would deal with whatever government emerges.

title: RESULTS
description: Skiing Tomba Gains 7th Cup Victory: Alberto Tomba of Italy yesterday won his seventh World Cup race of the season in a giant slalom at Saas Fee, Switzerland, widening his lead over the defending champion, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, in the overall standing. Tomba skied the two fastest heats to finish with a total time of 2 minutes 33.42 seconds. Guenther Mader of Austria was second, 1.93 seconds behind Tomba. Helmut Mayer, another Austrian, clocked 2:35.73 for third place. Zurbriggen, who has won only one downhill this season, finished fourth, 8-hundredths of a second slower than Mayer.

title: Salt Lake City Hospital Offering
description: Salt Lake City is tentatively offering $81.6 million of hospital revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of about 8.17 percent for an issue due in 2015 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer error, an article yesterday about a survey of race relations in New York City incorrectly described responses to a question asking Hispanic residents to name a person to whom they looked for leadership during racial conflict.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Squawks; Painful Gibberish Underground
description: The New York City Transit Authority undoubtedly thought it was doing riders a favor when it installed public address systems on subway platforms. But instead of offering information, the screeching sound systems only add to the subway's assault on the ears. The P.A. racket earns the T.A. a worm.

title: Courts Should Hire Impartial Technical Consultants; The Chaplin Suit
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Inflation Rate
description: Canada's annual inflation rate held steady at 4.2 percent in December, unchanged from the annual rate in the previous month, the Government statistical agency reported today.

description: Joyce Brown, the first person picked up under a New York City program to remove mentally ill homeless people from the streets, walked out of Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday after being forcibly hospitalized for 84 days.

City Ballet: 'Tombeau de Couperin'
description: THOSE who complain that George Balanchine's ballets all look alike, in effect, pay tribute to his strength of vision. What this view means, of course, is that his signature is immediately recognizable.

title: 82.1% Capacity Rate Is Highest Since 1980
description: The nation's industry operated at 82.1 percent of capacity in December, the highest level in almost eight years, as smokestack America continued to benefit from the falling dollar abroad.

title: An 'Active Partnership' That Spurs Learning
description: In the early 1980's, Columbia Park Elementary School in Landover, Md., was in trouble. On the average, its students, most of them black and from low-income families, could not crack the 50th percentile, or upper half, on national or local standardized tests. Discipline was so weak that officials suspended 20 to 30 students a year for five consecutive years.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bell Atlantic Corp., Arlington, Va., a telecommunications holding company, said its New Jersey Bell unit would run fiber optic cable to homes as part of a technical trial this year.

description: The Reagan Administration believes that a Panamanian plan to move the military-backed Government of Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega toward democracy remains a viable framework for negotiations despite a rift between the Panamanian leader and the plan's author, State Department officials said today.

title: U.S. Eases Stand on Membership For Moscow in Economic Groups
description: President Reagan has opened the door to Soviet membership in the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, provided that Moscow makes good on its talk of economic reforms, according to a policy document the White House is expected to release within days.

description: b-Includes a gain from the prepayment of a promissory note of $103,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: 'Phantom': Scalpers' Bonanza
description: Inside the hotel, tickets to ''Phantom of the Opera'' were unavailable at any price. ''I don't have anything to do with that show,'' the man behind the theater-tickets counter at the Sheraton Centre said yesterday at lunch time. He threw up his hands and shrugged in response to a question he'd had a hundred times before. ''There's nothing available for more than a year, so I don't even try.''

description: With a barrage of earnings reports, a schism emerged yesterday between the big New York banking companies and their regional counterparts over how to deal with loans to financially troubled third-world countries.

Taste of Mexico Becomes Harder to Find
description: SANTIAGO MONEO is out of work. But Mr. Moneo is not just another faceless New Yorker who is unemployed. He is the sole proprietor of Casa Moneo, and the closing of his store has had repercussions throughout the New York food world.

title: G.M. Plans to Drop Two Small Autos
description: The General Motors Corporation said it planned to discontinue two cars at the end of the current model year. The Cadillac Division will discontinue the Cimarron, a compact car introduced in 1981. The Oldsmobile Division will retire the Firenza subcompact, which was introduced in 1982. Sales of both cars have declined.

description: LEAD: Stock prices fell in moderate trading yesterday.

title: TV Reviews; '48 Hours,' Series From CBS News
description: WE were there, so to speak, at Parkland Memorial Hospital in Dallas; ''48 Hours,'' the new CBS News series, visited last night. What was the hospital like? It was attractive and intense, for one thing; it was full of television reporters, for another. ''48 Hours'' was really a public-television documentary with wings.

Year-ago quarter and year both include restructuring charges of $134 million and additional operational charges of $42 million.

title: Stage: 'The Last Resort' And a Geriatric Revolt
description: IN ''The Last Resort'' six people make life at a Long Island nursing home more lively than their keepers or relatives can stand. This place may be the last resort of the families that sent their elders to it, but to its inmates the last resort is escape, and even if the plotting of their breakout is hilariously inept, you keep hoping they will make it.

title: HOMETOWN BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NASA Challenge: Space Station Power
description: ENGINEERS designing the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's permanent space station are planning for the most part to use already developed, ''off the shelf'' technology to create the station, which will be assembled in earth orbit in the mid-1990's. But one of their more demanding challenges will be supplying electricity to the station - 15 times more power than an American spacecraft has ever needed.

Real Estate; Envisioning Brooklyn as Office Center
description: NEXT month a pioneering group of employees of Morgan Stanley & Company will cross the East River, leading a relocation from Manhattan to a new 19-story office tower nearing completion in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Australian Trade Deficit
description: Australia's current account deficit, the measure of exports of goods and services, fell to $467 million in December, from $590 million in November, according to official statistics released today. If the present trend continues, the country could end the financial year in June with a current account shortfall of more than $8.5 billion, analysts said. In the first half of the fiscal year, the total deficit was $4.29 billion.

title: Sandinistas Warn Political Foes And Briefly Hold 5 in Opposition
description: A strongly worded editorial in the official Sandinista newspaper Barricada today warned that the Government's recent decision to restore suspended civil rights ''should not be misinterpreted as a blank check for irresponsibility and subversion.''

description: The results for all periods have been restated to include the acquisition of Delaware Trust Co., on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Foote, Cone Gets President
description: Stanley H. Katz, the chairman and chief executive of FCB/Leber Katz Partners, has named J. Charles Taney Jr. president of its Foote, Cone & Belding subsidiary.

title: Hearings on G.O.P. Are Delayed
description: Confronted with Republican challenges of its jurisdiction, the State Commission on Integrity in Government today postponed what were to be its first major hearings.

title: CROWN ANDERSEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Cuba, North Korea Prepare to Be Hosts
description: Despite their announced intention not to participate in the Seoul Olympics later this year for political reasons, Cuba and North Korea are proceeding with preparations for other games to be held in their capital cities.

description: b-Net income Results include the operations of ACMI since its acquisition by Circon in August 1986.

title: FIRSTFED AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISRAELIS INVOKING EMERGENCY POWER IN EAST JERUSALEM
description: Seeking to quell Palestinian protests, Israel reportedly prepared to impose emergency police powers in East Jerusalem tonight for the first time since it annexed the Arab sector almost 21 years ago.

title: Di Giorgio Plans To Buy Back Stock
description: The Di Giorgio Corporation said its board had approved a restructuring and a stock repurchase program. The company plans to buy up to 1.5 million of its approximately 8.5 million common shares at a price of $21 a share. The company's stock closed today at $19.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, down 87.5 cents.

title: Nearly All G.O.P. Delegates Challenged in Michigan Race
description: Nearly all the delegates elected in last week's Republican county conventions in Michigan have been challenged, increasing the likelihood of competing state Republican conventions in Grand Rapids later this month.

title: British Phone Booths Saved
description: Britain has designated 1,000 telephone booths as national landmarks, the Environment Department announced today. The traditional red boxes have been a familiar sight since 1936. But British Telecom, in a modernization drive, has so far replaced 20,000 of 50,000 with a new design.

title: A Dearth of Strategic Thinkers
description: With the imminent departure of Under Secretary of Defense Fred C. Ikle, who announced his resignation last weekend, there remains no one at senior political levels of the Reagan Administration's national security apparatus who could be termed a strategic long-range thinker.

title: ISRAEL DELEGATION INVITED TO SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union said today that it had agreed to allow an official Israeli delegation to visit Moscow.

title: Nordic Skier Is Barred
description: Kerry Lynch of Denver, the Nordic Combined specialist, was barred from international competition at least until the end of 1988 after acknowledging he practiced blood doping at the last world championship. The International Ski Federation announced the ban yesterday in Bern, Switzerland. The exact length of the suspension will be determined later, but it includes next month's Winter Olympics. The federation also formally stripped Lynch of the silver medal he won in the men's Nordic Combined at the championships last year in Oberstdorf, West Germany. Blood doping involves withdrawing one's own blood, charging it with oxygen and then reinjecting it. Lynch's trainer, Doug Peterson, and a United States ski official, Jim Page, were initially barred for the same period as Lynch. . . . An arbitration panel of the International Amateur Athletics Federation has upheld the two-year suspension of the Swiss runner Sandra Gasser for using steroids at last year's World Track and Field Championships. The panel said that Gasser and the Swiss Athletic Federation had failed to show that proper procedures were violated in the tests that found the presence of drugs. Gasser, who will be ineligible for the Olympics said, ''I cannot prove that I did not dope myself. I can only say again and again that I did not.''

title: PRINTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1.5 million. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $1,379,000.

title: Former Head of Bates Discusses Sale Furor
description: Ted Bates Worldwide parlayed Saatchi & Saatchi's burning desire to be the biggest agency in the world into the Bates sale for $507.4 million, said Robert Jacoby, Bates's former chief executive, in a signed page 1 article in Adweek this week.

title: Chrysler May Sell Its Acustar Unit
description: At least three companies are reported to be interested in acquiring Acustar Inc., an auto parts supplier formed in May by the Chrysler Corporation as a wholly owned subsidiary. Chrysler and Acustar refused to comment on the report, which appeared in The Detroit News today. The three companies -the United Technologies Corporation, the ITT Corporation and Harvard Industries - also refused to comment.

title: Gene Deal for Beckman
description: Beckman Instruments Inc. has signed an agreement with British Bio-technology Ltd. to distribute the British company's line of synthetic genes. The synthetic genes, sold under the trademark Designer Genes, produce proteins used in research, the company said. Until now, researchers have had to grow their own genes for medical research. Beckman Instruments Inc., based in Fullerton, is a subsidiary of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: New York to Give Welfare Grants In Cash to Single Homeless People
description: The Koch administration has agreed to provide modest cash welfare grants to the 10,000 single men and women living in New York City's homeless shelters, city officials said yesterday.

title: Taylor Poetry Award Goes to Richard Wilbur
description: Richard Wilbur, the poet laureate of the United States, has been chosen as the second winner of the Aiken Taylor Award for Modern American Poetry.

title: COLORADO PRIME reports earnings for Year to Oct 30
description: The company changed its year-end to Oct. 30 from Jan. 30. The company said in the 12 months ended Oct. 30, 1986, it earned $2,638,000, or 79 cents a share, on $75,732,000 in revenue.

title: Market Place; New Uncertainty On Lockheed
description: THE price of the Lockheed Corporation's stock has been depressed for some time by concerns about military spending cuts and increasing pressure on contractors to share costs of developing new military hardware. Now, there is new uncertainty for investors in Lockheed, which some analysts believe is building a new high-flying, lightning-fast spy plane that will be designed to evade enemy radar and infrared sensors.

description: Many tournament players are capable of winning a title every year or two, when the fates, and their opponents, are kind. But a much smaller number do well almost every time they sit down.

title: Free Reading of Austen
description: The actors Barbara Feldon and Michael Tolan will give a free reading from works by Jane Austen on Thursday at 6 P.M. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street. Among the works from which they will read are ''Pride and Prejudice,'' ''Persuasion'' and published letters by the author. The reading is part of a free series of events at public libraries throughout the city. Information: 621-0618.

title: MCI to Reduce Its Phone Rates
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it would reduce its long-distance telephone rates by about 3.5 percent on March 1, matching rate reductions announced earlier by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: 7 Weeks to Super Tuesday: Key Questions Awaiting Answers
description: Nationally, the news nowadays is about Iowa and New Hampshire. But in the South, all the talk is about Super Tuesday.

title: Henley Seeks to Oust Santa Fe Management
description: A multibillion-dollar battle for control of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation erupted yesterday with the announcement by Michael D. Dingman, chairman of the Henley Group Inc., that he would wage a proxy fight to unseat the management of the railroad, oil and real estate giant.

title: Contras Agree to Attend Truce Talks
description: The political leadership of the Nicaraguan rebels agreed today to hold cease-fire talks next week with a delegation of the Managua Government.

title: AMSERVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Missile Test Is Successful
description: An unarmed Minuteman missile was launched Monday night after several days of delays in a successful test, an Air Force spokesman said today. Lieut. Col. Richard Hill, who observed the test, said the test rocket reached its destination at Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific Ocean, about 4,200 miles from here, in about 30 minutes.

title: Icahn Raises Texaco Stake
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn said today that he had increased his stake in Texaco Inc. to 14.5 percent, from 13.3 percent. The stock purchases cost him about $110 million.

title: DOMAIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $33,000 for the quarter and $208,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-Includes extraordinary gains of $166,000 and $520,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BRONCOS ARE STILL ON THE MEND
description: They finished with the American Conference's best record after playing most of the season without their top rusher, and they won the title game in an aerial shootout as their leading receiver watched from the hospital.

title: Ex-Chief to Return To General Homes
description: James W. Olafson, who founded the General Homes Corporation in 1973, agreed yesterday to return as president and chief operating officer of the Houston-based development concern as it begins its rebuilding strategy.

title: American Medical
description: American Medical International Inc., an operator of hospitals, said it had placed its British operations under a new holding company and was considering the sale of an unspecified minority interest to reduce the parent company's debt.

title: Study Says Quitting Smoking Reduces Risk of Stroke by 50%
description: Cigarette smokers who give up the habit cut their risk of stroke by about 50 percent, and even longtime smokers benefit from quitting, a new study indicates.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Net income

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago fourth quarter and year both include a charge of $68,863,000 from Columbus Southern Power Co.'s writeoff, after taxes and related adjustments, of a portion of its investment in the Zimmer plant. The company said the 1986 results are restated to reflect reclassification of certain sales to other utilities.

title: A Belgian Executive Amid Hushed Halls
description: Despite what must have been the company's most shattering news since it was founded in 1822, the marble halls of Societe Generale de Belgique headquarters retained their habitual hush today.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE subject is street clocks and the New Yorkers who rely on them but take them for granted until one day when . . . Well, listen to Richard T. Mermelstein, a lawyer who lives on Roosevelt Island and works in Manhattan in an office facing the Newsweek Building, at Madison Avenue and 50th Street, a structure topped on its north, south and west sides by a digital time and temperature sign:

title: New Jet Coaches
description: The Jets have named Wally Chambers as new defensive line coach and Mike Faulkiner as the coach of their defensive backs. Chambers played for the Chicago Bears and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and then was defensive line coach at Temple. Ray Callahan moved from defensive line coach to special assistant to Coach Joe Walton. Faulkiner had been a special assistant to Walton. Bud Carson, the coordinator of the Jets' defense, had previously also had prime responsibility for coaching the secondary.

title: U.S. to Resume Sending Arms to Contras
description: President Reagan formally reported to Congress today that he did not believe the Nicaraguan Government was trying in good faith to comply with the Central American peace plan. Under the law, that allowed the Administration to resume weapons shipments to the contras that had been suspended for a week.

title: Electoral Math
description: To the Editor:

title: KRUEGER, W A CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June. The company attributed much of the sales increase to the Fullerton, Calif., and Olathe, Kan., divisions which were acquired in November 1986 and May 1987, respectively.

title: Bell Atlantic Rebuts Panel In Inquiry on G.S.A. Bids
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation yesterday rebutted a Senate committee's accusations that one of its officials had admitted receiving confidential bid information from a Government employee about a telephone-switching contract.

title: Tyson Takes New Approach
description: Larry Holmes may get a break from Mike Tyson. To Tyson, it turns out, Holmes is just another opponent, and the undisputed heavyweight champion bears his challenger no ill will.

title: A Donation To Neediest Is a Tribute
description: A native New Yorker who migrated to Hollywood some 13 years ago and became a leading film producer, Daniel Melnick, has sent $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net gains of $26.5 million and $27,156,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, primarily from the sales of the 50 percent owned Beverly Hilton and Dallas Hilton Hotels and a parcel of land adjacent to the New York Hilton. c-After a loss on property transactions equal to 5 cents a share for both the quarter and year.

title: MELLON BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods' losses are after a $180 million addition to loan loss reserves for the quarter and $635 million for the year, and expenses related to business and benefit-plan restructuring of $44 million for the quarter and about $46 million for the year. Mellon said fourth quarter writedowns of real estate acquired and other assets, as well as charges arising from its mortgage servicing activities, totaled $78 million. The latest quarter results also reflect a gain of $126 million from the purchase of an annuity contract to settle a portion of the retirement plan's obligations, and a $24 million pension expense reduction resulting from changes in actuarial assumptions related to the retirement plan. The prior year net is after a $120 million addition to loan loss reserves.

title: Council Panel Backs Campaign Limits
description: A New York City Council committee yesterday unanimously approved a plan for public financing of city election campaigns, culminating months of effort by the Koch administration to respond to the calls for political reform that grew out of the municipal corruption scandals.

title: Hope Golf Starts Today
description: he 29th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic begins its five-day, 90-hole run Wednesday over four desert courses. This year, however, the tournament will not include PGA West, where Corey Pavin birdied the final hole to win the 1987 tourney.

title: SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss included a $350 million credit loss provision for developing-country debt, and included gains of about $27 million from sales of redundant operations resulting from the acquisition of Rainier Bancorporation in the third quarter. The year-ago results have been restated to include, on a pooling of interest basis, the acquisition of Rainier and an accounting change. The 1987 results included a total of $908 million in additional provisions to credit loss reserves in connection with loans to developing countries. The latest year's results include the earnings of Arizona Bancwest Corp., acquired in the fourth quarter of 1986, but the first 9 months of the prior year do not.

title: FIRST INDIANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CB&T FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in September 1986.

title: Courts Should Hire Impartial Technical Consultants
description: To the Editor:

title: IU Acts to Avoid Neoax Takeover
description: The IU International Corporation said it was negotiating with unnamed third parties ''concerning an extraordinary transaction, which could involve an acquisition or recapitalization of the company,'' in order to defeat a proposed $520.6 million tender offer from Neoax Inc. Neoax, a custom-vehicles maker based in Stamford, Conn. said it might increase its bid for IU, after the Philadelphia trucking concern rejected a $19-a-share offer.

title: Trade Coalition Formed to Urge The Recycling of Plastic Bottles
description: A newly formed coalition of chemical and packaging companies announced today that it was joining in a campaign to encourage the recycling of plastic bottles to help stem the nation's growing surfeit of garbage.

title: VIDEO DISPLAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a gain on the sale of assets of $596,058. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Aug. 31.

title: A Ballet by Massine And Colors by Lacroix
description: THESE are very busy days for the French designer Christian Lacroix. The American Ballet Theater's new production of ''Gaite Parisienne'' - with costumes by Mr. Lacroix - had its premiere yesterday in Tampa, Fla. On Sunday, Mr. Lacroix will introduce his eagerly awaited second couture collection in Paris. That night, the House of Lacroix will celebrate its first anniversary with a dinner dance at the Opera-Comique.

title: New York's Presidential Booby Traps
description: Just to get on the ballot, candidates in New York must overcome pointless legal obstacles that stud the state's 300-page election law. The rules encourage the nitpicking that has marred countless campaigns for local office. Now those same legal nits could taint the Presidential races in New York's April 19 primary. The booby-trapped election rules might block some candidates altogether and deny others their fair share of delegates.

title: Eating Well
description: FOLLOWING in the footsteps of other celebrities, Elizabeth Taylor has written a weight-loss book. Unlike many other authors - including Victoria Principal, Jane Fonda and Bess Myerson - Miss Taylor gained and lost her weight in full public view.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter results reflect a restructuring and other special charges totaling $117 million primarily relating to the exiting of certain businesses, a sharpening of focus in selected markets, the closing of domestic offices, and a staff reduction of about 2,500. The restructuring portion of the charges amounts to $82 million. The company said the 1987 loss reflected the impact of a previously announced decision in the second quarter to increase the reserve for possible credit losses by $1.7 billion. The 1986 net income was after an extraordinary charge of $33.5 million in the fourth quarter, resulting from the repurchase of high-coupon debt securities. The results for the latest quarter also include a gain of $35.7 million, or $23.5 million after taxes, on the sale of a 20 percent interest in Banco Manufacturers Hanover (Portugal), S.A., and a gain of $25.9 million, or $14.1 million after taxes, from the sale of aircraft previously on lease to corporate customers. The 1986 fourth quarter results included a gain of $44.5 million, $29.3 million after taxes, from the sale of properties in New York City. The company said that earlier in 1987 it realized a gain of $55 million, or $29.4 million after taxes, by recognizing a portion of the excess value in its pension fund, and a gain of $29.2 million, or $12.8 million after taxes, from the sale of two residential properties in Tokyo. The full year 1986 results also included a gain of $172 million, or $117 million after taxes, from the sale of the company's mortgage banking subsidiary.

title: Meaning of Christmas
description: To The Living Section:

title: Tharp Foundation Chief
description: AhEON Fwearwn Luckman has been appointed executive director of the Twyla Tharp Dance Foundation Inc. Ms. Luckman, who has been the director of development at the foundation, was previously director of the 92d Street Y Dance Center.

title: Political Memo; Babbitt's Moment in the Media Sun
description: The story of Gary Hart's rocky relations with the press is old news. The new story is about Bruce Babbitt: Mr. Babbitt, languishing at the back of the pack, is getting a lot of positive attention these days, and it is starting to get on the nerves of the other Democratic Presidential campaigns.

title: HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASPEN RIBBONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Moscow Grants U.S. Couple An Asylum From Capitalism
description: An American couple who came to Moscow as tourists have been granted political asylum after choosing life in the Soviet Union as an ''alternative to capitalism,'' the Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: RAYONIER TIMBERLANDS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are in units.

title: FALCON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DUQUESNE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in February 1987.

title: Dukakis, in Annual Address, Looks to New Hampshire and Beyond
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, making what he hopes is his last State of the State Address, said tonight that running for the Democratic Presidential nomination had been ''an extraordinary experience'' and that he had tried his best ''to make you proud of me and of what this commonwealth represents.''

title: Jean Mitry, Film Historian, 83
description: Jean Mitry, a film historian and co-founder of the Cinematheque Francaise, died of cancer Monday. He was 83 years old.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The per share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend declared on Oct. 5, 1987. The latest periods are after provisions for possible credit losses of $213 million for the quarter and $4,410,000,000 for the year, compared with $508 million for the year-ago quarter and $1,825,000,000 for 1986.

title: New Study Indicates One in 3 Tend To Get Risky Form of Cholesterol
description: About one of every three Americans inherits a tendency to produce a form of cholesterol that appears to be linked with an unusually high risk of heart disease, research released today shows.

title: Chambers Denied He Had a Date With Levin, Witness Says
description: Only hours before telling the police that he had killed Jennifer Levin, Robert E. Chambers Jr. told a friend of hers that he had not seen Miss Levin since they left a bar together, the friend testified yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CREATIVE COMPUTER APPLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Nothing to Cheer About in Anyone's Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cheap Dollar's Slippery Slope
description: LEAD: With the sharp improvement in the November balance of trade figures, the cheap dollar has emerged as the economy's deus ex machina. The joy, however, should be constrained.

title: NEWMIL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Who Killed Palme? Doggedly, the Hunt Goes On
description: By now, the 22-month-old hunt for the killer of Prime Minister Olof Palme has become a workaday job.

title: ALICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Prosecutor Says Nofziger 'Cashed In' on Reagan Ties
description: Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political director, repeatedly violated Federal ethics laws when he became a powerful Washington lobbyist and ''cashed in'' on his ties to the President, a prosecutor charged today.

title: TV Reviews; Ron Reagan In a Special On Cinemax
description: THERE is Ronald Reagan, the President, and there is Ron Reagan, the dancer, journalist and television host who is likely to pop up anywhere from ''Saturday Night Live,'' cavorting in his underwear, or as the star of his very own cable-television special, aptly titled ''Ron Reagan Is the President's Son.'' Ron Reagan may not be an enormous comfort to his folks as they approach their retirement years, but he has a certain kind of goofy charm for many of the rest of us.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: ALTHOUGH ground meat in any form is generally looked upon as less choice than a solid slab - hamburger as opposed to sirloin steak, for example - it has long been my contention that the ground version offers a chef or cook a great deal more latitude and fires the imagination.

title: Jordan Offers to Pay
description: For their roles in a brawl involving Rick Mahorn on Saturday night that cost the Detroit Piston power forward $5,000 and a one-game suspension, four members of the Chicago Bulls were assessed fines totaling $3,500 by the National Basketball Association. Yesterday, Michael Jordan, who was knocked to the floor by Mahorn - the action that caused the brawl - offered to pay the fines for the Chicago players. ''It's my way of showing my gratitude for them really stepping up for something I believed in,'' said Jordan. Charles Oakley ($2,000 fine), Horace Grant ($500), Scottin Pippen ($500) and Granville Waiters ($500) all accepted Jordan's offer, but Coach Doug Collins ($1,500) said he would take care of his own fine.

title: Rangers Trounced After 3-0 Advantage
description: Dave Taylor scored two goals and assisted on another, leading the Los Angeles Kings from a three-goal deficit to a 6-3 victory over the Rangers tonight.

title: Takeover Bid Cleared By Robins
description: The A. H. Robins Company said yesterday that it had accepted a sweetened takeover offer from the American Home Products Corporation, one of three bidders seeking the pharmaceutical company.

title: CAMBEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $85,000 and $44,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively.

title: Chief Executive Named At The New Yorker
description: S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman of Advance Publications Inc., announced yesterday that Steven T. Florio, 38 years old, had been named the chief executive of The New Yorker, a new title at the magazine.

title: Samuel Regenstrief, 78, Is Dead
description: Samuel Nathan Regenstrief, an Austrian immigrant who founded one of the world's largest dishwashing machine companies and became a millionaire-philanthropist, died Sunday at his home in Connersville, Ind., near Indianapolis. He was 78 years old.

title: Alfonsin Sees Democratic Gains in Rebel's Arrest
description: Speaking hours after the surrender of the leader of the latest wave of army mutinies here, President Raul Alfonsin on Monday night described the failure of the rebellions as proof that ''democracy in this country has been consolidated.''

title: Shots Fired in Standoff With Utah Polygamists
description: Shots were fired this afternoon from a house where members of polygamous family believed responsible for a church bombing continued a standoff with the authorities for a fourth day.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Executives
description: * Abraham & Straus Department Stores, Brooklyn, a division of Federated Department Stores Inc. named Joseph Pennacchio senior vice president and general merchandise manager.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1988
description: International A3-14

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All the results are adjusted to reflect the retroactive adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 91, accounting for fees and costs associated with originating or acquiring loans.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4.2 million for the quarter and a gain of $3.2 million for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain of $16.7 million and a loss of $238,900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW - WORKING GROUP ON CONTRACT PRACTICES - 10 A.M. AND 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMISSION ON INTERGOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE AND FUNCTIONS IN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL FIELDS - 10 A.M.

title: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF HISTORIAL DOCUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Share earnings in the latest quarter was less than one cent.

title: Cramped Convention
description: Leaders of the Democratic Party are trying to prepare their troops for the fact that the 1988 national convention hall, the Omni in Atlanta, is going to be a tight fit next July.

title: Andrew Dempsey, 46, A Magazine Executive
description: Andrew J. Dempsey, the president and chief executive officer of Times Mirror Magazines, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 46 years old. Late last year, Mr. Dempsey was instrumental in negotiating Times Mirror's $167.5 million acquisition of four magazines - Field & Stream, Skiing, Home Mechanix and Yachting - from Diamandis Communications Inc. Times Mirror Magazines also publishes Golf, Popular Science, Ski and Outdoor Life.

title: CHIPS & TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rockwell Profit Increases 29.1%
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said today that its earnings rose 29.1 percent in its first quarter even as the company's aerospace profits fell 23 percent as B-1B bomber production neared completion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1988
description: International

title: ARISTECH CHEMICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1986 fourth quarter and year results are on a pro- forma basis.

title: ENVOY IS BLAMED IN MOSCOW SPYING
description: In a report completed last summer but not made public, a Presidential panel concluded that the former United States Ambassador to Moscow should be held responsible for the misconduct of marine guards there, according to a staff aide to the panel.

title: DELCHAMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Report Faults School in Case Of Slain Girl
description: Signs of child abuse on Lisa Steinberg, the 6-year-old girl who the authorities say was beaten to death, should have been noticed by personnel at her public school in Greenwich Village, according to a report by the city's Board of Education.

title: The Pop Life; Hall of Fame Inductees
description: The Beach Boys, the Beatles, the Drifters, Bob Dylan and the Supremes will be inducted into the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame this evening during the organization's third annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Three other artists -Woody Guthrie, Leadbelly and Les Paul -will also be inducted as early influences on rock music. And Berry Gordy, the founder of Motown Records, will be added to the Hall of Fame's select list of nonperforming music-industry professionals.

title: Jazz: Hamiet Bluiett
description: THE baritone saxophonist Hamiet Bluiett brought a jubilantly noisy nine-piece big band to Carlos 1 (432 Avenue of the Americas, below 10th Street) Monday for the beginning of an indefinite stay of Monday nights. Mr. Bluiett, one quarter of the World Saxophone Quartet, has been leading a big band off and on for the last decade, and has ideas about what he wants from his orchestra. He wants it to breathe like one person, be attentive to its parts and, most important, act like a running back and improvise on its feet.

title: Indian Analyst Turns Freudian Eye On His Compatriots
description: A FREUDIAN view of Indian behavior and mythology hardly seems far-fetched in a country where the Hindu god Shiva is worshiped in the form of a phallic symbol and the mother goddess is often depicted as a violently destructive and castrating ogre. Yet Dr. Sudhir Kakar is one of only 25 practicing psychoanalysts in the entire country.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pretax gains of $66 million and $33 million for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively, on the disposition of investments in Georgia Gulf Corp.

title: INCSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $35,500 for the quarter and $78,300 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also includes a loss of $51,300 on early extinguishment of debt.

title: IMMUCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After tax credits of $142,386 for the quarter and $249,081 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $86,025 for the quarter and $188,214 for the 6 months.

title: Quebecor's Plans
description: Quebecor Inc., a newsprint and publishing company, said it was negotiating a multimillion-dollar acquisition that could be completed in about two months. Quebecor's president, Pierre Peladeau, said the deal would be for ''many, many, many millions'' of dollars. He declined to give further details. Montreal-based Quebecor publishes 3 Canadian daily newspapers, 6 magazines and 48 weeklies in Canada and the United States. It also owns 18 printing plants.

title: Two Homeless Men Set Afire by Youths At a Bus Terminal
description: Two homeless men were set on fire while they slept early yesterday in an isolated area of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, the police said, and two teen-agers were arrested shortly afterward when witnesses spotted them near Times Square.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 earnings included the results of the former Crocker National Corp. beginning on June 1. Wells Fargo acquired Crocker on May 30, 1986. The latest fourth quarter net included a $39 million special addition to the allowance for loan losses made in the fourth quarter in connection with loans to developing countries, and the remaining tax benefit from the previously reported $550 million special addition in the second quarter of 1987. The net for the year 1987 reflected the special additions to the allowance.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included after- tax provisions of $7,260,000 for the quarter and $22,440,000 for the year, as additions to its reserves for foreign loans.

title: Stop Rounding Up Those Wild Horses
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about ceremonies honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King included an erroneous identification provided by police officials and Mayor Koch's office for a woman who protested Mr. Koch's appearance at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church. She was not Beverly Weston.

title: Yonkers Agrees To Back a Plan For Integration
description: Yonkers officials told a Federal judge yesterday that they accepted his demand to integrate the city's neighborhoods and that the City Council would meet today to formally commit itself to a plan to do so.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Budget Reductions Force Marines To Seek 3,100 Fewer Good Men
description: Gen. Alfred M. Gray, the Commandant of the Marine Corps, said today that nearly 3,100 marines would be cut from the corps and that procurement of tanks and aircraft would be slowed as budget reductions are put into effect.

title: Bidder Held Below 25% Of Belgique
description: The Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti acceded to a request by the Belgian Government today to keep his stake in Societe Generale de Belgique below 25 percent of the outstanding shares.

title: At the Nation's Table; Alexandria, Va.
description: FOR those who have savored the three-star cuisine at the Auberge du Pere Bise in Talloires, France, on Lac d'Annecy, Le Chardon d'Or at the Morrison House hotel in Alexandria, just south of Washington, might be a good choice from Jan. 25 through Feb. 2.

title: A Morning Cola Instead of Coffee?
description: It's morning in Arnold, Mo., and, as he has on most days for 10 years, Tim Ernst is having a Coca-Cola for breakfast.

title: PARK COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
City Ballet Elects Chairman
description: The New York City Ballet has announced the election of Theodore C. Rogers as chairman of its board, succeeding Orville H. Schell Jr., who died last June. Mr. Rogers, a former president and chairman of the board of NL Industries Inc., has served on the New York City Ballet board and was formerly a director of the Houston Ballet.

title: Ban Greed? No: Harness It.
description: Program trading . . . index arbitrage . . . portfolio insurance . . . While regulators struggle to understand the implications of new ''derivative securities,'' it's a fair bet that most small investors have come to a simple conclusion. These all sound like tools for hustlers. They make it possible for speculators like Gordon Gekko, the villain in the movie ''Wall Street,'' to profit at the expense of honest investors. The right response is to regulate such derivative securities out of business.

title: Philadelphia Journal; On the Amtrak 7:30 to New York: Adventures of Commuting 2 Hours
description: It is 6:30 on a dark January morning, and some of the hardy ones who hurry shivering into the welcoming warmth of Philadelphia's elegant old 30th Street Station have been up since 5 o'clock. They quickly pick up coffee, doughnuts, bagels and The Philadelphia Inquirer and join the line for the 6:50 train to New York.

title: CRITICARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ADAPTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $982,000.

title: At the Nation's Table; San Francisco
description: AT the San Francisco International Airport, people are heading for their departing flights armed with sleek black cartons inscribed with the words Jetty Box. Their packages are the work of a restaurant and caterer called Vivande, Porta Via, which has been packing in-flight picnics since its opening in 1981 in downtown San Francisco.

title: Judge Rebuffs Secord On Evidence for Jury
description: A Federal judge refused today to order a grand jury to review Congressional testimony that a target of the Iran-contra investigation, Richard V. Secord, says exonerates him.

title: The Stage: Jan Munroe
description: JAN MUNROE, a Los Angeles-based performance artist who made his New York debut at Performance Space 122's downstairs space on Friday evening, is a one-man portrait gallery of Southern rural Americana. In ''Alligator Tails,'' he offered a spoken collage of characters from his Florida hometown of Quincy.

title: Film: An Early Bergman
description: WATCHING Ingmar Bergman's ''Three Strange Loves'' now - 39 years after it was made - is like opening a time capsule whose contents are familiar though they're being seen for the first time. Titled ''Torst'' (''Thirst'') in Swedish, the film opens today at the Film Forum in what is apparently its first New York theatrical engagement.

title: Astronauts, Worried Over Shuttle Flaws, Want an Extra Test
description: Senior astronauts, concerned about flaws in a test of a booster rocket for the space shuttle last month, have asked that the shuttle not be cleared to fly again until the booster passes at least three more tests.

title: UST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Both latest periods include a pre-tax charge of $3 million for the loss on the sale of UST's House of Windsor Inc. unit.

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $37,000 for the quarter and $1,365,000 for the year. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $839,000 for the quarter and $1,066,000 for the year. The prior year included an after-tax gain of $3.7 million, or 26 cents a share, from a special credit on the sale and lease-back of a research and development facility.

title: ATLANTIC FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank is based in Baltimore, Md.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $236,000 for the quarter and $456,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $459,000 and $512,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The reduced 1987 fourth quarter loss was due principally to the expensing in the fourth quarter of 1986 the net present value (about $525,000) of an employment contract with the company's former president. This charge was partially offset by increases to inventory reserves during the latest fourth quarter of about $225,000.

title: Food Notes
description: Dumplings and Things

title: Boyd F. Morgan, Stuntman, 72
description: Boyd F. (Red) Morgan, a stuntman who doubled for John Wayne in dozens of Westerns and boasted of falling off 2,000 horses in front of cameras without injury, died of heart failure Jan. 8. He was 72 years old. Mr. Morgan, who was born in Waurika, Okla., served in the Navy during World War II and coached high school football before becoming a stuntman in 1948.

title: Seton Hall Downs Providence by 82-80
description: John Morton sank two free throws with 3 seconds left, and Mark Bryant blocked a layup attempt by Chris Watts of Providence just before the buzzer as Seton Hall defeated the Friars, 82-80, in a Big East Conference game tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Commuter Plane Down With 12 People Injured
description: A commuter airliner with 16 people aboard crashed near here tonight, and officials said there were at least 12 people seriously injured. There was no word on fatalities.

title: FIRST REPUBLICBANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter loss reflects a loan loss provision of $340 million and a writedown of foreclosed assets of $53 million. The latest year results include those of InterFirst Corp., from the effective date of the purchase, June 1. The year-ago results are those of Republicbank Corp., the predecessor to First Republicbank.

title: In Jerusalem, Shopkeepers on the Front Line
description: The main street of Arab East Jerusalem was a long line of closed, gray steel shutters today as Palestinian shopkeepers refused to open their stores for the 13th day in a row.

title: Japan News Cuts Treasury Prices
description: Prices for short- and long-term Treasury securities declined modestly yesterday.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Both year-ago periods reflect a decrease in earnings of $43,741,076, net of taxes, or 78 cents a share, resulting from the December 1986 provision for the coal mining operations refund.

title: Hollywood Catches a Wave
description: It is Christmas in January for Hollywood this week. Fueled by the blockbuster opening of ''Good Morning, Vietnam'' and the unstoppable ''Three Men and a Baby,'' both movies from Walt Disney Pictures, the box office went wild last weekend.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page on Monday misidentified a Yugoslav folk music ensemble. It is Ivo Lola Ribar.

title: Citicorp Notes Yield 9.409%
description: Citicorp is offering $250 million of 9 3/8 percent notes due 1993 at a price of 99.896, to yield 9.409 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Enter a New French Superchef
description: ONCE in every decade, France seems to produce a chef who is acclaimed as the heir to a tradition of greatness.

title: Louisiana Bans Commercial Catching of Redfish
description: Louisiana has temporarily banned commercial fishing for redfish, in an effort to keep the species from becoming extinct.

title: HOMEOWNERS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,742,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Smaller Processor Does a Big Job Well
description: DOWNSCALING is the buzzword in kitchen appliances today, as major manufacturers reach out to small families and people who live alone.

description: There is nothing fancy about the corniced, four-story, red-brick building on West 40th Street into which Joyce Brown moved last night.

description: b-After a $14.7 million gain primarily from tax credits for the quarter and after a tax credit of $18.8 million for the year. c-After tax credits of $12.9 million for the quarter and $22.2 million for the year; both periods also included a $31 million pre-tax inventory gain, a $35.5 million pre-tax charge associated with uneconomic operations and a $116.2 million pre-tax gain on the sale of Robertshaw Controls Co.; the year also included a $67.7 million gain from new pension accounting rules. The year-earlier share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed July 1, 1987, and the addition of certain operations that are now consolidated.

title: Food Notes; A French Staple That's Made in America
description: SOME American cheese makers are now producing fromage blanc, long a staple in France. Fromage blanc is like an extremely smooth cottage cheese made from whole or skimmed milk. It is eaten either spiced or sweetened, often with fruit, and is also used in cooking.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $79,000. c-Includes tax credits of $1,174,000 and $2,070,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

Japanese Trade Report Shows Mixed Picture
description: Japan said today that its trade surplus with the United States rose in December and for all of last year, although its global trade surplus declined in 1987 for the first time in five years.
