description: The latest quarter and year includes investment gains by First Colony Life Insurance Co. due mainly to early bond redemptions of $2,667,000 and $15,359,000, respectively, and the year-ago quarter and year includes similar investment gains of $3,945,000 for the quarter and $20,588,000 for the year.

title: Excerpts From School Poll: What Administrators Think
description: A recent survey by the National Center for Education Information found an ''amazing similarity of views among superintendents and principals in public schools in this country'' on a wide variety of education issues. Following are excerpts from the report, which analyzed the responses of 3,577 elementary and secondary school administrators: 1,704 superintendents, 1,349 principals in public schools and 524 principals in private schools. The survey was conducted between Oct. 16 and Dec. 20, 1987.

title: FIRST MARYLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Interpublic Group Seeks Phillips-Ramsey
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies Inc., which had the acquisition craze before the Saatchis appeared, has just announced a plan to buy Phillips-Ramsey of San Diego and Phoenix. It will be its first acquisition since its deal for the United States arm of Geers Gross Advertising was completed earlier this month.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LSB BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $111,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A New Weapon Is Seen in Cancer Fight
description: SUBSTANCES that undergo a chemical reaction when exposed to light are likely to become a new weapon in the treatment of cancer. Known as porphyrins, they are given to patients intravenously and concentrate in cancer tumors. When exposed to light, they give off energy that kills the cancer cells.

title: City Opera Beginning 6-Week National Tour
description: A six-week national tour of Rossini's ''Barber of Seville,'' presented by the New York City Opera National Company, will begin tomorrow at the Tropicana Hotel in Atlantic City.

title: Regan Questions M.T.A. Over Awarding of Leases
description: The New York State Comptroller yesterday asserted that the real-estate department of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has made ''inconsistent and questionable'' decisions in awarding leases, and said he has referred the matter to the United States Attorney in Manhattan.

title: EDUCATION: LESSONS
description: Richard Jungkuntz flew across country this week to sit in conference with some of higher education's most powerful leaders. It is the last time this provost of a small Lutheran college will formally attend such a gathering. This spring, at the age of 70, he plans to end his 30-year career as an educator and retire to the tennis courts.

title: CITIZENS FIRST BANCORP, NJ reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings restated to reflect a previously declared 6-for-5 stock split scheduled for distribution Feb. 1.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HRUDEY BURNED BY PENGUINS
description: Kelly Hrudey tried to differentiate between which of the six Penguin goals were his fault, which were the product of defensive laxity and which were pure credits to the opposition's offense, but he ultimately gave up.

title: French Pupil Ordered Home
description: A foreign exchange student has been ordered to return to France because she visited her homeland for Christmas week instead of staying to watch Americans celebrate the holidays.

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL MANAGEMENT & REEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1986 results are restated for adoption of a new accounting standard for income taxes.

title: Economic Scene; Electoral Politics Dictates the Script
description: FOR Americans traveling or residing abroad, the shrunken value of the dollar is felt not only as a strain on the pocketbook but as a personal insult. Feeling overcharged, overspent and over there, Americans ask: ''Is this what we're worth now - half what we were a few years ago?''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society gave an incorrect date for the Blizzard of 1888. It was March 12.

title: CONSULTANTS GET ROBERTSON FUNDS
description: The Presidential campaign of Pat Robertson, in contrast to other candidates, made unusually large payments to a few consultants last year, a new study shows. By doing this, the campaign has avoided disclosing how it is spending millions of dollars.

title: Dole Urges Caution Toward Soviet Union and Distrust of Gorbachev
description: Senator Bob Dole said tonight that if elected President he would he would shape a relationship with the Soviet Union marked by ''caution'' and essential distrust for the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Safety Panel Urges More Controls On Connecticut Building Projects
description: Stricter controls on construction projects in Connecticut were proposed today by a gubernatorial advisory committee appointed after the collapse last April of an apartment complex in Bridgeport that killed 28 construction workers.

title: Jared French Is Dead; Figural Artist Was 82
description: Jared French, a figural painter who used realist techniques to deal with metaphorical subject matter, died Friday in Rome, where he had lived for nearly 20 years. He was 82 years old and also had a home in Hartland, Vt.

title: The Scots Know Oats Are Hard To Beat
description: LEAD: OATMEAL cookies rank with chocolate-chip and Oreo cookies as American favorites.

title: CLINICAL SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The company announced a change in its fiscal year-end from Feb. 28 to Dec. 31. This change to a calendar year will become effective with financial results reported for the 10-month period beginning March 1, 1987 and ending Dec. 31, 1987.

title: Life in the 30's
description: AT 2 o'clock in the morning I am awakened by the appearance of a person no taller than a fire hydrant, only his black eyes visible over the horizon of the mattress. ''What do you want?'' I whisper. ''Nothing,'' he whispers back.

title: BANKERS FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods included provisions for loan losses of $350,000 for the quarter and $17,778,000 for the year, and losses on the sale of real estate of $2,308,000 and $2,049,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year-ago periods includes provisions for loan losses of $1,913,000 for the quarter and $2,821,000 for the year, and gains on the sale of real estate of $693,000 and $1,210,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Concert: The Philomusica
description: HAYDN, Mozart and a light, tart Neo-Classical homage to them made up the New York Philomusica's program Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. The Haydn was a curio: a pair of trios for violin, viola and cello cobbled by the composer out of his own piano sonatas. It was profitable in those days to publish music in multiple versions for home consumption, which remains the best use for these arrangements; playing them in a concert is certainly not objectionable but not particularly enlightening either. They were done with vigor, some dash and a few scratchy moments by Todd Philips, Karen Tuttle and Melissa Meell.

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the higher year earnings occurred despite additional loan loss provisions of $36 million in the second quarter for potential Latin American loan losses.

title: ZZZZ Best Pleas Filed
description: Barry J. Minkow, the 21-year-old millionaire, and nine others pleaded not guilty today to charges of racketeering, securities fraud and tax fraud. Mr. Minkow was indicted last week by a Federal grand jury.

title: Parents in Absentia
description: LEAD: I am at a dinner party and so is the mother of three children, ages 3 and under. She is wearing a magenta miniskirt and has just come from a cocktail party. She speaks of her weekly Nautilus program, her child care (two full-time sitters) and her work. As a mergers and acquisitions lawyer, she is out of town on business at least one night a week, and mentioned nine cities she had visited in the last month and a half alone.

description: Dani Nikas moved to Brooklyn last week. It was her 18th or 19th move since she hit town in autumn. Getting settled here can be hard on people.

title: David Bernstein, Physician, 77
description: Dr. David Bernstein, a staff member of Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn for more than 40 years, died Friday at Maimonides after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: I.B.M. Net Rises 50.4% In Quarter
description: In a long-awaited and somewhat muted rebound, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 50.4 percent, to $2.09 billion, after a year of cost-cutting measures that John F. Akers, the company's chairman, declared ''are beginning to pay off.''

title: A New Raider Move?
description: The Los Angeles Raiders have called a news conference for today amid speculation that Tom Flores will step down as coach. A Raider spokesman, Steve Hartman, said only that the team would make a ''significant announcement.'' The Raiders recently completed a 5-10 season, the team's worst since Al Davis, the team's managing general partner, took over in 1963. Among the names mentioned as possible successors should Flores leave have been two current 49er assistants, Dennis Green, the team's receivers coach, and George Seifert, the defensive coordinator. If Green were to be named, he would become the only black head coach in the National Football League.

title: CALIFORNIA MICRO DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Further Decline in Minority Enrollment Is Feared
description: Without support from Federal and state governments, minority participation in higher education will steadily decrease, experts said here today at the 70th annual meeting of the American Council on Education.

title: A Tooth Tugger
description: To The Living Section:

title: Some Major League Requests
description: A record 14 players, led by George Bell of Toronto and Andre Dawson of the Chicago Cubs, submitted figures of $1 million or more for salary arbitration yesterday. Bell, at $2,105,000, and Dawson, at $2 million, became the first players in the 13-year history of salary arbitration to break the $2 million barrier.

title: Swiss Trade Deficit Up
description: Switzerland's trade deficit widened in 1987 as a rising tide of imports swamped a small increase in exports, the Federal Customs Office said today. The trade deficit totaled 7.69 billion Swiss francs, or about $5.63 billion, compared with a gap of 6.51 billion francs in 1986. A strong domestic economy drew 6.9 percent more imports into Switzerland on an inflation-adjusted basis, but exports grew by only 1.1 percent.

Viazzi Memorial
description: A memorial service for Alfredo Viaz-zi, the proprietor of Trattoria da Alfre-do, is to be held at 4 P.M. Sunday, Jan. 31, at St. Luke in the Fields Church, 437 Hudson Street, at Grove Street. Mr. Viazzi, who was 66 years old, died of a heart attack on Dec. 28 at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: 'Password' Winner's Logic
description: Kerry Ketchem, the 36-year-old former Air Force airman who was arrested on mail fraud charges after trying to collect $58,600 in prize money he won on the television show ''Super Password,'' sent a Mailgram to the show's producer yesterday saying he deserved the money and had provided the show with ''priceless free publicity.''

title: Sports People; Coe's U.S. Indoor Debut
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain, the 1980 and 1984 Olympic 1,500-meter champion, will make his American indoor debut on Feb. 13 in the Vitalis Olympic Invitational meet in East Rutherford, N.J. Coe will run in the 3,000 meters against Doug Padilla, who is the best American in that event, and Frank O'Mara and Paul Donovan of Ireland, who finished first and second, respectively, last March in the first world indoor championships.

title: Government Tightrope: What Price for Talent?
description: The $150,000-a-year salary granted to New York City's new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, apparently makes him the nation's highest paid public school administrator.

title: U.N. Chief Asks Panel For Mideast Peace Plan
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will ask the five permanent members of the Security Council to begin a new Middle East peace initiative modeled on their efforts to end the Iran-Iraq war, according to senior United Nations officials.

title: Mobil Says It May Sell Retailer
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it was exploring the sale of its Montgomery Ward & Company subsidiary after having received inquiries from ''some sizable companies'' interested in acquiring the retailing chain.

title: Foreign Trawlers Accused of Violating U.S. Zone
description: Federal officials meeting in Anchorage today began investigating evidence that foreign trawlers may have been fishing illegally in rich American waters off the Aleutian Islands in Alaska.

title: ARTIST DISCOVERS HIS MURAL, REDONE
description: RECENTLY, on his way to a party, the muralist Richard Haas rounded a corner at South Street and Peck Slip in lower Manhattan, and was startled to see that a mural he had painted in 1978 on a Con Edison substation had been changed.

title: Record Profit for Volvo
description: Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, today reported record pretax profits for 1987 of 9 billion crowns, or about $1.5 billion, substantially better than some analysts had expected. Most had said the company would do well to match its 1986 profits of 7.5 billion crowns. The 1987 figure included October's 1.15 billion crown sale of Volvo's 49.6 percent stake in the Hamilton Oil Corporation, a Denver-based oil and gas company. But even discounting that, the company had profits of 7.85 billion crowns - better than the previous record of 7.7 billion crowns, achieved in 1985.

title: Newspaper Merger Planned
description: The Columbia Record, the afternoon newspaper in South Carolina's capital city, will cease publication after the April 1 issue and its staff will be merged into its sister morning newspaper, The State, the newspapers' publisher announced today.

title: Drug Use Blamed in Rail Crash
description: A Federal safety agency said today that impairment from drug use and a failure to require automatic braking devices on freight trains were responsible for a fatal collision between an Amtrak passenger train and a string of freight locomotives last year.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: In Morning Game-Show Slot, ABC Turns to Practical Matters
description: THE camera pans to wooden beams and a roaring fire. This is the setting for ABC's new late-morning television program ''Home.'' The network calls it a ''how-to talk show'' that will not be discussing life styles of the rich and famous but nitty-gritty subjects like home remodeling, bulk buying, fancy meals under $25, and a thousand uses for a glue gun.

title: Minister of Defense Quits in Philippines, Citing Rise of Rebels
description: Defense Minister Rafael Ileto announced today that he had submitted his resignation, saying the Government had failed to address the welfare of the people, allowing the Communist insurgency to grow ''alarmingly strong.''

title: Bus in San Francisco Kills 3 and Injures 15
description: A bus sped out of control through a downtown intersection and ''just mowed people down'' in a rush-hour crash Tuesday, killing 3 pedestrians and injuring 15 others, witnesses and the authorities said.

title: FRANK GEHRY REALLY LOVES FISH
description: THE question seems to come up at dinners among architects just when the fish course is being served: can the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry really be designing a high-rise office tower in the shape of a fish to be built on the present Madison Square Garden site?

title: PRESIDENT PRAISES ENRICHED SCHOOL PROGRAM
description: President Reagan traveled today to a suburban Washington school that has the kind of program he favors to achieve school integration. He praised the plan and announced that he would ask Congress for more money for such programs.

The net loss for the year included the fourth-quarter LDC provision as well as special reserves of $845 million made in the second and third quarters.

title: Dole Critizices Kemp Leaflet On Social Security Measures
description: Senator Bob Dole accused Representative Jack F. Kemp today of trying to scare elderly voters by sending out a brochure that criticizes Mr. Dole's votes on Social Security.

title: Russian, in Spain, Suggests Talks Over Central America
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, proposed today that Moscow and Madrid open talks to improve Central America peace hopes.

title: Summer's Colors Bloom in Glass Houses

But the truth never stopped any horticulturist from dreaming, and with snow and slush a reality, thoughts of tropical species beckon. As indoor gardening has become more tempting, interest in the the city glass house for winter growing has increased, and the result is a variety of styles and prices for a variety of uses.

title: Owner of Crane in Collapse Was Fined for '84 Accident
description: The company that owned the crane that collapsed at a construction site at Seton Hall University, killing two workers, was fined for a fatal crane accident in 1984, a Federal inspector said today.

They left with a 103-101 victory, compliments of a fourth-quarter collapse by the Nets, who have the second-worst record in the league.

Rise Reported In Sterling Bid
description: Hoffmann-La Roche & Company is raising its bid for Sterling Drug Inc. to $81 a share, from $76, a person close to Hoffmann said last night.

title: The American Family Is Adjusting To Teen-Agers' Work-Spend Ethic
description: LaDONNIA FULLMER, a 17-year-old high school senior in Los Altos, Calif., works 25 hours a week and earns $500 a month doing housework and baby-sitting. She has an A average. ''My parents can't afford to pay for me to buy the clothes I want or to go out with friends,'' she said. ''I wouldn't have to work if I didn't want any of those things. But I do.''

title: The Bricks of Scholarship
description: Disagreements between scientists are meant to be resolved by data. But when facts are elusive, even scientists occasionally throw aside the professional pretense of objectivity and tear into each other with invective, shameless appeals to authority and arguments that are unabashedly ad hominem. Take the ruckus that has erupted over the demise of the dinosaurs.

title: Q&A
description: Q. There are cracks in a ceiling of our 1867 house. One contractor says the plaster has separated from the lath and recommends that the entire ceiling be taken down and replastered. A second contractor says that the plaster may have separated only in some areas, and that if he tapes the cracks, smooths out the plaster and inserts long screws into the beams, the ceiling will hold. What do you recommend? A. The second procedure is a gamble. I would favor complete replastering because there is a good chance the wood lath is rotted and needs replacing. Also, if the plaster has separated in one place, it probably is loose in other places. Q. I want to change the color of the ceramic tile on my bathroom walls and floor. Is there an effective method of painting tile? A. You can paint ceramic tile with a two-part epoxy enamel, or you can use a good grade of alkyd enamel, although this probably will not last as long. Either way, you must carefully clean the tiles and the grout or the paint will peel. If you use an alkyd enamel, first use a shellac-based primer like Enamelac or BIN. Remember that the paint on the floor tiles will wear quickly, and you will have to repaint periodically. Q. I want to paint the brick at the entrance of my house to change the color. Does the brick have to be treated first, and should I use a special paint? A. You can paint brick with a latex masonry paint made for exterior use. Just be sure the brick is clean first. Painting brick, however, is seldom a good idea because peeling and flaking become a problem. Brick manufacturers do not recommend painting, as the paint traps moisture inside the brick.

title: Koch Creates a Panel to Study Streamlining of Agencies
description: LEAD: Announcing the need for a tough examination of how city government operates, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was creating a commission to study agencies and recommend improvements as the city's economy cools.

title: New Poll Finds Wide Support for Abortion Rights
description: Broad public support for preserving the right of women to obtain abortions remains undiminished seven years after Ronald Reagan came to office on a strong anti-abortion platform.

title: Vd Mehta to Discuss Modern Indian Culture
description: Contemporary Indian culture will be discussed by the writer Ved Mehta on Feb. 16 at 7 P.M. at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. Robert Oxnam, president of the Asia Society, will interview Mr. Mehta, a novelist and contributor to The New Yorker magazine.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (FORT MYERS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Children's Haircuts Without the Tears
description: Having her hair cut was not Sydney Blumstein's idea, but her mother's. Sydney, who is 3 years old, thought her long dark hair was just fine the way it was, until the video screen before her in a midtown hair salon lit up with a cartoon tape starring Mickey Mouse.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Eurobond Deal By G.M.A.C.
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 3/4 percent noncallable Eurobonds due 1991 at 101 1/8 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International.

title: EXCHANGE STUDIES SUSPENDING TRADE IN VOLATILE STOCKS
description: The New York Stock Exchange will consider a proposal to halt trading temporarily in individual stocks if their prices rise or fall by a certain amount, the exchange's chairman, John J. Phelan Jr., said in an interview yesterday.

title: Keyless Ways to Unlock a Drawer
description: LEAD: One of life's minor difficulties is trying to open a locked drawer with no key. Luckily, many locks in old chests and desks are fairly simple and similar and often open if turned with a key of similar size.

title: Critic's Notebook; Conserving Asia's Arts Without Stifling Them
description: ONE thing that fascinated this sympathetic neophyte on a recent three-week dash through Southeast Asia was the varied ways in which traditional performing arts are being preserved and offered to the public. There seemed to be three general categories: fairly unself-conscious manifestations of traditional behavior, more or less compromised presentations for tourists, and scholarly efforts to preserve traditional arts in the face of the inexorable onslaught of Westernized modernity.

title: Zimbabwe Share Prices
description: Industrial share prices hit record levels on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange this week, passing an index figure not seen since the country's first year of independence. The index measuring price movements for shares of the 50 industrial companies listed on the exchange hit 487.2 Monday, its highest level in seven years, then rose further Tuesday to 488.5. After hitting its previous peak of 487.1 in January 1981, nine months after the southern African country gained independence, the index slipped in the next three and a half years to a post-independence low of 100.6 in August 1984.

title: CROSSLAND SAVINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $17,303,000 for the quarter and $57,752,000 for the year. The company said year-ago quarter results included a pre-tax $6 million gain from termination of its pension plan. The bank said gains on sale of securities and mortgages for the latest quarter were $1.6 million, compared with $5.5 million for the year-ago period. The gains on sale of securities and mortgages for the latest year were $25.7 million, compared with $25.4 million for 1986.

title: Soviet Official Says Press Harms Army
description: The Soviet Defense Minister, in a rare television appearance, has sharply criticized the Soviet press for undermining public respect for the Soviet Army.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Philippe de Rothschild, 85, Dies; Maker of Chateau Mouton Wine
description: Baron Philippe de Rothschild, a member of the Rothschild banking family, owner of Chateau Mouton-Rothschild in Bordeaux and a tireless champion of French wines, died at his home in Paris yesterday after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: SOCIETY FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $387,000 for the quarter and $1,395,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $638,000 for the quarter and $7,031,000 for the year.

title: PENNVIEW SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $105,000. The latest first quarter is the first full quarter of operations for the company since conversion to stock form.

title: Crazy Eddie Reports a Loss
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., a financially troubled retailer of electronics products, said yesterday that it had lost $73 million in its third quarter that ended Nov. 29. In the quarter a year earlier, Crazy Eddie posted net income of $3.7 million.

title: OLD CRAFTS, NEW LAMPS
description: JACK CUNNINGHAM makes early-American lamps the way craftsmen made things 150 years ago. He uses many of the tools used in the 19th century to trim the metal and fold the pieces together, and hand-solders each joint -as many as 75 in one lamp.

title: CINCINNATI BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
N.B.A. Notebook; Richardson Starts Bid for Reinstatement
description: ''Have you been arrested or charged with any crimes since being disqualified from the National Basketball Association?

title: Israelis Said to Kill 3 Guerrillas
description: Israeli troops killed three Palestinian guerrillas early today, moments after the guerrillas cut a security fence on the northern border and slipped into Israel, apparently to mount an attack.

title: GROVE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank went public in August 1986.

title: Bristol-Myers Net Up 14.8%
description: The Bristol-Myers Company, citing a strong rise in profit and in domestic and international sales, reported yesterday that it fourth-quarter earnings rose 14.8 percent on a 13.3 percent increase in sales.

title: New York Area Costs in '87 Up 5.9%
description: Consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose slightly in December, ending 1987 on a ''welcome quiet note'' after a 12-month increase of 5.9 percent, the largest in six years, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of labor statistics, said yesterday.

title: Child Molester Attacks 15th Victim, Girl, 9
description: A child molester with a mustache and pock-marked face who preys on Queens schoolgirls attacked his 15th victim on Tuesday, the police said yesterday.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM (INCN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 results included a provision of $160 million taken in the second quarter to build reserves for losses on loans to less developed countries.

title: ALBERTO-CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring after-tax gain of $2.3 million from the sale of Lamaur Inc. common stock.

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Flores Steps Down As Raider Coach
description: Tom Flores stepped down today as head coach of the Los Angeles Raiders after nine seasons, and speculation over a successor flared up immediately.

title: Iowa, or the Smoke-Filled Room?
description: Why is everybody paying so much attention to Iowa? Things are looking up for Babbitt in Iowa . . . Dole's lead in the Iowa polls is widening . . . Hart looked rattled on TV in Iowa. Who made Iowa the national barometer? Why should we care what happens in the Iowa precinct caucuses on Feb. 8? Let's go back to the old way and let the political professionals pick the candidates.

title: SOUTHTRUST CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; Time for Some New Buddies
description: AS of today and counting, the National Football League has still not had a new black head coach since Fritz Pollard joined the Hammond (Ind.) Pros in 1923.

title: Washington Talk: Foreign Press Corps; Lively Beat Keeps Visitors on Toes
description: While some merchants of doom see the United States as a waning power in the world, up against mounting economic and political competition from Asia and Europe, there are those who find the daily happenings of this capital city of ever more interest.

title: Long Terms Urged For Three in Attack
description: The prosecutor in the Howard Beach attack case urged the judge yesterday to sentence three white teen-agers convicted in the case to 10 to 30 years in prison because ''raw racial hatred'' had motivated them to attack three black men.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $30 million from the sale of the company's Animal Health Care business for both the quarter and year. The company also provided for the impairment of certain assets and other items. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock split.

title: A.T.&T. Plant Will Be Closed
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would close a manufacturing plant employing 3,300 workers in this central North Carolina city, where it has had operations for more than 40 years. The factory - part of

title: George D. Clahr, 53, A Contact Lens Expert
description: George D. Clahr, a New York City ophthalmologist and expert in the use of soft contact lenses, died of cancer of the colon yesterday at his home in New Milford, Conn. He was 53 years old.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nicaragua Seeks to Move Up Truce Talks With the Contras
description: A Nicaraguan official said here today that the Sandinista Government wanted to open direct cease-fire talks with the Nicaraguan contra rebels on Thursday, a week earlier than scheduled.

title: Hartford Insurance
description: The Hartford Insurance Group has laid off 400 people and indicated that more cuts might be necessary as the company tries to reduce its costs. Hartford Insurance employs 9,000 people in Connecticut and 20,000 nationwide. Donald R. Frahm, its president, said he hoped attrition might offset the need for future layoffs. The layoffs affected 236 people in the company's property-casualty headquarters in Hartford; 103 employees from the life, health and employee benefits unit in Simsbury, Conn., and 61 others outside the state.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yustin Sirutis, Boxing Coach, 79
description: Yustin Sirutis, a former Golden Gloves heavyweight boxing champion and a coach for many years at the City College of New York, died Jan. 6 in Rincon, P.R., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Rincon.

title: Stage: 'Woza Albert!' Performed at City College
description: WHEN ''Woza Albert!,'' the acclaimed two-man South African play, was first presented in New York several years ago, high-powered political South African ''township'' theater was a something of a novelty. Since then, Lincoln Center's Woza Africa Theater Festival and its production of ''Sarafina!'' have familiarized us with an emotionally charged genre of spare, confrontational theater that transfuses political anger into ritualistic communal affirmation.

title: JEFFERSON BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Town Forgives the Past And Honors Janis Joplin
description: For years communities across the country have been making their peace with the troubled 60's, usually with belated homecomings for the men who fought in the nation's least popular war.

title: Report on Adviser to Meese Describes Investment Fraud
description: The investment adviser to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d transmitted ''over $1 million in apparently ill-gotten gains'' from some of his clients to Hong Kong accounts from 1985 to 1987, according to an affidavit by a Federal investigator looking into Mr. Meese's affairs.

title: Relief Convoy Ambushed
description: Rebels ambushed a convoy in northern Ethiopia last Friday and burned seven trucks carrying food for famine victims, relief officials said today. Guerrillas of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front attacked a column of trucks on the road from the port of Massawa to Asmara, the capital of Eritrea Province, the officials said. No casualties were reported.

title: CATERPILLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $31 million from a tax benefit. c-Net loss The company said in the year-ago fourth quarter and year it took a charge of $109 million from plant closings. The company also said its cost reduction program, which began in 1986 has, so far, reduced overall costs about 7 percent.

title: SOFTWARE PUBLISHING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Change Seen In Limits on Soviet Trade
description: The Western allies and Japan are expected to agree next week to fewer but more rigorously enforced curbs on exports to the Soviet Union, American and European officials said today.

title: Gore as Candidate: Traveler Between 2 Worlds
description: If politics is the art of pleasing different groups of people simultaneously, Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, seems to have chosen the right profession.

title: Evert Upsets Navratilova
description: Chris Evert beat her longtime rival, Martina Navratilova, 6-2, 7-5, today to advance to the final of the Australian Open.

title: In Sandinista Wall, Cracks Revealed
description: Nicaragua's effort to comply with the Central American peace accord has accentuated differences within the Sandinista leadership, according to diplomats and Sandinista officials.

title: ARCHITECTS TO CREATE IVORY TOWERS
description: ARCHITECTS, unlike dancers or gymnasts, are still considered young at the age of 40. Many are just receiving the commissions that will showcase their talents.

title: REAGAN WILL LIMIT AID FOR ABORTIONS
description: Despite the certainty of a legal challenge, President Reagan will soon announce rules prohibiting abortions and abortion counseling by family planning programs that receive Federal funds, White House officials said today.

title: FIRST ALBANY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN BANK OF CONNECTICUT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIRMINGHAM STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Business People;
Low Profile Pays Off For Dyncorp President
description: LEAD: Dan R. Bannister, the president of Dyncorp who has quietly won control of the technological services company, first joined the concern in 1953 to work his way through college.

title: White House Berates the Foes of Contra Aid
description: The White House attacked Congressional opponents of renewed aid to the contras today, saying their criticisms of the Administration's Central America policy were ''outrageous'' and tantamount to ''surrender.''

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Children Cited In Donations To Neediest
description: Emma Myers, 4 years old, of Brooklyn saw homeless people every day and wanted to do something for poor children. Her mother, Susan B. Myers, told her about The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, and they sent a gift of $10.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect the issuance of 7,576,000 shares of class B common stock on Oct. 27. Year-ago 9 months includes a $970,000 charge resulting from the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Final Seconds in a B-1's Cockpit Are Pieced Together by Air Force
description: It took less than three minutes for a new B-1 bomber to crash into the Colorado desert last September after it struck a bird the size of a turkey that ripped through electrical, hydraulic and fuel lines to ignite a catastrophic fire.

title: Dow Drops By 57.20, To 1,879.14
description: LEAD: Stock prices plunged yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell to its lowest point since Dec. 11. Technology issues were particularly hard hit, despite some strong earnings reports.

title: BOWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the results of Star Forms Inc., acquired late in December 1986, are included only in the 1987 results.

title: COMMERCE BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition on Jan. 2, of Commerce Bank-Pennsylvania N.A., on a pooling of interests basis. The year-ago per share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend payable Feb. 1.

title: Rosewood Buys 6% Stake in Cronus
description: Rosewood Financial Inc., an investment concern controlled by the Texas investor Caroline Rose Hunt, has purchased a 6 percent stake in Cronus Industries' 5.38 million shares outstanding.

title: GENCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $4,000,000 and net of $1,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations, and gains from the sale of discontinued operations of $242,000,000 for the quarter and $456,000,000 for the year. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $16,000,000 for the quarter and $60,000,000 for the year, and the year also includes a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $1,000,000. Year-ago results are restated for discontinued operations and a 3-for-1 stock split declared last November.

title: Wartime Merchant Seamen to Get Veterans' Status
description: The Defense Department, under orders from a Federal district judge to reconsider the issue, has agreed to extend veterans' status to the men who sailed merchant ships in World War II, the Pentagon said today.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dart in $834 Million Bid for Stop and Shop
description: The Dart Group Corporation yesterday announced an $834 million offer for the Stop and Shop Companies, a chain of supermarket and discount department stores.

title: Not Too Late for a Palestinian-Israeli Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DESIGNING PROCESS
description: THE thin line separating design and fashion becomes thinner in April when the American version of Elle, sister of the French fashion magazine, inaugurates a series of features on design and architecture. The same month, Esquire magazine will also start a design feature, ''Living Quarters.''

title: Keep the Pressure On the Sandinistas
description: Congress will soon vote on whether to renew military aid to the Nicaraguan democratic resistance. For all its apparent complexity, the issue before Congress and the nation is quite simple.

title: Head of New Division At CPC International
description: CPC International Inc., which makes such household foods as Skippy peanut butter, Knorr soups and Hellman's mayonnaise, announced yesterday that it had established a worldwide consumer foods group and named Richard W. Siebrasse as its president.

title: United Technologies' Profit
description: The United Technologies Corporation, led by a strong performance in its power group and in its automotive and wire and cable operations, reported yesterday that it had fourth-quarter earnings of $172.5 million, or $1.32 a share, in contrast to a deficit of $228 million in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: TV Anchorman Gets Suspension For Harsh Report
description: John Roland, an anchorman for WNYW-TV, was suspended yesterday by the station because, the station's management said, ''his emotions prevailed over objectivity'' in an interview with Joyce Brown broadcast live on the 10 P.M. news Tuesday.

title: Redmen Shoot Down Hoyas
description: St. John's needed big performances from its top three guns tonight, and this is how they responded: Michael Porter scored and soared for a game-high 21 points; Shelton Jones added 16 points with 14 rebounds; and Boo Harvey scored 9 points and guided the Redmen offense through Georgetown's vaunted press.

title: GATEWAY BANK (NORWALK, CONN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $25,740,000, resulting primarily from the sale of the company's insurance premium finance division.

title: FAMILY OF AQUINO SET BACK IN VOTE
description: Partial results of local elections held across the nation Monday led Philippine analysts to conclude today that President Corazon C. Aquino remains popular but that her relatives are not.

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: the latest results reflect $15 million in the fourth quarter and $30 million for the year for special provisions for loan losses primarily related to less developed countries' debt. The per share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 10 percent stock dividend distributed on July 31, 1987. The year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the 1987 acquisition of United Midwest Bancorp Ltd., accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Illegal Contributiaons to Hart Reported
description: Gary Hart faced new allegations today about the finances of his 1984 and 1988 Presidential campaigns but asserted he had no knowledge of any possible wrongdoing.

title: Icahn Goes to Court To Pitch Texaco Plan
description: Carl C. Icahn, the largest shareholder of Texaco Inc., came to Federal Bankruptcy Court here today to try to persuade a judge to allow his bankruptcy reorganization proposal to go to the company's shareholders for consideration.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday described the appointment of J. Charles Taney Jr. incorrectly. He is president of FCB/Leber Katz Partners, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.

title: SMITH, A O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $3 million gain from an accounting change. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,983,000 and $2,869,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mr. Rabin's Policy
description: ''The first priority is to use force, might, beatings.'' That is the message from the man in charge of Israel's response to the Palestinian protests, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

title: Big Gains in Computer Industry
description: Buoyed by strong sales of its newer products, Apple Computer Inc. today reported the highest quarterly revenue and earnings in its history.

title: U.S. Ends Curb On Photographs From Satellites
description: Reversing decades of Federal policy, President Reagan has acted to allow civilian American satellites to make photographs as sharp as their foreign competitors', removing constraints on taking more highly magnified pictures of the Earth, White House officials said yesterday.

title: Photo of Syrian troops moving into the Shatila refugee district, which was devastated during a three-year siege (AP) Shiites End Siege of 2 Palestinian Areas in Beirut
description: Hundreds of Shiite militiamen withdrew today from positions around two Palestinian refugee districts in south Beirut, ending a three-year siege.

title: Kennedy Backs Extension in Sale of The Post if Deal Emerges
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said yesterday that he ''would have no objection'' to extending Rupert Murdoch's March 6 deadline on selling The New York Post if such an extension is needed ''to complete the sale.''

title: 'Lost' Tapes by Lennon In Yearlong Radio Series
description: ''The Lost Lennon Tapes,'' a yearlong weekly radio series, begins this week on stations associated with the Westwood One Radio Network. Culled from more than 300 hours of John Lennon's taped archives, the series includes interviews, unreleased recordings (including an acoustic-guitar version of ''Strawberry Fields''), songs in various stages of development, jam sessions and other material - some of it dating back to the Quarrymen, Lennon's band before the Beatles - that was made available by Yoko Ono, Lennon's widow.

title: Brazil's Trade Surplus
description: Brazil had a trade surplus of $11.15 billion in 1987, with exports totaling $26.21 billion, the second highest ever, the Government said today. Imports came to $15.06 billion. The surplus was 33.8 percent higher than the 1986 figure of $8.33 billion.

title: Executives
description: Bacardi Imports Inc., Miami, the U.S. marketer of Bacardi rum, named Eduardo Sardina and Rodolfo Ruiz executive vice presidents. It also named Steven Naclerio senior vice president.

title: Advances in Breast Reconstruction Ease the Trauma of Cancer
description: Dramatic improvements in the art and science of breast reconstruction have transformed the experience of surgery for breast cancer for many women, reducing the long-term trauma.

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Rockwell Picks 2 in Shuffle
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said today that it would combine its aerospace and space operations and realign the responsibilities of two executives, adjustments that reflect the conclusion of B-1 bomber production.

title: La Meri, 89, a Dancer, Teacher And Specialist in Ethnic Repertory
description: La Meri, the dancer, teacher, writer and dance ethnologist, died in a San Antonio hospital on Jan. 7. She was 89 years old.

title: Bankers Trust Net Soars; Irving Has Loss in Quarter
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, corporate parent of the Bankers Trust Company, yesterday reported extraordinarily high net income for the fourth quarter - nearly triple its earnings a year ago - mainly because of huge profits from its foreign-exchange and bond-trading activities.

title: Talking Deals; Spirit of '92 Comes To Belgium Early
description: WITH his bold bid for Societe Generale de Belgique - the holding company that is said to control a third of Belgian industry - Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian entrepreneur, seems to have moved far ahead of the crowd in building a European-wide business empire.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING TUMBLE BY 16.2%, WORST IN 3 YEARS
description: Housing starts plunged an unexpectedly steep 16.2 percent in December, the sharpest monthly decline in more than three years, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: Ex-CBS Chairman Tells of Takeover
description: Thomas H. Wyman, the former chairman of CBS Inc., said yesterday that the 1986 assumption of management control by Laurence A. Tisch was a brilliantly plotted and executed takeover at bargain prices, and not the friendly management change it was depicted to be.

title: 10 Killed in Taiwan Crash
description: Ten people died when a Taiwan Airlines commuter plane crashed into a mountain on Orchard Island, 170 miles southeast of Taipei, the Government said today. One man survived. The British-built Britten-Norman 2, a propeller-driven plane, had taken off Tuesday morning from the fishing port of Taitung, 160 miles south of Taipei, for a 20-minute flight to Orchid Island.

title: North Korea Added to Terror List
description: The United States today put North Korea on its list of nations that support international terrorism, citing its role in the bombing of a South Korean jetliner last November that left 115 people dead.

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year includes a gain of $13.1 million taken in the second quarter from the transfer of the company's commercial glass business.

title: No Jewish Dictators
description: To the Editor:

title: If a Doll Wears an Eye Patch, I Can Too
description: IN 1981, when her 3-year-old son underwent surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, Gail Zayka noticed that pediatric nurses, using teddy bears and medical jargon, often failed to address the real misconceptions and fears of their young patients.

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3 million and $26 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, said it would spend $1.90 billion this year to expand and improve its facilities, an increase of 9 percent above the $1.74 billion it spent last year on capital expenditures.

title: The Stage: Alaskan Myth, 'Summer Face Woman'
description: ''THE Summer Face Woman,'' Dave Hunsaker's meditation on Aleut history and mythology, begins with a nifty nugget of musical humor, as six of its cast members gather to sing a rock-and-roll version of Johnny Horton's 1960 hit, ''North to Alaska.'' The sight of a group of actor-singers who include several Alaska natives joining together in a tune that celebrates Alaskan territory as a new American frontier ripe for conquest, sets us up for a bracing indictment of marauding exploitation. Instead what follows is a meandering, dispirited retelling of Alaskan history interspersed with an Aleutian myth that suggests a twist on the story of Circe.

title: Norway Bank Change
description: The managing director of Norway's biggest bank, hit by losses and a stock trading scandal, said today that he had resigned because the bank lost money in 1987. Leif Terje Loeddesoel, managing director of Den norske Creditbank, said in a letter to the board that he was resigning because of the group's net loss of 1.5 billion crowns, or about $235 million, last year. The board said in a statement that it had accepted his resignation and that the bank, with operations in London, New York and Zurich, would not pay a dividend on 1987 results as a result of the huge losses. The bank lost nearly 900 million crowns, or about $140 million, in stock trading last year.

title: FRENCH NAVY AIDS A FOREIGN TANKER
description: France appears to have altered its rules of military engagement in the Persian Gulf, announcing today that one of its warships intervened to stop an Iranian attack on a non-French tanker flying a Liberian flag last weekend.

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge equal to 40 cents a share.

title: Arizona Impeachment Hearings Open
description: A committee of the Arizona House of Representatives opened hearings tonight to consider the impeachment of Governor Evan Mecham.

title: Pennsylvania Issue
description: A $160 million issue of Pennsylvania general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.20 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 6.55 percent in 1998 and 7.40 percent in 2008 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago 9 months is after a loss of $406,000, reflecting a net gain of $17.4 million primarily from the sale of securities in connection with the proposed acquisition of Sanders Associates and a writeoff of non-recurring costs of $17.8 million, applicable to the defense electronics segment, previously deferred in connection with a foreign production program. Loral said the latest third quarter includes contribution from Loral Systems Group (formerly Goodyear Aerospace), which was acquired March 13.

title: GLENFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $5,152,000. c-After an extraordinary loss of $1,888,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $3,171,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest second quarter's earnings are basically unchanged from a year-ago, and would have been higher except for certain one-time expenses associated with the consolidation during the quarter of Guarantee Savings & Loan into Glendale Federal.

title: Pop: Daniel Ponce Ensemble
description: LATE last year, Daniel Ponce, a Cuban conga drummer, released ''Arawe,'' one of the most ambitious Latin albums of the decade. On ''Arawe,'' Mr. Ponce's band pulls together rhythms and melodic ideas from traditional and pop music all around the Americas: Cuban rumbas, New York jazz and funk, Brazilian samba, Dominican merengue, Puerto Rican bomba and plena, and Yoruba rhythms that look back to West Africa. At Sounds of Brazil on Tuesday, Mr. Ponce led a dozen musicians in music from ''Arawe'' - performances considerably less polished than the recording, but full of spirit.

title: Abdul Ghaffar Khan, 98, a Follower of Gandhi
description: Abdul Ghaffar Khan, a Moslem disciple of Mohandas K. Gandhi who opposed British rule in India and partition of the subcontinent, died yesterday in a hospital in Peshawar, Pakistan. He was 98 years old and had suffered a stroke six months ago.

title: IT'S ORANGE, GREEN AND PURPLE
description: CHITA RIVERA, the dancer and singer, is opening a new restaurant today at 444 West 42d Street that looks like a Broadway set of a New York restaurant: vivid, spirited, capable of delivering a slightly heightened experience along with grilled steak.

title: U.S. Trial of AIDS Drug Is Failing the Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Tournament in the Hague Is Limited to 16 Elite Pairs
description: For most bridge purposes democracy is the norm.

title: Pacemaker Use Questioned
description: One in five of all the pacemakers implanted in patients by doctors in one city were clearly not needed and about a third of them were of uncertain value, according to a review of medical records from 1983.

title: Black vs. Black in South Africa
description: High in the hillside cemetery of Sinathingi, his name on a roughhewn cross, lies the freshly dug grave of Arron Mabuza. Nearby, in jumbled rows of still newer graves, lie at least three other blacks, perhaps as many as eight or nine, who were killed as they made their way to Mr. Mabuza's burial shortly before the New Year.

title: FRANKFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Film: 'Half of Heaven,' From Spain
description: ''HALF OF HEAVEN,'' the appealing Spanish movie that begins a run at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema today, is a quiet comedy, a low-temperature romance, a matter-of-fact fantasy. It's all about Rosa, a cheerful, affectionate, diligent girl who works her way up from the family farmhouse to running Madrid's most fashionable restaurant.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter and year includes pre-tax charges of $23.1 million and $32.3 million, respectively, from unrealized exchange losses related to debt denominated in Japanese yen, and the year also includes a pre-tax gain of $14.6 million from sale of property rights. Year-ago fourth quarter and year include an unrealized pre-tax gain of $2.3 million and a pre-tax charge of $20.5 million, respectively, related to foreign currency exchange, and pre- tax gains from the sale of certain property rights of $14.8 million for the quarter and $60.3 million for the year.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a loss provision of $90 million after taxes for estimated contract losses at Norden Systems, a gain of $32 million after taxes from the 1986 sale of the company's headquarters building in Hartford, Conn., and the benefit from the reversal of $25 million after taxes of unrequired reserves for discontinued operations established in 1985. The company said net for 1986 would have been $419 million without provisions for restructuring and employee severance costs.

title: Upper East Side Has Become a Dirty Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Protest Figure Reported To Be a U.S. Informant
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, a Brooklyn minister who has organized civil disobedience demonstrations and has frequently criticized the city's predominantly white political leadership, assisted law-enforcement officials in at least one recent criminal investigation of black community groups, Government sources said.

title: HIGH COURT BARS EXPELLING DISTURBED PUPILS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that public schools may not expel or remove disruptive, emotionally disturbed students from their classrooms for more than 10 days, even to protect others from physical assault, without the permission of the parents or a judge.

title: Popularity Has Its Price, and With Americana, It's High
description: MOST antiques enthusiasts, even collectors of American furniture, were stunned last January when a 200-year-old Philadelphia wing chair with furry-looking feet and a frame riddled with nail holes was sold at Sotheby's to a New York dealer for $2.75 million.

title: Sports People; N.H.L. All-Stars
description: Denis Potvin, the Islander defenseman, was among 13 players added to the Wales Conference all-star team by Coach Mike Keenan of Philadelphia yesterday. It will be the ninth all-star game for Potvin, a three-time winner of the Norris Award as best defenseman.

title: 'Justice' for AIDS Patients
description: LEAD: I recently observed first-hand how New York City's criminal justice system treats people with AIDS. I saw horrifying mental and physical abuse and the denial of basic human rights.

title: Consumer Prices Rose 4.4% in 1987
description: Consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December, a modest finish to a year in which inflation at the retail level climbed 4.4 percent, the fastest pace in six years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A Haitian Opposition Leader Is Seized After Tour Abroad
description: With Haitians awaiting an announcement on the results of the flawed presidential election three days ago, the authorities detained a prominent opposition leader today as he returned home from an anti-Government campaign abroad.

title: Cambodia Negotiators Dispute Hanoi's Role
description: A second round of talks on Cambodia began near here today and ran into trouble as both sides insisted on tough conditions to settle the war that has raged in that country since 1978.

title: Tour Presses Family Issues in Campaign
description: A doctor, a television producer and a United States Representative are touring the country to promote what they think should be a central issue in the Presidential election: the status of the family.

title: Savings Unit Fines Imposed
description: A jury has fined three former directors of the defunct First Maryland Savings and Loan $100 million each for mismanagement and fraud that contributed to the thrift institution's collapse in 1985.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes a writedown of preferred stock investments of $7,440,000.

title: ALEX BROWN & SON INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1986 are on a pro-forma basis assuming the company was public for the entire year.

title: Ethics Unit Investigating Elections Board
description: The New York State Commission on Government Integrity disclosed yesterday that it is investigating the State Board of Elections as part of its inquiry into campaign contributions to Poughkeepsie Town Board candidates by a shopping mall developer.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $10 million for consolidation costs in connection with the acquisition of the consumer packaging division of Boise Cascade Corp.

title: Japanese Cut 'Last Emperor'
description: When Bernardo Bertolucci's epic ''The Last Emperor'' opens in Japan on Saturday it will not be quite the same film that audiences in the United States and Europe got to see.

title: New Envoy: Native Son For Vienna
description: A new American Ambassador, Henry Anatole Grunwald, presented his credentials today to President Kurt Waldheim.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rock Hall of Fame Inducts Members
description: The Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame moved into rock's second generation last night. The Beatles, Bob Dylan, the Beach Boys, the Supremes and four members of the Drifters were inducted at the third annual hall of fame ceremony, a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel's Grand Ballroom, with speeches, tributes and a closing jam session.

title: Music: Mahler's 9th, by the Philadelphia
description: MAHLER did not believe in moderation as a way of making his musical point. As an artist, he lived a life of unquiet desperation, both victimized and motivated by a nameless dread. However, at times in his last completed symphony, the turbulent and emotionally searing No. 9, he seems to be desperately searching for even more immoderate ways to express himself. He explicitly rejects the Grecian ideal: nothing to excess. In fact, everything to excess might be the motto of his Ninth, as Klaus Tennstedt and the Philadelphia Orchestra brought out in a harrowing performance of the work on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: SOVRAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Rebellion by Mayors
description: Thirty or more American mayors are lining up against President Reagan's plan to provide more aid for the rebels fighting the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes non-recurring writeoffs equal to 49 cents a share for the quarter and 95 cents a share for the year.

title: 'Top Gun and Beyond,' on Pilots
description: ''NOVA'' flies in fighter jets tonight: ''Top Gun'' with a sense of purpose. In fact, the program is called ''Top Gun and Beyond.'' What happens when air technology becomes so complex it exceeds a pilot's ability to use it? ''Nova,'' on Channel 13 at 10 P.M., says there are problems; it also says that jets need pilots.

title: Farmers Group Rejects Offer
description: The Farmers Group Inc. today rejected a $4.2 billion takeover bid from the United States arm of the British tobacco conglomerate B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., saying the offer was inadequate and not in the best interests of shareholders.

title: JOHNSON WORLDWIDE ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Net loss

title: No Emergency Seen in East Jerusalem
description: The Minister of Police said today that he had no immediate plans to use emergency powers to impose curfews in Arab East Jerusalem or order striking shops there to open.

title: Heineken Chief Sets Retirement
description: Alfred H. Heineken, who helped Heineken Breweries N.V. grow from a Dutch domestic beer supplier to a worldwide company, will retire next year, the company said today.

title: COMMERCIAL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year loss is after a charge of $22 million from an addition to loan- loss reserves made in the third quarter.

title: A Flamboyant Leader of Protests
description: From his manner of dress to his celebrity connections to the high-profile demonstrations he has led over the last 15 years, the Rev. Al Sharpton has been one of the more flamboyant civil-rights advocates in New York.

title: Dance: City Ballet Performs Robbins's 'Fanfare'
description: JEROME ROBBINS is at his brightest and most goofily amusing in ''Fanfare.'' And the ballet received a correspondingly bright and funny performance on Tuesday, when the New York City Ballet presented it at the New York State Theater.

title: PUGET SOUND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter included a $9.2 million special provision for loan losses. In addition to the special provision for loan losses in the latest fourth quarter, the latest year results were adversely affected by a loan loss provision of $15 million in the third quarter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 21, 1988
description: International A2-13

title: Pop: Houserockers, Blues
description: THE ghosts of the blues guitarists Magic Sam and Freddie King swirled around the room Tuesday for the Abilene Houserockers, a blues trio. At their first set at Mondo Cane, 205 Thompson Street, where they play regularly, the Houserockers worked their way through Texas-styled guitar instrumentals, and blues and soul standards, including Magic Sam's ''All of Your Love'' and Little Willie John's ''Fever.''

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: REPAIRING large holes in wallboard - larger than four inches across - requires some ingenuity and moderate experience with some basic tools. Unlike patches for small holes, which were discussed in last week's column, these patches must be braced from behind. The bracing, or backing, creates a surface to which the patch can be fastened.

title: '88 Bond Activity Is Brisk; 30-Year Offerings Stressed
description: New financing activity in the corporate bond market is off to a brisk start this year, with an especially heavy supply of 30-year offerings.

title: MICROSOFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CARTERET BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Republic's provision for loan losses in the latest quarter included a $10 million special provision for less developed country loan losses. The net for the quarter is also after losses of $18.9 million from either sales or marking down to estimated market value obligations of certain LDC. The net for the latest quarter was also after one-time costs of $4.7 million in connection with staff curtailments and an early retirement program. The year-ago quarter's net is after loan loss provisions of $28.7 million. The 1987 net from operations is after a special provision of $110 million related to the company's lesser developed country exposure and after additional losses amounting to $83.8 million through sales or marking to estimated market value sovereign obligations of certain LDC. The year was also after an extraordinary loss of $15.9 million from early extinguishment of debt. The 1986 year included an extraordinary loss of $12.9 million from early extinguishment of debt.

title: ALTOS COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes a net gain of $3.1 million from the sale of an investment.

title: Arms and Allies: NATO A-Arsenal Cuts Disputed
description: France and Britain are lobbying the Reagan Administration to prevent West Germany from maneuvering NATO into conceding further reductions of nuclear weapons on the European central front. At stake, some European officials argue, is the future agenda of the Atlantic alliance.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN OF (S C) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,512,000 and $2,148,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in October 1987. The company said the latest quarter and 6 months include gains from the sales of loans and investments of $473,787 and $276,523, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 6 months include gains from the sales of loans and investments of $2,413,704 and $3,096,078, respectively.

title: World Soybean Output
description: The world output of soybeans in 1987-88 is smaller than had been forecast, according to an Agriculture Department report on Tuesday. World production was estimated at 101 million metric tons, down 1.4 million tons from last month's forecast.

title: Argentina to Purge Officers In Effort to Buoy Democracy
description: Bolstered by the failure of an army revolt here this week, President Raul Alfonsin's Government is planning a purge of extremist middle-ranking officers in the hope of securing more solid military support for Argentina's fragile democracy.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ONE morning, my third-grade classmate Clive didn't have his arithmetic homework ready. When our teacher asked him where it was, Clive didn't bat an eye. ''My cat ate it,'' he replied.

description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $95,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-Includes extraordinary charges of $663,000 and $314,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Knicks Can't Elude Another Roadblock
description: Xavier McDaniel produced career-highs of 41 points and 18 rebounds in leading the Seattle SuperSonics to their 16th straight home victory, a 108-96 triumph over the Knicks tonight.

description: b-Net income

title: Interest Rates Post a Modest Drop
description: Interest rates fell modestly yesterday as traders were encouraged by Government data showing a steep drop in housing starts and a smaller-than-expected rise in consumer prices.

title: U.S. Denies Shift on Soviet
description: The White House, the Treasury and the State Department said today that the Administration's policy opposing Soviet membership in the major international economic organizations ''remains unchanged.'' The comments came in response to an article in The New York Times on Wednesday that gave an account of the President's annual National Security Strategy assessment.

title: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $91,323,000 gain from the cumulative effect of accruing unbilled revenue.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Too Good a Cleanup?
description: When new Presidents move into the White House, they invariably denude it of any reminders of their predecessors, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the former Presidential aide to Jimmy Carter, was saying yesterday.

title: SUMITOMO BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Personally, I worry that if we ease up too much, the contras will take advantage. You don't want to let your enemies act openly.'' - German Mendoza Huete, of the official Voice of Nicaragua radio, on recent arrests. [ A10:2. ]

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SECRETS OF THE TEMPLE: How the Federal Reserve Runs the Country. By William Greider. 798 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: AN UPDATE ON 'THE COSBY SHOW'
description: IS he running out of steam? Has he peaked? How far can a megastar slip before he becomes an ordinary superstar again? The subject is, of course, William H. Cosby Jr., comedian, actor, writer, producer and, according to some estimates, the top money-earning performer in these United States. But suddenly the Bill Cosby media machine is showing signs of strain. His new movie, ''Leonard Part 6,'' over which the star exercised considerable control, is a box-office disaster. His books have recently slipped from No. 1 positions on the best-seller lists, hard cover and paperback. Most significantly, ''The Cosby Show'' on NBC has so far this season taken a ratings nosedive of about 18 percent from a year earlier.

title: CONSTELLATION BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nokia Oy Buys Stake in Ericsson
description: The Finnish high-technology company Nokia Oy said it had bought a controlling interest in the data systems division of the Swedish telecommunications giant L. M. Ericsson. The sale, in which Nokia acquired an 80 percent share of the Ericsson division, makes Nokia the largest computer company in Scandinavia and the second-biggest European manufacturer of data terminals.

title: Old-Fashioned Dance
description: Dennis O'Connor and Ann Papoulis will present ''Leonard and Cinciana,'' which they describe as a ''retro comedia de la danza,'' on Jan. 28 at 8:30 at At the World, 254 East Second Street. The piece, conceived and performed by Mr. O'Connor, a member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, and Ms. Papoulis, the choreographer, has a score by John King that will be performed live and a set by Cis Bierinckx. Tickets are $5. Reservations: 477-8677.

description: b-After a gain of $516,000 from an accounting change. c-After a charge of $90,000 from an accounting change.

George F. McGrath, 70, Is Dead; Ex-Correction Chief in New York
description: George F. McGrath, New York City Commissioner of Correction in the Linday administration and an authority on penology, died yesterday at his home in Boston. He was 70 years old.

title: Shake-Up at Pan Am Is Expected Today
description: The board of the Pan Am Corporation expects to change the company's top management today, a board member said yesterday.

title: Washington Talk: Foreign Press Corps; Center Is a Home Away From Home
description: Engulfed in a cloud of tobacco smoke, a group of Turkish reporters waited for a briefing by an American arms control official on the outlook for reducing conventional arms in Europe.

description: COPIES of Harrowsmith magazine will suddenly appear in waiting rooms of doctors, dentists and even some veterinarians across the country next month under the sponsorship of General Foods.

description: Antiques Show

description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER SPACE MARATHON, SOVIET ASTRONAUT LAUDS EXERCISE PLAN
description: A strict and ''very monotonous'' new exercise regimen by a Soviet astronaut paid off in a smooth and relatively quick readjustment to Earth's gravity after 326 days in space, the astronaut, Col. Yuri V. Romanenko, said today.

title: Ask the Joint Chiefs
description: To the Editor:

title: Heriditary Link Studied As Colon Cancer Cause
description: Scientists in Japan have found evidence that hereditary predisposition to cancer of the colon and rectum may be a result of a highly complex process involving loss of protective genes on any of several different chromosomes.

title: Missile Pact Must Be Amended, Helms Says
description: Senator Jesse Helms, a leading opponent of the recently signed treaty eliminating American and Soviet medium-range missiles, asserted today that it must be amended before it can be approved by the Senate.

title: Washington Talk: Football and the Gourmet; Some Hot Recipes From Red Hot 'Skins
description: A newly published Washington cookbook gives top billing to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for 12 recipes submitted by his wife, Ursula, who admits her husband is no whiz in the kitchen.

title: Bank-Failure Causes Cited
description: A study of bank failures from 1979 to 1987 shows that although troubled regional economies had an obvious impact, much of the blame had to be placed on poor managers, the Comptroller of the Currency, Robert L. Clarke, said today.

title: Legal Limits on Young Workers
description: FEDERAL and state laws restrict the kinds of jobs that teen-agers may hold and the number of hours they may work. But enforcement is ''virtually nil,'' according to Dorianne Beyer, general counsel for the National Child Labor Committee, a nonprofit agency that examines youth-employment policy.

title: Profit Scoreboard
LACLEDE STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from an accounting change of $2,618,000 for the quarter and year.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company had $15.2 million in tax benefits in the fourth quarter related to the addition of $700 million to the allowance for credit losses taken in the second quarter. The latest year results include the provision of $700 million for credit losses. Bankers Trust said in its fourth quarter the provision for credit losses totaled $70 million, compared with the $188 million provided in the year-ago period.

title: Newark Council Overrides a Veto On AIDS Exams
description: The Newark City Council overrode the Mayor's veto tonight and approved an ordinance mandating AIDS testing for prostitutes and their clients.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Now that Bob Horner has signed with the St. Louis Cardinals after playing one season with the Yakult Swallows of the Central League in Japan, the Swallows have responded by signing Doug DeCinces, a 37-year-old third baseman who batted .234 last year with California and St. Louis, and Terry Harper, a 32-year-old outfielder who hit .246 with Detroit and Pittsburgh in 1987. . . . Jackie Joyner-Kersee, who won the heptathlon and the women's long jump in last September's world outdoor championships, received the Vitalis Award for Sports Excellence yesterday at a luncheon in New York. Joyner-Kersee will compete in the long jump in the Vitalis meet and in the Panasonic Millrose Games on Feb. 5 in Madison Square Garden. . . . Warren Moon, the Houston Oilers' quarterback who suffered injuries to his right shoulder in a game on Nov. 22 against the Cleveland Browns, underwent an arthrogram yesterday in Houston to determine a course of treatment.

title: College Basketball; Kentucky Shocked By Florida, 58-56
description: Vernon Maxwell scored 19 points and Dwayne Schintzius added 18 tonight as Florida, despite going scoreless over the final 3 minutes 24 seconds, upset Kentucky, 58-56, in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Chambers and Levin Didn't Seem To Be Intoxicated, Bartender Says
description: John A. Zaccaro Jr., who said he was the bartender on the night in August 1986 that Robert E. Chambers Jr. met Jennifer Levin at a Manhattan bar, testified yesterday that he did not recall seeing Mr. Chambers or Miss Levin intoxicated that night.

title: Patricia Anne Hoffman Friedman Modern-Furniture Manufacturer
description: Patricia Anne Hoffman Friedman, executive vice president and a partner in International Contract Furnishings, an importer and manufacturer of modern office and residential furniture, died of cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital. She was 44 years old.

title: Vacancy Rate Shows a Dip
description: National office va= cancy rates fell in 1987, the first decline in six years, according to a study by Coldwell Banker Commercial Group, a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Checking Art Against Life
description: Delegates from the make-believe world of the theater and a real-life former delegate from the world of nuclear arms negotiations faced each other in an unusual encounter a few mornings ago during a rehearsal of ''A Walk in the Woods.'' To their mutual delight, they discovered they were not far apart at all in their instincts and perceptions about what really happened in Geneva in 1982 and what will be presented on the Broadway stage in 1988.

title: STATEWIDE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
34 Treated After a Chemical Is Sprayed in Subway Station
description: At least 34 people were treated for eye and respiratory injuries after being sprayed with a Mace-like chemical on a subway platform during last evening's rush period, officials said.

title: Congressmen Claim an Accord With Hanoi to Resettle Amerasians
description: Vietnam and the United States have agreed to move thousands of children of American servicemen and the children's immediate relatives to America within two years, two Congressmen said here today.

title: UNION NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
