In the latest fourth quarter, First Options of Chicago Inc. wroted off $90 million of receivables and provided an additional $9 million for potential losses as a result of extreme volatility in the fianancial markets during October.

title: Arafat Is Ready
description: To the Editor:

title: Role of Child's Sex In Divorce
description: Sexism plays a role even in divorces, with the parents of sons less likely to separate than the parents of daughters, according to a new study.

title: Advertising; New Fashion Magazine Fills Its Editor Post
description: Gay Bryant, former editor of Family Circle, is now editor of Model, a fashion and beauty magazine for a younger crowd that will make its debut in June as a joint venture between Family Media and Times Mirror Magazines, with Family Media managing the show.

title: Music: Chamber Society
description: THE novelty on this week's program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, heard Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, is a bristling, scherzo-like essay for clarinet, horn, piano and string trio by Peter Lieberson. The title is ''Ziji,'' a Tibetan term associated by Mr. Lieberson with the ''the energy of confidence,'' according to the program notes.

title: New Baseball Grievance
description: The dispute between baseball players and owners over the owners' treatment of free agents reached the point yesterday where they could not tell the conspiracy cases without a scorecard. The Players Association filed a grievance creating Conspiracy Case III.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Close Sweatshops, Open Jobs
description: Mass production of ready-made clothes started a century ago in New York City's old tenement ''sweatshops.'' In the wake of tragic fires, business shifted to fireproof elevator factories shoehorned into mid-Manhattan. Now, suddenly, sweatshops are reappearing in apartment basements all over the city. Clothing manufacturers seek to exploit Dominican, Chinese and Korean arrivals. The state Labor Department laudably works to discourage sweatshops. But that's only half the job. Though the modern sweatshop hardly revives Jacob Riis's mordant tenement scenes, it remains dangerous. Oil-fired steam boilers for pressing finished garments, basement locations from which escape is difficult, too few or blocked fire exits, unsupervised hotplate cooking, storage of flammable supplies - all raise the threat of fire that endangers workers downstairs and apartment tenants upstairs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article in some editions yesterday about Madonna's planned stage debut misstated the role she is to play in David Mamet's new play ''Speed-the-Plow'' at Lincoln Center.

title: Kastellaun Journal; If Missiles Go, Will Rebels Be Without a Cause?
description: Sweeping her hand over the frozen, wind-swept field, Beate Ronnefeldt tried to evoke the moment almost four years earlier when a quarter of a million people gathered there with signs and songs, united in passionate opposition to the new cruise missiles being deployed behind the forest line and barbed wire.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Janice Raskin, Singer On Radio, Dies at 77
description: Janice Raskin, a singer who performed on radio programs, died of colon cancer yesterday at a nursing home in Del Mar, Calif. She was 77 years old.

title: Skulls Appear On the Frontier Of Urban Design
description: HERE in the urban badlands where the briefcase buckaroos dwell, an icon for the 1980's is beginning to burn a trail across the changeable frontiers of decorating.

title: Personal Health
description: The lineup of dental products in drugstores is becoming as dazzling as the cereal aisle in a supermarket. Fifty dentrifices, a score of mouth rinses and dozens of mechanical devices greet the shopper eager to have sweet-smelling breath, no cavities and, above all, no tartar or plaque.

title: The Greatest Tragedy
description: It couldn't have happened at a more appropriate time than the eve of the Martin Luther King birthday observances: Jimmy Snyder, a sports tipster known also as The Greek, was fired from his television job for a number of remarks claiming that blacks had been bred since the Civil War to be better athletes than whites.

title: Alan Patricof Sets Deal to Sell Details
description: Advance Publications, the magazine company that owns The New Yorker, has agreed to acquire Details, the avant-garde fashion magazine, from Alan Patricof, head of Alan Patricof Associates, which is a venture capital group, and a group of investors. S. I. Newhouse Jr., whose family owns Conde Nast Publications Inc., is chairman of Advance. Conde Nast owns numerous fashion magazines including Vogue, Glamour and Mademoiselle.

title: Advertising; Shaffer Clarke Signs With a New Agency
description: Roman & Tannenholz has become the agency for Shaffer Clarke & Company, a subsidiary of Britain's U. B. Holdings P.L.C. The budget should be around $1.5 million, according to the agency. And that is more than has been spent recently through Maged & Behar.

title: Metro Matters; Today's Outrage May Inspire Tomorrow's Vote
description: Two demonstrations are planned in New York City today - one to register outrage through civil disobedience and another to persuade outraged people to register to vote.

The per share earnings in the year- ago periods reflect a 25 percent stock split paid in June 1987, and year-ago figures reflect the acquisitions of Bank of Barrow, First Bank of Conyers and Heritage Bank, accounted for as poolings of interest.

title: Dance: Jazzdance Troupe, With Danny Buraczeski
description: DANNY BURACZESKI has hit the jackpot with the new choreography his jazz dance company will be presenting this week. There is a haunting piece of interplay between Willie Ruff, the master French horn player, and Mr. Buraczeski; a surprisingly effective work about victims of Argentina's recent military dictatorship; and an abstract bluesy piece with a sophisticated commissioned score.

description: Latest quarter had 16 weeks, and 6 months, 28 weeks. The company said its earnings for the latest quarter were favorably affected by a lower LIFO charge and the statutory reduction in its tax rate.

title: View From the Canvas: Losers Rate Tyson
description: Since he knocked out Trevor Berbick for the World Boxing Council title in November 1986, Mike Tyson has been a busy fighter.

description: In the battle to stem the growing epidemic of osteoporosis and bone fractures, researchers are looking for alternative therapies to halt the rapid loss of bone that occurs in the first few years after a woman reaches menopause.

description: b-Net income The latest periods' losses are after loan loss provisions of $47,162,000 for the quarter and $167,878,000 for the year. The year-ago periods are after loan loss provisions of $17,474,000 for the quarter and $63,277,000 for the year.

title: Stanadyne Board Rebuffs Emhart
description: The board of Stanadyne Inc. formally rejected the $40-a-share bid from the Emhart Corporation, as ''inadequate and not in the best interests of stockholders,'' and authorized the management to ''explore alternatives for maximizing shareholder value.''

title: Two Fords Discuss Goals
description: Edsel B. Ford and William Clay Ford Jr. say they want to be treated like any other mid-level executives at the Ford Motor Company.

title: Protest Leader: Did He Inform?
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, a Brooklyn minister who has frequently organized displays of civil disobedience by blacks, has cooperated in at least one Federal investigation of black community groups, Government sources said.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Marino to Have Surgery
description: Dan Marino, quarterback of the Miami Dolphins, said yesterday that he would undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee and miss the Pro Bowl game on Feb. 7 in Honolulu. The Dolphins said they expected Marino to recover quickly.

title: NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year loss reflects the second quarter addition of $204 million to the allowance for credit losses related to international loan exposures.

title: KEY RATES

THE BASIC SPEECH;
Bid for New Leadership To Meet Moral Deficit
description: LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: Doctor and Patient; Physicians May Bungle Key Part of Treatment: The Medical Interview
description: The physicians' art, so often reflected in the ability to communicate with patients through an interview, is in trouble, according to researchers who are bringing light to this traditionally private corner of medicine.

title: Youths Finding Success Elusive Without College
description: American youths who do not go to college are as eager to succeed in the work force as their college-bound peers, but they are facing increasing difficulties in finding good jobs, according to a report released today.

title: WOBURN FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Al Hall, Jazz Bassist, Dies at 72; Broke Color Barrier on Broadway
description: Al Hall, a jazz bassist believed to be the first black musician in a Broadway theater orchestra, died of lung cancer Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect the 2-for-1 stock split in May 1987.

title: ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Arias Is Critical of Nicaragua for Detaining Foes
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez strongly criticized Nicaragua's ruling Sandinista Party on Tuesday night for arresting opposition political leaders. The Costa Rican leader said the arrests were not in accord with the pledges Nicaragua made in the Central American peace treaty.

title: Belgique Issues Much Of Disputed New Stock
description: Societe Generale de Belgique, the vast holding company resisting an attempt by the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti to build a substantial stake in Belgium, disclosed today that it had proceeded with its plan to issue at least 12 million shares of new stock.

title: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter includes a special provision of $10 million for additions to the company's loan loss reserves. The latest year includes additions to the company's loan loss reserves of $10 million in the fourth quarter and $20 million in the second quarter.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture on Jan. 2 with a review of the New York Philharmonic's Dec. 31 concert was published in error. The picture, distributed by the orchestra last month, showed the New Year's Eve concert of 1984. It was reissued to publicize Zubin Mehta and Kathleen Battle, who were once again appearing with the orchestra on the holiday, but it was imprecisely labeled.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Business People column yesterday omitted the effective date for Morris Tabaksblat's new duties at Unilever N.V. as regional director for North America and chairman of its Lever Brothers Company. The date is May 4, when Gordon K. G. Stevens will retire.

title: Grounded Ship Stalls Carter and Hundreds
description: Former President Jimmy Carter and nearly 2,000 fellow passengers finally left on a Caribbean cruise today after being delayed nearly 24 hours by a grounded freighter that trapped their cruise liner in San Juan Harbor.

title: Super Bowl Notebook; Coaching Aides Begin Annual Scramble
description: This is scramble time for the National Football League's assistant coaches - Super Bowl season is when heads roll. And for the assistants on the Broncos and Redskins, the courtship is on. When there are openings for a head coach, the names of assistants on winning teams always surface.

title: Cuomo and Moynihan Fighting Over Who Lost Big U.S. Project
description: New York's highest officials, among them Governor Cuomo and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, are caught up in a bitter political dispute over who is to blame for what is widely viewed as the state's embarrassing fumbling in efforts to attract a $4.4 billion Federal project.

title: Housing Plan Approved In Yonkers Council Vote
description: The City Council took a step tonight that it had long avoided, voting to approve a plan for construction of 200 units of low-income housing in the largely white neighborhoods of east and north Yonkers.

title: HERS
description: WHEN I was small, my family sailed on the Chesapeake. Once, we ran aground. Erma was beaming. When she ran aground, she did so solidly.

title: Market Place; Analysts Term Rorer Attractive
description: WHEN the A. H. Robins Company agreed Tuesday afternoon to be acquired by the American Home Products Corporation, there was a notable difference in how Robins's two other suitors took the news.

title: Sports People; Olympic Director Quits
description: In an unexpected move, Harvey Schiller resigned yesterday as executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, less than three weeks after he succeeded George Miller in the position. Schiller returned to his former job as commissioner of the Southeastern Conference.

title:
A Year From Now, What Will Reagan's Legacy Be?;
He Rebuilt the Presidency
description: LEAD: When Ronald Reagan leaves Washington a year from now, perhaps the forecasts of his critics will have been borne out: The inflation, unemployment and interest rates could all be in double-digits, and the superpowers could verge on blowing up the world.

title: CITIZENS FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An obituary of Baron Philippe de Rothschild yesterday listed his survivors incompletely. They are his daughter, Baroness Philippine de Rothschild; three grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

title: Jazz Premiere Highlight Of Festival At Juilliard
description: The New York premiere of a work by the jazz saxophonist Ornette Coleman is to highlight the first concert in the Juilliard School's ''Focus! Festival'' that begins tonight at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. Five concerts in all are to be presented during the festival, which is free and runs through next Friday.

title: United Nations Journal; A Time to Slumber and a Time to Dream of Glory
description: From September to December every year, the United Nations stages its annual extravaganza at Turtle Bay.

title: Cellular Makes Bid
description: Cellular Communications Inc., based in New York, has begun an unsolicited tender offer for a majority holding in the American Cellular Network Corporation for $15.50 cash a share, or a total of $69.75 million. The bid was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. American Cellular builds and owns cellular telephone systems in the Middle Atlantic region from its headquarters in Pleasantville, N.J. The company had no comment on the offer. Cellular Communications operates similar phone systems, primarily in Ohio. The company said it would finance the bid through a $100 million credit agreement with a group of domestic and foreign banks.

title: Chauncey Eskridge, Lawyer for Dr. King
description: Chauncey Eskridge, once legal counsel for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and who was with Dr. King when he was assassinated, died Monday. Mr. Eskridge was 70 years old.

title: Curious Come For a Glimpse Of Dutchess
description: With a winning smile and a friendly wave to her admirers, the Duchess of York, known to most of the world as ''Fergie,'' made her first official visit to New York City last night for a fund-raising performance of Andrew Lloyd Weber's ''The Phantom of the Opera'' benefitting three charities.

title: The Paper Bag Players: Still Zany
description: FIRST, it was ''Cut-Ups.''

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes one-time gains totaling 89 cents a share from the sale of the company's investments in Stone Container Corp. and U.S. Plywood Corp.

title: TV Weekend; 'Murder of Mary Phagan,' on NBC
description: PERHAPS it's just coincidence, but the subject of anti-Semitism is unusally prominent in television movies these days. A couple of weeks ago, ABC's ''Evil in Clear River'' dealt with the fact-based story of a neo-Nazi in rural Canada. On Home Box Office, ''Into the Homeland'' takes a look at white-supremacist hate groups in this country. And now, on Sunday at 8:30 P.M., NBC will begin to unfold the five-hour production of ''The Murder of Mary Phagan,'' which returns to 1913-14 for a review of the notorious Leo Frank trial and its tragic aftermath. The case was finally solved only a few years ago when a witness, only a boy at the time of the murder, came forward to reveal what really happened.

title: Profit at Recovering BankAmerica
description: In a further sign that it is recovering from several years of losses caused mainly by bad loans, the BankAmerica Corporation today reported a fourth-quarter net income of $60 million, or 27 cents a share.

title: BANK OF BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss included a pre-tax charge of $200 million related to Third World debt. The latest year net included the $200 million fourth quarter provision plus an additional $300 million provision for Third World debt taken during the first 6 months.

title: Dance: Ice Capades, Torvill and Dean
description: THE way to remember Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean, ice dancers par excellence, is in lonely splendor on a huge and empty rink. Seemingly isolated from the thousands watching them, they skate together wrapped, so to speak, in a rapt encounter.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article from Washington on Wednesday cited a study showing that Pat Robertson's Presidential campaign paid more than $4 million to three consulting companies in the first nine months of 1987. The article noted that under Federal law, consultants in turn can hire subcontractors in a way that lets a candidate avoid disclosing precisely how the money is spent.

title: Grumman Appoints New Chief Executive
description: The Grumman Corporation yesterday named John O'Brien, the aerospace company's president since mid-1986, to be its new chief executive.

title: GREAT LAKES BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $600,000.

title: A Year From Now, What Will Reagan's Legacy Be?; 'Greed Isn't Enough'
description: Almost a year hence, President Reagan will leave the White House.

title: Immigrant Girl's Dream of Attending West Point Hangs in the Balance
description: On an unpaved street in the poorest section of the city, in a tiny house whose front stoop has long since sunk into the dirt, lives a high school senior who wants to escape to the Military Academy at West Point.

title: Bad Finishes Sink Islanders and Devils; Whalers 4, Islanders 3
description: They were hardly trounced by Hartford tonight, but the Islanders, who traveled here hoping to smother a two-game losing streak, went away very unhappy.

title: Soviet Looks at Lenin's Executed Comrades
description: Soviet publications and films used the anniversary of Lenin's death today to call attention to his contemporaries who were executed under Stalin.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $10.8 million, or 15 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change to adjust deferred income taxes on the balance sheet to reflect reduced tax rates under the Tax Reform Act of 1986; the adjustment has been retroactively included in first quarter 1987 operating results. c-Includes a business disposition and consolidation which generated a pre-tax gain of $12.8 million, or 10 cents a share, after tax. The sales for both year-ago periods included $33.2 million related to the company's central heating and cooling business which was sold in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: Sports People; Million-Vote Players
description: When the fans' ballots had been counted, Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls and Earvin (Magic) Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers were the only players to draw more than a million votes each for the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game Feb. 7 in Chicago. Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics was named a starter for the ninth time in nine seasons.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Music: Joshua Ensemble
description: WHATEVER idea was behind the Joshua Chamber Orchestra's evening at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday, it was not a good one. Two young performers from South Korea - Jeong Soo Kim and Hae Kyung Lee - were its stars, and the music was Prokofiev's ''Classical'' Symphony, Mozart's ''Jupiter'' and the Beethoven Piano Concerto in G. If meant as a showcase for a young conductor and pianist respectively, this concert did its best to make things hard for them. First was the choice of music - three of the most exposed and picked-over pieces in the repertory. Second was the Joshua Chamber Orchestra, apparently an orchestra of local freelancers who -though not untalented individually -seemed only passingly acquainted with one another.

title: Austria Opens a Flood of Wartime Memories
description: The first major event of Austria's Year of Reflection had barely begun on Jan. 6 when anti-Semitic leaflets and words of hate rained down on the audience.

title: Manila Defense Chief Quits And Ramos Is Named to Job
description: President Corazon C. Aquino accepted the protest resignation of Defense Secretary Rafael M. Ileto today and said she would nominate the armed forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, to replace him.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The loss in 1987 reflected the second quarter $1.1 billion addition to the allowance for credit losses relating to developing countries.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $8,000,000 and $26,554,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the quarter also includes a gain of about $8 million on the sale of the company's land development business. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $10,986,000 and $23,824,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also includes an after-tax writedown of $118 million in the book value of its oil and gas properties.

title: A Family Quarrel on Wall St.: Kidder vs. G.E.
description: Nothing irritates investment bankers more than losing a shot at the huge fees they can earn for arranging major corporate deals. And when the investment banking firm's own parent is the one that snatches the deal away, tempers can flare.

title: Gould to Sell Unit To Westinghouse
description: Gould Inc., a maker of electronic products and systems that is getting out of the military business, announced today that it had agreed to sell its antisubmarine warfare operation for a sharply lower price than it had originally intended.

title: KENNEDY CHEERED ON STUMP IN IOWA
description: His face was familiar to everyone, and so were the deep voice and the broad Massachusetts accent. And the name, after all these years, was still magic.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Down 23.1% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Jan. 15 decreased from the previous month by 114.2 million shares, or 23.1 percent, to 380.4 million.

title: B.A.T. Seeks Talks
description: A day after its $4.2 billion takeover bid for the insurer Farmers Group Inc. was rejected, a subsidiary of Britain-based B.A.T. Industries indicated it might be willing to raise its offer. Henry Frigon, president of Batus Inc., based in Louisville, Ky., urged Farmers' directors to meet with B.A.T. officials, adding that the company is ready to discuss all terms of its proposal. Batus offered $60 a share for the 70 million shares outstanding in Farmers, the nation's seventh-largest insurer. Analysts have estimated the company could attract $75 to $80 a share. The stock closed today at $57.25 a share, up $1.25 and up from $44 when Batus began its overtures on Jan. 13.

title: On Stage
description: Fierstein Says No Roller Skaters

title: Dow Registers Tiny Gain, to 1,879.31
description: Stock prices edged slightly higher yesterday in moderate trading.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $4,113,000 from the effect of an accounting change. c-Net loss and after a tax credit of $1,007,000.

title: Texas Court Fight Puts Focus on Elected Judges
description: In some ways it looks like a quintessential Texas battle royal played against a background of big money, big egos and big stakes, with the largest court judgement in the nation's history serving as a juicy subplot.

title: U.S. Bonds Advance on Japan Report
description: Treasury bond prices rose nearly a point yesterday in response to a report that the Bank of Japan was considering a large increase in its buying of longer-term Treasury issues.

title: 7 TV Stations Focus on Candidates' Character
description: In an unusual alliance cutting across network boundaries, seven local television stations have joined forces to produce profiles of the 1988 Presidential candidates that focus on the character issue that has dominated the campaign.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 22, 1988
description: Companies

title: CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: Dole Makes Nice

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter net included a loan loss provision of $19 million for less developed countries and a gain of $35 million from the sale of a building. The latest year included a loan loss provision of $88 million.

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $7 million of pretax gains from the sale of tuna boats. c-Includes an after-tax gain on the sale of the domestic agricultural products business of $209,300,000, or $2.78 a share. The company said the year-ago first quarter includes the operating results of the Drake Bakeries Inc. unit, sold in August.

title: Genscher Urges Arms Cuts
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany urged President Reagan today to press for the elimination of chemical weapons and for reductions of battlefield nuclear weapons in Europe. Administration officials said that cuts in battlefield nuclear weapons with ranges under 300 miles was a low arms-control priority and that there would be little progress on the chemical arms issue until the United States can verify the destruction of the weapons. Mr. Genscher is visiting Washington as a representative of the European Community.

title: EASTERN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Restaurants
description: THE palatial home of the former Quo Vadis restaurant on East 63d Street was beginning to get the reputation of being cursed.

title: BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Super Bowl XXII; Broncos Recall Turning Point
description: For winners, there's always a turning point: the moment when a team sees itself, hitches up its pants, stops losing and gets to the Super Bowl.

title: Advisory Panel For Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange plans to form a pension manager advisory committee after its next board meeting, which is scheduled for Feb. 4.

title:
About Real Estate;
A Middle-Income Project in Bayswater
description: LEAD: When the Trust for Public Land received a gift of 13.5 acres in the Bayswater section of the Rockaways in 1983, the nonprofit group, which seeks to preserve land for the public's use, hoped the city would buy the property for parkland. The city was not interested, however.

title: WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $103,000 and $263,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,313,000 and $1,510,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for the year-ago periods are restated to reflect the acquisition of Faraday Electronics Inc., accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Argentines Report Infection by Altered Farm Virus
description: Officials in Argentina have concluded that several farm workers there inadvertently became infected with a genetically altered virus that had been injectd into cattle as an experimental vaccine against rabies, according to press accounts and an American critic of the biotechnology industry.

title: NCR Chairman Gives Up His Position as President
description: The NCR Corporation said yesterday that it had named Gilbert P. Williamson president.

title: Witness Says Levin Was 'Physically Assertive'
description: A witness described Jennifer Levin yesterday as a ''physically assertive'' young woman who ''went after what she wanted,'' and who went to an Upper East Side bar on Aug. 25, 1986, determined to spend the night with Robert E. Chambers Jr. The witness, Larissa Thomson, a 20-year-old college student testifying in Mr. Chambers's murder trial at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, told the court that on the night of Miss Levin's death, she repeatedly mentioned wanting to go home with Mr. Chambers, whom she had dated in the past.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from the early extinguishment of debt of $2,054,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6-month also includes a gain of $2,151,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: AFFILIATED BANKSHARES OF COLOADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Convening of U.S. Judges Is Termed Extraordinary
description: Lawyers and legal scholars said the convening of Federal district judges in Brooklyn in an ''en banc,'' or ''entire bench,'' panel yesterday was exceptionally unusual.

title: Film: 'Promised Land'
description: ''PROMISED LAND'' tries hard to win you over but finally wears you down with its sincerity. Michael Hoffman, the writer and director, seems determined to inject freshness into the old story about graduating seniors who discover life is hard after high school, but he transforms his best ideas and images into bludgeons. Nothing that follows is quite so ponderous as the opening sequence, though, a basketball game in the small Utah town of Ashville - a winning basket in slow motion, choral music in the background, the camera picking out each major character in close-up. They are called Davey and Mary and Danny, but are such types their names are superfluous. The basketball hero dates the cheerleader; the shy misfit wants to belong but can't.

title: Skin Cream Seems to Reverse Some Harmful Effects of Sun
description: A small study has found that a prescription cream containing a chemical cousin of vitamin A appears capable of reversing some of the damaging effects that sunlight has on skin.

title: Surge in AIDS Cases in Congo Could Be an Omen for africa
description: Jean-Marie Matsiona, a 38-year-old oil tanker navigator, is one of the one million Africans expected to die of AIDS in the next decade.

title: When Students Take On Real-World Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Village Invites Change But Finds It Scary, Too
description: When Dee Staffa moved here three years ago, she formed a close bond with St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, both as a parishioner and as a volunteer religion teacher.

title: 500 March in Brooklyn Over Racism
description: In a carefully choreographed and controlled rally that highlighted the growing frustration among blacks over drugs, almost 500 demonstrators marched yesterday along a circuitous route through some of Brooklyn's most drug- and crime-ridden communties.

title: F.A.A. Seeks Seasoned Pilot in Cockpit
description: Pressing for increased airline safety, the Federal Aviation Administration urged today that two ''relatively inexperienced'' pilots not be assigned to the same flight, and it also ordered a tightening of maintenance rules.

title: U.S. Warns Japan Not to Kill Whales in Antarctic
description: The Reagan Administration has warned Japan that it would be breaking an international agreement if a Japanese whaling fleet now approaching the Antarctic fisheries killed even a single whale, Government officials said today.

title: ARCO CHEMICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings were not available because ARCO Chemical went public in October 1987. The latest quarter and year results are after an after-tax charge of $10 million for estimated future environmental clean-up costs, and include after-tax foreign exchange gains of $9 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page last Saturday about radar detectors incorrectly described some applications issued by Geico. Those distributed with mail solicitations specify that Geico does not insure vehicles equipped with radar detectors; all other applications do not.

title: BRANDYWINE SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $93,000. The company converted to stock ownership in June 1987.

title: DIC Deal Opposed
description: Two shareholders of Computer Memories Inc. said they opposed a proposed merger between the computer equipment maker and the cartoon maker DIC Animation City Inc. of Burbank, Calif., and intended to seek control of the company. Paul and Natalie Koether of Far Hills, N.J., said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that they had increased their interest to 9.7 percent of Computer Memories, based in Chatsworth, Calif. The Koethers said they had an agreement to buy 1.7 million shares of Computer Memories from the Intel Corporation, which would raise their stake to 25 percent. Computer Memories has first claim to Intel's shares, but the company is still considering whether to purchase them.

title: Hartford Director Plans O'Neill Play in Moscow
description: Mark Lamos, artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company, will direct Eugene O'Neill's ''Desire Under the Elms'' in Russian at the Pushkin Theater in Moscow. Rehearsals begin there on Feb. 18.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7.6 million for the quarter and $4.4 million for the 9 months. The year-ago periods' nets included special items that increased net income by $10.6 million.

description: ''Keep thou the napkin and go boast of this.'' - ''Henry VI, Part III.''

title: Science Talent Search Names 13 Winners From New York
description: Thirteen students from 6 New York City high schools were among the 40 national winners of this year's Westinghouse Science Talent Search announced yesterday.

title: Case of Unwritten Decorum
description: It was mid-December, at two simultaneous Christmas parties in a downtown hotel here, when a chance meeting between a lawyer and a justice of the Virginia Supreme Court became a historic encounter that has just been resolved in a special hearing.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK OF PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on pension plan liquidation of $2.1 million. The thrift converted to stock ownership early in 1987.

title: LAKE SHORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Polish Workers Get Cash to Offset Price Rise
description: Facing heavy pressure from officially sanctioned trade unions, the Government said today that it would triple cash payments promised to workers this year to offset planned consumer price increases.

description: The head of the Vietnamese Communist Party suggested today that Vietnam, ''a backward agricultural country,'' could learn lessons from the capitalist world.

title: Jimmy Witherspoon
description: Jimmy Witherspoon, the blues and jazz singer, will perform tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Auctions
description: Offbeat Furniture

title: ENVISIONING THE SHOW'S HEAVY ARTILLERY
description: IT so happens that I live down the block from the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 66th Street. For much of the year, I am aware of it as a thickset and bloodshot presence somewhere over my left shoulder. In my dreams, ensigns straight out of Walt Whitman and sharpshooters straight out of Winslow Homer troop in and out of it. Tattoos are beaten on Civil War drums. On a quiet city night, like the one made famous in music by Aaron Copland, taps can be heard as the soldiery go to their night's rest.

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $23,900,000 related to the retirement of debt. c-Includes net gain of $138,200,000 from the combined effect of a real estate and other special items for the quarter, and the year is after an extraordinary charge of $9,900,000 related to the retirement of debt.

title: INSIDE
description: Vietnam and Capitalism

title: Diner's Journal
description: UPDATE on Dominick's, the pint-size, wildly popular Italian institution on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx: At 3 P.M. on a Sunday, customers were lined up in the foyer while inside gleeful diners, packed tighter than a jar of Italian peppers, were digging into oval platters of homemade lasagna, stuffed shells, ziti in red sauce, bresaola, pork chops and more. This 33-year-old family-run restaurant has expanded slightly in the last few years by moving the kitchen farther back, allowing for about a half-dozen more communal tables.

title: Fed Urged Caution on Reserves
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York told the leading New York banks last month that it did not necessarily want them to increase reserves against their loans to third-world countries, despite sharp increases in such reserves by some large regional banks.
