description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Toronto, said it was negotiating to form a partnership with the Canadian investment dealer Wood Gundy Inc.

title: City Ballet: 'Jewels'
description: LOOKED at one way, George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' could be called a three-act abstract ballet in which each act evokes qualities associated with a particular jewel. Looked at another way, it could be argued that ''Jewels'' is not a three-act ballet at all, but three one-act ballets, for each of its parts is self-contained and has music by a different composer.

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains from restructuring of $10 million for the quarter and $18 million for the year. c-Included a gain of $22 million from restructuring. d-Included gains of $131 million from the sale of chemical assets and charges of $46 million from the writedown of electronics business resulting in a gain of $85 million.

title: College Basketball; Duke Upsets North Carolina
description: Danny Ferry hit a free throw with 52 seconds left tonight and second-ranked North Carolina missed two chances to win in the final 16 seconds as No. 9 Duke beat the Tar Heels, 70-69.

title: AHMANSON, H F & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes after-tax gains on loan sales of $16 million and $83.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a charge of $16.5 million from the writeoff of the company's $24 million investment in the Federal Savings & Loan Insurance Corp. secondary reserve taken in the second quarter.

title: Panel to Study Racial Fairness of New York Courts
description: The Chief Judge of New York named a 16-member commission yesterday to examine whether minority groups are fairly served by the state's courts.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
From Dispute, Aid to Neediest
description: A threatening encounter at the Port Authority Bus Terminal inspired Lorraine Shanley to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CULLEN-FROST BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Assails Ethiopia Rebel Raid
description: The cargo of a commercial convoy attacked by rebel forces in northern Ethiopia last week included 176 tons of relief food being sent to drought victims, the State Department said today.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Wants To Resume Japan Talks
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to resume promptly negotiations with Japan on opening Japanese public works contracts to foreign construction companies.

title: E-II Holdings Gets Offer From American Brands
description: Worried about a possible takeover by E-II Holdings Inc., American Brands Inc. turned the tables last night and announced plans to spend nearly $2.4 billion to buy E-II, the Chicago-based offshoot of the Beatrice Companies.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FAMILY ROMANCE OF THE IMPOSTOR-POET THOMAS CHATTERTON. By Louise J. Kaplan. 301 pages.

title: Sports of The Times; Holmes, Ali and Tyson
description: EVER since Larry Holmes agreed to take $3.1 million for taking Mike Tyson's punches, he has been a different Larry Holmes, a hermit in a stylish sweatsuit. He trained in his own quiet gym in Easton, Pa. He hardly talked to sportswriters. He didn't arrive in Atlantic City until 48 hours before he will try to dethrone Tyson as the world heavyweight champion. This isn't the same Larry Holmes who reigned as the undefeated champion for more than seven years, who enjoyed the stage of his workouts, who played blackjack in the Las Vegas casinos, who sat in the coffee shop telling stories.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If there is no vaccine, it will be like a war for us.'' - Pierre Mpele, secretary of Congo's Committee to Combat AIDS. [ A1:5. ]

title: 27 Pit Bulls Are Put to Death
description: Twenty-seven pit bull dogs seized in a raid last month were put to death today after a judge ruled they had been trained for violence. The dogs belonged to a couple who face cocaine-trafficking charges. Judge William Green said he issued the order because ''these animals have been bred and trained for no purpose other than to viciously attack other animals.''

title: PINNACLE WEST CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes about $18.5 million, or 22 cents a share, for the effect of an accounting change at the company's Arizona Public Service Co. unit.

title: Konstantin A. Andrianov, Olympics Delegate, 78
description: Konstantin A. Andrianov, a member of the International Olympic Committee and the first Soviet representative to that organization, has died, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. He was 78 years old.

title: Bad Finishes Sink Islanders and Devils; Red Wings 3, Devils 2
description: Sam St. Laurent, a goaltender the Devils traded to Detroit two summers ago, helped drop New Jersey below the .500 mark for the first time this season as he made 27 saves tonight for the Red Wings, who beat the Devils, 3-2. Brent Ashton's second goal of the game, scored 3 minutes 37 seconds into overtime, was the difference.

title: Washington Talk: Pentagon; Cost-Cutter's Target: Secret Bomber
description: There are a few people left at the Pentagon who still think it's possible to turn the place around on a dime, or preferably a nickel.

title: CARDINAL FEDERAL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $110,000 of after-tax investment gains. The year-ago per share earnings are not available; the bank converted to a stock savings institution in March.

title: Airbus Would Like U.S. Assembly Line
description: Airbus Industrie, the European airplane consortium that captured nearly 25 percent of the world market for new jetliners in 1986, wants to set up an assembly line in the United States with an American aerospace company as a partner, a senior executive said. Adam Brown, vice president for group strategy, said in an interview that Airbus needed to increase production because of a backlog of orders for its A320 jet, which has been bought by several United States carriers.

title: 2 Concerts at St. Ann's Offer Bach Cantatas
description: The first of two concerts featuring Bach cantatas is to be presented by an ensemble with choir and soloists on Sunday at 4 P.M. at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn Heights.

title: Robert Todd, 90, Dies; World War I Ace Pilot
description: Robert Todd, one of the few remaining World War I flying aces, died Wednesday of pneumonia at the Veterans Administration Center in La Jolla, hospital officials said. He was 90 years old.

title: Sugar Traders Are Betting On Long-Term Price Rise
description: Traders in world sugar futures, which are at their highest price level in five years, again rolled forward positions yesterday in expectation of still higher prices later this year and next.

title: AMERICAN PRESIDENT COS reports earnings for 14wks to Dec 25
Leland C. Wyman, Authority on Navajos, 90
description: Leland C. Wyman, a scholar in physiology and anthropology who was a leading authority on the culture and history of the Navajo Indians, died here Jan. 13. He was 90 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: TEXACO CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Murdoch Moves to Avoid Shutting Post
description: Rupert Murdoch moved on several fronts yesterday to avoid shutting down The New York Post in six weeks.

title: Rock Slide Kills Passenger On Thruway in Westchester
description: A boulder, unleashed by a rock slide, struck a car traveling south on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Westchester County yesterday afternoon, crushing a passenger to death and injuring the driver.

title: STANDARD FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of about $10.6 million. c-After tax credits of about $4.6 million for the quarter and about $53.2 million for the year. The per share earnings do not apply to the 1986 periods because the company went public in January 1987.

title: US BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $7,695,000 loss from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for loan fees and a $16,529,000 gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. Results from Old National Bancorp. are included since its acquisition July 1. Results from Peoples Bancorp. are included for all periods since the acquisition was a stock transaction and accounted for a a pooling of interests. U.S. Bancorp said its latest quarter included $7,830,000 in pre-tax costs associated with the Peoples merger.

title: UNI-MARTS INC reports earnings for Sales
WLIB: Radio 'Heartbeat' of Black Life
description: When the Rev. Al Sharpton was being besieged Wednesday by reporters for his response to a newspaper report that he was a Federal informant, he chose to speak first to a reporter from WLIB, a New York City radio station that he calls ''the heartbeat of the black community.''

title: In an $880,000 School Program, $300,000 for Custodians
description: A special after-school program run by the Board of Education and designed to relieveracial friction among students spent one-third of its budget on fees for school custodians who kept the school buildings open at night.

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits; the amount of the extraordinary tax credits were not available. c-Includes a $15 million charge taken for research and development expenses related to a payment to be made to Fujitsu Ltd. for Amdahl's share of joint development work for future products.

title: OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter included a gain of $12 million, or 27 cents a share, for the recalculation of the gain associated with the sale of the company's aerospace and strategic materials group, and a charge of $1 million resulting from the redemption of debt. SThe year-ago fourth quarter was adversely affected by a U.S. income tax provision of $12 million on undistributed earnings from foreign operations. The year-ago quarter sales included operations subsequently discontinued or divested in the company's restructuring. The latest year included a third quarter extraordinary charge of $5 million from the purchase of subordinated debt; a second quarter charge of $14 million related to the termination of a bank credit facility, and a first quarter gain of $83 million, or $2.01 a share, from the sale of the aerospace and strategic materials group. The year-ago period's results included a $200 million pre-tax restructuring charge.

title: Righetti Ready to Sign
description: The Yankees and Dave Righetti have resolved their dispute over the timing of a physical examination, and Righetti is expected to sign his three-year, $4.3 million agreement in New York today, Bill Goodstein, the pitcher's agent, said yesterday.

title: At the Movies
description: Drop in the Bucket

title: Mecham's New Worry: Lasers
description: As he faces criminal charges and possible recall or impeachment, Gov. Evan Mecham of Arizona says he has yet another worry: someone may be eavesdropping on him with laser beams.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Israel's New Violent Tactic Takes Toll on Both Sides
description: The Israeli Army was reported today to be sending teams of psychologists to units in the Gaza Strip because it was worried about the effect of a new crackdown on the mental health of the troops.

title: Yevgeny Mravinsky, Conductor, 81
description: Yevgeny Mravinsky, who became the chief conductor of the Leningrad Philharmonic Orchestra in 1938, has died of a heart attack, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. He was 81 years old. Tass did not say when or where he died.

title: IRWIN UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Editorial Notebook; The Two Roerichs Are One
description: The gulf between politics and art can be seen in the gulf between two Nicholas Roerichs. Devotees of dance know one as the creator of the costumes and sets for the 1913 premiere of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring.'' A revival of that production was the sensation of the Joffrey Ballet's recent season, prompting a fine show at the Lincoln Center Library of Performing Arts.

title: THE LAW: At the Bar
description: Most people, accepting the maxim that everyone is entitled to his day in court, are willing to forgive a lawyer for his clients. Attorneys spend legal lifetimes representing drug dealers or Mafia kingpins or murderers, and remain invulnerable. Not so Jack T. Litman, the man representing Robert Chambers in the death of Jennifer Levin in Central Park.

title: Super Bowl XXII; Backing for Patriots Renewed
description: Emergency financing for the New England Patriots from the rest of the National Football League will continue, and so will negotiations to sell the franchise.

title: Surcharge Set For Car Owners In New Jersey
description: To prevent the collapse of the agency that insures more than half of New Jersey's 4 million motorists, all drivers will have to pay a surcharge averaging $66 for each car they own when they renew their insurance policies, the state's Insurance Commissioner said today.

title: A Good Quick Fix for Downtown Traffic
description: Governors Cuomo and Kean have agreed to set aside $50 million in Port Authority funds to relieve traffic congestion. New Jersey has decided to spend its $25 million on a new busway feeding into the Lincoln Tunnel. That suggests a sound use for New York's share: a downtown terminal for express buses from New Jersey and elsewhere.

title: Corrections
description: The restaurant review in Weekend last Friday gave an incorrect cross street for David K's. The restaurant, at 1115 Third Avenue, is near 65th Street.

title: MIDWEST FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNIFI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes a currency gain of $653,113 and $972,812 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a currency loss of $110,325 and $411,267 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Lottery Could Help Tracks
description: Officials from Florida's horse racing tracks held a news conference in Miami today under the funereal banner of ''Florida Horse Racing Is Facing Extinction.'' There is no such imminent threat, but the officials effectively painted a gloomy picture.

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Van Breda Kolff Ailing
description: Butch van Breda Kolff, Lafayette's basketball coach, suffered chest pains during a game last night against Drexel and was admitted to Easton (Pa.) Hospital. He was listed in stable condition after undergoing tests, according to a nursing supervisor who declined to provide further information.

title: Nofziger Letter Hinted at Reagan Help for Wedtech
description: Lyn Nofziger suggested that President Reagan could help persuade the Army to give the Wedtech Corporation a military contract, according to a letter produced Thursday at the former Presidential aide's trial.

title: GOOD SIGNS FOR TV INDEPENDENTS
description: In the last 18 months the nation's independent television stations have learned firsthand how tough life can become when the number of players in an industry grows too quickly.

title: PLAZA COMMERCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings for 1987 and 1986 are adjusted for the 10 percent common stock dividend paid by the company in December 1987.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas/Fort Worth Airport, a holding company, named Donald J. Carty senior vice president and chief financial officer, filling a vacancy left by John C. Pope, who left earlier this year to become executive vice president and chief financial officer of Allegis Corp., parent of United Airlines.

title: Protecting Jerusalem's Holy Places
description: LEAD: The clash between Palestinians and Israeli police around the Dome of the Rock mosque atop Temple Mount in Jerusalem must send foreboding through all who know history.

title: MERITOR FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Pan Am, in a Union Deal, Ousts 2 Top Executives
description: Bending to the pressure of a union coalition, the board of the Pan Am Corporation forced the resignation yesterday of its top two officers and three subordinates.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Soviet Seems Eager to Quit Afghan War
description: The Soviet and Afghan authorities did their best this week to create the impression that the end game of Moscow's military intervention in Afghanistan has begun.

title: Art: Works by 7 Women, 'Aspects of Abstraction'
description: IN ''Aspects of Abstraction,'' the Holly Solomon Gallery has put together the kind of exhibition with which it has not been identified. All seven artists are women. All are abstract painters for whom touch and process are important. All the paintings have an unapologetic, take-it-or-leave-it quality.

title: Dairy Board Awards 2 Jobs
description: After less than a year's absence the National Dairy Board is returning its Children's Milk Promotion program to McCann-Erickson in San Francisco, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings are about $6.5 million.

title: Film: 'Missing In Action III'
description: LAST week, the Living Dead returned. Again. This week, it's Chuck Norris. As Col. Jim Braddock, in ''Braddock: Missing in Action III,'' he returns to Vietnam to find his Vietnamese wife, who was unfortunately left behind at the fall of Saigon. On his prior trips, he rescued American prisoners of war; this time, he brings out a batch of Amerasian children, including the son he didn't know he had.

title: 16 Million Layoffs Foreseen By Soviet in Next 12 Years
description: About 16 million workers will be laid off by the year 2000 under Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for restructuring the Soviet economy, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.

title: ANCHOR SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $2.2 million for the quarter and $4.3 million for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $5.5 million for the quarter and $41.3 million for the 6 months. The tax credit for the year-ago 6 months included $32.2 million representing forgiveness of annual income payments by the FSLIC. The thrift converted to stock form April 1, 1987.

title: CRIME STUDY FINDS RECENT DRUG USE IN MOST ARRESTED
description: Half to three-fourths of the men arrested for serious crimes in 12 major cities tested positive for the recent use of illicit drugs, according to a study by the Justice Department.

title: U.S. to Submit Anti-Missile Treaty Draft
description: The United States has prepared a formal treaty to present in Geneva on anti-missile defense systems, Administration officials said today.

title: Stop and Shop To Study Offer
description: The Stop and Shop Companies, responding to an $834 million cash offer from the Dart Group Corporation, was noncommittal yesterday but said it would review the proposal. The Haft family of Landover, Md., which controls Dart, has long been rumored to be interested in acquiring Stop and Shop, and the Boston-based retailer has taken defensive measures. Robert M. Haft, Dart's president, said the earlier rumblings on Wall Street ''were simply rumors.''

title: Art People
description: Modern Modern

title: TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STUDY TRACES AIDS IN AFRICA CHILDREN
description: Nearly one in 15 Central African children receiving blood transfusions to combat malaria-related anemia may become infected with the AIDS virus as a result, a new study has found.

title: Manhattan Youth Shot in Subway Station
description: A 17-year-old Manhattan youth was shot in the leg yesterday afternoon during a dispute at the 34th Street station of the Seventh Avenue IRT subway line, a Transit Authority police spokesman said.

title: Our Towns; Thin Mint Alert: Super Girl Scout Is On the Loose
description: It's that time of year in the suburbs. The doorbell rings. You answer. At first you don't see anything. You look down and it's a lovely little girl with a million-dollar smile and maybe a ponytail to break your heart. You smile back - relieved it's not a religious pamphleteer, or even worse, a guy selling meat out of his trunk - and already you have made the fatal mistake. This is no little girl. It's a Girl Scout!

title: Kids 'R' Us Awarded To Scali, McCabe, Sloves
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, already the agency for Toys ''R'' Us, has now been tapped to create advertising for Kids ''R'' Us , a chain of 74 children's clothing stores in the Northeast that is a unit of the toy company.

title: ADAMS-RUSSELL ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
Australian Open; Wilander Accurate To Upset Edberg
description: Mats Wilander outlasted Stefan Edberg, the defending champion, 6-0, 6-7, 6-3, 3-6, 6-1, today to move into the men's final of the Australian Open Tennis Championships.

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $2,327,000 for the latest year and $1,168,000 for 1986.

title: In Rare Session, 9 U.S. Judges Convene to Review Mob Trial
description: Nine Federal judges from the Eastern District of New York were convened yesterday in a highly unusual formal court proceeding to decide issues arising from a mob trial now under way.

title: Dining Out Guide: Chinese
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AUNTIE YUAN, 1191A First Avenue, near 65th Street (744-4040) -

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Stage: 'Sally,' by Kern
description: JEROME KERN'S ''Sally'' was a major musical success in 1920, running for almost two seasons and establishing Marilyn Miller as one of Broadway's most popular stars. In contrast to other Kern hits, the show is seldom revived. For that reason, one might suppose that the New Amsterdam Theater Company is performing a service by presenting the quasi-concert version that began a five-performance engagement Wednesday at the New Academy Theater. However, as often happens with very old musicals - and some newer ones - one wonders why there was such initial enthusiasm.

title: Fordham Tops Iona With 28 by Parrotta
description: In recent years, whenever Fordham and Iona clashed on the basketball court, two things were virtually guaranteed: an intense atmosphere and an Iona victory.

title: Chain of Dry Cleaners Chooses Kirshenbaum
description: Kirshenbaum & Bond has become the first agency of Clean Street, a chain of dry cleaning establishments. The budget is about $1 million. Colgate-Palmolive recently acquired a majority interest in the chain, which is based in Great Neck, L.I. It now has 30 outlets and has hopes of expanding to 1,000 by 1993.

title: Mother Sentenced in Suicide
description: A woman convicted in connection with her daughter's suicide was sentenced today to a year in jail, two years of community control and three years of probation.

title: New Orleans Sound
description: Dr. John, the New Orleans pianist and singer, will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (242-1664), with G. C. Dangerous opening the show. Shows are scheduled for 9:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.

title: Cary Elliott Odell, Movie Art Director, 77
description: Cary Elliott Odell, a movie art director and three-time Academy Award nominee, died of cancer Tuesday. He was 77 years old.

title: Record British Spending
description: British consumers spent a record amount in 1987, estimated at $:170.7 billion, or about $305.5 billion, but the boom slowed almost to a halt after the stock market collapse, the Government said today. The Central Statistical Office said that in the last quarter of 1987, consumers spent only a little more than they did in the third quarter, despite the Christmas shopping.

title: Put the Stock Markets On a Cash-Only Basis
description: To the Editor:

title: Poetry of Britten's 'War Requiem' Inspires Dutoit
description: Belying its title, Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem'' is a cry for peace, and in this season of glasnost, Central American peace efforts and promises of troop withdrawals from Afghanistan, its choice for tomorrow's Carnegie Hall concert by the Orchestre Symphonique de Montreal seems very logical. But Charles Dutoit, the orchestra's music director, cheerfully insists he had no political statement in mind when he decided to do the work.

title: G.M. and China In Auto Deal
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it had reached an agreement to sell a used engine assembly line to the China National Automotive Industry Corporation and to cooperate with various Chinese agencies in developing an auto industry in that country.

title: Kenneth Harper, 48, Producer of 'The Wiz'
description: Kenneth G. Harper, who produced ''The Wiz'' on Broadway in 1975, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48 years old. The cause of death was cancer, said his mother, Mildred Harper.

title: G.E.'s Profits Increase 18.9%
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings climbed 18.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1987, buoyed by stronger performances from nearly all of its core businesses.

title: NBC News Explores Problem of the Homeless
description: Who are the homeless, and why are they on the streets? ''Home Street Home,'' an NBC News special, on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, offers a number of answers. That turns out to be its weakness. Drugs, alcohol, mental illness, post-Vietnam stress, a failing farm economy and an uncaring society are rolled up as one. We know we're supposed to be sympathetic to the homeless, but other than for reasons of common decency, we're never quite sure why.

title: Zimbabwe Emergency Stays
description: The Government extended its 13-year-old state of emergency for six months today, saying it needed to deal with threats from rebels. Parliament was told that South African-backed Mozambique National Resistance rebels were responsible for 101 incidents from July 12 to Jan. 4, including murders, abductions and the burning and ransacking of villages.

title: Film: Tony Bill's 'Five Corners,' With Foster
description: ''FIVE CORNERS,'' opening today at the Baronet and other theaters, is about coming of age in the Bronx in the autumn of 1964, when student activists were listening to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., young women were still doing their darnedest to look like Jacqueline Kennedy and glue-sniffing was an acceptable way to attain a high.

title: The Jazz Passengers
description: Roy Nathanson on saxophones and Curtis Fowlkes on trombone will lead the Jazz Passengers, tonight at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Admission is $6.

title: WILMINGTON TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VISTA CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $5,817,000.

title: UNION PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a third-quarter credit of $23 million. c-Net loss and includes net restructuring charges of $945 million. The company said that the acquisition of Overnite Transportation Co. has been accounted for as a purchase effective Nov. 1, 1986 and is fully consolidated in 1987. The equity method was used in 1986 because Interstate Commerce Commission approval was pending.

title: Joseph H. Ream, 84, A Former CBS Director
description: Joseph H. Ream, a former executive vice president and director of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of neurological complications from an aneurysm at the Mobile (Ala.) Infirmary Wednesday. He was 84 years old and lived in Fairhope, Ala.

title: Sports People; Snyder Defended
description: In a coincidenal twist to the Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder flap, Gene Upshaw, executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said yesterday in Washington that he was supposed to have dinner with Snyder last Friday night. Earlier in the day, Snyder made his remarks on blacks in sports that led to his dismissal last Saturday by CBS.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that in 1987 it had two tax-related accounting changes which resulted in one-time net earnings of about $700 million; these gains were more than offset by business restructuring provisions of about $750 million after taxes.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Administration Lowers Goals on Contra Aid
description: The Reagan Administration, acknowledging that Congressional opposition is intense and growing stronger, is planning to ask for significantly less aid for the Nicaraguan rebels than President Reagan had wanted.

title: Sports People; Incentive for Olympics
description: To get the best track and field performances for the Seoul Olympics, The Athletics Congress, the national governing body of the sport in the United States, announced that it would provide $400,000 to 26 Olympic hopefuls.

title: MCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss included a provision for possible loan losses of $52.6 million, which brought the provision for loan losses for the year to $282.6 million.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $5.1 million related to liquidation of a subsidiary and an after-tax gain of $3.4 million from the sale of certain operations. c-Net loss The company said year-ago fourth quarter includes a $3.2 million after- tax charge related to an environmental matter, and the full-year loss includes an after-tax restructuring provision of $90 million. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Sept. 30, 1987.

title: Piano, Bass and Drums
description: Jill McManus, a pianist, will lead a trio - with Ray Drummond on bass and Eliot Zigmund on drums - Sunday at 7 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street in the Citicorp Center (935-2200). Admission is $7.

title: Opera: 'Luisa Miller,' Season's First at Met
description: EXPECT nothing and you will never be disappointed. That bit of folk wisdom has been the safest shield to carry to the Metropolitan Opera on most evenings this season and certainly it fortified one in advance for the return to the repertory of ''Luisa Miller'' on Wednesday night.

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago fourth quarter results included reductions of 20 cents a share for the loss of investment tax credits under the 1986 Tax Law and 10 cents a share to relocate the paper group's headquarters to Boise. The company also said the prior year results include a negative effect of 33 cents a shae related to a strike at the company's pulp and paper mill in Rumford, Maine. The company said share earnings reflect a 5-for-3 stock split paid earlier this month.

title: Reinhardt's Hot Club Back in Style
description: FEW jazz legends have a more exotic mystique than Django Reinhardt, the Belgian-born gypsy guitarist and banjo player who led the legendary Parisian ensemble known as the Quintet of the Hot Club of France in the 1930's and 40's. By the time of his death in 1953, at age 43, he was recognized as one of the three or four most important jazz guitarists in history, and his influence has reverberated from Les Paul, one of his great champions in the 1940's, to Willie Nelson in his nostalgic mode.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Baaron Pittenger has returned to the post of acting executive director of the United States Olympic Committee while a search is begun for a replacement for Harvey Schiller. Schiller, 48 years old, became executive director less than three weeks ago, but then resigned to return to his job as commissioner of the Southeastern Conference. He said he thought it was a mistake for him to take the Olympic job. Pittenger had served as interim executive director since last August. . . . The Rangers have acquired Joe Paterson, a veteran left wing, from the Los Angeles Kings for two other wings, Gord Walker and Mike Siltala. Paterson, 27 years old, had his best season two years ago, when he had 9 goals and 18 assists in 47 games. This season, he had 1 goal and 3 assists in 32 games. He will join the Rangers in Vancouver tonight.

title: G.S.A. Said to Try to Deflect Inquiry
description: The General Services Administration is attempting to shift the focus of an investigation into possible corruption in the awarding of telephone contracts to the BellSouth Corporation and away from top agency officials, three people familiar with the inquiry said last night.

title: Institutional Nature of Schools Is the Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $619,000 for the latest quarter and $1,388,000 for the year-earlier period. Year-ago quarter results include restructuring costs that reduced net income by $2.6 million and a gain that increased net income by $16.1 million, or 38 cents a share.

title: ANTIQUE CREATURES GREAT AND SMALL AT ARMORY
description: MERCURY, monsters and scores of their mythological brethren are installed throughout the Winter Antiques Show, opening today in previews and tomorrow to the public for a nine-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

title: Irston R. Barnes, 83, An Economics Expert
description: Irston Roberts Barnes, an economist and naturalist, died after a short illness Tuesday at his home in Groton, Conn. He was 83 years old. Mr. Barnes was an assistant professor of economics at Yale University from 1932 to 1941 and a professor of political economy at the graduate school of business administration at Columbia University from 1960 to 1963.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Congress vs. Pentagon
description: The epic struggle between Congress and the Pentagon over the appointment of an Assistant Secretary for Special Operations and Low Intensity Conflict continues.

title: War Powers Resolution Can Still Be Salvaged
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; HIC's and NIC's
description: The HIC's, NIC's and SSA's that you might hear being discussed around the World Bank these days sound as though they could be hot new hockey or basketball teams. Actually, they are clusters of countries.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday DICHTER AND ROMANCE

title: PYRAMID TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $305,000 from a favorable foreign currency transaction due to the decline of the U.S. dollar in relation to the British pound. c-Net loss

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $142,000 from pension termination. The company said that latest year figures reflect a change in its fiscal year which now ends the last day of February instead of the last day of April; for a more meaningful comparison, the year-ago 9-month figures are also recast.

title: Film: 'The Grand Highway,' Childhood in France
description: IN ''The Grand Highway,'' the French director Jean-Loup Hubert gives us his romance with childhood innocence. The autobiographical story, set in a pretty peasant village in 1958, has the makings of a nostalgic glance backward, full of easy charm and sentimentality. Louis, an adorable 9-year-old, is sent from Paris to the country for three weeks while his mother has a baby. And though the film has its moments of cheap charm, it is unexpectedly rich in warmth, wit and intelligence. Through the child's eyes we are lured into an enchanted landscape, as lush as Monet's gardens, only to have Mr. Hubert insistently block this lyrical vision with a cold, adult look at his characters' disenchantment and at the harshness of peasant life. The result makes ''The Grand Highway'' more convincing, more charming.

title: Bridge: Manhattan Club's Successes Rivaling Those of Beverly
description: Players from the Beverly Club, at 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, are accustomed to capturing titles at every level. But their successes are now being rivaled by those of the Manhattan Club, at 27 West 72d Street.

title: Advertising; New Drive By Condom Marketer
description: IN the midst of a marketplace revolution in the category, Ansell-Americas, a big but relatively unknown condom marketer, has assigned its Lifestyles brand to Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK.

title: MIDLANTIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter net included a special provision for loan losses of $25 million. Midlantic said its provision for loan losses totaled $55 million during the latest year. It said the special provision made during the second quarter reduced earnings by $18 million, and the additional provision made in the fourth quarter reduced earnings by $15 million. The results for 1986 are restated on a pro-forma basis to reflect the Jan. 30, 1987 merger of Midlantic Banks Inc. and Continental Bancorp Inc. The per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Folk Music Benefit
description: Bill Milford, a folk singer and guitarist, is to give a concert on Sunday at 7 P.M. at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street. Proceeds will benefit Clinton Community Services, a group that provides assistance to the homeless. Admission is $5. Information: 864-0510.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Art: Cy Twombly At Pace
description: SINCE the beginning of the 1980's, several aspects of Cy Twombly's long career have been reviewed in small gallery exhibitions in New York. It is almost as if, in lieu of the large retrospective his work deserves in this country, a sequential version is being patched together over time. The most recent addition, now on view at the Pace Gallery, concentrates on the artist's work on paper between 1955 and 1985.

title: Q and A, and Q's, on Judge Kennedy
description: Judge Anthony Kennedy sailed through his Supreme Court confirmation hearings last month in almost total triumph, and he deserved it. He described his views of the Constitution with insight as well as diplomacy, and he demonstrated an outlook and temperament that reassured people with much different politics.

title: KEY RATES
Film: 'Family,' From Scola
description: ''THE FAMILY,'' directed by the usually perceptive Ettore Scola, recalls 80 years in the life of a large, loving upper-middle-class Roman family. It begins in 1906 at the baptism of the baby Carlo, lying in the arms of his patrician grandfather (Vittorio Gassman) as the members of the family gather for a group photograph.

title: States on the Frozen Plains Offer Some Candidates a Toehold
description: Two weeks after the caucuses in Iowa, a week after the New Hampshire primary, the spotlight in the Presidential campaign will switch to Minnesota and South Dakota. Or will it?

title: Piano-Bass Duo
description: The duo of Steve Kuhn on piano and Eddie Gomez on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:45 P.M.; there is no cover charge or minimum.

title: L. Maxell Peace, Bank Executive, 35
description: L. Maxell Peace, a former vice president at Marine Midland Bank, died of complications of AIDS Monday at New York University Medical Center. He was 35 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hammer to Build a Museum
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman and chief executive of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced in Los Angeles yesterday that he intends to build a $30 million museum and cultural center to house his well-known and widely circulated art collections.

title: Marvin F. Camillo, 51, Is Dead; Started Ex-Convicts' Stage Group
description: Marvin Felix Camillo, the founder and director of the Family, a theater group composed primarily of former prison inmates, died last Saturday in La Rochelle, France, where he had been hospitalized since being injured in an automobile accident this month. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: San Jose Journal; Silicon Valley Laundries With Frills
description: Until now, everyone knew what it was to talk about coin laundries: It meant peeling linoleum, month-old cigarette butts stubbed out in tin cans, orange molded plastic chairs bolted to the floor, old magazines and ''out of order'' signs on half the machines.

title: Drug Therapy for Professor
description: A municipal judge ordered Glenn C. Loury, a professor at John F. Kennedy School of Government of Harvard University who was charged with posssessing drugs, to continue a program for drug treatment that he has entered since his arrest and to pay $115 in court costs and other fines.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING A NEW INITIATIVE FOR MIDEAST PEACE
description: As a result of the continuing violence in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, the Reagan Administration is conducting internal deliberations on whether the United States should take a more active and visible role in pursuing peace efforts in the Middle East, American officials said today.

title: Weigh-In Is Quick and Quiet
description: Larry Holmes stepped back into the boxing spotlight today, uttering his first word in a while at the weigh-in for his fight Friday night with Mike Tyson.

title: AMCORE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SIMON AND JACKSON GAIN IN NEW YORK
description: About 3,500 New York Democrats have indicated they intend to run in the April 19 Presidential primary for 222 positions as members of delegations to the Democratic National Convention from Congressional Districts. The Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois filed the most names of candidates, according to a Democratic state committee count yesterday.

title: Met Lineup Looks Familiar
description: There was quiet optimism at Shea Stadium yesterday, where the Mets held a midwinter luncheon to discuss such issues as the pitching staff, the team's new hope at shortstop, the status of Mookie Wilson, and the future of Dave Johnson as manager.

title: Super Bowl XXII; Monk Works Out With the Redskins
description: Art Monk practiced with the Washington Redskins today for the first time in more than six weeks as the team began preparations for the Super Bowl.

title: Simon Sees Gephardt at Heels and Toughens Pitch
description: Senator Paul Simon's campaign is trying to adjust to a new political landscape in Iowa, refining and toughening his message as it tries to turn back a stiff challenge from Richard A. Gephardt.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Jan. 6 about sweet potatoes incorrectly described the conversion of beta carotene to vitamin A. It is converted within the body, not in cooking.

title: PNEUMATIC SCALE CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $68,507 and $139,400 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Ameritech Profit Up 16.1%
description: The Ameritech Corporation said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1987 rose 16.1 percent, to $322.2 million, compared with $277.4 million in the 1986 fourth quarter.

title: SCHWAB, CHARLES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the previously reported $22 million after-tax loss on customer receivables. c-Net income Figures are pro forma. The company noted that comparisons with historial results of prior periods are not meaningful because of its acquisition of its brokerage subsidiary in March 1987 and its initial public offering in September 1987.

title: Haitian Rock Band
description: Tabou Combo, a Haitian rock band, will perform tonight at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Sets begin at 11 P.M., 1 and 2:30 A.M.; there is a $15 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Data General Profits Up
description: The Data General Corporation said today that its profits had soared in its fiscal first quarter as shipments rose and cost-cutting efforts took hold. The computer maker said its net income totaled $12.4 million in the quarter that ended last Dec. 26, compared with $3.3 million for the corresponding quarter in 1986. The results were better than expected, analysts said. The company's stock rose 50 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today to close at $24.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bells, Bells, Bells
description: Come Feb. 15, if you happen to be in in the upper northwest corner of the capital, you might sense a ringing in your head around noontime, but it won't be from anything you ate or drank.

title: Orion Stake Raised
description: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom International Inc., has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation to 26.1 percent from 25.1 percent. Analysts said Mr. Redstone was interested in acquiring Orion's motion picture and television production operations to augment Viacom's cable and movie theater businesses. But in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Redstone only reiterated that he had purchased the Orion shares for investment purposes only. Analysts said that any designs that Mr. Redstone had on Orion would be affected by the actions of John W. Kluge, the chairman of Metromedia Inc. and a director of Orion, who is portrayed as friendly to Orion's management. Mr. Kluge told the S.E.C. Wednesday that he had raised his stake in Orion to 21.9 percent.

title: Haiti Jails Opposition Leader on Disorder Charge
description: A prominent opposition leader was charged today with inciting public disorder and taken back to jail after a hearing in the Palace of Justice, his lawyer said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 22, 1988
description: International A2-13

title: METROBANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARCO Settlement
description: ARCO said it had agreed to pay $481,000 to buy back from its retired chairman the deep-drilling rights on 15 West Texas properties. The move settles two shareholders' suits, filed in 1986, that contended Robert O. Anderson had received a special deal. In the out-of-court settlement approved Jan. 11, ARCO agreed to buy the rights from Mr. Anderson for what represents ''the low end of a range of appraisals,'' a company spokesman said. In addition, the company agreed to pay about $211,000 in court and legal costs for the shareholders. The drilling rights were acquired in a package of oil and gas properties bought by Mr. Anderson after his retirement, for $180 million. The rights were not listed among assets at auction, however, and the suits contended the sale had therefore been unfair.

title: America, Shadowed by Death Squads
description: In an unusual trial under way in Costa Rica, Honduras stands accused of maintaining an army death squad responsible for murdering four people in 1981. That a special court set up by the Organization of American States is hearing the case sets a powerful precedent - so much so that two key witnesses have now been killed.

title: John H. Mitchell, 66, Former TV Executive
description: John H. Mitchell, a former television executive, died of a heart attack in Los Angeles Tuesday. He was 66 years old.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Clang and Grind

title: NEWSPAPER'S FATE TIED TO JOINT PACT
description: The board of directors of Knight-Ridder Inc. voted today to close The Detroit Free Press if a joint operating agreement with The Detroit News is not approved by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

title: Forsman Gets 62 With Eagle
description: Just 14 months after he underwent surgery on the rotator cuff in his left shoulder, Dan Forsman shot the best round of his career today as he scrambled for an eagle at the 18th hole to finish with 10-under-par 62 on the 6,478-yard Indian Wells course.

title: J. Walter McClancy, Judge, 94
description: J. Walter McClancy, a retired judge of the Family Court of New York City, died Jan. 15 at his home in Woodside, Queens. He was 94 years old.

title: Hart's Advisers Deny New Charges, but Are Fearful of Impact
description: Gary Hart's political advisers gathered at his campaign headquarters in Denver today to decide how to deal with allegations of financial irregularities that they acknowledge have damaged his renewed Presidential bid.

title: Rep. Latta Is Retiring
description: United States Representative Delbert L. Latta said today that he would not run for re-election this November. Mr. Latta, a 67-year-old Republican who has been in the House since 1959 and who is a key White House ally on budget matters, said he was retiring to spend more time with his family.

title: Two First Boston Officials Get Wider Management Roles
description: The First Boston Corporation yesterday placed its two biggest stars, Bruce Wasserstein and Joseph R. Perella, at the helm of its corporate finance and real estate finance businesses.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 414 money market mutual funds increased $2.05 billion, to $273.55 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $616.8 million, to $79.76 billion. Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were up $79.2 million, to $81.09 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased $1.35 billion, to $112.70 billion.

title: Washington Talk: Urban Affairs; Mayors See Captial's Gold Dust Turn to Sawdust
description: America's mayors used to view the nation's capital as El Dorado, a city of gold, the source of limitless financing, where no urban problem was too remote or complex to escape the attention of dedicated professionals.

title: UNION CAMP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of about $1.1 million, or about 9 cents a share, for both periods from the sale of an excess plant; the 9-month period also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $491,000.

title: APPLE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $3,351,000 for the quarter and $8,366,000 for the year, and included pre-tax losses of $1,014,000 and $14,152,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from asset restructuring. c-After tax credits of $2,347,000 for the quarter and $8,690,000 for the year.

title: Market Place; Profit Jump Seen In Paper Industry
description: BUSINESS is booming in the paper industry, particularly for commodity-oriented companies that produce such basic materials as linerboard, bleached board and market pulp. Price increases are going into effect; production is humming at capacity levels, and the weak dollar has made American producers exceedingly competitive in world markets.

title: Trial Set for John Zaccaro Jr.
description: April 4 has been set as the trial date in the drug case of John Zaccaro Jr., who will be be tried in Vermont District Court in Middlebury. Mr. Zaccaro, the son of former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of New York, was a Middlebury College senior when he was arrested in February 1986 on charges of cocaine possession and sale. The trial was delayed to allow the Vermont Supreme Court to hear a series of motions on the defendant's behalf.

title: Sandinistas Make Offer to Set Up Monitor Team With U.S. Members
description: The Nicaraguan Government made a proposal today in what it said was an effort to promote peace talks with the rebels.

title: Big Drop in Jobs in New York City Is Predicted by Its Budget Director
description: New York City will lose more jobs this year - 39,000 - than at any time since its fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, the city's Budget Director said in a report yesterday.

title: Economic Scene; The Big U.S. Shift Toward Exports
description: THE steep drop in housing starts in December reawakened worries that the economy might be sliding into a recession and sent the stock market plunging.

title: AIR PRODUCTS & CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes special charges of $3.5 million related to a salaried staff reduction program.

title: A JAZZ-DANCE AMALGAM
description: AMERICAN dance has been formed and shaped by choreographers who broke from tradition to follow their own lights. In the case of Danny Buraczeski, whose jazz dance pieces are being performed by his company this weekend at the Joyce Theater, the break was twofold. Mr. Buraczeski, who began dancing as a Japanese major at Bucknell University and went on to Broadway show-dancing, chose to devote himself to choreographing jazz dance, a form that has seldom been taken so seriously. But he was also drawn by music that is even more infrequently heard on the concert dance stage.

title: KRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $39.9 million for the quarter and $53.9 million for the year. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $26.1 million for the quarter and $19.5 million for the year. The latest fourth quarter net included a $45 million charge for taxes related to restructuring of foreign subsidiaries. Kraft's results reflect adoption in the fourth quarter of FASB No. 96, a new method of accounting for income taxes. The company said the cumulative effect of the change on years prior to 1987 increased net income for the year by $45.2 million, or 33 cents a share, which will retroactively apply to the 1987 first quarter.

title: CENTRAL JERSEY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Mayor and Joyce Brown
description: Joyce Brown no longer lives on a patch of sidewalk on Second Avenue. She no longer shivers in the cold, huddled silently sometimes, shouting at passers-by other times, befouled and alone in her misery.

title: Nobel Laureates Agree to Meet Again in 1990
description: At the end of four days of deliberations, 75 Nobel laureates decided today to hold another meeting in two years and to create an emergency committee to intervene with moral authority in crises around the world.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chrysler Motors Head Plans to Retire on Feb. 4
description: LEAD: Harold K. Sperlich, the president of Chrysler Motors, will retire from the company on Feb. 4, the company said yesterday.

DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing First for Matthews Keep: Jose Santos rode Matthews Keep to a four-length victory in the $47,000 Bold Bidder Purse yesterday at Aqueduct. He went one and one-sixteenth miles in 1:42 3/5. He earned $28,200 for his owner, Marc Barge, and paid $5.60 for $2 to win. (AP) Road Rally Finn Is First: Juha Kankkunen of Finland, driving a Peugeot 205 with Juha Piironen of Finland as his navigator, won the 10th Paris-Dakar Rally yesterday. Eddy Orioli of Italy, on a Honda, won the motorcycle division of the 7,982-mile event through France and the former French colonies of Algeria, Niger, Mali, Mauritania and Senegal. Three competitors and three bystanders were killed during the race.(AP)

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are restated to reflect a change in accounting principle. The 1987 net included a mandated after-tax writeoff of $8.9 million interest in the FSLIC's secondary reserve during the second quarter and a $6.9 million after-tax writeoff of certain deferred policy acquisition costs in the life-insurance operations during the fourth quarter. The provision for loan losses for 1987 totaled $84.8 million, compared with $63.5 million for 1986.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK-TENESSEE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted to stock ownership last month. The year-ago second quarter included gains of $291,000 from the sale of mortgage-backed certificates and bank-owned properties.

title:
Patents;
A Digital Watch
description: LEAD: A watch named Equium, manufactured by Equitime Inc. of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., displays the hour numerically in the center of its face, with the number of minutes before or after the hour shown numerically at the left or right. Berj A. Terzian, president of the company, was awarded patent 4,720,823 this week for the push-pull, stem-controlled digital display, which avoids the push-buttons previously required.

title: Arabs Recount Severe Beatings By Israel Troops
description: Both hands encased in plaster casts, Imad Omar Abu Rub explained from his bed in the Rafidiya Hospital what happened when the Israeli Army came to the Palestinian village of Qabatiya.

title: Unwanted Lottery Ticket Brings Holder $10 Million
description: A bartender won $10 million in the Illinois lottery after hitting the wrong button on a computer and dispensing $50 worth of unwanted tickets that she had to buy herself.

title: City Ballet: Balanchine's 'Variations'
description: Men in George Balanchine's ballets often yearn after mysterious women. So it was no surprise that Bart Cook yearned after Maria Calegari in Balanchine's ''Variations Pour une Porte et un Soupir,'' which the New York City Ballet presented Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Super Bowl XXII; Redskins Studying Each Move Closely
description: A sign of the times: ''MTV needs 15 guys to talk about their favorite music and to intro videos Friday after practice.''

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Flying for Less: The Search for a Seat at the Best Possible Fare
description: The lowest air fare between Los Angeles and San Antonio was about $125 last fall. So when Diana Homer's supermarket in Northridge, Calif., offered shoppers $89 coupons for use on any domestic Continental Airlines flight, she bought four coupons for the family's Christmas trip to San Antonio.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,518,000 for the latest year and $1,529,496 for the year-earlier period.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH AGAINST ABORTION
description: An estimated 50,000 people demonstrated here today against abortion on the 15th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision legalizing it.

Matriarch, 95, Can Be Citizen Under '29 Law

title: Origins of the 'Pac-Man' Defense
description: When the Martin Marietta Corporation introduced the ''Pac-Man'' defense in 1982 - boldly bidding for the very company that was trying to take it over - many on Wall Street wondered if the aerospace giant could survive its spectacular and innovative strategy.

title: HYTEK MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $154,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: LTU-Boeing Deal
description: A West German charter airline, Lufttransport-Unternehmen, or LTU, ordered three Boeing 767-300 jetliners, for a total of $205 million. Deliveries to the Dusseldorf-based carrier are to begin in January 1989. LTU's order was for 767-300ER aircraft, which are a high-gross-weight version of the extended-range airliners that first entered commercial service in October 1986. The aircraft will have a nonstop range of more than 6,700 miles, and it will be outfitted to carry 276 passengers in a single class.

title: Tricentrol Fight
description: The British oil group Tricentrol P.L.C. said it might seek the aid of a friendly company to fight a hostile bid by the French oil giant Elf Aquitaine. But Tricentrol's chairman, James Longcroft, who has urged shareholders to reject Elf's offer of $:134.7 million, or about $240 million, said a friendly suitor was not now under consideration. A week ago, Tricentrol said its defense plan would provide for a United States financial institution to take at least 20 percent in the company. The new investor has not been identified.

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $649,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations and a loss of $204,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $277,000 and $360,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Stephen King, Author, Dons a Publisher's Hat
description: Stephen King has a novel coming out next week, but this one will appear under the name Don Robertson. That is not another pseudonym like ''Richard Bachman,'' under which Mr. King wrote several books. Don Robertson is the actual author of the novel, and Mr. King is its publisher.

title: HAMMOND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New York Health Chief Faults New Courtroom Guidelines on AIDS
description: One week after New York State's Chief Administrative Judge issued guidelines on how courts should handle defendants who may have AIDS, New York City's Health Commissioner has said key portions of the guidelines convey ''a very inappropriate message'' about transmission of the disease.

description: Most mornings, the Rev. Kenneth J. Doyle celebrates the early Mass at a local Roman Catholic church, distributing communion from an altar framed by statues of angels. Then he heads for the State Capitol, where his clerical collar makes him the most easily recognized lobbyist in town.

title: Tyson Keeps Title With 3 Knockdowns in Fourth
description: Mike Tyson and Father Time caught up with Larry Holmes tonight.

title: New Design for Cup Boat
description: A catamaran is being built to defend the America's Cup against New Zealand's challenge, marking the first use of the multihull boat in the cup's 137-year history, the design coordinator for the San Diego Yacht Club effort said today.

title: AUDIOVOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Pact in Spain to Form Nation's Biggest Bank
description: Two leading Spanish banks, Banco de Bilbao and Banco de Vizcaya, have stunned the financial community here by announcing plans to merge their operations and create Spain's largest bank.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $1,750,000 from the settlement of a suit by a First Commercial banking unit against its bonding company.

title: Rules Set On Market Makers
description: The board of the National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday approved a series of measures aimed at restoring public confidence in a stock trading system that was nearly paralyzed by customer orders on Oct. 19 and 20.

title: Bond Yields Continue to Decline
description: Prices of fixed-income securities continued to rise and their yields declined further yesterday, despite some brief flurries of pre-weekend profit taking. While prices of Treasury coupon issues finished below the best levels of the day, the gains for the session and week were impressive.

title: SUNWEST FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Zev Vilnay, Geographer, 87
description: Zev Vilnay, a geographer and author of an authoritative guidebook to Israel, died Thursday. He was 87 years old. His ''Israel Guide,'' published in 1955, went through 24 editions and was translated into many languages.

NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Sermon at the Coal Pits: A Britain for Workers
description: By 9 P.M. on Thursday, the Arthur Scargill gospel hour had begun at the Maltby Miners Welfare Club in this south Yorkshire coal-mining town.

title: Detectives Arrest a Fugitive Diamond Thief
description: A multilingual con man who disappeared from a midtown Manhattan office with $3 million in diamonds two years ago emerged yesterday when investigators caught him trying to repeat the scheme and arrested him, the police said.

Let's Look at Rights of Our Mental Patients, Too; Change Soviet Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: REGIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods' earnings included $762,000 from a non-recurring dividend from the Mutual Savings Central Fund. The per share earnings are not available for the year 1986; the company completed its conversion to stock form in March 1986.

title: COMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Santa Fe Nets $113.7 Million
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation today reported a fourth-quarter profit of nearly $113.7 million, or 72 cents a share, up from a steep loss posted in the period a year earlier.

title: In Taiwan, Rumblings About Another Chiang
description: Some elderly conservative leaders of the Nationalist Party on Taiwan have sought to install Madame Chiang Kai-shek, 90 years old, as chairman of the party after the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo last week.

title: REPUBLIC BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $64,900 for the quarter and $147,600 for the year. c-Net loss and after a tax credit of $16,305 for the quarter and year.

title: Rushing to N.F.L.?
description: Craig Heyward, Pitt's all-America tailback, has not attended classes this semester and has told friends he wants to play in the National Football League next season, according to published reports. Heyward, second in the nation in rushing last season with 1,655 yards, flew to Washington last night to meet with an agent, Bruce Allen, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported in today's editions. National Collegiate Athletic Association rules prohibit a player from having any contact with an agent while he has college eligibility remaining. The 5-foot-11-inch, 284-pound Heyward, who rushed for at least 100 yards in all 12 of Pitt's game last season, would not be eligible for the N.F.L. college draft this April under N.C.A.A. rules because he has one year of eligibility remaining and has not graduated. However, if the N.C.A.A. were to declare Heyward ineligible, he could be placed in a special supplemental draft. Cris Carter, a wide receiver for Ohio State, joined the N.F.L. last September under similar circumstances. Several N.F.L. scouts said Heyward, who was a redshirt junior last season, would be a high first-round draft pick if he were in the April draft. The Post-Gazette reported Heyward had told friends for several weeks he wanted to turn pro. The newspaper said Heyward did poorly in his fall semester classes and has not attended winter-term classes, which began Jan. 6. Heyward finished fifth in the Heisman Trophy balloting behind four seniors.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 23, 1988
description: Companies

title: Belgian Dispute to Court
description: Societe Generale de Belgique S.A., the subject of a takeover bid by the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti, said today that it had initiated court proceedings to counter Mr. de Benedetti. Rene Lamy, governor of Societe Generale, Belgium's largest holding company, refused to elaborate on the nature of the proceedings before the Brussels commercial court. The company had earlier said that a number of legal approaches were possible to oppose Mr. de Benedetti, the head of the Olivetti Corporation, who is seeking to acquire a controlling stake in the Belgium company.

title: Mayors Vow to Renew Drive for Aid
description: Robert M. Isaac, the Republican Mayor of Colorado Springs, puts it with as much asperity as anyone.

title: Award in Channel Disaster
description: Britain's High Court awarded more than $295,000 in compensation to a family whose father died when a English Channel ferry, the Herald of Free Enterprise, sank off Belgium in March, killing nearly 200 people.

title: BOULEVARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNION PLANTERS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,397,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $612,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After extraordinary gains of $1,630,000 for the quarter and $5,716,000 for the year. The latest quarter included an $11 million addition to its loan loss reserve. The latest year included a first quarter recovery of $629,000 of state excise taxes from successful litigation against the State of Tennessee, and also included non-interest expense of $158,000 in legal fees related to the litigation. The year-ago figures are restated to reflect the merger of Borc Financial Corp., First Citizens Bank of Hohenwald, Merchant State Holdings Co. and First BancCrossville Inc.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What should be obvious to everyone here is that racism breeds hatred and hatred breeds racism and it is a vicious circle.'' - Justice Thomas A. Demakos of State Supreme Court in Queens. [ 1:4. ]

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 12
NATIONAL COMMERCE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 4.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Abernethy, a former Atlanta sports agent, filed a plea of not guilty in Opelika, Ala., yesterday to misdemeanor counts stemming from payments to an Auburn football player. . . . Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, who was dismissed last weekend by CBS Sports after making controversial remarks about blacks, was admitted yesterday to Duke Medical Center in Durham, N.C., after reporting chest pains, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: Prices Set for Eagle Cars
description: The Chrysler Motors Corporation has announced firm prices for its Premier four-door sedans, the first models to be sold under the No. 3 auto maker's new Eagle nameplate. The manufacturer's suggested retail price for the 1988 Eagle Premier LX is $12,274, and for the Eagle Premier ES, $14,079, Chrysler said. Both models are being produced at Chrysler Motors' new assembly plant in Bramalea, Ontario.

title: GENERAL HOUSEWARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest periods' earnings include a decrease in pension costs in 1987 from adoption of FASB No. 87, resulting in an increase in net income of $62,000, or 2 cents a share, for the fourth quarter, and $250,000, or 10 cents a share, for the year.

title: ADVANCED MAGNETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes writedowns on realized and unrealized losses on value of marketable securities of $294,689 and $110,864 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

F & M NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KNAPE & VOGT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year figures included results of Roll-It Inc., acquired in January 1987.

title: Contain AIDS by Treating Addicts
description: New York City has long had to cope with crimes committed by its 200,000 heroin addicts to finance drug purchases. Now the addicts pose a new danger. By sharing the needles they use to shoot up, they spread AIDS. Mayor Koch deserves praise for recognizing the need to increase the city's drug treatment capacity. State officials, already taking steps to boost drug treatment, would earn more credit by finding the funds for the Mayor's plan.

title: Kodak Agrees to Buy Sterling for $5.1 Billion
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Sterling Drug Inc. for about $5.1 billion, forcing an end to a competing hostile offer from Hoffmann-La Roche & Company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JANUARY 23, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6, 28 Israelis are beating Palestinians under a new army policy. The policy is designed to end the wave of protests in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip that began in early December. Page 1 A curfew on an Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem was imposed by the Israeli police, who invoked emergency powers in the city for the first time since East Jerusalem was annexed in 1967. 6 A European armaments plan intended to maintain the military balance on that continent was endorsed by top Pentagon officials. The plan would be effective after the withdrawal of nuclear missiles under a new treaty. 1 A Paris and Bonn military council was created along with the legal basis for a French-German brigade on the 25th anniversary of their friendship treaty. They also unveiled an advisory council to coordinate economic policies. 3 Sandinista demonstrators attacked and broke up a meeting at which speakers were demanding amnesty for prisoners. Police officers stood by as the demonstrators threw rocks at relatives of the prisoners. 5 The amount of aid to the contras that President Reagan will request will be postponed until the last minute because the situation in Washington and Central America is so fluid, White House officials said. 5 A second Haitian opposition leader was detained at the airport in what many Haitians and diplomats said appeared to be a Government effort to divert attention from the presidential elections last Sunday. 5 The head of England's miners' union, Arthur Scargill, is preaching his message of working-class struggle in the vernacular of Marxism while the rest of the British trade union movement is headed toward moderation. 3 Conservative leaders in Taiwan have sought to install the 90-year-old Madame Chiang Kai-shek as chairman of the Nationalist Party after the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo last week. But specialists said the plan is unlikely to succeed. 28 Caracas Journal: A President and a Liaison 4 P.L.O. is said to delay on setting up a government in exile 6 U.N. chief asks action on Arab-Israel conflict 6 NATIONAL 7-9, 50 A law on 'independent counsels' was struck down by a divided Federal appellate panel. The law had authorized the appointment of officials to investigate and prosecute suspected crimes by high-level members of the executive branch 1 A 'Star Wars' contract was awarded to the Martin Marietta Corporation. The company is to develop a billion-dollar computer complex to simulate strategic defense systems and evaluate whether it is technically possible to repel a nuclear attack. 1 7 baseball players can be free agents without relinquishing their existing contracts. The ruling was made by the arbitrator who found that baseball club owners acted in collusion against free agents. 1 Extensions for illegal aliens who, for reasons beyond their control, are unable to meet the May 4 deadline to apply for amnesty under the new immigration law may be granted by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, officials said. 7 Mayors expressed frustration and anger over the way they think Washington has treated cities for the last eight years. But some were cautiously hopeful that there would soon be changes. 7 About 50,000 anti-abortion protesters demonstrated in Washington on the 15th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision legalizing the procedure. 50 Gary Hart sought to rebut charges of financial irregularities in his campaign, offering details he said showed that neither he nor his campaign organization had knowingly violated Federal election law. 9 Students confronted George Bush with questions seeking explanations for several changes in his past positions and on his role in the Iran-contra affair. Mr. Bush was put on the defensive at a high school in Iowa. 9 Bush gains in Michigan delegate struggle 9 Eye on Iowa in New Hampshire 9 A convention of dentists in Boston is among the city's most important ever. It is the first chance to show off the rebuilt John B. Hynes Veterans Memorial Convention Center, a $200 million development in the Back Bay section. 7 Unwanted lottery ticket becomes $10 million winner 7 Nofziger stock payment revealed 50 REGIONAL 29-32 The first Howard Beach sentence was levied on Jon Lester, who is to serve 10 to 30 years in prison, the maximum. One of three white teen-agers convicted for the attack on three black men, Mr. Lester was denounced by the judge for the ''savageness'' of his actions. 1 A mistrial in an organized crime case involving Gene Gotti and nine co-defendants was declared by a Federal judge. He said Government charges of jury tampering had persuaded him a mistrial was required. 1 The M.T.A banned smoking on all Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Commuter Railroad trains. Railroad officials said that with the ban, cars would be cleaner and cost less to maintain. 29 In a Brooklyn anti-drug drive, Muslims with walkie-talkies, some of them armed off-duty correction and police officers, have begun patrolling the Bedford-Stuyvesant section. 29 Harassment of two witnesses for the prosecution was charged by a Queens prosecutor in the case of the burning of a house intended for foster-care infants. He said the actions included sending anonymous threatening letters. 31 Four bids to buy The New York Post by publishers and real-estate developers were submitted as a deadline for offers closed. But Rupert Murdoch, the owner, said all amounted to offers for The Post's real estate, not the newspaper. 31 AIDS guidelines for New York courts convey an ''inappropriate message'' about the disease's transmission, New York City's Health Commissioner said. The criticism comes one week after the guidelines were issued. 31 In Robert Chambers's murder trial, the prosecution asked to be allowed to use medical evidence that it says will indicate that Jennifer Levin was gagged or that her mouth was covered before her death. 31 About New York: Concert for orchestra and tennis balls 29 Priest lobbies in Albany 29 Westchester town divided on housing for homeless 29 Neediest Cases 30

title: U.S. Cites Aid to Manila
description: The United States is committed to helping the Philippine economic recovery by stepping up investments, keeping its doors open to imports and maintaining aid flows, United States Ambassador Nicholas Platt said today. He told a meeting of American business executives that the Philippines had a trade surplus of $640 million with the United States in 1987 compared with a surplus of $461 million in 1986.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in The Living Section on Jan. 6 about Les Chefs de France, a restaurant at Epcot Center in Orlando, Fla., misidentified the Disney character greeting visitors. It was Pluto.

title: No Further Contra Aid
description: Following a meeting of the five Central American presidents in Costa Rica last week, the Central American battlefield has shifted north momentarily, to Washington, where the fight is under way over aid to the contras.

At City College, Vexing Action Off Stage
description: Little is pleasant about a years-long construction project on the front doorstep.
