Devils Frustrated And Penalized, 7-3
description: The Devils fell behind by two goals in the first period tonight and never recovered, losing their fourth consecutive game, a 7-3 decision to the Buffalo Sabres.

title: VANGUARD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Loews to Acquire U.S.A. Circuit
description: The Loews Theater Management Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire U.S.A. Circuit for approximately $165 million in cash. U.S.A. owns about 325 screens in five states: Massachusetts, New York, Connecticut, Ohio and Kentucky. The acquisition reflects the move among movie theater concerns to expand their theatrical holdings.

title: McDonnell to Pay U.S. In Overcharging Case
description: A division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation yesterday agreed to pay the Goverment $1.6 million to settle allegations that it overcharged on Air Force contracts.

title: Caracas Journal; A President, a Liaison and a Lot of Political Clout
description: When President Jaime Lusinchi took office in early 1984, his longtime liaison with his private secretary, Blanca Ibanez, seemed nothing out of the ordinary for a country where the extramarital relationships of prominent politicians have traditionally been heralded as signs of virility.

description: b-Net loss

title: FLEET-NORSTAR FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are pro-forma because of the merger between Fleet Financial and Norstar Bancorp, which took effect Jan. 1. A net reserve, in the latest fourth quarter, of $4.1 million was established for the sale of the company's Chapdelaine & Co. Government Securities Inc. subsidiary. The company also added $28.9 million net to its Latin American loan loss reserves for Fleet National Bank and wrote off $28.8 million of goodwill related to securities subsidiaries. The company also established $5.1 million net accruals related to expenses incurred in the consolidation of banking operations of Fleet Financial and Norstar banks.

title: Guidepost; Lighting Homes
description: There are new ways to light homes during the long, dark days of winter, including low-wattage bulbs that use less electricity, and incandescent and halogen bulbs that last longer. Halogen bulbs are more efficient because their quartz cases allow the tungsten filaments to burn at a higher temperature. Sylvania has developed a new kind of halogen bulb enclosed in hard glass that can be used in ordinary light fixtures. Most hardware and household-goods retailers carry the following bulbs for conventional screw-in fixtures: $ Wattage Brightness Lifetime Price Incandescent 60 855-870 lumens 750-1,000 hours $0.75-1.31 Long-life incandescent 60 640 lumens 3,000 hours $1.50-1.85 Low-wattage 52 855-870 lumens 750-1,000 hours $0.80-1.31 Fluorescent 20 855-870 lumens 9,000 hours $9.50-20.00 Sylvania Capsylite (halogen) 72 1,300 lumens 3,500 hours $2.50-3.69 Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California .

title: Dance Teacher Wins Stay of Eviction Order
description: Mary Anthony, the modern dance teacher who was to be evicted from her loft in lower Manhattan this week, was granted a stay of the eviction order yesterday after the Loft Board said it would consider reopening her case.

description: A Federal judge declared a mistrial yesterday in the nine-month-old racketeering and drug trial of Gene Gotti and nine co-defendants. The judge said the Government's allegations of jury tampering had persuaded him such a move was needed.

title: Your Money; Mortgage Offers Way to Cut Rate
description: GEORGIA COX, an office manager of a trucking company in Woodstock, Ga., took out a new type of mortgage last month that will allow her to take advantage of falling interest rates quickly and inexpensively.

title: Reagan Delaying Decision On Amount of Contra Aid; Rebels Back Escrow Idea
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders said today that they would ask Congress to approve renewed military aid to the contras but to put the money in an escrow account for 30 days while they hold peace talks with the Sandinistas.

Listen to Haiti's Democrats
description: The elections in Haiti have only complicated the political tragedy there. Gen. Henri Namphy will now claim to have kept his pledge of providing for an elected successor by Feb. 7, the second anniversary of Jean-Claude Duvalier's departure. Never mind that in doing so, the general has trampled on Haiti's new Constitution.

BellSouth May Give Up Federal Phone Contract
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to give up a Government telephone contract because its employees might have used secret bid information belonging to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to win the contract.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: The Philadelphia Phillies signed Lance Parrish to a one-year contract yesterday for $1 million plus incentives. Last spring, Parrish signed an $800,000 contract that provided an additional $200,000 if he played the first half of the season without going on the disabled list. The Phillies guarded against a recurrence of a back problem that caused Parrish to miss the last half of the 1986 season with the Detroit Tigers. Parrish remained healthy. Tony Siegle, a vice president of the team, said the 1988 pact was ''a guaranteed one-year deal'' with no disability clause. Parrish declared free agency last year after reaching a contract impasse with the Tigers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cooper Cos., Palo Alto, Calif., said it had completed the sale of its contact lens care solutions business outside of the U.S. to Swiss-based Ciba-Geigy Ltd., for about $50 million in cash.

title: Super Bowl XXII; Broncos' Johnson Can Start to Practice
description: The Broncos' irrepressible wide receiver, Vance Johnson, who risked reinjuring a damaged artery when he rode a horse for a music video on Wednesday, has been cleared to begin practicing next Tuesday for the Super Bowl game against Washington in nine days.

title: CK FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings is not available; the company became a stock concern in July 1987.

title: Firefighters Strike in Dublin
description: Firefighters went on strike here today for the first time in 20 years, and 300 soldiers trained for firefighting and emergency services handled emergency calls. Talks between the 800 firefighters and the city broke down early today. The dispute is over staffing, training and what the firefighters' unions say are breaches of wage agreements. Part-time fire crews in towns in County Dublin refused to fight fires in the capital.

title: Werner Nachmann, German Jewish Leader, 62
description: Werner Nachmann, president of the Jewish Council of West Germany, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 62 years old. Mr. Nachmann, who was born here, fled the Nazi regime for France in 1938 and returned to West Germany in 1945 to rebuild his family's business.

title: Oslo's Insider Inquiry
description: The Oslo stock exchange said today that it would investigate trading in the shares of Norway's biggest bank to be sure no insider dealing occurred before the bank announced a huge loss. Insider dealing is a criminal offense in Norway. The exchange said it would check with dealers, including those at Den Norske Creditbank, because its shares fell sharply on Wednesday just before the bank disclosed that it had a 1987 loss of 1.5 billion kroner, or about $236 million. The bank announced the loss and the resignation of its managing director, Leif Terje Loeddesoel, after the exchange closed.

title: DAISY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: About New York; Four Movements For Orchestra And Tennis Balls
description: A summons from the Little Orchestra Society skittered across the transom a while back, directing us to 132 West 65th Street at 9:30 yesterday morning.

The latest quarter included a $23 million provision for shutdowns, a $50.8 million credit from the settlement of litigation against Koppers Co. The year-ago fourth quarter included a $49 million credit for LIFO, a $26 million gain on the sale of certain assets and a $9.5 million provision for the shutdown of selected facilities. The latest year included an investment tax credit of $50 million. The prior year included total credit from LIFO of $64 million.

title: Center Is Suspended
description: The Minnesota North Stars' Dennis Maruk, a center, was suspended by the National Hockey League for cross-checking Wendel Clark of Toronto in the forehead on Jan. 13. A cut on Clark's forehead required seven stitches. Maruk, who has 6 goals and 3 assists in 15 games, will begin his suspension tonight with Minnesota's game at Hartford. . . . The Whalers traded Paul Lawless, a left wing, to the Philadelphia Flyers for Lindsey Carson, a center and left wing.

description: HAROLD CONRAD, the former boxing press agent, ran into an old friend, Mickey Duff, the British boxing promoter, in Trump Plaza here the day before last night's heavyweight title fight.

Thomas E. Barker, 33; Wrote Chamber Works
description: Thomas E. Barker, an award-winning composer of chamber works, died Jan. 12 at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 33 years old. Mr. Barker was being treated for bone cancer, according to his sister-in-law, Laura Smith.

description: In following through today on its announced plans to make a hostile tender offer for E-II Holdings Inc., American Brands Inc. appears to be hoping that it can dissuade E-II from making its threatened bid for American Brands.

description: Top Pentagon officials have endorsed an armaments plan intended to maintain the military balance in Europe after the withdrawal of nuclear missiles under a new treaty.

description: Sandinista demonstrators attacked and broke up a meeting today at which speakers were demanding amnesty for prisoners.

DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

title: HOUSING FOR HOMELESS FUELS DEBATE IN WESTCHESTER TOWN

title: Graf Holds Off Evert to Capture Final
description: Steffi Graf captured the Australian Open women's singles title today, defeating Chris Evert, 6-1, 7-6.

title: Stage: 'K,' a One-Man Play About Kafka
description: Not long after the start of ''K,'' Jan Hartman's play about Franz Kafka, we begin to hear portions of several of Kafka's most famous stories, including ''The Judgment,'' ''Metamorphosis,'' ''The Trial'' and ''In the Penal Colony.'' Graeme Malcolm, who plays the writer, delivers them with considerable power. In these segments of the 80-minute one-man performance, Kafka's tortured vision of man as guilt-ridden victim of forces beyond his comprehension takes hold. These scenes are like flashes of light in a work that never otherwise manages to flare into drama.

title: Excerpts From Court Opinion Invalidating the Law on Independent Counsel
description: Following are excerpts from the decision today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia invalidating the law that creates an independent counsel, or special prosecutor. Judge Laurence H. Silberman wrote the majority opinion, in which Judge Stephen F. Williams joined; Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg dissented. FROM THE OPINION By Judge Silberman

title: Mary Brosnan Kratschmer, Mannequin Designer,81
description: Mary Brosnan Kratschmer, a former designer and manufacturer of mannequins, died of cancer of the spine Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

15 Hindus Killed in Punjab
description: Gunmen believed to be Sikh terrorists killed at least 15 Hindus today in the northern state of Punjab, including Khushi Ram Sharma, vice president of the opposition National Peoples Party, the police said. The killings came two days after the state's top police official, Julio F. Ribeiro, declared that his troops had captured or killed about 300 Sikh terrorists.

title: Philharmonic: Haydn's 'Seasons'
description: In terms of sheer creative struggle, ''The Seasons'' is perhaps even more a triumph than Haydn's other great oratorio, ''The Creation.'' The latter was built on a text in which he believed; ''The Seasons'' - with its romantic depictions of peasant labors, loves, hardships and celebrations -was more or less forced on the composer, who remarked to a friend that though he was an industrious man, it seemed strange to be setting industry to music.

title: Murdoch Seeks Other Offers After Four Bid for The Post
description: At least four bids to buy The New York Post - two by publishers and two by real-estate developers - were submitted yesterday as a deadline for offers closed. But Rupert Murdoch, the owner, said all amounted to offers for The Post's real estate, not the newspaper.

title: Pianist's Trio
description: Barry Harris, a pianist, will lead a trio tonight at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue, at 23d Street (242-9066). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is an $8 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: LSI LIGHTING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rangers Beat Canucks, 6-3
description: Tomas Sandstrom scored two first-period goals and the Rangers took advantage of a poor Vancover middle period to score a 6-3 victory tonight.

title: Newspaper Merger Planned
description: The Columbia Record, the afternoon newspaper in South Carolina's capital city, will cease publication after the April 1 issue and its staff will be merged into its sister morning newspaper, The State, the newspapers' publisher announced Wednesday. The publisher, Ben R. Morris, told the newspapers' 650 employees that no layoffs were planned. The newspapers were bought in 1986 by Knight-Ridder Inc.

title: Copeland Blues Band
description: Johnny Copeland will lead his blues band tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: About Ballet, in Black and White
description: LEAD: The recent hiring of a black dancer by the Rockettes - the first since New York City's Radio City Music Hall opened in December 1932 - was generally regarded as long overdue. One excuse given for waiting so long was that uniformity of size, shape and skin color was essential for the famous chorus line's precision routines to make their proper effect.

title: INSIDE
description: Sandinistas Attack Meeting

title: More Women in State Posts
description: A survey made public here Thursday by the National Women's Political Caucus shows that the number of women appointed across the nation to state cabinet-level posts has increased to 130 in 1986 from 70 in 1981.

title: KEY RATES
A Bad Judgment on a Good Law
description: A divided Federal appeals court panel has ruled that there can be no special Federal prosecutor independent of the executive branch. This country is in trouble if the judgment stands.

title: Paris and Bonn Set Up Military Link
description: France and West Germany marked the 25th anniversary of their friendship treaty today by creating a joint military council and the legal basis for a French-German brigade. The leaders of the two nations also announced the formation of an advisory council to coordinate their economic policies.

title: SCHOOLCHILDREN SACRIFICE TO GIVE TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Throughout December, Shirley Bernard's sixth graders at the Tenafly (N.J.) Middle School gave up desserts, candy, gum, baseball cards and other luxuries. The pocket money saved from these sacrifices amounted to $37, which was sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

description: Two prosecution witnesses in the case of the burning of a house intended for foster-care infants have received anonymous threatening letters and have been subjected to ''verbal harassment'' by two of the five defendants, a Queens prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Security-Blanket Surrogates
description: If urban life seems more crowded these days, one reason may be the Big Pack - that 4-by-4-foot, 20-pound pouch swinging from just about every other shoulder in downtown America. Big Packs, riding high on crowded buses or trains, broadside fellow travelers, jam automatic doors, crush ribs.

title: Sun State Drops Holding Unit Plan
description: Sun State Savings and Loan Association said it had dropped a proposal to form a holding company, a plan opposed by a dissident shareholder and director who is seeking control of the company. Sun State said it had filed suit Thursday against the dissident, David P. Maniatis, in United States District Court in Phoenix. The suit charges that the Scottsdale, Ariz., real estate syndicator violated securities laws by failing to disclose in filings that he opposed the holding company reorganization or that state regulators had rejected his application to buy a controlling interest in Sun State.

title: HOWARD BEACH DEFENDANT GIVEN MAXIMUM TERM OF 10 TO 30 YEARS
description: One of three white teen-agers convicted of manslaughter and assault for attacking three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, was sentenced yesterday to the maximum of 10 to 30 years in prison by a judge who denounced him for the ''hatred'' and ''savageness'' shown by his actions.

title: Ben-Fleming Sessel, Banker, 86
description: Ben-Fleming Sessel, a retired executive vice president of the Irving Trust Company, a New York commercial bank, died of Alzheimer's disease Jan. 13 in the Hotel Seteais in Sintra, Portugal. He was 86 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

U.S. COURT UPSETS LAW ON APPOINTING KEY PROSECUTORS
description: A divided Federal appeals court today struck down the law authorizing judges to appoint the special prosecutors who investigate suspected crimes by high-level officials of the executive branch.

title: Parliament in Vienna Bars a Waldheim Talk
description: Parliament decided today that President Kurt Waldheim will not deliver an address on the 50th anniversary of Hitler's takeover of Austria, but a Government commission decided to ask him to address another assembly.

description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar called on the Security Council today to begin an urgent effort to end the Arab-Israeli conflict, saying a political solution was the only way to insure the safety of Palestinians in the occupied West Bank.

title: Parker W. Fennelly Dies at 96; Was Actor in Radio, Film and TV
description: Parker W. Fennelly, who played Titus Moody, the cryptic New Englander, on the Fred Allen radio program in the 1940's and early 1950's, and who was later the television spokesman for Pepperidge Farm products, died yesterday at his home in Peekskill, N.Y. He was 96 years old. Mr. Fennelly, who retired at 85, was known especially for his portrayals of old Yankee characters, whose accent he knew well; he was born and raised in Northeast Harbor on Mount Desert Island, Me.

title: Nofziger Stock Payment Revealed
description: A former official of the Wedtech Corporation testified today that the company turned over 1 percent of its stock to the lobbying concern of Lyn Nofziger, the former White House aide, after Mr. Nofziger's partner told them they were ''more or less like a welfare case.''

title: Bush Takes Hard Knocks at School
description: Vice President Bush, attempting to narrow the hefty Iowa lead of Senator Bob Dole, was pressed today by hostile student questioners who sought explanations for several changes in his past positions and on his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Brown-Forman
description: The Brown-Forman Corporation, the Louisville, Ky., liquor producer with annual sales of more than $1.4 billion, said that it had agreed to sell its Artcarved jewelry division to the SGI Acquisition Corporation for about $120 million. Artcarved, which makes diamond engagement rings, wedding rings and scholastic class rings, has operations in New York, Austin, Tex., and P.R. Brown-Forman did not disclose information about the acquiring company.

title: Memorial for Rapoport
description: A memorial service for the sculptor Nathan Rapoport will be held Sunday at 11 A.M. at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 West 87th Street. Mr. Rapoport, who was known for his monuments to the Holocaust, died June 4 at the age of 76.

title: Smog, More Smog and Still More Smog
description: LEAD: When the Clean Air Act was passed in 1970, many people suspected that the original 1977 deadline for states to achieve safe surface ozone and carbon monoxide levels was unrealistic. One of the law's drafters, Leon Billings, now says of that initial effort to get rid of urban smog, ''We threw the TV in the bathtub, hoping to shock society into action.

title: Hart Tries to Deflate Charges on Funds
description: Gary Hart sought today to refute growing allegations of financial irregularities in his Presidential campaign. He offered documents and comments that he said showed that neither he nor his campaign organizations had knowingly violated Federal election laws in receiving contributions or assistance from a California businessman.

title: Back on the Slope
description: Sidelined since Nov. 9 when she suffered a broken leg in a training accident, Tamara McKinney will resume racing at the United States Alpine championships Feb. 4-8, according to a spokesman for the United States Ski Team in Denver. McKinney, a World Cup skier and the best hope of the United States for an alpine medal at the Winter Olympics in Calgary, will skip the remaining World Cup races in January. McKinney should be fit for the Olympics, which open Feb. 13.

That gave him a 200, 16 shots under par, for a share of the lead after three rounds of the 90-hole Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

description: There are 17,000 more dentists here this weekend than the city's mouths require. The Yankee Dental Congress is staging its 13th annual convention and the gathering is among the most important ever for Boston.

title: 15 Killed at Afghan Rites for Pathan Leader
description: Two bombs exploded today during the funeral of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, the Pathan leader who preached nonviolent resistance to British rule in India and opposed the partition of the subcontinent. The United News of India reported 15 people were killed and witnesses said 25 were wounded.

description: The Martin Marietta Corporation won a contract yesterday to take the lead in developing a billion-dollar ''Star Wars'' computer complex. The complex would be able to simulate strategic defense systems and evaluate whether it is technically possible to repel a nuclear attack.

P.L.O. Is Said to Delay on Government in Exile

title: Chrysler in Europe
description: The Chrysler Corporation's return to Europe after nine years' absence will begin in March with a program to sell cars in five nations, a spokesman said in Paris. Alexander Demuth said that Chrysler was initially planning to sell in West Germany, which is Europe's largest car market; Belgium; Switzerland; the Netherlands, and Austria. Mr. Demuth said the company had also advanced the date for importing cars to France. This would probably be timed to coincide with the start of the Paris car show, from Sept. 29 to Oct. 9.

title: FIRST HAWAIIAN BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Viola Honored
description: As a sophomore at East Meadow High School he played first base and hit .288. As a junior he hit .333, and after switching to pitching at midseason, went 5-0. As a senior he boosted his batting average to .413 and turned in a 10-1 record. Those were pretty good statistics, but when he was graduated in 1978, nobody thought about retiring his jersey number. Then he went on to the major leagues, won a total of 69 games over the last four years with the Minnesota Twins, and captured the most valuable player award in the World Series. And the folks in East Meadow, L.I., began to take notice of Frank Viola. Yesterday, they did something about it. Viola, who now lives in Florida, was honored twice in East Meadow during the day, once at a luncheon sponsored by the local Chamber of Commerce and again last night at a ceremony at the gymnasium of East Meadow High School, where, a decade after his graduation year, his number, 16, was officially retired. It was the first time a player there was so honored.

title: Stake in Orion Up
description: For the second time in less than a week, John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Corporaiton, has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Kluge said he had raised his stake in Orion to 23 percent from 21.9 percent, purchasing 176,200 additional Orion shares in the open market for prices ranging from $12.125 to $12.875 a share. A separate investor group led by Sumner M. Redstone holds 26.1 percent of Orion's shares outstanding. The shares, which are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, rose 62.5 cents each today, to $14.375.

title: Textile Manufacturer Is Killed in Bay Ridge

description: Shearson Lehman Brothers said yesterday that it had voluntarily given up practicing a controversial form of trading that some people have tied to the stock market's large swings.

title: Library Puts Crumbling Books on Film
description: To preserve the millions of crumbling books, newspapers and maps that are slowly disintegrating because of the high-acid content of their paper, the New York Public Library has established a new state-of-the art laboratory in the cellar of the central research library on Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. It replaces a facility built in the 1930's.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Article on Jan. 2 about the expiration of British copyrights to ''Peter Pan'' incompletely described the status of the United States copyrights to J. M. Barrie's work. The novel ''Peter Pan'' entered the public domain in the United States in 1986. The play ''Peter Pan'' is still protected under copyright in the United States.

title: Recital: Ilton Wjuniski, Harpsichordist
description: Ilton Wjuniski, Brazilian-born but Paris-trained and -based, made his New York debut Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and offered as appealing a harpsichord recital as this harpsichord enthusiast has ever heard.

description: Only 32 of the 58 cruise ships that regularly sail to the United States met Government health standards, the Centers for Disease Control has reported.

title: L.I. Woman Convicted In Killing of Husband
description: A Long Island woman was convicted of manslaughter today but acquitted of murder charges after she was accused of hiring three men to kill her husband, who she asserted had sexually abused her.

The full year 1987 included an additional $75 million to the allowance for loan losses for loans to less developed countries that was taken in the second quarter.

title: Mexico Oil Price to Rise
description: The Government-owned oil company Pemex has announced that it will increase the price of light Isthmus crude by 30 cents a barrel to its customers in the United States. Pemex, whose official name is Petroleos Mexicanos, said in a statement released late Thursday that the change would go into effect Feb. 1. It did not say what the new price for Isthmus would be to United States clients. Prices vary monthly and the company does not announce the change in advance. In December, the average price was $14.81 a 42-gallon barrel for Isthmus and $11.43 a barrel for heavy Maya brand.

Patents;
A Smoking Mixture That Has No Tobacco
description: LEAD: A patent on non-tobacco smoking materials was received this week by Tripar Inc. of Stamford, Conn. The inventor named in patent 4,719,929 is Robert G. Breckwoldt of Goshen, N.Y. The patent specifies a composition consisting of a homogeneous blend of a smokably acceptable cellulose carrier and flavor enhancer, including a distiller's dried grain, but no tobacco or tobacco extracts.

description: President Reagan decided today to postpone until the last minute a decision on how much aid he will request for the Nicaraguan rebels, White House officials said.

title: National Symphony To Record Soviet Works
description: The National Symphony Orchestra announced today that it had signed an agreement with Erato Records to make seven recordings over the next three years, beginning with works by two Soviet composers who were associates of the orchestra's music director, Mstislav Rostropovich.

title: SLUGGISH DE LEON KEEPS TITLE
description: Carlos De Leon successfully defended his World Boxing Council cruiserweight title tonight when he took a 12-round unanimous decision over Jose Flores.

title: How Public Art Is Changing New York City
description: It's a show of art, a show of architecture and a show of urban design. Most of all, it's a show that vividly portrays and explains the role New York City is playing in what many people say is the largest nationwide public art movement since the Works Progress Administration of the 1930's: ''Percent for Art'' programs in cities, counties and states throughout the United States. The show is at the City Gallery of the Department of Cultural Affairs, 2 Columbus Circle, through March 4.

title: Concert: Speculum Musicae Plays Work by Ge Gan-ru
description: Ge Gan-ru, a young Chinese composer now studying in New York, is a name that crops up with increasing regularity, partly because of the Kronos Quartet's championing of his work. Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall, Speculum Musicae devoted the post-intermission portion of its program to the New York premiere of Mr. Ge's 27-minute de facto piano concerto, ''Wu'' (1986).

title: Stampfel at Speakeasy
description: Peter Stampfel, a singer and songwriter, is to perform tonight at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission is $7 with a two-drink minimum.

title: Europe's Inflation Rate
description: Consumer prices in the 12 member countries of the European Community edged up a tenth of a percent in December to an average of 3.2 percent for 1987, Eurostat, the community's statistical service, reported today.

title: Hawaii G.O.P. Move Vexes Robertson Camp
description: Faced with a huge influx of new registrants, Republican Party officials in Hawaii abruptly canceled a Presidential caucus and straw vote scheduled for next Wednesday, and partisans of Pat Robertson are crying foul.

title: Volvo Expansion
description: The Swedish car maker A.B. Volvo, which has just reported record profits, says it will be on the lookout in 1988 for companies to buy in North America and Europe. ''Volvo is seeking companies in the United States and Europe, and is particularly keen to crack the West German market in terms of sales,'' Volvo's finance director, Lennart Jeansson, said in an interview. Despite reporting record earnings last year, Volvo, Sweden's largest industrial company, said sales would have been about $666 million higher in 1987 if the dollar had not fallen.

description: The Giants signed an agreement today to use the Fairleigh Dickinson campus for preseason training. The Giants previously trained at Pace University in Pleasantville, N.Y.

Heat on Campaign Reform
description: Last month, New York's new Commission on Government Integrity dutifully added its own volume to the shelf of reports proposing reform of the state's lax campaign funding rules. The report inspired no more than pious nodding. But now the commission could yet unearth the compelling cases of abuse that finally might shame the State Legislature into approving reform.

description: Dr. Zacharias Dische, professor emeritus of biochemistry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died Sunday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: When they first started running, I could remember only four or five of the official Presidential candidates. Nowadays I can often remember as many as 11. Considering that there are 13, 11 is probably good enough to put me in the 99th percentile, memory-wise.

description: By the nature of things, spendthrifts attract more attention than misers.

description: Renting a car in the New York City area for a week costs $49 to $145 above the advertised or quoted price, according to a review of the car-rental industry by the Better Business Bureau.

description: BORN a storefront enterprise in 1975, Real Art Ways has long since grown into a sleek arts center with many sponsors in the public and private sectors.

title: Reagan to Seek Reduction on Capital Gains Tax
description: President Reagan will ask Congress next week to reduce the tax on capital gains, White House officials said today.

title: Off by $4 Billion and 14 Years, Michigan Nuclear Plant Starts
description: The Enrico Fermi II nuclear power plant went into commercial operation today, 14 years late and about $4 billion over its budget.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CABARET STARS Julie Wilson, singer and actress, and Marilyn Michaels, comedian, will present an evening of music and comedy Saturday at Raritan Valley Community College in North Branch.

title: WILLIAM L. GATES WEDS ANNE O'NEILL IN JERSEY
description: Anne O'Neill, a daughter of Mrs. Hugh John O'Neill of Brewster, N.Y., and the late Dr. O'Neill, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to William Lippincott Gates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore Gates Jr. of Princeton. The Rev. Richard J. Devine, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: JERSEY'S GAMBLING: TOO MUCH OF A BAD THING?
description: LEGALIZED gambling in New Jersey has generated more than $4 billion in state revenues over the last 17 years, but there is a growing sense of alarm about its social effects.

title: MIR STATION RECEIVES CARGO
description: A cargo craft carrying food, fuel and mail docked today with the Mir space station, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency. The Russians periodically send cargo to the space station, where two Soviet astronauts are one month into a yearlong mission.

title: NOT EVERYONE IS HAPPY WITH GARBAGE ACCORD
description: LEAD: ATTORNEY GENERAL W. Cary Edwards spent most of last Tuesday trying to convince a skeptical Senate committee that he did not let New York City off easy last month when he settled a suit on the city's handling of garbage.

title: REDUCING MISSLES IN EUROPE: HOW THE SENATE BATTLE SHAPES UP
description: THE PROVISIONS Missiles eliminated

title: Reynolds Is 400 Winner In Kodak Invitational
description: Butch Reynolds outdueled Antonio McKay for the victory in the 400-meter dash, and Marcus O'Sullivan continued his winning form in the mile tonight in the Kodak Invitational indoor meet.

title: ARAFAT HAS PLEA FOR ARAB NATIONS
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, asked Arab nations tonight to provide support for the protests by Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories ''so the revolution can continue.''

title: DR. LISA S. WHITE TO WED IN APRIL
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert White of Medford, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Lisa Sue White to Dr. Barry Stephen Paul, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Paul of New Rochelle, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in April.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Riverhead's Route to Controlled Growth
description: LEAD: THE Baiting Hollow-Centerville area on Riverhead's North Shore has for several years been drawing vacation-home buyers attracted by the quiet beauty of farm country within relatively easy reach of New York City.

title: WELL DREAMT AND SPLENDILY WOVEN
description: ''When a Maya woman puts on her huipil she emerges through the neckhole symbolically in the axis of the world. The designs of the universe radiate from her head extending over the sleeves and bodice,'' Walter F. Morris Jr. writes in LIVING MAYA (Abrams, $40). During 14 years of research, this American anthropologist found parallels between the diamond patterning woven into intricately brocaded blouses of contemporary Mayas in Chiapas, Mexico, and the fabric designs depicted 1,200 years ago in the art of their ancestors, the Classic Mayas. He believes that the symbolic signs reiterate the same sacred concepts: the path of the sun from east to west, toads symbolic of fertility, and the Earthlord, master of rain and the world of the dead. The weavers told Mr. Morris that female saints, who appear in their dreams, are the source of the design differences that distinguish the various communities. To weave a perfect huipil, it must be well dreamt, they say. Scenes of fiestas and daily life, in the stunning photographs by Jeffrey J. Foxx, are juxtaposed with illustrations of their vibrantly colored garments.

title: ART VIEW
description: WHEN FORTUNE MAGAZINE hired Charles Sheeler to paint a series of pictures for its December, 1940, issue celebrating the glories of American technology they found just the man for the job. Sheeler had by then become known for his paintings and photographs of cities and machines. For Fortune, the artist created steely, crisp images of an airplane propeller, a steam locomotive's wheels, a turbine engine, an electric transmission tower - pictures that treated the bits and pieces of technology as if they were icons of a new, bracing religion.

title: A New Era Is Dawning for the Grand Concourse
description: ON DEC. 18, New York City officials turned over the last five vacant apartment buildings on the Grand Concourse to private developers for rehabilitation into badly needed housing for the Bronx.

title: Du Pont's Iowa Strategy Is Hanging by a Thread
description: How does a Presidential candidate who is trailing badly in the polls make a breakthrough and convince voters he is worth supporting?

title: Classical Music
description: A lot of next week's music will come in twos, with four duos competing for attention Sunday alone. Bradshaw and Buono, the pianists, offer new music (by Elizabeth Bell), a recent piece (by the late Vincent Persichetti) and more traditional repertory by Schubert, Rachmaninoff and Liszt - all at 2 this afternoon at Alice Tully Hall. Hanna Lachert, violin, and Jonathan Feldman, piano, (at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street at 7:30 P.M.) also balance the new and the old - Philip Glass, Dmitri Shostakovich and Karol Szymanowski against Mozart and Beethoven. Better known is the duo of William Bolcom and Joan Morris who play and sing their famous cabaret repertory at Town Hall (123 West 43d Street) today at 2. The Aeolian Players move into the same space at 8 P.M. with Gilbert Kalish, piano, and David Gilbert, flute.

title: VACCINE FOR FOOT-IN-MOUTH DISEASE IS A POTION OF PLATITUDES AND CLICHES
description: THE vocal misadventure of Senator Joseph Biden, in which the then, but now former, Presidential aspirant recaptured - unfortunately, verbatim - Neil Kinnock's musings about the proletarian characteristics of his British ancestors, reveals a common peril for public figures.

title: SOME ISRAELI VIEWS ON THE CONSEQUENCES OF OCCUPATION
description: INrrxh Israel's occupied territories, fighting was sporadic last week, but military law was firmer than ever. As the Palestinian protests entered their seventh week, soldiers were carrying out a new policy of force in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Palestinians and foreign relief workers said hundreds of people were brutally beaten, some in street clashes and some in house-to-house searches, as the Army tried to break a general strike. Israel also invoked emergency powers in East Jerusalem, imposing a curfew on an Arab neighborhood.

title: SNYDER STIRS MANY REACTIONS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Verbatim; The Shadow and the Act
description: 'Intellectuals should make themselves heard by putting forward their perceptions of what is right. Then let the politicians worry about what is possible.' Henry A. Kissinger speaking as one of 76 Nobel laureates summoned by President Francois Mitterrand of France to discuss the problems of the 21st century.

title: Fiery Train Collision Kills Man in California
description: A freight train collided with another train that was halted in its path, exploding in a fireball that killed one worker, injured two others and sent engines and train cars careening into a residential street.

title: Should Congress Take the Cap Off Retirement Income?
description: DR. OTIS R. BOWEN, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and other top officials in the department want Congress to repeal a law that limits most elderly people's earnings to $8,400 a year. For those 65 to 69 years old, the law reduces benefits by $1 for every $2 of earnings above that amount, until, when earnings top $20,000, no benefit is paid at all. People 70 and older are free to earn whatever they can.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Jim Thorpe, Pa.: Mauch Chunk Rejuvenation
description: LEAD: Spurred by tourism, this mountain village of gingerbread porches and steam railroad lore has experienced a growth in its economy in the last five years that has created 45 new businesses and caused property values to triple.

title: What's Doing In Dallas
description: A few years back local slogan makers decided to dub Dallas the Time of Your Life City. It's not clear exactly what that was supposed to mean, but its hint of French Quarter-style merriment rang hollow as an inducement to visit Dallas.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Two Office Buildings Rising in Peekskill
description: THANKS to a combination of grants, tax abatements and low-interest mortgages, and a cleanup effort ''that overnight turned a sea of useless muck into valuable topsoil,'' construction began this month on two new office buildings in downtown Peekskill, the first in 25 years.

title: Jazz Refreshes Itself With a Dash of Brazil
description: MUSICIANS, LIKE MOST FOLK, love to travel. Unlike other tourists who bring home clothing and carvings or other such bric-a-brac, musicians pick up odd-sounding rhythms, exotic melodies, new ways of turning a phrase. Sometimes what they accomplish amounts to colonialist plunder. But at times their wanderlust produces unexpected insights.

title: Headliners; Telling Story
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, a Brooklyn minister, orbited on the periphery of civil rights and political circles for years before his leadership of recent demonstrations against racism brought him the high visibility he admittedly enjoys. But the spotlight got a little warm last week after New York Newsday reported that Mr. Sharpton had for five years supplied information to Federal law enforcement authorities. The newspaper, citing unnamed sources as well as an interview with Mr. Sharpton, said he had helped investigations of prominent blacks as well as organized crime figures. Mr. Sharpton said he cooperated with the authorities to help fight drugs, and he denied that he had helped investigate black civic leaders. His lawyers accused Federal officials of improperly disclosing Mr. Sharpton's role in an effort to discredit him.

title: KNICKS LOSE AS SHOT MISSES AT BUZZER
description: Reggie Theus scored 22 points and the Sacramento Kings blew a 15-point lead before rallying for a 97-94 victory over the Knicks tonight.

title: CARA BACHENHEIMER, A LAWYER, TO WED
description: The engagement of Cara Conway Bachenheimer to Neal Joseph Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Reynolds of Boston, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph James Bachenheimer of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: A Mixed Harvest Of 1987 Statistics
description: The harvest of statistics from 1987 continued. A steep, 16.2 percent plunge in housing starts in December got the most attention. That put housing construction for all of 1987 at 1.62 million units, the lowest since 1982 and down 10 percent from 1986. Much of the December decline was in apartment construction, which has lagged since tax laws changed last year.

title: An Extraordinary Portrait
description: ONCE AT A BORDER: ASPECTS OF STRAVINSKY With Igor Stravinsky, Robert Craft, others. Directed by Tony Palmer. 1981. Kultur. 166 minutes (2 cassettes). $69.95.

title: FICTION
description: BLOOD HUNT. By Neil M. Gunn. (Walker, $15.95.) Though this book, first published in Britain in 1952, includes a murderer on the run, a wronged woman and a revenge-obsessed policeman, it is not really a mystery or a thriller. It is, rather, a charming, old-fashioned novel of life in a remote section of the Scottish Highlands right after World War II. Old Sandy has retired from the sea to the croft that belonged to his ancestors, there to live with his dogs, hens and cow. But suddenly both his serenity and his self-sufficiency are shattered by the arrival of Nicol Menzies, the village policeman, as he searches for Allen Innes, a young man who has just killed Menzies' brother in a brawl over a woman. Sandy knows and likes Innes and decides to help him escape the ''blood hunt.'' But Sandy's efforts on Innes's behalf involve him far more deeply than he ever expected in the lives of his neighbors, whom he - and we - come to see as ''quiet decent people. . . . The salt of the earth. And the earth needs its salt.'' Like these characters, ''Blood Hunt'' is a quiet, decent novel, one of the more than two dozen Neil M. Gunn (1891-1973) wrote about the fishermen, farmers and villagers of the Highlands and their struggle not only to adapt to the stern demands of its land and sea but also to strike the correct balance between individual freedom and a duty to society. Gunn's work is not well known in the United States, an oversight that will be corrected as his new American publisher introduces the novels here. They offer readers a chance to recapture a world that, to our loss, has all but disappeared.

title: THE CELESTIAL CHILD
description: POINTS OF LIGHT By Linda Gray Sexton. 308 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: GERI L. FRIEDLAENDER TO MARRY E. A. BAND
description: Geri Lynn Friedlaender, a consultant in occupational therapy, and Edward A. Band, an assistant manager and a senior financial analyst at Citicorp Credit Services in Manhattan, plan to be married in October. Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Friedlaender of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Band of Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Headliners; Point of Departure
description: Some people can take it, but can't, or won't, dish it out.

title: LAWRENCE J. PEREZ AND MISS PERSICO TO MARRY IN JULY
description: Vanya Maria Persico and Lawrence Jeffrey Perez, staff members of the New York State Assembly, plan to marry in July, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Persico of Albany and San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, have announced.

title: THE QUANDARY OF AIDS AND INSURANCE
description: SINCE AIDS began its cruel assault, the insurance industry and homosexual rights advocates have been locked in a rancorous debate over the testing of insurance applicants for antibodies to the disease. But the groups are finding common ground on two issues: regulatory AIDS guidelines designed to keep discrimination out of the underwriting business, and health insurance pools for so-called uninsurable people, such as those who test positive for the virus.

title: Wave of Palestinian Unrest Reaches Once-Quiet Village
description: Israeli-Occupied West Bank, Jan. 22 - ''Greetings to the children of the stones,'' intoned the voice from the minaret of the lone mosque in this little Palestinian village. ''Greetings to the uprising.''

title: SLED DOGS FINDING WORK ONCE AGAIN
description: LACK of adequate snow cover will probably cause the postponement of the 10th Annual International Sled Dog Races that were to have taken place at Saranac Lake, N.Y., next Friday, Saturday and Sunday. The new dates would be Feb. 27 and 28.

title: Blueberry Growers Gain Use of Pesticide in Maine
description: The growers of Maine's famed wild blueberries, fearing large losses to their $50 million-a-year crop this summer because of an outbreak of the span worm, have persuaded the State Pesticides Control Board to make a rule change that will let them use a pesticide against the bloom-eating worm.

title: FIREFIGHTERS SEEK DATA ON STORAGE OF TOXINS
description: MANUFACTURERS in the state are filling out forms this month that will warn firefighters of any hazardous materials stored on company property.

title: Schubert - Note by Note
description: DEVOTEES OF SCHUBERT WILL BE HAPPY to know that the next 10 years of their lives have been planned for them. In an act of extraordinary devotion and tenacity, the 92d Street Y has committed itself to performing the 600 songs, nine symphonies, 22 piano sonatas and 15 string quartets, plus the duos, quintets, trios, octets, operas, masses and choruses that poured out in such profusion over Schubert's short but immensely rich span of life.

title: Next Week; Who Will Win The Super Bowl?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
PRIZE SCULPTURE
description: LEAD: ''I relate the process of changing something square and rough into something different to the way volunteers change themselves and the world,'' said Joanne Lubchenko of Somers, who is this year's winner of the sculpture competition sponsored by the Volunteer Service Bureau of United Way.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 30-year-old house has cedar shakes on the outside. To my knowledge, these shakes have never been painted or treated in any way. Should we leave them as is, or should they be treated in some way?

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 30-year-old house has cedar shakes on the outside. To my knowledge, these shakes have never been painted or treated in any way. Should we leave them as is, or should they be treated in some way?

title: What Israel Is Losing
description: It would be a profound mistake for Israel to believe that it can restore order in occupied Gaza and the West Bank by resorting to brazen brutality and betraying its own values. How can that open a path to serious political talks with the Palestinians?

title: OUR TOWNS AND CHANGE
description: Sharlene A. McEvoy asked what happened to ''Our Town'' as it appeared in Thornton Wilder's 1938 play. Her answer was that it was ''ravaged by hordes of greedy developers'' and changed to ''their town.'' My answer is a little different. It is 50 years later and ''our town'' has changed quite a bit. If you remember the play, both the Gibbses and the Wellses were families with a dad, a mom who stayed home, and two or three freckle-faced kids. Like a lot of families these days, maybe it's just Emily and her mom.

title: DR. JOANNE LESLIE TO MARRY IN MAY
description: The engagement of Dr. Joanne Leslie to Dr. Jonathan Ames, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ames of Tucson, Ariz., and Nantucket, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan Leslie of Jackson Heights, Queens. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: SAVING LIVES BY PHONE BEFORE RESCUERS ARRIVE
description: ON Jan. 9, a phone call was received at the Medical Communications Center in East Meadow. Man: ''The baby is turning blue!'' Medical technician: ''An ambulance is on the way.'' Woman: ''She's turning blue!'' Technician: ''Listen carefully. Lay the baby flat on her back. Lift the chin, slightly back.'' Woman: ''O.K.'' Technician: ''Cover the baby's mouth and nose with your mouth and nose. O.K.?'' Woman: ''O.K.'' Technician: ''Take two small breaths, very small.''

title: Research Findings
description: CHECK indoor plant collection for presence of mealybugs, white flies, aphids and spider mites; control if found. Use water-soluble fertilizer sparingly; indoor plants are semi-dormant during the winter months since light levels are low. Keep up with seed and nursery catalogue orders; plan the garden for this spring and summer. Outdoors, prune dormant plants, weather permitting. Shrubs Indoors

title: Millesgarden
description: To The Editor: Gunilla Martenson's article on Millesgarden, Carl Milles's villa at Stockholm (Travel, Dec. 27), failed to point out that practically all of the great sculptor's original works are in the United States where they may be seen free of charge from 10 A.M. to sunset seven days a week. In a wooded setting covering several square miles of trees, pine shrubs and gardens at the Robert Allerton Estate at Monticello, Ill., 29 miles from Champaign, one may wander among these priceless Milles originals.

title: DOES PRO GOLF NEED A NEW STAR TO SUCCEED?
description: Pro golf is a slow, noncontact sport. It would only be more boring if one new ''star'' would predictably win every tournament. ROBERT J. MOORE Bloomfield, N.J.

title:
FOCUS: Development;
Directing Growth in Virginia
description: LEAD: When Vinton L. Pickens, now 88 years old, first moved to her family's manor house in Loudoun County, Va., 52 years ago, her closet neighbor operated a farm more than a mile away.

title: Moments of Truth for U.S. and the Sandinistas
description: THE coming Congressional vote on renewing aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and the demands made by a frayed regional peace treaty have combined to make the next two weeks perhaps the most decisive of the many turning points in Central America's current turbulent passage.

title: FISH OR CUT BAIT, SAYS MARINE EXPERT
description: The article, ''New State Law in Licensing Fishermen Stirs Debate'' [ Dec. 27 ] does not adequately describe the provisions of the new law and erroneously states that all New York State residents fishing in state waters must obtain a $100 license.

title: Replacement Players in Line for Super Payoff
description: From their living rooms, about 80 former Redskin and Bronco players will share in next Sunday's Super Bowl winnings, adding from $9,000 to $18,000 apiece to their postseason swag.

title: BEST SELLERS: JANUARY 24, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 2 12 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 1 9 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 3 3 14 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 4 4 31 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 5 7 8 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Continuing the space saga begun in ''2001'' and ''2010.'' 6 5 26 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 7 13 4 WINTERS' TALES, by Jonathan Winters. (Random House, $13.95.) Unusual short stories by the comedian and television personality. 8 * 6 17 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' 9 8 19 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 10 11 4 WINTER, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $19.95.) The experiences of a Berlin family, from Kaiser Wilhelm to Adolf Hitler. 11 9 17 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families, the Mains of South Carolina and the Hazards of Pennsylvania, in the aftermath of the Civil War. 12 1 MONGOOSE R.I.P., by William F. Buckley Jr. (Random House, $17.95.) Blackford Oakes in charge of a secret operation involving Fidel Castro, Soviet missiles and President Kennedy's death. 13 12 23 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $19.95.) Ten thousand years of British history, seen through the experiences of five families. 14 1 THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (Abrahams/Dutton, $21.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 6 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 2 3 9 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat that adopted and soon owned him. 3 7 11 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 4 2 17 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $15.95.) Counting his blessings and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50. 5 37 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 6 15 33 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 7 * 5 26 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 8 6 26 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 9 4 20 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 10 11 5 PERESTROIKA, by Mikhail Gorbachev. (Bessie/ Harper & Row, $19.95.) The Soviet leader's views on changing his country and the world. 11 1 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 12 8 53 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 13 10 20 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (Random House, $19.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells his story. 14 14 9 FREE TO BE . . . A FAMILY, edited by Marlo Thomas with Christopher Cerf and Letty Cottin Pogrebin. (Bantam, $19.95.) Stories, poems and drawings about family relationships. 15 13 8 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) Profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 9 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. 2 3 29 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 3 2 8 SUPER MARITAL SEX, by Paul Pearsall. (Doubleday, $18.95.)
