The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) CHATTERTON, by Peter Ackroyd. (Grove, $17.95.) Wheels turn within wheels in this vivid historical romance: impersonations by real and imaginary characters involving real and imaginary facts about the 18th-century teen-age poet Thomas Chatterton. WEBSTERS' FIRST NEW INTERGALACTIC WICKEDARY OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE, by Mary Daly with Jane Caputi. (Beacon, $35.) A spirited glossary of correctives to patriarchal speech, defining such terms as Gyn/Ecology and Crone-ology. A HOUSE OF TREES, by Joan Colebrook. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) Vivid detail of an untamed land informs this memoir of Australia at the turn of the century. KIDDUSH HASHEM: Jewish Religious and Cultural Life in Poland During the Holocaust, by Shimon Huberband. (KTAV Publishing House/Yeshiva University, $35.) Unbearable testimony to unbelievable suffering, chronicled on the spot by a young rabbi, talented at historical writing, who himself perished in 1942. DR. GRUBER'S DAUGHTER, by Janice Elliott. (Hodder & Stoughton/David & Charles, $18.95.) A comic novel of postwar England, abounding in dotty characters and sinister confusion. HITCHCOCK AND SELZNICK: The Rich and Strange Collaboration of Alfred Hitchcock and David O. Selznick in Hollywood, by Leonard J. Leff. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $22.50.) An illuminating study of a short-lived but wonderfully productive partnership. THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS: Economic Change and Military Conflict From 1500 to 2000, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) The author, a Yale historian, argues cogently that the modern empires declined when their military commitments outran their economic strength; guess who is next.

title:
MUSIC;
PIANO AND FORTE PIANO IN LAWENCEVILLE RECITAL
description: LEAD: THE pianists Jerome and Maria Van Epenhuysen Rose will give a joint recital at the Lawrenceville School here Tuesday night, with Mr. Rose playing a modern instrument and his wife a fortepiano.

title:
ART;
RETURNING HUMAN FIGURES TO A PLACE OF PROMINENCE
description: LEAD: THE two artists now sharing the exhibition space at the Bryant Library in Roslyn have nothing in common beyond an interest in the human figure. Dale Dyer is a painter, while Hilda Steckel works in clay. His style is academic in the Old Master tradition, while hers is abstracted and simplified in the modern manner.

title: MARY MCMANUS, NURSE, ENGAGED
description: Mrs. John Herbert McManus of Bethesda, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter Mary Alice McManus to Dr. Richard L. White Jr., a son of Mrs. John H. Keating Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and the late Dr. White. A May wedding is planned. Miss McManus is also a daughter of the late Mr. McManus, a lawyer for the United Mine Workers of America in Washington. She is a recovery room nurse at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. She received a B.S. degree in nursing from Georgetown University.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 'DANCIN' FEET' There is nothing static about either the name or the contents of the North Shore Dance Theater's latest production. It is called ''Dancin' Feet'' and that is what members of the energetic young, Huntington-based jazz dance company, under the direction of Sandi Bloomberg, a former Rockette, and Toni Wortman employ today at the Harborfields Public Library. Their dancing feet are the centerpiece of a program that ranges from American jazz to Afro-Caribbean rhythms, with a pause on Broadway for recognizable show-stoppers.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE LOCKED ROOM: The New York Trilogy, Volume Three, by Paul Auster. (Penguin, $5.95.) In the latest of Paul Auster's self-reflexive, metafictional whodunits, a biographer turns detective and sets out to solve the literary and linguistic mysteries surrounding the disappearance of a friend. Last year our reviewer, Stephen Schiff, said he had found the author's previous two novels annoyingly austere, but added that in ''The Locked Room,'' his ''philosophical asides now sound heartfelt instead of stentorian and his descents into semiological Angst feel genuinely anguished and near.'' BEARING THE CROSS: Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, by David J. Garrow. (Vintage, $10.95.) The victories of the civil rights movement were not Martin Luther King Jr.'s alone, but this biography ''reminds us anew that his leadership was the indispensable ingredient,'' Howell Raines said here in 1986. ''Through tireless interviewing, through skillful use of the Freedom of Information Act and, not least, through his principled refusal to submit to F.B.I. entreaties to suppress details of the bureau's spying on King, Mr. Garrow has provided the fundament of fact on which future King biographies must rest.'' To coincide with his birthday this month, Mentor/New American Library is reissuing another classic King biography, LET THE TRUMPET SOUND: THE LIFE OF MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR., by Stephen B. Oates ($4.95.), which won the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Book Award. In 1982, Eric Foner said in The Book Review that the author was especially good at ''tracing the origins of King's ideas in his early upbringing and preparation for the ministry.'' The same publisher is also reprinting King's own book, WHY WE CAN'T WAIT ($2.95), which was first published in 1964. FOE, by J. M. Coetzee. (King Penguin, $6.95.) The South African novelist adds a new character, Susan Barton, to Daniel Defoe's story of Robinson Crusoe. She returns to civilization from the desert isle and entreats Defoe to immortalize what (without literary embellishment) was actually a rather boring experience. The novel ''illuminates the fiction-making process and the relationship between reality and art'' and is ''a finely honed testament to its author's intelligence, imagination and skill,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. THE WISE MEN: Six Friends and the World They Made: Acheson, Bohlen, Harriman, Kennan, Lovett, McCloy, by Walter Isaacson and Evan Thomas. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) By interweaving the life stories of six of the most influential members of the country's foreign policy elite, Walter Isaacson and Evan Thomas show how human volition can reshape the geopolitical landscape. In 1986 our reviewer, Ronald Steel, called the book ''a fascinating, informative and ultimately disquieting study.'' THE BOOK OF EBENEZER LE PAGE, by G. B. Edwards. (Moyer Bell, $8.95.) Published posthumously, this story of life in the provincial Channel Islands is ''one of the best novels of our time,'' Guy Davenport said in The Book Review in 1981. ''I know of no description of happiness in modern literature equal to the one that ends this novel.'' TOMBEE: Portrait of a Cotton Planter, by Theodore Rosengarten. With the Journal of Thomas B. Chaplin (1822-1890), edited by Theodore Rosengarten and Susan W. Walker. (McGraw-Hill, $12.95.) The historian Theodore Rosengarten - whose previous book, ''All God's Dangers: The Life of Nate Shaw,'' a biography of a black sharecropper, won a National Book Award in 1974 - re-creates the life of an unsuccessful plantation owner who is ruined by the Civil War. ''By deftly combining the inner world of an individual, the performance of a social class and the material conditions of community life, Mr. Rosengarten bares a society that is long gone but that still haunts a racially rent America,'' Eugene D. Genovese said here in 1986. THE JUDGE'S STORY, by Charles Morgan. (Ballantine, $3.50.) To save a man from prison, a retired judge sacrifices his material well-being, showing that money doesn't really matter so much after all. In 1947, our reviewer, Richard Sullivan, called this novel a ''quiet, intense drama'' that ''combines a theme of absolute importance with . . . accomplished skill in story-telling.'' THE RISE AND FALL OF AN AMERICAN ARMY: U.S. Ground Forces in Vietnam, 1965-1973, by Shelby L. Stanton. (Dell, $4.95.) Written by a military historian who served in Vietnam, this detailed history of the war is often superficial in its analysis, Eliot A. Cohen said here in 1985, but at its best ''it gives the reader a terrifyingly graphic description of combat,'' and it ''will stand for years to come as an indispensable resource for students of the war and the American defense establishment that has survived it.'' O BEULAH LAND, by Mary Lee Settle. (Scribner, $8.95.) In the days before the Civil War, Jonathan Lacey struggles to carve from the Virginia wilderness an estate idealistically called Beulah. ''Remarkable for its inclusiveness, this historical novel is head and shoulders above most of its contemporaries,'' Charlotte Capers said here in 1956. The same publisher has also reissued PRISONS ($8.95), which, published 17 years later, now forms the first volume of what has come to be called the ''Beulah Quintet.'' THE INLAND ISLAND, by Josephine Johnson. (Sandstone/Ohio State University, $8.95.) From the seclusion of an abandoned farm in Ohio, Josephine Johnson writes about the ills of contemporary society. When this chronicle was published in 1969, our reviewer, Edward Abbey, called it ''terse and tense and starkly clear. . . . There is hardly a prosaic line or a smoggy thought in the whole book.''

title: DEBORAH A. OESTREICH WEDS JASON SETH RUBIN
description: The marriage of Deborah Ann Oestreich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Oestreich of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Jason Seth Rubin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mel Rubin of Great Neck, L.I., took place last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbis Arnold S. Turetsky and Jeffrey S. Salkin officiated.

title: SAN DIEGO MAKES LEAP TO WORLD-CLASS CENTER
description: ROBERT PAYNE thinks of the Super Bowl as literally the biggest thing ever to hit this city.

title: ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER: SUPERSTAR
description: John Rockwell's defense of Andrew Lloyd Webber's oft-charged ''derivativeness and even plagiarism'' employed an ill-chosen example (''Andrew Lloyd Webber: Superstar,'' Dec. 20). Yes, ''I Don't Know How to Love Him'' (from ''Jesus Christ, Superstar'') possesses a ''big, arching tune and sweeping melodic momentum.'' Why shouldn't it, when it is patently derived from the slow movement of the Mendelssohn violin concerto?

title: HALF A NATION DEAD OR DISPLACED
description: THE WIND BLOWS AWAY OUR WORDS And Other Documents Relating to the Afghan Resistance. By Doris Lessing. 171 pp. New York: Vintage Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: And This Little Piggy Had Modern Genetics
description: His office is adorned with color posters of pigs. His tie has a pig embroidered on it. His car has a chrome-plated pig mounted on the hood.

title: Cashmere That's Lean And Spare
description: ''EITHER very square and loose, or very spare - nothing in between.'' That's how Michael Kors describes his fall cashmere collection for Lyle & Scott, the Scottish sweater manufacturer.

title: William Manee; Real-Estate Investor, 91
description: William Manee, a New York lawyer and real-estate investor, died of a heart attack Jan. 16 at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 91 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: VILLANOVA KEEPS LEAD IN BIG EAST
description: Kenny Wilson scored 21 points and Mark Plansky added 20 tonight as Villanova defeated Seton Hall, 69-63, in a Big East Conference game.

title: HARVEY'S OVERTIME PAYS OFF
description: For the last three days, Connecticut players studied the scouting report that focused on how to contain Greg (Boo) Harvey and Michael Porter, St. John's stunning backcourt combination. The secret: cut off the drive, keep them out of the paint, give them the outside shot and encourage the 3-point shot.

title: First the Lucky Break - and Then?
description: WHOEVER FIRST SAID ''I'D rather be lucky than good'' was on to something, of course. In music, it does appear as if careers often rise and fall at the spin of the wheel. A conductor in Rio de Janeiro is hissed off the podium, a young cellist named Arturo Toscanini jumps in as his replacement and a musical legend is set in motion. In New York, another conductor falls ill, a New York Philharmonic assistant named Leonard Bernstein steps up, and you know the rest. Frustrated colleagues of both those young substitutes must have muttered darkly about the unfairness of a universe that is run like a dice game. However, we tend to remember such mythic cases, not the countless times an opera singer, say, will be thrust into a vacated spot in the cast and thereafter sink from sight.

title: SARAH VAN ALLEN WED IN PRINCETON
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., Sarah Halsey Van Allen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James A. Van Allen of Iowa City, Iowa, and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Gerald Roark Trimble, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gerald R. Trimble of Atlantic City. The Rev. Raul H. Mattei performed the ceremony.

title: Milton Adler Dies at 82; Ran for Congress
description: Milton H. Adler, a former assistant attorney general in New York, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: O. O. GABUGAH INTERVIEWS HIMSELF
description: THINGS AIN'T WHAT THEY USED TO BE Musical Memoirs. By Al Young. Illustrated. 233 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: A Donald S. Ellis Book/ Creative Arts Book Company. Paper, $8.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about AIDS education, discussing the prevalence of AIDS in the Bronx, characterized an estimate incorrectly. Dr. Peter Gillette, an assistant professor of medicine at the State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn, indeed said ''30 percent of the kids'' in the South Bronx test positive for the AIDS virus. But he was offering his own estimate. No survey has reported such a finding; the prevalence of infection among students there has not been determined.

title: Honor for 11 Ex-Stars
description: FAME can be fleeting, but the National Football Foundation does its part to keep the names of former stars fresh at its College Football Hall of Fame in Kings Island, Ohio. In the process, its annual inductions can provide fresh ammunition for trivia buffs.

title: GIBSON MAY FIND FREE AGENCY WONDERFUL 2D TIME AROUNG
description: SO now can anyone other than the Detroit Tigers use Kirk Gibson?

title: WHEN JUSTICE IS JUST ANOTHER FORM OF INSANITY
description: WHEN Soviet authorities announced earlier this month that new legal safeguards were being introduced to protect the rights of psychiatric patients, human rights advocates were pleased but skeptical. The Soviet Union has continued to use mental wards as holding tanks for nonconformists and the politically suspect, despite years of world protest. Why believe things would be any different now?

title: SUSAN EINBINDER TO MARRY EDITOR
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jason R. Einbinder of Lincroft, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Dana Einbinder to Aaron Michael Brenner, the son of Dr. Robert P. Brenner of Los Angeles and Dr. Johanna Brenner of Portland, Ore. A May wedding is planned.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 10 about E. F. Hutton & Company misidentified Launny Steffens. He is chief executive of Merrill Lynch Consumer Markets.

title: Missile Treaty Deserves to Be Ratified Quickly
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Action Seen Over Jet
description: The Japanese Government plans to impose sanctions on North Korea for its suspected role in the destruction of a South Korean airliner Nov. 29 with 115 people aboard, news reports said today. Newspapers, quoting unidentified Foreign Ministry officials, said the measures would include a ban on North Korean officials entering Japan, and barring most trips to North Korea by Japanese officials. A woman identified as a North Korean said she planted a bomb on the Korean Air Lines jet. North Korea has denied involvement.

title: Union City Arcade: $4 Million Project
description: At 3:20 A.M. on March 15, 1987, Robert DeRuggiero got a rude awakening. A phone call informed him that his building in downtown Union City, N.J., was on fire. ''Just as I got there, I saw my offices collapse,'' he said. ''It was quite a shock.'' The building at 4100 Bergenline Avenue had housed Mr. DeRuggiero's real estate agency.

title: Stockholm
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Richard Kostelanetz's article ''In Stockholm, the Sounds of Silence'' (Travel, Dec. 6) but question his report of helium-filled balloons carrying people over the city.

title: LISA KAREN SMITH TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Neil Smith of Greensboro, N.C., of the engagement of their daughter Lisa Karen Smith to Warren Seth Waters, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Waters of Clifton, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla. A May wedding is planned. The future bride is a senior at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro. Mr. Waters, who is president of the Palm Beach Development Company in Clifton, graduated from the Montclair Academy and the University of Florida.

title: Concert: Focus Festival at Tully Hall
description: YEARS hence, perhaps in 2016 when Milton Babbitt turns 100 years old, some venturesome organization will mount the premiere of ''Fabulous Voyage,'' a musical-comedy version of Homer's Odyssey by Mr. Babbitt. I don't mean that when the arch-serialist and academician attains his century he will suddenly be moved by a desire to make money and try his luck on Broadway; the show has already been written. It has lain unproduced since 1946, but three songs from it were sung Friday night at Alice Tully Hall to kick off the Juilliard School's annual Focus Festival of 20th-century music. This year's theme is that well-known object of wishful thinking, the interaction of American popular music with the classical tradition.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: MISS LYONS PLANS OCTOBER WEDDING
description: The engagement of Katherine M. Lyons, a daughter of Jane C. Lyons of Irvington, N.Y., and the late Robert K. Lyons, to Robert C. Michele has been announced by the future bride's mother. Mr. Michele is the son of Dr. Evelyn W. Michele of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Dr. Charles T. Michele. An October wedding is planned.

title: Revised Financing Bill May Help Incumbents
description: A last-minute change in the New York City Council's bill for public financing of city election campaigns could be a boon to some current officeholders, including the Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 30-year-old house has cedar shakes on the outside. To my knowledge, these shakes have never been painted or treated in any way. Should we leave them as is, or should they be treated in some way?

title: Flamboyant Mayor of Washington Says He's Trying to Change His Act
description: Mayor Marion Barry was standing bare-chested in his office, surrounded by polished mahogany, inscribed brass plaques and tables piled high with the wordage of urban government, his stocking feet planted a good half-inch deep in the baby blue pile of the wall-to-wall carpet. An aide stood by, proffering a freshly starched tuxedo shirt.

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 10 about a Gallup poll on the 10 men most admired by Americans misstated the year in which the list was first compiled. It was 1946.

title: Piadina, Flat Bread Prized in Romagna
description: LEAD: ON a summer evening in Romagna after a day at the beach, supper is likely to be a piadina or two. At a bicycle race in Romagna, when spectators or racers head for the concession stand, they may find pizza and probably sandwiches, but almost certainly there will be piadinas. In the wine cellars of Romagna the snack most often served to go with the local vintages is a piadina.

title: Stockholm
description: To the Editor: The eloquent description provided by Mr. Kostelanetz is like a bit of madeleine for those of us who have shared the delights of which he speaks. Unintentionally, however, he gives too short shrift to the attractions of Kungstradgarden, the green oasis in downtown Stockholm.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: DAYTON, OHIO;
Tower Is Key To a Revival
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS here are hopeful that a $50 million, 20-story tower rising in downtown Dayton, the first major office building since the mid-70's, will prove a catalyst to the revitalization of a six-block business center scarred by a decline in the city's economy.

title: Former Actresses Compete for Political Power in India State
description: Indian politics were enlivened last week by a dramatic confrontation between two women, both former actresses, competing for power and office in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.

title: Teldec Label Trying Again In the U.S.
description: IN THE 1960's, WHEN THE authentic-instrument revolution began gathering steam, record collectors had few places to turn for performances played on early instruments and based on the latest musicological discoveries or theories. One label that saw the potential of the early-music market early was Telefunken, which introduced its Das Alte Werk line in 1958 (joining Archiv, Deutsche Grammophon's early-music line, established a decade earlier). Telefunken recorded other literature, too, of course, and while early-music enthusiasts made up a large part of its market in the United States, many buyers also regarded the label almost as an audiophile line, for it had built a reputation for magnificent LP pressings. In the early 1980's, in fact, the German company developed a new process, Direct Metal Mastering (DMM), which further refined LP sound and made longer sides possible.

title: Armstrong on Team
description: SHE won a gold medal at the 1984 Olympic Winter Games, and if all goes well, Debbie Armstrong, will win another in Calgary next month. At least she'll have a chance. Armstrong, who has been hampered by injuries since the 1984 Games, was one of five women named yesterday to the United States women's Olympic ski team. Joining Armstrong on the super giant slalom team were Pam Fletcher, Edith Thys and Krisrin Krone. Those three, plus Hilary Lindh, will form the downhill squad.

title: Art
description: Showing an artist in 1986, 1987 and now in 1988, as the CDS Gallery (13 East 75th Street) has done with the painter Peter Booth, is often an indication that an artist is being pushed too hard. But Booth lives in Australia, far from the pressures of New York, he has a career of work behind him, and prior to 1986, he had never had a solo show in the United States. His current show (through Saturday) is the first devoted to his work on paper.

title: Apple Completes Its Transformation
description: THE MacWorld Expo, a computer trade show and conference held here earlier this month, signaled the success of Apple Computer Inc.'s transformation from a renegade manufacturer of hobbyists' computers to supplier of information systems to the most powerful corporations in America.

title:
DINING OUT;
VARIETY IN IBERIAN, AMERICAN FARE
description: LEAD: THE Peninsular House Restaurant, which was opened just a few months ago in Scotch Plains, serves a variety of Spanish, Portuguese and continental American dishes in an unexpectedly stylish setting.

title: Practical Traveler; Bypassing Waiver Fees
description: THE year has begun with a tug-of-war over auto rental companies' coverage for collision damage. On New Year's Day, the Hertz Corporation placed a greater burden on those choosing not to pay Hertz for this coverage. Within days, a large insurance organization responded, saying that it was insuring holders of certain credit cards against this and any other new risks the auto rental companies might hold the customer responsible for. Some travel insurance programs' offerings also expanded to cover the new risks.

title: Wallis Bleecker Dunckel; Banker, 86
description: Wallis Bleecker Dunckel, the president of Bankers Trust Company from 1960 to 1966, died Thursday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Easton, Conn.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE SUPERCONDUCTIVITY BUSINESS;
Stars Are Born
description: LEAD: MAJOR industries, such as steel or electronics, consist of many segments, from producers of raw materials to providers of instrumentation to sponsors of conferences.

title: ISLANDERS REGROUP AND WIN
description: On Friday they had a meeting to articulate the soul-searching that went on during the silent bus ride home from Thursday's loss, their third in a row. Tonight, they skipped their morning practice, regrouped at game time, and plowed their way to a 3-2 victory against Edmonton.

title:
INVESTING;
Those Tardy Insider Filings
description: LEAD: CORPORATE insiders who are slow to report their transactions in their companies' securities would get a prod from a bill the Senate is expected to take up this term. The legislation would tighten filing deadlines to five days after a trade, from up to 40 days now. The bill would also stiffen penalties on late filers; currently the Securities and Exchange

title: 4 CHURCHES TO OPEN FOOD PANTRY
description: LEAD: REPRESENTATIVES of the four Episcopal churches here recently agreed to open a food pantry for the town's poor at Trinity Church.

title: WILLIAM SIMON'S PACIFIC OVERTURES
description: If William Simon does become taipan of a trans-Pacific trading company, he will be able to develop such extraordinary opportunities for small American companies that he will silence his detractors (''William Simon's Pacific Overtures,'' by L. J. Davis, Dec. 27).

title: Design of Cup Defender Causes a Dispute
description: A new and potentially disruptive dispute has risen over an announcement Friday by the San Diego Yacht Club that it would sail a multihull yacht against New Zealand's monohull challenger in the America's Cup next fall.

title: The Wealth Effect
description: To The Editor:

title: CONJURING AN EERIE WORLD FOR THE PHANTOM
description: VENICE AT NIGHT. THE PAINTER DEGAS.

title: Bringing Down the Gavel on the Life of a Texan
description: His eye took in a quarter-million-dollar painting, fabulous antiques and imposing mementos of fame and power, but as he looked across the possessions of a lifetime Friday, John B. Connally Jr. found himself musing about a 12-gauge shotgun he won at the Grand National Quail Shoot in Enid, Okla., in 1967.

title: Agrippa and the Hamburger
description: THE name, in two-foot-high bronze letters, on the portico of the Pantheon is that of Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa. He was the general, admiral and son-in-law of Augustus, the emperor who in 27 B.C. built the complex of baths, water gardens - and the temple that has survived. The name newly inscribed in black and gold on the 18th-century house facing the Pantheon is Burghy. It is underneath a large marble plaque recording in Latin that Pope Pius VII at the start of the 19th century had the ''ignoble slums'' in the neighborhood cleared, thereby reclaiming the ancient dignity of the Pantheon.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Dirty Dancing Starring Jennifer Grey, Patrick Swayze, Cynthia Rhodes, Jerry Orbach, Jack Weston. Directed by Emile Ardolino. 1987. Vestron Video. 100 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG-13.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
High Honors Given To Worthy Hobbyists
description: LEAD: THE American Numismatic Society bestowed its J. Sanford Saltus Award on John Cook in recognition of his excellence in the field of medallic design. Mr. Cook, who is a professor of art at the School of Visual Arts at Pennsylvania State University, is a highly respected medalist. He has been in the forefront of efforts to broaden the boundaries of this art form.

title: HART CAMP STRUCK RARE DEAL ON DEBT
description: In accepting 10 cents on the dollar, the company that was owned by a businessman now embroiled in the controversy over Gary Hart's finances agreed to an unusually low settlement of the debt it was owed by Mr. Hart's 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: Cable TV
description: Let's face it - you can't keep a good phantom down. On Monday, the night before Broadway unwraps Andrew Lloyd Webber's highly-touted, musical ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' home cable is showing the original Lon Chaney film from 1925 (and Gaston Leroux's novel) - at 9 P.M. and 1 A.M. on Arts & Entertainment.

title: Toward South Africa
description: Last July a Palestinian lawyer, Mona Rishmawi, went to the Ramallah prison to interview a client. While there she saw a handcuffed detainee being held with a heavy hood over his head, making it difficult for him to breathe. The temperature was 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Heyward to Pros?
description: HE has a year of collegiate eligibility left, but Craig (Ironhead) Heyward, the Pittsburgh running back who was the nation's second-leading rusher last season, has apparently given up on college and plans to seek a pro career. According to The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, Heyward did poorly in his courses last fall, has not been going to classes at all this term and has told friends he wants to turn pro.

title: DOES PRO GOLF NEED A NEW STAR TO SUCCEED?
description: The PGA Tour has reached the burping contentment stages of success. Just ask the young pro who will bank hundreds of thousands of dollars without ever being described as ''in the hunt.'' As the money becomes all but meaningless, and commitments clog his calendar and choke off his practice time, the pro can only blink in wonder at how quickly he has crossed that microfine line between winner and also-ran. New stars are created every year on the tour, and discover quickly how slippery stardom can be. ROBINSON HOLLOWAY New York

title: The Case of the Missing Mail
description: Families who moved into a new development on the Warren-Bristol line had no idea they were moving into an area overlooked by the Postal Service.

title: Somers Conversion: Waiting Barn
description: The year-old magazines will be familiar, but not the rough-hewn beams above or archeological artifacts displayed along the walls. The 100-year-old barn is being converted into the waiting room for three doctors in Somers, N.Y. Behind it, a new structure is being built for offices and examination rooms. The $1.4 million project at the intersection of Routes 100 and 116 will be completed in May and will include the repainting ofthe barn's exterior from worn rustic red to pristine hospital white.

title: LISA JANE MELONE MARRIES IN JERSEY
description: Lisa Jane Melone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Melone of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Robert Charles Cloughen Jr., the son of Dolores Cloughen of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Mr. Cloughen of Boynton Beach, Fla. Msgr. Harold Murray performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

title: ARMY BACKING OUT ON AIRCRAFT DEAL
description: The Army, in a move that could drive up expenses for the other armed services, has reportedly decided it will not buy a combat aircraft designed to take off and land like a helicopter but fly like an airplane.

title: FISHERMEN DISPUTE BAN ON SITE NEAR GLEN COVE
description: A GROUP of fishermen, some of whom have been fishing peacefully for more than 50 years off East Island in Glen Cove, are appealing a decision by a State Supreme Court justice that they are trespassing and must stop.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am especially concerned with voter registration programs. I think it's sort of sad to know that we have to push for such now after the long struggle we had in the South to become registered voters and to be able to vote freely. It is hard to understand how it could be that those who have the opportunity to do so seem to be indifferent and complacent.''

title: Amusement and a Feast: Formula for Franchises?
description: The mammoth neon cactus and life-size fiberglass cows that guard the Hilltop Steak House here may soon become familiar emblems around the world as the owners work out a plan to franchise the restaurant.

title: YVETTE D. HELLMAN TO WED GARY DAVID ANSEL IN MAY
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Hellman of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Yvette Dawn Hellman, to Gary David Ansel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Darrell Ansel of Minnetonka, Minn. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Army Rebels vs. Alfonsin
description: LEAD: The suppression of last week's mutiny may mark an important turning point in Argentina's efforts to bring the military back into constitutional government. But the zealotry of the vanquished rebels and their leader, Lieut. Col. Aldo Rico, reflects a continuing threat to civilian Government that will take years to defuse.

title: Borrowing Against Life Insurance
description: A NEW JERSEY executive, eager to participate in a joint venture, ''needed to get his hands on some funds, fast,'' said the executive's financial planner, Paul S. Brienes, president of Paul Stewart Associates in Princeton, N.J. After assessing his client's portfolio, Mr. Brienes tapped the executive's life insurance policy for a loan.

title: THE WORLD'S OLDEST PROBLEM
description: LEAD: UNEASY VIRTUE The Politics of Prostitution and the American Reform Tradition. By Barbara Meil Hobson. Illustrated. 275 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.95.

title: ON DEMOCRACY, LATIN GENERALS REMAIN UNCONVINCED
description: A BOOK was published last month that contained 39 military proclamations issued during coups and attempted coups since the last civilian president of Argentina completed his term 60 years ago. Had the book been delayed, the list would have been longer. Last week, there was yet another army revolt and, while it failed, it produced the customary grandiose pronouncements.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: WAITNG OUT THE SECOND COMING
description: REFORMING FUNDAMENTALISM Fuller Seminary and the New Evangelicalism. By George Marsden. Illustrated. 319 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.: William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: Controlling Growth in Rural Virginia
description: LEAD: WHEN Vinton L. Pickens, now 88 years old, first moved to her family's manor house in Loudoun County, Va., 52 years ago, her closest neighbor operated a farm more than a mile away.

title: No Dream Matchup
description: St. Anthony of Jersey City and St. Nicholas of Tolentine from the Bronx, two of the top high school basketball teams in the country, will be on the same program one more time this season. Unfortunately, they won't be playing each other.

title: FICTION
description: BONES OF THE MOON. By Jonathan Carroll. (Arbor House, $15.95.) Cullen James is not your ordinary Manhattan housewife. Though she and her all-American husband have a cute little girl and a lovely apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, when Cullen goes to sleep at night she dreams of Rondua, a land of strange beasts and quests and hidden dangers that could be straight out of C. S. Lewis's Narnia chronicles. And when she wakes, she discovers that she has an unsettling ability to, well, zap people. Clearly this is not your ordinary novel. Jonathan Carroll, an American writer who lives in Austria, juxtaposes the richly drawn dreamscape of Rondua with Cullen's significantly less interesting daily existence: she takes walks around the neighborhood, chats with her upstairs neighbor and contemplates an affair with a movie director. Gradually the dream world seeps into the real one. Unfortunately, the novel's psychological insights are all too obvious (Cullen's companion in Rondua is a young boy, the son she would have had if she hadn't undergone an abortion several years earlier) and the writing is flat, the characterizations superficial. The surrounding plot, such as it is, is meant to be a thriller in which a homicidal young boy is obsessed with Cullen. But the final climactic scene comes as no surprise. Mr. Carroll does let himself go when it comes to Rondua, a land of salmon-colored pyramids, yellow waves and an enormous dog named Mr. Tracy; here Cullen crosses the Plain of Forgotten Machines, sees a circus where memories perform and encounters the villainous Jack Chili. Rondua is the product of an unfettered, un-self-conscious imagination; it's too bad the rest of the novel doesn't measure up.

title: TWIN EVILS SPUR METHADONE CLINICS
description: INCREASES in addicts lured by cheaper, stronger and more widely available heroin and in the spread of AIDS through intravenous drug use have given new impetus to opening more methadone clinics around the state, officials say.

title: New Effort for Victims of Lead Paint
description: For what is believed to be the first time, the companies that made and sold lead pigment for paint used in houses around the country for most of this century have been sued on behalf of children poisoned by the lead.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE SUPERCONDUCTIVITY BUSINESS;
Become the Merlin of Magnetic Fields
description: LEAD: IF anything is capable of rejuvenating student interest in science, it's superconductivity. A handful of small companies, banking on the magic of a levitating ceramic disk, have begun selling superconductivity demonstration kits at an average of $50 each for use in school classrooms.

title: OUR TOWNS AND CHANGE
description: ''Whose Town Is It, Anyway?'' was interesting and many of Sharlene A. McEvoy's statements were right on the money. The problem seems obvious to me in her statement that ''we have watched our beloved small towns being ravaged.'' Hers is a plea for political action, for when one ''watches,'' the inevitable happens: the course of least resistance results in results not always to the liking of the watcher.

title: Social Events; Divertissements of the Night
description: Raffle Par Excellence

title: 'Professionalizing' New York Cabbies
description: THE idea, the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission said, was to ''improve the image'' of the cabbies, ''professionalize'' them and ''respond to consumer complaints.''

title:
WINE;
GOOD AND BAD NEWS FOR AFICIONADOS
description: LEAD: THE new year brings good and bad news for county wine consumers.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CARRIE CHAPMAN CATT: A Public Life. By Jacqueline Van Voris. (Feminist Press, $24.95.) This new biography, the second of Carrie Chapman Catt in as many years, is unlikely to change the popular image of this notable feminist leader as a pre-eminent political organizer and a master strategist of the woman suffrage movement in the United States.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ACCEPTING CUSTODIANSHIP OF THE PAST
description: LEAD: ON ONE of Bernardsville's former estate properties, in an area of steep hills, old farms and woods, where the New Jersey brigade of Washington's Army passed the winter of 1779, what is thought to have possibly been a caretaker's cottage was built about 125 years ago.

title: Buying Perfumes In the Bahamas
description: TRAVEL easterly through the Bahamas and you come to Crooked and Acklins Islands, fragrant with cascarilla bark, the base for Campari.

title: DOES PRO GOLF NEED A NEW STAR TO SUCCEED?
description: The PGA may have to liberalize its rules to permit more foreign players to compete more frequently in the United States. A Seve Ballesteros, a Greg Norman, an Ian Woosnam radiate a charisma now missing among American players. The college education and PGA training process seems to have bleached the color out of our current crop of leading money-winning pros. WALTER WALDMAN The Bronx

title: DATA UPDATE
description: HOUSING COSTS/N.Y.-NortheastN.J. area*

title: A Tape Measure of the Top 10
description: MUSIC CRITICS LEAD A pampered life. While we can skip record-store and box-office lines, we can generally count on decent concert seats and early pressings of the latest LP's. Presumably this Olympian, streamlined existence makes us objective, but every so often, I start to wonder what it's like for more typical music fans. Last week, I decided to check out what ordinary rock listeners hear.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: ROCKY HILL;
STUNG BY RACISM REPORT, OFFICIALS OFFER DENIALS AND PROMISES
description: LEAD: ROCKY HILL is a small town of fewer than 15,000, nine miles south of Hartford. Its Town Hall and police station occupy a single red-brick building a mile up the road from the ferry landing on the Connecticut River. It is a quiet community of tidy, single-family homes owned by workers who moved out of

title: New Canaan Offices: Another Story
description: When downtown zoning in New Canaan, Conn., allowed for three-story structures, most builders limited themselves to one. But that was when the Fairfield County town was still manufacturing shoes. Now, with a growing docksider population and new, two-story zoning, many of those buildings are getting an extra floor.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Drawing the Line On Liquor License

title: Ex-Head of California Board Sentenced for Embezzlement
description: The former chairman of the state teachers pension board has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for embezzlement and taking a $1 million bribe.

title:
GARDENING;
Branches Offer a Touch of Spring
description: LEAD: SOMETHING from the garden can be in bloom indoors all winter, from the first dreary days of January until February or early March. Branches can be cut from spring-flowering shrubs and trees on relatively mild winter days and brought into the house in a warm, humid atmosphere to bloom.

title: Aid Cuts Push Haiti Finances to Brink
description: On the cable television programs here, stores in the capital advertise for foreign exchange, offering to purchase American dollars and travelers' checks at a premium over the official exchange rate of five Haitian gourdes to the dollar.

title: Headliners; Prescient Verse
description: The Soviet poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko continues to display a knack for sensing when changes in the Kremlin's view of the past are about to affect the future. In a poem that he wrote and read around Moscow last summer, but which has only recently turned up in the United States, Mr. Yevtushenko expressed admiration of Nikolai I. Bukharin, the Bolshevik leader who was executed by Stalin in 1938 and banished from Soviet history. The appearance of the poem, ''Bukharin's Widow,'' was likened by Kremlin watchers to a nail out of Bukharin's historical coffin. A few months after Mr. Yevtushenko celebrated Bukharin, the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, confirmed in a speech the official righteousness of the poet's judgment, speaking favorably of Bukharin. Now, experts suggest, Bukharin's official rehabilitation may soon occur.

title: 4 Arab Envoys Ask U.S. Aide For More Pressure on Israel
description: The representative of the Arab League and three other Arab diplomats met with a senior State Department official today to complain about what they considered inadequate United States pressure on Israel to halt the violence against Palestinians in Jerusalem, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: POND'S ICY SURFACE YIELDS A GLIMPSE OF SPRING
description: FROM my office in an old North Shore mansion, as I sip my lukewarm coffee and aim my little heater at my frozen feet, I watch a mallard in the pond below that appears to be walking on water.

title: Ortega Said to Face Challenge Inside His Regime
description: Only a week after winning an important diplomatic victory at the summit meeting of Central American leaders, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra is facing an unexpected challenge from within his Sandinista regime.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TEVYE THE DAIRYMAN AND THE RAILROAD STORIES. By Sholem Aleichem. Translated by Hillel Halkin. (Schocken, $19.95.) With most of Sholom Aleichem's major works already translated, the re-translations are now appearing. And such is the case with ''Tevye the Dairyman,'' most of whose stories were first published in English in the late 1940's.

title: SPACE DRIVE'S TILT TO INDUSTRY GAINS WIDE NEW IMPETUS
description: In a series of policy decisions, some known publicly and some not, President Reagan has accelerated his campaign to increase the role of private enterprise in the nation's space effort. And Administration officials hope they can set in motion forces that will change the character of both the civilian and the military space programs.

title: Spaniards Around U.S. Base Divided Over Closing
description: Standing in front of his insurance company as a jet plane whizzed overhead, Ismael Recio seemed in shock.

title: City Hall Notes; Press Office Is a Perpetual-Motion Machine
description: Every day, one of the most active hubs of Mayor Koch's administration, his press office, works at making news, an endeavor that some might consider superfluous, given Mr. Koch's own efforts in that pursuit.

title: SNYDER STIRS MANY REACTIONS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: About Men; A Brother's Dreams
description: EACH TIME I GO home to see my parents at their house near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., my brother, a schizophrenic for almost nine years now, comes to visit from the halfway house where he lives nearby. He owns a car that my parents help him to maintain, and his food and washing are taken care of by the halfway house. Somewhere, somehow along the way, with the support of a good physician, a social worker and my ever-resilient parents, he has managed to carve a niche for himself, to bite off some independence and, with it, elusive dreams that, to any healthy person, might seem trivial.

title: HOW RACISM IS EMBEDDED IN THE FABRIC OF LANGUAGE
description: ''WALL Street's Blackest Day Rocks Nation'' was the The New York Post's Page 1 headline on Oct. 30, 1987. News magazines like Newsweek also reported (Nov. 2, 1987) ''How a handful of brokers and traders survived Black Monday -and its even scarier aftermath.''

title: The Sun May Set On More and More U.S. Bases Abroad
description: THE showdown between Spain and the United States over the F-16 fighter planes based near Madrid illustrates just how prickly a number of American allies have become about having American troops on their soil. While welcoming the revenue that the presence of thousands of soldiers brings, they have doubts about American reliability and they desire to shed the most visible vestige of postwar dependence on the United States.

title: Hart Aides Accused In an Effort to Raise Illegal Contributions
description: Gary Hart's top campaign aides instructed at least one supporter to ''raise and conceal hundreds of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions,'' The Orange County (Calif.) Register reported in a copyright article yesterday.

title: PENNY WOLFSON IS WED TO ROBERT LIEBERBERG
description: The marriage of Penny Joy Wolfson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Wolfson of New York, to Robert Lieberberg, a son of Col. and Mrs. George Lieberberg of Westfield, N.J., took place last evening at the Lotos Club in New York. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff, assisted by Cantor Martha Novick, performed the ceremony.

title: Hidden Memories of Incest Are Shared
description: LEAD: PAT DARO, a victim of incest, recalls being in a therapy group whose participants were asked to envision themselves as teen-agers being molested. ''When my turn came, I was asked what I felt toward the girl in my mind,'' she recalls. ''I replied that I wanted to slap her face because she's a slut.

title: Rohde Wins Brilliancy and a Double Prize
description: IT isn't often that the same game gets both a brilliancy prize and a prize for excellence in the end game, but Michael Rohde showed, in the 1987 United States Championship, that such a feat is not impossible.

title:
ART;
MONTCLAIR MUSEUM PAYS HOMAGE TO INNESS, A FAVORITE SON
description: LEAD: GEORGE INNESS lived in Montclair from 1878 to 1894, the year he died, so the current show at the Montclair Art Museum of Inness works owned by that institution is, in a sense, honoring a favorite son.

title: Why Being Fired Is Losing Its Taint
description: ITEM: Just a few weeks after Richard D. Bernard learned that his job as manager of merchandise marketing at NBC would be eliminated last May, he was given a shot at another position in the company. Mr. Bernard chose instead to take his chances as an unemployed job hunter. ''I wasn't so sure that being a survivor was any better than being let go with a severance package,'' he said.

title: Union Aide Draws 15 Years
description: Stephen Traitz Jr., a union leader convicted of conspiracy to bribe judges and embezzle union funds, was sentenced in Federal District Court here Friday to 15 years in prison and a $50,000 fine. Mr. Traitz, the 50-year-old business manager of Local 30-30B of the Roofers Union, was convicted in November along with two sons, a son-in-law and eight former officials of the local. Eight co-defendants were given prison terms of 8 to 14 years, and three other defendants will be sentenced later.

title: NEW YORK FAULTED ON TUBERCULOSIS
description: Amid a disturbing resurgence of tuberculosis in New York City, a Federal review has found major failings in local prevention efforts, and city health officials have vowed to revamp the entire program.

title: HELPING THE FLEDGLING LEAVE THE NEST
description: HE entered my life last July in a bowl of Depression glass, covered with a light blue embroidered hand towel. He was naked, pinkish-purple, all mouth and decidedly not cute.

title: 2 New York Charities to Merge in Effort to Aid Fund-Raising
description: Two of New York's charity establishments are about to be restructured into one.
