title: DEMOCRATS IN IOWA GO ON THE ATTACK
description: The Democratic Presidential candidates, searching for ways of moving a still highly volatile and uncertain Iowa electorate, stepped up their attacks on one another today in a series of forums held just 16 days before the state's Presidential caucuses.

title: INSIDE
description: Connally on the Block

title: STATE PLAN: DRAFTERS SEEKING CONSENSUS
description: LEAD: WITH only five days before the state Planning Commission releases the second draft of its controversial state development and redevelopment plan, interested parties are wondering if it will really relieve problems of sprawl and congestion, as intended, or shift the state's remarkable economic growth to

title: CABLE NEWS STATION CATCHING ON
description: LEAD: WHEN the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury began News 12 Long Island, the country's first regional 24-hour all-news television channel, Al Ittleson, the station president, said he planned on ''keeping the Alka-Seltzer handy.''

title: Free Bus Rides And the Clergy
description: FOR more than a century, Roman Catholic nuns and priests had received free public transportation in New Orleans. But not until last October did the practice come under legal challenge.

title: Utah Police Step Up Pressure on Barricaded House
description: The police stepped up psychological pressure today on an armed group barricaded in a log house in an effort to arrest some of the members in connection with the bombing of a Mormon Church chapel.

title: Correction
description: A notice yesterday about a memorial service for the sculptor Nathan Rapoport gave an incorrect address for the service. It will be held at 11 A.M. today at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street in Manhattan.

title: Body and Mind; Defining Hypertension
description: DEFINITION OF disease is a tricky business.

title: BOMBSMITHS TO THE WORLD
description: LEAD: MAKING AND MARKETING ARMS The French Experience and Its Implications for the International System. By Edward A. Kolodziej. 518 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $55.

title: Dissident Said to Get Visa
description: Naum S. Meiman, the 76-year-old mathematician who is among the last of the prominent Soviet dissidents denied exit visas, has been told that Soviet officials have decided to allow him to emigrate. Mr. Meiman reported Friday evening that he had received a telephone call from the French writer Simone Veil, who has taken an interest in his 14-year struggle to emigrate. She reported that Yakov P. Ryabov, the Soviet Ambassador to France, had told her that a decision had been made to grant Mr. Meiman a visa.

title: So Don't Let Them Discover Dubuque
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Portsmouth, R.I.: Home Market Moves North
description: LEAD: WITH land in nearby Newport scarce, developers have been moving north to this rural town settled by religious dissidents in 1638 to find sites on farms and estates for the expensive houses and condominiums they want to build.

title: Airport X-Rays
description: To the Editor: As a documentary filmmaker who longs for the easy, good ol' days when you could just walk from car to plane with your film in your carry-on bag, I might be of some help to the travelers who complain that their trip was ruined by some security officer in Austria or Hong Kong.

title: REFUSING TO BE A PUSSYCAT
description: KRAZY KAT A Novel in Five Panels. By Jay Cantor. Illustrated. 250 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: MEASURING HOW DRUGS, CRIME MIX
description: IT seemed last week that Government experts were suddenly discovering what any grocery store owner or police officer in the inner city had known long ago: the problems of street crime and drugs are inevitably intertwined.

title: ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER: SUPERSTAR
description: John Rockwell refers in his article to the phrase ''The Record-Breaking Broadway Musical,'' which is used in advertisements for the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical ''Starlight Express.'' In repeating the phrase, he adds, ''just which record is left unsaid.''

title: In the Debates, Appearance Conquers Substance
description: GEORGE BUSH WAS IN TROUBLE; Pat Robertson had said the Vice President didn't know the difference between a missile and a warhead, and for an instant, which is a very long time on television, the Vice President appeared confused. Missile? Warhead? He really didn't seem to know the difference. One thought of Gerald Ford in 1976, when he said that Eastern Europe was not under Soviet domination. Mr. Ford knew better than that, just as Mr. Bush, who is the former Director of Central Intelligence, the former Representative to the United Nations and the former just about everything else, knew better about missiles. Television debates, however, are a tough arena. Whether they are conducted one on one or among a handful of candidates, they can make anyone look bad.

title: Drop in the Dollar Brings an Increase In Tourism in U.S.
description: Benefiting from a steep, three-year decline in the value of the dollar, the tourism industry is prospering around the nation, with a rising number of visitors coming from overseas.

title: City Ballet: 3 Works by Balanchine and Martins
description: ALTHOUGH the musical compositions by Michael Torke that serve as the accompaniment for Peter Martins's ''Ecstatic Orange'' are called ''Green,'' ''Purple'' and, like the ballet itself, ''Ecstatic Orange,'' the dancers wear simple black costumes. Nevertheless, Mr. Martin's choreography is always bright, and sometimes even glaring in its intensity.

title: A SON CHAMPIONS ARTISTIC LEGACY
description: LEAD: IT is not that Alexander Bacon Brook has embarked upon a deliberate campaign to make his mother, Peggy Bacon, the prolific artist and writer who died last year at age 91, a household name.

title: MARIA GUREWITSCH PLANS TO BE WED TO JACQUES BRAND
description: Mrs. A. David Gurewitsch of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter Maria Anna Gurewitsch to Jacques Brand, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Felix Brand of New York and Brussels. The couple plan to marry in June.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LAPSING. By Jill Paton Walsh. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) There are few gazes more stony than a lapsed Catholic's cold glare at the church. Jill Paton Walsh's first novel for adults tells of the devastation its strictures wreak upon a love affair. Tessa is a brilliant Roman Catholic student at Oxford University during the 1950's and Father Theodore is the brilliant leader of her religious discussion group.

title: SEA CLIFF SCOFFLAWS FACE A CRACKDOWN
description: LEAD: SEA CLIFF village officials have kicked off a massive crackdown of scofflaws that is intended to immobilize those who don't pay, as a four-month amnesty period comes to a close.

title: MARGUERITE LEE TO WED IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Vandegrift Lee of Charlestown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marguerite Lammot Lee to Frank Perkins Hixon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hixon of Franklin, Tenn.

title: Man Hired to Aid Wright Doesn't
description: A press aide hired by House Speaker Jim Wright to polish his image could lose his job in the wake of disclosures that he wrote a sex book in 1982, Congressional sources said today.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Casanova's Anticlimax Casanova, the great lover, talker, intriguer, came to a sad end as librarian to a count in Bohemia, where he complained away his last 13 years. This is from ''Casanova: A New Perspective,'' by J. Rives Childs (Giniger/Paragon House).

title: 'Spare Rib,' a Revue,
description: ''The Spare Rib Variety Show,'' a two-hour revue featuring female musicians, comedians, performance artists and writers, will be presented Monday at 8 o'clock at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street.

title: Opera Patron Dies in Plunge From a Balcony at the Met
description: An elderly man plunged to his death from the top balcony of the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon during an intermission of the Metropolitan Opera's performance of ''Macbeth.''

title: SALEM DRIVE RALLIES TO WIN AT GULFSTREAM
description: Salem Drive scored his third stakes victory of the Florida winter season when he surged through on the inside to run down Equalize and win the $157,100 Gulfstream Park Breeders' Cup Handicap today at Gulfstream.

title:
DINING OUT;
A WARM AND RUSTIC SPOT IN RYE
description: LEAD: THE Black Bass Grille is a welcome addition to the area. Although this warm, pub-like dining spot and bar missed on a number of points, the place nevertheless has charm, the food has potential and the prices offer good value.

title: MAESTRO'S PROTEGE TO LEAD SYMPHONY
description: ANTONIO PAPPANO lived in London until 1973, when he was about 13 years old. But it was his life in Brideport, not Europe, that led him onto the podiums of many internationally renowned concert halls and opera houses.

title: POTATO DISHES PROVIDE SUSTAINING WINTER FARE
description: EVERY time I go back for a visit to England I realize how good potatoes can be.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: D.A.R., ALIVE AND KICKING

title: RETIREMENT: DAYS OF FREEDOM AND NATURAL WONDERS
description: HE wears retirement like a burnoose; it surrounds him but doesn't quite fit.

title: SENATE'S DAY ON CABLE TV
description: Live television coverage of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings on the Soviet-American treaty on intermediate-range nuclear missiles will be carried by C-SPAN, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network, beginning at 10 A.M. on Monday.

title: DEBBIE ISAACS TO WED C. M. KAMINER IN JUNE
description: The engagement of Debbie May Isaacs to Craig Martin Kaminer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John A. Isaacs 3d of St. Louis, parents of the future bride. Mr. Kaminer is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Kaminer of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: New HAVEN COLISEUM'S DEMISE IS FEARED
description: A PROPOSAL by Mayor Biagio DiLieto to tear down the New Haven Veterans Memorial Coliseum and use the site for a shopping mall has raised fears that the arena will not be replaced.

title: CHICAGO'S GRUMPY GURU
description: James Atlas describes the upheaval at Cornell University in the spring of 1969, when ''gun-toting blacks occupied Willard Straight Hall and threatened terrified administrators with a whole agenda of demands,'' an episode from which Mr. Bloom is ''still deeply traumatized.'' Readers might want to be reminded that these students did not just take it into their heads one day to pick up weapons and occupy the student union, as Mr. Bloom's book might lead us to suppose. Among the precipitating events, I recall, were cross-burnings on the lawn of the Afro-American student residence, and a brutal assault by a car full of whites upon a lone black freshman one evening, which left him unconscious.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Protecting Against A Weak Dollar

title: Asylum News Is a Miracle To L.I. Family
description: The news came to Tamas Koppany last Saturday, in a form letter from the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Because his request for political asylum had been denied and he had failed to leave the country, the letter said, deportation proceedings would begin against him, his wife and their 3-year-old daughter.

title: New York State to Add To Forest Preserve Area
description: New York State has agreed to buy 16,796 acres of land to add to the state forest preserve in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains.

title: GEORGE ST: 'LEAR' WITH TWISTS
description: IT is 1957 and a stooped-over but imposing elderly woman, wearing a fur-trimmed dressing gown, darts about at a backyard barbecue party in Smyrna, Ga., wielding a cane and followed by her entourage. She doles out pieces of cake to her three sons, demanding to know which loves her most.

title: Costa Rica's Quiet Beaches And Lush Landchief of The New York Times.
description: DIPPING and bobbing in their awkward way, the flock of shimmering green parrots swept into the bare guanacaste tree where they cacklingly congratulated themselves on their abrupt landing. All beak and feet, large parrots are poor airmen who seem ridiculously relieved to arrive anywhere at all. The noisy comedians of Latin skies, they flap madly through the air until they crash into a friendly tree, almost always with a shriek of gratitude.

title: Actresses And the Oscar Race
description: ''WHO IS PEARL HARBOR?'' SALLY White asks in Woody Allen's ''Radio Days.'' Sally's big break as a radio actress has been abruptly terminated by the announcement that the Japanese have attacked the United States naval base on Oahu. One minute before air time, Sally's debut performance has been canceled to make way for a special news broadcast.

title: A WIND-CHILL FACTOR OF ABOUT 200 FEET UP
description: THEIR eyes were set on the sky, where multi-colored triangles wafted in the breeze. Their feet were lodged in snow.

title: Thwarting Terror At U.S. Centers
description: IT LOOKS like an ordinary suburban sports van, but that's when the machine gun is stored inside. Actually it is an antiterrorist patrol vehicle, and a gunner can deploy the weapon through a motor-operated roof hatch.

title: FAIRFIELD DEFEATED BY FORDHAM, 63-61
description: Fred Quartlebaum, a reserve guard, sank two free throws with 10 seconds to play today to break a tie and give Fordham a 63-61 Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference victory over Fairfield.

title: Perspectives: Staten Island Wetlands; Looking to an Appeals Board for Relief
description: IT is easier to cry ''Save the wetlands!'' than it is to figure out what a wetland is - or so one can conclude from the debate that has swirled around New York State's efforts in the last several years to designate freshwater wetlands on Staten Island.

title: STEPHANIE SHEPARD TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Seth Shepard of Potomac, Md., of the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Lee Shepard to Erik Lipson, a son of Seymour Lipson of Philadelphia and Britt Lipson of Beulah, Mich.

title: A Deceptive Strategy
description: THAT clever satirist, Tom Lehrer, once explained in song the mental processes involved in subtraction: ''If you are over 35 and went to a private school, . . '' and so on. Where and when you learned your subject is also important for bridge players.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CORPORATE DISSENT;
When Leadership Collides With Loyalty
description: LEAD: DESPITE our cry for more effective leadership, I've become convinced that we are quite satisfied to do without it. We would much rather have loyalty than leadership. Recall the fight between former General Motors board member H. Ross Perot and G.M.'s chairman, Roger B. Smith, that erupted when someone other than the official leader of the corporation began to articulate a strategic vision for the company.

title: TALE OF TWO TOWERS ON BOSTON BOYLSTON STREET
description: There are times, occasion-ally, when the cumbersome, irritating, ponderous and essentially irrational process of public review of large building projects yields positive results, and this saga of two towers on Boylston Street is one of them. It is a long story that can be summarized like this: In 1982, the New England (formerly the New England Life Insurance Company), along with the Gerald D. Hines Interests development company, commissioned Philip Johnson and John Burgee to design a new headquarters for a site in Boston's Back Bay. The architects proposed a building consisting of twin 25-story slabs topped by arches, which was intended to look something like a 19th-century crystal palace stretched out into a skyscraper, but to many people this odd form looked more like a pair of 1930's Wurlitzer jukeboxes.

title: TRUCK RESTRICTIONS SAID TO POSE THREAT
description: FEDERAL transportation officials have ruled that environmental safety in Westchester is indirectly threatened by New York City regulations restricting the size of fuel tankers that can enter the city. The officials also said that the restrictions violate Federal law and also threaten the environment in parts of New Jersey.

title: Cabaret: Julienne Scanlon Sings
description: JULIENNE MARIE SCANLON, who was known only as Julienne Marie when she played leads in musicals on Broadway in the 1960's and early 70's, has renewed her singing career after a 10-year retirement with an act made up of songs that were sung in musicals by ''the other woman,'' the second female leads. It is a provocative idea because these songs were often more interesting than those given to the relatively bland lead roles.

title: Southwestern Breakfasts
description: BREAKFAST MAY BE THE FIRST meal of the day, but lately it has seemed last in our affections. The crackle and spatter of eggs, bacon and sausage on the griddle have become a casualty of hectic schedules and the latest diet plan. Breakfast seems to have lost its esthetic and psychological properties - warm, sustaining food shared by the family early in the day's labor - to become, at best, an injection of nutrients.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LINCOLN A Photobiography. By Russell Freedman. Illustrated. 150 pp. New York: Clarion Books/Ticknor & Fields. $15.95. (Age 9 and up)

title: ELIZABETH DANIELS RICH TO WED IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steven Weber of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Weber's daughter, Elizabeth Daniels Rich, to Michael Lindsay, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lindsay of Union City,, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: Aiding the Homeless Is Goal of Donors to Neediest
description: Erna Weill, a sculptor who lives in Teaneck, N.J., has been troubled for some time by the sight of families living out in the open.

title: RUNAWAY YOUTHS OFTEN HOMELESS
description: A GROWING number of teen-age runaways in Westchester are in reality homeless youths who are abandoning bleak motel rooms and trying to return to their own communities, according to the county Youth Board. Its latest report also describes how young males who lack education and training are deliberately putting themselves in jail and says that nearly 100 percent of homeless teen-age women in the county become pregnant.

title: WARSAW
description: Poland Extends An Official Hand To Rebel Artists Once Held At Arm's Length

title: EFFECT ON STATE OF NEW U.S. LAWS ASSESSED
description: A RECENT survey of Federal laws that have taken effect since Jan. 1 shows that several - ranging from changes in income tax provisions to the appropriation of hundreds of millions of dollars to clean up toxic-waste sites and build highways and tunnels - will have multiple effects on New Jersey.

title: Safety in Numbers: A Shiny New Look
description: THE safety pin has had nothing if not an interesting existence. It started off keeping diapers together; in a few old-fashioned families it still serves that purpose. Then came the punk movement, which turned this humble clasp into a symbol of rebellion.

title: FACING THE 'STICKY ISSUES'
description: BETWEEN WOMEN Love, Envy, and Competition in Women's Friendships. By Luise Eichenbaum and Susie Orbach. 223 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: AN IDENTITY LEFT BEHIND AT THE ALTAR
description: I WAS the only single woman left among my friends until three years ago. I remember that time well, because while my friends were altering their existence for a lifetime partnership, I was preparing for what I thought would be a life alone.

title: MS. PRESENT IS AFFIANCED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Present of New York and Pittsfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Danielle Present to Michael Joseph Podolak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Podolak of Kensington, Md.

title: INTELLECTUALS AND ASSASSINS - ANNALS OF STALIN'S KILLERATI
description: IN the latter half of the 1930's a gang of killers appeared in Western Europe whose accumulated crimes - considering their impact on history - are probably unequaled in the annals of murder. They were agents of the Soviet secret police - then called the N.K.V.D., now the K.G.B. - operating in a special unit dedicated to terrorism. The unit's existence became known through a series of sensational incidents 50 years ago - including the assassination in Switzerland in September 1937 of Ignace Reiss, an N.K.V.D. defector; the kidnapping from the streets of Paris of a White Russian general, Yevgeni Karlovich Miller, only weeks after Reiss's death; and the murder in a Paris hospital of the son of Leon Trotsky, Lev Sedov, in 1938. Though centered in Paris, the group's tentacles reached into Spain, where an anti-Stalinist leftist, Andreu (Andres) Nin, disappeared from police custody in June 1937. And in 1940 the leading member of the group, Leonid Eitingon, directed the assassination of Trotsky in Mexico.

title: A Town in California Where Waste Isn't Wasted
description: Public restrooms in this coastal city are called ''pre-treatment facilities.'' An office in City Hall is decorated with a poster of a toilet headlined ''The Origin.'' And every September, thousands of people are drawn to this city's foggy shoreline for the ''Flush With Pride'' festival.

title: SHRUGGING OFF THE INVADERS
description: CHRONICLE IN STONE By Ismail Kadare. 277 pp. New York: New Amsterdam Books/ The Meredith Press. $17.95.

title: British Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Bantam's $250,000 Gamble on Jorge Amado of Brazil
description: THE first novel by Jorge Amado was published in the United States in 1945 and more than a dozen others by the Brazilian author have been published here since. While Mr. Amado is one of the most popular foreign authors elsewhere in the world, his sales in the United States have never begun to match his international reputation. Three years ago Mr. Amado published another novel that become an international best seller. Titled ''Showdown,'' it is a tale of the violent settling of the backlands of Brazil's cacao country. Bantam Books bought it last year for $250,000, and it will be published in hardcover on Feb. 1.

title: 4 COMEDIES ON THE BILL IN YALE REP WINTERFEST SERIES
description: AT Winterfest, the annual plays-in-progress series at Yale Rep, the accent this year is on comedy.

title: A Blow to Journalism
description: To the Editor:

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
Couture Sets The Stage in Paris
description: LEAD: FOR THE SPRING AND SUMMER couture collections that open in Paris today, designers are talking about ''a logical continuity,'' which is a rather stark phrase given the feminine frivolities most of them are planning to show.

title: WITHOUT SIN, WITHOUT TIME
description: LEAD: THE FIFTH ESTATE By Ferdinando Camon. Translated by John Shepley. 163 pp. Marlboro, Vt.: The Marlboro Press. $16.95. LIFE EVERLASTING By Ferdinando Camon. Translated by John Shepley. 189 pp. Marlboro, Vt.: The Marlboro Press. $17.95.

title: WHEN BRADLEY IS READY . . .
description: AS THE small commuter plane flew through a storm, Bill Bradley outlined for Michael Kaye, a political media consultant, his plan for Federal tax reform. The plane rocked violently and Mr. Kaye paled at the prospect of a crash.

title: ZARZUELA'S TUNE: AUTHENTIC IBERIAN
description: TO music lovers, La Zarzuela is Spanish opera. To serious eaters, it's a classic seafood casserole. But, many Long Islanders think of a six-year-old Spanish restaurant in Rockville Centre when they hear La Zarzuela.

title: On the Drive: Fringe Co-ops
description: Proximity to a sewage treatment plant is not always a draw for co-op buyers, but Bernard McElhone hopes the $1 billion North River facility and New York State's promise to carpet its roof with grass and trees by the end of next year will attract purchasers to the upper reaches of Riverside Drive. His 31-unit building at 604 Riverside Drive is opposite the entrance at 138th Street to the planned Riverbank Park atop the plant.

title: OPERA, FOR LACK OF A BETTER WORD
description: MUSIC BY PHILIP GLASS By Philip Glass. Edited and with supplementary material by Robert T. Jones. Illustrated. 222 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: From Whitman to Plath, PBS Gives Poets a Voice
description: AMERICA FORGETS HER POETS.

title: What the Police and Courts Could Do
description: Beyond public attitudes, the police and the courts could do much to build confidence in the criminal justice system with specific reforms.

title: Tax Cut Sought On Capital Gain
description: President Reagan will ask Congress next week to reduce the tax on capital gains, White House officials said today.

title: Fresh Winds Blow Through French Museums
description: IN PARIS, THERE HAS LATELY BEEN more good art than almost anyone can keep up with. Momentarily, there will be much more. To those who remember how long and slow was the recovery of the great city from the effects of World War II, there is an element of wild exhilaration about the current exhibition schedule.

title: Bid for Grand Slam Now in Graf's Path
description: Steffi Graf became the Australian Open women's champion for the first time today. Now she can concentrate on winning the elusive Grand Slam.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Delaware and Raritan Canal Commission has proposed new land-use regulations that would further restrict development close to the canal.

title: Correction
description: A chart in The Times Magazine on Jan. 10 with the Body and Mind column, about the effect of alcohol on the removal of body fats, omitted credit for the source of the data. The credit line should have read as follows:

title: LISA DEZANGER TO WED ROBERT STUART SILBAUGH
description: The engagement of Lisa Suzanne deZanger to Robert Stuart Silbaugh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Silbaugh of Garden City, L.I., and Boynton Beach, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arie deZanger 2d of New York and Sugar Loaf, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in July.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FORTUNES. By Vera Cowie. (Dutton, $18.95.) Sure, ''Fortunes'' contains a glutton's share of sex and intrigue among the super rich, of glamour and betrayal in exotic locales, but it's more than mini-series fodder. Vera Cowie, the popular British author, can also write. When Charles Despard, owner of one of the world's most prestigious auction houses, dies, he leaves a will dividing control of his estate between his plain daughter Kate, who had proudly rejected him when he abandoned her mother for a second marriage, and his stepdaughter

title: KURT A. CORSO, AN ARTIST, IS MARRIED TO SUSAN FALK
description: At the Gramercy Park Hotel in Manhattan yesterday, Susan Lucia Falk and Kurt Antony Corso were married by the Rev. Mary Alice Brown of the Unity Church of Christ in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Civil Rights 'Patron Saint' Comes to Brooklyn
description: As the tiny, bespectacled woman made her way into the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn, an audience of 1,200 rose in admiration and curiosity, their Kodaks and Polaroids flashing. Downstairs, in the fellowship hall, an overflow crowd of several hundred watched on closed-circuit television.

title: THE REGION: A 30-Year Reign; MOB RULING AN EMPIRE OF GARBAGE
description: GARBAGE is still very much the Mafia's bag.

title: Attack Case Might Get a Special Prosecutor
description: Governor Cuomo will use a panel of top legal aides to decide if a special state prosecutor should be appointed in what has been described as a racial and sexual attack on a teen-age girl, a spokesman said today.

title: New Measurements
description: IT'S going to be easier to visit the outfield monuments in Yankee Stadium this season, but don't give the credit to Jack Clark. It's true that the project to widen the access paths to the monuments will require moving the fences in a bit at the left-center-field power alley, but Yankee officials say the plans were in place last July, well before the team picked up the right-handed power-hitter from the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: New Moves From Two Grand Old Men of Retailing
description: THEY both started with a single store in the South. Over the years, those stores multiplied and grew into sprawling empires blanketing the region and, lately, some of the rest of the country. Now, at a time when most of their contemporaries have long since given up the game, Sam M. Walton, the 70-year-old founder and chairman of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., and William Dillard, 74, his counterpart at Dillard Department Stores Inc., are still looking for new ways to fill the cash register.

title: PAMELA BIEL PLANS TO WED JAMES R. WETZEL 2D IN JUNE
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Biel Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela Biel to James R. Wetzel 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Wetzel of Baltimore.

title: WHAT IN THE WORLD IS GOING ON IN ARIZONA?
description: AT the first day of hearings on whether Governor Evan Mecham should be impeached, it was quickly apparent that his critics had a good deal of ammunition. But it was also clear that Mr. Mecham's greatest sin may not have been corruption or deceit, but that he had embarrassed Arizona.

title: A Great Hospital In Crisis
description: ANDY WARHOL HATED hospitals, so when the pain in his upper abdomen came on, he turned to his chiropractor-nutritionist. The pain persisted, and a specialist who gave the 58-year-old Pop artist collagen injections for smoothing face wrinkles urged him to see an internist. On Feb. 18, 1987, Warhol was advised by his regular physician, Dr. Denton S. Cox, that he needed immediate surgery to remove an infected gallbladder, normally a routine procedure. Pathologically fearful of dying, Warhol locked many of his valuables in a safe and on Feb. 20 checked into New York Hospital on Manhattan's Upper East Side. His operation on Feb. 21, all agree, was flawless. But by the next morning, he was dead. Andy Warhol's death last year and a continuing controversy over the 1984 death at that same hospital of Libby Zion, an 18-year-old Bennington College freshman, have plunged one of America's biggest and best-known medical centers into a state of siege. New York Hospital has been battered by government inquiries, bad publicity and internal dissension. It has seen its teaching system questioned, its pride diminished, its occupancy rate decline, and, in an unusual state action, three doctors affiliated with the hospital threatened with loss of their medical licenses. Throughout the hospital, anxiety is almost palpable - anxiety about what is happening inside patients' rooms and operating suites and administrative offices, and anxiety about how the institution looks from the outside, especially to prospective patients and staff and to philanthropists.

title:
Photo of Vincent Tese (pg. 1) (NYT); William J. Catacosinos; William L. Mack (pg. 11) (NYT);
SHOREHAM'S FUTURE: A DECISION NEARS
description: LEAD: ONE year after their first meeting, the nine directors of the Long Island Power Authority seemed agreed last week, after some pointed discussions among themselves, that the hour has struck for their crucial vote on whether to attempt a takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: OUR TOWNS AND CHANGE
description: Thank Heavens for public hearings! Often loud and argumentative, they are a unique part of our Yankee heritage and have determined the face of our Connecticut towns.

title: Fear of Crime, Fear of Justice; Innocent Whites - and Innocent Blacks
description: I was skating once with a group of my white friends . . . a policeman walked over to me and he pushed me against the wall, and he took out his club and he was like, 'What do you think, you're like them? Do you think you have the privileges they do?' . . . I do well in school, I'm a nice young person, I don't seem dangerous, I don't think. So why would you pick on me to do this to? . . . It doesn't seem right, really.

title: A MOTHER ASKS: WHAT PRICE GLORY?
description: A RECENT issue of a national news magazine brought some surprising news to my attention: It isn't enough to eat and rest well, avoid drugs and alcohol and see my doctor regularly to lead the proper pregnant life. Now, halfway into my third pregnancy, I learn that I should be playing ''educational'' tapes for my developing fetus to hear and presumably gain greater intelligence from.

title: STATE'S GROUP HOME ANGERS COMMUNITY
description: THE state has acquired a five-bedroom home here as the start of an $11 million program to reduce, from 835 to 500, the number of patients at the overcrowded Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital in Morris County.

title: Condo And Co-op Challenges
description: THE final weeks of January are traditionally the time in New York City when co-op directors and thousands of individual condominium owners start thinking about challenging their property tax assessments.

title: The United States and Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
LOOKING BACK AND AHEAD
description: LEAD: Anyone wanting to brush up on local history might do well to buy the Town of Mount Pleasant's 1988 community calendar. Designed to commemorate the town's 200th anniversary, it features a dozen photographs of historic sites in addition to day-by-day listings of bicentennial and community events.

title: F. W. LAFFERTY JR. AND HILARY EDDY TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Sackett Eddy of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Clark Eddy, to Frederick Wayne Lafferty Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lafferty of Baltimore. A May wedding is planned.

title: A Soviet Composer Awaiting Discovery
description: IT'S EXCITING TO COME ACROSS A talented new composer or performer.

title: Stories Make a Family
description: IN THE BEGINNING, AS FAR back in my family as anyone could go, was my great-grandmother, and her name was Annunziata. In the next generation, it would be my grandmother's name, in the generation after that (in its Anglicized form, Nancy) it would be my aunt's first name and my mother's middle name, and in the generation after that, my sister's middle name as well.

title: Temple Freshman a Wise Owl
description: AFTER the hordes of college recruiters have offered all they can offer, a high school basketball star chooses the school that has displayed something special for him. The temptation is not always wholesome, but for Mark Macon it was. He wanted a good education and a chance to see the country, but the hook would be a straight coach, someone he could trust. And he sensed that John Chaney of Temple University was that kind of coach.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 24, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: HORSES WANT TO KILL
description: TALES OF AN OLD HORSETRADER The First Hundred Years. By Leroy Judson Daniels. As told to Helen S. Herrick. 235 pp. Iowa City: University of Iowa Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Tyson, Spinks Closer
description: IN his wispy voice, Mike Tyson was talking about how ''Larry Holmes was a great and courageous champion in his time. I just wanted to let him know his time is over.'' And let the world know that Mike Tyson's time is now. But until the heavyweight champion fights Michael Spinks, his time will be clouded by the presence of the one heavyweight with the style that might confuse him, that might even conquer him.

title: 3 COLLEGES HELP UNCOVER A BIBLICAL CITY
description: LEAD: A NEW site has been added to the archeological map of Israel: Tel Hadar. Believed to be a buried Aramaean city, the ruins were discovered recently in the northern part of Israel.

title: HOW 4 WOMEN BUILT BUSINESSES
description: LEAD: AFTER a year in her own business, Gail D. Eagle of East Brunswick sometimes feels as if she is on vacation because she no longer works 15-hour days.

title: NASA GRANT HELPS BUY 7 SCHOOL SATELLITE DISHES
description: LEAD: USING a special NASA fellowship, the state is scheduled to add seven satellite receiving dishes for educational programs.

title: WADING RIVER TRIES TO RETAIN TRANQUIL PACE
description: FOR more than 300 years, since the first eight families settled here, residents of Wading River, a community that depends on others for government, have enjoyed the rural flavor of farm stands, a local general store, open fields and country roads. But a spurt of growth in the last decade is threatening to change the bucolic character of this waterfront community, and is generating a good deal of concern.

title: On Language; Ruling the Jet Set
description: Keep your eye on ruling,'' advised Maureen Dowd, a reporter for The New York Times, more than a year ago. She said that ruling, long used by Soviet propagandists to derogate American democracy in the term ruling circles, was now being used here as a participle to mean ''advanced, with-it, avant-garde'' or ''in.'' Two quite different senses are in use, confusing the incognoscenti: the first is ''doing well, going along fine,'' as in ''My day is ruling''; the second sense is ''socially dominant,'' as in ''Jackie O. rules.''

title: RELIGIOUS SCHOOLS GET U.S. AID ABROAD
description: The United States has funneled tens of millions of dollars to religious-affiliated schools and hospitals around the world under a little-known program administered by the Agency for International Development, The program, American Schools and Hospitals Abroad, has since 1971 quietly financed Jewish, Catholic and Protestant schools and hospitals in Africa, Latin America, Asia and the Middle East. The most sensitive part of the program has involved grants to Orthodox Jewish institutions in Israel whose primary purpose is to teach religious studies.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL North 21, South 7: Chris Chandler of Washington and Don McPherson of Syracuse each passed for a touchdown to lead the North in the 39th Senior Bowl yesterday. Chandler led a 99-yard scoring drive in the first period, hitting Willie Anderson of U.C.L.A. for a 36-yard touchdown. McPherson hit Anthony Miller of Tennessee on a 53-yard scoring play 50 seconds before halftime. The North, cutting the South's series lead to 19-17-3, built its lead to 21-0 early in the final quarter on a 1-yard run by Icky Woods of Nevada-Las Vegas one play after Mississippi Valley's Vincent Brown returned an intercepted pass 26 yards. The South avoided the first shutout in the game's 39-year history when Florida's Kerwin Bell connected with South Carolina's Sterling Sharpe for a 60-yard touchdown with 11:41 left.(AP) SKIING Mair Leads Italian Sweep: Michael Mair scored his first World Cup victory in more than two years, leading a 1-2-3 Italian sweep in a downhill race yesterday at Leukerbad, Switzerland. Mair was timed in 2 minutes 19.08 seconds for the third victory of his seven-season World Cup career. The bends and bumps on the 3,810-foot Torrent course with a 3,230-foot vertical drop were softened by fresh snow. Giorgio Piantanida and Werner Perathone finished second and third, in 2:19.42 and 2:19.69, respectively. The defending World Cup champion, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, finished 39th.(AP) Another Victory for Swiss: Beatrice Gafner continued Switzerland's domination of women's downhill racing this season, becoming the sixth consecutive skier from her country to win a World Cup race. In scoring her first triumph of the season, in the final women's downhill before next month's Olympics, Gafner led a 1-2 Swiss sweep at Badgastein, Austria, yesterday, beating her teammate, Brigitte Oertli. Gafner started second and sped down the long, winding course in 1 minute 43.80 seconds. Oertli, starting third, was timed in 1:44.14. Veronika Wallinger of Austria, the 23d starter, had the best result of her World Cup career, placing third in 1:44.60. Adele Allender of Sun Valley, Idaho, suffered a broken wrist in Friday's training and became the sixth American woman to suffer an injury this year.(AP) SKI JUMPING Mike Holland Wins 3d Straight: Mike Holland of Norwich, Vt., won his third straight event by capturing the 90-meter competition yesterday at the United States Olympic trials at Lake Placid, N.Y. Holland soared 103 and 109.5 meters to finish with 198.3 points. He had been assured of a spot on the team based on his previous World Cup performances. Mark Konopacke of Kingsford, Mich., was second with 191.8 points and Ted Langlois from Newport, N.H., came in third with 185.5. Both assured themselves of berths on the Olympic team. The seven-member ski-jumping team will be announced today after the 70-meter competition.(AP) HORSE RACING A Repeat Performance: For the second straight year, King's Swan and Jose Santos combined to take the Assault Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. King's Swan, the 8-year-old son of King's Bishop and Royal Cygnet, scored by 4 1/2 lengths over Palace March after leading most of the way. The victory was the third straight for Santos on yesterday's card. King's Swan covered the mile and an eighth in 1:48 4/5 to earn $68,160 as the favorite in a field of six. He paid $3.60 for $2 to win. The victory was his first in two starts this year and his 23d in 73 career starts. He finished first in the Aqueduct Handicap on Jan. 2 but was disqualified for interference during the stretch run. SCHOOL TRACK Invitations to the Millrose: Derisa Walters and Andrew Butler scored impressive victories yesterday at the Yale Interscholastic Meet in Coxe Cage on the Yale campus. Later, they accepted invitations to the Millrose Games high school mile runs in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 5. Walters, a 14-year-old freshmen from Penfield, N.Y., took over the lead with three laps to go, held off a late challenge by Kari Bertrand of East Syracuse, N.Y., and won the girl's mile in 4 minutes 56.57 seconds. Bertrand was second in 4:57.23. Butler, a junior at St. Raphael High School in Pawtucket, R.I., trailed the field in the boys' mile until the final 660 yards when he took the lead, winning in 4:18.47, his personal-best time. Joe Tuttle of Moore Catholic, Staten Island, was second in 4:19.02. Four records were posted in the girls' events. Monifa Taylor of Truman, the Bronx, took the 55-meter hurdles in :007.98, fastest in the nation this year. The other records went to Kim Kessell of Longwood, L.I., in the shot-put at 42 feet 5 inches; Tilden of Brooklyn in the 1,600-meter relay in 3:54.03, and Notre Dame of Staten Island in the 3,200-meter relay in 9:21.34. Ian Jones of Nazareth, Brooklyn, was the winner of the 400-meter dash in a record 49.05 seconds.

title: Go Gracefully, Mr. President
description: LEAD: ''All farewells should be sudden,'' Lord Byron counseled. The advice may be sound but it is not for Presidents to take. No one knows this better than Ronald Reagan, who must decide how he will play his final year in office.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING HOUSEPLANTS THROUGH WINTER
description: LEAD: ABOUT this time of year, a lot of house plants develop a case of the midwinter blahs.

title: Propping Up Payments at the Bottom
description: ONE of the most contentious pieces of legislation that Congress will face when it convenes a new session tomorrow is a bill to raise the minimum hourly wage, which has been $3.35 since 1981.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Loyalty of Good Soldiers
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver North may still be ''a national hero'' to President Reagan, but he's no paragon in the military. To high-ranking officers who met recently at the National Defense University, men every bit as loyal as he, Ollie North is an embarrassment.

title: Key to High School Censorship Case Was Public Ownership
description: To the Editor:

title: Removal of Dixie Flag Barred in Alabama
description: The state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will not be allowed to pull down the Confederate flag atop the Alabama Capitol, Gov. Guy Hunt said today.

title: Crazy Horse Saloon
description: To the Editor: My husband and I are irritated by the ''ranks lower than the others'' rating that Paul Chutkow gave the Crazy Horse Saloon (''Paris Is Still Kicking,'' Travel, Jan. 3).

title: FOR WASHINGTON, IDEAS TO SECURE AMERICA'S FUTURE
description: TOMORROWrrxh, the 100th Congress will convene for its second session, and Ronald Reagan will go to Capitol Hill to deliver to the assembled legislators the State of Union Message for his final year in office. The expectation, encouraged by the comments of senior White House officials, is for few new initiatives. ''We've already done so much,'' one aide said. But so much remains to be done.

title: Japan and Iceland Will Defy Ban on the Killing of Whales
description: Japan and Iceland will continue to hunt whales despite an international moratorium and have threatened to leave the International Whaling Commission if the organization objects, Icelandic radio and officials said today.

title: CHICAGO'S GRUMPY GURU
description: Allan Bloom's colleague Saul Bellow asks: ''Who is the Tolstoy of the Zulus? The Proust of the Papuans?'' He implies that these people have not reached the stage of civilization required to produce artists of this stature.

title: FIDEL CASTRO WANTS A COKE
description: MONGOOSE R.I.P. A Blackford Oakes Novel. By William F. Buckley Jr. 322 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Streetscapes: 13th Regiment Armory; A Brooklyn Fortress Yields to the Changing Times
description: NEW YORK CITY'S armories are generally elaborate structures, often with 200-foot-wide drill halls and unusual architectural character. But as the need for armories has declined since their heyday at the turn of the century, several have been demolished and it has been hard to find alternative uses for the others. The 13th Regiment Armory in Bedford-Stuyvesant, which is being renovated as a shelter for the homeless, is typical of a trend in armory adaptation.

title: Israel Says Troops in Arab Areas Will Be More Closely Supervised
description: The Israeli Army, concerned about reports of excessive brutality and beatings of Palestinians by Israeli soldiers, said today it would take steps to increase supervision of soldiers in the field.

title: ADJUSTING TO THE TRANSITIONS OF LIFE
description: THE other day, I took my wife's car to the garage for a periodic checkup. Six hours later and $436.61 poorer, I had the ransomed car back home.

title: FEMALE ENTREPRENEURS: A FAST-GROWING FORCE
description: LEAD: AN INCREASING number of women are entering the world of business ownership. But whether a woman employs 1 part-time or 10 full-time workers, whether her business is teetering, starting to move or wildly successful, chances are she welcomes a chance to exchange ideas with other female business owners.

title: U.S. OLYMPIC OUTLOOK: GOLD COULD BE RARE
description: IN the good old summertime of 1984, the most popular song on the charts was ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' Now, it's the winter of 1988, and by the close of the Olympic Games next month, the national anthem may seem like a golden oldie.

title: Iraqi's Death in Sudan Linked to Iran Faction
description: A prominent Iraqi dissident was shot to death in a Sudanese hotel last weekend, and Arab diplomats in Lebanon linked his death to a plan by opponents of the Baghdad Government to establish a rival government backed by Iran.

title: A LITTLE NOTICE FOR A LITTLE-KNOWN SPORT
description: WHEN Evelyn Nostrand mentions curling to her friends, they usually assume she's referring to her hair. ''I tell them, no, I'm not talking about hair, but about my favorite winter sport,'' she said.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
A NURSING HOME CHRISTMAS
description: LEAD: 'LET'S visit Sue on our way home,'' my husband suggested. It was Christmas, and we were celebrating with my parents. My affirmative reply was not notably enthusiastic.

title: SCHOOL VIDEOS OPEN NEW DOORS FOR PRODUCERS AND ACTORS
description: AN ambulance speeds down a narrow street in Irvington and stops beside a teen-ager lying in the road, severely injured after being thrown from her car in a collision. As ambulance volunteers prepare the girl to be taken to a hospital, a silent group watches intently. One films the incident from atop a truck, one holds a microphone, and a third studies the drama on a television monitor.

title: Dan Daniel, Virginia Congressman, Is Dead at 73
description: Representative Dan Daniel, a 10-term Democratic Congressman from Virginia, died today after suffering a heart attack. He was 73 years old. Mr. Daniel earlier this week said that poor health would prevent him from seeking re-election.

title: AUTO-INSURANCE RESOLUTION SOUGHT
description: PRESSURE on the pocketbook, the type both the public and elected officials respond to, began building last week behind the need to change the state's automobile insurance system.

title: Columbia U. Announces the Appointment of 66 to Jury for the Pulitzer Prizes
description: Columbia University yesterday announced the 66 newspaper editors, executives and others who will make up the jury to nominate entries for this year's Pulitzer Prizes in journalism.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; Dobbs Ferry
description: LAURENCE DENGLER stood in the dining room of his red-brick ranch in suburban Westchester County and pointed to a towering, 600-year-old beech tree in the backyard.

title: Auto Executive Ready To Take On the T.V.A.
description: In the nearly 55 years since the Tennessee Valley Authority was created as a public agency with the flexibility to operate much like a private corporation, it has wandered from that ideal on a path as meandering as the mountain rivers it has sought to tame.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BASEBALL CLINIC Bobby Valentine, manager of the Texas Rangers, is to be one of seven speakers at a baseball clinic from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. Saturday in the Physical Education Center on the West Hartford campus of the University of Hartford.

title: HOUSECLEANING PLAN FOR THE HALL OF FAME
description: ARGUMENTS about mediocre ballplayers in the Hall of Fame come up all the time. When they do, I always think of the term Thomas Hoving dreamed up while delicately cleaning house as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He wasn't getting rid of masterpieces, merely ''deaccessioning'' a few works the museum no longer needed.

title: B.Y.U. HITS 14-0; IOWA STATE UPSET
description: Jim Usevitch scored 24 points and led a strong inside game today that powered Brigham Young to an 89-82 Western Athletic Conference victory over New Mexico.

title: THE BLACK WRITER AND THE MAGIC OF THE WORD
description: AT a certain point in my writing career, after I had done three books, I made a decision. I wanted to reach out to readers that the earlier works had perhaps excluded. I wanted to get everybody's ear. I had in mind a book for people familiar with America, with the technique and history of the novel - a book that audience could appreciate and applaud and relate to the Great Traditions, if there really are such things. But at the same time a book my brothers, sister, aunts, uncles, cousins, mother and father would want to read. And in my mind it became quite clear that I wouldn't be writing down to a black audience. My people's lives embrace the whole range of human experience. In fact, the language they speak, refined and tested by centuries of racial oppression and racial assertion, offers a unique vision of America. So it wasn't a question of condescending to a less educated set of readers, but of becoming more ambitious.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Variety of Futons And Accessories Arise Futon Mattress Company in White Plains and a franchise in Mount Kisco are part of a group of metropolitan-area stores supplying cotton foldable mattresses, easy-to-assemble frames and convertible, wood-slatted sitting-or-sleeping arrangements for studio apartments and college dormitories, family rooms and offices, living rooms and wherever else overnight guests are stowed in what is usually sitting space. Each futon - the Japanese word for bedding - has a 15-year warranty on workmanship and materials.

title: IN PHYSICS, DO TINIER FACTS ADD UP TO THE GRAND TRUTH?
description: FROM a 2,000-foot television tower in North Carolina comes news guaranteed to irritate physicists who thought that their theory of the universe -with four fundamental forces and dozens of subatomic particles - was already cluttered enough.

title: Commercial Property: Model Offices; Setting Up on a Small Scale Helps to Avoid Trouble
description: IN the showroom and on the design schematic, the leather-backed chair and the pedestal desk seemed to be a great combination for 95 offices in the headquarters center American Re-Insurance is erecting in Plainsboro, N.J.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: EXCHANGE RATES;
A Cheap Dollar Won't Cure the Deficit
description: LEAD: CURRENCY markets are in turmoil. Not only has the dollar declined by 40 percent against the Japanese yen and the German mark during the last year, but there is beginning to be a measure of suspicion that devaluation will not do much to improve America's balance of payments in the foreseeable future.

title: DOES PRO GOLF NEED A NEW STAR TO SUCCEED?
description: Do you think the tens of thousands of fans who cheer for Seve, Fuzzy, Greg and Jack realize that not one of them won during the 1987 tour? The PGA had 37 winners out of its 46 events in 1987. Corporate sponsorship, spectator attendance, prize money, charitable contributions and media coverage all were up last year. The PGA Tour does not need an old or a new ''star'' to succeed. Golf is the star on the men's tour.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A MOTHER'S LEGACY: 3 DECADES OF THEATER
description: LEAD: WHEN I was young, I wondered what I would do if my mother died. I was an only child, fatherless since infancy and raised by a woman who compensated for fate's improvidence by being both father and sibling.

title: Budget Holiday In the South Pacific
description: LEAD: WHEN we started talking about Tahiti our friends warned us it would cost a lot of money - which we didn't have. They told us horror stories of $400 hotel rooms and $20 Continental breakfasts. My husband, Michael, and I were both at Stanford on sabbatical; this was our chance to go to the South Pacific, and Tahiti was our first choice.

title: Looking Back on A Cavalcade of TV
description: IT WAS NOT THE AMERICANS BUT the British who largely invented television, as the new public-TV series ''Television'' makes clear. And so, there may be a certain poetic justice in the fact that this eight-part retrospective of the medium, which makes its hourlong debut tomorrow night at 8 on Channel 13, is based on a British series that ran three years ago in England but was never shown in this country. Yet the two productions are profoundly different in emphasis and tone, despite the fact that 35 percent of the material in ''Television'' comes from the British original.

title: NASSAU PRESSES FOR V.A. UNIT
description: LEAD: THE Veterans Administration's rejection of Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta's request that it use one floor of the Nassau County Medical Center as a medical facility has drawn criticism from veterans and politicians, who say such a facility is needed.

title: Haas Shoots 68-268 to Lead Tway by a Stroke in Hope Golf
description: On the fourth straight perfect day for golf in this desert resort area, Jay Haas once again took the sole lead after 72 holes of the 90-hole Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: BREATHES there a soul in this city who has never been whacked or tripped by a duffel bag, backpack, briefcase or shopping bag? Maybe -if that soul has a car and driver and a personal shopper, never stands in movie lines and confines his or her walking to thoroughfares like Madison and Fifth Avenues between 2 and 4 A.M.

title: SAY HEY, GROVER LOWDERMILK!
description: CLASSIC BASEBALL CARDS The Golden Years 1886-1956. By Frank Slocum. Foreword by Yogi Berra. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Warner Books. $79.95. BASEBALL IN THE '50S A Decade of Transition. By Donald Honig. Illustrated. 238 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $24.95. MAYS, MANTLE, SNIDER A Celebration. By Donald Honig. Illustrated. 151 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: She's The Top
description: SHE HAS AN ATHLETE'S lithe body and a trumpeting soprano voice. But when Patti LuPone makes her entrance in ''Anything Goes,'' what grabs you is her face. Emphasized by stage lighting and set off by a turban and orange wig, Ms. LuPone's face positively stretches forward: a hooked Roman nose above big lips and a strong chin. It's an expressive face, full of experience, with no apologies. When her jaw drops in comic surprise or her mouth curls with annoyance or her dark eyes shift sideways in assessment, each small gesture hits the audience.

title: HOLLY TROXELL PLANS TO WED
description: The engagement of Holly Dana Troxell to Peter Eric Ruhlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Ruhlin of New Canaan, Conn., and Hilton Head, S.C., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. D. Chase Troxell of Short Hills, N.J., and Chatham, Mass. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: RONNA L. TULGAN TO MARRY THOMAS W. OSTHEIMER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry Tulgan of Pittsfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ronna Lynn Tulgan, to Thomas Winslow Ostheimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Ostheimer of York, Me.

title: PATRIOTS AND OTHER SUSPECTS
description: QUEST FOR AN ISLAND Vassily Aksyonov. 246 pp. New York: PAJ Publications/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: James D. Theberge; Former Ambassador, 56
description: James D. Theberge, a former United States Ambassador to Nicaragua and Chile, died of a heart attack Wednesday on a visit to Jamaica. He was 57 years old and had lived in Washington.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A Boom in Hackensack Sets Off Alarms
description: LEAD: AFTER decades of neglect, Hackensack has come back to life in the 1980's both as a vital commercial center and as an attractive city in which to build housing.

title: FRAMED BY HER HUSBAND
description: LULLABY AND GOOD NIGHT By Vincent T. Bugliosi with William Stadiem. 405 pp. New York: New American Library. $17.95.

title: Passion and Intrigue Seethe On a Greek Island in 1908
description: HERE, WHERE COLOSSUS IS said to have straddled the harbor and where history hides behind the geometric sprawl of modernity, James Dearden, who wrote the hugely successul ''Fatal Attraction,'' turned for his next excursion into passion, intrigue and betrayal.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: JIM THORPE, PA.;
Mauch Chunk Rejuvenation
description: LEAD: SPURRED by tourism, this mountain village of gingerbread porches and steam railroad lore has experienced a growth in its economy in the last five years that has created 45 new businesses and caused property values to triple.

title: Restaurants
description: To the Editor: This past fall we spent an enjoyable two weeks in Paris. We particularly delighted in the quality of the French cuisine; not only the subtleties and nuances of fragrance and taste but also its beauty of presentation, the elegance of restaurant decor and the impeccable service. However, into the midst of this culinary splendor, our privacy and senses were assaulted on numerous occasions by smokers, often seated in close proximity.

title: SNOWTHROWERS: CARE AND FEEDING
description: TO those who own or use a snowthrower, happiness is trouble-free operation. Although knowing how to operate a snowthrower safely and skillfully is important, smooth sailing throughout the snow season depends largely on performing manufacturer-recommended maintenance thoroughly and on time. Complete maintenance information is usually printed in the owner's manual furnished with the snowthrower or available from the manufacturer.

title: In Iowa Caucuses, Uncommitted Did Better Than Jimmy Carter
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C.A.A. Ticket Lottery
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern Regional basketball tournament at Byrne Meadowlands Arena March 24 and March 26 will allocate tickets by lottery.

title: SOVIET IMPLICATES OFFICIALS IN BRIBES
description: A five-year investigation has uncovered bribery and corruption that cost the Uzbek Republic at least $6.5 billion and involved high-ranking officials, including the son-in-law of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today.

title: TENEMENT VIRTUES
description: To the Editor:

title: JODI F. KRIEGER ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David E. Krieger of Spring Valley, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Jodi F. Krieger to Gary Alan Kittrell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Kittrell of Brooklyn. Ms. Krieger and her fiance expect to graduate in May from the Brooklyn Law School. She is an alumna of the State University at Binghamton, N.Y. He graduated from the University of Connecticut.

title: 5 Slain in Landover, Md.
description: Five people were killed and one was wounded in apparently drug-related violence in this Washington suburb, said a police spokeswoman, Officer Carol Landrum. She said the five people, whose bodies were found in an apartment, had not been identified. The spokeswoman declined to say why police believed the killings were drug-related.

title: Correction
description: A listing on Jan. 3 with an article about Zurs, Austria, gave hotel rates incorrectly. The rates cited were for one person in double occupancy, not for two people in a room.

title: CBS AND SNYDER
description: RACISM crawled out from under a rock of silence and onto the network airwaves once again last week. Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder's comments to a Washington television news reporter for a report about the progress of blacks in society revealed a mind married to a number of dangerous stereotypes.

title: Truth in Travel
description: To the Editor:

title: A 1905 Melodrama Is Alive and Well in Soho
description: ''AN AMERICAN JOURNALIST WAS absolutely infuriated with all the drama that was coming over here from England - angry that the theater was being so dominated by the British, when America had a perfectly good drama of its own. That was in 1832,'' says British-born Julian Webber, who is directing the revival of David Belasco's 1905 melodrama, ''The Girl of the Golden West,'' opening Friday at the Soho Repertory Theater. ''In other words, the complaint about the British influx has been going on for over a hundred years. The fact is, there's a sort of cultural inferiority complex, when actually there is an extraordinarily strong American dramatic heritage, and 'The Girl of the Golden West' is part of that. I want to show that it's a great play.''

title: 66 WAYS OF LOOKING AT OUR LITERATURE
description: COLUMBIA LITERARY HISTORY OF THE UNITED STATES Emory Elliott, general editor. Martha Banta, Terence Martin, David Minter, Marjorie Perloff and Daniel B. Shea, associate editors. Houston A. Baker, Nina Baym, Sacvan Bercovitch and Louis D. Rubin Jr., advisory editors. 1,263 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $59.95.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS DECRY TEST OF PLASTICS
description: THE New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection has, since October, been putting eight-ounce plastic vials containing self-addressed and color-coded postcards into Raritan Bay and New York Harbor.

title: DOES PRO GOLF NEED A NEW STAR TO SUCCEED?
description: No! There are many players on the PGA Tour who possess both the talent and qualities needed to attain star status. It is rather that viewers are subjected to media coverage that focuses on past achievers and achievements. Jack Nicklaus attracts much too much camera time, even when he's playing 7 over par. Tom Watson is often found in the spotlight but not on the leader board. And then, there's the Skins Game: Palmer, Trevino, Nicklaus and Zoeller year after year after year after year. Does golf really need another star, or does television need to concentrate more on the players and the good play that already exists? AL CORSINI Westbury, L.I.

title: AN AGENDA FOR DEALING WITH 1988
description: IT has been my observation that Long Island has changed fundamentally in recent decades, and that we, by which I mean all those concerned about public issues in our region, have not yet fully come to terms with those changes and what they mean for the future.

title: THE SHOULDER PAD: LIKE IT OR LUMP IT
description: THIS will be remembered as the year of the shoulder pads. As fast as I could take them out, designers and manufacturers were putting them in.

title: Snyder Resting
description: ONE week after being dismissed by CBS Sports because of controversial remarks on black people and athletics, Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder checked into a North Carolina hospital complaining of chest pains on Friday, but hospital officials said yesterday that he was in good condition and in no apparent danger.

title: STEPHANIE GOSLER ENGAGED TO ALAN H. FREUDENSTEIN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joel H. Gosler of Jersey City have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Lynn Gosler to Alan Howard Freudenstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Freudenstein of Teaneck, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: HELPING CHILDREN TO FAIL
description: q THE LEARNING MYSTIQUE A Critical Look at ''Learning Disabilities.'' By Gerald Coles. 330 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BUILDING A HOME
description: LEAD: Known as the ''Y without walls,'' the Northern Westchester Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. will soon have a permanent home - the former Bear Ridge Elementary School in the town of Mount Pleasant. The nonprofit community organization, which now serves more than 600 families, will be opening the doors of its new center during its 10th anniversary year.

title: Vivid Images From An Ancient World
description: ANCIENT CARTHAGE - A city of immense wealth where commerce and culture flourished - left a legacy of some of antiquity's most compelling mosaics, 17 of which are on view at the American Museum of Natural History through May 1.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CELLO CONCERTO In keeping with his mission to promote the contemporary and rarely played cello repertory, Yehuda Hanani, the Israeli cellist, will perform Luigi Boccherini's Cello Concerto in B Flat Major at 8 P.M. Saturday as soloist with the Chappaqua Orchestra at Horace Greeley High School.

title:
INVESTING;
How Top Managers Adjust to Volatility
description: LEAD: INDIVIDUAL investors have been virtually absent from the stock market in the wake of the October market plunge, but some of the top-performing equity mutual fund managers continue to buy stocks. They are proceeding carefully, though. Because of increased volatility and the relative scarcity of buyers, the managers see no need to chase stocks.

title: Guns Mark End of Mourning for Tribal Chief in Afghanistan
description: The thud of artillery and the crackle of gunfire filled Jalalabad today, a day after two terrorist bombs killed 17 mourners during the funeral of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, the pacifist leader of the Pathan people.

title: Q And A
description: Condo Improvements

title: FOUR COMMUNITIES TO ASSESS PLANS FOR HOUSING HOMELESS
description: THE first four sites have been chosen for 258 temporary homes for Westchester's homeless but it will be three to six months before a shovel goes into the ground on any of them, according to Robert Schulman, the designated developer for the housing.

title: Towns Use Zoning To Rein In Growth
description: IN heightened efforts to prevent overdevelopment and to preserve the character of suburban communities, several Nassau County municipalities have recently revised their zoning codes, and in most cases, the amendments provide more restrictive requirements for single-family homes, two-family housing, parking lots and building heights.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This country faces a great problem with entrenched management. If shareholders don't stand up for their rights, we are going to be a third-rate power.''

title: James Harris: Almost in the Super Bowl
description: HE came as close as a quarterback can come - second and goal on the Vikings' 1-yard line, fourth quarter, 4 points behind, needing a touchdown to lead his team to the Super Bowl.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DREAD. By Robert Steiner. (Sun & Moon, Cloth, $15.95; Paper, $10.95.) Robert Steiner's ''Dread'' examines how expectation and fantasy imbue experience with a ''soft-core realism.'' His main character, Keller, who enters the lives of two American couples vacationing aboard a Mediterranean cruise ship, runs off to Cairo with Hilly, one of the wives.

title: Tyson Never Let Up
description: Back in November, at the Larry Holmes Training Center in Easton, Pa., the man after whom the facility was named was standing before the speed bag, talking - riffing, really - as his hands beat a steady rhythm on the small bag.

title: TOKYO QUARTET TO PLAY AT PURCHASE
description: MANY ensembles take on the complete cycle of Beethoven Quartets as an early challenge in their collective careers, but not so the Tokyo String Quartet. It took well more than 15 years of international concertizing before the Tokyo felt ready to tackle this most demanding of musical enterprises. That was in the summer of 1986, and since then the quartet has repeated the cycle a number of times, always to great critical and audience acclaim.

title: SENATE HEARINGS ON MISSILE TREATY A TEST FOR REAGAN
description: Against the backdrop of election-year politics, rivalries among Senators and uncertainty over the future of arms control, the Senate begins consideration Monday of the arms treaty that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed at their summit meeting here last month.

title: Q&A
description: Mexico Question: I have heard there is an organization that conducts tours and seminars for Americans considering retirement in Mexico. Do you have the address and details? - L. V., New York, N.Y. Answer: A travel company called RIM, for Retirement in Mexico, was formed in Mexico City about a year ago, and since October has been represented by Barvi Tours, a Los Angeles company. Barvi organized a series of seminars on the West Coast for people interested in retiring in Mexico and has started a tour program. Efren Marquez, the manager of Barvi, who comes from Guadalajara, says a typical 12-night tour begins in Mexico City with a four-hour seminar on investment, health facilities and real estate and visits to residential areas near the city. Two nights are spent in each of Guanajuato, San Miguel de Allende and Morelia and three nights in Guadalajara. From Guadalajara, there are visits to the Lake Chapala area. Visitors on the tour are transported with a guide by van or car, Mr. Marquez said.

title: From the Necks Down
description: ''I'D SAY WE'RE ONE OF THE world's smallest manufacturers of electric guitars,'' says Jolyon Dantzig, who with his partner, Frank Untermyer (above), operates Hamer Guitars in Arlington Heights, Ill. Specialists in custom-made instruments for professional musicians, Hamer does regular business with rockers like The Police, Judas Priest, Billy Idol and Steve Stevens. The Flying V doubleneck Untermyer is working on is for Jeff Watson of the band Night Ranger. Hamer has five Night Ranger guitars in production, including one with a snakeskin finish and one with greenish holograms, made to look like eyeballs, embedded in a pink body. ''For us, the imagination is the limit,'' Dantzig says. ''We've built a guitar with five necks.''

title: SHIRA MORRISON ENGAGED TO J. I. KANTER
description: The engagement of Shira Ilena Morrison to Jonathan I. Kanter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Kanter of Clifton, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Morrison of Summit, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 30-year-old house has cedar shakes on the outside. To my knowledge, these shakes have never been painted or treated in any way. Should we leave them as is, or should they be treated in some way?

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING HOUSEPLANTS THROUGH WINTER
description: LEAD: ABOUT this time of year, a lot of house plants develop a case of the midwinter blahs.

title: Exploring A Jungle Park In Costa Rica
description: MOST visitors arrive barefoot -and with warm, wet sand between their toes - at the entrance to Manuel Antonio National Park on Costa Rica's Pacific coast. We were no exception, having shed our sandals to stroll along North Espadilla Beach just outside the park, then ford a shallow, sun-warmed estuary that hugs the tumble of rock and vegetation at beach's end.

title: THE TALK OF NEW ROCHELLE300 YEARS OF HISTORY AND MYTH IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: LEAD: ARLY morning in snowy Hudson Park is more than bracing - it is bone-chilling. The wind whipping off Long Island Sound can lower temperatures to well below zero, hardly fit for man or beast.

title: Venezuelan Ban Throws Auto Rally Off Track
description: Bending to pressure from environmental groups here, the Government has refused to allow a transcontinental automobile rally sponsored by the Exploration Society of America to cross Venezuelan territory.

title: PROSPECTS
description: What's in Store for Banks?

title: The Senate and Conditions
description: Although senators routinely speak of offering amendments, reservations or understandings to the Soviet-American treaty on intermediate-range nuclear missiles, staff members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee say these terms are outmoded.

title: Cyprus
description: To the Editor: With reference to the item ''Visiting Cyprus,'' I would like to comment on the last paragraph, which, to our profound disappointment, purported to deal with issues pertaining to travel to Northern Cyprus in a very misleading fashion and totally based on false information provided by sources other than the authorized representatives of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.

title: Culture Clashes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stage: Jawole Zollar In 'Song of Lawino'
description: JAWOLE WILLA JO ZOLLAR has had a consistent and innovative interest in mining tradition and creating new ritual, most notably with her Urban Bush Women company and with Edwina Lee Tyler and Tiye Giraud, composers and musicians who share her passionate involvement. In ''Song of Lawino,'' which opened Thursday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, the three women have joined Valeria Vasilevski, the experimentalist director and writer, for an evening of incomparably rich and powerful theater. Music, dance, the spoken word and teeming visual elements are combined in this seamless collaboration.

title: MICHELLE RITHOLZ ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton Ritholz of Bellmore, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Michelle Ritholz to Gary Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bernstein of Searingtown, L.I. Miss Ritholz is a special assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. Her fiance is an associate in the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler. A fall wedding is planned.

title: The Foreign Policy Tussle
description: JAMES CLAUDE WRIGHT JR., the Speaker of the House, is perfectly happy to bask in the glow of a historic moment, but he is not one to waste time on social small talk. So when he arrived at the White House for the state dinner last month honoring Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Texan was determined to catch the ear of a ranking Soviet official and promote his views of the Central American peace process.

title: Sweden's Set of Six Depicts Its Inland Boats
description: INLAND boats and waterways play an important role in philately. Sweden recently added to the field with a set of six stamps that use inland boats as a commom motif.

title: JAMES G. TURINO AND JULIE L. KALBERER, ARCHIRTECTS, PLAN TO BE MARRIED IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kalberer, of Providence and Wakefield, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Lawton Kalberer to James Gerard Turino, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerard Turino of Alpine, N.J, and East Hampton, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: INCINERATOR STIRS FEARS IN GROTON
description: LEAD: A HAZARDOUS-WASTE incinerator that the Electric Boat Division wants to build at its shipyard in the city of Groton has some residents wondering whether the city of 11,000 is paying too big a price as home to the southeastern Connecticut's largest employer.

title: The Opera: Pavarotti and Freni in 'La Boheme'
description: CARLOS KLEIBER, who made his Metropolitan Opera debut on Friday evening as conductor of the season's eighth ''La Boheme,'' arrived on a wave of excited expectation that had to make one wary. Before he even lifted the baton, the 57-year-old German musician was treated to the kind of heady ovation that many conductors do not receive after their finest performances. Obviously, celebrity has caught up with Mr. Kleiber in spite of - or because of - his reputation as a difficult fellow who restricts his appearances sharply and demands extra rehearsals when he does accept an engagement.

title: DOES PRO GOLF NEED A NEW STAR TO SUCCEED?
description: The answer has to be no. People who watch golf are for the most part more interested in good shot-making, better coverage and carrying an event to its conclusion. STEVEN S. WEBER Brooklyn

title: SPREADING THE WESTERN DISEASE
description: THE WORLD REVOLUTION OF WESTERNIZATION The Twentieth Century in Global Perspective. By Theodore H. Von Laue. 396 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: DELEGATES TO ALBANY OUTLINE GOALS FOR BUDGET
description: LEAD: AFTER a long weekend of listening to constituents in their home districts, the county's 13 state legislators returned to Albany last week to determine how Westchester would be affected by Governor Cuomo's $44.2 billion budget proposal.

title: Periwigs and Brocade
description: THE RISE OF CATHERINE THE GREAT With Douglas Fairbanks Jr. (in photo), Flora Robson and Elizabeth Bergner. Embassy/Nelson Entertainment. 88 minutes. $39.95.

title: JENNIFER HALL ARLEN, A LAW PROFESSOR, TO WED ROBERT LEE HOTZ, A REPORTER
description: Jennifer Hall Arlen and Robert Lee Hotz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Hotz of Washington and Middletown, Md., plan to marry in May, the parents of the future bride, Ann Warner Arlen and Michael Arlen, both of New York, have announced.

title: With the Smiling Face
description: Michael Deaver, that Icarus of influence peddlers, has a new lease on freedom. A Federal appeals court struck down the independent counsel law as unconstitutional, holding that it invaded the authority of the executive branch. Because the overconfident Deaver prosecutor disdained a parallel appointment from the Justice Department (as the Iran-contra prosecutor was careful to accept), Mike may never have to pay for lying under oath.

title: Some Things Are New
description: OLYMPUS, the Japanese camera maker, which featured off-the-film flash metering and compact single-lens-reflex design, has announced a handful of new products. They range from a budget-priced point-and-shoot camera to a Super-VHS format video camcorder.

title: 'LE CORSAIRE': PASSIONATE TALE TOLD ANEW
description: LENINGRAD'S KIROV BALLET RECENTLY concluded a two-month season in Paris that included the first full-length version of ''Le Corsaire'' seen in the West since this initially French work was staged in Russia in the 19th century.
