So fascinating and entertaining was this venture that one even felt impelled to go back to the ballet's literary inspiration - namely, the long poem Byron wrote in 1814 and entitled ''The Corsair.''

title: 10 Minutes From Doom
description: To the Editor:

title: Tuner Separates Bach From the Beasties
description: MORE PEOPLE NOW live farther from urban centers than at any time in recent years.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE SUPERCONDUCTIVITY BUSINESS
description: UNTIL 1986, most people had never heard of superconductivity. But for 75 years scientists have known that certain materials lose all resistance in conducting electricity under conditions of extreme cold. Such temperatures can be achieved only by cooling with liquid helium, which is quite expensive and difficult to use.

title: DATA BANK: January 24, 1988

IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FROM SET SHOT TO SLAM DUNK: The Glory Days of Basketball in the Words of Those Who Played It. By Charles Salzberg. (Dutton, $17.95.) Professional basketball hasn't always been a spectacle of airborne wizardry performed by players who often earn millions of dollars during their careers. The game favored in the early years of the National Basketball Association (formed in 1949) emphasized team play planted securely on the ground, and players often rode the overnight sleeper to Syracuse or Fort Wayne, Ind., or Waterloo, Iowa.

title: Falmouth, Mass.: Homeowners On an Airstrip
description: WHEN they look for sites on which to build $300,000 homes, most developers stay as far away from an airfield as they can.

title: MS. KINBERG ENGAGED TO ARTHUR J. DECROSS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Kinberg of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Donna Kinberg, to Arthur Joseph DeCross, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur DeCross Jr. of West Brighton, S.I. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: MODEL RAILROADING

title: CONTRA AID FOES GAINING IN HOUSE
description: With a crucial vote less than two weeks away, there is a growing reluctance in Congress to approve new military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, even among some members of Congress who are key to the Administration's strategy.

title: Navy Trident 2 Missile Fails For First Time in 9 Launches
description: The Navy's new Trident 2 submarine missile has failed for the first time in nine test launchings, officials have reported.

title: A FAMILIAR STRANGER
description: LEAD: CHAMBERET Recollections From an Ordinary Childhood. By Claude Morhange-Begue. Translated by Austryn Wainhouse. 115 pp. Vermont: The Marlboro Press. $14.95.

title: The Treaty in the Senate
description: What the intermediate-range missle treaty would do, the issues in dispute and the people likely to lead the debate. Page 12.

title: Taking a Trip Overseas With the Kids
description: ON that always anxious night before the end of winter vacation, our 10-year-old son, Josh, sat on the edge of the bed, legs swinging.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A NEW AWARD
description: LEAD: WHEN it came to Westchester's youth, the late Marjorie S. Dammann of Rye was often associated with firsts.

title: BEHIND THE FLOOD OF MAIL: NAME BROKERS
description: LOOKING for a millionaire under 40 who owns a sailboat? Or a New England high school coach? Their names and millions of others are readily available from three Westchester list brokers, who specialize in renting out names.

title: IRIS M. SCHNEIDER MARRIES IRA DON ROSEN, A PRODUCER
description: At Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., Iris Miriam Schneider, a daughter of Bernard Schneider of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Anita Schneider, was married last evening to Ira Don Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Rosen of Fresh Meadows, Queens. Rabbi Perry Rank officiated. The bride, the director of research and planning at the New York Telephone Company, graduated from Cornell University and received a master's degree in communications from George Washington University. Mr. Rosen, also a Cornell graduate, is a producer of the CBS News program ''60 Minutes.'' He received an Emmy Award in 1982 for investigative reporting for the program.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on Jan. 10 incorrectly attributed the lithograph ''Elfriede Mahler, Dance.'' The artist was Marguerite Doernbach.

title: SNYDER STIRS MANY REACTIONS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SAVING THE DAY
description: LEAD: THE bright spot in the bleak snow was Mike's arrival.

title: WATER UTILITIES SELLING AN ASSET: LAND
description: LEAD: WATER company land, often the last bastion of open space in a community, is an increasingly valuable asset, and the companies are increasingly interested in cashing in on it. Towns, usually interested in preserving the land for open space, are trying to raise money to buy it.

title: The Small Museums of Montreal
description: IN Montreal, as elsewhere, large museums with a broad variety of programs and large-scale exhibitions receive lots of attention, but specialized small museums are all too often passed by.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING HOUSEPLANTS THROUGH WINTER
description: LEAD: ABOUT this time of year, a lot of house plants develop a case of the midwinter blahs.

title: Veteran Whose Legs Were Severed Is Sued
description: On Sept. 1, S. Brian Willson and two other demonstrators protesting arms shipments to Central America sat down on the railroad tracks leading to the Navy's Concord Naval Weapons Station, about 20 miles east of here.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Theater Problems? Call Dr. Chekhov
description: THERE'S A POPULAR STORY going around the theatrical community in Los Angeles. Apparently a casting director called a Hollywood agent about setting up an audition for his client in a local production of ''The Three Sisters'' and the agent efficiently queried, ''Will the playwright be present at the audition?'' Furthermore, the actor received notice of his audition by a routine message from the agent's secretary on his phone machine: ''David, you're up for a part in 'The Sisters.' I'll have a messenger send over the script.''

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE SUPERCONDUCTIVITY BUSINESS;
1-2-3 Powders - at $105 to $2,000 a Kilo
description: LEAD: THE high-temperature superconducting ceramics have jumped out of the laboratory test tubes and into the commercial marketplace in less than a year after their discovery.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: MIAMI BEACH;
New Money For Old Resort
description: LEAD: INVESTMENT activity in the oldest parts of south Miami Beach continued to accelerate in the last year. Most of the activity focuses on a 42-square-block area that has been designated a historic district to preserve its Art Deco buildings.

title: Farm Upturn Clouds Issues In Campaign
description: Down at the Maid-Rite snack bar in Perry, where farmers from Dallas County have long sought refuge on winter mornings, the talk used to be of hard times and worse choices: who was in trouble with the bank, who had gone broke, who wasn't going to be around for spring planting.

title: Rock: No Safety, A Quintet, at P.S. 122
description: THE first installment of ''Cement Chalet,'' a weekly mixed-media series at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, was headlined on Thursday by No Safety, a rock band featuring downtown improvisers. While Chris Cochrane, the guitarist, and Zeena Parkins, the keyboardist and harpist, have built reputations with noisy, open-ended improvisations, No Safety plays crisply structured rock - knotty with dissonance, fond of noise, clattery and asymmetrical, but as carefully plotted as a Joe Orton farce.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: MICHAEL HELFGOTT;
'WE HAVE MAJOR GAPS IN TOWN WEALTH'
description: LEAD: WHEN the General Assembly returns to work next month, it will consider proposals to change the financing of local school districts. The State Department of Education is recommending a new formula for calculating aid and a major increase in state aid.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DOCTOR DEALER. By Mark Bowden. (Warner, $17.95.) How does a preppy who started out selling marijuana to his friends at Exeter turn into the biggest cocaine dealer in Philadelphia? ''Doctor Dealer'' traces the rise and fall of Larry Lavin, a dentist in his early 30's who is now serving a 42-year term in prison.

title: IRAN DEAL HAUNTING THE BUSH CAMPAIGN
description: GEORGE BUSH'S role in the Iran-contra affair has come back to haunt him at a critical juncture in his Presidential campaign. The problem isn't so much what Mr. Bush has said he knew about the affair as what he has said he didn't know: that it was an arms-for-hostages swap, from which funds were diverted to the contras.

title: MS. MCNENNEY WED TO W. J. BURKE 3D
description: Lauren Mary McNenney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McNenney of Scarsdale, N.Y., and William Joseph Burke 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burke Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass., Hyannis Port, Mass., and Stuart, Fla., were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Damian O'Connell performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: ASBESTOS PIPE REPLACEMENT IS URGED
description: A WATER-QUALITY study that revealed minute levels of asbestos in one area of the Dix Hills Water District has prompted district officials to recommend replacement of 10 miles of asbestos-cement pipe in the 160-mile system even though ''there is no health hazard,'' the administrator of the district said.

title: Don't Link the Dollar to Commodities
description: JAMES A. BAKER 3d, the Secretary of the Treasury, has been winning articulate supporters for his suggestion that a market bushel of commodities, including gold, be relied on as a guides to stablize dollar exchange rates and credit market conditions. But the concept raises disturbing questions which its proponents ignore. To wit:

title: Unethical Lawyers Are Target of Bar Unit
description: The Connecticut Bar Association adopted measures this week intended to protect clients from unscrupulous lawyers.

title: A Mayan Past, A Latin Present In Guatemala
description: ARRIVING in Antigua, Guatemala, is like falling into a time warp and ending up in 16th- or 17th-century Spain. Colonial-style mansions line the landscape, shrouded by eight-foot walls that hide pools, gardens brimming with multitudes of flowers and, beyond, elaborate hand-carved woodwork.

title: Cyprus
description: To the Editor: It is not surprising to see a question on Cyprus appear in the Q. & A. column (Travel, Jan. 3).

title: ASSESSING THE RISKY JOB OF RISK ASSESSMENT
description: EARLY this century, the principal insecticide used on fruits and vegetables went by the elegant appellation ''Paris green.'' Today's chemists have a less appetizing name for the toxin - lead arsenate.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The name of the writer of an article on Jan. 10 on Nebraska farm real estate was misspelled. The correct spelling is Dick Herman.

title: PARIS WAS NO DARN FUN
description: LEAD: ARMAND By Emmanuel Bove. Translated by Janet Louth. 180 pp. New York: Carcanet. $17.95.

title: Nizar Jwaideh; Editor, 55
description: Nizar Jwaideh, director of public affairs for the Washington mission of the Arab League and editor of the magazine Arab Perspectives, died Wednesday of pancreatic cancer at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 55 years old.

title: U.S. Reporting Arrest of Politician in Zaire
description: Zairian police forces arrested a prominent opposition figure in the capital of the African nation during a violent confrontation last Sunday, according to the State Department.

title: Already, a New Look at a Legend
description: THE date was Oct. 9, 1982, a Saturday in the hinterlands of Virginia, and Paul A. Volcker had just addressed a private meeting of chief executives of companies like General Motors, General Electric and I.B.M. at the Homestead resort. As he strode to the stage of the hotel's movie theater for a news conference, the sometimes-jocular and engaging Mr. Volcker gazed straight ahead. The look, by now a familiar one, let the towering Mr. Volcker evade inquiring eyes.

title: CHICAGO'S GRUMPY GURU
description: James Atlas describes well the Chicago I knew as an undergraduate (''Chicago's Grumpy Guru: Best-Selling Professor Allan Bloom,'' Jan. 3). I studied with Allan Bloom and other members of the Committee on Social Thought. It was an invigorating education that continuously forced us to consider what it means to be a human being and a member of civil society.

title: Back to Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FIRST PROFESSIONAL AUTHOR
description: JOHN DRYDEN AND HIS WORLD By James Anderson Winn. Illustrated. 651 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: Millesgarden
description: To the Editor: Re the article on Carl Milles: a quibble. Milles did not bring a forest of antique sculptures filling his living room to Cranbrook in order to use them as teaching aids for his students. When I was in his home with a group of students in 1944, Milles told us, ''These are my resource books, my library. When I need inspiration I come here.'' DORIS BAKER Williamsburg, Va.

title:
GARDENING;
GETTING HOUSEPLANTS THROUGH WINTER
description: LEAD: ABOUT this time of year, a lot of house plants develop a case of the midwinter blahs.

title: Pop Music
description: Throughout his career, Irving Berlin has been creating precedents and today another will be launched. In celebration of Mr. Berlin's 100th birthday on May 11 the ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series at the 92nd Street Y (1395 Lexington Avenue), which has been examining American songs and songwriters for 17 years, will for the first time devote its entire five-concert season to the work of a single songwriter.

title: BLACK WRITERS IN PRAISE OF TONI MORRISON
description: I will call them my people which were not my people: and her beloved which was not beloved. - Romans 9:25

title: Japanese Cello Music
description: The 13th annual ''Music From Japan'' series, under direction of Naoyuki Miura, begins at 5 P.M. today at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue at 70th Street Tickets for the concert and a reception afterward are $10. Information: (212) 517-2742.

title: NONFICTION
description: RESCUE: The Exodus of the Ethiopian Jews. By Ruth Gruber. (Atheneum, $19.95.) ''For the first time in history, white people were transporting black men and women and children out of Africa not to be sold but to be saved,'' writes Ruth Gruber, the author of 12 previous books and the only foreign correspondent permitted to witness the secret mission that the world came to know as Operation Moses. In November 1985, Israeli agents, using more than $65 million raised in secret from people throughout the world, clandestinely airlifted 15,000 black Ethiopian Jews to Israel. Ms. Gruber weaves history, international politics and personal interviews into her suspenseful, behind-the-scenes chronicle. She recounts the day-to-day struggles of 15-year-old Alitash and her boyfriend, Daniel, who flee with a group of their friends on a perilous journey through the forests and deserts of Ethiopia and the Sudan; of 72-year-old Yona ben Naftali, the spokesman for the Jews of Gondar, who waits years for permission to fly to Israel with his wife, Tourou; and of 14-year-old Ezekiel, who buried his family along the way to the Holy Land. ''Rescue'' documents the worldwide network of support that sustained the undercover mission, as well as the corruption, press leaks and bureaucratic errors that left thousands of Ethiopian Jews stranded in disease-ridden refugee camps. Instead of getting caught up in the bureaucratic problems of backslapping and blame, the author makes the decision to focus on the human story of the Jews called Falashas, or strangers. It's the right decision. Ms. Gruber, an adept storyteller with a fine eye for detail, draws a vivid portrait of an ancient community whose members maintained their faith through 2,700 years of exile, in such isolation that they believed themselves to be the last Jews in the world.

title: CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA TO PERFORM IN HARTFORD
description: FIVE state orchestras, as well as the Cleveland Orchestra, perform this week.

title: AS CARTOON MUSEUM STRUGGLES, ITS WILSON SHOW DELIGHTS
description: THE Museum of Cartoon Art's castle was already cracking when this reviewer first saw it almost a decade ago. Now, the concrete edifice, which is on Comly Avenue in Rye Brook, has plastic protecting part of an outside wall and wood beams shoring up its curving colonnade. These and other temporary measures cost $30,000, said the museum's curator, Sherman Krisher, who added that ''the building is collapsing faster than we can raise money for the radical surgery that it needs.''

title: VARIATIONS ON FAMILIAR CHINESE
description: ''YOU can never have too many Chinese restaurants,'' a Sinophile and friend of ours once said. And it does seem that Chinese restaurants have been proliferating in Fairfield County in the last 10 years.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: PARSING THROUGH CUSTOMS: Essays by a Freudian Folklorist. By Alan Dundes. (University of Wisconsin, $22.75.) In the preface to this fascinating collection of seven essays, Alan Dundes, a professor of anthropology and folklore at the University of California, Berkeley, argues that ''while psychoanalysts have continued to be interested in folklore .

title: Yugoslav's Data Link Waldheim to Atrocities
description: A Yugoslav adviser to an international commission investigating Kurt Waldheim said today that he had seen documents implicating the Austrian President in war crimes.

title: UNMOVED BY TAX CUTS: Underground Economy Is Not Rising To the Bait
description: LOWER tax rates, the Reagan Adminstration long maintained, would not only encourage people to work harder but would also make them more honest. If less was taken by various tax collectors, the argument ran, fewer people would risk evasion, and significant numbers of moonlighters, barterers and other members of the ''underground'' economy would be lured into fiscal rectitude.

title: Jersey Gas Tax to Rise to Help Pay for Road Work
description: Starting July 1, New Jersey's tax on gasoline will rise to 10.5 cents a gallon, from 8 cents, following Governor Kean's signing this week of a law to help finance a seven-year $5.7 billion highway construction program.

title: Growth Raises Fear in Southampton
description: Very little ties this community to Queens, 70 miles to the west. Very little, that is, except the fears of some Southampton residents who worry that rapid growth is turning their town of 50,000 into a tiny, tonier version of New York City.

title: TRANSPLANTS: ETHICAL THICKET
description: LEAD: HEART transplants are ''reaching the point where major decisions must be made'' on who gets a chance to live and who does not, says Dr. Jacques G. Losman, a former director of the transplant program at Beth Israel Medical Center here.

title: SUDS SLIP UP A SHORTCUT
description: FOR people who live in Port Washington and drive to work in Great Neck, or vice versa, there is something between the villages called Northern Boulevard, or 25A. It is loved by drivers of enormous trucks in no hurry to get where they're going and by non-North Shore notorists in no hurry either because they don't even know where they've been.

title: Sunday Observer; Life in the Waist Land
description: LIVING IN NEW YORK you forget about driving. It's one of the great luxuries of New York that a car is absolutely superfluous there. Unless you dedicate your life to parking, you can't keep the thing at the curb, and unless you are Croesus, you can't afford garage space.

title: Comedy: Jeffrey Essmann
description: JEFFREY ESSMANN, a character comedian whose fine-tuned sensibility places him in the tradition of Ruth Draper, Lily Tomlin and Danitra Vance, is a performer whose pursuit of comic truth embraces all ages and freely crosses sexual boundaries. Mr. Essmann is also something of a literary daredevil, for his most ambitious pieces assume some historical knowledge and steer away from pat comic formulas.

title: ALLISON W. CUTLER TO WED F. E. FOX
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. E. Newton Cutler Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Allison Waring Cutler to Francis E. Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Fox of Ardmore, Pa. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Beauty; BODY LANGUAGE
description: JUST AS SKIRT lengths and shapes go in and out of style, so too do body types. When the reedy, angular physique of models in the 1960's and 70's was replaced by a more curvaceous ideal, many fashion pundits declared that, at last, womanly women were attractive again. But the new ideal, shown off in the tight and skimpy spring clothes that crowded the runways late last fall, seems even more demanding than the old one.

title: Oil of North Slope in Alaska Is Reported Polluting Tundra
description: Oil production at Prudhoe Bay on Alaska's North Slope is polluting the fragile tundra and has resulted in hundreds of violations of environmental regulations, three environmental organizations have charged.

title: Music: Fine Arts Quartet At Alice Tully Hall
description: THE Fine Arts Quartet is an American ensemble with a decided Central European tint. In its program at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night, one heard a rounded rather than a finely cut edge to phrasing and timbre. At its worst, the Fine Arts sounds fuzzy to the point of imprecision; yet there is a depth to the group's sound and a relaxed, welcoming quality to the music itself.

title: Outdoors: Hints on How Not to Hunt for Ducks
description: A SHORT while ago when the waning moon was a brilliant sliver above the heaving Atlantic, I was driving along the outer beach of Martha's Vineyard island an hour and a half before dawn wondering when the three quick cups of black coffee I had quaffed would begin to rouse me from my torpor.

title: Roy Blount Jr. Puts His Misadventures on Stage
description: Roy Blount Jr. has rafted down the Amazon River, taking a brief swim that ended abruptly when he realized piranhas had wiggled into his bathing suit and were nibbling at his upper thigh - an unpleasant experience that nonetheless enabled him to write an account of the trip that began with the lead of a lifetime: ''Wild fish tore my flesh.''

title: Oak Park Journal; No Welcome Mat for Black Church
description: Officials in this predominantly white Chicago suburb have been wrangling in recent days over a black church's efforts to move into town.

title: Signs of a Slowdown in Buybacks
description: They were a ray of hope in the dark days following the Oct. 19 collapse of the stock market: signaling a vote of confidence in the financial markets, corporations big and small announced large buybacks of their shares, telling investors that they stood ready to buy their companies' stock even if no one else would.

title: India's Fading Airlines Stir First-Class Hopes
description: In an effort to polish the image of India's Government-controlled airlines and prepare for an anticipated surge in tourists and traffic, a band of ambitious technocrats and officials is beginning a sweeping overhaul of two big carriers.

title: Haas Wins Hope Golf By 2 Shots
description: Jay Haas, one of the consistent but not spectacular players on the PGA Tour for the last dozen years, played just that way today - managing steady but not spectacular golf - to win the 29th annual Bob Hope Chrysler Classic by two shots over David Edwards.

title: Pan Am and the Rise of Union Power
description: In his spacious 46th-floor office, C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive of the Pan Am Corporation, and Martin R. Shugrue, the vice chairman, were going over airline schedules and seat sales last Thursday morning. They were trying their best, it seemed, to keep their minds off a far more pressing matter.

title: Lacroix in High Spirits for Spring
description: For the second successive season, Christian Lacroix has opened the couture showings here on an exuberant note. He is always high-spirited and his clothes always merry. Because the season at hand is spring and summer, usually a lighthearted time for fashion, he has been inspired to new heights of gaiety.

title: Question Box
description: Question: Years ago, before the T-formation became standard, the single-wing formation was the most popular one in the National Football League. Which pro team was the last one to give it up?

title: Growth Seen For Germany
description: West Germany's economy is expected to grow between 1.5 percent and 2 percent this year, compared with 1.7 percent growth in 1987, the Economics Minister, Martin Bangemann, said today.

title: Poor Example Is Set
description: To the Editor:

title: 23 Palestinians Seized by Jordan; Plot to Subvert Regime Is Charged
description: More than 20 Palestinian militants have been arrested in Jordan, according to the Government there and a radical Palestinian group, amid signs that several Arab Governments are concerned that the unrest in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip may spill over into their territory.

title: Organ Services Vying for Franchises
description: A looming Federal deadline has set off intense competition among private agencies that retrieve kidneys and other organs for transplanting.

title: New Learjet Head Plans International Sales Push
description: Beverly N. Lancaster received his given name from a clerk in a rural Kansas hospital who mistook the British boy's name, Bevley, for the misspelling of the more common girl's name. During the Depression, his parents did not have $2 to change his birth certificate.

title: 'Notch Babies' Bill Will Restore Faith in System
description: To the Editor:

title: Poll Puts 3 Democrats Neck and Neck in Iowa
description: Three Democratic Presidential candidates are running almost even with two weeks left until Iowa's precinct caucuses, according to a poll published yesterday in The Des Moines Sunday Register.

title: Off-duty Officer Is Stabbed and a 2d Is Shot
description: One off-duty police officer was stabbed in the face in a struggle with a car thief in the South Bronx, and another off-duty officer was shot during a dispute with a motorist in Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: Sanford-Ford Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Steady a State
description: A television commercial promoting tourism in the Garden State employs the slogan, ''New Jersey and you, perfect together.''

title: The Immediate Threat
description: The designation in Washington of the Martin Marietta Corporation to operate a billion-dollar computer complex as an important part of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative may suggest that a ''Star Wars'' missile defense is just around the corner.

title: Advertising; History to Be Stressed In Parker Celebration
description: The Parker Pen Company, whose management, after a leveraged buyout, has halted its downward skid, is in high spirits as it approaches its 100th anniversary this year.

title: Wilander Needs An Extra Effort
description: Pat Cash was hoping to turn the Australian Open into a national celebration, but Mats Wilander spoiled the party.

title: Mental Health on the Street
description: It remains to be seen whether Joyce Brown's release from the hospital to a residential program puts a happy ending to the story of a homeless woman's fight against involuntary psychiatric treatment. Beyond law, her case dramatizes the failure of a policy - deinstitutionalization, the emptying of state mental hospitals during the 1970's.

title: Decent, Affordable Housing for All
description: The 1980's have been a disaster for affordable housing. Federal housing assistance has shrunk by 75 percent, from $33 billion to less than $8 billion. Construction of new housing for the poor has come to a virtual halt. The result has been a decline in home ownership (for the first time since World War II), skyrocketing rents (with many families paying more than half of their income just to keep a roof over their heads) and rising homelessness.

title: Exchange Plan To Add Stocks
description: The Midwest Stock Exchange said this week that it plans to list 700 additional stocks for trading.

title: Back Again: Ethics Issue in Albany
description: Just six months after the State Legislature passed a set of ethics bills hailed as among the most important reform measures in New York's history, the issue of legislative ethics has again begun to dominate debate here.

title: A Paradox for Haiti's Presidency: Leslie Francois Manigat
description: On the morning after Haiti's widely criticized presidential election, Leslie F. Manigat, an energetic former professor of political science, strode through his crowded campaign headquarters smiling broadly and waving one hand high in a victory sign.

title: Gunman and a Hostage Killed
description: A man sought in a series of abductions was killed along with one of his hostages today in a gun battle with the police. A second suspect was wounded.

title: Far-Away Home Court
description: When Billy Ray Bates was signed by the Portland Trail Blazers out of the Continental Basketball Association in 1980, his acrobatic slam dunks and spinning moves to the basket made him an instant crowd favorite and earned him a nickname: The Great Legend of the Northwest.

title: Park Popularity Threatens Virgin Islands Paradise
description: The words rasped through the afternoon air with no-nonsense authority:

title: Nay to Trendy Culotte
description: The struggle to maintain decorum in the Capitol has pitted its custodians against the fashion industry, specifically: the new mid-thigh-length culotte suits being featured for spring.

title: Congress Reconvenes Today, Facing Wide Range of Issues
description: After struggling through a first session characterized by confrontations with the White House on the budget and foreign affairs, the 100th Congress will return Monday facing a broad range of unfinished business that must be crowded into a legislative calendar shortened by the 1988 elections.

title: Paul J. Babbitt Sr., 89, Father of Candidate
description: Paul J. Babbitt Sr., the father of former Gov. Bruce Babbitt, a Democratic Presidential candidate, died today. He was 89 years old.

title: A Clash of Styles: Japanese Companies in U.S. Under Fire for Cultural Bias
description: After years of fascination with Japanese management, some American executives are confronting it from a new perspective - as employees of the Japanese enterprises that are multiplying in the United States.

title: In Robin Williams's World, Delight Is a Many-Sided Thing
description: Suddenly, ''Good Morning, Vietnam'' is a smash hit, and Robin Williams was coping with this information as might be expected. The star of the film said he was appropriately delighted. He added that he was understandably grateful. And, as he paced his suite in the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan, he spoke rather earnestly of America's fascination with the Vietnam experience.

title: The Right Twitch
description: As its name suggests, the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, which was established in St. Andrews, Scotland, in 1754, is steeped in tradition, much of it reflected in the club's priceless collection of paintings, prints and historic relics.

title: Bridge: Nell Wells Was an Example Of Longevity and Optimism
description: There are two generalizations about bridge enthusiasts that seem valid.

title: San Diego's Super Roots
description: ONCE it was known as a sleepy Navy town near the Mexican border, the best place in California to get a tattoo. But now San Diego awaits the circus maximus of sports, Super Bowl week. And when the thousands of visitors depart after the Denver Broncos and the Washington Redskins determine the Super Bowl XXII champion Sunday, an estimated $140 million will have been spent during the circus max in this sparkling harbor city that the American Football League discovered.

title: Dance: Tsai Fung Troupe, In a Mixture of Styles
description: THE Tsai Fung Dance Company aims for the integration of contemporary and traditional dance forms. But the pieces that were the most compelling in a program presented on Friday at Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, were those that seemed the purest.

title: Joggers' Kids Can Roll Along
description: Phil Baechler, a 39-year-old athlete from Yakima, Wash., wanted to spend more time with his newborn son, Travis. But Baechler had a crowded schedule: he had a full-time job as a copy editor, and he was a competitive runner.

title: Radium Company Misses a Deadline
description: Nearly a month after the expiration of a state-imposed deadline, a small company in New York City has yet to comply with an order to empty its plant of an enormous inventory of radium-226, a dangerously radioactive material that was once widely used in treating cancer.

title: Babbitt and Gephardt Given Iowa Voter List in Fund Deal
description: In a special arrangement that may violate Federal election laws, two Presidential campaigns obtained copies of a list of Iowa caucus participants and other voters from the state's Democratic Party and in exchange each campaign got its supporters to contribute $10,000 to the party.

title: Two Killed in the West As Small Planes Crash
description: Two planes collided Saturday over this Los Angeles suburb, and two men aboard one plane were killed when it crashed, the authorities said. The other plane landed safely.

title: Treasury's February Plans Expected
description: Treasury financing looms large in the credit markets this week.

title: Brazil Accepts One U.S. Software Product
description: Acting under the threat of trade reprisals by the United States, Brazil has relaxed some protection of its fast-growing computer industry by authorizing commercialization of an American-made software program.

title: 11 BELIEVED KILLED IN NICARAGUA; Plane Struck by Missiles
description: The contra supply plane that crashed in southern Nicaragua on Saturday was hit twice by Soviet-made surface-to-air missiles, foreign reporters taken to the scene today were told.

title: Market Place; Is Orion a Target? Drama Builds Up
description: THE situation at the Orion Pictures Corporation is certainly a curious one. Two of the wealthiest men in the media industry have gradually been buying up stock in the relatively small motion picture and television company. Its recent films include ''Platoon,'' ''Robocop,'' ''No Way Out'' and ''Throw Momma From the Train,'' and its television series include ''Cagney and Lacey.''

title: Trade Bridge to China
description: Clayton K. Yeutter will be the first United States Trade Representative to visit China. He will leave for Beijing Jan. 31 to sign a pact governing trade in the sensitive sector of textiles.

title: Canadian Offering $4 Billion For Owner of Bloomingdale's
description: In its second major excursion into the United States in just over a year, the Campeau Corporation of Canada last night began a $4.2 billion offer for Federated Department Stores Inc., the owner of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Filene's.

title: Ferrer, at Inauguration, Sees Bronx Shedding Glum Image
description: Offering an image of the Bronx as ''the front line, the proving ground of urban America,'' Fernando Ferrer took his first oath of office yesterday as the elected Borough President of the Bronx.

title: Apartment Intruder Fatally Stabs a Man
description: An 82-year-old man was fatally stabbed and his wife was injured during a robbery Saturday in their apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: What's Happening to the Neighborhood Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL REPORT Unemployment in Western Europe is expected to get worse as a result of the dollar's drop, which has made American goods more competitive with European products. The situation is already grim, with Europe's jobless rate at 11 percent. No net new jobs have been created in Europe since 1980. Spain's unemployment rate is more than 20 percent, and Ireland's is close to 19 percent. [ Page A1. ] A sweeping overhaul of India's Government-controlled airlines is beginning, and the plan looks costly. [ D8. ] Argentina has begun searching for new loans to help cover this year's interest payments on its $54 billion foreign debt. [ D8. ] Brazil has relaxed some protection of its computer industry in hopes of averting U.S. trade reprisals, but it may be too late. [ D8. ] COMPANIES Campeau began a bid last night for Federated Department Stores, offering $47 a share in a bid that values the company, which owns Bloomingdale's, at $4.2 billion. [ A1. ] A.T.&T. has told the General Services Administration that a growing contract controversy has compromised the project to replace the Government's antiquated telephone system. [ D1. ] The outside members of E. F. Hutton's board will receive fees of more than $2.5 million because of the firm's merger with Shearson Lehman Brothers, according to Hutton documents. [ D2. ] Kodak's bid for Sterling Drug represents a sharp departure from its previous approach to acquisitions. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY Orders for American-made machine tools surged 76.7 percent in December from the previous month, to $242.5 million, according to a report by the industry's trade association. [ D1. ] The power that unions are wielding in the airline industry was demonstrated again when five top officers at Pan Am were ousted last week. [ D1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS One of the most expensive and most sought-after hair colorists in the U.S. is Louis Licari. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] Texaco's lawyers are gearing up for new wrangles this week over a disclosure statement. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Orion Pictures is in a curious situation, with two of the wealthiest men in the media accumulating its stock. Market Place. [ D6. ] The bond market is leaning toward lower interest rates in anticipation of weak economic data. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Name Game: Who's Who
description: A cast of larger-than-life characters that makes grown people go ''Oink'' and others shout ''Ole!'' is invading San Diego.

title: Boeing Losing Chairman As It Adds 2 Jet Models
description: Tonight, Thornton A. Wilson, who is 66, intends to ''have fun'' at his retirement party at a Seattle hotel where he will be toasted by 500 friends and international business associates. They are flying in to celebrate his 17 years of guiding the Boeing Company out of the ''Boeing Bust'' of 1970 to its position today as the world's largest aerospace company, with revenues of $16.3 billion in 1986.

title: C.G. King, 91, Dies; Found Vitamin C In Nutrition Study
description: Dr. Charles Glen King, a nutritionist who co-discovered vitamin C, died of heart failure yesterday at West Chester (Pa.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Kennett Square, Pa.

title: Snag at European Talks
description: European Community ministers today resumed their struggle to agree on strict curbs on farm spending that could clear the way for a revamping of the near-bankrupt group's finances. Diplomats said differences remained unresolved after three days of talks last week and a session that lasted more than 10 hours on Saturday. Farm spending takes up two-thirds of the group's annual $47 billion budget.

title: Hoyas Surprise Syracuse
description: Georgetown limped into Syracuse this afternoon without a victory in its last three games, punchless on offense and close to falling hopelessly behind in the Big East race.

title: Educators Seek Answers as Bias on Campus Rises
description: An increase in the number of racial and anti-Semitic incidents on campuses is forcing soul-searching at many of the nation's institutions of higher learning, according to educators at a conference on racism.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Swiss Get 1-2 Sweep: Daniel Mahrer led a 1-2 Swiss sweep yesterday in the men's World Cup downhill at Leukerbad, Switzerland. Mahrer scored his second victory of the season with a surge of speed near the bottom of the course, sweeping through an icy curve and finish slope to win in 2 minutes 17.53 seconds. Franz Heinzer, with his left arm in a cast, took second place, 38-hundredths of a second behind.(AP) Surge by Swiss Women: Vreni Schneider and Brigitte Oertli yesterday combined for two more victories for their surging Swiss women's team. Schneider had the best time in both heats of a slalom at Badgastein, Austria, to win in 1 minute 19.11 seconds.(AP) Holland on U.S. Team: The United States Nordic combined team for the Calgary Olympics will include Joe Holland, 23, of Norwich, Vt., who led the final stage of the qualifying this weekend at Lake Placid, N.Y. Holland finished third in the 15-kilometer cross-country yesterday after winning the jump event on Saturday. Also named to the team were Pat Ahern, Breckenridge, Colo.; Gary Crawford, Steamboat, Colo., and Todd Wilson, Winter Park, Colo. Ahern, an Olympic veteran, was second in the cross-country behind Jeff Graves of Steamboat, who did not qualify for the team. (AP) HORSE RACING Mining Sets Mark: Mining remained undefeated and set a stakes record yesterday in winning the $86,850 Coaltown Stakes at Aqueduct by 2 1/2 lengths. The 5-year-old son of Mr. Prospector-I Pass went six furlongs on a fast track in 1:09 3/5, bettering the mark of 1:10 set by Dr. Blum in 1981 and tied by Top Avenger in 1983. It was the fourth victory for Mining, who was ridden by Randy Romero and carried 114 pounds. Raja's Shark was runner-up.Mining returned $9.60 for $2 to win. Ruhlmann Wins El Camino Real: Ruhlmann blazed through a field of nine 3-year-olds, minus late scratch and favorite Purdue King, in stakes-record time at Bay Meadows in San Mateo, Calif., yesterday Ridden by Pat Day, Ruhlmann won by six lengths over the mile-and-a-sixteenth distance in 1:39 2/5, nearly 2 seconds faster than the record posted by Tank Prospect in 1985. The pacesetter, Havanaffair, was second as Bay Meadows concluded its 89-day racing season. Ruhlmann, carrying 117 pounds, paid $9.20, $5.40 and $3.60. (AP) N.H.L. Whalers 2, Red Wings 1: Ray Ferraro scored 2:21 into overtime to lead the Whalers at home yesterday. Ferraro stole the puck from Joey Kocur behind the net and stuffed it into the net for his 12th goal of the season. Paul MacDermid also scored for Hartford, which won its fifth game in a row. It was his seventh goal in the last four games. Mike Liut, who was beaten on the first shot of the game, by Steve Yzerman, turned aside the final 16 by Detroit. (AP) North Stars 5, Flyers 3: Bob Brooke's second-period goal broke a tie and Minnesota went on to win at the Spectrum in Philadelphia for the first time since 1978. Minnesota had been 0-11-5 at Philadelphia since then. Brooke got behind the Philadelphia defense after just coming out of the penalty box and beat the Flyers goalie, Ron Hextall, to the short side with 4:09 left in the second period. Minnesota added an insurance goal when Moe Mantha, recently acquired in a trade with Edmonton, beat Hextall in the crease with 9:55 left in the game.(AP) Canadiens 5, Nordiques 3: Mats Naslund, Claude Lemieux and Sergio Momesso each had a goal and an assist to lead Montreal in the game at Quebec. The Canadiens snapped a two-game losing streak and moved back into first place in the Adams Division. The Canadiens had a 4-1 lead starting the third period and had to hold off a Quebec rally when the Nordiques scored on goals by Mike Hough and Jason Lafreniere. Both the Quebec goals in the final 20 minutes were scored against Patrick Roy, who replaced Brian Hayward at 1:54 of the third period. (AP)

title: Iranian Said To Link Hostage Release Gulf War
description: Iran has informed Lebanon that all foreign hostages held by extremists loyal to Teheran will be released once the war in the Persian Gulf ends, Lebanese Government officials said this week.

title: Express Train Derailed in China; 90 Reported Dead and 66 Injured
description: An express train derailed early today in the mountains of southern China, and 90 people were killed and 66 others seriously injured, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: U.S. SAYS POLAND AIDED TERRORISTS
description: The Abu Nidal terrorist network for at least four years maintained an important financial operation in Warsaw that traded arms and consumer goods to raise funds for terrorist acts, according to a classified State Department report on the group's operations.

title:
The Editorial Notebook;
Teach a Child's First Teacher
description: LEAD: The next 10 years, says Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, should be the ''decade of the child.'' That's right in principle. It's also effective in practice, especially for very young children, as is evident from successful, even inspiring, experiments around the country.

title:
SUPER BOWL XXII;
A Scout's-Eye View of the Conference Champions - Washington Redskins
description: LEAD: The weekend before last, Bob Hollway and Mike Lombardi watched the National Football League conference championship games with special interest. They were the advance scouts for their teams, and if their teams had won the conference titles, their scouting reports would have been incorporated into game plans for the Super Bowl.

title: ISRAEL IS REBUKED ON ARAB BEATINGS
description: A leader of Reform Judaism in the United States yesterday urged Israel to end its policy of beating Arabs to quell violence in the West Bank and Gaza, calling the practice ''an offense to the Jewish spirit'' that ''betrays the Zionist dream.''

title: PLOT TO SUBVERT REGIME IS CHARGED; Arabs Pledge Support
description: Arab foreign ministers today pledged moral and financial support to Palestinians who for nearly two months have been violently protesting the Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

title: Just Misinformed
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Shandwick in Canada
description: For its ninth acquisition in North America, Britain's Shandwick P.L.C., a public relations concern, has made its first move into Canada, buying PIR (Public and Industrial Relations of Canada) Communications. Shandwick is putting up $2.9 million in cash, with the payout over four years not to exceed $9.2 million.

title: 'Last Emperor' Wins 4 Golden Globe Awards
description: ''The Last Emperor,'' a panoramic history of modern China, won four Golden Globe Awards, including best dramatic motion picture, on Saturday night while Sally Kirkland, who played an emigre actress in ''Anna,'' and Michael Douglas, a ruthless trader in ''Wall Street,'' took top honors for actors in dramas.

title: Talks Intensify to Scrap Shoreham but Not Lilco
description: The Long Island Lighting Company and New York State, trying to put the stalemate on the Shoreham nuclear power plant behind them, have intensified negotiations that could close Shoreham but allow Lilco to remain an independent, investor-owned utility.

title: Israelis Worry About Their Image
description: The new Israeli policy of beating Palestinians to stop the protests in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip has spurred relatively little official debate here, but brought mounting worries over Israel's image abroad.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title:
ON YOUR OWN: GOLF;
Staying Sharp When Winter Drives You Indoors
description: LEAD: TOM WATSON, the wine connoisseur, broke his best bottle of vintage burgundy one winter day while chipping balls off the rug at home in Kansas City, Mo. Tom Watson, the husband, was told to restrict his practicing to the basement.

title: Ann Rork Light, Former Actress, 79
description: Ann Rork Light, who was a silent film actress, died here Saturday at the Vanderbilt University Hospital. She was 79 years old and was being treated for emphysema and lung cancer.

title: Gore Campaign Testing Value of Endorsements
description: Every few days for the last several months, another Southern politician has endorsed Senator Albert Gore Jr. for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Temple Suffers First Defeat
description: Anthony Todd hit a 10-foot jumper with two seconds left today as Nevada-Las Vegas rallied from a 12-point deficit to defeat previously unbeaten Temple, 59-58.

title: Black F.B.I. Agent's Ordeal: Meanness That Never Let Up
description: On this one point, the Government's investigators are already agreed: Donald Rochon, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was a victim of often brutal racial harassment by his white colleagues.

title: Owner Is Shot Dead In a Booklyn Bakery
description: The owner of a bakery in Brooklyn was shot to death in his office yesterday after three masked and armed men entered the shop, the police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No one's attempting to hide it.

title: Man's Death at Opera Is Called a Suicide
description: The death of a singing coach who plunged from an upper balcony to the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera House was a suicide, the New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Sharpton Reports Cause Anguish In an Uneasy Civil Rights Alliance
description: Reports that the Rev. Al Sharpton may have been a Federal informant have caused deep consternation among black New Yorkers who had been forging an alliance, sometimes uneasy, to address concerns ranging from the public schools to racially motivated violence.

title: Secret Is Out on Listing China as Hostile Country
description: An obscure Federal court case here has compelled the Defense Department to disclose a minor secret that has implications for sensitive issues in American foreign policy.

title: HAITI REGIME SAYS EX-PROFESSOR WON PRESIDENTIAL VOTE
description: One week after elections marred by widespread irregularities and charges of fraud, Haiti's government-appointed electoral council today declared Leslie F. Manigat, a 57-year-old former political science professor, as the country's next president.

title: New Yorkers & Co. A Man Paid to Get in People's Hair
description: Louis Licari can't tell you whether it's true blondes have more fun. But he can answer that other question asked in the old Clairol hair color commercials, ''Does she or doesn't she?''

title: Merger Resulting in Big Fees for Some on Hutton's Board
description: The outside members of the board of the E. F. Hutton Group will receive more than $2.5 million in fees as a result of the brokerage firm's merger with Shearson Lehman Brothers, according to Hutton officials. One director, Peter V. Ueberroth, will receive nearly $1 million.

title: More Than Just a Treaty
description: Washington goes back to work today with the usual State of the Union pomp but also with hearings, starting this morning, on what might be Ronald Reagan's most important legacy: agreement on arms control with the Soviet Union.

title: PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE ON THE AIR TONIGHT
description: President Reagan's State of the Union Message will be broadcast live at 9 o'clock tonight on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on C-Span, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network.

title: Forecasts Favoring Lower Rates
description: At the present time the credit markets are leaning in the direction of lower interest rates, as traders and investors seem to be anticipating weak economic data in the first several months of 1988.

title: Dallas Ballet Forced to Close
description: The Dallas Ballet, which is $1.8 million in debt, has canceled its spring program and laid off its 33 dancers and most staff members.

title: Sri Lanka Leader Going to India
description: President J. R. Jayewardene is to travel to New Delhi Monday to discuss the possibilities of a mutual-assistance treaty between Sri Lanka and India and the phased withdrawal of 38,000 Indian troops who were sent to support a plan for ending the Tamil insurgency here.

title: MEXICAN ILLUSION
description: LEAD: The much-touted Mexican debt relief scheme establishes a dangerous precedent overlooked by many Wall Street wizards and observers. It entails a subtle shifting of responsibility for third world debt from American banks to the Federal Government. Moreover, contrary to the claims that the swap will be cost-free to the Treasury, this undertaking will reach deep into the pockets of

title: Business and the Law; New Wrangles In Texaco Case
description: THE lawyers for Texaco Inc., after a victory in a key battle in bankruptcy court last Friday, are gearing up for a new round of legal wrangling this week, this time over a disclosure statement that is intended to provide the details on how the company plans to restructure.

title: Advertising; USA Weekend To Offer Scent
description: Ramon Gaulke, president of USA Weekend, the Gannett Company supplement that appears in 293 newspapers with a circulation of 14.6 million, reports that there is something in the wind.

title: Advertising; Newspaper Ad Bureau Gets Detroit Manager
description: William J. Tausch, 52, a former executive vice president at Lintas: Campbell-Ewald, where he once headed the Chevrolet account, is joining the Newspaper Advertising Bureau as vice president, automotive marketing, and manager of the Detroit office. He replaces Valentine Corradi, who has retired.

title: Democrat Outlines Arms-Pact Strategy
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden, Jr., previewing a likely Democratic strategy for dealing with the new missile accord the Senate will begin considering on Monday, said today that he plans to attach ''conditions'' to the accord that would define a broad arms control agenda for the United States.

title: Plane Supplying Contras Crashes; 11 Believed Killed in Nicaragua
description: A DC-6 cargo plane on a supply mission to contra guerrillas crashed inside Nicaragua Saturday night, apparently killing 11 Nicaraguan crewmen and cargo handlers.

title: Advertising; Executive Is Returning To Travel Magazine
description: Carl J. Portale is returning to European Travel and Life magazine and his old job as its publisher. He left the magazine, which he had helped found, after Rupert Murdoch acquired it last year. Since then, the 48-year-old Mr. Portale helped Tiffany & Company put out a one-shot magazine marking its 150th anniversary.

title: PRESIDENT OF RADCLIFF COLLEGE PLANS TO RESIGN IN JUNE '89
description: Matina S. Horner has announced that she will resign the presidency of Radcliffe College, a post she has held since 1972, to pursue her research into social change and women's issues.

title: Advertising; Job Awarded To Ammirati By GE/RCA
description: BRITISH-owned Ammirati & Puris has won the GE/RCA consumer electronics business. Its $20 million in billings make it the biggest account in the agency's 14-year history.

title: Music: Tsuyoshi Tsutsumi
description: TSUYOSHI TSUTSUMI played solo cello pieces by Japanese composers at the Asia Society late Saturday afternoon. Five of the six have been written in the past three years and one especially for this concert.

title: HAWAIIANS CONCLUDE YEARLONG CELEBRATION
description: With the sounding of conch shells, revelers wrapped up a yearlong celebration of Hawaii's 1,000-year-old native culture.

title: Advertising; Southern Bride Added To Pace Magazine List
description: Southern Bride is a new magazine from Pace Communications, Greensboro, N.C., that will serve the nuptially inclined in 17 Southern states and the District of Columbia.

title: Kodak's Diversification Plan Moves Into a Higher Gear
description: Until the Eastman Kodak Company agreed Friday to spend $5.1 billion to acquire Sterling Drug Inc., it had been pursuing a diversification strategy that could best be described as busy but dainty.

title: Molestations Spread Fear in Queens
description: A gaggle of girls and boys from the St. Joan of Arc School in Jackson Heights, Queens, crowd the Glendale Bakery every day, eyeing and buying sweets and sandwiches. But in recent weeks the children have not lingered long after school.

title: Cincinnati Shuts Water Taps To River as Oil Spill Arrives
description: The million-gallon oil spill floating down the Ohio River from the Pittsburgh area has reached Cincinnati, and intake valves that draw water from the river for about 850,000 people have been closed.

title: AFTER THE HOLIDAYS, DONORS CONTINUE TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Stephen and Lois Plumlee of Sarasota, Fla., deliberately sent their contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund after the holidays.

title: Reagan to Try Again; Call to Lower Taxes on Capital Gains Would Revive Congressional Dispute
description: Prospects are considered slim that President Reagan's call for lower capital gains taxes will go anywhere in the Democratic-controlled Congress in the forseeable future.

title: Ortega to Ask Madrid Role 871
description: President Ortega says that during his trip to Spain this week, he will ask the Madrid Government to become active in Central American peace efforts.

title: BURNED BODY OF A CHILD FOUND
description: The badly burned body of a child, possibly 4 years old, was found in a plastic bag in a vacant lot in Harlem by a passer-by yesterday morning, the police said.

title: TV Review; Mini-Series From BBC, 'Murder of Moderate Man'
description: EACH of the five episodes of ''Murder of a Moderate Man'' - beginning tonight at 10 on Channel 31 and running through Friday - begins with the same dreamlike sequence. A distinguished looking man in a white robe is being greeted at an airport. A small girl hands him flowers. A hand holding a gun suddenly appears, horrifying the man's supporters. The assassination victim is a democratic leader from an unnamed Middle Eastern country.

title: Image Maker Aids New Democracy
description: On Monday, when the Republic of Suriname inaugurates a new, freely elected Government headed by President Ramsewak Shankar, there will also be a small festivity here in the tenth floor offices of van Kloberg & Associates, which styles itself as an international consulting firm.

title: Seemingly Endless War Is Strangling Mozambique
description: This desperately poor nation on the southeastern coast of Africa is playing out a tragic drama whose chapters are scrawled in blood. A 12-year-old conflict is strangling Mozambique.

title: Heyward Meeting Set
description: Mike Gottfried, the Pitt football coach, said today he would meet with Craig Heyward Monday to discuss the all-America tailback's relationship with Bruce Allen, a sports agent.

title: It Was All a Mistake
description: With the House convening today, Representative Tom McMillen plans to go before his colleagues to explain that he misinformed them when he described an ''internal, high-level'' Japanese Government memo that turned out to be bogus.

title: INSIDE
description: Congress Reconvenes

title: Advertising; Richmond Shop Gets Work for a CSX Unit
description: The Martin Agency in Richmond, a subsidiary of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, is going to be doing the advertising for CSX/Sea-Land Intermodal, a recently created business unit of the CSX Corporation.

title: Saudi Phone Fees Rise
description: Saudi Arabia, in a move to help reduce its budget deficit, has raised telephone charges for the first time in 14 years. Fouad Abu Mansour, the deputy minister for posts, said in an interview reported today by the Saudi press agency that the move was taken to keep pace with rates in neighboring countries.

title: Australia, at 200, Suffers An Attack of Self-Doubt
description: Australia is preparing for the celebration of its bicentennial on Tuesday with a characteristic mixture of flamboyance and self-doubt.

title: Elway Triggers The Denver Shotgun
description: ''THE greatest Elway play?''

title: Concert: Montreal Symphony
description: SOMEONE once said of of Gabriel Faure's music that it behaved like a cat - discreet, graceful, with a sense of great adventure but at the end, always landing on its feet no matter how high or dangerous the fall. His chaste little Pavane - as performed by the orchestra and singers of the Montreal Symphony on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall - was an instructive microcosm of Faure's quiet risk-taking. Its melody is simple and charming, but the composer sends it in startling directions, deposits it so to speak on a series of precarious ledges from which it somehow manages to modulate its way homeward.

title: MODERN SCIENCE ALLOWS OLD-FASHIONED POLITICKING
description: A Louisiana real estate broker wanted to know what Paul Simon would do if Soviet missiles were launched at America. A California woman, noting that her mother had prayed after winning a seat on the town council, asked if Michael S. Dukakis would do so in the Oval Office.

title: Keep the Handcuffs on Prisoners in Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: Sled Dog Races Are Postponed
description: The 10th Annual International Sled Dog Races, which were scheduled to be held at Saranac Lake, N.Y., next weekend, will now take place Feb. 27-28, according to Peter Lesser, executive director of the community's chamber of commerce.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods Dec. Wednesday G.N.P. Fourth Quarter Thursday Personal Income Dec. Friday Farm Prices Jan.

title: Gulf War Spurs Brazil Arms Makers
description: After a lull of several years, Brazil is re-emerging as a major supplier of weapons to the Middle East. The Persian Gulf war has given a major impetus to Brazilian arms makers and they are competing with the big powers with increasing success.

title: Dance: 'Supply Side' And '3 Chairs for Bach'
description: AT times, actions spoke louder than words and dancing was more vivid than scenic effects in the program that Dancecompass offered Saturday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. At other times, choreography was subservient to gimmickry.

title: Metro Matters; Beyond a Lobby In Manhattan, Corridors of Pain
description: One year ago today, Yvonne McCain and her children finally left the ranks of the homeless.

title: Kennel Operator: Saint Or Abuser of Animals?
description: For nearly 15 years, Justin McCarthy has operated a refuge for hundreds of unwanted cats, dogs and barnyard animals at his 67-acre farm here. Now he is accused of abusing the animals he pledged to care for until their ''happy, natural death.''

title: BAD TIMES FADING FOR DEVILS' SCORER
description: He came of age suffering the indignities of being on a poor team and fearful of losing a career at 21 because of a freakish accident. But an improved team and the mastery of modern medicine are beginning to erase the bad memories for the New Jersey Devils' Pat Verbeek.

title: Advertising; David Deutsch Agency Lands 4 Assignments
description: David Deutsch, chairman of David Deutsch Associates, took time out from his busy vacation schedule in sunny Florida to call New York about his agency's new assignments.

title: Girl, 2, Is Raped in Queens, And Relative, 18, Is Arrested
description: A 2-year-old girl was raped early yesterday in Queens, and an Astoria man was arrested and charged with the attack, the police said.

title: Democrats Grow Testy As the Contest Tightens
description: With a scrappiness symptomatic of a tightening race, the seven Democratic candidates for President squared off here today over the trade imbalance and the Federal deficit.

title: Machine Tool Orders Surge 76.7%
description: Orders for American-made machine tools surged 76.7 percent in December from the previous month, to $242.5 million, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: 'Twentieth Century's Triumphant Entry'
description: To the Editor:

title: Stengel's Advice to The Chief
description: Less than 10 months from now, the winner of the Presidential election, exhausted by the campaign, will face an assignment almost as cruel as the campaign itself.

title: Fitness; It May Not Be Exciting, But You'll Perform Best With a Balanced Diet
description: ONE of the enduring myths of athletics is that eating protein will enhance one's performance. Since protein is composed of amino acids, some advocates take the notion one step further: loading up on certain amino acids will improve strength, promote muscle building and increase performance.

title: Dollar's Plunge Expected to Make Unemployment Worse for Europe
description: Western Europe's unemployment picture, which has been exceedingly grim for several years, is expected to grow even grimmer over the next few months as a result of the dollar's plunge, which has made American goods more competitive with European products.

title: Cynthia Zarin, Writer, Weds a Painter on L.I.
description: Cynthia Rebecca Zarin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Zarin of Great Neck, L.I., and Wellfleet, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Seccareccia, the son of Michael F. Seccareccia of Pawtucket, R.I., and the late Grace Partridge Seccareccia. Rabbi Eugene J. Lipsey officiated at the Woman's Club of Great Neck.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Comstock Group Inc., Danbury, Conn., an engineering and construction company, elected Joseph G. Munisteri president, chief executive and a director.

title: A.T.&T. Has Doubts About Phone Project
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has told the General Services Administration that a $25 billion project to replace the Government's antiquated telephone system has been compromised by a growing contract controversy.

title: Top Teams Roll to Victory
description: St. Anthony of Jersey City, ranked as the top high school team in the country by USA Today, easily improved its record to 13-1 yesterday with a 60-47 victory over All Hallows of the Bronx.

title: No Hats in Ring for Big Fight
description: Negotiations between representatives of Mike Tyson and Michael Spinks broke down over the weekend, making the prospect of a fight between Tyson, the undisputed heavyweight champion, and Spinks in the near future seem unlikely.

title: Steinberg's Chief Seen As Suitor if It Is Sold
description: Always try to give the customer ''a little more than expected'' was the credo of Ida Steinberg, a Hungarian immigrant who opened a small grocery store in Montreal in 1917.

title: Argentina in Glum Search for Aid
description: Warning that the price of failure will be a suspension of its debt payments abroad, Argentina has begun searching for new loans to help cover this year's interest payments on its $54 billion foreign debt, the third largest in Latin America after Brazil and Mexico.

title: Tokyo Journal; Motto for a New Breed: Less Work and More Play
description: When older Japanese worry about the fate of their country, they tend to think about young people like Hirokazu Kishida.

title: CBS Plans 'Noids' Cartoon Series
description: CBS, looking for an edge in the heated Saturday morning children's television competition, is trying an unusual and potentially problematic programming ploy, developing a weekly cartoon series based on the trademark character of a national pizza chain.

title: Two Falls Take Their Toll As Orser Adjusts His Routine
description: Brian Orser, the reigning world champion, won his eighth consecutive Canadian figure skating championship Saturday night, but not in the way he expected.

title: ABC Crew Works on Its Game Plan
description: For ABC, the good news about its Super Bowl telecast is that the teams feature two prominent and distinct quarterbacks: John Elway, the Yuppie-looking scrambler, and Doug Williams, the drop-back passer and the first black quarterback to start a Super Bowl.

title: Broken Hill Buyback Plan
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company's multibillion-dollar plan to buy back some of its shares would free the Australian mining giant from a possible takeover fight while giving much-needed cash to its two biggest shareholders, according to securities analysts.

title: Stage: Brook's 'Cherry Orchard'
description: IT is not until the final act of ''The Cherry Orchard'' that the malevolent thud of an ax signals the destruction of a family's ancestral estate and, with it, the traumatic uprooting of a dozen late-19th-century Russian lives. But in Peter Brook's production of Chekhov's play, the landscape seems to have been cleared before Act I begins. Mr. Brook has stripped ''The Cherry Orchard'' of its scenery, its front curtain, its intermissions. Even the house in which the play unfolds -the Brooklyn Academy of Music's semirestored Majestic Theater - looks half-demolished, a once-genteel palace of gilt and plush now a naked, faded shell of crumbling brick, chipped paint and forgotten hopes.

title: Court to Hear Carbide Plea
description: A state court has agreed to hear an appeal by the Union Carbide Corporation of an interim award of $270 million to the victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas leak, a news agency report said. But the court declined to stay proceedings in a $3 billion damage suit filed by the Indian Government against Carbide, the United News of India said late last week.

title:
SUPER BOWL XXII;
A Scout's-Eye View of the Conference Champions - Denver Broncos
description: LEAD: The weekend before last, Bob Hollway and Mike Lombardi watched the National Football League conference championship games with special interest. They were the advance scouts for their teams, and if their teams had won the conference titles, their scouting reports would have been incorporated into game plans for the Super Bowl.

title: Hawks Hold Off Pesky Nets
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 31 points but the Atlanta Hawks had to withstand a fourth-quarter rally to defeat the New Jersey Nets, 118-111, today.

title: A Namibia Solution
description: LEAD: As the Administration enters its final year, another attempt is being made to achieve a breakthrough in southern Africa. Assistant Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker is scheduled to visit Luanda this month to resume talks with Angolan authorities in a last-ditch effort to link the independence of Namibia, a territory ruled by South Africa since World War I, to the withdrawal of Cuban troops from

title: Dori Ann Hanswirth Marries Joseph N. Lamport
description: Dori Ann Hanswirth, an associate in the New York law firm of Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer, and Joseph Nathan Lamport, an associate in the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, were married yesterday at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis officiated.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington article on Saturday about illegal aliens misstated the status of a proposal to extend a May 4 deadline for applying for legal status. The Immigration and Naturalization Service is considering, but has not formally announced, action that would allow aliens who have made known their intention to apply by May 4 to submit the necessary documentation later; they could do so as long as they could show that the delay was caused by reasons beyond their control.

title: The Election Process; IOWA'S WEIGHTY CAUCUSES: SIGNIFICANCE BY ACCIDENT
description: They started with a creaky mimeograph machine and an aroused Governor, and they grew into a political institution.

title: MULTIPLE FETUSES RAISE NEW ISSUES TIED TO ABORTION
description: Quietly, with virtually no publicity, a number of doctors have begun offering a way out for women who are pregnant with more fetuses than they want or can carry safely: They are aborting some of the fetuses while allowing the rest to proceed to birth.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: EMPEROR OF THE AIR. By Ethan Canin. 179 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 25, 1988: MONDAY Acme Electric Consol Freightways Archer-Daniels-Midland Foster Wheeler Armstrong World Indus Lubrizol Corp Black & Decker Phila Elec Co TUESDAY Ball Corp Interstate Pwr Becton, Dickinson & Co Interstate Securities Black Hills Corp NUI Corp Borden Inc Norwest Corp Cilcorp Inc Phila Suburban Corp Duke Power Santa Fe Southern Pacific EDO Corp UGI Corp Fedders Corp USX Corp Glenfed Inc WEDNESDAY AMP Inc Oneida Ltd Alltel Corp Philips Indus Amer Elec Pwr Russell Corp Chevron Corp Squibb Corp Columbia Svgs & Ln Assc SmithKline Beckman El du Pont de Nemours Standex Intl Corp Energen Corp TW Services Inc Hercules Inc Tokheim Corp Houghton Mifflin Union Carbide Lukens Inc West Point Pepperell THURSDAY Acme-Cleveland Kentucky Utilities Anadarko Petrolm Corp Mead Corp Avemco Corp Morton-Thiokol Inc Bay Stae Gas NACCO Indus Cameron Iron Works Natl Distillers & Chem Delta Air Lines Norton Co Donaldson Co Olin Corp Empire District Elec Pfizer Inc Equifax Inc Potomac Elec Pwr Ethyl Corp Quaker State Corp General Nutrition Sonat Inc Georgia Pacific Veeco Instruments Iowa-Ill G & E XTRA Corp FRIDAY Coachmen Indus Natl Medical Enterprises Donnelley RR & Sons Sizzler Property Invstrs Kaufman & Broad Inc Tyler Corp Kysor Industrial Vulcan Materials Mobil Corp Weis Markets SATURDAY Federal Signal Wackenhut Corp SUNDAY Louisiana Pacific Corp

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
description: International A2-14

title: Bidder for Post Ready to Omit Its Real Estate
description: Leonard Stern, the chairman of Hartz Mountain Industries and owner of The Village Voice, said yesterday that he would offer to buy The New York Post without its real estate if economic agreements could be struck with the newspaper's labor unions.

title: Possible Law Violations Under Study by S.E.C.
description: As part of its broad investigation of the October stock market collapse, the Securities and Exchange Commission is studying the extent to which companies may have announced stock buyback plans without actually intending to buy the stock.

title: Advertising; Harvard Changes Look Of Its Business Review
description: As an antidote to the October Wall Street collapse, the Harvard Business Review will include cartoons in a revamping that will make its debut with the January-February issue.

title: A Life Defiant, Despite AIDS
description: The brightly lighted hall with its metal folding chairs was a far cry from the dim, smoky clubs where Robert Sanford played before his illness. And his selection of music was dictated by the fact that his left hand, damaged by chemotherapy, is virtually useless these days, and by his blindness, which limits his keyboard bravado.

title: Cornerbacks Strive to Avoid Blame
description: They have been targets long before a game was called super. The development of the passing game and the evolution of two-platoon football created the need for people to be in the right place while hoping that it was not the wrong time.

title: Former Aide Says He Can Detail Noriega's Corruption
description: A former top adviser to the Panamanian military ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, said yesterday that he would provide details on the general's involvement in drug and arms smuggling, corruption and money laundering, unless the general removed himself from politics.

title: Bus Strike Jams Golden Gate
description: Cars jammed the Golden Gate Bridge today as a strike by bus drivers who normally haul 27,000 passengers a day forced commuters to form car pools, ride ferries and seek other ways of getting to work. About 300 Golden Gate Transit drivers and telephone operators walked off the job early Saturday after negotiators remained deadlocked beyond a Friday midnight strike deadline.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What's bugging me is that you seem to get access to early drafts of intelligence. I don't even get a final copy.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz to Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. [ A18:4. ]

title: Merrill Shows Profit for Quarter
description: Capping a tumultuous year, Merrill Lynch & Company, the parent of the nation's largest stock brokerage, yesterday reported a small fourth-quarter profit, surprising analysts who had expected it to post a small loss.

title: Schmertz, Mobil's Warrior, Said to Plan Own Business
description: Herbert Schmertz, whose combative responses to critics of the Mobil Corporation and the oil industry made him the nation's best-known corporate public relations executive during the 1970's, is said to be preparing to leave the company to set up his own business.

title: Chess: Gelfand Wins Junior Event With Two Queen Sacrifices
description: Two Soviet players captured the top places in the 1988 European Junior Championship in Arnhem, the Netherlands. Boris Gelfand won the gold medal with an 11 1/2-1 1/2 score, a half-point ahead of the silver medalist, Vassily Ivanchuk, an international master who was last year's winner.

title: IMPERIAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special gains of $29 million for the quarter and year. c-After a special charge of $155 million. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Boeing Profit Declines 26%
description: The Boeing Company today reported fourth-quarter earnings of $141 million, or 92 cents a share, down 26.2 percent from $191 million, or $1.23 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Transcript of Reagan's State of the Union Message to Nation
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's State of the Union Message, prepared for delivery to Congress tonight:

title: Washington Talk: Cabinet; Secret of a Survivor Is Topic of Hot Debate
description: Samuel Riley Pierce Jr., the only member of President Reagan's original Cabinet still in office, says he has survived by doing his job quietly and effectively.

title: TAUNTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Both year-ago periods' nets include a net gain of $261,000 from a Mutual Savings Central Fund dividend. The bank converted to stock form in June 1986.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why are days in January colder than those in December, though the amount of sunlight (and hence heat) is steadily increasing as the new year progresses?

title: REAGAN PROMISES TO PURSUE AGENDA TO END OF HIS TERM
description: President Reagan said tonight he would remain a vigorous, aggressive President ''right to the finish line'' of his Administration a year from now.

title: Gulf Lull: An Iran Offensive on Hold
description: Iran is hesitating to mount a long-forecast winter offensive against Iraq in the seven-year-old Persian Gulf war, Western and Iraqi officials say, and apparently is concentrating instead on diplomatic efforts to break up a broad coalition of pro-Iraqi Arab nations.

title: Sandinistas Begin Talks With Indian Rebels
description: The Sandinista Government opened formal peace talks today with Miskito Indian leaders who have been waging a sporadic anti-Sandinista war for seven years.

title: THE DAY HE CAUGHT WALTER JOHNSON
description: BOB BERMAN was a 19-year-old rookie for the Washington Senators when he was sent into the game in the bottom of the ninth to catch Walter Johnson. It was June 12, 1918, 70 years ago this summer, in Sportsman's Park, St. Louis.

title: Prices Fall on Talk of Sales Of Gold by Large Producers
description: Precious metal futures were battered yesterday on reports of substantial sales of gold by South Africa and the Soviet Union, the two largest suppliers of bullion. Meanwhile, copper prices tumbled as more analysts said the yearlong rally in copper prices appeared to be sputtering out.
