title: E-11 UNDAUNTED BY BID FROM AMERICAN BRANDS
description: E-II Holdings Inc. made it clear today that American Brands' ''Pac-Man''' ploy had not dissuaded it from trying to take over the tobacco and consumer goods giant.

title: Yankees Won't Pursue Gibson
description: Three days after Kirk Gibson and six other players were awarded a second shot at becoming free agents because of collusion among the club owners, the Yankees announced yesterday that they would not pursue Gibson in the open market.

title: Stage: Roy Blount in Humorists' Series
description: ''ROY BLOUNT'S Happy Hour and a Half'' is one of the season's most self-descriptive titles. For 90 minutes we are, figuratively, at a bar with the author and raconteur as he expounds wittily on his shaggy life and his and our hard times.

title: Three Mile Island Cleanup Uncovers New Details
description: When operators lost control of the Unit 2 reactor at Three Mile Island on March 28, 1979, it was widely feared that Pennsylvania, or even the United States, might be bathed in radioactive material. This did not happen. The reactor had evidently remained intact.

title: REAGAN INFLUENCE WANES, POLL FINDS
description: President Reagan's influence is continuing to recede as the 1988 election year commences, and the nation's political mood is one of drift and uncertainty, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Rule Witnesses May Be Barred by Judge
description: In a 5-to-3 decision, the Supreme Court ruled today that criminal trial judges may bar defense witnesses from testifying in order to punish attorneys for failing to disclose the witnesses' identities soon enough. The Court said the judges could take the action regardless of whether the defendants were at fault.

title: A 25-Year Term Given in Killing Of a Policeman
description: As more than 50 police officers watched, a man described as a low-level drug dealer was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a rookie police officer in a gun battle in Queens.

title: Nascar Drug Testing
description: While saying ''we don't think we have a problem at this time,'' Bill France Jr., the president of Nascar, announced yesterday a drug testing program for Winston Cup Series stock car racing drivers. The policy, which goes into effect immediately, would incorporate ''reasonable suspicion'' as the basis for testing drivers, mechanics, crew members and Nascar officials. Positive test results for such drugs as marijuana, cocaine and heroin would lead to an indefinite suspension. ''If someone tests positive, they're out,'' France said. ''If they come back, whenever, and test negative, they can go back to racing again.'' There will be no set time limit before a competitor could be retested.

title: EXCEL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings for 1986 is not meaningful because the bank converted from a mutual to a stock organization in September 1986. The per share earnings for the year- ago quarter is before an extraordinary item.

title: Opera: Szymanowski's 'King Roger' in California
description: The Long Beach Opera is interesting to sociologists of the operatic scene as a point of entry in this country for the school of deconstructionist stage direction that has flourished in Europe over the past decade or so, especially in Germany. The dominant artistic presence here in recent years has been that of the brothers Christopher and David Alden, both directors. The latter, who has worked more prominently in leading European houses than American ones, presented a version of Karol Szymanowski's ''King Roger'' at the Terrace Theater Sunday afternoon.

title: LOTUS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Pitney Bowes Switches to Hill, Holliday
description: HILL, HOLLIDAY, CONNORS, COSMOPULOS of Boston has won Pitney Bowes Inc.'s account, which includes the corporate advertising and most of work for the company's business systems. Billings will be between $7 million and $10 million. This is the first new account of 1988 for Hill, Holliday, which last year increased its billings 23 percent, to $320 million.

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $9,100,000 for both periods and extraordinary tax gains of $300,000 and $8,200,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title:
Market Place;
Hedge Fund Best In Bank Grouping
description: LEAD: DESPITE the October stock market collapse, which wiped out billions of dollars in previous stock gains throughout the investment world, the Bank of Oklahoma's Option Equity Fund held its own. By falling ''only'' nine-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter, it was the best performer out of 321 commingled bank common stock funds tracked by CDA Investment

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 14 about a Supreme Court ruling involving promotions in the New York City Police Department misstated the number of officers promoted to sergeant as an outgrowth of a competitive examination first given in 1983. Of more than 11,000 who took the test, 2,039 have been promoted.

title: Music: Morocco's Gnawa
description: IN Marrakesh, and elsewhere in southern Morocco, Gnawa musicians play for all-night, outdoor rituals with dancing, singing and spirit possession. A young master Gnawa musician, Hassan Hakmoun, brought a solo version of the music to the Ethnic Folk Arts Center (179 Varick Street) on Sunday, as part of its Music Around the Mediterranean series. Although a solo musician before a foreign audience can't re-create a community festival, even on his own Mr. Hakmoun conveyed the propulsive, ecstatic quality of the music.

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $53 million to cover litigation contingencies. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $473 million from the repurchase of debentures and a charge of $36 million associated with divested businesses. d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $569 million, an accounting adjustment resulting in a gain of $270 million, and an extraordinary charge of $473 million.

title: Colleen Moore, Star of 'Flapper' Films, Dies at 85
description: Colleen Moore, the star of the silent screen who personified the ''flapper'' of the 1920's, died of cancer yesterday at her ranch near Paso Robles, Calif. She was 85 years old. Miss Moore appeared in about 100 films beginning in 1917 and ending with one of her comparatively few talking pictures, ''The Scarlet Letter,'' in 1937. But it was in the Roaring Twenties that she put her stamp on American social history, creating in dozens of films the image of the wide-eyed, insouciant flapper with her bobbed hair and short skirts.

title: Johnny Gee Former Pitcher, 72
description: Johnny Gee, who pitched for the Pittsburgh Pirates and the New York Giants in the 1940's and played basketball with the Syracuse Nationals, died Saturday. He was 72 years old.

title: Violin: Hanna Lachert Plays
description: HANNA LACHERT is a violinist whose education began in Poland and continued in a gradual westward direction, including a stay at the Royal Conservatory of Brussels. Ms. Lachert joined the New York Philharmonic in 1972, settled into the American musical life and has still worked at keeping her status as a solo recitalist.

title: Rather's Questioning of Bush Sets Off Shouting on Live Broadcast
description: Vice President Bush and Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, shouted at each other in a 10-minute interview about the Iran-contra affair on live national television last night.

title: Power Furnishings
description: Several weeks ago Michael Deaver, the former Presidential adviser, in need of money to pay his legal bills, held a tag sale of his office furnishings. Last weekend John Connally, a former Governor of Texas in need of money to pay an army of creditors, consigned his worldly goods to auction. Mr. Deaver got about $100,000 from his sale. Mr. Connally should get nearly $3 million from his. And the American public got a close look at the decorating taste of political power.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Boston Stock Exchange Inc. said Linda R. Coleman had joined the exchange as executive vice president, planning and development.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the financing of political campaigns in Iowa misidentified a Phoenix lawyer who contributed $5,000 to the Iowa Democratic Party on behalf of former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona.

title: PEOPLES BANCORP (NORTH CAROLINA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lights at Wrigley Field?
description: The chairman of the Cubs told a Chicago City Council hearing yesterday that the club would consider leaving Chicago if the city did not allow night baseball games at Wrigley Field. The chairman, John Madigan, appeared before the council's committee on energy and environmental protection. The panel is considering a proposal to install lights at Wrigley Field. Currently, the lights are banned by city ordinance and state law. ''Without the ability to play night baseball, we would be forced to consider moving to another municipality, where we could operate under more reasonable conditions,'' Madigan said. Residents in the Wrigley Field area have opposed night baseball, saying it would increase noise and congestion in the area. If the city amends its ordinance to allow lights, the State Legislature is expected to take a similar action.

title: Family Opens Home to 63 After Storm Closes Road
description: A couple who saw a line of stranded motorists near their home invited them in for the night and ended up serving breakfast today to 63 new friends, including a missionary from Japan and a couple from England, ''It's been quite fun - it's a lovely group of people,'' said Nickie Jones, 23 years old, of London. ''It was like a jigsaw on the floor last night, with all the people sleeping on it.''

title: South Africa Trade Causes Rift in Japan
description: A senior Foreign Ministry official said today that Japan's booming trade with South Africa was an embarrassment to the Government, and he expressed fear that it might undermine the credibility of Japan's anti-apartheid policy.

title: Costly Federal Fix for Local Tolls
description: Hard facts now prove the folly of a Federal law that ordered one-way tolls on the bridge over New York harbor. Local tolls are none of Congress's business, and the consequences were predictable -lost revenues, clogged traffic and polluted air.

title: Union Carbide Posts a Profit
description: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday reported fourth-quarter net income of $23 million, or 17 cents a share. In the period a year earlier, the giant chemical company reported a net loss of $495 million, reflecting an after-tax charge of $473 million from the company's repurchase of shares during a takeover battle with the GAF Corporation.

title: St. Patrick's Challenge: Woman Grand Marshal
description: On Sunday, the reporters began to phone. A photographer visited her yesterday afternoon. Friends have been calling to wish her luck and the house on Penelope Avenue in Middle Village, Queens, has begun to take on an air of celebration. The challenge, therefore, for Dorothy Hayden Cudahy has been obvious but not simple: to keep her emotions in order, to be mindful of recent history.

title: MOORE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Cuomo Offers Pension Fund for Loans
description: Governor Cuomo said today that $100 million from the state pension system would be made available for loans to small businesses at below-market interest rates.

title: Apple's Products
description: Apple Computer Inc. has introduced two new software products designed to improve communications between its Macintosh personal computers and the larger computer systems offered by such vendors as the Digital Equipment Corporation. One product, MacAPPC, establishes standards for software design to the larger computers from microcomputers. The company also introduced MacWorkStation, which allows developers to create programs with Macintosh computers for use on minicomputers.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,428,000 for the quarter and $3,222,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $612,000 for the quarter and $1,650,000 for the year. The year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: Duchess of York Is Pregnant; Child Would Be 5th in Line
description: The Duke and Duchess of York are expecting their first baby in August, Buckingham Palace said today. The child would be fifth in line to the British throne.

title: Poland Says It Expelled Reported Abu Nidal Aide
description: A Polish Government spokesman said today that Warsaw acted this month on American information to expel a Palestinian businessman reported to be a close associate of Abu Nidal, the Palestinian terrorist leader.

title: Mid-January Vehicle Sales Up 32.7%
description: Mid-January sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were up 32.7 percent from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Unit of Affiliated To Buy Publication
description: Billboard Publications, the newest subsidiary of Affiliated Publications Inc., said that it had signed an agreement to acquire The Hollywood Reporter, the trade publication. The 57-year-old daily, with a circulation of about 20,000, is owned by Hollywood Reporter Industries, which is owned by Tichi Wilkerson Kassal. Mrs. Kassal will continue as publisher and editor, Affiliated said.

title: 2 POSSIBLE BUYERS SEEN FOR 6 NBC STATIONS
description: The Emmis Broadcasting Corporation and Quantum Media Inc. are among several companies interested in acquiring the six stations of NBC Radio, according to industry executives familiar with the negotiations.

title: Boston Curator Defends Black Artists' Exhibition
description: When Edmund Barry Gaither decided to assemble an exhibition of black artists at the Museum of Fine Arts here, he expected a certain amount of criticism.

title: Jews Must Not Break Bones
description: There is a gift that foreign supporters of Israel, particularly Jews, can now give to the country. And there is a gift that a particular leader of Israel, who has fought for her in war after war, can give. It would be a gift of great cost to himself, but would burnish his name and that of his perpetually embattled nation.

title: Belgique Plan By Gevaert
description: Gevaert N.V., a Belgian maker of photographic products, announced today that it would lead a group of investors in an attempt to buy most of the new shares issued last week by Societe Generale de Belgique.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2.4 million and $4.2 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a credit of $14.2 million representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes tax credits of $6.2 million for the quarter and $14.9 million for the year. The company said net for the latest fourth quarter and year benefited by $16.4 million resulting from a tax settlement regarding tax accounting methods for certain depreciable assets. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Hazleton Laboratories during the second quarter of 1987 on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Dissolve the Taxi Commission and Start Again
description: To the Editor:

title: New Haiti Chief Seeks To Quiet Vote Critics
description: A day after he was designated President-elect by a Government-appointed electoral council, Leslie F. Manigat tried today to quell renewed charges of fraud and to turn toward the future with a pledge that he would strive to build ''a society of social justice.''

title: TV Reviews; The Rev. Jim Bakker And the Government
description: WHAT did the Rev. Jim Bakker do, and how did he do it? Forget the sexual scandal. ''Frontline'' is exploring a more important area: Mr. Bakker and the Government. Did some agencies look the other way when the television preacher was piling up money? ''Frontline,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, suggests they did.

title: People
description: * Douglas B. Leeds has become president of Thomson-Leeds Company, which has been acquired by the Ogilvy Group.

title: Soviet Space Contract
description: A West German concern has signed an agreement with the Soviet Union to use Russian satellites for space experiments. The company, Kayser Threde, is to conduct three experiments on board the Soviet Foton spacecraft between 1989 and 1992, according to the Soviet news agency Tass. The news agency gave no details, but said the company was developing a laser device to measure environmental pollution from space.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $186 million after-tax gain from the initial public offering by ARCO Chemical Co. of 19,550,000 of its common shares completed in October 1987. The company said the gain was offset by several charges, including a $53 million after-tax charge resulting from ARCO's withdrawal from a proposed natural gas pipeline project in Alaska that the company deemed uneconomic; a $45 million after-tax charge for interest on unsettled tax issues; and a $95 million after-tax charge to reserves for future environmental cleanup costs associated primarily with chemical segment assets retained by ARCO, and certain assets acquired in the 1969 merger with Sinclair Oil but never operated by ARCO.

title: Cowles Media Unit To Buy Bowhunter
description: Blue-Jay Inc. of Fort Wayne, Ind., the publisher of Bowhunter magazine, is on the verge of being acquired by Historical Times of Harrisburg, Pa., a subsidiary of the Cowles Media Company. No details of the sale were released.

title: Japanese Imposing Sanctions on North Korea
description: Japan imposed diplomatic sanctions on North Korea today, saying it was convinced that ''organized terrorism from North Korea'' was responsible for the bombing of a South Korean airliner two months ago.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Basics From Bush

title: Exxon Net Rises 5.4%; ARCO, Ashland Gain
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that strong sales of chemicals and refined oil products, as well as higher average crude-oil prices, lifted its fourth-quarter net income by 5.4 percent.

title: The News Movie: A New Form
description: IT has been heading there all along; now it has arrived. The news movie is here. CBS News finally gave birth to ''48 Hours.'' What's real is what's real, but properly filmed, edited and scored, it is supposed to reach out and grab us. The news movie is the television equivalent of the nonfiction novel.

title: Group Bids for Canadian Chain
description: A group of Canadian companies has offered to buy Steinberg Inc., one of the country's largest supermarket chains, for $980 million in cash (Canadian), or $764 million (American). The group is Oxdon Investments Inc., which is owned by the Unicorp Canada Corporation, the Gordon Investments Corporation and the Oxford Development Group.

title: 'Bog Man' Reveals Story of a Brutal Ritual
description: ABOUT 2,200 years ago, an aristocratic young Celt was brutally slain and thrown into a bog near what is now Manchester, England. His body, almost perfectly preserved, has become the focus of a scientific effort that some scholars believe will lead to rewriting the history of ancient Europe.

title: EXXON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $7 million resulting from asset dispositions. c-Includes a gain of $486 million, or 34 cents a share, on asset dispositions for both the quarter and year.

title: Broncos Fine Receiver
description: The Broncos arrived today for the Sunday Super Bowl game, and Coach Dan Reeves announced he had fined Vance Johnson, his star receiver, for an incident last week.

title: 'Praying' Dolls Bring Some Mixed Blessings
description: A new line of dolls that kneel and clasp their hands in a gesture of prayer has drawn mixed reactions from religious groups.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Getting Tough
description: There's a bit of a competition in Congress for who can bash Japan hardest in public works.

title: KEY RATES
Two Convicted of Murder in Plot Linked to California Finance Club
description: Two members of a former Los Angeles social and business club, the Billionaire Boys Club, were convicted in Redwood City today of murdering the father of one of the defendants in a plot to obtain his assets.

title: U.S. Issues Continue to Advance
description: Prices of outstanding Government issues continued to improve yesterday, despite the specter of a heavy supply of new Treasury notes and bonds to be auctioned next week.

title: Thomas P. Hackett Jr., Psychiatrist, 59
description: Thomas P. Hackett Jr., chief of psychiatry at Massachusetts General Hospital, died of a heart attack Saturday while horseback riding. He was 59 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: Seminar Honors 'Queen' of Soap Operas
description: In the world of soap operas, Agnes Nixon is the reigning queen. She has had at least one show on the air every weekday, 52 weeks a year, for more than 30 years - and that's all original episodes, with no reruns. Three of ABC's current soaps are her creations: ''One Life To Live,'' which has been on the air for 20 years; ''All My Children,'' a veteran of 18 years; and one relative newcomer, ''Loving,'' which is five years old.

title: Computervision In Merger Talks
description: The Computervision Corporation has begun negotiations with Prime Computer Inc. about a possible acquisition by Prime, but the companies warned that no agreement might be reached. Computervision officials said the company was still urging its stockholders not to tender shares to Prime under its offer of $443.5 million, or $15 a share.

title: Garberville Journal; Marijuana Once Reigned as the King
description: Not long ago, when hundreds defied the law and grew marijuana openly in this region's remote valleys, cash flowed easily along the town's Main Street, spurring one of the biggest bonanzas in the history of a rawboned town whose economic story has been one long chronicle of boom and bust.

title: NEWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $694,000 for the quarter and $3,392,000 for the year.

title: A New Superconductor
description: AMERICAN and Japanese scientists have independently discovered a new high-temperature superconductor that differs dramatically from the family of materials that set off a flood of research over the last year.

title: Elton John to Sell Artworks
description: Elton John is selling a major portion of his collection of paintings, personal memorabilia and 20th-century decorative arts - at auction in the early fall at his home near Windsor, Berkshire, a Sotheby's spokesman, Fiona James, said yesterday by telephone from London.

title: 'Chemical Clamps' May Eliminate Some Surgery
description: MEDICAL researchers have begun experimenting with synthetic hormones that effectively block harmful body secretions, an approach they hope will lead to the better treatments for many common diseases. In the case of some cancers, the new approach may even eliminate the need for surgery.

title: Cocaine's Many Dangers: The Evidence Mounts
description: AS reports of cocaine-related deaths steadily accumulate, doctors are gaining a sharper awareness of the dangers of the drug. Increasingly, the doctors realize they must add cocaine abuse to their checklist of considerations when they are confronted with certain medical emergencies - in infants as well as adults.

title: Boxing Notebook; Tyson-Spinks Door Still Open
description: During negotiations last weekend for a Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks match in June, Bill Cayton, Tyson's co-manager, told Butch Lewis, Spinks's promoter, that if he walked out on the discussions not to bother to come back. Lewis left in spite of the warning.

title: 2 Presidents Named At Chrysler Motors
description: Bennett E. Bidwell and Robert A. Lutz have both gained the title of president, along with some added responsibilities, at the Chrysler Corporation's Chrysler Motors subsidiary. Their job changes followed the resignation last week of Harold K. Sperlich, the unit's president since 1985.

title: CRANE COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $9,002,000 from an accounting change to comply with current FASB requirements for gain on pension asset reversion. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ROOSEVELT AND DE GAULLE. Allies in Conflict: A Personal Memoir. By Raoul Aglion. 237 pages. Illustrated.

title: Utility Officer Will Resign
description: Charles M. Heidel said today that he would resign as president and chief operating officer of the Detroit Edison Company.

title: American Jews Must Let Israel Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Readings of Short Stories
description: Selected Shorts: A Celebration of the Short Story, a series of live readings that runs through May, continues on Feb. 3 at 6:30 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. The writer Calvin Trillin is the host for the reading, which will feature as readers George S. Irving, Josef Sommer, Mercedes Reuhl, Phyllis Newman and Christine Baranski. Works to be read include Mark Twain's ''Private History of the 'Jumping Frog' Story,'' Nora Ephron's ''My First Husband'' and Thomas Meehan's ''Yma Dream.'' Admission is $8.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Aborigines Cast a Cloud Over Australia's Party
description: Thousands of aborigines from around the country met here tonight in what their organizers said could well be the largest gathering of this ancient people in its 40,000-year history.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,007,000 for the quarter and $887,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,716,000. The results for the latest fourth quarter also include pre-tax gains of more than $21.7 million from the sale of branches of its American Savings unit and its ICA Mortgage Corp. unit. The sales also resulted in certain one-time costs resulting from branch closing, severance and other related charges. The latest year includes a second quarter after-tax writeoff of $10.2 million for the FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes interest expenses of $13,300,000 and $45,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, related to a December 1986 share repurchase. The 1986 full-year earnings were reduced by non-recurring charges and Contac re-launch expenses of $41,400,000.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday misidentified a new director at the GTE Corporation. He is George V. Grune.

title: Providence Suffers A Shattering Loss
description: Jerome Lane had 17 points and 17 rebounds, and halted the game for a half-hour with a backboard-shattering slam dunk tonight as Pittsburgh routed Providence, 90-56, in a Big East Conference game.

title: Freddie Mac Plans Purchase Of Convertible Mortgages
description: The growing popularity of adjustable-rate mortgages convertible to a fixed interest rate led the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation to announce yesterday that it would issue participation certificates in exchange for those mortgages, or else buy the mortgages for cash.

title: Israel's Military-Injustice System
description: LEAD: Speaking in Jerusalem last December, William J. Brennan Jr., Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, said it may be Israel, not America, that provides the best hope for building a jurisprudence that can create a democracy that will best protect civil liberties against national security demands.

title: KEYSTONE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ozone Study In Arctic
description: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration scientists who earlier studied the loss of ozone over the South Pole are now turning their attention to the North Pole, the Federal agency announced today.

title: I.B.M. and A.T.&T. Donate Chip Technology to Sematech
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are expected to announce Tuesday that they will donate designs and manufacturing technology for advanced computer chips to Sematech, the new consortium formed by many of the nation's leading computer and semiconductor companies.

title: UNITED BANKS OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results include after-tax gains from the settlement of the company's retirement plans of $5.5 million, or 38 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $8.2 million, or 56 cents a share, for the year-ago period. Preferred dividends exceeded net income for the latest full year. All prior period financial statements restated to reflect the acquisition of Intrawest Financial Corp. on April 30, 1987.

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: The latest quarter's net included a pre-tax charge for employee severance of $47.4 million. Also included are charges for credit reserves and operations, related settlement expenses as well as relatively minor trading losses, all of which aggregated $55 million durng October's turbulent market conditions. A change in the firm's vacation policy reduced compensation and benefits expenses by $69.2 million in the quarter. In addition, insurance proceeds of $51.5 million were received in settlement of several outstanding insurance claims. The latest year net included after- tax gains, adjusted for full-year results, of $96.7 million from the sale of Merrill Lynch's right to acquire a partnership interest in the South Tower of the world financil center and related transactions, $108.3 million from the sale of a portion of the company's leasing business, and $45.5 million from the sale of Master Limited Partnership units of the company's residential real estate operation. The prior year net included an after- tax gain of $105.2 million from the sale of a portion of the company's leasing business and an after-tax loss of $14.8 million from the early recall of certain debt issues. The 1987 full-year results included an income tax provision of $38.5 million, compared with a provision of $286.8 million for 1986. In the latest fourth quarter, income tax benefits of $36.8 million were rcognized, compared with an income tax provision of $71.7 million for the year- ago period.

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the effect of accounting and other plan changes, after considering inventory carry values, is an increase in 1987 net earnings of $39 million and share earnings of 25 cents.

title: Figure in Corruption Case Is Said to Be Aiding Inquiry
description: A former Queens Democratic Party official convicted on corruption charges, Richard L. Rubin, has secretly been cooperating with a state agency investigating political corruption and patronage in the Queens judiciary, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: No Crimp in Her Style
description: Joan Benoit Samuelson, the Olympic gold medalist and two-time Boston Marathon winner, said that recent motherhood isn't putting a crimp in her running style. In a 10-kilometer race at Wilton Manors, Fla., on Sunday, she finished first in the women's division in 34 minutes 12 seconds and 11th over all in a field of 560. Her 3-month-old daughter Abigail slept on the sidelines during the race. ''Actually, my energy levels were very high during pregnancy and they've been high since,'' she said. She hopes to compete in the Olympic trials in Pittsburgh on May 1.

title: Beijing Journal; In Baldness War, Rumors of Advance for Hairline
description: His pate gleaming like a freshly peeled potato, the man waited expectantly in the whitewashed room, the buoyant confidence of a lottery ticket buyer lighting his eyes.

title: Group to Install New Director
description: The International Federation of Advertising Agencies will install Norval B. Stephens Jr., a veteran advertising man, as its managing director next Monday.

title: Bureau Provides List Of Magazine Ad Pages
description: The Publishers Information Bureau, a sister organization of the Magazine Publishers of America, has released its annual list of its members along with the ad page count and estimated ad revenues for 1987.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 split of the company's stock that was distributed April 24, 1987, to stockholders of record on March 31, 1987.

title: You Could Look It Up
description: MODERN reporters write on computers and editors use the electronic equivalents of pencils, erasers and scissors. Even so, a pile of old-fashioned books can usually be found next to the computer. Dictionary, thesaurus, stylebook and computer manual - old technology and new technology side by side.

title: NATIONAL SAVINGS BANK (ALANY) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $259,500.

title: MERCANTILE BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A graph in Business Day last Tuesday, with an article about businesses' reluctance to build new factories, bore an incorrect label. It represented gross spending on machinery and factories.

title: Indianapolis Conductor Wins Stokowski Award
description: William Henry Curry, associate conductor of the Indianapolis Symphony, has been named this year's winner of the Leopold Stokowski Conducting Competition.

title: Home Sales Down 3.8%
description: Sales of existing single-family homes dropped 3.8 percent in December, the National Association of Realtors said today. It was the second consecutive monthly decline.

title: Yonkers, Ending 2-Year Battle, Agrees to Low-Income Housing
description: After a two-year battle over a court desegregation order that has left Yonkers a divided city, local officials and the plaintiffs yesterday agreed on a plan to build low-income housing in mostly white neighborhoods.

title: INSIDE
description: A Panamanian's Threat A former Panama official threatened to tell of illegal acts by the military ruler unless he left politics. Page A3. 'Flapper' Star Dies at 85 Colleen Moore, the silent movie star who personified the ''flapper,'' has died in California. Page B6. Ex-Official Helps Inquiry A former top Queens Democrat, convicted of corruption, has been aiding an inquiry on the judiciary. Page B1. Tennis Acts on South Africa The International Tennis Federation will no longer require players to enter a South African tournament. The move stems from concern over a possible boycott of the Summer Olympics by African nations. Page B7.

title: New Session, Old Odor
description: Congress started over yesterday with the usual inflated pomp and optimism. But it's hardly a fresh start. The first half of this 100th Congress ended at a new low, with bad law, furtive deals and the odor of pork. As President Reagan demonstrated in his State of the Union Message last night, holding up 43 pounds worth of last-minute law, the lesson is plain: Renounce monster money bills.

title: Nissan Plant in Tennessee is U.A.W. Target
description: The United Automobile Workers Union last week opened a campaign to organize workers at the second-largest union-free Japanese automobile plant in the United States.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted from a mutual to a stock form of ownership on July 24, 1986. Per share earnings for the 1986 year are not shown as the computation will not present meaningful results for periods or partial periods in which the bank was in mutual form.

title: Pre-Nuptial AIDS Screening Taxes Illinois Health System
description: A new Illinois law requiring tests for the AIDS virus before marriage is sending thousands of couples into a health system ill-prepared to handle them and has left health officials wondering how to pay for couples who cannot afford the test.

title: 42.94 Jump Puts Dow At 1,946.45
description: Stock prices surged in heavy trading yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average recaptured much of last week's loss, climbing 42.94 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,946.45.

title: The Duty of a Democrat in Haiti
description: The Haitian military has stuffed a reasonably good man into the presidency - to the profound indifference of Western Hemisphere leaders.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Art and the F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission has become involved in a case of alleged art fraud that a commission attorney, calls ''a first'' for the agency.

title: CENVEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
Siamese Twins to Get Skull Plates
description: Two California companies are making plates to repair the skulls of German Siamese twins separated last September, and the plates will be inserted as soon as they are finished, according to officials at Johns Hopkins Hospital.

title: Fast-Food Plastic Is Minuscule in Landfill Garbage; Efforts in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Britoil Rejects Higher B.P. Offer
description: Britoil P.L.C. has rejected an increased takeover offer from the British Petroleum Company that values Britoil at $:2.5 billion, or about $4.45 billion. ''B.P. has consistently failed to recognize Britoil's true worth,'' said David Walker, Britoil's chairman. ''Its latest offer still significantly undervalues Britoil.''

title: The Lessons of '68 for Liberals in '88
description: Before we are inundated by the inevitable flood of articles and television specials commemorating the tumultuous events of 20 years ago, any Americans who still call themselves liberals would do well to remember that 1968 was a year of unmitigated disaster for their cause. It marked the end of New Deal, Fair Deal, New Frontier and Great Society liberalism. And, with all its deaths, disruptions and disillusions, 1968 inflicted deep traumas from which America has yet to recover.

title: Rivals Will Pray Before They Play
description: Most of the Denver Broncos and the Washington Redskins will join Saturday in a prayer meeting that is believed to be the first to bring together National Football League players from opposing teams on the eve of any game - much less a Super Bowl.

title: Heyward Decides He Will Turn Pro
description: Craig Heyward, Pitt's all-America running back, said today that he would forgo his final season of college football eligibility in the hope of playing in the National Football League next season.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $10,947,000 related to adjustments for foreign currency exchange and taxes for the quarter, and the year includes net gains of $611,431,000, or $10.94 a share, on the sale of the company's Himont Inc. affiliate. c-Includes non-recurring charges of $8,500,000 related to retroactive provisions of the 1986 Tax Act for the quarter, and the year includes net gains of $20,800,000, or 36 cents a share, related to retroactive provisions of the 1986 Tax Act.

title: Pacific Telesis Profit Declines
description: The Pacific Telesis Group today reported a 37 percent drop in its fourth-quarter earnings. A restructuring program, early-retirement incentives and an adverse rate ruling were cited.

title: Number of Homeless Far Below Shelter Forecasts
description: After years of steady increases, the number of homeless people in New York City shelters and welfare hotels has remained far below levels forecast by the city this winter, leaving city planners and advocates for the homeless puzzling over the unexpected development.

title: Unforeseen Resignation At Pittsburgh Brewing
description: Harvey Sanford announced his resignation yesterday as president and chief executive of the Pittsburgh Brewing Company, as a result of its integration into the G. Heileman Brewing Company.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dusty Baker, who hit 242 home runs during his 14-year career, has been named first-base coach for the San Francisco Giants. . . . Sean Green, a freshman forward, has transferred from North Carolina State to Iona and will be eligible to play for the Gaels next December. . . . Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, was married in Danville, Calif., yesterday to Jill Uann Guiver, a freelance photographer. Mickey Mantle was the best man.

title: Viewers Are Speaking Up About Snyder
description: JIMMY (THE GREEK) SNYDER may be gone, but he is far from forgotten at CBS Sports, or among viewers.

title: The Basic Speech; There's No Challenge That 'the American Mind Collectively Cannot Solve'
description: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a basic speech. It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Law page last Friday about the Texas Supreme Court described appointments to that court incorrectly. Jack Hightower and Lloyd Doggett are Democrats running for seats on the court; they were not appointed to it by Gov. Bill Clements.

title: Washington Talk; Legacy of 'Granddad'
description: Susan Eisenhower was 9 years old when the man she calls ''granddad'' left the White House. Now 36 and head of the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute, she is presiding over activities commemorating the 30th anniversary of the United States-Soviet exchange agreement.

title: Poor Policy to Forgive The Mexican Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Chip Imports Slip
description: Japanese imports of foreign microchips appear to have tapered off after reaching a peak in the second quarter of 1987, an official with the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The United States has charged that Japan has failed to open its market to foreign semiconductor makers. Washington has imposed $165 million worth of trade sanctions on selected Japanese exports for that reason. Foreign chip imports rose to a high of 12.6 percent in the April to June quarter of 1987, but slipped to 12.4 percent in October, the Japanese trade official said.

title: Food Units for Sale
description: Rowntree-Mackintosh P.L.C., a confectionery company, said it wanted to sell its British and American snack-food units for at least the $:155 million, or $277 million in United States currency, it paid for them. The company said that both the Tom's Foods Inc. unit in the United States and the Rowntree Snack Foods Ltd. subsidiary in Britain were profitable but the company did not want to invest the additional money needed to improve the businesses.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included securities gains of $83,397 for the quarter and $846,396 for the year. c-Included securities losses of $3,762 for the quarter and securities gains of $745,606 for the year.

title: Addendum
description: * Bill Communications is changing the name of Incentive Marketing magazine to Incentive May 1.

title: Man Convicted Again in Killing of Georgia Family
description: A man convicted more than 13 years ago of murdering six members of a rural Georgia family was again convicted of those murders tonight.

title: Murdoch Is Given Extension Of Date to Give Up The Post
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Rupert Murdoch may continue to own The New York Post at least until late March, in effect extending a March 6 deadline he had faced.

title: 2d Man Pleads Guilty in Killing of Bicyclist
description: A second assailant pleaded guilty yesterday in the fatal beating and stabbing of a 20-year-old Brooklyn man who was riding a bicycle when he was attacked in Coney Island in May 1986, officials said.

title: NUMERICA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $7.6 million associated with the company's Florida-based banking subsidiary, Numerica Financial Services Inc. for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: New York's Shelters: Who Uses Them and Why
description: To many people, the word homeless conjures up a disheveled, middle-aged alcoholic sprawled on the floor in Grand Central Terminal. But beyond this world of doorways, benches and trash can fires in the night are thousands of homeless people who have never lived on the streets of New York.

title: PATTERNS
description: Flanders in Charge

title: Hertz Concedes It Overcharged For Car Repairs
description: For seven years the Hertz Corporation charged motorists and insurance companies higher prices to repair cars damaged in accidents than it actually paid, the company said yesterday.

title: Talkback's Incentives To Read Magazine Ads
description: If magazine readers are given an incentive to read an ad, their awareness of the product climbs measurably. And awareness is the precursor of sales.

title: IN PARIS, GIDDY MOOD IS CATCHING
description: As the spring and summer couture openings take off in earnest after the lively prologue by Christian Lacroix on Sunday, it is clear that the freewheeling Lacroix spirit has left its mark. Even the most staid, conventional houses have loosened up, so clothes look lighter, brighter and more good humored than they have in many years.

title: MEMORIES STIR AID TO NEEDIEST
description: Edna M. Telep of Yardley, Pa., recalls fondly how she grew up in New York City and ''benefited from the surroundings and the excellent education,'' all of it free.

title: Blast Kills 10 in a Mexican Mine
description: An explosion and fire trapped more than 125 men in a coal mine in northern Mexico today, and authorities said at least 10 had died.

title: Hearings on Missile Treaty Begin; Shultz Sees New Arms-Control Era
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the treaty eliminating land-based medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles would strengthen American and allied security, would enhance international stability and could open a new era in arms control.

title: Bush and Rather Clash Over Iran
description: Vice President Bush and Dan Rather of CBS News shouted at each other yesterday in a combative, live interview. Pointed questions about Mr. Bush's role in the Iran-contra affair brought a forceful response; the Vice President accused CBS of misrepresentation in obtaining the interview.

title: Shock Torturing Of Drug Suspect Charged at Trial
description: A Queens prosecutor charged in court yesterday that a police sergeant had tortured a drug suspect with an electronic stun gun after beating the man with the help of two other officers.

title: Court Blocks Florida Execution in Cause Celebre
description: The United States Supreme Court today blocked the execution of a Florida prisoner whose innocence has been proclaimed by opponents of capital punishment in this country and abraod.

title: Business and Health; H.M.O. Troubles With Medicare
description: THE Reagan Administration's program to persuade elderly Americans to join prepaid health plans is gaining momentum, but nearly 20 percent of the health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, that signed up for the program have dropped out, displacing 80,000 people.

title: Careers; Job Hunting On Wall St. In Aftermath
description: ARE dismissed Wall Street middle managers finding jobs?

title: HOWARD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 per share earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split, effected in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend, paid in February 1987. All per share earnings restated for acquisition of C & C Insurance Associates in August 1987 and Consulting Actuaries Inc. in December 1987, on a pooling of interests basis.

title: 5 Shot, 1 Fatally, on East 28th St.
description: One man was shot and killed and four others were wounded last night in a hail of gunfire during a dispute over illegal drugs on East 28th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues, the police said.

title: Koch Won't Rule Out Seeking Tax Increases
description: Mayor Koch, continuing his drumbeat of dreary fiscal predictions, refused yesterday to rule out proposing increases in any local taxes except those on personal income. He said higher taxes would be needed to help close what he said would be a $500 million budget gap in the next fiscal year.

title: Catfish Slime's Healing Agents
description: CATFISH slime, a gel-like substance secreted by the fish, has remarkable properties that help heal wounds, a team of American and Kuwaiti scientists has discovered.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adler & Shaykin Inc. said it accepted for payment about 7.8 million shares, or about 92 percent, of the outstanding common stock of Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., Torrance, Calif., at $14 a share in cash.

title: SARA LEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: Results for year-ago periods are restated to reflect Bil Mar's pooling of interest, occurring in fiscal 1987.

title: Dismal Devils Lose Fifth Game in Row
description: The Devils have been slipping and sliding on the ice lately and falling in the standings.

title: Victim of a Fatal Plunge At Met Seemed Depressed
description: The 82-year-old opera fan who fell to his death Saturday from an upper balcony of the Metropolitan Opera House during an intermission of Verdi's ''Macbeth'' had indicated that he was severely depressed or contemplating suicide.

title: Don't Let I.N.F. Suffer SALT II's Fate
description: LEAD: As the Senate begins hearings on the ratification of the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces, we are hearing faint stirrings of the same misguided arguments that undermined the SALT II treaty eight years ago. While virtually nobody in Washington believes the I.N.F. pact will be defeated outright, there is great concern that opponents may attach enough ''killer amendments'' to put the I.N.F.

title: Molly Berns, 77, Heart Charity Fund Raiser
description: Molly Berns, an honorary chairwoman of the New York Heart Association for which she had been a principal fund raiser for many years, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the effects of an early retirement program which increased fourth quarter expenses by $217 million, and also includes the effects of a restructuring of the PacTel Communications companies and the 1986 retroactive impact of the California Public Utilities Commission's December 1987 ruling on Pacific Bell's 1986 rate case. Share earnings for 1986 have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split on March 25, 1987.

title: Snow Country to Sell Premier Issue in March
description: While most skiing magazines cover only skiing, here comes a magazine called Snow Country that will also report on off-season activities in its monthly issues.

title: Federated's Fading Profitability
description: When Howard Goldfeder became chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc. in 1981, he vowed to improve the profitability of a company that had long been one of the nation's most respected retailers. But Mr. Goldfeder's failure thus far to accomplish that goal, according to analysts, is a major reason why he now finds himself having to fight off an unwanted $4.2 billion bid from Robert Campeau, the Toronto-based real estate developer.

title: SUFFIELD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax loss of $1.5 million from the sale of equity securities and a pre-tax loss of $3.1 million from the writedown of certain securities. c-Net income d-After a tax credit of $136,000 and a charge of $364,000 from a change in accounting for real estate sales commissions. Both year-ago results restated to reflect the acquisition of Coastal Bancorp., accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

title: JACKSON PRESSES FOR RACIAL PEACE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, campaigning in New York yesterday, called for ''healing'' and ''focusing on common ground'' in the wake of a recent rise in racial tensions in the city.

title: UNIONFED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid in September.

title: Congressmen See Confrontation Over Contra Aid
description: Congressional leaders said today that President Reagan's request in his State of the Union message for renewed aid to the Nicaraguan rebels had placed the Administration squarely in confrontation with Congress at the start of the new legislative year.

title: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $8,747,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $31,847,000 for the year, and the both periods included a loss from an accounting change of $149.7 million.

title: ROYAL PALM SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Few Israelis Dispute Army Tactics in Unrest
description: ''They've risen on us, we didn't rise on them,'' Yehuda Genyan, a tailor, was saying today of the Palestinian protesters. ''They walk around here like kings, but a Jew goes to pray at the wall and he gets stabbed.''

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
JEFFERSON SMURFIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corning Net Surges 72%
description: Corning Glass Works today reported a 72 percent rise in profits in the fourth quarter and a record profit for 1987, thanks to one-time gains in the tax and accounting areas and the addition of an extra week into the financial figuring.

title: Our Towns; Mother's Stand: AIDS Video And Its Message
description: Normally, Andrew Daly, a junior at Ridgewood High School, would not pay attention to a bunch of parents arguing over whether to show an AIDS video at school. ''Not a chance,'' said Andrew. Except one day he looked up and realized his mother was one of the video's leading opponents.

title: Ombudsman Agency for Child Abuse Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Natural' Habitats Offer Insights Into Social Behavior of Animals
description: IN a growing effort to learn more about animal behavior, researchers are constructing ecologically complex swamps, aviaries and cages that try to make captive animals feel more at home.

title: Joyner-Kersee Honored
description: One day after Ben Johnson, the sprinter from Canada, was named the Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year, the news agency yesterday selected Jackie Joyner-Kersee as the Female Athlete of the Year. It was only the third time in the 57-year history of the awards that athletes from the same sport were chosen in the same year. Joyner-Kersee received 128 first-place votes and a total of 860 points. The women's runner-up, Steffi Graf, the West German tennis star, had 108 first-place votes and a total of 806 points. Joyner-Kersee, 25 years old, equaled the world outdoor record in the women's long jump, clearing 24 feet 5 1/2 inches, at the Pan American Games at Indianapolis in August. She won the long jump and heptathlon in the world outdoor championships at Rome in September.

title: Bangladesh Bans Rallies After 8 Are Killed
description: The Government banned rallies and protests today, hours after the opposition vowed to avenge a police fusillade in which at least eight protesters were killed at a rally in Chittagong.

title: Wine Makers Agree To Reduce Urethane
description: American wine producers have reached a voluntary agreement to reduce levels of urethane in table and dessert wines, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.

title: FOURTH FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Inside the Mob: Agent Recalls 'Game of Wits'
description: An undercover agent who infiltrated the Mafia for five years found that his life inside the mob was filled with boredom, loneliness and the constant danger of death.

title: Phelan Defends Specialists In Market's October Plunge
description: On Oct. 19, John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, was at the center of one of the worst financial panics of the 20th century. These days, he is reliving that period as he defends the performance of the Big Board's specialists in the wake of a recent report.

title: GREAT FALLS BANCORP (TOTOA, NJ) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods results were after utilizing tax benefits from prior years operating loss of 5 cents per share for the quarter and after 17 cents per share for the year.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMOCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Variation Detected In Rocket Booster
description: Engineers using new methods to test engine parts of the space shuttle have found unexpected structural variations that could affect the resumption of flights if they prove to be problems, space agency spokesmen said today.

title: George F. Howe, 86; Historian and Author
description: George Frederick Howe, a historian, author and teacher whose career spanned six decades, died of cancer Jan. 18 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 86 years old and lived in Harrisville, N.H., and Washington.

title: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $59.4 million for the quarter and year; the quarter also included an extraordinary loss of $19 million. c-Net income and after an extraordinary loss of $4.6 million. d-After an extraordinary gain of $14.3 million, or 50 cents a share.

title: For the Adventurous
description: IT really is a nightmare. You wake up in a shower stall in a dilapidated building, your head throbbing, your right hand caked with dried blood that is apparently not your own, and a pain under your left forearm where someone may have injected you with - something. As if that weren't enough, you haven't the faintest idea who you are. Even a look in a mirror rings no bells. That's just the beginning of Deja Vu, an interactive adventure from Mindscape. This time, that software publisher's slogan, ''Software that challenges the mind,'' is really appropriate. You'll do a lot of hard thinking, and dogged exploring, before you get out of this one. Did I mention the corpse of a man you may or may not have killed, the policemen who are not exactly your friends, and the mobsters right out of the movies?

title: Mecham-Recall Forces Have Names to Spare
description: State officials today certified that more than 300,000 Arizonans had signed petitions demanding Gov. Evan Mecham's recall. The Governor will be told officially Tuesday that he has five days to resign or agree to run in an election to recall him from office.

title: Fast-Food Plastic Is Minuscule in Landfill Garbage
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp Plans to Avoid U.S.-Mexico Debt Swap
description: Citibank does not plan to participate in a Treasury-backed program designed to relieve Mexico's debt burden, John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman, said in an interview yesterday.

title: '87 Gas Use Up in West
description: Europe and North America used 3.7 percent more natural gas last year than in 1986, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today. The increase was higher in Europe, at 4.8 percent, than in North America, where the United States and Canada each registered a 2 percent gain. Natural gas production in Europe, the United States and Canada rose 2.1 percent.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Washington Talk: U.S.-Soviet Exchanges; Pact Endures 30 Tumultuous Years
description: Thirty years ago this week, Moscow and Washington agreed to get to know each other better.

title: Specialist Gives Up Stock
description: M. J. Meehan & Company, one of Wall Street's largest specialist firms, said yesterday that it had resigned as a market maker in the stock of Gould Inc. after an investigation by the New York Stock Exchange of the way Meehan handled Gould's stock during the week of Oct. 19.

title: Mite From Asia Poses Big Threat to Honeybees And U.S. Crops
description: A TINY Asian mite that kills honeybees has recently invaded the United States, posing a serious challenge to the nation's beekeepers and farmers.

title: Bridge: Unusual Partnership Wins Tournament in the Hague
description: An unusual partnership won an unusual event Sunday in the Hague in the Netherlands. Zia Mahmood, the globe-trotting Pakistani star who is seldom at his London home, teamed with Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., a reigning world champion, to snatch a victory in the Statenbank World Top Tournament, which has a good claim to be considered the world's strongest annual event.

title: By Design; French Chic
description: Whatever you call it - chic, cachet or ''chien,'' that odd French expression - it is something Frenchwomen just seem to have. It's an indefinable quality, a knack for putting oneself together, that results in an enviably stylish look.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Green Is 5 Million Point Man: Rickey Green, a Jazz reserve, took a shot at National Basketball Association history last night and made it during Utah's 119-96 home victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers. His 3-point basket at the end of the third quarter pushed the league 1 point over the 5,000,000 mark since play began in 1946. Before the fourth quarter, there was a brief ceremony and Green autographed the ball, which will be sent to the Basketball Hall of Fame, in Springfield, Mass.(AP) Bullets 118, 76ers 117: - Moses Malone scored 26 points and Bernard King added 22 as Washington won in overtime, running the Bullets' home winning streak to seven since Wes Unseld took over as coach. (AP) Skiing Canadian Wins Super-G Slalom: Felix Belczyk posted Canada's first victory in a World Cup super-G slalom race yesterday in Leukerbad, Switzerland. Heavy snow halted the event after the 73d of 110 starters, but race officials said the event would count in the World Cup standing. Belczyk had a time of 1 minute 51.20 seconds. Primin Zurbriggen was second.(AP) Horse Racing Bristlin' Belle Wins: Bristlin' Belle, a 4-year-old daughter of Alydar-Mary Queenofscots, won by half a length yesterday in a $32,000 allowance for fillies and mares 4 years old and up at Aqueduct. The filly carried 119 pounds under Jose Santos in 1:11 4/5 for six furlongs. N.H.L. Flames 11, Maple Leafs 3: Calgary's John Tonelli scored 40 seconds after the opening face-off last night, triggering a six-goal outburst in the first 14 1/2 minutes that powered Calgary to victory.(AP) Oilers 6, Penguins 4: Dave Hannan registered his first hat trick in his 313th game as the Oilers ended the Penguins' four-game winning streak, at Pittsburgh. Hannan played his entire career with the Penguins until he was part of the Nov. 24 Paul Coffey trade.(AP)

title: Oil Rig Count Declining
description: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States fell again last week, by 28, to 1,026, Baker Hughes said today. The count had dropped by 48 the previous week, to 1,054. A year ago it was 837. The count peaked at 4,500 in December 1981 and reached its low of 663 in mid-1986.

title: BellSouth Purchase
description: The Mobile Communications Corporation of America is negotiating with the BellSouth Corporation to sell its cellular and and certain other businesses. Mobile said the merger would be structured as a tax-free transaction in which each share of Mobile's class A and class B stock would be exchanged for $24 in BellSouth common stock. Both classes of Mobile together total about 23 million shares.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Candidate's Foibles
description: The American electorate may still be divided over the extent to which a politician's personal foibles should be considered in judging his fitness to hold office. But in the Soviet Union a vote has been taken on the subject.

title: Accounts
description: * Western Union to McCaffrey & McCall Direct Marketing for its Easylink and Infomaster programs.

title: Lab Dispute Delays Chambers Trial
description: Lawyers and scientists continued to squabble yesterday at a hearing over whether a laboratory test that has apparently never been used in a criminal case in the United States could be used in the trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. The test, using a laboratory-engineered antibody, showed a high level of an enzyme found in saliva on a stained denim jacket that investigators discovered in August 1986 with Jennifer Levin's body in Central Park. The prosecutor, Linda Fairstein, wants to use the scientific testimony to argue to the jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that Mr. Chambers gagged Miss Levin or covered her mouth with the jacket when he killed her. Mr. Chambers has said he killed Miss Levin accidentally during sex.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JANUARY 26, 1988
description: International A2-11, B6

title: Actors Studio, Long in Turmoil, Seeks a New Artistic Director
description: After months of internal turmoil and financial stress at the Actors Studio, a search is under way to find a replacement for the artistic director, Ellen Burstyn. At the same time, the institution - for more than 40 years the major American training ground for Method acting - is broadening its program to emphasize the development of writers along with actors and directors.

title: Federated Stock Soars After Bid
description: A battle between two major department-store operators opened yesterday as the Campeau Corporation of Canada, owner of Jordan Marsh and Brooks Brothers, began its hostile tender offer to buy Federated Department Stores, which owns Bloomingdale's, Bullock's, Rich's and Filene's.

title: I.C.C. to Get Plea On Santa Fe Unit
description: Kansas City Southern Industries said that it would seek approval from the Interstate Commerce Commission to acquire the Southern Pacific Transportation Company unit of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation. Santa Fe has agreed to sell the unit to Rio Grande Industries, but the commission has not approved the agreement.

title: Illicit Trade Is Built on Reptiles in West
description: Wearing high boots and carrying long poles and burlap bags, lawenforcement officers invaded homes, shops and offices in Arizona and eight other states earlier this month, seizing hundreds of rattlesnakes and exotic crawling desert creatures.

title: Hart and Dukakis Clash at Debate in Boston
description: Former Senator Gary Hart and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachussetts went on the offensive tonight against theis rivals for the Democratic Presidenthal nomination and against each other, turning a debate that began cordially into another forum for sparring among the Democratic candidates.

title: Rock Cracks Mapped
description: Borrowing from sculptors, scientists have developed a new technique that reveals the microscopic cracks that form as rocks or buildings collapse under pressure.

title: USX President Is Seen As Chairman Candidate
description: The USX Corporation announced yesterday that its board had elected Charles A. Corry, a leading company strategist, as president of the giant steel and energy concern.

title: U.S. Jews Torn Over Arab Beatings
description: Israel's policy of responding to unrest in the occupied territories by having its troops beat Palestinian Arabs has generated some quiet expressions of concern but only a few scattered public complaints among leaders of American Jewish groups.

title: Tennis Acts on South Africa
description: Philippe Chatrier, president of the International Tennis Federation, said yesterday that it would no longer require players to play in South Africa. The decision is intended to placate African nations and anti-apartheid groups, as well as the International Olympic Committee, which had expressed concern about a possible African boycott or disruption of the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, because of the annual tennis tournament held in Johannesburg.

title: African Movement Fights for Lives Of the Handicapped
description: CHUBBY little Yao is an African serpent child.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $21 million gain from the reversal of a prior provision for natural gas price refunds.

title: CUBANS WRONGED, MIAMI BISHOP SAYS
description: Auxiliary Bishop Agustin A. Roman of Miami, the Cuban-born prelate who played a major role in the peaceful ending of two prison riots by Cuban inmates, charged today that the Justice Department had not lived up to the spirit of the agreement that brought about the solution to the uprisings.

title: CONSOLIDATED FREIGHTWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Building a Future From a Past
description: Jose Limon, one of the major figures in American modern dance, died in 1972. It has been 10 years since Carla Maxwell, then a Limon dancer with no administrative experience, took over the directorship of the Jose Limon Dance Company.

title: 2 Nordiques Suspended
description: Coach Ron Lapointe of the Quebec Nordiques and Terry Carkner, a defenseman for the club, were suspended for five and 10 games, respectively, for leaving the bench during a third-period fight in a game against the Montreal Canadiens on Sunday night. Lapointe also was fined $1,000 and the team was fined $10,000. Under a new league rule, immediate suspensions are automatic for coaches and players who leave the bench during a fight. Carkner, who initially received a game misconduct for his action, left the bench after a fight broke out early in the third period when Gord Donnelly of the Nordiques crashed into the Montreal goalie, Brian Hayward. Hayward was out of his crease and in the process of clearing the puck when Donnelly hit him, removing him from the game with a sore neck. Jean Perron, the Montreal coach, said that ''there are ways to bother a goaltender without trying to rip his head off.'' Lapointe said that ''Hayward was out of his net, and that's what happens.''

title: Nissan Raises Prices
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation said today that it had raised the suggested retail price of its cars and light trucks by an average of 1.9 percent, or $224 a vehicle, effective immediately. The company attributed the increase to the depreciation of the dollar against the yen. The price increase will not apply to its standard Sentra model or it Pulsar NX model, the company said.

title: BELL ATLANTIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Promise of Liberty Scholarships
description: One intriguing proposal by Governor Cuomo of New York for the Decade of the Child is Liberty Scholarships. Combined with existing grants, they would guarantee four years of funding for poor high school graduates admitted to a college or university in New York; 25,000 students a year might qualify.

title: PREMARK INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $36.4 million pretax charge relating to asset writedowns and warranty provisions for the company's Dartco commercial plastics operation which is expected to be sold in 1988. c-Net loss and the full-year results include after-tax charges of $159.1 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Jets 3, Capitals 2: Dale Hawerchuk and Iain Duncan scored second-period goals to lift Winnipeg to victory at Landover, Md. last night. Hawerchuck snapped a 1-1 tie with an unassisted goal at 10:04 of the period. Duncan made it 3-1 when he knocked in a rebound from out of the air for his 14th goal of the season six minutes later.(AP) Nordiques 5, Kings 3: Peter Stastny scored three goals as the Nordiques won at Quebec. Guy Lapointe and Alain Chainey guided the Nordiques in place of coach Ron Lapointe, out for the first game of a five-game suspension. Stastny, who has a team-leading 34 goals, delivered his second three-goal performance of the season.(AP) Blackhawks 6, Red Wings 4: Steve Larmer had two goals and an assist as the Blackhawks won at Detroit. Larmer scored a goal in each of the first and second periods, for his 21st and 22d goals, and added an assist on Denis Savard's third-period goal to give the Blackhawks a 5-3 lead.(AP) Blues 7, Canucks 6: Tony McKegney scored a pair of goals at St. Louis to lead the Blues to their third straight victory over the Canucks. Randy Boyd and Jim Sandlak each had two goals for Vancouver, which has lost four games in a row.(AP) N.B.A. Celtics 102, Hawks 97: Robert Parish keyed a 10-0 Boston surge in the final two minutes to power the Celtics to victory, snapping the Hawks' home-court winning streak at 16 games. Dominique Wilkins scored 38 points for the Hawks and Kevin McHale led the Atlantic Division-leading Celtics with 21 points. Danny Ainge's streak of hitting at least one 3-point goal in a game ended at 23 consecutive games. He missed on five attempts.(AP) Rockets 124, Clippers 104: Akeem Olajuwon scored 22 points and grabbed 10 rebounds at Houston, leading the rout of Los Angeles. Michael Cage of the Clippers, the No. 2 rebounder in the league this season, was held to 7 rebounds and 13 points.(AP) Pacers 97, Bulls 93: Chuck Person sank two free throws with seven seconds left to ensure Indiana's home victory. The Bulls have lost nine straight road games. Person paced Indiana with 19 points.(AP) Tennis Americans Win Early Matches: Top seeded Eliot Teltscher and third-seeded Lawson Duncan of the United States won their opening-round matches yesterday in the $130,000 Nabisco Grand Prix tennis tournament at Sao Paulo, Brazil. Teltscher defeated Ivan Kley of Brazil, 7-5, 6-2, and Duncan beat Alexandre Hocevar, another Brazilian, 6-3, 6-1.(AP) Indoor Lacrosse Saints 25, Wave 15: Scoring 11 straight goals in the second half, the New Jersey Saints (3-0) broke a 13-13 tie and went on to win last night at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The total of 40 goals was a new standard for the four-team Major Indoor Lacrosse League, now in its second season.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $520,000, or 8 cents a share, due from the capitalization of software costs.

title: Iowa to Keep Its Caucuses
description: The leader of the Iowa House of Representatives today rejected a proposal to replace the state's precinct caucuses with a primary election. The caucuses, to be held Feb. 8, are the first major nominating contest in the 1988 Presidential race.

title: When One Ambush Meets Another
description: On the air, the dramatic television confrontation between Vice President Bush and the CBS News anchor Dan Rather seemed a spontaneous and unexpected collision of tempers. But the event that sent the television world into an uproar was, in fact, a result of weeks of backstage political moves and countermoves, with CBS News and the Bush camp each carefully plotting ways to surprise the other side.

title: Bonds Drop After 4-Session Rise
description: Treasury bond prices declined nearly a point yesterday as traders and investors waited for more information about the economy and the Treasury's announcement today on its borrowing needs.

title: Anti-Discrimination Measure Taken Up on the Senate Floor
description: The Senate began debate today on an anti-discrimination bill that was described by its backers as one of the most significant pieces of civil rights legislation to come before Congress in several years.

title: BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods include sales of Williams Gold acquired December 1986.

title: KEY RATES
SOUTHWESTERN BELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BABBITT REVIEWING IOWA DEAL
description: Bruce Babbitt's Presidential campaign said Monday that it would send $10,000 to the Iowa Democratic Party after questions were raised about whether the campaign broke the law in the way it obtained a list of caucus participants from the party.

title: Sandinistas to Permit New Radio News Programs
description: The Sandinista Government announced tonight that it was authorizing new radio news programs, including several that were suspended under a state of emergency six years ago.

title: METS SIGN HOWARD JOHNSON
description: The Mets avoided an arbitration contest yesterday when they agreed to pay Howard Johnson more than twice his 1987 salary for this year.

title: Polenta: The Cornmeal Mush With a Little Italian Accent
description: A PERSON could be forgiven for thinking that polenta, the Italian version of cornmeal mush, has just become a hot new item for American food lovers. A person would be wrong.

title: Coffeyville, Kan.
description: ON a farm 20 miles east of Coffeyville in southeastern Kansas, the Eck family is reviving the tradition of sorghum making. Once a staple, this dark golden syrup used to be the heartland's answer to Vermont maple syrup.

title: Our Ambivalence About Blacks in Sports
description: LEAD: Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder's injudicious remarks and dismissal by CBS are the latest indications of the ambivalence many Americans feel about the increasing dominance of major professional sports by black athletes.

title: Dance: The Limon Company
description: THE Limon Dance Company opened a two-week season last night with a beautifully danced performance of ''There Is a Time,'' truly one of the classics that Jose Limon contributed to the modern-dance heritage.

title: Wickes Lumber Buyer Still Sought
description: The Wickes Companies said a management group that had tried to buy its lumber business had been unable to arrange financing. Instead, the company said it had turned over to its investment banker the names of several parties that had expressed interest in buying the unit.

title: Crazy Eddie Tells Of Investigation
description: Crazy Eddie Inc. disclosed today that members of its former management were under investigation for possible violations of Federal securities laws, including those prohibiting insider trading.

title: The Dan & George Show
description: Xerxes, King of Persia, thought he could trap the Greek fleet off Salamis. The Greeks, directed by Themistocles, shrewdly fostered that Persian belief, and then sprang a trap of their own, concentrating their forces to ambush the attackers.

title: Healing on Wheels: Treating Welfare Children
description: Dr. Irwin Redlener whispered first in one ear and then in the other: ''What's your name? Where do you live?''

title: Report Shows 12% Rise in Anti-Semitic Incidents
description: Anti-Semitic incidents in the United States increased 12 percent in 1987, reversing a five-year downward trend, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported yesterday.

title: Bacon the Old-Fashioned Way
description: IF you think of bacon as sliced strips of meat sealed in plastic, sample some of the varieties sold in the German and Hungarian butcher shops along Second Avenue on the Upper East Side.

title: Drexel Sees No Quick Resolution
