description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment house that for more than a year has been the subject of two extensive Federal investigations, said yesterday that it did not expect any issues arising from those investigations to be resolved for several months.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said a series of non- recurring events substantially reduced 1987 earnings, including the write-off of the company's $49 million investment in the FSLIC secondary reserve, a one-time higher federal tax rate and an after-tax loss on the sale of the company's insurance and leasing subsidiaries. The company also said it has elected to implement retroactively the recently issued FASB standard on income tax accounting. This change lowered previously reported fourth quarter and annual 1986 earnings by $20.2 million.

title: BORDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Travers J. Bell Jr., 46, Founder Of Only Black Firm on Exchange
description: Travers J. Bell Jr., the founder and owner of the only black-owned member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, died Monday, apparently from a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan. He was 46 years old.

title: Florida Considering Locking Up Some Carriers of the AIDS Virus
description: Florida is considering establishing special lockup wards for AIDS virus carriers who persist in endangering others despite counseling and warnings.

title: Chairwoman Named for Fresh Air Fund
description: The Fresh Air Fund has announced the election of Mrs. Donald E. Newhouse, a board member for five years, as chairwoman. Mrs. Newhouse is also a trustee of the New York Public Library, the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Temple Emanu-El and the National Dance Institute.

title: Excess of Centralization Stands in India's Way
description: To the Editor:

title: VARIAN ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Includes restructuring charges of $22.8 million for a cost reduction effort that will result in consolidation of two divisions and discontinuation of a product line in the semiconductor equipment group, as well as other actions being undertaken as part of a company-wide cost reduction effort. c-Net income and includes a gain on the sale of a subsidiary of $500,000 and a royalty agreement advance settlement of $1.9 million.

title: Man to Lead Irish Parade
description: When New York's Irish stage their annual march up Fifth Avenue on St. Patrick's Day, the parade will be led by a man - for the 226th consecutive time.

title: FEDDERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,167,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,356,000, or 40 cents a share, for the year. c-Included tax credits of $754,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,452,000, or 19 cents a share, for the year. The year-ago results restated to reflect spun-off operations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about legislative action in Albany inaccurately described an education bill passed on Monday by the New York State Assembly. The bill makes several revisions in elections to New York City community school boards, including a prohibition on board membership by employees of the school system.

title: SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses of $1,834,000 and $1,500,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, on real estate investments. The quarter also includes securities losses of $2,222,000, and the year includes securities gains of $44,046,000 as well as a tax credit of $21.6 million, or 32 cents a share. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $187,000 and $4,732,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; securities gains of $14,258,000 and $71,771,000 for the same periods, respectively; and also includes losses of $5,693,000 and $5,580,000 for the same periods respectively, on real estate investments.

title: PRIMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring charges of $18 million for the quarter, and for the year includes nonrecurring credits of $15.8 million. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2 million and $47.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and also includes nonrecurring credits of $15.8 million and $45.1 million for the same periods, respectively.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The loss reflected several factors, notably a previously announced $400 million special provision for loan losses, made in the second quarter of 1987, plus an additional $200 million special provision made in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: Duguay Goes to Minors
description: Ron Duguay, who has spent 11 seasons with three teams in the National Hockey League, will finally get to play in the minor leagues. The lower back ailment that has kept Duguay, 30, from playing with the Rangers for the last two weeks has improved and yesterday the team sent the forward to the Colorado farm club in the International Hockey League for conditioning. Duguay was selected by the Rangers in the 1977 amateur draft after four seasons of junior hockey and moved into their lineup that fall. After being traded to Detroit in 1983 and Pittsburgh in 1985, the Rangers reacquired him a year ago and he scored 21 points in 34 games. This season, with his back problems, Duguay has scored only 4 times and has 4 assists in 41 games. Before this season, Duguay had not missed a game because of injury in five years.been a high school

title: PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its 1986 results were restated to reflect compliance with Financial Accounting Standards Board pronouncements. It said retroactive to 1986 it has written off $368.9 million of Limerick Unit no. 1 costs which were disallowed by the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission in its June 1986 electric rate order and $94.4 million associated with its phase-in rate increase approved by the PUC in the same order. It said these retroactive writeoffs reduced 1986 earnings per share by $1.59.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Seattle
description: LEAD: WHEN Gwenyth and Theo Caldwell took early retirement 10 years ago - she from the restaurant business, he from housing construction - and moved to a farm outside Goldendale, Wash., near the Columbia River, they thought they would try breeding sheep. Mrs. Caldwell had grown up among sheep in Sudbury, Mass., where her father had been something of a gentleman farmer, much like his father before him.

title: Dow Falls 25.86 as Volume Slackens
description: LEAD: Stock prices sagged yesterday, as trading volume returned to the slower pace that has recently been the norm.

title: And in This Corner . . .
description: Negotiations for a Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks fight have taken a new turn. Shelly Finkel, a fight manager and close friend of Tyson's co-manager, Jim Jacobs, has entered the acrimonious negotiations in an attempt to smooth out the differences between the Tyson and Spinks camps. Talks broke off over the weekend in Atlantic City, ostensibly because of differences on the money to be paid to the fighters. However, there have also been strong personality clashes between Spinks's promoter, Butch Lewis, and Bill Cayton, who is co-manager with Jacobs of Tyson. Finkel spoke Monday to Jacobs and Cayton, and asked whether they would mind if he spoke with Milt Chwasky, the attorney for Lewis. They agreed, and Finkel and Chwasky met Monday. ''We're hopeful,'' said Finkel, ''something will happen with the fight this week. I'm optimistic. Look, the reality is that it's the best thing for both fighters; it's the most money for both fighters. I point-blank asked both sides, 'Do you want the fight to happen?' '' Finkel said the responses were affirmative. Finkel has a stake in the negotiations - he could wind up being in charge of the closed-circuit operation for the lucrative bout. Cayton has also entered discussions with promoters of Frank Bruno, who would replace Spinks in a June bout if a Tyson-Spinks match is not made.

title: UNITED STATES SURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,666,000 and $3,239,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Death Toll at Least 34 in Mexico Mine Fire
description: Thirty-four miners were killed in a fire in a coal mine in northern Mexico and 10 others are still trapped about 400 feet underground, a local official said today.

title: Hollings Defends His Sponsorship Of Legislation Affecting Murdoch
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings took to the floor of the Senate today to defend his role in passing legislation that could force Rupert Murdoch to sell The New York Post, insisting that he had not tried to sneak it past his Senate colleagues or the public.

title: Hynes Sees No Charges For Holtzman
description: A special New York State prosecutor said yesterday that there were no grounds to bring criminal charges against Brooklyn District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman or any of her prosecutors concerning a dispute over whether a complainant was mistreated at a sexual misconduct trial.

title: WASHINGTON WATER POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $20,838,000 from accrual of unbilled revenue and a loss of $51,212,000 from a provision for abandonments and disallowances of plant costs.

title: JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included a reduction and depreciation of $768,000 for the quarter and $1,536,000 for the 6 months from a change in estimates of service lives of restaurant buildings and leasehold improvements; the 6 months also included a charge of $1 million for a litigation settlement. c-Included additional net earnings equal to about 2 cents a share as a result of 184 days of operation, against 182 days in the latest 6 months.

title: Letter on Wedtech Bid Described at Nofziger Trial WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -
description: A letter about the Wedtech Corporation's proposed military contract was drafted for Lyn C. Nofziger's signature and delivered to a senior White House aide, a witness testified today at the trial of the former Presidential adviser on charges of violating the ethics law.

title: Martell Shifts Support To Grand Met's Offer
description: Directors of Martell & Compagnie, the renowned 273-year-old cognac house, announced today that they would support a takeover offer made by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British hotel and spirits group.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 11:30 A.M. on the situation in occupied territories. General Assembly PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR SPECIAL SESSION OF ASSEMBLY DEVOTED TO DISARMAMENT - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M COMMITTEE ON DRAFTING CONVENTION AGAINST RECRUITMENT, USE, FINANCING AND TRAINING OF MERCENARIES - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COUNCIL FOR NAMIBIA - 3 P.M.

title: TRINOVA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a net restructuring charge of $9.7 million and $30.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a one-time net gain of $85 million from the sale of certain businesses.

title: Vietnam to Return Remains
description: Vietnam intends to turn over to the United States the remains of five Americans missing in the Vietnam War and has information about 18 other missing Americans, the State Department said today. The department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said Vietnam made its pledge in a three-day meeting of Vietnamese Government representatives and United States experts that ended Monday in Hanoi. About 1,700 Americans are missing in Vietnam.

title: SHEARSON LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDNGS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago periods' share earnings are not reported because the shares were owned by American Express Co. Shearson said the adoption of a rule on accounting for income taxes increased the latest fourth quarter and year nets by $2.5 million and $10 million, respectively. It said the adoption added $7.5 million and $30 million, respectively, to the 1986 fourth quarter and full year.

title: Article 249588 -- No Title
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that it would pay stockholders a special dividend of $30 a share, or $4.7 billion in cash and securities, starting in three weeks.

title: Tennis Dispute Is Unresolved
description: The decision by the International Tennis Federation not to require players to play in South Africa did not resolve the issue but only inflamed emotions, said an adviser to the African nations that oppose professional tennis's continued recognition of South Africa.

title: TV Review; Zeffirelli's Lavish 'Turandot' at the Met Opera
description: NOW it can be seen by those not lucky enough to get into the theater. The Franco Zeffirelli production of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' ridiculed by many critics but cheered by audiences who made it one of New York's hottest tickets, is being telecast at 8 o'clock this evening on Channel 13. Inasmuch as none of this season's broadcasts will be live, the name of the public-television series has been quietly changed from ''Live at the Met'' to ''The Metropolitan Opera Presents.'' This recording of ''Turandot'' was taped on April 4 last year; it is sung in Italian with English subtitles.

title: Reading Test May Get an F
description: Officials of a federally financed student testing program that bills itself as ''the nation's report card'' are concerned that the program and not the pupils failed on the latest round of reading examinations.

title: Salvador Releasing 3 in Killing of 6 Americans
description: A military appeals court has ruled that three suspects charged in the 1985 killings of six Americans should be freed under a Government amnesty, officials said today.

title: Federated Sues in Ohio To Block Campeau Bid
description: Federated Department Stores, in its first countermove against a hostile takeover offer, filed suit yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, seeking to block the Campeau Corporation's tender offer.

title: Rare Victory By Nicaragua On Airdrops
description: When a ball of fire lit up the night sky over the Cerro de Lomas mountains Saturday, the Sandinista Government had every reason to be pleased. Its forces had shot down a contra resupply plane, a rare event in the seven-year-old Nicaraguan war.

title: Bridge: Has the Hideous Hog Made A Return as the Club Expert?
description: For the thousands of enthusiasts around the world who feared that the death of Victor Mollo last year meant the end of his Griffins Club and the Hideous Hog, there is a small silver lining.

title: TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
USX Reports a Loss of $14 Million
description: The USX Corporation today reported a fourth-quarter loss of $14 million, a reflection of weakness in crude oil prices.

title: EUROPEAN AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The losses for the latest periods resulted from a charge to earnings of $140 million comprising a special provision of $128 million for possible loan losses related to loans to lesser developed countries and a writeoff of an equity investment in an affiliated company. The loan loss provision was $159 million for the full year 1987, compared with $44.9 million in 1986.

title: About New York; Scotland's Poet Hailed With Kilt And Tex-Mex
description: Monday, as snowflakes fat as Easter chicks flew out of the evening sky, an old fellow in need of a restorative popped into a place on West 12th Street just in time to catch the act of a man in a kilt who caressed a bagpipe and blew the bar away. ''It seems to come earlier every year,'' the serious drinker said, ordering his own brand of antifreeze. ''I guess I should have worn green.''

title: Gibbs Sends Spies in Motion
description: To his players' amusement and the consternation of would-be spies, Coach Joe Gibbs has ordered the Redskins to switch uniform numbers every day while practicing for Super Bowl XXII.

title: G.A.O. Says Computer Jams Added to Stock Panic
description: Repeated breakdowns of computerized trading systems on the New York Stock Exchange aggravated the selling panic on Oct. 19 and were far more extensive than previously known, according to a report released today by the General Accounting Office.

title: CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $91 million as a result of settlements reached in litigation filed by the owners of the Zimmer plant in 1984 against General Electric Co. and Sargent & Lundy Engineers. The company said the writeoffs involved amounts previously disallowed for rate-making purposes that had been deferred pending the results of the litigation for the quarter, and the year includes cumulative effect of accrual of unbilled reserves resulted in an increase of $16.8 million, or 37 cents a share. c-Net income The company said the latest fourth quarter and year includes gains from an accounting change of $8.8 million, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and $18 million, or 40 cents a share, for the year.

title: In Boston, Pilgrims' Food (With a Touch of Paris)
description: MOST serious students of the American culinary scene still think of New England cooking - the boiled dinners, codfish cakes and baked beans - as quaint at best, and as heavy, tasteless and overcooked at worst. Even many Bostonians don't have a high opinion of the food with which they are inextricably linked.

title: Poachers Lurk at Hutton's Door
description: In 1981, when Sears, Roebuck & Company bought Dean Witter Reynolds, other brokerage firms gleefully lured away some of the firm's finest talent.

title: CONSOLIDATED EDISON CO OF NY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Gulfshore Publishing Names Chief Executive
description: G. Robert Griswold, McGraw-Hill 25-year man and former publisher of Architectural Digest, will be moving to Naples, Fla., to become president and chief executive of the Gulfshore Publishing Company.

title: Soviet Panels Reviewing Treaty
description: The Soviet Union plans an extensive public examination of the treaty eliminating land-based intermediate-range missiles and may amend the pact before it is formally ratified, Soviet officials said today.

title: Life in the 30's
description: MY friend's voice was as plaintive as a bird's song at night. ''Do you know what I really want to do?'' she asked.

title: New Chief at Pan Am Takes Control Quickly
description: Last year was not an easy one for Thomas G. Plaskett, the new chairman, chief executive and president of the Pan Am Corporation.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; Junk Food That's Lean And Healthy?
description: THE strategic thinkers at food companies have long coveted the potentially enormous markets that would be created if a low-cholesterol, low-calorie fat substitute could be developed for use in such things as ice cream, french fries, chocolate doughnuts and potato chips.

title: After Opening at Majestic, the Gala at the Beacon
description: Last night, the Majestic wasn't the only theater to have the logo of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' on its marquee. The mask also appeared at the Beacon Theater for the show's opening night party given by Cameron Mackintosh and the Really Useful Theater Company, the producers.

title: Our Prankster G-Men
description: The latest F.B.I. horror story is about the pranks white agents in Omaha played on Donald Rochon, the only black agent in the office.

title: German-Speaking Alliance Is but a Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Talk
description: IN front of me as I write is a small menu card, about the size of a postcard, dated Oct. 4, 1973.

title: Panel Investigates Poughkeepsie Election Spending
description: Holding its first hearings designed to expose political and governmental scandals, the New York State Commission on Government Integrity today heard witnesses describe how up to $776,967 was funneled through various Republican committees and Democratic and Republican political consultants to influence an election and win approval of a shopping mall in Poughkeepsie.

title: Market Restraints Can Curb Some High Rollers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Indicts Rockwell On Billing
description: A Federal indictment unsealed here today charged the Rockwell International Corporation with double-billing the Air Force for $450,000 on contracts to build a navigational satellite system in 1982.

title: Can Scholarship Plan Stem the Dropout Rate?
description: Is the promise of money to attend college enough to keep students from becoming high school dropouts? And if so, will it also be enough to spur them to aim for college?

title: Ex-Head of Bar Group Fatally Shoots Himself
description: A former president of the Westchester County Bar Association, stricken with cancer and a heart condition, shot and killed himself Monday while on the telephone with his doctor, the authorities said.

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Legislative Slowness
description: To the Editor:

title: April Retirement Is Set For Chairman of Centel
description: Robert P. Reuss, one of the telephone executives who moved early and fast to diversify at the onset of deregulation, is retiring as chairman of the Centel Corporation, effective April 1.

title: One More Time: The Reagan Hymn
description: If ours were a parliamentary system, the Reagan Government would have fallen 14 months ago. When the Democrats recaptured the Senate in 1986, it reflected a surprising loss of confidence. Then, almost immediately, came the Iran-contra bombshells. President Reagan's popularity sank like a stone, from 67 percent to 46 percent in a month, and it's barely more than that today.

title: FIREMAN'S FUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $61,596,000 on pension plan termination. The company said that operating earnings for the fourth quarter of 1987 included $16 million of tax benefits and an $11 million reduction in the alternative minimum tax plus a one- time charge of $12 million associated with Fireman's Fund withdrawal from Massachusetts. The company also said net investment income for the latest quarter and year were $119 million and $448 million, respectively, compared with the year-ago quarter of $112 million and $457 million for the year.

title: Study Finds Barrage of Sex on TV
description: Americans are bombarded by sexual messages on network television but are hardly ever reminded of the results of sex, according to a study conducted for the Planned Parenthood Federation of America and made public yesterday.

title: HEART ATTACK RISK FOUND TO BE CUT BY TAKING ASPIRIN
description: A major nationwide study shows that a single aspirin tablet every other day can sharply reduce a man's risk of heart attack and death from heart attack.

title: 'Piffling Niceties'
description: To The Living Section:

title: Lorenzo J. Greene, 88, Black History Scholar
description: Lorenzo J. Greene, a retired professor at Lincoln University professor who was an authority on the history of blacks in America, died Sunday. He was 88.

title: Paradise Valley Journal; Town Hires Robot to Curb Speeders
description: Howard Schwartz, a Maricopa County deputy attorney, was driving his Corvette along a cactus-lined street of this Phoenix suburb recently when he saw a burst of light. A few days later he received a notice in the mail from the City of Paradise Valley charging him with speeding and summoning him to traffic court.

title: Texas Bank Alters Plan To Thwart Shareholder
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that it had altered the legal structure of its proposed $1.5 billion Federal bailout plan to prevent a disgruntled shareholder from blocking the transaction.

title: Advertising; M&M Mars Account to 2 Agencies
description: M&M Mars Inc., whose account melted in the hands of the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, in December, has decided to give the business to Backer Spielvogel Bates in New York and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in St. Louis and New York.

title: Navajos Suing U.S. to Block Arizona Relocation of 6,000
description: Representatives of 45 Navajo Indians filed a lawsuit today against the Federal Government to block the relocation of approximately 6,000 Navajos from part of a reservation in northern Arizona.

title: CHEVRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a special $316 million writeoff for certain oil and gas assets.

title: Stage: 'Phantom of the Opera'
description: IT may be possible to have a terrible time at ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' but you'll have to work at it. Only a terminal prig would let the avalanche of pre-opening publicity poison his enjoyment of this show, which usually wants nothing more than to shower the audience with fantasy and fun, and which often succeeds, at any price.

title: Shultz to Meet 2 Prominent Palestinians on Unrest
description: The State Department announced today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz had agreed to meet Wednesday with two leading Palestinians, one from East Jerusalem and the other from the Gaza Strip, to hear firsthand accounts of the recent clashes between Arab demonstrators and Israeli troops.

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods included securities losses of $30.7 million for the quarter and $23.8 million for the year. The year-ago periods included securities gains of $2.9 million for the quarter and $18.8 million for the year. All financial data for 1986 has been restated to include NTC Corp., which was acquired in July 1987 and which has been accounted for using the pooling of interests method.

title: Nutrition Doesn't Sell
description: To The Living Section:

title: BRUNO'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in November.

title: Reader's Digest Buys Magazine
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. announced that it had bought 50 Plus, a monthly magazine with a circulation of 500,000, from the Whitney Communications Company. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Earlier this month, Reader's Digest acquired The Family Handyman, and in December 1986 it bought Travel-Holiday, its first purchase of another American magazine.

title: A Winning Black Doll
description: To The Living Section:

title: Colleen Moore, Ultimate Flapper Of the Silent Screen, Is Dead at 87
description: Colleen Moore, the star of the silent screen who personified the flapper her ranch near Paso Robles, Calif. She was 87 years old.

title: Calcium Tablets Are Not All Created Equal
description: IT may come as a shock to those who have been diligently taking calcium pills to find that they may be wasting their money.

title: Cummings, Cooper Fined
description: Seven members of the Knicks and eight Los Angeles Lakers were fined a total of $16,750 yesterday by Rod Thorn, the National Basketball Association's vice president of operations, as a result of last Friday's fourth-quarter fight during the Lakers' 113-112 home victory.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The October crash was a crisis that nearly became a disaster. We will probably never know how close we came to the disaster.'' - Charles A. Bowsher, Comptroller General. [ A1:2. ]

title: Koch, Lobbying Albany, Lectures the Legislators
description: In characteristically confrontational style, Mayor Koch attacked New York City's state legislators today as he issued a plea for more state aid to the city.

title: SUN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $15 million after-tax charge related to a provision for employee terminations. c-Reflects a $40 million after-tax gain from the sale of its industrial products distribution business and a $24 million after-tax charge for a provision for employee terminations and writedown of certain coal assets.

title: ORANGE & ROCKLAND UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DELUXE CHECK PRINTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After non-recurring gains of $8,350,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $16 million, or 19 cents a share, for the year, from the reduction of capital gains taxes accrued in the third quarter on the sale of the company's investment in Data Card Corp.

title: F.B.I. Asked to Check Contributions to Hart
description: United States Attorney Robert Bonner says he has asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to look into allegations of improper contributions by a producer of home videotapes to Gary Hart's Presidential campaigns.

title: Future Food: A Look at Eating in the Year 2000
description: LEAD: THE turn of the century is only 12 years away, hardly longer than it takes to brush away the last traces of a caramel apple from your teeth. What will Americans eat when the year 2000 comes, and why?

title: SANFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Cargo Companies Accused of Illegal Flights
description: Two overnight cargo-delivery companies, involved in four fatal plane crashes in the last five years, were accused by the Federal Government yesterday of operating thousands of illegal cargo flights since 1983.

title: Concert: Jazz and Classics Of Early in the Century
description: THIS year's Focus festival of contemporary music at the Juilliard School is devoted to ''Crosscurrents: Classical Music and the American Popular Tradition.'' Joel Sachs, the organizer, has always been good at programming, but his titles and subtitles are getting out of hand.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1988
description: International A2-10

title: MORGAN STANLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $75 million underwriting loss on British Petroleum, a contraction in the flow of securities offerings, and the postponement of certain financial advisory assignments.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN ENERGY & PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and attributed primarily to a $321,994,000 non-cash first quarter writedown of the partnership's oil and gas-related assets. The share earnings are in units.

title: U.S. Officials Say Haiti Election Will Not Lead to Aid Resumption
description: The election of Leslie F. Manigat as Haiti's President will not affect the cutoff of most United States aid to that country, Administration officials say.

title: Revere Copper
description: The board of Revere Copper and Brass Inc. announced that the company would be offered for sale. Revere Copper's businesses include Revere Ware Inc., which manufactures home cookware and related items. The board gave no reason for the sale in its brief announcement. It said Mor-gan Stanley & Company had been re-tained to act as its financial adivsor.

title: Reagan Agenda: Taking New Tack
description: The Reagan Administration took office in 1981 with three goals for education: abolishing the newly formed Department of Education, obtaining a constitutional amendment to permit organized prayer in public schools and obtaining legislation to offer tuition tax credits to parents of pupils in private and parochial schools.

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Ballet, Second Home Helps Budget
description: Two homes may be better than one, at least where ballet companies are concerned. Several American companies now call two cities home, and people involved in these projects have explained in recent interviews how such ventures work.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Candy Maldonado, one of three San Francisco Giants who filed for salary abritration, signed a two-year contract with the club worth $1.65 million. The outfielder made $415,000 last season. The Giants also added Phil Garner, who split last season between Houston and Los Angeles before becoming a free agent. He agreed to a one-year contract. ''Phil Garner is the veteran infielder we've been looking for,'' said Al Rosen, president of the Giants. ''He can play any position and he'll be a valuable asset to our bench.'' . . . The United States Olympic Committee officially accepted the resignation of Harvey Schiller and named Baaron Pittenger to replace him as executive director.

title: Who Was Unfair on the Air?
description: Who set up whom in the now infamous CBS Evening News shootout between Vice President Bush and Dan Rather Monday night? Did the anchorman unfairly surprise the Republican front-runner with hostile questions about the Iran-contra scandal? Or did Mr. Bush, looking for ways to show that he's no wimp, walk in eager to show muscle and show up the media?

title: Morgan Stanley Net Drops 46%
description: In a reflection of last fall's turbulent financial conditions, the Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income dropped 46 percent.

title: QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $58,000,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, and for the year includes a gain of $58.2 million.

title: U S WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STRATUS COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Stage: Robert Moresco's 'Half Deserted Streets'
description: SET on the mean streets of Hell's Kitchen, Robert Moresco's ''Half Deserted Streets'' belongs to a ''kitchen sink'' school of drama that has become so familiar it is almost incapable of delivering any surprises. Among many other ingredients from the past, this version of the recipe calls for a smidgen of ''Dead End,'' a teaspoon of ''On the Waterfont,'' a dollop of ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear,'' and a dash of ''A View From the Bridge.''

title: Helms Criticizes Arms Negotiators On Issue of Warhead Destruction
description: Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative North Carolina Republican, stepped up his attacks on the new missile treaty today by assailing American negotiators for concluding an accord that does not require destruction of missile warheads.

title: INDEPENDENCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
USX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest fourth quarter loss was significantly impacted by a non-cash charge of $96 million to increase the market valuation reserve applicable to Marathon's crude oil inventory; without this charge, net income would have been $82 million. Operating income in 1987 included a $66 million favorable remeasurement of the restructuring provision taken in the fourth quarter of 1986; the restructuring provision decreased operating income by $1,025,000,000 in 1986.

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $1,400,000 gain from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Includes losses of $79,600,000 and $89,900,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Forgiveness for Parents
description: To The Living Section:

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN RESOURCE PARTERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1986 results include only the period from June 27, 1986 through Dec. 31, 1986. The shares outstanding are in units.

title: Jackson Assists In Homecoming
description: The Knicks were at home last night, so they won. The Nets were on the road, so they lost.

title: Guessing Game
description: Forecasting population trends can be a tricky business, but the General Accounting Office has taken the leap by predicting that legal immigration into the United States will jump from 546,000 in 1986 to 605,000 in 1990.

title: DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company noted that the losses in the latest periods resulted from special provisions for credit losses. Valley National increased the reserve for credit losses by $90 million for loans to less developed countries and $45 million for domestic loans. It said recent economic and financial developments have made it necessary to add $60 million to the reserve for credit losses for the domestic portfolio in the latest fourth quarter. The 1987 provision for credit losses was $240 million and the net credit losses for the year were $155 million, resulting in a reserve of $195 million at Dec. 31. This compares with a reserve of $109 million a year earlier.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of 64 cents a share from the sale of a health technologies business.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in October.

title: Alternate-Side Parking Suspended in Snowy Weather for Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: PEOPLES WESTCHESTER SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $3,225,000 for the quarter and $9,181,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $2,872,000 for the quarter and $8,616,000 for the year.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS $36 MILLION IN AID FOR THE CONTRAS
description: The White House will ask Congress for $36.25 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels over the next several months, including $3.6 million to buy weapons, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday misidentified the advertising agency for the Parker Pen Company. It is Lowe Tucker Metcalf.

title: DIME SAVINGS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $835,000 and $5.1 million in pre-tax gains from the sale of Dime-originated loans. The bank converted to stock form in August 1986.

title: C. W. Ranson, 84, Ex-Church Council Head
description: The Rev. Charles W. Ranson, a former general secretary of the International Missionary Council, a forerunner of the World Council of Churches, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old and also had a home in Lakeville, Conn.

title: A Correction on the Budget
description: Yesterday's editorial on the 1988 budget erred in faulting Senator Domenici of New Mexico for a $50,000 appropriation to aid New Mexico's wildflower business. The sponsor was Senator Bingaman, also of New Mexico.

title: The Pop Life
description: Makeba Returns

title: Staring at Monsters
description: In a world that changes faster than the eye blinks, it is reassuring to hear from Tass, the Soviet news agency, that there's an abominable snowman, or yeti, living near the Afghanistan border. This one paid several evening visits to the camp of four researchers from Kiev, stared at them for awhile, then disappeared into a handy thicket.

title: Fordham Defeats Columbia
description: In the previous five meetings, each Fordham-Columbia matchup was decided in the final 30 seconds. Four times, the schools were separated by 2 points or less, and once they went into overtime.

title: Butch Sits One Out
description: ONE of the best basketball coaches in the business missed a game for the first time in his 1,173-game career last Saturday. We always assumed that behind the cigar smoke and the foghorn voice beat a heart that was mechanically flawless. Not true.

title: MINNESOTA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
5.5% Drop in Uncovered Nasdaq Short Sales
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the over-the-counter market's short interest position - the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Jan. 15 - fell by 10.4 million shares, or 5.5 percent, to 178.4 million shares.

title: OFFENSIVE LINES ARE READY TO SPRING
description: Before this season was half over, the Washington Redskins' offensive line had been chopped up by injuries. By the time the strike had ended, the Denver Broncos were trying to replace two offensive-line starters lost to knee injuries.

title: Lessons
description: Joe Clark won't go away. The contentious principal of Eastside High School, one of education's more arresting figures, weekly has something to say. But each time he raises his bullhorn to his mouth and calls for discipline, each time he expels another ''hoodlum'' or ''miscreant,'' as he calls those he adds to this city's flotsam, Joe Clark is making a statement that troubles many educators.

title: Article 304588 -- No Title
description: The belongings of John Connally went on the auction block for the last day today, bringing in $240,000 to increase the grand four-day total to nearly $2.7 million.

title: Freeway Overpass Collapses
description: A freeway overpass collapsed at rush hour Monday evening, blocking traffic for about five hours, the police said. Debris from the collapse of the Harbor Freeway bride caused a huge traffic jam about 10 miles south of downtown Los Angeles but no injuries were reported, Officer Charlotte Foley of the California Highway Patrol said. Damage estimates were not available.

title: Ulster Police Trial Dropped by Britain
description: The British Government has announced that it will not prosecute Northern Ireland police officers who interfered with an investigation of shootings by the police. Ireland warned today that the move would undermine security cooperation with Britain.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year net included a first- quarter non-cash, after-tax writedown of $149,578,000 of oil and gas related assets.

title: State of Union: Bewitched by Pageant
description: When the British rebuilt the bomb-damaged House of Commons after World War II, Winston Churchill insisted that it contain many fewer seats than members. This was to guarantee standing-room-only crowds for major events, just to impart an appropriate sense of drama.

title: LAST WORD ON TIPS, TORTE AND FOCACCIA
description: THIS is one of those occasional columns devoted directly to what is on readers' minds, usually expressed in questions. If the questions are of general interest, and if the pile of letters is getting too high, it's time to compile a column that provides the answers. Not all the answers are satisfactory, but we do our best.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart yesterday with an article on a national political poll misidentified a co-sponsor. It was a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Israeli Asks U.S. Critics, What Else Can We Do?
description: President Chaim Herzog challenged American Jewish critics today to suggest an alternative to Israel's tough policies against Palestinian protests.

title: Los Angeles Harbor Unit Issue
description: The Los Angeles Harbor Depart-ment if offering $138.8 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds with a maxi-mum yield of 7.60 percent for an issue due in 2018 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: About Real Estate; A Market Overhaul for Lower East Side
description: For generations the Lower East Side of Manhattan has been both a settlement community for successive waves of immigrant families and a bustling market for bargain-hunting shoppers.

title: New York City Is Seeking Underwriters' Bond Ideas
description: New York City, which sells more bonds than any other local government in the country, asked securities dealers yesterday for proposals to manage the city's financings.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an $870 million after-tax charge resulting from increases by American Express Bank Ltd. to its reserve for credit losses; a $200 million after-tax gain from implementation of new FASB rules dealing with the treatment of deferred income taxes and annual card member and loan fees; and a $142 million after-tax gain from the sale of 18 million common shares of Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. c-Net income d-Includes an after-tax $140 million gain on the sale of the company's interest in Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., which was treated as a discontinued operation. The latest quarter loss reflects the effects of securities markets difficulties on Shearson Lehman's results and also reflects an addition to credit loss reserve by American Express Bank of $350 million. The company said results include benefits of $32 million for the 1987 quarter and $4.7 million for 1986 from implementation of new FASB rules.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BOOK AND THE BROTHERHOOD.

title: PHELPS DODGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $19.1 million for the quarter, and for the year includes an extraordinary gain of $55.1 million, consisting of a tax credit and an after-tax profit of about $3 million on early extinguishment of debt. c-Includes a tax credit of $3.2 million and $19.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: A Tough Stance by the Planning Chief
description: With their recent refusal to approve the way Cityspire was built, Sylvia Deutsch and her colleagues on the New York City Planning Commission filled the popular imagination with visions of workers wielding chain saws to shave 11 feet off that mid-Manhattan skyscraper.

title: Advertising; Ritz Thrift's Long-Lived Commercial
description: IF someone ever decides that commercials can be granted landmark status our first vote would be for that single enduring spot for the Ritz Thrift Shop.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Bush Camp Feels Galvanized After Showdown With Rather
description: Vice President Bush's dramatic on-the-air shouting match with Dan Rather of CBS News won Mr. Bush a flood of praise from conservatives yesterday while his aides argued that it showed he was tough and would help his Presidential bid.

title: Canadian Imperial
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said it had agreed in principle to acquire 60 percent of the Wood Gundy Inc. securities firm for $110 million (Canadian), or about $86 million (United States). The bank said a minimum of 75 percent of that amount would be paid in Canadian Imperial stock, with the balance in cash. Under the agreement, the bank will also buy another 24 million Gundy shares for about $80 million, provide up to $100 million in subordinated loans and issue 10.8 million convertible shares to Gundy shareholders.

title: Back to High School
description: Emory Bellard, who coached football teams at Texas A&M and Mississippi State - some of them ranked among the nation's top 20 - from 1972 to 1985, was named head coach yesterday at Westfield High School in Spring, Tex., a suburb of Houston. While at Texas A&M, Bellard compiled a 48-27 record that included three bowl appearances. At Mississippi State he was 37-42 with two bowl appearances before he was dismissed. Bellard, 59, an early proponent of the wishbone offense, had been a high school coach in Texas for 15 seasons before moving into college competition.

title: C.P.A. Role Under Study
description: Congress will turn its attention again today to the system under which certified public accountants act as watchdogs over publicly held companies.

title: Singer Rejects Lower Award In His Verdict Against NBC
description: Wayne Newton has rejected a reduced $5.3 million award in his libel suit against NBC, clearing the way for a new trial to determine how much the network must pay the singer, his lawyer said Monday.

title: Carpenter Dropped As Devils' Coach
description: The Devils changed coaches today in an attempt to motivate a team that has been playing without inspiration while losing its last five games.

title: If Pupils Ran Schools: Suggestions For Ponies, Gifts and Better Food
description: ''If I were principal,'' wrote Raymond Diaz, a third grader at Public School 146 in East Harlem, ''I would care for my children. I would give them karati lessons. In this way, they could fight in a civilized way in the gym.''

title: SAN DIEGO GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend paid earlier this month.

title: Profits Up Slightly at 'Baby Bells'
description: Three telecommunications companies - U S West Inc., the Southwestern Bell Corporation and the Bell Atlantic Corporation - yesterday reported only slightly improved results for the fourth quarter of 1987 and for the year.

title: Economic Scene; The Geopolitics Of the Budget
description: IN his final State of the Union Message, President Reagan attacked the huge budget deficits that are likely to go down as his most disturbing economic legacy. The gross Federal debt has risen from $1 trillion at the end of the 1981 fiscal year to what will total $2.587 trillion by the end of the current fiscal year, according to the estimates of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: STANDARD PACIFIC LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of about $3,300,000 to value at market certain inventory of improved lots in Houston. The prior year pre-tax income included a gain of $4.8 million pre-tax profit from the sale of land.

title: South Africa's Loss
description: Anthony Bloom, perhaps the most outspoken foe of apartheid in the South African business community, is moving to England. Mr. Bloom, the 49-year-old chairman of a food processing conglomerate, says he is leaving for ''business, personal and family'' reasons. But it's no secret that the man who accused his Government of ''thuggery and authoritarianism'' in the last election has been deeply depressed by the drift of white South Africans to the right.

title: Airplanes Lead Surge In Orders for Durables
description: Orders for big-ticket durable goods, bolstered by demand for aircraft, shot up 6.7 percent in December, the largest increase in 15 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A New Nicaraguan Bill
description: New 100,000 cordoba notes, worth about $5, were put into circula-tion today. Guillermo Vega, treasurer of the Nicaraguan central bank, said the bills were sent Monday to offices of the country's banks.

title: Error at Delta: Some Fly Free
description: A Delta Air Lines computer mistakenly gave about 700 people free and reduced-price plane trips this month, and the carrier will honor the commitments, a Delta spokesman, Bill Berry, said today.

title: City Ballet Invites 2 Bolshoi Dancers
description: The New York City Ballet has invited Andris Liepa and Nina Ananiashvili, two young stars of the Bolshoi Ballet, to perform with the company several times toward the end of its current season.

title: Houston Discovers the Diner
description: Diners, the old-fashioned stainless-steel and tile kind, don't blend with the landscape here as they do on the Jersey Shore or the roadsides of Long Island. That's probably because, until recently, there were no diners to speak of in Houston. But if restaurateurs here missed out on the diner business the first time around, they seem determined to cash in now that diners are the nostalgic rage.

title: Sematech Gets Chip Processes
description: In an unusual sharing of proprietary technology, the International Business Machines Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday, as expected, that they would turn over the processes for making two chips to an industry consortium that is trying to revive the domestic semiconductor industry's competitiveness.

title: Advertising; Siperstein's Agency
description: Keyes Martin Gaby Linnett, Springfield, N.J., has been named agency for Siperstein's of Jersey City, a chain of 14 paint and wall covering stores. The ad budget is $1.5 million. The former agency was Gregory, Malara & Jacoby.

title: For the New Era, a Song of Truth From the Grave
description: Vladimir Vysotsky, the singer who growled in an impassioned voice the bottled-up loves and resentments of a silent generation here, was adopted posthumously this week as the official bard of the Gorbachev era.

title: High Court Ruling Is Sought on Special Prosecutor
description: A special prosecutor said in court papers made public today that she would urge the Supreme Court to quickly overturn a Federal appellate decision Friday that struck down the Federal law on special prosecutors.

title: Thaw on Black Ties
description: The Soviet Union's aversion to Black-tie events here appears to be crumbling, Washington socialites report.

title: Belfast, Me.
description: NORTHERN New England is famous for hearty farm breakfasts that begin with porridge and go on through eggs, bacon and muffins to end with doughnuts or pie.

title: Donations for Neediest Replace Snacks Gifts
description: Every year over the holidays, Karen and Richard LeFrak of Manhattan used to send gift-wrapped jams, pretzels, caramel popcorn or other tasty snacks to their friends.

title: 'Chaotic' State Of School Halts Inspection Visit
description: The New York State Education Department said yesterday that its officials had to stop an inspection of a high school on the West Side of Manhattan and leave because conditions at the school were so ''chaotic.''

title: Why the Fairness Doctrine Should Be Restored
description: To the Editor:

title: Leadership and Racism
description: To The Living Section:

title: Boeing Updates 2 Jets In a Shift of Strategy
description: The Boeing Company introduced new versions of its popular 737 and 747 jet airliners today that are expected to produce the bulk of its sales and earnings through the end of the century.

title: Food Notes
description: How Much Juice?

title: COMMONWEALTH ENERGY SYSEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the prior year includes a non-recurring gain of $5.1 million from the sale of an ownership interest in Algonquin Energy Inc. and $2.1 million of equity earnings from Algonquin.

title: For Jews in One U.S. Town, Israel Is Anguish and Hope
description: ''I feel guilty talking about this, because in my opinion the only people with a right to speak out are there, in Israel,'' Kenneth Hoffman said. ''But systematically beating up Arabs -this is not the idea of the Israeli army, a Jewish army.''

title: CALMAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year includes a gain of $24,922,000 from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Music: Irving Berlin Salute
description: IT has often been said that of all the great American songwriters in this century, not one had his finger more firmly on the pulse of popular taste than Irving Berlin. The truth behind that legend was amusingly demonstrated early in the opening program of the 92d Street Y's Lyrics and Lyricists series. In a slide montage of vintage sheet music, titles like ''The Beautiful Rag, ''The Dying Rag,'' ''The Whistling Rag,'' ''Ragtime Soldier Man'' and ''Ragtime Violin'' all rolled by. All happened to have been written or co-written by Mr. Berlin when the public appetite for songs with the word ''rag'' in the title seemed insatiable.

title: REGINA CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I.B.M. Introduces Computer Device
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new communications controller that allows mainframe computers to share information with personal computers on a local area network and to send data over telephone lines, both at significantly faster speeds.

title: A Solvent That May Solve an Ozone Problem
description: As part of the manufacturing process, electronics companies clean circuit boards with solvents that contain chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, which are implicated in the depletion of ozone in the upper atmosphere. Now, a small chemical company in Fernandina Beach, Fla., has developed a circuit board solvent based on natural substances, particularly the chemical terpene, that meets electronics manufacturers' solvent requirements and could replace CFC's.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-tax-deductible charge of $2,653,000 related to a proposed leveraged buyout and an after- tax charge of $993,000 related to the settlement of a lawsuit. c-Includes the reversal of investment tax credits of $1.4 million, or 4 cents a share.

title: From Here On, Reagan May Have More Power Outside U.S.
description: While President Reagan retains enormous influence in foreign affairs, his ability to control the domestic agenda has diminished considerably as he begins his final year in office, analysts in the White House and on Capitol Hill said today.

title: OHIO CASUALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Profits Scoreboard
Contemporary Music Group To Give Composers Grants
description: Meet the Composer, a New York organization devoted to contemporary music, has announced a new three-year commissioning program. With a budget of nearly $1 million, it is billed as ''the largest and most diverse commissioning program in the world,'' in the words of the organization's news release.

title: Citicorp Rates Dip
description: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.7916 percent, down from 6.82 percent last week. It also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 6.879 percent, down from 6.93 percent.

title: Bush vs. Rather: A Tonic for TV News
description: LEAD: Who sandbagged whom? That's the big question about Monday night's matchup on CBS between Vice President George Bush and Dan Rather, which became television's big story of the year, for this week at least.

title: Lutheran Minister Prodding U.S. Catholics to Lead Christian Revitalization
description: What is a Lutheran minister doing injecting himself into controversies within the Roman Catholic Church?

title: Afternoon Program Keeps Bronx Students in School
description: Three years ago, the dropout rate at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx was climbing dramatically. With 26 percent of its 3,400 students quitting school, the administration decided it had to change its approach.

title: At Age 200, Australia Makes Merry
description: Hundreds of boats filled the sparkling harbor, fighter aircraft roared overhead and huge crowds packed the rocky shoreline today to celebrate the landing here 200 years ago of the English convicts who were Australia's first white settlers.

title: What Makes Senators' Sons Run?
description: In America, they say, anybody can grow up to be President. They also say that the apple seldom falls far from the tree. In combination, the adages have a currency now because of a little-noticed though historically interesting coincidence: Three of the current crop of candidates for President are sons of United States Senators.

title: ALLEGHENY POWER SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represent total operating revenue.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Question and Answer column in Science Times on Tuesday incorrectly described Dr. J. E. Jelinek's explanation of hair loss after high fevers, pregnancy, anesthesia and other conditions. Dr. Jelinek said hair loss results when many more hairs than normal enter a resting phase.

title: 17 Times an All-Star
description: For the 17th time in his 19-year career, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar will be in the National Basketball Association All-Star Game. The 7-foot-2-inch Los Angeles Laker center was one of seven players selected in a vote by the 12 Western Conference coaches to augment the five starters chosen in a vote by the fans for the game on Feb. 7 in Chicago. Abdul-Jabbar, who has scored more than 37,000 points, has missed only two All-Star Games. He was chosen for the team in 1973, but was excused for personal reasons. The only time the 40-year-old Abdul-Jabbar was not named to the team was in 1978, after he suffered a broken hand in a fight with Kent Benson of the Milwaukee Bucks and missed 22 games. The other players named by the coaches were Steve Johnson and Clyde Drexler of the Portland Trail Blazers; Xavier McDaniel of the Seattle SuperSonics; James Worthy of the Lakers; Mark Aguirre of the Dallas Mavericks, and Alvin Robertson of the San Antonio Spurs. Johnson won't play, however. The 6-11 Portland center will have surgery today on his right thumb for a benign growth on a tendon.

title: Yale and Two Unions Reach A Tentative Contract Accord
description: Yale University and its two unions announced agreement today on a tentative contract, apparently ending the threat of a strike.

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,063,000 for the quarter, and the year includes income from discontinued operations of $1,764,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $228,000 and $1,556,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Laser Industry's Image Problem
description: WHEN the Candela Laser Corporation wants to demonstrate the pinpoint accuracy and sensitivity of its medical lasers, it shows potential customers that the laser can chip the shell off an egg without breaking the membrane underneath.

description: The San Diego Yacht Club has proposed a compromise in an effort to avoid an America's Cup regatta this summer.

title: G.E.-Martin Marietta Satellite Deal
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, announcing what is by far the largest contract yet for the nascent commercial space-launching business, said today that it had agreed to launch 15 communications satellites for the General Electric Company's Astro-Space division.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: OVER the years I have often been asked if I find it odd that certain dishes combine poultry and other meats with seafood, and my answer is always in the absolute negative. To the best of my knowledge, the blending of meats with seafood occurs in almost all cultures, East and West.

title: Carteret Bancorp's Merger Agreement
description: Home Group Inc. said that, despite its merger agreement with Carteret Bancorp, it would allow the Delaware-based savings and loan holding company to look for a new merger partner until mid-February.

description: The West Germans seemed to be busy on every diplomatic front at once last week.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Minneapolis
description: LEAD: THE September opening of D'Amico Cucina, a stylish Italian restaurant here, received almost as much fanfare as the World Series victory by the Minnesota Twins. By Jan. 1, the restaurant had been named one of the best to open last year in the Twin Cities. It is only the latest in a string of successes achieved by Richard and Larry D'Amico, who are brothers as well as president and executive chef, respectively, of D'Amico & Partners

title: U S Sprint to Cut Its Rates by 4.1%
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company, based in Kansas City, Mo., said it would lower its interstate long-distance rates an average of 4.1 percent on March 1, more than matching reductions by its two main competitors. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's long-distance leader, dropped its rates an average 3.5 percent on Jan. 1, and the MCI Communications Corporation, the No. 2 long-distance carrier, has said it will cut its rates by the same amount on March 1.

description: William F. Larkin, a lawyer and former member of the New York State Assembly, died of lung cancer Sunday at Cabrini Hospice of Cabrini Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: The Xtra Corporation said it would sell its marine cargo container operations in two separate transactions worth a total of about $180 million. The larger acquisition is by the Itel Corporation of Chicago, which will pay $130 million for 80,000 steel containers and leases on some of the containers. The Flexi-Van Corporation of Los Angeles will pay $52 million for Xtra's fleet of 17,000 marine chassis, which hold shipboard cargo containers.

description: Governor Cuomo ordered Attorney General Robert Abrams today to act as a special prosecutor in the case of a 16-year-old black girl who was found in Dutchess County two months ago, with ''KKK'' and ''Nigger'' written across her body.

description: Henry R. Kravis, a New York financial investor, has given $10 million to the Mount Sinai Medical Center to establish a women's and children's center to provide medical, psychological and social services.

title: Smooth Flow on Golden Gate
description: A mass traffic tieup that was predicted on the Golden Gate Bridge Monday failed to materialize as commuters used ferries and automobile pools and stayed late in the office in an effort to avoid delays that were expected to be caused by a strike of bus drivers. The morning rush hour was marked by a peaceful demonstration at the bridge by representatives of the 300 bus drivers of the Golden Gate Transit District.

title: Problems With the Marquis Theater
description: It is not modesty that compels the chorus dancers in ''Me and My Girl'' to wear body stockings under their costumes. It's that sometimes they can see their breath onstage and backstage at the Marquis Theater. And if they could, they'd hold their noses as they twirl, because of the stench that rises from precisely where, nobody knows.

title: Merrimack Hoping for Independent Bid
description: College hockey's Division I championship tournament will expand this season from eight to 12 teams, and at least one of the invitations will go to an independent. Merrimack hopes it will be the one.

title: Ward Seeks Aid Of Educators In Recruitment
description: New York City Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward asked college officials yesterday to join him in a new drive to recruit college-educated people who might never have thought of police work as a career.

He was rewarded with excited shrieks and screams of approval after the show, as he walked down the runway, which was lined with models wearing his flower-strewn, audacious styles.

Bilzerian has extended his $50-a-share offer for the Singer Company until next Monday amid talks with Singer's banks about the company's credit status after the $1.06 billion proposed takeover. He also said Tuesday that almost 15.7 million of the 21.1 million shares had been tendered.

title: Washington Talk: Working Profile; Don Wilson; Keeper of Vast Archives Is a Believer in Brevity
description: When Don Wilson was a freshman in graduate school, the future historian and archivist was stunned to receive a D-plus on his first midterm examination in European history. He had earned straight A's in his undergraduate studies and had filled two blue books answering the questions in the examination.

title: Tom J. Maloney, 83; Published Magazines
description: Tom Maloney, retired editor and publisher of U.S. Camera Annual, died of a heart attack Jan. 18 at his home in Cranbury, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Senate Panel Approves Judge Kennedy
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to recommend confirmation of Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court. The vote by the full Senate is likely to come next week, enabling Judge Kennedy to take his seat well in advance of the Court's return from its recess on Feb. 22.

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Super Bowl Notebook; Nattiel Will Start In Place of Johnson
description: Coach Dan Reeves of the Denver Broncos decided today that Ricky Nattiel, rather than the ailing Vance Johnson, would start at wide receiver in Super Bowl XXII on Sunday against the Washington Redskins. Reeves left no doubt that Johnson would play.

description: To the Editor:
