title: RESULTS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 106, Bullets 100: Larry Bird scored a season-high 49 points, including four consecutive free throws down the stretch, and the Celtics posted their 10th consecutive Boston Garden victory last night. Parish scored 26 points and Kevin McHale 21 as the Celtics ended Washington's four-game winning streak. Bernard King had 32 points to lead the Bullets.(AP) Pistons 103, Pacers 86: Detroit's Adrian Dantley scored 23 points and the Pistons held the visiting Pacers scoreless for more than six minutes in the fourth quarter. The cold-shooting Pacers, whose three-game winning streak ended, also went without a basket for almost six minutes of the third quarter, although they managed four free throws during that stretch. Bill Laimbeer, playing his 600th consecutive game, had 15 points and 15 rebounds.(AP) Bulls 119, 76ers 109: Michael Jordan scored 37 points, including 4 in a 6-0 overtime burst, as the Bulls snapped a nine-game road losing streak. In the overtime period, Chicago went ahead, 107-105, on a field goal by Brad Sellers, who scored 19 points. But the 76ers tied the score on Charles Barkley's driving layup. Barkley, who scored 24 points, made a field goal for Philadelphia's last points. The Bulls then ran off 6 more points to hand the Sixers their sixth consecutive loss. Mike Gminski, playing in his fourth game since being traded to Philadelphia from the Nets, scored 23 points.(AP) Cavaliers 112, Spurs 102: Tyrone Corbin scored 21 points and Ron Harper had 8 points in a 14-4 spurt down the stretch that carried Cleveland at San Antonio. Berry led the Spurs with 27 points, but only 4 in the second half. Mark Price had 19 points and Brad Daugherty 17, plus a team-high 13 rebounds, for the Cavaliers.(AP) Mavericks 121, Suns 102: Derek Harper and Mark Aguirre combined for 23 points in the fourth quarter as the Dallas Mavericks tied a club record with their fifth consecutive road victory. Dallas has won six games in a row and is 3-0 against Phoenix, which has dropped six straight games and is 2-14 against the Mavericks since March 4, 1985. Brad Davis scored a season-high 25 points for Dallas, 11 in the second period.(AP) N.H.L. Canadiens 4, Sabres 1: Claude Lemieux, who has 15 points in his last 12 games, scored twice as the Canadiens snapped the Sabres' home-winning streak at six games last night. Lemieux scored Montreal's first two goals, his 20th and 21st of the season. Christian Ruuttu, who has scored in all but two of his last 11 games, scored for Buffalo.(AP) Maple Leafs 5, Kings 2: Mike Blaisdell, who was just called up from the minors Tuesday, scored two goals as the Maple Leafs won for the first time in 15 games. The Maple Leafs had lost their six previous games to set a club record for the longest streak without a victory by going 0-11-4 since Dec. 23. (AP) Jets 4, Penguins 1: Dale Hawerchuk scored his 29th goal of the season and set up Frederick Olausson's tiebreaking goal to lead the visiting Jets. The Jets won their second road game in two nights on the start of a four-game trip. Mario Lemieux scored his 48th goal for the Penguins when his shot was deflected off Mario Marois, a Winnipeg defenseman.AP)

title: Corrections
description: The ''Paradise Valley Journal'' article yesterday, about a device that measures highway speed and photographs violators, misidentified the headquarters community of Traffic Monitoring Technologies, which holds American rights to the device. It is in Friendswood, Tex.

title: Hospitals' Medicare Profits Drop; Decline May Curb Access to Care
description: Profits earned by hospitals for the treatment of Medicare patients declined significantly in 1986-87, the Department of Health and Human Services reported today.

title: A Stealth Deal For Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation said it has been awarded a $2 billion contract for work on the advanced Stealth bomber, an unusual announcement that implied to analysts that full-scale production had begun.

title: No Way Out?
description: The reports come in day after day: Israeli soldiers going into houses in the occupied territories, pulling people out, beating them with rifle butts and two-by-fours, breaking their bones. ''Often the victims were quiet residents,'' the newspaper Haaretz said, ''not suspected in violent or illegal activity.'' But they were Palestinians.

title: If the Design Is Offbeat, the Book Is, Too
description: Aficionados of popular culture may first have noticed the rather unusual book jackets: the bowling ball with three die-cut holes, for instance, or the lush expanse of plastic grass on the cover of ''Miniature Golf'' by John Margolies.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Paris Journal; Waiting for Raymond (What's the Rush?) Barre
description: He has been waiting in the wings for seven years and now, like the tortoise in the fable of La Fontaine, he has started to lumber. Raymond Barre's quandary as he embarks on his official presidential campaign is that he is not only plodding against a hare but could also face another tortoise in the shape of President Francois Mitterrand.

title: Psychedelic-Art Show Is Reflection of Its Era
description: The exuberant one-quarter- to one-half-inch squares will almost certainly never fall into the category of art. But as cultural artifacts, the graphics currently on display at the Psychedelic Solution Gallery in Manhattan are moody evocations of their era - images of floating half-moons, flying saucers, astrological symbols, or Mickey Mouse wearing his sorcerer's cap from ''Fantasia.''

title: German Finance Official to Visit U.S.
description: With the dollar stable and their disputes of last fall apparently settled for now, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and the West German Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, will meet here next week to discuss trade, third-world debt and closer international coordination of economic policies.

title: Savings Unit Posts Big loss
description: The Financial Corporation of America, the parent of the nation's largest savings and loan institution, said today that it had lost $224.6 million in the fourth quarter after adding $235.5 million to its reserves for bad loans.

title: Joseph M. Lowry, Executive, 79
description: Joseph M. Lowry, who retired as senior vice president of the Ethyl Corporation in 1973, died Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in Richmond, Va., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Goochland, a Richmond suburb.

title: EXCEL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a dividend of $814,000 for the quarter and year from Massachusetts Mutual Savings Central Fund. Excel converted to stock form of ownership in September 1986.

title: John F. Gummere, 86, Quaker Headmaster
description: John F. Gummere, a leading Quaker educator who was a founder of the National Association of Independent Schools, died of heart failure Tuesday in Philadelphia. He was 86 years old.

title: Cabinetry Worth Fixing
description: WHAT do you do if the gooseneck ornament of your English clock snaps off during a move? Or if a piece of inlay disappears from your game table? Perhaps you want to remove those cherubs from the Victorian headboard you inherited.

title: TV Review; 'Voices and Visions' Of 13 Poets
description: THE theory goes that television, in thrall to the visual image, is a spoiler of words.

title: Nicotine Gum a Boon That the Experts Say Should Be Used More
description: More than four years after it was approved by the Food and Drug Administration for sale as a prescription drug, nicotine gum's effectiveness in helping people quit smoking has been well established in clinical trials.

title: City of Yonkers Votes to Back Housing Order
description: After a raucous five-and-a-half hour meeting in which they were branded liars, wimps and masters of deceit by their former supporters, Yonkers City Council members voted 5 to 2 early this morning to begin building low-income housing in predominantly white neighborhoods.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Critic's Notebook; The Lobbying for Literary Prizes
description: THE tribute to Toni Morrison by 48 black writers in last Sunday's New York Times Book Review does not come right out and charge that Ms. Morrison has been denied a major literary prize because of her race, but the implication is inescapable. An accompanying letter by two of the signatories, June Jordan and Houston A. Baker Jr., dispels any doubt by reminding us that James Baldwin ''never received the honor of these keystones to the canon of American literature: the National Book Award and the Pulitzer Prize: never.''

title: Am I Reading the Papers Correctly?
description: LEAD: I'm not a political activist. If anything, I'm an uninformed coward, totally convinced that a stand on any issue from subway fares to the length of women's skirts will ultimately lead me before a firing squad.

title: Soviet Rights Aides Get A New Word: Dissident
description: The official Soviet Human Rights Commission found itself playing unwilling host to one of the country's leading dissidents today at an unusual and volatile meeting with Western human-rights advocates.

title: Sale by United Technologies
description: The United Technologies Corporation has reached a definitive agreement to sell domestic operations of its Essex Group Inc. to investors who include members of Essex management and a leveraged equity fund operated by the Morgan Stanley Group Inc., the companies announced today.

title: Moving of Office Fought By Business Volunteers
description: For the last two decades, the Executive Volunteer Corps, a group of retired Manhattan executives, has helped thousands of aspiring entrepreneurs form businesses or save existing ones from bankruptcy. But last month the 21 members of the corps resigned in anger after their sponsor, a New York City agency, refused to renew the lease on the group's midtown headquarters.

title: In San Antonio, Home Restoration Is Everyone's Business
description: BARBARA HUNTER, all but bursting with civic pride, is giving an unofficial tour of restored homes in this historic town. It is an account she recites often in her role as spokeswoman for the San Antonio Conservation Society. But this time it is interrupted, briefly.

title: Battling Obscurity, Babbitt Leads With Chin
description: When Bruce Babbitt got off a plane at La Guardia Airport in New York the other day, tired and hoarse from campaigning in Iowa and New Hampshire, he looked around for the driver who was taking him to his next appearance.

title: CENTERIOR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Negotiating the Arms Treaty: Verification Issue Proved Thorny
description: On Dec. 6, two days before Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan were to sign a new missile accord in Washington, American and Soviet negotiators were still arguing in Geneva about a key treaty detail.

title: Irving Protecting Its Pension Fund
description: The board of directors of the Irving Bank Corporation has moved to make the assets of its employee pension plan invulnerable in the face of a hostile $1.08 million takeover offer by the Bank of New York Company. Under amendments to the plans approved by Irving's board on Jan. 19, the bank's surplus pension assets ''can only be used to provide for existing medical and life insurance benefits of retirees and employees eligible to retire within five years of the change of control,'' acccording to company documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Abie Grossfeld of Southern Connecticut State University has been named head coach of the United States men's gymnastics team for the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. It will be the second time in succession and the third time over all that Grossfeld will coach the team. Grossfeld, who competed in the Olympics in 1956 in Melbourne and in 1960 at Rome, was chosen by the United States Gymnastics Federation and the United States Olympic Committee's executive board. . . . Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, the former CBS sports broadcaster who was dismissed after making racial remarks about blacks in a television interview, has been released in good condition from Duke Medical Center in Durham, N.C. He had complained of chest pains. . . . The Yankees signed Dr. Stuart J. Hershon, as their new team physician yesterday. He is an orthopedic surgeon at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital and the North Shore University Hospital. He succeeds Dr. John Bonamo, who served as team physician for eight years.

title: Chief Acts to Expand At North Side Savings
description: Thomas M. O'Brien, president and chief executive of the North Side Savings Bank, a relatively small institution in the Bronx, did something that none of his predecessors did: he went out and acquired another bank.

title: What Is Needed to Promote Mideast Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: WISCONSIN ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Engineer to Get Award For Warning on Shuttle
description: An engineer who warned that it was dangerous to launch the space shuttle Challenger in cold weather only hours before the craft exploded has been named a winner of the Scientific Freedom and Responsibility Award from the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

title: Frenetic Pace in 'Serious Money'
description: When ''Serious Money'' opened downtown at the Public Theater in December, its British cast had had months of practice in working up the play's frenetic speed, quick changes and complex logistics. With each actor playing multiple characters, most of the rapid-fire dialogue overlapping, and the play's subject the complicated antics of the world's financial markets, ''Serious Money'' is not only a difficult work to stage, but also one that must move at a dizzying pace.

title: More Fund Fees Tied To Results, Not Assets
description: After paying out hundreds of millions of dollars a year to money mangers whose results have been mediocre on average, corporate pension fund executives are turning the tables.

title: Shift Likely at Shearson
description: Peter Solomon, a vice chairman of Shearson Lehman Brothers, is likely to give up his duties as co-head of the firm's investment banking division to focus on its merchant banking activities.

title: ALLIED BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Texaco Increases Estimate Of 1987 Loss to $4.9 Billion
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it would report a loss of more than $4.9 billion for 1987 as a result of its restructuring and the settlement of its legal dispute with the Pennzoil Company.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ADVERTISING;
description: Paramount Home Video is once again announcing plans to spend $10 million on advertising. That's good for business, because local video-rental outlets will order more copies if they believe the new issues will receive heavy advertising support.

title: FAMILY MUTUAL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $533,000 from a joint venture investment. c-Included a dividend from the Mutual Savings Central Fund of $1,238,000. The bank converted to stock ownership in November 1986.

title: NATIONAL BANC OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year per share figures are restated to reflect the acquisition of Chemical Bank of South Charleston in January 1987.

title: United Artists Set To Acquire Daniels
description: United Artists Communications Inc. said it intended to merge with a smaller, rival cable television company, Daniels & Associates Inc. The deal calls for Daniels' shareholders to receive $108 million in cash and $82 million in convertible preferred stock. The deal will increase United Artists' subscriber-base by 48 percent, to 1.2 million subscribers in 26 states. Both companies are based in Denver.

title: New President at Bell
description: W. Marshall May, 57 years old, has become president of Bell & Partners, a four-year-old marketing services and sales promotion firm. He started in the business with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn in 1960, but soon moved away from the general agency business. He had his own company, Merchandising and Promotion Associates, which he sold to Comart-Aniforms Associates. He was also a senior vice president-planning for Atwood-Richards, the barter company, and most recently was senior vice president and managing partner of Ted Colangelo Associates, the sales promotion subsidiary of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: WELDS DEFECTIVE IN RUPTURED TANK
description: The Ashland Oil Company tank that ruptured and spilled more than a million gallons of diesel fuel into the Monongahela River contained defective welds that were reported to the company more than a year before, according to documents made available today.

title: MARSH & MCLELLAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MICROPOLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEFENDANT GUILTY IN BOMB SMUGGLING
description: One of three Lebanese-born Canadian citizens accused of smuggling a bomb into the United States has pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here to two charges in connection with the incident.

title: 20 Soviet Scientists Visiting Nuclear Test Site in Nevada
description: Twenty Soviet scientists are studying the American nuclear testing program at the Nevada Test Site as part of a scientific exchange.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter included a $75 million charge for divesting certain businesses; a $70 million gain for the early retirement of debt; a $33 million investment tax refund; a LIFO credit of $16 million, and an additional $10 million in pension expenses as the result of an accounting change. The latest year included $130 million in tax credits, a $28 million LIFO credit and a $70 million gain from the early retirement of debt. It also included a $75 million charge from discontinued operations and a $40 million loss for an accounting change.

title: Bush Says He Lacked Details of Arms-for-Hostages Plan at Critical Meeting in Israel
description: Vice President Bush said today that at a critical meeting in Israel before the American decision was made to sell arms to Iran, he did not have enough information to realize he was discussing a swap of arms for hostages.

title: Old-Style Roses Are Tough as Well as Sweet
description: SINCE the first hybrid tea roses were bred early in this century, they have loomed ever larger in the consciousness of the American gardener as well as in the commercial horticultural economy. They appear early every spring in huge numbers at almost every neighborhood garden center, as familiar a sight as bales of peat moss or bags of fertilizer.

title: The Art in Ordinary African Objects
description: ''Suppose you had a slightly mad and creative gas station attendant,'' Susan Vogel said the other day. ''Now suppose he had a huge pile of spare tires, and he said, 'I could make something with those,' and he threw them into a big pile. Is it a work of art? If the same pile of tires is shown in front of the Whitney Museum, does it then become art?''

title: An Opening for Democracy in Panama
description: Chances grow for Panama to be rid of its corrupt strongman and move toward democracy, without much more pain. The Reagan Administration rightly seems to understand that the present military Government undermines rather than underpins Panama's stability. Even Gen. Manuel Noriega, the Panamanian dictator, seemed a few weeks ago to realize that he had to go. The task is to bring him back to that point.

title: Rock Stars of West Plan Anti-Drug Soviet Tour
description: Several Western rock stars, including David Bowie, George Harrison and Julian Lennon, have said they are to take part in a series of concerts in Moscow to campaign against drug abuse, the Moscow Communist youth daily, Moskovsky Komsomolets, reported.

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $816,000 from refinancing of long-term debt.

title: Rates Fall To Lowest Since July
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday and interest rates fell to their lowest level since July as signs accumulated that the economy is heading for a period of much slower growth.

title: Market Place; The Stock Impact Of Aspirin Report
description: THE news announcement yesterday that an aspirin every other day may sharply reduce the risk of heart attacks in men is expected to have a far bigger impact on American consumers than investors. The aspirin market is dominated by the Bristol-Myers Company, the American Home Products Corporation, and the Sterling Drug Company, enterprises so large and diversified that even a sharp increase in aspirin sales would have a modest impact at best on their bottom line.

title: Jackson to Pass the Plate at Churches Sunday
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson plans to collect contributions for his Presidential campaign on Sunday from churchgoers around the country, an idea that has aroused concern that it might violate Federal tax law.

title: NOXELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Some Gray Hairs and a Bare Foot
description: HE'S only 27 years old, but atop Ali Haji-Sheikh's stylish black mop, occasional long gray hairs betray his burden. At a quick glance, the Washington Redskins' kicker appears to have sprouted one for each of the 35 field-goal attempts he has missed in his five seasons. As he awaits a Super Bowl XXII duel with Rich Karlis, the Denver Broncos' barefooted kicker, the Sheikh has missed five of his last eight attempts. And for more than a week, Joe Gibbs, the Redskins' coach, had suggested that Jess Atkinson, who has recuperated from a dislocated ankle, might be their kicker on Sunday.

title: What Is Needed to Promote Mideast Peace; Hear the Palestinians
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Guardians; Aspirin Report Illustrates the Control of New England Journal on Data Flow
description: For weeks the results of a major new study on aspirin's ability to prevent heart disease were known by many scientists, government officials, business leaders and journalists.

title: Net at Mobil and Shell Soared in 4th Quarter
description: Aided by production and exploration gains, the Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil refiner, yesterday reported a 91.6 percent rise in its fourth-quarter net income.

title: X-Rated Computer Displays
description: The personal computer your child got for Christmas may be more educational than you think. Animated pictures of nudes, sex-related messages and files of dirty jokes are accessible to computers that have modems, devices that enable them to reach other computers by telephone.

description: The National City Corporation of Cleveland, the second-largest bank holding company in Ohio, announced yesterday that it had reached agreement to acquire the First Kentucky National Corporation of Louisville, the largest banking company in that state.

title: Corrections
description: The Home Improvement column in The Home Section last Thursday misidentified a substance used in patching wallboard. The substance - less effective than joint compound for the perimeter of a large patch - is not putty but spackling putty.

description: Doyle Graf Mabley has become agency for the Reuters USA Media Group, which sells the British news agency's services to newspapers, broadcasters and magazines. The billings could go as high as $1 million. The previous agency was Poppe Tyson.

description: New York's home health-care system, because of low pay and difficult working conditions, is having problems attracting and keeping workers, according to health and labor experts and officials of agencies that provide the care.

title: Bigotry and the F.B.I.'s Answers
description: If Donald Rochon's experience typifies that of blacks in the F.B.I., then the new Director, William Sessions, has a catastrophe on his hands. Even if it's atypical Mr. Sessions has a problem, because the handling of the Rochon case has sent all the wrong signals to his agents and to the public about the F.B.I.'s attitudes on race.

They announced yesterday they had replaced him with Tom Coughlin, who coached the Green Bay Packers' receivers the last two seasons. Coach Bill Parcells met with his assistants on Monday and told them all would be retained except Hodgson.

description: For the first time, a patient diagnosed with AIDS while in the United States has been found to be infected with a second variety of AIDS virus that was previously found mainly in West Africa.

title: Q&A
description: Q.My split-level apartment is on the top floor. Some minor roof leaks left little water spots here and there, but in January dark spots appeared over every nail in the ceiling and deep down in each wall. Since it is unlikely there is a major leak from one ceiling to another one at a different level, what could cause these dark spots and what steps must be taken before repainting?

description: West Germany said today that it would press commercial development of a train that travels without touching the ground. The Research and Technology Minister, Heinz Riesenhuber, told reporters that the Transrapid train carried passengers at 255.9 miles an hour in a test last week. Using electromagnets, it moves along an elevated track while remaining about half an inch above the rails.

title: Rangers Acquire Nilan
description: The Rangers, who have been bringing up the rear of the Patrick Division pack, will be packing some extra offensive punch when they travel to Philadelphia to take on the front-running Flyers tonight. In a deal with Montreal announced last night, the Rangers acquired Chris Nilan, a right wing who has scored 7 goals and 5 assists in 50 games with the Canadiens this season. The 29-year-old Nilan, a nine-year veteran, has averaged nine goals a season. He is also something of a scrapper, ranked fourth in the league in penalty minutes. Discussing the deal, Phil Esposito, the Rangers' general manager, said that Nilan was ''very excited'' about coming to New York and that the Ranger coach, Michel Bergeron, was ecstatic. The Rangers may not have to pay for Nilan. Under the arrangement with Montreal, the Canadiens were given the right to trade first-round picks with the Rangers in the 1989 draft.

title: Philip Morris Profits Rise
description: The Philip Morris Companies reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 28.8 percent, on a 7.8 percent gain in revenues.

description: The opposition newspaper, La Prensa, has published articles recently saying that Nicaragua is in the midst of a ''wave of repression'' that includes the use of jails ''dreadful enough to recall Treblinka and other Nazi concentration camps.''

Mubarak, in U.S., Seeks Peace Efforts
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was reported today to have appealed to Secretary of State George P. Shultz to step up American peace efforts in the Middle East during this time of clashes between Palestinian Arabs and Israeli troops.

title: Quilts: New Esthetic, New Craftsmen, New Collectors
description: SINCE the early days of the Republic the American spirit has served as a powerful tonic for the age-old craft of quilting. Here more than anywhere else in the world quilting has flourished, inspired by homespun innovation. Today that innovation is propelling quilt making into new territory.Contemporary quilt makers are transforming the craft. Their works are as far removed from what came out of the old-fashioned quilting bee as microwave oven is from the wood-burning stove. ''The contemporary quilt has a whole new esthetic to it,'' said Paul Smith, director emeritus of the American Craft Museum in Manhattan. ''In the last 10 to 15 years, there has been a lot of experimentation with the quilt format. Quilters have broken with traditional geometric patterns and materials, and have expanded the vocabulary of the traditional quilt.'' No longer interested in creating decorative covers for the bed, contemporary quilt makers are piecing and stitching fabric into visually exciting works intended to be hung on walls, like paintings. No longer bound by the patterns of traditional quilts, they are creating abstract and allegorical patterns of their own. And no longer tied to the tradition of hand stitching, they are using the sewing machine for part - and sometimes all - of the work.

title: Music: Neikrug Concerto By Cleveland Orchestra
description: THE Cleveland Orchestra opened a six-concert series in the New York area Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall (four of the concerts will be there, tonight's will be at Avery Fisher Hall, and the sixth at C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University, in Greenvale). There were only two pieces on this first program, a blockbuster preceded by a shorter New York premiere. But the premiere was the more interesting musical event of the two.

The net from continuing operations for 1987 included pretax gains of $337.5 million from the sales of shares of subsidiaries to the public; the year also reflects pretax nonrecurring charges of $47.3 million of which $20 million are non-cash charges. c-Net loss and includes income from discontinued operations of $91,000, an extraordinary credit of $3,316,000. The year-ago quarter loss from continuing operations is after a writedown of $60.1 million pretax of copper interests. d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $652,000 and a tax credit of $6,362,000. The net from continuing operations for 1986 included pre-tax gains of $43 million from the sales of shares of subsidiaries, and a pretax provision of $60.1 million for losses on properties and investments.

title: RIBI IMMUNOCHEM RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Judge Rejects Secord Plea
description: A Federal judge refused today to bar the special Iran-contra prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh, from seeking to indict Richard V. Secord while an appeals court decides whether he should be allowed to defend himself before the Iran-contra grand jury. Judge Aubrey E. Robinson Jr. of United States District Court denied the emergency motion by Mr. Secord but gave no reason for his ruling. A lawyer for Mr. Secord said the decision would be appealed. Mr. Secord and his business partner, Albert Hakim, ran Swiss-based companies that handled the United States arms sales to Iran. Some profits from the sales were funneled to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: 11 HELD AS RIGHTS PROTEST HALTS LA GUARDIA TRAFFIC
description: Eleven people were arrested at La Guardia Airport and scores of departing passengers were delayed yesterday evening when about 60 people protesting racial injustice in New York City blocked traffic lanes outside a terminal building.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain on the disposal of discontinued units of $8 million for the quarter and year. c-After a loss of $2 million from discontinued operations. d-After income of $38 million from discontinued operations and a gain on the disposal of discontinued units of $283 million, as well as an extraordinary loss of $58 million from the early extinguishment of interest rate hedge contracts. The results for 1987 and 1986 include Caremark Inc., acquired on Aug. 3, 1987, in a pooling of interests transaction and consolidition of the company's wholly owned finance subsidiary.

title: IPALCO ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Both year-ago nets include a net gain of $48,684,000 from the sale of assets.

title: VERMONT FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Games Help Calgary Solve Hard Times
description: The times were heady here, back at the dawn of the decade. Oil prices were up. Agricultural markets were strong. Unemployment was virtually nonexistent. New glassy buildings were creating a skyline. So many people were moving here that city leaders were discouraging others from coming.

title: Music: 'Schubertiad' Begins Its 10-Year Run
description: IN the dear, dead days beyond recall, we are told, families used to gather on winter evenings with the intention of reading the Bible from start to finish, each member taking a turn at a chapter or two. There was something of the same devotional attitude - as well as an endearingly loony optimism - in the ''Schubertiade'' project that got under way on Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y. For many in the sizable audience, Schubert's music is the Good Book, an aid to salvation whether swallowed whole or in part.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Before Chernobyl, to have a nuclear power plant was profitable - and also prestigious. In addition to providing self-dependency in energy, a nuclear power plant guaranteed increased attention toward the region, including jobs, housing and social and cultural amenities. But then the entire world started talking about Chernobyl.'' - The Soviet newspaper, Komsomolskaya Pravda. [ A9:2. ]

title: H.J. Schonfield, 81, Author and Editor Of Books on Religion
description: Hugh J. Schonfield, author of ''The Passover Plot'' and many other books about religion and the Bible, died Tuesday in London. He was 81 years old.

title: Report of Bias in F.B.I. Leaves Reagan 'Upset
description: President Reagan is ''very upset'' about reports of discrimination against a black agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and he has asked F.B.I. Director William S. Sessions to investigate, the White House said today.

title: M. David Henkle, Lawyer, 79
description: M. David Henkle, a lawyer and former assistant vice president of Prentice-Hall Inc., the publishing company, died Tuesday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: ENDING PARTY, WORKERS HELP THE NEEDIEST Ending Party, Worker Help The Neediest  Recorded yesterday... $10,326.00  Previously recorded... $3,351,672.98  Total... 3,361,998.98
description: For the third year, Jerry Fields Associates of Manhattan sent a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of spending the money on an office party.

title: TRANSTECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
North Stars Score Twice in Final 4:26
description: Herb Brooks, the Minnesota coach, hadn't expected to have anything to beam about after this game. For the longest time, his players trailed the Islanders by a 1-0 margin, but then, with half of the final period elapsed, it was the North Stars who skated dangerously close to the New York goal, tied the game, and then won it in the final second left on the clock.

title: Regret, No Rancor as Carpenter Departs
description: A day after his dismissal as coach of the Devils, Doug Carpenter said it was inevitable that he would be blamed for the team's recent slide, but added that the team was on the right road.

title: Chef Sues in Attack by Goose
description: A chef who says he was attacked by a goose at the restaurant where he worked is suing the restaurant for $1 million. Richard Braue, a former chef at the Villa Victor in Syosset, said he was standing by a pond on the restaurant's property in June 1985 when he was charged by a Canada goose. While trying to avoid the bird, he fell and broke his back, he said. The Villa Victor's attorney, John Martin, said the restaurant was not responsible for the incident, adding, ''This case is fowl and it is not what it's quacked up to be.''

title: U.S. Agents Search For Drugs on QE2
description: Drug-sniffing dogs were taken aboard the luxury liner Queen Elizabeth 2 when it docked here today and hundreds of passengers had to wait in line for hours for their luggage to be searched.

title: HARMAN INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Vance and Rogers Press for Arms Treaty
description: Two former Secretaries of State, one a Republican and one a Democrat, warned the Senate today that failure to approve a new treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles would have ''devastating'' consequences for the United States and its NATO partners.

title: F.B.I. PAPERS SHOW WIDE SURVEILLANCE OF REAGAN CRITICS
description: Documents made public today show that the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted extensive surveillance of hundreds of American citizens and groups opposed to the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.

title: STOCKTON SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
At Disney, Playful Architecture Is Very Serious Business
description: WHETHER to put statues of Dumbo in the atrium, Pluto in the pediments and Grumpy, Sleepy, Sneezy, Doc and Dopey along trellised colonnades: those were the questions that faced Walt Disney executives and the architect Michael Graves in the design of a new convention kingdom being unveiled today at the Epcot Center in Orlando, Fla.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a special third quarter restructuring charge of $620.4 million and after-tax gains of $56.5 million from the sale of Piedmont Aviation stock. The sale of Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corp. stock added $37.5 million to earnings in 1986.

title: N.B.A. East All-Stars
description: Patrick Ewing, the Knick center, was among 7 players selected yesterday by 11 Eastern Conference coaches as reserves in the National Basketball Association All-Star Game on Feb. 7 in Chicago. It was the second time in his three seasons that the 7-foot Ewing was named to the team. Of the other six players chosen, Danny Ainge of the Boston Celtics and Glenn (Doc) Rivers of the Atlanta Hawks, both guards, and Brad Daugherty, the Cleveland Cavalier center, were named for the first time. Charles Barkley and Maurice Cheeks of the Philadelphia 76ers and Kevin McHale of the Celtics round out the squad of reserves.

title: SAY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: b-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $85,000 and $214,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Metro Matters; Corporate Flight: Role Playing Offers Insights
description: Should Apex of America shift its corporate headquarters and 15,000 employees to another city?

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Pinch-Hitter for Trump
description: Donald J. Trump turned them down, and the Democrats have found a less controversial host for their gala fund-raising dinner in Washington on March 16: former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. Mr. Trump, a Republican who has made contributions to Democratic candidates, rejected efforts last year by House Speaker Jim Wright to persuade him to accept the invitation.

title: Home Improvement
description: EVERY building using commercial electric power has a safeguard system of circuit breakers or fuses incorporated into the wiring. If an overload occurs - when, for instance, too many appliances make too large a power demand - these devices automatically interrupt the current, preventing an electrical fire.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $2.5 million charge for write-up of assets.

title: Restoring Fanciful British Pavilions
description: In 1721, the poet Alexander Pope helped his friend Lord Bathurst design Alfred's Hall, a curious little castle for the garden of Cirencester Park, Bathurst's estate in Cirencester, Gloucestershire. With ivy-covered turrets and stained-glass windows, it resembled a Gothic ruin and promptly set a fashion for similar fanciful structures in large English gardens. The two men knew they had succeeded when visitors mistook it for an old castle of King Arthur's.

title: Yields Are A Bit Lower
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly down for the week ended yesterday, as evidence pointing toward slower economic growth and lower interest rates in the coming months continued to mount.

title: Currents; Design for Astronauts' Memorial
description: IN honor of the 14 astronauts who have died in the space program, and in celebration of the mysteries of space exploration, a remarkable mechanized black-granite memorial is to be erected at the visitors' center at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla., in 1990.

title: HUGE INVENTORIES MAR GROWTH RATE OF 4.2% FOR G.N.P.
description: The nation's economy grew at a 4.2 percent annual rate in the final quarter of 1987, the Commerce Department reported today. But because of a sharp contraction in consumer spending, most of the increase piled up as unsold inventory.

title: Edelman Makes Offer To Foster Wheeler
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, has asked the management of the Foster Wheeler Corporation to discuss creating a recapitalization plan or, as an alternative, to accept a buyout for $16.50 a share, the New Jersey-based engineering and construction company said today.

title: Global Flu Risk Seen in Asia Fish Farms
description: The growth of fish farming in Asia may increase the risk of worldwide epidemics of influenza, two scientists suggest in the journal Nature.

title: High-Tech Exports Case
description: French officials said today that five entrepreneurs from southern France had been charged with espionage for illegally selling sophisticated communications equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: PARIS BUSINESS FORMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of unrealized securities losses of $198,000.

title: UNGERMANN-BASS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $297,000.

title: What Is Needed to Promote Mideast Peace; Wrong Target
description: To the Editor:

title: New Post of President Is Filled at Vestron
description: Austin O. Furst Jr., 45 years old, has turned to Strauss Zelnick, who is 30, to help him manage Vestron Inc., the video company that has turned to movie producing.

title: Kentucky Routed by Vanderbilt, 83-66
description: Scott Draud scored 22 points, 18 on 3-point goals, to lead Vanderbilt to an 83-66 Southeastern Conference upset victory over Kentucky tonight.

title: ARMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago first quarter results include operations of businesses acquired from Dayco Corp. in October 1986.

title: NATIONAL PIZZA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included a charge of $852,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TENEMENT DEMOLITION PLAN ENDED
description: The Koch administration has temporarily shelved its plan to demolish a historic, but derelict, apartment house in Brooklyn. Instead, it has offered what amounts to a challenge grant to encourage preservation of the city-owned building.

title: Nabisco Ending Sponsorship in '90
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. announced yesterday that it would continue sponsoring the men's Grand Prix tennis circuit for the next two years, but would phase out sponsorship in 1990.

title: Score of 'Phantom': How Good Is It?
description: What is the music of Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera'' worth? Some composers and performers for whom songfulness is serious business are responding this week.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: TWO movie projectors run in my head. The dominant one rolls out the sights and sounds and smells of the present in powerful color. The other projects cracked images from the past in faint black and white. Recently I was sitting in a restaurant, listening to a friend's story, when the projectors changed dominance.

title: PRESIDENT PRESSES CONTRA AID PLAN
description: President Reagan began an intensive Administration lobbying effort today to win more than $36.25 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels. But he provoked some lawmakers by apparently rejecting suggestions that Congress play a role in deciding whether to release $3.6 million in military aid that would be held in escrow.

title: PENNSYLVANIA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BSD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Security Pacific To Sell Mortgages
description: Security Pacific National Bank filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $1 billion of mortgage-backed securities.

title: Carlos Rangel, Author, Dies in Venezuela at 58
description: Carlos Rangel, an author and journalist and one of Latin America's most articulate conservative intellectuals, has died at age 58.

title: BROOKLYN UNION GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics of The Times; Colombia Fights Back
description: The powerful drug mafia that profits from Colombia's huge cocaine trade declared war on the nation's Government Monday when it gunned down Attorney General Carlos Hoyos. A day later, President Virgilio Barco picked up the gauntlet. Challenging guerrillas as well as drug lords, he sent troops into the streets, created new police and judicial positions and closed legal loopholes.

title: Advertising; POP Radio Is a Hit With Retailers
description: THERE is pop radio and there is POP Radio. The former you snag from the airwaves; the latter snags you in the aisles.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-percent stock dividend paid Dec. 1, 1987.

title: Snuff Merger Hits Snag
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would ask a court to bar the American Maize-Products Company temporarily from going ahead with its planned $36.5 million acquisition of the dry snuff assets of the United States Tobacco Company. The F.T.C. said the merger ''could substantially reduce competition.''

title: HOME GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $14.8 million for the quarter and a gain of $53 million for the year on the sale of securities by insurance subsidiaries. c-After a charge of $1.6 million for the quarter and a gain of $97.7 million for the year on the sale of securities by insurance subsidiaries; tax credits of $10.5 million and $33.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a gain of $32.3 million from an accounting change.

title: 30-Year Bonds Yield 9.42% At Financing Corporation
description: The Financing Corporation yesterday offered $650 million of 9.40 percent 30-year bonds at a price of 99.24, to yield 9.42 percent.

title: The Sound of Politics in Iowa Town
description: It was three degrees below zero at 10 o'clock Monday morning, the wind was knifing in from the north at 30 miles an hour, snow was piled around the old gold-domed bandstand, and the plate glass windows of Gale Stapp's Purity Drug Store were coated with ice.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26

Soviet Scraps a New Atomic Plant In Face of Protest Over Chernobyl
description: The Soviet authorities have abandoned construction of a nuclear power plant near the Black Sea in the face of public opposition generated by the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl atomic power station, a Soviet newspaper reported today.

title: MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects an addition of $235.5 million to reserves for losses on loans and real estate and a gain of $20,044,000 from the sale of premises; also reflects $3,617,000 of net pre-tax gains from the sale of mortgage-backed securities and loans and $12,000 of net gains from the sale of investments. c-Reflects a $551.2 milllion provision for losses on loans and real estate, a pre-tax gain of $20,044,000 on the sale of premises, and a pre-tax writeoff of $22,668,000 related to the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp.'s secondary reserve; also reflects net pre-tax gains of $143,360,000 from the sale of mortgage-backed securities and loans and net gains of $169,000 from the sale of investments. d-Net income The year-ago quarter reflects an addition of $302,160,000 to reserves for losses on loans and real estate; net pre-tax gains of $304,126,000 from the sale of mortgage-backed securities and loans and net pre-tax gains of $5,511,000 from the sale of investments. The 1986 year reflects a $463,841,000 provision for losses on loans and real estate, net pre-tax gains of $568,155,000 from the sale of mortgage-backed securities and loans and net pre-tax gains of $6,742,000 from the sale of investments.

title: Clarinet: Hakan Rosengren
description: HAKAN ROSENGREN, a first-rate Swedish clarinetist who recently won the Concert Artist Guild's international competition, was presented in his prize recital Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Talking Deals; Advisers' Conflict In Merger Battles
description: IN the wake of the recent spate of takeover battles, investment bankers, company directors and the courts are grappling with a controversy over loyalty between investment banking firms and their clients.

title: Article 614388 -- No Title
description: A group that contends that Americans are still imprisoned in Southeast Asia announced a drive today to create a reward for the release of any prisoner left from the Vietnam War.

title: Mab Moltke Dies at 78; Ex-Publicity Executive
description: Mab Wilson Moltke, a former advertising and publicity executive in New York, died Jan. 1 at her home in Blackrock, County Dublin, after a long illness. She was 78 years old and had moved to Ireland in 1970.

title: Boxing Awards
description: Mike Tyson, the undisputed heavyweight champion, was named Fighter of the Year by the World Boxing Council at its annual awards luncheon in New York yesterday. The Marvelous Marvin Hagler-Ray Leonard fight of last April 6 was named Fight of the Year and Leonard was awarded a special trophy for winning his third world title. Other fighters honored were Julio Cesar Chavez, who was the W.B.C. junior-lightweight champion before he won the World Boxing Association lightweight title from Edwin Rosario in November; Thomas Hearns, who won his fourth world title in October when he knocked out Juan Roldan for the W.B.C. middleweight title, and Chang Jung-Koo, who has defended his W.B.C. light flyweight title 14 times. Don King was named Promoter of the Year.

title: CHESAPEAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of about $2.5 million, or 12 cents a share, from the December sale of a minority interest in Groveton Paper Board and previously unrealized gains from other restructuring activities. c-After restructuring activities lowered net by $1.2 million, including a previously announced gain from the sale of a housing company, a charge from the sale of Plainwell Paper, writeoffs from the closings of a sawmill and plywood plant, and the sale of the Groveton paper board stock. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in September 1987, and a 3-for-2 stock split in 1986.

title: Parent & Child
description: THE things that children find funny tell us a great deal about their level of development and what is on their minds. There is a connection between the 2-year-old who bursts into a fit of giggles upon hearing the nonbursts into a fit of giggles upon hearing the nonsense phrase ''bottle, battle, bittle'' and the young adolescent who laughs at the ''naughtiness'' of a joke about sex. By understanding that connection, childhood researchers say, you can learn things about your children you otherwise might not see.

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Real Target
description: Opponents of the treaty eliminating shorter- and medium-range nuclear missiles really have a more important target in mind - the pact being negotiated by Moscow and the Reagan Administration to reduce superpower nuclear arsenals by 50 percent across the board.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $29,364,000, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of the company's 18.9 percent interest in South China Morning Post Ltd. c-Included a non-recurring gain of $2,780,000, or 3 cent a share. d-Included a net gain of $34,138,000, or 35 cents a share, largely from the sale of a portion of Dow Jones's holdings in Continental Cablevision.

description: b-Included pre-tax profits of $21 million resulting from the recovery of excess funds in its pension plans and the liquidation of excess metal inventory valued on a LIFO basis, and an extraordinary charge of $17.5 million resulting from a reduction in the estimated benefit from the tax loss carryforward reported in the third quarter. c-Included pre-tax profits of $243 million from the sale of shares of M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an associated company in Australia, and Asarco Australia in public offerings and an extraordinary tax credit of $71 million resulting from utilization of all of Asarco's net operating loss carryforwards. d-Included pre-tax items totaling $15.4 million, consisting of LIFO profits and income from the sale of an interest in Asarco Australia Ltd. less an increase in reserves for bad debt, and a $12.9 million foreign exchange translation gain related to changes in the U.S. dollar value of the debt of M.I.M. Holdings. e-Included pre-tax items totaling $38.4 million consisting of LIFO profits and income from an M.I.M. rights offering, and the reduction of Asarco's interest in the Wiluna gold project. There were no share earnings in the year 1986 after preferred stock dividend requirements.

title: German Abducted in Beirut As Bonn Tries Conciliation
description: A day after a Government official acknowledged that the threat to West German hostages in Lebanon had influenced Bonn's decision not to extradite a hijacking suspect sought by Washington, another German was reportedly seized today.

title: SUNCOAST SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WM WRIGLEY JR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Help for Murdoch Is Blocked in Senate
description: The Senate today defeated a measure that could have helped Rupert Murdoch retain control of The New York Post even though he also owns a television station in New York City.

title: CENTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $14.5 million, or 33 cents a share, from the initial public offering of a stake in Centel Cable Television Co. for the quarter and year. c-Included a pre-tax gain of $12,218,000 on the sale of Centel Cable Television Co. of Texas for the quarter and year. Both year-ago periods' share earnings were reduced 64 cents a share as a result of a writedown of the company's investment in Argo Group Inc.

title: Changes Seen At I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will announce major organizational changes today, people in the computer industry said.

title: Ex-Bakery Art Center In Florida
description: Twin silos are still attached to the former bakery, but now it is an unusual arts complex coated in bold coral and thriving north of downtown Miami in an area to be redeveloped.

title: Who's Antonio? Koch's Calendar Unravels Puzzle
description: Who is Antonio?

title: NASA Delays Flight of Shuttle Until August
description: The space agency announced today that it had delayed by two months, until Aug. 4, its target date for launching the next space shuttle. The delay was caused primarily by problems with the solid-fuel booster rockets, the agency said.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ballcarriers Are Playing Modest Role
description: The position has produced some of the most memorable moments in 21 years of super Sundays. The power of Franco Harris. The force of Larry Csonka. The relentlessness of John Riggins. The suddenness of Marcus Allen. The adventures of William Perry.

title: SILICON VALLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
W. Hawkins Ferry, Patron of Arts And Architecture Historian,
description: W. Hawkins Ferry, an architectural historian and a well-known collector and patron of 20th-century art, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at his home in Grosse Pointe Shores, a suburb of Detroit. He was 74 years old, and had for some time suffered from a neurological disorder.

title: AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss The latest quarter loss primarily reflects writedown of crude oil and refined product inventory values. The loss includes non-recurring income of $25,596,000, resulting principally from a refund of U.K. taxes and income of $47,421,000, resulting in a change in accounting for income taxes to comply with FAS 96. The 1986 figures are restated for change in accounting for income taxes, which increased net in the fourth quarter of 1986 by $19,723,000 and for the full year by $36,873,000. The share earnings assume conversion of the $3.50 cumulative preferred stock through the date of redemption Sept. 17, 1987 and exercise of outstanding stock options.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Secretary of State George P. Shultz's plans to meet with two Palestinians misidentified a speaker for an event to be held on Saturday at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Manhattan. Along with Mordechai Bar-On, a leftist member of the Israeli Parliament, the scheduled speaker is Tahseen Basheer, a former Egyptian Ambassador to Canada. (Hanna Siniora, editor of the East Jerusalem newspaper Al Fajr, is not on the program.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JANUARY 28, 1988
description: International A2-9

title: Music: Marimba Quartet
description: THE Manhattan Marimba Quartet, formed in 1979, has dedicated itself to demonstrating the potential of their chosen instrument to play chamber music of a textural complexity comparable to that made by wind and bowed instruments. In an era when many ''serious'' musicians in this country are busily integrating non-European polyrhythms and percussive textures into concert music, the group, which includes William Trigg, Kory Grossman, Bill Ruyle and James Preiss, is right in step with the times.

title: U.S. Wins Order on 2 Companies
description: A Federal judge yesterday temporarily prohibited two overnight cargo-delivery companies from conducting air-cargo flights. The Government says the airlines were involved in four fatal crashes in the last five years.

title: Currents; 'Swaying' Palm Trees Need No Breezes
description: THE sheet-metal palm trees that seem to lean with the wind at the Pink Cadillac Cafe in Los Angeles are witty and useful, too.

title: BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago period. The bank holding company took in the latest fourth quarter a $17.1 million provision for loan losses. The 1986 year loss included a $42.8 million writeoff of goodwill.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a man who pleaded guilty in a 1986 Brooklyn slaying included an incorrect plea description from the Brooklyn District Attorney's office. The defendant, Frank Casavilla, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder, which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison.

SELVAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: RACHEL AND HER CHILDREN. Homeless Families in America. By Jonathan Kozol. 261 pages. Crown. $16.95.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: KEY RATES
24% of U.S. Children Live With Just One Parent
description: Nearly a quarter of all American children now live with just one parent, and the Census Bureau estimates that more than half will, at some time before they reach adulthood, live in single-parent households.

title: Coe Prepares
description: Sebastian Coe, the only man to win the 1,500-meter run two times in the Olympic Games (in 1980 and in 1984), has a third consecutive triumph in that event as his goal as he begins preparation for the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea. The 31-year-old Briton has not run competitively since last May because of problems with an Achilles' tendon. He will return to competition on Feb. 13 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., where he will run 3,000 meters against a first-rate international field in the Vitalis/United States Olympic Invitational meet.

title: Broken Children, a Truth of Nicaragua's War
description: Inside the Fernando Velez Paiz Hospital in Managua, one follows the screams to find the ward where wounded and maimed children are attended.

title: PROFIT SCOREBOARD
FIRSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest third quarter included the results of Durham's First Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: CYPRUS MINERALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Old Idea Flies Again
description: It was evident enough in the State of the Union Message that at the White House, these are times for reheating old ideas, and the Council of Economic Advisers will soon join in with a ringing defense of airline deregulation.

title: Houston Journal; Inescapable Pitches That Ring Up Profits
description: Life here has never quite been quite the same since the fateful evening in early 1983 when Jim McIngvale rented time in a local television studio, pulled a stack of greenbacks from his back pocket and jumped in the air for the camera shouting in a manic, fast-forward voice, ''Gallery Furniture will SAAVE YOUUU MONEY!''

title: Bridge: An Australian Tournament To Be a Bicentennial Event
description: Bridge is not being overlooked in the wide-ranging activities Australians are undertaking during their bicentennial year.

title: Vancouver Symphony, In Debt, Ends Activities
description: The Vancouver Symphony Orchestra, Canada's third largest, suspended operations after Tuesday night's concert because of poor attendance and a debt of nearly $1.5 million.

title: Apartments Planned for the Homeless
description: A partnership of government and education, religion and banking has developed a $7 million plan to create 101 apartment units for homeless young families and the elderly in a handsome old building on the Upper West Side.

title: Principals' Accord to Extend Probation Period to 5 Years
description: The Board of Education and the principals' union announced a tentative three-year contract yesterday that extends the probationary period for all school supervisors, to five years from three.

title: Net Rises 8.2% At Dow Jones
description: Despite a decline in advertising linage at The Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter rose 8.2 percent, to $50.3 million, or 52 cents a share, from $46.5 million, or 48 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed to $417.2 million from $311.99 million. The 1986 quarter included a nonrecurring gain of $2.8 million.

title: Many Nursing Homes Are Overlooking Needs Of Younger Patients
description: Amid all the recent concern about conditions in the nation's nursing homes, the problems faced by one group have been overlooked, experts say. Younger patients, some of them disabled since birth and others cut down suddenly by accident or stroke, make up a small but significant share of the residents of the nation's nursing homes.

title: Kemper Switches Shop
description: Bayer Bess Vanderwarker & Flynn of Chicago has become agency for the property and casualty insurance companies of the Kemper Corporation in Long Grove, Ill. The agency puts the budget between $4 million and $5 million. The account had been with J. Walter Thompson, Chicago, for 15 years.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the sharp increase in sales for the latest quarter and year resulted from the consolidation of the continuing Anchor Hocking product lines, beginning July 2, 1987.

title: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORAION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 5-Year Notes Set By Mobil Canada
description: Mobil Oil Canada Ltd., a unit of the Mobil Corporation, is offering $500 million of 8 3/8 percent noncallable notes due in 1993, at a price of 99.92, to yield 8.393 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: MOUNTAIN CLIMBING ON SKIS
description: BECAUSE it's there has always been an acceptable reason to climb a mountain, as it was for Tony Goodwin when he conquered Mount Greylock on cross-country skis in the early 1970's.

title: Marriage Of Fashion And Art by Saint Laurent
description: Clothes that will stun the crowds in museum exhibitions in the future were paraded by Yves Saint Laurent's models today. In a dazzling collection paying homage to the Cubists, the designer mixed art and fashion in a way that celebrated both fields.

title: Steel Shutters In West Bank: New Defiance
description: Hefting their crowbars and their rifles in what is a now a daily ritual, the Israeli soldiers moved from store to store this morning, ordering the owners to open up their steel shutters or, if the owners were not around, breaking the locks.

title: U.S. HOMES TO GET A BOOKLET ON AIDS
description: The United States Government plans to mail an informational brochure about AIDS to all American households later this year, a senior Reagan Adminstration official said today.

title: Topics of The Times; Renovated Rhythms
description: Gentrification means new sights: gleaming restaurants, cookie stores, video shops and repaved sidewalks. But there's more than meets the eye to the changes that turn neglected neighborhoods into fashionable places to live. Some are heard, not seen.

title: Bus Kills a Boy in Rockland
description: A boy was killed this morning when he was struck by a school bus in this Rockland County community, the police said. The boy, identified as Pincus Zisholtz of 11 Yale Drive, believed to be about 4 years old, was struck about 8:30 A.M., the police said. They said the bus driver, David Ben-Zikry, 30, of Maple Avenue in Monsey. was not issued a summons in the accident.

title: Calendar: Pottery Classes for Youngsters
description: Children's Crafts

title: Surprise Bid for American Standard
description: The stock of American Standard Inc. advanced nearly $21 a share yesterday in heavy trading, closing at $58.875, after the Black & Decker Corporation made a surprise $56-a-share tender offer for the big producer of plumbing fixtures, air-conditioning units and transportation products.

title: Colombian Chief Signs An Antiterrorist Decree
description: President Virgilio Barco Vargas signed an emergency antiterrorist decree today, strengthening security forces and offering rewards to informers to counter rising violence by drug traffickers and left-wing rebels.

title: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 620988 -- No Title
description: The family of a cancer patient who died after he was given seven times the normal dosage of an anticancer drug will receive an $11.1 million settlement from the hospital, officials say.

title: Childhood Regained, on Film
description: ''The movie camera is very close to the eye of a child,'' John Boorman said last week, as the British writer and director of ''Hope and Glory'' was heading off to collect several awards from the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, including one for best picture of the year. Last Saturday, his gently humorous autobiographical film about a young boy's coming of age during World War II also won a Golden Globe Award. ''A child looks at the world clearly, sees things sharply, without bringing a set of moral judgments to it,'' Mr. Boorman said, speculating on the appeal of his film. ''Movies made from the point of view of a child often have that beautiful simplicity.''

title: Article 535988 -- No Title
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, bolstered by strong long-distance revenues and huge cost reductions, yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $498 million, or 46 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $1.17 billion a year earlier.

title: HOWARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings restated to reflect 4 percent stock dividend paid in October.

title:
The Basic Speech;
Jobs, Wages and an Aggressive Trade Policy
description: LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

title: Attack Puts Quiet Hudson Area in Civil-Rights Fight
description: Tawana Brawley sat at the table, hunched over a bowl of cold cereal and a stack of letters. Her mother, Glenda, answered phone calls from ministers, reporters and the curious concerning the reported attack on her daughter here two months ago.

title: PACER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $185,700 and $446,700 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax benefit of $225,000 and $397,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Currents; Variations on the Comfort Theme
description: ''I DO not personally see my work as having moved from the harder concept to a softer feel,'' said Rei Kawakubo, the Tokyo-based fashion and furniture designer. But her newest collection of furniture, which combines aluminum with linden, a pale blond wood, is far less severe.

title: West German Cancels 'Siegfried' Appearance
description: Peter Hofmann, the West German tenor scheduled to sing the title role in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Wagner's ''Siegfried,'' has withdrawn because of a bronchial infection, the company announced yesterday.

title: ROLLINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARINE CORP-ILLINOIS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings reflect the initial public offering of 534,750 common shares in March 1986, as well as 2-for-1 stock splits in January and June 1986.

title: KEY CENTURION BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results restated to reflect certain mergers.

title: Woman Held in Attack On Patient in Hospital
description: A 40-year-old Manhattan woman was arrested at Beth Israel Hospital yesterday after a nurse caught her trying to cut a pneumonia patient's breathing tube, the police said.

title: Impeachment Panel In Arizona Requests Mecham Testimony
description: Gov. Evan Mecham was asked today to testify next week before the select committee of the state's House of Representative that is studying whether he should be impeached.

title: School-Tower Plan in Doubt
description: An unusual combination of politics, public perception, mayoral miscalculation and the legacy of the New York corruption scandals has thrown a proposal for an office tower into the center of a battle.

title: Nunn's Sensible Shield
description: LEAD: A proposal by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, to design and deploy a limited shield against nuclear missiles is a modest but important plan that could improve American defenses.

title: Nutrasweet Reports Fat Substitute
description: The Nutrasweet Company, which makes the artificial sweetener aspartame, announced yesterday, as expected, that it had developed a low-calorie, cholesterol-free substitute for fat that is derived from proteins in such sources as milk and egg whites.

title: U.S. to Request Bail Revocation For Gene Gotti
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that he would ask to have Gene Gotti put in prison and kept there while awaiting the outcome of his new trial on racketeering and drug charges.

title: Wolf-Ferrari Works
description: Two orchestral works by Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari will be played for the first time in the United States tonight at 8 o'clock at the Manhattan School of Music, Broadway at 122d Street.

title: 'Eyes on the Prize' Tops DuPont-Columbia Awards
description: ''Eyes on the Prize,'' a public television documentary series about the American civil rights movement, won two top honors last night in the annual Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University awards for broadcast journalism.

title: Doles Team Up for Campaign Blitz Through New Hampshire
description: It was shortly before 9 o'clock Wednesday night, and Senator Bob Dole was winding up his speech before a packed dinner of the town's Chamber of Commerce. His wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, sat beside him.

title: Cab-Robbery Suspect Seized
description: A 23-year-old suspect in a series of cab robberies in East Harlem was arrested last night at East 102d Street and Lexington Avenue, the police said. The suspect, Erick Mourino, of 60 East 102d Street, was charged with one count of robbery.

title: Viking Pact for Burns
description: Mike Lynn, the general manager of the Minnesota Vikings, said yesterday that the Vikings had offered Coach Jerry Burns a two-year contract extension. Lynn said he expected Burns to agree to the extension to the three-year contract he signed before the 1986 season. ''I don't think it's right for a coach to have one year left,'' Lynn said. ''It would give the wrong impression, that he's a lame-duck coach. I think it's good from the organizational standpoint for everyone to know Jerry will be with us the next three years.'' Burns led the Vikings to the National Football Conference playoffs for the first time since 1982.

title: Revised Curbs on East-Bloc Trade
description: The United States and its principal allies reportedly agreed today to tighten controls on the export of high-technology goods to Warsaw Pact members while committing themselves to keep shortening the lists of items banned for sale to Communist nations.

title: Corrections
description: The introduction yesterday to the text of the ''basic speech'' of Richard A. Gephardt, Democratic candidate for the Presidency, misstated his title. He is a Representative from Missouri, not its former Governor.

title: NYNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Poll Finds Support For Space Shuttle, But Doubts Persist
description: Two-thirds of American adults say the space shuttle program is worth continuing, but as many also expect it not to be ''successful'' by the end of this year, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREATER NEW YORK SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,279,000 for the quarter and $9,657,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $3,120,000 for the quarter and $10,970,000 for the year. d-After a loss of $5.9 million on sales of securities, which the company said were primarily the result of prepayments of mortgage-backed securities. The company converted to stock form on June 24, 1987. The prior year operating net included a $5.5 million net gain from the sale of two branch offices as well as net gains of $11.2 million on sales of securities undertaken to restructure assets and realize the benefits of net operating loss carryforwards, a significant portion of which were scheduled to expire at year-end 1986.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $6.7 million for the quarter and $5.7 million for the year; the quarter also included a gain of $90.8 million from the sale of the company's remaining interest in Commercial Credit Corp., and is after a charge of $21.5 million for reserves for SFD II Disk Drive Component Replacement Program and a charge of $22.8 million related to the company's business and technology centers. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary loss of $200,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $4 million for the year.

title: ALLEGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $19,887,000 for the quarter and $68,817,000 for the year, and a gain on the sale of subsidiaries of $270,494,000 for the both periods. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $9,228,000 for the quarter and $124,435,000 for the year. Allegis recorded in the latest quarter a $30 million provision for an expected loss based on a decision to sell one of its aircraft fleets.

title: FIRSTFED FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Film: 'Anguish,' Horror From Bigas Luna
description: BIRDS fly around the room, and a little old lady with her hair in a bun croaks murderous orders at her son. John always does what Mama says, so he leaves the house, kills a couple of people and gouges out their eyes. He is, however, well raised enough to rinse off the eyeballs neatly in the victims' bathroom sinks.

title: WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS DC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $101,000 for the quarter and $272,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $60,000 for the quarter and $300,000 for the 6 months and is after a charge of $735,000 from a prepayment penalty on a federal home loan bank advance for the quarter and 6 months. The bank converted to stock ownership in May 1957.

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $9,247,000, or 21 cents a share, from year-end inventory adjustments for the quarter and net from discontinued operations of $2,772,000 for the year; the quarter also included gains of $9,890,000, or 21 cents a share, from year-end inventory adjustments. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $2,951,000 for the quarter and $9,991,000 for the year. d-Includes a gain of $9,890,000 or 21 cents a share from year-end inventory adjustments. The company said 1986 results for both periods were revised to exclude unusual items for comparitive purposes.

title: Coca-Cola Unit To Buy Bottlers
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the bottling subsidiary created by the Coca-Cola Company in 1986, said it was buying several bottling operations from the large soft-drink manufacturer for $500 million. Last week, the parent company said it would reorganize its American subsidiary, Coca-Cola U.S.A., to respond to changes in its bottling operations.

title: Pentagon Asks No New Weapons In Return for Backing Arms Pact
description: In a departure from their practice with previous arms control treaties, the Joint Chiefs of Staff are not demanding compensation in the form of new weapons as a condition for endorsing the new treaty governing missiles in Europe.

title: GLENN CLOSE IN 'STONES FOR IBARRA'
description: GENTLY and intelligently, ''Stones for Ibarra,'' the ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' presentation on CBS tonight at 9 o'clock, takes chances and ends up succeeding wonderfully. There is an entrenched mechanism in television drama, with roots in the 19th-century novel, that forces writers into a naturalistic mode, a straighforward chronological unfolding of a story. The result could be called the ''Masterpiece Theater'' syndrome. Breaking loose is difficult, especially when television executives are a singularly unadventurous lot. The occasional triumph of a Dennis Potter and a ''Singing Detective'' is rare.

title: Ohio Nuclear Plant Bonds Backed by Lease Payments
description: A $646 million bond issue was offered yesterday by the Beaver Valley Power Station Funding Corporation, a specially created company whose debt will be backed by lease payments of the Ohio Edison Company.

title: BEST BUY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grand Plan for a Park Stalls in Miss Liberty's Shadow
