description: A $10 million private marina proposed for prime public waterfront at Liberty State Park has slowed the development of the park and jeopardized the organization managing it. The 750-acre park has been extolled as potentially one of the grandest in the New York metropolitan region, with the Manhattan skyline and Statue of Liberty as its eastern backdrop.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter included a gain of $2 million from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Dr. John D. Lewis, 82, Teacher of Government
description: Dr. John D. Lewis, a professor of government at Oberlin College for 37 years, died of cardiac arrest Saturday at a nursing home in Oberlin, Ohio. He was 82 years old.

title: MUSIC: VIOLIN AND CELLO DUO
description: ENTHUSIASM - especially when it is supported by two strong techniques - is hard to resist in any musical format. Laura Hamilton and Lanny Paykin gave us an unusual one on Wednesday night in Merkin Hall - a violin and cello duo augmented only in Beethoven's String Trio in G. Here Michael Ouzounian, Miss Hamilton's colleague in the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, played the viola part.

title: FAIRHAVEN SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $694,000 from a dividend the company received from the mutual central savings fund of Massachusetts. The company went public in October 1986.

title: NATIONAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $2 million tax credit and a $400,000 gain from the liquidation of LIFO inventories for both periods. c-Includes an unusual charge of $4.6 million which covers the closing of a coke facility, net of previously provided reserves. d-Net loss and reduced by $8.2 million from the liquidation of LIFO inventories.

title: Meese to Make F.B.I. Inquiry
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he would review allegations of harassment in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's surveillance of opponents of the Reagan Administration's Central America policy.

title: Poll Finds Even Split on Bush-Rather Battle
description: In the television battle between Vice President Bush and Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, Americans divided sharply along party lines, with Democrats backing Mr. Rather and Republicans supporting Mr. Bush, according to a new poll by the Gallup Organization.

title: DU PONT DE NEMOURS, E I & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Replacement' Label Hard to Remove
description: When do they stop being replacement players?

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW WORKING GROUP ON CONTRACT PRACTICES - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. SECURITY COUNCIL ON UNITED NATIONS INTERIM FORCE IN LEBANON - 11 A.M. PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR SPECIAL SESSION OF ASSEMBLY DEVOTED TO DISARMAMENT - 11:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council COMMISSION ON INTERGOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE AND FUNCTIONS IN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL FIELDS - 10 A.M.

title: On the Lines, Strength Meets Finesse
description: The Washington Redskins' defensive line is big and strong, and the Denver Broncos' offensive line is relatively small and quick.

title: U.S. and Egypt Ask 6-Month Israel-Arab Restraint
description: President Reagan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt agreed today to press for a six-month cooling-off period between Israel and the Palestinians who live on the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: AMERICAN TELEVISION & COMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are restated to include Manhattan Cable Television Inc., which was transferred from Time Inc. to American Television on March 18, 1987 in exchange for 9.4 million shares of American Television class B common stock.

title: A Sonic Mix On the Lower East Side
description: THE Lower East Side has often been treated as a neighborhood producing one sort of music, neatly categorizable and easily stuffed away with the dirty laundry. But when historians of the Lower East Side reconsider the facts, the 1980's will be thought of as an immensely diverse, fecund era for music. The composers and improvisers John Zorn, Elliott Sharp and Wayne Horvitz have broken out of their turf, gaining a larger audience as they reached artistic maturation. The intense and radical social criticism of rock groups like the Swans and Sonic Youth, and the once endless stream of legendary clubs (now curtailed by real-estate prices), from 57 Club and 8BC to the still-vital CBGB and the new Knitting Factory, will make the 80's sound like Eden.

title: Allies on Night Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: Gains at Nynex, BellSouth
description: The Nynex Corporation and the BellSouth Corporation yesterday reported modestly higher earnings for the fourth quarter and the full year.

title: Profit Up 14.1% At McDonald's
description: The McDonald's Corporation said today that its profit for the fourth quarter of 1987 rose 14.1 percent over the period a year earlier.

title: British Back Guilt of 6, Upsetting Irish
description: After one of Britain's most politically sensitive judicial reviews, a three-judge court today upheld the convictions of six men for the murder of 21 people in the bombing of a Birmingham pub in 1974.

title: Art: Works by Richard Artschwager
description: THE Richard Artschwager retrospective, a survey of 25 years of art, looks wonderful installed in the big fourth-floor galleries of the Whitney Museum of American Art, and it also looks fresh and informative. This is no mean feat for an artist of Mr. Artschwager's popularity. Throughout the 1960's, his idiosyncratic, multifaceted work hovered in the vicinity of Pop, Minimalism and Photo-Realism without ever requesting permission to land. A master of the reconstructed readymade, an assiduous manipulator of appropriated images, forms and uningratiating, non-art materials (often within the same hybridized painting-sculpture), Mr. Artschwager established himself as a free agent, a jack-of-all-trades.

title: FIRST SOURCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $995,000 from the unrealized appreciation of an investment portfolio.

title: Klaus Fuchs, Physicist Who Gave Atom Secrets to Soviet, Dies at 76
description: Klaus Fuchs, the German-born physicist who was imprisoned in the 1950's in Britain after being convicted of passing nuclear secrets to the Soviet Union, died yesterday, the East German press agency A.D.N. reported. He was 76 years old.

title: FILM: FROM GERMANY, 'SINGING THE BLUES IN RED'
description: AT the age of 40, Klaus Drittemann, a writer and performer of protest songs, is given a one-way visa to leave East Germany for the West. Klaus has been in trouble with the authorities ever since the 1960's. He's a bristly character and has been a merciless critic of the East German Government for failures to realize its Marxist aspirations.

title: INTERLAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,835,000. The latest quarter included charges of $27.5 million for restructuring of certain of Interlake's operations and other exceptional cost items, included net of $38.5 million from overfunded pension plans. The 1987 year net is after the fourth quarter charges of $27.5 million.

title: Elizabeth S. Kean, 90, Mother of Governor
description: Elizabeth S. Kean, the mother of Governor Kean, died early today at her home in Livingston. She was 90 years old and had been ill for a month.

title: Roger DeKoven Dies; Diverse Actor Was 81
description: Roger DeKoven, an actor who appeared in roles as diverse as Edmund, in Erwin Piscator's modern staging of ''King Lear,'' and Florenz Ziegfeld Jr., in the Broadway musical ''Funny Girl,'' died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Vatican Leader Questions Some Bible Scholarship
description: The Vatican's chief keeper of the faith raised some sharp questions Wednesday and yesterday about modern methods of studying the Bible, but at the same time he showed himself to be no friend to biblical fundamentalism.

title: Grey Said to Be Agency For Olympic Coins
description: The word around the street is that Grey Advertising, which knows a thing or two about the marketing of gold and silver, has been selected by the Treasury to promote its Olympic Coins, which will be available in both precious metals. Reports also have it that the billings will be $20 million.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about Secretary of State George P. Shultz's plans to meet with two Palestinians, and a correction in this space yesterday, misidentified a speaker for an event to be held tomorrow at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Manhattan.

title: 'The Great Correction'
description: The President's Council of Economic Advisers isn't saying much about its examination of the stock market's drubbing on Oct. 19 that it will discuss in next month's Economic Report of the President for 1988. It is safe to assume though that it the council sees little need for tight restraints on trading because the chairman, Beryl W. Sprinkel, is a dedicated free-marketeer. A chapter of the report assesses the 508-point one-day rout of the Dow and its impact on the nation's economy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a campaign appearance by Vice President Bush misstated the circumstances of a 1986 meeting he had in Israel. It was held while the United States was selling arms to Iran, not before the sales began.

title: MIDDLE SOUTH UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior-year results are restated to reflect the impact of the writeoff of costs disallowed for rate recovery related to the company's Louisiana Power & Light Co. unit's Waterford 3 Nuclear Plant.

title: Antonin Himl, Czechoslovak Politician, 54
description: Sports Minister Antonin Himl, a member of the Communist Party Central Committee, died of a stroke in Beijing on Wednesday while visiting China with a sports delegation. He was 54 years old.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BARNES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year included a one-time $2.9 million charge for the company's engine valve spring modernization program.

title: Israeli General Describes Charges Of Brutal Beatings as 'Just Stories'
description: A top Israeli general said today that beatings of Palestinian civilians by troops were ''exceptions'' to Government policy and that many of the widespread complaints of brutality were rooted in ''imagination.''

title: BELLSOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Raymond Williams, British Writer, 66, Dies
description: Raymond Williams, a cultural historian and critic who championed the arts for the working class and taught at Cambridge and Oxford universities, died on Tuesday at his home here. He was 66 years old.

title: PACIFIC INLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Art: 2 Gallery Shows On Marsden Hartley
description: AMONG the early American modernists who were a part of Alfred Stieglitz's circle, Marsden Hartley has attracted an especially healthy dose of attention in recent years. He was the subject of a major retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 1980 and of several smaller shows since, including two now. The Vanderwoude Tananbaum Gallery has hung 16 works from the artist's last decade, 1933-43. And the display of 44 paintings and drawings at Salander-O'Reilly Galleries is roughly half the size of a Hartley exhibition mounted in the same space three years ago but covers similar ground. The two shows outline the essential phases of a singular artist's career.

title: Welfare 'Rights' vs. Children's Rights
description: Supporters of welfare rights assail as ''punitive'' child support provisions in Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's constructive welfare reform bill. The criticism is shortsighted. The support provisions are essential to a plan that could put unemployed fathers to work and help repair broken families.

title: Vatican and the AIDS Fight: Amid Worry, Papal Reticence
description: Pope John Paul II, who has spoken out on many sensitive issues of sexual ethics, has not addressed the campaigns under way in many parts of the world to help prevent the spread of AIDS by promoting ''safe sex'' and specifically the use of condoms.

title: APOLLO COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Icahn Hints at Strategy
description: Carl C. Icahn, the largest shareholder of Texaco Inc., told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that he might join with a third party to buy more Texaco stock.

title: Time Runs Out at Old Car Plant
description: A sword has been hanging for years over the giant automobile factory here - the oldest operating auto-assembly plant in the country. The sword fell Wednesday when the Chrysler Corporation announced plans to close most of its Kenosha operations by the end of the 1988 model year.

title: Income Up Only 1.2% Last Year
description: Americans' after-tax incomes grew a sluggish 1.2 percent last year, the poorest showing since the last recession, while their savings rate in 1987 fell to a 40-year low, the Government reported today.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Eclipse Award Election Needs Reform
description: The system for electing thoroughbred racing's Horse of the Year clearly needs revamping - not because Ferdinand won by so narrow a margin when the results were announced Wednesday, but because only one vote kept him from unfairly losing the title.

title: Earnings Jump At Time Inc.
description: Time Inc.'s net income more than quadrupled in the fourth quarter, to $52 million, or 88 cents a share, from $12 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier. The company took a charge of $63 million, or 55 cents a share, in 1986's fourth quarter to cover the cost of staff cuts. Revenues rose 9.7 percent, to $1.14 billion, from $1.03 billion a year earlier.

title: FIRST AMERICAN SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reduction equal to 9 cents per share by the one-time writeoff for the company's contribution to the secondary reserve of the FSLIC.

title: Fear of Lending
description: To the Editor:

title: AFFILIATED BANK CORPORATION-WYOING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After provision for loan losses of $628,000 for the quarter and $2,486,000 for the year. c-After provision for loan losses of $5,734,000 for the quarter and $19,162,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: CONTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company in the latest quarter recorded $204.3 million in pre-tax charges associated with writeoffs and writedowns of certain assets, and the disposition of certain other assets. The 1987 results reflect $34.7 million of net after-tax loss from discontinued operations, associated with the operations and the disposition of Executone. The prior year results have been restated to include companies subsequently acquired on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Strike Issues Still Unresolved
description: Gene Upshaw, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said today that he was willing to resume negotiations at any time to achieve a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Hempstead Churches to Shelter Homeless
description: The leaders of a dozen churches in this Nassau County village said today that they had formed an emergency assistance network for homeless people that would use church buildings as shelters.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Nueva Generacion

title: 2 Film Companies Set Stock Merger
description: The New Century Entertainment Corporation, a publicly owned film company that had losses of $6 million in the first nine months of 1987, said it had agreed to a stock merger with New Vision Inc., a private, independent production company responsible for ''La Bamba'' and other films.

title: Theater: 'Hedda Gabler'
description: In his stage directions for ''Hedda Gabler,'' Ibsen calls for the Tesman drawing room to be decorated with bouquets of flowers, in celebration of Hedda's wedding. For the opening scene of his production at the Hartford Stage Company, Mark Lamos festoons the stage with bouquets, not as a sign of beauty but of the airlessness that is pervasive, of the decay that has already begun to infect the marriage.

title: Council Backs Housing Order In Yonkers
description: After nearly five hours of being denounced by residents as wimps, liars, snakes and ''masters of deceit,'' the City Council voted early this morning to obey a Federal court order to build low-income housing in predominantly white neighborhoods.

title: Seattle Journal; Downtown Epidemic Of Growing Pains
description: On a recent visit to Seattle, the New York humorist Fran Lebowitz was asked what she thought of the city. ''It's cute,'' she replied. ''Why are they tearing it down?''

title: Art Show at Armory
description: ''Art at the Armory,'' an exhibition of paintings, drawings, prints and sculpture from the late 19th century to the present, will continue through Sunday at the Lexington Avenue Armory, at 25th Street. More than 50 galleries from the United States, Canada and Europe are to exhibit about 1,500 works, among them paintings by Picasso, Matisse, Renoir, Picasso, Dali and O'Keeffe. Hours are today and tomorrow, noon to 9:30 P.M. and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Perot, in an Article, Takes a Jab at G.M.
description: H. Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire not known to mince words or turn down a good platform for speaking them, audaciously tells ''How I Would Turn Around G.M.'' in the issue of Fortune magazine that comes out Monday.

title: Norway Joblessness Up
description: Unemployment in Norway, which has one of the lowest levels of joblessness in the West, rose 25 percent in January, to 42,600 from 31,500. The rate, however, is still at only 2 percent of the working population.

title: XEROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $51 million provision for additional reserves at Industrial Indemnity Financial Corp., which was discontinued in 1985. c-Includes a $65 million loss from discontinued operations, a $42 million gain from a change in accounting for pensions, and a $12 million charge and a $2 million operating loss related to the sale of Century Data Systems. d-Increased by $21 million from federal tax-rate changes applicable to Xerox Credit's leveraged lease portfolio. There were no discontinued operations in the latest fourth quarter and year.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sisters of Charity Hospital Offering
description: Sisters of Charity Health Care Systems yesterday offered $190 million of refunding revenue bonds for five hospitals in Colorado and Ohio through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company. All of the bonds are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation and are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.

title: Slower Spending And Fed's Policy
description: THE American economy grew faster in the final quarter of 1987 than most economists expected. But since most of the gain was due to an unintended surge of inventories, a sharp slowdown in the economy appears to be in the works. While it is not yet the general view, some economists think a 1988 recession may have begun.

title: Whose Bloated Staff?
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder has a bone to pick with a Reagan Administration official over the size and role of Congressional staffs.

title: Two Yale Unions Ratify 4-Year Pacts
description: Two unions representing 3,600 Yale University employees yesterday approved a four-year contract with annual salary increases of six percent.

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $5 million from a from an increase in its inventory valuation due to its LIFO accounting methods and includes a pretax charge of $50 million for a special employee separation program. c-Includes a pretax gain of $27 million and $212 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from asset disposition; pretax charges of $15 million and $114 million for the same periods, respectively, from an employee separation program; an $18 million charge related to its mineral operations for both periods; and for the year includes a pretax gain from retirement plan restructuring of $275 million.

title: People
description: * Clark Hine, formerly of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Chicago, joining Quaker Oats U.S. Grocery Products as vice president, advertising.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Recalling Mingus

title: EQUIFAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: The latest year includes revenue of $8,917,000 and net income of $5,620,000, or 39 cents a share, from the sale of an 80 percent subsidiary, Communications & Cable Inc., and certain interest in recreation leases to Communications & Cable.

title: Plan for Highway Through Amish Region Is Killed in Pennsylvania
description: Declaring that the life and traditions of Pennsylvania's Amish ''should not be destroyed or dislocated or interrupted,'' Gov. Robert P. Casey has killed a proposal to build a superhighway through the heart of the Amish country in Lancaster County.

title: Film: 'Mammame,' Tribe of Dancers
description: ''MAMMAME,'' which will be seen in its first New York screenings today and tomorrow at Film Forum 2, is the work of Raul Ruiz, the Chilean expatriate film director, and Jean-Claude Gallotta, the French experimentalist choreographer. Mr. Ruiz is a surrealist. Mr. Gallotta is a fabulist. And the surprisingly immediate private worlds of these two enfants terribles of the arts are complementary here.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JANUARY 29, 1988
description: International A2-9, B6

title: Accounts
description: * Warnaco to Wells, Rich, Greene for Valentino Intimo intimate apparel.

title: A Weinberger Memoir
description: Warner Books will publish Caspar Weinberger's first-hand account of his years as Secretary of Defense, from 1980 to 1987. Mr. Weinberger will personally write the book, which has no title yet, according to the publisher, which acquired it at auction for a reported high six figures. It is scheduled for publication next year.

title: Restaurants
description: ''ARE there any New Yorkers in this place?'' asked a fellow diner one evening as we sat in the Crystal Room at Tavern on the Green, Manhattan's gastronomic Xanadu where every day is a holiday and the Christmas lights never come down.

title: Cuomo Proposals Will Simplify Rent-Regulation Procedures
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: CONSIDERING the sizable demand for vegetarian fare in New York, there are few places around that make an effort to be distinctive in either ambiance or food. A happy new exception is the Health Pub, a cheerful vegetarian cafe at 371 Second Avenue, at 21st Street. The two large dining rooms are crisp and tidy, done in soft beige with butcher-block tables.

title: Photo one of 30 autographed Mark Twain items to be auctioned Monday by Christie's Auctions
description: Twain's Typewriter

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Guy F. Atkinson Co., South San Francisco, Calif., which is involved in construction, steel fabrication and makes pumps and heavy machinery, appointed Robert D. Langford senior vice president, chief legal officer and corporate secretary. Mr. Langford succeeds Bryant K. Zimmerman, who becomes senior legal counsel, in anticipation of his retirement.

title: The 'March of Folly' in Further Contra Aid
description: In her classic book ''The March of Folly,'' the historian Barbara Tuchman notes the compulsion of national leaders all through history to behave woodenheadedly - that is, to follow policies contrary to those indicated by good sense and enlightened self-interest. Calling Philip II of Spain ''the surpassing woodenhead of all sovereigns,'' she observes, ''No experience of the failure of his policy could shake his belief in its essential excellence.''

title: Bush's Role in Iran Affair: Questions and Answers
description: If Vice President Bush benefited from his televised confrontation with Dan Rather on Monday night, he also paid a price.

title: The Impact In Westchester
description: For residents of Westchester County, where I.B.M. is a dominant corporate presence, yesterday's restructuring announcement came after two years of retrenchment.

title: Omni Ensemble
description: The Omni Ensemble, a New York chamber-music group, will play Messiaen's ''Quartet for the End of Time,'' Elliott Carter's ''Esprit Rude/Esprit Doux'' for flute and clarinet, Weber's Trio for Flute, Cello and Piano, and Edward Smaldone's Double Duo for Flute, Clarinet, Violin and Cello, Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, 58 Seventh Avenue, in Park Slope. Tickets are $6, or $4 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 622-3300.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $2,588,000 for the quarter from discontinued finance operations and a loss of $83,000 from discontinued operations for the year. c-Included gains from discontinued finance operations of $567,000 for the quarter and $5,446,000 for the year.

title: Minor Candidate Gets U.S. Funds; Decision on LaRouche Is Delayed
description: The Federal Election Commission today grappled with whether to grant public matching funds to Presidential campaigns of two minor candidates who received donations from people who the commission feared might not have realized they were contributing to a political campaign.

title: Ballet: Suzanne Farrell Returns, in 'Waltzes'
description: SUZANNE FARRELL made a triumphant return to the New York City Ballet Wednesday night when she swept through George Balanchine's ''Vienna Waltzes'' at the New York State Theater.

title: Albany Split as It Tries To Solve Garbage Crisis
description: Stressing the need for quick action, the Governor, the State Assembly and the State Senate have each drawn up comprehensive legislation to deal with New York State's garbage crisis. But the proposals indicate that so far the only point the three parties agree on is the urgency of the problem.

title: Aircraft Maker Recounts Paying $25,000 to Nofziger for Lobbying
description: Lyn Nofziger's lobbying firm received $25,000 from a military contractor a day before prosecutors say the former White House aide urged government officials to continue production of a warplane, according to testimony today at Mr. Nofziger's trial.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HERITAGE-NIS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $845,000. c-Restated to conform with general accounting principles. The company went public in October 1986.

title: Bulgaria Parley Is Foretaste Of a Scaling Down of Change
description: The Bulgarian Communist Party, which startled the rest of the Soviet camp last year by moving to change its Government, society and economy, opened a special conference today that signified a sharp scaling down of its initiatives.

title: New York's Three-Musician Limit For Clubs Is Held Unconstitutional
description: A New York City law that sets a limit of three musicians on stage at a time in many of the city's clubs and cabarets is unconstitutional because it abridges the First Amendment rights of composers and performers, a judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Detroit Tigers have offered Kirk Gibson a one-year contract extension with a no-trade clause, according to Greg Shea, a team spokesman, who refused to specify details of the offer. Gibson, one of seven players declared a free agent until March 1 by an arbitrator last week, is being pursued by the Los Angeles Dodgers and is entering the final year of a contract with Detroit that will pay him $1.3 million in 1988. . . . Jimmy Howard, who holds the American indoor and outdoor records in the men's high jump, has joined the field for the Panasonic Millrose Games next Friday at Madison Square Garden. . . . A member of the United States' four-member Nordic combined ski team, Pat Ahern of Breckenridge, Colo., fell and broke his hip while skiing downhill Wednesday and will miss the Olympic Winter Games next month in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Bridge: Jersey Sectional Tournament Takes Idea From Magazine
description: New ideas in tournament planning are none too common, but one will surface today at the New Jersey Bridge League's Winter Sectional at 33 South 21st Street in Kenilworth, N.J.

title: Opening Night Plans For U.S.-Soviet Festival
description: Opening night of Making Music Together, a three-week arts festival to be staged here by American and Soviet performers starting March 11, is to feature Dzhansug Kakhidze, a Soviet conductor, and Maksim Vengerov, a violinist.

title: Dining Out Guide: With Music
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMBASSADOR GRILL, 1 United Nations Plaza, First Avenue at 44th Street (355-3400) - *(Oct. 3, 1986) Music soothes the savage beast and might make digestion easier as well. A number of restaurants feature music during dinner or at a cocktail lounge before and after dining. Piano music is featured nightly as well as during Sunday brunch at this urbane East Side spot. Half the menu here is devoted to the foods of Gascony in southwest France, and starters include warm duck foie gras with quince; lobster ragout with baby vegetables, and warm shrimp salad with lemon-basil vinaigrette. For a main course, you might try poached salmon paupiette with a vermouth-tinged cream sauce; braised free-range chicken with sweet-and-sour gooseberry sauce; grilled brochette of duck breast with mushrooms, or cassoulet with duck meat. Three-course dinner prix fixe $27. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Sundays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M. ENCORE ENCORE, 318 West 45th Street (489-6100) - *(Jan. 1, 1988) The black walls, pinpoint lighting and giant bar make this restaurant in the theater district look like an after-hours music club. The tightly organized and reasonably priced menu is basically American, and live music is featured several nights a week. For starters, there is a briny plate of steamed mussels in saffron broth; woody wild mushroom ravioli garnished with grilled shiitake mushrooms, and a light scallop flan with truffle juice. Entree options include roasted chicken with shiitake mushrooms and sweet-potato chips; rack of lamb with eggplant, couscous and roasted red peppers, and fricassee of lobster with Sauternes and ginger. Dinner entrees $14 to $22. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 5:30 P.M. to midnight. RUSSIAN SAMOVAR, 256 West 52d Street (757-0168) - *(March 6, 1987) During dinner hours on weekends, this comfortable midtown restaurant offers a pianist and a singer andguitarist; and on weeknights a singer and pianist entertains. The menu includes a standard repertory of Russian dishes. Recommended appetizers are eggplant samovar, which is thin sheets of grilled eggplant sprinkled with coriander and ground walnuts; thinly sliced strips of spicy Georgian dried beef rubbed with hot paprika, and chicken-liver terrine bolstered with Cognac. Main-dish options are chicken Kiev; karsky shashlik, the marinated lamb chops charred outside and juicy within, and salmon shashlik, cubes of cooked salmon in a light white-wine sauce with dill-seasoned potatoes and onions. Pre-theater dinner prix fixe $19.95; entrees $12.75 to $18.95. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 4 to 11 P.M. TRUMPET'S, Grand Hyatt, 109 East 42d Street (850-5999) - *(Oct. 2, 1987) The extravagant space between tables contributes to the appeal of this softly lighted and comfortable restaurant, which offers piano music during dinner nightly. You might begin with slices of seared ahi tuna with three Japanese sauces; pate of wild game, and medallions of cold poached salmon. Among the entrees are pecan-breaded chicken breast with apricot-apple chutney; stuffed loin of lamb with spinach and feta cheese, and tournedos of beef with mustard and horseradish sauce. Dinner entrees $21 to $27. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. VILLAGE GREEN, 531 Hudson Street, at Charles Street (255-1650) - **(Sept. 25, 1987) This romantic split-level restaurant with its small brick-and-wood dining room downstairs has a handsome old bar upstairs that features a jazz duo Tuesdays through Saturdays until 2 A.M. The American menu is manageable in size, and starters include wild game stew with mushrooms and leeks; thinly sliced salmon with basil and creme fraiche, and steamed Pacific clams with potato, fennel and parsley puree. For a main course, you might try pan-roasted spicy moulard duck breast with plums and sauteed greens; roasted loin of lamb stuffed with spinach and crusted with mustard and herbs, or baked brook trout with sorrel puree, fennel and shiitake mushrooms. Entrees $21 to $26. Fridays through Sundays, 6 to 11:30 P.M. What the stars mean, page C20.

title: SONAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $320,000 and $25,945,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations; the year includes $23 million from the sale of the company's marine transportation business and $14 million from the sale of Timberlands acquired in the disposition of the company's forest products joint venture. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $8,941,000 and $8,874,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year reflects a $367 million after-tax effect of charges related to restructuring the company, settling natural gas supply contract disputes, revaluation of oil and gas properties and certain other nonrecurring items.

title: Allegis Posts Loss; Delta Off
description: Two major airlines reported mixed results for the fourth quarter yesterday with the Allegis Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, reporting a large operating loss that it blamed on severe winter weather while Delta Air Lines Inc, showed an operating gain attributed to higher fares.

title: NEW-MUSIC OFFERINGS FOR ADVENTUROUS EARS
description: IN previous centuries, audiences expected new music; anything older than a decade or two was considered ''ancient'' or in desperate need of modernization, as with Mozart's reorchestration of Handel's ''Messiah.''

title: Perles Staying Put
description: Even the possibility of someday earning a fifth Super Bowl ring could not break the loyalty of Coach George Perles to Michigan State University. So the head coach of the Spartans, who earned about $200,000 for leading Michigan State to its first Rose Bowl victory in 22 years, has turned down an offer to coach the Green Bay Packers for five years for a reported $1.8 million. Perles was defensive assistant for the Pittsburgh Steelers from 1972 to 1981 when they turned four Super Bowl appearances into victories.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago periods are on a pro forma basis. The company said that on a pro forma basis, the latest periods nets would have been $75 million, or $1.09 a share, for the quarter and $250 million, or $3.62 a share, for the year. The results for the year 1987 included an after-tax credit of $22 million, or 32 cents a share, resulting from a required pension accounting change. The net income on a pro forma basis represents actual reported net income for the 1987 and 1986 periods adjusted for the effects of the cancelled benefits, as if their cancellation had occurred at the beginning of 1986.

title: Piano-Bass Duo
description: The duo of Jack Wilson on piano and Santi DeBriano on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:45; there is no cover charge or minimum.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Agreed to terms with Spike Owen, shortstop; Brady Anderson, outfielder; Pat Dodson, first baseman; Dan Gabriele, pitcher, and Randy Kutcher, infielder. CLEVELAND (AL) - Named Paul Olden radio announcer. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Agreed to terms with Mike Marshall, outfielder, and Ken Howell, pitcher, on one-year contracts. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Sent Roger Mason, pitcher, outright to Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League. BASKETBALL PORTLAND (NBA) - Placed Steve Johnson, center, on injured reserve. HOCKEY MINNESOTA (NBA) - Announced the resignation of Lou Nanne, general manager, effective when a replacement is named.

title: Spinks-Tyson Called Unlikely
description: Shelly Finkel, the fight manager who this week joined the negotiations for a Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks bout, said yesterday that he was not optimistic that the match would take place.

title: THE LAW: AT THE BAR
description: Lawyers are reluctant to ask judges to recuse themselves - to step down from a given case - and it's easy to understand why. Such motions are rarely granted, and if one is denied, an attorney can find himself before a judge fuming over the implication that he's anything but even-handed and judicious.

title: Jackson to Skip Debate Among the Democrats
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson abruptly canceled all campaign appearances for Friday afternoon and Saturday and will skip a South Dakota Democratic debate because he needs some rest, a spokeswoman said today.

title: Investor Sells Stake
description: A member of the investment group Ivanhoe Partners, which sought control of the Newmont Mining Corporation last fall, has withdrawn from the partnership and sold his stake in the New York-based energy and minerals company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, John M. Harbert 3d, the owner of the Harbert Corporation of Birmingham, Ala., said he had sold 1.6 million Newmont shares for $34 a share. The filing contained no reason for the sale.

title: Physicians Can't Be Selfless Entrepreneurs
description: To the Editor:

title: Older People's Group Forces Out Chief
description: The American Association of Retired Persons, the nation's most influential voice on issues affecting the elderly, has forced the resignation of its new executive director amid disagreement over the philosophy and finances of the organization.

title: COURT IN CANADA RULES ON ABORTION
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Canada's restrictive abortion law unconstitutionally interferes with a woman's right to control her own body.

title: EMPIRE OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $375,000. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $2 million for the quarter and $33,807,000 for the year. d-Includes an extraordinary gain of $5,125,000. The company said that 1987 earnings were after a one-time charge of $5 million from the elimination of their FSLIC secondary reserve fund, and after a second quarter loss of $6.3 million in loans sold or held for sale. Also, the latest quarter results include a $3.9 million writedown on real estate acquired in the settlement of loans. The company said that 1986 results include a gain of $21.8 million from a transaction with the FSLIC.

title: DRUG DEALER SAYS HE GAVE NORIEGA 'MILLIONS' IN BRIBES
description: A convicted American drug smuggler told Senate investigators today that he gave ''millions of dollars'' in cash and kickbacks to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the army commander of Panama, for his help in drug deals and illegal money laundering.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $47,400,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Music: The Cleveland
description: AT age 74, Witold Lutoslawski remains the most consistently interesting of the band of avant-gardists who emerged from the social and political upheavals of Poland after World War II. Like many composers of his generation from whatever country, he likes music made of angular lines, off-center rhythms, systematic atonality and structural formulas. As if to counterbalance the rigidity inherent in such a scheme, Mr. Lutoslawski has often added a pinch of anarchy in the form of aleatoric or chance techniques, allowing performers choices within a carefully controlled context.

title: Bush-Kemp Alliance Passes First Test in Michigan
description: The new alliance between Vice President Bush and Representative Jack F. Kemp has passed its first test, a 12-hour session to settle credentials challenges for the Republican state convention that begins Friday.

title: Patterson's Board Drops Its Case Against Clark, but Orders Inquiry
description: The Paterson Board of Education tonight voided its insubordination proceedings against Joe Clark, the principal of Eastside High School, but directed two schools officials to investigate the expulsion of 66 students by Mr. Clark last month and to recommend what action, if any, to take against him.

title: Love Ahead by 3 Shots
description: The only thing Davis Love 3d may enjoy doing on a golf course more than letting out shaft on his big drives is sinking those pesky little putts that so often elude the best golfers.

title: ONE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $508,000 for the quarter and $1,983,000 for the year. c-After a reversal of tax credits of $793,000. Year-ago results were restated to reflect the acquisition of BAnk of Hartford on a pooling-of-interest method.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday HISTORIC THEORIES

title: DUN & BRADSTREET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter included a pre-tax charge of $35.3 million from restructuring, compared with $50,684,000 for year-ago period.

title: Don't Be Bullied by School Custodians
description: New York City's public school custodians wield such excessive power that it warps administration of the whole school system. The custodians have reigned unchallenged for so long that cutting them down to size won't be easy. Yet that task remains essential to meaningful school reform.

title: Film: 'You Can't Hurry Love'
description: ''YOU Can't Hurry Love,'' opening today at the Gemini and other theaters, is a very dim comedy about how funny and peculiar sunny Los Angeles is supposed to be to a square young man from Akron.

title: WHY DO ASIAN PUPILS WIN THOSE PRIZES?
description: LEAD: The newspaper photograph showing the smiling faces of 11 students from Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Bayside, Queens, who were semifinalists in the prestigious national Westinghouse science awards competition is arresting. All 11 are Asian, though the high school principal chooses to characterize them as 10 Asians and one

title: Margeottes/Fertitta Wins Business Week
description: McGraw-Hill's Business Week magazine has assigned its trade advertising to Margeottes/Fertitta & Weiss. The account, which has a budget of $2 million, was formerly served by the Edwin Bird Willson agency.

title: Judge Sets Limits On Child Aid Society
description: The Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children has been ordered not to say it is a police agency or a state agency and has been forbidden to lock up suspects.

title: POLICE OFFICER DIES AS SIEGE ENDS IN POLYGAMISTS' ARREST
description: A burst of gunfire ended a 13-day standoff today between a polygamist clan and the police. An officer was killed and the group's leader was seriously wounded.

title: CRONKITE TESTIFIES AT TRIAL
description: Walter Cronkite, a retired anchor for CBS news, who is an avid yachtsman, testified today in the trial of an alleged leader of cocaine smuggling network that he was once shooed away from a Bahamiam island that prosecutors say was used as a way station by the smugglers. He testified that he often visited Norman's Cay on his Christmas vacations. His testimony came in the trial of the alleged leader of the operaton, Carlos Lehder Rivas, 38 years old, and a co-defendant, Jack Carlton Reed, 57, who are accused of conspiring to import 3.3 tons of cocaine into the United States from Colombia.

title: KEY RATES
Precedent for Lower Courts: Tyrant or Teacher?
description: To say that judges of lower courts follow precedent has long been a maxim seemingly unworthy of debate in the American legal system. But that unquestioned belief suddenly lies at the heart of the next round in the battle over the Federal judiciary.

title: Theater: Pearl Troupe In Sophocles' 'Electra'
description: WHATEVER else one may say about the Pearl Theater Company, which has taken on the classics since its beginnings in 1984, it does not do things by halves. This season, it has already come to grips with Shakespeare (''Macbeth''), Moliere (''The Imaginary Invalid'') and Shaw (''Candida'') and is readying itself for Chekhov (''Uncle Vanya''). One may admire the young troupe's reach, yet come away from its current stab at Sophocles' ''Electra'' with the feeling that despite thoughtful planning and imaginative use of a modest budget, it has overreached or reached in the wrong direction.

title: DELTA AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains of $50,827,000 for the quarter and $50,916,000 for the 6 months from the sale of aircraft. The latest 6 months' net included a gain of $411,000 from disposition of aircraft.

title: At the Movies
description: Turning '50'

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Chief of Cuisinarts Banking on Its Cachet
description: LEAD: Cachet, the elusive quality that sells perfumes and sports cars, rarely settles on utilitarian products, but when it does, investors like George K. Barnes take notice.

title: Despite It All, Poland Rocks
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Rebate Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had added the Chevrolet Nova to its buyer-incentive programs by offering a $1,200 cash rebate to buyers who own an imported car and a $600 rebate to others. The Nova is made by New United Motor Manufacturing Industries of Fremont, Calif., a G.M. venture with the Toyota Motor Corporation.

title: LAFARGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIN BROADCASTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $862,000 and a gain on sales of $31,125,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $782,000 for the quarter and $3,156,000 for the year and gains on sales of a paging business and radio stations of $12,301,000 for the quarter and $20,702,000 for the year; the year also included the cumulative effect of an accounting change for investment tax credits of $2.4 million.

title: Metropolitan Soloists
description: The Metropolitan Soloists, a Manhattan-based wind chamber group, will play an all-French concert tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock at the Lincoln Center Performing Arts Library. The group will play works by d'Indy, Milhaud, Eugene Goossens, Francois-Joseph Gossec and F. H. J. Castile-Blaze. Admission is free. Information: 795-9340. The concert will be repeated Feb. 7 at 2:30 P.M. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d

title: Shearson Adds Hutton's Name
description: When the rest of Wall Street was consolidating in the late 1970's, E. F. Hutton had boldly advertised itself as a firm that ''after 74 years still has one name.'' No longer. Shearson Lehman

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $8,522,000 from revaluation of deferred income taxes.

title: Retin-A's Impact On Johnson Stock
description: AN old product with new and potentially profitable applications can excite investors, especially when the maker of the product is an established company that has not had anything new and hot in some time.

title: Bethlehem Profit Spurts
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has reported that its income more than doubled in the fourth quarter, to $71.5 million, from $34.2 million a year earlier.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: Landmark by Acclaim?

title: Donor to the Neediest Cases Seeks to Aid Victims of Crime
description: An appeal to aid victims of crime was received recently by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Prestige's Super Bowl Magazine
description: THIS Sunday 4.5 million newspapers in 13 top markets will be carrying Super Bowl XXII The Official Home Viewer's Guide, a slick standard-sized magazine that if nothing else will certainly be timely.

title: Rights Monitors at a Protest By Group of Jews in Moscow
description: More than 100 Soviet Jews seeking exit visas demonstrated in Moscow today in a large and peaceful protest attended by members of an international human rights group.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Following the Account
description: An interesting aspect of the ad agency business is the way certain people follow accounts from agency to agency. A most stunning example of that is at the Los Angeles office of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, whose new president and chief executive, Eugene F. Cameron, 42, followed the Apple Computer account in from Chiat/Day. As did the new chief creative officer, Stephen E. Hayden, 40, who is also the agency creator of the stunning, internationally acclaimed ''1984'' TV spot for the Macintosh introduction that made its debut during the Super Bowl four years ago. Donald C. Mitchum, the former head of the office, is already ensconced as president and chief operating officer of BDA/BBDO, Atlanta. Mr. Cameron, who started with Scott Paper in Philadelphia, rolled west for a job at Ogilvy & Mather, then in 1977 hopped to Chiat/Day.

title: Koch Panel to Offer Project Design Guidelines
description: Mayor Koch has formed a committee to recommend design guidelines for publicly sponsored development projects.

title: Stop and Shop Bid
description: The Stop and Shop Companies said its board had rejected the Dart Group's $30-a-share takeover offer. The board decided that it was in the best interest of the company to remain independent, Stop and Shop said. The retailer's shares fell 37.5 cents today, to close at $31.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS BANK OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,613,000 for the quarter and $24,358,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $6,193,000 for the quarter and $21,711,000 for the year.

title: ARVIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 per-share new were lower because of additional preferred and common shares issued during the first quarter of the year.

title: College Basketball; Wake Forest Stuns Tar Heels by 83-80
description: David Carlyle led a second-half comeback that was capped by Sam Ivy's two free throws with three seconds remaining as Wake Forest upset third-ranked North Carolina, 83-80, tonight.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HAMPTON HEAT. By Irving Weinman. 225 pages. Atheneum. $17.95 LOVER AND THIEF. By Arthur Maling. 230 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95. A PARAMOUNT KILL. By Gaylord Larsen. 211 pages. E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: ALLEGHENY LUDLUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: The year-ago periods' earnings are not comparable because of recapitalization effected Dec. 28, 1986. The results for the latest periods included a change in accounting for income taxes which increased earnings by 1 cent a share in the fourth quarter and 7 cents a share for the year. In addition, each of the three previously reported quarters will be restated to reflect an increase of about 2 cents a share.

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge from a tax credit adjustment of $1 million for the quarter and year.

title: Vote Set on Judge Kennedy
description: The Senate will vote next Wednesday on Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's nominee to the Supreme Court, the office of Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, announced today. The vote will follow about one hour of floor speeches. Judge Kennedy received unanimous approval from the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday. No Senator has announced opposition to the Federal appellate judge from Sacramento, Calif.

title: DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $2 million for the quarter and $5 million for the year from extinguishment of debt. c-After charges of $1 million for the quarter and $9 million for the year from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Nuggets' Natt Arrested
description: Calvin Natt of the Denver Nuggets was one of about 60 people arrested in a police ''sting'' operation in Aurora, Colo., that used an escort service to draw sexual solicitations, the police said yesterday. Natt, 31 years old, was arrested Jan. 15, according to Mary Schumacher, a spokeswoman for the Aurora police. Natt, a 6-foot-6-inch forward, immediately called a news conference to apologize, saying, ''I am terribly embarrassed for any discomfort that this could bring to my wife or to the Denver Nuggets because I love and respect both of them as well as all of my fans and people who have supported me.'' Natt has been in the National Basketball Association for eight seasons, the last four with Denver. An injured left knee has kept him out of 22 of Denver's 39 games this season. Nugget team officials declined to comment on the incident, but said Natt would remain on the team.

title: Lindsay Undergoes Heart-Valve Surgery
description: Former New York City Mayor John V. Lindsay underwent surgery Wednesday to repair a leaky heart valve and was in critical but stable condition yesterday, officials at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center said.

title: Amtrak Train Derails South of Philadelphia
description: An Amtrak train carrying about 130 people derailed 15 miles south of Philadelphia early this morning, causing some injuries.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are no agreements or disagreements.'' - Jaime Morales Carazo, negotiator for the Nicaraguan rebels. [ A3:4. ]

title: Waning Days Cast New Glow Over White House
description: Nancy Reagan, sitting in the Capitol Monday night watching her husband deliver his State of the Union Address, was touched by the moment. This performance, so familiar after six re-runs, was making its final appearance on national television.

title: Santa Fe Off $1.75 a Share
description: Shares of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation fell $1.75, to $45.75, yesterday in the wake of Wednesday's announcement that the company would pay stockholders a dividend of $30 a share, or $4.7 billion. The payout came a week after the Henley Group, which owns nearly 15 percent of Santa Fe, said it was considering a proxy fight.

title: Jay Hoggard
description: Jay Hoggard, a vibraphonist, is leading a group tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum. Tonight's first set will be broadcast by WKCR, 89.9 FM.

title: Pretoria Challenged on Apartheid Foe's Death
description: An anti-apartheid church leader challenged the Pretoria Government today to prove that it had not murdered an 18-year-old anti-apartheid student leader who was found shot dead in Soweto on Monday.

title: Counterpoints to Catch the Fancy
description: Clients at couture houses, where prices this season generally run to five figures, usually have a good collection of precious jewelry to complement their clothes. Still, designers pay attention to the accessories they choose at their openings to carry out the mood of their clothes. This season some of the accessories are memorable. Almost everyone noticed the flat metal earrings in the shape of doves that were worn with sailor hats and plain tailored suits at Yves Saint Laurent. For evening, the same earrings were shown in colored jewels. Marc Bohan's butterfly-shaped earrings were also noteworthy at Dior. Long drop earrings that grazed the shoulders were shown at most houses.

title: Gault on Bobsled Squad
description: Willie Gault, the Chicago Bears wide receiver, was named today to the men's bobsled team that will compete for the United States in the Winter Olympics next month at Calgary.

title: Volvo's Loan Plan
description: Volvo Cars of North America said it would offer buyers 10-year car loans, more than double the period that is customary in the industry. The company said that a survey had indicated that nearly half of its customers intended to keep their cars for at least 10 years.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Nice Core Wins by a Neck: Nice Core raced near the leaders early, went to the front once into the stretch and held on gamely to win by a neck in the $31,000 allowance feature yesterday at Aqueduct. Special Message, one of the outsiders in the field of 12, was the runner-up. Nice Core carried 112 pounds under Carlos Correa for a mile and an eighth on the fast but dull racing strip in 1:54 to win his first race this year. He earned $18,600 for his owner, Gold-N-Oats Stable, and returned $10 for $2 to win as the third choice. N.H.L. Bruins 3, Nordiques 0: Boston's goalie, Reggie Lemelin, playing behind a tough defense, recorded his third shutout of the season as the Bruins won in Boston last night. Lemelin faced only 19 Quebec shots in securing his ninth career shutout. The Bruins had 33 shots on Mario Gosselin. Randy Burridge scored what proved to be the game-winning goal for Boston. He took a pass high in the slot from Bob Sweeney and ripped the puck past Gosselin to give the Bruins a 1-0 lead at 3 minutes 25 seconds of the second period. The victory, Boston's fourth in six games, moved the Bruins (29-18-5) to within a point of the Canadiens for the Adams Division lead. (AP) Blues 9, North Stars 1: Doug Gilmour registered the second three-goal performance of his career and added an assist to lead St. Louis. It was the Blues' fourth straight victory. Six other players scored for St. Louis, which moved into sole possession of second place in the Norris Division. Brian Benning had three assists for the Blues, who outshot Minnesota by 37-21.(AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 109, Rockets 85: Cleveland's Brad Daugherty led a balanced attack with 18 points and the Cavaliers held Houston without a basket during an 11:41 stretch of the second half. The Cavaliers outscored Houston, 23-3, during the Rockets' cold spell, which started with 5:58 left in the third period. Mark Price added 17 points for Cleveland; Phil Hubbard had 16 points and Tyrone Corbin contributed 12 points and 12 rebounds. Akeem Olajuwon led the Rockets with 23 points and 12 rebounds. The Rockets trailed, 68-63, with 2:49 to go in the third quarter, but the Cavaliers took a 77-64 lead into the final period by converting 14 of 15 free throws in the third quarter.(AP)

title: GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2.5 million.

title: Ocean Spray Company Indicted as a Polluter
description: In the first felony indictment of a company under the Clean Water Act, Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. was charged today with polluting the sewer system of a Massachusetts town and a nearby river.

title: New Software Game: It Comes From Soviet
description: As computer games go, it is simple and addictive. Critics say it lacks the guns and explosions and mayhem that appeal to young connoisseurs of American entertainment software, but then, Soviet software is apparently soft-line.

title: ARCO Purchases 14% Of Britain's Tricentrol
description: ARCO said today that it had acquired an interest of 14.6 percent, or about $43.7 million, in Tricentrol P.L.C., an independent British oil company that is fighting an acquisition offer from Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, France's state-owned oil company.

title: Simon Takes Off Gloves But Puts Them Back On
description: Throughout last fall, after jumping to the front of the polls in Iowa and finding an unmistakable link with many of its voters, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois campaigned as the different politician.

title: Robert K. Enders, Professor, 88
description: Robert K. Enders, chairman emeritus of the biology department at Swarthmore College, died Monday at his home in Swarthmore, Pa. He was 88 years old.

title: Democracy Is Far In South Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $18.9 million and $29.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from losses on short-term marketable equity securities; the quarter also includes an after-tax gain of $15.4 million, or 37 cents a share, related to windfall profit tax refund and other items. c-Includes for the quarter an after- tax gain of $32 million, or 77 cents a share, on the recovery of excess assets from the termination of the salaried retirement plan. The year includes an extraordinary loss of $23,098,000; non-cash charges equal to $1.98 a share resulting from a writedown of $58 million, or $1.42 a share of the oil and gas properties of the company's 48.7 percent-owned affiliate Proven Properties Inc.; and $23.1 million, or 56 cents a share, incurred in connection with the company's debenture exchange.

title: The 1935 'Mutiny'
description: The 1935 film ''Mutiny on the Bounty,'' with Charles Laughton, Clark Gable and Franchot Tone, will be shown Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, 54 Pearl Street. This version, directed by Frank Lloyd, features Clark Gable as Fletcher Christian and Charles Laughton as Captain Bligh. The screening is part of the museum's film series, ''Love, Intrigue and Revolution: 1715-1830.'' The price of tickets is included in museum admission: $2.50 ($1 for students, children and the elderly). Information: 425-1778.

title: DONNELLEY, R R & SONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time gain equal to 51 cents a share from the Rockford- Park Cablevision Inc. in the third quarter.

title: On Stage
description: Ibsen, via Bergman, in Brooklyn

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I.B.M.'s Two New Vice Chairmen
description: Jack D. Kuehler

title: American Stars to Stage Film Festival in Russia
description: Several Hollywood stars will travel to Moscow and Leningrad next month to help stage an American film festival.

title: Colombians Are Skeptical Over Drug Crackdown
description: As death threats against local journalists and officials increased, the Government struggled today to convince Colombians of its new determination to combat the country's billionaire cocaine traffickers.

title: INSIDE
description: Big Changes at I.B.M.

title: Smoker's Death Turns Eyes to Court
description: In a windowless courtroom in this rural county seat that is so small there is no stoplight, squads of lawyers have spent the last month arguing whether smoking caused Nathan Horton's cancer.

title: Jersey Man Is Killed By Fumes From Car
description: A man who left his car running in a closed garage while polishing it was killed by carbon monoxide from the exhaust fumes, the police said.

title: A Narrow Escape
description: Nella Domenici, daughter of Senator Pete V. Domenici, recently survived a fire in a Manhattan apartment building that claimed five lives.

title: Pop: Earth, Wind And Fire
description: EARTH, WIND AND FIRE needs to work some bugs out of the elaborate show that opened a sold-out five-night stand Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall. Reconstituted after a four-year hiatus, with seven sidemen bolstering five longtime band members, Earth, Wind and Fire had to force the buoyancy that made the band so popular a decade ago.

title: Blood Banks Plan No Testing For 2d Variety of AIDS Virus
description: The American Red Cross said today that it would not test blood donors for signs of infection with a second variety of AIDS virus that has just been detected in this country.

title: CORNERSTONE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $304,000 from repurchase of the company's convertible subordinated debentures.

title: BANKRUPTCY FILED BY LEADING UTILITY IN SEABROOK PLANT
description: Beleaguered by the controversy surrounding the Seabrook nuclear power plant, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, the first major public utility to take that step since the Depression.

title: 'Alto e Basso'
description: ''Alto e Basso,'' a program of music for the lower strings, will be offered Sunday at 3 P.M. at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street. The three musicians - Richard Spencer, violist; Lawrence Zoernig, cellist, and Joseph Russo, bassist - will play works by Rossini, Haydn and Beethoven. A contribution of $5 will be requested. Information: 751-1616.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pretax gains of $15 million on the sale of Discover, $32 million on the sale of the company's interest in the USA Network, a $17 million premium to refinance the company's long-term debt at more advantageous rates, and an $8 million pretax loss on the sale of SAMI/Burke Inc.; the net gain from these non-recurring items was 8 cents a share. c-Includes a charge of $63 million, or 55 cents a share, to cover the costs of staff reductions. d-Includes pretax gains of $351 million and pretax charges of $113 million, resulting in a net gain of $1.98 a share. The gains came from the initial public offering of 20 percent of the common stock of ATC and the sale of Time Inc.'s holding in Temple-Inland Inc.

title: HART CHALLENGES MOTIVES OF CRITICS
description: Gary Hart fought back against his critics today, suggesting that he had become a special target of the press and of his party because ''my candidacy is different and it is the fact of that difference that threatens the defenders of the status quo.''

title: Devils Win One For New Coach
description: It took Jim Schoenfeld only six and a half minutes into his first game as head coach of the Devils to make his first major decision.

title: Nanne Quits Stars
description: Citing the effects the continuing stress of working with the team may have on his health, Lou Nanne, the Minnesota North Stars' general manager, resigned yesterday after more than 20 years with the team as a player, coach and executive. ''I couldn't divorce myself during the game from the stress of winning and losing,'' said Nanne, who is 46 years old. ''This gives me an opportunity to enjoy hockey a lot more, and a lot longer.'' Nanne said he would stay on until the North Stars found a replacement. He underwent two days of tests last spring as an outpatient at the Mayo Clinic after he lost 12 pounds in 10 days when the North Stars missed the playoffs for the first time in eight years. Recently, he said, he awoke in the middle of the night hyperventilating after dreaming about making a bad trade. The North Stars have been struggling this season with the National Hockey League's second-worst winning percentage (.357).

title: A Broad Decentralization at I.B.M.
description: In a sweeping restructuring intended to reverse three years of disappointing performance, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday created five new, highly autonomous organizations that will be responsible for all of the company's innovation, design and manufacturing.

title: 'Password' Says It Won't Pay $58,600 Won by Wanted Man
description: Kerry Ketchem, a contestant on the NBC-TV game show ''Super Password'' who was arrested on mail fraud charges when he came to the production office to claim $58,600 in prize money two weeks ago, will not be paid his winnings, the producer says.

title: Bonds Rise Again on Rate Hopes
description: Bond prices continued to rise yesterday as investors and traders remained convinced that slower economic growth in coming months would keep inflation low and bring lower interest rates.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 29, 1988
description: Companies

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After provision for loan loss of $56.7 million for the quarter and includes a reserve for loan loss of $150.8 million for the year. c-After provision for loan loss of $19.6 million for the quarter and includes a reserve for loan loss of $118.5 million for the year.

title: About Real Estate; Greenwich Project Offers a Victorian Mansion Look
description: Although Greenwich, Conn., has a reputation as a patrician community of fine estates and mansions, it is nevertheless a place where condominiums are gaining fast. Unlike most suburban condominiums, these tend to resemble luxurious, generously landscaped private houses.

title: An Officer Sues Hasidic Patrol In Assault Case
description: A 49-year-old officer in the New York City housing police filed a $2 million lawsuit yesterday against a Hasidic community patrol in Brooklyn and five of its members, who he said beat him and tried to take his service revolver when he went to the aid of an elderly man they were kicking and pummeling.

title: 900 Age Cases Died Wrongly, Agency Chief Says
description: The chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission admitted today that his agency deserves ''harsh criticism'' for allowing 900 age discrimination cases to expire before victims had a chance to gain relief.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day yesterday with an article on the gross national product gave an incorrect number for the G.N.P. deflator. The deflator, a measure of prices throughout the economy adjusted to reflect changes in the composition of the G.N.P., was 2.7 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: Schering-Plough To Get Cooper Unit
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said it had signed a letter to acquire the worldwide contact lens operations of the Cooper Companies for about $150 million. Cooper, based in Palo Alto, Calif., has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing the first ultraviolet light-blocking contact lens in the United States.

title: Dance: Limon Troupe's New 'Traitor'
description: HAVING started out on the right foot, the Limon Dance Company was off and running by the second program of its current season Wednesday night. There is a new cohesiveness to the troupe, not entirely remote from the equally new and stronger male dancing that has now come to the fore.

title: Stocks Up Broadly; Dow Rises 18.90
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved broadly higher yesterday in continued moderate trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average was up 18.90 points, to 1,930.04. Transportation issues were particularly strong.

title: Jewish Heritage Songs
description: Nico Castel, a tenor with the Metropolitan and New York City Opera companies, will sing ''Songs From the Jewish Heritage,'' Sunday at 7 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. He will be accompanied by Ann Lewin, pianist, and C. J. Everett, percussionist. The program includes Russian-Jewish and Yiddish songs arranged by Rimsky-Korsakov, Glinka, Mussorgsky and Shostakovich; Sephardic songs and liturgical chants, and pieces by Gounod, Ravel and Castelnuovo-Tedesco.

title: Mitchell House Given A Reprieve in Atlanta
description: The stucco Victorian-style apartment building here where Margaret Mitchell began and finished the first draft of her novel ''Gone With the Wind'' has received a reprieve from the wrecker's ball, with Mayor Andrew Young turning down a developer's permit to demolish it.

title: Film: 'The Tree We Hurt'
description: IT'S summer 1960, in the picturesque Greek town of Chios, where people get around by donkey. School is ending, and a present-day narrator is calling up memories of the idyllic weeks he spent between fourth and fifth grades. They compose ''The Tree We Hurt,'' an unassuming Greek movie that opens today at the Public Theater.

title: DISNEY, WALT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $18,047,000.

title: Bernstein Rein Gets Blockbuster Account
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has assigned its $4 million advertising account to Bernstein Rein in Kansas City, Mo., and its collateral work to Gabe, Tomlin & Giles in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Opera Coach Died in His 'House of Worship'
description: Until a few months ago, Bantcho Bantchevsky, the 82-year-old opera coach who plunged to his death at the Metropolitan Opera House last Saturday, was a gregarious man, rich in friendships and surrounded by music.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Allentown Cement Co., Allentown, Pa., has been purchased by Euroc A.B. for about $83 million.

title: ST. PAUL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $5,324,000 and $37,698,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and also includes realized capital losses, net of taxes, of $23,921,000 and $5,489,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $16,392,000 and $57,529,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; also includes realized capital losses, net of taxes, of $4,705,000 for the quarter, and realized capital gains of $5,703,000 for the year.

title: Anyone Here Wish to Be a Tree?
description: IF you were a tree, what kind of tree would you be?

title: CHITTENDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $5.4 million provision for loan losses made during the second quarter.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter included a pre-tax charge of $25,217,000 from restructuring costs.

title: Computervision-Prime Deal
description: The Computervision Corporation has accepted a $434 million takeover offer from Prime Computer Inc., the two Massachusetts companies announced yesterday.

title: SENATE, TO OVERRIDE COURT, VOTES A BILL EXTENDING ANTI-BIAS LAWS
description: The Senate tonight passed a civil rights bill that would reverse the impact of a 1984 Supreme Court decision that significantly limited the reach of Federal laws against discrimination.

title: The Games We Play
description: Are we all just a little mad?

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE SAVINGS BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an after-tax loss of $2,333,000 from mortgage banking operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of the Seabrook Bank & Trust on a pooling-of-interest method.

title: Art: Change of Fortune For Viollet-le-Duc
description: ONE of the more astonishing among recent reversals of accepted opinion is summed up in an exhibition entitled ''Viollet-le-Duc: Architect, Artist, Master of Historic Preservation'' at the Grey Art Gallery. Until quite lately, there were literally no limits to the unpopularity of Eugene Viollet-le-Duc (1814-1879), the architect who from 1840 onward was in charge of the preservation of historic buildings all over France.

title: Face to Face for Sandinistas and Rebels
description: Officials of the Nicaraguan Government and anti-Sandinista guerrillas met for their first face-to-face negotiations here this afternoon and agreed to hold further talks Friday morning.

title: King Helps Bullets Romp Past Knicks
description: Remember Bernard King, the free agent the Knicks did not want and then lost without receiving compensation?

title: Letter Linked to North Describes Witness Plan
description: A document found in Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's safe shows that participants in the White House-directed efforts to supply the contras sought to silence at least one witness who was helping Congress investigate the secret operation.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $1.5 million from the repurchase of debt for both periods, and the net income in the latest year includes a gain of 68 cents a share from assets sales in the third quarter. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $48.8 million and an extraordinary loss of $7.1 million. d-Includes a loss of $65.9 million from discontinued operations and a extraordinary loss of $7.1 million from retirement of debt. The company said its net in the latest year included a gain equal to 68 cents a share from assets sales in the third quarter.

title: Cuomo Broke Budget Surplus Agreement, G.O.P. Senators Charge
description: State Senate Republicans said today that the state's budget surplus was almost $300 million higher than Governor Cuomo has estimated. They accused the Governor of having spent most of the difference on routine state operating expenses instead of putting the money, as agreed, into a special capital fund for roads and housing.

title: City Council Wakes Up but Still Lags
description: Mayor Koch assembled the news media one afternoon last May to propose the elimination of two business taxes on energy use. The ceremony, like similar occasions in City Hall, ran a predictable course, until Councilman Jerome X. O'Donovan marched to the podium to offer his support.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a fat substitute developed by the Nutrasweet Company misidentified Norman S. Singer. Mr. Singer is Nutrasweet's director of new product development. The article also misstated the location of the Monsanto Company, which owns Nutrasweet. It is in St. Louis.

title: The Proper Study Of Economists
description: To the Editor:

title: Streak Haunts Islanders
description: Led by a coach whose face was still drawn the morning after their surprising defeat here, the Islanders went through their practice paces and then, still a subdued bunch, filed onto a flight to Buffalo. There, on Friday, they will have a chance to repair an 11-game streak on the road without a victory.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 415 money market mutual funds increased $1.22 billion, to $274.83 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $499.1 million, to $80.26 billion. Assets of the 207 general-purpose funds were up $83.1 million, to $81.24 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased $634.9 million, to $113.34 billion.

title: Gretzky Expected Back
description: Wayne Gretzky says he is ready to play again and expects to be in the Edmonton Oiler lineup for the game tonight against the first-place Calgary Flames. Gretzky, who hasn't played since suffering a severely strained ligament in his right knee Dec. 30, said the knee was greatly improved. ''The knee feels strong, the range of motion is solid,'' he said. ''But until I get hit, we won't know where it's at.'' This is the longest stretch Gretzky has missed in his career, and during it the Oilers have a 5-4-4 record.

title: Japan and Apartheid
