description: The Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986 is getting an especially close look these days from staffers of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and members of the Congressional Black Caucus.

title: WHERE BIRTHS ARE KEPT DOWN AND WOMEN AREN'T
description: For thousands of years, this small coastal area of southern India has fancied itself as a world apart, separated from the rest of the subcontinent by mountains and influenced by spice traders, missionaries and other foreign visitors.

title: What Is George Bush Hiding?
description: As long as Vice President Bush offers his experience in world affairs as a qualification for his Presidential candidacy, the questions he refuses to answer about the Iran-contra affair will haunt him. Unless he says more, voters are left to judge him by the known record. It presents three possibilities, each disquieting - or worse.

title: Tennis Anyone? Not After Dark In This Suburb
description: For years the Alpine zoning board has tried to insure that residents don't ruin this suburb by building too many tennis courts in their yards. ''Tennis courts take up most of the board's time,'' said John Langan, the zoning board's attorney. ''And swimming pools.''

title: Cabaret: 'Call Me Ethel'
description: ''COLE PORTER used to say, 'You can hear Merman's voice all the way to the last row of the balcony,' and that's before I start singing,'' trumpets Rita McKenzie at the beginning of ''Call Me Ethel,'' her one-woman salute to the Broadway legend Ethel Merman.

title: White Plains Police Revise Report of Lawyer's Suicide
description: The police said a former president of the Westchester County Bar Association who killed himself Monday did not fire the fatal shot while on the telephone as they originally reported.

title: Estimate Board Delays Vote on School Project
description: The New York City Board of Estimate, lacking the votes to approve a Koch administration plan to have private developers renovate a landmark school in exchange for air rights to build a 48-story office tower next door, delayed acting on the plan yesterday.

title: Rangers Triumph With Unusual Ease
description: The Rangers were outstanding tonight as they beat the first-place Philadelphia Flyers, 5-2, at the Spectrum and raised for Coach Michel Bergeron and the team's followers the following question:

title: AIDS TEST SOUGHT FOR U.S. COLLEGE
description: American health officials hope to screen every student at a major university this spring to help determine the incidence of infection with the AIDS virus among young adults, C. Everett Koop, Surgeon General of the United States, said today.

title: Merc-Comex Link Delayed
description: The twisted route to a possible merger between New York's two largest futures exchanges took another turn yesterday, when the Commodity Exchange said it had been informed by the New York Mercantile Exchange that the Merc would be unable to respond to the merger proposal by Feb. 1, as previously agreed.

title: Haitian Music
description: System Band will play Haitian music tonight at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Sets begin at 11 P.M., 1 and 2:30 A.M.; there is a $15 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: 15 Indicted in Drug Profit Plot
description: A former aide in the Nixon Administration and a former Congressman from Illinois are among 15 people indicted in a nationwide investigation into a scheme to hide drug profits, the Government said today.

title: Givenchy Blossoms
description: Hubert de Givenchy found still another way to deploy the flowers that are blooming freely all over spring and summer fashions. He uses, of course, the popular flower prints, which suggest Monet's garden at Giverny at the height of the season.

title: Photographs That Reflect and Confront Cultural Icons
description: JUDGED by its first month, 1988 promises to be an energetic, expansive and sometimes controversial year for photography. On a weekend's excursion to museums and galleries currently exhibiting photographs, one can sense a ferment that compensates for the often uninviting chill of winter streets and sidewalks.

title: Citicorp to Buy Arizona Bank
description: Citicorp announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the United Bank of Arizona in Phoenix and merge it into its existing subsidiary in the state, Citibank Arizona.

title: NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $45,000,000 from discontinued operations as well as a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change amounting to $58,185,000.

title: NITTY-GRITTY THAT THE CANDIDATES SIDESTEP
description: LEAD: Even though the Presidential primaries are fast approaching, none of the many candidates has yet to address the sort of issue that would inspire me to pull the lever for any one of them.

title: Delaware Takeover Curb Near
description: Delaware will soon have a new law that makes hostile takeovers of corporations more difficult.

title: IU Rejects Bid; Offers Alternative
description: The IU International Corporation has rejected as inadequate a hostile $520 million bid from Neoax Inc. and has offered shareholders an alternative restructuring plan. IU, a trucking and waste management company, offered $14 in cash and a new share of its common stock for each of its 27.4 million common shares outstanding, or a total of about $383 million in cash.

title: Charles Tennant, 33, Zoning-Law Specialist
description: Charles E. Tennant, a lawyer specializing in zoning and land-use issues, died of lymphoma yesterday at New York Hospital, according to a hospital spokesman, Jed Golden. Mr. Tennant was 33 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ARMS ADVISER ASSERTS U.S. CAN DETECT HIDDEN SOVIET MISSILES
description: Paul H. Nitze, the senior arms control adviser to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, today defended the American ability to monitor the new missile treaty against charges that the treaty cannot be verified effectively.

title: Federated Board Holds Meeting
description: Directors of Federated Department Stores Inc. met yesterday for a regular meeting in the wake of Monday's $4.2 billion bid for the chain by the Campeau Corporation of Canada. Federated declined to comment on the meeting, but the company said it would have a response by Feb. 5.

title: Protester Crippled by Munitions Train Sues Navy and Crew
description: A protester who lost his legs when he was struck by a train carrying munitions filed a civil rights lawsuit today against Navy officers and the train crew.

title: OCCUPATIONAL MEDICAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net loss

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
E-II Meets With American Brands
description: Officials of E-II Holdings Inc. and American Brands Inc. met today after E-II rejected an $875 million takeover bid from American Brands, calling it ''grossly inadequate.''

title: Student's-Eye View
description: To the Editor:

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After a $500,000 gain from a change in accounting for deferred taxex for the both periods. c-Net loss The year-ago fourth quarter and year include $491,000 of costs associated with a terminated leveraged buyout merger. The 1986 quarter also reflects the reversal of investment tax credits of $384,000.

title: NBI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax provision of $12,468,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $111,000 and $409,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title:
Patents;
Optical-Cable Link
description: LEAD: Gordon Gould of Kinsale, Va., a physicist who has been called ''the father of the laser,'' was awarded a patent this week in a different field. Patent 4,721,355, assigned to the Chevron Research Company of San Francisco, a division of the Chevron Corporation, covers an optical-cable connector assembly link used in logging oil wells.

title: ANDOVER BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $104,000 on the sale of securities and loans. c-Includes a gain of $333,000 from the sale of securities and a special dividend of $747,000 from the Mutual Savings Central Fund. d-Includes gains from the sales of securities and loans of $2,217,000 for latest year and $1,648,000 for 1986. The per share figures for year 1986 were not available.

title: CNB BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. URGING ANGOLA ON CUBAN PULLOUT
description: After seven years of intense but futile diplomatic efforts, the Reagan Administration is making a final attempt to reach an agreement on the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola and independence for South-West Africa.

title: Comments on Paterno
description: One person who seems unlikely to apply for membership in the Joe Paterno Fan Club is Darin Roberts, who in 1984 was a highly publicized and talented quarterback from Franklin High School in Somerset, N.J. Roberts was heavily recruited, but he chose Paterno and Penn State because ''they told me I was going to play quarterback when they recruited me,'' he said. ''They said if I was good enough, I would play. I just never got my chance.'' Earlier this month, Roberts, who lost his football scholarship for academic reasons, left Penn State after carrying the ball five times and throwing one pass in three seasons. Now he is looking forward to playing football next fall at Trenton State and to improving his academic record. But he still has memories of Penn State: ''It's good football and everything, but up there it's very political. It's things you don't know about if you are outside. State College is Joe Paterno. It is his town. Everyone has some fear of him. He is so higher and greater than everyoneelse.''

title: ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Peril in the Playroom
description: In 1986 the nation's hospital emergency rooms treated more than 113,000 children for toy-related injuries; 35 died. Some of these accidents might have been avoided if toy labels were more explicit about potential risks.

title: REAGAN ON TV FOR CONTRA AID
description: President Reagan will go on television Tuesday to press his plea to Congress to approve fresh aid for the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government, the White House announced today.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Texaco Financial Statement
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge approved Texaco Inc.'s financial disclosure statement today, setting the stage for the oil giant's emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

title: Response to Carl Lewis
description: John Holt, the general secretary of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, track's governing body, yesterday accused the American track star Carl Lewis of making ''vague and unsubstantiated'' charges concerning drug abuse in the sport. Holt said Lewis, who won four gold medals at the 1984 Olympics, should come forward and identify anyone he knew to be on drugs instead of ''firing off unfounded allegations.'' In a news briefing in London, Holt was responding to Lewis's statement Wednesday that drug use had led to deaths in the United States and Britain. Speaking on British television, Lewis said that many drug abusers were not being caught and that some athletes had agreements with meet promoters to avoid being tested. He did not identify anyone as taking drugs, nor did he give any evidence for his charges. Lewis and his manager, Joe Douglas, checked out of their London hotel yesterday afternoon and their whereabouts were unknown. Holt said Lewis should have made his views known to his national track federation, The Athletics Congress.

title: Paquito D'Rivera
description: Paquito D'Rivera, an alto saxophonist, is leading a quintet and Hilton Ruiz, a pianist, is leading a group in a Latin-jazz double bill tonight and tomorrow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. with a 1:30 A.M. show today; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: ACME STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,875,000 for the quarter and $6,041,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Concert: Musica Sacra Offers the Old and New
description: Musica Sacra's program at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night was an interesting survey of the old, the recent and the brand new. There were two Magnificats: one by Luciano Berio marking his postwar transition from respectful apprenticeship to high originality and the other Francesco Durante's example from the Baroque.

title: Peak Japan Jobless Rate
description: The unemployment rate in Japan, seasonally adjusted, averaged 2.8 percent in 1987, the worst on record, the Statistics Bureau reported today. In December, the rate stood at 2.6 percent of the labor force, down a tenth of a percentage point from November, the bureau said.

title:
Patents;
A Computer System for Restaurants
description: LEAD: A COMPUTER system for restaurants that allows diners to order at a terminal and play video games while they await their food was patented this week by two brothers in New York.

title: Nets Provide Treat To Bulls and Crowd
description: If the Chicago Bulls score 120 points or more, the fans at the game are treated to free chicken and biscuits. If they hold their opponent under 100 points, fans can receive two free hot dogs.

title: ROCHESTER COMMUNITY SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,687,000 for the quarter and $11,651,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $2,496,000 for the quarter and $7,490,000 for the year. d-After a loss on debt prepayment of $470,000. The company converted to stock ownership in April 1986.

title: City Ballet to Offer Bonus at Intermission
description: Dancers from the New York City Ballet and the School of American Ballet will demonstrate the arts of makeup, costume and dance at the ''Family Matinee'' performance on at 1 P.M. tomorrow at the New York State Theater, Lincoln Center.

title: To Moscow: Let Your Satellites Go
description: LEAD: As the leaders of the two superpowers continue to bask in the summit afterglow and talk of other triumphs down the road, it becomes even more important to recall that one major aspect of Soviet-Americanrelations has been left untouched.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JANUARY 30, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 28 Edwin Meese was told of payments to be made to the Israeli Labor Party for help in arranging a billion-dollar Iraqi oil pipeline, present and former Government officials said. Page 1 Special trade preferences will be cut for Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore, the Reagan Administration announced in advance of critical negotiations with Congress. 1 A Chinese newscaster's new clothes stirred excitement in Beijing. For two nights, the news reader on a television news program appeared before cameras in a Mao suit, having shed his Western-style attire. 1 A Dutch actor faked a kidnapping. Jules Croiset, whose father was Jewish, had reported being abducted by a neo-Nazi commando. News of his fraud has forced the Dutch to examine a troubling collective past. 1 Nicaraguan negotiations adjourned after two days in Costa Rica with a decision to meet again in two weeks in Guatemala, but little other substantitive agreement in the first face-to-face talks between Sandinista and contra representatives. 3 50 Palestinians were injured after Israeli police officers swept through a refugee camp in East Jerusalem in a disciplinary roundup of male residents, relief workers said. The injured were said to include an 18-month-old baby. 5 The new missile pact was criticized by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former American delegate to the United Nations, in testimony before a Senate committee. But she said the Senate should approve it anyway. 5 Cuba's withdrawal from Angola and independence for South-West Africa are the focus of a final attempt by the Reagan Administration to reach an agreement with Angola after seven years of intense but futile diplomatic efforts. 2 Pope gives Ortega a cool reception 3 Britain and France differ on economic and defense policy 3 Ho Chi Minh City journal: Old Saigon haunt gets new life 4 Never wanted power, Seoul chief says 4 Thailand announces it will turn back refugee boats 4 Bulgarian rejects greater openness in restructuring economy 4 U.S. and Brazil at odds over Libya arms 28 NATIONAL 6-9, 50 In a major new policy on abortion, the Reagan Administration prohibited family planning clinics supported by Federal funds from providing any assistance that would help women obtain abortions. The rules are to take effect March 3. 1 An internal review of F.B.I. policies was ordered by President Reagan, officials said. Mr. Reagan is concerned about the disclosures that the bureau conducted domestic surveillance on groups opposed to his Central American policy. 1 An Amtrak passenger train derailed in Chester, Pa., injuring 24 people. The northbound train struck a piece of maintenance equipment after being switched onto the wrong track, an Amtrak official said. 1 Postal service cost-cutting moves will be made in mid-February. They include a one-day delay in delivery that will affect many first-class letters that are mailed on Sundays. 6 Gary Hart's financial circumstances in his 1984 campaign led top advisers to his insurgent Presidential effort to take desperate financial measures that are haunting his battered 1988 campaign. 8 Richard Gephardt is optimistic as he heads toward the first round of the 1988 Democratic Presidential competition that he can break out of a three-candidate field of leaders and win the Iowa caucuses. 8 Bob Dole offered budget plans that would either increase Social Security and other retirement cost of living adjustments or leave them ''the way they are.'' The move seemed to bow to political pressures. 8 The battle of the airwaves in Iowa is reversing the usual party roles: Republicans are violating their own commandment against negative advertising, while Democrats are trying to be inspirational. 8 Democrats take debate show to South Dakota 9 In a trial against a tobacco company accused of causing the death of a smoker, a mistrial was declared. The case in Lexington, Miss., was widely viewed as having the best chance of succeeding where others brought by smokers had failed. 7 Survey finds wide ignorance on AIDS 6 Study disputes aspirin's value as a preventive 6 Protester crippled by munitions train sues navy and crew 7 Nofziger trial is told of Meese aide's help for Wedtech 9 REGIONAL 29-32 A 'sting' faked deaths and as a result New York state and city investigators are reported to have videotaped court representatives taking valuables from apartments of people they thought were dead. 1 A witness in a corruption trial lied during his testimony against Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, Federal prosecutors said. Defense lawyers said they might seek a new trial. 29 Two union officials received payoffs from the Wedtech Corporation, the military contractor, in return for negotiating favorable contracts, the Government charged. The teamsters' union officials were charged with receiving at least $465,000. 29 A ship repair company's pullout last week from negotiations to help revitalize the Brooklyn Navy Yard has dealt a serious blow to plans to continue the yard's tradition as a major ship repair center. 31 The income tax on commuters who work in New York City would be doubled under a request made by Mayor Koch to the State Legislature. But legislative leaders of both parties shot down the proposal. 29 Churches in a growing rural town are troubled by congregations in a constant state of flux. The turmoil, pastors say, comes from factors contributing to the demise of Raritan Township as an intimate country town. 29 New York Urban League's head quit this week to accept a resident fellowship at Harvard University. Harriet Michel has been president of the civil-rights organization five years. 31 The body of a man who had been shot in the head was found in an apartment in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, the police said, and it was unclear how long he had been dead. 31 Challenges confront Legal Aid 31 Neediest Cases 30

title: Floating Point Names Chief
description: Floating Point Systems Inc., the troubled maker of scientific computer systems based in Beaverton, Ore., has named Howard Thrailkill president, chief executive and a director. He succeeds Milton R. Smith, a co-founder who was appointed interim chief executive 15 months ago and who will continue as a board member.

title: BLACK HILLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,248,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Postal Service Set to Impose Cutbacks in Mid-February
description: The United States Postal Service will put new cost-cutting measures into effect in mid-February, including a one-day delay in delivery that will affect most of the first-class letters that are mailed on Sundays.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If it was cold, that was because it is colder in Rome than in Nicaragua.'' - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, on his reception at the Vatican. [ 3:3. ]

title: COURIER DISPATCH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
V.A. Lowers Loan Rate
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it would lower its maximum interest rate for federally backed home mortgages by a percentage point, to 9.5 percent.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects about $7 million of gains from sales of loans, loan servicing and real estate.

title: IOWA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Witness Says He Lied on Stand In New York Corruption Trial
description: Federal prosecutors have disclosed that one of their witnesses recently admitted giving some untrue testimony in the corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader.

title: Ho Chi Minh City Journal; A Haunt of Old Saigon Gets New Life
description: Back when Saigon was Saigon, the Hotel Continental had a certain combination of decadence and class that made it a favorite of artists and writers. The occasional drug dealer roamed its spacious halls; transvestites and other inhabitants of the demimonde were said to gravitate to its neighborhood.

title: BCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4.3 million, or 11 cents a share, related to the repurchase of a portion of the company's outstanding convertible debentures.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: The year-ago second quarter earnings were reduced by 2 cents a share because of a reversal of a tax credit.

title: Britain and France Stay at Odds On Economic and Defense Policy
description: The leaders of France and Britain failed to narrow their differences on economic and defense policy in talks here today, but they left the way open for further discussions on military cooperation.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLDCoping/With Restaurant Abuses
description: Your party of four made a reservation for 8 P.M. at an expensive restaurant. An hour later, you are seated without apology at a table near the kitchen in the path of rushing waiters. You eventually order four steaks, rare; they eventually arrive, well done. By that time it's 10:30. The sentiment is a unanimous ''let's walk out.'' But can you? Or must you pay for the indignity of poor service and improperly prepared food? In a word, yes. Sgt. Peter Sweeney, a public-affairs officer with the New York City Police Department, put it this way: ''If you don't pay, you can be arrested. If you ordered the food and it's served, you should pay. We can't force you to pay, and it's not up to us to decide if you're justified - that's up to a judge - but the owner can press charges if you don't. The customer's recourse is Small Claims Court, the Department of Consumer Affairs or the Better Business Bureau.''

title: The Battle Against Fraudulent Ads
description: ''Just take Dream Away before going to bed,'' said the advertisement printed in newspapers and shown on television last year. ''You will wake up the next morning slimmer, trimmer and looking better than you did before.''

title: DEMOCRATS SPAR IN SOUTH DAKOTA
description: The Democratic candidates for President brought their much-practiced road show to South Dakota tonight, jabbing at one another's weak spots and, along the way, debating issues from economics to Central America policy.

title: U.S. Will Drop 4 Areas in Asia From Trade Aid
description: In a hardening of its trade policy, the Reagan Administration announced today that it would end special trade preferences for four of the most powerful third-world economies: Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore.

title: STALEY CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $253,000 and a $7,268,000 loss from the early redemption of debt.

title: WESTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ZIONS BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MCCLAIN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Patents;
New Way to Produce Enzyme for Cheese
description: LEAD: A patent was granted this week for a method of producing from microbes an enzyme, normally found in calves, that can be used to turn milk into cheese. The patent was for the Genex Corporation, a biotechnology company in Gaithersburg, Md. Jack R. Uren and two former staff members were granted patent 4,721,673.

title: VOLUNTEER BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LANDMARK BANCSHARES CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Guidepost
description: Giving Gold Valentine's Day is approaching, and gold jewelry remains a popular gift. Beyond the choice of the item, decisions must be made about karats, color and texture. Gold in its purest state is generally too soft for jewelry and so is mixed with copper, zinc, silver or nickel, which increases its hardness and modifies its color. Twenty-four karats is 100 percent gold; 18 karats is 18 parts gold and 6 parts other metal; 14 karats is 14 parts gold and 10 parts other metal. Copper produces a reddish tint, and a mix of copper and silver retains gold's natural yellow color . The jewelry listed here is available at many jewelry and department stores. The wide price range reflects the value of design and workmanship. Prices at the most prestigious jewelry stores may run thousands of dollars more. Karats Color Texture Price Earrings (round) 18 Pink Brushed $400-2,000 Bracelet (hollow bangle) 14 Yellow Shiny $175-1,500 Ring (men's signet) 14 Yellow Smooth $200-1,000 Cuff links (oval) 18 Yellow Ribbed $400-2,500 Source: World Gold Council Inc.

title: Music: Parley of Instruments
description: The Parley of Instruments, a London early-music group founded in 1979, appeared Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art with two American soloists in an all-Vivaldi program. It was an evening of attractive, high-level music-making, genuinely appealing without standing out in any really sterling way.

title: U.S. Scales Back on Military Aid; Most to Latin Nations Is Dropped
description: The Reagan Administration is cutting back sharply on security assistance to some key allies and is ending military grants to all of Latin America with the exception of three Central American countries, the State Department announced today.

title: Field vs. Fields: A Fight Over a Name
description: Debra Fields, who turned a favorite cookie recipe into a 400-store corporation, and Marshall Field & Company, the department store chain, are battling over names.

title: Legal Aid Society Pressed on Backlog
description: After years of failing to persuade the Koch administration that it needed major budgetary increases, the Legal Aid Society of New York forced a showdown. Starting in April 1986, its lawyers, who every year represent thousands of indigent criminal defendants, refused to handle most arraignments.

title: ALLIED SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERIWEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A MEMO TO MEESE SAID TO ASK CASH FOR ISRAELI PARTY
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was told in a 1985 memo from a close friend who wanted his help in arranging Government support for a billion-dollar Iraqi oil pipeline that the project would involve payments to the Israeli Labor Party, present and former United States Government officials said today.

title: New York Inquiry Is Said to Tape Court Aides Stealing From 'Dead'
description: New York state and city investigators have videotaped court representatives in the act of taking valuables from apartments of people they thought were dead, according to people familiar with the unusual ''sting.''

title: 'Tristan and Iseult,' By Boston Camerata
description: ''Tristan and Iseult,'' a new production by the Boston Camerata, will have its New York premiere on Feb. 18 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The drama, which is based on medieval musical scores and texts, chronicles the story of Tristan, Iseult and King Mark.

title: HEALTH CARE PROPERTY INVESORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; Tennis Courting a World Stage
description: HERE it is, the final shopping day before Super Bowl Sunday, which has become an undeclared national holiday in this country but, more interestingly, a growing phenomenon in parts of Europe and Asia as well. If there is a trade imbalance in sports, it appears to favor the Americans, as fascination with football, baseball and basketball continues to spread around the world while soccer - on a professional level, anyway -has been unable to get a foothold in the United States.

title: Critic's Notebook; Unadorned but Complex Chekhov
description: When Peter Brook first staged his production of ''The Cherry Orchard'' in Paris in 1981, he approached the play as, in his words, ''a theatrical movement purely played.'' The idea was ''to avoid sentimentality, a false Chekhovian manner that is not in the text.'' For him, ''The Cherry Orchard'' was not ''gloomy, romantic, long and slow,'' but ''a comic play about real life.''

title: Cedar Walton Trio
description: Trios with Cedar Walton on piano, Ron Carter on bass and Billy Higgins on drums are scheduled tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Beck Posts 63 For Lead
description: After nine years of coming close, Charles Henry (Chip) Beck has more second-place finishes than any of the other nonwinners on the PGA Tour.

title: John A. Williams, Executive, 55
description: John A. (Jack) Williams, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Japan, died of kidney cancer Sunday at the clinical center of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 55 years old and lived in Tokyo and Manhattan.

title: Milton J. Raisbeck, Cardiologist, 99
description: Milton J. Raisbeck, a retired cardiologist, died Tuesday at Children's Hospital in San Francisco. He was 99 years old.

title: ALTUS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $659,000. The company said the loss reflects a provision of $7.1 million for losses on loans and real estate. c-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $2,263,000. d-Includes extraordinary credits of $682,000 for the latest year and $2,374,000 for 1986.

title: In a Bronx School, a '38 Free Speech Victory
description: LEAD: The United States Supreme Court decision upholding censorship of a high school newspaper recalled an episode nearly 50 years ago. It took place at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx in 1938, but it did not involve the school paper.

title: Pope Gives Ortega a Cool Reception
description: Pope John Paul II offered President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua a markedly cool reception at the Vatican today and then sternly advised the Sandinista leader that respect for human rights and democracy was necessary to achieve peace in Central America, Vatican officials said.

title: BELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MIDWEST FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Seats Are Sought On Ameron Board
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., which holds an 18.7 percent stake in Ameron Inc., has requested two seats on the company's board of directors. In a letter Thursday to Ameron's board, Industrial Equity said its holdings in the contruction concern, based in Monterey Park, Calif., were ''nearly two times the next largest shareholder.'' The letter was contained in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: MEDSTAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $113,000 and $122,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: FIRST FINCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Belgian Group Acts On Company Bid
description: A group of Belgian companies announced it was ready to acquire 34.25 percent of Societe Generale de Belgique in an effort to thwart a bid by Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian financier. Andre Leysen, chairman of Gevaert, Belgium's photographic material company, said his company and a series of allies had gathered commitments to acquire the stake in Societe Generale, which is Belgium's leading financial and industrial company.

title: Liggett & Myers Told To Issue Smoking Data
description: A Federal district judge, in a ruling that stemmed from a tobacco liability case, has ordered the release of secret studies on the dangers of cigarette smoking that were conducted for the Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company over the course of 30 years.

title: Pistons Top Celtics Before 61,983 Fans
description: Joe Dumars scored 6 of his 20 points in a crucial third-quarter run as the Detroit Pistons beat the Boston Celtics, 125-108, tonight before 61,983 fans, a National Basketball Association record.

title: Guard Held in Gun Smuggling
description: A New York City Correction officer was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn after law-enforcement officials said he had been videotaped receiving $3,000 for having smuggled a loaded pistol to a prisoner on Rikers Island.

title: Trying to Save Man, Woman Dies in Fire
description: A Queens woman was killed yesterday afternoon after running back into her burning house to rescue an elderly invalid trapped by the flames in a second-story bedroom, the Fire Department said. The invalid and another man also perished.

title: Bush Prevails at G.O.P. Parley in Michigan
description: Vice President Bush won the first prize of the 1988 Presidential campaign late tonight when he prevailed over Pat Robertson at a contentious Republican state convention here to capture the biggest share of Michigan's 77 national convention delegates.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
24 Hurt as Amtrak Train Derails; Key Rail Operator Leaves Scene
description: An Amtrak train bound from Washington to Boston derailed here early today when it struck a piece of maintenance equipment after being switched onto the wrong track, an Amtrak official said. Twenty-four people were hurt. The control tower operator responsible for setting the track switches left his post soon after the accident and could not be found, according to the official, John L. Jacobsen, Amtrak's director of public affairs.

title: Bridge:; Some Transfer Themselves Out of Playing Their Hand
description: Many players would like a system that permitted them to play more than their fair share of the hands, either to take advantage of superior skill, or because they have a partner with a headache, or from pure selfishness.

title: F.D.A. Petition By Nutrasweet
description: Under pressure from Federal regulators, the Nutrasweet Company said today that it would submit for review its new fat substitute.

title: Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: Claude Frank, pianist, and Mareda Gaither-Graves, soprano, will be guest soloists with the Bronx Arts Ensemble at its third chamber-music concert of the season, Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Riverdale Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., 5625 Arlington Avenue, at 256th Street in the Bronx. On the program are Handel's ''Lucretia'' cantata, three songs by Pizzetti, and the Schumann Quintet in E flat (Op. 44) for piano and strings. Tickets are $8, or $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 549-1899 or 601-7399.

title: COHERENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The fiscal 1987 first quarter results are restated to reflect adoption of FAS No. 96, accounting for income taxes.

title: Investor Seeking A Chicken Chain
description: Francis J. Spillman, a Dallas investor, has offered to purchase all of the shares of the Winners Corporation that he does not already control for $4.25 a share in cash, or about $15.4 million. In a telephone interview, Mr. Spillman said that he had had ''preliminary discussions with another chicken chain'' about the possible takeover of Winners. The company operates 131 Mrs. Winner's Chicken & Biscuits fast-food restaurants, most of which are in the Southeastern United States, from its headquarters in Brentwood, Tenn.

title: Resurgence of Brooklyn Navy Yard Is Dealt Blow by Company's Rebuff
description: When a ship repair company New York City officials hoped would help revitalize the Brooklyn Navy Yard pulled out of negotiations last week, it dealt a serious blow to plans to continue the yard's tradition as a major ship repair center.

title: BEGLEY COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Patents;
Nuclear Fusion Reactor From Princeton Lab
description: LEAD: A nuclear fusion reactor was patented this week for the Department of Energy by staff members at the Princeton University Plasma Physics Laboratory in New Jersey. Henry S. Greenside and two associates obtained patent 4,721,595. In the reactor, hot fuel that enhances the fusion reaction is contained by a wall made of hydrogenated semiconductors.

title: FIRST WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $146,000 from an FHLB prepayment penalty.

title: Carteret Bancorp
description: Alpine Associates, a limited partnership based in Cresskill, N.J., has purchased a 5.5 percent stake in Carteret Bancorp Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Alpine said it had acquired the Carteret shares for investment purposes only. Carteret, a bank holding company based in Morristown, N.J., has until mid-February to find a better offer than its $19 a share, or about $232 million, merger agreement with Home Group Inc. Between Nov. 29 and Jan. 20, Alpine made net purchases of 186,600 Carteret shares on the open market for an average price of $16.21 a share.

title: Islanders End Road Slump
description: The Islanders snapped an 11-game streak without a victory on the road tonight with a 5-2 triumph over the Sabres.

title: Benefits Extended For Jersey Homeless
description: About half of the homeless families living in New Jersey motels will receive an extension of their emergency shelter aid, but their futures remain uncertain after the extensions run out, officials said yesterday.

title: TV: 'Wonder Years,' A New Series on ABC
description: Super Bowl Sunday has spawned a tradition. Immediately after the game, while the network still might retain access to one of the year's biggest audiences, a new series is previewed to take advantage of the ''sampling'' opportunity. Getting viewers to see your product is considered a crucial aspect of the programming game. So tomorrow, after Super Bowl XXII and post-game coverage, expected to conclude sometime around 10:30 P.M., ABC is introducing a new half-hour sitcom called ''The Wonder Years.'' Because of the Winter Olympics and other special events, the series will not begin its regular weekly run until March. Contrary to most evidence, ABC believes that television viewers have long memories.

title: QUAKER STATE OIL REFINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Harry Avrutin, former secretary of the New York City Central Labor Council, A.F.L.-C.I.O., died of cancer of the liver Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Union, N.J.

Standardizing Funds' Charges

description: Two teamsters' union officials were charged yesterday with receiving at least $465,000 in illegal payoffs from the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor, in return for negotiating favorable union contracts and preventing labor unrest at the company's Bronx manufacturing plants.

title: N.F.L.'s Stormy Season Comes Down to a Game
description: This National Football League season of strike, of confrontation, of replacement games - a season of disruption - will end Sunday on a newly seeded grass field that could symbolize a rebirth.

Man Is Held in Death Of a 2-Year-Old Boy
description: A Brooklyn man man has been charged with fatally punching the 2-year-old son of the woman he lived with, the police said.

title: PARTIES' ROLES REVERSED IN IOWA ADS
description: The battle of the airwaves for the Iowa Presidential caucuses has produced a reversal of the usual party roles: Republicans are violating their own commandment against negative advertising while the Democrats are trying be inspirational without living up to their reputation for bloodying the television landscape.

title: Dole Revises Budget Proposals to Eliminate Social Security Freeze
description: For two weeks Bob Dole has focused his Presidential campaign on urging a ''temporary spending freeze'' in 1989 to reduce the Federal deficit. He said such a politically risky step would affect most Social Security recipients except the needy.

description: b-Net loss and includes a one-time pretax restructuring charge of $2,934.000.

title: Clemency Declined by Britain or Six Convicted Irishmen
description: The Government today refused clemency for six Irishmen convicted in a 1974 terrorist bombing after a British court dismissed their appeals.

ANSWERS TO QUIZ

title: KAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dance: At the World, 'Leonard and Cinciana'
description: The theater was packed when Dennis O'Connor and Ann Papoulis presented ''Leonard and Cinciana'' at the World, at 254 East Second Street, on Thursday. That was unsurprising, for Mr. O'Connor is a gifted member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and Ms. Papoulis is a performer of special resonance. What was surprising - considering the subject of the new piece and the fact that neither dancer appears to have a great deal of experience as a choreographer - was how consistently interesting the evening was.

title: GENERAL BUILDING PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Wave Hill Trio
description: The Wave Hill Trio - Sung-Ju Lee, violinist; Roberta Cooper, cellist, and Marian Hahn, pianist - will play Schubert's Piano Quintet in A (''Trout''), Brahms's Trio in C minor (Op. 101), and Duos for violin and viola by Mozart at 3 P.M. tomorrow in the Armor Hall of Wave Hill, 249th Street and Independence Avenue in the Bronx. Guest artists are Masao Kawasaki, violist, and Timothy Cobb, bassist. Tickets are $10; $8 for the elderly, $7 for members of Wave Hill. Information: 549-3200.

title: Denise Stoklos
description: ''Denise Stoklos Unearths Hamlet in Irati,'' a solo dramatic piece written and performed by Ms. Stoklos, began performances this weekend at La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street. Several issues are covered in the work, which is based on Shakespeare's ''Hamlet.'' In it, Ms. Stoklos uses her childhood years in Brazil to examine the issue of independence for third-world countries. Performances are at 8 P.M. today and tomorrow. Tickets are $8. The show is to run weekends, including Fridays, through Feb. 21. Information: 475-7710 or 475-7908.

title: DURAKON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MENTOR GRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kirkpatrick Assails Treaty But Urges Senate Approval
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former American delegate to the United Nations, said today that the new missile accord was a bad agreement but one the Senate should approve anyway.

description: In an auction that ended Thursday night, Warner Books bought the paperback rights to ''Trump: The Art of the Deal'' by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz.

description: Postal Cuts in February

Layoffs at First Boston Expected to Total 300
description: The First Boston Corporation began a first round of layoffs last week, dismissing about 150 staff members, executives at the investment firm said yesterday.

title: 'Highlights in Jazz' Concert
description: A number of noted jazz musicians, including Tito Puente, Phil Woods, and Jon Faddis, will perform at a ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert on Thursday, at New York University, Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place. The concert marks the 15th anniversary of the jazz series. Also appearing will be John Pizzarelli Jr., Bob Mover, Tony Monte, Kenny Washington and James Williams. Tickets are $9 ($6.50 for students.) Information: 998-4999.

title: In China, Wrinkle of Change Or Just a Crumpled Old Suit?
description: ''Something strange is going on, that is certain,'' a Chinese writer said. ''I don't know what it is, but there is something.''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: CALTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings reflect the distribution of class B common stock to record holders during 1987, which had the effect of and was accounted for as a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: Survey Finds Wide AIDS Ignorance
description: A new survey has found widespread misinformation about AIDS, with 26 percent of the respondents thinking they would probably get the disease from giving blood and 36 percent believing they could get AIDS by eating at a restaurant where the cook has it.

title: Skier Sums Up Chances
description: Bill Johnson, the American downhill skier who surprisingly won a gold medal in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games, does not like his chances of gaining a berth on the 1988 United States Olympic Alpine ski team. In a telephone interview with the Rocky Mountain News from Schladming, Austria, where he in competing this weekend, Johnson said: ''The coaches are trying to get rid of me. They don't like me. They have never liked me. They never will. This year I haven't skied to my potential. But I feel I'm getting stronger.'' Johnson's best finish this year is a 33d, so his chances of selection seem meager. The Olympic team will be named next week, shortly before the United States Alpine championships.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a drawing on the Health page on Thursday about strokes incorrectly described two arterial systems feeding the brain. The vertebral-basilar system of arteries is parallel to the carotid arteries in the neck and behind them; the two systems join in the brain.

title: COAST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $700,000 and $2,900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $1,100,000 for the quarter and $3,200,000 for the year.

description: b-Includes a gain on disposition of discontinued operations of $11,207,000 and a charge of $4,200,000 from the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in income tax accounting method. c-Includes a tax credit of $5,894,000 and $16,740,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a gain of $2,595,000 from the renegotiation of an executory contract.

title: Seabrook Filing Stirs Fears on Rates
description: Who will set electricity rates for the customers of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire and whether the utility's assets will be sold emerged as major issues today following the utility's filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Up by 2.4%
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products this month rose an average 2.4 percent from last month's level and were 7.4 percent above prices last January, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Devils Recover for Victory in Overtime
description: Jan. 29 - Specialty-team play is one area Jim Schoenfeld, the new coach of the Devils, will have to improve if New Jersey is to make the playoffs for the first time in its history.

title: Desperate Financial Steps in '84 Come Back to Haunt Hart's '88 Campaign
description: Out of cash and nearly out of hope, Gary Hart's insurgent 1984 Presidential campaign took desperate financial measures that are now dogging his already battered 1988 candidacy.

title: Museum in Harlem Celebrates 3 Ways
description: A major Harlem cultural institution, the Studio Museum, celebrated its 20th anniversary in decisive fashion recently by announcing a new executive director, opening two new exhibitions and becoming the nation's first black or Hispanic institution accredited by the American Association of Museums, the world's largest organization of museums.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Angel Cordero, fully recovered from injuries to his chest and back suffered in a spill at Santa Anita Dec. 30, will resume riding at Aqueduct on Feb. 11. His agent, Kevin Lyons, said Cordero's first stakes engagement would be aboard D. Wayne Lukas's Cougarized in the $75,000 added Whirlaway Stakes at Aqueduct Feb. 12. . . . Barclay Plager, a former defenseman and coach for the Blues of the National Hockey League, is hospitalized at St. Luke's Hospital in St. Louis with inoperable brain tumors. He has elected not to undergo further experimental treatments and not to rely on life-support systems. Plager, 46 years old, has battled the tumors since 1984. . . . The Rangers have assigned Jim Pavese, a defenseman, to the Colorado Rangers of the International Hockey League. . . . Tom Seaver, who retired at the end of the 1986 season, was honored at the Boston Baseball Writers annual dinner as the winner of the Judge Emil Fuchs Memorial Award for long and meritorious service to baseball.

title: George Adams Quartet
description: George Adams, a saxophonist, and Don Pullen, a pianist, are leading a quartet with Cameron Brown on bass and Dannie Richmond on drums tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said during the latest year it acquired National Bancard Corp., Endata Inc. and First Data Mangement Co.

title: About New York; Brazilian Niche For an Author And His Fans
description: They had a book-signing party the other night on West 46th Street in a narrow shop brimming with smoked sausages, meat pies, manioc flour, coffee beans, beer, books, cassettes and periodicals, among other items. Nearly everyone spoke Portuguese, a silky language slipping off certain tongues. The author, who is famous round the world but not so hot in this republic yet, is Brazilian.

title: Koch Urges Commuter Tax Increase
description: Mayor Koch wants the State Legislature to double the income tax on commuters who work in New York City to help close the city's budget gap, he said yesterday.

title: Super Bowl Notebook; Humphries Expected to Start
description: Stefan Humphries, the Denver starting offensive guard who was injured in practice Thursday, was reported feeling better today. Coach Dan Reeves said he expected Humphries to start against the Washington Redskins Sunday in Super Bowl XXII.

title: ARCO-Tricentrol
description: ARCO slightly raised its stake in Tricentrol P.L.C. and indicated an intent to buy the entire company, an oil exploration and development concern. ARCO, which swooped into the market Thursday and scooped up 14.6 percent of Tricentrol's shares, said its further purchases brought the total stake to 14.8 percent, or 13.8 million shares. In addition, Arco said in a statement that it was considering a full bid for Tricentrol, which is also the target of potential acquisition by the British arm of the French state-owned oil company Societe Generale Elf Aquitaine. Tricentrol's shares rose about 3.5 cents today, to $3.36 a share.

title: EPSCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Allegis Begins Offer For 63% of Its Shares
description: The Allegis Corporation said yesterday that it had begun an $80-a-share tender offer for 35.5 million, or 63 percent, of its shares but added that it had still not completed an agreement with its banks that would finance the offer.

title: Judgment Delayed In Free-Agency Bid
description: A Federal judge today delayed judgment on a request by the National Football League Players Association to overturn the league's rules restricting free agency.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 30, 1988
description: International

title: Abie's English Phantom
description: When the English musical version of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' opened Tuesday night, it was already sold out until the second coming, which makes you wonder why they bothered to open it.

title: Out With the Bad Air: Dirt and Noise Fighters
description: For city dwellers, winter can mean stuffy rooms and heating pipes that clank through the night. Often an open window will only yield sooty, malodorous drafts and more noise.

title: Concert: Sinopoli Leads 2 Scriabin Symphonies
description: A conductor who decides to conduct two Scriabin symphonies on one program is unquestionably a brave man, confident of his powers. What can be questioned, however, is his good sense. Scriabin's orchestral works, intended as mystical or philosophical revelations, are so much alike in their shapeless meanderings and overheated rhetoric that hearing two of them in an evening can be numbing. Can be and was on Thursday night when Giuseppe Sinopoli led the New York Philharmonic in the Symphony No. 3 (''The Divine Poem'') and Symphony No. 4 (''The Poem of Ecstasy''). The Italian guest conductor, obviously a convinced Scriabinite, expertly aroused the orchestra to dozens if not hundreds of orgiastic climaxes but did not avoid the trap he had set for himself with such a musically arid program.

title: Jazz: Jay Hoggard's Quartet Plays at the West End Cafe
description: Jay Hoggard's quartet, which is playing at the West End Cafe, (2911 Broadway, between 113th and 114th Streets) through Sunday, has a free-flowing sense of unity that is the mark of an exceptional jazz group.

description: Bond prices advanced for the third consecutive session yesterday as market participants abandoned both their usual pre-weekend caution and the practice of balancing books before a Treasury refunding.

title: Better Off Under Reagan? Mostly, No
description: As we approach another Presidential election and in the aftermath of President Reagan's rosy State of the Union Message it is appropriate to revisit the question that Ronald Reagan used with such effect as a candidate in 1980: ''Are you better off now than you were when this Administration took office?''

title: Closing of Nuclear Reactor Is Near, Oregon Senator Says
description: Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, said today he believes the Reagan Administration has decided to permanently close the 25-year-old N Reactor at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington state.

title: Humbler G.M. Is Now Listening
description: For decades, executives of the General Motors Corporation decided among themselves what kind of cars Americans wanted. Now, with its market share down sharply executives at G.M. appear to be trying to find out what customers want.

title: In Jersey, Seeking Faith and Friends
description: The Calvary Episcopal Church has its ''Merry Mixers.'' The Flemington United Methodist Church has started a young-adult fellowship centered around potluck suppers and bowling.

description: b-Net loss and included a provision for takeover defense costs of $1.1 million, or $629,000 after pro forma tax effect. The company said it completed the sale and lease-back of its principal operating facility in Melville, N.Y., which produced an after-tax gain of about $2 million; it said the gain will be deferred and amortized over the 10- year lease period.

title: Ohio School Bus Overturns; 9 Students Are Hospitalized
description: A school bus carrying 35 high school students on a field trip slid off a highway and overturned today, the State Highway Patrol said. Nine students were hospitalized, one in critical condition.

title: Trade Gain For Bonn And Tokyo
description: West Germany and Japan posted record trade surpluses for 1987, according to reports released today. But the excesses are expected to ease this year because of their strong currencies and global demands that trade imbalances be cut.

The 1987 results also reflect a fourth-quarter net charge of $2.8 billion, applicable to the earlier announced proposed settlement of the disputed Pennzoil Co. judgment claim filed as part of Texaco's Chapter 11 reorganization plan in the U.S. bankruptcy court. c-Reflected in the fourth quarter of 1987 were foreign currency gains, net of related income taxes, of $43 million, compared with currency translation gains of $31 million for the 1986 period; for the full-year 1987, foreign currency translation gains amounted to $46 million, as compared with gains of $130 million for the year 1986. d-Net income

title: Change at Apple Creates New Posts
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it would restructure its research and development organization to encourage new products and emphasize products for networking and communications. The action created positions for two new vice presidents who will report to Jean-Louis Gasse, senior vice president of research and development.

title: Killer of 2 Policemen Wins Parole in Jersey
description: A man convicted of killing two Bergen County policemen more than 24 years ago will be released from prison March 15 unless the State Parole Board intervenes, a board official said yesterday.

title: Tyson-Spinks 'Very Close'
description: Shelly Finkel, a manager involved with the negotiations for a proposed Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks fight on June 24, said late yesterday that the match seemed ''very close.'' Finkel said that Butch Lewis, Spinks's promoter, is seeking a buyout rather than a guaranteed advance.

title: 3 Visual Artists Win $5,000 Film Awards
description: Two film makers and a video artist are the recipients of this year's Maya Deren Awards, sponsored by the American Film Institute. The three - Bruce Conner, Yvonne Rainer and Bill Viola - will each receive a $5,000 cash award. J. Hoberman, a film critic for The Village Voice, is to receive a citation from the institute for contributions to independent film and video.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an an editing error, an article yesterday about questions surrounding Vice President Bush's knowledge of the Iran-contra affair misstated the record on what is known about the involvement of Donald P. Gregg, an aide to Mr. Bush. Mr, Gregg was aware of a plan to resupply the contras; there is no evidence that he knew it was financed in part from proceeds of arms sales to Iran.

title: HOGAN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $950,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $1,279,000 for the quarter and $2,578,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago third quarter and 9-month have been restated to include operations of GDK Systems Inc., acquired in May 1987.

title: KEY RATES
Donors to the Neediest Recall History of Gifts
description: Hortense M. Hirsch, who celebrated her 100th birthday last August with congratulations from wide and far, contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund again, for the 70th year in a row.

title: Man Is Found Shot to Death At His Apartment in Chelsea
description: The body of a man who had been shot in the head was found in a Manhattan apartment yesterday, the police said, and it was unclear how long he had been dead.

title: ISRAELIS ACCUSED OF MORE BEATINGS
description: The focus of Palestinian protest shifted to East Jerusalem today as relief workers charged that 50 Palestinians had to be treated for injuries after Israeli police officers swept through a refugee camp in a roundup of male residents.

title: South Korea Chief Says He Never Sought Power
description: Although he seized control in a military coup eight years ago, President Chun Doo Hwan insists that he never actively sought power. ''The country was in peril,'' he said today. ''The job was thrust upon me.''

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes for the quarter a $40.0 million pretax gain from the sale of DC-9 jetliners to an airline that had been leasing them and also includes $12.0 million, before tax, from the sale of part of McDonnell Douglas's interest in an aircraft leasing operation. The required adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 87, which changed the method of accounting for pension costs, and an increase in the actuarial rate of return on pension plan assets increased fourth quarter earnings by approximately $46.2 million before tax, compared to the fourth quarter of 1986. Fourth-quarter 1987 net earnings were approximately $27 million higher as a result of a decline in the corporate income-tax rate. c-Includes a contribution of $177 million to the improvement in pre-tax earnings from 1986 to 1987 due to the required adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 87 and an increase in the actuarial rate of return on pension-plan assets; a decrease in 1987 pretax earnings by $64.5 million due to a voluntary early retirement program; pretax gains of $37.6 million from the conversion of Md-80 jetliners from short-term to long-term leases, and $40.0 million from the fourth- quarter sale of previously-leased DC- 9s.; research and development spending of $647.7 million compared with $504.8 million in 1986; and a $45.1 million decline, from 1986, of amortization costs connected with the acquisition of companies, mostly by the Information Systems Group. d-Includes writeoffs of $71.1 million involving CF-18 aircraft for Canada, $61.6 million involving modifications to the AH-64 Apache helicopter, and $12.1 million involving equipment for producing pharmaceuticals in space. Gains totaling $14.5 million before tax from the sale of several small companies and of $14.6 after tax from the sale of real estate.

title: SMOKER'S LAWSUIT ENDS IN A MISTRIAL
description: A mistrial was declared here today in a lawsuit against a tobacco company charged with causing a smoker's death by lung cancer. The jury deadlocked in the case that had been widely viewed as having the best chance of succeeding of any brought by smokers who charged that their illnesses were brought on by cigarettes.

title: GEPHARDT HOPEFUL ON IOWA CAUCUSES
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt heads toward the first round of the 1988 Democratic Presidential competition with cautious optimism that he can surge ahead of the field and win the Iowa caucuses.

title: Dutch Actor's Tale Exposes A Nation's Guilt About Jews
description: After an amazing piece of psychopolitical theater Dutch Jews and Christians have found themselves looking anew at a painful past that many of them would prefer to forget.

description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $88,000.

title: Nurses in Los Angeles Return
description: Nurses returned to work at hospitals in Los Angeles County today after a judge ordered an end to their strike, but pharmacists called in sick and doctors vowed to strike the county's largest medical center. The doctors, nurses and pharmacists have been working without contracts since September.

title: Suzanne Farrell's Hard Road Back: From 'Mr. B,' a Little Bit of a Push
description: There was a moment's silence as a slender figure in a white gown moved to the center of the stage, alone, and began to dance. And then applause broke like a wave about the dancer. Suzanne Farrell was back, and the roar of acclaim that swept her off the stage at the end suggested that, for a good many New York dancegoers, all was once more right with the world.

title: When the Census Is Precisely Wrong
description: With the 1990 Census still 27 months away, the Commerce Department says it seeks ''the best census ever,'' including a reduction of the perennial undercount. Yet it has decided, prematurely, that it won't consider adjustments that could smooth the undercount's uneven and unfair impact. It's a mistake that could be costly for the cities and states that bear the undercount's burden. Congress needs to move quickly with corrective legislation.

title: Thailand to Turn Back Vietnamese Refugee Boats
description: Seeking to stem a flood of new Vietnamese refugees fleeing their country through Cambodia, Thailand this week officially began turning back refugee boats arriving in eastern Thailand from Cambodian ports.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: MYLAN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sizzler Coach Dismissed
description: John Killilea, who spent 14 years as an assistant coach in the National Basketball Association under Tom Heinsohn in Boston, Don Nelson in Milwaukee and Stan Albeck of the Nets, somewhere along the line developed an explosive temper that may have cost him his job as head coach of the Topeka Sizzlers of the Continental Basketball Association. Killilea, in his second year with Topeka, had been called for 15 technical fouls while his team was compiling a 13-17 won-lost record. Yesterday he was dismissed by the team's owner, Bernie Glannon, a day after Killilea suffered his third ejection of the season in a 138-132 loss to the Spirits in Savannah, Ga.

title: Greyhound Set To Drop Verex
description: The Greyhound Corporation said today that it would get out of the mortgage insurance business. As a result, the company will take an after-tax charge of $45 million in the fourth quarter of 1987 to reclassify its Verex Corporation mortgage insurance subsidiary as a discontinued operation.

title: South Africa Crash Kills 13
description: A bus carrying black policemen on their way to give a gymnastics exhibition plunged off a mountain road today, killing 13 officers and injuring 71, the police said. The crash occurred at Robinson Pass in Cape Province.

title:
Patents;
Pest-Control Method
description: LEAD: A method has been invented for controlling pests, including insects, mites and worms. Patent 4,721,727 was granted this week to Kenneth L. Mikolajczak of Dunlap, Ill., and two co-inventors, and assigned to the Agriculture Department. The method uses chemicals called acetogenins. No licenses toward protection have yet been granted, but some interest has been expressed by pharmaceutical companies, the inventors said.

description: The General Electric Company has emerged as the leading candidate to buy Montgomery Ward or lead a leveraged buyout of the revitalized, 315-store chain, investment bankers said yesterday.

title: French Decorative Arts Subject of a Symposium
description: Four experts will present slide-illustrated lectures on topics ranging from the landscape architecture of France before the revolution of 1789 to the interiors of private palaces and Parisian town houses. The four are Baroness Marie-Therese de Willermin, a professor of art history; Princess Laure de Beauvau Craon, an art historian and lecturer; William Howard Adams, an authority on landscape architecture and gardens, and Barbara de Portago, a set and costume designer and lecturer.

Driver Flees After Car Kills a Girl in Harlem
description: A 9-year-old girl was killed and her two companions were seriously injured in Harlem yesterday when a car went out of control and struck them, the police said. The driver fled.

title: AIDS and Headlong Headlines
description: Much news about AIDS is grim, but the isolation of a new form of AIDS virus, known as HIV-2, from a woman in Newark is no particular reason for panic. ''New AIDS Bug Perils Blood Banks,'' gasped the hasty tabloid headline. That's just what the virus doesn't do.

title: Reagan Bars Mention of Abortion At Clinics Receiving U.S. Money
description: In the first formal step of what promises to be a major legal battle, the Reagan Administration today prohibited most of the nation's family planning clinics from providing advice or other assistance that would help women obtain abortions.

description: American and Brazilian officials have been locked in a sharp dispute this week over Brazil's intention to sell a large quantity of arms to Libya.

description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Downing Pope, 87, Dies; Promoter of Florida and Tourism
description: Richard Downing Pope Sr., the flamboyant showman who built Cypress Gardens park and was credited with revitalzing Florida's tourist industry after World War II, died Thursday at his home here. He was 87 years old.

title: Super Alternatives
description: Brace yourself, America. Super Bowl coverage begins at 2:30 A.M. tomorrow, Eastern time, with ESPN's highlights of the first 21 games, and goes on and on until ABC's coverage of the 22d ends around 10 P.M. Eight of the earlier games rank among television's top ten most watched programs. Tomorrow's may make it nine. ABC estimates that 120 million Americans will watch some of it, roughly half the population.

title: Court Allows Mother's Suit Over Taking of Child's Eyes
description: An appeals court has ruled that a woman may sue Dr. Shashi Gore, an Orange County assistant medical examiner, who is accused of removing her dead daughter's eyes for transplants against the mother's wishes.

COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Atlas Van Lines Inc., Evansville, Ind., which is controlled by affiliates of Wesray Capital Corp., said that a group of Atlas agents were exploring ways to acquire the company.

title: Nofziger Jury Is Told How Wedtech Got Pact
description: The Small Business Administration helped the Wedtech Corporation finance a military contract only because of interest expressed by a top aide to Edwin Meese 3d, the agency's former second-ranking official testified today.

title: BULGARIAN REJECTS POLITICAL OPENING
description: A top Communist Party official today defended Bulgaria's lack of eagerness to accompany its program of restructuring economic and administrative life with a parallel emphasis on greater openness.

description: Stock prices rose yesterday as the market continued its seesaw pattern of recent weeks.

STUDY TURNS UP NO PROTECTION DUE TO ASPIRIN
description: A six-year study involving more than 5,000 British doctors has found no strong evidence that regular use of aspirin reduces the risk of heart attack, but the authors say their data do not necessarily invalidate a similar but much larger American study that showed the rate of heart attacks was cut almost in half.

title: Head of New York Urban League Quits, and Regrouping Is Planned
description: Harriet Michel resigned as president of the New York Urban League this week to accept a resident fellowship at Harvard University.

title: Japan Confirms It Will Continue U.S. Quota of 2.3 Million Cars
description: Japan's trade minister confirmed today that the nation would continue its quotas on automobile exports to the United States for another year, at the current level of 2.3 million cars.

title: B.P.'s Britoil Stake
description: The British Petroleum Company has completed the purchase of the 24 percent stake in Britoil P.L.C. that had been held by ARCO and in the process gained a majority of the shares of the North Sea oil producer. But B.P.'s control of the company's board still hinges on a Government decision. The British Government said it was ready to meet Britoil and B.P. next week to discuss the bid of $:2.5 million, or about $4.5 billion, which Britoil is resisting. B.P. has acquired 54 percent of Britoil's shares, but the Government holds a ''golden share'' in the company and has said it will use it to block any attempt to control the board if that were seen to conflict with the national interest.

title: Court Bars Legal-Fee Award For Iran-Contra Case Figure
description: The special court that appointed an independent counsel to investigate the Iran-contra affair refused today to award legal fees to a retired Air Force officer who received immunity in the inquiry.

description: Sandinista and contra negotiators ended their first face-to-face talks here today with a decision to meet again in two weeks in Guatemala, but little other substantive agreement.
