title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Zurbriggen Atop Standing: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland won his second downhill race of the season and vaulted into first place in the overall World Cup standing yesterday, ahead of Alberto Tomba of Italy. Zurbriggen swept down a dangerous course in Schladming, Austria, in 1 minute 59.28 seconds. Franz Heinzer of Switzerland was second in 2:00.01, edging Peter Duerr of West Germany by one-hundredth of a second in the last World Cup downhill before the Olympic Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta. Zurbriggen, the 1984 and 1987 champion, increased his World Cup total to 211 points. Tomba has 206. (AP) Track Johnson Sets World Best: Ben Johnson, erasing his standard, set a world best of 5.15 seconds in the men's 50-yard dash, and Angella Issajenko matched the world best of 5.74 in the women's 50-yard race at the Toronto Sun Challenge track and field meet last night. Johnson had set the existing mark of 5.20 two weeks ago in Hamilton, Ontario, erasing Stanley Floyd's mark of 5.22. Desai Williams was second in 5.28 and Mark McKoy, who earlier won the 50-yard hurdles, was third in 5.29 to complete a sweep by Toronto runners.(AP) College Basketball Princeton 72, Brown 60: Bob Scrabis and Dave Orlandini scored 19 points each for Princeton, which broke open the game with seven 3-point field goals in the second half last night. The Tigers are 9-4 over all and 1-0 in the Ivy League. Brown is 4-11 over all and 0-3 in the league. Marcus Thompson and Anthony Katsaros had 15 points apiece for the Bruins.(AP) Penn 87, Yale 76: Tyrone Pitts had 26 points and 14 rebounds to lead Penn to the victory in Philadelphia. The Quakers improved their record to 3-9 over all and 1-0 in the Ivy League. The Elis are 6-9 and 2-1. Paul Maley led Yale with 28 points. (AP)

title: The High Cost of Care For the Frail Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Treaty Is Not a Christmas Tree
description: Senators will be sorely tempted to put their stamp on the treaty to eliminate medium- and shorter-range missiles. The itch seemed irresistible as the hearings got under way this week. But an array of political and military authorities told them the treaty was good for American security as is, and that other issues could be attended to elsewhere. It's good advice. The Senate's duty here is not to settle old scores or push new agendas but to decide whether to ratify this treaty.

title: Europeans Assail Bill On Export Sanctions
description: The European Community, in a note to the State Department, has protested a Senate-passed measure imposing sanctions against violators of allied export controls. It threatened retaliation should European companies be hit by the legislation.

title: BALDWIN TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Media Have Wronged Howard Beach
description: Over the past year, ''Howard Beach'' has become the new catch-phrase for racism.

title: MYOPIC INADEQUACIES OF L.I. HIGHWAYS
description: The Dec. 20 article ''The Expressway: Is a Fourth Lane in Sight?'' imperatively spotlights this massive, myopic example of the highway inadequacies impeding our Long Island economy and life style.

title:
Body and Mind;
Kick Off Your Heels
description: LEAD: A FRIEND OF MINE, a sedate historian, allows how he used to sit in the library as a graduate student at Princeton trying to bury his thoughts in some thick tome. In those bad old days, when Princeton was all-male, the appearance of a female visitor would sometimes be signaled by a sound outside the window in the summer evening: the unmistakable click, click of high heels on the garden walk.

title:
DINING OUT;
A HOPE FOR RECOVERED EXCELLENCE
description: LEAD: PERHAPS it's the seven-year itch, or maybe the management has simply dropped the ball, but whatever it is, a meal at Sonny D is not what it used to be.

title: SICK THINKING
description: It is an excellent idea to take your spouse or another person to the doctor with you, especially if surgery is on the agenda. The subtle mental dysfunction discussed in Morton Hunt's article must not cloud what lawyers and physicians recognize as informed consent to undergo a surgical procedure. Relevant questions should be asked and note should be made of the risks of the intervention, possible complications and the expected benefits. E. DOUGLAS WHITEHEAD, M.D. New York, N.Y.

title: Kean Seeks AIDS Agency
description: A new state agency to deal with the AIDS crisis in New Jersey will be urged by Governor Kean in his proposed $11.8 billion budget. Page 36.

title: On New Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: For Arabs and Israelis, Maybe It Never Ends
description: SOME three years ago, two Israeli college students were out on a hike on a sunny weekend morning near a monastery outside Bethlehem. An angry Palestinian youth, who had somehow got hold of a gun, ran into them on the trail and decided on the spur of the moment to tie them to a tree and murder them for nationalist reasons. A short time later, several Israeli university students, two men and a woman, got into an Arab taxi, asked the driver to take them down a lonely road and then shot him in the back of the head.

title: Is the Upper East Side Moving North?
description: ON the east side of Manhattan, from 96th Street north, empty lots still outnumber condominiums, boarded-up windows are more common than ''For Sale'' signs and trash far exceeds brass. Nonetheless, people who live there are worried that the neighborhood is getting trendy.

title: Jonah D. Kosovsky; Physician, 61
description: Dr. Jonah D. Kosovsky, an assistant attending physician in Mount Sinai Medical Center's department of medicine, died of cancer last Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 61 years old.

title: Nicaragua Frees American Pilot
description: An American jailed and charged with anti-Government activities after his small plane was shot down last month was released to a United States Senate candidate and a group of lawyers today and flown to Los Angeles.

title: THE PHANTOM'S MANY FACES OVER THE YEARS
description: For Gaston Leroux, author of the novel ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' there was no doubt that his Phantom existed, that he was a man assuming the appearance ''of a spectral shade.'' The tangibility of the Phantom - what might be called Leroux's Law -is preserved through all the disparate dramatizations, from Lon Chaney's hollow-eyed, death's-head version in the 1925 silent film to Claude Rains's more sedate 1943 cinematic impersonation to Brian De Palma's rock-toned modernization, ''The Phantom of the Paradise.''

title: STATE OFFICIALS FEAR RISE IN HOSPITAL FEES MAY ENDANGER PLANS TO EXPAND MEDICAID
description: LEAD: AFTER months of hearing complaints that New Jersey hospitals can no longer afford to recruit and retain enough nurses, state regulators have given the institutions an 8.5 percent across-the-board rate increase. Due to take effect tomorrow, it will be the largest increase since the state began, in 1980, to tell hospitals how much they could charge.

title: BALLROOM DANCING MAKES A COMEBACK
description: WHENEVER a band struck up a fox trot, waltz or any other number associated with ballroom dancing, Karen Gross of Stamford would remain seated.

title: TALKING: Home Office; The New Outlook On Taxes
description: PEOPLE who run an office out of a home may no longer find it worthwhile to take allowable deductions on the office when preparing income tax returns this spring.

title: A Lyrical Pianist Who Had Everything
description: Benno Moiseiwitsch (1890-1963) started recording in 1916, and thus he lived through several revolutions in the recording industry, from acoustic to electric, to LP, to stereo. He was, along with Paderewski, Schnabel, Friedman, Gabrilowitsch and many other headliners of the day, a pupil of Theodor Leschetizky, who produced as many great pianists as Liszt. (The last living Leschetizky pupil of importance is Mieczyslaw Horszowski, 95 years old and still going strong.) In his great days, up to World War II, Moiseiwitsch was one of the supreme pianists. He had everything - technique, a glorious sound, poetry, strength when needed, an easygoing and unmannered musical mind. He made playing the piano sound so effortless, and so natural. His colleagues ranked him with any living pianist. Stylistically he was primarily a lyricist. He was not as mercurial as Hofmann, or as pre-planned as the more austere Rachmaninoff. Perhaps the closest pianist to him in style was Josef Lhevinne.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I have a chair whose frame is made of white plastic that has discolored to an uneven beige. Yet a painted metal brace is still white. Is there any way to clean or bleach the plastic, or is there a white paint I can apply?

title: DR. FLORENCE HOUN, AN INTERNIST, TO WED
description: Dr. Florence Houn, an internist in Baltimore, and Dr. Mark Jay Goldberger, an attending physician at the Presbyterian Hospital in New York, are planning a summer wedding, the parents of the bride-to-be, Prof. Franklin Wu Houn of Amherst, Mass., and Frances Lu Houn of Cambridge, Mass., have announced.

title: U.S. PROMISE TO STUDY THE SOUND WAS RELUCTANT
description: THE spending bill Congress passed last month included $2.2 million to continue environmental studies of Long Island Sound and the surrounding shoreline.

title: Senator Nunn's Questionable Defense
description: Senator Sam Nunn went to dinner at the Arms Control Association last week to receive a peace award, and dropped a bombshell in his hosts' laps. Being honored for his efforts to restrict the scope of ''Star Wars'' research, he startled his audience by suggesting that America should consider deployment of a land-based mini-''Star Wars'' system to defend against an accidental or unauthorized missile attack.

title: LAFAYETTE RELIES ON CLASSIC FRENCH
description: A Frenchman on the street in Lafayette's day would have found the menu at Lafayette restaurant in Smithtown very familiar. All the French golden oldies are there: pate, escargots, coquilles St.-Jacques, duckling a l'orange, entrecote au poivre, rack of lamb, Chateaubriand, frog legs Provencal and crepes suzette.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: EVEN talking about it, Mary Jean Tully gets exceedingly annoyed. She isn't the self-pitying type, but on certain social occasions, she does wonder, ''Why, oh, why me?'' And it doesn't help much to know that the same thing happens to a lot of other people, and that these people often have the very same thought.

title: Excerpts From the Budget Message to Be Delivered by Kean
description: Following are excerpts from the budget message Governor Kean will deliver to the Legislature on Tuesday:

title: KAY LIVES WITH FEAR OF ADDICTION
description: In and around the Rocky Mountains, and wherever people wear orange with a passion during the football season, the moment is remembered as the one that changed a Super Bowl.

title: LOVE POSTS 66 TO REGAIN LEAD IN PHOENIX
description: Fred Couples opened today's third round of the Phoenix Open with an eagle 2 on the first hole, then sank a 40-foot birdie putt on the second. That was a strong enough start to get the attention of Davis Love 3d.

title: Industry and River Form a Gulf Between 2 States
description: As the Pigeon River winds through the Great Smoky Mountains in North Carolina, its waters are clear and filled with bass and trout. But about 40 miles before crossing into Tennessee, the river turns the color of coffee, and the only fish found in it are bottom dwellers like carp and bullhead.

title: THE SCHOOLS NEED PARENTS IN WAR ON AIDS
description: THE schools are being asked to lead the battle against AIDS, whether fully prepared or not, and to do so hurriedly in a desperate race against worldwide tragedy.

title: ANDREW LERMAN ENGAGED TO JULIA MCKAY VAN RODEN
description: The engagement of Julia McKay van Roden to Andrew Howard Lerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max R. Lerman of East Falls, Pa., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mary McKay Biddle of Jamestown, R.I., and Donald van Roden of Wyomissing, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

title: Car Stereo: A Turn for the Better
description: Music keeps chang-ing venue. From church and palace, it moved to the public concert hall as its chief abode. Then the parlor piano and later the phonograph and radio brought music into the living room. And now it seems that music is on the move again, in more than one way. These days, much of it is heard in cars.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LEAKING: Who Does It? Who Benefits? At What Cost? By Elie Abel. (Twentieth Century Fund/Priority Press, $18.95.) In Washington, leaking Government secrets to reporters is as old as the filibuster, but, Elie Abel says, hardly anyone outside the Capital Beltway understands it. For the uninitiated, Mr.

title: Tarte Flambee From Alsace
description: IN the dialect spoken in Alsace, flammekueche means ''cooked in the flames''; the French flambee has a similar meaning. Whatever it's called, tarte flambee is to northern Alsace what pizza is to southern Italy.

title: Cynthia Shelton, Business Student, Is Wed in Atlanta
description: At St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Atlanta, Cynthia Anne Shelton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Shelton of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Nassim Taleb, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Nagib Taleb of Beirut, Lebanon. The Rev. William W. Shelton, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: AN AMERICAN HABIT: SHUNNING THE BALLOT BOX
description: ONLY the very brave or the very foolish are making predictions about the voters' choices this year. But one prediction can be made with confidence: Of Americans eligible to go to the polls, the largest group will shun all the candidates. They will not vote.

title: Collectors and Curious Buy Marcos Bric-a-brac
description: There were none of the legendary pairs of shoes. There were none of the cushions with the pithy sayings, such as ''Nouveau riche is better than no riche at all,'' and none of the formal portraits that were actually blown-up photographs, painted over in oils.

title: FIRST AMENDMENT: IS IT JUST FOR ADULTS?
description: AS an editor of a high school newspaper I am enraged by the Supreme Court's Hazelwood v. Kuhlmeier decision.

title: LAURA YORKE, EDITOR, WEDS
description: The marriage of Laura Best Yorke, a daughter of Lane Harvey Yorke of New York and Aaron Jones Yorke 4th of New York and Southampton, L.I., to Thomas Peter Kikis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Kikis of New York and Nassau, the Bahamas, took place yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. Bishop Isaiah, chancellor of the Archdiocese of North and South America, performed the ceremony. The Rev. Dr. Theodore O. Jones, associate minister of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, gave the benediction.

title: Taking Off From Tucson
description: SOUTHERN ARIZONA. To an Easterner who had never traveled to this corner of the United States before, the image Tucson and its vicinity brought to mind was of vast, dusty plains, an expanse broken only by the profile of a straggly cactus. But, in fact, the natural beauty of this section of the Grand Canyon State is startlingly diverse; day trips from Tucson will take the traveler from the lush coolness of a mountain canyon to the raw beauty of a forest of saguaro cactuses. And a wealth of historic sites along the way, from the ruins of a Franciscan mission to a restored Victorian mining town, evoke the region's rugged past.

title: Philadelphia Group Sees Homeless Study As Help to Officials
description: A coalition for the homeless is banking on a survey of Pennsylvania's homeless to give officials a better idea of who needs help and what help is needed.

title: CAR RENTALS: THE UNADVERTISED EXTRAS
description: RENTING a car can be a frenzied experience. Initial here, sign there, grab the keys and be gone.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Giant Resort Flexes Its Housing Muscles
description: LEAD: FOR the last 20 years a large swath through the central portion of Vernon Township in Sussex County has been slowly evolving into a residential-resort community set against the side of the Kittatinny Mountains.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Back Bay's New Neighbor
description: LEAD: BY spring the Heritage, an $85 million mixed-use complex with a traditional look, will open on what was the last remaining development site bordering the Public Garden.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
The Riverfront Is Bustling
description: LEAD: THE name - Riverview Lofts - evokes images of luxury. And many of those who inquire about space in the renovated 200,000-square-foot warehouse at North Delaware Avenue and Spring Garden Street are apartment hunters who are not deterred by the surroundings: the eight-story building is on one of Philadelphia's truck routes and opposite a riverfront garbage incinerator.

title: POSTINGS: Coming Attraction; 9 Bronx Stores
description: A former RKO movie theater is being converted into nine storefronts on Broadway at 232d Street in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. The 14,500-square-foot building, which David Magier purchased last August for $1.4 million, was built in the 1920's and for the past 20 years has been used as a bingo parlor. The $1.6 million project will be completed in May, and its space will rent for about $30 a square foot.

title: Bistate Team to Help Homeless Is Proposed
description: A bistate crisis team should be formed to deal with the needs of homeless people who have established almost permanent homes in public transportation centers, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: 75 Years Late, Pennsylvania Honors 2 Civil War Heroes
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Secret Weapon: Horseradishes

title: Mail Fraud Conviction Of Blanton Dismissed
description: A Federal judge, relying on a Supreme Court ruling last year, has thrown out the mail fraud charges on which former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee was convicted and served two years in prison.

title: LINKING OWNERSHIP AND MAINTENANCE
description: I read, with great interest, the article on ''A Private Owner for Public Housing'' [ Jan. 10 ] . Although I think that private ownership of public housing has possibilities, I would have preferred to see public housing sold to tenants of the buildings rather than to a private company.

title: Recalling Moment With Ali
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: PERLMAN IN MONTCLAIR

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
NEIGHBORS
description: LEAD: After Temple Beth Am in Yorktown Heights was covered recently with swastikas, anti-Jewish slogans and references to Satan and heavy metal music, the community and the county responded.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BALLAD OF ANOTHER TIME. By Jose Luis Gonzalez. Translated by Asa Zatz. (Council Oaks Books/Independent Publishers Group, Paper, $7.95.) Jose Luis Gonzalez, a Puerto Rican short-story writer and cultural historian living in Mexico City, is one of the island's foremost writers, a man whose compact style creates an atmosphere of extreme tension throughout his brief narratives.

title: MUMBLING TO THE COMPUTER
description: I would like to add to William Safire's collection of ''summative dribble-offs'' such as et cetera, blah, blah, blah and whatever (On Language: ''I am Appalled,'' Dec. 20). Among folks who work in computer science, artificial intelligence and cognitive science, the term mumble has become a mildly self-deprecatory way to terminate a thought that has gotten beyond the control of its thinker. This happens not infrequently at the cutting edge of the information sciences. The user can safely exit to ''mumble'' when he is at risk of flaming - another Silicon Valley locution that means ''getting intellectually outrageous or otherwise losing it.'' ARNOLD S. WASSERMAN Blue Bell, Pa.

title: ALEXIS EFTHIMIOU TO WED IN APRIL
description: The engagement of Alexis Efthimiou to Scott Livington Probasco 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Probasco Jr. of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George B. Efthimiou of Garden City, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: PREPAID PROGRAMS FOR HEALTH CARE ENCOUNTER SNAGS
description: After 15 years of spectacular growth in which health maintenance organizations have enrolled nearly 30 million Americans, there are signs that consumers are losing their enthusiasm for the plans, which offer comprehensive medical care for a set fee.

title:
DINING OUT;
FRENCH MENU IN BRIARCLIFF MANOR
description: LEAD: IT'S sad to report that over the last few years this promising restaurant - surely one of the area's prettiest - has declined in both food and service. Hope that the kitchen would in time muster a meal worthy of the decor brought us back now and again for a sampling; but our visits resulted in disappointments.

title: Link to Meese Brings Fame and Allegations
description: As investigators have looked into the role of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in the Wedtech affair and in a never-built Iraqi pipeline project that now appears to involve hints of bribery, the name E. Robert Wallach has come up repeatedly.

title:
GARDENING;
HYBRID CREATION CAN BE WORTH THE EFFORT
description: LEAD: MANY of the most useful garden plants are hybrids. That is, they have resulted from crossing plants of dissimilar characteristics.

title: A Bergman Star Savors Chekhov
description: When Erland Josephson enters as Gaev, brother of Lyubov, in Peter Brook's current production of ''The Cherry Orchard'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater, American audiences may experience a Scandinavian-accented sense of deja vu. A familiar face from nearly a dozen Ingmar Bergman films, including the director's most recent work, ''Fanny and Alexander,'' Mr. Josephson is making his American stage debut - indeed, his English-language stage debut - in an acting career that includes more than 100 plays.

title: Deerfield Will Admit Girls in Fall of 1989
description: Deerfield Academy, one of the largest all-male preparatory schools, announced today that it would begin admitting girls next year.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Paying a Big Price for a Spot at the Shore
description: LEAD: FOR most people, the thought of paying $35,000 or so for a 100-square-foot structure would seem outrageous. But for those who wish to own even a small piece of the Long Island waterfront, the idea makes a great deal of sense.

title: VERBATIM: WHOSE PARTY?
description: 'Anybody that suggests aboriginal people have a lot to celebrate this year as a result of the last 200 years hasn't taken much note of history.' - Gerry Hand, Australia's Minister for Abroriginal Affairs, announcing that he would boycott the bicentennial festivities.

title: Photography
description: Only a few months ago, at the Museum of Modern Art, Henri Cartier-Bresson was shown to us as a photographer rooted in the styles and ideology of Surrealism. Now, with ''Henri Cartier-Bresson in India,'' a show of some 100 of his prints at the International Center of Photography (1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street), we can see him in his later, more conventional guise as a photojournalist.

title: Correction
description: A Travel Advisory report on Jan. 3 reversed the dimensions of the screen at the Max-Linder movie theater in Paris. It is about 28 feet high and 54 feet wide.

title: Miss Minnesota-U.S.A. Held On a Charge of Shoplifting
description: Miss Minnesota-U.S.A. was arrested on a gross misdemeanor theft charge after a security guard at a department store here told police she was shoplifting, City Attorney Marsh Halberg said today.

title: COUNTY COURTROOMS TO BEGIN EXPERIMENT WITH CAMERAS
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER is joining the statewide experiment with cameras in the courtroom tomorrow, something the district's new administrative judge says is good for the judiciary and good for the public.

title: HELEN F. MICHALIS IS MARRIED
description: Helen Fahnestock Michalis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Fahnestock Michalis of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Michael Hayden Bonebrake, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Bonebrake of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: U.S. Cautions Doctors On Use of Flu Vaccine
description: The flu vaccine in current use may not give optimal protection against this winter's most prevalent type of influenza, Government scientists say.

title: Trump: Symbol of a Gaudy, Impatient Time
description: Not since the first William Zeckendorf rose to prominence in the 1950's has a real-estate developer loomed so large in the public mind as Donald Trump. Part of this, of course, is Mr. Trump's propensity for naming his projects after himself - there is Trump Tower, Trump Plaza, Trump Parc, as well as Trump's Castle and Trump Plaza in Atlantic City - but a great deal of it is the manner in which Mr. Trump has positioned himself as a symbol of the values of this age.

title: THE BEAUTY - AND MYSTERY - OF GLASS
description: A WHILE ago, a friend at odds with his colleagues told of a dream in which they were feeding him glass. This writer, at an offbeat exhibition recently, recalled her visceral reaction to his story when she confronted a pile of broken glass contained within a circular rim. Glass at its rawest -jagged, brittle, uncivilized by shaping and capable of hurting - rarely shows up in galleries where glass is the theme.

title: Recalling Tet, the Attack That Began the End
description: Col. Do Tan Phong remembers Jan. 31, 1968, in vivid detail. Before dawn on the second day of Tet, the Lunar New Year, five small units of Vietcong commandos struck Saigon.

title: Bulgaria Planning Value Tax
description: Bulgaria plans to introduce a Western-style value-added tax to accompany major increases in prices, a leading Communist Party official said today. But the official, Emil Christov, a Central Committee Secretary, promised that wages would keep pace with the price rises.

title: Racism in Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: MARTHA WOLFE, LAWYER, TO MARRY
description: Judge and Mrs. Sheldon J. Wolfe of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Louise Wolfe, to James Phillip Verscaj, a son of Catherine Verscaj of Los Angeles and the late John J. Verscaj. A June wedding is planned.

title: TURNPIKE CHIEF LEAVING POST
description: LEAD: FOR many people, a drive on the New Jersey Turnpike could not end soon enough.

title: Players, Plans and Statistics: How They Match Up: Broncos
INSIDE
description: James R. Killian Jr. Dies

title: Iowa Tactic: Shake the Hand That Shook the Hand of . . .
description: Representative Marvin Leath of Texas seemed disappointed. Here he had come all the way from Waco to persuade Charlie Gross, an Iowa farmer, to support Representative Richard A. Gephardt in next month's Democratic caucus, and Mr. Gross confessed he was still leaning to Senator Paul Simon.

title: JANE PENZINER TO WED DANIEL DAUSCH IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Penziner of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Laura Penziner to Daniel George Dausch, a son of Kathryn Dausch and George Edward Dausch, both of Easthampton, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: EAST HAMPTON CONSIDERS IMPACT OF PLANNED MARINA
description: ON the western shore of Fort Pond Bay in East Hampton Town rests the stripped earth of an abandoned sand mine. A developer is proposing to reclaim the disturbed area by scooping out upland and bay bottom to build a five-acre marina.

title: NEWARK OF THE 40'S LIVES AGAIN IN FILM THAT PREMIERES THURSDAY
description: THERE'LL be a bit of Hollywood in Montclair next Thursday night - searchlights, actors, music and a reception at the venerable Wellmont Theater.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MUSICAL EVENTS: A Chronicle, 1980-1983. By Andrew Porter. (Summit, $24.95.) Andrew Porter has been a music critic at The New Yorker for more than 15 years, and ''Musical Events'' is his fourth collection of previously published reviews. What makes Mr. Porter so readable is not simply his brilliant intellect, insatiable curiosity and catholic tastes, but his masterly command of language.

title: Opera: Bernstein's 'Trouble in Tahiti'
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN'S ''Trouble in Tahiti'' has raised its public profile the past few years, but encased within the composer's newer, altogether grimmer opera ''A Quiet Place.'' It was nice on Friday to see this lovely, touching, delicately put-together treatise on love in the suburbs (the original is from 1952) floating free of its more recently acquired burdens. The production is by the American Chamber Opera Company and part of a double bill featuring Douglas Moore's ''Gallantry.

title: HE WHO HASN'T GOT MAY NEVER GET
description: DOLLARS AND DREAMS The Changing American Income Distribution. By Frank Levy. Charts. 259 pp. New York: Russell Sage Foundation/Basic Books. $27.50.

AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) KRAZY KAT: A Novel in Five Panels, by Jay Cantor. (Knopf, $16.95.) The innocent hedonism of the great and ditzy Kat is translated to print in this delightful novel-cum-homage, wherein the Coconino folk meet the Bomb, psychotherapy and S-E-X. HER OWN TERMS, by Judith Grossman. (Soho, $16.95.) A witty, ambitious and cant-free first novel whose heroine grows up lower-middle-class in London and Oxford in the 50's and 60's, baffled because feminist social analysis hasn't been discovered yet. THE LEARNING MYSTIQUE: A Critical Look at ''Learning Disabilities,'' by Gerald Coles. (Pantheon, $22.95.) A psychiatry professor respectfully debunks the categorization that too often blames the child's cognitive abilities for failure to learn. BETWEEN WOMEN: Love, Envy, and Competition in Women's Friendships, by Luise Eichenbaum and Susie Orbach. (Viking, $17.95.) Sisterhood isn't always hunky-dory, and the authors can't make it so, but their examination of the issues is lucid and lively. QUEST FOR AN ISLAND, by Vassily Aksyonov. (PAJ/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) Four stories and two plays by the Soviet dissident expelled in 1980; in them, disappointment and loss are tempered, never subdued, by breezy, allusive wit and imagination. JOHN DRYDEN AND HIS WORLD, by James Anderson Winn. (Yale University, $29.95.) Hefty (651 pages), authoritative and lively, this is the most important biography yet written of the mighty 17th-century poet, critic and translator. CHATTERTON, by Peter Ackroyd. (Grove, $17.95.) Wheels turn within wheels in this vivid historical romance: impersonations by real and imaginary characters involving real and imaginary facts about the 18th-century teen-age poet Thomas Chatterton.

title: A Separate Solution For the Gaza Strip
description: LEAD: The United States cannot afford to delay a new peace initiative in the Middle East until after the Presidential election in November and the Knesset election in the fall.

title: BECKY WEAN TO WED ROBERT STILIN IN APRIL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond John Wean Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Rebecca Wean, to Robert Scott Stilin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Stilin of Mellen, Wis. An April wedding is planned.

title: AUDREY COHEN IS WED TO DR. R. N. WHARTON
description: Audrey C. Cohen and Dr. Ralph Nathaniel Wharton were married last evening at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Computer Systems Under Siege
description: LEAD: It could be a science-fiction nightmare come to life. In the last nine months, computer viruses - which could subvert, alter or destroy the computer programs of banks, corporations, the military and the Government - have infected personal computer programs at several corporations and universities in the United States, as well as in Israel, West Germany, Switzerland, Britain and

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SYMPATHY FOR THE DEVIL. By Kent Anderson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Sergeant Hanson is a Special Services misfit for whom killing is ''the skill of his young life.'' With a copy of Yeats's collected verse shoved in his pocket and armed with the knowledge that he can only feel truly alive when he makes the enemy become truly unalive, this gladiator-poet and born survivor practices his sullen craft at the height of the war in Vietnam, in a country where everything ''either bites or stings or blows up.

title: Eagle Caught Up In Irish Adventure
description: AN Irish bald eagle? Hardly. But how did it get to a field near Killarney, Ireland, where it was found exhausted and almost starved last Nov. 18?

title: The Smothers Brothers Redux: A Bittersweet Reunion at CBS
description: On the surface, at least, the scene is innocuous.

title: Glittering Crystal From Portugal
description: LIKE some ancient ritual fire dance, shadowy figures dart hither and yon, bearing blazing torches. One man jabs the air with a great glob of fire; another rolls a flaming mass in rapid swirls; still others breathe life into their burning bubbles.

title: GARDEN OF HIS OWN
description: Jim Davidson is looking forward to cultivating his own garden this summer. Mr. Davidson, the president of Handleman's Garden Center, a White Plains landmark, has been selling plants and telling customers how to grow them for 32 years.

title: FOSTER PARENTING AND AIDS
description: STEVE, 10 months old, pushed Emily, 14 months old, across the living-room floor on her three-wheeler. Ricky, 9 months old, played with a hat. Their foster mother sat on the floor, occasionally reaching out to hug or pat one of the children. ''A house full of kids - just what I always wanted,'' she said, laughing as Ricky hid behind the hat.

title: MAUREEN WALSH TO MARRY MAY 7
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Walsh of Cumberland Center, Me., of the engagement of their daughter Maureen Anne Walsh to Jonkheer Ferdinand Folef Hooft Graafland, a son of Lydia Z. Hooft Graafland-Stahl of Wassenaar, the Netherlands, and the late Jonkheer Folef Ferdinand Joan Hooft Graafland. A May 7 wedding is planned.

title: Davis Looks Ahead
description: HE has been the National Basketball Association's rookie of the year, he has been an All-Star six times, he has been in drug rehabilitation twice and he is 33 years old, so Walter Davis, the career scoring leader for the Phoenix Suns, figured it was about time to think about the future. Yesterday, he said he planned to retire after the 1988-89 season and to devote his time to a youth drug-abuse treatment center he is founding in Phoenix. Davis said that he had been thinking about when he would end his career for the past few weeks. ''Next year will be my last,'' said Davis, who is in his 11th pro season. ''I'm 33, and next year is the last year on my contract. You have to start thinking, 'What comes after basketball?' ''

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: Should Super Bowl XXII be a contest worthy of its title (unlike most of the previous 21) then the fans, regardless of rooting interest, will be the winners. NORM LEVISON New York

title: Minority Groups Are Urged To Focus on Economic Issues
description: Black, Hispanic and Asian groups should make fiscal and employment issues - rather than racial violence -the focus of their lobbying efforts and demonstrations, participants in a conference on minority groups and the New York City budget urged yesterday.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Investment Boom?

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: Denver will win. No team besides the Minnesota Vikings has ever lost two Super Bowls in a row, and the Vikes aren't in this one. LARRY COHEN New York

title: Killings Laid to India Rebels
description: Tribal rebels were blamed for the shooting deaths of 30 people in four attacks in northeastern Tripura state, the United News of India said today. The authorities said the Tribal National Volunteers, an outlawed group seeking a separate state, was responsible for the killings Friday, the Government-run news agency said. The group has been blamed for at least 61 killings this year.

title: Final Exam for Seniors Could Be for Sobriety
description: The principal of Trumbull High School wants seniors to make their final exam a sobriety test.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WEST OF THE MOON. By Jonathan Nasaw. (Franklin Watts, $16.95.) In the children's book genre known as the ''problem novel,'' the protagonist has a medical or social problem but with the help of friends and professionals learns to live successfully. Such novels are useful because they demystify illness, handicaps and sorrows, but they are seldom literature.

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: In the end, the Broncos will win, because of their superiority in both the offensive and defensive departments, and also because they are returning after being routed by the Giants last year. THEODORE A. PAULY Radnor, Pa.

title: Take Heart, Fiction Lovers
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLY CROSS BEATS FORDHAM, 97-85
description: Holy Cross, which had lost seven straight games on the road, spoiled Fordham's Homecoming Day by defeating the Rams, 97-85, in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game yesterday at Rose Hill Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: Child Sex Abuse Cases Rising in Massachusetts
description: Since a 1983 state law made reporting of child sex abuse cases mandatory, the number of those cases has risen dramatically.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The name of the writer of the Focus article on Nebraska farm real estate on Jan. 10 was misspelled. The correct spelling is Dick Herman.

title: Salvador Supreme Court Judge Shot to Death
description: A Salvadoran Supreme Court judge was seized outside his home and killed by unidentified men, the police said today.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I have a chair whose frame is made of white plastic that has discolored to an uneven beige. Yet a painted metal brace is still white. Is there any way to clean or bleach the plastic, or is there a white paint I can apply?

title: Super Mirror Images
description: ON the Super Bowl sidelines, coaches have always projected a variety of images. Vince Lombardi, as tough as his tombstone teeth. Don Shula, as solid as his Mount Rushmore jaw. Chuck Noll, as cool as his icy eyes. Tom Landry, as unflappable as his snap-brim hat. Bill Walsh, as organized as the game plan on his clipboard. But at Super Bowl XXII today, Joe Gibbs of the Washington Redskins and Dan Reeves of the Denver Broncos each will be a mirror image of the other. Each is as thoughtfully sensitive as a preacher, each as strategically imaginative as a war-college professor.

title: LEO'S HALL OF FAME: HITS AND ERRORS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An Ex-Contra Is in Managua Under Amnesty
description: A former contra leader has returned to Nicaragua under a Government amnesty, the official newspaper Barricada said today.

title: CONFUSING A CARNIVORE
description: TWO decades ago bridge was a recreation of the capitalist countries, spurned by the communist world as a bourgeois pursuit that promotes gambling. But times have changed.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WHERE'S OURS? By Natalie McKelvy. (Academy Chicago, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $7.95.) Natalie McKelvy has taken a bit of a chance in writing a serious novel about a young couple in the midst of professional and marital failure. What reader, heartily sick of anything to which the word ''yuppie'' can be attached, can muster sympathy for characters who aspire no higher than upward mobility?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Turkeys and Then Some IF it's a gaggle of geese and a flock of sheep, what do you call a group of turkeys? (You can have fun with that one for a while.) Whatever you call them, a whole lot of turkeys are gobbling away at the Connetquot River State Park in Oakdale. The 3,500-acre park is home to about 50 to 60 wild 20-pound turkeys, although, as a New York State park ranger, Gary Lawton, said, ''These turkeys aren't really so wild - they're somewhat tame because they're so used to seeing people in the park.''

title: The Era of Palms and Ferns
description: TAKE a walk down Main Street of any town born a century or more ago and you will find evidence of the fascination for house plants during the Victorian era. Horticultural hobbies were such an intrinsic part of 19th-century life that the architecture reflected this penchant for plants.

title: Porsches Leading After Three Hours
description: Defending champions Chip Robinson, Al Holbert and Derek Bell, sharing a Porsche 962, led after three hours of the Daytona 24 Hours at Daytona International Speedway today.

title: Bernice Franklin; Nursing Supervisor, 79
description: Bernice Franklin, a retired supervisor of pediatric nursing at New York Hospital, died of complications arising from Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79 years old. Mrs. Franklin was associated with New York Hospital for four years, retiring in 1940. Earlier, she worked for the Nursery and Child's Hospital, which has since closed, on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: READING THE FRIENDLY SKIES
description: A HISTORY OF WESTERN ASTROLOGY By S. J. Tester. Illustrated. 256 pp. Wolfeboro, N.H.: Boydell & Brewer. $36.

title: Wilderness Caesars and Their Wives
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Observer; Super Supernumerary
description: THE XXIst CENTURY was still in knee pants in the year MMXVI, but the Super Bowl had grown long in the tooth. To be precise, that year was the Lth anniversary of the stupendous sporting event, and the public's loss of interest in it was pronounced, as well as galling to advertisers, or Super Splurgers as they were called out of respect for their willingness to pay Super Sums for XV-second Super Messages.

title: Correction
description: An item in Sports People last Sunday misidentified the former University of Michigan All-America running back who will be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame next December. He is Bob Chappuis.

title: A NEW COMMITMENT TO SAVE THE SOUND
description: LEAD: THE life of Long Island Sound has been at risk for a decade. Pollution threatens its commercial and recreational uses by killing fish and closing beaches, endangering a vibrant and inviting body of water.

title: THE MANY WAYS OF USING VERSATILE NUTS
description: RECORD crops of nuts, especially walnuts and almonds, were harvested this fall in California, according to the Department of Agriculture. This volume is good news for consumers. Wholesale prices for walnuts are below last year's levels and almond production was more than double last year with prices also lower.

title: U.S. Looks Into Deal Involving Ex-Dole Aide
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has joined a Government inquiry into a $260 million no-bid Federal contract involving a former aide to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.

title: ALL THE KING'S MIRRORS
description: LEAD: LOUIS XIV A Royal Life. By Olivier Bernier. Illustrated. 373 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a ceremony honoring Rosa L. Parks reversed the identities of the two men with her. The Rev. Herbert Daughtry was at far left and next to him was Assemblyman Roger L. Green.

title: Safety Issues Test Europe's Faith in Nuclear Power
description: ALTHOUGH much of Europe remains committed to nuclear energy, the European nuclear power industry, which many American experts envy because of its safety record, has been suffering blow after blow.

title: F.B.I. Director Defends Spying on Political Groups
description: William Sessions, the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, defended today the F.B.I.'s spying on groups opposed to the Reagan's Administration's policies in Central America.

title: Nuclear Agency Said to Lag in Seeking Out Crime
description: Three years ago former workers at a nuclear plant here told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that plant managers repeatedly falsified radiation readings, thus hiding evidence of problems that would otherwise have forced an expensive shutdown.

title: Romance of Hats
description: HAVE hats, will travel: that's Laurie Kaye's motto.

title: Key Matchups For Redskins
description: Darrell Green, Redskins' cornerback, vs. Ricky Nattiel, Broncos' wide receiver - Green is one of the two or three best cornerbacks in the league, with exceptional speed and an ability to be physical despite his small size. Nattiel, a 5-foot-9-inch, 180-pound rookie, caught 31 passes for an average 20.3 yards during the season. Nevertheless, he may be outmatched by the veteran Green. But even if Green shuts him down the Broncos have other receiving threats. ''Nattiel is aggressive and fast and looking to block,'' said Green.

title: 20 ARE SEIZED IN GAMBLING RAIDS
description: An illegal gambling ring that handled about $500 million in bets on sporting events was the target of raids on seven apartments in Manhattan last night that resulted in the arrests of 20 people, the police reported.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the appointment of the jurors for the 1988 Pulitzer Prizes misstated the date the appointments were announced. It was Jan. 20.

title: Addicts to Get Needles in Plan To Curb AIDS
description: The Cuomo administration, reversing an earlier stand, will let New York City distribute clean needles to hundreds of drug addicts as part of an experiment to reduce the spread of AIDS, officials familiar with the administration's thinking said today.

title: Boys and Girls on Same Team
description: The Louisiana High School Athletic Association has decided that girls may play competitive contact sports with boys if there are no comparable girls' teams.

title: Reservoir Bursts in Soviet
description: A sewage reservoir burst in Soviet Kazakhstan on Friday, releasing a towering wave of stagnant water and gravel that destroyed two bridges and caused deaths, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today. Without giving a casualty toll, Pravda said people were killed when the mud slide destroyed a bridge on the road between Kapchagai and Alma-Ata, capital of the Soviet republic in Central Asia. Pravda said the wave hit a railroad bridge with such force that it destroyed the structure. Pravda said the driver of a passenger train averted a catastrophe by slamming on his brakes when he spotted the twisted rails.

title: JOINT ISSUE CELEBRATES A BICENTENNIAL
description: AUSTRALIA'S bicentennial celebration is underscored by a joint issue. First day ceremonies were held in Washington, D.C., and Sydney last Tuesday, Australia Day, which marked the first European settlement in Australia. The 22-cent commemorative issued by United States Postal Service is the 19th cooperative stamp or stationery item released by the Postal Service.

title: HEADSTRONG
description: PUTTING ON A HAT CAN BE A ceremonious act, an elegant gesture in the ritual of dressing. That's no news to the spruce

title: Headliners; Postponing in Florida
description: For the sixth time, Willie Jasper Darden has broken a date with death. The United States Supreme Court last week blocked the execution of the Florida prison inmate, who was scheduled to be electrocuted this week for the 1973 murder of a Lakeland merchant, pending his latest appeal, which will be heard after the Court reconvenes next month. In winning previous postponements, Mr. Darden has argued that his conviction and sentence resulted from racial bias: He is black; the man he was convicted of killing was white. His cause has been taken up by Amnesty International, Andrei Sakharov and others who have appealed for clemency on his behalf.

title: U.S. FAILURES PROMPT GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST
description: For the first time, Edwin Neff Jr., president of the Computer Equity Corporation of Manhattan, sent a contribution of $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: GERONIMO AND PRINCESS ALICE AND A WRITER'S CAREER
description: DURING the summer of 1904, my parents, my little brother and I lived in St. Louis, in one large room, of which we had only the privacy of curtained-off corners.

title: In Search of Clare Boothe Luce
description: LATE IN THE FALL OF 1980, ARCHIE AND Selwa Roosevelt called me in New York and invited me to dinner in Washington. It seemed a long way to go for a party, until Selwa casually said, ''Clare Luce is coming.''

title: PUTTING A CONSERVATION PLAN TO WORK
description: THE National Fish and Wildlife Foundation is helping to implement the North American Waterfowl Management Plan, an ambitious and much-needed cooperative agreement that this country and Canada signed in 1986 but for which no funds were allocated.

title: The Spell of the Rain Forest
description: SO sudden is the change as one steps off the Tamborine Mountain Road (outside Brisbane, Australia) and into the pocket of subtropical rain forest that I feel like those children in ''The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe'' by C. S. Lewis; they stepped through a doorway in the back of a closet and abruptly entered a room that was another world. The rain forest is another world, and it is also, in a sense, its own room with its own abrupt and lofty walls and its own ceiling more than a hundred feet above. Up there, the crowns of the trees interlock and are further overlaid with a lush matting of vines, epiphytes, orchids, giant ferns - a roof garden to top all roof gardens.

title: ENGLAND REDISCOVERS IT AGE OF CHIVALRY
description: To what extent can an ex-hibition sum up an entire civilization? Every generation has its own answer to that, but some of the answers haven't worn too well. Once upon a time the huge, baggy, ''comprehensive,'' all-star national survey was in high favor. Governments loved them, and in a time of relative inactivity in the museum world the public often loved them, too.

title: Next Week; Are Free Agents Free Again in Baseball?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: DATE WITH A WOLF MAN
description: THE CONSOLATION OF NATURE And Other Stories. By Valerie Martin. 147 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: JANUARY 31, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, an evil wizard and a mouse. 2 12 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 3 9 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $4.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 4 13 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in previous novels. 5 1 OUTBREAK, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) Tracking down a deadly disease that ophthalmologists pass on to their patients. 6 1 SILVERSWORD, by Phyllis A. Whitney. (Fawcett, $4.50.) A San Francisco woman returns to Hawaii, hoping to find the man whose charm has haunted her since childhood. 7 9 CAPER, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.50.) A mystery writer dreams up a multimillion-dollar jewel heist that becomes horribly real. 8 4 FINAL FRONTIER, by Diane Carey. (Pocket, $4.50.) The galaxy on the brink of catastrophic war in a new ''Star Trek'' tale. 9 5 SHAN, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Chinese-American attempts to realize his father's dreams for Asia. 10 * 29 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 11 * 9 PATIENCE OF A SAINT, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $4.95.) A hard-bitten newspaperman on the trail of a wily politician. 12 9 NIGHT OF THE FOX, by Jack Higgins. (Pocket, $4.95.) A mission to keep D-Day plans from being discovered by the Germans. 13 * 21 FLOWERS IN THE ATTIC, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) An 18th-century Englishwoman uses her beauty and wiles to become mistress of an estate. 15 2 PRIVILEGE, by Leona Blair. (Bantam, $4.95.) A woman makes her way from the workshops of Paris to the glitzy spots of Europe and America. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 1 COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Avon, $4.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his home. 2 223 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 49 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 4 8 A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Fireside/Pocket, $4.50.) The Indiana University basketball team during the 1985-86 season. 5 * 65> WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 6 11 DANCING ON MY GRAVE, by Gelsey Kirkland with Greg Lawrence. (Jove, $4.50.) The ballerina recalls her checkered career. 7 40 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star. 8 26 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. (Dell, $3.95.) A search for a true love. 9 23 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold Kushner. (Pocket, $4.50.) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 10 24 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 11 * 16 ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Bantam, $4.95.) A case involving the 1979 murder of a high school teacher. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 6 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1988. (World Almanac/Pharos Books, $5.95.) Its 120th year. 2 36 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 3 40 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) Cartoons. 4 1 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 5 * 25 THE BOOK OF QUESTIONS, by Gregory Stock. (Workman, $3.95.) Provocative and challenging questions to ask yourself. 6 * 14 THE FAR SIDE OBSERVER, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) Cartoons. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: In Hot Pursuit of a Wonder Drug
description: Over lunch at Danny's Restaurant here six years ago, a brilliant medical researcher from Johns Hopkins University and two brash New York brothers who fancied themselves company founders batted around ideas for creating a drug company.

title: New Drug Rules
description: TRACK and field's governing body, the International Amateur Athletic Association, has toughened its anti-drug rules while calling for Americans to ''cure'' their legal barriers to random testing.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Loft Conversions; When Renting Out Pays More Than Manufacturing
description: VICTOR TRAGER expected to build a career within the company his grandfather founded more than a half-century ago. But last summer the company, Herman I. Zacharia & Son, a lingerie manufacturer, went out of business and Mr. Trager began converting the former plant in lower Manhattan into an office building.

title: CRIME
description: Don Flynn is a reporter for The Daily News who writes mysteries about Ed Fitzgerald, a reporter for a New York daily that could be no other paper than The News. The third entry in the series is ORDINARY MURDER (Walker, $16.95), and like its predecessors it is sophisticated, lively and as fast-moving as hurdlers off the starting block -even if Fitzgerald takes time out to quote his favorite author, Marcus Aurelius, of all writers.

title: Tet Offensive: Turning Point in Vietnam War
description: At 3 o'clock in the morning of Jan. 31, 1968, North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces launched a wave of simultaneous attacks on South Vietnamese and American forces in major cities, towns and military bases throughout South Vietnam.

title: AS THEY LAY DYING
description: BLOOD LINE Stories of Fathers and Sons. By David Quammen. 169 pp. St. Paul: Graywolf Press. Paper, $8.

title:
ART;
VARIETY SPICES A GALLERY'S SHOW
description: LEAD: SIX artists share the spotlight at the Discovery Gallery's two exhibition spaces in the Glen Cove Village Square complex. This is a show that illustrates good and bad aspects of each one's work, spotlighting the inconsistency artists struggle to expunge.

title: Marbled Paper
description: To the Editor: Readers interested in Susan Lumsden's article ''Marbled Paper From Florence'' (Travel, Dec. 13) have an opportunity to learn of the process as applied to another material - slate. The first exhibit dealing with this process as used on slate is on view at the Vermont Historical Society Museum in Montpelier through April 30.

title: MOTHER'S NETWORK: FEMINISM AT AGE 40
description: IN my small suburban town, a group of children are shared freely by a group of mothers who happen to be friends. The friendships began with the children, but they have grown more quickly than the toddlers who used to crawl on our laps and upset coffee cups when we were full-time mothers. All of us have jobs outside our homes now, with a variety of titles, hours, responsibilities and pressures.

title: Peggy Lee at 67: Still in the Swingtime of Her Life
description: As a shy, frightened little girl of 8 growing up in Jamestown, N.D., Peggy Lee had a childhood obsession: aviation.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE COMIC BOOK BUSINESS;
Growing Up Into 'Graphic Novels'
description: LEAD: THROUGHOUT the industry, the push is on to restore the idea of comics as art. The latest buzz word is the ''graphic novel'' - a self-contained work that goes beyond the traditional 32-page comic book form. The majority of graphic novels are an outgrowth of mainstream comics. DC Comics' very successful ''The Dark Knight Returns,'' for example, tells of an aging

title: INTELLECTUAL SEDUCTION
description: It is apparent that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is, indeed, ''an actor creating his own ideal image'' (''Intellectual Seduction,'' by Joyce Carol Oates, Jan. 3). I hope that President Reagan equally will plan to create his own ideal image during his visit to the Soviet Union later this year. I hope that Mr. Reagan will endeavor to make contact with all important segments of Soviet society.

title: POSTINGS: Georgetown Conversion; Mixed-Use Complex in a Historic Mill
description: When Georgetown, Conn., was placed on the National Register of Historic Places last March, it was recommended as ''a community which today resembles the rural industrial village of 19th-century Utopian ideology.'' The mill of the Gilbert and Bennett Company, founded in 1818, forms the center of the unincorporated village near Norwalk. Now, the venerable manufacturer, whose products advanced from horsehair sieves to wire fences, will leave its brick mill for a more modern facility and convert the mill complex to offices, shops and homes that have the potential of attracting 400 new families.

title: Dubious Tactics: F.B.I. Again Called Lax On Liberties
description: As they pored over newly declassified documents last week, members of civil liberties groups wondered how much of the spirit of J. Edgar Hoover - a spirit that several successors have tried to exorcise since he died in 1972 - survives at the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: NONFICTION
description: COVENANT HOUSE: Lifeline to the Street. By Bruce Ritter. (Doubleday, $16.95.) This book is a selection of epistles - monthly newsletters-cum-fundraising appeals - issued from Times Square. The Rev. Bruce Ritter is a remarkable Roman Catholic missionary to the runaway, castoff and abused street kids drawn into drugs and prostitution. His calling came when six homeless youths knocked on his apartment door in 1969. Since then Father Ritter has sheltered, by his count, more than 100,000 young people in Covenant Houses in New York, Houston, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Toronto and Guatemala. The lives he depicts are wrenching. Meet Ernie - ''We found him sleeping in a garbage can.'' Cheryl, 14 years old, was strangled in a West Side warehouse. The brothers Jose and Gustavo were conceived, born and orphaned in a Guatemalan brothel. Nandy, an 11-year-old boy, was offered by a pimp for $20. Some passages are repetitive; others are preachy tirades against the sex industry. Father Ritter's style is conversational, occasionally rising to memorable: ''Sometimes God has a kid's face.'' A shelter ''was right next to the biggest pimp bar on the Strip and right across the street from a porno theater and a massage parlor. You couldn't want a more perfect location.'' He pleads for supplies: ''Anyone with some extra sheets and pillow cases or blankets can win some points with the Lord.'' For his tireless good deeds, Father Ritter surely has earned a bounty of points.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JANUARY 31, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Americans Are Unlikely to Head Off a Slide in Success
description: NIGHT was descending in the Alps.

title: MISS MATHESON WEDS W. H. SAWYER 3D
description: At the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, Marie Matheson, a daughter of Gladys May Matheson of Townsville, Queensland, Australia, and the late Donald Duncan Matheson, was married yesterday to Willits Herbert Sawyer 3d of New York and New Haven. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Case Sawyer of Zanesville, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. William Randolph Robbins and the Rev. Gerald Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Ex-Cheerleader Wages Lonely Fight at Ohio State
description: It was a familiar sight at Ohio State University basketball games last season: The cheerleading squad back-flipping into formation as a lone black cheerleader, shunned by the others, did cartwheels near the bench.

title: Film: 'Melo,' a Drama From Resnais
description: ''Melo'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times October 5, 1987. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: 'A PROCESS SO FRAGILE WE FORGET HOW MIRACULOUS IT IS'
description: AT exactly 3:33 P.M. on Jan. 16, 1987, in the midst of a week punctuated by power outages, cold fronts and a wave of snowstorms, my daughter, Julia, forced her way kicking and screaming into the world.

title: JUDY SCAVONE, BANKER, IS WED TO TODD SLOTKIN
description: At Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, Judy Scavone and Todd Slotkin, vice presidents and senior credit officers of Citicorp, were married last evening by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel.

title: What's Do8ing in Cologne
description: Cologne's age is disputed. Peg its birthdate to 38 B.C., when it was established as a Roman garrison town by Marcus Vispanius Agrippa, the military genius who orchestrated Augustus Caesar's victory over Antony and Cleopatra, then it is 2,026.

title: EMBATTLED CASTLE IS NOW IN COURT
description: WHEN Barry Trupin purchased the old Henry duPont estate in Southampton in 1979, he had visions of converting it to his dream house by the sea, a French Gothic chateau. But that dream has turned into a nightmare for Mr. Trupin and officials of the Village of Southampton.

title: 7 Finalists In Hall Voting
description: Fred Biletnikoff, Mike Ditka, Bob Griese, Jack Ham, Alan Page and Art Shell emerged today as the finalists on this year's Pro Football Hall of Fame selection committee list along with Lou Rymkus, the old-timers committee nominee. The result of the secret

title: Sports of The Times; The Fabric of the Old-Boy Network
description: SOME in the so-called news media have come to refer to Pete Rozelle's annual Super Bowl news conference - No. XXII was held here on Friday - as a state of the union address. That's the last thing it is. It is, in fact, a state of management address.

title: The Redskins' Owner Relishes His Role
description: NOW hear this. Jack Kent Cooke is speaking, and no greater love has anyone else for the sound of his own voice.

title: Giants Look Like Only Repeaters
description: OF last season's four division winners, the St. Louis Cardinals can't possibly repeat this year because they lost Jack Clark and the Mets have, on Jan. 31 at least, the best team in baseball; the Detroit Tigers will have trouble repeating because they have lost Kirk Gibson and they have Toronto, Milwaukee and the Yankees to contend with, and the Minnesota Twins won't repeat because (1), their 1987 success was a fluke and (2), they are the only contenders in their division that haven't done anything during the winter to improve themselves.

title: JILL B. JEFFERY IS AFFIANCED
description: Mrs. Carleton Jeffery of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter Jill Burr Jeffery to Mark E. Garvin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Everett Garvin of Groton, Mass. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Outings Along the Great Barrier Reef
description: LEAD: THE Great Barrier Reef reclines in limpid seas, a graceful, unbounded living creature 1,200 miles long.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Big Markdowns At Chappaqua Shop This That & More in Chappaqua has 20 to 50 percent markdowns through Feb. 13 on a variety of goods. The sale items include handloomed scarves and sweaters; fringed lace shawls; metallic, beaded, fabric and skin evening bags; one-of-a-kind leather jackets with Japanese kimono insets and leather and suede tops; beaded lace blouses and coordinated lace-trimmed velvet skirts; leather gloves, belts and handbags; and sterling Art Deco Austrian crystal jewelry.

title:
DANCE;
AS AMERICAN AS ROBBINS & IVES
description: LEAD: A glance at the 18 songs by Charles Ives that Jerome Robbins has selected for his new ballet, ''Ives, Songs,'' reveals a progression from joyous evocations of childhood to haunted anticipations of death.

title:
HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES;
Top-Notch Dancing
description: LEAD: AN EVENING WITH BALLET RAMBERT Directed and produced by Thomas Grimm. Stereo hi-fi, color. Home Vision. 98 minutes. $39.95.

title: IT'S NEVER TOO EARLY TO PROTECT THE SHORE
description: BETWEEN winter storm warnings and people wondering whether they can get one more season out of the brown overcoat, thoughts of the Jersey Shore are scarce. Except in the State House.

title:
INVESTING;
Alleco's Costly Debt Transfer
description: LEAD: WHEN a management group had trouble last fall raising all the $450 million needed to buy the food service business of Alleco Inc., the debt-laden Alleco - which faced a threat of bankruptcy if the deal was not completed - hit upon a solution: why not transfer $105 million worth of its debt to the new company?

title: ELIZABETH MEHREN AND FOX BUTTERFIELD, NEWSPAPER REPORTERS, MARRY IN UTAH
description: Elizabeth Mehren, a reporter in New York for The Los Angeles Times, and Fox Butterfield, a reporter for The New York Times, were married yesterday in Park City, Utah. Hal Taylor, the Mayor of Park City, officiated at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Mathews.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BLACK HISTORY MONTH The Greenburgh Library's celebration of Black History Month begins this week with a talk by Terrie M. Williams, who grew up in Mount Vernon and is now a vice president of Essence Magazine Inc. She will speak about ''Making It to the Top: A Black Woman's Journey'' at 7:45 P.M. Wednesday. Throughout February an exhibition of abstract paintings embellished with gold, silver and copper leaf by Marian Glenn Straw and a collection of portrait and landscape photography by Francis Giraud Jr. can be seen in the library's art gallery and exhibition case. The artists will be on hand for a reception from 2:30 to 4 P.M. next Sunday.

title: Death Sentence Imposed for '73 Georgia Killings
description: A jury today sentenced Carl Isaacs to die in the electric chair for the 1973 murders of six members of a family.

title: Harry Reichenbaum; Lawyer, 63
description: Harry Reichenbaum, a lawyer who specialized in negligence and medical malpractice cases, died of a heart attack Monday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx. He was 63 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Stopping Start
description: To demonstrate more than a dime's worth of policy difference between himself and George Bush, Bob Dole must find an issue on which he can take a more hawkish stance - without appearing to be disloyal to Ronald Reagan.

title: Theater
description: Last winter, Artificial Intelligence, an audaciously imaginative 22-member troupe of comic actors led by Nancy Cassaro, invaded the Ballroom, a normally staid Chelsea cabaret to put on a mock TV special, ''Vicki's Valentine Thing,'' which satirically recreated the sound and style of a 1967 family variety show. Played by Ms. Cassaro, the Vicki of the title was a fictional character named Vicki Oberjeune, modelled loosely after the late Judy Garland. Audiences saw not only the show but the studio technicians ''filming'' the event with all its backstage chaos and family squabbles. Last Christmas, Artificial Intelligence returned to the club with an equally zany holiday spoof, ''A Very Vicki Christmas,'' set in 1965 and featuring the same characters.

title: Settling Suits
description: To the Editor:

title: Statistics on Black Poor Don't Tell the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: EXAMS FOR POLICE STIR WIDE DEBATE
description: Calvin Ayres wants to be the first black police officer in Lufkin, an East Texas town of 30,000 people about 150 miles from here. But first he has to pass the police entrance examination, and therein lies a problem.

title: Accord Is Reached in Talks For New Miners' Contract
description: The United Mine Workers and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association reached agreement today on a new 40-month contract one day before a strike deadline.

title: Players, Plans and Statistics: How They Match Up: Redskins
U.S. Seeks Iraqi Payment for Kin of Dead Sailors
description: After an eight-month interagency inquiry, the United States has decided to ask Iraq for tens of millions of dollars to compensate the families of those killed in the Iraqi attack on the guided missile frigate Stark, State Department and Pentagon officials say.

title: COMPOSTING PLANT STIRS DEBATE
description: LEAD: AN $11 million Cape May County sewage composting plant will never work properly and should be abandoned, according to Dr. Melvin Finstein, a professor of environmental science at Rutgers University's Cook College.

title: WHY WE MUST INTEGRATE OUR SCHOOLS
description: I WOULD like to summarize several points about the State Department of Education report on racial integration in our public schools that was presented to the State Board of Education earlier this month. The report raises fundamental issues about excellence and equity in education, and a review of the facts helps brings the report and its goals into clear focus.

title: RANDI EILEEN NOSKIN WEDS RUSSEL L. MIRON
description: Randi Eileen Noskin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Noskin of Glencoe, Ill., and Russel Leeds Miron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Lane Miron of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., were married last evening at the Ritz Carlton in Chicago. Rabbi Herbert Bronstein performed the ceremony.

title: A New State Song For Old Virginia?
description: YES, critics agreed, ''Carry Me Back to Old Virginia'' - Virginia's official state song - is indeed steeped in sentiment and history. But in today's world, they argued, it is basically a slur on blacks and an unwelcome reminder of slavery.

title: CHERI ANNE DELAY WEDS A. F. VENEZIANO JR., LAWYER
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., Cheri Anne DeLay, the daughter of Mrs. Wayne T. DeLay of Nashville and the late Mr. DeLay, was married yesterday to Anthony Francis Veneziano Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Veneziano of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Leslie Ivers officiated.

title: A BENEVOLENT AND BRUTAL PATERNALISM
description: LIKE A FAMILY The Making of a Southern Cotton Mill World. By Jacquelyn Dowd Hall, James Leloudis, Robert Korstad, Mary Murphy, Lu Ann Jones and Christopher B. Daly. Illustrated. 468 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $34.95. Paper, $12.95.

title: MS. WOODWARD ENGAGED TO WED
description: The engagement of Christina Melissa Woodward to Benjamin Ruggles Woodbridge Strong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodbridge Strong of Highland Park, N.J., and Lenox, Mass., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Mark Rittenhouse Woodward 3d of Shaker Heights, Ohio, parents of the bride-to-be. The couple plan to marry Sept. 10.

title: U.S. Envoy in Austria Would 'Set Aside' Rift
description: The new United States Ambassador to Austria, Henry Anatole Grunwald, says it would be in the best interest of both Washington and Vienna to set aside the Waldheim affair, a magazine reported today.

title: MEMORIES OF A TEACHER AND OF A BROTHER
description: Credit is due to Anthony Robinson [ ''Saying Hello to My Teacher of the 1940's,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 3 ] . His memories of the good old days at St. Pascal's brought back my own share of smiles and tears. In particular, I too have fond memories of Sister Devota Maria, a kind and courageous teacher.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW GRADING SERVICE HAS A PROFESSIONAL OUTLOOK
description: LEAD: THE successful debut of a new coin-grading service in Parsippany, N.J., suggests that the field has room for fresh approaches. The new company is the Numismatic Guaranty Corporation of America. Since opening in August, it has built a solid base and continued to expand.

title: Michigan G.O.P. Elects Rival Slates
description: The Michigan Republican Party's long and fractious contribution to the process of selecting the next President of the United States ended today in a political production of upstairs, downstairs.

description: Vice President Bush holds a commanding lead in the South in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination while the Democratic contest is unsettled, according to a poll released yesterday.

description: Jade Hunter benefited from an uncontested early lead and an 11-pound swing in the weights to hold off Cryptoclearance by a length and win the $200,000 Donn Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

description: LUKAS FOSS's now 15-year-old Meet the Moderns series is changing. In recent years offered in pairs of programs, one at the Brooklyn Philharmonic's home base of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the other at Cooper Union, the series - this season, at least - has abandoned Brooklyn and now consists of five single concerts in Manhattan, three at Cooper Union, one at Town Hall and one at Merkin Concert Hall.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Isle of Wight, Md.;
A Sour Note In a Preserve
description: LEAD: FACING strong local opposition, Maryland officials have refused permission for two Baltimore developers to lease part of this 225-acre state-owned wildlife management island to build a $5 million music pavilion.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: CANDIDATES HAVE BECOME A DEBATING SOCIETY
description: In the midst of an exhausting string of debates, the Presidential candidates are wondering whether they are worth it.
