description: As he briefed reporters before the State of the Union address last Monday night, Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, insisted that President Reagan ''is very mindful of the fact that he was elected for eight years, not seven years.''

title: ISRAELI CONFIRMS BACKING PIPELINE
description: Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres confirmed today that his Government gave the United States assurances in 1985 that Israel would not interfere with the construction of an Iraqi oil pipeline through neighboring Jordan.

title: 'GIVE US A SHOT AT SOMETHING'
description: RACHEL AND HER CHILDREN Homeless Families in America. By Jonathan Kozol. 261 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $16.95.

title: 'CONNECTICUT IS THE ENVY OF THE COUNTRY'
description: KENNETH O. DECKO has been president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the largest business group in the state, for 17 years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''From our point of view, there were five main targets. The American Embassy was one of them.'' Col. Do Tan Phong, a Vietcong commander in the Tet offensive in 1968. [ 1:2. ]

title: COLD-WEATHER CRISIS: RESTARTING THE FURNACE
description: WHEN the furnace shuts down or will not start, puzzled homeowners often panic. But you will be doing yourself and utility personnel a favor, particularly in storms or cold snaps when service crews are strained, by trying to restart the furnace yourself.

title: Music: Ives's 'Holidays Symphony,' in Focus Series
description: THE Juilliard School ended its weeklong ''Focus'' series, devoted to interactions between American vernacular music and the art music we call ''classical,'' with Charles Ives's ''Holidays Symphony'' Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall. The performance, under Paul Zukofsky, was worthwhile: a reminder that there is broad music of deep feeling woven throughout this piece, which has been played rather infrequently since its overexposure in the years of the Ives centennial and the nation's bicentennial.

title: Islanders Cannot Keep Rolling
description: All the repairs the Islanders made Friday were conspicuous by their absence tonight. The team seemed to suddenly lose its sense of direction, and found itself humbled, 6-2, by the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Opponents of Aid to Contras To Start Broadcast Campaign
description: Opponents of aid to the Nicaraguan rebels will begin airing four television and radio advertisements in 17 targeted Congressional districts represented by House members or Senators who are undecided or wavering in their support of contra assistance.

title: Who's On First?
description: THERE ARE TIMES WHEN Bordeaux fanatics can really get to you. Even in Bordeaux.

title: SICK THINKING
description: The mental confusion of hospital patients recovering from surgery should not be surprising; general anesthesia wears off gradually and is known to produce such disorientation, even days afterward (Body and Mind: ''Sick Thinking,'' by Morton Hunt, Jan. 3). More disturbing is the failure of Morton Hunt, and Dr. Eric Cassell, whom he quotes at length, to understand that the patient's loss of intellectual perspective and regression to childlike dependency may be socially produced by a series of events that strip away his identity as an integrated and fully functioning adult.

title: Some Thoughts On Racism
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
THE REGION: Weicker Runs Again;
Connecticut Maverick in Home Court
description: LEAD: AS the Reagan era enters its final year, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the relativly liberal Connecticut Republican who often swam against his party's conservative currents, portrays himself as being in the best political health of his career.

title: Riding A Ghost Train To New York
description: THE Montrealer was a classic train.

title: VALERIE KINDRED TO WED SCOTT WALKER
description: Valerie Prescott Kindred, a geologist for Shell Oil in Houston, and Scott Cameron Walker, a telecommunications analyst for International Business Machines in Boulder, Colo., plan to be married in April. Their engagement has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. G. Estabrook Kindred of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Skytop, Pa. The future bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Walker of Boulder.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: LEAD: VOLATILE and fast-moving as it seems, the world of publishing is much beholden for its insights into institutions like the American Antiquarian Society of Worcester, Mass.

title: 'PHOTOGRAPHY MASTERS OF THE 30'S' AT THE PELHAM ART CENTER
description: COLOR in photography has become the equivalent of sugar in the diet and is every bit as addictive. This may explain not only the fad for colorizing old movies but also the jolt that comes from seeing those that have escaped the treatment.

title: THE ANATOMY OF KNOWING
description: How do we know what we know? In THE RING OF TRUTH: An Inquiry Into How We Know What We Know (Random House, $24.95), an immensely pretty book crafted as a companion volume to a public television series of that name on scientific inquiry, Philip and Phylis Morrison, master teachers both - he at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, she in classrooms for all ages - go a long way toward telling us. From ''the big new idea of 1280'' (eyeglasses) and ''the commonsense emphasis on the visible,'' to the ''magnificent finding of the eighteenth century,'' that weight is unchanged through all sorts of processes - that is, the constancy of matter - to the astrophysical mysteries of our own period, the Morrisons show how lines of argument follow experience and experiment underlies theory. Take the 19th century's ''deepest insight'': ''the identification of the idea of energy.'' Tour de France cyclists are the scientific instruments, with calculations of their intake and output augmented by their own analyses. ''You can use up an awful lot of calories, so . . . you have to put them back in,'' says one. To demonstrate the essentiality of carbon, the chef Julia Child is the applied biochemist. In less deft hands, such devices could cloy. Intermingled as they are with an illustrated history of mapping or reports on the archives and archivists of the Harvard Observatory, and infused with the Morrisons' seriousness about transmitting in a personal way a grasp of science as a whole, they are mostly fun. They also work.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Assessments on Offices; A Heavier Load for the 'Second Tier'
description: IN the past, there was a type of investment property that the city's assessors called ''sleepers.'' These were the buildings that the were suspected of being underassessed. But since there was no recent sale with which to confirm market value, and no income and expense data unless owners cared to protest an assessment they considered too high, assessors could greatly underestimate their true value. In the absence of a sale, the courts have found operating data to be the most valid indicator of value.

title: 'FAST GIRLS' IN TEANECK, 'BILOXI' AT THE PAPER MILL
description: ''FAST GIRLS,'' the American Stage Company's new comedy, is about sex and the single woman in the age of AIDS anxiety.

title: Unwed Mother In Job Dispute
description: CRYSTAL CHAMBERS was a part-time arts-and-crafts teacher when the Girls Club of Omaha discharged her in 1981 because she was pregnant out of wedlock. She has been battling her dismissal since.

title: INDIANA ENDS PURDUE'S STREAK
description: Dean Garrett scored a career-high 31 points and got the winning basket with 5 seconds left as Indiana ended Purdue's 16-game winning streak with an 82-79 upset in Big Ten Conference play today.

title: FICTION
description: TITCH. By Chaim Bermant. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) Chaim Bermant's brief eighth novel closely resembles the oft-told tale of the American Jew who comes of age during World War II, discovering in wartime his Americanness as well as his ambivalence about his Jewish identity. The differences in ''Titch'' are that its bookish Jewish youth, the repository of his immigrant family's ambitions, is British; that the locale is neither the Bronx, Brooklyn nor Newark but Manchester; and that the forbidden fruits are rashers and the granddaughters of baronets. ''Titch'' otherwise runs along familiar lines. Polish-born Sammy Hoch grows up in a traditional Jewish home ruled by his opinionated father, who is a big noise at the synagogue and an even bigger noise once his son wins a scholarship to the prestigious Manchester Grammar School. When Sammy is called up for military service, he is assigned, to his shock, to the army of the Polish Government in exile. In basic training with his British peers, Sammy had believed that he ''had been finally grafted to the trunk of olde England, integrated, assimilated, at one with the men around me, to the point almost of resenting the Jew in me. And now, suddenly, I was reclassified a foreigner.'' Sammy serves the Polish Army as a rabbi's assistant, an irony whose bitterness Mr. Bermant could have expressed more fully, given Poland's history of anti-Semitism. The first in a projected trilogy, ''Titch'' ends abruptly with a cliffhanger that dangles at curb height. Despite its occasional flashes of humor, the novel never approaches the wit and inventiveness that has distinguished American literature exploring the same ground.

title: OUR BIG HITS: OUT OF THIS WORLD
description: IT ALL DEPENDS ON WHERE YOU'RE sitting. Some women argue that ''Fatal Attraction'' does the unmarried career woman a disservice in its lubricious exploitation of the character played by Glenn Close. The film, they say, is reactionary.

title: Winston-Salem
description: To the Editor: As a long-time resident of Winston-Salem, N.C., I was interested in ''Forums for Art and Design in North Carolina'' (Travel, Dec. 13), which mentioned five museums in our city, but I was disappointed that there was no mention of Salem Academy and College, the distinguished institutions for women founded in 1772 by the Moravians and still in existence.

title: Wilderness Caesars and Their Wives
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebel Threats in Philippines
description: A rebel band based here warned today that it may try to kill the United States Ambassador and other foreigners said to be supporting the Government's war against Communist guerrillas. A rebel spokesman told an Australian journalist that guerrillas were considering an assassination attempt against the Ambassador, Nicholas Platt. ''We will give him ample time and warning before we do it,'' said the spokesman, who also said that the guerrillas would target Australians, Britons and Israelis he claimed were helping the Government against the rebels. Previous rebel threats had been limited to Filipinos and Americans.

title: LEFISTS IN LOVE
description: THE BOOK AND THE BROTHERHOOD By Iris Murdoch. 607 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: WAR, DISEASE, SLAVERY AND POISONED WELLS
description: AMAZON FRONTIER The Defeat of the Brazilian Indians. By John Hemming. 647 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Dog in the Poet When he was almost 40 and severely depressed, the poet Rilke fell in love with a young concert pianist. The lifting of his spirits prompted some almost hysterically enthusiastic love letters, like this one from ''Rilke and Benvenuta: An Intimate Correspondence'' (Fromm).

title: FOOTBALL FANTASIA COMES TO POWER TOWN
description: THERE will be a curfew in Washington this evening. It is self-imposed and will begin at approximately 5 P.M. The streets will be deserted, the delicatessen shelves emptied and most restaurants, drugstore and supermarket chains shuttered early.

title: A HOME AUDIO SYSTEM FINDS BUYERS AT $50,000
description: ''GO ahead and turn the knob all the way to the right, then all the way back,'' said Mark Levinson, as he twirled a burnished aluminum dial. The soprano voice coming from two sets of stereo speakers shot to singularly clear high-range notes. He adjusted five other knobs, muting some sounds and bringing life to others.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE GREAT ESCAPE
description: LEAD: FROM a distance, it looks almost like a Miami Beach hotel: a big white building with lots of plate-glass windows and streams of relaxed people moving through the door. But it is, in fact, the All-Westchester Saw Mill Multiplex Cinema, a gargantuan haven for movie addicts and presumably the wave of the future with its 10 movie screens under one roof.

title: Gibson Tells Why He Left Tigers
description: Kirk Gibson's three-year, $4.5 million contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers may be a landmark in baseball's owner-player relations, but the former Detroit Tigers' left fielder said he wished it had never come to this.

title: LEO'S HALL OF FAME: HITS AND ERRORS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHALK UP ANOTHER ONE FOR THE BRITISH
description: THE current fascination with all things British has certainly left its mark on well-dressed Americans. Take the chalk-striped suit, for instance. While it has never exactly disappeared from wardrobes on this side of the Atlantic, these days it seems to be asserting itself with a vengeance.

title: Kundera's Shadow Colors 'Lightness'
description: EARLY IN ''THE UNBEARABLE Lightness of Being,'' Daniel Day Lewis stares at women. Tomas, the character he portrays, is a Czechoslovak brain surgeon whose easeful life will soon be wrenched apart - by undesired love, by the Russian military invasion of Prague in 1968 - but for now he has a look Don Juan might envy. Tomas, the actor says, has ''eyes like lasers. They constantly devour the details of women, the details of brains, the details of life'' - a description Mr. Day Lewis curiously echoes when recalling his first meeting with Milan Kundera, the Czechoslovak emigre author who created Tomas in the 1984 novel on which this new film is based.

title: NONFICTION
description: RED ON RED. By Red Holzman and Harvey Frommer. (Bantam, $17.95.) When they want to feel good, fans of the New York Knickerbockers remember the years 1968 to 1975. While Knick teams of the 80's play bad basketball to a lot of empty seats, great Knick teams of not so long ago treated sellout Madison Square Garden crowds to the playoffs every year. Hoop fans everywhere know the 1969-70 and 1972-73 Knick championship teams. Walt Frazier, Willis Reed, Dave DeBusschere, Bill Bradley and Jerry Lucas are in the Hall of Fame. So is their coach Red Holzman, who taught them teamwork and showed them how to win. ''Red on Red,'' written by Mr. Holzman and Harvey Frommer, a journalist and sports historian, is the entertaining account of a man's life in the sport that made him a legend. Born on the Lower East Side in 1920, Mr. Holzman was an all-American player at City College and turned pro with the old Rochester Royals. He joined the Knicks as chief scout and assistant coach when he was 37 and scouted such future stars as Frazier, Reed, Bradley and Cazzie Russell. When Mr. Holzman became the

title: German's Release Is Sought
description: Syria's military intelligence chief in Lebanon was in West Beirut today to seek the release of a West German who was kidnapped Wednesday, a Syrian close to events said. Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan reportedly drove from Syria Friday and made it known that ''Syria wants Schray released, the sooner the better.'' The German, Ralph Rudolph Schray, was abducted in West Beirut, which is policed by Syrian troops.

title: Right on Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Matchups For Broncos
description: Dave Studdard, Broncos' offensive tackle, versus Dexter Manley, Redskins' defensive end - Manley is coming on after a sluggish season during which he had 8 1/2 sacks. However, if he keeps his composure, he is the quickest and most dangerous pass rusher in this game, and he can disrupt an offense. Studdard is not as skilled as Manley. But as Studdard said, ''the only thing that upsets John Elway is not giving him time to throw the ball, and I don't want to upset him.''

title: New York Says Thanks To 'Ultimate Volunteer'
description: His lyric tenor filling the room, Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn offered a ballad about love.

title: OPEN SPACE VS. DEVELOPMENT: THE STRUGGLE INTENSIFIES
description: LEAD: WHEN Suffolk County bought the eastern tip of the Island's North Fork this month, it ended a seven-year struggle between community groups and developers.

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: The Broncos will, 34-17. EDWARD RANDALL New York

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: It all comes down to John Elway, the Bronco quarterback , against Doug Williams, Redskin quarterback. No contest. The Broncos will win, making the 1988 Super Bowl almost as boring as the last two Super Bowl games. R. M. FETTER Jenkintown, Pa.

title: SMALL-TOWN BENEFITS OF NEIGHBORS OUTWEIGH INCONVENIENCES
description: THE bell rang as I was preparing dinner, and I wiped my hands on my apron and opened the door. A golden-haired moppet of about 7 piped sweetly, ''Would you like to buy cookies for my Brownie troop?''

title: AS THE ROOM TURNS
description: THE HISTORY OF A ROOM IS A scrapbook of lives; the evolution of its decor, a record of evolving tastes and fashions. The room shown here was originally the newspaper publisher Joseph Pulitzer's bedroom. Tucked away on the upper floor of an old New York house, Pulitzer's private quarters were grand, his bedroom measuring 32 by 36 feet, with 16-foot-high ceilings.

title: PLANNING EARLY FOR RETIREMENT IS URGED
description: THE ideal time to start preparing for retirement is ''the day you begin working,'' the experts say, yet this advice almost always goes unheeded. ''Most people fear retirement emotionally and psychologically,'' observed Jean Carlson, a retirement consultant. ''Especially Americans, who derive a sense of self from the job.''

title: Sandinista's Ease Up on Their Opponents at Home
description: In an effort to persuade Congress to defeat President Reagan's request for new aid to the contras, the Sandinista Government has mounted a campaign of good deeds.

title: SATELLITE MAP CENTER PLANNED
description: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY'S department of environmental resources, which makes maps from satellite photographs for the state, has received a $10 million grant from the university's board of governors and plans to build a state-of-the-art center here on the campus.

title: TOBIAS 'SCULPTURAL PAINTINGS' IN RUTGERS ZIMMERLI SHOW
description: ABRAHAM Joel Tobias hasn't had a show since the mid-1930's, but he has made several murals. The earliest, done for the post office in Clarendon, Ark., is dated 1942; the most recent is a fresco, ''History of Science,'' that the artist worked on from 1960 to 1975 but for some reason left incomplete. It is in Brooklyn's Polytechnic Institute, along with two 1957 panels in colored Plexiglas called ''Science and Engineering.''

title: From California, a Helper for Mother Teresa
description: The former Governor of California, Edmund G. Brown Jr., is spending three to four weeks in this impoverished city working with patients at Mother Teresa's Home for Dying Destitutes.

title:
GARDENING;
HYBRID CREATION CAN BE WORTH THE EFFORT
description: LEAD: MANY of the most useful garden plants are hybrids. That is, they have resulted from crossing plants of dissimilar characteristics.

title: Cable TV
description: Definitely a notch above the norm are the two films making their cable debut this week - the 1986 box-office smash ''Crocodile Dundee'' and the 1987 thriller ''Black Widow.''

title: Social Events
description: A Concert, a Tea, a Cruise Black History Awards Feb. 1 - The Associated Black Charities, comprising 59 health and service groups, is holding a Black History Makers Award and Benefit Concert to honor Marian Anderson and other leading figures. The event opens with a cocktail party from 6 to 7:30 P.M. at the Parker Meridien. Billy Taylor, Melba Moore, Cleavon Little and Brock Peters are among those who will make presentations and perform at the concert at 8 at Carnegie Hall. Tickets, $150, or $25 and $45 for the concert alone, from 212-247-7800. Tea at the Regency Feb. 4 - The New York Riding Program for the Handicapped is developing a therapeutic horseback riding program for the disabled in the city's public parks. A tea will be held from 3 to 5 at the Regency, Park Avenue at 61st Street, to elicit support for the new program. Hosts for the benefit include Eddie Bracken, Vincent Gardenia, Larry Kert, Ed Kranepool, Carol Lynley, Boom Boom Mancini, Roddy McDowall, Floyd Patterson and Kyle Rote. Tickets, $25, from 212-535-3917. Champagne Cruise Feb. 5 - There will Champagne on deck, an open bar, a buffet and the music of Cole Porter in the lounge as the yacht Princess cruises up the Hudson River. Boarding is at 6 at Pier 62 (West 23d Street), with the three-hour cruise starting at 7. The evening will benefit Citymeals-on-Wheels, which provides meals for the homebound elderly in conjunction with the city's Department for the Aging. Tickets, $50, from 212-577-7324. Downtown Mardi Gras Feb. 6 - In its 103d year of service, the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club provides guidance at five centers in the metropolitan area to more that 6,000 youngsters a year. A benefit for the club, its second Mardi Gras Mambo, will be held at the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street (Houston Street). Hors d'oeuvres, an open bar and dancing start at 9 P.M. Black tie or costume. Tickets, $50, from 212-532-5751, or $60 at the door. Magical Family Show Feb. 7 - A magic show with the magician Harry Blackstone, a buffet brunch, and a laser show and dancing will be held for families with children age 8 to 15 at the Saint disco, 105 Second Avenue (Sixth Street). The benefit, from noon to 4, will aid the Trail Blazers, a 100-year-old social and educational agency serving disadvantaged children 8 to 17 who are referred to the organization by 35 social agencies in New York and New Jersey. Tickets, $100 for adults, $50 for children, from 212-691-2720. Veterans' Benefit Feb. 7 - A musical benefit saluting Vietnam veterans will be held at the Shubert Theater at 8. An imposing array of talent will be on hand, including the jazz greats Dizzy Gillespie and Dave Brubeck, the Gregg Smith Singers and Philip Glass with the premiere of a composition accompanying Alan Ginsberg's poem ''Wichita Vortex.'' There will be readings by David Rabe, the author of ''Sticks and Bones,'' ''The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel'' and ''Streamers.'' Sponsored by the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company, the evening will benefit the company's community programs, including the Borden Avenue Shelter in Queens, a shelter for homeless people, especially veterans. A reception with the performers follows at Sardi's. Tickets, $100, or $25, $40 and $50 for the performance alone, from Telecharge, 212-239-6200. Goodbye, Children Feb. 10 - Louis Malle's newest film, ''Au Revoir, les Enfants,'' is described as the director's most personal film, inspired by what he has termed ''the most tragic memory'' of his childhood. The official French entry for best foreign film at the Academy Awards, it will have its New York premiere at 8:30 P.M. at Cinema I, at Third Avenue and 60th Street. The premiere will benefit the Starlight Foundation, which has granted the wishes of more than 3,000 terminally ill children. A Champagne reception follows the movie. Tickets, $50 and $25, from 212-302-3970. Garment District Party Feb. 10 - The Needlers, a group in the garment district that raises funds for underprivileged children, is holding a comedy benefit at the Club 1407 Restaurant at 1407 Broadway (38th Street). Rob Bartlett will lead the hilarity, starting at 8. Tickets, $15, from 212-575-1407, which does not include dinner and drinks, which may be ordered from the regular menu starting at 6. Aiding Heart Research Feb. 11 - The Heart Research Foundation will present its 1988 International Recognition Award to Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, a pioneer in cardiac surgery and research, at its annual black-tie fund-raising dinner. The dinner, which starts with cocktails at 6 at the Pierre, marks the 20th anniversary of the foundation. Tickets, $300, from 212-241-5484. Staten Island Benefit Feb. 11 - Founded 12 years ago, the Staten Island Children's Museum at Snug Harbor presents exhibitions for children and their parents. A fashion show and dinner to benefit the museum will be held from 7 to 11 at the Monte Bianco restaurant at 2131 Hyland Boulevard in the Dongan Hills section. Tickets, $30, from 718-273-2060.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
WHEN FLU STRIKES, CAN THIS MARRIAGE BE SAVED?
description: LEAD: EACH year as the flu season looms, I send up a small prayer for my husband.

title: BETS ARE HEDGED IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Call it political inverse proportion, or whatever, but the closer the Feb. 16 New Hampshire Presidential primary gets, the more the voters and campaign workers here seem to hedge their bets.

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: Who cares?! MARK G. BRENNAN Jersey City

title: Hutton's End
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Correction Officers Demoted at Sing Sing
description: Four senior correction officers at Sing Sing have been demoted and transferred after an investigation late last year indicated that they were ineffective in stopping drug smuggling by guards, gambling and sex between inmates and female guards, the commissioner of New York State corrections said yesterday.

title: HOW THE RAILS WON WESTCHESTER
description: LEAD: HORACE GREELEY, the New York Herald-Tribune editor famous for exhorting young men to ''Go West,'' was equally enthusiastic in urging those who stayed behind to commute by train.

title: Food Giant CPC Is Big In Everything but Name
description: If American Express did corporate ''Do you know me?'' ads, CPC International Inc. would be a natural choice. Most everyone knows Mazola corn oil, Hellmann's mayonnaise, Skippy peanut butter, Thomas's English muffins and its other products. But CPC itself? It seemed to have made a high science of keeping a low profile.

title: Kean to Propose a $11.8 Billion Budget
description: Governor Kean will recommend a state budget of $11.8 billion Tuesday that includes money to raise minimum starting salaries of teachers and to create a new state division to deal with AIDS.

title: THE AFTERSHOCKS OF AN ACCIDENT REPEAT A LESSON ABOUT SURVIVAL
description: IN April my daughter and I were in a car accident. We were driving to my parents' house in Pennyslvania; it was rush hour on a three-lane interstate highway. I was in the right lane. The 18-wheeler to my left didn't see me. He pulled abruptly into my lane and hit my car, sending me spinning in front of him, where he hit me a second time. I was hurled backward down the highway and across the third lane into the grassy median, where I managed to regain control of the car before it crossed into the opposing three lanes.

title: Confident St. John's Catches Seton Hall
description: It's tempting to feel sorry for Coach P. J. Carlesimo and his Seton Hall Pirates.

title:
ART;
THE INDUSTRIAL AND THE BESTIAL IN STAMFORD
description: LEAD: ART EX, the shedlike extension of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, is an appropriate rough-hewn site for the current exhibition of 12 paintings by Gerald McLaughlin, which have about them an odd sense of the machine shop.

title: REPORT FAULTS EMPLOYMENT OUTLOOK
description: THE New Jersey Council of Churches has taken a hard look behind the state's low unemployment figures and found disquieting evidence that putting people to work is no longer enough to make the American Dream a reality for many citizens.

title: F.A.A. Shuts Down Alaska Commuter Airline
description: Alaska's largest commuter airline has been temporarily shut down by the Federal Aviation Administration because of safety problems.

title: IN ASSEMBLY, THE THEME IS FISCAL
description: PROPERTY-TAX relief, low-income housing and a new school-aid formula are expected to top the agenda when the General Assembly convenes Wednesday.

title: Hints of Weakness In Growth Report
description: The economy's growth rate for the final quarter of 1987 was deceptively robust. Gross national product rose at an annual rate of 4.2 percent during the quarter, but most of the increased output piled up as unsold inventory, which is likely to be a drag on the economy in the immediate future. The economy grew at an inflation-adjusted rate of 3.7 percent for all of 1987, the fifth year of expansion.

title: PORT CHESTER SCHOOLS GET REPORT ON BIAS
description: LEAD: AN advisory committee to the Port Chester Board of Education has proposed establishing so-called magnet programs as the best means of achieving racial balance in the district.

title: GROUPS SEEK TO CURB TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: AS an aftermath to the suicides involving four teen-agers in Bergen County last year that touched off a rash of what some police officials termed ''copycat'' suicides, a consortium of New Jersey nonprofit organizations has started a campaign to educate the public on spotting and helping teen-agers with suicidal tendencies.

title: Gretzky Returns
description: IT was his first day back at work after the longest layoff of his career, and for Wayne Gretzky it was a busy, if ultimately unsatisfying, night Friday in Edmonton. He set up all four Oiler goals in a game against Calgary, but the Flames got five, spoiling Gretzky's return after a 13-game absence. Gretzky, who strained the ligaments of his right knee on Dec. 30, said that his knee had passed its first game test. ''The leg's fine,'' he said. ''I got hit a couple of times and it was O.K.''

title: DATA BANK: January 31, 1988
SUPER BOWL XXII
description: That Game Is Today

title: FORD'S ALL-WHEEL DRIVE
description: PLASTIC garbage cans are a boon to those of us who work nights and sleep days.

title: RACIAL REPORT ON SCHOOLS: THE FALLOUT
description: NATIONAL Black History Month begins tomorrow, and to Education Commissioner Gerald N. Tirozzi, the way it is being observed in Connecticut's schools is an indication of the need for more racial balance.

title: PATRICIA E. HARRIS IS WED TO LAWYER
description: Patricia E. Harris, the executive director of the New York City Art Commission and an assistant to Mayor Koch, and Mark D. Lebow, a lawyer who is the chairman of the City Civil Service Commission, were married last evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs officiated.

title: Bearing Witness
description: THREE YEARS ago, when I suggested an article to the editors of this magazine on ''the human cost of AIDS,'' most reporting on the epidemic was scientific in nature and people with AIDS were often portrayed as faceless victims. By profiling a man with AIDS and his volunteer counselor from Gay Men's Health Crisis, I proposed to show the devastating impact AIDS was having on a few individual lives. It had certainly had an impact on mine. I suspected that I was carrying the virus and I was terrified.

title: Dance: Balanchine's 'Stravinsky Violin Concerto'
description: THE program note for George Balanchine's ballet ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto'' remarks that the choreographer used the same score in 1941 for an earlier ballet, ''under the title 'Balustrade,' with beautiful costumes and scenery by the late Pavel Tchelitchev.''

title: Maryland Politician Convicted
description: A jury in Federal District Court on Friday found Clarence Mitchell 3d, a former State Senator, guilty of conspiracy and obstructing a grand jury investigation into his connection with a convicted Baltimore drug dealer.

title: L.I. SOUND GOVERNMENTS JOIN FORCES
description: REACHING beyond the boundaries that divide them, the leaders of Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties in New York have joined with New York City and Stamford to discuss mutual and increasingly difficult environmental problems.

title: Round-the-World Mark Aids Charity
description: Riding a strong tailwind, a Boeing 747SP on a mission for children's charity smashed the round-the-world speed record today, landing here 36 hours 54 minutes 15 seconds after takeoff.

title: CELEBRITY MATCHMAKER: Marty Blackman Marrying Athletes and Endorsements
description: The advertising agency executive, Marty Blackman recalled, was frantic. He had just heard a rumor that a former football star serving as a spokesman for his client, a major soft drink company, was gay. He wanted Mr. Blackman to find out whether it was true.

title: E. STACY CREAMER TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Shane Creamer of Blue Bell, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter E. Stacy Creamer to C. Roger Finney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clement Seymour Finney of Victoria, British Columbia.

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: Joe Gibbs is arguably the best coach in football. John Elway is unquestionably the best quarterback in football. This Super Bowl will be decided by these two men. In the World Series, the on-field leadership of Don Baylor outmatched the off-field leadership of Whitey Herzog. Super Bowls, like World Series, are won or lost on the field, not in the locker room. Elway will lend further credence to this theory in the big game. ANDREW SIFF Middletown, Conn.

title: Music
description: Increasingly, classical music lovers are finding some of their deepest satisfactions before and after the ''standard repertory,'' which means mostly music composed between the late 18th and early 20th centuries. This week, there are piquant events both old and new to be heard.

title: WHAT THEY'RE WEARING
description: NOW, THE PAPARAZZI'S cameras catch them, though at the turn of the century it would have been the brush of a portrait painter.

title: Maine Couple Pick Up Lives After Nightmare
description: The painting of two blond-haired children on the outside of what was once the Mother Goose Nursery School is faded now. The small desks and chairs and brightly colored pictures are no longer inside.

title: DR. PHYLLIS SCHMIEDEBERG MARRIES SCOTT SHERMAN
description: The marriage of Dr. Phyllis Schmiedeberg to Scott M. Sherman took place yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York. Acting Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, who is also the supervising judge of the Civil Court in Manhattan, officiated.

title: Newspapers' Chains Assailed
description: Independently owned newspapers are fading and big chains are elbowing their way into domination of American journalism, according to Charles K. McClatchy, editor and chairman of the board of McClatchy Newspapers. He said several chains paid more attention to profits than quality journalism.

title: The Santa Fe Opera Announces '88 Season
description: The Santa Fe Opera will present the United States premiere of Krzystof Penderecki's opera ''The Black Mask'' during its 1988 season, which begins July 1 and ends Aug. 27, the company's director, John Crosby, has announced. The opera is one of six that will be given during the 37-performance series.

title: STATE SUES WATERBURY ON RACIAL BALANCE
description: IN its first court test of a 1969 school desegregation law, the state has filed a suit to force Waterbury to balance the racial enrollments at an elementary school in the city.

title: FICTION
description: OUT ON THE RIM. By Ross Thomas. (Mysterious Press, $17.95.) Here's one solution to that panicky, last-ditch scramble at the airport for the perfect book to read on the plane. Ross Thomas's nimble international thriller will get you to Washington, Malibu, Manila, Hong Kong and even - with a few backup books like his earlier ''Briarpatch'' and ''Cold War Swap'' - to the Philippines. These are also the locales visited by the putative hero of ''Out on the Rim,'' Booth Stallings, an expert on terrorism who is given the unenviable assignment of waving a $5-million bribe at a Communist guerrilla leader to dissuade him from bringing down the Aquino Government. Being no bushwhacker himself, Stallings shrewdly recruits the services of four professional adventurers, who are no sooner hired than they're scheming with (and against) him on ways to take the money and scoot. At this point, Mr. Thomas proves that he really knows how to fly this airline literature as he puts his plot through some sidewinder loops that confound all our assumptions about the moral and political value of the original do-good assignment. With each twist of the story, he also reveals a darker side to his disarmingly comic characters, who include a consummate con artist who goes by the sobriquet of Otherguy (as in ''the other guy did it'') Overby and a wily tactical genius, Arthur Wu, who declares himself the Emperor of China. Ultimately, Mr. Thomas uses the heroic conventions of the genre to mock the very notion of heroism. With cynical amusement, his witty rogues define a world war as ''the ultimate geography lesson'' and terrorism as ''politics without moral compunction.'' It's this kind of black humor that can keep you laughing even while the plane goes down.

title: To Expel Troublesome Students or Keep Them in School
description: To the Editor:

title: KATHRYN GRINER ENGAGED TO WED G. H. MEHLMAN
description: Kathryn Griner and G. Hamilton Mehlman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Mehlman of Brookline, Mass., plan to marry in August, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Griner 3d of Portola Valley, Calif., have announced.

title: Golf's Busy Day
description: THERE'S something about meeting in the nation's capital that gets the legislative juices flowing, and for those at the United States Golf Association's 94th annual meeting, it was a gavel-filled day in Washington yesterday. Among other things, the organization elected a new president, William C. Battie of Ivy, Va.; selected the United States team for the 1988 Curtis Cup, and issued four international exemptions and one expatriate exemption for qualifying for the United States Open.

title: FINANCIAL FIRMS SHOWING SIGNS OF A SLOWDOWN
description: AFTER some great years, the financial-services industry in the state is showing signs of slowing down.

title: THE LITTLE DIRTY GIRL AND HER SISTERS
description: LEAD: THE HIDDEN SIDE OF THE MOON By Joanna Russ. 229 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $15.95.

title: On the Costly, But Open Road
description: EVER since the concept of personal mobility dawned on me, I had dreamed of renting a motor home and traveling cross-country. What a convenient, entertaining and inexpensive way to go, I thought. Well, two out of three, as they say, aren't bad.

title: ORCHESTRA EVENTS AND 1689 OPERA AMONG WEEK'S HIGHLIGHTS
description: ORCHESTRAL concerts will be bountiful this week, beginning Tuesday evening when the noted Soviet emigre maestro, Rudolf Barshai, will be the guest conductor for the Hartford Symphony.

title: Forger Who Killed 2 Must Spend Life in Prison, Board Rules
description: A man who killed two people to cover up his forgeries of historical documents must spend the rest of his life in prison, the Utah Board of Pardons decided Friday.

title: LAUREN MOLLOY, DESIGNER, TO MARRY MARIO BUCCELLATI
description: Lauren Rebecca Molloy and Mario Buccellati plan to marry in March, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. John Haywood Molloy of Newburgh, N.Y., have announced.

title: DR. STEINBERG ENGAGED
description: A June wedding is planned by Dr. Ricki Ellyn Steinberg, a senior resident in pediatrics at Beth Israel Hospital, and Dr. Dean Cory Mitchell, a senior resident in internal medicine at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. The couple graduated from the Sackler School of Medicine in Tel Aviv. Dr. Steinberg, the daughter of Lynne B. Steinberg of New York, graduated from the State University at Albany. Dr. Mitchell, a graduate of Brown University, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Merton Mitchell of Lido Beach, L.I.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Bedford, N.Y. $310,000 Brundage Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old frame raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $3,956. New Rochelle, N.Y. $143,000 43 Third Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 98-year-old stucco colonial; enclosed porch, 2-car garage; taxes $1,637. Peekskill, N.Y. $177,750 74 Locust Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old stone/frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, patio, walk to station and stores; taxes $4,458. Branford, Conn. $235,000 39 Knollwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; family neighborhood, large rooms, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,640. Canton, Conn. $175,000 12 Freelawn Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old ranch; 2-car garage, 125- by 315-foot lot; taxes $1,918. Roxbury, Conn. $600,000 South Street 7-bedroom, 2-bath, 1784 Colonial; Palladian windows, barn, 8 acres; taxes $3,852. OTHER AREAS Denville, N.J. $255,000 68 Kitchell Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old ranch; wall-to-wall carpeting, central air conditioning; taxes $2,400. Livingston, N.J. $445,000 14 Princeton Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 36-year-old ranch; finished basement, den, formal dining room; taxes $4,547. East Setauket, L.I. $138,000 11 Rack Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,500.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE STATE CAPITOL IN HARTFORD;
WAITING IN THE WINGS FOR THEIR CUE FROM THE GAVEL
description: LEAD: ON Wednesday, the Secretary of the State, Julia Tashjian, will rap a gavel to begin the 1988 session of the General Assembly, and once again the ornate halls of the State Capitol will fill with the noise and bustle of legislative activity as 187 lawmakers officially report to work.

title: PISTONS ARE LISTLESS AND NETS CAPITALIZE
description: The Detroit Pistons, who had the league's fifth-best record, came to New Jersey today thinking they would beat the Nets. Even though the Nets led by 10, then by 13, and then by 16, it was clear that the Pistons were waiting until the fourth quarter to beat the team with the worst record in the National Basketball Association.

title: Father Threatens Son's Life For 7 Hours Before Giving Up
description: A domestic dispute turned into a tense standoff in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday between the police and a distraught father who theatened to jump out of a seventh-floor window with his year-old son.

title: Arizona Governor Won't Quit; Recall Vote Set
description: Declaring, ''I have broken no laws,'' Gov. Evan Mecham said today he would not resign but instead will run in a recall election to keep his job.

title: COUNTY SEEKS BALL TEAM
description: LEAD: ATLANTIC County freeholders hope to attract a minor-league baseball team to the area by the summer of 1989, andat least one double-A league team has indicated interest.

title: COMMITMENT ON L.I. SOUND GAINING STRENGTH
description: LEAD: THE life of Long Island Sound has been at risk for more than a decade as pollution - at times closing the beaches or killing the fish - threatens its commercial and recreational uses.

title: NANCY L. CLARK TO WED RICHARD JOHN ANGERER
description: Nancy Lawrence Clark and Richard John Angerer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Angerer of Lansing, N.Y., plan to marry in August, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Clark of Cooperstown, N.Y., and St. Simons Island, Ga., have announced.

title: JONAH WAS CLAUSTROPHOBIC
description: THE STRANGE NATION OF RAFAEL MENDES By Moacyr Scliar. Translated by Eloah F. Giacomelli. 309 pp. New York: Harmony Books/Crown Publishers. $19.95.

title: At 85, Frightened By a Loss of Power
description: LEAD: Her walk is slow, hesitant, leaning slightly forward from the waist. Her hands, swollen and misshapen with arthritis, have traceries of blue veins across the back. They are never still.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 31, 1988
HARPER HELPS CAVALIERS DEFEAT BULLETS
description: Ron Harper, whose short bank shot with 1 second left in regulation forced overtime, made a 10-foot jumper in the lane with 10 seconds to go in the extra period tonight as the Cleveland Cavaliers defeated the Washington Bullets, 128-126.

title: L.I. SOUND COUNTIES FORM COALITION
description: REACHING beyond the political and geographic boundaries that divide them, leaders of three counties and two of the cities bordering Long Island Sound recently formed a coalition to resolve their mutual and increasingly difficult environmental problems.

title: Headliners; Ending in Colombia
description: Drug traffickers in Colombia demonstrated a new level of ruthless audacity last week with the kidnapping and murder of Carlos Hoyos, Colombia's Attorney General. American law-enforcement authorities considered Mr. Hoyos an important ally in the campaign to prosecute the Colombian drug kingpins believed to be responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine entering the United States. The official was taken from his bullet-ridden Mercedes after he and two bodyguards were caught in a hail of machine-gun fire near the city of Medellin. Mr. Hoyos, who was investigating the release from jail of a drug trafficker whose extradition the United States had sought, was later found dead. A caller to a Colombian broadcaster said he had been executed for ''betraying the country.'' American officials said the crime was ''a real blow.''

title: LUNDINE TRIES TO BUILD A JOB AND A NAME
description: SHORTLY before Stan Lundine took office as Lieutenant Governor of New York in January 1987, he consulted the man who had held the job longer than anyone else: Malcolm Wilson, No. 2 to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller for 15 years. Surprisingly, Mr. Wilson's advice was exactly the opposite of what Mr. Lundine had hoped for. Do not build a large independent empire and staff, Mr. Wilson said. Instead, become integral to the Governor's operation and force his staff to serve you as well as him. That is the path to power.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: PUNISHMENTS MUST FIT THE 'CRIME';
Court Verdicts Are Fair
description: LEAD: ALARMED by large increases in the dollar value of jury awards, many in the business community insist that juries are no longer able to dispense justice fairly and that our civil justice system has become too expensive. Careful analysis of jury behavior and the functioning of the tort system shows, however, that efforts to weaken liability laws and limit court awards for product-related injuries are not only unjustified but also socially harmful.

title: About Men; A Son on His Own
description: SHORTLY AFTER GRADUATING from high school next June, my son will join the Navy. He announced this decision - which I don't much like - by telephone, just before arriving for one of his holiday visits from the Middle West, where he lives with his mother.

title: Q&A
description: San Diego Trips Question:I would like to take a cruise of three days or so from San Diego down the coast of Baja California, Mexico. If there is such a cruise, on a small ship, who administers it? - Z. C. M., New York, N.Y. Answer:Opportunities for a short cruise of this kind are limited. One option is the Executive Explorer of Catamaran Cruiselines which does four-night round trips from San Diego with an overnight in Ensenada, Mexico. Among other places visited are Anacapa and Santa Catalina Islands. This cruise will be available on the 104-foot-long vessel, which carries 49 passengers, in April and May.

title: Plague Years In the Imagery Of Those Who Endured Them
description: Banzhen is a goddess who travels through China spreading smallpox, accompanied by two young attendants called Elder Brother Smallpox and Elder Sister Smallpox. Mariyamman is a goddess who scatters smallpox among the Tamils of South India and Sri Lanka whenever she is angered. Shopona is a god who uses smallpox to punish members of the Yoruba people of Nigeria who have broken his taboos.

title: Does Rock Merit Subsidy?
description: An article tucked away in a recent Billboard magazine and filed for future reference reports that Australia, which already provided a modest sum (slightly more than $50,000) in such support in 1985, is considering a significant expansion in public subsidies for rock music. The debate in that country apparently revolves around such questions as who should administer the funds, whether they are better provided for international touring bands or for mid- or entry-level groups, and so forth.

title: SPECIAL OLYMPIANS UNITE TO WIN
description: LEAD: PROMINENT on the bulletin board inside the Darien High School weight room is a poster that reads: ''What is a workout? A workout, is 25 perspiration and 75 percent determination.''

title: A Witches' Brew to Create a Clone
description: A COVEN of smaller technology companies announced recently that it had stirred together the silicon equivalent of eye of newt and toe of frog, wool of bat and tongue of dog. From this brew, it said, would come the makings of a clone of the new Personal System/2 line of computers from I.B.M.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Robocop Starring Peter Weller, Nancy Allen, Daniel O'Herlihy, Ronny Cox. Directed by Paul Verhoeven. 1987. Orion Home Video. 103 minutes. $89.98. Rated R.

title: Defer the Contra Decision
description: Yes or no: Continue aid to the contra rebels in Nicaragua, or finally cut them off? For the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has by hook and, almost literally, crook, kept the aid flowing. This week Congress will vote on the newest proposal, for $36 million in aid, including $3.6 million in military aid. Congress, rightly eager to support the peace plan of President Arias of Costa Rica, seems ready to pull the plug on the contras.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I wouldn't be surprised to see negative growth in this quarter and even in the second quarter.''

title: Rethinking Needs Some Thought
description: I recall reading in an old book that the world was rushed into production in six days, after which a complete rest was felt to be necessary. Presumably, the work was considered perfect at the time. Or maybe the result fell so short of expectation that the whole show was simply allowed to stand, flaws and all, to be rethought another day. At any rate, it is not recorded that attempts were ever made to improve on the original.

title: PARIS ARIANE CARLIN TO BE WED MARCH 5
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Carlin of Bryn Mawr, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Paris Ariane Carlin to Johan H. W. Christofferson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lars H. Christofferson of Greenwich, Conn.

title: PORSCHE TEAM ENJOYS LUXURY
description: Karl Durkheimer's new home-built Porsche 911 race car was transported from Portland, Ore., to Florida in an enclosed trailer, towed by a new six-seat truck for the start of the SunBank 24 Hours of Daytona yesterday.

title: Marbled Paper
description: To the Editor: Miss Lumsden asserts that ''marbled paper-making survives today almost exclusively in Florence.'' This is most certainly not true. Neither can Italy, nor France, whose firm of Michel Duval is referred to in the article, be said to be the only Western countries in which the marbling tradition continues. Cockerell in England has been world famous for many decades, and in the United States a major revival of the art has taken place over the last 15 years and gained tremendous momentum in the last seven or eight. Here marbled paper is not only used in book binding and in desk accessories but is also incorporated by designers in wall papers, room accents, bed linen, window-treatment patterns and clothing, to name a few nontraditional uses.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE COMIC BOOK BUSINESS;
Out of the Ghetto, Into the Mainstream
description: LEAD: ''IT'S time for the comics business to get out of the ghetto and into the mainstream,'' said Gary Groth, founder of Fantagraphics Books. Comics must be marketed on a large scale, he added, employing mainstream publishers' techniques.

title: DONNA GAIL JONAS TO WED IN AUGUST
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sterling Jonas of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Gail Jonas, to Harry Isadore Goldberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Goldberg of Savannah, Ga. An August wedding is planned.
