Livingston $445,000 14 Princeton Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 36-year-old ranch; finished basement, den, formal dining room; taxes $4,547. Maplewood $149,000 165 Jacoby Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; deck, fenced yard, living-room fireplace; taxes $2,467. Millburn $240,000 28 Greenwood Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, C/A, enclosed porch, 2-car garage; taxes $3,334. OTHER AREAS Peekskill, N.Y. $177,750 74 Locust Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old stone/frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, patio, walk to station and stores; taxes $4,458. Branford, Conn. $235,000 39 Knollwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; family neighborhood, large rooms, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,640. Rocky Point, L.I. $138,500 319 Locust Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400.

title: STREETSCAPES: 1020 Madison Avenue; A Lonely Rowhouse Ignored By Two Historic Districts
description: THE five-story house at 1020 Madison Avenue, built in 1913, looks no different from the other rowhouses in its Upper East Side neighborhood. But it is a sort of orphan, inexplicably marooned just outside the invisible boundaries of the two historic districts that cover most of the area.

title:
MUSIC;
KING'S DAUGHTER TO NARRATE TRIBUTE
description: LEAD: ''NEW Morning for the World,'' a tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will be played by the Cathedral Symphony Orchestra next Sunday with Yolanda King, eldest daughter of the slain civil rights leader, narrating.

title: THE MEANS TO WAR
description: THE ARMS CONTROL DELUSION By Malcolm Wallop and Angelo Codevilla. 220 pp. San Francisco: ICS Press/Institute for Contemporary Studies. $16.95

title: The Chinese Hear Why It's O.K. for Some to Get Rich First
description: SOME people are getting rich, while many other Chinese are complaining about rising cabbage prices. Gambling is on the rise. And the press is full of reports of extravagant weddings, jealousies over individual successes and soaring divorce rates. At the same time, the power of petty and not so petty Communist Party officials is eroding.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; For Connecticut, Home-Grown Modulars
description: ON Feb. 20, the model of a modular home built in the Victorian style is to be unveiled on Peck's Lane in Newtown, a first step in a new era for prefabricated housing in Connecticut.

title: Amtrak Crash Inquiry Seeks Tower Operator
description: Federal investigators today were still trying to contact an Amtrak control tower operator who fled after a passenger train derailed Friday when it hit a maintenance vehicle on a track that should have been closed.

title: The Secondary Market for Mortgages
description: WHEN Citicorp recently announced layoffs in its North American investment bank, including many in the mortgage-backed securities department, some people wondered whether the cutbacks signaled an industry contraction that could mean less money for residential mortgages - and ultimately higher rates.

title: Senator Returns Donations From a Contributor to Hart
description: Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts has returned campaign contributions that a former employee of the video producer Stuart Karl has alleged were illegally donated, a spokesman for Mr. Kerry said today.

title: 'Vladimir's Carrot'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CYCLE BEGINS AT ST. JAMES
description: A SERIES of concerts organized last winter at the historic St. James Episcopal Church in North Salem drew such an enthusiastic response that a new cycle of ''Music at St. James'' has been arranged for the final Sundays of January, February and March - with the first concert beginning this afternoon.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE COMIC BOOK BUSINESS
description: LEAD: THOUGH Archie, Jughead and Veronica still smile out from the newsstands - just as comic heroes did during the ''Golden Age'' of the 1930's and 1940's - comics increasingly are housed in specialty shops and are even invading traditional bookstores. And the adventures of these new heroes have changed to meet the tastes of a more sophisticated and cynical time.

title: A HARDY SHRUB FOR WINTERTIME
description: RECENT ice/wind storms may have broken limbs or branches; check yews, hemlocks, rhododendrons, junipers, birches, dogwoods and magnolias; if damage is found, saw or prune back to main trunk or strong wood. If trees and shrubs are not broken, but bent over, they should right themselves naturally in time. Winter Bloom

title: Noah's Ark: The Sequel
description: IT MAY SEEM WILDLY FUTURISTIC, but the whole idea actually recalls Noah's Ark. Biosphere II, a completely enclosed, 2.25-acre, self-supporting ecosystem designed to accommodate plant, animal and human life, has been in the works since 1984 near Tucson, Ariz. Supporters see the project as a hedge against the eventual extinction of life on Earth (aka, Biosphere I), as well as a step toward colonization of the Moon and Mars.

title: Gandhi Dissolves State Rule After Assembly Brawl
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today dissolved the government of the southern state of Tamil Nadu, acting two days after violent brawling on the floor of the State Assembly had to be broken up by the police.

title: 'LET'S SAY YOU WROTE BADLY THIS MORNING'
description: LEAD: In September 1986, I had a novel rejected. In October of the same year, I had that rejection on my mind as I watched the American and National League baseball playoffs. I had a new television set that allowed me to see what I had never really noticed before - the facial expressions of the players.

title: APPEAL ON GROUP HOME LOSES
description: STATE efforts to bring more group homes to Westchester communities provoked new controversy this month as Larchmont lost an appeal, the town of Mamaroneck initiated an appeal and Hastings-on-Hudson began reviewing a proposal. The Larchmont community residence will serve nine mentally disabled men, while both the Mamaroneck and Hasting homes are to serve developmentally disabled adults.

title: Bavarian Premier Assailed for South Africa Visit
description: Premier Franz Josef Strauss of Bavaria said today that the South African Government promised to free 14 jailed blacks within a week and review the cases of more than 100 more.

title: BETH JOY SCHLEGEL WED TO JAY S. RAND ON L.I.
description: Beth Joy Schlegel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schlegel of Woodmere, L.I., and Jay Samuel Rand, the son of Earl Joseph Rand of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Naomi Ruth Rand, were married last evening. Rabbis Morris Pickholz and Mordecai Waxman officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: KNICKS ROAD WOES GROW IN OVERTIME
description: Sedale Threatt's basket from the right of the key with 55 seconds remaining in overtime tonight enabled the Chicago Bulls to defeat the Knicks, 97-95. The loss extended the Knicks' road-game losing streak to 15; they have lost 20 of the last 21 on the road.

title: Oral Record of a Loquacious Mayor Strains Storage Space
description: In a high-ceilinged room in a 110-year-old building near City Hall, the ubiquitous sight and sound of Edward I. Koch is filling file cabinets at the rate of more than a drawer a month.

title: Specialists
description: WASHINGTON Punter: 12 Cox Kickoffs: 12 Cox Field-Goal Kicker: 6 Haji-Sheikh Holder: 10 Schroeder Punt Returner: 28 Green Kick Returner: 35 Griffin DENVER Punter: 2 Horan Kickoffs and Field Goals: 3 Karlis Holder: 8 Kubiak Punt Returner: 27 Clark Kick Returner: 35 Bell

title: MORE ARE SEEKING HELP IN LIFTING DEBT BURDENS
description: LEAD: THE number of Connecticut residents so heavily in debt they sought help from a nonprofit credit counseling agency to work out repayment plans increased by 50 percent last year.

title: The Many Sounds of Joyce
description: James Joyce loved coinci-dences - especially about his own birthday - so he certainly would love his birthday celebration at Merkin Concert Hall tomorrow night, were he around to take part in it, which he will be, in a manner of speaking.

title: U.S. Envoy Sees Hussein on Mideast
description: In a new effort to get Arab-Israeli peace talks under way, President Reagan has sent Philip C. Habib, his former special Middle East envoy, to Jordan to meet this weekend with King Hussein, American officials said today.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I have a chair whose frame is made of white plastic that has discolored to an uneven beige. Yet a painted metal brace is still white. Is there any way to clean or bleach the plastic, or is there a white paint I can apply?

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: FRONTIER ARTISTS

title: Rome, Hollywood Style
description: QUO VADIS Starring Robert Taylor (in photo), Deborah Kerr, Leo Genn, Peter Ustinov. Produced by Sam Zimbalist. Directed by Mervyn LeRoy. 1951. MGM/UA Home Video. 171 minutes (2 cassettes). $89.95.

title:
THE WORLD: A VOICE FROM ISLAMABAD;
FRONT MAN FOR AMERICA, AND PAYING FOR IT
description: LEAD: For too long and at too high a cost, Pakistan has been paying for the sins of the Russians and the ambitions of the Americans in a region that is vital to both.

title: Behind Super-VHS
description: Those who worry about the innovative acumen of American industry have some reassuring news.

title: L.I. SOUND NEIGHBORS FORM A COALITION
description: REACHING beyond the political and geographic boundaries that divide them, government leaders of the areas bordering Long Island Sound have agreed to form a coalition to resolve environmental problems. ''We've got a lot of clout down here,'' Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, a Democrat, said. ''We want to exercise it.''

title: At the Trade Talks, America Must Lead
description: NEXT month, the 95 members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will reconvene in their Geneva headquarters to begin the second year of negotiations on revisions of world trade rules. Watched with a good deal of fanfare in the fall of 1986 in Punta del Este, Uruguay, these negotiations are scheduled to end in 1990. And their results could be pivotal.

title: Jesse Helms: The Arms Treaty Is Only His Latest Target
description: It is not as if anyone on Capitol Hill expected hearings on the new treaty banning medium- and shorter-range nuclear weapons to produce riveting television or scintillating news stories. But the members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee had hoped at least for a dignified showing as they set out to advise, consent and perhaps even improve on the first major arms agreement with the Soviet Union to come before them in nearly a decade.

title: JENNIFER SLINGLUFF ENGAGED TO WED PATRICK ROBINSON
description: The engagement of Jennifer Grant Slingluff to Patrick Malone Robinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Miller Robinson Jr. of Nashville, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Haines Slingluff Jr. of Rumson, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: WHAT HE SAW IN BONWIT TELLER
description: A WOMAN RUN MAD By John L'Heureux. 258 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE only rookie in the National Basketball Association's slam-dunk championship in Chicago on Feb. 6. has had to withdraw because of injury, but another rookie will be taking his place. Greg Anderson, a first-year San Antonio Spur, was named to replace Scottie Pippen, a Bulls rookie who is nursing a back injury. . . . John Brockington, whose skill as a running back took him from Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn to Ohio State to the Green Bay Packers and the Kansas City Chiefs, pleaded guilty to tax evasion in San Diego and faces sentencing March 1. The 39-year-old Brockington, whose last pro season was 1977, admitted that he had failed to file a return for 1982, a year he worked as a commodities salesman for J. David Dominelli, who has since been convicted of swindling his customers.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Challenge to the Church on Race
description: On a late summer Sunday in 1954, the pastor of the only Catholic church in Ashland, Ky., mounted the pulpit and made an important announcement to his parishioners. That fall, he said, there would be a ''colored'' family in the parish for the first time - ''colored'' was the polite term for blacks in those days - and ''colored'' children in the parish school. He wanted them treated with decency and grace, and if there was any unkind action, the person who committed it would have to answer to him personally.

title: Guide to the Sights of World Expo '88
description: Six-Month Event

title: GOLF TOURNAMENTS IN DISTANT PORTS
description: WHEN Maurie Fisher and June Breton Fisher organized their first ''floating golf tournament'' five years ago, it prompted a lot of tongue-in-cheek questions.

title: Players, Plans and Statistics: How They Match Up: Team Comparison
PIPELINE DEAL: INTRIQUE IN HIGH PLACES
description: Shortly after Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter became national security adviser in December 1985, a predecessor in the job offered him sober advice about a billion dollar Iraqi oil pipeline project that was supported by the National Security Council and by President Reagan.

title: EMPHASIS ON INFORMAL ITALIAN
description: ''SCUSI'' means ''excuse me'' in Italian, but a restaurant as good as the recently opened Scoozzi Trattoria and Wine Bar in New Haven, which takes its name from a playful spelling of the Italian, has no need to be apologetic.

title: WHEN A TOWN BECOMES THE TOWN DUMP
description: The ''Garbage Crisis'' has been in the headlines for the past year, and it now appears possible that this unsolved problem will eventually ruin the natural beauty of Westchester County.

title: Beginning in Britain
description: Sometimes it seems that the British press has found a foolproof way to cover the news of royal pregnancies:

title: IT WAS TRAFFIC, NOT PEDIGREE
description: We wish to take exception to several of the comments made by Dr. William G. Sharwell, the president of Pace University, in the article ''Town and Gown: How Friendly Is the Relationship?'' [ Jan. 3. ] In that article, Dr. Sharwell stated that when Pace took over Briarcliff College ''it was a classy finishing school for young women and Pace taking it over didn't please everyone in the community.'' Noting that Pace's curriculum and students were predominantly career-oriented, he said: ''We looked like a different type of institution, which we are. That doesn't mean we're worse, or dirtier, or sweatier - just different.'' The implication clearly was that the people of Briarcliff objected to Pace's presence for reasons neither admirable nor well-founded.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CAPTIVES OF TIME By Malcolm Bosse. 268 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. (Ages 14 and up)

title: MISS STERN WEDS MARTIN R. KRAVET
description: Susan Leslie Stern, the publicity director for Saks Fifth Avenue in New York, and Martin Ross Kravet, the vice president of the Royal Abstract Corporation, a New York title insurance agency, were married last night at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated.

title: Jury Awards Are Too Big
description: IN too many cases, the American legal system treats civil violations as if they were criminal. There are fundamental differences between criminal and civil offenses, and there are large costs from confounding them.

title: Poland Increasing Food Prices by 40%
description: The Polish Government announced sweeping price increases tonight, including a rise in retail food prices averaging 40 percent.

title: Where Dance Is Heading
description: Is the party over? Has American dance, re-cently perceived as the pride of American creativity, actually become estranged from the culture around it?

title: Arthur J. Raporte; Executive, 70
description: Arthur J. Raporte, a former vice president in charge of real estate for the Loews Corporation, died of respiratory failure Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: EVELYN H. SEELER, LAWYER, TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Seeler of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Evelyn Harrison Seeler to John F. McKay 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McKay Jr. of Hempstead, L.I. The wedding is to be in September. Miss Seeler, an associate in the New York law firm of Rosenberg & Estis, graduated from the Kew-Forest School and cum laude from the University of Richmond. She and her fiance received J.D. degrees from the St. John's University School of Law. The future bride's father is the president of the real-estate firm of Cross & Brown in New York and a former chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: COURTS PREPARE FOR CAMERAS
description: EIGHT years after legislation was first proposed, Long Island, along with the rest of New York State, is embarking on an 18-month trial that will permit audiovisual equipment in courtrooms. Beginning tomorrow, at the crophones will be allowed in criminal and civil court proceedings, including trials that the press wishes to cover.

title: CHRISTIE WILLIAMS PLANS TO BE WED TO CATE MOFFETT
description: The engagement of Mary Catherine Moffett to Christie Max Williams, a son of Ann L. Williams of Los Angeles and Robert C. Williams of Spencerville, Ontario, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William W. Moffett of Mystic, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
HYBRID CREATION CAN BE WORTH THE EFFORT
description: LEAD: MANY of the most useful garden plants are hybrids. That is, they have resulted from crossing plants of dissimilar characteristics.

title: LEO'S HALL OF FAME: HITS AND ERRORS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JESSE LONDON MARRIED TO FREDA DIANE ADLER
description: The marriage of Freda Diane Adler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Adler of Ridgefield, Conn., to Jesse London, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin London of New York, took place last evening at the Westbury Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg officiated.

title: On Language; Grovel, Grovel, Grovel
description: FIRST OFF, I OWE AN apology to Mikhail Gorbachev, author of ''Perestroika,'' whose book tour recently included a stop in Washington. (Why first off? Why not just first? Because I am being determinedly colloquial, and it's better than the awkward firstly.) With a loud ''Ah-hah!'', I quoted an anonymous refusenik catching the Soviet General Secretary using a Russian word that was kind of an insult to President Reagan. When Mr. Reagan used a Russian maxim, doveryai no proveryai, Mr. Gorbachev replied, according to his interpreter, ''You repeat that at every meeting.'' Got a laugh, no hard feelings.

title: HANDBAG HEFT: CLUE TO AGE
description: THE size of a woman's purse is directly related to her age. The same is true of her attitude toward wristwatches.

title: No Clear Favorite, According to Poll
description: Americans are almost evenly split over whom they want to win the Super Bowl, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. But even more say they don't care or don't know whom they want to win.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 32 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Critics Say 'Privatizing' the Post Office Is Long Overdue
description: Since 1983, postal officials have boasted of machinery that could sort a letter right to a specific carrier - if it bore a nine-digit zip code. Unfortunately, nearly everybody else thought four extra digits were four too many, so most letters didn't get sorted so quickly after all.

title: Minority Students Still Lag, A Survey of Schools Shows
description: Minority students were more likely than whites to be suspended or placed in classes for the handicapped and were less likely to graduate from the public schools in the 1986-87 school year, according to a survey whose results were issued Friday by the Department of Education.

title: New York State Harvests: A Mixed Picture
description: New York farmers grew more apples, grapes, sour cherries, cabbage and sweet corn in 1987 than the year before, but fewer pears, sweet cherries and onions, according to a series of year-end farm reports issued this week, They also received less money for their fruit and vegetable crops last year, $308 million, compared with $324 million in 1986, a drop of 5 percent, the State Agricultural Statistics Service said.

title: Q and A
description: Empty Apartments

title: TEMPORARY CHIEF FOR PLAYLAND IS NAMED AMID INVESTIGATION
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER government officials are trying to insure a smooth May 14 opening of Playland, the county-owned Rye amusement park, in the aftermath of allegations of financial and sexual improprieties brought earlier this month against E. Richard Keeler, its executive director since 1983. Those charges have cast an initial pall on the county's plans to highlight Playland during this 60th anniversary year.

title: POSTINGS: New Headquarters in Mahwah; Jaguar to Build on a 20-Acre Site
description: The Jaguar XJ6 has a 195 horsepower, 24 valve, 3.6 liter fuel-injected engine. The four-door sedan has leather seats, a walnut dashboard and a top speed of 150 miles an hour. It goes from zero to 60 in 10.5 seconds. Price: $43,500.

title: Loan Fund Turns to Developing Nations as Donors
description: The International Fund for Agricultural Development, known as the ''peasants' banker'' for its innovative loans to the rural poor, sought help this week from the most successful developing nations because oil-producing countries, traditional supporters of the agency, are facing an economic squeeze.

title: THE SOUL THAT WANDERS
description: LOVESONG Becoming a Jew. By Julius Lester. Illustrated. 248 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Nierlich Leads Austrian Sweep: Rudi Nierlich, a 21-year-old from Austria, scored his first World Cup victory yesterday and led Austria to a sweep of the top four places in a World Cup giant slalom at Schladming, Austria. Nierlich was timed in 2 minutes 45.54 seconds for the two runs down the course which dropped 396 meters and had 57 gates. Second went to Hubert Strolz, 2:45.63, followed by two countrymen, Helmut Mayer in 2:46.03 and Guenther Mader in 2:46.91. Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland held onto his overall World Cup lead, 219-213. He finished in eighth place, one spot ahead of Alberto Tomba.(AP) Svet Carries Yugoslav Banner: Mateja Svet, a 19-year-old, won the last women's World Cup giant slalom before the Olympics yesterday and gave Yugoslavia its first World Cup victory in two years at Kranjska Gora, Yugoslavia. Svet won with an aggregate time of 2 minutes 15.75 seconds. Vreni Schneider of Switzerland was second in 2:17.41. Anita Wachter of Austria and Blanca Fernandez-Ochoa of Spain tied for third place, each with a combined time of 2:17.82. Michela Figini of Switzerland held to her overall World Cup lead although she was disqualified in the first heat yesterday.(AP) N.H.L. Flyers 4, Jets 3: Peter Zezel broke a 17-game scoring drought with a goal in the first period and added an assist for the Flyers yesterday at Philadelphia. Zezel beat the Jets' goalie, Daniel Berthiaume, to the stick side with 2 minutes 45 seconds remaining in the opening period and got an assist at 5:25 of the second period when Scott Mellanby converted his rebound and put the Flyers ahead, 2-1. Iain Duncan tied the game on a backhander at 10:21 of the second period, but Mark Howe put the Flyers ahead to stay when he scored at 15:21.(AP) Flames 4, Canucks 3: Joe Mullen's second goal of the game with 6:26 to play lifted the Flames to a home victory. Tony Tanti scored all three goals for Vancouver, giving him 31 for the season. Mullen broke a 3-3 tie when he skated down the left wing and beat the goaltender, Frank Caprice. Tanti scored one minute into the game and gave the Canucks a 3-1 lead with goals at 5:22 and 10:15 of the second period before Mullen cut the deficit to one at 16:03.(AP) Maple Leafs 5, Red Wings 5: Wendel Clark's second goal of the game at 12:44 of the third period gave the Maple Leafs a 5-5 tie. The Red Wings broke a 3-3 tie with goals early in the third period by Steve Chiasson and Steve Yzerman. Mark Osborne of Toronto made the score 5-4 at 9:30 and Clark tied it when he wristed a low shot past the goalie, Glen Hanlon.(AP) Penguins 4, Blackhawks 2: Dan Quinn scored a pair of power-play goals to help the Penguins end a seven-game winless streak. The Penguins won their first home game since Dec. 26, ending a 0-4-3 slump at the Civic Arena and a three-game overall losing streak. Pittsburgh took a 2-0 lead on first-period goals by Paul Coffey and Quinn. Quinn scored his second goal and 19th of the season at 4:51 of the third period, knocking in a pass from Mario Lemieux. The loss ended the personal seven-game winning streak of Darren Pang, Chicago's goalie.(AP) Cross-Country Budd Finishes 4th; Fans Demonstrate: Four anti-apartheid demonstrators ran onto the course but failed to stop South African-born Zola Budd from finishing yesterday at Gateshead, England, as she came in fourth and earned a place on Britain's team for the world cross-country championships in March. The demonstrators broke through a security barrier and tried to block Budd's path on the first lap of the world championship trial. But the 21-year-old runner, who became a British citizen in 1984, sidestepped them. Angela Tooby of Wales finished first, covering the 5,400-meter course in 18 minutes 6 seconds. Budd was timed at 18:42. Second was Jill Hunter in 18:16 and third was Tooby's sister Susan. It was Budd's first major race since the 1986 European track and field championships.(AP) Horse Racing With a Twist Wins: With a Twist staged a strong stretch rally to overtake Triple Wow in the final strides yesterday and win by a neck in the Rare Treat Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Videogenic was third. With a Twist, a Virginia-bred 5-year-old daughter of Fappiano and Classy Twist, carried 110 pounds and was ridden by Nick Santagata. She covered the mile and an eighth on a fast track in 1:51 1/5 for her fifth victory in 35 career starts. With a Twist earned $50,400 for Centennial Farms and paid $17.80 for $2 to win. Tennis Teltscher, Mattar Gain Final: Top-seeded Eliot Teltscher of the United States and Luis Mattar of Brazil won their semifinal matches in a $130,000 Grand Prix tournament yesterday and will meet today in the final at Sao Paulo. Teltscher, No. 22 in the ranking of the Association of Tennis Professionals, defeated Danilo Marcelino of Brazil, 6-1, 6-4, and No. 38 Mattar beat Martin Wostenholme of Canada, 6-3, 6-3.(AP) Soccer Port Vale Upsets Tottenham: Port Vale of the Third Division upset Tottenham Hotspur of the First Division by 2-1 yesterday in the fourth round of the English League soccer F.A. Cup. Coventry City was also eliminated, losing by 1-0 at home to Watford. The defending league champion, Everton, was held to a 1-1 tie at home by a Second Division team, Middlesbrough.(AP) Golf Rodriguez Leads in Senior Skins Game: Chi Chi Rodriguez won three holes and $40,000 yesterday on the first day of the inaugural $360,000 Senior Skins Game at Honolulu. Arnold Palmer snapped a two-year drought in Skins competition by winning a hole worth $20,000. Gary Player and Sam Snead were shut out. The final three holes, worth $20,000 each, were tied, making the first hole today worth $80,000. In the match-play Skins format, the low score wins a hole, with ties thrown out and the money carried over to the next hole.(AP)

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: The Washington Redskins will triumph. The tremendous dependence of the Bronco team on John Elway will allow the Redskin defense to focus chiefly on his activities. This will result in the sharpening of the Redskin play as the game winds down, culminating in an exciting final two minutes, in which the Redskin defense will frustrate the Bronco offense. DAVID M. SHAPIRO Lincoln Park, N.J.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SHORT GAP, W. VA.;
Mineral County Battling Back
description: LEAD: MINERAL COUNTY in northeastern West Virginia is rebounding with some economic growth after two of the region's largest employers closed manufacturing plants.

title: DON'T CAST SHADOW ON ANIMAL SHELTER
description: It was with great delight that I read your article on the progress of the plans to open a new Central Westchester Humane Society shelter [ Westchester Journal, Dec. 6 ] . It was with great disgust that I read Nancy Johnson's letter [ Letters to the Westchester Editor, Jan. 10 ] faulting the spending of monies for the shelter instead of for the human homeless and the use of an architectural firm for the planning.

title:
GARDENING;
HYBRID CREATION CAN BE WORTH THE EFFORT
description: LEAD: MANY of the most useful garden plants are hybrids. That is, they have resulted from crossing plants of dissimilar characteristics.

title: Fighting Words
description: THE dollar difference between the Mike Tyson and Michael Spinks camps over a guarantee for Spinks to fight the heavyweight champion seems to have narrowed a bit.

title: Average Women and Love
description: To the Editor:

title: INTELLECTUAL SEDUCTION
description: I am an admirer of Joyce Carol Oates and of Henry A. Kissinger, and also of Mikhail Baryshnikov, Alexander Solzhenitsyn, Yevgeny Yevtushenko. Imagine if an American leader and spouse were to give a dinner in the Soviet Union for their favorite Russian intellectuals. The Soviet Government would have to pull many of them from Gorky, from Siberia, from phony psychiatric facilities, from exile, from defection. Until the Soviet Union is a place that can be trusted by its own intellectuals, propaganda will remain propaganda. BARBARA ROSENTHAL New York, N.Y.

title: MUSIC, POSSESSION AND POLITICS
description: MAKEBA My Story. By Miriam Makeba with James Hall. Illustrated. 249 pp. New York: NAL Books/New American Library. $18.95.

title: PUTTING THE SHELTER INTO PERSPECTIVE
description: In response to ''Homeless Should Live Such a Dog's Life,'' [ Letters to the Westchester Editor, Jan. 10 ] , it is clear to see that the writer is a self-proclaimed animal lover but not a lover of animals.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GENIUSES TOGETHER: American Writers in Paris in the 1920s. By Humphrey Carpenter. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Drawing on the many works already published on the subject, Humphrey Carpenter retells the story of the Lost Generation in ''Geniuses Together'' while making the effort to discern within the abundance of well-known anecdotes the most revelatory common features.

title: Family Ties And Bindings At a Ski Resort
description: WINTER vacation: a time for family to sit together by the fire. My 63-year-old husband wants to learn to ski. I want to do some cross-country skiing. My stepson-in-law wants to ski. My stepdaughter, four months pregnant, wants to ski; the obstetrician says don't go down hill. My 17-year-old wants to ski. My 19-year-old wants to stay home and see her friends. What has family to do with her? she asks. We take her along anyway.

title: Jersey Episcopalians Offer A Blessing for Homosexuals
description: Representatives of 125 Episcopal parishes in northern New Jersey voted today to give their blessing to homosexual relationships and to unmarried couples.

title: TRUE CONFESSIONS OF A TREND SETTER
description: I LIKED TV even before it became trendy. For a long time this meant guilt. I was reared on Praire Public Television in Fargo, N.D., as a sort of intellectual irrigation -without it, cultural death - and was disdainful of commercial entertainment.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Waldwick
description: LEAD: EVERY workday thousands of commuters on the New Jersey Transit trains from Suffern, N.Y., to Hoboken pass through Waldwick, where a gingerbread station and a 30-foot-high signal tower have stood for more than a century.

title: Antiques; French Empire Rules at the Armory
description: Period French chairs and commodes are more visible than they have been for many years at the Winter Antiques Show, which continues through today at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street. There is, however, a dramatic difference. For the first time at the nation's most prestigious antiques show, now in its 34th year, 19th-century styles - Empire through Art Nouveau - upstage those of the 18th century at most of the 11 dealers' booths where French furniture is on display.

title: OUT ON A LIMB, SHOUTING
description: Sinead O'Connor sings sweetly on her debut album, ''The Lion and the Cobra'' (Chrysalis 41612; LP, cassette and CD). But not very often. She's more likely to howl or snarl, to make her voice rasp or crack, to summon the gnarled embellishments of Celtic songs or the open-throated wail of arena-rock. Ms. O'Connor knows the power of the female voice, and she uses it to rail against every betrayal or barrier she can envision. ''I don't know no shame/ I feel no pain,'' she declares in ''Mandinka'' - and she wants to make her listeners believe it.

title: WHITE HOUSE TOLD OF KEY MEESE ROLE IN PIPELINE PLAN
description: The special prosecutor investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told senior White House aides Friday morning that Mr. Meese had played an important and sustained role in 1985 in promoting an oil pipeline project in which Mr. Meese's close friend had a financial interest, according to Administration officials.

title: An Exile-Observer of the Blizzard of '88
description: To the Editor; May I add to your colorful Jan. 14 article on the ''The Blizzard of 1888'' exhibition at the New-York Historical Society? The Latin American press back then carried a front-page article headlined, ''New York Under the Snow'' by Jose Marti, the Cuban revolutionary poet, educator, writer of children's stories, art and literary critic, and journalist.

title: JENNIFER B. KURTZ, LAWYER, TO MARRY
description: Jennifer Barton Kurtz and Aharon Unger, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Robert Unger of Spartanburg, S.C., plan to marry in April, the parents of the future bride, Margery G. Kurtz of New York and Dr. Anthony D. Kurtz of Teaneck, N.J., have announced.

title: INTELLECTUAL SEDUCTION
description: One of Mikhail Gorbachev's more heartening traits is his willingness to break through the barriers of bureaucracy and protocol to reach the people. The trouble with Joyce Carol Oates's essay on the Soviet Embassy reception for artists and intellectuals is that she was embarrassed by what people were saying - the woman with tears in her voice welcoming Gorbachev with wide-open arms, the man with the scheme to send thousands of Americans to Russia. Ms. Oates found them naive. Maybe they weren't subtle, but I thought they sounded great. MARCIA LAWTHER New York, N.Y.

title: PROVIDENCE UPSETS VILLANOVA, 82-76
description: Eric Murdock's 3-point basket snapped a tie with 1 minute 21 seconds left in overtime as Providence broke a five-game losing streak with an 82-76 upset victory over Villanova in a Big East Conference game tonight.

title: Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title: ON BATTERY POWER
description: WAY back when, all photographers ever needed to know about batteries was their size. There were AA ''penlight'' cells and C- and D-size ''flashlight'' cells. Those were the days when cameras were mechanical marvels full of gears and springs and flash units looked like potato mashers.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I have a chair whose frame is made of white plastic that has discolored to an uneven beige. Yet a painted metal brace is still white. Is there any way to clean or bleach the plastic, or is there a white paint I can apply?

title: COMPANY BUYOUTS ASSAILED IN STUDY
description: The increased borrowing of large sums of money by managers of publicly owned companies who want to to make the companies private has contributed to excessive levels of corporate debt, a study by the Congressional Research Service says.

title: Bush Responds in Writing To Queries on Iran Affair
description: Vice President Bush said today that he had ''no precise recollection'' of when he learned of the sales of United States arms to Iran but that he did not oppose the policy when he was told about it.

title: Reagan Presses Case for Aid to Nicaragua Rebels
description: President Reagan said today that while the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua had made limited concessions toward greater democracy, continued military pressure by the contras was necessary to continue that progress.

title: Balsamic Vinegar
description: To the Editor: The article on Balsamic vinegar by Anne Marshall Zwack (Travel, Jan. 3) left out an important bit of information for your readers.

title: SICK THINKING
description: I have earned both a bachelor's degree in communications and a master's degree in journalism while receiving chemotherapy and radiation treatment for leukemia.

title: TURNPIKE GROWTH IS A PARTNERSHIP
description: LARGE-SCALE construction programs, whther private sector or public, must be planned, designed and implemented in a partnership between need and nature. Such partnerships must balance the need for the project with sensitivity to its impact on the natural environment.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
THE BEDFORD 'BOOT'
description: LEAD: AFTER months of kicking around ''the boot,'' the Bedford Town Council is nearing a decision on whether to use the device - which is attached to an automobile tire to immobilize a vehicle - in catching parking-ticket scofflaws.

title: POSTINGS: Five-Story Rehab; 21 New Co-ops In Fort Greene
description: The five-story building at 147 South Oxford Street in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn cost Louis Perlman $700,000. To that he added a $1.3 million gut rehab, and dividing his investment by the 21,000 square feet of space he created among 21 cooperative apartments, he found that he had developed unsubsidized housing for under $100 a square foot. Five of the mostly two-bedroom apartments - priced from $99,999 for an 800-square-foot unit to $135,000 for a 1,100-square-foot - have been sold. Maintenance ranges from $360 to $440 a month.

title: SUSAN HENRY TO WED
description: The engagement of Susan F. Henry, a senior analyst for Integrated Resources in New York, to Glenn E. Higgins, a senior research analyst for Salomon Brothers in Atlanta, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Norman Henry of Valley Stream, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance, a son of Margaret Higgins of Maplewood, N.J., and the late Edward Higgins, graduated from the Virginia Military Institute and received an M.B.A. degree from Wake Forest University. Miss Henry is a graduate of Adelphi University.

title: This One Might Truly Be Super
description: Year after year, Super Bowl football games have been anything but super. In the last five years, in order, the Washington Redskins have won by 10 points, the Los Angeles Raiders by 29, the San Francisco 49ers by 22, the Chicago Bears by 36 and the Giants by 19.

title: Classical Music: What Next?
description: The date is Jan 31, 2038. At 8 o'clock tonight, Carnegie Hall will be the scene of a special concert of rediscovered music - music that has not been played for three decades. There will, however, be no orchestra - not enough people play the violin, or the cello, or the oboe, anymore. All of the instruments will be played on a new computer, programmed for the occasion: the Bach 9000, which sounds more like an old-fashioned symphony orchestra than the real thing. For the last 30 years, Carnegie has specialized in pop, rock and rage, the new fusion of new age and rock, but not tonight. The rediscovered works: Symphony No. 9, by Ludwig van Beethoven, Eine Kleine Nachtmusik, by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, and Brandenburg Concerto No. 2, by Johann Sebastian Bach.

title: How American Business Helps Create Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAPELY SKIRTS
description: POUFS ARE FAST BECOMING passe for evening, but the bouncy or puffed skirt is beginning to be big news for day. Some of the most forward of the new spring styles, while fairly simple above the waist, wind up in skirts that look as though a passing breeze could tilt them this way and that. Sometimes, the effect is achieved with a petticoat or two propping up a fullish skirt. This gives a suit a buoyant proportion. A slip of a short skirt becomes one out of the ordinary when it is cut to deliberately round out over the hip line. And a ''plain Jane'' dress perks up when the skirt is shaped to swing out from a snug waist.

title: Correction
description: Because of incorrect information provided by WNET, a picture on the first page of The Guide for Jan. 17 misidentified a performer in Benjamin Britten's ''Turn of the Screw.'' The woman pictured is Magdalena Vasaroya, who plays the role of the governess; the character's singing voice is that of Helen Donas.

title: Sihanouk, Citing Feud, Resigns as Coalition Head
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk resigned today as the nominal head of the three-party coalition of Cambodian guerrilla forces fighting Vietnamese troops occupying Cambodia.

title: OTHMAN MAKES IT
description: RESPECTED SIR By Naguib Mahfouz. Translated by Rasheed El-Enany. 154 pp. New York: Quartet Books/ Salem House Publishers. $13.95.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE COMIC BOOK BUSINESS;
Learn to Read With 'Word Warriors'
description: LEAD: COMICS may or may not be high art, but they are becoming a popular educational tool. This month Archie Comic Publications Inc., the nation's leading humor comic book publisher, begins a yearlong anti-AIDs educational campaign in its comic books and digests, following earlier campaigns to discourage use of tobacco and drugs.

title: WHEN THE WORLD LACKS A LEADER
description: Japan's growing economic strength is gradually dislodging the United States as the dominant economic power of the non-Communist world. But despite its gains, Japan remains unwilling - and probably unable - to shoulder many of the responsibilities that have traditionally gone with global leadership, according to many economists and historians.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE deer paused at the edge of the trees, studying the open field before her. Not even the pain in her empty stomach could erase the lessons of centuries.

title: ELIZABETH KARNES ENGAGED TO GARY MEYERS, PROFESSOR
description: Elizabeth Helen Karnes, the executive assistant to the president of Middlebury College, and Gary Griffith Meyers, an assistant professor of political science at Middlebury, plan to marry this summer.

title:
FOCUS: Oakland;
A Twist in the Revival of Downtowns
description: LEAD: IN their fight to win back shoppers, office workers and residentsfrom the suburbs, cities have tried to resurrect their decayed downtown cores.

title: DONNA ELLIS TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Ellis of New York City and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Donna Louise Ellis to Mitchell Freeman Senft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Senft of Flushing, Queens. Ms. Ellis, an associate in the law office of Monroe J. Korn in New York, graduated from Boston University and the Touro College School of Law. Mr. Senft, a graduate of Queens College and the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, is an associate in the New York law firm of Edelman, Schoenfeld & Weinberg.

title: Australia
description: To the Editor: One thing travel agents and travel articles fail to mention is that the Alice Springs and Ayers Rock areas in central Australia are ''the fly capitals of the world.'' Seeking moisture, they attack the mouth and eyes.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ISLE OF WIGHT, MD.;
A Sour Note In a Preserve
description: LEAD: FACING strong local opposition, Maryland officials have refused permission for two Baltimore developers to lease part of this 225-acre state-owned wildlife management island to build a $5 million music pavilion.

title: RANGE OF PROGRAMS SET FOR BLACK HISTORY MONTH
description: ROSA L. PARKS, who refused to relinquish her bus seat to a white man in Montgomery, Ala., in 1955, will be among the speakers visiting the state for celebrations of National Black History Month, which begins tomorrow.

title: RANGERS EXTEND ROAD STREAK TO 3
description: Playing again with minimum mistakes, the Rangers beat the Bruins, 4-2, today at the Boston Garden where the Bruins had compiled a .640 winning percentage this season.

title: BUON APPETITO!
description: FOR THE PAST decade, the most persistent culinary enthusiasm in America has been for Italian food. Witness the continuing proliferation of Italian restaurants.

title: A California Inn for Romance
description: DRIVING north from San Francisco toward Little River, (a three-hour ride on Route 101, six hours on Route 1) you can get so involved in the spectacular scenery along California's northern coastline with its rocky promontories, green hills and awesome vistas of the Pacific that you can easily miss the sign for the turnoff for Heritage House. But once you find this casual and rustically beautiful spot, you will be well rewarded even if it's after a few wrong turns.

title: NONFICTION
description: A TIME FOR GIANTS: Politics of the American High Command in World War II. By D. Clayton James with Anne Sharp Wells. (Franklin Watts, $19.95.) A distinguished historian and the author of the well-received three-volume biography ''The Years of MacArthur'' here focuses attention on the careers of 18 top American military leaders. The roster comprises seven Army generals (Dwight Eisenhower, Douglas MacArthur, George Marshall, Joseph Stilwell, George Patton, Mark Clark and Omar Bradley), five admirals (Ernest King, William Halsey, Chester Nimitz, William Leahy and Raymond Spruance), four Army Air Force generals (Henry Arnold, Carl Spaatz, George Kenney and Ira Eaker) and two Marine generals (Holland Smith and A. Archer Vandegrift). D. Clayton James outlines the prewar old-boy network that helped to propel graduates of the service academies to the highest command positions at the outset of World War II. Mr. James amasses a great deal of information, relying primarily on published biographies, but - strangely for such an accomplished historian - he fails to evaluate it. Disconcertingly, he does not provide an in-depth examination of the processes through which America's top military leaders were chosen. In fact, the book has the subdued, judicious tone usually found in official histories. In the end, Mr. James reaches the breathtakingly prosaic conclusion that ''without exception, these eighteen leaders seemed to have achieved their positions of high command by being the best qualified and most experienced officers available for the jobs at the time.''

title:
ART;
DIVERSE PATHS AT NASSAU MUSEUM
description: LEAD: IT is time again for the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art's annual Long Island Artists Exhibition, an event that presents simultaneous solo exhibitions and fills all display areas in the building.

title: GURNEY'S 'AMERICAN LIFE' REVIVED AT LONG WHARF
description: WITH the current Long Wharf Theater revival of one of A. R. Gurney Jr.'s early works, the 1970 ''Scenes From American Life,'' and the opening Off Broadway of his latest produced play, ''Another Antigone,'' at Playwrights Horizons, chroniclers of Mr. Gurney's career have a rare chance to see the playwright in perspective, and to contrast his past and present concerns.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: YOUTH CONCERT

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. CROIX, V.I.;
Building Surge In the Tropics
description: LEAD: WHEN Eugene Hutchins, a builder, said last summer that he would renovate a deteriorated ancient town house for sale as two condominium units, and build three more town houses with six units, he sold out within a week at prices of $140,000 to $260,000.

title: 10 ARABS WOUNDED BY ISRAELI GUNFIRE
description: The Israeli Army opened fire today on Palestinian demonstrators in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, wounding at least 10 people.

title: Question Of the Week; WHO WILL WIN THE SUPER BOWL?
description: John Elway is capable of winning the game almost by himself, and with Denver's running game he may have to. Washington will find a way to contain Elway somewhat. Final score: Washington 37, Denver 24. ROBERT FABRIKANT New York

title: FLORIO SITES 'IRONY' IN CITING OF KEAN
description: REPRESENTATIVE James J. Florio of Runnemede, who lost to Thomas H. Kean in the 1981 gubernatorial election - and who has indicated he may run again next year -said that President Reagan's praise in his State of the Union speech for Mr. Kean's education efforts was ironic.

title: James Killian, 83, Science Adviser, Dies
description: James R. Killian Jr., the first Presidential assistant for science and technology, an architect of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and a president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Friday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 83 years old.

title: A WINTER'S TALE OF FIRE ISLAND, BETWEEN ICE AND OPEN OCEAN
description: IT'S cold, and it's going to be a rough day on the beach. I can tell as soon as I look out the window. The snow is blowing so hard that I can scarcely see the crest of the dunes, 100 yards away. A lone deer walks stiffly through the beach grass, and a marsh hawk fights the winds. Nine mourning doves line up on my porch railing; with feathers fluffed up to trap air and preserve heat, they look like tiny hens.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PHOTOGRAPHY AND TRUTH

title: CHERNOBYL LEGACY: RUSSIANS WARY, TOO
description: DESPITE the Chernobyl accident in 1986, in which 31 people died after a reactor exploded, the Soviet Union has clung to its ambitious plans for developing nuclear power. By the turn of the century, Soviet officials hope to double - to more than 20 percent - the percentage of electricity generated by nuclear reactors.

title: Conversions
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeowners on Cape Cod Battle Sea and Town
description: Pointing to a spot on his map where Holway Street reaches Chatham's eastern shoreline, Doug Wells, chairman of this town's conservation commission, said that the sea had come up to that point before, in 1875.

title: Strategies for Harried Air Travelers
description: WHILE storm clouds and spare parts still cause most flight delays, a growing number of late planes are the result of crowded airports. Yet avoiding airport congestion can be as simple as bypassing congested airports. Most major American cities have mid-sized airports in and around them that are served by major airlines but are less busy than the city's main facility. Older airports, suburban airports and airports in neighboring cities can provide surprisingly viable alternatives to more well-known and well-traveled airports.

title: Correction
description: A chart on page 9 of the Travel section today about airports around the nation locates Kennedy International Airport incorrectly. It is southeast of midtown Manhattan, not southwest.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE STARS AT NOON, by Denis Johnson. (Vintage, $5.95.) A young American woman seeking ''the exact dimensions of Hell'' goes to Nicaragua in this story by the author of ''Fiskadoro.'' ''It is daring, this political novel that disdains politics, this philosophical work that rejects all philosophies,'' Caryn James said here in 1986. ''It suggests that Denis Johnson is one of our most inventive, unpredictable novelists.'' WILLA CATHER: The Emerging Voice, by Sharon O'Brien. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) Willa Cather, whose best-known novels include ''O Pioneers!'' and ''Death Comes for the Archbishop,'' so closely identified with men that she went by the name William in college, yet she created memorable female characters. In her detailed look at this affecting writer, whose works made the lands of Nebraska and New Mexico come alive, Sharon O'Brien has ''written a woman artist's life, seldom if ever re-created so imaginatively and, therefore, so accurately,'' Carolyn Heilbrun said in The Book Review in 1986. THE MISALLIANCE, by Anita Brookner. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $6.95.) When Blanche's husband leaves her for his young secretary, he takes the couple's friends with him. ''Few writers have come close to [ Anita ] Brookner in the depiction of female loneliness,'' our reviewer, Fernanda Eberstadt, said here last year. The novel ''exercises an almost inexplicable grip on the reader - a tribute to her formidable gifts as a psychologist of the wounded woman's heart.'' THE RIVER THAT FLOWS UPHILL: A Journey From the Big Bang to the Big Brain, by William H. Calvin. (Sierra Club, $12.95.) Written in the form of a mile-by-mile diary of a raft trip through the Grand Canyon, William H. Calvin's book is not only about geology and evolution but about cosmogony, ecology and neurobiology. ''Vivid analogies bring the science down to earth,'' Ricki Lewis said here in 1986. The result is ''a unique piece of science writing.'' POISON: An 87th Precinct Novel, by Ed McBain. (Avon, $3.95.) One of the greatest mysteries posed by this Ed McBain novel, John Gross said in The Times last year, is why the author's formulaic police procedurals are so much better than those of his competitors. In this story of a triple murder, two committed with a poison called nicotine, ''the investigation snakes its way to an exciting and unexpected conclusion.'' THE DEAL OF THE CENTURY: The Breakup of AT&T, by Steve Coll. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) With local rates rising and Mickey Mouse telephones glutting the market, some critics wonder whether the divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was such a noble cause after all. By re-creating the tale and its real-life characters, Steve Coll has produced ''an edifying account of a seminal antitrust case [ that ] also manages to be a moving story,'' Susan Kinsley said here in 1986. LOVE AND WORK, by Reynolds Price. (Ballantine, $3.50.) In this novel about a novelist, a self-centered writer who resents the demands of family and friends finally comes to accept love and responsibility. In 1968, Thomas Lask said in The Times that the solution to the protagonist's dilemma seemed too pat, but he admired the book's style. The ''prose is a pleasure to read, pliant, capable of fine gradations of mood and atmosphere and especially effective in building up the interior weather of every act and scene.'' MEN'S LIVES, by Peter Matthiessen. (Vintage, $7.95.) For more than 30 years, Peter Matthiessen has lived among the Bonackers (natives) of Long Island's South Fork, watching as the fishermen's lives have been destroyed by encroaching Manhattanites. ''In this magnificent and somber portrait [ he ] shows a stubbornly surviving culture being carelessly exterminated,'' our reviewer, Jonathan Raban, said in 1986. The same publisher has added two more titles to its series of Matthiessen reprints - the novels FAR TORTUGA ($10.95) and RACE ROCK ($8.95). THE ALL OF IT, by Jeannette Haien. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) An Irish woman confesses to her priest that her husband, now dead, was really her brother. ''Though the novel is slight, both in length and scope,'' Jeanne McCulloch said here in 1986, ''it is an elegantly written, compact and often subtle tale.'' PLAYING GOD IN YELLOWSTONE: The Destruction of America's First National Park, by Alston Chase. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) Through stupidity, neglect and mismanagement, the National Park Service is ruining Yellowstone, the author argues in this polemic. In 1986, our reviewer, Philip Shabecoff, said the book is ''single-minded to the point of absurdity,'' yet ''provocative, well written and well meant.'' TONGUES OF FLAME, by Tim Parks. (King Penguin, $5.95.) In the climax of a novel about religious fanaticism in modern England, a 15-year-old boy watches in horror as his rebellious older brother is forced to undergo an exorcism. The book, which won the Somerset Maugham Award for writers under 35, ''is a hilarious and original portrait of a young boy grappling with good and evil,'' our reviewer, Meg Wolitzer, said here in 1986. MY FATHER AND MYSELF, by J. R. Ackerley. (Poseidon, $7.95.) ''I was born in 1896 and my parents were married in 1919.'' The writer of those words, the first sentence of this memoir, was a shy homosexual, his father a hard-drinking womanizer. In reconstructing his private life, the author and editor J. R. Ackerley produced ''a classic of autobiographical literature,'' Michael Holroyd said in The Book Review in 1969.

title: The 'Kiddie' Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: British Antics in 'Noises Off'
description: ''NOISES OFF'' is a knee-slappingly funny comedy about the behind-scenes doings of a live theatrical production called ''Nothing On.'' At Theater Three, where this delightful show by the British playwright Michael Frayn is currently playing, ''Noises Off'' is productions this theater has come up with in several seasons.

title: Fossilization Evolves Into a Modern Metaphor
description: One of the stranger and more revealing aspects of art this season has been the number of works suggesting fossilization. In some sculptures, human beings and plants seem embedded in earth or frozen in stone. In others, industrial objects resembling plants and bones lie on the floor like prize findings of a dig. In some paintings, monuments of postwar abstract art resurface in fossilized form.

title: CAN TV BE TAKEN SERIOUSLY?
description: Taking television seriously - the very notion still seems ludicrous to too many people, including a goodly number who work in the medium.

title: Breaking the Stalemate
description: President Mubarak of Egypt has been here this week urging the Reagan Administration to get actively involved in the search for Arab-Israeli peace. He had a central message, delivered with passion.

title: The Beer and The Boycott
description: LAURENCE GOLD, THE A.F.L.-C.I.O.'S GEN-eral counsel, was up to his elbows in work one day in November 1984 when his phone rang.

title: THE WISE OLD GRANDMOTHER: FANTASY AND REALITY
description: I USED to create fantasies of how I would be when I reached a certain age. I even created the appropriate rocking chair and the porch where I would sit and view life passing by; where I would receive my children and tell tales of my past to numerous grandchildren, who would delight in my company; where friends would gather to reminisce happily about our long-ago adventures; where I would feel at peace - wise, loving and loved.

title: FOR PRESERVATION OF THE GAS STATIONS
description: After reading your article [ Westchester Journal, Jan. 3 ] , I was disturbed at the proposed demise of the four abandoned gas stations on the Saw Mill and Taconic Parkways.

title: Johnson, Monk Activated
description: Vance Johnson of the Denver Broncos and Art Monk of the Washington Redskins, two of pro football's best receivers, were activated today for Super Bowl XXII on Sunday.

title: Before You Start Gulping Those Aspirins for Your Heart ...
description: SINCE he had a heart attack, says the former tennis player Arthur Ashe in Bristol-Myers's new commercial, a daily Bufferin tablet gives him peace of mind.

title: STUDENTS AT KENNEDY STAR IN A SUCCESS STORY
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, scores at a Port Chester elementary school ranked among the lowest in the state in reading and math, and the State Education Department directed the district to make improvements.

title: No Bragging For U.S.F.L.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of a transcription error, a review of Primo Levi's book ''The Drowned and the Saved'' on Jan. 10 misstated the year in which Levi joined a group of anti-Fascist Italian partisans. It was 1943.

title: When Bonds Lose Their Convertibility
description: WHILE takeovers and restructurings may enrich common stockholders, owners of corporate bonds in many cases are left reeling from losses. That has been particularly true in recent months for holders of debt convertible into corporate shares. These bonds are generally sold at lower than prevailing interest rates because investors get a kicker: a chance to share in any appreciation of the common stock. But in some instances, bondholders have taken a beating.

description: Fare Tactics For Visitors To Australia

title: TESTING THE POWERS OF SPECIAL PROSECUTORS
description: THE challenge by the Reagan Administration and others to the constitutionality of court-appointed special prosecutors will soon come before the Supreme Court. The Watergate-inspired law provides for independent counsels to investigate possible crimes by high-level officials. Many conservatives assail the statute as a flagrant invasion of the President's authority to enforce the laws. Most liberals defend it as an essential check on executive branch abuses.

title: EVENTS MARK BLACK HISTORY MONTH
description: BLACK HISTORY Month in New Jersey promises a wide variety of events, from lectures and art exhibitions to theater and musical programs. (Yolanda King, eldest daughter of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will narrate ''New Morning for the World'' with the Cathederal Symphony Orchestra in Newark. Page 17.) Most events focus on the theme of black heritage as an integral part of American society and its culture and the pride instilled by Dr. King.

title: LISA JEAN AMOROSO TO MARRY DAVID E. WALKER IN AUGUST
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene V. Amoroso of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Jean Amoroso to David Elisha Walker, a son of Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Walker. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: DURABLE STRATEGIES HAND ON DESPITE FAILURE
description: PUT a strategy into the mind of the chessplayer and it stays there, embedded, forever. It may fail miserably, yet that's not enough to expel it. There are always myriad tactics to explain why the plan failed. If the idea enjoyed one meager triumph, it might just as well have been hammered into Mount Sinai.

title: AS NORMAL AS IT EVER WAS
description: DOMESTIC REVOLUTIONS A Social History of American Family Life. By Steven Mintz and Susan Kellogg. Illustrated. 316 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.
